column2: CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- Although wheat prices averaged higher last week, the strength came largely from short covering in the deferred deliveries combined with a little mill buying of May. The latter continues to act somewhat tight and at one time showed 3 cents over the finish of the previous week, going to the highest price since Feb. 1 and within 1 5/8 cents of the ceiling on futures.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 27 -- The Banco de Mexico (the Federal bank) declared last week in its annual report for 1943 that industrialization of Mexico had been retarded indefinitely by the repercussions of the war on world economy.

Lent should be the season during which we try to correct two faults of which human beings are guilty -- overconfidence and defeatism -- the Rev. Dr. W. Russell Bowie said in his sermon yesterday in the James Memorial Chapel at Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street, of which he is a faculty member.

LONDON, Monday, Feb. 28 -- Soviet troops advanced to within fifteen miles of Pskov at two points yesterday, while 100 miles to the south other Red Army forces captured the rail and highway junction of Pustoshka, eighteen miles east of the last German-held north-south railroad in northern Russia, and forty-four miles from Latvia.

The Regional Plan Association reported yesterday that the New York metropolitan area had "the greatest diversification of employment to be found in the United States under normal peacetime conditions."

KEARNY, N.J., Feb. 27 -- The Navy daughter of a Navy hero broke the traditional bottle of Wine across the prow of the new 2,200-ton destroyer English as the trim fighting ship went down the ways of the United States Steel Company's Federal Shipbuilding Corporation yard into the gray waters of the Hackensack River here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- A proposal that the United States participate in a post-war international food board will be sent to Capitol Hill for consideration by Congress about April 1, it was learned today.

The good life is a series of small deaths in practice for "the masterpiece of the final death," Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the Catholic University of America declared yesterday in his first Lenten sermon this season at St. Patrick's Cathedral. Preaching on the necessity of self-mortification, urged by the church during Lent, he said:

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 27 -- Despite the Argentine Government's strenuous efforts to keep up the pretense that nothing unusual happened Thursday evening and Friday morning when Gen. Pedro P. Ramirez was forced to yield his Presidential powers to Gen. Edelmiro J. Farrell, all signs indicate that the Government's situation is precarious and that the Army, the only prop holding the regime in power, is torn by dissensions, which are growing bitterer every day.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Mrs. Neame, our charwoman, came around this afternoon to tell us she had found a new place to live. "It ain't much of a place," she said, but Mrs. Neame has been bombed out three times now and she knows that if you can get only a little back from this war every time it hits you, you are doing well.

When the freezing of the Erie Barge Canal recently made it impossible for LCT's -- landing craft for tanks -- from the North Tonawanda (N.Y.) fabricating plant to be brought under their own power to the Atlantic seaboard, the Todd Shipyard Corporation stepped into the breach to enable the continuous movement of the LCT's toward invasion fronts, it was made known yesterday.

GROTON, Conn., Feb. 27 -- Dressed in the leather jackets and pants of welders, their hair tied securely in bandanas, Luba Eaves and Peggy Alligood stood opposite each other at noon today beneath the hull of the submarine Besugo in the yards of the Electric Boat Company here.

The Bradley Marine Repair Company bought the one-story garage building on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 727 Monroe Street, in Hoboken, N.J., from Krieg, Specter Citron through the Joseph J. Garibaldi Organization, broker.

A BRITISH PORT, Feb. 27 -- A convoy hauling one of the greatest contingents of American troops ever to cross the Atlantic has arrived in England with thousands of reinforcements for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's invasion army massing in the British Isles.

The twenty-sixth anniversary of the establishment of the Red Army was celebrated last night at a service in Grace Church, Tenth Street and Broadway, under the auspices of the Greenwich Village Committee of American-Soviet Friendship.

In his first comment on the action of Congress in overriding President Roosevelt's veto of the Tax Bill, Wendell L. Willkie said yesterday that the fact that we have an inadequate tax bill was not primarily the fault of Congress but was due to waste of the people's money by the National Administration in extravagant spending.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Germany has lost her last hope of maintaining a successful air defense as a result of last week's heavy attacks on her airplane production plants by United States bombers working in close cooperation with the Royal Air Force, according to an official of the United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The War Department, the War Manpower Commission and the War Production Board were accused of violating the Baruch proposals for planned reconversion by a scheduled layoff of 50,000 workers in small-arms plants in a letter of protest sent today to Senator Harry S. Truman by Russ Nixon, Washington representative of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, CIO.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The largest crowd, 3,500, ever to witness an indoor amateur skating meet in the United States saw the New York Skating Club entrants walk away with the Large Trophy, emblematic of top honor for having placed most contestants in the national figure-skating championships here Saturday night.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Feb. 27 -- The value of Nicaraguan imports in 1943 was $13,530,000, exceeding the 1942 figure by $7,000,000, Col. Irving A. Lindberg, Collector General of Customs, announced today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 27 -- The notion that some day French Jews may regain their belongings is unthinkable because not one estate or undertaking is in the same condition today as when it was "Aryanized," according to a trustworthy person who is familiar with the situation and who recently came from Paris.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- Hope for enactment of any broad program of assessment reform was snuffed out today with submission by the State Tax Commission of a report to Governor Dewey rejecting virtually every major recommendation of the Bewley committee on assessing and reviewing, which studied the problem three years.

While the powers-that-be continue to deliberate and weigh the evidence that will determine the last two available berths in the forthcoming national invitation basketball tournament, one of the candidates, Long Island University, is keeping its collective fingers crossed, hoping that the committee in charge does not act too hastily.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Feb. 27 (AP) -- Border patrolmen reported today that about 400 persons were denied access to the Rainbow Bridge, closed at one minute after twelve this morning when the Niagara Falls Bridge Commission failed to post a bond, required by the United States Treasury Department, to pay double-time to customs inspectors for Sunday work.

Alumni will be hearing more frequently and more insistently from the old campus now, and it is a call that, in a time of many demands on the pocketbook, deserves an affirmative answer. Army and Navy use of college and university facilities in training was the financial salvation of many of these institutions.

A large apartment property near the Sutton Place section passed to new control in a deal announced over the week-end when the sixteen-story and penthouse building at 400 East Fifty-ninth Street, southeast corner of First Avenue, was sold by Webb Knapp to a client of Netter Netter, attorneys.

FITCHBURG, Mass., Feb. 27 (AP) -- Carmelita Landry retained her titles in the 440 and 880 yard New England speed skating races today at Mirror Lake, staving off a last-lap drive by Miss Beatrice Amann of Meriden, Conn., which brought the Connecticut skater across the finish line only two feet behind the winner.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 27 (UP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

The Legislature should initiate legislation so the voters of New York City would receive opportunity to say whether they desire a change in the present methods of selecting Supreme Court Justices, Surrogates, County Judges, Judges of the Court of General Sessions and Justices of the City Court, the Committee on Law Reform of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York declared in a report made public yesterday.

Mrs. Kenneth Beghold of Scranton, Pa., and E.F. Smith of Washington, D.C., won the Eastern States contract bridge pair championship and the Julian Goldman trophy in the tournament at the Park Central Hotel here last night, outstripping a field of thirty-two finalists who had survived from a sixty-two pair field which started Saturday afternoon.

WITH CHINESE FORCES IN THE HUKAWNG VALLEY, Burma, Feb. 24 (Delayed) -- The scale of the fighting and the strategic importance of this front have grown steadily in the last few months. Relatively small Chinese forces opened up hostilities here last November when they moved into the northern end of the Hukawng Valley to screen further construction on the Ledo Road to China.

BRANCH RICKEY is performing a chore not unlike bringing coals to Newcastle when he decides to give his Brooks a little more color by furnishing them fancy satin uniforms for night baseball. The Mahatma thought that the ordinary flannel garb looked too drab under the arcs and hence determined to have his heroes glisten in the floodlights, forgetting slightly perhaps that all is not gold that glitters.

Pressure upon President Roosevelt and the State Department to lift the blockade of Europe so that children in Nazi-occupied democracies could be fed was urged in a resolution adopted yesterday by the seventh annual United Pacifist Conference at the Labor Temple, 242 East Fourteenth Street.

The National Distillers Products Corporation had last year a net profit of $8,461,526, or $4.14 a share, against $6,896,765, or $3.37 a share, in 1942, according to a report by Seton Porter, president, made public today.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 27 -- William Flynn, 55 years old, and his daughter Mary, 18, who returned from safety in an attempt to save him, lost their lives just before dawn today before firemen could reach them in their blazing flat on the second floor of 698 Springfield Avenue.

The British churches are facing their task of spiritual and material reconstruction "in a gallant and high-hearted manner," the Rev. William Cecil Northcott, home secretary and literary superintendent of the London Missionary Society, declared in a sermon yesterday in the Congregational Church, Scarsdale.
LONDON, Feb. 28 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

New York is a city abounding in specialty establishments. There are barber shops where only haircuts are given (no shaving and no scalp tonic for sale), restaurants where hamburgers constitute virtually the whole menu, and fruit stores (look for these on Ninth Avenue) where, during the fall, the stock in trade is made up of purple grapes for brewers of homemade wine.
LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 29 (UP) -- The Russian Monday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

The. St. John's basketball team, assured of a play-off berth and in position to finish no worse than tied for the metropolitan championship, will be without the services of its outstanding man, Dick McGuire, for the balance of the campaign, Coach Joe Lapchick told the basketball writers at a luncheon at Toots Shor's yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 28 -Lana Turner and Laraine Day have been named by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to star in "The Wacs." Part of the picture will be filmed at the Wac headquarters in Des Moines, with Army cooperation. Edward Buzzell will direct.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 28 -- Slugging Sammy Byrd, former New York Yankee outfielder, won top honors today in the $5000 all-War Bond open golf tournament with a 72-hole total of 285, five less than his nearest competitor, Byron Nelson, Toledo pro, who scored 290 in the four days' play.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- The stock markets here generally were quiet today owing to a lack of buying. Investment stocks were unsettled, due to the approaching "salute the soldier" campaign, gilt edge issues declining fractionally.

Representative James H. Fay resigned yesterday as chairman of the New York County Democratic Executive Committee, leaving Charles W. Culkin as the only holdover from the Michael J. Kennedy regime among the committee's appointed officers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- In an important interpretation of the powers of the Price Administrator, the Supreme Court today unanimously held that issuance of injunctions to prevent future price violations was not mandatory where the past violations had been committed without wrong intent.

With the President's signature there was enacted yesterday a law to continue the life of the Commodity Credit Corporation until June 30, 1945. The President had vetoed a previous bill which carried a rider eliminating most food subsidies. Congress failed to pass that bill over his veto.
ALGIERS, Feb. 28 (AP) -- A communique:

LONDON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Jan Ciechanowski, Polish Ambassador to Washington, arrived in London today with the latest views of the United States Government on the Russian-Polish dispute and went immediately into consultation with Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk and Foreign Minister Tadeusz Romer of the Polish Government in Exile.

Track fans who annually await the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. indoor championships, which will be held Saturday night at Madison Square Garden, for the opportunity of seeing many new faces will not be disappointed this time. The twenty-third annual meet has attracted a total of twenty-three colleges in thirteen varsity events, and quite a number of the performers are regarded as newcomers.
Eleven teams began play last night for the Curt H. Reisinger Cup and the Eastern contract bridge team-of-four championship in the tournament in progress at the Park Central Hotel here.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 -- The Niagara Falls Power Company, a subsidiary of the Buffalo, Niagara and Eastern Power Corporation, received today from the Securities and Exchange Commission permission to reduce the stated value of the subsidiary's common stock $14,497,768, in compliance with orders of the Federal Power Commission.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Foreign Economic Administration bought last year a total of $809,000,000 worth of strategic materials from foreign countries out of United States Government funds, Leo T. Crowley, FEA administrator, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Two Navy Air Transport pilots, who flew through North African weather so bad that combat planes were grounded, helped beat back the Germans in Italy with shells they brought from the United States in thirty-four hours.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 5 per cent for the week ended Feb. 26, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week sales had held even with those of the like week a year ago.

While controversy rages over how high the cost of living has risen since the war, local social welfare agencies have increased by almost 50 per cent their relief allowances for essential goods and services.

For a week our bombers over Rabaul have not met a single enemy interceptor plane. Our warships shelling the stronghold are now answered only by sporadic ire from the shore. A few days ago we sank a convoy evacuating ground crews from this area. There are apparently no longer any enemy combat craft either at Kavieng or Rabaul. General MacArthur confidently announces that every enemy airfield in the Bismarcks has been neutralized.

Beau Jack, recognized here as lightweight champion, and Bob Montgomery, Philadelphia's former titleholder, yesterday passed examination by the State Athletic Commission as physically fit for their fifteen-round championship bout Friday night in Madison Square Garden.

LONDON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Mounting patriot activity in German-held Europe has brought the word "Maquis" increasingly into the news. Today, for example, the Belgian news agency reported that 20,000 inhabitants of Liege have "taken to the Maquis."

Realism for Everybody By all means let us be realistic, as we are being urged to do on every hand; but let us be really realistic; let us be realistic all round. If we are to build a better post-war world by emancipating ourselves from the slogans, the cliches and the legends let us bid farewell to all the catchwords about everybody, not excluding the late Warren Harding.

As a layman who for years has been interested in education as it affects the foreign trade and investment fields, I have followed with interest and concern the report in THE TIMES of the debate between the schoolmen attending the regional conference of the American Association of School Administrators on the question of world control over Axis and other overseas schools.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- A spokesman for Bill Jack and Ralph Heintz reported today that more than 200 members of Congress have accepted invitations to a dinner to be given by the partners of Jack Heintz, Inc., Cleveland war contractors, at the Mayflower Hotel tomorrow night.

AT ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Tuesday, Feb. 29 (AP) -- Shore defenses of Rabaul offered only sporadic return fire to the bombardment of that enemy base by United States destroyers last Friday.

Retailers may have some difficulty in peaking their spring apparel stocks by March 10 to 15, as originally planned, because of the continued tight situation in deliveries, particularly on wanted types of women's suits and coats, reports here yesterday showed.

The second exhibition sent East by the California Water Color Society blew into the Riverside Museum (where it opens to the public today) on what might metaphorically be called a March gale. But it contains many a portent of mellowing spring, for the selection of water-colors, if gusty and vigorous, is also warmed by sunshine and impregnated with the germ of genial growth.

Entering second weeks today are "Lady in the Dark" at the Paramount, and "Standing Room Only" at Loew's Criterion. . . . "Voodoo Man" and "Trail of Terror" comprise the week's new double-feature program, starting today, at the New York.

NAPLES, Italy, Feb. 28 (AP) -The Italian Committee of National Liberation protested tonight against Prime Minister Churchill's endorsement of the Government of Premier Marshal Pietro Badoglio last week.

CURLY LAMBEAU flitted in and out of town not so long ago, and the chief mahout of the Ponderous Packers from Green Bay began to talk about one of his Packer heroes of yesteryear, the fantastic Johnny Blood. "I received a letter from Johnny recently," he said. "And where do you suppose he is? He's in India with the ground crew of a bombing squadron.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -Assets of national banks totaled $64,532,000,000 at the end of last year, an increase of $9,751,000,000 from the figure for a year earlier but $1,625,000,000 less than it was on Oct. 18, date of the last previous call, Preston Delano, Controller of the Currency, said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Those symbols of modern warfare, planes and ships, coupled with high wages, have caused more 16 and 17 year old boys to leave home for work elsewhere than ever before in the nation's history, according to Miss Beatrice McConnell, Director of the Industrial Division of the Children's Bureau.

Charles Seligson, trustee in reorganization of Adolf Gobel, Inc., meat packer, filed here yesterday in Federal Court a plan of reorganization, said to be based on a proposal submitted by Flug Strassler, attorneys, who represent $723,000 of debentures of the $1,081,000 outstanding.

Her three children are in school and her husband is a busy Brooklyn pediatrician, so Mrs. Dorothy J. Givan yesterday joined the Women's Army Corps, volunteering for overseas duty. After being sworn in she was assigned to the Air Forces.

Some idea of what housewives may hope for in post-war kitchens may be seen in the "Kitchen of Tomorrow," designed and built by the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company, and ready for inspection in Macy's basement starting today. Whether or not its individual features actually will become available depends to a large extent on how much they appeal to the majority of women.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, Feb. 29 (U.P.) -- More than 200 Solomons-based bombers blasted Rabaul, New Britain, Saturday with 164 tons of bombs in their continuing offensive against the enemy base, while other Allied planes destroyed or damaged an estimated twenty-nine Japanese planes in blows against airdromes in northern New Guinea, it was announced today.

New Yorkers were reminded yesterday by Commissioner William F. Carey that his Department of Sanitation was thoroughly mobilized to begin regular weekly collections of waste paper in the five boroughs tomorrow. Mr. Carey will direct the operations of 10,000 men and 1,000 trucks to be used exclusively in picking up waste paper and tin cans every Wednesday.
A UNITED STATES BOMBER STATION, England, Feb. 28 (U.P.) -When the men of the United States Eighth Air Force have to hear bad news, they want it dished out straight, without any trimmings.

The purchase of Robert Joseph Collins, a catcher, from its Kansas City farm link in the American Association, was announced yesterday by the Yankees. President Ed Barrow declined to divulge the purchase price, in a deal which returns Collins to the major leagues after an interval of four years.

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 28 (AP) -Just forty-seven hours after they sped down the corridor of the Hinds County courthouse, three young desperadoes, manacled and held firmly by deputies, were escorted back to the jail and put in solitary confinement tonight.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- The prospect of cold, raw weather following the German aerial 'blitzlet," which blasted out countless London windows last week, has forced a slight relaxation of the stringent coal restrictions. The Ministry of Fuel announced today that persons whose homes suffered as a result of the recent enemy activity may have extra quantities of coal or coke for heating.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 28 -- The radio has made it impossible to conceal major war developments from the whole German people, and we, coming out of the Reich, were surprised on reading British newspapers to learn how close to the accurate picture of the front we had obtained from the Nazi press.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The armed services must look increasingly to fathers, rather than to men now in 4-F, to meet their manpower needs, a five-man medical commission appointed by President Roosevelt stated today in a report that lowering of present physical standards would impair military efficiency.

Federal subsidies for education and a proposed Federal amendment for "equal rights for women" were criticized yesterday by the Catholic Daughters of America at the semi-annual meeting of the supreme directorate in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

There can be little question that the future of private flying needs a basis of sound planning now. Robert H. Hinckley, former head of the Civil Aeronautics Administration, recently has emphasized a sound statement made before the Senate subcommittee on aviation to the effect that, aeronautically, America's future lies in building up an informed citizenry familiar with and versed in the everyday use of the airplane.

Richard (Red) Smith, who did the quarterbacking for the Football Giants during the 1930 and 1931 campaigns will be back with the Polo Grounders this year in the capacity of line coach, it was announced yesterday by President John V. Mara.

With the Fourth War Loan drive closing its books at midnight tonight, the War Finance Committee reported yesterday over-all sales in New York State through Saturday totaling $4,601,900,000, or 109.6 per cent of the quota. Two days of sales are still to be tabulated, those for yesterday and today.

A general solicitation of proxies in behalf of an entirely new slate for the board of directors of Phoenix Securities Corporation is to be started soon by Joseph I. Lubin and his associates. The announcement was made by the Lubin group, which recently purchased the 32 per cent common stock interest in the company formerly owned by Wallace Groves.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Generally recognized as the greatest quick kicker in National Football League history, Sammy Baugh of the Washington Redskins tightened his grasp on that honor today. For the fourth consecutive year he was named top punter in the pro circuit.

The New York Public Library has just received as a gift the only known manuscript of all of Byron's poem "The Curse of Minerva" and the rare, privately printed first edition of 1812. The gift was made by Gabriel Wells and Dr. Albert A. Berg, both of New York.

Attention to fine dressmaker details was emphasized throughout the collection of custom-made clothes shown yesterday by Alice Orvan at the St. Regis. Insertions of contrasting fabrics or lace, fagotting designs and the subtle use of tucks were the outstanding features. A varied collection of hats ? designed by Roth Margit complemented the costurne Shantung suits were exhibited' for town wear.
The coming invasion of western Europe will be the acid test of Allied strategy and of the Anglo-American military systems.

The excess profits taxes, as now levied on the railroads, not only deprive the carriers of a reasonable return on their investment but also menace the future of the industry, M. W. Clement, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, declared yesterday in the company's ninety-seventh annual report to stockholders.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- Governor Dewey asked the Legislature in a special message tonight to increase the size of the industrial board to eliminate "unjustified delay" in disposition of workmen's compensation cases.

Owen Berger, young American pianist from Barrington, Ill., gave a recital last night in Carnegie Hall in his first appearance in this city. He played a solid program in a solid manner that made no concessions to the groundlings. The program opened with an "Ode" by Purcell, followed by Schumann's "Kreisleriana," Brahms' Intermezzo in A major and Capriccio in G minor and Beethoven's Sonata in B flat, Opus 106 ("Hammerklavier").

There will be blackouts elsewhere on this troubled globe this summer but there will be none in the electrically lighted parks of the American League as one glance at the junior loop schedule, released today, will show.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Supreme Court moved into a new area of labor relations today when it made two rulings holding that individual contracts cannot supersede collective bargaining agreements and may not be used to "forestall collective bargaining or deter self-organization."

WITH A CHINESE EXPEDITIONARY FORCE, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The revitalization of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's armies has begun with the arrival of concrete American aid. American Army officers and men under the command of Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell have started the job in southwest China, in cooperation with commanders of Chinese expeditionary forces.

As the nation's housewives had their first weekday experience with the food ration tokens, New York consumers had both praise and criticism for the new system, while the Senate Judiciary Committee in Washington moved promptly to head off counterfeiters.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Feb. 29 -The Soviet High Command reported tonight the capture by the Red Army of more than 650 inhabited points yesterday in the continued drive for the important German stronghold of Pskov from three directions and in an offensive fanning out from Novosokolniki.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Two announcements today by the Office of Defense Transportation indicated that the shortage of rail transportation was reaching a crucial stage and that the Government was prepared to cut non-essential travel to the bone.

Mr. Churchill, who can write and speak so noble an English, delights to shock the prigs by his peculiar pronunciations. He remembers the vogue of "Weepers" in the First World War. The "z" in "Nazis" is a good sturdy English letter to him. "Gestapo" he utters as "jeestapo," with the accent on the antepenult.

The nation's steel industry has natched Government expenditures dollar for dollar in financing the $2,000,000,000 wartime steel expansion program started in 1940, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday. Companies in the industry, from 1940 through 1944, will have spent a total of $1,151,000,000 in developing new ore mines, building new blast furnaces and steel furnaces, and installing other new equipment. Government expenditures are placed at $1,063,000,000.

Cotton prices were slightly easier yesterday than they were on Saturday, under pressure of commission house liquidation and hedge selling. Moderate trade price fixing, coupled with small New Orleans buying, absorbed the offerings. At the close of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts were unchanged to 3 points below Saturday's final prices.

Last spring Ted Gerken and Joe Chandler arranged to bring "Kicked Upstairs" to the Windsor, now known as the Forty-eighth Street. They tested the Clyde North farce in Boston, then canceled the local booking and decided to wait awhile before making their bows as Broadway producers.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 28 -- The Allies have scored their first major victory in Burma with the destruction of a task force of 8,000 Japanese in two weeks of confused fighting in the jungles of Arakan, north of Akyab, the Southeast Asia Command announced tonight. The Japanese "gradually were driven back, hemmed in, split up, hunted and killed. Most, with their accustomed tenacity, fought to the death.
The Tuesday communique from Allied Headquarters in the Southwest Pacific as relayed through the Office of War Information:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -The Dies Committee recommended today the removal of Dillon S. Myer, national director of the War Relocation Authority, and Ray C. Best, Tule Lake camp director, "because of their evident inability to cope with the problem of disloyal Japanese."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Revisions to the Maximum Export Price Regulation which will have the effect of reducing ceiling prices for a large proportion of the manufactured goods imported into the United States for the first time since August, 1943, were detailed today by the Office of Price Administration.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 28 (AP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

An indifferent tone with a high degree of selectivity prevailed yesterday in the stock market and prices went irregularly higher. The list generally was firm throughout the session, with some of the rails, sugars, woolens, liquors and communications the strongest features and the steels a shade better at the close. Business dropped to the lightest in a week as transfers on the Stock Exchange reached only 753,870 shares, against 900,186 shares on Friday.

Thirty-six million, six hundred thousand pounds of excess butter from the Federal Government's 130,000,000-pound hoard will go to Russia if recommendations of its Butter Advisory Committee are adopted by the War Food Administration.

William Randolph Hearst charged that Marshal Joseph Stalin was "still trying to steal Finland and absorb the Baltic republics, and reravish Poland" in a column-long reply in The New York Journal-American last Sunday to attacks on the American publisher in Pravda, Communist party newspaper of Moscow.

Two plywood manufacturers who recently started joint warehouses now are launching an advertising campaign together. Copy featuring Weldwood Plywood, Mengel Flush Doors, products of the United States Plywood Corporation, New York, and the Mengel Company, of Louisville, Ky., respectively, is scheduled for consumer magazines and trade papers beginning March.

The increase voted last week in the Federal excise tax on distilled spirits from $6 per 100-proof gallon to $9, effective April 1, will have a direct effect on the plan for distribution of the whisky inventory of American Distilling Company to its stockholders, which last week was extended to April 20, it was pointed out yesterday.

The spring showing of Sophie originals took place yesterday afternoon in the Salon Moderne, at Saks Fifth Avenue. Sophie ran true to form. Her suits were good, her prints were smart, her evening dresses luscious. No effort to add any startling innovation to the season's styles was evident.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 -- Professional traders and shorts were active on the buying side of grains today on the Board of Trade, especially in rye. This led the advance and ended 1 1/8 to 1 1/2 cents higher than Saturday's close, going into new ground for about ten days.

IRUN, Spain, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Three trainloads of German wounded soldiers, diplomats and officials crossed the Spanish frontier into German-occupied France near here today and a gloomier lot seldom has been seen in these parts.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Tuesday, Feb. 29 -- Fire that started last midnight quickly spread through the 78-year-old Westminster Presbyterian Church at North Broad and Prince Streets here. Early this morning firemen summoned on a general alarm seemed to be fighting a losing battle to save anything but the shell of the structure, and perhaps a part of the parish house.

More than 3,400 Catholic monasteries and clerical institutions in Germany were confiscated by the Nazis during the first three years and eight months of the war -- to May 1, 1943 -- the British Broadcasting Corporation said yesterday in a broadcast beamed to the German people and reported by United States Government monitors.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- The Times of London, in a leading editorial to be published tomorrow, takes sharp issue with a considerable body of British opinion that holds that the world's security demands that Germany should be dismembered after this war.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Jonathan Daniels, an administrative assistant to President Roosevelt, today refused -- even under threat of possible imprisonment -- to discuss before a Congressional group his purported attempts to force the resignation of Harry Slattery as Rural Electrification Administrator.

AN RAF AIRDROME ON THE INDIA-BURMA BORDER, Feb. 24 (U.P.) (Delayed) -- For a tense eleven-day period between Feb. 8 and 18 troop-carrier squadrons of the British and American Air Forces dropped 1,500 tons of food and ammunition to encircled British troops of the Seventh Indian Division and enabled the Fourteenth Army to repel Japan's attempt to cut off the whole British Arakan force.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- In order to bring estimated chemical supplies into balance with requirements, the War Production Board announced today that it had placed allocation controls over hydrogen peroxide, sodium peroxide and sodium perborate under general order M-300.

LONDON, Feb. 28 (U.P.) -- German forces have launched a series of new offensives in Slovenia and Hercegovina, Yugoslav Partisan Headquarters announced today, as Italian-based Allied planes and warships continued to hammer enemy positions along the Yugoslav coast.

LONDON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The national debt of Holland, which under Nazi occupation has already climbed from 3,527,000,000 guilders (about $1,900,000,000) to more than 10,000,000,000 guilders ($5,400,000,000), is expected in Amsterdam financial circles soon to be increased by another state loan, it was reported today by the Netherlands News Agency.

The appointment of Dr. Kenneth C. Reynolds, nationally known for his studies in hydraulic engineering, as head of the Department of Civil Engineering at Cooper Union with the rank of full professor was announced yesterday by Dr. Edwin S. Burdell, director of the Union.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (U.P.) -In two dissents today Justice Frankfurter criticized Supreme Court rulings.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Feb. 28 -Premiums written last year by the Glens Falls Insurance Company, the Glens Falls Indemnity Company and the Commerce Insurance Company dropped slightly more than $2,000,000, compared with the previous year, but losses during the same period fell nearly $3,000,000, according to the annual report of H. Ferry Crawford, president.

LONDON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- More than 195,000 Soviet citizens were "tortured to death, shot, or poisoned in murder vans" by the Germans during the occupation of Kiev, a commission investigating destruction of the ancient city said tonight in a report broadcast from Moscow.

For the first time in several years Frederick Brown, operator, has purchased a theatre building. He has just acquired from the Unum Real Estate Corporation (G.I. Cutler, president) the Stoddard Theatre Building at the southwest corner of Broadway and Ninetieth Street.

Warren B. Ashmead, Republican leader of Queens, called yesterday for the nomination of Governor Dewey for President at the Republican National Convention because, he said, the Governor is the only Republican who can be sure of carrying Queens by a substantial plurality.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 28 -- Col. Juan D. Peron became a member of the Argentine Cabinet today when he took the oath of office as Acting Minister of War.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- Another test of Britain's wartime political truce is foreseen in the by-election to be held tomorrow in the Bury St. Edmunds division of Suffolk where voters will go to tile polls to decide whether the district will be represented in the House of Commons by Mrs. Corbett Ashby, independent Liberal candidate, or by Maj. E.M. Keatinge, active Army officer and Conservative, who has the official blessing of the Churchill Government.

ALGIERS, Feb. 28 -- That political divisions continue in France on much the same lines as before the war, but that the masses are as republican as ever, with a deep dislike of too many laws and a strong predilection for order and liberty, are among the conclusions of two exhaustive studies of French public opinion made inside France somewhat in the Gallup manner.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 23, the Federal Reserve Board announced today:

A test mobilization of the First Brigade of the New York Guard brought 210 officers and 765 enlisted men, or 37 1/2 per cent of its total strength, to their armories in lower Manhattan, Brooklyn and Staten Island within an hour and a half after the mobilization order was issued yesterday afternoon.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- Tax officials today reminded all those who must pay State income tax that, for the third successive year, a deduction of 25 per cent from the amount due under the normal rates can be made. Forms that already have been distributed make no printed reference to the allowance.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- Flying Fortresses and Liberators of the United States Eighth Air Force dealt very heavy blows to German military installations and airfields in northern France in a day-long Allied aerial assault across the Channel.

ALGIERS, Feb. 28 -- Leaflet warfare waged during the last war with telling effect is being continued in the battle of Italy. The psychological warfare branch of Allied Headquarters today told how the leaflet program is being carried out.

The recent enactment of the mustering-out pay bill is a good start in the direction of a planned demobilization of our fighting men and women. Mustering-out pay is not a bonus; it is, rather, assistance in an emergency.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- A specific recommendation that the War Production Board be empowered to make the high policy decisions on cancellation of war contracts and resumption of civilian production and employment is contained in a new appendix to Bernard M. Baruch's report made public today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Hog receipts were moderate today, the first day since Jan. 24 that producers were allowed to ship swine without first obtaining a permit from stockyards agents. Arrivals totaled 37,000 head, of which big packers had 13,000 on direct consignment. However, supplies were augmented by 3,500 head held over from last week and indications were that 5,000 swine would remain in first hands at the end of today's session.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- A spokesman for the Allies' Invasion Command told the French people tonight that they would be given "clear and precise instructions" on the part they were to play in "large scale operations that will affect French territory."

In times of war as well as peace, the British Council of Foreign Bondholders never fails to issue its annual report in pamphlet form listing the world's governmental defaulters. The seventieth annual report of the council; covering 1943, has just reached these shores, although cabled excerpts of the report were published here several weeks ago.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 28 -- The three-and-a-quarter-acre property in this village that was formerly occupied by the Highland Manor School for Girls will be developed as a civic center, with a municipal building, quarters for the Fire and Police Departments, gardens and woodland path, Mayor Fred A. Graber said today.

A Japanese Imperial Headquarters communique said Monday that more than ten aircraft carriers and eight battleships led the United States Pacific Fleet task force that attacked the Japanese Marianas Islands last week, and that 200 planes were engaged.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- The Swedish Government, in the hope of inducing Finland to get out of the war, has promised to do everything in its power to help feed the Finns if they break with the Axis and thus lose their German food supplies, it was learned tonight.

As a teacher in one of the New York City vocational high schools. I am in a position to know what the future worker will look like from what he is now as a young pupil in a school where he is being trained for admission to the world of industry.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 -- The American Bar Association will ask Congress for a law to provide fair trials and appeals to the courts for all citizens who become involved in controversies with governmental agencies.

Herman Sperber, owner of a butcher shop on Rockaway Boulevard, Arverne, Queens, was penalized $900 yesterday by Magistrate Edward Cassin in Municipal Term Court, Brooklyn, for violation of Office of Price Administration ceilings.

New York University's College of Engineering, Department of Meteorology, conferred certificates yesterday upon six civilians, 154 Army Air Force cadets and a score of naval ensigns who have completed a thirty-five weeks course in advanced meteorology.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Stephen Early, White House secretary, said today that Judge Samuel I. Rosenman "had nothing to do with the writing of the tax veto message which last week caused a Congressional uprising against President Roosevelt."

Continuing his fight against juvenile delinquency, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he had ordered the Police Department to close immediately all dance halls where girls under 16 are found. The places would be closed pending hearings to revoke their licenses, which are issued by the Police Department.
LONDON, Feb. 28 (Reuter) -- The German radio broadcast tonight a speech by Dr. Joseph Goebbels in which he said:

A crowd of 19,231 amateur boxing fans in Madison Square Garden last night was in agreement with Jerry D'Ambrosio that virtue may be its own reward, but the reward for perservance is a negative quantity.

ALGIERS, Feb. 28 -- The interim lull on the beachhead below Rome continued yesterday as British troops took two houses that the Germans had fortified two miles southwest of Aprilia in the day's only flurry of infantry fighting.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -The Treasury Department announced today plans to refund $4,730,000,000 worth of securities in an exchange offering to be made formally on Thursday.

Prompt passage by the State Legislature of a bill providing for a New York City Transit Authority to operate the rapid transit lines and to charge a self-sustaining and self-liquidating fare not in excess of 10 cents will be sought by a newly formed Citizens Transit Committee, Paul Windels, chairman, announced yesterday.

LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 29 (AP) -- The Red Army's advances toward Pskov imperiled the railway bastion of the Baltic region which the Nazis had turned into a concentration camp for German soldiers who mutinied on the Leningrad front in January.

Involved in the construction of a pipeline across Arabia from the Persian Gulf to a Mediterranean port is the expenditure of around $200,000,000 by the oil companies holding the concessions in Arabia and Kuwait. These include refineries on both the Persian Gulf and the Mediterranean and the construction of a permanent city at Ras Tanura, Saudi Arabia, at a cost of $8,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -Tightened controls over the rationing of new passenger cars were announced by the Office of Price Administration today, but the number allotted for sale to civilians in March, 10,000 vehicles, was the same as in February.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -President Roosevelt laid down today as a Government policy the principle that ex-service men shall get preference in Federal employment.

Brooklyn, Manhattan and the Bronx could not wait for the formal opening of the Red Cross 1944 War Fund drive, which will be launched officially tonight at Madison Square Garden with a huge rally, and held rallies of their own yesterday.

DETROIT, Feb. 28 -- About 2,000 employes of the Briggs Manufacturing Company's Outer Drive plant were made idle today when the factory was closed down following a work stoppage by 350 men in the machine shop. The plant produces bomber-plane turrets.
Five talesmen were put through exhaustive questioning in General Sessions Court yesterday at the start of Wayne Thomas Lonergan's trial for murder of his wife Patricia, but none reached the jury box.

IN Maxwell, Ga., the whites went to Deen's Corner Drug Store for their cokes. The Negroes patronized Salamander's Lunch Counter, four doors away. Maxwell believed in keeping the Negro "in his place." But as Sam Perry, the Negro doctor, knew, the whites weren't willing to keep their place. White men went over into "Colored Town" looking for a good time. Sometime a tragedy resulted.

In his latest speech Prime Minister Churchill, putting military necessity above all political considerations, went "all the way" in endorsing the official Russian point of view regarding Russia's "right to reassurance against future attacks from the west." He spoke only about Poland; but his words obviously apply to other East-European countries as well, including Finland and the Baltic states.

MONTEVIDEO Uruguay, Feb. 1 28 (AP) -- Paraguayan refugees here reported today that a general strike in Paraguay was spreading and that 1,500 workers had left their jobs at Campo Grande, where they had been building a military airport under the Army's orders.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 28 -- Ostensibly coming to resume his last week's talks with fellow Swedish labor leaders allegedly on trade union matters, Eero Vuori, Finnish trade union boss, is returning here on Thursday, he has told local friends.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The "oldest government in exile in the world" will celebrate its twentyfifth anniversary March 1, on the date of the formation of the Provisional Government of the Republic of Korea.

ROCHESTER, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Despite an eight-State alarm, two robbers who early today beat Mrs. Elizabeth Sibley Gonzales, daughter of Harper Sibley, former president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, were still at large tonight.
Several leases completing the rental of four more business buildings were reported yesterday by Ruford D. Franklin, agent.

A recommendation that restaurants observe three butterless and meatless days a week because of meager supplies and the reduction of ration allocations that will begin on Wednesday was made last night by Paul Henkel, president of the Society of Restaurateurs.

Heavy buyer attendance and substantial writing of orders featured the opening here yesterday of the New York Gift and Art Show. Because of restrictions on hotel space, the offerings of some 250 exhibitors were divided between the Hotels Pennsylvania and the New Yorker.

The report of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation and its subsidiaries issued for publication today shows a consolidated net profit for the nine months ended with January of $5,656,174, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.62 each on 2,261,199 shares of common stock.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 28 (AP) -- A Socialist Deputy, Jose Pedro Cardozo, declared before the Chamber today that an atmosphere of war was developing between sister American nations and he proposed that all American Legislatures denounce the situation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Senate and House conferees on the deadlocked service men's voting program appeared tonight, after their eighth session of unsuccessful efforts at agreement, to be nearing the point of reporting failure to their parent bodies and asking for instructions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Indications that the Rainbow Bridge and the Peace Bridge over the Niagara River might remain closed on Sunday hereafter unless Congress adopts legislation to correct a situation involving overtime pay for customs inspectors developed from a conference here today of representatives of the companies operating the bridges and Treasury officials.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 -- Formation of a commission to conduct a two-year study into the status of the freedom of the press in the United States was announced tonight by Robert M. Hutchins, president of the University of Chicago.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 28 -Repression of the resistance movement in France is proceeding apace, thanks to the aggressiveness of Joseph N. Darnand's forces for the maintenance of order, which his undoubted dynamic personality has been instrumental in throwing into the fighting lines.

The first Richard Pearson Strong Medal for distinguished achievement in tropical medicine, named for Col. Richard Pearson Strong, director of tropical medicine at the Army Medical School, Washington, was presented last night to Colonel Strong at a meeting of the American Foundation of Tropical Medicine at the University Club.

Houghton Mifflin announced yesterday the winners of the ninth annual Houghton Mifflin Fellowship. Two fellowships of $1,500 each have been awarded to Edward Kimbrough of the University of Alabama, for fiction, and to Joseph Wechsberg of Hollywood, now in the Army, for nonfiction.
An abundance of ideas and originality was evident in the collection designed by Lil Picard shown yesterday morning at Bloomingdale's.

Feb. 29 was among the many insoluble mysteries that offer themselves to children. It came every four years, like a Presidential election, but nobody was trying to get elected. There was something uncommon about it. It ought to be celebrated, but school went on the same unless the day was Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Striking at the President's Fair Employment Practices Committee and a score of other organizations and agencies which have been created by executive order and maintained without specific legislative authorizations or appropriation, a Senate appropriations subcommittee adopted tentatively today an amendment assigned to give Congress control after they had been in operation for twelve months.

A special Congressional election is being held today in the Twenty-first District, at the northern end of Manhattan, to fill the vacancy resulting from the resignation of Joseph A. Gavagan, now a justice of the New York Supreme Court. The rival candidates are William S. Bennet, Republican, and James H. Torrens, Democrat, who also has received the American Labor party nomination.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 28 -- A six-point program to cushion the reconversion and adjustment period in New Jersey when peace comes was laid before Gov. Walter E. Edge and the Legislature today by the State Commission on Post-War Economic Welfare.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Although their criticism was not so caustic as on some recent occasions, Justices of the Supreme Court were free today in finding fault with majority opinions in two cases.
SHENANDOAH, Pa., Feb. 28 (AP) -- Eight thousand anthracite miners returned to their jobs today after a one-week strike which cut the country's production by about 16 per cent.

Charging that the "Communists dominate the Congress of Industrial Organizations," John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America and founder of the CIO, declared yesterday that "if I had my way, not a single Communist would belong to any labor union in the United States."

LONDON, Wednesday, March 1 -- Continuing the smashing Allied blows at German aircraft production, big formations of Flying Fortresses escorted by swarms of American and British long-range fighters battered Brunswick, site of large Messerschmitt plants, in daylight yesterday in the fourth attack there this month by the United States Eighth Air Force.

Two exhibitions under the joint auspices of the Metropolitan Museum, the Municipal Art Society of New York and the Byzantine Institute of America will open to the public today, installed in several adjoining galleries on the second floor of the Metropolitan.
The police started a check-up on the city's dance halls last night with orders from Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine to close immediately places where boys or girls under 18 years old were found.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Feb. 29 (AP) -- The State House of Representatives adopted a resolution today demanding that "henceforth the damned agitators of the North leave the South alone" in inter-racial relations, and reaffirming "our belief in and our allegiance to established white supremacy."

The annual campaign of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies and the 116 medical and social welfare agencies affiliated with it has just been completed in "a wonderful spirit and with extraordinary results," George Z. Medalie, president of the federation, reported yesterday.

HARBOURTON, N.J., Feb. 29 -- Police of New Jersey and Pennsylvania and the children of this community are bending every effort to end a fast started last Wednesday by Stanley Hoffman, whose dog, Jatta, disappeared on Washington's Birthday.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

ALBANY, Feb. 29 -- As real estate interests appeared in force before the Assembly Codes Committee today to oppose the Steingut bill putting a ceiling on commercial rents no higher than 15 per cent above levels of March 1, 1943, the Assembly Committee on Affairs of the City of New York reported out an even more stringent measure.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 29 --The housing committee of the Bridgeport Chamber of Commerce today called upon John B. Blandford Jr., Administrator of the National Housing Agency, to halt installation of new heating equipment in 1,900 dormitory war housing units here, some of which already have been closed and also demanded a Congressional investigation into construction of the dormitories in a protest against "willful, extravagant and inexcusable spending and waste of taxpayers' money."

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 29 -- Mettlesome today carried the colors of Mrs. Beatrice Di Giorgio more powerfully than ever to take the $5,000 Leap Year Handicap at Hialeah Park, rather to the surprise of many in the crowd of 8,504 that wagered $662,817.

LONDON, Feb. 29 (AP) -- The Vichy radio, broadcasting a Tokyo report, said tonight that Aleutian-based American reconnaissance planes had been over Japan proper in preparation for "an invasion from the north."

Officers of the State Federation of Labor denounce Governor Dewey's proposal for the appointment of judges as "a blow to the people's right of free democratic choice." Those who hold such a concept of democracy must logically demand that all Federal judges, including, justices of the Supreme Court, should also run for election.

Housewives are paying $1,200, 000,000 tribute annually to operators of food black markets alone, while there are "millions of dollars of overcharges" on other consumer goods, Chester Bowles, administrator of the Office of Price Administration, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- Civilians were assured a larger share of the country's meat supply today when the Office of Price Administration made "sweeping reductions" in the point value of pork and cut one to two points off the value of many beef items.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, March 1 (AP) -- A communique:

The fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 17 East Ninety-sixth Street, assessed at $635,000 and occupying a plot 85 by 100 feet, has been sold by the East River Savings Bank to A. Ruth Sons, operators and builders, for cash above a new purchase-money mortgage of $460,000 for ten years at a reported interest rate of 3 per cent. A. Robinson was the broker.

Many consumers are complaining that the butter they now buy is of inferior quality. Part of the dissatisfaction seems to spring from what the State Department of Agriculture and Markets calls "the prevalent practice of upgrading."

Fire hazards along New York city's waterfront, which have increased with the war, were the subject of argument yesterday in Supreme Court, where Justice Louis A. Valente is hearing a suit brought by the Uniformed Firemen's Association to enjoin Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh from enforcing his "emergency order."

"Research results are presumptive evidence and not proof. Research people must remember this or else place themselves in a vulnerable position where they may be discredited," Dr. W.E. Wulfeck, vice president and research director of Federal Advertising Agency, said yesterday before a discussion group of the American Marketing Association at the Hotel Sheraton.

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 29 (AP) -- Alleghany Corporation, top holding company of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway system, reported today that its "net income and gains" after taxes in 1943 was $2,780,361, against $2,338,443 in 1942. Total income last year was $6,619,624, compared to $6,560,643 the preceding year.

LONDON, Feb. 29 -- The Soviet Government confirmed tonight that it had offered to make peace with Finland provided the Finns would break relations with Germany, withdraw their troops to the 1940 Russo-Finnish frontiers and collaborate with the Red Army in the task of interning German troops and warships now in Finland.
New York's hotels and restaurants disclosed yesterday that Mayor La Guardia had advised them that he would not again proclaim butterless luncheons until he had been asked to do so by Washington.

Commission-house liquidation and increased hedging pressure, influenced in part by weakness in grains, brought yesterday one of the sharpest breaks in cotton futures in several months. At the close of trading active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were down 17 to 22 points, or 85 cents to $1.10 a bale, and virtually at their lows for the day.

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 29 (AP) -- American planes dropped thirty tons of bombs Sunday on Ponape atoll in the Carolines and nearly fifty tons on seven unidentified Marshall atolls in central Pacific neutralizing raids, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today in a press release.

ALBANY, Feb. 29 -- Mayor La Guardia's campaign against "tinhorn gamblers" took concrete form here today with the introduction of a series of five city-sponsored anti-gambling bills by Senator Frederic J. Coudert Jr. and Assemblyman John R. Brook, both of Manhattan.

A vast backlog of post-war public housing to be financed by $82,700,000 in loans from the State has been approved to provide early employment for thousands of workers and to carry forward slum clearance in New York, the State Division of Housing revealed yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 29 (AP) -- Despite shortages of material and manpower and greatly increased demands for service, the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company "met promptly in 1943, and will continue to meet, all requirements for service essential to the war effort and public welfare," President Chester I. Barnard declared today in the company's annual report for 1943. Long-distance calls were 31 per cent more than in 1942.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- Representative Albert J. Engel, Republican of Michigan, accused President Roosevelt and high officials of the War Department today of "flouting the will of Congress," in spending nearly $86,000,000 to build the pentagon building instead of the $35,000,000 maximum which Congress appropriated.

FIFTH ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Italy, Feb. 29 -- It is one of the war's incongruities that boys from New York who had never seen anything taller than the Empire State Building are learning the art of mountain fighting in the high snows near a famous nobleman's hunting chalet from Italian Alpini officers who, last year, were battling Yugoslav partisans in Montenegro and from a Minnesota ski-jumper who used to run an Army class in Iceland.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- Samuel C. Hadden, president of the American Association of State Highway Officials, proposed to the House Committee on Roads today that the Federal Government retire from the field of automotive taxation, or turn over to the States all revenue from the levies on automotive units and parts and on motor fuels.

A new overall retail price regulation, based on the principle of the historical mark-up, will be presented to the Council of National Retail Trade Associations within three weeks, Chester Bowles, Price Administrator, said yesterday in an address at the opening session of the two-day annual meeting of the American Retail Federation at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 29 -- The Argentine Cabinet met informally for more than two hours this afternoon. Presidential Secretary Gregorio Tauber said a variety of important questions had been considered and that it was the Government's intention to "continue and consolidate the work begun by President Pedro P. Ramirez."

Net sales of the Chrysler Corporation for 1943 amounted to $886,467,702 within $2,000,000 of the pre-war peak of $888,366,410 for 1941 and 42 per cent above the sales of $623,655,208 for 1942, first year of the war, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

The proxy statement for the annual meeting of the P. Lorillard Company to be held at Jersey City on March 14 contains two resolutions opposed by the management and inserted under rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission at the request of James Fuller of Hartford, owner of twelve shares.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., Feb. 29 -- Betty Nuthall, darling of the tennis world in the last days of the golden era of sports, today is the darling of the British Navy.

A new legal move which would almost certainly forestall the execution tomorrow night of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter will be made today in Federal court, it was learned yesterday. J. Bertram Wegman, Lepke's counsel, will file a petition for a writ of habeas corpus on the ground that it was illegal for the Federal authorities to deliver the industrial racketeer to the State for execution while he was under sentence in the Federal courts.
LONDON, Feb. 28 -- Following is the text of a statement by the Soviet Information Bureau of the Russian Foreign Commissariat, broadcast by the Moscow radio and recorded here:

Most of the discussion at the public hearing on pending conservation legislation at the Senate Chamber in Albany today is expected to revolve around this year's deer seasons in the Catskills, Adirondacks and southern tier and western counties, Vic Skiff, deputy conservation commissioner, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- Substantial expansion in the scope of the investigation of the liquor industry, which has been under way for several weeks by a special subcommittee of the Senate Judiciary Committee, was indicated today by Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat, of Nevada.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- Premier Stalin told President Roosevelt in a message made public today that he believed that the time was near for the success of the concerted Allied military actions agreed on at Moscow and Teheran for the final defeat of "Hitlerite Germany."

Two films, both of which will open on Saturday, have been added to the week's arrivals, thereby bringing the total of newcomers to six. At the Central, the attraction will be "Woman of the Town," a Western melodrama produced by Harry Sherman for United Artists release.

Insurance carried by the Mutual Life Insurance Company on the lives of 1,000,000 policyholders amounted to $3,660,000,000 at the close of 1943, according to the annual report issued yesterday by Lewis W. Douglas, president. New insurance issued last year totaled $170,500,000, or 9 per cent more than in 1942, he said. Lapses and surrenders were about 25 per cent less, reflecting a high rate of employment and personal income.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange in February dropped to the smallest total since October; it was also considerably below the same month in 1943, which had the largest total for a corresponding month since 1937. Sales in February, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, amounted to 17,100,772 shares, compared with 17,811,394 in January and 24,434,084 in February, 1943.
ALGIERS, Feb. 29 -- At the beginning of its third session today the Provisional Consultative Assembly Successfully asserted itself as a coordinate authority with the Committee of National Liberation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- Senate and House conferees on the conflicting bills providing for service men's voting suddenly broke their two-week deadlock today and agreed upon a program which would give Congressional recognition to the Administration-endorsed Federal ballot, but on a "States' Rights" basis.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- The decision of a Senate Agriculture subcommittee to investigate its power to require testimony in the REA inquiry from Jonathan Daniels, an assistant to the President, illustrates once more that political trends and counter-trends are like pendulums: they go from one extreme to the other.

The American Labor party, in which two rival factions are contending for control, will provide the only contests of consequence in this spring's primary elections, it was indicated last night as the deadline for entering primary candidates expired.

Continuing its headlong investigation of how much the human nervous system can stand, the local theatre last evening offered "Mrs. Kimball Presents" at the Forty-eighth Street. In this one, Alonzo Price has whipped up a terrific witches' brew about actors and love; it has the bad features of truly bad plays, suitably performed.

In the face of Librarian of Congress MacLeish's dislike for chromium kitchen sinks, the planners of the post-war kitchen keep on developing their marvels of economy and beauty. Speaking not at all in satire but in heartfelt admiration, we find that only one thing has been omitted.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- Elmer Davis, Director of the Office of War Information, has sent to Senator Harry F. Byrd an explanation of the distribution by the British Ministry of Information of leaflets to American troops which have been criticized as being in effect New Deal propaganda.

LONDON, Feb. 29 -- The Royal Air Force has completed its preparations for the invasion of western Europe and is ready to meet any attack the Luftwaffe may direct on Britain, Sir Archibald Sinclair, Secretary of State for Air, told the House of Common today.

Following a disclosure that the Foreign Economic Administration is limiting exports of certain commodities to individual "quotas" set up for each exporting concern, foreign traders attending a meeting of the Latin-American section of the New York Board of Trade yesterday recommended action by the group to seek publication of "such secret quotas."
LONDON, Feb. 29 -- Business in the stock markets here today again was on a small scale.

Among those reported yesterday as having leased apartments was Naboth Hedin, manager of the Swedish American News Agency, who took a suite at 21 East Sixty-fifth Street through Wm. A. White Sons, brokers.

ABOARD A U.S. WARSHIP WITH GENERAL MacARTHUR, Feb. 29 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur visited his troops and inspected their positions on Los Negros Island in the Admiralties less than eight hours after they landed under Japanese fire and seized the vital Momote air strip.

Greatly expanded production in the post-war period is a foregone conclusion, and the chief problem Which American industry will face after the war is marketing of new products and increased quantities of existing items through the development of more comprehensive sales techniques, John T. Woodside, president of the Weco Products Company, declared yesterday.
Two learned and accomplished booklovers, Gabriel Wells and Dr. Albert A. Berg, have enriched the New York Public Library with the sole existing complete manuscript of Byron's "The Curse of Minerva."

Although regular play in the P.S.A.L. basketball tournament was completed yesterday, two of the sections have yet to crown their champions. Erasmus routed Lafayette, 53 -- 33, on the loser's court to win the Section 2, Brooklyn title, with ten victories and two reverses.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 29 (AP) -- Several hundred holders of common capital stock of the United Gas Improvement Company failed in their attempt to defeat a proposed retirement annuity plan for ninety-four of the company's 142 employes and officers at a special meeting of stockholders today.

The names of 100 additional talesmen were drawn yesterday for Wayne T. Lonergan's trial in General Sessions Court for the murder of his wife, Patricia, last October. The trial is to resume this morning after a one-day intermission.

Surrounding the highly controversial tax bill which elicited a Presidential veto and, in turn, a revolt among Democratic members of Congress, there is considerable confusion of thought. In the first place, no one can doubt that the position taken both by President Roosevelt and Mr. Willkie in regard to inflation is sound.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,255 against 525 in the preceding week and 1,370 in the similar period a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals numbered 602, whereas none was listed last Tuesday, Washington's Birthday. Buyers recorded during February were 4,441 against 3,879 in the same month of 1943, an increase of 14.5 per cent.

ALBANY, Feb. 29 -- Formation of a State board to review assessments would violate the constitutional principle of home rule for localities and concentrate excessive power in Albany, representatives of town, county and city governments asserted today at a hearing in opposing the Bewley bill, which would set up such a board as a division of the executive department.

A small, unidentified Czechoslovak town of 1939, dominated by the Nazis, furnishes the locale for "Thank You, Svoboda," opening tonight at the Mansfield under the auspices of Milton Baron. Sam Jaffe is starred in the comedy, derived by H.S. Kraft from John Pen's book entitled "You Can't Do That to Svoboda." Two seasons ago Mr. Jaffe impersonated a fabulous bus boy in Mr. Kraft's play, "Cafe Crown," and they have been pals ever since.

LISBON, Feb. 29 -- The Americans just arrived from Baden-Baden are endeavoring to regain their balance after thirteen months of confinement and German propaganda. They have had ample opportunity to observe that formidable machine at work.

Non-bank subscribers in the Fourth War Loan drive contracted bank loans amounting to about $1,250,000,000 to aid in financing their purchases, a decline of about 40 per cent from the volume of such loans in the previous drive, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday in the March issue of its Review of Credit and Business Conditions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- War veteran Paul Skobbeko of Astoria, Queens, can return to his coal business with the aid of an exceptional ruling made today by C.J. Potter, deputy solid fuels administrator for war.

Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the Maritime Commission and War Shipping Administrator, was inducted into the Dexter Fellows Tent of the Circus Saints and Sinners at their monthly luncheon yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Although short of the actual goal of $500,000 in the campaign to sustain the Boy Scout program in this city during the year, a total to date of $401,500 was announced yesterday at a special meeting held by the Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America, in the Hotel Commodore.

British diplomacy is straining every nerve to convince King Peter of Yugoslavia that he must part with his present Cabinet -- including Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch, the "Minister of War in the field" -- and join hands with Marshal Tito (Josip Broz).

The Treasury's Foreign Funds Control Department has just issued a sheaf of amendments to its rules, designed to relieve banks of considerable "paper work" on comparatively insignificant transactions involving the use of foreign-owned funds.

Rudolph Rubino Loening, a lawyer, publicly apologized yesterday in Jefferson Market Court for having had two young women ejected from his box at a concert in Carnegie Hall on Feb. 16. Magistrate Peter A. Abeles then acceded to the request of one of the young women, Miss Susan Sage, a portrait painter, and quashed the summons she had obtained.

ALGIERS, Feb. 29 -- The lull in the Italian campaign went into its tenth day today. It was interrupted yesterday only by a localized German attack at 6 A.M. on the Allies' positions about two miles southwest of Aprilia.

An underwriting group headed by Smith, Barney Co., Lazard Freres Co. and Blyth Co., Inc., will offer publicly today 60,000 shares of new $4 preferred stock of the Houston Lighting and Power Company at $102 a share. Net proceeds from the sale of this stock will be added to working capital, with part going into the company's treasury for cash to be used in construction.

James H. Torrens, Democratic and American Labor party candidate, was elected to Congress yesterday by a narrow margin at a special election in the preponderantly Democratic Twenty-first Congressional District. His final plurality over William S. Bennet, Republican, was 1,571 votes, less than half the number he received as the ALP candidate.
LONDON, Feb. 29 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 29 -- Three German generals were shot at Pskov on Adolf Hitler's orders two weeks ago for insubordination, according to information in possession of Berlin diplomatic circles here, it was asserted here today.

MOSCOW, Feb. 29 -- In the steady advance on Pskov, the Red Army is out-pacing the reports, and last night's official reference to fighting on the city's approaches probably means that, barring unexpected developments, the city's early fall can be counted on.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Feb. 29 (AP) -- A retired woman court stenographer read to a crowded court room late today what the State contends was John F. Noxon's version of the killing by electricity of his 6-month-old, mentally defective son in September.
MOSCOW, Feb. 29 -- The "second front" issue -- which most Britons and Americans here had thought finally settled at Teheran -- is now being revived here.

A floor in the Life Extension Building, 7-11 East Forty-fourth Street, has been leased to Col. Gordon S. Kleeberg and George M. Glassgold, lawyers, through Cushman Wakefield, Inc., brokers, and Schlang Brothers Co., agents.

LONDON, Feb. 29 (U.P.) -- Attempts to effect agreement between Russia and Poland received a fresh setback tonight when Polish government sources said that the Polish underground had protested against "Communist" activities in Poland.

Most stockholders' suits prove to be unfounded and are conducted "principally for the benefit of the plaintiffs' attorneys," according to a report yesterday by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York following an eighteen-month survey of such litigation from 1932 through 1942.

Army and Navy did a perfect Alphonse and Gaston act at the track writers' luncheon yesterday, each handing the other the laurels in Saturday's I.C. 4-A indoor track and field championship and each bowing the other almost out of the New York Athletic Club where the food was served.

OTTAWA, Feb. 29 -- Temporary suspension of meat rationing and meatless Tuesdays in Canada, effective at midnight, was announced tonight by Douglas Abbot, parliamentary assistant to Finance Minister James L. Ilsley.

The City Council adopted unanimously yesterday a resolution requesting the State Legislature to approve a pending bill providing for a referendum this year on a $450 pay increase for the police and firemen. Action by the Council is required under home rule law if the Legislature is to enact the bill.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- The Office of Defense Transportation, in authorizing yesterday the operation of two additional coach trains daily to New York, has gone as far as it is prepared to go at present in supplying emergency transportation for the thousands stranded in Florida, officials of the agency said today.

The busy hands of war-working women can be just as beautiful, according to a hand-care authority, as their languid pre-war predecessors. Their very strength and capability is an asset to our current taste -- and there is no reason why the skin that covers these working hands cannot be kept soft and white, too.

The resumption, after a weekend lull, of heavy air attacks upon Germany was coupled with the optimistic assertion in Britain yesterday of Air Minister Sir Archibald Sinclair that "air supremacy" is now clearly within Allied reach.

ALGIERS, Feb. 29 -- An Italian priest stood in front of his church as Allied and German planes battled overhead, and watched an American airman, dangling from his unopened parachute, crash to the ground alongside his flaming plane.

PEORIA, Ill, Feb. 29 -- Hearing on a motion to intervene in the plan of the American Distilling Company to distribue its whisky stocks to its shareholders will be held in United States Federal Court here tomorrow morning before Judge J. Leroy Adair.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 29 (U.P.) -- The scattered remnants of a routed Japanese Army fled for western Burma today, their ranks western Burma today, their ranks thinned by their defeat in Arakan, and Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten asserted in a ringing order of the day that a "complete victory'' had been won.
LONDON, Feb. 29 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
The address by Chester Bowles, Administrator, Office of Price Administration, at the New York Times Hall yesterday follows:
