President Ed Barrow yesterday released the 1944 Yankee roster and, at the same time, learned that Uncle Sam had taken another of the thirty-two players listed thereon.

ON THE SECOND UKRAINIAN FRONT, in Russia, Feb. 25 (Delayed) -- To the sound of trudging columns of war prisoners winding through streets lined with burnt-out trucks, I talked with an officer of the SS Viking Division today.

In planning reconversion to civilian production, the War Production Board cannot attempt to hold back civilian output until all manufacturers are able "to start in the race on an even basis," Henry A. Dinegar, director of the durable goods and products division of WPB'S Office of Civilian Requirements, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP) -- A Federal District Court hearing in the legal battle between Joan Manners, one-time movie actress, and her divorced husband, John Langan, over the custody of 11-year-old Joan Langan, was ended abruptly today when Miss Manners testified that Mr. Langan was not the child's father.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (UP) -- Navy communique 507:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- Cooperation of Government agencies with Congress and its committees, free of executive domination, was demanded as essential to the proper functioning of the legislative branch in the interest of the whole country, in an address made today by Representative Richard D. Wigglesworth, Republican of Massachusetts, which evoked great applause from his side of the chamber.

Cottons, woolens, rayons and "war baby" textiles held the center of the stage at the Fashion Group luncheon yesterday at the Murray Hill Hotel. Interesting in weave and radiant in color, they were paraded before members and guests in styles created by some of New York's leading designers. All told twenty-one costumes were presented.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- Before an audience of more than two hundred, William S. Jack, head of the Jack Heintz Company of Cleveland, manufacturers of airplane parts, pleaded tonight for sufficient profit to retain his 7,600 "associates" at work and build a backlog for men returning to work when the war ends.

OTTAWA, Feb. 29 -- Canada has paid for all the work done on the chain of airdromes and intermediary fields on the Northwest staging route from Edmonton to Alaska and the route on Canadian property, C.D. Howe, Minister of Munitions, announced in the House of Commons today.

LONDON, Wednesday, March 1 -- Moscow announced last night that the Red Army had torn the Germans from 250 more localities around Pskov, ancient trade center of the north, capturing Pogorelka, six miles north of the fortress city at the door to the Baltic States.

ALBANY, Feb. 29 -- Charges of terrorism in connection with the extraordinary grand jury's investigation of alleged crime in Albany County were under triple inquiry tonight, following submission of an affidavit by a Negro witness stating that he was kicked, beaten and suspended from the twenty-ninth floor of the State Office Building.

John D. Rockefeller Jr. told the fiftieth anniversary meeting of the Men's Bible Class of the Riverside Church at the Hotel Commodore last night that if the world were to survive it must rededicate itself to the ideals of duty, service and sacrifice.

Sartorial i's were dotted and t's crossed in the styles shown yesterday morning at Milgrim's. Sally Milgrim, who is responsible for the custom-made collections presented by this specialty house, did not miss a trick when it came to endowing dresses, coats and suits with finish in details. From that point of view it was truly a couture collection.

Incomplete returns on the results of a three-week fund-raising drive to further the work of the National Conference of Christians and Jews show that $100,000 has been collected, it was announced yesterday at a luncheon at the Hotel Commodore attended by 1,000 members of the textile and allied industries who conducted the campaign.

It would be a mistake to interpret the British victory in the Arakan sector of Burma as a major success. This is not a front on which decisive results can be achieved, and no large forces were involved. Nevertheless it was a victory the more heartening because it was apparently snatched from the jaws of defeat.

CHICAGO, Feb. 29 -- Grain traders placed a bearish construction today on war and political developments in Europe, and although professional operators on the Board of Trade here bought rye early, the markets developed a heavy undertone and reacted sharply with rye in the lead.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- Reductions in alleged "excessive prices" for household lamps and lamp shades were promised by the Office of Price Administration today as it announced a series of new pricing methods which jobbers will use to determine their ceiling prices for those articles.

Because of his alleged carelessness as a workman on the battleship Missouri during its construction at the New York Navy Yard in Brooklyn, a 31-year-old welder was indicted yesterday on a charge of sabotage by the Federal Grand Jury in Brooklyn. He is Vincent J. Amoroso, married and the father of two children.

For the second successive month, offerings of new bonds here exceeded $100,000,000 in February, despite the virtual cessation of new investment financing during the Fourth War Loan drive, which ended on Feb. 15, after a four-week campaign.

Long Island University, once the apple of Clair Bee's eye and one of the country's most formidable fives, will be more or less on trial tonight when it tackles Cornell in the first game of the double-header at Madison Square Garden, for a bid to the national invitation tournament later in the month may hang on the outcome.

CHICAGO, Feb. 29 -- The American Bar Association went on record through its house of delegates today as favoring the Connally Senate resolution calling for United States participation in a world authority to prevent aggression and preserve peace, but almost unanimously voted down all other commitments.

LONDON, Feb. 29 -- This week the American officers and fighting men in Great Britain will get 2,500,000 meals and snacks from the American Red Cross and, no doubt, many thousands will spend their leaves sleeping in clubs maintained by that organization.

The appointment of Magistrate Edgar Bromberger as Commissioner of Investigation was announced yesterday by Mayor La Guardia. He will succeed William B. Herlands, who has held the post since 1938 and resigned Feb. 6 to enter private practice. The new appointee will be sworn in by the Mayor at noon today at City Hall.

Sailors were featured in the hat collection presented by Eric at the Ritz yesterday. Shown in all sizes, they were designed for both young and older women. Rough straw was prominent and lacquered palm fronds were used as trimming. This designer advocates a clear, deep green for spring hats.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- Larger supplies of children's wearing apparel and women's low-cost dresses, both of which have been hit hard by the shortage of cotton textiles, were predicted tonight by Chester Bowles, Price Administrator, who told shoppers they could expect to have better luck buying these items of clothing by late spring.

Your editorials have pointed out that Congress rightly overrode the Administration's discriminatory tax bill, but in the process deleted billions of needed revenue. The Congressional tax committee, treating its tremendous powers responsibly and realistically instead of politically, contended that confiscatory taxes cannot be slapped on the comparative few while exempting in part the many from a legitimate share.

Last year the American Tobacco Company and its consolidated subsidiaries did the largest volume of business in its history, record net sales reaching $529,422,104, an increase of $87,269,901 over the 1942 volume of $442,152,203, the annual report to stockholders disclosed today.

"Tell the Folks Back Home" is the title of Senator James A. Mead's forthcoming book on his tour of the battlefronts, to be published late this season by Appleton-Century. Senator Mead was one of the four Senators who visited Army camps from Greenland to Guadalcanal last year and met many of the outstanding Allied leaders.
LONDON, Wednesday, March 1 (AP) -- The Russian Tuesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

ALBANY, Feb. 29 -- The Assembly Ways and Means Committee, at its final meeting of the session today, killed appropriation bills involving $87,485,000 and reported favorably on fifteen bills carrying appropriations of $1,295,500.

Saturation of the system for one week with a daily dose of 500 milligrams of vitamin C, and then gradually reducing it, has enabled individuals allergic to certain foods to overcome their allergies, it is reported in the "Annals of Allergy" by Professor Harry N. Holmes of the Oberlin College chemistry department, a past president of the American Chemical Society.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- Every effort to provide rolling stock for the special campaign trains for Presidential and Vice Presidential candidates in the coming election will be made by the Office of Defense Transportation this fall, it was officially indicated today.

LONDON, Feb. 29 (AP) -- Soviet admirals and a general, in a new degree of military cooperation with the Allies, took part recently in American amphibious exercises for the continental invasion, United States naval headquarters disclosed today.

Last night's performance of "Goetterdaemmerung," the first of the season at the Metropolitan, was a remarkable one for several reasons, but chiefly for the singing of Bruennhilde by Helen Traubel, an artistic achievement which should rank with the finest of the season.

BOSTON, Feb. 29 (AP) -- Toronto aggravated the Bruins' apparently hopeless National Hockey League play-off plight by outscoring them, 7 -- 3, tonight before 12,000 at the Boston Garden. Goalie Bert Gardiner was credited with an assist on one of the Boston goals.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 29 (AP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

CHICAGO, Feb. 29 (AP) -- Shipments of swine here this month have set a twelve-year record for February with 401,200 salable hogs, plus 277,000 arriving direct. Receipts have declined this week, showing that the heavy hog-marketing season is about ended. Arrivals of 20,000 salable head today were about in line with advance estimates, but big packers had only 6,000 head coming in on direct billings, cutting the total supply sharply from recent marketings.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- A "Draft-Byrd-for-President Committee" which, according to its sponsors, has effected considerable organization in the South, started here today a movement to win the Democratic Presidential nomination for Senator Harry F. Byrd of Virginia.

Although taxes and contingency reserves were double those of the year before, an increase of 56.8 per cent in sales enabled the B.F. Goodrich Company to increase its earnings last year to $11,584,501 from $9,524,706 reported for 1942, according to the annual statement issued yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 29 (AP) -- Otis Co. of Cleveland, investment bankers, filed today in Federal District Court a suit for $1,000,000 against the Pennsylvania Railroad; its subsidiary, the Pennsylvania, Ohio Detroit Railroad Company, and sixteen officers and directors.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- Leo T. Crowley, Foreign Economic Administrator, said today that lend-lease food shipments last year had been large in terms of tons, 5,744,000, but relatively small in terms of United States supply.

Donald C. Townley has been elected vice president in charge of a newly formed foreign division of the American Home Products Corporation, Alvin G. Brush, chairman of the board, announced yesterday. The new division consolidates all foreign companies and export business into an operating unit on a par with the five other operating divisions of the company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- Carroll L. Beedy, counsel for the subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Agriculture before which Jonathan Daniels refused to testify yesterday received instructions today to assemble the evidence and to ascertain the law covering such an action preliminary to possible prosecution of the President's confidential adviser.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- Guns, torpedoes and bombs of the American forces have sunk almost half the merchant tonnage controlled by Japan when the war began, Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, announced today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, March 1 -- United States forces successfully landed in the Admiralty Islands yesterday, it was announced by Gen. Douglas MackArthur in a communique issued here today.

Edward A. LeRoy Jr., treasurer of the Phoenix Securities Corporation, commenting on the announcement by Joseph I. Lubin of plans to nominate an entirely new board of directors, issued the following statement yesterday in behalf of the company's management:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- A request for authority to broaden the cultural relations activities of the State Department to cover the world, instead of restricting them, as at present, to Latin America, China and a few other countries, in order to meet war and especially post-war problems was made to Congress by President Roosevelt today on the recommendation of Edward R. Stettinius rJ., Acting Secretary of State.

A warning that the peace that ends the present war "must not be the dictated result of personal conferences" was sounded last night by Governor Dewey at a rally attended by 18,000 persons in Madison Square Garden marking the opening of the New York City drive for $22,386,000 as its share of the $200,000,000 1944 Red Cross War Fund.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 29 -- Warner Brothers has signed Rosalind Russell to a term contract and will star her in an adaptation of Louise Randall Pierson's current novel, "Roughly Speaking." This family life story of a mother and her four children was bought last July for $35,000.

MAJ. HARRY HENSHEL, who once was a member of the American Olympic Committee and now is getting a ringside view of another type of international competition from somewhere in England, sends along a note and a clipping -- beg pardon. It's from The London Daily Express which makes it a "cutting," doncha know.

This month the American Red Cross asks the American people for a minimum war fund of $200,000,000. No words of urging are needed in support of the appeal. The public knows what the Red Cross means to our fighting men, their loved ones and all who bear the burden and pain of the nation's struggle.

Nora Norman, English pianist, who lives in New York, where she has studied with Louis Finton, gave a recital last night in The New York Times Hall before a large and enthusiastic audience. She played a program of unusual interest, including the rarely heard "Introduction and Allegro Appasionato" in G major for piano and orchestra by Schumann, with Erich Itor-Kahn at a second piano for the orchestral part.

Many of us in our youth had to learn by heart Macaulay's "Lays of Ancient Rome." We recall Lars Porsena of Clusium, who swore "by the nine gods" to overthrow popular liberties in favor of the Tarquins, and Horatius Cocles, who held the bridge over the Tiber single-handed "in the brave days of old."

Mayor La Guardia yesterday swore in Magistrate Edgar Bromberger as Commissioner of Investigation to succeed William B. Herlands, who resigned to enter private law practice. The ceremony was witnessed by Mr. Herlands and 100 former associates of Mr. Bromberger in the Department of Sanitation when he was Deputy Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Two young New Yorkers, who represented themselves as hospitalized soldiers, invaded the sanctum of John L. Lewis in the United Mine Workers Headquarters today and tried "to put him on the spot" with reference to coal miners' strikes.

Major league baseball along the New York front experienced a varied assortment of developments yesterday. The Yankees lost a player and the Giants gained one, while the Dodgers once again seemed in the process of entering upon negotiations with another prospective purchaser of the club.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Mrs. A.M. Sobel and Miss Ruth Sherman of New York won the women's pair championship in the Eastern States contract bridge tournament at the Park Central Hotel yesterday afternoon, repeating their victory in the same event in 1943.

The motorist who does not have his automobile registration number and State written on the face of every one of his gasoline ration coupons will face the prospect, starting next Monday, of an enforced visit to the Office of Price Administration.

If Gilbert Dodds ever is going to get any outside help in his endeavor to shatter the mile record it ought to come Saturday night when the Bostonian takes another whirl at the 4:07.4 mark which Glenn Cunningham, Charles Fenske and Leslie MacMitchell now hold.

Among the organizations reported yesterday as having taken business space for the Jewish Social Service Association, one of the city's oldest family welfare agencies, affiliated with the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Failure of Congress to extend the Lend-Lease Act for another year would mean calling off an essential part of the war just at the moment when the United Nations are poised for their greatest offensive, Leo T. Crowley, head of the Foreign Economic Administration, told the Foreign Affairs Committee of the House here today.

NEW ORLEANS, March 1 (AP) -- Democratic voters of the State rejected yesterday a group of candidates for office who advocated a return to "the liberal government of the late Huey P. Long" and elevated to the Governorship Jimmie H. Davis, author of "You Are My Sunshine," who campaigned with a hillbilly band.
On leaving Hattie Carnegie's new collection yesterday afternoon one felt highly stimulated Originality and daring were present. Here were creations to start new trends.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 1 -- Charles Laughton has been signed by Universal to star in "The Suspect," a murder mystery to be based on James Ronald's novel, "This Way Out." The film will be produced by Islin Auster. The studio has bought "Murder in the Blue Room," an original screen story by Stanley Davis, for Grace McDonald, who has just returned from a personal-appearance tour.

COLUMBIA, S.C., March 1 (AP) -- The Negro Citizens Committee of South Carolina took exception today to a resolution adopted by the State House of Representatives yesterday which called upon "damned agitators of the North" to "leave the South alone" with its racial problems.

MEXICO CITY, March 1 -- A twenty-year plan to expand Mexico's oil industry so as to cope with a feared shortage of oil after the war is being studied in Washington by officials of the Petroleum Reserve Corporation and Efrain Buenrostro, general manager of Petroleos Mexicanos, the government-controlled oil monopoly, according to today's Excelsior.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The War Production Board has decided to abandon plans for giant cargo aircraft of wood-and-plywood construction.

Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman of the Turf Committee of America, announced yesterday that horse racing's contributions to the war effort in the past two years had reached $8,520,980.86. Of this total $5,326,292.48 was contributed in 1943 for an increase of $2,131,604.10 over the previous year.

LONDON, March 1 -- The great Allied air offensive against Germany last week, in which for the first time since the opening of European aerial warfare planes of the United States Army Air Forces played the principal part, will be duplicated whenever the weather permits operations on such a scale.
The three-story store building on a plot 28 by 93 feet at 249 Newark Avenue, Jersey City, has been sold by Joseph Burieci to the Efficiency Realty Corporation.

As 100,000 volunteer workers took the field in the first full day of solicitation for the Red Cross 1944 War Fund, New York City's campaign for its $22,386,000 share of the national goal of $200,000,000 got off to a flying start when a gift of $150,000 was received from the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

Wayne Lonergan's trial for the murder of his wife, Patricia, dragged through another six hours of legalistic bickering as more talesmen were questioned in General Sessions Court before Judge John J. Freschi yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Representative Clarence F. Lea, Democrat of California, chairman of the House Committee investigating the Federal Communications Commission, was urged today by James L. Fly, FCC chairman, to hear fully, promptly and at length the members and staff of the commission, especially in regard to the activities of its radio intelligence and foreign broadcast intelligence divisions, and also on the alleged forced sale and transfer of radio station WMCA in New York.

Sewell L. Avery, chairman of the United States Gypsum Company, said yesterday at the company's annual meeting in Chicago that he was "unable to share the optimism now prevalent, particularly in regard to the post-war housing situation.

MIAMI, Fla., March 1 -- Bankrupt, carrying the silks of the Navy's Townsend B. Martin, decisively took the $3,500 Sunny Isles Purse at Hialeah Park today by eight lengths. It was a good race for the 4-year-old son of Pay Up and Strong Wheat who had been such a disappointment in his previous start.

The lady on the upper deck of the south-bound Fifth Avenue bus looked steadily out of the window on her right. She was obviously wondering what this impressive low gray stone building might be, stretching all the way from Eighty-fourth Street to Eightieth Street, a full fifth of a mile.

Bob Montgomery, Philadelphia lightweight who formerly was recognized here as class champion, apparently is going to have trouble making the lightweight limit of 135 pounds for his championship battle of fifteen rounds against Beau Jack, the title-holder, tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- An advisory committee on rules of procedure in Federal courts proposed today the elimination in criminal proceedings of legalistic verbiage which one member said "mystifies rather than informs."

A German flag bearing the signatures of 20,000 Bronx residents who bought bonds of $100 or more in the Fourth War Loan drive was turned over yesterday to Lieut. William E. Shomaker, 22-year-old Army pilot, for return delivery to Germany. The flag, captured in Sicily, was presented to him by Postmaster Albert Goldman at the war materials exhibit in the Chrysler Building.
LONDON, March 1 -- The British Government has decided to introduce less stringent censorship of political information, it was learned tonight.

MOSCOW, Thursday, March 2 -- The Soviet High Command announced last night that the Red Army had forced the Narva River south of Narva and cut the German escape railway leading from Narva to Tallinn, threatening the city from the north, south, east and west.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., March 1 (AP) -- The marriage of Lieut. Col. Evans Fordyce Carlson of Plymouth, Conn., leader of Carlson's Marine Raiders, well known in the Pacific campaign, and Mrs. Peggy Tatum Whyte of La Jolla, Calif., was announced today by the bride's sister, Miss Nancy Tatum.

LONDON, March 1 -- The stock markets here today were cheerful although business continued on a reduced scale. Industrials were good, rayon section particularly showing strength. Celanese and Courtaulds each went ahead. Diamonds and kaffirs weakened, but oils were better.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 1 -- Joseph N. Darnand, head of Vichy's forces for the maintenance of order, is extending his field of operations. From Savoie he first sent detachments into the Vaucluse, in the Rhone Valley. Now he has swept across the southern part of the country to attack the resistance movement in Dordogne.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, March 2 -- Fighting zestfully, the United States First Cavalry Division turned its heavy firepower against a strong Japanese counter-attack on the newly won positions at Momote airfield on Los Negros Island, in the Admiralties, repulsing the enemy "bloodily," Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced in a communique issued here today.

Though James H. Torrens, the Democratic and American Labor party candidate, actually won Tuesday's election to Congress from the Twenty-first District, his margin of victory was so narrow that, in view of the history of the district, the Republicans were justified in drawing the encouragement from the result that they did.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Protest to recent budget cuts for New York training schools followed fast today upon testimony of six rehabilitated youths who told the Pepper subcommittee on juvenile delinquency that they had found little help in New York reform schools.

The schools motion picture committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

CHUNGKING, China, March 1 -- "The American experts sent to China through the cultural relations program of the United States State Department are making an extremely valuable contribution. China wants the people of the United States to know how highly China values the work the experts have done," said P.H. Chang, counselor of the Executive Yuan, this afternoon.

Mrs. Edna Hancock, 30-year-old former attendant at Brooklyn State Hospital, went on trial yesterday before Kings County Judge Peter J. Brancato and a jury on a charge of first-degree perjury. The indictment followed her testimony at the trial of Murray Goldman, 30-year-old Brooklyn salesman, who was convicted of attempted rape but was later exonerated by Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz after Goldman had submitted to a lie-detector test.

Yesterday a letter on this page brought back to some of us the tremors, glory or breaking-down of Declamation Day at school. It summoned our old acquaintances the Tarquins, brave Horatius, the captain of the gate, and Lars Porsena, by the nine gods who swore.
LONDON, March 1 (UP) -- An Air Ministry communique:
The increased civilian supply of meat was reflected yesterday in a cut in the retail ceiling prices of five types of Virginia cured pork specialties.

An exhibition of Hungarian paintings owned in this country will open with a private view this evening (8.30 to 11 P.M.) in the Peikin Galleries, on the second floor of the Hotel Gotham, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street. It opens to the public on Friday and will continue until March 26.

LONDON, March 1 (U.P.) -- The mining parish of Heanor, Derbyshire, today rallied to the support of Nora Carpenter, unmarried mother of quadruplets, as the family of the 23-year-old girl member of the British armed forces disclosed details of her wartime romance with a Soldier whose name and nationality were kept secret.

An eleven-room apartment in 1100 Park Avenue has been leased to Samuel Sennet, general manager of Howard Clothes, Inc., through the Payson McL. Merrill Company, agents, and Rossbach Associates, brokers. Other rentals included:

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. returned today from a fortnight's holiday in Florida to announce that his health had not been broken down, that there would be no changes of personnel at the Treasury because of the attitude of Congress toward its tax proposals, that he was highly satisfied with the recent war loan campaign and that the Treasury would make a $4,700,000,000 exchange offer, starting tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia has affirmed an order of the Federal Power Commission directing the Connecticut Light and Power Company to comply with the uniform system of accounts set up for uilities in interstate business.

Viewing small business as in a perilous position now and needing strong backing by government to maintain its existence, Maury Maverick, chairman and executive director of the Smaller War Plants Corporation, yesterday outlined an eight-point program designed to protect "the little business man."
One of the United States Army's greatest weaknesses, as it girds for the coming invasion of western Europe, is, in the opinion of a corporal of about a year's service, 'a general want of conviction."

LONDON, Thursday, March 2 (U.P.) -- The Red Army, in new offensives at opposite ends of a 400-mile front, has by-passed the German stronghold of Narva by smashing ten miles deeper into northern Estonia, and advanced to within six miles south of Vitebsk, key Nazi base in northern White Russia, Moscow announced last night.

Plans for immediate establishment throughout New York State of central veterans' information and service centers through which returning veterans will have access to the facilities of government and private agencies were announced yesterday by Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the War Manpower Commission.

Fearing that the contest between the right and left wings for control of the American Labor party may lessen the chance of President Roosevelt carrying New York State at the November election, close friends of the President for several weeks have been trying to induce Sidney Hillman to withdraw his opposition to the present State leadership of the party and to end his alliance with the Communistic left wing, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON, March 1 -- The Finnish Government tonight allowed its people to know Soviet Russia's terms for peace with Finland. The Finnish radio announced at 9 P.M. that no negotiations had taken place but confirmed that the Government had received Moscow's offer and seemed to emphasize that the offer was not a demand for "unconditional surrender."

ALGIERS, March 1 -- What may be the third and possibly the greatest German drive intended to roll the Allies' beachhead troops back into the sea began yesterday morning between Aprilia and Cisterna, south of the main electrified coastal railway that has been the spine of the German defenses.

Several seemingly unrelated items in yesterday's TIMES are, indeed, complementary, and when assembled tend to reveal opinion that is doubtless widely held, therefore the more deserving of review. I refer to your editorial "Post-War Military Service," Mrs. Roosevelt's approval of a year of military training for boys of 17 and the observations on education by Dr. Lewis, president of Lafayette College.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- President Roosevelt signed legislation increasing pensions of Spanish-American War veterans from $60 to $75 a month for disability or upon their reaching the age of 65. The President also signed a bill authorizing payment of $4,852 to the State of Oregon Forestry Department and privately organized protective associations for protection of public forest lands.

WEST POINT, N.Y., March 1 (AP) -- Army's unbeaten basketball team smothered a weak Maryland quintet under an 85 -- 22 avalanche today for its fourteenth straight victory, and the West Pointers established three field house records while doing it.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- President Roosevelt returned to the White House today after a week's rest away from the capital and spent most of the day conferring with military chiefs.

LONDON, March 1 -- The final count in the Bury St. Edmunds, Suffolk, by-election brought the Government candidate home a winner with the comfortable margin of 2,584 votes and it hoped now to put such contests back where they belong.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The House committee appointed to investigate acts of executive agencies beyond the scope of their authority inquired today into the activities of Craig Vincent, Atlantic Coast representative of the organizing and manning division of the War Shipping Administration.

At least two city magistrates ate regularly in a restaurant owned by a man who was fined Tuesday for purchasing garbage swill to serve his customers, it became known yesterday at a hearing for the scavenger who collected the rotting fruits and vegetables.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- The Chesapeake Ohio Railway today petitioned the Interstate Commerce Commission to reconsider its decision denying the road permission to issue $76,573,700 of preference stock as a dividend to its holders of common stock. It set forth that it would have a surplus of $93,000,000 after the distribution.

CHUNGKING, China, March 1 (U.P.) -- Kim Koo, President of the Provisional Korean Government in Chungking, said today that "nothing short of full and immediate independence" after the war would satisfy the 30,000,000 Koreans now under Japanese domination.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 1 -- The Egyptian Government's reminder to the United States Government of its attitude concerning Jewish immigration into Palestine would appear to be closely in line with the policy of Premiere Mustafa Naha's Pasha, who championed Arab postwar collaboration, observers here agree.

A vacant plot 57 by 107 feet at the northeast corner of Pine and William Streets has been sold by the Mutual Life Insurance Company to a client of Raymond D. O'Connell, attorney. It is assessed at $650,000 and was acquired by the seller on foreclosure of a $900,000 mortgage, according to John J. Reynolds, the broker in the sale.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- Two high military men agreed tonight that Japan was powerless to break up the "leaps and bounds" American attack in the Pacific, but one warned that the Japanese were "playing possum" in the hope of a chance to hand out an unexpected smashing blow.

Leaders in the Harlem community, Democrats and independents as well as Republicans, were agreed yesterday that the voting in Tuesday's special election in the Twenty-first Congressional District indicated that Negro voters were turning away from the Democratic party.

The preliminary report of the Western Union Telegraph Company for 1943, issued yesterday by A.N. Williams, president, shows a net income of $7,235,008 after operating expenses, taxes and other charges. Under the participating provisions of the company's new capital stock, 1943 net was equal to $5.80 a share on the Class A stock and $3.80 a share on the Class B stock.

With Alvin Rubenstein giving a true-to-life performance in the role of Frank Merriwell at Madison Square Garden last night, Long Island University retained its chance to become one of the two remaining choices for the national invitation basketball tournament, but only with the final curtain halfway down.
NEW DELHI, India, March 1 (UP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

A syndicate headed by the Chase National Bank won yesterday the award of a new issue of $8,300,000 of State of New York housing bonds dated March 2, 1944, and due $170,000 annually on March 2, 1946 to 1994. The bankers bid 100.3599, naming the interest rate as 1.30 per cent. This was equal to an interest cost to the State of 1.2862 per cent, a new low rate on its housing bonds.
CHICAGO, March 1 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:

The three four-story apartment houses at 148-52 Parkside Avenue and 5 St. Paul's Place, Brooklyn, have been bought by Frederick Brown, operator, from Abraham B. and H. Lawrence Spiegelglass. The structures are on an irregular plot 209 by 225 feet and contain sixty-seven suites.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 1 (U.P.) -- Southern Association baseball directors gave a vote of confidence to a post-war professional football league tonight and authorized President William G. (Billy) Evans to open negotiations with the National Football League for player-option agreements.

Post-war business and industry can thrive only if existing tax laws are lowered drastically and the excess profits and capital gains levies eliminated, speakers declared yesterday at the American Management Association's conference which opened in the Hotel New Yorker.

MOSCOW, March 1 -- Leading United Nations diplomats generally took the view today that the Soviet armistice terms offered to Finland were generous and expressed the hope that the Finnish Government would see its way clear to accept them.

ABOARD A U.S. BATTLESHIP AT TRUK, Feb. 17 (Delayed) -- After sinking four and possibly five enemy warships within sight of the Truk Islands, the small but powerful striking force of which this brand new battleship is a unit boldly circled the atoll last night, interposing ourselves between Truk and Japan.

To put the city's campaign against black markets on a "democratic community basis," the Office of Price Administration is setting up price panel headquarters in every large shopping district, from which women volunteers will be assigned to work with neighborhood stores, Daniel P. Woolley, regional administrator, announced yesterday.

Walter Hoving, chairman of the national board of the United Service Organizations, accepted yesterday the chairmanship of the United Negro College Fund Campaign Committee, which will seek to raise $1,500,000 this year for twenty-seven leading Negro colleges and universities in this country.

So great was the demand to hear Jascha Heifetz at his recital last night in Carnegie Hall that the entire house was sold out two months in advance. Not only was the auditorium packed to capacity, but all available space on the stage was filled as well, that part of the house having been set aside for service men and women who occupied all of the 300 seats on the platform.

PEARL HARBOR, March 1 -- A formation of big Navy Liberators swept over Wake Island Monday afternoon in a successful attack that destroyed or badly damaged six grounded enemy planes and blasted an airdrome and other installations, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, announced today.

The New York City Budget Council, the recommendations of which are used by private agencies in estimating relief allowances, has just announced that a family of five living on a low or marginal income must spend a minimum of $13.25 weekly for groceries.
Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 2 per cent in February under the like month of last year, according to the monthly survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

New York will be the scene of a battle for patronage between two major ballet companies next month when the Ballet Theatre and the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo open their spring seasons competitively in the same night. On April 9 the former company will begin an engagement of four weeks at the Metropolitan Opera House, while the latter organization opens at the City Center for three weeks with the possibility of a fourth.
The tip-up season of fishing through the ice for pickerel closed in this State yesterday, which made reports of recent activities in that field timely.

Louis (Lepke) Buchalter's few remaining chances of escaping electrocution for the murder of a Brooklyn candy store owner were reduced further yesterday in a ruling by Federal Judge Clarence G. Galston. Judge Galston declined to issue a writ of habeas corpus, which probably would have delayed the electrocution of Lepke, scheduled for tonight.

Consolidated net income of the Aviation Corporation for the fiscal year ended Nov. 30, 1943, amounted to $3,519,437, compared with $3,993,575 in the preceding year, and equaled 61 cents a share on the capital stock, against 69 cents the year before.

ALBANY, March 1 -- Agreement on an integrated veterans' welfare program was reached in committee rooms today, and with Irving M. Ives, majority leader of the Assembly acting as director general, the items of the program are generally set for passage.

A few years ago H.S. Kraft was investigating a fabulous restaurant on Second Avenue, with Sam Jaffe to help him as the equally fabulous waiter of "Cafe Crown." Last evening the pair of them were together again, as the author and star, respectively, of "Thank You, Svoboda," which opened at the Mansfield.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 1 -- Greek guerrillas led by a British officer blew up a German troop train and killed 400 German officers and soldiers, it was officially announced today.

ALBANY, March 1 -- A bill designed to ease the income tax burden of lawyers, doctors and other individuals who often collect in a lump sum for services performed over a period of years was sent to Governor Dewey for signature today after being adopted unanimously in the Assembly.
A bill has been introduced in the New York Legislature to dispense with bar examinations for law school graduates who have served at least one year in the armed forces.

CHICAGO, March 1 -- An advance of 1 cent a bushel in parity price of wheat last month, as reported by the Department of Agriculture, led to a reversal of sentiment today on the Board of Trade, and, with some let-up in pressure, futures advanced slowly and closed about the top, gaining 5/8 to 3/4 cent a bushel.

Crude oil production of the Union Oil Company of California reached last year the highest level in its fifty-three-year history, with a total of 25,000,000 barrels, Reese H. Taylor, president, declared in his annual statement to stockholders issued for publication today.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Office of Price Administration today extended until April 15 its ruling permitting unrestricted sales by producers of finished piece goods to jobbers who sell 65 per cent or more of their goods to retailers or foreign buyers.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Reports by two of three impartial observers who participated in a recent investigation of charges of brutality toward Federal prisoners at the Springfield (Mo.) Medical Center were made public today by Attorney General Biddle.

LONDON, March 1 -- A delicate situation is bound to arise after the war as a result of the reversed roles of the United States and Britain in the realm of shipping, Lord Winster told the Royal Empire Society. A conference of the Allied nations interested in the world-carrying trade should be called "at the proper moment," he added.

WITH CHINESE FORCES, in the Hukawng Valley, Burma, Feb. 28 (Delayed) -- Chinese troops are advancing rapidly on Maingkwan, the main town of Hukawng Valley, after annihilating most of the Japanese forces in the upper half of the valley and drivng out the rest.
Organized labor is faced with vast responsibilities. In consequence, the current demands on the part of many leaders for general wage increases are not reassuring.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The war administration of the United States, which has drafted men for combat, endorsed a national service law, instituted a measure of price and wage controls, rationed food, shoes, gasoline and rubber, taken back industrial profits by renegotiation of war contracts and in many other ways harshly regulated the daily life of the people, has maintained a peacetime policy with respect to the public use of transportation.

Continued Government controls of civilian goods production for a three-year post-war emergency period was advocated yesterday by Arthur D. Whiteside, former vice chairman of the War Production Board in Charge of Civilian Requirements and president of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

American exporters have no need for a government foreign credit insurance plan to aid the post-war expansion of trade, exporters attending a meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau at the Hotel Pennsylvania declared yesterday.

How one manufacturer tested his war advertising copy is described in the monthly bulletin of Grey Advertising Agency, Inc. Copies of current "ads" were sent to all 312 of the concern's employes in the armed forces with a request for frank comment.

Looking to the day when building or remodeling a house will again be possible, the Dime Savings Bank has prepared a Home Buyers Institute Exhibit that will be opened to the public Monday on the sixth floor of its building at Fulton Street and De Kalb Avenue in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Americans in 1943 increased their earnings at a more rapid rate than they spent them on consumer goods and services, despite the fact that the expenditures were the largest ever reached for one year, the Office of War Information declared today.

LONDON, March 1 (U.P.) -- Marshal Tito (Josip Broz) announced today that Yugoslav Partisans had resumed the initiative on all sectors except Italian Istria and Slovenia, where heavy fighting is raging, while the Berlin radio claimed that 23,616 Partisans had been killed and 14,621 had been captured since Dec. 1.

The appointment of 100 teachers for grades 1A to 6B was approved yesterday at a special meeting of the Board of Education. To be made from the regular eligible list, the appointments will take effect March 6, and according to Ellsworth B. Buck, president, will provide teachers for all vacancies except those caused by day-to-day illness.

LONDON, March 1 -- Great Britain and the United States have each agreed to underwrite 500,000 [$2,000,000] this year for the expenses of the Inter-Governmental Committee on Refugees, to care for some 20,000,000 homeless Europeans, Minister of State Richard K. Law told the House of Commons today.

ALBANY, March 1 -- Mayor Erastus Corning 2d submitted to Governor Dewey today a formal request for a full and impartial investigation of charges that a Negro of the city was beaten and kicked by State Police associated with the investigation of alleged crime in Albany County.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week increased rather sharply, but both light and heavy fuel oil supplies were lower, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the close of the period, gasoline stocks were 85,248,000 barrels, an increase of 1,317,000 over the 83,931,000 a week earlier. A year ago, they were 92,772,000 barrels.

NEWARK, N.J., March 1 -- The State Chamber of Commerce gave "whole-hearted approval" today to the proposed State Constitution, scheduled to be considered by the Legislature next Friday, while the New Jersey Taxpayers Association warned friends of the document of a movement to defeat the provisions for a single fiscal year and single State fund.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 1 -- The stockholders of the United Corporation were told today by their president, William M. Hickey, that the Securities and Exchange Commission had given virtual approval of the proposed voluntary offer of an exchange of securities designed to retire one-half of the outstanding shares of the $3 cumulative preference stock of the holding company.

Reporting on last year's operations of the General Foods Corporation, Clarence Francis, chairman, informed stockholders in the preliminary annual report released today, that sales were up 12 per cent, over the 1942 figure, taxes were 14 per cent higher, and wages and salaries were up 31 per cent while net profits increased only 2 per cent.
The New York Stock Exchange has admitted to dealings the Phillips Petroleum Company's 2 3/4 per cent sinking fund debentures due in 1964.

Increased trade covering and commission house buying yesterday produced an improved tone in cotton futures, and allowed prices to recover some of their losses of the previous day. At the close of trading, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 5 to 9 points, or 25 to 45 cents a bale.

LONDON, March 1 -- The British are all for streamlining this well-weathered civilization of theirs, but slowly. Some would amend the law to make it possible to drive on the right side of the road along with everyone else except the Chinese and the Indians.

ALGIERS, March 1 -- Another more or less "secret" weapon has been turned loose by the Germans on the beachhead below Rome. It is a ground-hugging, remote-controlled tank carrying 1,000 pounds of high explosive to its target, where it can be exploded at will.

WINTER PARK, Fla., March 1 (AP) -- James Wren (Zack) Taylor, coach and assistant manager of the St. Louis Browns, predicts the baseball manpower shortage will result in the development of an outstanding crop of young players.

A member of the national board of the Young Women's Christian Associations since 1932, Miss Margaret E. Forsyth, assistant professor of religious education at Teachers College, Columbia University, was appointed yesterday as head of the Y.W.C.A. foreign division.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- A guarded prediction of improvement in the newsprint supply for newspapers in the last half of this year came today from Harold J. Boeschenstein, director of the forest products bureau of the War Production Board.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Agreements similar to the supplementary treaty that was made last month with Brazil, under which the United States Government will pay a premium of 33 1-3 per cent above previously fixed prices for rubber with the southern republic assuming the cost of developing wild rubber within its borders, are to be concluded with Peru, Colombia and Ecuador, it was made known here today.

Tonight's premiere is "Bright Boy" at the Playhouse. It's a comedy dealing with life at a prep school, the work of John Boruff, an actor, now serving as a lieutenant in the USNR. He has had some experience as a playwright, his "Timber House" having been done in 1936 and "Washington Jitters," of which he was co-author, in 1938.
LONDON, Thursday, March 2 (AP) -- The Russian Wednesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

CHICAGO, March 1 -- Every major operating unit of Marshall Field Co., including retail stores and manufacturing and real estate divisions, had the largest volume of business in its history during 1943, Hughston M. McBain, president, said today in the company's annual report.

In these lean days of new State and municipal financing, it is not often that bankers have an opportunity to bid on a prime issue such as that of $8,330,000 of State of New York long-term serial housing bonds, which were awarded yesterday.
ALLIED HEADQUARTER IN SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, March 2 (AP) -- A communique:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, March 2 (AP) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur said in his communique today that landing troops of the dismounted First Cavalry Division had "successfully consolidated" their position on Los Negros Island.
LONDON, March, 1 (AP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

In an all-cash deal, the fourteen-story apartment house at 820 Park Avenue, northwest corner of Seventy-fifth Street, has been sold by the Greenwich Savings Bank to an investing client of Alfred C. Marks, broker. Former Governor Herbert H. Lehman has an apartment in the building which fronts 102.2 feet on the avenue and 51 feet on the street and is assessed at $740,000.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Senate and House conferees on the service men's voting bills moved today to prevent the use of the Administration-endorsed Federal ballot by the armed forces stationed in the continental United States.

NEW DELHI, India, March 1 (U.P.) -- Japanese remnants trapped behind the British lines on both sides of the Mayu range in western Burma were being mopped up today as the fighting switched southward to the main Arakan front, fifty miles north of Akyab.

NEW DELHI, India, March 1 (U.P.) -- Japanese remnants trapped behind the British lines on both sides of the Mayu range in western Burma were being mopped up today as the fighting switched southward to the main Arakan front, fifty miles north of Akyab.

With hundreds of thousands of fathers being drafted into the armed forces, the health of their dependents becomes a matter of both military morale and the future security of our country. For this reason we must face the fact that many families of service men are threatened with malnutrition because of the high cost of living in some of the areas in which they reside.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- Robert E. Hannegan, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, will head the arrangements committee for the national convention in Chicago.

Reports that the Finnish Government is sending a delegation to Moscow headed by Juho Paasikivi, former Premier and negotiator of the treaty that ended the "winter war" of 1939-40, indicate that Finland's long and tragic struggle is near an end. Great Britain, which is bound by agreement with Russia not to make a separate peace, has accepted the Soviet terms.

Roman Totenberg, the Polish violinist, has been appointed solo violinist and concertmaster of the newly-formed New York City Symphony by Leopold Stokowski, the orchestra's conductor, it was learned today. Mr. Totenberg, who was formerly concertmaster of the orchestra of the New Friends of Music, is a recitalist of wide experience.

LISBON, Portugal, March 1 -- In the years immediately before the war there was a great deal of talk about Germans sacrificing their appetite to have cannons instead of butter. This may have been done then, but all that can be said is that in the upper Rhineland there is plenty of butter now.

ALBANY, March 1 -- Chairman D. Mallory Stephens of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee introduced today the measure, sponsored by the Committee of Fifteen, that would set up a New York City transit authority to run the city's rapid transit lines on a 10-cent fare.

Cooper Union will begin this week a series of four meetings, planned for successive Sundays, on the literatures of the United States, England, China and Russia. The first meeting will be given over to Chinese literature with Chi-chen Wang, Professor of Chinese at Columbia University, as the speaker.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- After a year of negotiation spokesmen for the Pennsylvania Anthracite Operators and the United Mine Workers of America were reported today to be nearing completion of a contract, governing the wages and working conditions of 77,000 miners.

Inasmuch as less than 10 per cent of the original issue of Stamp 18 in Ration Book 1 is estimated to be "out" still, the Office of Price Administration is expected to announce within a week validation of a new shoe coupon, shoe wholesalers stated yesterday.

An altercation early yesterday morning among three patrolmen outside a Bronx tavern, in which one of them fired three shots at two other patrolmen called to quell the disturbance, resulted in the suspension of the three the arrest of the one who fired the shots.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- Dr. A.G. Black is expected to resign soon as governor of the Farm Credit Administration in another personnel change involving the departure of proteges of Vice President Wallace from farm posts.

The stock market regained yesterday to some extent the ground it lost in the previous session, but the recovery generally held to major fractions. Some interest was whipped up in the public utilities, which dominated dealings, and in a fairly wide assortment of specialties, with little attention accorded the prime investment type of issue.

Fire, fanned by a brisk wind, yesterday wrecked the four-story brick building at 411 East Thirty-sixth Street, which housed the Cadet Aeronautic Corporation and the Blackstone Corporation, manufacturers of equipment for the Army and Navy.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The death yesterday of Representative Thomas H. Cullen of Brooklyn reduced Democratic representation in the House to three votes below an actual majority.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The inclusion of Latvia in the sixteen Soviet Republics was "a flagrant violation of the Atlantic Charter and international and moral law," the Latvian Legation here declared in a bulletin issued today. So dominated will Latvia be by the central organizations of the U.S.S.R. and the Communist party that "it could never dream either of seceding from the U.S.S.R. or having its own independent foreign policy," it said.

Power output and gross revenues of the Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago, for the fifth consecutive year, reached record high levels last year and currently 40 per cent of the company's power sales is going directly into war production, Charles Y. Freeman, chairman, reported yesterday to stockholders in his annual report for 1943.

By another one of those daring surprise moves made possible by American superiority in the southwest Pacific and the virtual blinding of Japanese reconnaissance, American forces under the personal supervision of General MacArthur have leaped forward more than 250 miles and landed on the Admiralty Islands.

Girls who become juvenile delinquents today would have become delinquent, war or no war, Dr. A.A. Brill, psychiatrist, said yesterday in a talk to welfare workers at the Girls Service Club, 138 East Nineteenth Street. The great effect of the war on the whole question, he added, was not that it increased the problem but rather that it made "squeamish people willing to talk about it, and even sometimes interested in trying to solve it."

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Procedures by which the school lunch, whether it be a box luncheon, a one-hot-dish lunch or a complete cafeteria meal, may be made "an integral part of the school's educational program" are outlined in a pamphlet soon to be issued by the United States Office of Education, "Making School Lunches Educational."

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- The "Stop-Roosevelt" advocates in the Democratic party have announced activities in the South, in Massachusetts and in all other States where they can get on the primary ballot, but a check today shows that President Roosevelt already has tentative promises of four-fifths of the convention vote needed for a fourth-term nomination.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, March 1 (AP) -- A special communique:

Dr. Horace H. Underwood, a missionary to Korea, who was arrested by the Japanese after Pearl Harbor, was ordained last night, together with his twin sons, John and James, 25 years old, in services at the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church, 85 South Oxford Street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- To officials of the Iraq Parliament who urged him by cable to withdraw the pending resolution reaffirming United States approval of Palestine as a Jewish national homeland, Senator Robert F. Wagner replied today that the Congress of the United States had been able, for more than a century, "to reach its own conclusions without advice from officials of foreign nations."

WHITE-PLAINS, N.Y., March 1 -- A theft from the County Office Building here of B and C gasoline ration coupons good for 150,000 gallons was disclosed today by the Westchester Sheriff's office, which said it had been secretly investigating the theft for six weeks.

Describing the Government's proposed Arabian oil project as an "unjustified venture by bureaucracy," James A. Moffett, formerly Housing Administrator in the Roosevelt Administration, declared yesterday that Harold L. Ickes, Petroleum Administrator for War, should be removed and possibly impeached and suggested that a Congressional committee should be appointed to make a thorough investigation of the entire proposal.
ALBANY, March 1 -- Action on legislation of particular interest to New York City was in the foreground at today's legislative session and in the committee rooms.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 1 -- Acting President Edelmiro T. Farrell and his Government tonight survived what in the intention of its organizers should have been a vast counter-revolutionary movement, having as its program the restoration of Gen. Pedro Ramirez to the Presidency and the calling of free elections at the earliest possible date.

TRENTON, N.J., March 1 (AP) -- Describing as "a feeble compromise" the absentee balloting system devised by Congress, Gov. Walter E. Edge said today that the plan would not facilitate voting by New Jersey men and women in the armed forces.

The Office of Price Administration is responsible for 50 per cent of the black market that exists today, Joseph J. Rosen, secretary of the Butter and Egg Merchants Association of New York, charged yesterday.

In his first nation-wide-broadcast since he made formal announcement of his candidacy for the Republican nomination for President, Wendell L. Willkie declared last night that the Democratic party was falling to pieces and the Republican party was faced with its greatest opportunity.

Broadway has had three new plays this week, the third swing having been taken last evening by "Bright Boy" at the Playhouse, and the batter now being out until week after next. The third try was somewhat different from the earlier two, although the final effect was much the same -- leaving the state of the theatre about where it was. For Lieut.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Led by further substantial increases in market prices for livestock and certain fruits and vegetables and higher prices for wheat and cotton, the Bureau of Labor Statistics index of commodity prices in primary markets rose 0.3 per cent during the week ended on Feb. 26. Quotations for principal industrial commodities generally were unchanged from the week before.

ON THE SECOND UKRAINIAN FRONT, in Russia, Feb. 26 (Delayed) -- On this front and on the way here there were abundant signs of the part that United States supplies sent to Russia are playing in the Red Army's successes.

Discussions are now taking place among the British, American and Soviet Governments on the armistice terms and conditions of occupation to be imposed by the victors on a defeated Germany. It is understood that the three Governments have drawn up separate plans and that these plans are being compared and correlated into a single program.

ALBANY, March 2 -- Opposition was expressed by organized labor, civic groups, bar organizations and political leaders to all of the three alternatives, offered in Governor Dewey's judicial reform program, at a public hearing before the Senate Judiciary Committee today.

Ceilings on salaries and wages are a severe handicap to long-established corporations, while they present little difficulty and some decided advantages to corporations organized solely for war-contract operations. It is customary in established companies to grant increases to executives, based on length of service, extra effort and initiative.

Bridal outfits will be sent to Wacs stationed abroad by the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, Mrs. Kenneth S. Strayer, president, revealed yesterday at the federation's annual spring festival, held at the Hotel Astor.

Graceful, feminine clothes that depended on symmetry of line rather than any specific trend were outstanding in the collection shown to the press yesterday at Henri Bendel. The Bendel originals, produced by the firm's designing staff under the direction of Mr. Leon, ranged from tailormades to formal evening gowns.

The need for coordinating the programs of all levels of the public school system to develop flexible, continuous curricula was emphasized yesterday in a panel discussion on trends in curriculum planning held at the Bank of the Manhattan Company, Sixty-fourth Street and Madison Avenue, under auspices of the Public Education Association.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Dr. Saul D. Alinski, criminologist who started Chicago's Back of the Yards Community, told the Pepper subcommittee investigating juvenile delinquency today that a change must be made in the civic systems which turned out "one delinquent in every ten children."

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total holdings of United States Government securities to have decreased $191,742,000 to the lowest of this year, while note circulation increased $152,348,000 during the week.

Shipments of meat into the city were lighter this week than last, the market news service of the War Food Administration reports. Even so, they were adequate to meet the demand, which for some reason, possibly the Lenten season, was small.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Our successful campaign in the Pacific means that Japan's secondary defense line, comprising the Marianas, the Carolines and the Philippines, now lies open to attack, Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of War, stated at a news conference today.
Time was when the sole function of a powder base was to "stick" one's face powder to one's face. It consisted primarily of a bit of stearic acid and a lot of water, bound together with soap.

Pierre Laval, speaking with what he termed his "usual sincerity,'' was quoted by the Nazi-operated Paris radio last night as asserting that the German Army would not necessarily defeat the Allies, but that it, in turn, would definitely not be beaten by them.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 2 -- The $1,000,000 County Center here, opened by Westchester in 1930 for music festivals, operas, concerts, expositions, civic rallies, art exhibitions and classes in the arts, probably will become a factory on May 1 for the manufacture of copper cables for the Navy, County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach said today.

Brooklyn will have a special Congressional election in the next month to pick a successor to the late Representative Thomas H. Cullen, but it is not expected to be a test of the New Deal, a check-up disclosed yesterday. Mr. Cullen will be buried tomorrow, and Gov. Thomas E. Dewey is expected to name the date for the special election in the next few days.

Wall Street had a bit of excitement at quitting time yesterday, when glass showered down into Nassau Street and Fire Department equipment blocked the narrow street between the New York Stock Exchange and the Bankers Trust Building.

LONDON, Friday, March 3 (AP) -- Moscow announced last night that the Red Army captured thirty communities yesterday in a drive toward Ostrov, thirty-five miles south of Pskov on the great trunk railway to Warsaw, while northward around the Estonian stronghold of Narva the Russians improved their bridgehead and flung the Germans from several strong points.

Urging immediate cancellation of contracts for some six hundred Liberty ships in favor of building larger, faster and stronger vessels of the Victory or Maritime Commission C types, Senator Mon C. Wallgren of Washington declared yesterday that since the Government built special-type vessels for special tasks, Libertys should not be converted into troop carriers or hospital ships.

A portrait of a small boy, "Le Petit Lange," by the French nineteenth century artist Edouard Manet, brought $18,500, the highest price, last night in the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., at an auction sale of paintings consigned by a Midwestern educational institution.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- Senators worried about the misbehavior of the young gave hopeful ear today to the story of an 18-year-old girl who told how the transformation of an old warehouse into a community center helped get youngsters of Moline, Ill., out of the saloons and into wholesome activities.

CHICAGO, March 2 -- Although wheat prices advanced today on the Board of Trade, the strength came largely from professional operations, except for a little buying which brokers said was for mills. There was no material pressure at any time, and closing sales were about the top, with gains of 3/8 to 3/4 cent a bushel, the former on May.

DARIEN, Conn., March 2 -- Michael Irving Mann, 5-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor I. Mann, who moved into a house on Pear Tree Point Road here yesterday, was drowned today in a well at the rear of the property and Mrs. Mann fell into the shaft in a frantic effort to rescue the child.

Charles Seligson, trustee of Adolf Gobel, Inc., said yesterday that under the reorganization plan filed by him in Federal court here on Monday, Flug Strassler had acquired $723,000 of old debentures of the company out of $1,081,000 outstanding, on which accrued interest amounted to $132,674 on Jan. 22.

LONDON, March 2 -- Prime Minister Churchill bade the Royal College of Physicians today to muster its strength behind the Government's national health scheme because, he said, "disease must be attacked whether it occurs in the poorest or the richest man or woman simply on the ground that it is the enemy."
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, March 3 (AP) -- A communique:

William Clark Hancock, a United States Navy seaman, told Kings County Judge Peter J. Brancato and a jury of eleven men and one woman yesterday that Thomas Cradock Hughes, acting district attorney, had assured him and his wife, Mrs. Edna Hancock, that he would not prosecute her "under any circumstances, because there is nothing against her."

It is reported that 36,000,000 pounds of the Government's hoard of butter represent "excess supply." The Butter Advisory Committee, speaking for the creamery industry, has opposed the sale of this butter in the civilian market, and has recommended that it be shipped to Russia (with the proviso that such shipments should be deducted from the allocation for Russia in the year starting April 1.)
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Department store sales for the week ended Feb. 26 were 11 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Increased price-fixing and persistent trade covering, which absorbed contracts and offset small flurries of hedge selling and liquidation, yesterday produced an improvement in cotton futures. At the close of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange, active futures contracts were up 4 to 8 points, or 25 to 35 cents a bale.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- A determined effort to induce Congress to hold up the construction of Secretary Ickes' Arabian pipeline may now be expected, in consequence of the severe attack on the project by James A. Moffett in New York yesterday, and other spokesmen for the petroleum industry in Washington today.
LONDON, Friday, March 3 (AP) -The l7sia Thursday idniglt supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

Laying blame for the gasoline black market upon the motoring public, a group of retail gasoline dealers told Office of Price Administration officials yesterday that about half the motorists in this city were violating gasoline rationing regulations in one form or another.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Impressive results have been achieved by the war workers' suggestion plan for increasing industrial production, according to the OWI. A report, based on figures compiled by the War Production Board, War Manpower Commission, Maritime Commission and Navy and War Departments showed that about 6,500,000 workers are now organized under the plan.

UNION CITY, N.J., March 2 -- As an aftermath of a "wolf" hunt in near-by Secaucus early this week, which resulted in the capture of a docile female police dog. William Kuhn of this city, a deputy game warden who first raised the cry of "wolf," submitted today his resignation to the New Jersey Fish and Game Commission.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (U.P.) -- Elmer Davis, Director of War Information, has issued a new policy directive for propaganda handling of 1944 campaign news. This instructs OWI employes to get "as close to the facts as the facts are known" in identifying candidates for the Presidential nominations.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Approaching the eleventh anniversary of entering the White House Mrs. Roosevelt is preparing for a Caribbean trip as on her first anniversary there.

LONDON, March 2 (U.P.) -- Sir James Grigg, War Secretary, warned Britons today not only that they could expect no big army demobilization after the defeat of the Germans because Japan remained to be whipped but that for years after the war Britain must maintain a big army in the interest of world peace.

The Matson Navigation Company has continued on an increased scale its preparation for participation in air transport over Matson's steamship routes and has recruited supervisory personnel for its air transport division from the air transport field, according to the annual report issued yesterday by William P. Roth, president.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, March 3 -- Heavy reinforcements have been landed on Los Negros Island, in the Admiralties, turning the surprise American thrust against the Japanese from reconnaissance in force into a campaign for complete occupation.

What shall we do with Germany at the end of the war? Doesn't she herself indicate the answer? When the German people believe, as their leaders tell them, that the penalty of defeat is destruction, isn't that the answer to the question?

ALGIERS, March 2 -- After a German attack by three divisions on a 1,000-yard front between Aprilia and Cisterna had gained 1,500 yards Tuesday, American troops on the beachhead below Rome, with the aid of a tremendous artillery barrage, not only stopped the Nazis but counter attacked and by noon yesterday had taken back 1,000 yards and were still driving ahead.

A proposed amendment to the city sanitary code, which would deny licenses to restaurants unless at least one member of the staff had completed a course in sanitary food handling, was outlined yesterday by Sol Pincus, assistant health commissioner, to a gathering at the Henry Hudson Hotel of 250 men who hold key positions in restaurants and hotels here.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- Director Elmer Davis of the Office of War Information today said the British United Press was the news agency that had sent abroad a story that a $50,000,000 fund was being raised in the United States to defeat President Roosevelt for re-election to a fourth term.
NEW DELHI, India, March 2 (AP) -- A communique:

PHILADELPHIA, March 2 (AP) -- Bobo Newsom dropped in on Connie Mack today but left without assurance where the rent money was coming from. In other words Bobo, traded to the Athletics by the Senators for Roger Wolff, didn't sign a contract.

HEANOR, Derbyshire, England, March 2 (AP) -- Nora Carpenter, 23-year-old mother of quadruplets, said tonight that she hoped to marry the American doughboy identified as the father of her babies and "would like to go to America with him."

LONDON, March 2 -- In another quiet session of the stock markets here today most sections held their ground or gained slightly. The industrials remained firm, Courtaulds showing a further improvement. In the stores group Woolworths gained a few pence and tobaccos went ahead.

The annual report of the International Silver Company, announced yesterday, shows a net profit of $1,020,245 for last year, compared with $818,416 in 1942. Net sales increased to $33,536,639 from $22,566,983 the year before.

LONDON, Friday, March 3 -- Fortresses and Liberators of the United States Strategic Air Forces, flying in considerable strength, blasted industrial targets in southwest Germany yesterday in the sixteenth major Allied blow at the Reich in thirteen days.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- A majority decision of the War Labor Board whose public and labor members held that change in a plant's ownership was not a bar to continuing a union shop agreement made by the previous owner, evoked a sharp dissent from the board's industry members.

In this week's election the only issue raised personally against the Republican candidate, Mr. Bennet, by the supporters of his Democratic rival was that Mr. Bennet was not a resident of the Twenty-first Congressional District itself nor even of the county. He lived in Mount Vernon.

MIAMI, Fla., March 2 -- Zacatine, always partial to Hialeah Park, now is 6 years old, but he survived a hustling race over his old stamping ground today when he took the Exodus Purse at $8.10 for $2. Ted Atkinson, leading jockey of the meeting, did his usual fine job with Zacatine, but had to accept second place so far as riding honors were concerned because Eddie Arcaro got a triple.

This is Town Meeting month in New England. The Town Meeting has flourished for more than three hundred years. If in the general tendency toward centralization it has lost something, it has not lost its old vigor or its usefulness as a direct democracy acting within its proper field.

Advocating that the United States should not only join but should take the lead in establishing a world organization, Dr. Henry M. Wriston, president of Brown University, expressed yesterday opposition to "any functional approach to peace" that tends "to defeat democratic control of foreign policy."

The reserve positions of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City and throughout the country generally were strengthened during the week ended on Wednesday, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

There is one wartime project whose workers can chalk up an outstanding record of success for the last year, with no charges of absenteeism, strikes, sabotage or excess profits to mar an enviable record of achievement -- the nation's backyard gardeners.

The United States Coast Guard is sending one of the top-ranking tennis players of the country to take part in the Red Cross matches at Madison Square Garden the night of March 14 to help the 1944 war fund drive of the Greater New York Committee.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 2 (AP) -- The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad company today reported that its previous figures covering operations for the year 1943 had been modified by the Interstate Commerce Commission to include retroactive wage awards and payroll taxes, granted recently, with the result that the net income was $22,901,437.

TRENTON, N.J., March 2 -- The manpower shortage caught up with Coach Frank J. Donlon of the Rider College basketball team today -- the day before the final game of the season -- and not even a delegation of special students from Iceland could save the situation.

LONDON, March 2 -- Reich Marshal Hermann Goering, in his most chastened public statement of the war, today held out to the once-supreme German Air Force on its ninth anniversary the bitter prospect of continuing sacrifices and new ordeals "in the hours of big decisions."

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, March 2 -- One of the main objects of battles is to wear down men, kill, maim, capture or tire out men. That necessitates continual rotation, bringing in replacements and taking out others for rest.

HOLLYWOOD, March 2 (U.P.) -- Jennifer Jones tonight won the prize as best movie actress of 1943 for her work in "Song of Bernadette." Paul Lukas, for his work in "Watch On the Rhine" was named best actor.

BUENOS AIRES, March 2 -- Another meeting of the Cabinet, under the chairmanship of General Farrell, took place at noon today and lasted two hours. The Subsecretariat for Information and Press afterward issued a communique saying that the Acting President has informed his Ministers that it was his intention to "maintain the course of international policy followed up to now, in conformity with Argentine interests, which are those of the Continent."

LINDEN, N.J., March 2 -- A forty-foot-high tank containing some 12,000 barrels of crude gasoline exploded soon after 8 o'clock tonight in the huge tank field of the Standard Oil Company here and at midnight the fuel was still burning fiercely, sending up a tongue of flame that was visible for miles around.

The largest and probably the most luxurious apartment known to realty men -- an imposing fifty-four-room suite at 1107 Fifth Avenue, corner of Ninety-second Street -- is available for rent, in case anyone is interested.

Commissioner William F. Carey of the Department of Sanitation expressed "sincere appreciation" yesterday of the public cooperation with the city's waste-paper collection campaign on the first of a series of Wednesdays, when all the forces at his command will be devoted to salvaging scrap paper and tin cans for the duration of the war.
