Difficulties in obtaining deliveries continue to impede retailers in building up peak stocks by the middle of this month for pre-Easter selling. Indications are, however, that shipments later this month will be heavy. Apparel volume this month will not suffer from the handicap of comparison with heavy scare buying a year ago, which was the major factor in the February showing.

LONDON, March 2 -- The British Government has ordered that all military supplies to Turkey under the Anglo-Turkish agreement shall be stopped, it was learned today. Official quarters in London decline to comment on this development, but it has been evident here for some weeks that Turkey could not expect to continue receiving supplies without fulfilling the terms of the Anglo-French-Turkish agreement, which obligated Turkey to render all aid in her power to Britain.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 2 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is negotiating a deal with Frank Sinatra for the crooner to be co-starred with Gene Kelly and Kathryn Grayson in Joseph Pasternak's production "Anchors Aweigh." Also set for the musical are Jose Iturbi and Keye Luke.

"The Curse of the Cat People," a melodrama produced by RKO, will open this morning at the Rialto. Simone Simon, Kent Smith, Jane Randolph, Julia Dean and the child actress Ann Carter head the cast of the thriller, which was directed by Gunther V. Fritsch and Robert Wise.

PHILADELPHIA, March 2 -- The Public Utilities Division of the Securities and Exchange Commission recommended today the approval of the joint plan of reorganization filed last November by the trustees of the Midland United Company and the Midland Utilities Company.

Acting upon instructions of the executive council of the American Federation of Labor, William Green, AFL president, addressed a circular yesterday to all affiliated unions of the federation, calling upon them to give no aid or cooperation to the Political Action Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, headed by Sidney Hillman.

In what is believed the first action of its kind by any trade group, the National Association of Tobacco Distributors yesterday went on record as favoring early amendment of the Emergency Price Control Act to empower the Office of Price Administration to establish "floor" as well as ceiling prices to meet possible deflation after the war.
LONDON, March 2 -- Germans in Poland are suffering from acute war jitters and such fear of the captive Polish populace that they are on the verge of panic, the Polish telegraph agency reported today.

Under existing law Lend-Lease expires on June 30, Yesterday Acting Secretary of State Stettinius appeared before the House Foreign Affairs Committee to urge its continuance for another year. Obviously this must and will be done. Lend-Lease is the kingpin of our whole war effort.
Another determined German attack on the Anzio-Nettuno beachhead seems to have been stemmed temporarily, judging from yesterday's late report.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- American lend-lease and British mutual-aid shipments to Turkey were understood tonight to have been suspended in a move apparently linked with vigorous military and diplomatic preparations for the Anglo-American invasion of Europe.

ALBANY, March 2 -- A comprehensive program of legislation designed to improve administration of the State Workmen's Compensation Law and eliminate kickbacks and other widespread abuses was recommended to Governor Dewey in a report submitted today by William F. Bleakley and Herman T. Stichman, Moreland Act Commissioners appointed to investigate the operation of the law.

ALBANY, March 2 -- Concentration in the hands of the Industrial Commissioner, who heads the Labor Department, of power heretofore vested in independent agencies within the department is planned in two separate moves under way here.

The "scientific" defense offered yesterday in the Bowery Court by one of three men charged with smoking cigarettes on Pier 20, North River, in violation of the war emergency restrictions resulted in his paying a $10 fine while each of his co-defendants got off with a $5 fine.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- Several canned vegetables, including tomatoes, peas and corn, will have lower point values beginning Sunday, but shoppers will have to give up more ration points in buying canned fruits.

With the return of cold weather and bright sunshine, skiers in the northeastern snow belt are looking forward to a continuation of spring skiing this week-end. Coming on the heels of mild temperatures and rain in many places, the frigid spell has given a crusted surface to open slopes, but the mountain trails are deep in powder snow.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Eight of the ten Senate and House conferees on the conflicting measures, providing for servicemen's voting, agreed today to "a States' rights" program. Then Senator Theodore F. Green, co-author of the original legislation, turned his back and expressed the hope that President Roosevelt would veto it.

LONDON, March 2 -- British submarines operating in the Far East have delivered a series of smashing attacks against the Japanese fleet and lines of communications, in Malacca Strait, sinking one aircraft carrier, damaging and possibly destroying one cruiser and sending two supply ships to the bottom, the Admiralty announced today.

ALGIERS, March 2 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle appeared before the Consultative Assembly today as peacemaker between the Assembly and the French Committee of National Liberation as a result of the miniature parliamentary revolt Tuesday and the critical, though more restrained, debate this morning.

WILKES-BARRE, March 2 -- If peace is to be maintained in the future, "one-sided changes in treaties" cannot be tolerated, Viscount Halifax, Ambassador to Washington, told an audience at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church House today.

LONDON, March 2 -- The British Government is not supporting and has no intention of supporting any party in American politics, and stories purporting to show that British officials are interfering in the forthcoming United States Presidential election are "ludicrous nonsense," Brendan Bracken, Minister of Information, told American correspondents today.

LONDON, March 2 -- Twenty air raid shelters in subways that have been opened only on the sounding of an alert are now available for regular tenants wishing to sleep there, the Ministry of Home Security announced today.

An hour and ten minutes before the time fixed for his death in the electric chair in Sing Sing prison, Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, once the master of organized crime in this city and overlord of the Brooklyn murder ring that killed more than eighty men, received a two-day stay late last night through the intervention of Governor Dewey.

NEW DELHI, India, March 2 (U.P.) -- Outflanking the main Japanese defenses in western Burma, West African troops have pushed down the Kaladan Valley to within forty miles of Akyab, it was announced today. A Southeast Asia Command communique said the West Africans were closing in on the Kaladan River town of Apaukwa, thirty-eight miles north of Akyab, in the face of increased enemy resistance.

Merely to say American Labor party doesn't settle anything. Just which American Labor party do you mean, Manhattan Labor party on the one hand, or Bronx and New York State Labor party on the other? It makes all the difference in the world -- the difference between Right Wing and Left Wing, compared with which the gulf between Kipling's East and West is just a narrow ditch.

Rescued from the sunny south-lands by the Office of Defense Transportation, 500 men, women and children arrived at Pennsylvania Station last night after a "miserable" thirty-four-hour trip in straight-backed coach seats. For the most part they were "glad to be back" in the North.
Wollmar Bostrom, the Swedish Minister, and Mme. Bostrom are visiting Baron and Baroness Carl G. von Seidlitz at the Ritz-Carlton.
LONDON, March 2 (UP) -- An Admiralty communique:

Shipbuilding in 1943 continued to hold first rank as a wartime consumer of steel, as in 1942, according to a preliminary report by the American Iron and Steel Institute placing at 11,433,000 tons the finished and semi-finished steel products shipped to the yards of naval and merchant vessel shipbuilders, or 19.1 per cent of total steel shipments of 59,760,000 tons.

The preliminary report of the Engineers Public Service Company for 1943, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, of $5,595,123. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.75 a share on the corporation's outstanding common stock, and compares with a net of $4,062,908, or 95 cents a common share, in 1942.

LONDON, March 2 (U.P.) -- A Yugoslav partisan communique announced today the defeat of powerful German armored forces in Croatia and Slovenia as Berlin broadcasts disclosed that Adolf Hitler had conferred with puppet Croat leaders at his headquarters yesterday.
LONDON, March 2 (UP) -- A German communique as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

The first step toward establishing in undisputed world lightweight champion will be taken tonight at Madison Square Garden. Beau Jack, Augusta's ex-caddy, who is recognized here as the title-holder, is to battle Bob Montgomery, Philadelphian who once held the title, in a battle scheduled for fifteen rounds.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Friday, March 3 (AP) -- The Finish newspaper Suomen Socialidemokraatti, mouthpiece of the Social Democratic party which is the strongest in Finland's Parliament, indicated today that the Finnish Government intends to make every effort to negotiate an armistice with Russia.

Alex Rose, right wing leader of the American Labor party, solicited and accepted support and aid from many persons and groups he has since denounced as Communist dominated, Louis Hollander, president of the New York State Congress of Industrial Organizations, charged last night.

PHILADELPHIA, March 2 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the sale of American Utilities Associates and the Lowell (Mass.) Gas Light Company by the American Gas and Power Company to the Alpha Association for $900,000.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Ten of fourteen railroads, cited by the Fair Employment Practices Committee for racial discrimination, have no intention of complying with mandatory orders to hire Negroes as firemen, train conductors and yard foremen, according to Sidney Alderman, their attorney.

Intent on "making enough of a rumpus" to insure placement of qualified women on policy committees of international post-war groups, both private and governmental, seventy-four women met yesterday afternoon at the home of Mrs. Albert D. Lasker, 29 Beeknan Place.

The annual report of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation for 1943 shows total assets of $1,044,869,730 at the year-end, comparing with $1,005,646,523 on Dec. 31, 1942, adjusted to reflect renegotiation of contracts. Plant, after $453,497,013 depreciation reserves, was valued at $431,381,432, comparing with $442,114,833 after reserves of $413,165,768 at the close of 1942.

CHICAGO, March 2 (AP) -- Ken Heinemann, who went from Texas mines to the Brooklyn football Dodgers last year as a passer, wound up the 1943 season in sixteenth place as a ball thrower but was first in handling kick-offs.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Chester Bowles, Price Administrator, disclosed today that he was seeking extension of the Emergency Price Control Act, which expires June 30 unless action is taken by Congress. He told reporters he had already talked With Senator Wagner and Representative Spence, chairmen of Congress' Banking and Currency Committees, about further price control legislation.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, March 2 - Fifty-five oil companies, members of the Petroleum Industry War Council, objected today to the Government's proposed Arabian oil project as a post-war and not a war enterprise, and said that it would involve the United States in international conflicts without Congressional authority and prove the thin end of the wedge of Government ownership.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Hinting that the coal mining industry might soon face disaster due to the loss of manpower, Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, declared today that employment in the mines has dropped to minimum levels below which the present war-production program would be hampered.

Off to an auspicious start, the Red Cross 1944 War Fund appeal in Greater New York was met with contributions of $1,000,000 during its first two days, John P. Stevens Jr., general chairman of the city drive, announced yesterday.

A plan to pay defaulted and current interest on the defaulted external bonded debt of the Republic of El Salvador, was announced yesterday by Dr. Hector David Castro, Ambassador of El Salvador to the United States, through the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., 90 Broad Street.

Hearings on departmental requests for 1944-45 were closed yesterday by Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson. The requests, totalling $762,000,000, will be analyzed and studied by Mr. Patterson and his staff and will then be considered by Mayor La Guardia in drafting his executive budget.

Terminating brief careers tomorrow evening are "Mrs. Kimball Presents," a farce about show business, and "Right Next to Broadway," a comedy dealing with New York's garment industry. Both were put on by newcomers to Broadway. Sponsored by Ted Gerken and Joe Chandler, "Mrs. Kimball Presents" will have occupied the Forty-eighth Street for seven performances, with Vicki Cummings and Arthur Margetson in the featured roles.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- A high ranking American diplomatic Official, possibly supported by two or three technical aides, will go to London in the course of the next few weeks to conduct conversations with the British on other than military operations, according. to reports here today.

A butcher who informed the Office of Price Administration yesterday that he had been "bewildered and befuddled" when he signed a consent suspension order last month, admitting irregularities in his ration banking account, was given another chance to explain his accounts.

LONDON, March 2 (AP) -- A single unidentified plane, flying at a 600-yard altitude, dropped four bombs on extraterritorial ground of the Vatican in Rome last night and two others near the Holy City itself, killing a workman and injuring a priest, the Vatican radio said today.
WASHINGTON, March 2(AP) -- The Army is contemplating "broad expansion" of its specialized training reserve program for men in the pre-induction, 17-year-old group.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Differences of opinion that have arisen between Admiral the Lord Louis Mountbatten, who commands for the United Nations in the southwest Asia theatre of war, and Lieut. Gen. Joseph Stilwell, who commands the United States Army forces under Admiral Mountbatten in Burma and under Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in China, are being ironed out here by Maj. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, United States Army, Admiral Mountbatten's Deputy Chief of Staff.

MOSCOW, Friday, March 3 -- Soviet troops continued their offensive battles for the capture of Narva and Pskov yesterday and drove within twenty-four miles of the Latvian border northwest of Novorzhev.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The body of Miss Catherine Cooper Reardon, assistant librarian of the Washington Episcopal Cathedral, was found early today in a basement pit of the library, and tonight, police said, Julius Fisher, 33, Negro groundkeeper and handyman at the cathedral, confessed that he killed the woman.

LONDON, March 2 -- A high official of the United States Government will come to London this month for a series of political and economic conversations with British and other Allied officials, it was learned tonight. Reuter's diplomatic editor said it was being widely surmised that Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Under-Secretary of State, might be the official.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (U.P.) -- Pope Pius' program to bring relief to war-stricken Poles at home and abroad is progressing satisfactorily in virtually all countries except Germany, where the lot of Polish internees is "deplorable," a Vatican report to the National Catholic Welfare Conference stated tonight.

The four seeded teams in a field of eleven which began play in the Eastern States contract bridge team-of-four tournament for the Curt H. Reisinger Cup Monday night entered the semi-final round last night at the Park Central Hotel. They had survived two qualifying rounds and won their quarter-final matches Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- With the Allied forces fighting to push their way nearer toward Rome, Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of War, announced today that everything possible would be done to spare religious and historic buildings and monuments in the vicinity of the Eternal City, but never at the cost of American lives.

Harcourt, Brace announces that a contract has been signed with Horace R. Cayton, director of the Parkway Community House in Chicago, and St. Clair Drake, for a study of Negro life on Chicago's South Side. The book, which represents several years' work and research, is tentatively titled "Black Metropolis" and is scheduled for publication this Autumn.

Charging that the Wicks-Steingut bill to amend the criminal libel law by penalizing malicious publication or radio broadcasting of statements exposing a person or group identified by race, color or religion to hatred or contempt constitute "a quack remedy which will cause more evil than it cures," the New York City committee of the American Civil Liberties Union sent letters yesterday to members of the Legislature asking defeat of the bill.

Two 16-year-old Staten Island high school boys are believed by the police to have been drowned while duck hunting in Raritan Bay early on Wednesday evening. A fourteen-foot flatbottom rowboat in which the boys, William Wilson Jr. and Walter Miggins Jr., both of Tottenville, sixth-term students at the Tottenville High School, were last seen shooting ducks, was found shortly before 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon about a mile north of Keyport, N.J.

An uncommonly brilliant evening for the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra and Dr. Rodzinski, who had arranged an unusual program for the concert given last night in Carnegie Hall! Not often in the list of the works to be heard at a single concert is there such illustration of the richness and variety of expression of orchestral music, and seldom have orchestra and conductor been more eloquent in its projection.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Feb. 26 were 782,463 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 6,771 cars or 0.9 per cent more than for the preceding week, 458 cars or 0.1 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 604 cars or 0.1 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

CHUNGKING, China, March 1 (Delayed) -- Ta Kung Pao, Chungking's leading independent newspaper, today demanded that the Japanese be compelled to pay for losses in life and property. An editorial stated that while the United Nations have reiterated their determination to show no leniency in punishing war guilt, "they have not yet made themselves clear on the question whether compensation for war damages should be demanded from the aggressors."

ALBANY, March 2 -- Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein has requested former Judge Edward R. Finch, Republican of New York City, to investigate charges that an Albany Negro was beaten and dangled from a twenty-ninth story window of the State Office Building by State Troopers employed in the investigation of Albany County.

With receipts at a cool $4.87 and audience reaction at a record high, the "Avenue B Playhouse" let down the curtain yesterday afternoon on another success. Playwright Betty McCann, 10 years old, had a hit on her hands and a tidy sum to turn over to the Red Cross War Fund.

R.H. Burnside's troupe, which has settled down at the Ambassador Theatre, added "Ruddigore" to its repertory last night. To many students of the Gilbert and Sullivan craft "Ruddigore" is the drollest of the operettas, but as it was introduced last night this reviewer found it listless and lacking in spontaneity.

A greater measure of confidence was displayed yesterday in trading on the stock market, but trends proved to be similar to those in the preceding session, with most emphasis on specialties. While the general list only showed fractional gains, a few stocks added a point and more.

NEW DELHI, India, March 2 -- Maj. Gen. J.S. Lethbridge, head of a special British mission, told a press conference today that one of the outstanding conclusions of a tour of the Southwest Pacific front was that British weapons were better than American.

Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. disclosed last night that the Fourth War Loan Drive had been oversubscribed by $2,730,000,000, with bond purchases of all categories totaling $16,730,000,000.

The net income of 730 leading industrial corporations for 1943, after taxes and reserves, amounted to $1,137,000,000, an increase of 2 per cent over the preceding year, the National City Bank reported yesterday in the March issue of its bank letter.

The War Department is planning to use the "sixty-day yardstick," recommended by the Baruch-Hancock report, as the time in which Government property will be removed from plants of war contractors Lieut. Col. Charles Lee Austin, chief of the redistribution and salvage branch of the Army Service Forces, disclosed yesterday.

Berries should be of particular interest to Victory gardeners because most plants of this type are suited to the small garden, Edwin Beckett, superintendent of a Red Bank estate, said last night at the New York Times Hall in the last of a series of meetings on Victory gardens conducted during the last several weeks by THE NEW YORK TIMES and the New York Botanical Garden.

Announcement of a seventeen-day beaver-trapping season in twenty-one New York State counties starting March 15 led to some investigation of this animal in the Empire State and the disclosure that about forty years ago the beaver was all but extinct here.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Passage of a national war service act is necessary to prevent a slump in war production when Germany is defeated and Japan still has to be conquered, Secretary Knox told the Senate Military Affairs Committee today.
LONDON, March 2 (UP) -- A UnitedI States tratgio Ar Forces % Eu-I , vop co;w%ziqze:
LONDON, March 2 (AP) -- Note circulation for the week ended yesterday, as reported today in the Bank of England's weekly condition statement, increased 8,868,000.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- One-third of the navy with which Japan started the war has been destroyed, and the American Fleet now can cruise the Pacific looking for trouble and battering any enemy forces encountered, a high Navy official said today.

Members of the District 13 committee of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., have come out in support of the Wicks-Archinal bill, now before the New York Legislature, which would cut the State transfer tax on stocks selling below $10 a share.

E.P. Reed Company, Rochester, makers of Matrix shoes, will start its spring advertising campaign this month. Schedule includes 460 line inserts in New York City newspapers, which will be followed by advertising over the signatures of exclusive dealers in seventy-five leading cities.

"I always like to push my sleeves up and then lift the tops into little wings; it gives me a sense of freedom." So spoke Fira Benenson suiting the gesture to the words a few days ago in her studio. The remark was in explanation of the new arched shoulder line that constitutes the big news of her collection, shown yesterday afternoon in the Salon de Couture, at Bonwit Teller's.

Ormsby McHarg, former Assistant Secretary of Commerce and Labor, has withdrawn from the National Committee to Draft Governor John W. Bricker of Ohio or General Douglas MacArthur for President, and has become chairman of the MacArthur National Associates with Edmund D. Horwath, a public accountant of 420 Lexington Avenue, as secretary-treasurer.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Spurred by "numerous complaints" from retailers, the Office of Price Administration notified manufacturers of furniture and other consumer durable goods today that they are forbidden to increase prices of their articles to the public by using new jobbers whose sales price might be higher than the original producers' price ceilings.

BUENOS AIRES, March 2 (AP) -- Gen. Edelmiro Farrell, Acting President of Argentina, declared today that Argentine foreign policy would not be modified and that close cooperation with the other American republics was an aim of his temporary regime.

NAPLES, March 2 (U.P.) -- Three left-wing Italian political parties -Communist, Socialist and Action -virtually defied tonight Allied officials who have forbidden them to stage a ten-minute "strike" Saturday morning in protest against Prime Minister Winston Churchill's recent declaration supporting the monarchial regime of Premier Pietro Badoglio.
Wayne Lonergan's trial for the murder of his wife, Patricia Burton Lonergan, went through a brief but explosive session in General Sessions Court yesterday.

Police were seeking last night the parents of 6-week-old Virginia Mulligan, who is in serious condition at Bellevue Hospital, to obtain their consent for an operation believed vital to the child's survival.
Where, in peace times, there generally were many hold-over champions on hand to defend titles they'd won the year before, this year finds the intercollegiates coming up with only two.

Post-war employment problems arising from what he termed the present lack of planning and lack of insurance against such probabilities may result in as many as twelve to fifteen million persons being jobless, Leon Henderson, former Director of the Office of Price Administration, declared yesterday.

DETROIT, March 2 -- The lowly Rangers twice came from behind tonight in a desperate bid to gain their first National Hockey League victory in six weeks, but the Red Wings finally won, 6 to 5, before 6,757 spectators. Adam Brown of Detroit shot three goals for the hat trick.

ALGIERS, March 2 (AP) -- A steady rain Tuesday during the opening day of the third major German attack on the beachhead below Rome aided the defenders, as it soon turned the ground into a quagmire and confined the heavy German tanks to the highways.

Modern science has reduced distance and time to a minimum and present methods of communication have brought the war to within an hour or two of our neighborhood, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, said yesterday at commencement exercises of Columbia College.

Manufacturers and distributors of men's straw hats believe that consumer demands this year will exceed those of 1943, when sizable inventories were appreciably reduced during the early part of the season. Smaller inventories generally will be the rule this year, it is said, while average prices will run above last year's levels.

LONDON, March 3 (AP) -- Major Walter C. Beckham, leading American fighter ace in the European theater of operations, was officially listed tonight as missing in action, the victim of a single burst from a German anti-aircraft gunner.

Operation of a racket based on the special philatelic appeal of stamps that are peculiar in some way was attributed yesterday to six stamp dealers. The charges were contained in seven indictments handed up by a Federal grand jury which had heard evidence presented by Clayton D. Hollinger, assistant United States attorney.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, March 4 -- On Los Negros, where reinforcements were put ashore Thursday to switch the operation from an original reconnaissance in force to full-fledged invasion, contact with the enemy is constant, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- President Roosevelt disclosed today that the Italian Fleet would be distributed equally among the United States, Britain and Russia for purposes of prosecuting the war.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Five major generals were nominated today by President Roosevelt to be lieutenant generals, among them Gen. Holland M. Smith, who commanded the marines and other ground forces in the Gilbert Islands invasion. The others were Courtney H. Hodges, Richard K. Sutherland, Raymond A. Wheeler and John C.H. Lee.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- President Roosevelt told his news conference today that the crux of the service men's voting issue now was whether more members of the armed forces would have an opportunity to cast ballots under the "States' Rights" compromise approved by Senate and House conferees yesterday or under the 1942 law which the Congress set out months ago to expand.

I share Father Sturzo's hopes that the "true and full story" of Italy will soon be told. In the article he quotes I specifically stated that "our preliminary calculations greatly overestimated the strength and scope of Italian resistance to the Germans. At one time prior to invasion some of our planners apparently thought we might hope to use chiefly Italian troops in the fighting in Italy, stiffened with British and Americans."

Retail trade here was active this week, but volume again fell under the comparative week of last year. Estimates put department store sales at about 5 per cent under 1943, with a larger decrease noted for specialty shops. Comparison with the period of scare buying of apparel last year continued a factor but this will diminish as the current month grows older.

ALGIERS, March 3 -- The Allied forces on the beachhead below Rome, paced by the American Third Infantry Division and with particularly effective artillery support, have won a complete defensive victory in rolling the third major German drive back to where it started.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 3 -- The internecine strife that has divided Greece and elicited pleas from Allied statesmen to the factions to compose their differences because they were hindering the United Nations' war effort has now ended. One of the saddest chapters of any nation's history is therefore presumably closed.

Mrs. Edna Hancock, a former employe of Brooklyn State Hospital, was acquitted late yesterday afternoon by a jury in Judge Peter J. Brancato's part of the Kings County Court on a charge of first-degree perjury. The jury of eleven men and one woman deliberated one hour and fifty minutes.

Total advertising linage in eight New York newspapers during February showed an increase of 0.96 per cent over that in the corresponding month last year, according to Media Records. Largest percentage gain in any classification was recorded in retail advertising, with an advance of 5 per cent.

There has been a sharp decline since last year in the number of daily newspapers which sell for 3 cents a copy and an increase in the number of 4-cent papers, the American Newspaper Publishers Association reported yesterday on the basis of a nationwide survey.

LONDON, March 3 -- A new British bomb, weighing six tons and declared to exceed in destructive power any missile hitherto employed by man, is now being used against specific enemy targets, it was revealed by the British Air Ministry today.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Frederick W. Nichol, vice president of the International Business Machines Corporation, was appointed today special adviser on administration to Secretary Hull. He will serve on a part-time basis as a general consultant in all matters of administrative procedure.

A syndicate represented by Maurice Epstein has purchased the five-story apartment building containing small suites at 22 East Sixty-seventh Street, near Madison Avenue, from the Guaranty Trust Company. Julius B. Friedman was the broker in the sale of the house, which formerly was owned by William Randolph Hearst and was the home of the Cutting family.
LONDON, March 3 -- Britain's Ministry of Supply, determined to save every scrap of raw material in these islands, has gone into the "old clothes business."
America's hotels, feeling the pinch of wartime shortages, are in immediate need of $110,000,000 worth of housekeeping equipment -- sheets, pillow cases, silverware and such.

MEXICO CITY, March 3 (AP) -- Rogers Hornsby, newly appointed manager of the Veracruz club of the Mexican Baseball League, tonight denied criticism by Leo T. Miller, general manager of the Syracuse (N.Y.) team of the International League, that he is luring players away from organized baseball.

WALTER NEWMAN of Dartmouth will do his sprinting for Cornell at the Inter-collegiate A.A.A.A. track and field championships at Madison Square Garden tonight, while Manhattan and St. John's, both of whom have abandoned track for the duration, will be represented in the meet. It's too late in the war to look for logic in any sports happening, but these items are slightly different from anything which has transpired before and therefore deserving of special notice.

LONDON, March 3 -- After MacDonald, smallest of the quadruplets born to Nora Carpenter, died in a hospital last night, Staff Sgt. William Thompson Jr., 26 years of age of 4547 Friendship Avenue, Pittsburgh, said in a London interview today that he was the father of the children born last Sunday in Heanor, Derbyshire.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 3 -- Mrs. Gabriel Baumwart, 49 years old, of 32 South Wellington Road, Garden City, spent last night in the Nassau County Jail rather than pay a $2 fine for overtime parking, a preference she made with the decided encouragment of her husband, who counseled that a matter of principle was involved.

LONDON, March 3 -- Bulgaria is seeking a way out of the war. Reliable diplomatic quarters agree that there is no doubt about that. But there is nothing new about it either and the advice of responsible people here is that this latest flood of rumors should be treated with reserve.

The life of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, whose name has been synonymous with the strong arm, labor racketeering, extortion and murder for hire in the city's devious underworld structure for the last two decades, hung today on the slender thread of a last-minute legal maneuver placed before the United States Supreme Court for decision.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Broadening of the Reserve feature of the Army Specialized Training Program by accepting qualified students under draft age to replace some of the 110,000 students ordered to the colors from ASTP college units was announced by the War Department today.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The project for a Saudi Arabian oil pipeline, which Secretary Ickes is urging and which is under attack by the oil industry, received indirect support today from President Roosevelt when he said at his news conference that he was thinking of the country's oil resources for not only the next five years but also for the next fifty.

Inasmuch as most of the beef now available is medium to poor in quality, it must be treated in one of two "tenderizing" ways -- grinding or cooking with moist heat -- both of which soften the connective tissue causing the toughness. If these methods are applied correctly and the meat is cooked with skill, the final product will taste as good -- well, almost -- as a choice roast or steak.

Operations last year of the Corn Products Refining Company and its domestic subsidiary sales companies resulted in a net profit for the year ended with December of $8,700,687, equal to $2.76 a share of common stock, the annual report to stockholders announced yesterday.
A communique broadcast by the Moscow radio and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

LONDON, March 3 -- President Roosevelt's announcement that the Italian fleet would be divided among the United States, Britain and Russia came as a surprise to the British, who fear that the announcement at this time may have "awkward repercussions." .

The first requisite of the new "long torso" fashions for spring is a smooth foundation garment. And in spite of wartime shortages, the foundations arriving in the stores now will give the same sleek lines that women had come to expect in the years before the war.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 3 -Strikes and lockouts affecting 6,000,000 Italian workers brought industrial production in northern Italy to a complete standstill today as German labor controllers began one of the boldest sweeps for conscripting "voluntary" workers for the Reich.

CHICAGO, March 3 (U.P.) -- A self-appointed group form gangland attempted today to reverse a jury verdict of innocent and obtain retribution against John Joseph Williams, southside gambling leader, by riddling him with bullets.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Spain, Portugal, Belgium, Sweden and Switzerland are likely to be in a good trading position soon after the war ends, but the position of France and Soviet Russia is more uncertain, according to an article by Louis Domeratzky, chief of the European unit of the Commerce Department, in the next issue of Foreign Commerce Weekly.

ALGIERS, March 3 -- Four former guards at the Vichy regime's concentration camp at Hajerat 'Guil were sentenced to be shot by a military tribunal today after a sixteen-day trial, which was the first judicial action growing out of brutality in Nazi-type political prison camps.

MIAMI, Fla., March 3 -- Thirteen, including Sun Again, Marriage and Bolingbroke, are named for the $25,000 added Widener Handicap, climactic race on the final day of the Hialeah Park meeting tomorrow. The size of the field surprised officials, who thought fewer than ten would run for the richest purse of the fifty-day session.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 3 -Asserting that the idea of "a cooling off period" before the writing of peace terms was "the most fanastic suggestion" ever made, Clark M. Eichelberger, executive chairman of the United Nations Association, advocated today the immediate formation of a world organization to draft peacetime policies.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 3 (AP) -- George Macdonald announced today the sale of four of Palm Beach's most valuable resort properties -- the Palm Beach Biltmore and Whitehall Hotels, Sun and Surf Club and Palm Beach Country Club -- in an all-cash real estate transaction.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Saturday, March 4 -- The Finnish Government has won the Finnish Parliament over to its position of declining the Russian armistice demands for internment of German troops now in Finland and restoration of the 1940 boun dary, the Stockholm paper Dagens Nyheter said today.

NAPLES, March 3 (AP) -- The forbidden ten-minute Italian strike in protest against Prime Minister Churchill's recent endorsement of Premier Badoglio's government has been called off, the Allied Control Commission announced tonight.

Benjamin Yelin, a partner in the former brokerage firm of T.J. Beauchamp Co., was expelled yesterday from the New York Stock Exchange on charges that he had defrauded his partners by putting profitable deals into an account in which he had an interest and unprofitable transactions into partnership accounts.

LONDON, Saturday, March 4 -- American warplanes made their first offensive flight to Berlin yesterday when a force of long-range P-38 Lightning fighters circled about the city for a quarter of an hour, had good luck and returned safely to their bases in England.
NEW DELHI, India, March 3 (AP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

Sufficient supplies of case goods to meet "any reasonable consumer demand" during 1944 have virtually been assured furniture dealers by the production increase in the last sixty days, a spokesman for the trade said yesterday. He pointed out that the greater majority of case goods factories have completed war contracts and are now devoting all their facilities to the manufacture of peacetime lines.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Eight war workers, one a woman and one a blind man, were honored at a War Production Board luncheon today for their efficient suggestions which help to speed the production of munitions and war materiel.
Mrs. Woodrow Wilson has arrived from Washington and is at the Plaza.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Today's Circuit Court of Appeals decision upholding the New York District Court in declaring Western Union messenger boys under the child labor provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act was pronounced "a great step forward in the protection of young workers which the law contemplates" by Miss Lenroot.

There must be no letdown in the cultivation of family garden plots in this country for the next few years -- the Victory gardens are playing too vital a part in the nation's war effort to permit a slack in this important source of food supply.
NEWARK, N.J., March 3 (AP) -- It was a sad day today for Two-Ton Tony Galento, the heavyweight fighter whose flailing fists once sent Champion Joe Louis to the canvas.
No comprehensive official report about the number of Italian naval or merchant vessels that succeeded last September and since then in coming over to the Allies has ever been published.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- Concluding testimony on applications of two competing natural-gas transmission systems to carry additional gas into northern Pennsylvania and western New York and contentions of coal and railroad interests that it is unnecessary were heard today by the Federal Power Commission.

The three-story building on a plot 134 by 100 feet at the northeast corner of Kent Avenue and South Eleventh Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by Merrill Brothers to an investing client of Baffa Dickson. Frank R. Fischer represented the seller.

An exhibition of American posters, from 1830 to 1880, opened this week at the Norlyst Gallery, where they will remain through March 15. This show is an attempt to present a cross section of native poster-making antedating the Eighteen Nineties.

The controversy that has arisen between Secretary Ickes and the oil companies places the Administration in a situation which it must clarify. Why is it necessary to lay a pipeline in Saudi Arabia at public expense? All authorities agree that, alarming though the inroads on our own reserves may be, the war can be won with the oil now available.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (U.P.) -- Julius Fisher, 31-year-old Negro handyman, was arraigned today on a charge of first degree murder after a coroner's jury found that he bludgeoned to death Catherine Cooper Reardon, 37, whose body was found stuffed into a narrow basement tunnel of the National Cathedral Library, where she was employed.

PEARL HARBOR, March 3 -- Army and Navy planes continued their attacks on the Japanese scattered defense bases on Wednesday and Thursday, planting more than thirty tons of bombs in the Kurile, Marshall and Caroline Islands, it was announced today.

President Roosevelt's almost casual statement at his press conference yesterday that it had been decided that about one-third of the Italian fleet or the equivalent would be turned over to the Russians has a great deal more political than military significance.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Lamps for heat, for health and many other uses than those of illumination were among the developing possibilities of radiant energy presented as a challenge to the scientist of the future in an address delivered at the opening session tonight of the third science talent institute by Dr. Samuel G. Hibben of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company.

The somewhat tedious process of collecting signed baseball contracts stepped up a bit for the Yankees yesterday when President Ed Barrow announced that Bud Metheny, outfielder, and Jim Turner, veteran relief hurler, had joined the fold.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Full participation by the United States Government in formulating and executing plans of the United Nations for the trial and punishment of the war guilty was called for in a resolution introduced in the Senate today by Senator Claude Pepper, Democrat, of Florida.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -The Army venereal disease rate reached a record low of twenty-seven cases per 1,000 men in 1943, according to preliminary figures, and the use of penicillin in extensive trials on gonorrhea cases resistant to the sulfa drugs effected cures in 96 per cent of them.

New bond financing here this week was given over entirely to tax-exempt securities, with five new bond issues aggregating $17,197,000 reaching the market, $9,300,000 representing two State flotations and $7,897,009, three city loans.

"The Yeomen of the Guard" will be given this afternoon at the Ambassador Theatre by the Gilbert and Sullivan Opera Company. The operetta is the repertory group's eighth offering. The cast includes Florenz Ames, Allen Stewart, Kathleen Roche, Robert Eckles, Robert Pitkin, Bertram Peacock and Catherine Judah. R.H. Burnside has attended to the staging.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 3 -- If the John Does and Mary Smiths of the country could attend a White House press conference and had the privilege of putting any question they wished to President Roosevelt, on subjects apart from the war the most frequently asked
CHICAGO, March 3 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows.

LONDON, Saturday, March 4 (U.P.) -- Soviet troops pounded to within five miles east of Pskov yesterday by capturing the town of Maloye Fomkino, while other Red Army columns swung below the ancient Baltic gateway city in a flanking drive that carried to within five miles of the Pskov-Warsaw railroad, vital rail route for the half-encircled German garrison.

The Women's National Book Association will hold its annual dinner on March 28 at the Hotel Pennsylvania, at which time the winner of the Constance Lindsay Skinner Award will be announced. Helen S. Lowitt is president of the club, and Sterling North will be the toastmaster at the dinner

Dominated by activity in low-priced public utility issues, the stock market drifted narrowly yesterday and closed mixed. Large-scale trading in the utility section came in response to indications that several integration programs would soon win approval of the Securities and Exchange Commission and thus permit shareholders to appraise correctly the worth of their holdings.

TRENTON, N.J., March 3 (AP) -Reductions in rates would be made more speedily for customers of the New Jersey Power and Light Company and lengthy hearings to determine the company's earnings would be eliminated under a rate adjustment plan proposed today by the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners.

CHICAGO, March 3 -- Scattered buying imparted a firm tone to wheat in the early trading today on the Board of Trade, but there was no evidence of buying by millers and the market settled back quickly on selling which was regarded as liquidation by professional traders who were buyers late yesterday.
A single gift of $300,000, the largest of the three-day-old campaign, was received by the Red Cross 1944 War Fund of Greater New York yesterday from the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation.

Election returns from three-quarters of the twenty-nine locals of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union representing 100,000 members show that not a single Communist or party follower has been elected to any local office as business agent, executive board member or convention delegate, David Dubinsgy, ILGWU president, announced yesterday.

With the time for filing declinations of nominations for party positions expiring last night, efforts of aides of President Roosevelt to effect a compromise in the contest for control of the American Labor party definitely failed.

Mayor La Guardia's fiscal policies, including his $1,300,000,000 post-war public works program, were denounced yesterday by former Corporation Counsel Paul Windels, who declared that the city, by means of excessive real estate valuations, was engaging in "the shabby practice of illegal extortion from people who can't help themselves."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 3 (AP) -- The Associated Press made two errors of fact in reporting a decision of Federal Judge Mell G. Underwood, Feb. 9, ruling that military courts hold jurisdiction over civilian personnel working on vessels operated in Army supply lines.

Sent to an apartment at 81 Morningside Drive to pick up a divan for repair, Louis Baruch, 60 years old, of 280 Christopher Street, and Milton Zahner, 30, of 1441 East New York Avenue, Brooklyn, stripped the apartment of furniture and furnishinngs and sold most of the goods to secondhand dealers, it was charged yesterday in Felony Court.

LISBON, Portugal, March 3 -- Sailing of the repatriation ship Gripsholm with American diplomats from Vichy and civilians from French and German concentration camps has been delayed. Originally set for last Thursday the departure will probably not take place before Sunday or Monday.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals unanimously upheld yesterday a ruling by Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind holding the Western Union Telegraph Company subject to the child labor provisions of the Federal Fair Labor Standards Act.

An investor has bought from Thorn Estates, Inc, the five-story apartment house at 433-38 Central Park West, occupying the block-front from 103d to 104th Streets, for cash over a mortgage of $177,300. Title was insured with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
As chairman of one of the 280 Selective Service local boards in Greater New York I desire to express my very deep appreciation for the editorial in today's NEW YORK TIMES, "The Draft Boards."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 3 -- Paramount plans a remake of the old Owen Wister novel and play, "The Virginian." Albert and Frances Hackett are writing a modernized screen play version for production by Paul Jones. The company filmed the story twice before -- as a silent picture in 1914, and in 1929 with Gary Cooper and Walter Huston in the leads.

Former Gov. Alfred E. Smith has again accepted the chairmanship of the special gifts committee of the Archbishop's Committee of the Laity for New York Catholic Charities, it was announced yesterday by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman, chairman of the agency's twenty-fifth annual appeal.
LONDON, March 3 (UP) -- A communique of the United States Strategic Air Force in Europe:

Under the sponsorship of the Committee on Evangelism of the Greater New York Federation of Churches, the pastors of two Fifth Avenue churches will give a series of six religious Lenten lectures in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria at noon each Wednesday, beginning next week and continuing through April 12.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 3 -- Finland's Foreign Minister, Dr. Henrik Ramsay, is now busy drafting, or has drafted, counter-proposals to the Soviet Russian terms as given by Mme. Alexandra M. Kollontay, Soviet Ambassador, to Dr. Juho K. Paasikivi during the former Finnish Premier's recent visit to Stockholm, it was stated here today.

Eighteen paintings have been presented to the Sarah Delano Roosevelt Memorial House, center of cultural, social and inter-faith activities for Hunter College, by friends, alumnae and faculty of the school, it was announced yesterday.

The Chilean Government announced last night that it would continue to recognize the Argentine Government of the Acting President, Gen. Edelmiro Farrell, inasmuch as it believes that President Pedro Ramirez has delegated his powers to General Farrell, Radio Agricultura at Santiago said in a domestic broadcast.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- move was under way today within the Senate Judiciary Committee to block President Roosevelt's appointment as Assistant Attorney General of Herbert T. Wechsler of New York, credited in some quarters with having had a hand in the drafting of the Administration's original Federal war ballot bill.

Nervousness over war -- developments including reports that Bulgaria was seeking armistice terms and that Rumania likely would join in the request, resulted yesterday in steady liquidation in the cotton futures market. At the close of trading active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 14 to 21 points, or 70 cents to $1.05 a bale, net lower.

LONDON, March 3 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav Partisan units striking along the important railway line between Zagreb and Karlovac have captured Horvati station and wiped out the enemy garrison there, a People's Army of Liberation communique announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The new exploits of American naval bombers against Paramushiru, the eastern Marshalls and Ponape constitute a renewed demonstration that our forces control the Pacific, Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, said today.

JERUSALEM, March 3 -- Palestinian Arab politics at this time present a somewhat confused appearance. Most of their powerful pre-war leaders are exiled and it is difficult therefore for the Arabs here to choose an effectively representative political body to take part in the Arab union talks which Premier Mustafa Nahas Pasha called in Cairo, Egypt.
LONDON, Saturday, March 4 (AP) -- The Russian Friday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

PHILADELPHIA, March 3 -William H. Hickey, president of the United Corporation, said today that none of his remarks before the stockholders of the company at their annual meeting in Wilmington, Del., on Wednesday was intended to imply that the Securities and Exchange Commission would approve the proposed preference stock exchange plan of the holding company.

Looking thoroughly fit despite a hirty-four-hour ride in a day coach from Miami, Francisco (Pancho) Segura, Ecuador's famous exponent of the two-handed drive, arrived in New York yesterday to begin preparations for the Red Cross tennis matches to be held at Madison Square Garden the night of March 14.

NEW DELHI, India, March 3 (AP) -- United Nations forces continued to make progress at widely separated points in Burma yesterday, and several bodies of Japanese troops were surrounded and undergoing annihilation, the Southeast Asia Command communique said today.

The Foreign Economic Administration's five-day old $5,000,000 distress buying program has received very little support from retailers, Herbert J. Kahnheim, program chief, disclosed yesterday. While over 250,000 garments have been purchased since Monday, Mr. Kahnheim stated major offerings have been made by wholesalers and manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (U.P.) -Benzedrene, the "pep" drug once used by college students for late-night cramming and by would-be draft dodgers to induce high blood pressure, is helping fliers to overcome fatigue under grueling conditions.

At present there are thousands of flight instructors throughout the nation who are engaged in flight instruction in Army and Navy schools These men have hundreds of hours of flying time accumulated over several years of flying under many varied conditions.

I recently heard someone tell about the Eskimos who inhabit Alaska and that portion of Siberia directly across Bering Strait It seems that when asked what, in their opinion, was the worst evil they unanimously replied "Gossip."

Two new films will arrive in midtown theatres today. At the Central the new attraction is "The Woman of the Town," a Western drama produced by Harry Sherman for United Artists release. Claire Trevor and Albert Dekker are starred, with Barry Sullivan, Henry Hull and Porter Hall among the supporting players.
The four-story apartment house at 209 Winfield Avenue, Jersey City, has been sold by the Winfield Corporation to Frederick Voessler, for investment. J.I. Kislak, Inc., was broker.

Michael Nadel, president of the Metropolitan Rod and Gun Club, says, that he has requested the State Conservation Department to consider the advisability of granting holders of hunting and fishing licenses a period of grace between the time old licenses expire and new ones become available.

The Riverhead Savings Bank of Riverhead, L.I., reports the sale of eight residential properties, one in Brooklyn and the others in suburban sections of Long Island. The transaction in Brooklyn involved the buildings at 398-402 Fifteenth Street, purchased by Lawrence Hofmann through Charles H. Pulis, broker.

NAPLES, Italy, March 3 -- Restoration of the Dodecanese Islands to Greece on a plebiscite basis and establishment of an international zone to house a new League of Nations in Fiume and to include the hinterland around it which is populated largely by Slavs were recommended today by Count Carlo Sforza in an interview with this correspondent.

The Bureau of Labor Statistics has exposed effectively the fallacies contained in the Thomas-Meany Cost of Living Report. However, the Bureau's own observations concerning the treatment of bonds and taxes when earnings and the cost of living index are compared must be examined carefully.
Wayne T. Lonergan's trial for the murder of his wife, Patricia Burton Lonergan, was put over indefinitely in General Sessions Court yesterday by decision of Judge John J. Freschi.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Plans are nearly complete for the National Red Cross to take over from the Army Emergency Relief the handling of community relief. Providing of immediate personal assistance for soldiers will remain in the hands of the Army.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The United States renewed pressure on Finland to make peace with Soviet Russia today after reports had indicated that the present conversations were in danger of falling through. Previously, through repeated statements of Secretary of State Cordell Hull and Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Under-Secretary of State, the desire of this Government in the matter had been made known.

The suspension of military supplies to Turkey and the allotment of one-third of the Italian fleet to Russia are fresh evidences of the change in the political balance as the war goes on. Both these developments, following the recent speeches of Mr. Churchill and Mr. Eden, indicate the increasing influence of the Soviet Government in Allied decisions and Moscow's active and expanding interest in the European settlements.

For the first time in the history of the cloth spreading industries blind men who operate a broom factory under Government contract at the Industrial Home for the Blind in Brooklyn have been able to lay an accurate spread by utilizing an automatic cloth spreader donated to the home by H. Walter Gilbert, president of Cutting Room Appliances Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Peter J. Salmon, director of the home.

The five-story walk-up containing eighty-six apartments and ten stores at 398 East 152d Street, the Bronx, has been bought by Morris and Samuel Resnik from clients of Goodman Mabel, attorneys. It is on a plot 150 by 130 feet and has an annual rental of $50,000. It is assessed for $265,000. Rubin Nason were the brokers.
LONDON, March 3 (AP) -- A communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

Two New York teams met last night in the final match for the Eastern States contract bridge team-of-four championship and the Curt H. Reisinger Cup in the tournament in progress at the Park Central Hotel here. They were the sole survivors of a field of eleven teams which started Monday night.

LONDON, March 3 (Canadian Press) -- That "Tea Bowl" football game Feb. 13 in which a Canadian Army team defeated one from the American Army was such a success that there will be a repeat performance March 19. This time, however, it will be known as the "Coffee Bowl."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 3 (AP) -- Federal Judge Carroll C. Hincks reserved decision today after hearing objections to plan of reorganization for the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad as amended by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- By a vote of 158 to 114, the House approved today a bill making compensation of civil employes and officers of the Government subject to garnishment or similar processes.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- President Roosevelt said today that supplies were going "over the hump" into China in a very satisfactory way. He referred to the southerly mountain barrier into China as "the hump."

RENO, Nev., March 3 -- Mrs. Ethel S. Morris-Smith obtained a divorce on grounds of cruelty today from Prescott Morris-Smith. They were married in New York City on Oct. 11, 1940, and have a daughter 2 years old.

Wolfgang Rose, pianist, gave his first New York recital last night in Town Hall. Mr. Rose, who is a nephew of Gustav Mahler and Arnold Rose, the celebrated Viennese violinist, presented a program containing Bach's English Suite in A minor; three Scarlatti sonatas; Beethoven's sonata, Op. 109; Liszt's "Legende," No. 2; two mazurkas and the "Ballade" in A fiat of Chopin, and a group of offerings by Debussy and Ravel.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- A Spanish consular official in San Francisco recently told Japanese camp sopkesmen at Tule Lake and Menzanar that American citizens of Japanese ancestry who were confined in the camps were not subject to induction in the armed forces of the United States.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The War Production Board today turned down requests for modification of restrictions controlling the manufacture of men's and boys' clothing. The clothing branch of the war agency announced that the restrictions will not be lifted or eased.

WASHINGTON, March 3 --Although President Roosevelt said at his news conference today that nothing new was to be said about recognizing the French Committee of National Liberation as a provisional authority for metropolitan France, another step toward recognition was taken today when control of requisitioned French merchant ships was turned back to France through the committee.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Failure to renew lend-lease legislation for another year would be "unthinkable" in the face of its proven effectiveness and the current acceleration of the pace of hostilities, Secretary Stimson told the House Foreign Affairs Committee today.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- President Roosevelt accepted tonight the resignation of Albert C. Black, Governor of the Farm Credit Administration, who is leaving for Iran soon for a new assignment, the nature of which was not disclosed.

Today's events: "La Boheme," 2 P.M., and "Tristan und Isolde," 7:45, Metropolitan Opera House; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; National Orchestral Association, Gabrilowitsch Memorial Series Concert, Carnegie Hall, 3; Rosalyn Tureck, piano, Town Hall, 3; Victory concert, New York Public Library, 5:30; Richard Dyer-Bennett, ballad singer, Town Hall, 8:30; "Lucia di Lammermoor," Salmaggi Opera Company, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:30.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., March 3 -- Miss Polly Miller, 18-year-old freshman at Sarah Lawrence College here, was found drowned today in the bathtub of her quarters in a dormitory of the college. Dr. Amos O. Squire, county medical examiner, ruled that she had died accidentally, with submersion probably caused by convulsions suffered while she was taking a bath.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- President Roosevelt announced at his press conference today that Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Under-Secretary of State, would be the diplomatic official who would go to London soon to engage in conversations with the British on war and post-war problems of a political character.

Employers and labor unions would suffer a "waste of time" if the State Industrial Commissioner were given the power, as is proposed in bills now before the Legislature, to review all findings of the State Labor Relations Board, it was charged yesterday by Paul M. Herzog, the board chairman.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 3 -- National socialism was defined as the "curse of Germany" by 24-year-old Dr. Erich Vermehren, former assistant military attache in the German Embassy in 'Turkey, whose statement, following his escape last month into Allied territory, was made public today.
LONDON, March 3 -- A royal commission set out today in quest of a solution to Great Britain's declining birth rate, described officially as "one of the most somber anxieties of the times."

GULFPORT, Miss., March 3 (AP) -- Harold (Jug) McSpaden, shuffled out of first money in his last two golf tourneys, was the only player to break par in the first round of the $4,500 Gulfport Open today, whipping out a 33, 35 -- 68 over the par-71 Great Southern course.
LONDON, March 3 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Skiing conditions improved for the week-end as reports of snow visiting several of the popular areas came in yesterday. In addition, the winter forecast from Washington promised one to three inches of dry powder snow in the Adirondacks and northern Catskills of this State, and in the Berkshires, Green and White Mountains of New England today, with clearing and colder tomorrow.

Guns will bark, crowds will roar and spikes will fly in Madison Square Garden tonight when the track and field stars of twenty-four colleges and universities will compete in the twenty-third annual I.C. 4-A indoor championships.

California sportswear makers are rapidly climbing to first place as creators of playclothes and slacks. The freshness of their designs lured some of New York's smartest buyers out to the Coast this winter, and the free and easy summer clothes they selected are appearing now in the stores, tagged with prices that fit conveniently into war bond buyers' budgets.
CHUNGKING, China, March 3 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops in northwestern Burma have advanced to within two miles of Maingkwan, main settlement in the Hukawng Valley, a Chinese communique announced tonight.

TRENTON, March 3 -- The Legislature voted approval today of the draft of a new Constitution prepared by a joint committee, insuring a referendum on the document at the polls next November. The signature of the Governor is not required.

LONDON, March 3 -- Herbert Morrison, Home Affairs Secretary, delivered a fighting speech to the people of Sheffield tonight, assuring them there would be no Dunkerque when the armies set forth from home this time. The British are tough enough, he said, to tackle the enemy without the fear of consequences.

In a brief but sharply worded statement the Board of Education yesterday challenged the accuracy of the recent report on the New York City school system made by the National Education Association. A panel of prominent educators charged in the report that Mayor La Guardia tampered with the schools and interfered with the independence of the board members.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., March 3 -- College courses must be shortened and limited to practical subjects to meet the needs of men and women from the armed forces and factories after the war, Col. John N. Andrews, post-war activities director for Selective Service, told sixty delegates to a district conference of the American College Publicity Association at the Hotel Gramatan here today.

The editor of the Chapel Hill weekly feels that in view of this country's unpreparedness for war two years ago we have done much better than could have been expected, and he seemingly has no fears as to the final outcome.

PHILADELPHIA, March 3 -- From the bottom of the Delaware River, which is being dredged to provide a deeper channel, are coming up the rusted and decayed remnants of "a secret weapon" of the Revolutionary War -- an underwater stockade with iron points designed to impale the wooden hull of any enemy vessel approaching Fort Mifflin and Philadelphia.

HARTFORD, March 3 -- Broken homes and working parents are responsible for much of the 30 per cent increase in delinquency in Connecticut, according to a report filed today by three juvenile court judges, Thomas D. Gili of Hartford, Fred D. Faulkner of New Haven and Stanley P. Mead of New Canaan.

CHICAGO, March 3 -- Federal Judge M. L. Igoe today authorized Charles H. Albers, receiver for the old Central Republic Trust Company of Illinois, to turn over $10,750,000 to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation as partial payment of a $15,500,000 judgment lodged against the bank's stockholders.

The Congressional Record reprints remarks made in the House of Representatives on Feb. 2, 1944, by Hon. Walter C. Ploeser of Missouri wherein he opposed the Wagner, Murray, Dingell bill and also stated as follows:

New York girls serving in the Women's Reserve of the United States Marine Corps yesterday earned special praise from Eastern division headquarters for filling "man-size" jobs at its bases and air stations throughout the country.

ON THE SECOND UKRANIAN FRONT, Russia, Feb. 27 (Delayed) -- During the interrogation of prisoners from the German Eighth Army this correspondent obtained ample evidence that the bombing of Germany has become an important factor in determining the morale of the men fighting against the Russians and contributed appreciably to their feeling of hopelessness.

Japanese soldiers attempting to storm the lines held by United States Marines on Cape Gloucester, New Britain, charged to their death with the battle cry, "To hell with Babe Ruth!" on their lips. Probably most of us have forgotten, even if we were ever aware of, what lay behind that strange battle cry.

After withholding details of the fatal shooting of an Army private nearly twenty-four hours, the police yesterday revealed that Private Alwin E. Owens, 34 years old, attached to Napier Field, Ala., died in Sydenham Hospital early Thursday morning as the result of a bullet wound in his abdomen received in the hallway of 33 West 114th Street in Harlem at 12:40 A.M. Thursday.
In two recent issues of THE NEW YORK TIMES (Feb. 21 and 23) I have found the two following statements on Italy's military, contribution to the war:

Strong support of two bills which would set up procedures for the disposition of excess Government food stocks, as recommended in the Baruch-Hancock report, was urged yesterday by the NationalAmerican Wholesale Grocers Association and the United States Wholesale Grocers Association.

LONDON, March 3 -- The stock markets here were generally quiet on the last day of an inactive week. Home rails were in demand, however, London, Midland Scottish gaining well. The British 3 1/2 per cent War Loan was among the gilt-edge securities that showed improvement.

Princeton University undergraduates who founded the "Veterans of Future Wars" in 1936 to protest demands on the Treasury by veterans of past wars are serving with distinction in the present war, according to The United Press.

RICHMOND, Va., March 3 -Patents for new chemical processes, including one dedicated "to the free use of the people in the territory of the United States," stand out among the 612 listed in the current official gazette of the United States Patent Office.

PITTSBURGH, March 3 (U.P.) -- There is no possibility that the marriage of Staff Sgt. William H. Thompson Jr., identified as the father of the quadruplets in England, can be broken under the laws of the church, the Rev. Joseph P. Sullivan, assistant pastor of St. Joseph's Catholic Church, said here tonight.

Consolidated Retail Stores, Inc., has declared a dividend of 15 cents a share on the common stock. Previous payments were 25 cents on Jan. 3, this year, and 12 1/2 cents each in May, July and October, 1943.

The automobile Club of New York believes that while the current campaign of the Office of Price Administration "may be helpful to some extent," little progress can be made until the theft and counterfeiting of gaoline ration coupons is stopped, it was asserted yesterday by J.R. Crossley, vice president of the club.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 3 -- Going on the Napoleonic maxim that in any military operation morale is to equipment as three is to one, American commanders in the Persian Gulf area have called on the Red Cross and their own special services to undertake an expanded welfare program designed to support the spirits of the men engaged in one of the most onerous and least glamorous tasks in the whole global war.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, March 4 -- In desperate fighting in which the Japanese forces were at least their equal in numbers, the United States Fifth Cavalry drove back the enemy and enlarged our perimeter around the Momote airdrome on Los Negros Island in the Admiralties, it was announced today.

The announcement from Chungking that the Chinese Government has decided formally to demand an indemnity from Japan for damage to Chinese property since the invasion of Manchuria in 1931 will come as a surprise here. All previous semi-official declarations from Chungking had been in the opposite direction.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Almost 50,000 Internal Revenue Bureau employes, headed by a former Brooklyn boy, are waiting on the March 15 yardline hoping that 50,000,000 taxpayers will throw the ball to them in time for a touchdown. The ball is the return on 1943 income, accompanied by any amount still owed on it or on the forgiveness of 1942 tax.

As the Office of Distribution formally took notice of the passing of the acute stage of the butter shortage, trade and Government representatives predicted yesterday that, in view of the big carryover of 70,000,000 pounds, the set-aside program would be resumed next month on the basis of 20 to 25 per cent instead of 30 per cent as a year ago.

PROBABLY you haven't stopped to notice, but if you will now give the matter a little thought you will sense how much motion pictures have come along in the past couple of years as a means of communication between the public and those who have thoughts to transmit.

The Police Department, ever alert in its guardianship of public morals and order, caught up last week with the "Studs Lonigan" trilogy completed by James T. Farrell, author and chronicler of Chicago's South Side, nine years ago, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -Merchant shipyards delivered 134 vessels in February, including the first of the new Victory ships. The total was ten greater than in January, but far below the December record of 208.

DETROIT, March 4 (AP) -- The Red Wings increased their second-place lead in the National Hockey League to 6 points by defeating the Black Hawks, 6 to 2, before 10,583 spectators tonight at Olympia Stadium. It was Chicago's first defeat in seven games.

THERE undoubtedly exist in this world a handful of infuriating females who "always look nice." You whirl into the local grocery shortly after dawn, you stagger into a crowded store or office building at 5:30, and there One of Them is . . . perfectly clothed, impeccably coiffed, with nary a thread of lint on her shoulder nor a chip in her glossy manicure.

WARNER BROTHERS will start production this week on "The Doughgirls," hoping to put at least 85 per cent of the Joseph Fields play onto the screen, in spite of the various Hays office and Washington "must nots."

IN a fine, spontaneous spirit, Elisabeth MacIntyre has made a second Australian picture book with a story in rhyme as lively and engaging as her "Ambrose Kangaroo." In lightly tripping couplets we learn all about young Susan

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Jonathan Daniels, one of President Roosevelt's executive assistants, today capitulated to demands of a Senate Agricultural Subcommittee that he appear before it and answer questions as to whether or not Harry A. Slattery, head of the Government's Rural Electrification Administration, had been asked to submit his resignation.

Mozart's Mass in C minor received an outstanding performance at the concert given by the National Orchestral Association, yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, as the opening event in its Gabrilowitsch Memorial Series for this season.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 4 -- The main question today in the Russo-Finnish truce problem is whether Dr. Juho K. Paasikivi, who received the Soviet terms, will return here to deliver to the Soviet Ambassador, Mme. Alexandra Kollontay, the Helsinki Government's answer.
MADRID, March 4 -- The wild, war-boom spree at Monte Carlo is over after three years of fabulous, incredible high jinks.

In connection with plans for observance of Port of New York Day on Tuesday, James A. Dennean, president of the Foreign Commerce Club of New York, declared yesterday that this port has done and will continue to do an amazing job in handling the shipments of vital supplies to our war fronts, despite certain port deficiencies brought about by the war which have affected all ports and industries.

JERUSALEM, March 3 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Emir Abdullah Ibn Hussein, ruler of Transjordan, today cabled a bitter protest to President Roosevelt against the pending Senate resolution reaffirming United States approval of Palestine as a Jewish national homeland. Meanwhile new violence broke out in the Holy Land.
DETROIT, March 4 (U.P.) -- Charles E. Sorensen, 62 years old, vice president and a director of the Ford Motor Company and its production genius for years, has resigned, it was learned today.

Consider the nice set-up that Tojo, the "one-man Cabinet," has arranged for himself. As Premier Tojo he can order Minister of War Tojo to call upon Chief of Staff Tojo to command Minister of Commerce and Industry Tojo to find more manpower for Controller of Munitions Tojo, even to the extent of raiding Minister of Education Tojo's teaching force.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Acting Secretary of State, revealed today that the United States Government had never entered into official relations with the Argentine regime headed by Acting President Edelmiro Farrell.

MIAMI, Fla., March 4 -- Thirty-one persons in Miami and Miami Beach have been arrested by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the first step of a country-wide drive to stamp out "a vicious black market" in reservations for railroad accommodations.

THOUGH Lenin has been dead two full decades and was without doubt one of the most influential makers of the history of our time, there is still no adequate biography of him. This new life has the one virtue of being official, as of 1943 -- the date of its Russian publication.

MOSCOW, March 4 -- Participation in the war by the Red Fleet as the result of successes along the coasts of the Finland Gulf of Finland and in the direction of Black Sea ports is envisaged by the creation by decree of the presidium of new orders and medals for distinction in naval actions.

PHILADELPHIA, March 4 -- Mr. Griscom was a son of Clement A. Griscom, a partner of the International Navigation Company and first president of the International Mercantile Company. His mother was Mrs. Frances Biddle Griscom.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Sunday, March 5 -- In what is officially described as "one of the fiercest encounters of the war," American troops smashed wave after wave of screaming Japanese charging in a desperate effort to recapture Momote airdrome on Los Negros Island in the Admiralties.
PANAMA CITY, Fla., March 4 (AP) -- The Rebecca Lukens, the first Liberty ship named for a woman industrialist, was launched at the Wainwright yards today.

EVERYBODY'S talking about bobby Socks and the bobby-socks brigade. The police are "taking steps" and sociologists and defenders of the home are calling meetings, but no one seems to know exactly what a bobby sock is and where it gets its name.
All the first round and two second round matches were concluded last night in the men's Eastern indoor tennis championship at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

VICTORY gardening includes fruit as well as vegetables and, to most people, fruit growing has been the greater adventure.
