Not everyone realized last year that no crop could be expected the first season; even strawberries do not bear well until the second year and many kinds of fruit trees need three to five years before they yield a harvest.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -President Roosevelt's political advisers probably will urge him to veto the compromise service vote bill, if Congress finally approves it in its present form, and Republicans may be just as well satisfied if he does.

DOMINICAN Republic observed last Sunday the centenary of its independence and commemorated the occasion with twelve stamps. In the group for normal postage, according to information received by Bamber ger's stamp department, are 1/2-centavo ocher, 1c green, 2c red,3c lilac, e orange, 7c dark blue, 10c sepia, 20c olive and 50c light 'blue, each 34 by 23 millimeters.

The audience that filled Town Hall last night to hear Richard Dyer-Bennet, "Twentieth-Century Minstrel," sing ballads was richly rewarded with a fine old art that has been so neglected as to become a "novelty" in our present-day music halls.
TORONTO, March 4 (AP) -- The Canadiens stretched their string of consecutive victories in the National Hockey League to seven tonight with a 5-2 triumph over the Maple Leafs.

Vigorous and prompt prosecution under the Federal laws of persons who sell theatre tickets at illegal premiums was promised by United States Attorney James B.M. McNally yesterday. Mr. McNally asked for the cooperation of the public and pointed out that persons registering complaints would not be inconvenienced.

STOCKHOLM, March 4 -- The Russo-Finnish problem is really a triangle drama. The fact that none of the parties has any love for anyone but itself hardly makes the solution simpler. In addition to the main parties -- Russia, Finland and Germany -- there are numerous more distant relatives and friends concerned whose influence on the whole is beneficial.

TO be sentimental would, in Nature, be suicidal; if there is no compassion in it, neither is there any persecution. You cannot find in Nature anything evil, save as you misread it by human standards. Anger blazes in a fight between two bull moose; anger then is a plain preservative measure, the fear which is the safeguard of all living.

MAYBE poor old "Swan Lake" gets kicked around too much, thank goodness. At any rate, La Meri's translation of it into the dance idiom of India, with which she is packing her little Ethmologlc Theatre two or three nights a week, does considerably less damage to it than some of the strictly academic performances it receives at the hands of the various ballet companies.

Confidence increased in retail circles here last week that the "no higher price line" provision of MPR 330, which has aroused widespread opposition among merchants, is on the way out. Many believe this provision, which prevented retailers from handling higher price lines than they did in March, 1942, will be eliminated before the new regulation to supersede the General Maximum Price Regulation is put into effect about June 1.

THE third annual series of concerts by Adolf Busch and his Chamber Music Players at Town Hall will be given on Friday nights, March 24 and 31 and April 14 and 21. Soloists include Mr. Busch, Rudolf Serkin, Miecio Horszowski, Eugene Istomin, Martial Singher, Frances Magnes and Hermann Busch.

IT is an easy thing to say that when a novel achieves only a photographic realism it fails to reach the higher levels of which fiction is capable. But just what is the missing quantity that the merely faithful and exact transcription of life is unable to include?

MIAMI, Fla., March 4 -- Charges that gambling establishments here are able to obtain "batteries of telephones" and provide extensive service to bettors while legitimate communications are curtailed because of the war are made in an editorial published in The Miami Herald.
Two young designers, Joset Walker and Vera Maxwell, contribute much to styles for many. Both breathe the spirit of young America into their designs.

The General Council of Congregational Christian Churches, which has 1,000,000 members, has filled its quota of chaplains, it was announced by the Rev. Dr. Ferdinand Q. Blanchard of Cleveland, Ohio, Moderator of the council, in a Lenten pastoral sent yesterday from the headquarters, 287 Fourth Avenue.

A more efficient utilization of the more than eighty "octaves" of the ether spectrum offers perhaps the greatest promise of bringing a fuller, healthier and longer life to mankind in the post-war era, said Samuel G. Hibben, noted Westinghouse engineer, before delegates who attended a meeting of the Science Institute.

ONE way to take advantage of the superabundance of eggs -- and the plenitude is expected to continue for another couple of months -- is to use them in angel-food and sponge cakes. Fortunately, in view of rationing, neither of these desserts requires any shortening and the amounts of sugar needed, though not modest, scarcely could be called excessive.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -The War Department made public today the names of the five Army nurses who died in the bombing of field hospitals in the Anzio beach head on Feb. 7 and 10.

THERE is an old story about the man at a revival meeting who kept calling out the pressing offer, "O Lord, use me!" But when the preacher took him up by pointing out that the church roof needed fixing he changed his tune to, "O Lord, use me, but use me in an executive position."

The War Shipping Administration has undertaken what foreign freight forwarders described yesterday as "the greatest step yet taken to return foreign trade to normal channels." The Government-operated War Forwarding Corporation, it was learned, has been instructed to discontinue on April 15 the handling of all shipments but those whose title is vested in the United States.

DETROIT, March 4 -- Nash-Kelvinator employes have found that the accurate income data they have been keeping in their individual financial record books is saving them time, inconvenience and money in filing income tax forms, George W. Mason, president, announced yesterday.

With an increasing number of veterans returning to the nation's campuses each month, colleges and universities throughout the country have readjusted their programs and made necessary changes in their schedules to meet the needs of the former service men. Many institutions have suddenly discovered that the post-war plans they have been talking about must be put into operation immediately.

NAPLES, March 4 -- The dispatch of Italian warships to the Black Sea would immeasurably help Russia's naval and military position on the southern Ukrainian front, not only restoring complete control of those waters to the Red Fleet, but placing Russia in a position potentially strong enough to launch a land and amphibious campaign against the Balkans especially Rumania.

Warning that a left-wing victory in the contest for control of the American Labor party would endanger the re-election of President Roosevelt, speakers at a luncheon meeting at the Hotel Woodstock declared yesterday that defeat of the Sidney HillmanCommunist-left wing coalition at the primary election on March 28 was the major task facing New York liberals.

Colgate University, founded 125 years ago to meet the need for a "literate ministry," celebrated its anniversary yesterday with a series of nation-wide alumni luncheons in forty cities and a radio symposium that was broadcast by shortwave to the Colgate alumni on battlefronts in all parts of the world.

SHE can be seen any weekday morning, hurrying off to work, urging along a small child to be left with a neighbor or a relative or at a nursery, if there is one. She can be seen again on the way home, standing in line at the meat or grocery counter between 5:30 and 6.

Steady increase in foreign students at Harvard University during the war has brought establishment this month of a new office, Counselor for Foreign Students. More than 250 of the 1,800 civilian students at the university are from abroad. Officials predict that the number will increase steadily into the post-war period at American universities generally.

THERE is a good and useful book to be written about bureaucracy in America. Bureaucracy on the grand scale is a new thing in our experience -- but we have it now. As Mr. Sullivan's opening chapter notes, the Federal Government now carries more than 3,300,000 employes on its civil payroll, 1 to every 41 of national population, as compared to 1 to every 153 in 1920.

Following a series of conferences beginning last month, between officials of the War Shipping Administration and the American Communications Association, decision was announced yesterday of the immediate institution of a three-man, twenty-four-hour, round-the-clock radio watch aboard American flag vessels in the interest of the full use of radio communications at sea in the war.

The American birth rate reached its wartime peak in December, 1942-January, 1943. Since that time it has been steadily declining, according to the statisticians of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. They found that the number of births in a group of large American cities was 22 per cent lower in December, 1943, than in December, 1942.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Labor statisticians who have analyzed the vote cast for the Presidential candidates in 1940 estimated that President Roosevelt had been re-elected by votes of urban dwellers, especially those in industrial centers.

AT this season many charming but transitory plants are supplied by the florist for the brightening of the window garden. There amid the enduring green of philodendron, ivy and fern, a delicate lavender primrose or gay pot of daffodils carries the very essence of spring, while drifts of snow or inches of mud out-of-doors still deter the gardener's progress.

THIS review is addressed to urban Americans who were born not much later than 1880, were earning their first real money around 1900 -- and were joyously spending it at the box-office windows of the most wonderful institution of entertainment ever known to the human race, namely, the theatre in its gaudy, sumptuous, meaty prime.

The second annual Garden Week, sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES, the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, Inc., and the Garden Club of New Jersey, will be held in Times Hall, Forty-fourth Street, west of Broadway, on March 22, 23 and 24.

PORTLAND, Ore., March 4 -- In a surprise move Governor Snell today appointed Guy Cordon, Republican attorney of Roseburg, as interim successor to the late Charles L. McNary, United States Senator. He also renounced his own aspirations to the office.

Every war takes the best of the nation's manhood and every war returns to civil life an army of young men who are disabled or in poor health because of their honorable service. From being above the physical average of their generation they are reduced below it. Theirs is one of the most difficult ordeals a person can be called upon to face.

Having already been honored as the only local squad invited to the national invitation tournament at Madison Square Garden, the St. John's quintet gained additional laurels yesterday when it was announced that it was the only combination to have two men on the All-Metropolitan first team, which is picked annually by the New York Basketball Writers Association.

MOSCOW, March 4 -- The title of Hero of the Soviet Union has been awarded to a 20-year-old Kasakh girl machine-gunner for valor in a battle. Manshuk Mametova joined the Red Army eighteen months ago to do staff work, but soon afterward she volunteered for machinegun duty.

TO Monte Proser, prodigal owner of the Copacabana, go the honors this week for offering the outstanding cafe event. On Thursday evening Mr. Proser, never one, to hold a firm grip on the purse strings, presents an elaborate revue headed by Sophie Tucker, last of the alleged "Red Hot Mamas.

LONDON, March 4 -- Powerful business interests under close Government supervision will take the place of unrestricted private enterprise in the world to come, British Home Secretary Herbert Morrison predicted at a meeting of Labor party leaders in Yorkshire today.
LONDON, March 4 -- The United States Army Air Forces bombed Berlin today for the first time.

WITH the February decline under last year held to moderate dimensions, retail trade has started on the new month under conditions which ought to produce a substantial increase over 1943. An early Easter will pile up most of the seasonal purchases into this period and pay-as-you-go has taken most of the sting out of the income tax date.

CATTLEYA trianae -- orchids to you -- once the millionaire's darling, are now the poor man's pride. Formerly sold only at luxury florists', orchids are blooming today on the black velvet "flash" boards of street venders and at subway flower stands, ranging in price from 75 cents for the familiar lavender flower to $1.50 for the exotic green or brown blossoms.

PHILADELPHIA, March 4 -Philadelphia's National League baseball club announced today that its new nickname -- chosen in a prize contest that produced 5,064 letters and 634 other suggestions -would be "Blue Jays."

NEW DELHI, India, March 4 (U.P.) -- West African troops have broken into the Kaladan River town of Apauka in western Burma in a drive that threatens both Akyab, thirty-eight miles to the south, and the main Japanese defense line in Arakan, it was announced today.

PERHAPS the proper solution is to induct all umpires into the Army, then they would simply love to listen to Leo Durocher talk. Under present conditions their attitude is unbearable. The Lip starts to jabber away and a minute or two later an umpirical thumb is jerking frantically in the air. Leo is heading for the clubhouse, his conversation at an end for the day.

CHICAGO, March 4 -- The regular grain trade will handle the distribution of wheat owned by the Commodity Credit Corporation under the new allocation program, it was announced today after a meeting between the Government agency and warehousemen.

Baseball's current off-season, perhaps as bizarre as any the game has known in many years, will come to a close one week from today. For next Sunday will mark the start of activities for a majority of major league clubs as the national pastime swings into its second successive streamlined, frost-bitten and war-restricted spring-training campaign.

Marshall, Army Chief of Staff, has urged the Senate Foreign Relations Committee to postpone action, for military reasons, on a resolution that would put the Senate on record as favoring continued Jewish immigration to Palestine, Senator Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota said today.

Kung, Finance Minister, is trying to find a formula that will relieve the United States Army of some of its financial burdens in China.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -The War Labor Board, dividing 8 to 4, ruled today that an order requiring maintenance of union membership among newspaper editorial employes would not be "an abridgment of freedom of the press or a violation of the First Amendment to the Constitution."
Mr. and Mrs. William Wallace Kellett of Philadelphia are at Hampshire House.

MIAMI, Fla., March 4 -- In as bristling a finish as Hialeah has seen, Four Freedoms today captured the $36,350 Widener Challenge Cup by a nose from the favored Sun Again as the season's biggest crowd, 18,984, shrieked and groaned at the finish.

THIS is a fine outdoor story of a brother and sister who went nearly every summer to Port Angus, a little fishing village in the north of Scotland. The summer holiday described in this book, however, was the most satisfactory and delightful of all.

ELIZABETH DEWING KAUP tells in this novel the story, of Josiah Madden from the time he returns a hero from World War I to the time he takes a job in a shoe factory at the beginning of World War II. What he does in the intervening twenty-two years is supposed to be typical of America in that period.

MOSCOW, March 4 -- The Supreme Soviet of the Russian Soviet Federated Socialist Republics unanimously approved today proposals for the creation of separate Republican Commissariats of Defense and Foreign Affairs in the sixteen Republics in the union after the measure's principal sponsor told the applauding delegates that the changes would "contribute to an early victory over enemies and the reaching of a universal peace and security."

Despite the closing of seventy-seven of their number, junior colleges since Pearl Harbor have attained the record enrollment of 325,000 students and, from all indications, the upward trend is continuing. A report prepared by Dr. Walter C. Eells, secretary of the American Association of Junior Colleges, shows that more students are entering the two-year institutions than ever before in their history.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- President Roosevelt and high officials of his Administration began observance of the beginning of his twelfth year in office today by attending religious services at the White House in the morning and ended on a festive note at the annual dinner of the White House Correspondents Association.

CLEVELAND, March 4 -- The twenty-eighth annual two - day show of the Western Reserve Kennel Club opened in the Cleveland Public Auditorium today with an entry of 958 dogs, an increase of 108 over last year's total.

In the opinion of New York City's high school principals, a small percentage of their students should be permitted to leave the classroom and go to work. At present the State education law requires a boy or girl to continue in school until he reaches the age of 16. If he secures working papers at that age, he can leave; otherwise he must continue until he is 17.

The favored team of Waldemar von Zedwitz, Lee Hazen, Harry J. Fishbein, Charles Lochridge and Pvt. Tobias Stone, all of New York, won the contract bridge team-of-four championship and the Curt H. Reisinger Cup in the Eastern States tournament at the Park Central Hotel here yesterday.

A MODERATE acquaintance with the facts of the history of this country from the beginning to the present leads to the conclusion that our "isolation" from the rest of the world -- and especially from the Continent of Europe -- is an illusion, and belief in it a miasma.

With the announcement yesterday of the fourth renewal of the Navy "E" Production Award to the Consolidated Shipbuilding Corporation at Morris Heights, the Bronx, William G. Wood, president of the company, disclosed that the yard has delivered nearly 100 assorted "small" craft, ranging from 110-foot Diesel-electric tugs, known as YT's, to 173-foot steel PC boats.

THE term rococo has always carried certain derisive implications. Its first use is attributed by Delecluze to a fellow-student in the atelier of the painter David and described as hardly permissible in polite conversation. Stendhal in his "Promenades dans Rome" refers to it as a "low word" and apologizes for mentioning it.

A warning that the most difficult phase of war finances, that of reconversion and rebuilding, lies ahead of the colleges, was made by Dr. Everett Case, president of Colgate University, in his annual report made public last week. This is Dr. Case's first report since he became Colgate's ninth president eighteen months ago.

Last week, as American forces moved to within 660 miles of Truk by landing in the Admiralty Islands, an official naval spokesman estimated that one-third of the navy with which Japan started the Pacific war has now been destroyed.

OSSINING, N.Y., March 4 -- A small, frightened man, the fallen overlord of the underworld, entered the execution chamber of Sing Sing prison at thirteen minutes after 11 o'clock tonight. Three minutes later he was pronounced dead. He was Louis (Lepke) Buchalter.

ON THE SECOND UKRAIN-IAN FRONT, Russia, Feb. 28 (Delayed) -- Talks with Ukrainian villagers in the hinterland of this front have left this correspondent with the deep impression that the German policy toward the Jews in the occupied Ukraine has been less terrible than has been reported previously by official sources.

Now conducting a special drive for funds to mark its tenth anniversary, the Homemaker Service of the Children's Aid Society will benefit from an exhibition of "Still Life From Manet to Picasso," which will open on Tuesday afternoon at the Durand-Ruel Galleries, 12 East Fifty-seventh Street. Mrs. Henry Adams Ashforth heads the executive committee for the benefit.

The public will have its first chance next Wednesday to see the comprehensive good-will exhibition of contemporary American art which is to be sent to England soon under the auspices of Artists for Victory, Inc., a wartime organization of American art societies.

Harry H. Woodring, chairman of the American Democratic National Committee, said yesterday that if the committee failed to block renomination of President Roosevelt at the Democratic National Convention it probably would nominate a third party candidate for President.

The people of the State of New York closed a long-due account last night. Given the benefit of every doubt by the law he had outraged for two decades, Louis (Lepke) Buchalter was put to death in the electric chair at Sing Sing prison at 11:16 P.M. With him to the death chair went two of his henchmen, Emanuel (Mendy) Weiss and Louis Capone.

EDWARD ELGAR once referred to Manchester as the musical capital of England. Manchester was then in effect the most important center of music in the land. It had a first-rate permanent orchestra conducted by Hans Richter; it had the Brodsky quartet to provide chamber music; its artistic life, wisely organized, was, unlike London, wholly independent of the visits of Continental artists.
BERNE, Switzerland, March 4 -The Germans in northern Italy today took a hand in quelling strike disturbances and succeeded in restoring essential railroad traffic for German war supplies.

Daniel P. Woolley, Regional Office of Price Administration Administrator released yesterday a last-minute appeal to automobile owners who have not done so to endorse their gasoline ration coupons before OPA begins its enforcement drive tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Few observers can recall having seen Congress more angry about more matters -- few of them apparently dealing directly with more effective prosecution of the war -than it has been in the last few weeks.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 3 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Authoritative Turkish sources said today that the only reason why Turkey was not now actively in the war on the Allies' side was that Britain had not met her request for 500 tanks and 300 planes.

THIS is Mikhail Rasumny, a man not given to discretion in speech but of robust declaration and laughter, once an illustrious member of the Moscow Art Theatre troupe, also dishwasher, bill collector, pilot of a hearse at "$2 an object" and now a feature player with Paramount Pictures.

China, too, is making plans for post-war economic transition, but in China's case the problem is not the relatively simple one of getting back to a normal peacetime economy. There it is one of getting to a new economy altogether -- a new principle of economic organization, and, what is of equal importance to us, a new relationship with Western countries.
GULFPORT, Miss., March 4 -Harold (Jug) McSpaden of Philadelphia, continued to pace the $4,500 Gulfport open golf field today, firing a one-under-par 70 for a thirty-six-hole total of 138.

LONDON, March 4 (U.P.) -- Fighting flared throughout all the Herzegovina region of southern Bosnia yesterday as Yugoslav Partisan forces captured the town of Lastva, twenty miles east of Dubrovnik, and smashed a German attempt to penetrate to Kalinovik, thirty miles south of Sarajevo, a communique from the Yugoslav People's Party of Liberation said today.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -On the eleventh anniversary of the first inauguration of Franklin D. Roosevelt, Senator Smith, Democrat, of South Carolina, proposed today that anti-Administration Democrats work together to name uninstructed members to the Electoral College and get "a real honest to God Constitution loving Democrat in the White House."

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The Army officially announced today the transfer of parts of its emergency relief activities to the Red Cross, confirming previous reports that this would be done. It said that the Red Cross would provide assistance from its own funds for basic maintenance needs, pending receipt of Government benefits but added that Army Emergency Relief would supplement Red Cross funds to meet specific non-recurring emergency needs.

THREE highly diverse sculptors are represented in a stimulating exhibition at the Argent Galleries including eleven pieces and more than a score of drawings by each. Alfeo Faggi champions the traditional, Ossip Zadkine the modernist, viewpoint; and Wharton Esherick may be termed individual innovator.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -The War Food Administration announced today a schedule of premiums and discounts which will be applicable under the 1944 Commodity Credit Corporation's cotton loan program. The schedule is designed to encourage greater production of staple of longer length needed for the war program.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 4 -Breaking two records and taking five of the nine first places, the Naval Academy swimming team today defeated West Point, 42 to 33.
NAPLES, March 4 (AP) -- A comunique:

MADELEINE GOSS, whose lives of Beethoven, Bach and Schubert rank high among biographies for young readers, and Robert Haven Schauffler, who some years ago wrote a life of Brahms for adults, form a happy combination of authorship in this biography of a great musician, whose music makes an especial appeal to young people.

While retail trade continued active here last week, volume again suffered in comparison with the 1943 figures. A decline of about 5 per cent was estimated for department stores, while a larger decrease than this was seen likely for specialty shops.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Sunday, March 5 (AP) -- A communique:

COMDR, GENE TUNNEY recently deflated jiujitsu as an effective method of hand-tohand combat, and that caused Capt. Steve Stayers, one-time Columbia swimming ace and now a crack Marine instructor, to rush to his typewriter for an exposition of the Marine system of hand-to-hand fighting.

LONDON, March 5 -- Keeping up their steady hammering of enemy targets, the United States Strategic Air Forces sent out Liberator and Marauder bombers today in day-long, heavy strikes at German military installations in southwestern and northern France.

NORTH CONWAY, N. H., March 5 (AP) -- Ed Bering won the fifth annual Gibson race of the Eastern Slope Ski Club today, an event which had been monopolized for the past four years b: Toni Matt, former national combined downhill and slalom champion, who now is in the Army.

The coal strikes caused last year a loss to the Pittsburgh Coal Company of 755,000 tons of coal and 151,058 man-days, the company disclosed in its annual report to stockholders made public yesterday by Augustus K. Oliver, chairman, and J.B. Morrow, president.

German troops have been called out to quell the general strike that is now "paralyzing" north Italy and "bloody street fighting" is in progress in Milan, the British radio said yesterday, United States Government monitors reported.

A scoring coup that netted them two goals in seven seconds kept the New York Rangers from losing their National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The brace of counters, coming in the third period, enabled the New Yorkers to erase a Boston advantage that had existed since early in the middle frame.

A slightly easier tone in the Canadian free dollar, and a sharp break in the Argentina peso on Saturday, represented the only change of importance registered in the trading in foreign exchanges last week. All other currencies were firm.

Gifts of $825,842 were received by the Greater New York 1944 Red Cross War Fund on Friday and Saturday, it was announced yesterday by John P. Stevens Jr., general chairman of the appeal for $22,386,000. This brought the total receipts by the Fund at the close of four days' campaigning to $3,872,000.

ALGIERS, March 5 -- An attack in only battalion strength was the worst that the Germans could muster on the beachhead below Rome in the period that ended at noon yesterday. The latest reports indicated that an American counter-attack, put in Friday evening, had taken back every inch that the Germans had gained.

NAPLES, March 5 -- It is now more than six weeks since the amphibious assault was launched on the Anzio-Nettuno beachhead and more than a month since the first Allied troops penetrated into Cassino in a preliminary effort to pierce the Gustav Line.

The Pure Oil Company reported yesterday for 1943 a consolidated net income of $13,874,517 after charges, taxes and reserves, equal, after preferred dividend payments, to $2.50 each on the 3,982,031 common shares outstanding. For 1942, the company had reported a net income of $13,761,826, or $2.47 a common share.

Two to four years will pass before the transition from wartime to peacetime employment in New York State has been effected, and during the first year 1,500,000 to 2,500,000 persons will be entitled to benefits from the State Unemployment Insurance Fund, according to a report to Governor Dewey by the New York Unemployment Insurance State Advisory Council.

MONTREAL, March 5 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadiens registered their second victory in two nights over the Maple Leafs tonight with an 8-3 decision that dealt a heavy blow to the Leafs' hopes of finishing better than fourth in the National Hockey League.
A peculiar situation existing for a long time in the distribution of beef in the City of New York and Long Island (and possibly everywhere) calls for explanation and inquiry.

A story of the American doughboy's courage and fortitude under enemy fire and his keen desire to have a broader picture of home-front activities was related yesterday by Staff Sgt. Jack Foisie, a member of the reportorial staff of the Army's newspaper, Stars and Stripes, in the offices of the publication at 205 East Forty-second Street.

NEW DELHI, India, March 5 (AP) -- North Burma Chinese forces were reported today to be meeting heavy Japanese artillery and mortar fire as they drove into the approaches of Maingkwan, main enemy base in the Hukawng Valley.

Charging that the "last-minute" introduction in Albany of a bill to abolish the Women's Division and the Division of Minimum Wage in the New York State Department of Labor was "a calculated move designed to defeat ordinary democratic processes," eight women's and labor organizations have protested to Senator Arthur Wicks of Kingston, a Republican, who is author of the bill. They demanded a joint legislative public hearing on the measure.

Plans for a School Part of the Children's Court, to be held in school buildings for the handling of truancy cases, were partly disclosed yesterday by Mayor La Guardia in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall. The plan has the approval of Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, and the Mayor intends to appoint a justice of the court in a few days.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, March 6 (AP) -- Allied bombers from the Solomon Islands bases dropped 164 tons of explosives on waterfront installations at Rabaul, the enemy base in northeastern New Britain.
NAPLES, Italy, March 5 -- All civilians in Italian front-line areas are being evacuated by Allied military authorities for security reasons. The evacuation has been on for about a week.

James T. Farrell, author of the "Studs Lonigan" trilogy in which the Police Department is reported to have evinced a sudden interest almost a decade after its publication, termed the mysterious investigation "shameful and unworthy of the administration of any civilized city."

After forty-six years of continuous operation, elevated railway service across Brooklyn Bridge ended when Motorman Harry Page of 36 Logan Street, Brooklyn, piloted a Lexington Avenue train across the span at 12:02 yesterday.

Not only was the winning of the I.C. 4-A night before last a distinct feather in Army's cap, but quite a boost for track in general, especially in days to come when the only wars will be on the gridiron, the diamond, and the rivers and lakes.

MOSCOW, Monday, March 6 -- Red Army forces under the command of Marshal Gregory K. Zhukoff in a two-day offensive on the First Ukrainian Front have smashed twelve German divisions and driven forward fifteen to thirty-one miles on a 112-mile front, capturing more than 500 inhabited points and placing them within easy striking distance of the vital Odessa-Lwow railroad.

CHICAGO, March 5 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks took undisputed possession of third place in the National Hockey League tonight by downing the Detroit Red Wings, 6 to 1, before a crowd of 17,937 at the Chicago Stadium.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 5 (AP) -- Jarred by Washington's "wait and see" policy, the Argentine Government of Gen. Edelmiro Farrell centered its attention today upon its neighbors, Uruguay and Paraguay, where there was a possibility of action independent of the United States.

Twenty-eight clergymen and other leaders issued an appeal yesterday protesting against continued "obliteration" bombings of German cities and calling upon Christians "to examine themselves concerning their participation in this carnival of death" and to acquaint themselves with "the realities of what is being done in our name in Europe."
Revocation of five licenses, the cancellation of eight others and eighteen suspensions were imposed yesterday by the New York State Liquor Authority.
LONDON, March 5 -- A "firm belief" that within a year Allied armies will bring relief to German-accupied countries was expressed today by Mrs. Winston Churchill.

CHICAGO, March 5 -- Whether the United States will have to allocate supplies of wheat during the 1944-45 season depends on the outcome of this year's harvest, grain experts assert. An analysis of the domestic situation made last week suggests that there will be a disappearance of around 1,250,000,000 bushels during the current crop year, after allowing for imports from Canada.

CHICAGO, March 5 -- Prices of oats on the Board of Trade averaged higher last week despite continued expectations that the Office of Price Administration would order a roll-back of the ceiling limits in the immediate future. A scarcity of offerings of cash oats at terminal markets and a fair demand had some effect on sentiment.
LONDON, March 5 -- The stock markets here continue to drift aimlessly with business at its slackest.

The nine-story and penthouse apartment building at 160 West Ninety-fifth Street and the adjoining three-story dwelling at 156 West Ninety-fifth Street have been resold by Ritter Co. to Civic Apartments, Inc., for cash over a first mortgage of $156,959.

Canned fish is regarded in grocery circles as a Lenten specialty, for more of it is sold during this period than at any other time of the year. This season, however, such old favorites as tinned salmon and tuna and shrimp have a discouragingly high value of twelve points a pound, and as consequence consumers are eager to find alternates.

The annual report of the New York Telephone Company, for 1943, issued yesterday by James W. Hubbell, president, shows for the year a net income of $31,700,547, equal to $7.52 a share on the company's outstanding common stock. This compares with $25,358,504, or $6.02 a share, in 1942. Gross operating revenues for the year were $255,518,295, an increase of $18,685,000, or 7.9 per cent, over the year before.

Cotton prices moved irregularly lower last week. At the close of the market Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 6 to 17 points net lower. The greatest losses were recorded in the distant positions.

The Allied Military Government has removed "several thousand ardent Fascists" from civil office and interned many of them in the occupied territory in Italy, John J. McCloy, Assistant Secretary of War, told the closing session of the American Labor Press conference yesterday at the Hotel Park Central.

Representatives of leading Jewish fraternal and benevolent organizations attended yesterday the annual conference of the Council of Organizations of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York in Manhattan Center, Thirty-fourth Street and Eighth Avenue, and pledged themselves to raise $1,000,000 of the $32,000,000 sought for 1944 by the United Jewish Appeal for relief work at home and abroad.

Attorney General Francis Biddle expressed opposition yesterday to proposals to ban all immigration after the war. In an address before the Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society at the Hotel Astor he told 2,500 delegates from religious, labor and fraternal organizations that he believed in restricted immigration after the war, but that an outright ban would not be wise or generous.

ALBANY, March 5 -- The wartime housing emergency in New York State, which was critical for more than three years, has been checked in its major aspects through cooperation of State and Federal Governments with private industry in a large building program, Ira S. Robbins, acting State Housing Commissioner, stated today in his annual report.

LISBON, Portugal, March 5 -- Mass arrests of French Red Cross and other important society people in France have been carried out by occupying authorities within the past few weeks. According to persons arriving with the liberated Americans from French concentration camps as many as 600 persons, including many with formerly influential names, have been arrested in France and deported to Germany since the first of the year.

The strikes in North Italy surpass in scope and violence any labor rising that has taken place so far in the Nazi-controlled factories in France or other occupied countries. They have the proportions of a general strike and something of the force of an insurrection.

With Bruno Walter at the piano, Lotte Lehmann gave a recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall devoted to Schubert's son cycle, "Winterreise." The event attracted a capacity audience, including an overflow of eager listeners filling the stage, and there were prolonged ovations for the conductor and the soprano at the start and conclusion of both halves of the cycle.

LONDON, March 5 (AP) -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, saying that "only a self-disciplined army can win battles," told American forces in Britain tonight that it was vital that they work with the British "both in the fighting service and in civil life on the basis of mutual respect, consideration and cooperation."

PROCESSED FOODS (most canned vegetables, soups, fruits, fruit juices and beans; frozen corn, lima beans and peas; frozen fruits, except frozen apples, applesauce and rhubarb; jam, preserves, marmalade -- except marmalade containing only citrus fruits -- jellies, and fruit butters). Green stamps K, L and M valid through March 20. Blue stamps A8, B8, C8, D8 and E8 in War Book 4 valid through May 20, at 10 points each.

LONDON, Monday, March 6 (U.P.) -- The new drive was announced earlier by Berlin, which said more than 200,000 Russians had attacked southwest of Shepetovka, twenty-three miles from the Polish border. Berlin admitted the Russians had succeeded in breaking through the Nazi lines.
I have read the letter of the Norwegian Ambassador in your issue of Feb. 26 and fully endorse his statement referring to food conditions in German-occupied European countries.
ALGIERS, March 5 (AP) -- A communique:

The American Newspaper Publishers Association warned here last night that remarks concerning the paper industry and the availability of newsprint during the next year made in Washington on Tuesday by Harold Boeschenstein, acting director of the War Production Board Forest Products Bureau, should not be interpreted as a forecast of greater supplies of newsprint for the next six months.
LONDON, March 5 -- Sharp disappointment is felt here over the delay on the part of Finland in accepting the peace terms offered by Russia a week ago.

R.C. Sherriff, author of "Journey's End," has written a new novel, "Chedworth," which will be published by Macmillan. Twentieth Century-Fox will film the book, which is a story of England during the present war.
NEW DELHI, India, March 5 (UP) -- A communique:

The New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children made public yesterday a report in which it blamed city agencies, including the Children's Court, for many of the shortcomings charged against the children's shelter at 2 East 105th Street.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 5 -- Ernst Lubitsch, recently recovered from illness, and Joseph Mankiewicz, now producing "Keys of the Kingdom" for Twentieth Century-Fox, will join efforts to produce two pictures a year for the company.

ALGIERS, March 5 -- The trial of Pierre Pucheu, which began yesterday, is expected to reveal tomorrow the details of the accusations, which were indicated only in general terms in the formal indictment.

DETROIT, March 5 -- The whole problem of reconstruction and reconversion from war to peace production, whenever it may come and whether it comes all at once or gradually, is likely to be particularly emphasized in Detroit, because the automotive industry is one of those which had to be completely converted to war, unlike some war industries which are merely making more of their peacetime products.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, March 6 -- Further battles appeared imminent in the Admiraly Islands as reports were received that the Japanese were sending reinforcements to Los Negros Island, where elements of the dismounted First Cavalry Division defending captured Momote airfield inflicted a smashing defeat on the enemy Friday night. Sea Eagle harbor and tried to eliminate carefully placed batteries protecting the harbor.

B.L. Weaver has been elected a vice president of the American Wire Fabrics Corporation, subsidiary of the Wickwire Spencer Steel Company. Mr. Weaver for the past two years had been associated with the War Production Board as chief of the Steel Casting Section.

Defeating the Kearny Celtics by 3 to 0, the Brooklyn Hispanos, holders of the National Challenge Cup, emblematic of soccer supremacy, once more won the Eastern Division final before a thrilled crowd of 4,000 fans in glorious soccer weather at Starlight Park yesterday.

LONDON, March 5 (U.P.) -- The Sunday Chronicle reported today that the German General Staff had begun planning for a new war twenty-five years from now in which the United States would be "the principal adversary."

Passage of the Transit Authority Bill now before the Legislature would be a long and realistic step toward taking New York's subways out of politics and giving the public the service to which it is entitled. Our subway problem has become a civic headache. It has now reached a stage so acute that it must be solved.

" Thank You, Svoboda," in which Sam Jaffe had the stellar role, gave its sixth and final performance Saturday night at the Mansfield, where it had its premiere on Wednesday night under the sponsorship of Milton Baron. Laid in a Czechoslovak town of 1939 during the Hitler occupation, the H.S. Kraft dramatization of John Pen's novel, "You Can't Do That to Svoboda," attempted to show how the meek react when stepped upon.

The New York City Defense Recreation Committee, 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street), through the generosity of the entertainment world offers a partial list of free amusements available today. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M., evening tickets after 4 P.M. Apply 99 Park Avenue for tickets.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 5 -- German naval circles predict that the allocation of Italian warships to Russia will make her a permanent factor in the Mediterranean and that the Allies' reported action is tantamount to a renunciation of British control in that area and the abandonment of a critical empire link.

The opening of a newly decorated reading and writing room for the patients of Halloran General Hospital, Staten Island, has drawn attention to the extensive volunteer work which professional interior decorators are contributing to the men and women in the armed forces.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, March 6 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Representative Andrew J. May of Kentucky said today that a threat by the House Military Committee to "expose the motive behind this book" had blocked Army distribution of a pamphlet which he said described Northern Negroes as the equals in intelligence of Southern white men.

Ministers in Protestant churches west of Central Park, taking part for the second year in a United Lenten Preaching Mission, delivered sermons yesterday on "The Sin of Privilege Without Responsibility."

LONDON, March 5 -- Netherland engineers here are weighing with the utmost care the chances and consequences of the flooding of the Netherlands by the Nazis. They have come to the conclusion that it can be carried out with relative ease and once done will cripple their country for years.

MOSCOW, March 5 -- After having completed an eight-day tour covering about 1,500 miles across territory liberated from the Germans during the past six months, this writer was impressed with the way in which the Russians had restored communications in those areas.

LONDON, Monday, March 6 -- Two hundred passengers were given a nightmare trip last night when the engineer of a British train went mad, beat off all efforts to keep him from the controls and carried his train past every danger signal on a seven-mile stretch of track.

The one-story factory and office building on a-plot 200 by 100 feet at 1181-87 Randall Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by the Manhattan Savings Bank to the Realty Dealers Company for investment through Ralph P. Obedin Co. It is assessed at $32,000.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- Deadlocked over the question of allowing the Controller General to have a voice on the amounts to be paid to contractors under terminated war contracts, a House military subcommittee returned the ssue today to the full committee.

GULFPORT, Miss., March 5 (AP) -- Harold (Jug) McSpaden of Philadelphia fired a three-under-par 68 in the final round today to win first place in the $4,500 Gulfport open golf tournament. Sammy Byrd, winner of the New Orleans open last Monday, was second with a four-round total of 282, six strokes above McSpaden.

Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, gangster chieftain, and Emanuel (Mendy) Weiss, one of his henchmnen who was electrocuted with him Saturday night for murder, found a common resting ground yesterday. They were buried within half an hour of each other in Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, Queens, in the late afternoon.

Age comes on, health grows more uncertain. Coeval friends pass, in the old-fashioned phrase, to their reward. There may even be money worries. But one singular benefit accrues to people grown old enough to be grandparents, and should suffice to assuage all grief.
It's pretty late for Mr. Gilbert to apologize. It may be true still in his tight little island that:

ALBANY, March 5 -- There will be no final action on the question of additional State aid for education until the closing days of the legislative session, it became apparent today after notice that the special report to the Legislature on the effect of the reductions forced by strict application of the Friedsam formula will not be available until "late this week."
WITH THE U.S. FLEET in the Central Pacific, Feb. 26(Delayed) (U.P.) -- Three Army artillerymen, through no fault of their own, are among the few soldiers who have witnessed the fleet in action.

At a moment when the pressing problems of eastern Europe burden relations between Russia and the Western Allies President Roosevelt has announced that in accordance with the terms of Italy's surrender Russia is to get an equal share in the Italian fleet together with the United States and Great Britain, and that Marshal Stalin is inquiring about the details of the division of more than 100 naval vessels now doing duty on the Allied side.

Women, even if they are not the sole support of themselves and their families, should not give up their jobs after the war, a majority of eighty-one members of the Advertising Women of New York believe, according to a poll taken to determine what women feel their contribution to the future should be.

The lively plaids and gay stripes of cottons dyed and hand woven in Guatemala are to be seen in interesting variety among the new casual clothes for summer. Their brilliant colorings have been used in practical young dresses for summer town wear, as well as sturdy playclothes for the country.

The Ankara radio deplored yesterday what it called the bitter comment of the British press on the turn in Turkish-British relations and expressed concern whether it was designed to bring pressure on Turkey.

Warning that there was "perhaps no such impervious selfishness as that which shelters itself behind an apparent devotion to high ideals," Dean Hughell E.W. Fosbroke of the General Episcopal Theological Seminary declared in a sermon yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine that people should not slip into mental ruts, but should develop the ability of exploration.

LONDON, March 5 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav Partisan troops have destroyed the Italo-Yugoslav border railway station at Rakek, on the vital Nazi traffic line to Trieste and Fiume, while the converted fishing fleet of Marshal Tito (Josip Broz) is attacking enemy communications off the Dalmatian coast, a headquarters communique announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- A study of thirty-six canneries in New York State and twenty-one in New Jersey has convinced research officials of the Federal Women's Bureau today that the employment of migrant labor in canneries should be a last resort in order to avoid community and industry disruption.

The New York Central Railroad carried last year more passengers and moved more freight more miles than in any previous year, F.E. Williamson, president, said in the annual report to stockholders, issued for publication today. As a result, he said, operating revenues were at the record level of $706,124,833, compared with $593,666,096 in 1942.

A recommendation that a commission proposed by Governor Dewey to study post-war plans for veterans include consideration of how to give to veterans "preference in public employment" without impairing "technical and other services of the State" was made yesterday by the State Charities Aid Association, according to The Associated Press.
Two one-story buildings at Broadway and Twenty-third Street, in Long Island City, were leased by I. Miller Sons through the Cross Brown Company.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- The Aluminum Company of America was commended today in a report of the Senate's Truman Committee for its swift response to critical early wartime needs for aluminum by using its own funds for expansion.

Night baseball, which will receive a big boost in the American League this year, also will see a substantial increase in the National League, for the official 1944 schedule, released for publication today, shows that a total of ninety-one nocturnal engagements will be played in the Ford Frick circuit next summer.

PEARL HARBOR, March 5 (AP) -- Heavy bombers of the Seventh Army Air Force and Fleet Air Wing Two, in new sweeps over the Central Pacific, concentrated twenty-three tons of high explosives on Ponape and also pounded Kusaie Island, the Navy disclosed today.

It is unfortunate that Congress was prevented from repealing the program of subsidies demanded by organized labor. For subsidies are nothing more or less than the shifting of a part of your grocery bill to future taxpayers with added costs of administration. Subsidies cannot reduce living costs by subterfuge.

Friends of France gathered yesterday at the French Episcopal Church (Eglise du Saint-Esprit), 109 East Sixtieth Street, to celebrate the 316th anniversary of the first sermon in French preached in New Amsterdam and to congratulate the rector, the Rev. Dr. John A.F. Maynard, on the completion of his forty years in the ministry, thirty years in the United States and twenty years as rector of his present church.

Since the beginning of the war tens of thousands of the foreign-born among us have hastened to become Americans. Our naturalization courts have been busy places; too busy at times to make the ceremony impressive. The taking of the oath of allegiance is soon over; the address of welcome may be perfunctory.

THIS war is only four and a half years old, but Quentin Reynolds has already written six books about it. The star correspondent for Collier's magazine is, as his publishers say with exact truth, "one of America's favorite reporters." His extraordinary gifts as a mixer and genial hail-fellow-well-met have won him a host of friends both obscure and illustrious all the way from Belfast to Teheran.

A program dedicated to the memory of Lorenz Hart was given last night to a capacity audience at the Majestic Theatre. Sponsored by the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers and the American Theatre Wing, the event realized a total of $5,980 for the Armed Forces Master Records, Inc., which supplies service men with recorded musical libraries.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 5 -- E.W. (Skip) Etchells, who came back from the West Coast early in the winter and resumed dinghy racing at the Larchmont Yacht Club, has been climbing the scoring ladder steadily, and today about went over the top by winning four of six contests with his craft, Sno Fun.
LONDON, March 5 (UP) -- A Russian communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman last night opened the fourth season of dance repertory in their Studio Theatre at 108 West Sixteenth Street before an audience that packed the little auditorium to the doors and remained long after the final curtain to applaud.

LONDON, March 5 (U.P.) -- The explosion of the new British six-ton blockbuster is so terrific that it rocks a plane several thousand feet above the target and illuminates the sky with the brilliance of daylight, Royal Air Force fliers who have dropped the new bomb reported today.
Recently your delightful comment about a wood stove lamented that poems have not been written about it. Poems may not have been published; that's hardly proof, though, that none have been written.

The preliminary report for 1943 of the Baldwin Locomotive Works, for publication today, shows an estimated net profit of $5,073,458 for the year after a deduction of $26,600,000 to provide for renegotiation and taxes on income. The net is equivalent, after dividend payments on the preferred stock, to $3.85 each on the 1,274,152 common shares outstanding on Dec. 31.

The churches must rise above "sectarian priorities" if they are to do their share in preventing and combatting juvenile delinquency, members of the Protestant Teachers Association were told by the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman at their annual service yesterday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Senators still picking hardtack from their bridgework agreed today that the Army's K-ration is good solid eating.

It would be difficult to measure the limits to the debt that the country owes the men now fighting in the armed services. But there are right ways and wrong ways of paying this debt. It will not help the veterans if proposals ostensibly for their benefit are of such a nature as to undermine the efficiency of Government service or to injure the general welfare.

CHICAGO, March 5 -- The movement of cash corn to terminal markets fell off sharply last week as the result of continued damp and mild weather which is reported to be hampering shelling operations. Much of the grain sold previously for deferred shipment has been moved out of country elevators despite the scarcity of box cars, and no material increase in receipts is anticipated until there is a betterment in weather conditions.

Scoring three goals in the final period, the Brooklyn Crescents succeeded in holding the New York Rovers to a tie in their Eastern Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden yesterday. The Manhattan sextet assumed a top-heavy lead midway in the battle, but could not stem Brooklyn's strong closing rush, and the teams had to be content with a draw, 8 to 8.

James S. Carson's recent letter in THE TIMES on post-war rehabilitation reflects a fortunately steady growth of opinion against sending an army of foreign school teachers to post-war Germany to re-educate that country. The writer intimates that a country must "run its own schools," but he offers no practical suggestion as to how or what part of the German people shall do this "running."

This, so far as the regular college basketball campaign is concerned, will be mop-up week. The final double-header of the season at Madison Square Garden Wednesday night and a few scattered games here and there are all that remain before the big post-season tournaments get under way.

PITTSBURGH, March 5 -- Raw steel output last week was estimated at 97 1/2 per cent of rated capacity, up 1 point from a revised figure for the previous week. Output in the latter period was revised downward 1 point, because of steel losses resulting from outlaw strikes at Detroit and Pittsburgh.
Mrs. Theodore E. Brown and her son-in-law and daughter, Lieut. George P. Sturgis, Medical Corps, USNR, and Mrs. Sturgis, have come from Boston to the Ritz-Carlton.

The Mexican furniture that has been trickling into the New York stores in small shipments for the last few months has now arrived in sufficient quantity to furnish some all-Mexican rooms. A living room designed to fill the requirements of a one-room apartment and a Mexican dining room have just been opened at Altman's.

Several of the score or more of shows this week in the art galleries have been arranged as benefits. One for the Red Cross 1944 Fund, "Stars of Yesterday and Today," opens with a preview tomorrow evening at the Wildenstein Galleries and to the public on Wednesday.
MIAMI, Fla., March 5 (AP) -- Twenty-three persons were reported injured tonight at Pompano in a collision between a passenger train carrying northbound tourists from Miami and a freight train.

Mayor La Guardia tossed into the laps of the Democratic and Republican leaders in the city and at Albany yesterday the proposal of the Committee of Fifteen for a ten-cent fare on the subway, elevated, street car and bus lines owned and operated by the city.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices was 112.72, a decrease of 0.1 per cent from the previous week's level of 112.85. The raw-materials index dropped 0.3 per cent and the farm-products index decreased 0.5 per cent.

Asserting that atheism had almost completely disappeared during this war, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, said yesterday that this represented a remarkable religious phenomenon "occurring, as it does, in the midst of a savage and universal war."

Challenging statements that the New York metropolitan area was faring worse than the average industrial community in employment opportunities, the Regional Plan Association made public a report yesterday showing that the region had made a slightly better showing in its trend of industrial employment in the ten years before the war, than the rest of the nation.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Indefinite postponement of action by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on the resolution that would put the Senate on record as favoring continued Jewish immigration to Palestine appeared tonight as the probable result of objections raised by Gen. George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff.
LONDON, March 5 (UP) -- A Ger man communique, as broadcast from Berlin:

A charge that "paid publicity agents" had exaggerated children's scribblings into a "phantom of anti-Semitic hate for the deliberate besmirching of the minority Catholic population of this area" was made yesterday by Bishop J. Francis A. McIntyre.

BUENOS AIRES, March 4 (Delayed) -- The Chilean Government's recognition of the Argentine regime of Gen. Edelmiro Farrell was received with joy today in official circles, who regard it as destroying any possibility that the American republics may present a united front toward Argentina in the same way as they did toward Bolivia last January.

A gloomy forecast of the postwar world, with World War III following the present conflict by perhaps twenty-five years, during which religion will be under attack by "a secularized, technical scientific propagandized barbarism," was made by Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the Catholic University of America, who preached a Lenten sermon yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Charles J. Solomon and Mrs. Benjamin Golder of Philadelphia won the Eastern States contract bridge mixed-pair championship and the George Reith Memorial Trophy at the Park Central Hotel last night, bringing to a close the tournament that has been in progress since Saturday, Feb. 26.

What will be the effect, when the war is over, of the removal of the present nation-wide thirty-five-mile-an-hour top speed limitation on the highways? Some interesting answers to that question have been reported to the Michigan State Highways Conference by Harold F. Hammond, director of the traffic and transportation division of the National Conservation Bureau.

CHICAGO, March 5 -- Material improvement in the demand for cash lard is expected in the next week or two as the result of the announcement by the Office of Price Administration that ration points will not be required this month for that commodity.

With reduced activity, financial markets alternately declined and advanced last week. No important change was apparent. Taken by itself, the forward movement of our Army in the Far East might have been reflected in the market; but the situation in Italy was not liked, the Nazi troops evidently holding our armies to a stalemate.

Stocking-up by retailers on handbag and jewelry items to meet an anticipated beat-the-tax buying rush by consumers was noted in the wholesale markets here last week. Numerous buyers were reported at the gift show. In the better coat and suit market requests have been heavy for dressy box coats.
LONDON, March 5 -- German and Japanese diplomats and "consular agents" in the various neutral countries on the fringe of Europe are causing the Allies considerable concern.

The success of recent operations in the Pacific and victories in Russia and in the air war have been somewhat offset, particularly in recent weeks, by our slow progress in Italy and in Burma and, above all, by what is best described as an international political situation "in flux."

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The Office of Defense Transportation outlined today a nationwide program to keep essential truck transportation operating, despite a mounting shortage of vehicles, through systematized and economical replacement of major worn-out parts and component units of parts.

CHICAGO, March 6 -- Additional precipitation in the winter Wheat Belt over the week-end and a lack of aggressive buying led some professional traders who bought wheat futures late last week to reverse their position in the market today on the Board of Trade and the market quickly developed an easy undertone.

Seven hundred and fifty thousand pupils and 40,000 teachers of the New York public school system halted their normal school work from 1:30 to 2 P.M. yesterday to listen to a radio broadcast over station WMCA that opened a campaign to raise $250,000 toward the $22,386,000 Red Cross 1944 War Fund of Greater New York.

James V. Mulholland, director of recreation for the Park Department since 1922, was appointed yesterday by Mayor La Guardia as a Justice of the Domestic Relations Court to preside over the new school part that will be held in school buildings to handle truancy cases.

The five-story structure known as the Shakespeare Apartments at 6049-55 Boulevard East, West New York, N.J., has been sold by the Boulevard East Realty Corporation (Felix Neumann) to the Shakespeare Apartments, Inc. (Jacob Drogin).

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Spokesmen for two major Government agencies, the Maritime Commission and the General Accounting Office, told a Senate group today that they recognized evils in the cost-plus-fixed-fee type of Government contract for war goods but could not agree with a proposal to eliminate arbitrarily all contracts of this type.

Intimations that the War Production Board will give consideration to resumption of the use of steel and iron in toys to save lumber and manpower was a major topic of discussion yesterday at the opening of the American Toy Fair at the Hotel McAlpin.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, March 7 -- The Soviet High Command announced last night that Marshal Gregory K. Zhukoff's troops of the First Ukrainian Front had smashed across the vital Odessa-Lwow railway and occupied a twenty-mile stretch of it between Proskurov and Tarnopol.

CHUNGKING, China, March 6 (AP) -- American Mitchells of the Fourteenth Air Force, escorted by fighters, destroyed from thirty to fifty enemy aircraft in the air and on the ground in a raid on Kingshan airdrome in the northern part of Hainan Island Saturday, a communique from General Stilwell's headquarters said today.

The Empress of Japan observed her forty-first birthday yesterday "in the best of health" as the Tokyo radio used the occasion to call on "Japanese women and girls on the home front" to "again pledge faithfulness in labor service to the nation."

A day or two ago I read a news item quoting the views of one Richard Frankensteen, a union official of the UAW, in which he is said to advocate a thirty-hour week after the war for the members of his union, with an accompanying increase in the wage rate so that his union's members would receive as much pay for thirty hours of labor as they had been receiving for forty hours.

A dispute over the manner of recording "surplus" has arisen between the committee on audit of the board of directors of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. and Arthur Andersen Co., independent auditors, the annual report for 1943, issued yesterday, disclosed.

Although Vinton Freedley made a valiant attempt to keep "Jackpot" on the boards, he decided yesterday to close the musical at the Alvin on Saturday night. It will be the second song-and-dance piece to end its Broadway run on that day.

LONDON, March 6 -- The day-long and night-long aerial campaign against the heart of Germany has started. The time of what was once called air "raids" is past; the day of the cautious daylight air battles on the fringe of Germany is passing; the Allied army of the air has started a campaign of attrition against the Luftwaffe which must be recognized as one of the decisive military campaigns of the war.

Hugh Byas, in his letter to THE TIMES published on Feb. 24, expresses the opinion that the ouster of the Chiefs of Staff of the army and navy in Japan "means the end of a policy" -- i.e., the end of the policy of waiting to use the main fleet until American lines of naval force are stretched thin enough to be assailable with assurance of victory.

The sum and substance of the first concert by the orchestra called the New York City Symphony, given last night in the New York City Center of Music and Drama, is that Leopold Stokowski, performing without pay, directed an ensemble hastily compounded of young players and veterans -- both men and women -- of the leading orchestras and theatre organizations of the land in a simply magnificent manner.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The Army-Navy Production pennant E has been awarded to the following concerns and plants:

ALGIERS, March 6 -- Lessening German thunder still muttered on the beachhead below Rome in the period that ended at noon yesterday as the Germans flung another small attack at the American positions near Cisterna.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 6 (AP) -- E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., produced 18 per cent more military explosives in 1943 than in 1942 with a manpower increase of only 3 per cent, the company's annual report to stockholders for 1943 -- largest year in sales volume in the company's history -- disclosed today.
CHICAGO, March 6 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The Ways and Means Committee gave "special consideration" today to a plan designed to arrange the present withholding tax in a fashion to eliminate for an estimated 30,000,000 taxpayers with incomes of not more than $5,000 a year the necessity of filing the regular income tax return.

J.K. Newman Jr., president of Investment Associates, Inc., addressed a letter yesterday to the stockholders of Byrndun Corporation, which owns 40 per cent of the shares of Hat Corporation of America, seeking proxies for the election of a new board of directors and management of Byrndun at its annual meeting on March 15.

Decorative possibilities of the spring chintzes in ensembles of harmonizing curtains, bedspreads, dinette table cloths, chair covers, and even fabric wall decorations are presented in the newly opened Victoria Shop, at Bamberger's Newark.

BALTIMORE, March 6 (AP) -- The Government withdrew without explanation today charges against five men in connection with a reported $1,000,000 war-contract fraud at Triumph Explosives, Inc., an Elkton, Md., munitions firm.

LONDON, Tuesday, March 7 -- The war in the air reached a new and perhaps decisive phase yesterday when about 800 American heavy bombers fought their way through the massed strength of the Germans' metropolitan air force to blast factories, airfields and other military installations in the Berlin area.

By the simple device of having five hats of identical fabric in as many colors and designs appear on the runway one after the other, Franklin Simon's millinery department demonstrated yesterday the wide range of choice now available.

TRENTON, N.J., March 6 -- The New Jersey Legislature began today the general reorganization of the State Government demanded by Gov. Walter E. Edge, passing a bill in both houses to create a new State department of law which will absorb all present uncoordinated legal agencies.

The National Dairy Products Corporation transacted last year the largest volume of business in its history with sales reaching $580,173,000, an increase of $17,722,000 over 1942, L.A. Van Bomel, president, declared in his annual report to stockholders issued for publication today.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- The oil industry White Paper suggested that "if the United States is legitimately concerned" about the future availability of Middle East oil, there should be a clarification of "what nations are expected to be bound to us as allies in the next war," what nations prospectively will participate in collective security and what world areas this country will be called upon to police in the interest of peace.

Amendments to the price regulation for raw furs, proposed by the Office of Price Administration, are unacceptable to dealers because they continue "multiple ceilings" and fail to reflect the historic procedure in the industry, Isidore Bergner, of the Ullman-Allied Company, and head of the Fur Brokers Association, said yesterday following a meeting of the organization at the Hotel Governor Clinton.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 6 -- Wednesday morning at 8 o'clock was set today by the new Fascist authorities and German labor commissioners as the deadline for the return to work of 6,000,000 striking or locked out employes of north Italy, idle since Thursday.

The 80-year-old system of butter and egg distribution of the New York metropolitan area is jeopardized by the city's rigid enforcement of Office of Price Administration regulations through the Magistrates' Courts, Sidney Schwartz, counsel for 200 jobbers organized as the Butter and Egg Merchants Association, declared yesterday as he appealed for relief to the New York State War Council.

Fifty Chinese-American school children heard yesterday the New York dentist who is credited with influencing the course of modern China's history read the last will of the founder of the Chinese Republic, Dr. Sun Yat-sen.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The Office of Price Administration today ordered producers and distributors of anthracite coal to make the customary discounts for cash payment available to buyers even when shipments are of emergency nature and ordered by the Solid Fuels Administrator for War.

PHILADELPHIA, March 6 -- The six holding companies in the New England Power Association system filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a comprehensive plan of simplification and reorganization designed to meet the require ments of the commission order of last March 17 under the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

PHILADELPHIA, Mar. 6 -- The Capital Transit Company of Washington asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for an exemption from the competitive bidding rules in connection with a tentatively contemplated issue of $16,000,000 of twenty-year 4 per cent first mortgage bonds.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission today ordered the Montana Power Company to produce Cornelius F. Kelley, chairman of the board of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company, to testify at a hearing in Butte regarding the account of the power concern.

Tribute to achievements of Soviet and American women on the home and battle fronts was paid by speakers last night at a meeting in Carnegie Hall under auspices of the committee of women of the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship.

The city and county Employes Retirement System of San Francisco announces that it will be in the market tomorrow with several blocks of California municipal bonds, aggregating $4,902,800. These bonds have been held in the system's investment portfolio and do not constitute new financing.

TRENTON, N.J., March 6 (AP) -- Republican Governor Walter E. Edge today accused Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, State Democratic chieftain, of trying to thwart adoption of a new Constitution by making the issue a political one.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- President Roosevelt is reported to have informed William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, today that the Congress of Industrial Organizations will have to be represented in the top delegation at the meeting of the International Labor Office in Philadelphia on April 20.

LONDON, March 6 -- The American air attack on Berlin today was the direct responsibility of about a quarter of a million men who shared the burden of mounting the assault at airfields in this country and fighting the battle over the enemy capital.

WASHINGTON, 1V[arch 6 {PPI -A general court martial has beeni ordered to try three officers of the Army Air Forces on charges of neglect of duty in the inspection of airplane engines produced at the Wright Aeronautical Plant at Lockland, Ohio.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 6 -- Jean Arthur, Charles Coburn and Lee Bowman will be starred in "The Impatient Years," a comedy of a discharged soldier and his bride, on which Columbia plans to begin production Monday. Virginia VanUpp, who wrote the story, will be the associate producer, and Irving Cummings will direct.

While more waste paper was salvaged last month in the city than in January, it was still not enough to meet the needs of mills in the metropolitan area, and the receipts by mills elsewhere in the country dropped alarmingly. National and local leaders of the paper conservation campaign appealed yesterday to the public for more cooperation.

A plan of recapitalization for the United Gas Corporation, an important unit in the Electric Bond and Share Company system, was filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission as a step toward compliance with the simplification provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

Assistant District Attorney Jacob Grumet yesterday notified Edward V. Broderick, counsel for Wayne Lonergan, that he would ask Judge John A. Mullen in General Sessions tomorrow for another blue-ribbon panel of talesmen to try Lonergan on the first-degree murder indictment in thee death of his wife, Patricia Burton Lonergan.

MOSCOW, March 6 -- Pravda published today a Tass news agency interview with Eric A. Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, who expects to come here in May or June for a discussion of post-war trade possibilities between the United States and the Soviet Union, which he regards as extremely favorable.

Nine leading merchants and processors of waste paper, including the National Gypsum Company, Newburgh, N.Y., and the Cornwall Paper Mills, Inc., Cornwall, N.Y., were accused yesterday of violating regulations of the Office of Price Administration. The charges were incorporated in ten criminal informations filed in Federal Court by United States Attorney James B.M. McNally.

LONDON, March 6 -- The United States and Great Britain, two of the foremost exponents of aerial warfare in the world, have now proved their ability to bomb Berlin by day and by night without crippling losses. The question that must be answered this year is whether this sort of strategic bombing is more important in modern warfare than tactical bombing closely allied with land operations.

The honor of opening the seventh annual national invitation tournament at Madison Square Garden on March 16 has fallen to St. John's and Bowling Green, according to an announcement made yesterday by Director Ned Irish at the Basketball Writers' luncheon at Toots Shor's.

MEXICO CITY, March 6 -- Plans to develop guayule and tree rubber in Mexico on a scale large enough to meet more of the needs of the United States were disclosed today by William H. Mason of the General Tire and Rubber Company.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 6 (AP) -- Reliable Cairo sources said today the Turkish Government had flatly refused to enter the war or grant bases to the Allies except on complete delivery of a huge volume of war materials which would require months to ship and prepare for use.

A few days ago our dismounted cavalrymen swept over the Momote airfield on Los Negros Island. What then began only as a reconnaissance in force is now developing into one of the bitterest battles of the South Seas.

CHICAGO, March 6 (AP) -- Prospective losses of trained railroad personnel because of decisions of some officials administering the Selective Service Act are alarming, E.J. Engel, president of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway Company, said today.
LONDON, March 6 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Wheat is in tight supply -- a fact that is common knowledge in the trade but news to the average consumer, who has been educated to the belief that all grains are superabundant. There is no danger that it will become so scarce that bread or flour will be rationed; in fact, millers and bakers queried by this column scoff at the possibility of such a thing coming to pass.

It has been said, "There is no one farther from home than a prisoner of war." That has never been truer than in this war, which draws the soldier, the sailor, the flier to the far ends of the earth and leaves him stranded and captive in a strange land. The situation of such a lad is no more helpless than that of his home folks.
