RIVERSIDE, Calif., March 6 (AP) -- Second Lieut. Beaufort G. Swancutt, 31 years old, of Lacrosse, Wis., suddenly drew his pistol at an officers' club party late last night, and killed three persons and wounded five others before he was critically wounded by police bullets.

The Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad Company in the period from November, 1942, through Feb. 15 last acquired at a cost of $13,789,083 a total of $26,176,500 of its mortgage bonds, according to Matthew S. Sloan, chairman and president, in the annual report for 1943. The purchase of these bonds, he said, has reduced fixed charges at the rate of $1,234,995 annually, or 29.8 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Military personnel and civilians traveling in the vicinity of Norfolk, Va., on essential business are reasonably assured now of finding hotel accommodations there despite the city's wartime congestion, the War Production Board reported today.

Anne O'Hare McCormick spotlighted a most vital problem in her column in THE NEW YORK TIMES Feb. 28 when she gathered from the witnesses of the now freed Americans that "we produce no psychological block-busters" in our warfare against Germany.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- Tom C. Clark, assistant attorney general, protested a Circuit Court ruling today before the Supreme Court, which, he said, would allow labor union officials "to hide behand the cloak of their union" and permit them "to frustrate grand jury inquiries."

The creation of an unnecessary increase in the risk element of business by unstable legislation and the delegation by Congress of many powers to various administrative agencies were cited yesterday by C. Donald Dallas, president, Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., as a fundamental factor "which may fetter the revival of the free enterprise system after the war."

Activity in low-priced public utility issues continued yesterday to spark the trading on the stock market while values edged forward slightly. Best quotations of the session, which averaged major fractions with a few isolated changes up to more than 3 points, were shaded in the final hour, but the emphasis still remained on the better side.

Government orders for wool yardage at the end of 1943 were at the lowest level of any quarterly period reported since the middle of 1941, the National Association of Wool Manufacturers reported yesterday. Such orders comprised 29 per cent of all unfilled orders by reporting mills, as against 71 per cent at the beginning of 1943.

A UNITED STATES BOMBER BASE, in England, March 6 -- Flying Fortress crewmen that Lieut. Col. Robert S. Kittel of Colorado Springs, Col., and Maj. Earl D. "Swede" Carlson of West Newton, Mass., led out of this station today in an attack on Berlin returned with three impressions -- all of which augur well for the continued destruction of the Reich capital.

A preview of the American-British Goodwill Exhibition will be held this evening from 9 to 11 at the Grand central (Terminal) Galleries. The show will open to the public tomorrow and remain through March 18. Proceeds are to be divided equally between the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy and the Artists for Victory.

A lively array of shoe fashions that revealed no hampering effect of Government restrictions was presented by Delman yesterday. Urbane as the spring tailleur for which they are intended was a group of highly polished classics in russet calfskin, all made with the extended sole for durability.

When the first eastbound El train left Park Row via Brooklyn Bridge in the early summer of 1898 its destination was the Borough of Brooklyn. It was a novel name then and so remained for some time to come. Only a few months earlier it was still the city of Brooklyn, but on the first of the year Greater New York had come into existence.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

DETROIT, March 6 -- Predicting a $250,000,000,000 national debt if the war continues another two years, Harold G. Moulton, president of the Brookings Institute, said that recovery of America's fiscal stability depended on the ability of industry to provide 7,000,000 more jobs than were available at the time of Pearl Harbor, in order to increase peacetime production 20 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- In planning to finance a 1,000-mile pipeline from the Persian Gulf to the Eastern Mediterranean the United States Government is using "the Fascist approach" to scuttle free American enterprise, the Petroleum Industry War Council declared today in what it called a White Paper.

Reflecting late flurries of hedge selling, which produced easiness in the distant positions, cotton prices were mixed yesterday. At the close of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts were down 2 to up 3 points, and about midway between their highs and lows for the day.

Acting on advice from Mayor La Guardia that "optimistic reports to the contrary, the city is facing an emergency situation in the purchase of beef for its institutions," the Board of Estimate at a special meeting yesterday morning authorized Albert Pleydell, Commissioner of Purchase, to contract for the services of the Chicago order buyer concern of Moog Greenwald to buy meat to be custom slaughtered for city institutions.

A diamond more than an inch long, once the property of the Queen of Spain, was brought to public notice yesterday by the action of a tailor who said the gem had been given to him in payment of a $196 bill by Paul E. Flato, former New York jeweler, now in Sing Sing.

" WHAT'S in a name?" sayeth W. Shakespeare. And then he goes on to philosophize that a rose by any other name, etcetera. The Phils have acquired no new redolence by changing their nickname to Blue Jays, although it must be admitted that the new label has infinitely more flare, color and appeal than the old cigar-like sound of Phillies.

The men gallantly stepped aside from their play yesterday in the Eastern indoor singles tennis championship at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street, and let the ladies have their say. So the latter began their title play, with five first-round matches.

ALBANY, March 6 -- Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein ruled today that District Attorney John T. Delaney, because of Governor Dewey's order superseding him in the investigation of alleged crime in Albany County, could not act on the complaint of Sonny Jones, Albany Negro, that he was beaten and kicked by State investigators and suspended from a window on the twenty-ninth floor of the State Office Building.

A preview of the college stars of tomorrow will be on display at Madison Square Garden during the next two days as eight of the city's crack schoolboy quintets see action in the quarter-final round of the annual Public Schools Athletic League championship tournament.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- President Roosevelt, acting under authority of a Congressional resolution, issued today a proclamation designating Sunday, May 21, as "I Am an American Day," a public occasion for giving "special recognition to all of our citizens who have attained their majority or have been naturalized during the past year."

Your editorial on Declamation Day winds up with a rhetorical question with regard to the seventy stanzas of eight lines which Macaulay wrote of "Horatius": "Did any human boy learn or speak the whole of it?"

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 6 (AP) -- Merrill Kenneth Wolf, 12-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Herbert Wolf, lawyer, of Cleveland, who spoke a complete sentence at the age of 4 months, has entered Yale, the youngest student on record.
ALBANY, March 6 -- A decision to kill a series of proposed changes in the State's labor laws has been reached by the legislative leaders, it was disclosed tonight.

Godey's Lady's Book came to life yesterday as the Brooklyn Woman's Club at 114 Pierrepont Street, second oldest woman's club in the country, celebrated its seventy-fifth birthday. Harking back to the days of its inception in 1869, its members, from the current president, Mrs. H.S. Rasi, to octogenarians, reacted its history in a pageant written by one of its past presidents, Dr. Cornelia C. Brant.
NEW DELHI, India, March 6 (UP) -- A communique:

The Book Clinic of the American Institute of Graphic Arts has named four books as its March selections, chosen on the basis of purposeful typographic design and excellence of production. The titles are "A Bell for Adano," by John Hersey (Knopf); "God's Front Porch," by Ketti Frings (Morrow); "Reunion on Strawberry Hill," by Berenice Thorpe (Knopf), and "The Life and Death of Little Jo," by Robert Bright (Doubleday, Doran).

Inasmuch as recent drastic curtailments in the allocations of textiles for export cut across long-planned import programs begun under the Foreign Economic Administration's predecessors, the new textile export program has caused the invalidation of a great number of import permits and will necessitate an increased amount of paper work for a smaller amount of trade, exporters stated yesterday.
The Tuesday communique from Allied Headquarters in the southwest Pacific as reported by the Office of War Information:

ALGIERS, March 6 -- Today's events at the trial of Pierre Pucheu seemed to indicate that the prosecution -- to judge by the ardent pleas made by three of its principal witnesses -- hoped that the military court would convict the former Minister of the Interior of Vichy because the Council of Resistance inside France had already condemned him to death and ordered his execution.

The Truman Committee has added its voice to those of Mr. Baruch and of Senator George's Committee on Post-War Economic Policy and Planning in emphasizing the important role to be played by the private enterprise system in the post-war period. The committee's position is summarized as follows: "Even in wartime it was the flow of private initiative that made possible the success of the war program.

NEW DELHI, India, March 6 -- American infantry units, in action for the first time on the Asiatic continent, have opened an attack in northern Burma under the direction of Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, who swore he would get even with the Japanese for the "hell of a beating" they gave him two years ago.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Jonathan Daniels, an administrative assistant to President Roosevelt, will appear for questioning tomorrow before the Senate Agriculture Subcommittee investigating the Rural Electrification Administration.
PITTSBURGH, March 6 (AP) -- The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company today revealed in its report for 1943 that last year's output was the greatest in the history of the company.

Jimmy Herbert, veteran N.Y.U. star now performing under the colors of the Grand Street Boys Club, will seek his third victory in the Casey 600, one of the features of the Knights of Columbus games to be run off at Madison Square Garden Saturday night.

Acceptance of a $1,000 bribe, admitted by Herman Van Cleef, 50 years old, a former investigator for the Office of Price Administration, brought him yesterday a prison term of a year and a day from Federal Judge John C. Knox. Van Cleef had received the money from a wholesale butcher.

Total admitted assets of the Hartford Fire Insurance Company at the end of 1943 were $147,098,084, an increase of $13,456,305 for the year, according to the annual report issued yesterday. Surplus to policyholders was $5,000,000 higher at $77,000,000.

" The manicure table," says a local authority on the care of hands, "has become a sort of repair shop for broken nails, torn cuticles and other results of wartime abuse." This repair work, she adds, is well within the scope of the competent manicurist, but most of it would be unnecessary if the hands received proper care in the first place.

ALGIERS, March 6 -- On the eve of his third trip to England, where it is expected he will hold further negotiations regarding the arming of the French resistance movement, Emmanuel d'Astier de la Vigerie declared today that the Committee of National Liberation had learned exactly what Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain intended to do when an invasion threatened his regime with disaster.

LONDON, March 6 (U.P.) -- Commanded by an American captain and aided by American non-commissioned officers, Partisan forces, in the first reported American participation in Yugoslavia land fighting, have attacked a German garrison on the strategic Adriatic Island of Hvar, it was officially announced today.

Wool prices recently have reflected war developments and the heavy surplus that has been built up in this country. In addition to domestic output, which has been heavy, large supplies of wool have been imported in recent years with the result that a huge stockpile has been accumulated.

The city's housewives will get the first of a series of new checks on food prices in about two weeks when flexible dollar and cents ceilings are placed on the fresh fruits and vegetables now under price control, Geoffrey Baker, assistant director of the food price division of the Office of Price Administration, declared yesterday.

The board of directors of Phoenix Securities Corporation voted unanimously yesterday afternoon to submit to the annual meeting of stockholders on April 19 a plan for the liquidation of the corporation, whose principal assets comprise substantial holdings in Pepsi-Cola Company and United Cigar-Whelan Stores.

ALBANY, March 6 -- With only two dissenting votes, members of the special committee of the New York State Bar Association on revision of procedure for selection of judicial offices today urged the adoption of the bill embodying Governor Dewey's program that provides for a referendum within each judicial district on the question of filling Supreme Court vacancies by appointment of the State's Chief Executive, subject to later confirmation by the Senate and the electorate.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 2 per cent last week in comparison with the like period of 1943, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week the bank had reported a decrease of 5 per cent in sales volume.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Hopes are held here that Uruguay and Paraguay will withhold recognition from the Farrell government in Argentina and that Chile will be found to have been the only Government to break the inter-American bloc by extending recognition in the present status of affairs.

Although "young people are making most of the trouble in connection with race difficulties today," children are unprejudiced until they acquire ideas of race hatred from adults, all the speakers agreed yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the annual institute of the Child Study Association of America at the Hotel Roosevelt.

PHILADELPHIA, March 6 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today scheduled oral arugments on reorganization proceedings of the Laclede Gas Light Company of St. Louis and an application by Republic Service Corporation of Wilmington, Del., for an extension of time in which to comply with the "death sentence" provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.
CHUNGKING, China, March 6 (AP) -- Fourteenth United States Army Air Force communique:
LONDON, March 6 -- The stock markets here commenced the week on a cheerful note today and in some sections business showed a gain in activity over the slow pace of last week.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The United States has sent almost 28,000 airplanes to the growing air forces of its Allies, together with $1,600,000,000 worth of aircraft engines and parts, since lend-lease began three years ago, Leo T. Crowley, Foreign Economic Administrator, disclosed today.

Formation of a food division of American Home Products Corporation and election of Henry W. Roden as vice president in charge was announced yesterday by Alvin G. Brush, chairman of the board. The new division will include three companies acquired recently by the corporation, Harold H. Clapp, Inc.; G. Washington Coffee Refining Company, and P. Duff Sons, Inc.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The sharp criticism heard so often in recent Supreme Court dissents was repeated today when a minority of four accused a majority of five of competing with Congress by laying down laws for banking instead of leaving this to the National Legislature.

MOSCOW, March 6 -- Pravda warned the Finnish Government today not to mistake the generosity of the proposed Soviet armistice terms for weakness or it would be "bitterly" disillusioned. The Moscow Communist party newspaper also reminded Finland that it was up to her to decide whether or not to find an exit from a blind ally or share the inglorious fate of Hitlerite Germany which is unhaltingly rolling toward her doom.

ROCKAWAY, N.J., March 6 -- Large quantities of lend-lease materials, chiefly blankets and shoes, were destroyed today in a fire at the building of the Cardinale Export Company here. The company works on contract for the Treasury Department, which has an office separated from the Cardinale structure by a freight siding.

CLEVELAND, March 6 -- The special for best in the show at the twenty-eighth annual all-breed dog show of the Western Reserve Kennel Club was won late last night by the Doberman pinscher Dictator v. Glenhugel, owned by Capt. and Mrs. Bob Adamson of Arlington, Va., and handled by John Cholley of Canton, Ohio.

The proposed 10-cent fare on the city-owned transit lines remained a political orphan yesterday, despite Mayor La Guardia's best efforts in his Sunday broadcast to have it adopted by the four county leaders, who, he said, "control the two major parties."

From the first advertisement in the campaign which it is sponsoring to help obtain 65,000 recruits for the United States Cadet Nurse Corps, Eastman Kodak Company received 33,000 inquiries. The largest number of answers came from high school girls nearing graduation, next were college students, young women with some nurses' training, service wives, business girls and defense workers, respectively.

LONDON, Tuesday, March 7 (U.P.) -- A supplemental German High Command report announced that the Red Army had opened a new offensive with 225,000 infantry and 240 tanks in the Zvenigorodka area along the middle Dnieper River and succeeded in breaking into Nazi lines.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The long contested service men's voting legislation ran into new troubles today when Senate and House conferees, meeting to give final approval to the "States' Rights" course adopted last week, decided instead to permit use of the Administration-endorsed Federal short) ballot in the United States under some circumstances.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 6 -- By 112 votes to eighty the Finnish Riksdag [Parliament] last Tuesday approved government action to negotiate with the Russians, I learned privately from reliable Helsinki sources today. Premier Edwin Linkomies and Finance Minister Valno A. Tanner were among the 112.

The friendly rivalry between Eastern United States and Canadian women will be renewed a week from Sunday when the second international downhill and slalom competition of the winter is to take place at the famous and precipitous Mount Baldy Speedway, a short distance from the picturesque French-Canadian hamlet of St. Margaret in the Laurentians.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Plans were said authoritatively today to be well advanced looking to an exploratory conference on international post-war civil aviation among the United States, Great Britain, the Soviet Union, China and Canada.

A UNITED STATES FIGHTER BASE, in England, March 6 -- Physically weary but undauntedly cheerful, American fighter pilots jumped out of their Mustangs here late this afternoon upon their return from the big aerial attack on Berlin today and almost unanimously they described the day's activities as the "best hunting" they had ever had.

Banks in the Second Federal Reserve District showed an average net profit in 1943 after taxes of 7.2 per cent on their total capital funds, compared with 4.4 per cent in 1942 and 5.5 per cent in 1941, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday in its annual survey of bank operating ratios.

DETROIT, March 6 -- Despite all that has been said and written about the post-war "dream car," production leaders in the automobile world say they have no intention of trying to produce anything of this nature in the immediate post-war period.
LONDON, March 6 (UP) -- A United State Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

ALBANY, March 6 -- By a vote of 30 to 16 the Republican majority in the Senate passed and sent to the Assembly tonight Governor Dewey's program bill extending for a year the mortgage moratorium with an increased amortization rate of 2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended March 1, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

Agreement on the terms of a new contract affecting 25,000 workers was reached last night at a conference in the Hotel McAlpin by the Joint Board of the dressmakers' union, an affiliate of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, and the Affiliated Dress Manufacturers, Inc., largest group in the dress industry.
NEW DELHI, India, March 6 (AP) -- A United States Army Forces in China, Burma and India communique:

OAKLAND, Calif., March 6 -- Machinists affiliated with the American Federation of Labor were brought here today from one of the yards of Henry J. Kaiser at Richmond, on San Francisco Bay, to put the finishing touches on two ships after 1,700 other machinists, who are unionized by the Congress of Industrial Organizations, had left the yards of the Moore Drydock Company in a dispute over pay.

ALBANY, March 6 -- The Assembly passed tonight the bill permitting Westchester County to charge ten cent tolls for the use of its parkways by motor vehicles and to instal and maintain stations for collection. A somewhat similar bill was vetoed by Governor Lehman in 1940.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, in Italy, March 6 -- Although the Allies' campaign in Italy has clearly been disappointing and negative in its results, from the short-range viewpoint, in the effort to expand the Anzio beachhead, and simultaneously to penetrate the Liri Valley, effecting an eventual junction, it is necessary to view certain positive accomplishments in terms of the broad strategic picture.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (U.P.) -- The War Department tonight made public the names of thirty-five officers and men who were prisoners in Germany and are being repatriated with other nationals aboard the Swedish liner Gripsholm, scheduled to arrive in this country March 15.
Six persons were taken to hospitals yesterday after a trolley car in Brooklyn failed to swing around a corner, jumped the tracks and crashed through the brick wall of a garage.

A UNITED STATES BOMBER BASE, in England, March 6 (AP) -- They wouldn't let the Flying Fortress Nelson King land at the home field tonight after she struggled in from a batlle on the Berlin mission in which fifteen companion Forts were shot down, but dispatched her instead to a repair depot.

The political problems of Europe are so complex and so major that upon the manner of their settlement depends in considerable measure the course of the war and the complexion of the peace. Some of them are problems of paramount significance.

ON THE FIFTH ARMY BEACHHEAD, SOUTH OF ROME, March 6 (AP) -- The bodies of German soldiers "piled up like cordwood" on the Anzio beachhead -- 24,000 have been killed, wounded or captured in the fighting here -- represent a serious dislocation of German plans to battle an invasion from Great Britain, it was authoritatively disclosed today.

PEARL HARBOR, March 6 -- New bases captured from the Japanese in the Marshall Islands are now being welded into our transpacific supply line, which must support any further operations westward. The violent phase of the war has passed over Kwajalein and Eniwetok like a tropical squall and now we are putting these atolls to the uses for which they were so well designed by nature.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 6 -- Mar-Kell, sporting the red and blue racing livery of Warren Wright's Calumet Farm, sped to a hard-earned triumph in the spring inaugural as the Gables Racing Association's thirty-day meeting at Tropical Park, final of the Florida season, got off to a splendid start today.

In his recital at Town Hall last night, Samuel Dushkin, Russian violinist, provided a few samples of his musical capabilities, but during most of the evening his playing was marred by technical insecurity and inaccurate intonation that were completely out of keeping with the artist's reputation and musical stature.

The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States has apportioned $41,400,000 for distribution in dividends to policy holders in 1944, Thomas I. Parkinson, the president, said yesterday in releasing the company's annual report for 1943.

A protest against passage of the 2 per cent amortization provision in the extension of the New York State mortgage moratorium has been lodged with Assemblymen Oswald D. Heck, Irving M. Ives, Irwin Steingut, Lee B. Mailler and other legislative leaders by Thomas H. Doyle, president of the Midtown Real Estate Association.
ON THE NORTH BURMA FRONT (Delayed) (AP) -- One of the youngest general line officers in the United States Army, General Merrill was handpicked by General Stilwell to lead the expedition into Burma.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Supplementing his charge last week that President Roosevelt and other Government officials utilized $51,000,000 of unauthorized funds to build the Pentagon, Representative Albert J. Engel, Republican, of Michigan, submitted to the House today a breakdown on operating costs.

In their public capacity and restaurant Senators are men of simple taste, plain folks that like plain food. Doubtless it was for this reason that Senator Bridges of New Hampshire formed a committee of colleagues to test the celebrated K-ration. Was it as good for civilian as for military palates?

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Dr. Willard H. Dow, head of the Dow Chemical Company, testifying before the Senate Truman Committee today, assailed the Department of Justice as the "authors and spreaders of a smear campaign" which sought to link his company with a German-controlled cartel.

The Committee on Unity that Mayor La Guardia appointed on Feb. 27 to promote harmony among racial and religious groups will make a thorough study of existing conditions and past experience in the city with the aid of a specially qualified staff, Charles Evans Hughes Jr., chairman, announced yesterday after an organization meeting in the Mayor's office at City Hall.

Dr. Camille Dreyfus, president of the Celanese Corporation of America, informed its more than 15,000 stockholders in the annual report released today, that the gross volume of business transacted last year was the largest in the company's history, but a combination of low profit margin on war contracts, excessive labor turnover and other production handicaps, resulted in a decline in earnings for the year.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, March 7 -- Troops of the dismounted First Cavalry Division pushed northward on the narrow peninsula of Los Negros Island in the Admiralties under Japanese artillery fire, and a small American amphibious force landed behind the enemy lines at Yaula Plantation, thirty miles northwest of Saidor on the New Guinea coast, Gen. Douglas MacArthur stated today.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- Five veterans' organizations joined today in proposing that the Government pay members of the armed forces bonuses up to $3,500 each for home service and $4,500 for overseas service.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 6 (AP) -- Uruguay temporarily withheld today her decision whether she will recognize the Argentine Government of Gen. Edelmiro Farrell, a Foreign Office informant said. This virtually meant a suspension of diplomatic relations with Argentina.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 6 (AP) -- Uruguay temporarily withheld today her decision whether she will recognize the Argentine Government of Gen. Edelmiro Farrell, a Foreign Office informant said. This virtually meant a suspension of diplomatic relations with Argentina.

Julius Katz of 112 Central Park South learned from his newspaper early yesterday that his 23-year-old brother, Werner, was a hero. A corporal, Werner had earned the distinction of killing the first Japanese in the American thrust into Northern Burma on Jan. 25.
ALBANY, March 7 -- Following is the text of Governor Dewey's special message today recommending a plan of soldier voting:

CHICAGO, March 7 -- Wheat futures advanced moderately today on the Board of Trade on short covering and professional buying induced by strength in securities and cotton. Prices held within rather narrow limits with the close at gains of 3/8 to 1/2 cent a bushel.

LONDON, March 7 -- Nazi airfields and other targets in northern France were blasted today by strong formations of Marauders of the United States Ninth Air Force and Mitchells, Mosquitos, Bostons and Typhoons of the British Second Tactical Air Force.

NEW DELHI, March 7 (U.P.) -- American troops have crushed a strong Japanese attempt to escape entrapment in the Hukawng Valley of northern Burma, inflicting heavy losses on the enemy, a southeast Asia Command communique announced today.

LONDON, March 7 -- One dispatch from a war correspondent at the battlefront is a hundred times more valuable than all handouts by the Ministry of Information or the War Office about campaigns, Brendan Bracken, Minister of Information, asserted today at the Press Club in Fleet Street.

PEARL HARBOR, March 7 (U.P.) -- Navy and Army planes, completing sixty days of non-stop aerial activities on the Pacific Island route to the Far East, attacked seven enemy-held bases in the Caroline and Marshall Islands Sunday, it was announced today.
Congratulations on your news report "Obliteration Raids on German Cities Protested in U.S.," on Page 1 of today's TIMES.

Winston Churchill has put in one more stroke for victory. He has ordered British officials in their reports to avoid the word "breakdown" in cases where it might cause misunderstanding. Anything that wastes time and manpower and creates misunderstanding is an obvious drag on victory.

A role the American Red Cross will play increasingly as service men return from war was indicated yesterday with the announcement of a new course for home nursing instructors at its New York chapter. Six prominent psychiatrists will deliver a series of lectures on types of war psychoses and nervous ailments so that when service men return their families and friends will know how to help them become readjusted to normal living.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- An Anglo-American conference on "petroleum questions" the principal object of which is understood to be the assurance that oil shall never become an irritant in the two powers' relations will open here soon.

NAPLES, Feb. 10 (Delayed) -- A Soviet military mission, consisting of twenty-two officers and headed by Lieut. Gen. Korneyeff, a well-known Russia Army commander who has been actively leading troops on the Soviet Union's western front, has arrived in Yugoslavia and is accredited to Marshal Tito's Yugoslav National Army of Liberation.

A growing demand for family service on a fee basis is reflected in a rise of 125 per cent in the number of families or persons who consulted the Jewish Social Service Association in the last two years, it reported yesterday. Extension of this service to self-supporting middle income groups was begun in 1942, when 436 families were aided.

Coming out with the bold prediction that four records would, not might, go by the board in the silver anniversary meet of the Knights of Columbus in Madison Square Garden on Saturday night, sunset event of the current indoor track season, the meet chairman, Frank A. Brennan, yesterday gave out the list of fields for the affair.

American life insurance companies last year increased their holdings of securities and mortgages in general by $3,310,000,000 and their holdings of United States Government securities by $3,340,000,000, the Institute of Life Insurance reported yesterday.

India's war industries have had no major strikes since the war began, H.G. Misra, leading Indian industrialist, said last night at a farewell dinner in his honor at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. Mr. Misra has just finished a good-will tour of this country.
HARTFORD, Conn., March 7 (AP) -- The State Supreme Court ruled today that a boy was justified in resisting his school principal because "unreasonable force" was used to discipline the pupil.

Scarcely a fortnight passes but the Federal Reserve Bank of New York is able to report the admission of a new member bank in the Second Federal Reserve District. Yesterday the bank announced that the Great Neck Trust Company of Great Neck, L.I., had joined the Federal Reserve System.
The Wednesday communique from Allied Headquarters in the Southwest Pacific, as reported by the Office of War Information:

WASHINGTON -- March 7 -- Chester Bowles, Price Administrator, compared tonight the cost of the Office of Price Administration (with a budget of $155,000,000) with savings to the consumer which, he said, were $22,000,000,000 in 1943 in the cost of civilian goods and services and $67,000,000,000 in the cost of the war program.

SALT LAKE CITY, March 7 (AP) -- Federal and State authorities arrested today more than fifty persons in raids in Utah, Idaho and Arizona in a move which an assistant United States District Attorney, John S. Boyden, said was designed to stamp out polygamy.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Conceding that the conferences on the servicemen's voting legislation had reached a stalemate "where it was this bill or nothing," the Senate and House conferees, by an eight-to-two vote, gave final approval today to the States' Rights program which would recognize the Administration's Federal ballot only as a supplement to State ballots.

Three men who used a 17-year-old girl as a decoy to rob a soldier were held without bail yesterday in Bronx Magistrate's Court for grand jury action. The girl, Dorothy Eleanor Cook, who was brought here from Bridgeport, Conn., to testify against the youths, was not held.

Volunteer solicitors for the Red Cross 1944 War Fund have discovered that many doors are open to them as a result of letters from service men overseas to their families back here expressing appreciation for what the Red Cross is doing on the fighting fronts, W. Lawrence McLane, chairman of the Manhattan Block Canvass, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- An odd set of circumstances seems to have attended the recent appearance before the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations of Gen. George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff, to recommend that the committee postpone action on the Wagner-Taft resolution in favor of the free entry of Jews into Palestine and the eventual establishment of a Jewish commonwealth there.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Announcements made today by the War Production Board, the Office of Price Administration and other agencies relating to trade and industry follow:
A 25-year-old co-pilot of a heavy bomber received in England from his parents in New York a letter that he thought sounded "a little as if you had gotten kind of blue about things in general."

A campaign to have a million persons in New York State sign cards urging President Roosevelt to seek a fourth term was launched formally here yesterday by the Committee for a United Labor Party, which is seeking to overthrow the present State leadership of the American Labor party.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. announced today closing dates for the receipt of exchange subscriptions for the Treasury bonds and notes for which subscription books were opened March 2.

Respect is due the sincerity, character and influence of the spiritual leaders who have issued a protest against the Allied bombing of the Axis. When, however, they suggest an ethical superiority over others who are bidden to "examine themselves concerning their participation in this carnival of death" a word of disclaimer may be permitted.

The $5 preview of "Stars of Yesterday and Today," held last night at Wildenstein's, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street, was a gala event. Just beforehand it was announced that the American Red Cross exhibition committee, headed by Mrs. Edward Larocque Tinker, had already sold $25,000 worth of tickets, which probably is an art world record in connection with events of this sort.

Entirely new industries may emerge in the post-war period as a result of wartime research developments in electronics and other phases of physics, according to a report issued yesterday by the committee on product development of the National Association of Manufacturers.
BOUGAINVILLE, Solomon Islands, March 7 -- The score now stands at 125 Japanese killed to one Fijian dead and two wounded.
New York City's retail food costs have risen 44 per cent since August, 1939, it was disclosed yesterday by an offical survey prepared for and released by the Regional Office of Price Administration.

The approach of March 15 calls attention again to the pressing need of tax simplification. Two phases of this problem may be noted: first, simplification of the forms to be filled out by taxpayers and, second, reduction in the number of taxpayers who must file returns. While some progress might be made in connection with the first phase by the Bureau of Internal Revenue, basically the responsibility for both measures rests with Congress.

Extension of the Baruch-Hancock plan to foster immediate establishment by industry of active committees to work with a single Government agency in preparing for the post-war economy was proposed last night by Joseph L. Dubow, executive director of the Merchants Ladies Garment Association, at the annual meeting of the organization last night at the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The American Federation of Labor will reject President Roosevelt's proposal that it share with the Congress of Industrial Organizations the workers' delegate representation at the April 20 meeting of the International Labor Organizations conference in Philadelphia.

In an effort to spur textile offerings for lend-lease shipments, Treasury procurement officials disclosed yesterday that the 1943 backlog of unfilled fabric requirements exceeds 90,000,000 yards. The fabrics, it was stated, are needed immediately for shipment to Australia, New Zealand, North Africa, French West Africa and Middle East areas.

In this most critical of all war years we should be thinking not of how many planes and guns and tanks we are making for our soldiers in the field, but of how many more we could make if we were properly organized for the task and really determined to do our best.

Brig. Gen. Brice P. Disque, retired, president of the Coal Consumers Protective Association, disclosed yesterday that dealers who are members of his organization had found that some householders already were beginning to hoard coal for next winter, though he explained that the hoarders represented only a small minority.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The House clamped down today on two proposals for expenditures of Federal funds, with repeated emphasis on the size of the national debt. The first negative vote, on an amendment to a bill authorizing various activities of the Department of Agriculture never formally sanctioned by law, rejected a $50,000,000 school luncheon program for the next fiscal year.

LONDON, March 7 -- The elimination of the Luftwaffe as a military force, which is the primary objective of Lieut. Gen. Carl A. Spaatz's Strategic Air Forces and one of the prerequisites of Allied strategy in Europe, was brought measurably closer by yesterday's smashing victory in the big American bombing attack on Berlin, said an authoritative air source today.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- American submarines have sunk so many Japanese tankers and supply ships that the enemy has perhaps decided to withdraw his heavy warships from Truk because they could not be refueled and supplied at the powerful base, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, said today.

The Iowa State Highway Commission announced yesterday that it will offer for sale ten new issues of county bonds aggregating $3,034,000, to refund callable issues of primary road obligations. All of the bonds will be dated May 1, 1944.

ALBANY, March 7 -- The Ives bill providing unemployment insurance benefits for discharged State veterans of the armed forces, first of a series of veterans' benefits measures before the Legislature, was passed unanimously today by the Assembly.

LONDON, March 7 -- A new series of strikes involving 40,000 coal miners and costing Britain's coal production more than 22,000 tons daily has broken cut in the valleys of South Wales and Monmouthshire despite the efforts of labor union leaders to persuade the men to remain at work pending negotiation.

The advance group plan ticket sale of the Dodgers for their 1944 home games at Ebbets Field appeared to receive considerable impetus yesterday with an announcement by the Internal Revenue office that the new 10 per cent additional Federal tax would not have to be included on tickets purchased before April 1.

LONDON, Wednesday, March 8 (U.P.) -- The Russians smashed to within ten miles north of the five-way Polish rail junction of Tarnopol, sliced the top from a wedge protecting the junction of Proskurov, sixty miles east of Tarnopol, and developed a new drive toward Zhmerinka, sixty miles southeast of Proskurov, bulletins broadcast by Moscow said last night.

" THE worst thing about war is that so many men like it." Anyone who has ever listened to a group of American Legionnaires reminiscing about that tough sergeant and that case of cognac or singing "Mademoiselle From Armentieres" will agree with this sad statement of fact by the inside Europe, Asia and Latin America specialist, John Gunther.

ALBANY, March 7 -- A fair trade bill providing even stiffer penalties than the one vetoed by Governor Lehman in 1942 was adopted in the Senate today by a vote of 30 to 10 after Senator Walter J. Mahoney of Buffalo, sponsor of the measure, pleaded for its passage on the grounds that "literally hundreds of corner store owners are crying for it."

Although Ezra Pound, American poet, has been indicted for treason to his country, the National Institute of Arts and Letters, a leading honorary organization here, has not expelled him and does not plan to do so unless he is convicted.

Ready-to-wear and custom-designed styles mingled on the runway yesterday noon in the Oval Room of the Ritz Carlton Hotel. The House of Jonai was responsible for them. And whether they came from the establishment's design room or were bought in the wholesale market, they reflected a unity of taste that represented refinement.

With Vera Zorina now set for "Dream With Music," the Richard Kollmar musical will be placed in rehearsal tomorrow for a Boston opening on April 10 and a New York premiere about May 1. The star's husband, George Balanchine, has been assigned to stage the dances.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 7 (AP) -- A Federal Court judge, calling the terms "fair and equitable," approved today an amended plan of reorganization for the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad that would wipe out present common and preferred stock values and set a new price for the Old Colony Railroad, now under ninety-nine-year lease to the New Haven.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- In a survey of Negro education made public today, the United States Office of Education recommended that schools and colleges for white students in the South open their facilities to Negroes, and that Negro institutions cooperate with white in the equalization of educational opportunities.
LONDON, March 7 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- A Federal Works Agency deficiency appropriation, to carry forward the child care program for children of working mothers under FWA with use of Lanham Act funds, was reported out by the House Appropriations Committee today and will come up for floor action tomorrow.
Edward J. Flynn, Democratic leader in the Bronx, told Mayor La Guardia yesterday, through Paul Windels, to "put up or shut up" on the question of a ten-cent fare for the city-owned transit lines.

Licenses issued by the British Board of Trade for the shipment of woolens to this country covering the four-month period February through May will be limited to 5 per cent of shipments of individual organizations during the quota year 1941, it was learned yesterday. Such licenses will be the first issued since May 31, 1943, when an embargo was placed on further shipments.

The first round of play in the Alfred H. Benjamin Jr. memorial handicap squash racquets tournament was completed last night with William H. Pell Jr. of the Princeton Club and Malcolm Muir Jr., Yale Club, the only ranking players to see action, moving into the next bracket.

The argument which Miss Vera Brittain and twenty-eight clergymen and other leaders have made against "massacre by bombing" is not in reality an argument against bombing. It is an argument against war. Miss Brittain and those who have associated themselves with her views are perfectly right when they say that "in our time, as never before, war is showing itself in its logical colors."

A streamlined schedule of only nine baseball games, including the engagement with the Yankees for the benefit of the Red Cross, was announced yesterday by the Giants as their exhibition program for the forthcoming spring training campaign, which will get under way at Lakewood, N.J., next Sunday.

Detectives in all police precincts of the city have been ordered to bring in Frank Costello, ex-convict who was accused of influencing the nomination of Thomas A. Aurelio for the Supreme Court and who was reputedly named by the late Louis (Lepke) Buchalter as a $25, 000 contributor to the campaign fund of a candidate for high public office, it was learned last night.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- A veterans' bonus bill backed by five service groups and providing benefits as high as $4,500 for overseas fighting men, got off to a bad start in the Senate today.

Benjamin Franklin and Erasmus Hall moved into the semi-finals of the city P.S.A.L. basketball championship yesterday afternoon by winning from Stuyvesant and Thomas Jefferson, respectively, before a crowd of 7,000 persons at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Five hundred devices, many of them original inventions, which simulate flying effects ranging from enemy gun-fire to tropical storms, have been turned out by the Navy in two and a half years for training its aviators.

The death of Martin Conboy yesterday recalls, first of all, his distinguished career as a lawyer and prosecutor. Less well known was his intense personal devotion to numerous welfare and charitable causes which have greatly benefited by his counsel and guidance through many years.

DENVER, March 7 (U.P.) -- Complete unofficial returns tonight showed Dean Gillespie, 59-year-old business man, Republican, the winner over his Democratic opponent in Denver's special Congressional election.
CHUNGKING, China, March 7 (UP) -- A communique:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, March 8 -- United States Marines have landed near Talasea on Willaumez Peninsula, New Britain, about 160 miles southwest of Rabaul and 110 miles northeast of their base at Cape Gloucester. On the opposite side of New Britain, American infantrymen advanced twenty-four miles from the Arawe airdrome toward Gasmata, chief town on the island's south shore.

UNION, N.J., March 7 -- Union-Springfield Selective Service Board 2 is running so short of men to fill draft quotas that it hung out a "help wanted," sign in front of its offices here today. The sign says:

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Asserting that twenty small semi-integrated steel producers were confronted with disaster because of "war-time distortions," Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, proposed today the creation of a "small steel commission to administer a plan that would, in his opinion, keep these companies in business.

With greater cooperation expected from the public, Commissioner William F. Carey expressed confidence yesterday that the Department of Sanitation would be able today "to better appreciably" last Wednesday's collection of more than 700 tons of waste paper for conversion into cardboard wrappings and containers of war material.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Edward R. Stettinius Jr. will go to London on his mission as Under-Secretary of State prepared to discuss a wide range of subjects, to judge from the advisers whom he will take with him.

Sid Trubowitz, the pace-setter among the metropolitan college scorers, who had been nursing a heavy cold, will definitely be in the C.C.N.Y. starting line-up tonight, when the Beavers engage N.Y.U. in their annual struggle at Madison Square Garden.

MAJURO, Marshall Islands, Feb. 27 (Delayed) -- This atoll, whose broad lagoon affords one of the best fleet anchorages in the Pacific, was occupied during the Kwajalein operations. Majuro had apparently been abandoned by the Japanese, for there was no garrison on the island.

Stan-B, Standard Brands' new vitamin product, is featured in an advertising campaign in approximately forty-five newspapers in the Middle West this week. The product will be introduced in Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, Ohio, West Virginia and Wisconsin. In addition to the newspaper schedule the radio will be used. The product is sold exclusively through the drug trade.

ALBANY, March 7 -- Governor Dewey made public today his soldier-vote plan for the State, which eliminates some of the difficulties under which soldier ballots in the State have previously been collected. It was coupled with a message to the Legislature in which the Governor took a "States' rights" stand and accused the Roosevelt Administration of being interested only in concentration of power in Washington.

With hundreds of thousands of American soldiers and billions of dollars' worth of supplies streaming to Europe over a bridge of ships that connects the European battlefronts with the "arsenal of democracy," it is both welcome and important news to hear how safe that bridge has become and how thoroughly the one grave menace to it, the German submarine, has been defeated.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 7 -- News came from Finland today that a revised text of the Finnish reply to Moscow on armistice proposals has been delivered.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Anne Hagopian, 16, of 114 East Ninetieth Street, New York City, and Charles A. Davidson, 17, of Fort Bridger, Wyo., were chosen today from among forty finalists to receive the four-year $2,400 Westinghouse grand scholarship awarded at the closing session here tonight of this year's Science Talent Institute.

No easing in leather supply may be expected this year, with all indications, in fact, pointing to the tightest conditions since the beginning of the war, Merrill A. Watson, executive vice president of the Tanners' Council of America, said yesterday.

American combat troops fighting deep in the Burma jungle are the pioneers of a new expeditionary force. These first arrivals call themselves "Merrill's Marauders," in honor of one of our youngest Generals, who leads them. Advancing side by side with tough Chinese fighters under the common command of "Uncle Joe" Stilwell, they are pushing a wedge toward China.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 6 (Delayed) (AP) -- Turkish Foreign Minister Numan Menemencioglu told Turkish editors today that Turkey plans to do everything in her power to preserve her alliance with Great Britain, which now is marred by a Turkish-British quarrel.
LONDON, March 7 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

The Home Owners Loan Corporation, created eleven years ago to save hundreds of thousands of distressed families from the threat of foreclosure on their homes, has taken over so many New York properties and has found resales on the basis of the original valuations so difficult here that its losses in the State are running several times those in other parts of the nation, a study of the Federal agency's records showed yesterday.

I wonder if many of your readers experienced the feeling of undiluted fury that swept me on reading, in today's TIMES, of the "protest" against the bombing of German cities. Are we beginning that maudlin chant again? Haven't we learned yet?
NEW DELHI, India, March 7 (AP) -- A communigue:

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, said today that the War Department had eliminated the use of cost-plus-fixed-fee contracts to the greatest possible extent under a policy adopted fifteen months ago and that consequently a Senate joint resolution to curtail that method of contracting for war materials was "unnecessary."

The British Air Minister, Sir Archibald Sinclair, has found it possible to declare in the House of Commons that "there lies before us now clearly attainable the glittering prize of air supremacy." Since he based himself on reports of Anglo-American air commanders like Air Chief Marshal Sir Arthur William Tedder and Gen. Carl A. Spaatz -- the best aviation brains in the world -- the Minister's optimism should carry great weight.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday were 1,207, compared with 1,255 in the preceding week and 1,266 in the like period last year, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals numbered 633, against 602 last Tuesday.

Directors of the American Crystal Sugar Company omitted yesterday the dividend on the common stock because of low earnings and high taxes in 1943. Payments on the common last year were 25 cents each in April, July, September and December.

Influenced by expectations of larger military demands for cotton textiles, the cotton market recovered sharply yesterday on trade price-fixing, commission house demand in the March delivery and renewed buying in the distant positions.
the harbor were hit and beached, and six barges were destroyed or damaged. The attack cost one Allied plane.

In a sudden break-through by the industrials, which caught many seasoned Wall Street observers off guard, the stock market registered yesterday the best performance of the year. Backed by a demand unequaled since early last December, the list pushed forward steadily from the opening until the close when gains ranged from fractions to approximately 2 points.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration (OPA) today established for the first time nation-wide dollars-and-cents price ceilings for all sales of both domestic and imported rough rice.

WITH LIEUT. GEN. JOSEPH W. STILWELL'S CHINESE-AMERICAN FORCES in Hukawng Valley, March 6 (Delayed) -- The American troops who this week became the first United States Infantry combat force to go into action against Japanese on the mainland of Asia are an elite detachment especially selected and trained for the job they are now doing. Many are veterans of Guadalcanal, Munda and Buna.

BERKELEY, Calif., March 7 -- Isolation in the pure state of the growth hormone, a step which gives hope of adding stature in extreme cases of dwarfism, was announced today by the University of California.

Thomas J. Curran, New York Secretary of State and Republican leader of New York County, declined yesterday to seek re-election as president of the National Republican Club because "as a matter of fundamental principle" he is "against third and fourth terms for high office."

PITTSBURGH, March 7 (AP) -- Bob Collins, Iron Man of Pacific Coast League catchers a few years ago, may climb down off his iron horse to help out with the catching chores of the New York Yankees this season.

ALGIERS, March 7 -- After five days of inaction, heavy bombers of the United States Fifteenth Air Force resumed operations today with widely separated assaults on the Toulon naval base, railway facilities at Florence and German fighter bases northeast of Rome.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The first returns on George Ruppert's 1944 fishing tournament have just come in and, beyond indicating that the entries thus far are running ahead of last year's, show that there is room for improvement before the prize-winning classifications are reached.

ALGIERS, March 7 -- Called By the defense as a witness at the trial of Pierre Pucheu today, Gen. Henri-Honore Girand, Commander in Chief of the French Army, said that when the French Committee of National Liberation discussed the case last June he had opposed the trial on the ground that no evidence was available in North Africa.

ALLIED AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS IN ITALY, March 7 -- As a result of the concentrated and coordinated Anglo-American strategic bombing campaign begun late last July and recently implemented by terrific attacks from both British and the Mediterranean bases, Germany's once proud air force is now being beaten to its knees.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 7 -- Argentina is exerting considerable pressure on the Governments of neighboring countries to forbid transmission of news unfavorable to Argentina. The Buenos Aires Government is trying to invoke an agreement concluded some years ago between various South American countries, whereby each undertook, as a measure for American solidarity, to prevent the transmission of news hostile to the others.

On his plea that he became enraged over a "double-cross" and that chance contact with a loaded revolver caused him to seize the weapon and kill two of his gambling partners, Max Fox, 53-year-old ex-convict, formerly of 200 West Ninety-third Street, was sentenced yesterday in General Sessions to serve twenty years to life in prison.

" The Purple Heart," a topical drama produced by Twentieth Century-Fox, dealing with eight American flyers who are captured by the Japanese after bombing Tokyo, will have its local premiere this morning at the Roxy. Heading the cast of the film, which was directed by Lewis Milestone, are Dana Andrews, Richard Conte, Donald Barry, Trudy Marshall and Sam Levene.
LONDON, March 7 -- Ostend, the most important town on the Belgian coast, has been ordered Partly evacuated, according to reports reaching London. The inhabitants have until Sunday to get out.

A plan under which, in the opinion of major distillers, the current liquor shortage could have been eased, a severe blow dealt to the black market and bootlegging made less profitable, was submitted to the Federal Government two months ago and apparently pigeonholed, it was learned here yesterday.

The major political problem of Europe is the problem of Tomorrow. The shape and complexion of post-war Europe, as defined by the inter-relationships of the great powers, is the great question mark of today.

The Atlantic Refining Company and its subsidiaries report in the annual operating statement for 1943, for publication today, net income of $10,687,828 after all charges, including $2,000,000 reserve for wartime and post-war contingencies and $10,821,639 Federal taxes on income.

LONDON, March 7 -- Losses of Allied merchant ships in Atlantic convoys caused by enemy submarines declined in the second half of last year to less than one in a thousand, it was disclosed today by First Lord of the Admiralty Albert V. Alexander in a speech introducing naval estimates in the House of Commons.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, March 8 -- The Russians widened their offensive in the Ukraine yesterday and turned back strong German counter-attacks. Further progress was made toward the Polish junction of Tarnopol and beyond the railroad between that city and Proskurov.

Designing clothes for the American woman requires a special technique, according to Claire McCardell, winner of the American fashion critics award for 1943. In addressing an invited audience of women fashion experts yesterday in the Coty auditorium at 612 Fifth Avenue, Miss McCardell hailed the American woman as "the most beautiful and best proportioned in the world, but having a posture all her own; she is not either erect nor queenly."

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Senators Elbert D. Thomas of Utah, Kilgore of West Virginia and Truman of Missouri introduced a resolution today calling for a commission to formulate out of the "welter of opinion" on the subject a foreign economic policy to be followed after the war.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, March 8 -- The Russians widened their offensive in the Ukraine yesterday and turned back strong German counter-attacks. Further progress was made toward the Polish junction of Tarnopol and beyond the railroad between that city and Proskurov.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) --Representative Ranulf Compton, Republican, of Connecticut, who wants Congress to go on record in favor of keeping Palestine open to Jewish immigrants, notwithstanding the provisions of a British White Paper that would close that area to such migration at the end of this month, told the House today:

LONDON, March 7 -- Again there was little activity in today's stock markets, although the general tone throughout was firm. Home rails made some further progress following yesterday's rise. Gilt-edge issues were in demand, the 3 1/2 per cent War Loan going as high as 104.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- Displaying liberality toward war agencies but slashing home front bureaus, the House Appropriations Committee approved today a $500,103,748 deficiency supply bill, $92,235,064 below budget estimates.

Many of the charitable souls who issued the plaint against the bombing of German cities are the identical people who have repeatedly, through the decade just past, set their names to appeals for justice, appeals for tolerance, appeals for humanity, appeals for international brotherhood and tenderness.

LONDON, March 7 -- The problem of Germany's use of Spanish-controlled Tangier as a basis for lively and dangerous espionage against the Allies at the Strait of Gibraltar and in North Africa was believed here today to be moving toward a solution.
Lieut. J. Donald Budge of the Army Air Forces, the world champion, will fly to New York from Texas to play in the Red Cross tennis matches at Madison Square Garden next Tuesday night.

A UNITED STATES HEAVY BOMBER STATION, in Britain, March 7 -- The next time you hear someone retailing the rumor that the Germans have torn down the Eiffel Tower for its metal, you can spike it. And you can take the word of Second Lieut. Mario L. Cornell, 23-year-old Flying Fortress pilot from Cleveland, and his crew that it still looks just as you have seen it on the picture postcards or in travel books.

PHILADELPHIA, March 7 (AP) -- Six corporations in fifteen war industry groups reported profits in 1942 of more than 100 per cent on invested capital after payment of taxes, the second in a series of Securities and Exchange Commission studies on profits and operations costs from 1936 through 1942, covering 261 companies, disclosed today.

BOSTON, March 7 (AP) -- With Don Grosso and Murray Armstrong each scoring twice, the shorthanded Red Wings romped to an 8-4 National Hockey League victory over the Bruins tonight before a crowd of 7,500 at the Boston Garden.
LONDON, March 7 -- Britain has reached the showdown stage in her protracted discussions with the Polish and Yugoslav Governments.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Jonathan Daniels, one of President Roosevelt's confidential assistants, told a subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Agriculture today why he sought the resignation of Harry Slattery, head of the Rural Electrification Administration.

Andre Maurois, French author who recently returned from North Africa and Italy, where he served with the French Army, will speak this evening at 8:30 o'clock in the Brooklyn Academy of Music. He will talk on the war in the Mediterranean. His lecture will be the nineteenth in a special forum series under the sponsorship of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences.

Lieut. Joseph Emmett O'Flaherty, former member of the New York City Fire Department, was killed Saturday in an airplane crash while on a training mission near Naples Airdrome, Naples, Fla., his family disclosed yesterday. He was 27 years old.

The Walton concerto for viola, which, we believe, had only been played previously in this city at an NBC radio concert, was performed by William Primrose and the Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy, conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 7 -- As things lined up tonight 6,000,000 workers in northern Italy and an estimated 700,000 youths belonging to the classes of 1923, 1924 and 1925 tomorrow face one of the most memorable dates in Italian history.

Prices of packaged synthetic vitamins are tumbling. The break was hailed yesterday by purchasing agents for hospitals and other institutions, as well as by individuals who stock their refrigerators and medicine chests with the prized capsules and tablets.

A special meeting of stockholders of Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company has been called for March 30 at West Allis, Wis., to vote on a proposal of the board of directors to create a new issue of 300,000 shares of $100 par convertible preferred stock.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 7 -- Fanny Brice has been signed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to play Baby Snooks in two sketches of the "Zegfield Follies." Twentieth Century-Fox is asking Tallulah Bankhead to assume the title role in "Czarina," the Lubitsch-Mankiewicz production.

BOGOTA, Colombia, March 7 -- The Cabinet was re-composed today following the decision of President Alfonso Lopez to present his resignation to a special session of Congress next month. The new Cabinet follows:

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $97,441,823 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. Average price per share of all listed stocks on Feb. 29 was $32.51 compared with $32.47 at the end of January.

Widespread unemployment in the post-war period as serious as that "during the worst of the depression" will result unless a national labor policy is adopted which will maintain wage levels and labor unions in their proper relation to existing economic conditions, Leo Wolman, Professor of Economics at Columbia University and a member of the board of trustees of the Mutual Life Insurance Company, said yesterday.

The Public Affairs Committee, through its editor, Maxwell S. Stewart, announced yesterday that it planned a fourth printing of the pamphlet "The Races of Mankind," despite a War Department decision to drop plans for circulating among officer-instructors 55,000 copies already purchased.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- Major league baseball clubs may play pro-season exhibition games with service teams without restriction, the Office of Defense Transportation said today, as long as the games are held near the ball teams' spring training camps.

No human experience prepares us for the effects of air war on populations subjected to it on the scale of the present bombardment of German cities. American airmen returning from their first great daylight assault on Berlin were awe-struck by the sight of the ruin caused by previous raids.

BALTIMORE, March 8 -- Feathers slightly ruffled, the Johns Hopkins University News Letter and Student Council dispatched a resolution today to the Philadelphia National League Baseball Club demanding "suitable satisfaction" for taking the nickname Blue Jays for the erstwhile Phillies.
Harry Collins, who has always had a feeling for the distinguished in fashion, opened his spring collection yesterday morning at 647 Fifth Avenue.

WITH CHINESE-AMERICAN FORCES IN BURMA, March 8 -- Chinese and American forces are closing in rapidly, completely smashing the main center of Japanese Army strength in the Hukawng Valley in the area south of Maingkwan.
With the opening of the Yankees' training campaign at Atlantic City only a few days away, President Ed Barrow spent a busy afternoon at his desk yesterday disseminating a variety of news.

LOS ANGELES, March 8 -- Los Angeles investment and brokerage houses are launching a post-war employment program, the blueprint of which already has been submitted to national leaders in the securities business.

A MUSTANG BASE, In England, March 8 (U.P.) -- Every type of fighter available to the Germans, including trainers, was thrown into the air today to break up the second American daylight mass attack on Berlin.

Last year 445 blind men, women and children came to the Lighthouse for the first time for aid and assistance in facing a new world of darkness. In fact, for the last ten years an average of 450 new cases per year have been added to the Lighthouse register, which now contains the names of 4,084 blind people.
LONDON, March 8 -- The stock markets here today were firm in tone although the trading volume again was small.

The $50,000 diamond clip that Paul E. Flato, the former Fifth Avenue jeweler, reported "missing" from his assets before he was sent to Sing Sing to serve two to four years for defrauding customers and wholesale jewelers of gems they had entrusted to him for sale, was turned over to its owners yesterday by Maurice Simmons, property clerk in Police Headquarters.

CHICAGO, March 8 -- President Roosevelt threw the weight of his authority today behind the idea that it is not only proper, but highly desirable in the national interest, to devote some time to post-war planning even in the midst of the war, so long as such activities do not interfere with the prosecution of the war.
LONDON, Thursday, March 9 (AP) -The Russian Wednesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

MEXICO CITY, March 8 -- In the strongest statement issued to date in favor of Mexico's direct participation in the war, President Manuel Avila Camacho told the Mexican Air Force today that he would decide when Mexico should send troops abroad.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Creation of an inter-departmental committee to study the post-war shipping situation with a view to holding international talks on the subect will be announced by the White House, it is understood.

Twenty-seven Negro institutions are to be the beneficiaries of the United Negro College Fund campaign to raise $1,500,000 which will get under way in a few weeks. It is a news item to be kept in mind when people are tempted to draw harrowing conclusions from this incident of the "Races of Mankind" pamphlet, banned from circulation in the Army after a protest by the chairman of the House Military Committee.
NEW DELHI, India, March 8 (UP) -A communique:

None of the day care centers for children of working mothers on the West Side is filled to capacity, although a great need for such centers has been shown by block surveys, Miss Helen M. Harris, Executive-Director of the Mayor's Committee on Wartime Care of Children, disclosed yesterday during a tour of the four centers set up by the Mayor's committee.

Because of a drop in enrollment in the last five years, most of New York City's forty-four academic and vocational high school annexes can be closed immediately and the pupils transferred to the main buildings at a "substantial saving" to the Board of Education, Stanley M. Isaacs, Manhattan Councilman, declared yesterday.

The Toronto Maple Leafs will be out to secure their hold on fourth place in the National Hockey League tonight when they oppose the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden. The Leafs, still mathematically subject to elimination, virtually will seal the lowest qualifying berth for the postseason play-offs if they beat the cellar-dwelling Blue Shirts.

TRENTON, March 8 -- The appointment of two deputy attorneys general and fourteen assistant deputy attorneys general to the new State Department of Law was announced today by Attorney General Walter D. Van Riper, who is reorganizing the State's legal bureau under legislation signed last night by Gov. Walter E. Edge.

CLEVELAND, March 8 (AP) -- Jim Bagby, Indians' pitching ace until now regarded as the American League's only 1944 holdout, told The News today he had "asked for voluntary retirement for the duration."

New issues of State and municipal securities publicly offered in February amounted to only $31,840,232, compared with $61,335,700 in February, 1943, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. The total for January, according to revised figures, was $59,068,571.

Harry Weinberger, theatrical lawyer, copyright expert and champion of civil liberties, who died last Sunday at his home, 41 Fifth Avenue, expressed the belief in his will filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court that the greatest work the bar can do for itself and the nation is to be well informed on the question of liberty and democracy.

The Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, at the request of the Army, the Navy and the Federal Bureau of Investigation, begins today a campaign to prevent our enemies from gathering even the smallest scraps of information about our fighting forces or war production, it was announced yesterday by Grover Whalen, CDVO director.

The program presented by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Bruno Walter, last night in Carnegie Hall contained Schumann's Fourth symphony, Samuel Barber's "Symphony in One Movement," which received its first New York hearing in its new revised version, and the Brahms piano concerto in B flat, with Rudolf Serkin as soloist.

Frank Brennan has arranged a most attractive relay program to add spice to the silver anniversary games of the New York Chapter Knights of Columbus, Saturday night at Madison Square Garden. In all, counting heats, there will be fourteen such events, so that the fans may expect to witness a four-man test about every ten minutes.
NEW DELHI, India, March 8 (AP) -- A United States Army Forces in India, Burma and China communique:

A 23-year-old New York girl, who ordinarily would be dead after such an ordeal, is alive and in excellent health today after the removal of a two-and-a-half-inch sewing needle from the ventricle of her heart, it was reported last night at a meeting of the New York Surgical Society at the New York Academy of Medicine, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- Concerned over future United States military and commercial rights in the Pacific, the House moved today toward establishment of a twenty-one-man committee to chart an American post-war program in that area.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., March 8 -- Selective Service Board 3 here is going to unusual lengths to prevent the draft from breaking up homes.

ALBANY, March 8 -- Former Judge Edward R. Finch of the Court of Appeals, who was appointed by Attorney General Goldstein to pass on the truth or falsity of charges that Sonny Jones, Albany Negro, was beaten by State troopers questioning him in connection with alleged vote frauds, filed a report with the Attorney General today stating that the charges were "wholly false."
Civilian and Navy students at Columbia College show a marked divergence in political opinion, according to a poll conducted by The Columbia, student yearbook, made public yesterday.

MOSCOW, March 8 -- The Soviet Union is paying tribute today to its women who are fighting alongside the Red Army and playing a major role in the manufacture of munitions and material with which the army fights.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Senate action on the much-revised servicemen's voting legislation was postponed today until Monday as proponents and opponents of the "States' rights" program which emerged from a Senate and House conference yesterday prepared for the showdown and wondered whether its final passage would result in a Presidential veto.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 8 (Netherlands Indies News Agency) -- Wanton brutality by the Japanese, terror and hunger have driven whole populations of some of the Netherlands Indies islands into the jungle, it was disclosed today in the first complete report on conditions in the archipelago after two years of Japanese occupation.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
Add to the list of films opening this week, "Amanecer Ranchero," a Mexican importation, which starts tomorrow at the Belmont. Dialogue is Spanish and there are no English titles.

LONDON, March 8 (U.P.) -- Col. Milosh Massalovitch, Cabinet chief under Premier Milan Neditch of the puppet Serb government, was assassinated in Belgrade this morning while on the way to his office, a German DNB agency broadcast said today.

The question of a higher fare on the city-owned transit lines was still being "kicked around" yesterday. The latest development was a letter to Mayor La Guardia from Paul Windels, chairman of the Citizens Transit Committee, urging the Mayor and the City Council to send to the Legislature a home-rule message requesting passage of the pending bill to create a Transit Authority mandated to impose a self-sustaining fare not to exceed 10 cents.

I cannot refrain from commenting on the article which appeared on the front page of THE NEW YORK TIMES on March 6 in reference to the appeal issued by twenty-eight distinguished clergymen and other leaders protesting American participation in the continued "obliteration" bombings of German cities.

A comprehensive survey of "what the American people think about doctors, medical care and prepayment plans" carried out by the Opinion Research Corporation for the National Physicians Committee for the Extension of Medical Service was made public yesterday by the committee at the 1944 conference on the extension of medical care at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Andrew Jackson High School's basketball team reached the semifinal round of the city-wide P.S. A.L. championships for the fifth consecutive year by registering 31-to-25 triumph over the Newtown High at Madison Square Garden yesterday.
Frank Costello, born Francesco Sevaria, walked and rode the city streets yesterday, and no official hand stayed him despite reports of oral police orders that he be picked up on sight.
Use of the New York Public Library in 1943 again proved somewhat of a barometer of the country's business conditions, according to statistics in the library's annual report, issued yesterday.
ALGIERS, March 8 -- The last witness at the treason trial of Pierre Pucheu, former Minister of the Interior in Vichy, was heard in camera today.

As the 1944 Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York began the second week of its annual drive yesterday, Bernon S. Prentice, vice chairman of the campaign, disclosed that a total of $4,902,000, or 21 per cent of the goal of $22,386,000, was raised in the opening week of the drive.

A considerable reduction in the number of Red Army casualties from shock is due in large measure to the work performed in this field by Dr. Walter B. Cannon, American physiologist, it was declared last night by Dr. Vladimir V. Lebedenko, the Soviet Union's representative of the Red Cross and the Red Crescent in the United States.
