BERNE, Switzerland, March 8 -- A renewed advertising campaign has been launched in France to attract recruits to the German armed forces, particularly the French section of the Waffen SS. All sorts of advantages are promised, including extra food rations for relatives, but advertisements are silent on the question of pay.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- How to deal with workers who deliberately invite discharge in order to take more desirable jobs is under discussion by the War Manpower Commission, and officials said today a national policy on "provoked discharges" probably would be formulated soon. They are also concerned about the "provoked quit."
Russian foreign policy is one of the great factors in the future of Europe; British foreign policy is another.

Premier Dobri Boshiloff's Government in Bulgaria has called up more troops following an increase in guerrilla activity and a series of German-Bulgarian military conversations that are expected to be continued at a meeting soon at Adolf Hitler's headquarters, the Swiss newspaper Basler Nachrichten said yesterday.

Increased price-fixing, supplemented by New Orleans and commission house demand, caused cotton futures to make further advances yesterday. At the close of trading, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed gains of 5 to 8 points, or 25 to 40 cents a bale.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 8 -- Loss than one-third of the 6,000,000 striking and locked-out workers of northern Italy returned to their benches this morning following the Government's edict ordering the resumption of work, according to frontier reports received here tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Greater supplies of high-grade shellac for civilian use appeared likely today as the War Production Board announced that it was planning to lift some of the restrictions in the present shellac allocation order.
There has been so much talk recently about the so-called lie detector which has been employed to determine the guilt or innocence of the accused.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (U.P.) -- The Army has a new weapon, known as the "goon gun," a 4.2 mortar which has the assault of light artillery, and can throw a score of twenty-four-pound projectiles two and a half miles in sixty seconds.

LONDON, March 8 -- The European Advisory Commission has started discussing the political, economic and territorial future of Germany, it was learned tonight, The discussions at this stage are nothing but a very tentative exchange of views, but the fact that this fundamental question is now at least being discussed is noteworthy.

Nearly 100,000 veterans in New York and Connecticut have applied for mustering-out pay since the Act of Congress entitling them to the benefits was adopted on Feb. 3, it was revealed yesterday by Col. C.K. McAllister, who is in charge of the Finance Office of the Army at 2 Lafayette Street.

ALBANY, March 8 -- Republican leaders in the Assembly made a pledge today of State aid to New York City for arterial highways, while the Senate, by a vote of 32 to 10, adopted the Hill-Williamson bill authorizing Westchester to charge tolls on its county highway system.

The question whether wives with working husbands should be retained in jobs in preference to war veterans who have less seniority has been raised at the plants in Jamaica, Queens, and Farmingdale, L.I., of the Ranger Aircraft Engines Division, Fairchild Engines and Airplane Corporation, where a layoff of several hundred workers, pending retooling, is impending, it was learned yesterday.

Commissioner William F. Carey said yesterday that "encouraging progress" had been made toward educating New Yorkers as to how they can cooperate best with his Department of Sanitation in the regular Wednesday collection of waste paper and tin cans in the five boroughs.

PEARL HARBOR, March 8 (U.P.) -- Navy Ventura patrol bombers, striking again at the northernmost base of Japan's home defenses, have blasted Paramushiru Island for the fourteenth time, and Army and Navy planes have dropped thirty-one more tons of bombs on isolated Japanese bases in the eastern Marshalls, it was announced today.

As part of a drive to hold down prices on women's and children's clothing, the regional Office of Price Administration obtained restraining orders in Federal Court yesterday against two New York clothing manufacturers who do a total business of $12,000,000 a year.

Another rise in gasoline stocks was recorded last week, but light and heavy fuel oil supplies declined further, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The country's gasoline stocks at the close of the week ended March 4 amounted to 86,091,000 barrels, an increase of 743,000 from 85,248,000 a week earlier. A year ago they were 92,765,000 barrels.

LONDON, March 8 -- Thanks to her enormous production, Great Britain, like the United States, now has a bigger navy than she had before the war in spite of combat losses, Oliver Lyttelton revealed to the House of Commons today.

CHICAGO, March 8 (AP) -- Prices of hogs remained steady today with yesterday's gains, but trading was slow on moderately expanded receipts. While the local receipts of 16,000 head were larger than a week ago. the general supply throughout the Midwest continued to dwindle, and at the twelve major markets shipments this week to date have been about 79,000 head smaller than they were last week.

Household appliances will be featured at the first Civilian Defense Volunteer Office swap shop to be opened about March 27 at 922 Madison Avenue, Mrs. Nathaniel Singer, director of consumer services of the Greater New York CDVO, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Any possibility of a "holiday" for liquor production to build up dwindling stocks on the basis of recent proposals made by the major distilling interests is definitely out, the Foreign Economic Administration made clear today.

Governor Dewey truly says that "citizens who fight for their country have the right to vote." The plan which he offers for the State of New York unfortunately does not guarantee that all our fighting citizens, and especially those in the most trying and exposed positions, will have a chance to exercise that right.
Several leases involving stores were among the commercial contracts reported yesterday by brokers.
LONDON, March 8 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

THE bigger they come the harder they fall, and no one can fall with as much authority or with as resounding a thud as a heavyweight fighter. The beauty of watching these oversize gents in action is that often it matters not which one is ahead. One punch frequently can turn the form charts and the opposition topsy-turvy.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Through its legislative representative, Millard Rice, the Disabled American Veterans today entered a demurrer against the measure known as the "G.I. bill of rights," covering benefits for the soldiers of this war. Formerly known as the American Legion omnibus bill, the bill now carries the endorsement of the Veterans of Foreign Wars.

Mr. and Mrs. Foye F. Staniford of Lawrence, L.I., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Staniford's daughter, Miss Mary Cordelia Thompson, to Pfc. Edward Matthews Crane Jr., USMCR, son of Mr. and Mrs. Crane of 320 East Seventy-second Street and Rumson, N.J.

Carey McWilliams, author of "Brothers Under the Skin," will speak on "A Practical Program for the Solution of America's Race Problem" at 8:15 o'clock tonight at the Ethical Culture Society, 2 West Sixty-fourth Street. His talk is uider the sponsorship of the City-Wide Citizens Committee on Harlem.

The furniture industry must fill the anticipated huge post-war demand for its products by making essential items available to the consumer with an annual earning capacity of $2,500 or less. Raymond Reed, advertising manager of Heywood Wakefield, Inc., said yesterday.

Not to mention anything about the previous four and a half years of this war, but just to thumb through your esteemed paper for one day only (Monday, March 6), we find some illuminating items (Pg. 7, Col. 4) concerning the German plan for the next war, conceived in a sixty-page memorandum by the expert Gen. Ernst von Stuelpnagel.

ALGIERS, March 8 -- A considerable movement of enemy troops around the Allies' beachhead below Rome was observed yesterday, but it was taken as indicating that they were being rearranged and regrouped. But it was not made clear whether this realignment was for a fourth offensive against the Allies' positions or in anticipation of new Allied attacks.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, March 9 -- Sanguinary battles were raging on New Guinea, New Britain and the Admiralty Islands, with the Japanese counter-attacking in the latter two battle areas. We held our own at all points and advanced on Los Negros Island in the Admiralties and north of Saidor on New Guinea.

Consolidated net income last year of the American Sugar Refining Company, according to the annual report for release today, amounted to $4,821,328. This was equal, after preferred dividends, to $3.71 a share of common stock. In 1942 the consolidated net income was $3,783,196, or $1.41 a common share.

DETROIT, March 8 (AP) -- Following a dispute in which a plant protection man was reported injured in the aircraft building of the Ford Motor Company's Rouge plant today, the company warned the United Automobile Workers (CIO) that if "riotous methods" were pursued the company could see no object of continuing its contract with the union.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 8 (AP) -- The Allies' blockade of the Aegean Sea, in which the Royal Air Force alone sank or damaged some sixty German ships last month, has produced a desperate food situation in the Aegean Islands and brought a refusal from some German troops to make the perilous voyage from Crete to the mainland, reports reaching here said today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 8 -- Finland's answer to Moscow's armistice terms, submitted last Monday through Stockholm, rejects three Russian points, compliance with which Moscow made the pre-condition for the signing of an armistice agreement, an unimpeachable high Finnish source said today.

A UNITED STATES FIGHTER BASE, England, March 8 (AP) -- Lieut. Charles F. Gumm Jr., a fighter ace who was the first Mustang pilot to shoot down an enemy plane over Europe, died a hero's death eight days ago to save civilians from his crashing plane, it was disclosed today.

Alfonso Lopez, President of Colombia, was inaugurated on Aug. 7, 1942. This, his second term, is considerably less than half through. Yet it is announced that he will resign at a special session of Congress in April. He tried to resign in his first term in 1937 because he was dissatisfied with the action of parties in Congress.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Three billowing parachutes served as substitutes for brakes on the shell-riddled Army bomber that was the first American plane to land on the fighter strip on Tarawa, in the Gilbert Islands.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Agriculture which is investigating the Rural Electrification Administration took further testimony today from Jonathan Daniels, an administrative assistant to the President, and then decided to cancel its recommendation that he be cited for contempt for previous refusals to answer questions and to issue no subpoena for or even request to see Mr. Roosevelt's files on the REA.

The exchange liner Gripsholm carrying expatriated Americans from Germany, is expected to reach New York harbor late Tuesday and dock in Jersey City about 9 A.M. on Wednesday, the American Export Lines announced yesterday.

Steel production in the United States for February and the first two months of 1944 were the highest on record for those periods, according to a report by the American Iron and Steel Institute placing February output at 7,188,482 net tons, compared to 7,595,202 tons in January and with 6,823,738 tons in February, 1943.

TRENTON, March 8 -- Motorists with defective windshield wipers, broken fenders, improperly focused auxiliary driving or parking lights and other minor flaws will no longer get rejections for those reasons at the State's twenty-eight automobile testing stations, it was announced today by Motor Vehicle Commissioner Arthur W. Magee. Inspectors will call attention to the deficiencies, but drivers will not be compelled to return for another test.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Preliminary meetings between the leaders of both parties in Congress to discuss legislation for continuing the present powers of the Office of Price Administration beyond their expiration date of June 30 were forecast today as both House and Senate prepared to question OPA executives.

Assets of the New York Life Insurance Company at the close of 1943 amounted to $3,342,000,000, of which $1,608,000,000, or 48 per cent, consisted of United States Government obligations, according to the annual report to policy holders, issued yesterday.

Since the balance of power shifted in the Pacific we have been winning such spectacular victories that a certain section of the public accepts them as indicating the early defeat of Japan. Admiral Nimitz's sober remarks at his Washington press conference should dispel any such runaway optimism.

PHILADELPHIA, March 8 (AP) -- J. Clifford Folger, president of the Investment Bankers Association of America, urged today that the Government provide a "catalogue" of all business firms which have received Government loans or advances.

ALBANY, March 8 -- While the Legislature was plowing through heavy calendars in both houses today, the ders reached the conclusion that they could not have an orderly adjournment next week, because of the pressure of last-minute legislation.
Add signs of spring: The business of providing fish for New York's angling hordes is in full flight, and it won't be long, April 1, to be specific, before these hordes descend upon the trout.

Operations of the Eastman Kodak Company last year resulted in record-breaking sales and operating income and the second largest earnings in the forty-one year history of the company, according to the annual statement issued for publication today.

LOS ANGELES, March 8 (AP) -Carol Ann Berry, five months old, was allowed today to have her "day in court" when a Superior Court judge overruled Charlie Chaplin's motion to dismiss the paternity suit brought against him by Joan Berry, the baby's mother.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Officers of three companies building Liberty ships and Joseph Curran, head of the CIO's National Maritime Union, whose members man most of them, agreed today when they testified before the Truman committe that the "cracking up" of a few of them under stress of war service did not discredit the value of these ugly ducklings as cargo carriers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 8 -- Anna Lee, who returned recently from an overseas Army camp tour, has been signed by Edward Small for the feminine lead, with William Bendix and Dennis O'Keefe, in the United Artists comedy, "Abroad With Two Yanks."

Judge John A. Mullen in General Sessions yesterday set March 20 for the new trial of Wayne Lonergan for the murder of his wife, Patricia Burton Lonergan. Judge Mullen, who is sitting in Part I, or the motion part, of the court, assigned the trial to Part IX, over which Judge James Garrett Wallace is presiding in the March term.

Light metals, plastics and alcohols will form the three basic industries of the future, Dr. William J. Hale, research consultant for the Dow Chemical Company stated yesterday. Outlining the potential capacities of each of the industries before a meeting of the Advertising Club of New York, Dr. Hale predicted that within two decades the combined fields would manufacture products having a market value in excess of $12,000,000,000.

CHICAGO, March 8 -- Strength in securities and cotton led to a little professional buying of wheat futures in the early trading today on the Board of Trade and prices were up 1/8% to 1/4 cent a bushel at one time. Later, when rye started to break, pressure appeared and the market weakened and last sales snowed net losses of 1/8 to 1/2 cent, the former on May.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- John A. Stephens, chairman of the Steel Case Research Committee and vice president of the United States Steel Corporation, provoked an immediate controversy today as the first industry witness at the opening of hearings by a panel of the National War Labor Board when he charged that the demands of the United Steel Workers of America, CIO, "deliberately" attacked the national stabilization policy.

Stockholders of the United Cigar-Whelan Stores Corporation will be called to a special meeting on May 23 to vote on a plan for the issuance of five shares of new $20 par prior preferred stock and $2 in cash for each outstanding share of no-par preferred stock, on which dividends in arrears will be $25 a share on May 1 next.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- James L. Fry, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, took the stand again today before the special House committee investigating his agency to make further denial of charges made against it by previous witnesses, and specifically to deny that he or the commission was in any way responsible for the surprise attack by the Japanese on Pearl Harbor.

LONDON, March 8 (AP) -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the House of Commons today that the British Government would continue to maintain a guarded, watchful attitude toward Argentina until the political situation there was clarified.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- President Roosevelt received from a committee of the Civil Liberties Union today a petition asking for increased remuneration for men classified as conscientious objectors to war and ending of military influence in the control over them.

The purchase by a syndicate of the sixteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 944 Park Avenue from the Bowery Savings Bank was announced yesterday. Tobias, Heller Co., general contractors, are members of the syndicate, which intends to convert the nine and ten room suites in the building into small apartments when materials are available.

There is reason to believe that the strikes which have paralyzed the war industries and the transportation system in the north of Italy since March 1 were originally planned to coincide with the expected liberation of Rome. This only stresses their significance as an organized political demonstration.
Mrs. Tobin Clark and Mrs. Alexander Albert have arrived from San Mateo, Calif., and are at the Savoy-Plaza.

Sidney B. Wood Jr., former Wimbledon champion and a member of the top ten, has been added to the all-star cast of tennis players who will participate in the Red Cross matches at Madison Square Garden next Tuesday night.

HOLLYWOOD, March 8 (AP) -- Sammy Angott lost his National Boxing Association world lightweight championship tonight to Juan Zurita of Mexico City in a desultory fifteen-round bout in Hollywood Baseball Park.

A NIGHT-FIGHTER BASE, in Italy, March 8 -- Night-fighter pilots live topsy-turvy lives and hunt only when the sun is down. They hunt singly rather than in packs, stalking their prey through the gusty, cold, Italian darkness above cloud-blanketed peaks.

BOSTON, March 8 (AP) -- Wendell Willkie declared tonight that the Presidential election would turn on "the ability of the Republican party to cut the President's strength on the Atlantic and Pacific seaboards, in the industrial seaboard cities and metropolitan centers of the Midwest."

LONDON, March 9 -- King Peter will accompany Prime Minister Bozidar Pouritch and other members of the Royal Yugoslav Governmen to London for their talks with Prime Minister Winston Churchill, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and Edward R. Stettinius, it was learned tonight.

LONDON, March 8 -- The black nightmare of another major coal strike is disturbing Britain. Tonight there are nearly 80,000 men idle in South Wales, where some of the best steam coal in the world is to be found.

Outstanding department store installment accounts at the end of January were 26 per cent below a year ago, and showed about the usual decline from December, the Federal Reserve Board made known yesterday. Charge accounts receivable declined by slightly more than the customary seasonal amount in January, but continued near the level of a year ago.

Both favorites performed as expected, so to New York University and St. John's went the spoils in the regular season's final college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden last night. The Violets, breaking away from a persistent foe late in the second half, took the measure of City College, 56 -- 46, after St. John's had routed Brooklyn College, 55 -- 42, to retain the metropolitan championship.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- Republicans rejoiced today over another special Congressional election victory, this time in the Denver district in Colorado where a business man defeated a war hero, who was a political neophyte. They looked upon the result as supporting their contention that the November elections may turn on domestic rathter han war issues.

Todd Duncan, who is best known hereabouts as the genial Porgy in "Porgy and Bess," made his New York recital debut at Town Hall last night and in so doing confirmed the impression gathered from his stage appearances that he is a singer of exceptional talents.

As the contribution of the 500 women members of the Pen and Brush Club to the $22,386,000 drive of the 1944 Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York, the second annual Red Cross fiesta will open at 2:30 P.M. today in the Community Church Auditorium.

The Japanese Cabinet approved a new mobilization decree during a four-hour meeting in the Imperial Palace yesterday, the Tokyo radio reported, as the home front was exhorted to resolve itself into "one burning ball of fire" to win the war.

A special performance of Wagner's "Parsifal" was given last night in the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Metropolitan Opera Fund, in which Emil Cooper, the conductor, and all the artists, donated their services.
The past year has been among the most momentous in our history so far as food is concerned.

LONDON, March 8 -- Germany has left nothing to chance in preparing the railroads under her control to meet the strain of resisting Allied invasion of the Continent, according to experts here, who have evidence of heavy capital expenditure on the lines.
The American Brake Shoe Company declared yesterday its regular 25-cent dividend and an extra of 10 cents on its common stock. In 1943 it paid 15 cents extra in March and 50 cents extra in December.

The three-family house at 1465 Forty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Greater New York Savings Bank to Gussie Paleschuch and Ethel Brod through Gaetano Derise, broker. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

LONDON, March 8 -- The largest daylight air attack ever mounted against a single target area was carried out today on Berlin with striking success by about 2,000 warplanes under the United States Strategic Air Forces' command.

Sixty-three contemporary American paintings from its permanent collections, including six recently bought from the Whitney Museum annual, have been placed on view on the balcony of the Main Hall of the Metropolitan Museum. This exhibition is the first step in a new policy to reserve the balcony for shows of contemporary art from the permanent collection and to keep contemporary art before the public while the main galleries are being redecorated.

Penalties even more harsh than those recommended by the prosecutor were imposed by Federal Judge Grover C. Moscowitz yesterday on a group of eight men who had conspired in the disposal of stolen securities worth $186,000. The group included Frank L. Miller, a lawyer; the only one who had been convicted at a trial, instead of pleading guilty.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Jobs will have to be found for 130,000,000 people throughout the world as the war economy is dismantled, the International Labor Office estimated today in a report prepared for discussion at the International Labor Conference in Philadelphia April 20.

Business in the stock market proceeded yesterday at the fastest pace in four months and prices approached the high marks set last October. Large unemployed funds were released and found their way into a wide variety of industrial issues as well as into some specialties, as trading encompassed the greatest number of individual stocks since early last November.

LONDON, March 8 (AP) -- Chances for a rapprochement between the Polish Government-in-exile and the Russian Government faded tonight as Moscow's flat rejection of the Poles' offer to establish a temporary Polish-Russian boundary was conveyed to the Poles by the British, through whom it was transmitted.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 8 -- A token shipment of the first lend-lease materials for Saudi Arabia was delivered to King Ibn Saud on Monday by two American generals in circumstances that would have done credit to a Jules Verne interpretation of the Arabian Nights, it was disclosed today.

ALBANY, March 8 -- An agreement under which New York City will take over five of the six State barge canal terminal piers and warehouses in New York City, with the sixth going to the Port of New York Authority, was disclosed today.

JERUSALEM, March 8 - Palestinian Arab circles were jubilant today over what was regarded as the successful first round in the campaign launched by neighboring Middle East governments against the proposed United States Congress resolution favoring a Jewish State.

Crane Haussamen's prize-winning play, "Return to Eden," has been bought by Guthrie McClintic, who is contemplating a spring production, according to our Washington scout. The author, who won first prize of $500 for his work in the recent Pittsburgh Drama League contest, is a member of the Washington staff of the OWI.

It is not quite true that all the New York Public Library needs is more books. It has lost 240 members of its staff since Pearl Harbor, 220 to military service. Three former librarians have died in battle. For those who remain the salaries are still low. Is there some unemployed New Yorker who has a college degree, a library school degree and special training, say, in the field of adolescent literature and psychology?

Asserting that "the only indispensable person in America is the American boy who dies needlessly in combat" because of strikes and inexcusable failures on the home front, Capt. Edward V. Rickenbacker, president of the Eastern Air Lines, denounced last night as "termites" those who would tear down the prestige of Congress and called for the election of a President who will respect States' rights and "will not cater to or coddle minorities or pressure groups."

Successful bombing raids on the Reich have caused to be released by one Vera Brittain, a British writer, an article released in England as "Seeds of Chaos" and in the United States under the caption, "Massacre by Bombing."

MOSCOW, March 8 -- This correspondent's conclusions after his recent visit to the Ukranian front, including a close inspection of the scene of the entrapment of the Eighth German Army, can be summed up as follows:

LONDON, Thursday, March 9 -- The Soviet First Ukrainian Army hurled back repeated counter-attacks by reinforced German infantry and tanks yesterday and advanced along the north bank of the upper Bug River to within seven miles northwest of the key junction of Proskurov on the Odessa-Lwow railroad by capturing the town of Gruzhevitsa, fifty-nine miles north of the Rumanian border.

LONDON, March 8 -- Capt Walker Mahurin of Fort Wayne, Ind., a Thunderbolt pilot, was credited with knocking down three German planes today to bring his total to twenty and put him at the top of the list of Eighth Air Force aces.

Every once in so often a selling job in the securities business stands out. There was one such yesterday -- the marketing of 15,000 shares of Royal Typewriter by Shields Co. at 18 3/4, with the not extravagant special commission of 50 cents. Although the entire February volume in the stock was 8,500 shares, bids were received for 31,355 shares and had to be allotted on a basis of 47.8 per cent.

In an effort to conserve paper, the Joint Committee on Government Relations of the Commercial Printing Industry is seeking to have the caption "Designed to conserve paper for the war effort" appear on all printed matter, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Efforts on the part of any manufacturer to "beat the gun" and return to civilian business will be unavailing, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, told more than 250 key advertising and business executives gathered here for an "off-the-record" review of military and civilian aspects of the war situation.

Gay, amusing ideas with a do-it-yourself twist have been carried out in a series of twelve table settings called "Whimsical Party Fare" that went on display yesterday at Wanamaker's. At first glance some of the settings seemed to be on the extravagant side, but the intention is to present decorative ideas -- which the hostess can adapt according to her purse -- rather than actual merchandise.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- A report in this space two days ago of the growing impatience and uneasiness with which members of Congress, as well as many outside groups, are viewing the fog that surrounds the war and postwar foreign policy of the United States mentioned the rising fear that this condition may bring about a bitter Congressional debate which would damage the unity of the United Nations.

Declaring that the twenty-seven private colleges and universities for Negroes represented in the United Negro College Fund provide nearly 50 per cent of the college training received by Negroes, Dr. F.D. Patterson, president of Tuskegee Institute, yesterday called upon Americans to see that all citizens of this country have equal educational opportunity.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- A "pronounced reluctance" by some manufacturers to accept contracts for war production was reported today by James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy.

President Roosevelt, Mrs. Roosevelt and Herbert H. Lehman, Director General of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, express hope that the rescue of Jewish children from the Nazis will continue in cables to be sent today to Miss Henrietta Szold, founder of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, who is in Jerusalem.
NAPLES, March 8 (AP) -- A grim secret kept for more than a month has been placed in the record of heroic but hopeless "last stands."

Production of civilian underwear this year will run from 25 to 30 per cent less than in 1943, Roy A. Cheney, president of the Underwear Institute, said at a press conference at the Yale Club yesterday. He warned that price ceilings will have a major effect on output in the weeks directly ahead, as a number of mills are already showing a loss in their over-all operations.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- A point of order made by Representative Taber of New York, that the attempted elimination of a $40,000,000 limitation on Lanham act child-care projects, under the Federal Works Agency section of the deficiency bill, would constitute "legislation under an appropriation bill," was quickly conceded today and the item was reinstated minus the limitation eliminating clause.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics' index of commodity prices in primary markets dropped 0.2 per cent during the week ended on March 4, chiefly because of lower prices for livestock, grains, cotton and certain fruits and vegetables. Quotations for principal industrial commodities were generally unchanged.

FORT BELVOIR, Va., March 9 -- Lieut. Gen. Brehon Somervell, commanding general, marked the first anniversary of the Army Service Forces today with the warning that, despite prodigious accomplishments, "bitter fighting lies ahead."

Seventy survivors of a medium-sized merchant ship which broke in two after it was torpedoed recently off the Atlantic Coast, arrived yesterday at the United Seamen's Service Branch at 134 West Fifty-eighth Street.

Member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City finished the fiscal week ended on Wednesday with reserve requirements and actual reserves on hand in exact balance, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, March 10 (U.P.) -- A communique:
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Casualties of the armed services of the United States have reached a total of 162,282.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox defended the proposed $150,000,000 Arabian oil pipeline before the House Foreign Affairs Committee today, declaring it is a military necessity and essential to prevent draining of vast amounts of oil from dwindling United States reserves.

CONCORD, N.H., March 9 -- Wendell L. Willkie called today for the unlocking of America's economic doors by abandonment of "narrow nationalism" as a means of dispelling what he described as a growing fear for the future of the country when peace returns.

The United Negro Colleges Fund seeks to raise $1,500,000 this year to be used by twenty-seven institutions of higher learning in continuing and improving Negro education in America. The sum is a small one to ask for a work that promises benefits so vast, not alone to the Negro but to the nation as well.

IN the market -- place of Stuttgart some 400 years ago a young peasant was beheaded for his part in the desperate peasants' rebellion that was put down with a ferocity worthy of the Germans of this supposedly more enlightened century. Just before the executioner's sword descended he cried out, "Alas! Now I must die, and in all my life I have never twice eaten my fill of bread."

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Gen. Thomas Holcomb of Delaware, who was commandant of the Marine Corps, until his recent retirement, was nominated by President Roosevelt today to be Minister to the Union of South Africa. The nomination was one of several in the diplomatic service sent to the Senate.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 9 -- Vichy is feeling a little more German pressure because the repression of resistance has not come up to expectations. The Germans stress that relatively few recalcitrants have been rounded up to be sent to the Reich for forced labor.

A glimpse into the future of mass production and prefabrication of housing and other types of buildings was given yesterday at the opening of a prefabrication exhibit, said to be the first of its kind under sponsorship of a society representing architecture and allied arts.

BOSTON, March 9 -- Urging the United States to accept its "fair share" of responsibility for the government of colonies after the war, faculty groups in forty-two colleges and universities have recommended the establishment of an international colonial commission to supervise the administration of mandated and dependent areas.

Wounded so badly by a German bomb that it took "more or less of a miracle to save me," Boatswain's Mate M.P. Booker of Macon, Ga., who is still convalescing, took part yesterday in a Pershing Square Information Center rally at which the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office officially opened a month-long educational program on the control of careless talk.
The great strength of American air forces now based in Britain has been illustrated by this week's series of major attacks on Berlin and other German cities.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total holdings of United States Government securities to have increased $404,631,000 during the week to the highest figure on record.
I Lieut. Comdr. John D. Houghton, USNR, and Mrs. HoughtonL have arrived from Kittery Point,] Me., and are at the Biltmore.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 9 (AP) -- Finland has sent a revised reply to Russian armistice demands which may be a satisfactory basis for furthering the negotiations, it was strongly indicated here today.

LOS ANGELES, March 9 (AP) -- Charles Chaplin and six other defendants failed in an attempt to set aside Federal grand jury indictments charging them with conspiracy to deprive Joan Berry, the actor's former protege, of her civil rights.

OTTAWA, Ont., March 9 -- Presenting naval estimates totaling $410,000,000 in the House of Commons today Angus L. Macdonald, Minister of Naval Defense, said that offensive U-boat action in the Atlantic was an essential part of Germany's defense and that until she was ready to throw in her hand her attacks on Allied shipping must be expected to continue.

Thirty thousand entry blanks for the Handcraft Contest of the New York Community Trust Winter Sports Championship have been distributed to boys and girls under 18 years old throughout the metropolitan area. The Boy Scouts and Girl Scouts are cooperating.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- If the President's release of his assistant, Jonathan Daniels, to testify before a Senate Agriculture subcommittee was the reason why the group decided to suspend its argument with the White House, then Mr. Roosevelt rendered the subcommittee a double service.

As the Red Cross 1944 War Fund of Greater New York started yesterday its drive for $3,000,000 in employe gifts as part of its $22,386,000 campaign, reports reached its headquarters at 130 West Forty-second Street indicating a rising tide of contributions from wage earners throughout the city.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Davis D. Graves, commander of an Army Air Forces fighter wing in the Mediterranean, has been missing in action over Italy since Feb. 8, the War Department announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- Secretary Knox told Congress today that the Axis now knew that the only remaining chance it had for victory was Allied disunity and he said that this last enemy prop could be knocked out by extension of the Lend-Lease Act.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 9 (AP) -- President Juan Antonio Rios said today that Chile's decision in the matter of Argentina "could not by any means whatever be considered as a departure from our established and demonstrated policy of continental unity, defense of the Americas and of sincere cooperation and friendship with the United States."

CILFYNYDD, Wales, March 9 -- A small cloud of steam waving like a white flag over the colliery was the only thing that moved here today. The great wheels, mounted high above the pithead, were motionless. Strings of coal cars, many of them loaded, stood deserted on the tracks, even the streets of this little town, carved out of a steep hillside, were silent.

Every Thursday night it is customary for the Treasury to mail to banks and others single-sheet announcements of the weekly issue of $1,000,000,000 of Treasury bills to be sold on the following Monday. Then on the following day it has been sending out to all interested parties mimeographed sheets giving the results of the sale of the preceding issue classified according to Federal Reserve districts.
BOSTON, March 9 (AP) -- More than 11,000,000 pounds of foreign wool were sold at auction today, with knitting mills and top-makers among the heavier purchasers.

LONDON, Friday, March 10 (U.P.) -- The Red Army, in a supreme drive to clear the Ukraine, has torn a huge gap in the German lower Dnieper lines, plunging to within forty miles of the Black Sea port of Nikolayev, Moscow announced last night.

CHICAGO, March 9 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens, who have clinched the National Hockey League pennant, rang up their thirty-fourth victory of the season tonight, as against four losses, by downing the Chicago Black Hawks, 3 -- 2, before 13,925 spectators at the Stadium.
NEW DELHI, India, March 9 (UP) -- A communique:

PRINCETON, N.J., March 9 -- Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey's recent statement that the Selective Service is "scraping the bottom of the manpower barrel" in its search for more than a million persons by July 1 once again throws into sharp focus the question of drafting single women for non-combat military service.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Allegations that American Army airmen must depend on a parachute requiring three releases when it reaches the ground, instead of the single-release, or British type, were denied at the Pentagon Building today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 9 -- Protests from Pelham, Larchmont, Mamaroneck and Harrison failed today to deter the Westchester County Board of Supervisors from approving, 29 to 3, a pending legislative bill that would establish procedure for post-war construction of the Pelham-Port Chester Parkway as part of a Boston-Washington through-way for mixed traffic.

Reflecting aggressive price-fixing in the near positions supplemented by increased trade buying, cotton futures made further advances yesterday. At the close of trading active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 1 to 5 points, or 5 to 25 cents a bale, above Wednesday's final quotations.

THE biggest shock any football season produced came when Notre Dame abandoned the Notre Dame system and adopted the new-fangled T-formation. Not that the T was new, please understand, but it was so old that its reincarnation gave it the sheen and gloss of newness. The die-hards blinked and couldn't believe their eyes.

Replying to the charges of Stanley M. Isaacs, Manhattan Councilman, that the school system could close many of its forty-four annexes, Ellsworth B. Buck, president of the Board of Education, declared yesterday that annexes were closed "as soon as we find out we can get along without them."
LONDON, March 9 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast

PEARL HARBOR, March 9 (AP) -- Several formations of Japanese bombers raided Eniwetok yesterday for the first time since American forces completed capture of that northernmost atoll of the Marshall Islands on Feb. 22.

WITH THE ALLIED BEACHHEAD FORCES AT ANZIO, March 4 (Delayed) -- Gen. Sir Harold old Alexander, Allied commander in Italy, told war correspondents today after a tour of inspection that "things are very much better on the beachhead than when I was here last three weeks ago."

ALBANY, March 9 -- A broad plan for enforcement and strengthening of existing anti-discrimination laws, drafted by the State Committee on Discrimination in Employment, was put before the Legislature today in two bills offered by Senator Arthur H. Wicks, Republican whip of the Upper House, at the committee's request.

Three years ago tomorrow the Lend-Lease Act received the President's signature. The occasion marked the end of our vain effort to remain isolated in an age of air travel and neutral when every interest that was close to us and every principle we valued was in deadly peril.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- Technical Sergeant Charles E. Kelly, from Pittsburgh, will be decorated with the Congressional Medal of Honor Saturday for his feats in Italy. This award of the country's highest honor will be made "somewhere in the North African theatre," the War Department said today in passing on reports which told of what he had done.

The board of directors of Freedom House issued a statement yesterday assailing the twenty-eight clergymen and other leaders who have called for a cessation of "obliteration" bombings of German cities as having given a "distinct shock to the majority of Americans" and provided a "great lift to enemy morale."

JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, March 8 (Delayed) -- Machine-gun-armed American troops stood guard today as $1,520,000 in Saudi Arabian silver coins, minted in Philadelphia under lend-lease, were heaved like so many sacks of potatoes on the dock here, with one broken case spurting a silvery stream at the feet of gaping Arab officials and pilgrims.

The Berlin radio broadcast to Britain yesterday an early release of Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels' latest article in the publication Reich, in which he said that "England's war has been based on a tragic mistake" and expressed concern for the true England, which would be destroyed by "an avalanche to the left in Britain" should Russia win.

The six-story apartment house on a plot 100 by 125 feet at 945 East 163d Street, the Bronx, has been sold by Aaron Rabinowitz, James L. Clare and Adrian P. Burke, trustees of Series F-1, to a client of Reuben Klein and I. Arthur Rosenberg, attorneys.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The War Manpower Commission was reported today to be drawing up recommendations that the draft classification 2-A, comprised of registrants who are necessary in civilian activities contributing to the war program, be abolished by Selective Service and that a "tougher" attitude be taken in granting deferments for those in 2-P, registrants essential in war production other than agriculture.

WITH THE AMERICANS IN HUKAWNG VALLEY, March 9 -- The Japanese here have dug into strong underground and trench positions but are being steadily reduced by American automatic weapons and mortars and by air bombings and strafings.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 9 (AP) -- Sparkling Maid, feather-weighted at 103 pounds, barely lasted in a hard stretch for a half length triumph in the Lake Worth purse today at Tropical Park.

Reorganization of the magistrate's courts to enable them to handle the increased load resulting from Office of Price Administration enforcement drives and adolescent delinquency, without adding to the number of city magistrates, is planned by Chief Magistrate Henry H. Curran, he made known yesterday.

DETROIT, March 9 (AP) -- While high officials of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, looked on, the Ford Motor Company today discharged ten men for participating in a Rouge plant disturbance in which a plant protection man was beaten and a labor relations office damaged.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Preliminary discussions have been in progress for six months between officials of the British and Canadian Governments and an American interdepartmental group looking toward an eventual international economic conference here.
Give an American soldier meat, ice cream and fresh fruit and he cleans his plate, but when the menu includes liver, kidney beans, spinach and other greens his appetite begins to lag.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Joseph B. Eastman, Office of Defense Transportation Director, reported the start today of a country-wide drive to enlist 100,000 men and women to fill "present and impending" job vacancies on the railroads.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The increase in liquor hijacking in the last six months, traceable largely to shortage of normal supplies, has become so serious there is danger of its "spreading across the country like a prairie fire," J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, warned today.

B.F. Goodrich Company, Akron, won first award in the industrial group of the second annual advertising competition of the Associated Business Papers of Chicago, it was announced yesterday. The agency handling the advertising was Griswold-Eshleman Company, Cleveland.

Blair, Bonner Co. has been reorganized as William Blair Co., with William McCormick Blair, Wallace M. Flower, Don G. Niehls, Leo H. Ostrander and Daniel J. Ritter as partners. Blair, Bonner Co. will continue in business as the William Blair Corporation and will confine its activities to the supervision of investment accounts.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- A legislative campaign to bring the financial operations of the $700,000,000 Tennessee Valley Authority under the control of Congress opened today under the leadership of Senator Kenneth McKellar of Tennessee, long a foe of the TVA chairman, David E. Lilienthal.

Appealing for strict discipline in the Fire Department in an informal talk yesterday to forty captains who had just received their promotions, Mayor La Guardia criticized those members whom he termed "smart alecks" and "agitators" who he charged had attempted to run the department.

The key case in organized labor's efforts to break the Little Steel formula is now under way with the opening of the panel hearings for the steel industry. The objective of organized labor in this case was clearly summarized by Philip Murray before the National War Labor Board on Feb. 7, when he said "frankly" that "we are trying to change the stabilization policy."

Spring sends its advance scouts to the south side of the woodlot. Here the sun's rays seem to concentrate and to warm the late winter air. Inside the woods it is still and frosty, and the accumulated snow crunches squeakily underfoot. But here on the south side of the tree barrier there's a cheerful, brief, preliminary caucus.

The stock market spent part of yesterday consolidating its recent gains, but enough selling appeared to produce a spotty closing. Activity was reduced considerably, but still held within the million-share range. The rails and an assorted list of specialties confirmed the recent strength in the industrials.
Housing properties along the West Side featured realty activity in Manhattan yesterday.

Lieut. J. Donald Budge of the Army Air Forces, world tennis champion, and Cadet John A. Kramer of the New London Coast Guard Academy, hard-hitting youngster regarded as successor to the Budge mantle, will meet in the feature match on the Red Cross program at Madison Square Garden next Tuesday night.

It resembled Children's Day at the fashion show held yesterday by Macy's at the Plaza. The "small fry" captured all the plaudits in the Easter prevue of mother and daughter fashions. "Just like "mother's" were tiny tailored coats of shepherd checks, crisp little suits of flannel and bright red reefer coats.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- Ted Gamble, national war loan director, said today that the cost of selling war bonds was about one-thirty-third of a cent for every dollar collected.

The novelty of the concert given by Dr. Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall was Samuel Barber's Second symphony, composed by commission of the Army Air Forces and dedicated to them. The symphony is further to be broadcast over short wave stations by the Office of War Information and scores of the work sent to London and Moscow.

In the first move of its kind involving the removal of demountable housing from another section of the country to the New York region of the Federal Public Housing Authority, the FPHA yesterday awarded a contract for the transfer of 172 surplus war homes from La Porte, Ind., for re-erection at Chambersburg, Pa., one of the few points in the region still urgently needing additional accommodations for workers.

Louis Capone, who was executed last Saturday night with Louis (Lepke) Buchalter and Emanuel (Mendy) Weiss for the murder of a middle-aged Brooklyn storekeeper, was the least publicized of the three gangsters, but his funeral yesterday in Coney Island was the most flamboyant of the three.

Direct efforts by six States to nullify the Fair Labor Standards Act, and the lowering of child labor standards by one-half of the States were charged yesterday by L. Metcalfe Walling, director of the wage and hour and public contracts divisions of the United States Department of Labor, in his report for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1943.

LOS ANGELES, March 9 (AP) -- Sammy Angott, dethroned last night as N.B.A. lightweight champion in a 15-round fight with Juan Zurita of Mexico City, today passed his physical examination and may be inducted any time after March 30.

LONDON, March 9 -- Edward R. Stettinius Jr., United States Under-Secretary of State; Viscount Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States; Herbert V. Evatt, Australian Attorney General, and Sir Stafford Cripps, British Minister of Aircraft Production, will mark the anniversary of lend-lease on Saturday by a broadcast arranged jointly by the American Office of War Information and the British Broadcasting Corporation, it was announced today.

Joe Baksi will be back in the main bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. The Kulpmont (Pa.) heavyweight who sprang to nation-wide prominence two weeks ago by scoring an upset triumph over Tami Mauriello will engage the veteran Lee Savold of Des Moines in a ten-round scrap.

The conservative attitude of the majority of the nation's citizens toward their increased buying power during the war augurs well for the development of private industry after the war, William B. Bailey, economist for the Travelers Insurance Company of Hartford, declared yesterday.

Surprisingly, there seems to have been little or no comment on the President's recent demand for an increase in the deductions from the nation's pay checks that are now being made under our Social Security program. Social Security does not need funds. It is taking in, currently, about eight times as much as it pays out.

LISBON, Portugal, March 9 (AP) -- Douglas MacArthur 2d, diplomat nephew of Gen. Douglas MacArthur, gaunt after internment in Germany, was in no mood for friendly small talk recently when he met well-fed Gaston Henry-Haye, former Vichy Ambassador to Washington, a witness reported here today.
Few meets have produced as many track milestones as has the Knights of Columbus event which will pull the quilts over the local season tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden.

The poet Coleridge had definite views on the indoctrination of young people. They would have sounded old-fashioned only a few years ago but seem to be coming back into favor today. One is always meeting them in discussions of child delinquency.

A panel of 300 blue-ribbon talesmen, including three women, was drawn yesterday in the Commissioner of Jurors' office in the Supreme Court Building for the second trial of Wayne Lonergan on the indictment accusing him of the murder of his wife, Patricia Burton Lonergan. The trial will open March 20.

Regulations aimed at taking younger men out of war plants at once, regardless of seniority, to fill the needs of the armed forces, were announced yesterday by Col. Arthur V. McDermott, New York City Selective Service Director.
LONDON, Friday, March 10 (U.P.) -- The Russian Thursday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

The Phelps Dodge Corporation and its subsidiaries had last year a consolidated net income of $14,079,560 after provision of $17,800,000 for excess profits and income taxes and renegotiation of war contracts and a transfer of $500,000 to reserve for contingencies, but before depletion, according to the annual report of Louis S. Cates, president, submitted for publication today.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Donald M. Nelson, head of the War Production Board, advocated today a program of reconversion of industry away from wartime manufacture which would encourage civilian production wherever possible but would place restrictions on the entrance of "new" companies into industrial fields until the needs of established firms for critical materials had been met.

LONDON, March 9 -- Prime Minister Churchill announced today in the House of Commons that the British Government would promote the teaching of basic English. Then he immediately demonstrated that he, personally, would have nothing to do with it.

Gross revenues and power output of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation system reached new highs last year, Earle J. Machold, president, said yesterday in his annual report to stockholders. Net income, however, declined.

The annual pamphlet report of the General Foods Corporation, mailed yesterday to its 68,210 stockholders, disclosed that net working capital at the end of 1943 totaled $71,034,161, against $61,781,827 a year earlier and $48,754,624 at the close of 1941.

LONDON, Friday, March 10 -- The Battle of Berlin, which is the most important operation in the campaign to eliminate the Luftwaffe, took a new and surprising turn yesterday. Strong forces of Fortresses and Liberators of the Eighth Air Force hammered industrial targets in the German capital through a "ten-tenths" cloud but met only meager opposition from the enemy metropolitan fighter force.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill jointly revealed tonight the striking progress of the Allied victories over the German U-boats.

Mayor La Guardia told a committee of right-wing leaders of the American Labor party who waited upon him yesterday (in City Hall that he was opposed to the Hillman plan for vesting control of Labor party machinery and policies in trade unions, according to Alex Rose, State secretary of the party and one of those at the conference.

The Office of War Information has renewed its program to have American exports carry distinctive labeling to indicate the American origin of merchandise, traders reported yesterday. The agency has urged exporters to become acquainted with specimens of distinctive colored labels which it has devised to advertise American goods.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- As a climax of an acrimonious session of the War Labor Board's steel dispute panel today, John C. Gall, attorney for the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company, proposed that the demand of the United Steel Workers for a wage increase of 17 cents an hour be excluded from consideration because both union and labor board officials had frankly admitted that this demand would mean a scrapping of the Little Steel formula.

Coordination of activities of local agencies concerned over the rise in juvenile delinquency was urged yesterday by Bradford Chambers, who is working with the Youth Counsel Bureau of the New York County District Attorney's office on a delinquency-prevention program.

MOSCOW, March 9 -- The Red Army's newspaper paid high tribute today to the "powerful and systematic blows" inflicted upon German industrial centers and vital communications, and the resultant lowering of German civilian and military morale, by day and night British and American bombers, but disagreed with the theory that air power alone can win the war.

For some time now a few expert fishermen have been going quietly about the business of putting their talents to work by helping disabled service men on the road to rehabilitation. It started when the authorities at Halloran General Hospital on Staten Island asked the Anglers Club to do something for the patients in the way of teaching fly tying and showing fishing movies.

CHICAGO, March 9 -- Henry J. Kaiser, shipbuilder and contractor, urged all sections of the housing industry today to get together on plans for a country-wide building program after the war with profits secondary to mass employment.

NEW DELHI, India, March 9 (U.P.) -- Paced by the Guadalcanal Ruffians, jungle-wise veterans of the Solomons campaign, American troops have killed at least 650 Japanese since going into action in northern Burma at the cost of only seven dead and thirty-seven wounded, Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters announced today.

The major daylight attacks by American bombers on Berlin have emphasized several important factors in addition to the proof they give that territory in the heart of Germany can now be subjected to genuine round-the-clock bombing. They have forced the Luftwaffe to summon its offensive fighters from the whole European theatre in a vain attempt to prevent the penetration to Berlin.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, March 10 -- American marines drove to within two miles of the Japanese base of Talasea on Willaumez Peninsula, New Britain, Tuesday, advancing past many abandoned enemy dead, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's communique announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Estimates of the number of Russians Premier Stalin's government has placed in thousands of labor camps throughout the Soviet Union vary from 10,000,000 to 18,000,000, Senator Burton K. Wheeler, Democrat of Montana, said Tuesday in quoting to the Senate an editorial from the Nineteenth Century and After, a magazine published in London.

The combination of Paul Bibeault, Lorne Carr and Gus Bodnar of the Toronto Maple Leafs proved far too much for the New York Rangers in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

The issue of a ten-cent fare on city-owned transit lines, raised by Mayor La Guardia in his radio broadcast last Sunday, was placed on the doorstep of the Fusion-controlled Board of Estimate yesterday by James J. Lyons, Borough President of the Bronx, a Democrat.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Department store sales in the week ended March 4 were 1 per cent higher than sales in the corresponding week last year. It was the first week since that ended Jan. 29 that sales were above those of last year.

The sale of half a million pounds of butter at prices 2 to 9 cents a pound above Office of Price Administration ceilings was admitted yesterday by A. Quinn's Sons, Inc., of 137 Reade Street, and Jacob and Nathan Quinn, president and treasurer of the concern.

Arthur Garfield Hays, national director of the American Civil Liberties Union, will speak at Cooper Union Forum this evening on Charles A. Beard's "The Republic," published last season by the Viking Press. Mr. Hays' lecture is one in a series he is giving on the Beard book, taking up the various aspects of liberty discussed in it.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The War Production Board, answering to a direction by its Office of Civilian Requirements, announced today it was issuing preference ratings on specific quantities of cotton yarn to be used for the manufacture of more than six million dozen items of infants' and children's wear during April, May and June.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- President Roosevelt gave encouragement today to the movement to establish in Palestine a Jewish commonwealth by authorizing two Jewish leaders to announce at a conference that "when future decisions are reached full justice will be done to those who seek a Jewish national home."

The question of what to do with Germany after victory is won has resolved itself largely into the issue of dismemberment or no. It is here proposed to bring to the fore a factor that has until now been given little consideration.

The Phil-American Corporation, manufacturers of radio and electronic equipment, have leased 65,000 square feet of space in 522-30 East Seventy-second Street from the Blackwell Holding Corporation, a subsidiary of the American Type Founders Company.

Many vegetables -- notably iceberg lettuce, escarole, cauliflower and broccoli -- are higher in price this week than they were last as the result of smaller supplies. The War Food Administration tells us that a number of factors are responsible for the change, among them rain in California and a labor shortage in Florida.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, March 9 -- The Japanese are now facing a major disaster in the vital sectors of their outer defense zones in the Pacific and have suffered tremendous losses of men and equipment, Air Vice Marshal Leonard M. Isitt, chief of the New Zealand Air Staff, said today on his return from a combat zone.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 9 -- Warner Brothers have announced plans to produce a film biography of Vincent Youmans, the composer, in musical form similar to the studio's "Rhapsody in Blue," the George Gershwin picture. The film will be titled "Sometimes I'm Happy," and Ann Sheridan and Dennis Morgan will be co-starred.

CAMP HALE, Col., March 9 (U.P.) -- Eight more American soldiers were disclosed today to have been involved in the recent escape of two Nazi war prisoners from the Camp Hale internment camp, an episode which resulted in Pvt. Dale Maple of San Diego being charged with treason.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 9 (AP) -- A temporary restraining order was handed down today by Judge Paul Leahy in the United States District Court here against the defendant in the case of Richard B. Hand of New York City, a large stockholder, vs. the Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line (Mokan) Company, a Delaware corporation, and William G. Maguire, Geoffrey R. Meller and Charles E. Main, officers and directors of that company.

The 1,092 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $96,631,760,238 par value as of Feb. 29, had a total market value of $96,837,473,171, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. As of Jan. 31, there were 1,091 issues, aggregating $90,741,549,801 par value, which had a total market value of $90,544,387,232.

Retailers of men's and boys' clothing are worried regarding the delivery situation on spring merchandise, which is well below normal and which, they believe, will continue backward throughout the season As in the case of fall numbers, full deliveries are not expected unless there is an unforeseen lifting of bottlenecks in materials and labor.

Retail compliance with rationing and price control regulations will be measured in a survey of every food store in the metropolitan area, Daniel P. Woolley, regional administrator of the Office of Price Administration, announced yesterday. The check by 1,000 OPA representatives will begin Monday -- the same day that similar surveys will be undertaken throughout the nation -- Mr. Woolley said at a press conference at the Empire State Building.
LONDON, March 9 (UP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

Retailers of men's and boys' clothing are worried regarding the delivery situation on spring merchandise, which is well below normal and which, they believe, will continue backward throughout the season As in the case of fall numbers, full deliveries are not expected unless there is an unforeseen lifting of bottlenecks in materials and labor.

Retail compliance with rationing and price control regulations will be measured in a survey of every food store in the metropolitan area, Daniel P. Woolley, regional administrator of the Office of Price Administration, announced yesterday. The check by 1,000 OPA representatives will begin Monday -- the same day that similar surveys will be undertaken throughout the nation -- Mr. Woolley said at a press conference at the Empire State Building.
LONDON, March 9 (UP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

Warning that a serious shortage in the supply of live poultry in the New York market is likely to develop by the end of this month, Milton E. Sahn, attorney for the New York Live Poultry Commission Merchants Association, Inc., charged yesterday that key officials of the Office of Price Administration in Washington and of the War Food Administration were "biased" in favor of the big Midwestern packers.

LONDON, March 9 -- Two striking arms of American air power in Europe, the Eighth Air Force based in Britain and the Fifteenth Air Force based in Italy, blasted the German aircraft industry and other German targets with 24,000 tons of bombs in February when the Strategic Air Forces, commanded by Lieut. Gen. Carl A. Spaatz, opened their coordinated attack designed to eliminate the Luftwaffe from consideration as a serious military force.

If extremely tight delivery conditions on women's apparel as the spring production season approaches its climax are any criterion, no material easing is indicated for the fall wholesale period, which will begin in May, merchandisers here said yesterday.

In this newspaper yesterday appeared a picture of two battalions of Seabees, the elders of that service, on their transport in San Francisco Bay. They were back from the South Pacific after an absence of almost two years. It reminded New Yorkers of the Seabees who came back here a few days before last Christmas, some of them with beards begun in Algeria or Sicily or at Salerno.
LONDON, March 9 (AP) -- The Bank of England in its weekly condition statement issued today recorded an increase of 4,269,000 in note circulation to the record high of 1,090,601,000.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Army War College Library was accused in the Senate today by Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan of selecting for circulation among the armed forces a magazine article which "smeared" General MacArthur in discussing him as Presidential timber.

It was not until the end of the last war that the military and economic importance of oil in world affairs dawned on statesmen. Stimulated by the pronouncements of Lord Curzon and Clemenceau, and by predictions of an eventual shortage of oil here, our State Department began to intercede diplomatically on behalf of American companies.

MOSCOW, Friday, March 10 -- The Soviet High Command announced last night a new offensive on the Third Ukrainian Front, where in a four-day battle Red Army troops have advanced eighteen to thirty-eight miles on a 105-mile front, severing the north-south railway feeding the Black Sea port of Nikolayev, while other forces broke into Tarnopol and engaged the Germans in battle in the city's streets.

Three new films will arrive in midtown theatres today. At the Strand the attraction will be "Shine On Harvest Moon," a musical produced by Warner Brothers based on the careers of Nora Bayes and Jack Norworth, with Ann Sheridan and Dennis Morgan playing the leads.

A new issue of $1,000,000 of tax-anticipation notes, due $500,000 on Nov. 3 and a like amount on Nov. 14, 1944, was awarded yesterday by Newton, Mass., to the Newton Trust Company. The bank bid an 0.31 per cent basis, plus a premium of $10.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Communists have seized control of the CIO's political action committee "and Sidney Hillman will soon succeed Earl Browder as head of the Communists in the United States," Representative Martin Dies of Texas charged on the House floor today.

LONDON, March 9 -- Production of new and secret types of equipment for the Army and concentration on certain types of bombers and fighter planes of proved efficiency efficiency will cause big changes in the British war industries program this year, Production Minister Oliver Lyttelton said in statements here today and tonight.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, NAPLES, March 9 (AP) -- Fifth Army forces have inflicted 9,000 casualties on the Germans in and around Cassino since the end of January, bringing total enemy losses in Italy for that period to about 40,000, Allied headquarters announced today.

YONKERS, N.Y., March 9 -- With the backing of a majority of the Yonkers Board of Education, Dr. William Crocker, chairman, ruled at a meeting today that Philip H. Cornick and Abraham H. Elkind were not entitled to membership on the board, although they received appointments from Mayor Curtiss E. Frank.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 9 -- American Federation of Labor machinists threatened today a general strike at the Kaiser shipyards in Richmond unless machinists affiliated with the Congress of Industrial Organizations were removed from a ship built at Richmond and dry-docked at present at the Moore company's yard in Oakland.

ALBANY, March 9 -- Recommendations which, if carried out, would grant less than half a million dollars in additional State aid for education, in place of the $7,500,000 sought by educational leaders, were submitted to the legislative leaders today by John E. Burton, Budget Director.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Navy Department disclosed today that American submarines have sent sixteen more Japanese ships to the bottom, as part of the drive to isolate the Japanese bases in the Pacific.

The first national conference on cancer prevention clinics ever held in the United States was conducted yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore, under the auspices of the American Society for the Control of Cancer, as a preliminary session to the society's annual two-day conference today and tomorrow.

Two more attractions are promised for the week of April 3, making three premieres for the period. The additions are "Public Relations," opening Saturday night, April 8, at the Mansfield, with Ann Andrews and Philip Merivale costarred, and "Only the Heart," due at the Bijou on Tuesday night, April 4.

HEADQUARTERS UNITED STATES FOURTEENTH AIR FORCE IN CHINA, March 9 (AP) -- Commemorating the first anniversary of the United States Fourteenth Air Force, Maj. Gen. Claire L. Chennault told his command in a letter today that "soon or late, the end is in sight" in the war with Japan.

The action of counsel for The Associated Press in obtaining permission to appeal to the Supreme Court from a special three-judge statutory Federal district court's ruling that the news agency had violated the Sherman Anti-Trust Act was followed yesterday by an announcement that the Government, too, would ask such permission.

Real winter ski conditions continue to prevail in the north country, with three to six feet of snow the rule above the 2,000-foot line in the mountainous area, thus assuring the best type of spring skiing for many weeks to come. According to yesterday's reports, new snow was visiting many points.

Not even the talents of Branch Rickey seemed able yesterday to dispel clouds of uncertainty enveloping major league baseball as it rushed toward another wartime training season. Tardiness of players in signing contracts and daily roster shifts by reason of service inductions are producing problems, admitted the Dodger major-domo at his weekly press conference, "that make this training campaign the most extraordinary in more than twenty years."

Harold H. Budds, vice president and general manager of the Ranger Aircraft Engines Division of Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation, declared yesterday afternoon that it is "squarely up to the union" to decide whether some plan can be worked out to waive seniority considerations in favor of veterans of World War II in the lay-off about to occur at Ranger plants, pending retooling.
It is indeed startling that most editorial comment of magazines and newspapers about the proposed Saudi Arabian oil deal has been so noncommittal.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Disclosure yesterday of an unpaid principal of $217,641,000 of Home Owners Loan Corporation accounts in New York State brought new demands in Congress today for prompt action on pending legislation to force liquidation as soon as possible of the HOLC, with its poor investments as well as its good ones.
A paper conservation message from Mayor La Guardia will be read to students in all public schools on Monday, Dr. John Wade, City Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday.

The thirty-third annual report of the New York State Conservation Department, just submitted to Governor Dewey by Commissioner John A. White, contains a five-point program designed to insure the proper management and wise us of the State's soil, water, forest, fisheries and wildlife resources during and after the war.

After displaying strength in the early dealings, pronounced weakness developed in the distant cotton futures yesterday. However, the near-by positions maintained their early gains. At the close of trading active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 8 points higher to 11 points lower.

A New Jersey scavenger accused of having sold garbage which an Elk Street restaurant served as food, was fined $200 in Municipal Term Court yesterday by Magistrate Charles Solomon. An additional sentence of ninety days in the workhouse was suspended, contingent on good behavior.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Secretary Stimson has informed Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan that he has directed the Army War College Library to eliminate from its future monthly bulletins lists of "outstanding" magazine articles.

Retail trade expanded here this week, sales figures topping those of a year ago. Department store volume was estimated as 7 to 10 per cent above 1943. This was the first gain since comparison with the hectic buying spree on apparel in 1943 brought declines in comparative sales figures.

The North Side Savings Bank has sold to Emma Mazzella, through the Grenell Realty Agency, the building at 1195 Washington Avenue, the Bronx, for alteration into a bakery. Klein Kravetz bought the five-story apartment house for thirty-four families at 771 Trinity Avenue through the same broker, who also sold two buildings at 433-35 East 135th Street for cash for Anna Dahm to Hilda Feola.
LONDON, Saturday, May 11 (AP) -- A Russian supplementary communique, recorded by The Associated Press:

Shoe manufacturers generally are satisfied with the relaxation of certain style restrictions offered in the amended War Production Board order M-217, effective Thursday, although retailers' opinions are that the curb lifting could have been better timed.

In London, where they had to report themselves on British request, King Peter II and his Prime Minister, Bozidar Pouritch, are now being pressed to part once for all with Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch, permanent Minister of War in the Yugoslav Cabinet and leader of the Chethiks in the homeland.

The city is in vital need of placing 3,000 children in foster homes, Harry W. Marsh, acting Commissioner of Welfare, said yesterday at the second report luncheon of the $54,000 finance campaign of he Brooklyn Children's Aid Society in the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn.

PEARL HARBOR, March 10 (U.P.) -- American bomber fleets Wednesday smashed at Ponape and Kusaie in the Carolines in their campaign to neutralize the Japanese bulwarks east of Truk and hammered four enemy positions in the blockaded Marshalls.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The Associated Press learned today that the United States and Britain planned to assign a dozen or more British and American warships to Russia while keeping the Italian fleet intact in the Mediterranean, where it now is operating under Allied direction.

Discipline, social and economic as well as within the family, must be tightened up if democracy is to survive in the future, Otto Tolischus, writer for THE NEW YORK TIMES and its former correspondent in both Berlin and Tokyo, declared last night.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 10 -- Creating an international precedent in university amity, Yale today opened in its art gallery an exhibition of Canadian artists with Leighton McCarthy, Canadian Ambassador to the United States, and Ray Atherton, United States Ambassador to Canada, heading an official party of international guests.

On the last day of last year Lieut. Gen. Thomas Holcomb, Commandant of the United States Marine Corps, retired with the rank of full general. The antiquarians told us that the first chief of that corps held the rank of Major in the Revolutionary War. General Holcomb entered the service in 1900.

The Appellate Division yesterday unanimously annulled the joint action of The Jockey Club and the New York State Racing Commission in refusing to grant a 1943 jockey license to Robert Merritt, ninety-six-pound jockey, and ordered the racing bodies to conduct a new hearing on the application "in accordance with law."

GUADALCANAL, Saturday, March 11 (AP) -- Striking during a rainstorm and under cover of low mists, Japanese broke through barbed-wire entanglements Thursday on the northern perimeter of the American lines at Empress Augusta Bay on Bougainville in the northern Solomons.

Immediate enactment of State and Federal legislation to combat a rising monopolistic trend within the liquor industry as evidenced by recent absorptions of wineries and breweries by large distillers which "constitutes a threat to adequate regulation and control by existing State agencies" was demanded yesterday by the Regional Continuing Committee on Liquor Control Problems, an organization comprising liquor control administrators and legislators of fifteen Northeastern States.

Not yet 68, Irvin Cobb died too early. Yet, since he had worked hard since he was 16, and the range of his activities was so great, few writers have excelled him in productivity.
