He was so companionable and sociable, member of so many clubs and societies, that you wonder he ever found time to write.

Wartime brings many legal difficulties to humble people who cannot afford a lawyer's fee. A soldier planning to marry while on brief furlough finds technical barriers in the way. The family of a man in the armed forces overseas has trouble with the landlord or the installment collector.

ALBANY, March 10 -- A new drive for adjournment of the Legislature next week was started today in the Assembly, which has its calendars in reasonably good shape, and is anxious to wind up its affairs. The lower house passed today, at a perfunctory session, a resolution calling for adjournment at 5 P.M. on March 18.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 10 (AP) -- A final tabulation today of endorsements by local unions received at International Typographical Union headquarters showed Woodruff Randolph of Chicago leading two other candidates for president, with 323 endorsements to 166 for Claude M. Baker of San Francisco, the incumbent, and 93 for Harry A. Miller of Dayton, Ohio.

BOSTON, March 10 (AP) -- Boxing with machine-like perfection, Boston's Sal Bartolo won the N.B.A. featherweight championship from Phil Terranova of New York by a one-sided fifteen-round margin tonight before a 12,130 crowd at the Boston Garden.
Once again New York City's education budget faces drastic and dangerous reduction. This financial crisis can be prevented by citizen action now.

Lieut. J. Donald Budge of the Army Air Force, world tennis champion; Miss Alice Marble, world women's champion, and Miss Mary Hardwick, Great Britain's leading player, arrived in New York yesterday for the Red Cross matches at Madison Square Garden Tuesday night.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Over-the-road truck operators will be required beginning March 27 to register freight and empty or partly loaded vehicles with Office of Defense Transportation district offices, the agency announced today.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- President Roosevelt announced today the resignation of Lewis W. Douglas as deputy administrator of the War Shipping Administration, effective about April 1.

Earnings of the Shell Union Oil Corporation rose last year $7,620,000 over the previous year despite an increase of $7,700,000 in taxes, according to the preliminary operating statement for 1943 issued for publication today.
INDIANAPOLIS, March 10 -- Gov. Henry F. Schricker in a speech before the Indiana Democratic Women's Club called for the renomination of President Roosevelt.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 10 -- The resignation of President Ramirez was delivered by his son-in-law, Maj. Francisco Filippi, to Acting President Farrell. At the same time General Ramirez sent a copy of his resignation to the President of the Supreme Court, together with a letter in which it is believed that he explained the reasons why he had taken that step.

Both in Washington and in Albany there has been much discussion recently about post-war highways. The real weakness of our congested highway system immediately before the war was that modernization so frequently stopped at the city line. Bottlenecks were created within the urban areas themselves which nullified much of the good effect of modernized construction in less-congested areas.

BUFFALO, March 10 (AP) -- Axis nations are encouraged "by the recent protest against our bombing of Germany from sources within our borders," said Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, in an address here tonight.
ALBANY, March 10 -- Two agencies of the State War Council, the Bureaus of War Information and War Training, have been abolished, with a resultant annual saving of $120,000 a year.

LONDON, March 10 -- The Most Rev. Wm. Temple, Archbishop of Canterbury, speaking today before 400 women representing seventy British organizations, urged that more women be appointed to the police force in Britain to meet the growing problem of juvenile delinquency.

Alfred Drake, a featured player in "Oklahoma!", the Theatre Guild musical production, married Miss Esther Harvey Brown of 72 East Fifty-sixth Street, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bache Hamilton Brown of New York and Sarasota, Fla., yesterday in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

A retrospective exhibition of prints by the late Emil Ganso, who died in the spring of 1941, is being held at the Brooklyn Museum. It opened with a preview yesterday afternoon and, beginning today, may be seen by the public. The exhibition, containing about 125 items, has been set up in the second-floor Print Room and a large adjoining gallery.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Developments today in the question of disposition of the Italian fleet indicated that Russia would receive British and American vessels equivalent to one-third of the surrendered Italian ships.

MOSCOW, Saturday, March 11 -- The Soviet High Command last night announced a smashing new offensive on the Second Ukranian front, where Marshal Ivan S. Koneff's men in a five-day battle were reported to have inflicted a heavy defeat on fourteen German divisions, killing 20,000 Germans, capturing 2,500 prisoners and seizing large amounts of material while advancing twenty-five to forty-four miles on a 110-mile front.
CHICAGO, March 10 -- Nine film producers, exhibitors and distributors were assessed $360,000 today by a Federal jury on charges of monopoly in the Chicago motion-picture field.
WITH THE AMERICAN FORCES IN INDIA, March 3 -- At nineteen different spots, from Karachi on the west coast of India to Chungking, China, you can drop down any day on a little American oasis.

Until recently just a potential prospect, the indications are now that Nathaniel Curtis' farce, "Money, Money, Money!" will arrive on Broadway sooner than anticipated. At the behest of Billy Rose, who holds an option on the play, the author has diligently applied himself to the task of getting the script in shape for an April production.

WITH THE SEVENTH ARMY AIR FORCE, in the Central Pacific, March 10 (U.P.) -- Heavy bombers of the Seventh Air Force, using strategic bombing tactics, wiped out Ponape, a town of about 10,000 population, on the island of the same name in the eastern Carolines during the past month.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that the 1944 crop season to March 1 was less favorable for field crops than last year, but that current production of milk, eggs and vegetables was satisfactory.

The Viking Press has postponed all March publications and will concentrate for the next weeks on titles already published, because of the large orders for such of its 1944 releases as Gene Fowler's "Good Night, Sweet Prince," Ludwig Bemelman's "Now I Lay Me Down to Sleep," and Arvid Fredborg's "Behind the Steel Wall."

New municipal securities issues up for award next week total $4,099,711, compared with this week's revised total of $9,551,300, according to the Daily Bond Buyer. The weekly average of new municipal financing thus far this year now stands at $18,299,681.

Stockholders of the Miller Manufacturing Company of Detroit, maker of service tools for automobiles, aircraft and engines, voted yesterday at a special meeting to create a new issue of 100,000 shares of $5 par convertible Class A stock to be used in connection with purchase of a controlling interest in the Rieke Metal Products Corporation, of Auburn, Ind., maker of fittings for metal containers.

The conviction of Samuel Solomon, alias Sam Boston, who was sentenced last November to a year in the city penitentiary on charges of betting and maintaining a gambling establishment in his apartment at 240 Central Park South, was reversed yesterday by the Appellate Division.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- An appeal by the United States for the Irish Government to remove German and Japanese consular and diplomatic representatives from the country because of their espionage activities, coupled with a hope that this would be followed by Ireland's severing diplomatic relations with the Axis, has been rejected by Prime Minister Eamon de Valera.

In a letter to THE TIMES which appeared in your issue of Feb. 25 Frank L. Apperly asked for the early formation of an international institution, or college, to be attended by students chosen from the United Nations and with an international faculty of experts, for the purpose of studying the history and problems of the various cooperating nations.

CHICAGO, March 10 -- The old theory that "love flies out the window when money comes in the door" receives a blow this month in figures on divorce and separation rates, compiled by Prof. William F. Ogburn, University of Chicago sociologist, and made public in The American Journal of Sociology.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., March 10 (AP) -- The Navy steamed ahead according to pre-meet dope tonight, to place six men in the semi-finals, losing only in the two heavyweight events, in the opening rounds of the fortieth Eastern Intercollegiate Association wrestling championships at Lehigh University, before nearly 2,000 fans.

The basic doubt about Basic English was admirably stated by one member of the House of Commons. Someone had suggested that Mr. Churchill's words on the subject ought to be translated into Basic English, and the Prime Minister said it was a good idea and he would have some of his friends make the attempt.
NEW DELHI, India, March 10 (AP) -- A southeast Asia communique:

SAN FRANCISCO, March 10 -- Lieut. Col. James Roosevelt of the Marine Corps, who participated in the landing on Makin Atoll in the Gilberts last November, received a silver star today for "gallantry in action."
A round-up of city-wide contributions to the Red Cross 1944 War Fund yesterday indicated that each of the five boroughs was well of its way toward achieving its quota.

Six men were indicted yesterday by a Brooklyn Federal grand jury on charges of conspiracy to make counterfeit gasoline rationing coupons. They were Jerihem Seeman, 1447 East Second Street; John Jacubovics, 1513 Cooper Avenue; Isidore Katz, 134 South Fourth Street; Henry Leamon of 60-72 Madison Street, all Brooklyn, and Martin B. Zwoboda, 183-07 Dunlap Avenue, Hollis, Queens, and Eugene McCarthy of 512 East 159th Street, the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The text of the State Department's note to Prime Minister de Valera of Eire:

Judge John J. Freschi postponed in General Sessions yesterday until April 14 the hearing of the contempt-of-court proceeding against Edward V. Broderick, counsel for Wayne Lonergan who on March 20 will go on trial for a second time for the murder of his wife, Patricia Burton Lonergan.

The discovery of penicillin, the miracle working chemical extracted from a soil mold, and the isolation of similar highly promising therapeutic agents from other molds and bacteria, has focused attention on the work of the late Dr. William B. Coley of New York City, who more than fifty years ago developed a method for treating cancer with bacterial extracts, known as "Coley's Toxins."

Revision of the present State laws governing insurance companies so that such firms could band together and erect housing projects was urged yesterday by J.P. Fordyce, president of Manhattan Life Insurance Company at the fourth annual appraisal conference in the Hotel Commodore.

In any war-loan drive, the Treasury relies heavily on New York State. Therefore, the man chosen to head the drive sales organization here has a heavy responsibility. For the initial war-loan drive, Nov. 30 to Dec. 23, 1942, the sales unit areas coincided with the boundaries of the twelve Federal Reserve Districts.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 10 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has named Robert Walker and Susan Peters for the co-starring leads in "Once Upon a Furlough," an original story by Carl Foreman and Otto Englander that deals with the adventures of a soldier and a female psychiatrist.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Secretary Ickes urged the War Labor Board today to approve the agreement negotiated between the United Mine Workers and the anthracite operators.

CHICAGO, March 10 (AP) -- Michigan State, the only major Midwest college to drop football last season, is planning to resume the sport in 1944 if a satisfactory schedule can be arranged, Ralph Young, athletic director, today told Big Ten coaches and directors at their annual winter meeting.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The drive against the black market in liquor, started in October by the Alcohol Tax Unit on orders from Secretary Morgenthau, has practically ended over-the-ceiling sales above the retailers' level, according to Stewart Berkshire, deputy commissioner of the Bureau of Internal Revenue ATU, but the Office of Price Administration admitted today that its enforcement activities in the retailers' field had not been effective.

Seventy veterans of the present war, laid off from their jobs in the plant of the Ranger Aircraft Company's engine division in Jamaica, met last night in the Hillcrest Post of the American Legion, at 164 Goethals Drive, Hillcrest, Queens, formed an organization to fight the ouster and called for special seniority privileges for former service men.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (UP) -A Pacific Fleet headquarters press release:

MOSCOW, March 10 -- The Soviet press today reiterated its charge that the Germans were violating international law by sending to the Eastern Front able-bodied soldiers who had been exchanged from British camps in England, Egypt, Canada and Tunisia.
LONDON, March 10 (AP) -- A communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associate Press:
Eastern district offices of the Duff-Norton Manufacturing Company, Pittsburgh, producer of industrial jacks, will be moved from 350 Fifth Avenue to 250 Park Avenue on March 15.

Large office space on the tenth floor of 93 Worth Street has been leased by Blue Bell, Inc., which recently bought the work clothes manufacturing business known as Casey Jones, Inc. Alterations according to plans by Percival Goodman, architect, will be made, reports the Charles G. Edwards Company, the broker.

LONDON, March 10 -- The disintegration of the German line in southern Russia and the severe defeats suffered by the Luftwaffe under the guns of the Amercian Air Force have created a new strategic situation in Europe. Beyond the attrition of the German Air Force and the German Army military observers here see a serious weakening of the Wehrmacht's ability to mount a major counter-offensive against an Allied invasion of western Europe.

The demands presented to the War Labor Board by the steel workers fall into two categories: a 17-cent-an-hour increase, which would require a direct breaking of the Little Steel formula, and a series of other demands which would indirectly break the formula. In the coal and railroad cases, demands for increases which would have violated the formula directly were rejected, but indirect concessions were granted.

CHICAGO, March 10 -- Reports that the Congressional farm bloc would press for the inclusion of costs of farm labor in computing parity prices when the bill extending the life of the Office of Price Administration came up for consideration started a broad buying movement in the grain markets today on the Board of Trade.

On their first visit home after two years of war transport flying from China to India over the Himalayan Mountains, four Pan American pilots described yesterday how vital lend-lease supplies are air-trucked "over the worst flying route in the world" and are exceeding in volume anything that ever moved over the surface of the Burma Road.

EUGENE, Ore., March 10 -- Joe Gordon's signed contract for the season of 1944, at the salary he received last year, which was "pretty good," was returned today to President Ed Barrow at Yankee headquarters in New York, but Joe is not following the document East.

LONDON, March 10 -- The Berlin radio said today that 1,500 British and American "commandos" -- "under the command of General Churchill" -- had landed on the tiny Adriatic island of Lissa and that other raids on the Dalmatian coast and near-by islands might be expected.
LONDON, March 10 (UP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

The first enlisted members of the Women's Army Corps to serve in the Pacific area will soon take up stations at airfields in Hawaii, Major Geraldine May, Wac staff director for the Air Transport Command of the Army Air Forces, revealed yesterday.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, Naples, March 10 (U.P.) -- American Warhawk dive-bombers, loosing 500-pound explosives, have started smashing the huge German railway guns trained on the Anzio beachhead.

Sales of leading mail-order and chain-store companies declined 1.3 per cent in February, compared with the like month of 1943, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The volume of twenty-nine reporting companies for the month was $344,819,421, against $349,204,272.

LONDON, March 10 -- Both houses of Parliament at their next sittings will issue a formal invitation to the United States Congress to send a delegation of members to visit Parliament at its earliest convenience.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 10 -- At the request of the Henry J. Kaiser organization, which was challenged by American Federation of Labor machinists to live up to its contract with AFL metal trades, the Moore Dry Dock Company at Oakland today prevented machinists affiliated with the CIO from putting the finishing touches on a Kaiser-built frigate.

Lee Savold boxed his way to victory over Joe Baksi of Kulpmont, Pa., in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. The veteran Des Moines heavyweight, flashing a potent weapon in the form of an educated left hook, just managed to earn the decision over his youthful, willing foeman.

A "Holy Hour" will be an innovation at the celebration in St. Patrick's Cathedral next Friday of its patron saint and the patron saint of the Archdiocese of New York. The service, at 5:30 P.M., will be one of "public prayer for the restoration of peace, with justice after victory."

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- President Roosevelt appointed Lieut. Gen. William N. Haskell, retired, today to be director of the Office of Civilian Defense, succeeding James M. Landis, who left about six months ago for Cairo as United States economic coordinator in the Middle East.

Representative Vito Marcantonio, New York County chairman of the American Labor party, described Governor Dewey last night as the Horatio Seymour of 1944 and took a verbal fling at Mayor La Guardia at the annual dinner of the New York County ALP committee in the Hotel Roosevelt.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, March 11 (AP) -- A communique:
Because of Bob Montgomery's need for a rest, promoter Mike Jacobs announced last night a change in the top bout for the Madison Square Garden boxing show for March 31.

By a membership vote of nearly ten to one, the Progressive Education Association, for the last twenty-five years the spearhead for the progressive movement in the American school field, has adopted a new program and changed its name to the American Education Fellowship, it was learned yesterday.
NEWARK, N.J., March 10 -- One man was burned fatally, two others critically and nine were treated for burns and other injuries as a result of two explosions here shortly before 2 P.M. today.

Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange in February rose from 847,335 to 960,617 shares, the widest advance since August, 1939, the month immediately preceding the present war. Both figures exclude short positions in the odd-lot accounts of odd-lot dealers, which were 34,322 shares on Feb. 29 and 38,139 shares on Jan. 31.

Prime Minister Winston Churchill's pre-invasion address which he recently gave before the House of Commons has been well received in this country. Regarding Allied unity Churchill said: "None of the ground made good at Moscow and Teheran has been lost. The three great allies are absolutely united in their action against the common foe.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, Naples, March 10 -- Fighter-escorted American medium bombers attacked railroad yards in Rome again today, and heavy damage was reported. On the Anzio beachhead the Germans made two localized attacks yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The text of the Irish Government's reply, written by Prime Minister de Valera and released by the Irish Legation in Washington

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State now offered by dealers:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 10 -- Berlin may soon resemble Oliver Goldsmith's "Deserted Village" if reports from private sources prove true that Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels in his capacity as City Gauleiter held a meeting Wednesday evening with his aides, S.S. leaders and police chiefs to consider the complete evacuation of the city, including all Government departments and industries, to south Germany and Austria.

Baroness Clarice de Rothschild, widow of Baron Alphonse de Rothschild, grandson of the founder of the Austrian branch of the famed European banking house, was beaten viciously and robbed by a young zoot-suited Negro when she resisted his attempt to mug her in Park Avenue near Eighty-third Street at 10:30 P.M. Thursday.

LONDON, March 10 -- The Royal Air Force is now at the healthiest point of its history, either in peace or war, according to Air Marshal Sir Harold E. Whittingham, director general of medical services, in a statement today.

Close on the heels of the blast Gus Mancuso let out of Houston, Tex., the other day that he would not accept a $1,500 pay slash, a fresh development yesterday indicated the Giants had another serious holdout.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- All imports of alcoholic beverages derived from cane sugar will be reduced by an order issued today by the War Production Board putting them under strict quotas beginning March 15.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Optimistic over the outlook for November, half a hundred Republican women began a three-day conference today to plan for the coming campaign. They comprised board members of the National Federation of Republican Women's Clubs, headed by Mrs. W. Glenn Suthers of Chicago, and feminine executive committee members of the National Republican Committee.

Prices of stocks resumed their advance yesterday under the guidance of a list of industrials which pushed upward to the best levels since last October, while the composite rate went to its highest territory since September of last year. Gains of between 1 and 2 points were plentiful, with scattered additions of even more, and volume passed the million-share mark for the third time this week.

Sun is climbing higher. Snow is melting at midday on the south side of the upland pasture. Cumulus clouds move across the blue sky. March wind is whipping the pussy willows and cattails at the edge of the meadow swamps. It's sap time again, and on the farm they are readying for the annual harvest. The buckets are washed; the old, weather-grayed sugar house in the maple grove is set in order.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- With the blessing of the Treasury, the Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee will attempt to get a special tax simplification bill through Congress within a few months. Secretary Morgenthau and Senator Walter F. George, chairman of the Finance Committee, announced today the purpose would be to make returns unnecessary for incomes of less than $5,000 and simplify returns on higher incomes.

WASHINGTON, March 10 - The 1944 campaign will find the Democratic National Committee working for the election or re-election of all Democratic nominees, without distinction between them, Robert Hannegan, new committee chairman, told a news conference at the Capitol today.

The bombing raids which have wrought such destruction in Germany are a preparation for the invasion still to come. That they serve a military purpose cannot be doubted, for they enormously increase the problems of the Germans in maintaining production. What is involved in thus attempting to bring Hitler to his knees appears in an analysis prepared by The Review of World Affairs.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The War Production Board, acceding to repeated demands by the industry, lifted its ban today on cross-hauling of portland cement.

WITH THE AMERICANS IN THE HUKAWNG VALLEY, Burma, March 8 (Delayed) -- If the wounded that the Japanese have been able to evacuate equals the number killed in the Hukawng Valley fighting the Japanese casualties so far will total well over five thousand.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 10 -- Mrs. Anna Rychel, mother of a 21-month-old girl, is accused here of taking a larcenous advantage of her toddler's natural tendency to wander while she was shopping and getting $143 that belong to other persons in the process of pursuing her offspring into places where valuables were kept.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 10 -- In his first interview since arriving here to take over command of the United States Army force in the Middle East, Brig. Gen. Benjamin F. Giles indicated his expectation that American soldiers and officers stationed in this theatre would not seek to return home despite the fact that they might already be qualified to return to the United States.

RICHMOND, Va., March 10 -- One of the outstanding patents among the 620 listed in the current issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office covers, in thirty-eight claims, a new and versatile kind of calculating machine.

MANSFIELD, Ohio, March 10 -- During the first five years following the war an annual average of 78 per cent more Westinghouse electrical household appliances will be sold than were distributed in either of the peak years of 1940 and 1941, according to nation-wide estimates made by 102 distributors of the company's electric appliance division.

The Netherlands Government Information Bureau in Australia has just given out what we may rely upon as a dependable account of Japanese outrages in the Netherlands East Indies. It is a story of abysmal folly as well as cruelty. Like the Nazis among the discontented in Europe, the Japanese had a chance to make friends among the discontented in Asia.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Regular officers of the armed services can accept such nominations for political office as come to them without solicitation by themselves, according to an interpretation of regulations announced today by President Roosevelt.

LONDON, March 10 -- The Irish Government not only rejected the United States request that German and Japanese diplomatic missions be closed but choose to interpret the State Department's note as an ultimatum and immediately took military precautions against an Anglo-American invasion of southern Ireland.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he would close the twenty annexes in the academic high schools termed "unnecessary" in a survey earlier this week prepared by Manhattan Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs and Theodore Fred Kuper, former law secretary of the Board of Education.

PITTSBURGH, March 10 -- The Mount Vernon Car Manufacturing Company and its subsidiary, the J. P. Devine Manufacturing Company, Inc., both with plants at Mount Vernon, Ill., have been purchased by the H.K. Porter Manufacturing Company, Inc., this city, bringing the organization into the freight car manufacturing field and greatly expanding its process equipment division.

The efforts of Representative May of Kentucky to protect our Army from exposure to some 55,000 copies of the pamphlet entitled "The Races of Mankind" have resulted in national publicity informing many millions of Americans that "the average Negro in New York, Massachusetts and Connecticut ranked on an intellectual level with the average white man in Kentucky, Arkansas and Mississippi."

CHUNGKING, China, March 7 (Delayed) -- During the next few weeks thousands of residents of Chungking must leave the city and no new restaurants or business enterprises will be licensed, according to an announcement by the police.

BUENOS AIRES, March 10 (AP) -- Gen. Edelmiro Farrell, who had served for two weeks as Acting President of Argentina, assumed the office of President today upon the resignation of Gen. Pedro Pablo Ramirez.

The proxy statement for the annual meeting of stockholders of Hayes Manufacturing Corporation to be held in Grand Rapids, Mich., on March 24 discloses that the corporation recently acquired 100,000 common shares formerly held by Alfred J. Miranda Jr., I.J. Miranda and F. William Zelcer at an aggregate price of $200,000.

LONDON, March 10 -- The stock markets here ended the week cheerfully today but business remained restricted. Diamond shares were bright on Cape buying, De Beers deferred showing a good rise. Kaffirs, however, were unchanged.

Last year saw the first upward movement in the number of New York Stock Exchange firms since 1937, according to the institution's yearbook, issued yesterday. At the beginning of 1944 there were 540 firms, against 537 a year earlier. The number of branch offices rose from 745 to 773 despite the shortage of manpower, but the number of non-member correspondents continued its downward trend, falling from 2,139 to 2,051.

Col. Arthur V. McDermott, New York City Selective Service Director, announced yesterday that men under the age of 26 now employed in more than 700 war plants in New York City would be principally affected by the latest draft ruling, which nullifies seniority rights in these plants.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- By direction of King George VI, decorations of the British Empire were bestowed upon eight Americans today by Lord Halifax, the British Ambassador.

LONDON, Saturday, March 11 (U.P.) -- The new drive down the center of the German lines toward the Black Sea put the Red Army on the offensive along an almost unbroken 535-mile front stretching from Tarnopol, where a vicious street battle was in progress, to Dobroye, thirty-one miles northeast of Nikolayev.

Your delightful piece about grandparents is true to tradition. The unfortunate thing is that modern grandparents themselves are not true to tradition. Your article might have more accurately referred to great-grandparents.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 10 -- Rome is a "booby trap" set by the "arch-criminals of our times," and if we spring it on ourselves we shall destroy not only the capital of Christendom but our own prestige and make a decent peace almost impossible, the Most Rev. Joseph P. Hurley, Bishop of the Diocese of St. Augustine, warned in a statement published today in The Florida Catholic.

Consistent advertising and carefully planned production were given the credit for the low labor turnover of the I.B. Kleinert Rubber Company last night at a dinner at the company's College Point plant. Of 1,130 employes, 557 were awarded service pins marking ten years and longer service.

" The Uninvited" today starts its fourth and final week at the Globe. . . . "Kings of the Ring" begins its eighth week today at the World. . . . "Stage Door," the revival at the Manhattan, enters its second week today. . . . "Adventure in Music," which was to have ended its run yesterday, will continue for a second week, beginning today, at the Little Carnegie.
LONDON, March 10 (U.P.) -- The scene of Richard Llewellyn's best-seller "How Green Was My Valley" today has a tint of red.

The five four-story buildings containing five stores and twenty-four apartments on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 129-35 Franklin Street, Jersey City, have been sold by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to the Young Corporation (Sidney Boeninger, president).

Tonight's the night of the Knights of Columbus games in which Gilbert Dodds, Boston's rampant racer goes on another rampage. It's the night when Galloping Gil will assay the task of assaulting two track records instead of one, as he's been doing ever since the season opened two months ago.

Between the shortage of new furniture and the urge to divert customer's dollars to war bonds, the stores' decorating departments have been offering a stream of ideas for salvaging attic pieces and doing them over yourself. The latest do-it-yourself idea comes from Lord Taylor's decorating experts, who suggest reviving the eighteenth century art of "decoupage" or cut-outs.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (U.P.) -- Indicating that many persons are cashing in war bonds to meet tax payments, the Treasury's daily statement showed today that almost as many bonds were redeemed as were sold in the first week of March, redemptions, being $62,290, 859, and sales, $74,313,514.

Citizens of the five boroughs who work with Police Department personnel on eighty-one coordinating councils organized to combat juvenile delinquency in New York will meet with Mayor La Guardia and representatives of the Police Department soon for their first official conference, it was announced yesterday by a spokesman for the department.

The 1943 annual report of the Philadelphia Electric Company, released yesterday by H.P. Liversidged, president, shows a net income of $14,791,521 after expenses and charges. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.37 a share on the corporation's outstanding common stock, and compares with a net of $15,536,672, or $1.47 a common share, in 1942.
Tire Soviet communique, broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

LLWYNCELYN, Rhondda Valley, Wales, March 10 -- People everywhere in Britain are asking themselves what on earth can have come over the miners of Wales --90,000 men going out on strike at this time? The only ones who can answer are the miners themselves.

Freda Trepel, young Canadian pianist, gave her first New York recital last night in Town Hall. The program featured the infrequently heard Sonata in B flat (K. 570) of Mozart, and Alkan's "Le festin d'Esope," Op. 39, No. 12. It also contained four sonatas by Scarlatti, Ravel's Sonatina, Liszt's "Funerailles," Liapunoff's "Lesghinka," and offerings by Debussy, Rachmaninoff and Ganz.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Great Britain and the United States agreed today through an exchange of notes between Secretary of State Hull and Viscount Halifax, the British Ambassador, on an extension of time for fulfillment of the conditions and formalities for obtaining copyright during the war.

NEW DELHI, India, March 10 (AP) -- Chinese-American forces under Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell smashed southward three to four miles in the Hukawng Valley of North Burma in the past twenty-four hours while Chinese troops continued to chop up trapped Japanese in the Ngamaw Ga-Walawbum-Ninghku Ga area, killing 600, it was announced today.

PEARL HARBOR, March 7 -- Two points stand out sharply among the evidence coming in from various participants and witnesses of the Truk and Marianas air strikes in the latter half of February. They are significant and pertinent.

CHICAGO, March 10 -- A million dwellings a year for ten or more years are the nation's probable post-war housing requirement, according to Irving W. Clark, manager of the better homes department of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, Pitsburgh.

THE subject will not be mentioned again. Gilbert Dodds has been doing some conjectural running in this space of recent weeks and it almost begins to look as though the needle jumped across the record -- not a Dodds record, of course -- and the phonograph is repeating itself. But track is such a conversational sport that the temptation is too great to let this last possible chance slide by.

Saving time in the kitchen -- a subject dear to the hearts of most women nowadays -- depends to some extent on "planned left-overs." This means deliberately cooking too much of a certain food for one meal, then serving the remainder at another.

In his fourth purchase of apartment property in Manhattan in the last four months, J.L. Rosenthal, an investor, has acquired the fifteen-story and penthouse building at 35-39 West Seventy-second Street through Emanuel Schwartz, M. L. Hess, Inc., and Loeb Rosenthal, brokers.

LONDON, Saturday, March 11 -Lancasters of the Royal Air Force Bomber Command made swift and sure attack on an aircraft plant at Marignane near Marseille Thursday night as the Allies' air offensive against the German aircraft industry spread outside the borders of the Reich to those factories that might take up the slack in production caused by American bombers' destruction of factories in Germany.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, March 11 -- United States marines captured Talasea airdrome Wednesday and then wheeled north to occupy the township the following day, thus cutting in two the Willaumez Peninsula of north New Britain, which they invaded only last Monday.

Initial operations in a comprehensive Catholic program of the Committee of Youth Counseling Service of the Archdiocese of New York to prevent and treat juvenile delinquency in this city were made public yesterday by the Catholic Charities of New York.

IT would appear that there could be no interest in a deal on which no one has an opening bid. Nevertheless, some of the bitterest post mortems in expert games concern hands which have been passed out; what the bidding should have been, and how the hands should have been played if the proper contract had been reached.

On Wednesday an estimated 200,000 high school students will take part in the third nation-wide test for candidates who desire to join the Army Specialized Training Program or the Navy's V-12 program. Although the regular training corps has been virtually disbanded, the War Department now intends to expand its 17-year-old reserve unit to replace the older trainees.
PRUNING of fruit trees is occupation for any mild weekends through March. Each kind of tree -- indeed each individual -- is a problem in itself.

ALGIERS, March 11 -- Pierre Pucheu, former Minister of Industrial Production and then of the Interior in Vichy, was sentenced to death today by a special military court after having been convicted of collusion with the enemy.

The anniversary today of the birth of Jane Delano, founder of the American Red Cross Nursing Service, is the occasion for a message of tribute to thhe leader from Maj. Gen. Robert C. Davis, director of the New York chapter of the American Red Cross, and an urgent call for recruits to carry on the humanitarian traditions of the service begun thirty years ago by Miss Delano.

EDWARD LEDYARD, the central character in Miss Monica Dickens' latest novel, fortunately has more fancies than one. His first led him to marriage with a frigid little piece named Connie, whose main preoccupation during England's war consists in keeping herself genteel and we-provided for, come blackouts, blitzes and invasion.

Both Col. Arthur V. McDermott, New York City Selective Service Director, and Maj. David Brady, chief of the occupational division of draft headquarters for New York, will meet with executives of the Ranger Aircraft Company tomorrow to confer on the revision of manpower replacement schedules.

ANSWERING the increasing demand for fiction. Harper's has opened its lists to six first-novelists -- the largest contingent of first-novelists on any list in recent years. "The Broken Arc," by Mayette Meyneng, published last week, is the first of the group.

IN an effort to make our total supplies stretch as far as possible, the Government is focusing attention on what it calls no-point and low-point foods. It is encouraging grocers to promote these in merchandising programs, and requesting women to work them into menus.
The statement issued by the Irish Minister, Robert Brennan, follows:

" THE LOW ROAD" is a simple, thoughtful, sincere story about a young man and his wife, living in a cottage on the shore of Lake Keuka in up-State New York, who are expecting their first baby. Clay and Karen Treman are not native country people.

In some respects the two Penelopes were alike, but in one picturesque detail they differed sharply. We refer, of course, to (1) the British light cruiser Penelope, recently sunk by enemy fire off Anzio beach, and (2) the lady Penelope, wife of the wandering Ulysses.

A WARTIME racket that is perhaps unequaled for sheer viciousness has cropped up in several parts of the country. It consists of several self-appointed busybodies who take down the names of American prisoners as read over the Berlin and Tokyo radios and then call relatives of the boys and ask for fees ranging from $3 to $100 before repeating what they heard.

NEW DELHI, India, March 11 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell enthusiastically said today, "The entire Hukawng Valley will soon be ours," as columns of tanks manned by Chinese and American soldiers cut a wide swath through Japanese ranks in that northern Burma sector, killing 500 to 700 of the enemy.
NAPLES, March 11 (AP) -- An Allied communique:

Wendell L. Willkie, candidate for the Republican nomination for President, will leave next Friday for a two-week speaking campaign in Wisconsin, where a list of candidates for delegates to the Republican National Convention, pledged to him, have been entered in the primary election on April 4.

IT makes little difference what the picture of the pepper looks like in the catalogue if every one on the plant rots at the tip from disease. The plant pathologists agree that there is little the gardener can do about bacterial diseases after they begin to show in the plants, but too little is said about preventives.

James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, suffered the first major reverse of his career yesterday when a special War Labor Board panel rejected on all counts his union's position against "canned music."

The performance of Verdi's "Falstaff" yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House was highly meritorious. Leonard Warten took the name part for the first time here. He sang the music very well. The fine quality of his voice was put at the service of significant diction.

CEDARHURST, L.I., March 11 -- The complete facilities of the Garden City Beach Club at Atlantic Beach, L.I., have been turned over to the armed forces for use this summer by wounded veterans recuperating at the St. Albans Naval Hospital, it was announced here today by Mrs. Morris Duow Ferris, chairman of the South Shore branch, Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy, Inc.

The reinjection of red blood cells into the veins of blood donors, which was instituted primarily to aid the work in China of the Chinese Blood Bank, may revolutionize all blood bank programs. Dr. Co Tui, first vice president of the American Bureau for Medical Aid to China, which set up the Chinese Blood Bank, originated the method.

To one who took part in the other war in Italy, it is strange that we seem to neglect Marshal Badoglio's military genius. Apparently our leaders are utilizing General Juin and other French officers: but the man whom Ludendorff considered his most redoubtable opponent and to whom, in his memoirs, he gives the credit for Germany's defeat, seems to be isolated in Bari from Allied war councils.

THE sign makers are having a a field day along Broadway, blotting out the facades of movie houses. Some of the "fronts" are a riot of color, like the one for the Paramount's "Lady in the Dark"; others are more subdued, like the Norman Rockwell painting for the Rivoli's "The Song of Bernadette."

LESTER COWAN is scheduled to start tomorrow to right a Hollywood wrong, with the collaboration and cooperation of the United States Army. The "wrong," as described by Producer Cowan, is Hollywood's neglect of the infantrymen of World War II.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 11 (U.P.) -- Senator Taft declared tonight that "usurpation of power by the President" is transforming the courts and the legislature into "a mere shell" and further charged that a fourth term would cause a steady enlargement of the Executive power.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Few war measures presented to the Congress have met with such wide division of opinion as the National War Service Bill, concurrently under consideration by the Military Affairs Committees of the Senate and the House.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -Hope that "a truly simple income tax return" would be developed from proposals now under consideration by the Treasury and the Congressional tax staff was expressed today by Randolph Paul, general counsel of the Treasury, in a letter to Representative Overton Brooks, Democrat, of Louisiana.

TWO murders by strangling bring Detective-Inspector Napoleon Bonaparte of the Queensland police to the small township of Carie, where the local police have failed to apprehend the murderer. It is not strange that they have failed, for each of the murders has been done during a sandstorm which has obliterated all tracks or other traces.

AT the opening of this story we find Jeff Miles on his way to his own funeral -- or so it seems. At any rate he is in a coffin, and the coffin is in a moving vehicle. Really, this is the middle of the story. Before and after this many astounding things happen.

The gentleman who is well and favorably known as Sparse-Grey Hackle would like this department's readers who have first-hand, practical experience with fishing as practiced by crippled and disabled persons to tell how it's done.

The cardinal's call is a welcome note in any March day. Insistent as the sun, it overrides the wind and declares that cold can't stay forever. There's no subtlety about it; the cardinal is as forthright as March itself, and a good bit more consistent. He has come ahead of the rush and he takes no back seat for bluejay or crow.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Seventy Senators, according to the American Legion, have agreed to sponsor its revised "GI Bill of Rights," authorizing appropriations to aid veterans of the present war. Prompt passage in the Senate is predicted.

THE sun rose on Boston, where men thought all would be well "if only ships could sail again, if only some ports were open to their goods, if only Congress would wake from its spineless lethargy." Its rays moved on to New Bedford, where an anxious merchant dusted his half-empty shelves; to Philadelphia, where recently ex-soldiers and unemployed workmen had rioted in the streets; to Charleston, where tobacco rotted on the wharves.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Because California will cease this year to produce heavy oil and because in the United States as a whole daily production of petroleum may drop 25 per cent in six or seven years, the Navy Department, it was learned today, firmly supports the Middle East oil development project.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 11 -- West Coast manpower leaders warned here today that high urgency and vital war activity on this coast would be "seriously retarded" unless local draft boards ceased to interpret "too literally" the statement of President Roosevelt on Feb. 26 dealing with draft deferments.

If it had not been for Dr. Sun Yat Sen there might have been no Chinese revolution in 1911, no Chinese Republic, no effective resistance to Japanese aggression in China and, to take a small but extremely significant incident, no union of Chinese and American troops such as has taken place on the Burma front during the past few days.

MICHAEL SEIDE'S title could mean only the recurrent appearance in his stories of a young Brooklyn Jew, Joe Bellinson; but they have a more organic relation. It is not even that all their characters are Jewish, but, more significantly, that in six of the ten, the themes themselves derive from psychological problems and insights which Mr. Seide presents as characteristic of orthodox Jewish life in America.

In close cooperation with the paper conservation drive, prominent real estate firms and corporations managing apartment buildings here have placed notices in elevators, lobbies and in evelopes containing monthly rental statements urging the conservation and salvage of paper, the New York City Newspaper Publishers' Waste Paper Salvage Committee revealed yesterday.

WHEN the present reviewer started his career as a sports writer on a New York paper some years ago one of his first assignments was to cover a football game in New Haven. The telegraph operator, taking the first sheet of his copy, observed the address and said: "If you come from New York you must know Quent Reynolds.

ALCHERS, March 11 -- Explicit and impressive evidence of the blow to the Germans' morale that resulted from their failure to drive the Allies' beachhead forces into the sea -- as Adolf Hitler, in a message to the troops had apparently promised that they would do within three days -- has been obtained from German prisoners and other sources, it was authoritatively learned today.

SOME of the fog that is wrapped around reconversion was lifted a little last week when War Production Chairman Nelson attempted to answer a few questions put to him by Senator Maloney of Connecticut, but the view remained quite misty, nevertheless.

Compositions of his adopted country and of his native Russia formed the program conducted by Serge Koussevitzky at the concert given yesterday afternoon by the Boston Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall. The American works performed consisted of William Schuman's "Symphony for Strings," which received its New York premiere, and Corp.

ALBERT F. KUNZE, chief of the Philatelic Section of the Pan American Union at Washington, was informed by Nicaragua's Ambassador last week that Nicaragua plans to issue postal paper this year in honor of the Red Cross in accordance with the Pan American Union's recent recommendation that all the twenty-one American republics accord such recognition to the Red Cross' wartime humanitarian effort.

A MILITARY hero's aide, less cynical than the valet of tradition, can be taken in, may indeed be the last of all to credit his chief with baseness. So Robert Gessner says in this novel of hero worship and disillusion, wherein he treats of that same chapter in our past which Carl Van Doren presented factually several years ago in his "Secret History of the American Revolution."

OFF on another radio marathon that will carry him week by week through half a year, Norman Corwin returned last Tuesday at 10 P.M. over WABC-CBS in his familiar triple-threat role as writer-producer-director, which, to the surprise of no reasonably alert listener, is good news.

Concerted action on any project is usually preceded by independent action on the part of small groups of individuals who possess strong convictions on the projected subject. This process grows until a fairly unified determination prevails over the opposition.

For more than four years and a half the Government of Eire has preserved a careful neutrality between the forces of civilization and those of the new barbarism. It has scrupulously closed its ports to German as well as Allied battleships. It has maintained punctiliously correct relations with Allied as well as Axis diplomats.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Recent disagreements among members of the United States Supreme Court are making lawyers here wonder whether further dissensions are delaying the settlement of some important cases that are officially listed as awaiting decision.

The greatest air battles in history were being fought in German skies last week. Berlin, the enemy's capital, third largest city in Europe and fifth in the world, was under heavy daylight attack for the first time. A center of government, a communications nexus and a war-production area, the city was also important because the Nazis were willing to risk their hard-pressed air forces to defend it.

WHAT goes on on a farm? City-bred youngsters' notions of that life are apt to be bounded on one side by brief excursions to the country and on three sides by our charming but not wholly practical picture books.

AN AIR BASE IN ITALY, March 11 -- Marauders bombed Florence today because aerial reconnaissance had disclosed a vast amount of German military traffic on the rail network based on the famous art center and Army and air force headquarters decided that it must be stopped.

LONDON, March 11 (AP) -- A reliable source said tonight that King Peter of Yugoslavia, who arrived by plane today, had formulated an eight-point program for unifying the war efforts of Yugoslav factions, and that he hoped to present it to Prime Minister Churchill and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden early next week.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The subcommittee of the Senate Agriculture Committee recently has been making news by quizzing Jonathan Daniels, one of President Roosevelt's six administrative assistants who are supposed to be endowed with "a passion for anonymity."

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Government-Labor-Industry controversy on the cost of living and its relation to wages moved into a new area this week when the national wage stabilization policy became the main subject at issue before the National War Labor Board's Steel Wage Dispute Panel.

DORIS HUMPHREY has created an extraordinary piece of dance-drama in her latest work, "Inquest." Neither she nor anybody else in the field has done anything quite like it before. It manages to be straight drama dealing with specifically characterized individuals in a definite situation, and yet at the same time to achieve a form as self-contained as music and as universal in its implications.

Members of society and music circles are cooperating in plans to present in the near future three "concert salutes" in tribute, respectively, to France, England and Russia, for the purpose of augmenting relief funds for the children of those countries.

LONDON, Sunday, March 12 -Red Army troops forced a spectacular new bridgehead across the wide Dnieper River in the last sixty-mile stretch held by the Germans near the Black Sea yesterday and captured the district center of Berislav, only thirty-seven miles above the big river-seaport of Kherson, Moscow announced today.

THE members' exhibition of the Art Directors Club is sprightly, and highly diverse is the work shown. Mehmed Fehmy Agha contributes two small paintings startingly in the trompe l'oeil vein. Lester Beall and Souren Ermoyen go surrealist.

A study of the teaching of American history in 400 public high schools of California, conducted by the Institute of American History at Stanford University, disclosed that the required course in history is too heavily burdened with other subject-matter to be satisfactorily completed in the time assigned to it, Dr. Edgar Eugene Robinson, director, reported last week.

Wall Street has not finished with the Richard Whitney case. The case has resulted in adding to the body of "decision law" a new principle -- that Exchanges and other bodies for the regulation of the brokerage business have a duty to protect the customers of their members and may be sued when negligence or cover-up tactics result in loss.
" I AM a coolie and the son of a coolie. I was born with the poor and I am still poor. My sympathies have always been with the struggling people."

A message from President Roosevelt praising the Girl Scouts of America for "developing world-minded citizens prepared to deal more intelligently with post-war problems" was delivered yesterday at a birthday party to mark the beginning of a week-long celebration of the organization's thirty-second anniversary.

LIKE every great conflict in history, the fight for India's freedom generates a literature claiming "to tell the truth about both sides." Invariably such books fail either because the "truth" is hopelessly entangled in the jungle of pros and cons, or because the authors' predilections unconsciously color their judgments.

DURING the heyday of the WPA the literary arm of that organization combed North Carolina for folklore. From the sounds of the Atlantic to the coves of the Great Smokies, the local raconteurs, white and colored, seem to have been obliging.

The maintenance of a larger American Merchant Marine as necessary post-war national insurance, with the premium paid to keep the policy effective an insignificant sum compared to that which the neglect of American shipping has cost this country twice in the last twenty-five years, is strongly advocated in a shipping analysis presented by the Grace Line and its parent company, W.R. Grace Co.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 11 -- Italian prisoners of war at Raritan Arsenal near here will worship tomorrow before a new altar built with their own hands from salvaged wood and painted to simulate Carrara marble. The altar has been constructed in the chapel of the internment camp at the arsenal, Col. Max A. Elser, commanding officer, announced today.
