LIFEBOAT stories are old hat this fifth year of the war. Too many men have spent unforgettable days tossing in terror around the seven seas. But to a woman who drifted in a lifeboat, wedged in a mass of men, the experience hit with new impact, as deep and hard as the torpedo that cracked open the freighter.

THE palm trees will rustly softly -- in the lobby of the French Lick Springs Hotel. The ocean waves will roll in and tumble caressingly over the bright sands -- at Atlantic City. However, there will be no flamingoes at Bear Mountain Inn and not too much warming sunshine at Muncie, Evansville and the other Indiana bases. Be that as it may, though, the baseball season is about to begin.

To raise funds for the purchase of knitting wool, the National War Service Committee of the Women's National Republican Club has arranged a benefit bridge party for the afternoon of March 23 at the clubhouse, 3 West Fifty-first Street. Mrs. Harry W. Hoskins is chairman of the event.

In the proceedings of the staff meetings of the Mayo Clinic appears a discussion by Lieut. Col. C.W. Mayo and Dr. E.G. Wakefield on the use of moss for surgical dressings. According to Mayo and Wakefield, moss was used successfully by Napoleon's surgeons. It was also used by both sides in the Franco-Prussian War and by the Germans and English in the last war.

RICHMOND, Va., March 11 (AP) -- Fire swept through two floors of Richmond's Jefferson Hotel shortly after last midnight, killing Mrs. James H. Price, widow of the former Governor; State Senator Aubrey G. Weaver and four other guests.

" It is the little hidden things that make a design important," said Omar Kiam, as he sat in his studio in a towering building in the garment center. He slipped the fingers of his right hand into the pocket of a silk suit that hung on a rack beside him and indicated the curved edge that distinguished it from the usual.

ANNAPOLIS, March 11 -- Naval Academy acrobats took three of six individual championships in the Eastern Intercollegiate Gymnastic League finals contested here today. However, the middies were closely pressed by the Penn State gymnasts, who took two individual places, as well as the all-around title.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Congressional by-election this week in the First Colorado District was more vexing to the managers of the Democratic party than others since November, 1942, that have steadily revealed a Republican trend, and for these obvious reasons:

The General American Transportation Corporation, builder and operator of tank, refrigerator and other special railroad cars and other equipment, and its subsidiaries had a net profit of $4,003,381, or $3.84 a common share in 1943, it was announced yesterday.

Beset by an almost unprecedented number of unsigned players, some of whom may develop into serious holdouts, and bewildered by a still endless flow of military inductions that are turning rosters topsy turvy overnight, major league baseball, none the less, points its nose resolutely into an uncertain future today as it embarks upon its second successive curtailed and ice-coated spring training campaign.

IN Hollywood one evening in the spring of 1941 I was invited to dinner by the late Max Reinhardt to meet Franz Werfel. Some months earlier I had read in THE NEW YORK TIMES an item to the effect that Mr. Werfel had been captured by the Nazis in France and killed.

AN eleven-week tour of the Mediterranean war theatre last summer, in the course of which he represented the combined American press at General Eisenhower's headquarters on the battered island of Malta before and during the invasion of Sicily, convinced John Gunther that the worst thing about war is that so many men like it.

LONDON, March 11 -- An unspecified number of American girls, selected for their "ruggedness, health, driving ability and skill in languages," are undergoing intensive training in England to accompany the invasion forces to Europe.

I note that there is now in the Legislature at Albany a new bill the purpose of which is to authorize a new Transportation Authority, which is intended to replace the present Board of Transportation in the City of New York, and to authorize the new Transportation Authority to increase the fare on our entire subway and elevated system to 10 cents from the present five-cent fare.

In Russia there are few hard-surfaced roads. The Germans, in moving the men, munitions and fuel needed by their Panzer armies, have had to rely chiefly upon railways. But Russian railways were laid to a five-foot gauge instead of the standard European four feet eight and one-half inches, and retreating Russians left behind very little usable rolling stock.

The United States Government, backed by London, has asked the Irish Government to expel the Axis envoys in Dublin on the ground that they are in a position to spy on the United Nations' military preparations for the invasion of the Continent. Prime Minister de Valera has replied that he will not do it. So what happens next?

The Red Cross 1944 War Fund of Greater New York up to noon yesterday had received 6,504,040 in cash, which is more than 29 per cent of the city-wide quota of $22,386,000, John P. Stevens Jr., general chairman of the drive, announced last night.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Praising the Philadelphia Convention and Tourist Bureau for a plan to discourage all conventions not directly related to furthering the war, the Office of Defense Transportation today appealed to other groups to follow the same pattern.
LONDON, March 11 (AP) -- A communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- Secretary Stimson wrote Senator Theodore F. Green, Democrat of Rhode Island, today that the War Department knew of no violations of its instructions against taking political polls or straw ballots among American soldiers in Great Britain.

Declaring that American forces in the Pacific and in India depend in vital measure on reverse lend-lease aid and crediting both lend-lease and its counterpart with generating the tremendous power of the current British-American air assault on Germany, Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Acting Secretary of State, yesterday hailed lend-lease on the start of its fourth year of operation.

A USEFUL addition to the fairly extensive catalogue of recordings of Beethoven string quartets is provided by the Budapest Quartet in its reading of the Quartet No. 15 in A Minor, Op. 132 (Columbia, M-MM 545, five twelve-inch records).

WASHINGTON, March 11 -Lend-lease aid, which has grown from a "trickle" to a "torrent" and which has "materially weakened the enemy forces which now face our own Army, Navy and Air Forces," totaled $19,986,000,000 from March, 1941, to Dec. 31, 1943, it was reported today by Leo T. Crowley, Foreign Economic Administrator.

MARY POPPINS would have known immediately what Miss Price was up to -- and would have approved, we feel sure. Paul, who was only 6, had an inkling when he saw her riding by his window in the night, but Charles and Carey didn't know until the day that elderly, prim English spinster fell off her broomstick and sprained her ankle.

The twenty-fourth annual benefit springtime fete for the Nearly New Shop and its affiliated philanthropic agencies will take the form this year of a tea and cocktail dance -- with an elaborate fashion show featuring orchids, jewels and hats from leading designers -- on the afternoon of April 20 in the main ballroom of the Pierre.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, March 11 (AP) -- It was a great day for Texas, but a pink-faced boy named Kelly from Pittsburgh hitched up to Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark in unpressed G.I. pants and a scuffed pair of shoes and walked away with the first Congressional Medal of Honor awarded in Italy.

This isn't O. Henry's hundredth anniversary or anything like that, but it does any New Yorker good, makes him think and gives him perspective to thumb the pages of this Manhattan laureate of the first decade of our century. Those were the days when a man who had an automobile naturally had a chauffeur to drive it and usually a crest of some sort painted on it.

TORONTO, March 11 -- The Toronto Maple Leafs became mathematically certain of a berth in the post-season play-offs for the Stanley Cup and world hockey championship by defeating the New York Rangers, 5 to 0, in a National League fixture before 10,366 fans at Maple Leaf Gardens tonight.

The voters of Colorado's First Congressional District, comprising the city and county of Denver, last week elected their first Republican Congressman since 1930. The winner was Dean M. Gillespie, truck dealer and oil man, who had run on an anti-New Deal, "business man's" platform.

FRITZ, the German Landser, the Wehrmacht's equivalent of GI Joe or Tommy Atkins, is after four and a half years of war not the cocky, boastful, spick and span, heavy-set, lusty fellow that his older brother was in 1939 or 1940. He is not so comfortably equipped. He is not so luxuriously fed.

MEMPHIS, March 11 -- Major league pessimism over the manpower shortage is unfounded, says President Billy Evans of the Southern Association, who insists the boys in the big show have become spoiled by lush rosters of "coddled specialists."
WASHINGTON, March 11 (U.P.) -Nearly 25,000 Americans in remote corners of the world have registered for military service in the last few months, Selective Service headquarters said tonight.

LONDON, March 11 (U.P.) -- British submarines patrolling German supply lines off Norway sank one large and three medium German supply ships near Bukn Fjord north of Stavanger on the southwestern coast, the Admiralty announced today.

LONDON, March 11 -- Milling crowds, topped by 35,000 at Everton, saw few upsets today as sixteen teams survived the initial round of the League North Football Cup series. The second round will start next Saturday.

Six months of New York Stock Exchange trading records fell yesterday, when the two-hour session was the heaviest and broadest for a Saturday since last Sept. 18. Stocks extended their gains and closed at the best levels of the movement, with rails, whisky, rubbers and specialties in the lead.

WE are too small farmers living on farms of less than 100 acres each in southeastern Pennsylvania. What is happening to us and to those like us who live on family-size places throughout the nation? In a technological society like ours the tendencies are toward bigness, and little people are being crowded to the wall in agriculture just as in other parts of our economy.

FOR us, nothing is a better indication of esthetic as well as musical development on the part of the American musical public than the patronage which Wagner's operas continue to receive at the Metropolitan.

Although the weather bureau predicted springlike and balmy weather with possible rain for today, veterans of the great blizzard of March 12, 1888, paid homage to stouter days yesterday at the fifteenth annual luncheon of the Blizzard Men of 1888 at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla. -- Definite arrangements to be completed this week by the Surf Club, Bath Club, Indian Creek Club and other organizations, as well as by scores of hotels here at Miami Beach, are regarded as presaging one of the most active spring seasons on record.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 11 -- Notre Dame will start football relations with Darmouth and Tulane for the first time this fall, including the two schools on a ten-game schedule announced today.

THIS is the story of one of the strangest partnerships known to medical history. Alexis St. Martin, the restless, sullen French-Canadian voyageur never knew nor cared how important was his unwilling role in the progress of physiological science.

Here are "the best screen actors and actresses of 1943" as they appeared -- without benefit of makeup experts or tricky lighting -- in Grauman's Chinese Theatre in Hollywood to receive their gold-plated "Oscars" from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. Each year the Academy selects the "best" movie talent through an industry-wide vote.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Senator Pat McCarran of Nevada, chairman of the Judiciary subcommittee investigating the alcoholic beverage industry, came out today in favor of "a holiday" to permit some resumption of liquor production as one "of the most effective instruments" for striking at the black market and heading off a return of pre-repeal gangsterism.

POST-WAR radio planning is going on at a lively pace. More than 100,000 specialists are now directing the production and maintenance of Uncle Sam's wartime radio organization, it is estimated. This big army of skilled engineers also is devising the radio-electronic future.

CARDIFF, March 11 -- In the rich coal mining valleys of Wales, where nearly 100,000 men have been quietly and stubbornly refusing to work for almost a week, meetings will be held tomorrow, when the miners will hear the appeal drawn up by their leaders here late this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The British Parliament's projected invitation to Congress to send a delegation to London for good-will conversations evoked general but not unanimous approbation at the Capitol today.

PEARL HARBOR, March 11 (U.P.) -- Long-range United States Army Liberator bombers, continuing heavy attacks against Japanese bases in the Carolines, blasted Ponape and Kusaie Thursday, while Army, Marine and Navy warplanes bombed three enemy positions in the eastern Marshalls, Pacific Fleet Headquarters announced today.

The highly accurate bombsights and the jet-propulsion planes, valuable as they have turned out to be, will soon give way to even greater marvels, Maj. Gen. Charles E. Branshaw, commanding general of the Army Air Forces Materiel Command, declared yesterday in a War Department announcement.

Recently in The Atlantic Monthly Prof. Sumner Slichter presented statistics which throw some interesting light on the demands now being made for an upward adjustment of the Little Steel formula. He pointed out that payrolls have more than doubled since 1939.
LONDON, March 11 (AP) -- The text of the note, dated Feb. 22, sent to Mr. de Valera by Sir John Maffey, United Kingdom representative to Eire, follows:

SOMETHING new in the night club medium is promised by the Monte Carlo, which the real estate firm of Webb Knapp operates. By May 3 the East Fifty-fourth Street establishment plans to convert its Casino Room, currently used for luncheon purposes, into an intimate motionpicture house to be run in conjunction with the spot's main activities.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -"Like alley cats at home, their mission was to keep the Japs awake with the whine of bombs," said the Navy today in summarizing six months of nocturnal prowlings of the "Black Cats" of Guadalcanal -planes which operated only at night against the enemy.

NAPLES, March 11 -- American Marauders bombed the art center of Florence today for the first time, while Flying Fortresses battered railway installations at Padua and Liberators struck at the Toulon naval base.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 11 -- Two questions frequently asked today by those who keep their eyes closely trained on political developments are:
AN American recently asked me, "What do Russians think of the future?" My answer was, "We have no time to think of the future, we are fighting."

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Warjammed trains have bred a bootleg industry in tickets which today looms large among better-known black markets, such as those affecting food and gasoline. Arrests by the Federal Bureau of Investigation have revealed that fees as high as $100 above regular railway fares have been paid by wealthy tourists and others in nonessential travel for the privilege of riding the trains as they please.

Germany must be transformed not only in its government but also in its military traditions, Jean Monnet, Commissioner-at-large of the French Committee of National Liberation, declared yesterday afternoon at the fourteenth Metropolitan Opera Victory rally of the season.

CHUNGKING, China, March 7 (Delayed) (AP) -- Shortage of shipping has made Malaya, Japan's richest conquest, a useless asset. Its principal resources, rubber and tin, are lying in idle stock plies because the Japanese have not the ships to transport them.

Many buyers were here last week for the opening of the American Toy Fair, at which manufacturers, for the most part, limited stores to allotments based on 1943 purchases, particularly on such items as dolls, stuffed toys and games, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc.

Predicting that the war in the Pacific would last a minimum of two more years, Lieut. Col. Evans F. Carlson of the Marine Corps, famed as the leader of Carlson's Raiders, who rank with the world's best as guerilla fighters, said yesterday that our fighters have not yet "met the cream of the Japanese Army."

THE bread-pudding quality of plain truths artfully embellished can appear as sillibub to the reader. Just so, a book with message can escape weighty discourse and become a flight into fancy. In her new novel, "God's Front Porch," Ketti Frings has this message: "To answer the question which is on everyone's mind today: What the Hell is going on in Heaven that they permit this Mess on Earth!"

Mrs. Norma Taubele Barber and Mrs. Jerry Metcalf Donnalley gained the final round of the Eastern indoor tennis championships yesterday at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street.

Another jazz concert was presented by Eddie Condon yesterday afternoon before an audience that filled Town Hall, the fourth and last of the regular season. An extra one, however, is to be given on Saturday afternoon, April 8.

CARDIFF, Wales, March 11 -- The green valleys of Wales, streaked with the dirty gray slag cast up from coal mines over many generations, are the setting for the worst strike in Britain since the famous general standstill order of 1926.

Although peace and security in the post-war world will depend to a large extent upon international understanding and international cooperation, the achievement of those goals will be extremely difficult because of the "enormous" amount of ignorance among vast numbers of Americans.

The letter by Lloyd M. Crosgrave of March 2 is marked by the same omission that consistently marks the entire argument for the control of inflation through wage and price ceilings. It drops, in its course, the most important factor in the situation, the fact that the national income in money is 150 billions and only 90 billions in salable goods, leaving a gap of 60 billions.

From the University of California last week came important scientific news. Drs. Herbert M. Evans and Choh Hao Li announced that they had succeeded in extracting from the pituitary gland one of its half dozen hormones -- the one that controls growth.

AFTER more than three years of shuttling between the Twentieth Century-Fox and Samuel Goldwyn studios, which share his contract on a fifty-fifty basis, Dana Andrews has come to the conclusion that it is quite possible after all for one man to serve two masters simultaneously and keep both of them happy.

A joint recital entirely in the Paris manner was given last night at Town Hall by Joseph Rogatchewsky, tenor, and Emma Boynet, pianist, before an audience that mostly filled the hall. The first half of the program was French, the second half Russian.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Sunday, March 12 (AP) -- A communique:

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 11 -- Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio old a Republican audience tonight hat he had found in the country rising tide of opposition to the "bureaucratic, automatic, one-man control" in Washington.
There has been wide discussion of the protest published by twenty-eight ministers of religion and others against the present bombing of cities in Germany.
LONDON, March 11 (U.P.) -- The Saturday operational communique broadcast by the Moscow radio:

Informed by their agents in South Africa that the purchase of pharmaceutical and certain industrial chemicals for that country will be done through the procurement division of the Treasury Department, commercial export houses are planning to protest the move as "another extension of unnecessary bulk indent buying," it was learned yesterday.

TODAY marks the thirty-fifth anniversary of the murder of Lieut. Joseph Petrosino, the almost legendary New York detective. American soldiers strolling through the Plaza Marina in Palermo, Sicily, may observe a small bronze tablet set in the sidewalk at the spot where he was ambushed by two unknown assassins.

PITTSBURGH, March 11 -- Fritzie Zivic, last -- and fightin'est -- of the five flying Zivics, tosses away his trunks to don an Army uniform early next month, but he has a bit of unfinished ring business before he takes his final bow.

NO one can tell the whole truth about himself. It is not only vanity that has prevented those who have tried to reveal themselves to the world from telling the whole truth; it is direction of interest; their disappointment with themselves, their surprise that they can do things that seem to them abnormal, make them place too great an emphasis on occurrences that are more common than they suppose.
LONDON, Sunday March 12 (UP) -- A supplement to the Russian Saturday midnight communique, broadcast from Moscow:

BERNE, Switzerland, March 11 -- The evacuation of civilian populations on the French Mediterranean coast by German order is proceeding with difficulty. The residents are showing no alacrity in leaving their homes on a week's notice, so in most cases departure has become compulsory.

AS might have been expected, Prof. Albert Einstein has his own theory about birthdays. He propounded it in 1940, at the age of 61, when a reporter pressed him for a birthday interview. "What is there to celebrate?" he asked. "Birthdays are automatic things. Anyway, birthdays are for children."

BENEFIT exhibitions seem to be cropping up everywhere now. The Hungarian show at the Peikin Galleries, Hotel Gotham, held as a benefit for the Hungarian division of the American Red Cross, has already been discussed.

LONDON, March 11 -- When private G.I. Joe, United States Army, lands on some shell-plastered beach at H hour of D day of the great invasion, he will set into final effective motion the vast and intricate mechanism of supply that has been building up for two years now just to enable Joe to beat the enemy.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (U.P.) -- Soviet Russia already has received a limited number of naval craft from the United States and is destined to get many more, an authoritative source revealed tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- The projected invitation for a Congressional delegation to visit the British Parliament drew today from John W. McCormack, the House majority leader, the comment that the plan provided an opportunity to "promote better relations and better understanding."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Sunday, March 12 (U.P.) -- Allied bombers have heaped new destruction upon Japan's crumbling Bismarck Archipelago air bases in widespread attacks, while hardened American troops on Bougainville Island in the Solomons killed 100 Japanese in repulsing an enemy attack, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.

LONDON, March 11 -- Economic pressure on the Government of Eire to induce it to expel German and Japanese diplomatic and consular officials is under consideration by the American and British authorities, it was reported tonight. In addition, it is likely that closer control will be imposed on travel between northern Ireland and Eire and on the activities of Eire's citizens employed in American and British establishments of military significance in northern Ireland.

Capturing first places in five of the eight events, Columbia Grammar gained the Athletic Association of Private Schools swimming crown for the third year in a row at the West Side Y.M.C.A. last night. Competing against swimmers from fifteen schools, the victors registered 49 points to win with ease.

LARRY KANE was not of a temper to wait placidly for his draft number to come up. Back in those first dark months after Pearl Harbor he tried to enlist but a bad eye put him out of the running as a soldier.

IT is pretty well established that a certain amount of sleep (at least seven hours a night) is essential to beauty of face and beauty of disposition. So if you've been lying awake nights worrying about the war, figuring out your income tax, or whatever, this is a good time to take corrective steps.

Immediate drafting and presentation by industry of blueprints for a return to civilian goods production which is not inconsistent with the war effort was urged in an interview here yesterday by Robert R. Guthrie, former War Production Board official and a director of the Allied Stores Corporation.

THERE are many home gardeners who have no trouble starting seeds indoors in a florist "flat," a clay "pan" or an old cigar box. But there are many more who need a seed starter that is more nearly fool-proof and complete with explicit instructions.

One of the largest benefit fetes of the spring season will be the Red, White and Blue Ball, which is given annually to raise funds for the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York. The entire ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton has been reserved for the event, which will take place the night of April 21.

Deposits in the 134 banks of New York City on Dec. 31 last were $30,009,320,764, the largest aggregation of banking totals in any city of the world, according to a compilation just completed by The American Banker. London's eleven banks on the same date aggregated about $16,000,000,000, Chicago's fifty-three $6,419,297,000 and San Francisco's banks $5,773,751,200.

OMAHA, Neb., March 11 -- For more than a year agricultural economists and their disciples have been issuing warnings about a land boom. Some of them say it is in the making, some that it is imminent, some that it is already here. But their warnings have met for the most part with the reception of one of Cassandra's prophecies.

Students under draft age desiring military training are being offered a special course by the Army ROTC department at Harvard University during the term starting this month, and continuing in the summer term. The course will not lead to a commission, but military authorities stated that men with this background will have an advantage over boys from civilian life without previous training.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- An official statement of policy recognizing the right of the press to report domestic disasters, but requiring cooperation by military authorities if tile Army is involved, has been issued by the War Department.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- While the country's 50,000,000 income taxpayers chew their pencils and scratch their heads over the most complicated tax returns yet conceived by the Washington mind, members of the House Ways and Means Committee are struggling with the even more difficult problem of doing something about it.

The two most powerful hitters in tennis will come together in the feature match on the program to be staged at Madison Square Garden Tuesday night for the benefit of the Greater New York Red Cross 1944 War Fund.
NEW DELHI, India, March 11 (AP) -- A Southeast Asia communique:

LONDON, March 11 (U.P.) -- British light naval craft have swarmed in close to the Yugoslav coast to batter German shipping and installations while Yugoslav Partisans have crippled rail lines in Slovenia and Croatia, it was announced officially today.

MRS. MULLINS wasn't a bad woman, only a phenomenally disagreeable one. That is Mrs. Donahue's verdict, and she knows whereof she speaks. And since Mrs. Mullins was a mother-in-law, one of the victims of her disagreeableness would naturally be her son-in-law.
A total of eighty-six teams started play in the annual Eastern men's, women's and mixed doubles badminton championships last night at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

AN AIR BASE IN ITALY, March 11 -- American bomber crews who man the Flying Fortresses now attacking Germany have their own peculiar lingo for cautioning each other on enemy fighter tactics. Curt, clear concise, they may be summarized: "The single-engine tailpecker will get you if you don't watch out."

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 11 -- Bruce Staser, Army heavyweight, pounded out a hard-earned victory over the Coast Guard Academy's George Richardson tonight to earn for the Cadets their third Eastern Intercollegiate boxing Association crown since 1938.

THIS novel can and probably will be read as a highly charged spy story, or a Geoffrey Household manhunt. There 15 violence enough in the idea of a young Czech refugee who makes his way to Europe in order to carry out a solitary vengeance on the SS man who killed his father.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The inception of a new and novel type of movement to mobilize influential domestic opinion of all types in support of specific common aims for maintaining peace after the war was announced today by Senators Elbert D. Thomas, Democrat, of Utah, and Warren R. Austin, Republican, of Vermont.

An experimental industrial health program by the Todd Shipyards Corporation at its Hoboken and Brooklyn Division yards has proved highly successful in maintaining health standards for workers, and has still further reduced the already exceptionally low absenteeism rate at both plants.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The State Department made public today the identity of the 524 American civilians aboard the Swedish motorship Gripsholm, due to dock at Jersey City on Wednesday at the end of a mercy voyage from Lisbon bearing persons who had been detained by German authorities.

TO every parent there comes a time when, at last, a pattern of acceptable childish behavior seems to be all set. The young are reasonably clean, polite and prompt; Junior comes to meals on time; Sister remembers to call up when she goes home with Lottie after school.

Mayor La Guardia and Park Commissioner Robert Moses jointly registered yesterday their opposition to the pending bill establishing a State arterial highway system under which State funds would be made available to municipalities.

THERE is a quotation in today's Treasure Chest, from Somerset Maugham, in which he speaks of our inability to tell the whole truth about ourselves. As instance of the way in which frankness, no less than vanity, can distort the picture, he mentions Rousseau's "Confessions," and he might well have added the Journals of that other unabashed self-detractor, James Boswell, whose concern about his weaknesses was no whit smaller than his enormous conceit.

The American people will have o "learn the facts of life about oreign trade and the need for a balanced budget in world trade," William L. Batt, vice chairman of he War Production Board, told the John Ericsson Society last night at its annual dinner at the Engineers Club, 32 West Fortieth Street.

Increased price-fixing and broad trade demand produced yesterday a substantial advance in valuations of cotton futures, which enabled the distant months to recover Friday's losses. At the close of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange, active futures contracts were at their high marks of the day, showing net gains of 4 to 11 points, or 20 to 55 cents a bale.

With a record-smashing total of 68 3/4 points, more than double the production of the runner-up Mount St. Michael aggregation, Coach George Eastment's Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School athletes, supreme in their class for a decade, made it eleven straight years as rulers of the senior C.H.S.A.A. indoor track field yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden.

FREE FRANCE, 11.97 megacycles, in 7:45 P.M. loud weekday English news to America now in lieu of French politics, stresses live reports of the resistance movement in Continental France. The French "Resistance" radio is itself heard on 9.72 megacycles at 3 and 5 P.M. (best at 3).

Lieut. Vyrl Leichliter, 24-year-old Navy pilot from Clayton, Kan., was credited yesterday with "expert airmanship." He brought a huge patrol bomber and her crew of nine men to a safe night landing at the naval air station here on only two wheels of the plane's tricycle landing gear, headquarters of the Third Naval District disclosed.

Dr. Frank E. Adair, surgeon at the Memorial Hospital and chairman of the cancer committee of the American College of Surgeons, was elected president of the American Society for the Control of Cancer yesterday at the close of its thirty-first annual meeting, at the Biltmore Hotel.

LONDON, March 11 -- The air offensive against Germany, initiated on a major scale by the Bomber Command of the RAF in March, 1943, has taken on new form and substance in the last three weeks. The major objective is no longer the elimination of all enemy industry but the destruction of the Luftwaffe on the ground and in the air.

Governor Dewey's plan to permit residents of the State now in the armed forces to cast their votes in November is "a mess," despite the fact that it is "the result of careful thought and study by the best minds and submitted in absolute sincerity," Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in a letter to United States Senator Theodore F. Green, Democrat, of Rhode Island, chairman of the conference committee on the soldiers' ballot.

The "paperwork" of reconversion has begun with the appearance of a new War Production Board form in the hands of the flatiron manufacturers, industry spokesmen stated yesterday. Experience to be acquired with the new form, under which flatiron production is to be resumed with "quotas" for each manufacturer, will, it was said, have an important bearing on all future developments in the manufacture of durable consumer goods.
WAR, disrupter of civilian life no matter how far removed from the battlefront, has laid heavy hands on show business in the Antipodes.

CHICAGO, March 11 -- Michigan won its ninth Big Ten indoor track and field championship in eleven years tonight by taking six firsts and tying for another, while accumulating a record total of 75 1/4 points.

IN his cheerful, sunny apartment overlooking Central Park, Bruno Walter discussed the fiftieth anniversary of his debut as a conductor which falls tomorrow. He will commemorate the occasion by conducting performances of the Bruckner Te Deum and Beethoven's Ninth symphony with the Philharmonic-Symphony this week.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The War Production Board announced today that John B. Smiley, formerly director of its beverages and tobacco division, has been named as a consultant to alcohol solvents section of the Chemicals Bureau. Mr. Smiley's duties will be to aid in administration of the order announced yesterday which places importation of all types of alcoholic beverages produced from cane sugar under strict WPB control beginning March 15.

FATHER KNICKERBOCKER, an impresario with sundry interests, is in the show business, and his children -- by the thousands -- appear to be glad of it. To be sure, he is not directly operating the City Center of Music and Drama, Inc., the sell-sustaining, non-profit corporation holding forth as the sometime Mecca Temple in West Fifty-fifth Street.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 11 -- Thanks largely to the fact that Harold Clark's favored Tiger Call ran out on the home turn, Warren Wright's Teddy Haste and W.A. Coleman's Don Chance finished as named in the photo finish of the Orange Blossom Stakes at Tropical Park today.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., March 11 -- Although hotly pursued by Army throughout the closing bouts, Navy topped eight opponents to win the team championship in the Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association tournament at Lehigh University tonight with 32 points.
A military victory on land, sea and air over Germany and Japan, although desirable and probable, will not be enough to justify America's participation in the war.
LONDON, March 11 -- The great American air offensive against Germany continued today unhampered by Nazi fighters.

" IT is one of the grim ironies of history that the man who gave to war one of its most powerful agents devoted * * * the fortune derived from its development to further the very things it has been used to destroy -- science and literature and the perennial hope of permanent peace."

PRINTS by the Norwegian artist, Edvard Munch, Who died a few weeks ago, are on view at the Buchholz Gallery. These etchings, lithographs and woodcuts are catalogued so that they cover three periods in Munch's strongly creative career: the first from 1894 to the turn of the century; the second from 1901 to 1910, and the third from 1911 to 1926, where the account breaks off.

MOSCOW, March 11 -- Stanoye Simitch, Yugoslav Ambassador to the Soviet Union, and Lieut. Col. Miodrag Lozitch, military attache, today publicly renounced the Yugoslav Government in Exile headed by King Peter and Prime Minister Bozidar Pouritch, transferring their allegiance to the National Committee of Liberation headed by Marshal Tito [Josip Broz].

HERE at last is a South American novel that challenges comparison with good contemporary writing anywhere. Adult, intelligent, passionately concerned with the problem of Argentina today, its essential quality survives even when strained through the uncertain cheesecloth of translation.

The six counties of Northern Ireland, containing a population of 1,275,000, are at war as Britain's ally, the site of important naval and military installations. The twenty-six counties of Southern Ireland, containing a population of 2,900,000 and forming the nation of Eire, have remained neutral.

NEARLY every child in this country goes to school. Our public school system is enormously big; billions of dollars are spent on it; an overwhelming majority of our boys and girls are influenced by it at a formative time in their lives. What are they taught? Why do we teach it? What end-result are we aiming for?

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 11 -- Argentina's former President, Pedro Ramirez, asserts that he was obliged to abandon his office because he was the victim of intrigue and of a campaign of falsehoods that made his continuance as head of the State incompatible with his dignity and honor.

LONDON, March 11 -- Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery, who will lead British invasion armies when the assault is made on the fortress of Europe, told several groups of cheering munitions factory workers today that "we've got this war absolutely gripped in a firm hold and the enemy cannot escape."

NO doubt you're busier these days than you've ever been before. And you probably have less help. Holding down a war job or doing your share of volunteer work, in addition to running a home, is a big drain on time and energy. Few women can keep it up unless they learn to streamline their schedules.

UNABLE thus far this season to get a new play on the Broadway boards, Gilbert Miller is of a mind to do a double-quick about the matter. The other day, before entraining for a one-week visit to Palm Beach, Fla., he revealed that he and not George Abbott, as was generally presumed, would be the producer and director of F. Hugh Herbert's fresh-fromthe-typewriter script -- a comedy still untitled.

IN his day (1807-1882) the great poet was the affable Mr. Longfellow, wealthy and enormously popular. The only dissenting vote came from an obscure young journalist named Edgar Allan Poe. But Poe, who often "mistook the prussic acid for the inkstand," was not regarded too seriously in America.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The text of the note on the requested sale of American ships to Ireland which was delivered to Prime Minister de Valera at Dublin on Jan. 6 by American Minister David Gray:

THIS is the first of what probably will be a series of novels that undertake to describe the thoughts and actions of men who have just come back from the combat area. It covers that bothersome phase of the warrior's homecoming when he slides up and down an emotional ladder and alternates between exultation and complete dejection.

BOSTON, March 11 -- Dr. Ernest V. Hollis, a representative of the United States Office of Education, expressed his concern today over the multiplicity of Federal agencies vieing for the task of counseling discharged war veterans on their educational futures.

HOLLYWOOD IF RKO's "Hollywood Star Time" passes a thirteen-week test on the Blue network's Coast and Mountain States stations, it will join the ranks of transcontinental programs "Hollywood Star Time" is broadcast at 12:15 P.M. (PWT) Monday through Friday from the RKO commissary.

A simple oil bath will protect eggs in storage, according to Dr. W.L. Mallman and Prof. J.A. Dayidson of Michigan State College. Eggs that were oil-treated eighteen months ago and stored at 31 degrees lost practically no moisture and were well preserved. Untreated storage eggs seldom keep over six months, or lose considerable moisture if they do not actually spoil.
ALLENTOWN, Pa., March 11 (AP) -- The Sampson Naval Training Station basketball team upset the Muhlenberg College five, 52 to 47, tonight.

ALBANY, March 11 -- Governor Dewey's soldier vote bill has been amended to make the date of the primary Aug. 1 instead of July 18. The basic reason for the change is to allow for possible delay by the localities in drawing Assembly lines under the legislative reapportionment of last year.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Calling women to fulfill their political responsibilities in wartime, Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Republican leader of the House, warned today against the "peril" of bureaucracy under the present Administration and asserted the Republican will to victory in 1944.
CHICAGO, March 11 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:

One of the greatest banking controversies since the wholesale changes in the banking laws in 1933 and one that may lead to unwholesome bank competition for deposits such as was experienced in the Nineteen Twenties, has come to a head.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, March 11 -- The American net this week stretched out steadily toward the Philippines, our next major objective on the way to the China coast and the defeat of Japan.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 11 -- Bill Dickey, veteran Yankee catcher, has been reclassified 1-A and will take his pre-induction physical examination here Wednesday, his mother, Mrs. Laura Dickey, said tonight. Dickey is married and has a daughter.

LARKSPUR is one of the most beautiful and satisfactory annual flowers, yet it has been much maligned in recent years, particularly in the Middle Western, North Middle Atlantic and New England States, mainly because it has been improperly handled.

CHICAGO, March 11 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission views the Public Utility Holding Company Act as "a shield to investors against the unreasonable exactions of controlling groups, not as a sword by which any class of security holders may appropriate to themselves the legitimate contract expectations of others," Commissioner Robert H. O'Brien told members of the Chicago Bar Association today.

Closing the twenty-five vocational and twenty academic high school annexes would eliminate the jobs of 957 teachers and save the city $3,273,311 yearly in teachers' salaries, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday. In the academic high school division 406 teachers with total salaries of $1,540,543 are involved, while in the vocational branch there are 551 positions and salaries of $1,732,768.

Freed from comparison with the exceptionally high sales figures of the apparel scare buying period of a year ago, retail trade turned upward here last week. Estimates indicated department store sales ran from 7 to 10 per cent higher than in the like week of 1942.

ONE of the theatre's most likable qualities is its fondness for superlatives. It has been called childlike before this, but indeed it does have that very youthful trait of dreaming only the rosiest of dreams, of suffering only the most harrowing of nightmares.

ALGIERS, March 11 -- The death penalty imposed today by a military court upon Pierre Pucheu, former Minister of the Interior of the Vichy Government, who had been accused of treason for collaborating with the Germans, brought to an end the first trial of a French official for political acts of the Vichy Government.

The failure of Anglo-American leaders to aid the Balkan countries in their present difficulties will make the unity of those nations more difficult to attain in the postwar period, authorities in this field declared yesterday at a luncheon held under the auspices of the Foreign Policy Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Lee Savold's success against Joe Baksi at Madison Square Garden on Friday night served to cause two fights to grow where only one was expected. So satisfactory was the Des Moines veteran's performance against the ex-coal miner from Kulpmont, Pa., that Mike Jacobs, president of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club, announced yesterday that he would give Savold a chance to repeat.

The quadruplets which were born to Nora Carpenter in England once more focus attention on multiple births. In this country there are seven sets of known quadruplets, and of these one set -- the Keys sisters -- are now full-grown young women. One of the English "quads" died.

MOSCOW, March 11 -- The situation now being set in motion along the whole Ukrainian front, from Lutsk to the mouth of the Bug River, is the result of the gradual, painstaking operations that enabled the Russian armies to maneuver into striking positions and wear down the enemy's power of resistance.

CHARLOTTE AMALIE, Virgin Islands, March 11 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt received an enthusiastic public reception today upon her arrival here from Puerto Rico in the course of her tour of the Caribbean area.

OTTAWA, March 11 -- Considerable division and a great deal of irritation is expected to result in Canada from the publication of the United States note to Eire and Prime Minister Eamon de Valera's reply.

THE fund of the United Service Organizations was enriched by about $11,700 when collectors and dealers from many points of the compass did some spirited bidding for stamps and related items at the Collectors Club on Wednesday night.

The China-America Council of Commerce and Industry has developed a twelve-point program designed to bring about mutual benefits to both the United States and China, Richard C. Patterson, Jr., president of the group, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -David E. Finley, director of the National Gallery of Art, today announced the establishment of an Inter-American office, made possible through a grant-in-aid from the Department of State. This new unit will be the Government's official clearing-house for the exchange of information on art activities in the American Republics. Porter A. McCray, formerly with the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, will be in charge.

HERE is a blind girl who insists that she is not and never was blind. Why, she had 4/60 vision in her one eye, and there was a tiny opening through the scar tissue in that eye that let her see a word at a time if she held the book so close to her face that her eyelashes blushed the page.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The political overturn in Argentina and the action of Chile and Paraguay in recognizing the Buenos Aires Government regardless of the views of the United States and the position finally to be taken by the other American republics has posed the question of the success of the Roosevelt Administration in dealing with Latin America in its most acute form since the Good Neighbor policy was enunciated eleven years ago.

WHEN a new motion picture comedian is suddenly projected upon the screen in all the enviable elegance of stardom, like Pallas Athene from the head of Zeus -- and that stardom in a Samuel Goldwyn musical, which is next to being sent down on a cloud -- it is cause for us soggy old-timers to do a fast and profound double-take.
WAR does terrible things to men. It degrades them and brutalizes them. If practiced long enough, it strips away the chief attributes of civilization, pity and honesty and hope for a better world.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 11 -- With the Russian Army almost at the gate of Bukovina and Bessarabia, Rumanian Quislings are in in a dither. Rumania is confronted with the greatest crisis in her history. She is the first of the Axis satellites about to pay very dearly for the mistake of climbing on Adolf Hitler's bandwagon.

CHICAGO, March 12 -- The War Food Administration is expected to take action this week to start to accumulate a reserve supply of corn to take care of the needs of essential industries, and although the details of the proposed program are not known to the grain trade, the latter expects that the buying will be done in the some manner as was in effect between June 30 and Aug. 10, last year.

NAPLES, March 12 (U.P.) -- More than 7,000 Italians jammed the Galleria Umberto I today and heard three hours of speeches advocating the overthrow of the monarchy and the establishment of a Leftist Government.

LONDON, Monday, March 13 (U.P.) -- The Daily Mail, in a dispatch from northern Ireland, said today it had learned on high authority that shipments of gasoline, coal and wheat to Eire would get a low priority. Summarizing Eire's economic plight, the correspondent said:

Almost 10,000 taxpayers in the Bronx, anticipating the Wednesday midnight deadline, filed their returns yesterday at the two Internal Revenue offices that were open. The offices are in the Postoffice Building at Grand Concourse and 149th Street and at 29 East Fordham Road, both in the Bronx. Staffs of forty men and women were working at each address from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- The British Combined Services soccer team held a clever, speedy New World team of New York to a one-goal tie today on Ellipse Field.

THE great manor house of Colcorton was a dreary memorial to former grandeur. Its exquisite proportions, its noble, lofty rooms, its hand-hewn oaken floors and its few surviving Sheraton chairs and the Duncan Phyfe table that would seat sixteeen were all part of a stately pattern of beauty that was built to endure. But Colcorton stood like a dignified ghost in the jungly back-woods near the Atlantic shore not far from St. Augustine, Fla.

Stricter enforcement of the Office of Price Administration ceiling regulations, under a State legislative enabling act providing for more severe punishment for violators than is required by the State War Council, was advocated by Mayor La Guardia in his regular Sunday broadcast from City Hall yesterday afternoon.
CARDIFF, Wales, March 12 -Striking Welsh coal miners voted today on the issue of returning to work.
Thanks, Uncle Sam! Today I became an American citizen. I am proud of it and would like to express how happy and grateful I am.

During most of the past week, the stock market advanced rather rapidly, with increased activity. On Tuesday, transactions in stocks reached 1,206,830 shares; on Wednesday, total trading was 1,692,575, the largest since the first week of last November.

Spotty reports were made both as to present retail activities and new buying by resident buying offices in their summaries of the markets prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES. Retailers in many instances are worried over the delivery situation, but in other instances certain departments are well stocked.

The United States should emulate the example set by Great Britain in cooperating with the Yuogoslav forces led by Marshal Tito (Josip Broz), Mayor La Guardia said yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall.
LONDON, Monday, March 13 (AP) -- The Russian Sunday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

It is surprising indeed to read that HOLC is forced to take back 34,233 dwellings in this State and that some of these owners never made any payments whatsoever, yet they continue to occupy the dwellings.

CINCINNATI, March 12 (U.P.) -- Senator Burton K. Wheeler, advocating a United States of Europe as the basis for a lasting peace, said today that two definite steps are necessary if such a plan is to work.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 12 -- Spring training gets under way for the world champion Yankees tomorrow on or about the spacious Bader Field. Here, where Pacific Avenue stares smack into the Atlantic Ocean, only one block away, Joe McCarthy is all set to begin his fourteenth term as manager of the New Yorkers, admitting that he is much in the dark, but hoping for the best.

This is a condensation of the first in a series of six lectures arranged by the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross for instructors of home nursing in preparation for reception of returning war veterans. Dr. John A.P. Millet, chairman of the Emergency Committee of Neuropsychiatric Societies of New York, delivered the first talk on "Personality Survey."
Four new films are scheduled to open during the week at Broadway theatres. The program follows:

PEARL HARBOR, March 12 -- Occupation by United States forces of Wotho Atoll in the Marshall Islands was announced this afternoon in a press release from the headquarters of Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet.

Secretary Ickes, who coordinates our fisheries, foresees a possible new use for the echo-sounding devices that detect the presence of submarines. These sensitive instruments, he thinks, may come handy in locating schools of fish. It gives a fisherman something to think about.

Kathleen Hinni, assisted by the American Dance Group, gave a recital of her own dances at the New York Times Hall last night. Miss Hinni is a leader in the neo-Duncan dance movement, whose object is to rescue Isadora's principles from the mere sentimental regard in which they are so generally held and to apply them to contemporary practice as a living part of the dance arts.
NEW DELHI, India, March 12 -(AP) -- A communique:

LONDON, March 12 -- Unopposed and unescorted squadrons of Liberators of the United States Eighth Air Force systematically bombed the Nazi military targets in the Pas-de-Calais Department of France today, without loss.

Senator Desmond's bill to create a Youth Correction Authority, having received unanimous approval by the Senate Judiciary Committee, is expected to come up for a vote in the Senate this week. It deserves the support of the Legislature. Our present system of dealing with young criminals is imperfect and frequently harmful.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 12 -- Edward Ryan, who played the youngest son in "The Sullivans," and Marjorie Massow, a newcomer, will have the romantic leads in "Take It or Leave It," Twentieth Century-Fox's screen adaptation of the radio program.

Although the crisis in our times may be described in military, economic and political terms, it has a deeper significance that is concerned with the nature of man and the meaning of life itself and that must be solved through rebirth and regeneration, the Rev. Ronald Allen, rector of Northenden Church, Manchester, England, asserted yesterday morning in a sermon at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

Women's greatest contribution to America after the war will be in the educational field, according to the majority of 102 leaders of women's clubs polled by the Advertising Women of New York, Inc. Lesser percentages were listed for homemaking, politics, "spiritual," culture and economics.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 12 -- Eight races, the top number of the cold season, were sailed today off the Larchmont Yacht Club under about perfect conditions, and competition was so keen that only one point in the scoring separated the winner and runner-up.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -Tight Federal controls over the distribution of lumber moved a step nearer today as the War Production Board announced that a system of controls comparable to those now applying to steel, copper and aluminum had been "favorably received" by eight WPB lumber industry advisory committees.

ALBANY, March 12 -- Life insurance companies in the State had an estimated $3,000,000,000 in new business in 1943, and State casualty and surety companies wrote less insurance in the first nine months of the year than in the same period of 1942, Robert E. Dineen, State Superintendent of Insurance, said today in the eighty-fifth preliminary report of the department.

Taking issue with recent warnings that the world's supply of petroleum was running, out, speakers at the annual meeting of the Oil Heat Institute of America estimated yesterday that world oil resources were sufficient to meet normal peacetime needs for more than a thousand years.

DETROIT, March 12 (AP) -- With Modere (Mud) Bruneteau hammering in three goals, the Red Wings closed their season series with Toronto with a 4-to-1 triumph before 12,184 tonight. The decision gave Detroit six victories and two ties with the Maple Leafs for the season.

WITH AMERICAN-CHINESE FORCES IN HUKAWNG VALLEY, March 10 (Delayed) -- The Japanese in the just-concluded Hukawng Valley battle were overwhelmed by a series of encircling and frontal attacks. In a remarkable coordination of many different Chinese and American formations Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell brought the full weight of his forces to bear on the enemy on March 3 and in the week of bitter fighting thereafter the battle was won.

NAPLES, March 12 (U.P.) -- Wellington bombers battered the port of Genoa before dawn today, rounding out twenty hours of aerial blows across the southern rim of Europe involving a record 1,700 sorties by the Mediterranean Allied Air Force.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC Monday, March 13 (AP) -- A communique:
Williamsport, Pa., re-entered the Eastern League yesterday after a year's lapse, President Thomas H. Richardson of the Class A baseball circuit told The Associated Press.

An option to buy 822 acres a mile and a half north of La Porte, Tex., has been taken by the du Pont Company to make phenothiazine, a chemical synthetic for ridding livestock of internal parasites, which was sent in large amounts after the invasion of North Africa to our armed forces under lend-lease to treat more than 2,000,000 African sheep.

I desire to comment on a letter from H.C.S. in your issue of March 4. H.C.S. uses the statement that "there are more than 30,000 persons now employed by the social security agency and more than 13,000 by the Social Security Board. The work of these agencies has consisted in administering the old-age and survivors insurance; it paid $110,000,000 last year."

In a half hour lecture on Hebrew contributions to civilization, Mayor La Guardia last night told 700 persons at a dinner meeting of the National Council of Fraternal and Landsmanshaften Organizations for the Yeshiva and Yeshiva College, that "a people that have such a tradition that has given so much has a lasting permanent place in this world, and nothing can destroy it."

Asking support for right-wing candidates, Dean Alfange, chairman of the Liberal and Labor Committee to Safeguard the American Labor Party, charged yesterday that a victory for Representative Vito Marcantonio, whom he described as head of Sidney Hillman's Committee for a United Labor Party in Manhattan, would "pave the way for the capture in 1945 of the New York City Mayoralty by a combine of machine politicians, Communists and underworld elements.''

CHICAGO, March 12 -- Soap manufacturers purchased 10,000,000 or more pounds of lard and rendered hog fat last week, but there is now a question as to whether all of the 50,000,000 pounds of hog fat allocated to that industry can be obtained and shipped before the deadline of March 31.

FIFTH ARMY BEACHEDHEAD, March 12 (U.P.) -- An American major general pinned medals on two United States soldier heroes today in a bomb-scarred building on the Anzio beachhead, while shells exploding near by shook the walls of the room.

CHICAGO, March 12 -- Oats and barley made a fair response last week on the Board of Trade to the bullish feed-grain situation, and the prospective Government action in regard to corn, but bullish enthusiasm was tempered by an announcement made some time ago by the Office of Price Administration that the ceiling price on both grains would be rolled back to reflect parity prices.

LONDON, March 12 -- The Home Office announced tonight that because of military considerations of paramount importance all travel between Britain and any part of Ireland, either north or south, except in a few special categories, will be suspended indefinitely, beginning tomorrow.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., March 12 -- The Charles A. Coffin Foundation, in a departure from the custom since its creation twenty-two years ago, conferred its major annual citation tonight upon the electric light and power industry. In the past this citation has gone to a specific electric service company.

Samuel Mayes, the youthful solo 'cellist of the Philadelphia Orchestra, made his recital debut at Town Hall last night in a program which gave him every opportunity to show off his considerable musical talent. There was the Weber Sonata in A major, arranged by Piatigorsky; Stravinsky's "Suite Italienne," Francoeur's Sonata in E major; Bach's unaccompanied Suite in C major, No. 3, and several shorter pieces.
Investments in apartment buildings and small houses featured Bronx realty deals reported over the week-end.

NEW DELHI, India, March 12 (AP) -- Tank-led American and Chinese forces, driving steadily down the Hukawng Valley of North Burma in a two-pronged advance, have cut the main Japanese escape routes to the south and southwest and have reached a point only eleven miles from the strategic valley's southern extremity.

In the last such list to be issued for 1943 Police Commissioner Valentine announced in general orders today 125 awards to members of the force for meritorious police action. Three patrolmen are cited for honorable mention, the highest grade; forty-eight received commendations and seventy-four were cited for excellent police duty.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- How Germany plans to retain the booty she has won in this war and to weaken her neighbors so by underfeeding and destruction that she win the next war within a quarter century is set forth in a number of quotations from German sources gathered by the French underground and supplied by the French delegation here.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The advisory board of the National Federation of Women's Republican Clubs ended its winter session today "deploring" what it called the National Administration's efforts "to make a political football of the soldiers' vote," and declaring "it is self-evident that Republican women want every service man to vote."

Hendrik Willem van Loon arrived in New York several centuries after our early Dutch settlers, but in some ways he came to possess this city as fully as they did. As journalist and pedagogue he soon proved himself a man of parts, and for more than two decades now the influence of his popularizations of history and the arts has radiated across the nation and across the seas in successive best-sellers.

James F. Sullivan bought the seven-room dwelling at 119-09 Eighty-second Drive, in Kew Gardens, L.I., through Charles Cook, broker, who also sold the six-room house at 157 Cuthbert Place, in Kew Gardens, to William A. Campo and the eight-room house at 115-12 Curzon Place, also in Kew Gardens, for Alice P. Burroughs to Joseph W. Plesser.

Well-known entertainers from virtually every branch of the amusement world will take part in the "Show of Shows," which will be presented tonight, starting at 8 o'clock, in Madison Square Garden under the sponsorship of the Emergency Committee to Save the Jewish People of Europe.
CHUNGKING, China, March 12 (AP) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek upbraided the people of China today in a speech calling upon them to brace themselves for the final fight for victory.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- A tightening of Federal purse strings was demanded tonight by Chairman Clarence Cannon on behalf of the House Appropriations Committee.

PITTSBURGH, March 12 -- Steel ingot output for the nation last week moved up a half point to 98 per cent of rated capacity, a new high since capacity figures were revised on Jan. 1. Indications are that raw steel output this week will be equally as heavy, especially in view of the tremendous pressure for increased plate and sheet production.

Governor Dewey and the Legislature will be responsible if the city's revenue for the fiscal year 1944-45 falls from $16,000,000 to $20,000,000 short of its budget requirements, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in his weekly broadcast from City Hall.

The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, minister of Christ Church, Methodist, at Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, reiterated yesterday in a statement made at the morning service his stand as one of the twenty-eight persons who in a recent statement opposed "obliteration" bombing of German cities. The protest of the twenty-eight clergymen and others was discussed and criticized in various churches yesterday.
A "sudden-death" goal by Billy Warwick gave the New York Rovers a surprise 5-to-4 victory over the Boston Olympics in the feature game of a hockey doubleheader at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

Roger Kent, Inc., Adds Unit to Chain of Men's Shops The tenth unit in the chain of men's clothing stores operated by Roger Kent, Inc., in Philadelphia, New Haven, Cambridge and New York will be established in the Transportation Building at 225 Broadway, where the concern has leased a large shop adjoining the main entrance.

In the Sutton Place section, at 1032 First Avenue, near Fifty-seventh Street, is a tiny establishment that produces outstandingly good French and American pastries. Perhaps their excellence derives from the professional skill and training of the proprietor, who served an apprenticeship in Cairo's Continental Hotel, then worked as chef in London, Paris and in New York's Rainbow Room.

ALBANY, March 12 -- Hundreds of miles of arterial highways and parkways in New York City are at stake in the battle now raging in Albany over the question of how to pay for the huge post-war developments.

CHICAGO, March 12 -- The Chicago Black Hawks blew up in the third period tonight and allowed a second period 4-0 lead to evaporate into a 4-4 tie with the last place New York Rangers before a National League hockey crowd of 16,423.

HEADQUARTERS, Fourteenth United States Air Force, March 11 (delayed) (U.P.) -- Maj. Gen. Claire L. Chennault, commander of the Fourteenth United States Air Force, warned today, on the first anniversary of the formation of the group, that "from now on we are going to give the Japanese the real thing."

LONDON, March 12 -- Grand Admiral Karl Doenitz substituted for Adolf Hitler at the microphone today and gave Germans a grim Heroes Day assurance that a "pitiless struggle is being waged for the existence or annihilation of our nation."

BOSTON, March 12 (AP) -- Winger Herb Cain became the third National Hockey League player in history to collect 73 points as his Bruins defeated Montreal's top-place Canadiens, 6 -- 5, tonight before 10,000 at the Boston Garden. It was the Bruins' third triumph over the leaders, who have lost only five of their forty-seven games to date.

Three thousand persons attended a meeting at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday to observe Sun Yat-sen Day and to hail the valiant fight of China against the Japanese invader. The meeting, marking the nineteenth anniversary of the death of Dr. Sun, was part of a nation-wide tribute in honor of the founder of the Chinese Republic.
NEWARK, N.J., March 12 -- Sixty-eight trains will be removed from schedules of the Central Railroad of New Jersey beginning tomorrow morning.

BOU SAADA, Algeria, March 12 -- To the improbable places all over the world where the American flag now flies and American troops are stationed may be added this ancient "city of happiness," set in an oasis bordering the Sahara Desert, walled in by great djebels and famous for its troupes of Ouled Nail dancing girls.

NOT so long ago the New York Football Giants announced that they had signed Richard (Red) Smith as assistant coach for the 1944 season. For many years the redhead had served as Curly Lambeau's right-hand man with the Green Bay Packers. Every one in the league knows and likes him. He has the reputation of being a keen strategist, a shrewd analyst of players and an unequaled tutor of young talent.
LONDON, March 12 (U.P.) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin:

The basketball intelligentsia, a peculiar type of fan, boasting cognizance of all matters concerning the court sport, finds an unusual situation in awaiting the start of the national invitation tournament at Madison Square Garden Thursday night.

The new and closer relationships between Canada and the United States that have been built up under the stress of war promise to be of permanent value, Leighton McCarthy, Canadian Minister to this country, declared in the current issue of International Conciliation, publication of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, released yesterday.

A vastly expanded program of adult education for the benefit of the 700,000 veterans to be discharged here after the war and for those who left their classes to go to work is recommended for New York City in a comprehensive report made public yesterday by a committee of thirty educators and civic leaders acting for the New York Adult Education Council.

The events of the week-end are curtain raisers. They are like scenes on a whirling stage that bring the threads of the drama together for the climax. The action swings in a single day from Algiers to Dublin, from Berlin to Rome, and everywhere it has the same effect of last words, last-minute breathlessness.

ALGIERS, March 12 -- If the Military Court of Cessation refuses to reopen his case in response to his contention that the procedure at his trial did not fulfill the legal guarantees to the defense, Pierre Pucheu will appeal directly to Gen. Charles de Gaulle for a commutation of his sentence, it was understood tonight.

The most precise description yet given of the plight to which the French people have been reduced comes from Professor Balthazard's recent presidential address to the Academie de Medicine. Despite the scientific rigor of its phrasing it is enough to arouse indignation at the ruthless depredations of the German army of occupation.

All but nine members of the crews of the Liberty ship J. Pinckney Henderson and the tanker J.H. Senior perished in fires and explosions when the two ships collided at sea in a dense fog, setting off flames and blasts that burned and detonated for three weeks, it became known yesterday.

City officials want a higher fare on the unified transit lines but are afraid to vote for it because of their fear of the political consequences, Paul Windels, chairman of the Citizens Transit Committee, charged yesterday in a radio talk from station WOR of the Mutual Broadcasting System.
LONDON, Monday, March 13 (AP) -- While the restrictions on travel to Ireland had been anticipated, it is doubtful that they will be followed by the imposition of outright

Total war brings out the best in good people and the worst in bad people Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the faculty of Catholic University of America declared yesterday in his Lenten sermon at solemn high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

" The Patriots," winner of last season's Drama Critics Circle award, will wind up its tour Saturday night in Chicago after a run of four weeks there. In the cast of the Sidney Kingsley play, produced by the Playwrights Company and Rowland Stebbins, are Walter Hampden, Cecil Humphreys, Julie Haydon and Guy Sorel.

With her armies cracking in the east and her skies filled with Allied planes roaring in from the west and the specter of defeat stalking about in the land, Germany has just observed her traditional Heroes Memorial Day -- the fifth during the present war -- in a grim and chastened mood.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in the Southwest Pacific, Monday, March 13 (AP) -- Bombers and fighters of the Fifth Army Air Force shot down twenty-six Japanese planes for certain and probably six more in a heavy assault Saturday on the Japanese base at Wewak, on the northeast New Guinea coast, the Allied communique said today.

Somewhat restrained approval was voiced yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission for Mayor La Guardia's announced plan to close twenty-five vocational and twenty academic high school annexes for reasons of economy. While this was a step in the right direction, the committee held, much greater economies could be realized if the Mayor followed its recommendations made in recent years.

From all the arguments for and against the Westchester County parkway toll bill, which has been passed by the Legislature and is awaiting action of the Governor, there emerges one outstanding fact: Westchester alone, of all the counties in the State, built numerous and costly arterial parkways at its own expense, while other counties subsequently obtained parkways at State expense.

The Union Carbide and Carbon Company reported yesterday that net income for 1943, after taxes, depreciation, depletion, amortization and interest, was $38,342,389, or $4.13 a share, compared with $38,088,723, or $4.10 a share, in 1942.

The Excelsior Savings Bank has disposed of a renovated holding on the East Side with the sale to an investing syndicate of the five-story building at 238 Madison Avenue containing two stores and fourteen apartments for cash over a first mortgage of $60,000.
ALGIERS, March 12 (AP) -- A communique:

The first examination of newspaper readership in a "boom town," as well as the first study of a newspaper since the 23 per cent reduction in newsprint went into effect, has been completed by the Advertising Research Foundation. The newspaper selected was The Mobile Press and the issue studied contained 72 per cent of advertising.
LONDON, March 12 (U.P.) -- The text of a BBC version of Pope Pius XII's speech today follows. Radio reception was poor and divergent texts were recorded in London and other listening centers:

BERNE, Switzerland, March 12 -- In a vigorous nineteen-address punctuated by cheers from a vast throng massed St. Peter's Square this afternoon, Pope Pius XII launched yet appeal to both belligerents to spare Rome from becoming field, as implicitly announced negotiations to this end virtually failed.

ON THE ARAKAN FRONT, Burma, March 12 -- An American fighting man has helped to work out a post-war "Beveridge plan" for African peasant farmers who joined up from Nigeria, the Gold Coast, Sierra Leone and Gambia to fight the Japanese.

JERUSALEM, March 12 -- A General Sherman tank crossed the muddy waters of the Jordan River in the Holy Land last Monday with a turbaned Indian at the wheel during large-scale exercises engaging many thousands of British, Indian, Greek, Yugoslav and local Arab troops.

Simple, private funeral services for Irvin S. Cobb, humorist and author, who died Friday, which were to have been held at 2:30 o'clock this afternoon at the Walter H. Williams Funeral Parlor, 52 East Seventy-fourth Street, will be held instead at 4:30 o'clock and with certain observances requested by Mr. Cobb in a letter written before his death, it was announced yesterday.

Vail Medals for valor in 1943 have been awarded to six Western Electric Company employes: Louis G. Delyon, posthumously; Alfred H. Gerlach, Alexander Mikolasy, William Mohrhoff, Louis J. Rom and William C. Neals, it was announced yesterday.

CHUNGKING, China, March 12 -- Although the time is probably too short for an effective Burma campaign this season, the delay is not because Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten and Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell are not in fundamental agreement about it.

New York men in the armed forces have written from such distant points as Guadalcanal and Great Britain to urge their families to back up the Red Cross 1944 War Fund drive, which has a goal of $22,386,000 in this city and $200,000,000 in the nation.

In a beautifully played match that brought roars of applause from the large gallery, Lieut. J. Donald Budge of the Army Air Force, world champion, defeated Francisco (Pancho) Segura of Ecuador 7 -- 9, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 1 yesterday at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn in a practice test for their appearances in the Red Cross tennis show at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- American imagination, which a century ago made a then important conquest of distance with the pony express, has achieved a new triumph, a three-and-a-half day regular scheduled air express service between the United States and India, 11,500 miles away, delivering war supplies for Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell despite wind and weather and wearing out five relays of air crews.

A row of three five-story apartment buildings on a plot 75 by 100.9 feet at 11, 13 and 15 West Eighty-eighth Street, 100 feet west of Central Park, was sold by the Central Savings Bank to a client of Bertram Field, attorney. William A. White Sons were the brokers.

If a newspaper man could, as he sat at his desk tonight, accurately foresee the future he would have no difficulty making up tomorrow morning's paper. It would be an editor's paradise. Sylvan Hoffman and C. Hartley Grattan, who have just brought out a new and novel history of the United States, have been living in just such a paradise.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- Expansion by Congress of Social Security coverage and an increase in payroll taxes on employers and employes were called inevitable tonight by Senator Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, a member of the Senate Finance Committee.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- A cooperative program to build economic, social and health conditions in United States and British possessions in the Caribbean will be discussed by the first West Indian conference to be held March 21-31 at Bridgetown, Barbados, B.W.I., the Anglo-American Caribbean Commission announced tonight through the Department of State.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices was 112.84, a rise of 0.1 per cent over the previous week's level of 112.72. The raw materials index and the farm products index each rose 0.3 per cent.

The inherent economic unity of the twenty-two counties in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut that comprise the New York metropolitan region has been emphasized by wartime developments, according to the findings of a survey made public by the Regional Plan Association.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- A committee of twenty-five Republican members of the House of Representatives was formed by the minority leader, Joseph W. Martin Jr., today to make "a thorough research of the tax field" and chart "a constructive and desirable" post-war revenue program for further study.

Rabbi Stephen S. Wise, who was born on St. Patrick's Day seventy years ago, was guest of honor at a dinner given last night by the Jewish Institute of Religion in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, opening a week's ceremonies in celebration of his birthday and the completion of more than fifty years of activity in American life.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast fro Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communication Commission:
