Some of the major criticisms of the Army concern not alone its methods of training and what a corporal calls "its general want of conviction," but also its slowness in developing new ideas and its system of tactics.

BOSTON, March 12 -- Public support of private industry, which should be permitted to take the lead in reabsorbing returning war veterans into America's post-war economy, was urged tonight by Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio in a presentation of his views on post-war domestic policies.

LONDON, March 12 -- The British Navy has a submarine named the Stubborn. And she's still afloat today because she and her crew were too stubborn to quit when it seemed there wasn't a chance in a million for them.

That Victorian and earlier nineteenth century furnishings may be comfortable, usable and attractive is the theme of a new display on the Abraham Straus furniture floor. Reupholstery has made some of the pieces, such as the easy chairs and sofas, more comfortable than when they were covered with black haircloth as shown on a few examples left in their original state.

I have read Drew Middleton's article "Nazi Exploit Bombing of Abbey" in THE NEW YORK TIMES Overseas Weekly of Feb. 20, and I do believe that Mr. Middleton is not well informed when he states: "German propaganda based on the Cassino bombing is likely to be most successful in Spain."

ALBANY, March 12 -- The fate and form of much important legislation, as well as the adjournment date of the Legislature, is being settled in a series of conferences which started tonight, and which will continue tomorrow, among Governor Dewey, the principal legislative leaders and the Governor's staff of advisers and lawyers.

Under the impetus of more aggressive trade and mill buying, cotton prices advanced sharply last week. At the close of trading on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net advances for the week of 18 to 39 points, with the greatest gains in the nearer positions.

Because he cannot act to his own satisfaction as a manager appointed by the Navy Department to operate the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation while representing the interests of the stockholders as president, Henry J. Kaiser, Western builder and industrialist, informed the stockholders yesterday that neither he nor his associates would serve as officers and directors after the annual meeting to be held May 17.

The Polish Telegraph Agency, in a London dispatch made public here yesterday, said that the Russian advance toward Lwow, almost directly west of Tarnopol, has brought wholesale massacres of the city's residents, with the Germans frantically evacuating the area.

A new issue of $2,980,000 of short-term notes was announced yesterday by the New York City Housing Authority for award on March 21. The new issue will be dated April 20, 1944, and will be payable on Oct. 20, 1944.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Legislation designed to remedy a situation where some disabled veterans of this war have been thrown on their families or charity for subsistence pending adjudication of their claims for pensions was opposed by the Army, Navy and Veterans Administration today Before the Senate Military Affairs Committee.

LONDON, March 13 -- It was expected in unofficial quarters here today that the British Government's ban on travel between Britain and all parts of Ireland as a precaution against leakage of vital Allied military information would be followed by a similar restriction on travel between Ulster and Eire, where there are enemy agents as well as diplomatic and consular representatives.

CHICAGO, Mar 13 -- Substantial disagreement with the Truman committee's proposal that the acquisition of buildings and commercial space required for military use be taken out of the hands of the War Department and consolidated in the Department of Justice has been registered by the National Association of Building Owners and Managers.

Coast Guard Cadet John A. Kramer arrived yesterday from the New London Coast Guard Academy, and the complete east was assembled for the all-star Red Cross tennis show tonight at Madison Square Garden.

The preliminary report for 1943 of the Union Pacific Railroad shows a net income of $45,293,259 after charges and taxes. After deducting $10,000,000 as a reserve against possible refunds on Government shipments and dividends on the preferred stock, the balance is equivalent to $14.09 each on the 2,223,025 common shares.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 13 (AP) -- African Sun, a gelding who just lasted to nose out the highly regarded Pensive in a race five days ago, came back with another winning effort in the featured Boca Raton Purse at Tropical Park today.

With the deadline for filing income tax returns only two business days away -- tomorrow at midnight -- internal revenue collectors of the various districts are reminding taxpayers that they must attach Form 1125 to their statements.

NAPLES, March 13 (U.P.) -- The Allies' big guns shattered the lull on the Anzio beachhead today with a barrage through the mist against "pre-located" German targets in a possible prelude to the long-delayed resumption of Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark's drive on Rome.

Uncle Sam brought out the queue lines yesterday as taxpayers poured into borough headquarters to beat tomorrow midnight's deadline in the greatest rush in the history of the Internal Revenue Bureau here.

The drastic tightening of lumber allocations for civilian use under a proposed WPB order which has been understood as practically certain of passage will result in such a serious reduction in furniture production within the next three months that "a substantial portion of the nation's furniture manufacturers will be driven out of business," a spokesman for the furniture industry said yesterday.

ALBANY, March 13 -- Governor Dewey executed a right-about-face on State aid for education tonight and sent to the Legislature a recommendation, scheduled for adoption, which will increase the school moneys throughout the State by $7,300,000 in a one-year period.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -The Bureau of the Census reported today that in the seven-month period from Aug. 1 to Feb. 29, 3,237,773 tons of cottonseed were crushed, compared with 3,653,938 tons in the correponding period a year ago.

CARDIFF, Wales, March 13 -- The coal strike, which has already cost the country over half a million tons of sorely needed fuel, entered its second week today. Nobody is certain whether the worst of it is over or is yet to come.
The New York Times Hall, at 249 West Forty-fourth Street, will come alive with spring and summer color next week, when it will be the scene of the second annual Garden Week.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The Senate, swinging into its third fight over the service men's voting legislation, today heard the Senate-House conference compromise denounced by Senator Joseph F. Guffey as "a bill to disenfranchise 12,000,000 American citizens in the armed forces of the United States."

Practical, stay-in-place coiffures for wartime women were featured yesterday in the hair-styling classes that marked the opening sessions of the International Beauty Shop Owners Convention, which is in session at the Hotel Pennsylvania through Wednesday.

Schubert's Mass in G was the feature of the concert given last night by the National Orchestral Association, Leon Barzin conducting, at Carnegie Hall. The mass was sung by the Dessoff Choirs, of which Paul Boepple is director, with Jean Carlton, soprano; Earl Palmer, tenor, and Paul Matthen, bass, as the soloists.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- A cut in "A" gasoline rations for motorists in the Middle West and Far West to what their compatriots in the seventeen Eastern States are legally receiving was reported tonight to be likely to be ordered.

Stockholders of the Certain-teed Products Corporation will vote at their annual meeting in Chicago on April 12 on the recapitalization plan presented last October, under which accumulated dividends on the 6 per cent preferred stock would be eliminated and $7,100,000 of 5 1/2 per cent debentures would be retired, providing some additional working capital as well.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- Legislation designed to abolish the Farm Security Administration was offered in the House today by an agriculture subcommittee which has been investigating the agency for months.

Elimination of oil in the enrichment of manufactured gas would give the American public about 20 per cent more fuel oil for heating, members of the Oil Heat Institute of America said yesterday at the organization's twenty-first annual meeting here.

The Kennecott Copper Corporation reported yesterday for 1943 a consolidated net income of $42,263,236 after taxes, depreciation and retirements and $4,000,000 reserved for contingencies. The net was equal to $3.90 each on 10,821,653 capital shares.
LONDON, March 13 -- The stock markets opened the week on a firm note with diamonds in demand on an announcement that the price of uncut gems is to be raised 7 to 10 per cent at the next "Sights."

Among the many foods that have been scarce or unavailable for some time are canned codfish cakes. Now, because of smaller military demands and the fact that more tin is being allotted for civilian use, this product is returning to the market.

To head off the influx of black-market gangsters in the liquor trade, Alfred E. Driscoll, chairman of the New Jersey Alcoholic Beverage Control Commission, announced yesterday that his bureau would prosecute all "bootleggers and operators of the black market" beginning today.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The War Department is completing regulations to remove occupational deferments for all except a few hundred of its 8,500 employes in the 22-25-year age group. It voided all deferments for its 18-21-year-old employes in October.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 7 per cent last week over the like week of 1943, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week the bank had reported a decline of 2 per cent.

Public officials and other friends filled the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Guadalupe, Brooklyn, yesterday morning at the funeral service for Kings County Judge Peter J. Brancato, who died unexpectedly Thursday night at the age of 61.

BEN HECHT was born in a New York Jewish neighborhood of Russian-Jewish parents. But that was the end of his Jewishness. For forty years thereafter he lived in America without encountering anti-Semitism or concerning himself remotely with its existence. He lived as an American, he breathed as an American, and he wrote books about problems that were anything but racial. But then came the scourge.

Congressman Lyle H. Boren, chairman of the House newsprint committee, has strongly criticized the practice of manufacturers of using paper to reprint their advertisements boasting of the fact "my firm has gone to war," it was revealed in the report of the recent committee hearings.

The Reichmans, Florence and Rejean, presented yesterday a showing in which hats and dresses complemented each other. mother-and-daughter combination (daughter Rejean selects the dresses) considers the needs of youth as well as those of the mature woman.

Tomorrow is Federal income tax day and the Treasury omitted yesterday its customary call effective at the end of the week on Government war loan deposits in the principal commercial banks of the nation. Advance payments of taxes have been fairly heavy.

DETROIT, March 13 (AP) -- Packard Motor Car Company and its subsidiaries reported today consolidated net profits of $4,754,587, or 31.7 cents a share on outstanding common stock, in 1943. The figures compare with $4,726,237, or 31.5 cents a share, in 1942.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- The Senate established today an eleven-member committee with a $25,000 fund to investigate the country's petroleum sources and the production and consumption of oil in relation to national security.

Spokesmen for the insurgent group in the American Labor party assured Mayor La Guardia yesterday in a conference at City Hall that there would be no Communist domination of the party if the present right-wing State leadership were ousted as a result of the March 28 primary.

Five years ago today the Republic of Czechoslovakia was invaded and occupied by German, Hungarian and Rumanian armies. The German Reich in the hands of Hitler claimed to be interfering for the protection of "the many German-language islands that the generosity of Germany last fall left to Czechoslovakia."

LONDON, March 13 -- Flying Fortresses and Marauders of the United States Army Air Forces and Mosquito bombers of the Royal Air Force continued today the blasting of the Nazi targets in northern France, at a loss of three planes -- two Fortresses and a Mosquito.

LONDON, Tuesday, March 14 (U.P.) -- Marshal Ivan S. Koneff's Second Army, striking in the center of the 500-mile Ukraine front, pushed to eighteen miles northeast of Pomashnaya, junction on the last German east-west railroad in southern Russia, by capturing the town of Zakharovka yesterday.

Part-wool fabrics ordered in large quantities for foreign relief consumption by the UNRRA are "grossly inferior" and will result in an undesirbale conception of all American products on the part of people in liberated areas, F. Eugene Ackerman, executive director of the American Wool Council, declared yesterday.

PEARL HARBOR, March 13 (AP) -- Army and Navy heavy bombers delivered a fifty-ton bomb attack on Wake Island on Saturday, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today, while other American planes bombed Nauru Island, and three enemy-held bases in the eastern Marshall Islands.
I have read with interest the editorial "March Meeting" in your March 3 issue.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- Representative Clare E. Hoffman, Michigan Republican, charged today that the CIO leadership, Communists in "policy-making" Federal jobs, the New Deal itself and "smear campaign" radio commentators had joined in efforts to smirch Congress and unseat some members.
LONDON, March 13 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull promised today that the Allied military authorities would seek to avoid as much as possible damaging religious shrines and historic structures in Rome in a reply to the appeal of Pope Pius XII that Rome be spared from being made a battlefield.

A sale of articles made by occupational therapy patients in various hospitals in the city will open next Monday morning at the clubhouse of the New York Junior League, 221 East Seventy-first Street, and will continue through Thursday.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- Senator Barkley, Democratic leader of the Senate, called on President Roosevelt today for the first time since his break with the White House over the President's tax veto, and reported a most agreeable session.
CHUNGKING, China, March 13 -- Gossip of Shanghai from several recent arrivals runs as follows:

WASHINGTON, March 13 (UP) -- Secretary Claude R. Wickard of the Department of Agriculture told a subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Agriculture today that an Agriculture Department investigator accused Harry E. Slattery, Rural Electrification Administrator, of "untruthfulness."

MOSCOW, Tuesday, March 14 -- Red Army forces swept across the lower reaches of the Dnieper River yesterday and captured the Black Sea port of Kherson, endangering Nikolayev, only thirty miles northwest.

As the Red Cross Prisoners of War Packaging Center, 39 Chambers Street, marked its first birthday yesterday, the 3,060,000th food parcel packed for shipment to a prisoner in the hands of the Axis forces came off the conveyor belt. The center is one of four in the United States.

A battle between Dartmouth and Catholic University of Washington will start the National Collegiate A.A. regionals here on Friday, March 24, according to a drawing made in the course of the weekly luncheon of the basketball writers at Toots Shor's yesterday.

THE TIMES of March 6 reports Representative Andrew J. May of Kentucky as saying that the House Military Committee, of which he is chairman, has blocked the War Department from distributing 55,000 copies of the pamphlet "The Races of Mankind" to Army officer instructors to be used as background material in Army orientation courses to help combat the Nazi theory of a super-race.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 13 (U.P.) -- Werner Dreschler, German prisoner of war, was found hanged today at the Papago Park internment camp shortly after Army officials had frustrated the second mass escape attempt in the last month.

Portia White, a young Canadian contralto, made what was in many ways a remarkable debut recital at Town Hall last night. Miss White is the possessor of a wonderfully rich, well-placed voice and natural, though not as yet fully developed, musicianship.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 13 -- After spending a day and a night adrift on two life rafts, nineteen officers and men from a United States Navy patrol bomber forced down at sea by engine trouble were picked up by a destroyer and returned safely to the naval operating base here on March 10, it was disclosed today in a delayed release by the Navy.

Mayor La Guardia, when asked yesterday to comment on Paul Windels' statement that city officials want a higher fare on the unified transit lines but are afraid to vote for it because of fear of political consequences, said at City Hall:
AmED HADOUERS If THE SO UTHWEST PACI?IO, ] Tesday, Mrc 14 (P) -- A COm
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:...

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- An 'important statement by President! Roosevelt on occupational draft deferment is expected in the next twenty-four hours, according to Paul V. McNutt, Chairman of the Continued on Page Eight Wr Manpower Commission, who called on the President today with Donald M. Nelson, Chairman of the War Production Board.

When our service men who have served in foreign lands for a year or two are given a short furlough in the States it seems only fair that they be furnished transportation by the Government to the point where they were inducted.

" Memphis Belle," a feature-length documentary film dealing with the twenty-fifth mission over enemy territory made the famous Flying Fortress of that name, is scheduled for release to theatres nationally on April 14. The picture was filmed in Technicolor by photographers and combat crews of the United States Eighth Air Force.
Your editorial "You're a Citizen Now" in a recent issue of THE TIMES should not only be read but also acted upon.

Many women doing the same jobs as men who work beside them in New York industries do not get equal pay for equal work, it was shown in a report issued yesterday by the Division of Women in Industry of the New York State Department of Labor.

The stock market closed yesterday to within range of the 1943 high marks set last July, and although the furtherance of the forward movement lacked some of the spectacular gains of recent sessions, additions still reached a point and more.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 13 -- Moscow's answer to Finland's counter-note on the Russian armistice proposals reached the Finnish Government at noon today, according to a Helsinki report.

Early this season Jed Harris and Jack H. Skirball were of a mind to bring "Jacobowsky and the Colonel" into the Martin Beck. Louis Lotito, who books the house, was notified, but the attraction failed to materialize when promised. At that time the play was credited to Franz Werfel (original author) and Clifford Odets (adapter).

The second concert of the New York City Symphony, Leopold Stokowski conducting, took place last night in the City Center of Music and Drama. There was an unusual program, with modern works of varying merit, and again there was superlative, electrifying conducting.

Permission to appeal from the special three-judge Federal District Court's ruling in the Government's anti-trust suit against The Associated Press was granted yesterday to the Department of Justice by Circuit Judges Learned Hand and Thomas W. Swan.

Promising work on the synthesis of penicillin, most powerful disease-fighting chemical ever discovered, is going forward in several laboratories in this country and abroad, it is revealed in the annual review of the activities of the Rockefeller Foundation by Raymond B. Fosdick, president.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 13 -- The Romans are quite frankly "disappointed" in what they term the "Pope's pleading attitude with both belligerents" in his address to the city of Rome yesterday, according to reports to the Swiss press tonight.

DETROIT, March 13 (AP) -- Asserting that he favored a minimum of governmental interference in the problems of labor relations, William H. Davis, chairman of the National War Labor Board, said today that he believed management and labor could advantageously begin a careful study of the scope of collective bargaining in its non-wage aspects.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended March 8, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

Stars of stage, screen and radio joined last night in giving a benefit performance, "The Show of Shows," to aid the Emergency Committee to Save the Jewish People of Europe. Twenty thousand persons attended the show, which, the committee announced, netted $80,000 for the support of its work.

Reporting on last year's operations of the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation, H.F. Atherton, president, declared in the annual statement to stockholders released today that total business for 1943 was the largest in the company's history and that principal plants operated at capacity.

PHILADELPHIA, March 13 -- Nine insurance companies filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a brief in support of the proposed findings and opinion of the public utilities division of the SEC recommending that the Buffalo, Niagara and Eastern Power Corporation be required to reclassify three classes of stock into a single class.

NAPLES, March 13 -- Russia and Italy are exchanging Ambassadors, Premier Pietro Badoglio's Government announced tonight, marking the first diplomatic recognition of the regime by any of the United Nations. The Russian action was apparently taken without consultation with other Allied Governments, which, it is said, also have Marshal Badoglio's requests for exchanges of diplomats.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Secretary Stimson today urged all 17-year-old youths who are eligible to take the examinations on Wednesday for enlistments in the Army specialized training reserve program.

A man charged in an indictment here with having obtained $276,000 by posing for four years as a well-known Canadian chartered accountant, was caught yesterday on a ferryboat between Vancouver and Victoria, B.C., the Manhattan District Attorney's office announced.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Out of nearly twenty-five cases listed as ready for decision, the Supreme Court handed down only one formal written opinion today and then retired from the bench for two weeks.

A small town on Australia's northern coast is one of the most popular "objectives" of men in our Fifth Air Force -- and a model for Red Cross leave-areas outside of large cities, Mary K. Brown, supervisor of canteens in the South and Southwest Pacific, reported yesterday.

Women who have worked for Army Emergency Relief, the functions of which are being taken over here by the Red Cross, were asked yesterday by Maj. Gen. Thomas A. Terry, commanding general of the Second Service Command, to serve on the women's volunteer committee of the new Personnel Affairs Division, Army Service Forces.

Persistent trade price-fixing and commission-house demand produced yesterday another substantial advance in cotton futures, and carried the March, May and July deliveries to new seasonal highs. At the close of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts were at their high marks of the day, recording net gain of 11 to 17 points, or 55 to 85 cents a bale.

ALBANY, March 13 -- Despite the protests being made by Robert Moses and the New York City administration, the Dewey administration is "standing pat" on the bill it sponsored last week for aid to arterial highways in New York City.

Who ever heard of Asibi? He is a hitherto unsung native of Lagos in West Africa who became a benefactor of mankind because he was stricken with yellow fever and because the Rockefeller Foundation was on the spot. Raymond Fosdick, president of the Rockefeller Foundation, sketches the story in his annual report, which is published today.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 13 -- As the result of a meeting that took place here Saturday night between authorized Rumanian emissaries and other "responsible persons," it is not unlikely that there may be a change in the government at Bucharest.

The proxy statement for the annual meeting of stockholders of National Dairy Products Corporation to be held here on April 20 reveals that the company will seek approval of the stockholders at that meeting for the reservation of 300,000 shares of unissued common stock for a proposed employes' share-purchase plan.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 13 -- Before long the Yankees unquestionably will begin to look the part of world champions, despite inroads made by the national emergency, but today, when Joe McCarthy officially opened the 1944 Spring training season, only two old stand-bys, Atley Donald and Bud Metheny, the "forgotten man" of the team, Oscar Grimes, and a pair of recruit hurlers, Floyd Bevens and Johnny Johnson, were in uniform.

William S. Jack, president of the Jack Heintz Company of Cleveland, Ohio, airplane parts manufacturers, whose employer-employe relations standards have aroused wide interest, yesterday attacked the Government's renegotiation policies in two talks here.

Establishment of a "corporate State" and a consequent destruction of the system of free enterprise will result in the post-war period unless opportunities for youth to establish new business organizations are available, Thomas F. Joyce, sales manager of the radio, phonograph and television division of the Radio Corporation of America, said last night.

Mayor La Guardia's charge Sunday that "certain real estate interests are deliberately trying to create a bear market" brought a counter-charge yesterday from Russell V. Cruikshank, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, that it is the city itself that is creating a bear market.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The Army-Navy "E" pennant, for achievement on war contracts, has been awarded to eighteen concerns as follows:

Changes in Army Regulations 600-90 by the War Department now permit civilians to make purchases of Army insignia, the wording of the section reading that sales may be made to "other individuals on behalf of Army personnel provided the seller mails the articles directly to the organization in which the officer or enlisted personnel is serving."

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The United States has stepped up its production of magnesium to a point where its use in more civilian goods is warranted, the Truman Committee reported today. It charged, however, that inefficiency and waste had delayed the construction and operation of a $133,000,000 magnesium plant financed by the Government at Las Vegas, Nev.

BOSTON, March 13 -- Eric A. Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, declared here tonight that organized labor was presently responsible for abuses against the national welfare as serious as those which brought the wrath of the public against management starting in 1930.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 13 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has named Lucille Ball for the lead in the Katharine Brush story "Red Head Woman in Washington." The film, which will deal with a Broadway showgirl who goes to Washington to become a "gold-digger" and instead becomes interested in war work, will be produced by Edwin Knopf.

LONDON, March 13 (Reuter) -- The Polish-Slav committee founded in London has joined the "All-Slav Committee in Great Britain." Its representatives are Stefan Wilanowski, lawyer of Lodz and member of the Polish Peasant party, land Michael Kochanczyk, leader of the trade union of Polish merchant seamen, biggest Polish organization in Britain.

Command of the harbor defenses of New York has been assigned to Brig. Gen. Charles D.Y. Ostrom, with headquarters at Fort Hancock, N.J., it was announced yesterday by Lieut. Gen. George Grunert, Commanding General of the Eastern Defense Command. General Ostrom will come here tomorrow from Jacksonville, Fla., where he commanded the former Southern Sector of the Eastern Defense Command.

" The kind of furniture we may expect after the war -- whether it is to be well-made native-furniture of new and fresh design, or dowdy caricatures and reproductions of outmoded antiques -- is up to the American women," the designer- decorator, T.H. Robsjohn-Gibbings, author of "Goodbye, Mr. Chippendale," said yesterday.
NEW DELHI, India, March 13 (UP) -- A communique:

ALBANY, March 13 -- The legislative leaders, acting at the request of Governor Dewey, took steps today to abandon controversial legislation which does not absolutely have to be passed, so that the Legislature can adjourn at the end of this week.

Obituary comment on Hendrik van Loon did not omit to mention the fact that Queen Wilhelmina made him a Knight of the Netherlands Lion. Everywhere else in the story van Loon was spoken of, and quite properly, as a Dutchman.

MADRID, March 13 (AP) -- For the first time since the period before Spain's civil war the United States. Government has accepted a Spanish invitation to participate in the twelfth International Sample Fair at Barcelona, the United States Chamber of Commerce in Spain announced tonight.
ALGIERS, March 13 -- A purge of the North African press was promised to the Provisional Consultative Assembly today by Francois de Menthon, Commissioner for Justice.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The full implications of Russia's recognition of Premier Pietro Badoglio's Government are not understood here but it presents some interesting aspects.

An Italian who forfeited his United States naturalization to serve in Italy's war on Ethopia in 1935 at a salary of 25 cents a day was among eighty-six draft delinquents rounded up here last week, according to E.E. Conroy of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. He was accused of having failed to report for induction.

Five years ago today the people of Prague were awakened by the dread sounds of the war lords of Germany come to claim their victim -- the democracy of Czechoslovakia. Arrogantly they came, those first emissaries of Hitler, and arrogantly they went, dragging their despairing prize to be offered in futile sacrifice to the modern Moloch of Berlin.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- Whether family sugar rations eventually will be cut "is not known at this time," the Office of Price Administration announced today in ordering a curtailment of most industrial uses of sugar.

Failure to post price charts was the most common violation of Office of Price Administration regulations found by 800 OPA investigators who began yesterday a city-wide check of 30,000 retail food stores to test compliance.
ST. LOUIS, March 13 (AP) -- Southwestern Bell Telephone Company reported today its operating revenues in 1943 amounted to $137,850,065, a gain of $18,225,234

The North American Company system, second largest public utility enterprise in the country, sold last year the greatest amount of electricity at the lowest average price in its history, Edward L. Shea, the president, said yesterday in his 1943 annual report to stockholders.

It does not seem to be realized generally that thus far the Allies have reconquered only about one-sixth of the immense island of New Guinea. General MacArthur's troops have cut a wide swath along the northeastern coast, straight across the island; but the great bulk of it is still held, or at least controlled, by the Japanese.
I want to thank you for your editorial in today's issue on "Tax Simplification."

LONDON, March 13 (U.P.) -- Intensified Allied operations to clear the Yugoslav coast of German garrisons were reported today. American-led Partisans were battling the Germans on two strategic Dalmatian islands and Allied warships and planes were pressing their blockade of the enemy's Adriatic lifeline.

The four young sons of Mr. and Mrs. John Ryan, 318 East Seventeenth Street, were congratulated yesterday by Mayor La Guardia for their zealous cooperation with the waste paper salvage campaign being conducted, throughout the city. In the past few days they have turned into the Madison Square Boys Club almost a ton of magazines, newspapers and loose paper, enough to fill two station wagons.
A continued tight production outlook on many items was reported yesterday at the spring conference of the Associated Chain Drug Stores at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Freely answering questions about the Rural Electrification Administration which he had previously hesitated to do, the Secretary of Agriculture, Mr. Wickard, told a Senate subcommittee today he had no further doubt of the President's wish that he testify.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, March 14 -- A desperate attack by three to four thousand Japanese on American positions at Empress Augusta Bay on Bougainville Island in the Solomons was turned back Saturday, with about one-third of the attacking force killed, the Allied communique said today.

Indications yesterday were that additional sweater mills will bid on the 5,300,000 high neck worsted sweaters for the Army Quartermaster Depot, following the hint by Maj. J.M. Gibbons, contracting officer for knit goods at the Philadelphia depot, that "drastic measures" may be necessary to bring forth more offerings.

WITH GENERAL STILWELL'S CHINESE-AMERICAN FORCES in the Hukawng Valley, March 12 (delayed) -- The Chinese-American tank force has played a major part in smashing Japanese resistance in the Maingkwan-Walawbum area. Grinding over a twenty-mile route through the jungle, often over trails cut by a vanguard of armored bulldozers, the tanks have been in action since March 3, crushing pockets of enemy troops, intercepting and decimating roving groups of Japanese seeking to escape.

The two six-family flats on a plot 66 by 100 feet at 27-29 Van Wagenen Avenue, Jersey City, have been sold by Barnet Holding Corporation (Joseph J. Harris, president) to the Professor Holding Company.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 13 -- In perhaps the most extraordinary turnout the Giants ever experienced, even in happier days before the war, Manager Mel Ott today cast an appraising eye over forty-two ball players as the Polo Grounders officially launched their 1944 training campaign.

CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V.I., March 13 (AP) -- Robert Mors Lovett, former Government secretary for the Virgin Islands, has resigned as executive assistant to the Governor at the request of Secretary Ickes, it became known today.

NEW DELHI, India, March 13 (AP) -- The inland part of the Buthedaung-Maungdaw Road, necessary for an offensive on Akyab, Burma port fifty-five miles to the south, has been taken with the capture of Buthedaung after two years of fighting by British and Indian troops, it was announced today.

NEW ORLEANS, March 13 -- Praising the contributions of the Palestine Jewish Community to the war effort of the United Nations and their achievements in reconstructing a home for more than half a million Jews, Senator James M. Mead addressed an emergency war conference for Palestine at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY BEACHHEAD FORCES, Italy, March 13 (AP) -- Maj. Ridgway B. Knight, senior civil affairs officer of the Allied Military Government in Italy, said today that of 18,000 Italian civilians estimated to have been in the Anzio area 10,200 had been withdrawn and that the evacuation problem was ended.

GUADALCANAL, the Solomons, Tuesday, March 14 (AP) -Five hundred Japanese hurled themselves into certain death upon the barriers in one sector before the American beachhead on Bougainville Island in the Solomons Saturday.

OTTAWA, March 13 -- Canada's position in the situation that has arisen with regard to the presence of representatives of Germany and Japan in neutral Ireland was made clear in a carefully phrased statement to Parliament this afternoon by Prime Minister William L. Mackenzie King.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- America's oldest minority, the American Indian, received some attention today in the House of Representatives, where a resolution authorizing an investigation into his current situation was passed by 200 to 100 on a roll call.

Walter Lippmann will deliver soon the complete manuscript of his next book, "U.S. War Aims," to his publisher, Little, Brown. The book will be an Atlantic Monthly Press publication. Mr. Lippmann's last book was "U.S. Foreign Policy: Shield of the Republic."

PRINCETON, N.J., March 13 -- Dr. Albert Einstein sent greetings to the people of England today on the eve of his sixty-fifth birthday, expressing the hope for active international collaboration to preserve the peace after the war ends.

ABADAN, Iran, March 13 (by cable) -- In the Persian Gulf oil fields I have been trying unsuccessfully to discover why Washington wants to build a 1,500-mile pipeline from Saudi Arabia to an undesignated Mediterranean port.

CHICAGO, March 13 -- Rye was the leader in the grain markets today on the Board of Trade, prices moving up 1 to 1 1/4 cents from the early low, with May in the lead. The latter sold at a new high in about a month, with numerous stop-loss orders uncovered at $1.29 1/2.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Makers of electrical test equipment who have had difficulty obtaining component parts were assured by the War Production Board today that their problem is being given serious attention by Government officials and the test equipment manufacturers' industry advisory committee.

LONDON, March 13 (AP) -- Two German commanders on the Russian front -- Field Marshal Gen. Guenther von Kluge, commander in chief of the center, and Field Marshal Gen. Georg von Kuechler, on the extreme northern flank -- have been permanently relieved and replaced by ardent Nazis not in the Junkers generals' caste, a usually reliable informant said today.

HOLLYWOOD, March 13 (AP) -- The Screen Directors' Guild, one of the strongest film industry unions, is pretty mad at the Motion Picture Academy of Arts and Sciences, and early today it voted appointment of a committee to make representations and probably a protest.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 13 -- Establishment of a central market in Westchester County for the distribution of vegetables, fruits, dairy products and meats to retail merchants was proposed today to the county's Board of Supervisors. By unanimous vote the board authorized the County Planning Commission to study the proposal.

Plans for a landing on Makin Island had to be changed at the eleventh hour after careless talk by civilians had given information away to spies, Capt. William Bingham Howe, security officer for the Third Naval District, disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The suicidal Japanese attacks against American positions at Empress Augusta Bay on Bougainville Island in the Solomons were described today by Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox as "a last desperate drive" to push us off the island.

An exhibition of rare antiques for the benefit of the American Red Cross was opened last night at Sherry's, 300 Park Avenue, by the Art and Antique Dealers League of America. The display will be open to the public, beginning this morning, from 11 A.M. to 11 P.M. daily.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (U.P.) -- Loss of the Corvina followed recent warnings by high-ranking naval officials that Japanese anti-submarine tactics apparently were improving. On Feb. 8 the Navy revealed the loss of two submarines. Our submarines, however, have sunk 477 Japanese ships.

Hats intent upon flattery, frankly romantic, sounded the keynote of the presentation by Walter Florell yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. A group of crownless hats called "magnets" provoked much favorable comment, but bretons, large profile hats and sailor hats were in abundance.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 14 -- "If any member of the household is more than fifteen minutes late, everybody waits anxiously in silence. After an hour the worst may be feared. The Gestapo has probably been at work. It arrests all and sundry for any reason or even for no reason at all."

Increased liquidation, influenced largely by technical developments following almost uninterrupted gains totaling $3 a bale since March 1, brought about yesterday losses of as much as 65 cents a bale in the cotton futures market. At the close of trading, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net decreases of 2 to 3 points in the distant months, while 10 to 13 points were lost in the near positions.

W.W. Norton Co. announces a new literary award "offered to encourage the writing of books on medicine and the medical profession for the layman." The prize is $3,500 and the contest closes Dec. 31, 1944. Manuscripts should be from 60,000 to 175,000 words, and may deal with the history of any phase of medicine, or medical science or medical theory, or be autobiography or biography.

Sales and earnings before taxes in 1943 were the largest for any year in the history of Standard Brands, Inc., according to the annual report by James S. Adams, president, issued for publication today.

ALBANY, March 14 -- The mortgage moratorium law for the ensuing year assumed its final form today when a last-minute Assembly revolt brought about an amendment to the James bill striking out the provision, previously approved by the Senate, that mortgages on moratorium-covered property sold subsequent to 1937 should become due on Jan. 1, 1945.

There was no blood and thunder in the remarks Mr. Churchill made yesterday about the little neutral nation on the other side of the St. George's Channel. Secretary Hull showed the same moderation in his comments at his press conference. Public opinion in both countries will support these spokesmen.

Before Their Time Two news items on the same page the other day might be said to carry a warning against the dogmatists and the sloganeers. One was the story of the late Dr. William B. Coley of this city as told by our science correspondent, William L. Laurence.
An operating syndicate headed by Alexander Hirsch and Bernard Kempner has acquired the nine-story and penthouse apartment building at 115 East Eighty-second Street.

Competition with the American dairy industry from both Argentina and the oleomargarine industry was viewed with concern by speakers at the ninth annual meeting of the Northeastern Dairy Conference at the Hotel Commodore yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- A charge that high Administration sources "seemingly" are trying to block his resolution for a bipartisan House inquiry of news and propaganda sent to our forces overseas was made in the House today by Representative Clarence J. Brown, Republican, of Ohio.

North Carolina Republicans at a State convention tomorrow in Charlotte will request Governor Dewey of New York to become a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination and will pledge him their support, Sim A. DeLapp of Lexington, N.C., Republican State chairman, said last night in a long distance telephone interview.

The Battle of Burma, as it may now be called, is developing into a much more ambitious and coordinated campaign than seemed possible even a month ago. It started with what appeared to be two isolated thrusts 700 miles apart on the northern and southern borders of India.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Wednesday, March 15 (AP) -- Willkie-minded candidates for delegates to the Republican National Convention clung to a majority of the seven delegate-at-large seats early today as returns from yesterday's New Hampshire primary, the first in the country, neared the halfway mark.

NOT so very long ago Mr. Al (Bummy) Davis knocked out Bob Montgomery in sixty-three seconds of the first round and a fort-night later that same Montgomery stripped Beau Jack of his lightweight championship. It may seem slightly on the illogical side but Davis and Jack are matched for a ten-rounder at Madison Square Garden on Friday.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- President Roosevelt emphasized the need for more younger men for the armed services at his press conference this afternoon, and late tonight Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Selective Service Director, ordered State Selective Service directors to pass upon the deferment of all industrial workers from 18 to 25 years of age.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 14 -- One of these fine days the Yankees will be able to take advantage of the local climate, of which the Chamber of Commerce is so proud. If nothing else, the law of averages is on the side of the New Yorkers.
MOSCOW, March 14 -- High tribute to the work of the American, British and Canadian navies in safeguarding shipments to Russia over northern sea routes is paid in the latest issue of The Moscow News.

One of the many wartime problems that confront banks involves the status of depositors in the armed services who are reported missing in action. This problem is accentuated where the depositor has executed a power of attorney to a friend or relative.

BOSTON, March 14 (AP) -- The Bruins kept their mathematical chances for a National Hockey League play-off berth alive tonight by defeating the Black Hawks, 6 -- 4 before a 7,500 crowd at the Boston Garden. During that engagement Boston's Herb Cain collected two assists to boost his season's total to 75, a new league scoring record.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Miss Jessie Sumner, Republican Representative from Illinois, expressed concern today over the course of the war in both the Atlantic and the Pacific theatres, and implied that concessions by this Government and Great Britain to demands by Marshal Stalin might result in heavy cost to American forces.

CHICAGO, March 14 (AP) -- The supply of swine here so far this week has been larger than that of a week ago by about 4,000 head. This is due, observers say, to the influence of higher prices paid last week. At the twelve major midwestern markets receipts this week to date are 27,000 head larger than those for the first two days of last week.

The six-story apartment house containing, sixty-eight suites and ten garages, with a total rental of about $55,000, at 30 East Chester Road, New Rochelle, Westchester County, has been sold by Samuel Knepper, operator, to the Mohawk Utilities Corporation.

Vladimir Horowitz, pianist, gave his first New York recital of the season last night in Carnegie Hall. It could have been written in advance of the event that the hall would be packed, that seats for a limited number of men and women in the armed services would be available on the stage, that enthusiasm would run high.

The one-story business buildings at 984 and 986 Sixth Avenue, between Thirty-sixth and Thirty-seventh Streets, have been sold by the Bowery Savings Bank to a client of Dwight, Voorhis Helmsley, Inc., brokers. The property, assessed at $273,000, measures 61 by 100 feet.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -Britain's plans to isolate Eire in connection with the operations of Axis spies were edorsed in general terms by Secretary of State Cordell Hull today.

To start right out with the good news, "Jacobowsky and the Colonel," which opened last evening at the Martin Beck, is the theatre's latest agreeable evening. The writing talents of Franz Werfel and S.N. Behrman, which outwardly might seem unalike, combined to tell its tale of a flight from France; and the Theatre Guild, already producing its share of the season's good plays, has given it a fine production.

Kings County Judge Franklin Taylor ruled yesterday that the title of "acting district attorney" now held by Thomas Cradock Hughes in the absence of District Attorney William O'Dwyer, who is a colonel in the Army, was "a statutory misnomer" and that the State Legislature enacted an unconstitutional law when it delegated to the acting district attorney the powers of the duly elected District Attorney.

Six hundred and sixty-three men and women, many of whom have spent months or years in Nazi internment and prisoner-of-war camps, will arrive here today on the diplomatic exchange liner Gripsholm, which is scheduled to dock at Pier F, Jersey City, at about 12:30 P.M.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,347, against 1,207 in the preceding week and 1,158 in the similar period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 480, compared with 633 last Tuesday.
ALBANY, March 14 -- Both houses of the Legislature drove steadily toward the goal of Saturday adjournment, although attainment will not be definitely certain for another day or two.

DOVER, Del., March 14 (AP) -- The management's slate of directors was re-elected at the annual stockholders' meeting of the American Superpower Corporation here today, over a slate of four entered in opposition by Randolph Phillips of New York.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- The House Committee for Investigating Civil Service is considering an inquiry to determine whether pilots of the Women's Air Force Service, known as Wasps, should be continued while thousands of experienced men pilots are looking for jobs.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 14 (AP) -- Authorities announced today that the German spy plot unearthed in Chile last month had resulted in the seizure of approximately $184,000, all of which was traced to Maj. Ludwig von Bohlen, former air attache at the German Embassy who was repatriated several months ago.

A new heel construction, described as "the first really new development in hosiery in many years" and cited as an example of post-war ideas that will radically change methods of manufacturing full-fashioned hosiery, was made known yesterday by T.H. Mueller, president of Julius Kayser Co. at a luncheon of the Kayser Fifty-Year Club at the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull exhibited an air of patience, apparently born of a realization that diplomatic questions were bound to arise from time to time as the war progressed, when he was asked at his press conference today to comment on Russian recognition of Premier Pietro Badoglio's regime.

Taxpayers in growing numbers herded themselves into internal revenue offices throughout the city yesterday. As the deadline for filing 1943 returns drew closer, the tension among those who had put off paying until the end mounted.

Arthur E. Lehrfeld, a practicing lawyer for eighteen years, was arrested last evening in his office at 1457 Broadway on an indictment alleging that after he had obtained the release of an ex-convict on bail in the Felony Court last Oct. 21 he "induced" him to perpetrate five burglaries in the midtown district and later bought some of the $6,000 loot for $625.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 14 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has bought the screen rights to A.J. Cronin's forthcoming novel, "The Green Years," paying the record price of $200,000. The highest amount previously for a book was $175,000, paid by Warner Brothers for Edna Ferber's "Saratoga Trunk."

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The exchange of diplomatic representatives, which Soviet Russia has proposed to the Badoglio government of Italy, under King Victor Emmanuel, and which is expected soon to take place, is only one fundamental step in advance of the prevailing relations of the Italian regime with the Governments of the United States and Great Britain.

Afraid that knowledge of parents' lying and stealing will affect permanently the standards of their children, women of the Norwegian underground are planning to re-educate these young people, once their battle against the Nazis is won, Dr. Lena Phillips, international president of the Federation of Business and Professional Women, back from a five-month trip to Great Britain and Sweden, said yesterday.

As anxious hundreds watched, a huge commercial airliner operated under contract to the Army Transport Command for transport and cargo crashed at La Guardia Field yesterday afternoon, and, bursting into flames after an explosion, turned into a funeral pyre for two mechanics who somehow had flown the ship for twenty minutes.
MADRID, March 14 (AP) -- Pierre Laval, French Chief of Government, has been left outside in the latest German-sponsored reshuffle of Vichy forces, border reports said today.

WITH AMERICAN AND CHINESE FORCES, in the Maingkwan-Walawbum Area, Burma, March 1 (delayed) -- Admiral the Lord Louis Mountbatten, Allied Commander in Chief in Southeast Asia, suffered a slight injury to the left eye when he was struck by a piece of bamboo while on a recent inspection of the Burma front lines.

A correspondent in the Vermont Middlebury told us yesterday on this page that in that charming and famous town "fence viewers are called upon several times each year to settle disputes between adjoining owners." To him that hath shall be given. Middlebury of the engaging landscape, Gamaliel Painter's Hall, Old Chapel and the air of ancient peace and long cultivation has the additional merit of preserving a venerable function.

There is general agreement that the morale of the home front must be maintained at a high level while the nation's fighting men are away at the battlefronts. It may be, however, that there is not a general understanding of the size and the difficulties of the task.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- An eleven-man Senate committee appointed by Vice President Wallace under a resolution adopted yesterday by the upper chamber, planned today to make an early start on a broad investigation of the petroleum situation.

CHICAGO, March 14 (AP) -- The railroad industry's future will depend to a large extent on engineering, James M. Symes, vice president in charge of the western region of the Pennsylvania Railroad, said today in an address at the annual convention of the American Railway Engineering Association here.

With a new show and a new name the old Jolson Theatre, 932 Seventh Avenue, between Fifty-eighth and Fifty-ninth Streets, is to have a rebirth on Saturday night, April 8. With the premiere of Dave Wolper's musical comedy, "Follow the Girls," the house will be rechristened The Century.
The Puerto Rican Golden Gloves amateur boxing team withdrew from the champion of champions tourney last night, charging its members had been discriminated against, according to The Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Miss Betty C. Wright, executive director of the American Society for the Hard of Hearing, who has traveled from coast to coast helping to restore the joy of everyday communication to deaf persons, has joined the staff of the American Red Cross to be consultant in the three Army hospitals designated for the special care of deafened soldiers.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, March 15 (AP)-- A communique:

White bread -- the ordinary enriched variety with which everyone is familiar -- has presented problems to commercial bakers during the past year. Two of the principal ingredients, dried milk and shortening, have been hard to come by.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- Senator James O. Eastland, Democrat, of Eastland, Miss., proposed today that Congress investigate the New York Cotton Exchange on the basis of a complaint by a cotton cooperative leader that it was offering "price destruction instead of price insurance."

Various interpretations will be put upon Moscow's decision to exchange Ambassadors with the Badoglio regime. They will all be highly speculative, for it is not easy to read the mind of Joseph Stalin, and no one can say with certainty what his motives are in beating his Western allies to the draw in according full diplomatic recognition to the Royal Italian Government.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 14 (AP) -- Beating par by a single stroke, Gene Sarazen, Sgt. Clayton Heafner and Leonard Dodson tied for the first-round leadership in the North and South open golf tournament today with scores of 71.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, March 15 -- The Soviet High Command reported last night that troops of Gen. Rodion Y. Malinovsky's Third Ukraine Front, following up Monday's dramatic capture of Kherson, had surrounded several German divisions in the region of Bereznegovatoye and Snigirevka, about thirty-seven miles east of Nikolayev, killing 10,000 officers and soldiers and taking 4,000 prisoners, as well as capturing quantities of materiel.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Finland was again urged by Secretary of State Cordell Hull today to get out of the war.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 14 --Two pitchers, one outfielder, two coaches, a manager, a trainer and two clubhouse men represented the Dodgers as they checked in at Bear Mountain Inn tonight for the start of training tomorrow for their National League championship campaign.

The Daily Worker, which had consistently assailed the Government of King Victor Emmanuel and Marshal Pietro Badoglio and supported the demands for its removal voiced by anti-monarchist and anti-fascist elements in Italy headed by Count Carlo Sforza, today gives its approval of the Soviet Government's recognition of the Badoglio regime.

At the annual meeting of the delegates to the American Kennel Club held at the club offices in this city yesterday, officers were re-elected, proposed amendments to the rules were voted upon and routine business transacted.

DUBLIN, March 14 (AP) -- Gloom was cast upon Dublin today by Prime Minister Churchill's warning in the House of Commons that travel restrictions to Eire were but the first step in a policy designed "to isolate southern Ireland from the outer world during the critical period which now is approaching."

A jury of five men and seven women that will decide the fate of Lieut. (j.g.) Adam Rother of the Coast Guard, accused of killing Miss Rita Costello, was selected yesterday in the Richmond County Court at St. George. It was sworn in by Judge Thomas J. Walsh, who is presiding at the trial, which opened on March 6.
Do Americans as a whole realize the magnitude and the heavy cost of the battle of the air now being fought over Europe?

In a season of vibrant colors it was challenging to see the insistence on black and white for a spring theme that Russeks made yesterday in its "spring finals" showing in the Cotillion Room of the Hotel Pierre. The Fifth Avenue specialty house advocated this combination for casual sports togs as well as for sophisticated street wear.

The National Labor Relations Board has been called upon to decide whether any of its officials or agents may use the instrument of free speech in representation elections of employes in a manner likely to affect the results of such elections.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Publication from unofficial sources of the proposals which the British and Canadian Governments will make at the coming international air parleys in Washington and the recent announcement of air policy by the Australian and New Zealand Governments indicate that the views of the British nations on post-war aviation differ from each other and from those held here.
LONDON, March 14 -- The German soldier who is not tainted by the Nazi ideology is "a good chap," Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery said Friday night during an inspection tour of the invasion forces.

Alfred E. Driscoll, chairman of the New Jersey Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, yesterday delivered another blow at the black market in liquor by ordering all licensees in the State to provide his office with complete new minimum resale list of all alcoholic beverages sold at retail.

CLEVELAND March 14 (AP) -- Transportation is the principal problem of America's wartime domestic economy, Brig. Gen. Leonard P. Ayres, USA, retired, economist and vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company, said today in the bank's monthly business review.

A ten-week course in occupational therapy ended with graduation exercises yesterday for eighty-five volunteer workers who will serve as "amateur" therapists as an emergency measure to help meet the rapidly growing demand for this type of service in military and civilian hospitals.

Thomas J. Curran, New York County Republican chairman, announced last night that his organization had rented Madison Square Garden for the closing Republican rally of this year's Presidential campaign on Nov. 4, the Saturday preceding the voting.

LONDON, March 14 -- Seven types of post-war transport aircraft, including one that is jet-propelled, are under consideration by the British Government, Sir Archibald Sinclair, Air Secretary, announced today in the House of Commons in a speech in which he defended the present government policy of civil aviation against demands that military and civil aviation be divorced.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, March 15 (AP) -- Trapped Japanese, dying by the hundreds in suicidal attacks rather than surrender, were reported today massing for another assault on American positions in the Empress Augusta Bay sector of western Bougainville, in the Solomons.

Reporting increasing production of the better grade of products made from synthetic rubber, Clyde DeLong of the B.F. Goodrich Company, said yesterday that by May rubber companies will be shipping fairly substantial quantities of sundries and by the end of the year there will be a notable increase in the number and range of such items that are available.

NAPLES, March 14 -- While political observers in Italy regard the Russian recognition of Premier Pietro Badoglio's Government as the probable preliminary to Moscow's full acceptance of liberated Italy, Communist party leaders here announced today that they would intensify their efforts to overthrow King Victor Emmanuel and Marshal Badoglio's Cabinet.

Total North American stocks of newsprint paper on hand at the end of February totaled 174,032 tons, compared with 155,287 at the end of the previous month and 189,147 at the end of the corresponding month last year, according to a report yesterday by the News Print Service Bureau.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -Here is the vote by which the Senate today approved the compromise service men's vote bill, which leaves the ballots for the armed forces largely to the States:

LONDON, March 14 -- Negotiations looking toward an agreement to permit Britain to resume exporting small quantities of some products while she is still receiving lend-lease aid from the United States are understood to be under way in Washington.

Marjorie Lawrence, the Australian soprano who is still severely handicapped from an attack of paralysis two years ago, sang the grueling role of Isolde in Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" at the Metropolitan Opera for the first time yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The U.S.S. Corvina, twentieth United States submarine missing since the war began, is overdue from patrol activity and must be presumed lost, the Navy Department announced today.

In protest to your editorial "Mr. de Valera's Neutrality," I raise the point that you, in common with most Americans, fail to comprehend, that this is not the neutrality of one man but the determined policy of a sovereign nation which happens to be within its tight isle the most united nation in the world.

A halt was called yesterday in the stock market's rapid upswing by selling which developed during the opening hour. While prices reacted, the liquidation was not impressive and speedily subsided after its initial appearance in certain issues.

The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday gave its assent to a postponement of the bout between Bob Montgomery, who recently regained his lightweight title from Beau Jack, and Sammy Angott, scheduled for March 31 at Madison Square Garden.

The Glee Club of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick featured the concert of Irish music, traditional and modern, presented last night at Town Hall. The Glee Club, founded by the late Victor Herbert, made its first appearance before a public audience under the direction of George Mead.

Production of a limited number of passenger automobiles will begin in the next six months, and the first new models will be placed on the market by July of next year, Ray Chamberlain, executive vice president of the National Automobile Dealers Association, said yesterday.

Potato dealers in New York City declared yesterday that a tidal wave of new-crop potatoes would swamp the market within three or four weeks unless the Federal Government speeds its ambitious program to move the 138,000,000-bushel carry-over from last year's record crop of 480,000,000 bushels.

CHICAGO, March 14 -- A heavy undertone prevailed today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade and at no time were prices above yesterday's closing quotations. Reports that Rumania was seeking peace terms with the United Nations had some effect on sentiment.

Announcing a new total of $8,100,000 for the Red Cross 1944 War Fund of Greater New York, John P. Stevens, general chairman of the city-wide drive here, made an appeal yesterday for workers to redouble their efforts to meet their quotas by March 31 and avert extending the drive into April, as was done last year.

LONDON, Wednesday, March 15 (AP) -- At least two waves of German bombers swooped across London last night and poured flaming phosphorus bombs, thousands of incendiaries and many high explosives on two of the city's best known business and residential districts.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 14 -Prince Barbu Stirbey, one of the Rumanian peace emissaries, has proceeded to Cairo after consultation with British authorities here. In Egypt Prince Stirbey will submit to British and American representatives Rumania's official peace proposals, it is asserted here.

Premier Hideki Tojo's Cabinet acted yesterday to relieve Japan's strained domestic transportation system by placing already restricted railway travel on a drastic "rationing" and "permit" basis, even for military men and Government personnel, and decreeing the abolition of taxis "as a general rule."

WASHINGTON, March 14 (U.P.) -- The armed forces do not have all the war tools they need and no one should get the idea "that the war is over when we discuss contract termination in terms of post-war problems," James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary of Navy, said today.

Capt. Harold E. Segal, Marine Corps fighter pilot, plunged into the waters off New Georgia Island at 110 miles an hour and is alive to tell about it, only because "a man named God was sitting beside me," he declared yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, March 14 (AP) -- An attractive 42-year-old Italian woman was acclaimed by Buenos Aires newspapers tonight as the mother of quintuplets, born eight months ago and jealously kept secret because she remembered "how crowds mobbed the Dionne home in Canada."

Your editorials and news items on Eire's neutrality status were more objective and fair-minded than others which were brought to my attention. However, in view of those Irish and Americans of Irish descent who are fighting for our country, I feel that several matters pertaining to Eire's side of the question should be presented.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation let it be known yesterday that it is once again on the lookout for Jack K. Meredith, and if anybody else sees him first -- it would be well to look out.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14 (AP) -- The question whether a redemption premium of $570,000 should be paid on the Laclede Gas Light Company's $23,000,000 of 1919 bonds was the subject of oral arguments today before the Securities and Exchange Commission between counsel for the company and for two investment bond holders, the Massachusetts Life Insurance Company of Springfield and the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company of Boston.

LONDON, Wednesday, March 15 (U.P.) -- The Third Ukrainian Army has trapped several German divisions in a 300-square-mile pocket north of Kherson while other units of Gen. Rodion Y. Malinovsky's army, advancing almost a mile an hour, have smashed to within twenty-one miles east of Nikolayev, Moscow announced last night.

Praise is not lacking these days for the airman -- and he deserves it. The ranger gets recognition when he crawls blackfaced into the enemy's lines -- he earns it. The parachute trooper is rightly honored. The men who take the submarines down and the submarine chasers out should be regarded as heroes, and they are.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- President Roosevelt described the Germans today as warriors against religion and said that it could be expected that they would desecrate Rome by making it a "military center."

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Early and favorable action by Congress on the proposed merger of United States communications companies operating in foreign fields was predicted by James L. Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, at today's hearing before the special House committee which is investigating his agency.

The report for 1943 of the Texas Company, issued for publication today by W.S.S. Rodgers, president, shows a consolidated net income of $42,889,797 after charges, taxes and reserves including $8,000,000 for contingencies due to the war.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Courteously but firmly the American Federation-of Labor today rejected President Roosevelt's request that it share equally with the Congress of Industrial Organizations in representation at the Conference of the International Labor Organization in Philadelphia on April 20.

Emil Schram, chairman of the New York Committee of the National War Fund, yesterday made public a letter he received from Hendrik Willem Van Loon last June, in which the writer made known his intention to take a part in the committee's activities despite his doctor's warning against overwork.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -Blaming "scant patronage," the Office of Defense Transportation disclosed that one of the two special all-coach trains added to Florida-to-New York rail schedules to handle emergency traffic had been discontinued.
Of the many plans for projects to take up the slack of unemployment after the war, there is one plan that never seems to be considered.

Yesterday's vote in the Senate, on the question of final approval of a bill which fails by a long way to do all that the Federal Government could reasonably and properly be expected to do to assure ballots for the armed forces in this year's national elections, reveals essentially the same partisan and sectional pattern which has prevailed throughout the long debate on this much argued issue.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Senate adopted today, by a vote of 47 to 31, the "States' Rights" conference compromise on the long-contested service men's voting legislation restricting sharply the use of the Administration-endorsed Federal (short) ballot in the Presidential-Congressional election.

LONDON, March 14 -- Reports from Stockholm tonight said the Swedish newspaper Allehanda had devoted a considerable part of its space today to photographs of what was said to be American propaganda literature dropped on Berlin last week, when United States bombers hit Berlin three times in four days.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

BOSTON, March 14 (AP) -- Lord Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States, warned the United Nations today against an intense German political offensive aimed at the disaster of a compromise peace.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Office of Price Administration reduced the rations of all A book holders west of the Allegheny Mountains today to the level of the Atlantic Coast States and sliced permissible mileage of B rations from 460 to 400 miles a month in California, Oregon, Washington, Nevada and Arizona.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Negotiations between British and American officials to work out a reciprocal arrangement by which each country could make exceptions to the general rule that lend-lease and reverse lend-lease goods should not enter commercial channels have been under way since last July, according to informed sources here.

The Hoboken (N.J.) Bank for Savings has sold its former four-story bank and office building at 84 Washington Street, to the Professional Associates, Inc. The parcel, assessed for $56,500, was bought for $35,000.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, March 15 -- A new landing on New Britain by American forces and another smashing aerial attack on the Japanese base at Wewak, New Guinea, where Allied fliers have shot down sixty-five enemy planes in three days, were announced today by Gen. Douglas MacArthur.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The handling by the Office of Price Administration of rent controls, food rationing and pricing, and of appeals from its adverse rulings were the targets of critics offering amendments to present price control laws before a special House committee investigating executive agencies.

School leaders, parents and educational groups joined yesterday in praising Governor Dewey for sponsoring increased State aid to education, estimated to give this city an additional $3,000,000. At the same time, educators called upon Mayor La Guardia to maintain existing standards, and not cut the school budget as he had indicated he might have to do if the State funds were not forthcoming.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 14 -- Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau and Congressional leaders who have worked on tax legislation will be interested to learn that, in spite of the groans from the American people when filling out their income tax forms, the vast majority say that the taxes they have to pay are justified and fair.
Lady Ross has returned from Florida and is at the Ambassador,

ALBANY, March 14 -- While Governor Dewey signed today without comment two Coudert bills authorizing the City Council to continue, for another year, New York City's sales tax and the city's utility tax, the Assembly passed the Crews bill without dissenting vote, to authorize a referendum on a pay raise of $450 a year for the city's 17,000 policemen and 10,000 firemen.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- With industry members dissenting, the labor and public majority of the National War Labor Board upheld today the decision of the Second Regional War Labor Board in the New York milk wage dispute as well as the award of Ralph T. Seward, impartial chairman of the metropolitan New York milk industry.

LONDON, March 14 -- The stock markets here were quiet today, the main interest centering in Kaffir and diamond shares. The approach of the Salute the Soldier Savings Week had a restraining influence on gilt-edge issues, with fractional losses being recorded in the 3 1/2 per cent War Loan, the 3 per cent War Loan, Old Consols and Local Loans.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Germany's boast of air superiority has been punctured in two respects, Charles E. Wilson, executive vice chairman of the War Production Board and chairman of WPB's Aircraft Production Board, said today. The Nazis are outfought in the air by Allied fliers and their aircraft plants are outproduced by the United Nations.

With strategy, stamina and organization that grow more and more impressive, the Russian armies which cut the life-line of the German forces in the Ukraine only a week ago are now proceeding to take full advantage of their bold stroke. Along a front of more than 500 miles, stretching from Kherson on the Dnieper to Tarnopol in Poland, they are closing in on what is left of Field Marshal von Mannstein's half a million men.
ALBANY, March 14 -- The Todd bill providing equal pay for women in industry passed the Assembly today without debate or opposition and was then sent to the Senate for concurrence.
LONDON, March 14 (AP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:
NEW DELHI, India, March 14 (U.P.) -- A communique:
LONDON, March 14 -- The Russian recognition of Marshal Badoglio caused considerable surprise here today.

War has brought sharp changes in the portfolios of the leading investment trusts, according to a survey just completed by the National Association of Investment Companies. Comparing the 1939 and 1943 year-ends, the survey reveals that holdings have gone up in rail bonds, preferred stocks and the commons of oils, banks and finance companies, foods and beverages, motion pictures and rubbers.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Feb. 26 (AP) -- More than 600 medals were awarded to members of the armed forces from New York State in this theatre of war in 1943, a recapitulation showed today.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- A "magnificent metamorphosis" in the plant of the Curtiss-Wrigght Aviation Corporation at Columbus, Ohio, where the Navy's SB2C "Hell Diver" dive bombers, and SB3C Seagull observation planes are manufactured, was reported today by Representative Melvin J. Maas, Republican, of Minnesota.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 14 -- The Argentine GOU [Grupo de Oficiales Unidos or United Officers Group], mysterious organization that more than once blocked former President Pedro P. Ramirez's efforts to draw closer to the United Nations, was dissolved by its governing board on Feb. 23, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The War Production Board wrote an end today to its order issued in June, 1943, which halted production of brewery, winery, beverage and ice cream machinery. Under the revocation and a new ruling manufacturers will be permitted to turn out a small percentage of their output during the pre-war years, 1939 through 1941.

NEWARK, N.J., March 14 (AP) -- Franklin d'Olier, president of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, reported today that admitted assets of the company increased by nearly $447,000,000 during 1943.

NEW DELHI, India, March 14 (U.P.) -- British Imperial troops have forced the upper reaches of the Chindwin River in northern Burma in a surprise thrust that threatens to outflank Japanese forces retreating from the Hukawng Valley before Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's combined American-Chinese offensive, it was disclosed today.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14 (AP) -- Railroad securities offered in 1943 more than tripled 1942 offerings, while industrial and public utility offerings declined, the Securities and Exchange Commission's statistical bulletin for February disclosed today.

LONDON, March 14 (AP) -- The Nazi-controlled Rome radio said tonight that Virginio Gayda, Fascist editor who became famous as principal journalistic spokesman for the Mussolini regime, was killed today in an Allied bombing of Rome.

Adequate provision for the disposal after the war of surplus materials, especially non-ferrous metals, in a manner favorable to industry and employment was recommended yesterday by Government and business officials at the annual convention of the National Association of Waste Material Dealers, Inc., held in the Hotel Astor.

CARDIFF, Wales, March 14 -- The crisis in the coal strike has passed and the "patient" is at last making steady progress toward full recovery. During the day more miners returned to the pits to bring the coalfields up to 72 per cent normal.
