The Free Synagogue, of which Dr. Stephen S. Wise is the founder, honored him last night at a dinner in the Hotel Biltmore. The affair marked the Jewish leader's forthcoming seventieth anniversary and his completion of more than fifty years of activity in American life.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Navy plans to commission nearly twelve ships a day, exclusive of small amphibious craft, during 1944, and will call on Selective Service to furnish about 550,000 men to reach a goal of nearly 3,700,000 for the Navy, Marines and Coast Guard by the end of the year, Secretary Knox revealed today.

Far-reaching plans to build Mexico City into a cultural center for Latin-American countries, matching the position New York City holds in the United States, were disclosed yesterday by Francisco Serrano Mendez, Coordinator of Artistic Affairs for the Mexican Government, now in this country obtaining the services of prominent artists in the fields of music, ballet and drama.

PEARL HARBOR, March 14 (AP) -- Army, Navy and Marine aircraft, which have been blasting Central Pacific Japanese bases almost daily, have bombed seven enemy-held islands in the eastern Marshall and Caroline Islands, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz reported today.

Senator George D. Aiken, Republican, of Vermont, declared last night that 1944 would prove to be the "year of decision" for the American people on the question of restoration of normal constitutional government, elimination of bureaucracy and return to the traditional independence of the people in economic life.

The Board of Estimate, declaring that it was "unalterably opposed" to the highway bill affecting New York City sponsored by Governor Dewey, voted unanimously yesterday to resubmit to the Legislature a bill offered by Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, and urged action at the present session.

Peter J. McGuinness of Greenpoint was appointed yesterday by John Cashmore, Borough President of Brooklyn, as the assistant commissioner of borough works. A few hours later he was sworn in by Supreme Court Justice John MacCrate.

LONDON, Wednesday, March 15 -- German air raiders took advantage of conditions the past night to give the London area an incendiary attack, the first enemy blow here since last Wednesday. The short, sharp attack set off a blistering anti-aircraft barrage that kept most of the Nazi planes high.

Peacetime developments which have unexpectedly proven useful in the war effort is the theme employed by General Motors in its new series of institutional advertisements to be released this week. The first advertisement in the series tells the story of "Freon," a non-toxic refrigerator compound developed twelve years ago which is now proving exceptionally useful to the armed forces as a protection against malaria-carrying mosquitoes.

Peacetime developments which have unexpectedly proven useful in the war effort is the theme employed by General Motors in its new series of institutional advertisements to be released this week. The first advertisement in the series tells the story of "Freon," a non-toxic refrigerator compound developed twelve years ago which is now proving exceptionally useful to the armed forces as a protection against malaria-carrying mosquitoes.
The winter campaign in Russia is ending in a sea of mud and considerable Russian victories.

Patrolman Theodore Abele, 38 years old, of 272 Cornelia Street, Brooklyn, was attacked and beaten by ten youths when he attempted to stop a disturbance early yesterday in the balcony of the Bushwick Theatre, at Broadway and Howard Avenues.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 14 -- The air was invigorating, there was warmth in the sun and so Manager Melvin Ott put his large assortment of Giants and Little Giants through their second successive training session today with excellent results.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -Representative John W. McCormack of Massachusetts, Democratic leader of the House, criticized today as a political move the creation of a twenty-five-man committee of the Republican party to formulate a tax policy for Congress.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 14 -- Members of the once numerous Swiss colony in Berlin, driven back to Switzerland by the destructive Allied air attacks there, are quoted in today's Basier National Zeitung as calling the former Nazi capital a city of desolation.

A total of 2,319 tons of paper was received from three unexpected sources, it was announced yesterday by the Newspaper Publishers Waste Paper Salvage Committee on the eve of the third regular Wednesday collection of all types of scrap paper throughout the city by Sanitation Department trucks.

The 1943 annual report of the United Light and Power Company and subsidiaries, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income, after operating expenses, taxes and other charges, of $4,753,793, compared with $6,655,250 in 1942.

Pupil proved too much for master in last night's Red Cross 1944 War Fund tennis show at Madison Square Garden as Cadet John A. Kramer of the United States Coast Guard Academy at New London, Conn., scored one of the greatest net upsets of all time by beating

Four advertising firms have renewed their leases in the Fred F. French Building at 551 Fifth Avenue through the Fred F. French Management Company. They are T.B. Browne, Ltd.; the Otto Kleppner Company, Roberts Reimers and the B.D. Iola Company.

LONDON, March 14 (AP) -- Forty-four American Thunderbolt pilots who disregarded their dwindling fuel supply and returned to help Liberators fight off an enemy attack after a recent bombing of Ludwigshafen were commended today for their gallantry and skill by five generals and the colonel whose Liberators were involved.
LONDON, Wednesday, March 15 (AP) -- The Russian Tuesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:
" When my country takes her place among the nations of the earth, then, and not till then, let my epitaph be written.

Three new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Victoria, the new attraction is "Voice in the Wind," a topical drama featuring Francis Lederer, Sigrid Gurie, J. Carrol Naish, J. Edward Bromberg and Alexander Granach.
NAPLES, March 14 -- The Prenestiana railway yards in eastern Rome were bombed today by Marauders, while Mitchells resumed their sharp blows at the other railway yards north of the city.

The regional War Labor Board announced last night that it had ordered a standard maintenance of membership provision, with a fifteen-day "escape clause," included in the contract between Time, Inc., and the Newspaper Guild of New York.

A drive to re-establish offshore fishing privileges for power party boat owners has been started by the Ocean County Board of Chosen Freeholders of Toms River, N.J. The United States Navy has eliminated the submarine menace to shipping, says A. Paul King of Beach Haven, director, and boatmen should be allowed to resume the work on which they depend for a livelihood and help provide fish for food.

LONDON, March 14 -- Prime Minister Churchill told the House of Commons today that the restriction of travel between Britain and all of Ireland was merely part of the first step designed to isolate southern Ireland from the outside world during the critical period of the war that is approaching.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Wednesday, March 15 -- A recommendation that Finland reject Russia's "last chance" proposal for an armistice was laid before a secret session of the Finnish Parliament by Premier Edwin Linkomies yesterday, it was reliably reported today.

For years the value of non-member correspondents to New York Stock Exchange firms has been debated. Recently those who doubted that value have been quoting the experience of a New York firm which executed orders for a large Midwestern corporation.
With a crowd of 16,039 fans looking on, the Golden Gloves tournament of champions, the highlight of the amateur boxing season, was presented at Madison Square Garden last night.

Income tax returns filed with Internal Revenue Collectors in New York City were running 25 to 35 per cent ahead of last year's record-breaking totals as the midnight deadline for filing without penalty was reached last night. From 15 to 30 per cent of the returns filed here called for refunds because of excess withholdings from wages and salaries under the pay-as-you-go system started last year.

The work of the Red Cross at home and abroad presents "a most challenging claim to our generous interest and support," Bishop Thomas E. Molloy of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn declared yesterday in making a $1,000 contribution to the Red Cross 1944 War Fund.

Net sales of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation for 1943 amounted to $280,676,172, a new record, comparing with $237,982,038 in 1942. Sales of rolled steel products totaled 3,559,673 net tons, against 3,210,992 tons, and total payroll was $105,471,580, against $84,521,482, with average employment slightly lower.

ALBANY, March 15 -- A charge that Governor Dewey had reduced the members of the Legislature to the role of "manikins," who could not pass a bill "without the approval of someone on the second floor," was made in the Senate today by John J. Dunnigan, Democratic leader, as the Legislature continued to drive to adjournment, now virtually certain to come Saturday.

The grand jury refused to indict 15-year-old Frank Drury in the death of Henry Pederson, 11, who was shot in the Drury home at 129 West Eighty-fifth Street with a mail-order .22-caliber rifle, on Feb. 11.

MOSCOW, Thursday, March 16 -- Troops of Marshal Ivan S. Koneff's Second Ukrainian Front have forced the Bug River on a sixty-two-mile front and, after overcoming enemy resistance on the right bank, have advanced twelve to nineteen miles, capturing more than 100 populated points, including the district centers of Bershad, Trostyanets, Obodovka and Olgopol, it was announced officially last night.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio today became one of three virtually equal co-leaders of the Senate Republican minority, which met to devise a temporary organization to serve until after the elections.

NAPLES, March 15 (Reuter) -- In a signed statement published today Marshal Badoglio defended his conduct during the armistice negotiations. The statement, published in the first number of the Corriere, declared:

MUNCIE, Ind., March 15 (AP) -- Outfielder Vince DiMaggio came under the category of a holdout today when he failed to put in an appearance as the Pirates opened camp. Seven other Buccos were absent from the initial workout, held under sunny skies with the mercury close to 70.

The Association of National Advertisers has released its quarterly readership survey of magazine advertising showing the trend of war-theme advertising. The study, which covers four three-month periods from October, 1942, through September, 1943, indicates that straight product advertising showed an important increase in volume in the third and fourth quarters.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- A revised plan for recognition of the French Committee of National Liberation as the authority with which the Allies' armies will deal when they enter France has been forwarded to London by the State Department and is still under consideration by the British Government.

Lieut. Gen. Ira C. Eaker, commander of the Mediterranean Allied Air Forces, broadcast an eye-witness description of the destruction of Cassino yesterday. Speaking on the Blue Network, according to The United Press, he promised that every stronghold in the "German world" where the enemy elected to make a stand would receive the same treatment.

Black market operators have created an "appalling and disgraceful" situation in the waste paper industry, Louis A. Speiss, attorney for the Waste Paper Trade Committee and the Cotton Rag Council, said yesterday at the war conference of the National Association of Waste Material Dealers at the Hotel Astor.

Answering the opinion credited to Vilhjalmur Stefansson that he didn't believe the East River froze over during the great blizzard, I beg to report that my father walked from Brooklyn to his office in Gold Street across the ice-covered East River on Wednesday morning, March 14, 1888, paying 25 cents to climb a ladder over a one-yard water gap at the New York dock line.

Our income taxes are now made out and in the mail. But few of us will quickly forget the bewilderment we went through in figuring them out. It is consoling that there has been some gain. Few politicians any longer defend the present intricacies of the income tax or claim that they are unavoidable.

Vast new markets for American industry and prosperity for American families in the post-war period were predicted yesterday by George W. Bacon, chairman of the board and one of the founders of the engineering concern of Ford, Bacon Davis, at a luncheon attended by 300 guests to observe the fiftieth anniversary of the organization.

ALBANY, March 15 -- A resolution urging immediate development of the St. Lawrence River power resources to keep and attract industry to New York State was passed unanimously and without debate today in the Senate.
LONDON, Thursday, March 16 (AP) -- The Russian Wednesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:
LONDON, March 15 -- Indecision was the rule in most sections of the stock markets here today, with little business being transacted.

Following a meeting of the New York representatives of dry goods wholesalers, Henry Matter of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute left for Washington last night to put before the Office of Civilian Requirements a proposal to limit directives for textile fabrics to essential service needs and lend-lease and allow the industry in the primary markets to distribute civilian goods without directives.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, March 16 (U.P.) -- American heavy bombers, attacking Japanese-held Wewak, New Guinea, for the fourth consecutive day on Tuesday, dropped 174 tons of explosives on the base and shot down eight enemy planes to run their four-day total to seventy-three, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Representative Clifton A. Woodrum of Virginia, a lifelong advocate of a strong army and navy in peacetime, has been selected by the House leaders to head the proposed House Committee on Post-war Military Policy.

Edouard Herriot, former Premier of France, former President of the Chamber of Deputies and mayor of the city of Lyon for more than twenty years, has died in captivity, according to repatriates from the French camp at Vittel who landed from the liner Gripsholm here yesterday.

Arthur E. Lehrfeld, the lawyer who was arrested in his office at 1457 Broadway Tuesday on an indictment accusing him of inducing Sam Croce, 26 years old, an ex-convict, to perpetrate five burglaries in the midtown' district and buying some of the loot, entered a not-guilty plea yesterday before Judge John A. Mullen in General Sessions.

The same skinful of meat that brings a maximum legal price of 50 cents a pound as soft salami may be sold as hard salami at 70 cents a pound if it is kept until 20 per cent by weight has evaporated, but neither the Office of Price Administration nor the Department of Markets allows for any middle ground between the two, so far as prices go, it was made clear yesterday.

Supreme Court Justice Denis O'Leary Cohalan ordered yesterday that the trial of Joseph Fay and James Bove, labor leaders, on charges of extortion and conspiracy to commit extortion be transferred from General Sessions to Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Enactment of the Price Control Law in a form "substantially" the same as at present, with companion legislation authorizing subsidy payments to keep food prices down, was urged on Congress today by Chester Bowles, head of the Office of Price Administration.

Speakers at a lunch given by the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office in this city on Tuesday let it be known that Americans are growing careless about military information. The CDVO is starting a campaign to correct this situation. The trouble is, perhaps, that some of us don't understand how spies work.

A group of thirty-six educators, jurists, publicists and religious leaders issued yesterday a statement calling upon the American and British Governments to raise with the Soviet Government the question of its unilateral efforts to settle the controversy over Poland's future frontiers and government and other problems affecting successful collaboration of the United Nations in the task of establishing a stable democratic world order.

Taking issue with those who have criticized the relationship of the Railway Express Agency and the nation's commercial airlines, L.O. Head, president of the express agency, said yesterday that contracts between his organization and the air transport lines had proved themselves through sixteen years of successful operation.

CHICAGO, March 15 (AP) -- Youths still eligible for American Legion baseball competition were ruled off major and minor league clubs today by Commissioner Kenesaw Mountain Landis, who warned that any contracts with such boys would be declared null and void and that fines of $500 would be imposed for any dealings with them.

PHILADELPHIA, March 15 (AP) -- The Cities Service Power and Light Company will be recapitalized on a single stock basis under a plan approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission as a further step in the company's compliance with "death sentence" provisions of the Holding Company Act.

Net earnings of United Air Lines, Inc., amounted to $4,203,276 in 1943, equal to $2.80 a share on the capital stock, comparing with $3,134,356, of $2.08 a share, in 1942, W.A. Patterson, president, announced yesterday. After a postwar reserve the profit was $3,203,276, or $2.13 a share, against $2,134,356, or $1.42 a share, in 1942.

A lot of fishermen will want to try their luck in the lakes and reservoirs of New York City's water-supply system when the season begins, particularly since Mayor La Guardia opened additional waters to boat fishing in Westchester and Putnam Counties last month.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 15 -- An incident that threatened to revive the "cannon war" of sixty-nine years ago was closed here today with an official apology by Princeton University for the daubing with orange and black paint of historic sites and buildings on the Rutgers University campus last Saturday.

NAPLES, March 15 (AP) -- Premier Pietro Badoglio proposed today that all discussion and provision for Italy's future government be postponed until the end of the war, when "the Italian people can freely manifest their own desire."
PINEHURST, N.C., March 15 -- Sgt. Clayton Heafner of Camp Croft, S.C., shot a par 72 today for a two-round total of 143 to take the halfway lead in the North and South Open.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- First Lieut. Helen E. Wharton, Army Nurse Corps, has been appointed Chief Nurse for the Fifth Army.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Eggers Higgins, New York architects of the Jefferson Memorial who carried through to completion the design of the late John Russell Pope, received the award tonight of the Biennial Certificate of Merit conferred by the Washington Board of Trade for excellence of architectural achievement during the period 1942-43.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The American Federation of Labor was rebuffed by the National War Labor Board today in seeking to win approval for a petition to request President Roosevelt "to modify realistically" the "Little Steel" formula, the basis of wage stabilization.

The Department of Markets, which brings dozens of food retailers up on the carpet at its weekly hearings where denunciations and court summonses are handed out for price ceiling violations, made it plain yesterday that the customer isn't always right.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 15 -- It looked from here today as if the Finnish Parliament had rejected the Russian armistice terms. But the question of whether or not Finland was accepting or rejecting the final Moscow bid was still open tonight after the Finnish Riksdag, in camera this afternoon, unanimously voted confidence in the Government on its course of action regarding a Russo-Finn truce.

MANHASSET, L.I., March 15 -- The Town Board of North Hempstead has received a complaint signed by the residents of the New Hyde Park section about the existence of some sixty frame structures built to house the barrage balloons used by the Sperry Gyroscope Corporation at its Lake Success plant and subsequently sold by the Government.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, at Cassino, March 15 -- The remnants of the stone-built town of Cassino, which the Fifth Army has been stubbornly striving to capture for more than six weeks, were literally torn to pieces today in the heaviest aerial bombardment in history, supported by an artillery barrage estimated to have been 40 per cent heavier than the one that preceded the battle of El Alamein, Egypt.

LONDON, March 15 (AP) -- Nazi raiders were turned back from London tonight by a heavy barrage of the capital's ground guns, less than twenty-four hours after one of the worst German air attacks on London since 1941.

Though Finland is reported to have rejected the Russian terms of peace, our Government, through Secretary Hull, continues to urge the Finns to get out of the war. To offer this advice is implicitly to assume some responsibility for the ultimate fate of the Finns if they follow it.

ALGIERS, March 15 -- Arriving here today on his way to Cairo to discuss relief with the exiled governments of Greece, Yugoslavia and Albania and with the Middle Eastern Relief Commission, Herbert H. Lehman, director of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, said the operations of his organization in any given country would be under the authority of the military command and with supplies provided by the military organization.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission, 299 Broadway, announced yesterday that the Bureau of Excise Taxes of the City Controller's office needed 100 experienced accountants as twenty-five permanent and seventy-five temporary vacancies existed.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand., March 15 -- A policy of perpetual cooperation with the United States was enunciated by Prime Minister Peter Fraser in an interview published in the Government newspaper The Standard today.
ALGIERS, March 15 -- General Charles de Gaulle will address the Provisional Consultative Assembly on Saturday to review the policies of the Committee of National Liberation.

In seventy-five of its 650 elementary and junior high schools the Board of Education now operates after-school centers. Two hundred and twenty-five teachers -- some of them instructors in recreation or shopwork, others regular classroom teachers -- take over the supervision of activities from 3 to 5 or 6 P.M.

The Writers Board yesterday condemned the action of Chester I. Barnard, president of the United Service Organizations, for refusing to permit distribution of the pamphlet "Races of Mankind" by the Young Men's Christian Association's USO centers.

Yesterday the Swedish liner Gripsholm arrived at Jersey City from Lisbon with some 660 passengers. She is called an exchange ship. She should be named a mercy ship. She brought back her travelers from the habitations of cruelty and the power of darkness to home and freedom.

A new distributing company has been formed to handle distribution of Bacardi rum, effective April 1, it was learned yesterday. Schenley Distillers Corporation, which has heretofore distributed the product, has already notified certain sections of the liquor trade that it will not act in this capacity after that date.
LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 15 -- Events moved at an accelerated tempo in the training camp of the Giants today.

Reminding winter-weary New Yorkers that spring, with its gay colors and fragrant blooms, is just around the corner, the Horticultural Society of New York opened yesterday a two-day flower show at its headquarters, 598 Madison Avenue.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 15 (AP) -- Corydon, whom C.B. Deberry acquired from the Greentree Stable at private terms during the recent Hialeah Park session, snapped out of a losing streak to win the Southland Purse at Tropical Park today.

CONCORD, N.H., March 15 (U.P.) -- Complete returns from New Hampshire's Presidential primary yesterday, the first such contest in the country in 1944, gave Wendell L. Willkie six of the State's eleven delegates to the national convention.

FORT WORTH, Tex., March 15 (AP) -- Robert K. Hanger, attorney for Mrs. Ruth Googins Roosevelt, said today that a suit for divorce would be filed in the district court tomorrow against her husband, Col. Elliott Roosevelt, now serving in the European war theater.

NAPLES, March 15 -- A faint echo of the appearance on the beachhead below Rome of radio-controlled tanks sounded here today with the publication of a German order of the day for Feb. 7, issued by the commanding officer of the Lehr Infantry Demonstration Regiment, which sent the manless tractor scuttling into action a few weeks ago.
LONDON, March 15 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

A group of folksongs, sung in their original Slavonian, Serbian, Macedonian, Montenegrin and Bosnian languages, featured last night's recital at the New York Times Hall by Carmen Reuben, soprano. Louis Goranin, Yugoslav folklore expert, collected the songs, and accompanied Miss Reuben on the accordion.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 15 (AP) -- Beau Jack, the Augusta bootblack who fought his way to a brief tenure as the world lightweight champion (New York version), was reclassified to 1-A by his draft board today.

The Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company has progressed from the difficult phases of conversion and adaptation to mass production in its wartime undertakings, John D. Biggers, the president, said yesterday in the 1943 annual report to stockholders.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 15 -- Howard (Stretch) Schultz, Dodger first-base sensation last year, checked in today and not only brought along his signed contract but a bit of information that may mean Brooklyn will have no second base problem this season despite the loss of Billy Herman.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- A plan to simplify the income tax laws was approved tentatively by the Ways and Means Committee today, holding out a promise to some 30,000,000 of the 50,000,000 individual taxpayers that the return which must be in by this midnight would be the last they ever have to file.

In his experience of more than a third of a century in the nation's transportation field Joseph B. Eastman did a splendid job. During that period he gained the confidence of all interested in transportation and his influence radiated into every phase of transportation in this continent.

A total of $8,425,878,000 of war production loans and commitments to make such loans by 436 of the largest banks in the nation were outstanding on Dec. 31, the American Bankers Association announced yesterday, following completion of its semi-annual war-lending survey. The volume of such loans showed an increase of $1,511,260,000 during the final half of 1943.

" Bright Boy" gave its sixteenth and final performance last night at the Playhouse, where it had its premiere on March 2. Written by Lieut. John Boruff, USNR, the prep-school comedy was presented by Arthur J. Beckhard, who also directed, and David Merrick.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The United States Cadet Nurse Corps has completed its shake-down cruise and is now ready to go "full speed ahead," according to Represnetative Frances P. Bolton, Republican, of Ohio, sponsor of the bill which created the corps in June.

Members of the Northeastern Dairy Conference, at yesterday's closing session of their annual meeting in the Hotel Commodore, pledged their support of a program of food production adequate for winning the war, furnishing food "for much of the world" and preventing famine in many destitute countries.
Two years ago, when Germany was on top, conditions in the Allied prisoners' camps were very bad; now that the tide has turned the Germans are making an effort to improve the prisoners' lot.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 15 -- Virginia Mayo, who made her film debut in "Jack London" and later had a small part in "Up in Arms," will play the lead with Bob Hope in Samuel Goldwyn's "Sylvester the Great," formerly "Treasure Chest." She is under contract to Goldwyn.

The regional War Labor Board denied yesterday a request for a five-day week and increased commission rates for 500 route men employed by twenty-two northern New Jersey laundries, made by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

PEARL HARBOR, March 15 -- Our air forces presumably based in the Marshalls advanced their offensive perimeter to the Truk area for the first time in attacks Monday upon seven enemy bases, according to an announcement this afternoon by Pacific Fleet headquarters.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that cotton consumed during February was 811,274 bales of lint and 106,846 bales of linters, compared with 879,572 bales of lint and 98,259 of linters in February last year.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Formation of an Automobile Industry Advisory Committee to explore "the basic problems that must be dealt with by industry and Government as a preliminary to the eventual resumption of passenger car production" was announced by the War Production Board today.

The burden of wartime responsibility has been assumed by the capitalist class, Dr. Carlos Arenas y Loayza, Peruvian Ambassador to Colombia, declared yesterday at a press conference in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Among other things it is pleasant to note that the president of the Rockefeller Foundation said "seldom." Raymond B. Fosdick was speaking of the grant of $1,280 to Dr. H.W. Forley of Oxford for a research which led to penicillin.

In a letter from the Citizens Budget Commission in THE TIMES of Feb. 18 opposing teacher appointments, D.E. Nolan makes several misstatements and assumptions without proof. The New York Teachers Guild, Local No. 2, American Federation of Teachers, wishes to point out some of the more obvious errors.

The Collector of Customs has eliminated the requirement calling for filing of a separate card at the Custom House outlining major details of all shipments in cases where complete shipments are made, exporters stated yesterday. Heretofore, it was explained, officials required this paperwork whether a complete shipment was being made or not.
CANBERRA, Australia, Wednesday, March 15 (AP) -- Australia's Army Minister, Francis E. Forde, said in an interview today:
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Investigation into charges or brutality against Federal prisoners in the Springfield (Mo.) Medical Center has been ended, Attorney General Biddle said today.

CHICAGO, March 15 -- Reports that more distillers had been asked to use rye in their mixtures for industrial alcohol led to fairly aggressive commission house buying at times today on the Board of Trade, and although there was a small dip early on professional selling, prices moved up steadily thereafter with the close about the top at gains of 5/8 to 7/8 cent.

The Retail Dry Goods Association, whose members incluude all the large department stores, announced yesterday a decision to discontinue wrapping many articles sold over the counter as an important contribution to the wastepaper salvage campaign.

Her bright blue and yellow superstructure gleaming in the faint sunshine that broke through the overcast sky, the 18,134-ton Swedish-American liner Gripsholm completed her fourth wartime voyage as a diplomatic exchange ship by docking at the American Export Line terminal at Pier F, Jersey City, at 3:45 P.M. yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 15 -- News of Bill Dickey's induction into the Navy reached the Yankees today after they had enjoyed their initial outdoor workout. The report from Little Rock, where Bill passed his examination, disclosing that he had made Uncle Sam's team, came as a jolt, what with a gas station attendant with no big league aspirations the only backstop in camp at the moment.

The sixteen-story apartment house at 9-11 East Ninety-sixth Street has been resold by Frederick Brown, after a month's ownership, to an investing client of Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc. The property is 72.6 by 100 feet, near Fifth Avenue, and is assessed at $540,000.

The undersigned's experience is that to assemble the data, to comprehend the intricate instructions and to prepare 1943 Federal and State income tax returns for his family cost at least 140 hours of his time. This is about three and a half weeks' work on a non-over-time basis of forty hours per week.
CHICAGO, March 15 -- The National Association of Popular Shoe Retailers, Inc., was formed here today by retailers who annually sell the American people almost half of their needed shoes.

A mother who did not know what had happened to her son since the fall of the Philippines, where he served in an engineering battalion, saw him in the movies yesterday. The discovery was made jointly with the soldier's fiancee.

ALBANY, March 15 -- The Appellate Division, Third Department, today modified a determination of Dr. Ernest E. Cole, former Commissioner of Education, in the case of Charles L. Baker, a former custodian-engineer of a public school in New York City.

In appreciation of the 3,500 hours of free instruction provided for 150,000 uniformed men and women, the Teachers Voluntary Service Organization received a citation yesterday from the Civilian Defense Volunteer Organization at a brief ceremony in the Hall of the Board of Education, 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.

Under the leadership of the steels and an assorted list of specialties, the stock market snapped back yesterday to a firm position and closed irregularly higher on the day. Trading was concentrated again in the low-price issues, and volume on the Stock Exchange held above the million-share mark for the ninth time this year.
The yelping of dogs broke out yesterday the second the Gripsholm docked. The canine chaos was caused by sixteen dogs rescued from Europe along with their owners.

A nation-wide campaign to teach tolerance in the schools and colleges of this country in an effort to stamp out prejudices and antagonisms is being undertaken by the National Education Association's commission for the defense of democracy through education, representing 200,000 American school teachers, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON, March 15 -- Still further and even more stringent measures designed to isolate southern Ireland and prevent her from being a channel through which vital military information might reach the enemy are under serious consideration by military and administrative departments of Britain and Northern Ireland, it was said today.

Miss Elsa Castendyck, director of special services and research in the social service division of the United States Children's Bureau, yesterday urged welfare agencies to work together under joint planning to meet the special needs of children in wartime.

NEW DELHI, India, March 15 (AP) -- Chinese troops in command of Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell maintained a steady advance southward today in Northern Burma's Hukawng Valley, besting the Japanese in a series of mortar and artillery duels.

Dried fruits, which come off the ration list the first of March, make good substitutes for the fresh varieties that are not too plentiful at this season. While some are expensive and hard to find, at least three that are readily available are raisins, figs and prunes.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Reorganization of the Office of War Information's foreign news bureau to aid "American news gathering media in exposing enemy propaganda efforts and in securing maximum information on the war" was announced today by Elmer Davis, director.

The Office of Price Administration is on the trail of "known and ruthless criminals" who have taken control of the black market in gasoline ration coupons in this part of the country, Irvin C. Rutter, chief regional enforcement attorney, disclosed yesterday.

Advances toward economic independence made recently by Latin-American women were described yesterday by Miss Mary M. Cannon, chief of the Inter-American Division of the Women's Bureau in the United States Department of Labor, at a meeting of the United Women of the Americas at the Hotel Biltmore.

LONDON, March 15 -- An authoritative report in London Yugoslav quarters today said the Government of Marshal Tito (Josip Broz) had asked banks in Allied and neutral countries to freeze all funds credited to the National Bank of Yugoslavia.

" Chip Off the Old Block," a comedy produced by Universal, will have its local premiere this morning at the Capitol Heading the film's cast are Donald O'Connor, Peggy Ryan, J. Edward Bromberg, Ann Blyth, Helen Vinson, Helen Broderick, Arthur Treacher, Patric Knowles and Quiz Kid Joel Kupperman.

LONDON, Thursday, March 16 -- The United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe reopened the campaign against the Luftwaffe yesterday when Flying Fortresses and Liberators in medium strength hammered Brunswick, an important center of enemy aircraft production, through a heavy overcast.

A wave of illicit gambling in private homes has swept Brooklyn like a "prairie fire," placing an undetermined number of women under the control of "loan sharks and procurers," Magistrate Charles Solomon warned yesterday in East New York Court.

Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran, speaking last night at the dinner of the Traffic Club of New York at the Hotel Commodore, urged that the United States maintain its present lead in merchant tonnage after the war. He praised all the transportation agencies serving the port of New York for their cooperative efforts in serving the war effort.

Private charity is part of the democratic way of life that we are fighting for and should receive continued support from those whose larger incomes oblige them to pay heavier taxes, former Gov. Alfred E. Smith said yesterday at the first general meeting of the special gifts committee of New York Catholic Charities in the Empire State Club.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Foreign Economic Administration notified American exporters today in Current Export Bulletin No. 152 that it is loosening some of the controls over the shipment of several groups of manufactured products to Latin-American republics "in attempts to bring exporter and importer in closer contact with each other."

MOSCOW, March 15 -- The Soviet Government has decreed an increase of 7,550,000 hectares in the agricultural land to be put under cultivation in 1944, of which 5,440,000 hectares are to be devoted to additional wheat production for a people whose diet is heavy with bread.

ALBANY, March 15 -- Two measures designed to give corporations protection against ill-founded suits by stockholders were adopted today in the Senate over objections that the net effect of the legislation would be to deprive individual shareholders of the right to go into the courts to protect their investments.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- President Roosevelt wired Governors of all States asking what they have done, or can do, to authorize use of Federal ballots for soldiers, after House approval completes Congressional action on the compromise soldier vote measure.

Pity the poor Communist editors in the United States. Those of the New Masses, for example. For their current issue they write a scathing attack on Mr. Churchill's support of the Badoglio Government, and by the time the editorial is published it has become an attack on the policy of Marshal Stalin.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Thomas Rhea, a Democratic leader from Kentucky, came from a conference with President Roosevelt today confident that the President would accept the nomination to run again, and would be re-elected.
The Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York has announced a loan of $450,000 to Stephens Brothers Petroleum Company for seven and a half years. It is secured by oil and gas properties in Oklahoma.

The third anniversary of the Lend-Lease Act last Saturday found that once controversial measure pretty generally and thankfully accepted in this country. In money and goods this country has given considerably more than it has received. The figure at the end of the year was close to $20,000,000,000 and presumably it is now close to $23,000,000,000 -- possibly more, for the wheels of war have been turning faster and faster.

H. Eliot Kaplan, executive secretary of the National Civil Service Reform League, made public yesterday a letter to Robert Ramspeck, chairman of the House Committee on Civil Service, urging elimination from the Independent Offices Appropriation Bill of the McKellar rider.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The House by a vote of 273 to 111 sent the "States rights" soldier vote bill to President Roosevelt today and he immediately telegraphed the Governors of all the States to advise him by wire whether the Federal (short) ballot will be declared an acceptable supplement to the State ballots to which Congress gave sweeping priority.

LONDON, March 15 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav Partisans, in probably the biggest battle since the start of organized resistance by Marshal Tito [Josip Broz] have smashed a costly German attempt to break into liberated Slovenian territory as heavy fighting raged throughout the country with the lifting of winter weather, it was announced today.

At the annual meeting of the Maryland Drydock Company here yesterday, George H. French president, reported to stockholders that last year's net sales of $42,402,028 were about one-third larger than the sales in 1942.
Houses formed the bulk of properties on the West Side reported in new ownership yesterday.
NEW DELHI, India, March 15 (AP) -- A communique:

CHUNGKING, China, March 15 (AP) -- Japan's island stronghold of Hainan was attacked by Mitchell bombers of the Fourteenth Air Force Monday, Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters announced today.

Suitable housing accommodations for juvenile delinquents in custody is a major problem of the city today, but opening of the former Lavanburg Corner House in East Twelfth Street as the Youth Center under city supervision in six weeks will supply an answer, Dr. Peter Amoroso, Commissioner of Correction, declared yesterday.
ALBANY, March 15 -- A series of moves of political interest were taken in the Legislature today.

The seasonal rise in the nation's gasoline stocks continued last week. At the close of the period, the American Petroleum Institute placed the supplies on hand at 86,559,000 barrels, an increase of 468,000 over the 86,091,000 reported a week earlier. A year ago they amounted to 94,280,000 barrels.

A lawyer, asking leniency for his 21-year-old son who had just pleaded guilty to draft evasion, drew judicial fire on his own head yesterday. The defendant, Alfred S. Blechman of 67 West Tremont Avenue, the Bronx, had made a claim of conscientious objection to war, which had been rejected as insubstantial.

Legislation and study to provide a master plan for post-war urban development, with special emphasis on housing, were urged in an address last night at a conference of the Institute on Post-War Reconstruction at New York University by Ira S. Robbins, acting State Commissioner of Housing.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- A Helsinki report that Finland has rejected the Russian peace terms was received here with disappointment today.

Scattered price-fixing and a moderate amount of local covering appeared in late trading yesterday and produced a somewhat better tone in cotton futures. At the close of trading, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were mixed, 2 points below to 3 points above Tuesday's final quotations, with the strength centered in the near positions.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Advocating Congressional team-work to expedite adoption of a broad program for unwinding the war economy as speedily as possible on the cessation of hostilities, John M. Hancock, co-author of the Baruch report, appealed to the House Special Committee on Post-war Economic Policy today to start from where we are in framing such legislation.
The property known as the Albertson Homestead comprising 110 acres of land in Hope Township, N.J., has been purchased by John C. Hamann through Charles C. Ort, broker.

The seventh concert of the season's Town Hall Endowment Series was heard last night, with Sir Thomas Beecham conducting a chamber orchestra in an interesting and unusual program. Betty Humby-Beecham, pianist, was soloist.

Reading in your paper today of the meeting of the 1888 "Blizzard Celebration" I cannot refrain from wondering at the accounts of what happened, which appear in the newspapers every year and are so different from my own.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 15 -- The Argentine Government yesterday arrested Gen. Benjamin Menendez, a leader of army officers who believe that the military government has failed to achieve the purposes of the June 4 revolution and should resign to make room for a government composed of civilians with only a few officers.

The annual report of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company for 1943, released yesterday by James B. Black, president, shows a net income of $22,345,744 after operating expenses, taxes and other charges. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.23 a share on the outstanding common stock. It compared with a net of $22,265,972, or $2.21 a share, in 1942.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- In the debate on the legislation to poll the armed services in the 1944 elections (the "soldier-vote bill") a good case has been made that the compromise measure meets the President's test, on the basis of which he will either sign or veto the bill.

DETROIT, March 15 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company appealed today to Gov. Harry F. Kelly for police protection after a blockade of gates at its Rouge plant in Dearborn caused a curtailment estimated at about 75 per cent of a day's production.

Standout basketball players of the season will be on view at Madison Square Garden tonight as St. John's engages Bowling Green, and Muhlenberg plays DePaul in the opening round of the seventh annual national invitation tournament.
LONDON, March 15 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

ALBANY, March 15 -- Mental institutions of the State are among the best in the country, but they have failed to keep pace with progress in the field in the last few years, the Moreland Commission, named a year ago by Governor Dewey to investigate the Department of Mental Hygiene, said today in its final report.

Harry Sacher, counsel for the Transport Workers Union, Congress of Industrial Organizations affiliate, suggested yesterday that the Fifth Avenue Coach Company reduce its fare from 10 to 5 cents "in order to increase patronage." The suggestion was made at a hearing before a three-man panel of the regional War Labor Board, 220 East Forty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- One of the sensational, though not generally known, results of the successful Allied anti-submarine campaign in the North Atlantic is that U-boats, although present in considerable numbers, almost never dare to venture an attack on our fast, well-protected convoys.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- America is so afraid of the well-dressed room that photographers have to disarrange the most artistic rooms before photographing them for merchandising purposes, Miss Gladys Miller, consultant on decoration for the Public Buildings Administration, told the Fashion Group today.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Major Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Selective Service Director, wrote to local draft officials today that 240,000 of 1,000,000 men needed by July 1 would probably have to be obtained from men now deferred on occupational grounds, including farm labor, and 250,000 more from pre-Pearl Harbor fathers.

LONDON, March 15 -- With 170-odd service clubs already operating in the British Isles and more than fifty others in preparation, the American Red Cross in all probability runs the largest chain of hotels in the world -- all for the purpose of furnishing a home away from home for American service men and women overseas.

WITH CHINESE-AMERICAN FORCES in Burma, March 11 (Delayed) -- The significance of this week's smashing victory over the Japanese in the Hukawng valley goes far beyond the gain represented by the killing of several thousand Japanese and the cutting up of a division of Japanese veterans.

A banking group headed by Lehman Brothers and Watling, Lerchen Co. will offer today 60,000 shares of 4 1/2 per cent convertible preferred stock, $100 par value, of the Fruehauf Trailer Company at $103 a share and accrued dividends from March 1 to date of delivery.
PHILADELPHIA, March 15 (AP) -- Required amendments to a $68,000,000 retirement program of the Illinois Power Company, Decatur, were approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
A UNITED STATES BOMBER BASE, in Britain, March 15 -- Maj. James Stewart returned to his base today after leading all Liberators on the Brunswick raid and said, smilingly, "It was all right."

The expected new over-all price regulation for retailing will be difficult to apply in the retail drug field, F.J. Griffiths, secretary of the National Association of Chain Drug Stores, said yesterday.

LONDON, March 15 -- The British Government again rejected appeals for additional relief supplies for occupied Europe despite fear expressed in the House of Lords that entire generations of Germany's neighbors were being weakened for an eventual new Teutonic conquest.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC, March 16 -- For the first time in this area organized Negro combatant troops have been in action. Led by Second Lieut. Henry J. McAllister of Hamburg, N.Y., they took the offensive against Japanese who had infiltrated American lines at Empress Augusta Bay, on Bougainville Island, drove the Japanese back, infiltrated their lines and generally caused a sensation.

The War Finance division of the Treasury Department has issued a War Bond copy guide pamphlet for advertisers and agencies calling attention to the need for continued advertising between War Bond drives. The guide recommends that advertisers use appeals urging potential bond purchasers to save for a specific purpose, help keep living costs down and build up a fund for emergencies.

Analysis and study of raw material price movements provides a better tool for guaging future business activity than stock price movements, Paul J. Weber, assistant treasurer, Hercules Powder Company, told a meeting of the New York Chapter of the Society for the Advancement of Business Management at the Midston House last night.

Formation of the Steel Shipping Container Institute, Inc., the first organization of its kind in this field, was completed yesterday at a meeting in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. Livingston B. Keplinger, vice president of the Rheem Manufacturing Company, of New York and California, was elected president.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Democratic membership in the House fell to the lowest point since President Roosevelt took office in 1933 with the death in New York today of Representative James A. O'Leary of the Eleventh New York District.

The charge that the right wing faction of the American Labor party had committed fraud in collecting signatures to up-State nominating petitions was made last night by Hyman Blumberg, campaign director for the Committee for a United Labor party.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- Representatives of corn products processors, meeting here today, proposed that the War Food Administration take steps to requisition corn moving into the hands of country elevators and shippers to help meet essential corn manufacturing needs.

DETROIT, March 16 (AP) -- The Bruins lost all hope of getting into the Stanley Cup play-offs tonight by losing to the Red Wings, 10 to 9, a total that tied the all-time Hockey League scoring record. A crowd of 7,932 looked on as the Bruins counted three times in the last two and a half minutes.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY AT CASSINO, March 16 -- The Allies' infantrymen worked their way across massive piles of rubble today to occupy approximately three-fourths of smashed Cassino, but everywhere they continued to meet amazingly fierce resistance from pockets of German defense sending sheets of rifle and machinegun fire from the piles of ruins and backed by intensive mortar and Nebelwerfer concentrations.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Department stores sales in the week ended March 11 were 11 per cent above sales in the corresponding week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Mrs. Bernard Shaw's gift to promote culture among the Irish people was acceptable at least to a great-grand-daughter of Patsy Buchanan, who was born in Dublin, Ireland.

ALBANY, March 16 -- Overriding Democratic efforts to amend Governor Dewey's soldier vote bill, the Republican-controlled Senate forced through the original bill today. The vote was unanimous because it was the only proposal before the House, but the Democrats said that they went along "very reluctantly."
Many vacant Government housing units in the New York region become homes for war prisoners brought to this country for work on farms or in other food production jobs, it became known last night.

LONDON, Friday, March 17 -- An untiring Red Army has split the German front in the Ukraine by severing the Odessa-Zhmerinka railroad at Vapnyarka, only twenty-eight miles from Bessarabia, and is battling on the approaches of Vinnitsa after isolating that big defense base in a new thrust across the Bug River, Moscow announced last night.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- Battered by bombs, torn by bullets from strafing planes, sheathed in fire from flaming gasoline, the LST 340 [landing ship, tanks] beat off an attack by nine Japanese planes and survived to return to service.

School children in the New York metropolitan area have in the last two months taken a 180,000-pound bite out of the potato surplus and have consumed carload lots of fresh cabbage, evaporated milk and eggs bought by the Government to support farm prices.

Ski conditions in the North Country yesterday varied from poor to excellent, with rising temperatures erasing surfaces at some popular areas and new snow adding to deep covers at other highly regarded centers. It is virtually impossible to predict or label conditions as good, poor or indifferent at this time of the year.

I have read and have heard complaints of able-bodied men who are unable to find work in New York. May I suggest that they try learning to clean windows? There is a scarcity in this industry and there are many contractors who would be willing to take on learners.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -More than twenty retailers of low and medium price clothing protested the so-called "high-line limitation'' in Maximum Price Regulations today in a long and heated discussion with the Office of Price Administration.

Wendell L. Willkie will leave this afternoon for a two weeks' campaign in Wisconsin, where a full slate of candidates for delegates to the Republican National Convention, pledged to support him for the Presidential nomination, has been entered in the primary election to be held on April 4.

The statistical statement of taxes collected in New York State on wine and distilled spirits sales during January indicates that more merchandise "percentage-wise" was distributed in the State last month than in December, 1943, the Greater New York Wholesale Liquor Dealers Association, Inc., reported yesterday.

THORNWOOD, N.Y., March 16 -- There is no chance for a resumption of ordinary civilian production on any broad scale until major war production programs are sharply reduced, members of the New York Lions Clubs were told here today by Joseph H. Liston, special assistant to Donald Nelson, War Production Board chairman.
Jacques Maritain's newest work in French, a group of metaphysical essays called "De Bergson a Thomas d A'quin," has just been published by the Editions de la Maison Francaise, 610 Fifth Avenue.

ALBANY, March 16 -- The DiCostanzo-Lamula bill that would permit 17-year-olds to box professionally was defeated today in the Senate by an overwhelming vote of 38 to 10 after the charge had been leveled that the legislation was "born and conceived along Jacobs Beach" with a view to "opening up a fresh reservoir of talent for Madison Square Garden."

CHICAGO, March 16 (AP) -- Charles E. Smith, vice president of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, said today at the annual convention of the American Railway Engineering Association, that the nation's railroads will meet "greatly intensified" competition from other transportation agencies after the war and must act now to meet conditions arising from a sudden drop in revenue.
LONDON, Friday, March 17 -- The air offensive against the Reich reached unprecedented heights during the twenty-four hours ended last night.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The need for young fighting men is so acute that the High Command is reconciled to losing some war production, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, told the Steel Advisory Committee of the WPB today.

Special arrangements of floral designs with the Red Cross motif and others appropriate for table decorations on St. Patrick's Day were displayed yesterday at the close of a two-day flower show sponsored by the Horticultural Society of New York, held at its headquarters, 598 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -President Roosevelt has appointed Brig. Gen. Charles D. Young, USA, retired, acting director of the Office of Defense Transportation. The White House announced the appointment today.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 16 -- Arnold (Mickey) Owen, Brookline, Mo., farmer and cattleman, will be available to catch for the Dodgers during the 1944 season, President Branch Rickey said today.

A correspondent of this newspaper, Sidney Shalett, reports after a trans-atlantic round trip that "U-boats, although present in considerable numbers, almost never venture an attack on our fast, well-protected convoys." Troops and supplies go through as they did in the First World War. This war's "bridge' is not yet buttressed in France, but it is a good bridge.

PEARL HARBOR, March 16 -- Truk, the Japanese stronghold of the Caroline Islands, was attacked by land-based bombers Wednesday for the first time, according to an announcement this morning by Pacific Fleet headquarters. It may now be inferred that Truk, which was raided by carrier planes Feb. 16-17, is vulnerable to the same kind of continued punishment by Army heavy bombers that helped soften and neutralize enemy bases in the Marshalls.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced last night the arrest of Samuel Gellard, proprietor of the "Overseas Cigarette Service," 226 West Forty-second Street, whom he described as the operator of "a vicious racket, exploiting the patriotic sentiments of city business men by soliciting and obtaining money under false pretenses."

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- Repeal of "archaic" land grant provisions of the Transportation Act, under which the Government receives a 50 per cent reduction in rail freight rates was recommended to Congress today by an investigating board.

Nobody who marches in or sees or thinks of today's procession can fail to think of the Americans of Irish descent, of the Americans of other origins, of all the armed forces of the United Nations. The layer of centuries between St. Patrick's death and the present disappears. To recall his career is to make him our contemporary or at least a symbol and prophecy of these days of trial.

ALBANY, March 16 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee reported out today the Young bill which would bar an enrolled member of one party from being nominated, at a primary election, as the candidate of another party. While designed by its sponsor to cover a local situation in Hamilton County, the bill caused some commotion here when the party leaders disrecovered its State-wide effect.

Wide changes in the character of banks' holdings of Government securities, as the result of the recent exchange offer of obligations due or called for redemption as of March 15, were shown in the figures for member banks of the Federal Reserve System in the week ended Wednesday, as disclosed yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

While it lasted it was a bold dream, grandly conceived and desperately fought for. Hitler's plan, as old as "Mein Kampf," was to extend the boundaries of German Europe and add the bread-basket of the Ukraine to the narrower fields of the Balkan peninsula.

Through his appointment of Judge Thomas M. Cooley as its first chairman, President Cleveland started the Interstate Commerce Commission off with a great tradition. To indicate as does your editorial today that no man contributed more distinction to that commission than did Joseph B. Eastman is not to be unmindful of the services of other distinguished commissioners -- men like Lane and Prouty.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 16 -- Francis Higgins, who read up on the law while serving a term for burglary in Sing Sing, and thus won his release on constitutional grounds less than a month ago, was back in the toils of the law again today.

LONDON, March 16 -- Numerous American C-47's were shot down during the opening stages of the Sicilian invasion last July by anti-aircraft fire from British and American warships and enemy guns. The barrages were apparently touched off by a German ruse raid.

It will be the hitter against the hornet at Madison Square Garden tonight. Al Davis, powerful punching welterweight from Brownsville, will stand up against Beau Jack, Augusta (Ga.) Negro, former ruler of the lightweight division, in the ten-round star bout at the Eighth Avenue arena.

BELFAST, Ireland, March 16 -- Control over the border between Eire and Ulster has been tightened notably during the past few days, but it is still a long way from providing that "isolation" of which Prime Minister Winston Churchill spoke in the House of Commons Tuesday. It is still probably the easiest border to cross in all wartime Europe.

A new point of view on antiques -- that of the homemaker to whom usefulness and decorative effect are most important -- now competes with the traditional collector's interest in history and value, according to the dealers whose antiques exhibition is now being held at Sherry's for the benefit of the American Red Cross.

Jennie Tourel, Canadian mezzo-soprano, made her first appearance at the Metropolitan Opera since 1937 in the title role of "Mignon" last night. For Miss Tourel, who has won critical acclaim for recent appearances in recital and as soloist with orchestra, last night's performance was a happy homecoming, as the part of the little gypsy dancer is one of her best.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- During the week ended March 15, member bank reserve balances increased $322,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from an increase of $205,000,000 in reserve bank credit and a decrease of $192,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve banks, offset in part by increases of $43,000,000 in money in circulation, $2,000,000 in Treasury cash, and $30,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts.

Mayor La Guardia left no doubt yesterday of his belief that he was the direct target of the bill, introduced in the Legislature Monday by Senator Young of Lewis County, seeking to bar candidates in primary contests from running for nominations of parties in which they are not enrolled.

CHICAGO, March 16 (AP) -- The Compania Swift Internacional reported today that consolidated net earnings for 1943 amounted to 20,561,550 Argentine pesos, compared with 17,647,932 pesos in 1942. The earnings, converted into United States currency at a rate of 25.16 cents for 1 peso prevailing Dec. 31, 1943, are equivalent to $3.45 a share, compared with $2.77 in 1942.

NEW DELHI, March 16 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's Chinese forces in northern Burma cut the only available road for motor transport in the southern Hukawng Valley after a sixteen-mile advance in a week from Walawbum, while other Chinese units opened an attack on the strategic Jambu Pass, leading to the broad Mogaung Valley to the south.

The first degree murder trial of Lieutenant (jg) Adam Rother of the Coast Guard, charged with killing Miss Rita Costello, 28-year-old secretary, of 140 Crescent Avenue, New Brighton, S.I., got under way yesterday afternoon in the Richmond County Court at St. George, after two alternate jurors, both women, had been selected at the morning session.
CHICAGO, March 16 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:

NATAL, Brazil, March 16 -- Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt pinned medals on three naval heroes this morning, decorated twenty-seven other officers and enlisted men and then partook of G I mess at the airport here. Lieuts. S.K. Taylor and C.A. Baldwin and Ensign H. C. Clark received the Distinguished Flying Cross and Air Medals.
LONDON, March 16 -A German spy was executed in Pentonville prison this morning, the fourteenth to be executed since the war began.

WITH GENERAL STILLWELL'S CHINESE-AMERICAN FORCES in the Hukawng Valley, March 12 (Delayed) -- They call them "the Tank Kids." They are the members of Col. Rothwell H. Brown's Chinese-American tank detachment that last week went into action for the first time in a way that sealed the defeat of the Japanese in the Maingkwan-Walawbum battle.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- A sliding scale of import duties made sufficiently flexible to fluctuate with the rising costs of domestic wool production, was advocated here today by Representative O.C. Fisher, Democrat, of Texas, and a member of the House Committee on Agriculture.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, March 16 (Canadian Press) -- First Lieut. Leon Crane, 24, of Philadelphia, reached this far northern town today after eighty-four days in the sub-Arctic wilds and brought with him first word of the fate of a United States bomber missing with five men aboard since Dec. 21.

LONDON, March 16 -- Some seventy-odd members of the House of Commons sought today to get clarification on the exact meaning of the Atlantic Charter, but their efforts did not get very far because Prime Minister Winston Churchill said the time could not be spared to discuss that matter at this session unless it involved an issue whether his government should stand or fall on the interpretations already given.

Since Oct. 7, last, substantial progress has been made in the actual integration of properties and personnel of the Western Union Telegraph Company and Postal Telegraph, Inc., according to Western Union's annual report for 1943, just issued by A.N. Williams, president.

Tennessee's Senatorial warhorse, Kenneth McKellar, has renewed his fight for two favorite proposals. One is to require Senate confirmation for 30,000 or more appointees to Federal jobs carrying salaries of $4,500 a year and up. The Senate accepted this suggestion last year but the House did not.

NAPLES, March 16 -- Over the uneasy capital of Bulgaria a strong force of Wellingtons accompanied by some Liberator and Halifax heavy bombers roared early this morning to pour high explosives up to two-tonners on Sofia's railway yards.

ALGIERS, March 16 -- The German air force, when attacking convoys in the Mediterranean, is often forced to bring fighter planes from north and west France, it was pointed out by a high officer in the Allies' Mediterranean coastal air force here today, who thus confirmed indications of a shortage of German aircraft.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The growing unrest in Congress and elsewhere over the blank spaces in the diplomatic record of the nation has arisen, not from any lack of statement of our general war and post-war principles but from absence of information if or how they are being applied.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- A proposal that Congress compel review of all major administrative orders of Government agencies by a special committee composed of eight members of the House and a similar number of Senate members was made today by Representative Everett M. Dirksen, Republican, of Illinois, at a hearing before a special House committee investigating executive agencies.

'TIS a wee stretch of time since the phenomenal athletic achievements of Finn MacCool were related in this space, and, glory be! what finer day could mortal man choose to chronicle his feats once more than on St. Patrick's morn? Did you ever hear about the wrestling match that Finn had with the Devil? Well, then, me bucko, draw up your chair and lend an ear.

The manpower problems of this country's insurance companies, especially with regard to sales manpower, today subordinate all the other perplexing questions that face the industry, Raymond C. Johnson, assistant vice president of the New York Life Insurance Company, declared yesterday at a luncheon of the Life Managers Association of Greater New York in the Hotel Roosevelt.

TRENTON, N.J., March 16 -- Although Gov. Walter E. Edge said he believes that two types of ballots for the armed forces would entail confusion and possibilities of fraud, he informed President Roosevelt in a telegram today that New Jersey was ready to authorize the use of the Federal ballot.
NAPLES, March 16 (AP) -- A communique:

Benjamin Franklin High and Andrew Jackson High earned the right to meet for the New York City P.S.A.L. basketball championship by surviving their semifinal round contests at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

CHUNGKING, March 16 -- Recent Japanese newspapers and magazines have lost the tone of confidence common a year ago, according to Aoyama, who is a Japanese now engaged in confidential work for the Chinese Government. There are no predictions of victory within the year, which was the usual attitude of last year.

Face powder should be chosen, the experts say, not only according to skin type but according to season. As spring approaches, costume colors become more delicate and fresh, more and more time is spent outdoors -- and a light, translucent type of make-up becomes desirable.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 16 (AP) -- The State Republican convention here today voted unanimously for a resolution urging a "Draft Dewey for President" movement.
LONDON, March 16 (UP) -- A German communique as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
ATLANTA, March 16 (AP) -- Maj. Damon J. Gause, American flier, has been killed in a plane crash in England, according to word received by Atlanta relatives.

Repatriated Americans came down the Gripsholm's gangplank at Pier F in Jersey City yesterday, as they had on Wednesday, with stories of hardship in German prison camps. The last of the 662 brought in by the ship may be cleared some time tonight.

William Dean Embree, president of the New York County Lawyers Association, sent identical telegrams yesterday to legislative and administration leaders in Albany protesting an "attempt to create socialized law" in a proposed amendment to the State Workmen's Compensation Law by establishment of a panel of lawyers and laymen to advise and assist compensation claimants.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- President Roosevelt took a hand today in applying pressure on Finland by issuing a statement in which he expressed the hope that she would withdraw from her "hateful partnership" with Germany.

An exhibition called Modern Cuban Painters opened with a members' preview yesterday afternoon at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street. It opens to the public today, and will continue through May 7. Thereafter the work is to be sent on tour by the museum's Department of Circulating Exhibitions.

Black markets in gasoline have increased to such alarming proportions that a cut in rations west of the Alleghenies has become necessary. OPA now estimates that black markets are diverting the equivalent of three gallons a month from each motorist. Black-market gasoline does not represent uncontrolled supplies.

Bruno Walter, arranging the program which celebrates the fiftieth anniversary of his career as conductor, selected the Bruckner "Te Deum" and the Beethoven Ninth Symphony for performances under his baton by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra and the Westminster Choir, the first of which was given last night in Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The War and Navy Departments confirmed today that twenty-three Army transport planes had been shot down over Sicily last July by a combination of fire from friendly naval and ground forces and enemy anti-aircraft, with a loss of 410 lives.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 16 (AP) -- Bob Hamilton, 28-year-old Evansville (Ind.) professional, making the complete winter golf tour for the first time, won the North and South Open today with a four-round score of 73, 72, 70, 71 -- 286.
NEW DELHI, India, March 16 (AP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total holdings of United States Government securities to have increased $81,307,000 during the week to the highest figure on record. Note circulation for the system as a whole was all at a new high, having increased $48,005,000 during the week.

HARRY HARRISON KROLL was a sharecropper once. But for a long time now he has been an industrious author, grinding out one lusty, gritty, violent novel after another. Some of them have been hell-for-leather historical novels of frontier days in the Deep South, filled with bandits, Indians and great plantations newly chopped out of the forest.

The 4-year-old King got frosting on his eyelashes, and the equally young Queen dropped her green and gilt crown trying to help him out, but both hosts and guests, including forty boys and girls, had a happy, noisy time yesterday at the annual St. Patrick's Day party at the Salvation Army's Day Nursery at 94 Cherry Street.

Senority regulations that resulted in discharged service men and many over-draft-age employes being laid off while workers under 38 were kept on their jobs were nullified yesterday by the Ranger Aircraft Company so that 350 employes of military age lost their right to deferment as essential craftsmen and were made available for immediate reclassification in 1-A, it was announced by Col. Arthur V. McDermott, City Selective Service director.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, March 17 (U.P.) -- Australia heaped new honors on Gen. Douglas MacArthur today in an expression of gratitude to the allied commander, who in the two years following his arrival "down under" from the Philippines turned almost imminent disaster into a spectacular military triumph, pushing the Japanese back 500 miles from the point where they threatened to invade the Commonwealth.
Yesterday's Soviet communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Paris after nearly four years of enemy occupation was pictured as a city of hunger, black markets, lawlessness, false gaiety and terror in an interview yesterday by Kathleen Cannel, the only person to be repatriated from the French capital on the liner Gripsholm, which arrived here Wednesday.

For the second time this year the British industrial organization, Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., was accused with American concerns of a conspiracy to divide the world into markets in which each of the alleged conspirators would enjoy non-competitive trade advantages.

MONTREAL, March 16 (AP) -- The Canadiens smashed the 14-year-old total-point record of the National Hockey League tonight and rode to their twenty-fourth home game without a loss this season by checking the Black Hawks, 3 to2.

PHILADELPHIA, March 16 -The Securities and Exchange Commission dismissed today the request of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., that the Department of Justice be denied intervention in the Public Service Company of Indiana underwriting case.

Net income from operations last year of Mack Trucks, Inc., increased to $3,073,088 after providing $1,000,000 for renegotiation and $500,000 for post-war reserve, Louis G. Bissell, chairman, reported to stockholders in the annual statement released today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 16 -- As Joe McCarthy was pondering the Yankees' desperate catching situation, into the Hotel Senator this morning strode Joe Glenn and no Hollywood director could have staged a more timely entrance.

The British Ministry of War Transport will seek to place "as many shipments as possible" into the hands of private foreign freight-forwarding concerns after the War Shipping Administration ceases to handle cash purchases of various missions, C.J. Moran, deputy director of the Ministry, stated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Even with sacrifices by consumers in the United Nations, it is doubtful if food needs of future liberated countries in Europe and the Far East can be fully met, Roy F. Hendrickson, deputy director general Of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, informed officials of the United States and foreign nations at a food forum dinner tonight.

A visitor comes out from a conference with the President. When the reporters ask if he has any information about 1944, the visitor replies: "He [Mr. Roosevelt] says he does not want to be a candidate."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 16 -- King Gustaf V of Sweden has joined his voice with that of President Roosevelt in exhorting the Finns to get out of the war, it was revealed today. The Swedish Government also counseled Helsinki to accept the "modified Russian terms as a basis for discussion."

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson defended the prosecution of the Italian campaign today, asserting vigorously that the objectives already won in Italy had amounted to "a great strategic victory for the Allies."

Data presented by the New York Adult Education Council on the amount of illiteracy among the adult population of this city are disturbing. We learn that 360,000 men and women above 25 years of age have never attended school. About 3,000,000, representing 65 per cent of our adult public, are by no means illiterate, but have not gone further than the eighth grade in elementary school.

A lively discussion of the feasibility and desirability of a thirty-hour week in post-war industry -- supported by Walter P. Reuther, vice president of the United Auto Workers, an affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, but derided by Eric A. Johnston, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, and Henry J. Kaiser, the industralist -- developed last night in the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

The annual report of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company for 1943, issued for publication today, reveals a net income of $13,339,588, equal to $6.06 a capital share, compared with $11,237,132, or $5.09 a share, earned the year before.
In Italy and in Russia great battles were raging yesterday, with the Allies on the offensive on both fronts.

CHICAGO, March 16 -- A committee on price regulation was formed and officers elected today by the National Association of Popular Price Shoe Retailers, Inc., which was formed yesterday by retailers who annually sell the American people almost half their needed shoes.
