WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Office of Price Administration today set aside the period March 20 through April 29 during which members of the shoe trade may sell slow-moving stocks of children's low-priced shoes in specified sizes ration-free but under a maximum wholesale price ceiling.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, March 17 (U.P.) -- A communique:

CHICAGO, March 16 -- Confirmation of recent reports that the Government would order distillers to mix rye in the mash used in producing industrial alcohol started today a buying movement in rye futures on the Board of Trade which carried prices up rapidly to a new high since early in February.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, March 17 -- Troops of the First Cavalry Division landed Wednesday morning (East Longitude time) on Manus, biggest of the already invaded Admiralty Islands, and within four hours and thirty-five minutes had pushed to within half a mile of the Japanese airfield at Lorengau.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Secretary Ickes said today that despite the situation in the coal fields, where shortages of manpower and machinery make increasingly difficult the achievement of production goals, he was opposed to the rationing of coal, the advisability of which for next Winter will be considered at the meeting of the War Production Board Tuesday.

"The Falcon Out West," latest release in the RKO mystery series, will open this morning at the Rialto. Tom Conway again plays the title character and Barbara Hale, Don Douglas, Carole Gallagher, Joan Barclay and Cliff Clark appear in supporting roles.

LONDON, March 16 -- In a street just off Piccadilly Circus in London, in a building once occupied by an internationally famous restaurant of the early Nineteen Hundreds, you will find one of the most unusual American establishments of this war. Walk in any day and here is about what you will see:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 16 -- Jennifer Jones will be starred by Twentieth Century-Fox in the film of Vera Caspary's mystery novel, "Laura," for which Gene Tierney had been scheduled. Rouben Mamoulian will direct the picture, his first since doing the broadway musical "Oklahoma!"

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Members of Congress awaited amid much speculation today the replies of State Governors to President Roosevelt's telegraphed inquiry as to what had or would be done to authorize the use of the Federal (short) ballot under the soldier vote bill sent to the White House by Congress yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (U.P.) -- The United States has advised the Bolivian military junta's confidential agent here to cease functioning as such, it was disclosed tonight.
PHILADELPHIA, March 16 (AP) -- Fred C. Perkins, York, Pa., battery manufacturer, faced a choice today of serving six months in prison or paying $15.13 social security tax.

Lieut. Commdr. Arthur F. McQuaid, chaplain of the cruiser Minneapolis, who was critically injured in a battle off Guadalcanal, told Red Cross workers at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night that he and others would have died without the blood plasma furnished by the Red Cross.

ALBANY, March 16 -- The Senate passed unanimously today, and sent to the Assembly, the proposed constitutional amendment giving veterans of all wars preference in civil service appointments, promotions and retention, with a "super-preference" for disabled veterans.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 16 -- The two greatest democratic Buenos Aires dailies, Nacion and Prensa, both published long editorials this morning reminding President Edelmiro Farrell that when he was sworn in as Vice President he had undertaken to re-establish the supremacy of the Argentine Constitution and to strengthen democratic institutions.

NEWARK, N.J., March 16 -- S. Haydu Sons, Inc., wholesale meat packers, here, were ordered today to suspend their wholesale business for the duration of the war as the penalty for being 10, 000,000 ration points short in their accounts over a period of six months.

The railroad issues took over yesterday the burden of furthering the stock market's new-found strength when the steels faltered under profit-taking. While the share list as a whole came within range of the year's high set on last Monday, and also within striking distance of last year's peak, the carriers reached a level unmatched since October, 1937.

Guarded by mountains from which German artillery has dominated the battlefield, protected by miserable winter weather which has hampered Allied operations, and defended by the Germans with suicidal determination, the ancient fortress town of Cassino has been the most difficult obstacle encountered by the Allies in the whole Italian campaign.

The construction of a pipeline across Saudi Arabia at a cost of some $130,000,000 to $165,000,000 by the United States Government was defended last night by Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, as a means of obtaining additional oil for both civilian and military uses.

The sleeping cars of the Pullman Company delivered last year more than 26,000,000,000 passenger-miles of military and civilian service, by far the highest ever recorded, and the Pullman Standard Car Manufacturing Company produced $273,600,000 in military and transportation equipment, 44 per cent more than the previous record, in 1942, David A. Crawford, president of Pullman, Inc., said in his annual report to stockholders for 1943.

FIFTH AIR FORCE Headquarters, Southwest Pacific, Friday, March 17 (AP) -- Look for the name of Capt. Richard I. Bong at the head of the list whenever headquarters issues its periodic report on ace fighter pilots operating under Lieut. Gen. George C. Kenney's command.
An estimated 50,000 wearers of the green will march up Fifth Avenue this afternoon in honor of St. Patrick, Patron Saint of Erin and of the New York Catholic Archdiocese.

ALGIERS, March 16 -- The political crisis brewing here seems likely to test the newly acquired powers of statesmanship that, many persons believe, Gen. Charles de Gaulle possesses, and at the same time to tax the limited resources of skilled experience available in Algiers, to judge by the signs that accumulated today.

NAPLES, March 16 -- There were flurries on the beachhead below Rome, where American troops, in fine weather, wrested two strong points from the enemy in the central sector between Aprilia and Cisterna.
Certain women's organizations have registered opposition to my bill, Senate Int. 1346, which eliminates certain in consistencies in the labor law relating to the organization of the Labor Department.

Katharine Cornell is planning a tour in "Lovers and Friends," it became known yesterday. Tickets are now on hand at the Plymouth until April 15. "A Highland Fling" is mentioned as the Plymouth's next tenant, opening the week of April 24.

Since its previous monthly report to the New York Stock Exchange the Borden Company has increased its holdings of its own capital stock from 102,058 to 109,058 shares, according to the March tabulation, released yesterday.

Camps in wartime and in the post-war period must be especially sensitive to the needs of community life, Dr. Hedley S. Dimock, dean of Williams College and coordinator of training for the United Service Organizations, declared yesterday at the Camp Conference, sponsored jointly by the New York section of the American Camping Association and Camping World, at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- In the sixty Army general hospitals of this country, the words "occupational therapy" are beginning to mean the first steps on the come-back road to the war wounded, under a program planned by Mrs. Winifred C. Kahmann, chief of the occupational therapy branch of the reconditioning division in the Office of the Surgeon General.

More than 3,500,000 individual and corporate income tax returns were filed with the three Internal Revenue Collectors in New York City through midnight Wednesday, accompanied by more than $643, 000,000 in cash, checks and money orders, it was estimated yesterday.

The city's right to bring alleged black market operators into the Magistrates Courts was challenged yesterday in the Bronx, where Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter signed an order calling upon Mayor La Guardia and the city to show cause why they should not be restrained from issuing summonses to egg dealers accused of violating Office of Price Administration price regulations.

The inspection by Office of Price Administration agents at gasoline stations of the ration coupons of motorists, which was started eleven days ago as a tactic in the war against the black market, was hailed yesterday as a success by Daniel P. Woolley, OPA regional administrator.

Small trade buying, supplemented by mill price-fixing against textile contracts, brought about a better tone in cotton futures yesterday, with the strength of the advance centered in the near-by positions. At the close of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange, active futures contracts were unchanged to 4 points above Wednesday's final quotations.
LONDON, Friday, March 17 (AP) -- The Thursday midnight supplementary Soviet communique:

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The question whether a panel of the National War Labor Board has authority to hear demands of the United Steel Workers (CIO) for a 17-cent-an-hour wage increase was put before the board today, but that body postponed decision at least until tomorrow.

Heavy penalties were imposed by Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind yesterday on five men convicted of attempting, on the night of Dec. 1,1943, to hijack two large trucks laden with liquor valued at $100,000. The hold-up was thwarted by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who were aware of the plans of the hijackers and were stationed around Tenth Avenue and Twenty-third Street even before the hold-up men arrived.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 16 -- The giant catching staff, which for a time was looking none too robust, what with Ernie Lombardi and Ray Berres still holding themselves aloof, took a decided brace today with a number of developments that immediately put that department in the forefront of the day's activities here.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- Demanding open-market sales of surplus Government property, Representative John J. Cochran, Democrat, of Missouri, said today that a Government employe had bought two lots of over-age dry-cell batteries from the Army, one for $15 and the other for $65, and that part of them were resold later for $20,000.

LONDON, March 16 -- Renewed fears of more labor troubles on the Rand led to further declines in Kaffirs on the stock markets here today. Business was slow, London prices being marked down on news from the Cape. Diamonds also gave way.

Stocks of butter are greater at present than the demand, which is restricted by rationing, and from now on it is thought that production will increase in a way expected at this season of the year. Whether as the result of enlarging supplies we can expect a reduction in the high value of sixteen points a pound is doubtful, according to one authority.

Drafting of proprietors into the armed forces was responsible for more than 25 per cent of all drug store closings during a five-month period, according to the results announced yesterday of a survey made by Dun Bradstreet for the National Wholesale Druggists Association.

A tribute to the French underground was voiced last night by Lord Halifax, the British Ambassador the United States, in a speech which also expressed confidence that France would emerge from the war with renewed energies and resume her rightful place in European and world leadership.

MOULTRIE, Ga., March 16 (U.P.) -- Representative Eugene E. Cox of Georgia urged today that the South unite to compel the Democratic National Convention to return to the two-thirds majority system of nominating Presidential candidates.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 16 -- More than 200 "students," sentenced by the Juvenile Court and other agencies since May to attend the Parental School of San Francisco, have been "graduated" and not a single "repeater" has been enrolled in this course, designed to help combat juvenile delinquency in this city, it was disclosed today.

ALBANY, March 16 -- Good-natured spoofing of Mayor La Guardia marked the passage by the Assembly today of the Ostertag bill, renewing for another year the general State war powers act, which contains the clause permitting the Mayor to go into the armed forces without losing control of the New York City administration.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Administration supporters, led by Senator Mead of New York, fought on the Senate floor today to save the Federal Communications Commission's radio intelligence work from abolition by cuts in appropriations.
LONDON, March 16 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:
LONDON, March 16 (AP) -- The condition statement of the Bank of England for the week ended March 15 showed an increase of 861,000 in note circulation, establishing a new high of 1,091,462,000.

Drastic reorganization of the operation of this city's four colleges, with reduction of the membership of the Board of Higher Education from twenty-one to nine; abolition of the rank of tutor, an increase in grants for scholarships, and acceptance of the principle of State aid for higher education is recommended in the final report of the New York City subcommittee of the Rapp-Coudert committee, made public yesterday.

St. John's, last year's winners, and De Paul, pre-tournament favorites, were victors in last night's double-header that started the national invitation basketball competition at Madison Square Garden before 18,197 spectators, the largest crowd ever to attend on opening night in this seven-year-old classic.

Rabbi Stephen S. Wise, who is 70 years old today, was guest of honor at a dinner last night in the Hotel Commodore sponsored by the American Jewish Congress, of which he is president, and the Zionist Organization of America, of which he is a leader.

Sports celebrities, including Lieut. Comdr. William Harrison (Jack) Dempsey, USCG, former heavyweight boxing champion, and Lieut. (jg) Helen Hull Jacobs, USNR, and former women's national tennis champion, will appear tomorrow morning at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, in one of the "Fun With Book People" series, sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES in cooperation with the Association of Children's Book Editors and Junior Programs, Inc.

STAMFORD, Conn., March 16 -- Two attendants of Stamford Hall, exclusive private sanitarium here, were taken into custody by police today in connection with the alleged fatal beating of Frederick D. Fuller, 84-year-old retired attorney of Tarrytown, N. Y.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 16 -- Since last midnight ten Allied bombers and one German pursuit plane have been forced either to land or to crash on Swiss soil after intensive aerial operations over southern Germany and elsewhere.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Commodity prices in primary markets were generally unchanged during the week ended March 11 and the Bureau of Labor Statistics' Index covering nearly 900 price series remained at 103.4 per cent of the 1926 average.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 17 (AP) -- Fred Havecker and Liberty B. won the first two races at Tropical Park today and paid $1,065.20 for $2 in the daily double.

Further strength in the railroad issues and a revival of buying in the neglected oil section held yesterday an otherwise sagging stock market on a fairly even road. Gains of major fractions appeared in the petroleum group, but the additions among the carriers ranged to a point and more.

MILWAUKEE, March 17 (AP) -- The Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company announced today that it expected to file with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Philadelphia a registration statement for the issue of $29,601,500 par value of cumulative convertible preferred stock.

Charging that "the American Government is grossly misinformed" on the subject of possible Axis espionage in Ireland, Robert Brennan, Eire Minister at Washington, in an interview here yesterday categorically denied that such espionage is possible.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 17 -- Considerable nervousness was noticed in Argentine Government circles today as rumors spread through Buenos Aires that the United States was about to make some important announcement concerning its attitude toward the regime of President Edelmiro Farrell.

ALBANY, March 17 -- Governor Dewey moved today to create a temporary commission of twenty-three members to study the anti-racial discrimination laws and report to the Legislature next year recommendations to give the State "an established basic policy" aimed at elimination of such discrimination.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- In executive session this morning the Foreign Affairs Committee of the House voted to defer action on the Palestine resolutions approving further immigration of Jews into the area and the eventual establishment of a Jewish commonwealth.

CHICAGO, March 17 -- Holders of May rye were more disposed today to sell their contracts and gave the market on the Board of Trade an easy undertone, more than offsetting aggressive buying of December by a house with Eastern connections.

WITH CHINESE-AMERICAN FORCES IN BURMA, March 15 (Delayed) -- The Japanese have been almost completely thrown out of Hukawng Valley of northern Burma. Chinese troops this morning captured Tingkawk Sakan, the last village at the southern end of the valley, and the Japanese began falling back into mountains bordering the valley in the south.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The "GI Bill of Rights," an omnibus war veterans' aid measure providing for hospitalization, education and vocational training, loans for homes, farms and businesses, employment service and unemployment benefits, was approved unanimously today by the Senate Finance Committee and plans were made to take it to the floor early next week.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 17 (U.P.) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur, on the second anniversary of his arrival in Australia, pledged tonight a great Allied offensive that would free the Philippines, isolate the Japanese in the South Seas and liberate the China coast.

ALBANY, March 17 -- Governor Dewey's State Soldier Vote Bill, which was attacked by Democratic members as "a fraud and a sham" and defended by Republican members as "simple and workable," was passed by the Assembly today and sent to the Governor.

MOSCOW, March 17 -- Few persons in Japan now believe that victory is possible and the optimistic declarations of Government circles have not succeeded in hiding from the populace Japan's failure in recent months, the publication War and the Working Class declared today.

PEORIA, Ill., March 17 -- The case of Harry Hendin of St. Louis, a stockholder of the American distilling Company who seeks to prevent the company from carrying out its plan to distribute stocks of whisky to stockholders, was closed today as Judge L. Leroy Adair allowed a motion of the defendant to vacate the continuance order.
The Lyric, one of the largest theatre properties in the Times Square district, has just passed into new hands, it became known yesterday.

The Actors Order of Friendship, in its day one of the foremost theatrical organizations in the country, has passed out of existence, it became known yesterday. An application for the dissolution of the body, which had come into being in 1849, has been granted by the New York Supreme Court.

LONDON, March 17 -- The Swedish legation here denied today a report that King Gustaf had been asked by Germany to act as intermediary in peace negotiations with the Allies. It was said that since Gustaf's appeal to the Finns to accept the Russian peace terms German relations with Sweden had become somewhat strained.

BOSTON, March 17 (AP) -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the First District upheld today orders issued by the Securities and Exchange Commission calling for the dissolution of the American Power and Light Company and the Electric Power and Light Corporation, both Maine corporations and subholding companies of the Electric Bond and Share Company, which has extensive holdings in the Midwest, South and West.

A campaign to stop "gambling on the high seas" in this locality was launched early last night when twenty-eight men were seized on ferryboats plying between Manhattan and New Jersey for playing dice. Commuters themselves, they were brought in as a result of complaints during the last two weeks from fellow-travelers.

Contributions of $1,035,416 to the Red Cross 1944 War Fund were announced at a luncheon yesterday of the food, chemical and drug industries of Manhattan in the Union League Club, Park Avenue at Thirty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- President Roosevelt told his news conference today that the Army was seriously in need of more men under 26 years of age, pointing out that when one was over 26 he was too old and that under that age was where the shortage lies.

Two stories published in this newspaper yesterday combine to suggest some anxious thoughts on the future of France. One is a dispatch from Algiers by Harold Callender describing the political crisis developing because of the necessity of reorganizing the National Committee and ridding it of personal intrigue in preparation for the grave responsibility it will assume when France is liberated.

When he administered the oath of office at City Hall to the newly appointed justice of the Court of Domestic Relations, Mayor La Guardia correctly observed that he was appointing Mr. Mulholland to a "job," not an "exalted office." It is an important job, one that will require all the tact and the sympathetic understanding at the command of any justice.

Vice President Henry A. Wallace urged last night recognition of the fact that "in peace as in war our national security and well-being lies in full production," and contended that only the fullest use of resources could bring full employment and create a national income large enough to carry the national debt safely.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The National War Labor Board wrestled for almost three and one-half hours today with the problem whether its steel panel should be permitted to hear wage increase demands of the United Steel Workers, an affiliate of the CIO, but the decision was put off until Monday.

State legislation to eliminate interstate trade barriers in the motor-truck field was advocated yesterday at a meeting of the Regional Continuing Committee on Motor Truck Problems, an organization comprising motor-truck administrators and legislators in fourteen Northeastern States.

Arrangements have been completed for the visit to New York City of the Most Rev. Cyril Forster Garbett, Archbishop of York, Primate of England and Metropolitan, and were announced yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divide.

Surrogate James A. Foley signed an order yesterday authorizing Aaron J. Simon and Charles Fredericks, executors of the estate of Samuel Klein, founder of "S. Klein or the Square," New York City's largest women's apparel dealer, located in Union Square, to accept the modified offer of a group of the decedent's relatives to purchase the business.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The aftermath of the saturation bombing of Cassino has highlighted two problems that are receiving most serious consideration in military circles here and in London: How far can air power go in clearing a beachhead for an invasion of western Europe, and have we enough trained -- and particularly combat-tested -- infantry divisions to match the Germans in such a test of strength?

Because of a statement he made charging that there are "zealous official efforts" to conceal undercover communistic activities at Brooklyn College, Seymour S. Leikind, a tutor in the school's chemistry department for twelve years, found himself suspended yesterday and in danger of losing his position.

A Tokyo broadcast to Japanese areas declared that "the news that the American Air Force is going to carry out air raids over our mainland of Japan from China has become rather too familiar of late," but warned that "if we should assume that this is merely empty propaganda of the enemy, we are making a great mistake," it was reported by United States Government monitors yesterday to the Office of War Information.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- A further decrease in the number of factory employes has come about through the smoothing out of production processes and a better flow of materials, Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins asserted today. She said also that 13,500,000 wage earners were employed in manufacturing industries in February compared with the peak of 14,000,000 in November, 1943.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC, March 17 -- Sometimes there is no accounting for the Japanese mentality and that is particularly true of their present mad attempt to drive the Americans off their Bougainville beachhead, where they have been established in force since November.

William P. Witherow, president of the Blaw-Knox Company, reported yesterday in the annual statement to stockholders that the net profit last year increased to $1,936,798, or $1.45 a share, from $1,425,718, or $1.07 a share, earned in 1942, despite larger tax charges.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- When peace returns to the world the athletes in uniform may join in battlefront Olympics, an Army plan of international service games to help heal the scars of war.

Fifteen one-family homes in the Bronx, consisting of four brick houses in the old Westchester Country Club section and eleven brick and frame dwellings in the Castle Hill area, were sold last month by Homer Homes, Inc. (Leon F. Scully, president).
LONDON, March 17 -- Adolf Hitler's continental fortress was hit twice today by two branches of the United States Army Forces after the Royal Air Force had struck hard not many hours before.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- A simplification law to relieve three-fifths of the country's individual income tax payers from computing annual returns and greatly lessen the task of the remaining two-fifths received the approval today of the Ways and Means Committee.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 17 (AP) -- President Edward E. Chase of the New England Council, pleading for "simplification of taxes on business," charged today that "the present tax system has put a premium on trickery."

Today's events: "Il Trovatore," 2 P.M., and "Das Rheingold," 8:30, Metropolitan Opera House; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Young People's concert, Carnegie Hall, 11 A.M.; College of St. Elizabeth Glee Club, Town Hall, 8:30; Busch Quartet, McMillin Theatre, Columbia University, 8:30; "Il Trovatore," Salmaggi Opera Company, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:30.

Wartime strains on American family life have brought to light serious inadequacies in our whole concept of the place of the home in an industrial society, it was agreed yesterday at a meeting on "The American Home" by speakers who stressed women's responsibility for correcting both immediate and long-term evils.

Easter apparel activity at retail is opening up in most sections of the country, with sales figures of most retailers thus far this month running ahead of the like month of 1943, reports reaching the wholesale markets here yesterday indicated.

MOSCOW, March 17 (AP) -- The Soviet journal War and the Working Class described today as a misrepresentation a recent comment it said appeared in The New York Sun to the effect that if supplies sent by the United States to Russia had been sent to Britain and American troops a new front against Germany probably would have been established long ago.

RICHMOND, Va., March 17 -- Among the 626 patents listed in this week's Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office is one covering a method for making certain kinds of vitamins taste and smell better.

ALGIERS, March 17 -- Pierre Pucheu's last chance in court vanished today when a Military Court of Appeals after an hour's deliberation refused to grant a new trial on the treason case that had resulted in his condemnation to death.

Tomorrow will be observed in Protestant churches as annual "Red Cross Sunday" and today as "Red Cross Sabbath" in the synagogues of the city. On March 26 a special Red Cross supplemental solicitation will be made at the doors of the parish churches of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- President Roosevelt today confirmed the report that he had drafted a new formula for partial recognition of the French Committee of National Liberation.

Carrying out their motto for 1944 -- "Serve by Sharing" -- the Camp Fire Girls celebrated yesterday the thirty-second anniversary of their organization by sharing their birthday cake with more than a thousand service men and women, at 99 Park Avenue, headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee.

DUBLIN, March 17 (AP) -- The bells of an uneasy peace rang out in troubled Eire this St. Patrick's day. The warning of Prime Minister Churchill that the country would be isolated from the outer world hung heavy over the nation.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 17 -- It remained for the Giant's outfield department to show the most progress today as Mel Ott drove his large squad through its fifth successive day of intensive outdoor training.

NEW DELHI, India, March 17 -- American gliders and transport planes have landed British and Indian troops 150 miles behind the Japanese lines in north central Burma in a successful airborne operation aimed at disrupting communications of enemy forces driving toward the Indian border, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (U.P.) -- The War Labor Board reversed tonight a decision of its shipbuilding commission which assessed a wage penalty against employes of the Cramp Shipyard at Philadelphia because of a strike.

ALBANY, March 17 -- The Legislature will end tomorrow its shortest session in twelve years. The Senate formally adopted the adjournment resolution today, setting the time for 3 P.M., instead of 5 as suggested by the Assembly, earlier hour.

With the aid of beneficent tax laws just enacted, reorganization and recapitalization of scores of corporations are being planned or launched, to clear up debts, or dividend arrears, or otherwise to improve or simplify corporate structures.

An exhibition entitled "Fifteen Hundred Years of Chinese Painting" opened on Thursday at the Boston Museum of Fine Arts, which regards it as one of the most important showings of Chinese paintings ever held in this country. This is the largest single exhibition of the treasures in the museum's collection.
A communique, broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

LONDON, March 17 -- The British Government has made a dramatic appeal for truck drivers to help with the impending invasion of western Europe. Thousands of them, both men and women, are wanted at once for service during the next few months.

Louis Kaufman gave a violin recital last night in Town Hall during which he did some of the best playing this reviewer had heard from him over the years. The serious artist was, as always, intelligent and sane in his interpretations and never at fault in matters of taste.
LONDON, March 17 -- Thomas Patrick Mitchell proudly wore his shamrock today about the hotel where he works -- but it took a lot of doing, even for a loyal Irishman.

LONDON, March 17 -- Although business in most sections of the stock markets was quiet today, the general tone was steady. Gilt-edge stocks showed some improvement, gains in them ranging up to 1/8. Support for Argentine Railway shares also was seen and was attributed to recent reports of good traffic and also to the better view now being taken of the political situation in Argentina.

PHILADELPHIA, March 17 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission issued today an order suspending the over-the-counter firm of Bond Goodwin, Inc., from the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., for thirty days because of allegedly violating repeatedly the anti-fraud provisions of the legislation administered by the commission.
LOS ANGELES, March 17 -- Declaring that she thought her 87-year-old mother was possessed of the devil, Miss Winifred Fairchild, 64, admitted to police today that she garrotted her last night.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, March 18 (AP) -- A communique:

IT is a wrench at the heart to see him go, but Bill Dickey undoubtedly has played his last game of baseball. The soft-spoken, mild-mannered Arkansas Traveler has been accepted for the Navy and that means that his diamond career is at an end. As long as it had to come that way, Bill probably is satisfied. He always is satisfied.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Mar. 17 -- Frenchy Bordagaray was rejected by the Army in New York this morning and suffered the same fate at the hands of Branch Rickey here this afternoon.

Have your Easter dry cleaning done early, warns the National Association of Dyers and Cleaners, whose members have good reason to dread being flooded with garments to be cleaned a few days before the holiday. With conditions what they are today, cleaners may not be able to return last minute "pick-ups" until several weeks after the Easter parade is over.

The Erie Railroad last year reduced its funded debt, including equipment trust obligations, by $11,054,120 to $194,329,395 at the year-end, according to Robert E. Woodruff, president, in his annual report to stockholders. Fixed charges were cut $658,827 from the 1942 level.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 17 -- E.J. (Dutch) Harrison, Army Air Forces sergeant, knocked out a six-under-par 66 today to lead the field in the first round of the $10,000 inaugural Charlotte open golf tournament.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 17 -- Replying to questions concerning the proposed Arabian oil pipeline, James M. Landis, director of American economic activities in the Middle East, declared at a press conference today that the United States did not seek privileges in the economic sense but rather only equal opportunities through free competition.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., March 17 (AP) -- David Filgas, 16 years old, was freed of a murder charge in his girl friend's death today in a sensational court-room scene. Amid screams of women spectators and whistles and cries from boys and girls in the corridors, a jury of nine men and three women in the Kent County Circuit Court returned a verdict of acquittal after forty minutes' deliberation.

MOSCOW, March 17 -- Hemmed in by Russian tanks, the German garrison at Vinnitsa is fighting desperately on the outskirts of the town. Rear guards, armed with mortars and heavy machine guns, have taken up positions on the approaches.

O.J. Elder, president of Macfadden Publications, Inc., yesterday informed stockholders of a proposed plan of recapitalization under which holders of 68,008 shares of $6 cumulative preferred stock, on which dividends in arrears totaled $43.50 a share on Dec. 31, will receive $50 in 6 per cent debenture bonds and one share of participating preference stock for each share outstanding.

Among the promising agreements reached at the historic Moscow Conference was one which dealt with problems that followed from the surrender of Italy. Here the principal Allies in the European war agreed not only on all the essentials of a long-term program but also on a policy and a method of meeting immediate questions as they arose.

" Target: Germany," published here by Simon Schuster, is now brought out in Britain by the Government Printing Office and has so far sold 550,000 of the first million copies printed. The book, in the British edition, carries a preface by Sir Archibald Sinclair, British Air Minister. "Target: Germany" is the official story of the United States Army Air Force's first year of bombing operations over Europe.

I am just a soldier overseas who has been listening in a rather alarmed manner to the various bulletins emanating from the "home front" relative to assorted industry-crippling strikes, race riots and all those other things which can be counted upon to ease no soldier's mind.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 7 -- The second heavy blow to hit the Yankees this week swept Joe Gordon right out of the 1944 picture today.

Scattered hedge selling and liquidation yesterday brought about a slight recession in cotton futures as mill buying against textile contracts slackened. At the close of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange, active futures contracts showed net losses of 1 to 4 points.

LONDON, Saturday, March 18 -- Red Army troops smashed to within ten miles of the Dniester River border of Bessarabia, former Rumanian boundary, at two points yesterday, opened a new drive toward the big Polish railroad junction of Lwow, and closed in on Pomoshnaya, eastern terminus of the last German east-west railroad across the lower Ukraine.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Twelve youths from as many parts of the country told the Children's Bureau Commission on Children in Wartime today that their generation wanted its education streamlined and vocational and its recreation more varied and available, and was ready to take over the task of educating their elders to less racial prejudice.

The old St. Agnes Chapel property at 115-121 West Ninety-first Street, running through to Ninety-second Street, has passed from the hands of Trinity Church to the New York Protestant Episcopal Public School.

TRENTON, March 17 (AP) -- President Roosevelt's name will appear on the New Jersey Democratic primary election ballot this year only if he formally approves its use, Secretary of State Joseph A. Brophy said today.

Retail trade here this week continued to expand under the impetus of pre-Easter buying of apparel and accessories. Department store volume was estimated as showing an increase of 8 to 10 per cent over the like week of last year.

Culminating ceremonies, attendant upon the fiftieth anniversary of Bruno Walter's debut as conductor, are planned for tomorrow with the performance of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony under his direction at the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society's concert.

Instead of a problem of filling the Long Island Sound schedule of championship races, with Larchmont sailing into the gaps, as was the case last year, it will be a matter of allotment when the delegates of the many clubs meet in the New York Yacht Club on March 29.

The extent to which the Federal Government's vast hoards of food are taxing the nation's storage facilities is revealed in a report released yesterday by the Office of Distribution of the War Food Administration.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 17 -- Warner Brothers, who in the past have glorified Dodge City and Virginia City with pictures under those titles, will produce a similar type extended-budget Western this summer under the title of "San Antonio," starring Errol Flynn.

OTTAWA, March 17 -- Defining Canadian aims and interests in international air transport as calling for "a liberal course of cooperation with other nations," Munitions Minister C.D. Howe today offered in the House of Commons the Canadian "tentative and preliminary draft" of an international air transport convention.
NAPLES, March 17 (AP) -A communique:
LONDON, Saturday, March 18 (AP) -- A supplementary Friday midnight communique, broadcast from Moscow:

In the cycle of fashion, capes have once again come to the fore, and throughout the spring collections their influence was apparent everywhere. Capes this season are not confined to any age nor are they limited to any particular type of costume. Suits, dresses for both day and evening, and playclothes all show versions of this important trend.

Millions of dollars and hundreds of thousands of man-hours are being saved by "package engineering," or more scientific packaging, packing and handling of materials, Lieut. Walter T. Sheldon of the Naval Clothing Depot, Navy Department, Brooklyn, reported last night at a meeting of the metropolitan section of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

LONDON, March 17 -- The Labor party, the great majority of whose members revolted last year against the coalition government's cautious approach to post-war social security, gave warning today that it would resist efforts to whittle down the Government's proposed national health service plan to provide minimum medical care for all.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- President Roosevelt paid a tribute to Irish-Americans today at news conference when a reporter commented on the President's "wearing o' the green."

LONDON, March 17 -- Prime Minister Eamon de Valera told the citizens of Eire in a St. Patrick's Day radio address from Dublin tonight, "We exist today as a separate nation because we were willing to endure and were not willing to yield."

Stressing the strong friendship between the United States and Ireland, Representative Albert A. Gore of Tennessee last night warned that Ireland must take a practical view on the question of neutrality or the country will hinder the Allied cause.
CANBERRA, March 17 (AP) -The text of General MacArthur's address at a State banquet in his honor tonight:

" The Fighting Seabees," a topical action drama produced by Republic Pictures, will have its local premiere this morning at the Globe. The cast of the picture, which deals with the Navy's construction battalions, is headed by John Wayne, Susan Hayward, Dennis O'Keefe, William Frawley, Leonid Kinsky and Grant Withers.

A recent report that this nation has 423,000,000 hens on 5,150,000 poultry-producing farms leads one to the conclusion that biddy has not received the literary attention she deserves. A hen hasn't many brains, but she's a sensitive, artistic creature. The fact that her cerebral powers are distinctly limited does not prevent her from knowing what she wants and how she wants it when she wants it.

Using as its theme the need for motor car conservation to offset wear and tear of wartime stop-and-go driving, the Shell Oil Company is launching a new campaign in 173 daily newspapers east of the Rock Mountains beginning Monday.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Retail stores will have to spend billions of dollars after the war to replenish inventories, the Department of Commerce predicted today in an article in the March issue of its publication, Survey of Current Business.
I have received the following letter from my boy. Perhaps you would like to print it T.N.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The United States has asked the Soviet Government for a clarification and explanation of its recent announcement of intention to recognize the Badoglio government in Italy. This was learned today when Secretary of State Cordell Hull said definitely for the first time at his press conference that Moscow had not consulted us before adopting the policy.

NAPLES, March 17 -- The ever-expanding offensive of the Mediterranean Allied Air Force against Adolf Hitler's inner fortress reached out today to strike for the first time within the city limits of Vienna, Austria, one of the most important railway centers in central Europe.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, March 18 (AP) -- Capture of Lorengau airdrome on Manus Island in the Admiralties and complete breakdown of the enemy's counter-offensive at Empress Augusta Bay on Bougainville Island in the Solomons were twin triumphs over the Japanese announced in Gen. Douglas MacArthur's communique today.
NEW DELHI, India, March 17 (AP) -- A southeastern Asia Command communique:

Gen. Bernard L. Montgomery, former commander of the British Eighth Army, now British Army group commander under Eisenhower, adds an authoritative word to the discussion as to the extent of German depravity. He divides German soldiers into two classes.

The spear, one of the most ancient of weapons, may be used for taking certain varieties of fish in New York State beginning Monday. The Conservation Department announced that the new spearing order goes into effect then and will continue in force until the end of November in most parts of the State.

The process of clearing American repatriates from the Swedish exchange motorship Gripsholm was completed yesterday afternoon, almost two full days after she had arrived Wednesday on her fourth voyage of mercy during the war.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Office of Price Administration clarified its definition of "grade" in the book paper price regulation, announcing it desired to avoid any misunderstanding of the regulation.

One can't tell what anothe day will produce in Argentina, but at the moment the press is unexpectedly holding its own against the army. Both Nacion and Prensa, the great liberal dailies of Buenos Aires -- and among the greatest in the world -- have just called on President Farrell, who succeeded Ramirez after the recent palace revolution, to hold free elections and restore the democratic form of government.

Beau Jack proved himself a fighter last night. The Augusta (Ga.) Negro, facing heavy-hitting Al Davis of Brownsville, took the best his rival had to offer in the early stages and went on to win by a decisive margin the 10-round battle that featured the card at Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- A reopening of the Senate's inquiry into James Caesar Petrillo's activities was prompted today by a published boast of his power to keep high school music off the air.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 17 -- Russian circles here revealed tonight the nature of the concessions that the Soviet Government had made to the Finns. The revised terms were stated to have included a more reasonable approach to the problem of how German troops in Finland were to be interned, plus the precise conditions under which Finland would be asked to move her troops back to the 1940 border.

A short while ago you published an interesting article by Pertinax which dealt with the schemes of Marshal Tukhashevsky. This article recalled some personal memories which will help, I think, to clarify further the personality of the Marshal.

The obituary news of day before yesterday included Gen. Otto yon Below, Commander in Chief in the last war of the German-Austrian armies which delivered the smashing blow against the Italian lines at Caporetto on Oct. 24, 1917.

Mgr. Joseph F. Flannelly, administrator of St. Patrick's Cathedral, called upon all Catholics to meet attacks upon their faith which, he charged, were attempting to break down morality, in a sermon yesterday at a solemn pontifical mass in the cathedral.
NAPLES, March 17 (U.P.) -- The Fifty Army has driven the German defenders of Cassino to a dead end in the southwestern suburbs.

Nathan Karell has bought for occupancy from Eleanor Brandt the two-story dwelling on a lot 19 by 100 feet at 2166 East Twenty-sixth Street, south of Avenue V, in Brooklyn, through the Harry Lewis Company.
MIAMI BEACH, March 17 -- Walter Winchell asks, "Why don't they subpoena Winchell?" when he was informed today of the Dies committee's action.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- With any sort of "break" in requirements for industrial alcohol this year, officials said tonight, they will be in a position to authorize the liquor industry to increase its stocks of potable spirits.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY AT CASSINO, March 17 -- In fierce, close-in combat, New Zealand infantrymen pushed on with their job of mopping up snipers' nests in devastated Cassino today and secured about three-fourths of the town as sappers along its southeastern edge, working under continual smoke screens, cleared a path for tanks toward the Liri Valley.

Premier Laval's Cabinet has a new member. Marcel Deat, editor of Oeuvre, organ of Nazi sweetness and light, has been appointed by his German masters Minister Secretary of Labor and Solidarity. Made by characteristically clumsy Nazi hands, the appointment is even more than a joke.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, March 17 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller, coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, and his party left Managua by plane today for Costa Rica. At the airport to bid the guests good-by were President Anastasio Somoza, Cabinet officers, high Government officials, Army officers and a large crowd.

In its final report the Rapp-Coudert committee has made some interesting and valuable recommendations for the public schools and colleges of this city. For the last two years the committee's survey staff, headed by Dr. George D. Strayer, has gone into the many ramifications of the local school system, trying to find specific means of improving it.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Development of the oil resources of Saudi Arabia by the Standard Oil of California and the Texas Company in collaboration with the Petroleum Reserve Corporation will not lead to any clash with British interests, private or governmental, it was stated today.

PEARL HARBOR, March 17 (U.P.) -- Intensifying their assault on the Carolines, Navy search planes Wednesday smashed at Oroluk Atoll, Japanese outpost, for the third time in three days, Pacific Fleet headquarters announced today.

LONDON, March 17 -- Returning to the air Thursday, the Luftwaffe sent up against the United States Army Air Forces a fighter that American airmen described as a twin-tailed, four-engined plane but that air experts today were unable to identify.

New issues of municipal bonds and notes aggregating $9,013,000 will come up for award through competitive bidding next week. This compares with this week's revised total of $4,299,711, according to the Daily Bond Buyer, and with the weekly average for the year to date of $17,026,956.

BOSTON, March 17 (AP) -- Jake LaMotta, 163, of New York, gave Coley Welch, 163 1/2, of Portland, Me., a lusty left-handed pounding on the head and body tonight to gain an unanimous ten-round decision over the New England middleweight titlist before a crowd of 9,601 at the Boston Garden.
Skirling pipes and sodden drumbeats, dampened brass and watery trumpets, urged 48,000 marchers up Fifth Avenue from Forty-fourth to 110th Streets yesterday in a wet St. Patrick's Day parade.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- President Roosevelt said today that the International Labor Office would have a place in the post-war organization of the United Nations' as he announced the names of the two delegates as an alternate who will represent the United States at the ILO conference at Philadelphia next month.

HEADQUARTERS OF SOUTH PACIFIC AIR FORCE, March 17 -- The South Pacific Air Force, which has been shattering Kavieng and Rabaul, has destroyed 806 Japanese planes in the air and fifty-two on the ground for a loss of 172 of its own in three months.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The State Department mission headed by Under-Secretary Edward R. Stettinius Jr., which will leave soon for diplomatic talks in London, said farewell to President Roosevelt at the White House today.

Warning that the Japanese still have a "real and dangerous reserve of vicious striking power," Lieut. Gen. Alexander A. Vandegrift, commandant of the Marine Corps, last night told 2,000 guests at the 160th annual dinner of the Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick at the Hotel Astor that "there can be no doubt that we axe growing sharply bolder as our experience and our means of fighting increase."

PHILADELPHIA, March 17 -- The applications of three stock exchanges to strike six issues of securities from listing and registration were granted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, effective at the close of trading on March 25.

Federal Judge Robert A. Inch, sitting in Brooklyn, imposed fines yesterday totaling $118,350 on twelve wholesale meat dealers and thirty-two individuals, some of them officers in the meat corporations, for selling or purchasing meat above the Office of Price Administration ceiling levels.
LONDON, March 17 (AP) -- A United States Air Force communique:
LONDON, March 17 (AP) -- A communique broadcast from Berlin:

RICHMOND, Va., March 17 (AP) -- Holders of common stock of Philip Morris Co., cigarette manufacturers, at a special meeting today adopted a retirement plan for the company's 3,500 employes, O.H. Chalkley, president, announced.

A decision by Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag yesterday dismissing the suit brought by Eliot D. Pratt, a sociologist, to restrain the city from proceeding with plans to raze the "Gas House District" to make way for Stuyvesant Town cleared away several legal obstacles to the post-war plans of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company for carrying out its housing plan.

A report that Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has purchased the screen rights to "Cabbages and Kings," the musical comedy that Michael Todd contemplated doing before his induction into the Navy, was confirmed yesterday afternoon by Stella Unger, co-author of the book with Joan Alison.

Household workers had a "day in court" yesterday when a group of Negro women, who formerly served as cooks, maids and housekeepers in private homes, were invited to take over the rostrum at a conference of Methodist Church women to tell why they had left private domestic employment for other fields.
LONDON, March 17 (AP) -- Prime Minister Eamon de Valera's St. Patrick's Day radio address as broadcast from Dublin and recorded here:

Sonia Essin, contralto, of this city, gave her first Town Hall recital since 1935 yesterday afternoon before a large and appreciative gathering. Her program contained the operatic arias, "Ah, spietato," from Handel's "Amadigi"; "Deh, non voler costringere" from Donizetti's "Anna Bolena"; "Divinites du Styx" from Gluck's "Alceste," and "Gerechter Gott" from Wagner's "Rienzi."

THE dust cover of Mr. Nathan's volume carries a statement by Mr. Donald Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, that it "bears out fully his reputation for deep insight and broad comprehension of the major economic and social problems the nation will face."

WE went to Berlin three times in a recent week -- on Monday, Wednesday and Thursday. Monday's mission was my second in combat; the first for my co-pilot, upper turret gunner, radio operator, ball turret and left waist gunners; the third for the bombardier, and the fifth for the navigator, right waist and tail gunners.

The first surplus material "auction" sponsored by the War Production Board and members of the Eastern aircraft industry will provide Government procurement agents with an indication of the amount of "dollar return" they can expect to salvage from inventory claims resulting from contract terminations, manufacturers stated yesterday.

THE sometime decline of film producers to the exhibition of enemy atrocities on the screen in a manner designed to goad black hatred or pander to lain morbidity has dingled the gudgeon of this department, every time it has been done.

DOMINICAN REPUBLIC is celebrating this year the 100th anniversary of its national independence. As one means of calling the world's attention to the observance, twelve large-sized stamps have been issued -- nine for ordinary postage and three for airmail use -- and this commemorative series, released on Feb. 27, the centennial date, is now being sold by New York dealers.

LONDON, March 18 -- Reports from Washington that President Roosevelt had announced that he has reached a decision regarding the role of the French Committee of National Liberation caused both surprise and puzzlement here today because the British are completely in the dark concerning what it is all about.

GRACE MOORE has been a star for twenty years, but this is her first autobiography. The prima donna of the Metropolitan Opera, Hollywood and the Roxy four-a-day has surrendered to the urge to get it down on paper.

THE autobiography of Angna Enters is a fascinating record of a one-woman theatre. A young girl who vowed she had no desire to go on the stage, no wish to become a dancer, found herself pushed, by a powerful impulse to express her "idea-forms," into a successful theatrical career -- first a succes d'estime, then a success that brought enjoyment to an increasing audience and, finally, a financial success.

WASHINGTON, March 18--Sightseers should not go to Chicago in June to see the Republican National Convention nominate "the next President of the United States," Harrison E. Spangler, party chairman, said today.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Pressed by mounting requirements both for the military services and essential transportation at home, and pinched further by an appalling loss to the black market, the Office of Price Administration was forced this week to cut another substantial slice from the civilian motorist's gasoline ration.

Considerable sifting and shifting of resources is likely in the post-war period, with further development of centralized buying and strong emphasis on private brands likely to feature merchandise planning, according to views expressed in retail quarters last week.

Retail trade was generally good last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, despite a slow start, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. The call for apparel was brisk, and children's departments and main floor sections were active.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Broadus Mitchell, research director of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, failed today in two attempts to put anti-war recommendations into the working platform of the Children's Bureau Commission on Children in Wartime.

OF all the arts, the one in which women have achieved the greatest distinction is the art of fiction. In poetry, although their record is impressive, it is less so than in the novel; in painting and sculpture, they have consistently fallen short of greatness; in music, there is no woman composer of the first rank.

DETROIT, March 18 (AP) -- Connie Dion's good work in the nets helped Detroit to a 6-to-3 National Hockey League victory tonight over Chicago, which has not won at the Olympia since 1940. The crowd was 10,331, raising the total for twenty-five games here to 285,641, a new record for the Red Wings.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The United States submarines Capelin and Sculpin are overdue from patrol and must be presumed to be lost, the Navy Department announced today.

NAPLES, March 18 -- The food situation in this war-gripped metropolis is fraught with a paradox. On one side of the street confectioners display luscious cream and almond-tipped pastry priced at fifteen cents each. On the other side ragged mothers with sickly babies wait outside American mess halls with cans and jars for leavings from soldiers' tables.

The new "declaration of estimated income and victory tax form and worksheet for 1944," which will be used by an estimated 15,000,000 taxpayers, is being mailed to all persons who filed declarations last fall, according to Joseph D. Nunan Jr., Commissioner of Internal Revenue.

Allied diplomacy worked hard last week to establish closer liaison among the three great capitals of the United Nations -- Washington, London and Moscow. There were reports that soon President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Stalin may meet to iron out political questions and establish closer working arrangements in tackling war and post-war problems.

WRITTEN primarily for aircraft workers, these books provide a notion of what it takes to transform ideas and countless parts into planes and airpower.

Among other things, such a striving after precious perfection sounds too much like Japanese notions of what a garden should be for our present taste. Also food this year is on every gardener's mind.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- "Living memorials" to the dead of this war, in the form of community sports centers, were proposed today by the Government-sponsored National Committee on Physical Fitness.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (UP) -- Reports were current tonight that Fred M. Vinson, Director of Economic Stabilization, told President Roosevelt three weeks ago that the "Little Steel" wage formula must be maintained. This would appear to lengthen the odds against approval of the pay increase of 17 cents an hour sought by the United Steel Workers (CIO).

BERNE, Switzerland, March 18 -- Berne had its first daylight air-raid alarm of the war today. Swiss officials announced that sixteen United States bombers had landed at various points of Switzerland following the American attack over southern Germany this afternoon.

Doubling the student body now attending the city's four colleges to increase the enrollment from 60,000 to 120,000 was recommended yesterday by Dean T.R. McConnell of the University of Minnesota, speaking before 500 educators and civic leaders attending the luncheon of the Public Education Association at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Wendell L. Willkie, in an article made public yesterday from the April issue of the quarterly review, Foreign Affairs, declared that our willingness to use force in concert with other peace-loving nations constitutes the only way to prevent a third World War and an attendant cycle of fear, inflation and depression.

John P. Stevens Jr., general chairman of the Red Cross 1944 War Fund of Greater New York, announced yesterday that to date $9,801,280 has been contributed toward the city's quota of $22,386,000. The contributions, Mr. Stevens reported, represent approximately 44 per cent of the city-wide goal, which is being sought in the five boroughs.

IN spite of the fact that his marches are so often played, John Philip Sousa's name is not so familiar to the present generation of boys and girls as it was to their parents and grandparents. This is a book which leaders of school bands and orchestras will be glad to recommend to budding musicians, and, once embarked on this account of the March King's life, boys and girls will read it with interest.

ONE of the best services that a biologist of long experience can render his fellow-citizens is to tell them in language which they can understand what he thinks of the human species. Professor Conklin has done his duty well in this regard for he has twice discussed in general terms what he rightly considers one of the most important of all questions: "What is man?"

With Russian troops now standing on Rumania's border, the Turkish Anatolia News Agency reported last night that "Rumanian sources" in Budapest were viewing the military situation "pessimistically." It quoted these sources as considering it "probable that the Russians may occupy Bessarabia and Bukovina, and that the front may be extended to the banks of the Prut River."

HINDSIGHT, it has been said, is better than foresight. If there is any doubt about television's future, consider its almost phenomenal growth to date. Consider that in 1925, less than twenty years ago, leading technical men were in the midst of a controversy over the relative merits of scanning and reproducing images at thirty and forty-five lines, neither of which was sufficient to permit the positive identification of a face, close up.

ALBANY, Sunday, March 19 -- The shortest session of the Legislature in many years still dragged toward a close early this morning, after clocks had been stopped at 3 P.M. yesterday. Both houses continued to dispute either routine or agreed legislation.

Under-Secretary of the Navy James V. Forrestal, speaking from Washington in a broadcast over the Blue Network in the season's fifteenth Metropolitan Opera Victory Rally yesterday afternoon, praised the work of the Red Cross in the present war and told especially of its work in collecting blood plasma.
LONDON, March 18 (Reuter) -- The British Broadcasting Corporation late tonight broadcast the following warning to Rumania:

MOSCOW, Sunday, March 19 -- The Red Army reached the Dniester River yesterday on the thousand and first day of its war with the German Wehrmacht. The news was released shortly after the capture of Zhmerinka had been announced.

Maria Kurenko, Russian soprano, appeared in the fifth of this season's Young People's Concerts given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Rudolph Ganz conducting, at Carnegie Hall yesterday forenoon. She sang a group of French and Russian songs.

NAPLES, March 18 (AP) -- Stars and Stripes, the American soldiers' newspaper, today published six letters from soldiers criticizing a group of American clergymen for protesting the obliteration bombing of German cities.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Sugar for home canning will be made available to consumers this year at the same rate as in 1943, and in much the same manner, the Office of Price Administration announced today.

SIX years ago Austria's independent existence came to an end, and for the first time in nearly a thousand years her name disappeared from the map of Europe. She was the first country on Hitler's occupationroll.

ONCE again the motion picture industry has rolled up its sleeves and stands poised to do another war service. This time it's out to help in every possible way to put over the top the 1944 Red Cross Drive for $200,000,000.

HEADQUARTERS OF THE USAAF FIRST AIR COMMANDO UNIT, India-Burma Front, March 18 -- In the heart of northern Burma, 150 miles behind the Japanese lines, a strong force of British-Indian airborne troops, supplied by American glider and air transport units, is exploiting a surprise aerial "break-through" that menaces all Japanese north-south supply lines in Burma.

STOCKHOLM, March 18 -- The daylight drubbings administered to the Reich capital this month by United States airmen were a rude shock to Berliners who now know that Reich Marshal Hermann Goering's Luftwaffe is too weak to prevent a major-scale round-the-clock bombing of their city.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 18 (U.P.) -- Senator John A. Danaher, Connecticut, Republican, called today for "the preservation of constitutional government against the creeping collectivism which has paralyzed democratic political action since the President came into power."

THESE stories come from the occupied countries. Some of them are reprinted from Underground papers, some were brought back by returning American soldiers. They are proof that Nazis may nazify official newspapers, broadcasts. plays, but they cannot nazify wit.

A military and naval reception and cocktail party will serve to open formally a full evening's program of festivities now being arranged as the annual Red, White and Blue dinner dance, which will be given on April 21 in the ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton for the benefit of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York.

HIGH octane ballyhoo, starting long before there was a picture, or even a script, has, in the case of Columbia's "Cover Girl," smartly reversed the usual procedure of opus first and publicity, advertising and exploitation afterward.

In a comprehensive study of the conditions giving rise to the browing tide of juvenile delinquency throughout the country, several noted penologists and social workers have set forth their views on how to rectify the situation and how to maintain a rigid check on it through concerted action now and after the war.

THE Cuban exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art opened too late to be reviewed here. It was commented upon last Friday. Meanwhile, there is the one-man show of work by a leading Cuban artist, Mario Carre+/-o, at the Perls.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., March 18 -- West Coast residents are waiting for the "big squeeze." Their thoughts in large measure, aside from certain sharp ones engendered by long hours over income tax forms, were directed this week to the probable eventual effects on everyday life of the speeding up of the war in the Pacific.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 18 -- The fourth annual Inter-American Seminar of the Inter-American institute will be held at the University of Havana for the 1944 summer session, Mgr. William Barry, chairman of the Committee on Cultural Relations with the American Republics and Canada and head of its university extension committee, announced here today.

IN "Cloudless May" Storm Jameson has once again done full justice to her talents. Once again she has used them to write about France, to describe a country which she knows well. Scarcely a page of this long book that does not contain a rare sentence pinning to our memories some detail of France's beauty, some half-forgotten aspect of her loveliness.

JIM HENDY and the other statistical-minded gentlemen in the National Hockey League have just made a startling discovery. While juggling the official figures the other day, they were amazed to learn that Frank Boucher's unselfish return to competitive play this year had brought that grand veteran of the steel blades a more tangible reward than he ever had dreamed possible.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 18 (AP) -- An ingenious "magic eye" that enables British bombers to detect the approach of German night fighter planes is one of several new gadgets the Nazis say the British are using in the current aerial offensives.

WRITING a book about servants is a risky business. Some outraged employers discuss at such lengths the perversity of the tribe that the reader is automatically inclined to give the maid the benefit of every possible doubt and to consider the author a narrow-minded Bourbon who really wants a set of serfs.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- Major Roger Willock of Sewickley, Pa., has received from Lieut. Gen. A.A. Vandergrift, Marine Corps commandant, the Cross of Boyaca in the grade of "Official" awarded to him by the President of Colombia for service as assistant naval attache at Bogota from October, 1940, to October, 1943.

THE war having made us conscious of Southeast Asia, the books have begun to appear. Mr. Lasker's is one of a different order. In the first place, he does not take up country by country but discusses the region as a whole, as a part of the world distinctive to itself -- colonial, non-white, culturally Eastern and "un-modern," non-industrial and possessed of great natural wealth.

There has recently come to the writer's attention another instance of the way in which the people are being victimized by a dictatorial bureaucracy. It is the case of the owner of a Series E war savings bond who has named another person as beneficiary and who later desires, for any reason, to make a change of beneficiaries or eliminate the beneficiary.

Seventy of the 669 repatriates who arrived here last Wednesday on the Swedish exchange liner Gripsholm were detained at Ellis Island for further interrogation as the Federal authorities ordered yesterday the release of ten men and women.

OTTAWA, March 18 -- Movement of capital to Canada through sales of securities to other countries reached a record level of $172,000,000 in 1943, against $105,500,000 in 1942, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- Postmaster General Walker suggested today a closer check on "penalty" mail with a view to reducing its use by Government agencies and applauded Congress for a decrease in "franked" matter.

Among the newspapers recently donated to the Cornell Collection of Regional History were copies of The Albany Register for June 7, 1799, and The Bath Gazette and Genessee Advertiser of Dec. 20, 1797. The latter was the first newspaper in western New York, according to Whitney R. Cross, curator of the collection.

Beau Jack flew to his home town of Augusta, Ga., yesterday. The former lightweight champion of the world, who decisively trounced the welterweight, Al Davis, at Madison Square Garden on Friday night, carried with him a check for $3,677, which represented 10 per cent of his earnings from the Davis clash.

Outlining a revised physical education program for schools and colleges, Lieut. Comdr. Ellwood C. Davis, in charge of the physical training program of the Third Naval District, declared yesterday that physical educators should concern themselves with planning for the Navy's immediate training requirements.

An early determination by the Appellate Division of the legal status of Acting District Attorney Thomas Cradock Hughes, which has beclouded the validity of many indictments found in Kings County, was assured yesterday after County Judge Louis Goldstein in Brooklyn sustained a demurrer entered in behalf of a defendant indicted for grand larceny.

THE Irish Sea was at its roughest and the third class as usual reeked of oil, brass and disinfectant. On the crowded deck hundreds of pale, sickly children, lifebelts slung over their shoulders, were running about restless and confused. And watching anxiously, the mothers were trying to forget the life they had left behind.

President Roosevelt, Vice President Henry A. Wallace and Paul V. McNutt, War Manpower Commission chairman, are among the many persons prominent in public life who have sent congratulatory messages to the Jewish Consumptives Relief Society, which will open its fortieth annual national convention here next Saturday.

NOW that Prof. Felix Ehrenfelt has subjected electricity to a little Einsteinian iconoclasm, the beginner in radio will approach the subject with more timidity than ever. As time and genius join again to shake the foundations of electrical theory, it is all the more important that books for the beginner be uncluttered by mystic language or the neophyte will find himself quite as shaken as the subject he is starting to learn.

The Tokyo radio said yesterday that the Japanese Government had announced its intention of shifting "more and more" of the financial burden of the war on the working classes and quoted the announcement as declaring "it cannot be helped if the distribution of the burden is not just."

Penicillin checks the growth of a bacterial species responsible for rot which has destroyed a number of groves of the picturesque giant cactus, or sahuaro, in the Southwest. This discovery, believed to be the first proved instance of penicillin's ability to cope with a plant-disease germ, was made at the University of Arizona by Prof. J.G. Brown and Miss Alice M. Boyle.

A NEW picture of Britain is being taken, a picture which will influence American international attitudes for generations to come. Americans, young, almost all men, almost all in uniform, are standing on street corners in Britain, passively exposed to what they see and hear and smell, taste and touch, and feel in their bones.
