WITH income taxes out of the way, Easter buying is expected to move ahead more briskly in the next three weeks, although the father draft may hold the gain within bounds. Current increases compare with the post-scare period of a year ago and a later holiday.

ALBANY, March 18 -- The 1944 session of the New York State Legislature presented as good an argument as any yet in sight for biennial rather than annual meetings of the State's lawmakers. Apart from soldier-vote legislation and the budget there was little done that could not have waited for another year.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Dudley DeGroot convinced a gathering of sports figures here today that the Washington Redskins professional football team would have a coach with a sense of humor next season whether or not they have a "T" formation and Sammy Baugh.

In expanding its program to include more 17-year-old students the War Department has made an excellent decision from the standpoint of both the Army and the colleges. With the scheduled withdrawal of 110,000 trainees from the classrooms, educational officials are concerned over what may happen to higher education in this country.

AMERICA should return, at the end of the war, to a system of free private enterprise, a system in which venture capital seeks profits at the risk of incurring losses in open competition. So we are being told, repeatedly and emphatically, by those who are qualified to speak with authority for American business.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Expansion of the dollars-and-cents price ceilings of the Office of Price Administration, now applied to foods, to include hardware, dry-goods, work clothing and similar products was urged upon the price agency today by its consumer Advisory Committee.

The S.S. Santa Rita, one of a group of six new C-2-type cargo vessels on the Grace Line's present construction program, will be launched on Saturday at the North Carolina Shipbuilding Company's yards in Wilmington, N.C., it was disclosed yesterday.

WE have been wondering whether there will be any relaxation soon of those irksome restrictions piled upon us ordinary folk under the emergency war measures, or whether, like Prime Minister David Lloyd George's decrees under the famous "Dora" Defense of the Realm Act) of World War I, they are to live on with us forever.

Hay fever belongs to the group of diseases called allergies. An allergy is extreme sensitivity to some particular substance, such as a plant pollen, to which most people are insensitive. A sufferer from hay fever may be sensitive to the wind-blown pollen of any one of hundreds of plants.

The Soviet autonomy decrees concerning the transformation of the People's Commissariat of Foreign Affairs from Union People's Commissariats into Union Republican People's Commissariats, as announced on Feb. 1, 1944, made unwarranted confusion all the more confounded among American newspaper writers and radio commentators.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 18 (AP) -- "For the world at large and for our citizenry at home and abroad, this Presidential year must serve as a dramatic demonstration of the vitality of our great American life," said Eric Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, in an address tonight.
This is the twelfth and last article of the New York Designer series.

A prediction that post-war Brazilian university students would continue their studies in this country rather than in Europe was voiced yesterday by Dr. Andre Dreyfus, dean of the faculty of philosophy, science and arts at Sao Paulo University in Brazil.

MOST of the difficulties encountered in growing roses are more imaginary than real. The first prehistoric man (or woman) to transplant a rose bush to the proximity of his crude dwelling was no skilled horticulturist in the modern sense of the term.

IT is indeed rare to come upon a book of wisdom that, based on a life-long study of history and political forces, and written with crystal clarity and charm, brings the fruit of mature scholarship within the reach of every man.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 18 -- The 8-year-old gelding Marriage was in a running mood today, and five other thoroughbreds in Tropical Park's $5,000 Coral Gables Handicap never had a chance.

Criticizing the recent investigation of his charges of brutality at the Medical Center for Federal prisoners in Springfield, Mo., Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, in a letter to Congress yesterday, urged "Congressional development of an intelligent machinery or investigation which may be employed in the sole interest of competency, integrity and fair play in government."

It was with the greatest interest that I read your imaginary letter to Anton Chekhov, and I felt I would like to send you my friendliest greetings. It gave me sincere pleasure to see you address Chekhov as a contemporary, and deepened my conviction that the creative work of the Russian writer of genius is deathless, not only for his fellow-countrymen but also for you who speak and think in another language.

Directors of the National City Bank of Cleveland have recommended that its capital funds be increased $3,375,000 by the sale of 112,500 shares at $30 a share and that rights to purchase the new shares be issued to stockholders, according to an announcement yesterday by Sydney B. Congdon, president.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 18 -- As the special Republican committee of twenty-five members of the House goes to work formulating an over-all tax policy, a survey of the attitude of the public toward taxation reveals several facts of interest to the committee as well as to Congress and the Administration.

With reference to recent correspondence which has appeared in your columns regarding the use of Basic English as an international language, I would suggest that in the initial stages men of different nationalities having no knowledge of a language common to all would be enabled to converse together if a code existed in which the words (and phrases connected with these words) of each language were arranged alphabetically and numbered consecutively.

SOME months ago Rusty Lane announced that he was searching for a script. Moreover, said Mr. Lane at the time, he had the necessary financial backing. Well, Mr. L. has his script and the wheels are turning. He has taken an option until August on "The Gentle Ghost," a drama by John Patrick, author of "The Willow and I" and "Hell Freezes Over."

The College of St. Elizabeth Glee Club of Convent, N.J., Frederic Joslyn conducting, presented its winter concert last night at Town Hall before a large audience which gave evidence of greatly enjoying the interesting program.

DETROIT, March 18 -- Commenting on reports that he was again speaking on political and international subjects from the pulpit, the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, pastor of the Shrine of the Little Flower, stated today that the talks referred to were being delivered as a series of Wednesday night Lenten sermons and that the subjects were confined to "religious matters."
NEW DELHI, India, March 18 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- David E. Finley, director of the National Gallery of Art, announced today the acquisition of a famous American portrait of Amos Lawrence, Boston philanthropist, who helped build the Bunker Hill Monument.

TINY gray kittens have come out along the branches of pussywillow trees, the song sparrow trills in the thicket and a faint tinge of green is beginning to brighten the dun-colored lawn. These are signs that the planting season is just around the corner. For the third successive spring the efforts of American gardeners are turned primarily toward the raising of food.

AGERATUMS, like marigolds and petunias, are becoming so numerous a group that it is hard to know what variety to select. It may be a help, therefore, in planning this year's list of flowers, to hear of a kind which has done well in an ordinary suburban garden.

Although sportsmanship has been sidetracked today as a result of the war, the children who in the future will decide the state of the world must not forget the true value of sportsmanship, Lieut. Comdr. William Harrison (Jack) Dempsey of the Coast Guard told an audience of children yesterday.

ABOUT the time that children are ready for kindergarten, they begin to take a keen interest in the rooms they live in. Young eyes study minute details of a design on the curtains, the pattern of the rug, or a picture on the wall -- particularly if it suggests a story.

AMERICAN AIR COMMANDO HEADQUARTERS, Burma Frontier, March 18 (U.P.) -- The daring little group of United States Air Commandos that landed far behind the Japanese lines to touch off the latest. Allied drive into Burma last week numbered among its members a world-known movie star, a major league ball player, and the original of a famous comic strip character -- plus a lot of gallant guys named Joe.

NAPLES, March 18--As a good Bronxite and former student in the College of the City of New York, Staff Sgt. Ralph Martin of The Stars and Stripes has just learned the enormous power of the name of "F.H. La Guardia" in the town of Foggia where the Mayor is Virgilio Guarducci.

In a first attempt to test the soldiers' attitudes toward post-war education, a survey conducted by the research branch of the Morale Services Division found that 7 per cent of the men think they will actually go back to full-time school or college after the war. These men say they will go back to school whether or not they receive Government aid.

WITH the departure of ebullient Jimmy Durante from the Copacabana, Monte Proser has installed at his East Sixtieth Street spot an equally effervescent artist, Sophie Tucker, the veteran trouper of songs.

MUSIC is a great mystery. By virtue of its sensual-spiritual nature and the amazing union it achieves between strict rule and dream, good form and magic, reason and emotion, day and night, it is without a doubt, the most profound, most fascinating and, in the eyes of the philosopher, most disquieting phenomenon.

FOUR HUNDRED locomotives built here by such companies as Baldwin, Lima and American Locomotive are now on active service with the British Railways, according to T.D. Slattery, newly appointed general traffic manager of the British lines who has just arrived to assume his post in this country.

" I AM the grass, I cover all," writes the poet, whereat the practical-minded gardener can only grit his teeth. For him, grass won't cover anything. Each March or September he tries a different kind, only to have it quail under the tread of human feet, retreat at the first appearance of crabgrass, slide quietly down from the terrace, and curl up and die against such odds as heat and drought.

SIGNS of a prevalent and growing trend toward a kind of romantic expressionism in American painting have not been wanting these last few years. The current exhibition of recent work by Philip Evergood, at the A.C.A. Gallery, focuses new attention on this development.

RECENT superlative performances by Dr. Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra of Rimsky-Korsakoff's "Scheherazade" suite have been as re-creations of a score of unique mastery and perpetual magic.

Miss Marilyn Sahner, former national 100-yard champion, added further glory to her swimming prowess last night when she captured the Metropolitan A.A.U. senior 220-yard free-style championship in the New York Athletic Club pool.

AMONG the interesting items culled from the Writers' War Board second annual report is the fact that the board now sends out a monthly Magazine War Guide and a War Guide Supplement for fiction writers, listing war subjects which would make timely articles in national magazines, and background material specially prepared for fiction writers.

NAPLES, March 18 -- For the third straight day there was nothing else in the Battle of Italy to compare with the Cassino fighting. Patrol action was reported elsewhere on the transpeninsular front while in the Anzio beachhead Allied artillery broke up an enemy thrust of perhaps company strength in the area five miles west and slightly south of Littoria.

With Easter buying of apparel and accessories gaining headway, retail trade here last week was active. Department store sales, it was estimated, ran from 8 to 10 per cent above the like week of last year. Specialty apparel stores had substantially larger increases.
LONDON, Sunday, March 19 (AP) -- The Russian Saturday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

I HAVE always found it baffling that novels about women's colleges are so seldom really good -- especially in comparison to the equivalent male product. Mostly they seem to suffer from an excess of coyness and girlishness and tend to present their characters as quite startlingly immature.

THERE is nothing spectacular about Detective John Bent. He hasn't an idiosyncrasy to his name. Consequently, the interest in the stories about him depends upon the problems with which he is confronted and the manner in which he solves them.

Team A of the Fencers Club retained the women's metropolitan open team championship yesterday in the victors' club. In the finals, the champions ran up a score of 5 to 1 against a composite team from Salle Santelli and the Greco Fencing Academy.

Small price-fixing operations, combined with a moderate volume of commission-house demand, produced yesterday a slight improvement in cotton futures. At the close of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts showed net gains of 2 points, or 10 cents a bale, over Friday's final quotations.

AFTER sundry delays and postponements, Milton Berle, currently appearing on Broadway in "Ziegfeld Follies," is scheduled to start a new program at 7 P.M. Tuesday over the Blue and WJZ. Capitalizing on the apparently inexhaustible demand for the zany, the show will invite studio guests to let go with their suppressed desires, etc. Jacques Renard and orchestra also are on the payroll.

Certain Railway issues drew sharp attention yesterday and trading on the New York Stock Exchange was the most active for a Saturday since July 31. Sales aggregated 727,200 shares, against 600,320 on the previous Saturday. The close was active and mixed, with some of the rail issues strong and pivotal industrials easier.

" THE OUTNUMBERED" introduces to the American public a novelist of mature stature and purpose. Catherine Hutter, who is American by adoption, has lived much of her life in Europe, some of it in the Wienerwald which she describes here in loving and inevitably somber detail.

GAY doings in Mexico City will divide honors with fishing contests in Mexican waters the coming weeks. The Tampico Tarpon Rodeo is scheduled for March 29-31, on Tampico's Panuco River; the Sailfish Rodeo for April 12-14, at Acapulco on the Pacific Coast.

AT A BOMBER BASE Somewhere in England, March 18 -- Every American air base in the British Isles is a tense place these days. Every day and all day there is an action, or reports of an action or rumors of an action.

BY way of Buenos Aires word was received last week that a decree signed by the Government of Paraguay authorizes the postal administration to have 100,000 copies of the 1939 "Buenos Aires Peace Conference" commemorative 10-pesos stamp overprinted " Adhesion U.P.A.E. Victimas San Juan y Pueblo Argentino" and surcharged "10 centimos."

THERE is little to the plot of this Irish novel: The boy is hard-headed, the girl is soft-hearted, and while he is sulking and she is pining, the pages roll by in a panorama of Kilkenny life that would turn copywriters for the California and Florida Chambers of Commerce inside out with envy.

I have in my possession a book entitled "Nursery Rhymes and Nursery Tales of England," collected by James Orchard Halliwell, printed by Frederick Warne Co., London. The date of publication is not given but there is a notation on the fly-leaf showing that the volume was given as a birthday present on April 27, 1885.

LONDON, March 18 -- A Britain no less grateful to Tommy Atkins than to "the few" of the Royal Air Force who won the Battle of Britain waited and watched this week as a committee of members of Parliament started conferences with three Government Ministers on the subject of increased basic pay for the British soldier and more liberal allowances for his family.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- A Pacific Fleet announcement:
The Russian drive to the Dniester River was by far the most important military accomplishment of last week.

MOSCOW, March 18 -- The Soviet Union commemorated today the 100th anniversary of the birth of Nikolai Andreyevich Rimsky-Korsakoff, author of fifteen operas and numerous other musical works, with special services in Moscow and Leningrad and with a decision by the Council of Peoples Commissars of the U.S.S.R. which will add much to the available public information about the man and his works.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 18 (AP) -- The newspaper Journal de Geneve, quoting an unidentified diplomat, said today that the Allies had presented seven conditions of armistice for Rumania to Prince Barbu Stirbey, Rumanian politician, including the return of Bessarabia and northern Bukovina to Russia.

CHUNGKING, March 16 (Delayed) -- Because of the necessity of flying generals, guns, gasoline and other impedimenta into China the monthly ration of American pipe tobacco at the Army PX has been reduced to three packages.

The first tabulated results of last week's check of 30,000 New York City retail food stores by 1,000 Office of Price Administration representatives to test compliance with ceiling and other regulations revealed that 60 per cent of 2,770 stores in midtown Manhattan complied fully with price and posting regulations while the remaining 40 per cent were chargeable with only minor errors.

Malaria is carried by a mosquito known as Anopheles gambia. The home of that dread insect is Africa. Scientists of the Rockefeller Foundation have been waging war on gambiae in this country, South America and other parts of the world. After years of effort gambiae were eliminated from Brazil -- so the scientists thought.

Homes are better than institutions for bringing up babies, as various studies have demonstrated. A new study reported by William Goldfarb in the American Journal of Orthopsychiatry reviews some of the earlier surveys and presents new evidence.

This organization of amateur pilots and their friends and associates, operating entirely on its own until its services proved to be so valuable that it was given military status by the Air Forces, has contributed in an important measure to the defense of our seacoasts.
LIKE the author's "Homesteaders' Horses" and "Firebeads," this well-written story vividly pictures ranch life and young people who rise nobly to the occasion when thrown on their own resources.

The pickup in retail trade brought additional pressure for delivery of merchandise, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. Most stores, the report notes, have already more than made up any loss in February volume.
CHICAGO, March 18 -- Gil Dodds, the Flying Parson from Boston, won his seventh consecutive mile race of the season tonight, turning in a new world competitive indoor record of 4:06.4.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- To clear up misunderstandings regarding the recruiting of women, the War Manpower Commission today restated the policy on which it has agreed with the Army, Navy and Office of War Information.

GILMORE HENRY, the young lawyer who did his first job of sleuthing in "The Rat Began to Gnaw the Rope," is at it again. He is no longer a member of the law firm with which he was connected but is in business for himself: the story begins with the arrival of a client who is in trouble because of an improperly issued life insurance policy.

PEARL HARBOR, March 18 -- American land-based bombers smashed six times Thursday and Friday at three of the Kurile Islands in one of the most sustained offensives carried out near the Japanese homeland, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today.

REALIZING that food and its preparation form a bond among women, the Common Council for American Unity has been holding some tasting parties in New York City as a way of furthering friendship in alien groups.

OMAHA, Neb., March 18 -- The Middle West received this week a sharp reminder of the impact of the war on its normal life, when its family gasoline ration was cut from three to two gallons a week, with an advance notice of only thirty-six hours that such a cut was even in contemplation.

DUBLIN, via Belfast, March 18 -- A little boy suddenly beaten by a mother who had always been kind, generous and indulgent could not be more astonished and hurt than are the people of Eire, confronted for the first time in their history by a dispute with the United States of America.

PHILADELPHIA, March 18 -- At a history-making rate that never dipped below $9,000,000,000 a quarter, American individuals during 1943 piled up $37,700,000,000 in liquid savings, or about 30 per cent of their disposable income after taxes, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

In "A 'Third Front' -- Against Juvenile Crime," in THE TIMES Magazine by J. Edgar Hoover, underlying causes and possible solutions are set forth. And, admittedly, much -- if not the greatest -- emphasis will be upon so-called education.
NEGRO boys are setting the war to music. Not for public show, but strictly on their own, to relieve the rigors and tedium of Army life and enhance the part they play in it.

CHICAGO, March 18 -- Wartime estrictions affecting the daily lives of citizens, rather than developments on the world battlefronts and in international and domestic political affairs, apparently were uppermost this week in the minds of the general public in the metropolitan areas of Illinois, Indiana, Michigan and Wisconsin.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- The Senate Finance Committee, in a formal report on a $3,000,000,000-plus "G.I. Bill of Rights," described it today as "admittedly more extensive and generous" in its benefits for veterans than any other bill in this or any other war. But, it added:

A study unit on health, prepared by the teachers of Springfield, Mass., is to be introduced into hundreds of school systems in all parts of the country next fall, it was disclosed last week. This unit, called "The Message of the Christmas Seal," has been prepared by the teachers in cooperation with the Nations Tuberculosis Association, now marking its fortieth year.

THIS is the third story of the great gray "husky" who has become a prime favorite with readers of Mr. O'Brien's books, and whose intelligence, courage and loyalty make him, in these stories, an invaluable companion to his master, Sgt. Jim Thorne of the Canadian Mounted Police.

More than 11,200 ships of all classes, representing 44,250,000 tons of shipping, have been built, repaired or converted by the Todd Shipyards Corporation's ten shipbuilding and ship repair yards from this country's entrance into the war to the first of this month, John D. Reilly, president of the company, reported yesterday.

THE outstanding recent event in our theatre is the appearance of Robert Helpmann as Hamlet. Helpmann has for years been a leader of the Sadler's Wells ballet and is generally considered the best male ballet dancer in England.

ST. MARGARET, P.Q., March 18 -- Miss Rebecca Fraser, Middlebury College ace, gave a brilliant exhibition of controlled running In leading the international field in today's downhill ski race between Eastern United States and Canadian women on precipitous Mount Baldy's speedway.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (U.P.) -- The Government tonight promised that revisions of the master lend-lease agreement now under consideration will "protect the interests of American industry and trade to the fullest extent consistent" with war requirements.

While the plants can be carried over several years the results are usually disappointing, and the work of weeding and keeping the plants free from insects and diseases greatly increases.

LONDON, Sunday, March 19 -- American Flying Fortresses and Liberators plunged deep into southern Germany yesterday to pound Augsburg, Friedrichshafen and other targets, plowing into heavy opposition that cost forty-three bombers and ten fighters.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY AT CASSINO, March 18 -- Virtually all of devastated Cassino is occupied by New Zealand troops as a result of today's mopping-up operations and although the crest of Abbey Hill and a few isolated small snipers' nests bordering the outskirts remain in enemy hands, to all intents and purposes one may say that the town itself is at last in Allied possession.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Sunday, March 19 (U.P.) -- Tank-supported American troops on Manus Island in the Admiralties have smashed through Japanese defenses on the outskirts of Lorengau and are battling enemy forces within the town, Gen. Douglas MacArthur reported today.

TORONTO, March 18 (AP) -- Toronto closed its National Hockey League season tonight with a 10-2 triumph over Boston before 11,308 fans at Maple Leaf Gardens. RICHLAND CENTER, Wis., March 18 -- In a speech directed especially to farmers, Wendell L. Willkie opened his two weeks' campaign in Wisconsin tonight by proposing a five-point program of general objectives, a six-point program of specific policies needed this year for farm production and a three-point program for agriculture after victory in the war.

ALGIERS, March 19 -- Twenty-four hours' reflection upon Gen. LONDON, March 19 -- Five British escort sloops, operating on the flanks of convoy lanes in the North Atlantic, sank six U-boats in a twenty-day action that will make a bright page in history. CHICAGO, March 19 -- Production of lard continues unusually heavy and with a lack of shipping directions against previous sales to the Government, stocks in cold storage are increasing rapidly, creating an acute storage situation. The Government is reported to be refusing to purchase refined lard in boxes except when the seller is able to store it until needed for shipment abroad.

LONDON, Monday, March 20 -Two-way attacks against Nazi targets in Europe continued by daylight yesterday when United States Army Air Forces bombers based in Britain and Italy delivered heavy, coordinated blows against the western and southwestern fronts of Hitler's fortress.

Red Cross week will be observed in motion picture houses throughout the United States beginning Thursday and continuing through the following Wednesday, as the film industry attempts the fulfillment of its pledge to collect $10,000,000 toward the 1944 Red Cross War Fund appeal for $200,000,000, it was announced yesterday.
Most of the criticisms of the Army's methods and systems are reduced, sooner or later, to one common denominator, leadership.

Mr. Sol Ballin's letter on this subject in the TIMES of March 12 is a well-thought-out handling of the vexed problem of making the subway self-supporting. A further contribution may be made by considering two zone fare systems now in operation, one partly within New York City and the other within the metropolitan area.

The shortage of onions that has been experienced throughout the country this winter as the result of an unusually light crop in 1943 is expected to be ended within a firstnight. The War Food Administration says that, barring excessively rainy weather that would impair the harvest, shipments from south Texas will begin to arrive the first of April.

The remedy for anti-Semitism is "for the Jews to protest against the persecution of all religion," Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen, of the faculty of the Catholic University of America, in Washington, declared yesterday in his Lenten sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Archbishop Francis J. Spellman presided in the sanctuary.
LONDON, March 19 (U.P.) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin:

MADISON, Wis., March 19 -- As Wendell L. Willkie began his two-week primary election campaign in Wisconsin, he found himself faced with formidable opposition from supporters of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York, Lieut. Comdr. Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota, and Gen. Douglas MacArthur.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 19 -- News comes from France that Edcuard de Curieres de Castelnau, General of the Armies and oldest officer of France, who was maintained on the active list regardless of the age limit, has died on his family estate near Toulouse at the age of 92.

Hearings were begun last week in Congress on the continuation of the Emergency Price Control and Stabilization Acts after June 30, when they expire. Several considerations must be kept in mind in determining the nature of the legislation to be adopted.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The Office of Defense Transportation today ordered closed at midnight, March 26, all industry-operated joint information offices which originally had been set up to assist over-the-road truck operators in meeting ODT loading requirements.

CHUNGKING, China, Monday, March 20 -- Regulations to "govern the encouragement of foreign capital," as the tentative document somewhat ironically phrases it, are being formulated by the Chinese Government. Briefly, they are severe.

ALBANY, March 19 -- The belief that Governor Dewey would be nominated for President on the first ballot at the National Convention of the Republican party was expressed freely last night and this morning by both legislators and political figures in the Republican State organization as they discussed the effect of the session on Mr. Dewey's political fortunes.

WHILE Poland still lies prostrate beneath the feet of her conquerors one of her most distinguished citizens speaks for her to the American public today. She is Zofia Kossak, author of many much-admired books, whose "Blessed Are the Meek"* is now published in this country and is assured wide attention, since it is the April selection of the Book-of-the-Month Club.

BOSCOTRECASE, Italy, March 19 -- Mount Vesuvius put on the greatest "show" since 1906 last night, and today this village on the south slope of the angered giant was the subject of an official visit by Prof. Giuseppe Imbo, expert on volcanoes, and American Military Government authorities, with a view to possible evacuation of some of the families.

LONDON, March 19 -- The stock markets here failed last week to broaden but continued to make up in tone what they lacked in business. The turnover was kept down drastically by the uncertainties of the immediate outlook.

The Russians have crossed the Dniester into Bessarabia. For the second time in this war they are on the western side of the river that for two decades was a kind of deadline, just as much a dead end as it seemed to the Roman legions when they put up four strong forts on the banks to mark the eastern limits of Europe.

Bruno Walter's fiftieth anniversary as a conductor was celebrated officially yesterday afternoon by the Philharmonic Symphony Society, after three anniversary concerts had been played on Tuesday, Friday and yesterday. The third concert featured Beethoven's Ninth Symphony, given with the Westminster Choir and four vocal soloists, three of them from the Metropolitan Opera Company.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 19 -- In a switch-about of boats in the sailing dinghy racing today at the Larchmont Yacht Club Corny Shields took the helm of Howard McMichael's Ordeal and made a sweeping score over the others. In seven contests he took the first two, was the runner-up in another and in third place the other three times out for 59 points.

The war in China, although it has wrought terrible destruction and suffering, has resulted in the biggest expansion of Christianity that nation has yet known, according to the Right Rev. Y.Y. Tsu, Bishop of Kunming and formerly assistant bishop of the diocese of Hong Kong.

Retailers sought to spur shipments of apparel last week as pre-Easter trade began to approach its peak. The delivery situation continues extremely tight and many cancellations of past-due orders were placed.

CHICAGO, March 19 -- Good rains fell over a large part of the winter Wheat Belt last week and, although favorable for that grain, the additional moisture left the soil in such a wet condition as to interfere with seeding of oats and barley.
Keeping their rivals scoreless until the third period, the Curtis Bay Coast Guard easily vanquished the New York Rovers in the play-off meeting between the sextets at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 19 -- Religious minorities in some of the British colonies will suffer if those countries receive complete independence after the war, the Rev. Basil Mathews, formerly of the British Office of Information and now Professor of Missions at Boston University, told the directors of the Missionary Education Movement at the annual meeting here today.

The police listed as suicides the deaths within a few hours yesterday of Charles Gerson Loeb, 58-year-old lawyer and former vice president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Paris, and his father, Felix V. Loeb, 92.
NEW DELHI, India, March 19 (AP) -- A communique:

Miss Florence Schmitt, 13-year-old free-style star, retained the metropolitan senior indoor 440-yard championship yesterday in the London Terrace pool. Coming from behind in the final, Miss Schmitt, the national 1,500-meter titleholder, overcame the lead of her W.S.A. team-mate, Miss Marilyn Sahner and triumphed by a thirty-foot margin in 5:38.6.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 19 -- American pilots are specialists in bad weather flying, according to the Berlin military spokesman, as reported in dispatches today. He said that compared to RAF pilots the Americans were "in a class by themselves."

Ludmilla Pitoeff, French actress, will make her English-speaking debut on Broadway tonight as the star of "The House in Paris," opening at the Fulton under the auspices of H. Clay Blaney. The plot comes from Elizabeth Bowen's novel of the same name, a Book-of-the-Month Club selection, and has been adapted by E. Mawby Green and Edward Allen Feilbert.

New York City today is the greatest wartime port in the world, with one-third of all American exports passing through it, Rear Admiral Stanley V. Parker, in command of the Coast Guard in this area, told a communion breakfast of Spars yesterday at the Hotel Astor.

CHICAGO, March 19 -- Corn continues to hold at ceiling prices with the movement last week below normal for the season, owing in part to wet weather throughout the main producing area, which prevents farmers from shelling and hauling the grain.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (U.P.) -- Summaries of replies by other Governors are as follows:

Two museums and the Morgan Library will open art exhibitions this week. Beginning Wednesday the Metropolitan Museum will show Chinese paintings by the late Kao Weng and his adopted daughter, Chang K'un-i. The Whitney Museum beginning today will display its accessions of the last two years.

Close upon the local War Food Administration announcement that New York City's butter supplies are "the best in some time," Mayor La Guardia yesterday renewed his demand for a separation of ration points for fats and meats.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The special trains in which Republican Presidential candidates in peacetime years made cross-country swings may be missing this year.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, March 20 -- Lorengau, on Manus Island, fell at 6 P.M. Saturday to American troopers of the dismounted First Cavalry Division following a desperate stand by the Japanese garrison in underground bunkers in the center of the town, and all vital areas of the Admiralties were in our hands eighteen days after the original landing, Gen. Douglas MacArthur reported today.
Five Broadway theatres will bring in new films during the week. The schedule follows:

The Metropolitan Opera Fund campaign for $300,000 has ended, and late returns indicated it has gone well over the top. This was announced yesterday by George A. Sloan, president of the Metropolitan Opera Association and chairman of the fund.
NAPLES, March 19 -- With a lapse of only a day after Friday's attack on Vienna, the heavy bombers of the United States Fifteenth Air Force again crossed the Alps to Austria today.

Mayor La Guardia gave the 1944 Legislature a tongue-lashing yesterday in his weekly broadcast from City Hall, devoting more than half of his thirty-minute talk to a castigation of its members, Republicans and Democrats alike, for denying legislation much needed by the city and burdening its treasury with new mandatory expenses.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Replies of forty-two Governors to President Roosevelt on the soldier vote bill, made public tonight, indicate that as many as half the States might not use the supplementary Federal ballot provided by the bill awaiting signature.
ANZIO BEACHHEAD, March 12 (Delayed) (AP) -- They crouched in a duck blind in a grainfield on the Anzio beachhead waiting for more ducks to come by.
PEARL HARBOR, March 19 (AP) -- The third bombing strike in three days on Paramushiro in Japan's northern Kurile Islands was reported today by Admiral Chester W. Nimitz.

CHICAGO, March 19 -- Announcement that distillers had been requested to use a moderate amount of rye in producing industrial alcohol led early last week to considerable buying of rye futures on the Board of Trade, but after the official statement was out holders of May futures started to sell freely, causing a reaction from the best prices.
LONDON, March 19 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

American leaflets dropped by our bombers over Berlin have notified the German people that the "greatest air offensive in the history of the world" is now under way on two fronts and that its aim is the complete annihilation of the Luftwaffe. The Germans, who began the war with full confidence that air power had replaced naval power as the key to victory, well know what that means.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 9 -- A three-and-one-half-hour workout in the West Point field house today may have been fine exercise for Lippy Leo Durocher's assorted athletes, only eleven of which are entitled to wear Brooklyn uniforms, but it revealed nothing so important as the fact that the Dodgers don't have a shortstop.

LONDON, March 19 -- While the British have not ceased their efforts to heal the diplomatic breach between the Soviet Union and the exiled Polish Government of Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, it cannot be said that they are proceeding with ardor or confidence.

The Bronx County Medical Society wrote yesterday to Governor Dewey protesting findings against the society in the recent report of William F. Bleakley and Herman T. Stichman, Moreland Act commissioners, who investigated the operation of the Workmen's Compensation Act and made recommendations for elimination of kickbacks and other abuses.

American bombs that burst on Matsuwa Island in the Kuriles last Thursday are probably still echoing in Tokyo. Only a few bombs were dropped from a single plane, but they fell within 960 miles of the capital, closer than our Aleutian-based fliers have ever come before.

Frederick Marantz gave a modestly proportioned but pleasing harpsichord recital at the New York Times Hall yesterday afternoon, playing music of Handel, Couperin, Rameau, Bach and Scarlatti. Mr. Marantz's mastery of the clean, brittle technique required by the harpsichord was obvious and he drew front the excellent instrument he played a variety of tonal colorations and dynamic shadings.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, March 20 (AP) -- A communique:

"Dear Sir: Your letter of even date is at hand and its contents have been duly noted. I appreciate the sound foundation of your complaints; they have much merit. However, it is a matter over which I have no jurisdiction, so I am referring it to Mr. Blank of the X Department, where I am confident it will have prompt consideration.

PITTSBURGH, March 19 -- Order volume and production in the steel industry last week reached a tempo as brisk as that at any previous period since the war began. While demand still was centered on furnishing flat-rolled products, increases in requirements for other types of steel products were in evidence.

The sorriest season in the history of the New York Rangers hockey team came to an end at Madison Square Garden last night. And, in concluding their schedule in the National League, the blue-jerseyed skaters performed just as impotently as they had through virtually the entire campaign.
A considerable increase in the flying training time for fighter and bomber pilots was announced yesterday by the Army Air Forces Training Command in a statement issued at Fort Worth.

This is a condensation of the second in a series of lectures arranged by the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross for its instructors of home nursing in preparation for reception of returning war veterans. Dr. Leland E. Hinsie, assistant director of the New York State Psychiatric Institute and Professor of Clinical Psychiatry at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, spoke on "Psychoses."
Pastors of Protestant churches west of Central Park, preaching a series of Lenten sermons on "Modern Sins and Their Cure," had as their topic yesterday "The Sin of Culture Without Character."
BOUGAINVILLE, Solomon Islands, March 17 (Delayed) -First Lieut. Robert W. Curry, 26 years of age, of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., is the Thirty-seventh Division's hero of the moment.
I was interested in the editorial in THE TIMES of March 11 entitled "Highway Needs."

ALBANY, March 19 -- The Public Service Commission called today upon public utilities not to yield to the natural temptation to increase dividend rates too greatly during the war boom, because plants and facilities, strained by the volume and pressure of war work, must be rehabilitated on the return of peace.

The annuhl service for the dead of the New York Chapter of the Sons of the American Revolution was held yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street. Three of the twenty-two who died last year were killed in action.

MERIDEN, Conn., March 19 -- This city of 45,000, designated by the War Manpower Commission as "the nation's ideal war community,'' was all excited today in anticipation of tomorrow's celebration, which will include a broadcast address by Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the WMC, and the first showing of a special film, "Main Street Today."

WASHINGTON, March 19 (U.P.) -- Senator Walter F. George of Georgia said tonight that the Senate Finance Committee intends to work out a further tax-simplification feature, one which would eliminate or ease the task of filing quarterly estimates on future income and taxes.

De Paul having proved its right to be rated the favorite in the seventh annual national invitation basketball tournament last Thursday night, it will be up to the remaining quintets in the competition to disprove such claims tonight at Madison Square Garden, where the quarter-final round will be completed.

A UNITED STATES FIGHTER BASE, England, March 19 (AP) -- Rather than sweep in for the kill themselves, two American aces who together have destroyed sixteen German planes stayed "upstairs" and coached Lieut. Edward F. Fox of Muskogee, Okla., while he bagged his first German plane, it was announced today.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

MOSCOW, Monday, March 20 -The Red Army has cleared the Germans from a sixty-two-mile section of the east bank of the Dniester River, driving up to the suburbs of Mogilev-Podolski and sweeping across the broad, swift stream on a thirty-one-mile front.

Spring will officially arrive at 1:49 o'clock (Eastern War Time) this afternoon to find a "welcome mat" of snow covering the city, according to the somewhat harried weather man, who last night was bemoaning that he had everything ready to start his victory garden.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, March 20 (AP) -- The cavalrymen who seized Lorengau with Allied air and naval ship support already had captured Los Negros Island, adjacent to Manus to the east. They landed on Los Negros Feb. 29, quickly captured Momote airdrome and then with reinforcements conquered the remainder of that island.

A four-alarm fire, with shooting flames and dense smoke, burned the roof and top floors of the six-story brick apartment house at 131-141 East Twenty-first Street, also known as Kenmore Place, between Caton and Church Avenues, Flatbush, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon. The 173 families in the house were taken out safely in the elevators.

CHICAGO, March 19 -- May wheat developed mild congestion last week on the Board of Trade, advancing to $1.72 1/8 a bushel, or within 1 1/4 cents of the ceiling on futures, and going into the highest ground since Jan. 31, although there was nothing in pit operations to account for the strength.

Builders face the task of supplying more than 1,000,000 new homes a year for ten years after the war, according to the Twentieth Century Fund, which has just completed a survey of the housing problem throughout the country. The research organization predicted that housing requirements after hostilities cease would bring employment and production in the home-construction and related fields beyond anything achieved in the past.

A program of contemporary chamber music was presented by the League of Composers last night at The New York Times Hall, and though much of the music played seemed, to this reviewer, to be of little more than passing interest, there was enough that was worth-while on the program to make the evening a fairly rewarding one.

The forty-fifth annual report of the American Smelting and Refining Company and its subsidiaries, issued for publication today, shows a net income of $11,749,978, after $9,530,061 taxes on income and corporate taxes accrued, not directly charged to operating expenses.

The big issues before the Christian church are the achievement of fellowship among nations and races and fellowship in the distribution of spiritual aid and economic goods, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, Moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, and president of the Union Theological Seminary, said yesterday in a sermon in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street.

CHICAGO, March 19 (AP) -- Goalie Mike Karakas registered his third shutout of the season tonight as the Black Hawks downed the Detroit Red Wings, 2 -- 0, in the closing game of their National Hockey League schedules.
A FOURTEENTH AIR FORCE Base in Southeast China, March 15 (Delayed) -American fliers using P-38 Lightning fighters have found that the average Japanese fighter pilot in China is anything but eager.

The advance in stocks continued last week. In transactions, every five-hour day crossed the million-share mark. Both industrial stocks and railway stocks reached at one time the highest price of 1944, the week's total advance being nearly 1 point and the gain from the lowest of 1944 between 6 and 7 points.

CHICAGO, March 19 (AP) -- Sales and earnings of Montgomery Ward Co., mail-order and retail merchandising concern, declined during 1943 as compared with the preceding year, Sewell Avery, chairman, told stockholders today in the company's annual report.

After moving into new high ground in initial dealings last week cotton prices turned reactionary and fluctuated narrowly throughout the remainder of the period. At the close of trading on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains of 3 to 13 points, with the more distant months showing the most improvement.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices was 112.89, a rise of 0.1 per cent over the previous week's level of 112.84. The farm products index rose 0.4 per cent due to the increases in the prices of apples, hogs and cotton, which were partly offset by decreases in orange and potato prices.

Charles Petremont, 18-year-old violinist from Boston, made his New York debut last night in a recital at Town Hall. He played the Vivaldi Sonata in D major arranged by Respighi, the Brahms D-minor Sonata, Opus 108, the Conus Concerto in E minor, the Chausson "Poeme," Praeludium and Fugue by Kreisler, "Beau Soir" by Debussy, arranged by Heifetz, and "Polonaise Brillante" in D major by Wieniawski.

Lieut. Col. Vincent Sheean, author of "Between the Thunder and the Sun," now in this country on a short leave from active duty on the Italian front, will speak at the Town Hall war correspondents' dinner at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period March 11 to 17 are given in the appended tabulation:

A weather-grayed village depot is a distant relation of a big-town railroad station. But it has an air of comfortable, everyday livability which is difficult to find in a large, hustling, efficient place. A village depot is an adjunct of measured living, not just a spot from which people go in a hurry or to which they come in a rush.

CHUNGKING, China, March 19 -- Last July educated Japanese in Tokyo thought Japan was losing the war, although the uneducated still assumed their country to be victorious, according to Cheu Chien-yuan, a Chinese who attended the Keio University Medical School in Tokyo from June, 1938, to July, 1943, and who has just arrived here.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 19 -- A friendly greeting John Harlan Lindell received from the President of the United States today threw the Yankee training camp into a dither. It was a notice to the 6-foot-4-inch-202-pound pitcher-outfielder to present himself for a pre-induction examination.
NAPLES, March 19 (UP) -- A communique:

LONDON, March 19 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 115.0 on March 7, compared with 115.2 a fortnight before, 115.1 a month before, 113.5 a year ago and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

WITH THE SEVENTH AMERICAN AIR FORCE in the Central Pacific, March 7 -- (Delayed) -- A great many American lives were saved and the Central Pacific timetable undoubtedly was speeded up by the introduction of cannon-carrying Mitchell medium bombers into the Marshall Islands campaign.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- A preliminary examination of the relationship between Certain-teed Products Corporation and the Celotex Corporation in the gypsum industry has recently been made by he anti-trust division of the Department of Justice, it was learned today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 19 -- Paramount has arranged with Cornelia Otis Skinner and Emily Kimbrough to produce a screen sequel to their story "Our Hearts Were Young and Gay," under the title "Our Hearts Were Growing Up."

STE. MARGUERITE, Que., March 19 (Canadian Press) -- It was a United States field day in international skiing at this Laurentian Mountain resort during the week-end as Miss Rebecca Fraser led her team of girl skiers from the eastern United States to victory in downhill and slalom races on near-by Mount Baldy.

Theatre ticket agencies were warned yesterday by Mayor La Guardia that the campaign to prevent them from charging more than the prescribed fees will be speeded up with an appeal to Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr., to direct the Internal Revenue Bureau to cooperate more actively with the city in rounding up law violators.

Landlords here face financial "jeopardy" and the loss of their properties unless allowed to accumulate sufficient reserves to make post-war repairs and replacements, the Office of Price Administration in Washington has been told by the Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee.

After the war we shall need a greatly expanded airport system. This will mean much larger fields for the use of commercial airliners. For the convenience of the private flier a number of interesting plans have been suggested. One of these is an extension of the system of "flight strips."

The most popular size for living rooms, according to Bloomingdale's decorating department, is 28 by 18 feet. That is the size of "The Big Room," a model living room that will be opened in the store today. Its dimensions are those the decorators came across most frequently during months of checking through city apartment buildings and hundreds of suburban homes.
An outstanding opportunity for public service seems to me to exist today. This opportunity calls for a revolution in thinking on the subject of international trade.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- A cautious assurance to civilians that they would be "adequately" fed in 1944 was made by the War Food Administration today in an omnibus 100-page report on the status and objectives of the Government's wartime food program.

On the assumption that President Roosevelt will run again, the right wing of the American Labor party, which controls the State machinery, came out yesterday for Vice President Henry A. Wallace as his running mate. The party leadership likewise pledged support for fourth terms for President Roosevelt and Robert F. Wagner, senior Senator from New York.

DAYTON, Ohio, March 19 -- The Army Air Corps has just ordered more than one hundred thousand of the British quick-release parachutes, regarding which controversy has raged during recent weeks, Drew Pearson, Washington newspaper man, said tonight in a radio broadcast.

LONDON, Monday, March 20 -- In an important pronouncement on the Atlantic Charter the influential Times of London says today that the principle of self-determination sometimes may have to be subordinated to economic and political adjustments to insure "freedom from want" and "freedom from fear."

LONDON, Monday, March 20 (U.P.) -- The German DNB news agency, in a report not confirmed by Moscow, said the Russians were attacking the railroad junction of Kovel, ninety-eight miles inside Poland and 125 miles northwest of Kremenets.

The East River Savings Bank has sold the fourteen-story apartment house at 736 West End Avenue, southeast corner of Ninety-sixth Street, to a syndicate headed by Irving Brodsky, attorney. Assessed at $265,000, the property was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $230,000.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- King Peter of Yugoslavia and Princess Alexandra, daughter of the late King Alexander of Greece, will be married tomorrow in London, the Yugoslav Embassy announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (U.P.) -- The Senate War Contracts subcommittee estimated tonight that 8,000,000 workers would be left jobless when war output ceased, and proposed that the country plan now for a $200,000,000,000 post-war production program assuring a sound economy and employment for all.

An entirely new formula for the fixing of electric power rates -- one which is expected to have far-reaching effects on utility rate regulation -- has been set up by the New Jersey Board of Public Utility Commissioners and the New Jersey Power and Light Company and is expected to be in actual operation within a month.
Except for a narrow price movement in the Canadian free dollar and a modest recovery in the Argentina peso, all other foreign exchanges remained firm on last week's market.

The fiftieth anniversary of the death of Louis Kossuth, Hungarian liberator, was celebrated yesterday afternoon at the Kossuth monument, Riverside Drive and 113th Street, with patriotic exercises under the auspices of the Hungarian American Committee. Five hundred persons braved a biting wind to witness the token presentation of twenty hospital service planes to the United States Army.

CHICAGO, March 19 -- Petitions Congress, signed by 105,000 Negroes and seeking the impeachment of Secretary Stimson and Secretary Knox, will be presented in Washington this week, Edgar G. Brown, director of the National Negro Council, announced today.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The replies of the Governors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut to President Roosevelt's queries on the Federal soldier ballot were as follows:

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 19 -- The mercury almost dropped out of the thermometer today, but the spirit in the Giant training camp fell even lower, for the indicator on fortune's wheel of war has come to a pause opposite the name of Melvin Thomas Ott.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- An ambitious plan to reform the functional processes of Congress is being talked by the Republicans, who confidently expect to win control of the House in the November elections and who also are hopeful of a Senate majority.

The stage at The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, will be transformed into a garden of flowering shrubs and perennials for the second annual Garden Week, which opens on Wednesday afternoon and will continue through Friday afternoon.

The New York region's record of 1,860,000 persons now engaged in manufacturing includes 700,000 in war industry, while the 1,160,000 in the manufacture of civilian goods represent a decrease of only 200,000 from the pre-war level, the Regional Plan Association said yesterday in a report on its survey of the region's economic resources.

The activities of the division of intercourse and education of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, extended and intensified during 1943, met with increasing public interest and support, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, director of the division, declared in his annual report, which was made public yesterday.

Time was when the word Chinese was almost a synonym for pacifistic, submissive, soft, even cowardly. When Theodore Roosevelt used to warn his countrymen that unless they withdrew their objections to a big Army and Navy the country would become "Chinafied" he meant "ignominious," "enslaved'' and not minding slavery.

The approval of the new schedule of admission prices to the race tracks was announced yesterday by the Racing Commission through its chairman, Herbert Bayard Swope. The new list was made necessary by the 100 per cent increase in the Federal tax on amusements. The State tax remains at 15 per cent of the net of the associations.

An interpretation of the amended renegotiation law by the War Contracts Price Adjustment Board of the Army, issued late in the week at Washington, exempts from renegotiation contractors with an annual business of $500,000 or less, and contains provisions which will prevent renegotiators from trimming profits in order to bring business below that figure.

Mayor La Guardia will start today his annual period of retirement to prepare his executive budget for 1944-45, which must be submitted to the Board of Estimate and the City Council not later than April 1.

MERIDEN, Conn., March 20 -Meriden celebrated tonight its designation by the War Manpower Commission as "the nation's ideal war community" in the presence of Chairman Paul V. McNutt. A coast-to-coast radio program carried the official tribute to the city.
LONDON, Tuesday, March 21 (AP) -- The Russian Monday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 20 -- Launching the second week of training for his Yankees in the depressing atmosphere of a snow and rain storm, Manager Joe McCarthy, watching the few veterans and the many yearlings under his charge going through their paces at the armory, frankly admitted today "I have plenty on my mind."

Despite the intercession of the State Department upon the problem of Egyptian import licensing regulations, which place an "unnecessary burden" upon American exporters in dealing with that market, little progress has been made in relaxing such restrictions, traders reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- Income-tax payments still are pouring into the Treasury in record amounts. Today's Treasury statement placed Friday's receipts at $554,000,000, a gain of $29,000,000 over the previous high set only the day before and $101,000,000 above payments recorded on the same day a year ago.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The National War Labor Board failed again today in efforts to decide whether its steel panel should hear arguments of the United Steel Workers (CIO) for a 17-cents-an-hour increase in wages, an increase which would shatter the "Little Steel" formula.

ALGIERS, March 20 -- Both Allied and French circles here were bewildered by what all those consulted today considered accumulating evidence of Allied intentions toward France. This evidence, which some regarded as overwhelming, was taken as presaging a refusal to recognize the Committee of National Liberation as the sole French authority and a decision to leave to the Allied High Command the choice of officials with whom to cooperate in France.

In support of the contention of the right wing State leadership of the American Labor party that opposition in the primary next week would be solely a coalition between Sidney Hillman and Communists, Dean Alfange, right wing campaign manager, made public last night an analysis of the rival slate for Manhattan.

The butcher who wouldn't sell a steak unless two pounds of tripe also were purchased has inspired some imitators in the fashion field, the Office of War Information reported yesterday in a warning to shoppers to guard against tie-in sales on Easter outfits.

MOSCOW, March 20 -- The main editorial in Pravda notes that the German Army destroyed in the region of Nikolayev recently bore the name of Sixth Army, the same as that of the army that was destroyed at Stalingrad in February of last year in a battle that now is regarded as the military turning point of the war.

NAPLES, Italy, March 20 -- The Allied Control Commission took an important step in the elimination of what might be called "industrial Fascists" from the current Italian scene when Lieut. Col. Charles Poletti as Allied Military Government Regional Commissioner for this city today ordered four directors of the Manifatture Contoniere Meridionali removed and two others arrested.
An increase in crime after peace comes, due directly to the war, was predicted yesterday by E.E. Conroy, head of the local office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

Formation of a committee on public affairs in the New York County Democratic organization to undertake the development of a long-range planning program for New York City and to frame a plan for the immediate post-war period was announced yesterday by Edward V. Loughlin, leader of Tammany Hall.

The spring collection presented yesterday by Carrie Munn stressed fashions for the woman with a flair for chic. A faille suit demonstrated its versatility for day and evening when teamed with accessories that changed its character completely.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -Senator Pat McCarran, Nevada Democrat, long an advocate of American supremacy in air commerce, proposed today creation of a $1,000,000,000 All American Flag Line to place the United States in top position in the world field after the war.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 20 -- The people of Finland plod through each day with grim, unsmiling faces, plainly showing the results of years of wartime strain, hardship and sacrifice. They give the impression of worry-but this should not be interpreted as a sign of moral collapse.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast fro Moscow to the Soviet Union and reporteg by tle Federal Commuzicatioz$ Commi$$io :

The Board of Higher Education named last night a committee of three of its members to hear charges against Seymour S. Leikind, chemistry tutor at Brooklyn College, accused by Harry D. Gideonse, president of the college, of irresponsible statements in asserting that there were "zealous official efforts to conceal undercover communistic activities at the college."

After slight early losses in trading yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange futures recovered and closed at the best levels of the day, 4 to 7 points net higher on active months. A report that the cotton acreage might be smaller than last year and the discounts at which new-crop months were selling under the old attracted new commission-house buying, especially in the March.

Industry must evolve means to ascertain vital facts relative to its management by adopting modern methods of internal control or face the possibility that government agencies will uncover these facts prematurely, William H. Garbade, president of the Institute of Internal Auditors and auditing manager of the Shell Oil Company, declared last night.

A new guide containing suggestions for the advertisers who desire to cooperate in the campaign to expand the use of V-Mail has been released by the War Advertising Council in conjunction with the Office of War Information. It describes the way in which V-Mail is handled and points out that such letters always are sent by air.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- When the history is written of the part played by the United States in the Second World War one of the most important and interesting sections will be that devoted to the production, allocation, loading and other forms of control of American shipping, without which the Axis would have won the conflict in its early stages.

LONDON, Tuesday, March 21 (U.P.) -- Moscow's broadcast communiques revealed that the Russians had captured more than 120 towns and settlements yesterday on five sectors of the front, along which Moscow dispatches said the German commander, Field Marshal Gen. Fritz Erich von Mannstein, was faced with the task of finding fresh armies to halt the Soviet tide.
LONDON, March 20 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 20 -- Old Man Winter plumped right down in the lap of spring last night, covering Bear Mountain and the adjoining terrain with six inches of snow, and knocking into a cocked hat Manager Leo Durocher's tentative plans for exercise on the diamond laid out near the inn.

Prime Minister de Valera's opening remarks in his St. Patrick's Day address were in the old Irish tongue -- "the national language in which I began this broadcast," he said later on. It was the same national language, said Mr. de Valera, in which St. Patrick expounded the Christian faith to the Irish people 1,500 years ago.

"See Here, Private Hargrove," Metro's screen version of the book by Sgt. Marion Hargrove, will have its local premiere tonight at the Astor. The opening will augment the Red Cross drive, which starts in the nation's theatres on Thursday.
NEW DELHI, India, March 20 (UP) -- A communique:

A Frenchman long known as an "arch collaborationist" died yesterday in Algiers before a firing squad, giving with his own lips the order that made the rifles bark. This man was Pierre Pucheu, once powerful in French politics, once Minister of Interior in the Vichy Government, now condemned to death by a special military tribunal on charges of collusion with the enemy amounting to treason to his country.

The Book of the Month Club announces two novels as its dual selection for June: H.E. Bates' "Fair Stood the Wind for France," to be published by Atlantic-Little, Brown, and "Lost Island," by James Norman Hall, also an Atlantic-Little, Brown book.

Stevie, thin-faced and sad-eyed, sat in his high chair at noon yesterday in a large infants' nursery on West 144th Street. There were six other babies in the room, three of them squalling lustily. Stevie didn't cry or play; he just sat and stared.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Miami Beach, where for the last two years hundreds of thousands of Air Force officers and men have been trained amid surroundings of luxury for the grim business of aerial warfare, is being virtually given back to the civilians.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -The Agriculture Department reported today that 1944 crop plantings, reflecting the farmers' concern over labor and machine shortages, might fall short of Government goals on many foods, and the wheat crop might be the smallest since 1939.

IN "Hour of Triumph"* Major George Fielding Eliot, hitherto known as a military expert, ventures well over the borderline into political commentary. His instinct is sound, for the basic military decision has already been reached: Germany and Japan have failed in their objective, which was to break out of Europe and East Asia to dominate the globe.

It was token of the potency of the music and of Artur Schnabel's position as an interpreter in the public esteem that last night, in spite of wading weather, Carnegie Hall was filled for the first of his series of three recitals of Beethoven sonatas.

LONDON, March 20 (U.P.) -- Field Marshal Baron Maximilian von Weichs, commander of the Nazi Balkan armies, has launched a new offensive in eastern Bosnia in a renewal of heavy fighting for strategic communications throughout Yugoslavia, a Partisan headquarters communique reported today.

Today's events: Recital by Margaret Brady, soprano, Town Hall, 3 P.M.; concert, Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conducting, Alexander Brailowsky, pianist, Westminster Choir and Ellen Faull, soprano, assisting artists, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; recital, Carole d'Arcy, soprano, Town Hall, 8:30; concert, Brooklyn Chamber Music Society, Brooklyn Academy, 8:30.

Your editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Monday, March 6, entitled "Helping the Veteran" has my complete agreement and recalls some of my experiences while I served as Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity under the late Mayor Gaynor, in coping with the difficulties created by similar legislation as well-intentioned and as misguided as the Hampton-Devaney bill.

ALBANY, March 20 -- Mayor La Guardia's statement in his Sunday radio talk, that bills were killed at the last session of the Legislature because of personal animosity to him met with official silence today. Actually it has been an open secret for several years that a substantial number of individual up-State Republicans need very little encouragement to join with the Democrats in opposing some of the Mayor's personally sponsored legislation.
Four inches of snow blanketed the city at 1:49 P.M., Eastern War Time, yesterday as spring arrived. It was one of the wintriest arrivals of the vernal season in many years.
The cancellation of three licenses and the suspension of eight others were announced yesterday by the New York State Liquor Authority.

OTTAWA, March 20 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. H.D.G. Crerar, who has been commanding the First Canadian Army Corps with the British Eighth Army in Italy, has been appointed commander of the First Canadian Army in England, it was announced today by Defense Minister Ralston.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores rose 17 per cent last week over the like week of 1943, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the previous week the bank had reported a rise of 8 per cent.
Wayne T. Lonergan's trial for the murder of his wife, Patricia Burton Lonergan, got briskly under way in General Sessions Court yesterday with the selection of three jurors before the noon recess.

The establishment of a board of trustees of five members for each of the four city colleges was proposed yesterday by Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College. This suggestion came after his disapproval of the recent report by Dr. George D. Strayer's subcommittee of the Rapp-Coudert committee recommending reorganization of the Board of Higher Education.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -Sidney Scheuer, executive director of the FEA bureau of supplies, told a House Agriculture subcommittee today the agency had bought 2,500,000 pounds of Iceland wools and stood to lose $100,000 on the transaction.
The annual report of the Aetna Life Insurance Company for 1943 shows new business of $140,927,814, which is $6,700,494 less than in 1942, while insurance in force rose $41,980,602 to $1,918,846,373.

A new demand for creation of an all-Jewish military unit in time to play a role in the "invasion and liberation of Europe" has been made to the Governments of the United States and Great Britain by the semi-official Jewish Agency for Palestine, it was revealed yesterday by Dr. Nahum Goldmann, the organization's political representative in this country and the chairman of the administrative committee of the World Jewish Congress.

A $32,917,656 secondary offering of 704,121 common shares of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company was made yesterday after the close of trading on the New York Stock Exchange by Blyth Co., Inc., and associates at 46 3/4 net, and was oversubscribed by 5 P.M., according to preliminary estimates by the bankers.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -An Army ground forces observer reported today that Americans fighting in Italy were facing "a first-class army" of smart Germans who were using a terrain well suited to defense.

When Kipling wrote of the "Fuzzy Wuzzies" he was not describing the natives of Britain's principal Pacific colony, the once cannibal isles of the Fijis, but he might have been. The Fijian's kinky hair, worn in that fashion for protection against the sun, makes the name fit him as a cartridge does its chamber.

The DeWitt Clinton, Hudson River excursion steamer whose name thousands of New Yorkers associate with memories of happy summer cruises, has returned to battle service and is once more an Allied troop transport.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The Navy announced today the losses of the destroyer-escort Leopold in the Atlantic and the Macaw, an auxiliary submarine rescue vessel, in the Pacific, bringing to 146 the announced total of naval vessels lost in the war.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 20 -- Hugh R. Jackson, United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Association director general for regional liaison, said today that he would proceed immediately with conferences planned for former Governor Herbert H. Lehman with representatives of British, American, Egyptian and Balkan Governments. It had previously been announced that Mr. Lehman's visit here had been indefinitely postponed because of a knee injury suffered in Algiers.

LONDON, March 20 -- All sections of the stock market here were cheerful today under the influence of the latest war news, the best feature being a showing of strength by the Argentine rails, in which group rises of 1/2 to 1 1/2 were recorded.

NAPLES, March 20 -- On the principle that a stolen Army truck can bring $1,000 profit within three hours regardless of its contents, organized gangs of thieves, working in conjunction with the black market, are posing a terrific problem for Allied military authorities here and draining hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of supplies away from the war effort.

CLEVELAND, March 20 -- The Warner Swasey Company, which was assessed $5,000,000 by the War Department as a result of renegotiation of its 1942, operations, has filed a suit in United States District Court for the District of Columbia to obtain a ruling as to the proper construction of an amendment to the Renegotiation Law, it was announced today.

A crisis in the shipping container situation is fast approaching in the toilet goods industry, it was reported here yesterday. Unless some relief is obtained, according to manufacturers, maintenance of retailers' day-to-day stocks will be crippled and shipments of holiday lines, which start in May, will be affected gravely.

The Oklahoma Natural Gas Company will offer at competitive bidding on March 28 a new issue of $18,000,000 of first mortgage bonds and 180,000 shares of Series A $50 par value preferred stock and yesterday at least four underwriting groups were reported formed to bid on these securities.

LONDON, March 20 -- The steady disintegration of the center of the German line in southern Russia has reawakened the hopes of British military observers that the Soviet armies will force the enemy to divide the southern group of armies defending the Balkans.

Toy dolls, washboards, trains, beds and other toys, made by the children of the Walden School, 1 West Eighty-eighth Street, were delivered yesterday by a committee of five children to the Lenox Hill Neighborhood House nursery, at 351 East Seventieth Street.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 20 -- Marsha Hunt, who has just returned from an Alaskan Army camp tour, has been borrowed by RKO from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for the second lead of "That Hunter Girl." Allyn Joslyn and Edgar Buchanan will also play in the comedy.

WITH STILWELL'S CHINESE-AMERICAN FORCES, in North Burma, March 19 (Delayed) -- Chinese troops captured Jambu Bum (mountain) today and marched out of the Hukawng Valley, crossing the divide separating Hukawng from the Mogaung Valley.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP)--Senator McCarran's proposed $1,000,000,000 air company to carry the American flag abroad resembles a plan which Pan American Airways, Inc., is understood to favor and which is opposed by all but one of the American air carriers.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 20 (AP) -- Marching home with his second 66 of the tournament, Soldier Dutch Harrison converted the $10,000 Charlotte Open into a one-man show today and took a four-stroke lead at the three-quarter mark of the 72-hole golf event with a total of 202.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, March 21 (UP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Executive action within a day or two defining the status of men 18 to 26 years of age as between industrial requirements and military service was predicted today in informed quarters here.

A new exhibition opens to the public today at the Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street. It contains work in various media acquired in the last couple of years and also much material that had entered the permanent collection previously. The exhibition will continue through April. Museum hours: 1 to 5 P.M. Tuesdays through Sundays.

LONDON, Tuesday, March 21 (AP) -- A Reuter dispatch from Stockholm today said the Helsinki radio broadcast today a Finnish communique saying the Government had found itself unable to accept Soviet Russia's armistice terms.

Indictments for extortion against Solomon Massarsky, general manager of the Congress of Industrial Unions, were dismissed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Morris Eder, who granted a writ of habeas corpus for the labor leader and held that "the indictments and prosecution are wholly without lawful warrant or authority and are null and void."

ANKARA, Turkey, March 20 -- It is now revealed that Marshal Ion Antonescu's main purpose in sending peace envoys to Turkey and Cairo is to try to persuade the British or Americans to grant refuge to him either in Britain or the United States if the Russians invade old Rumania.
Mr. Paul Windels has asked for a fair discussion of the five-cent fare on New York subways, as reported in your columns.

Five new appointments to the medical faculty of Columbia University were announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university. The new members are: Samuel Gelfan, assistant professor of physiology; Wendell Hughes, associate clinical professor of ophthalmology; Willis J. Knighton, associate clinical professor of ophthalmology; Edgar M. Medlar, associate professor of pathology, and Maxwell D. Ryan, associate clinical professor of otolaryngology.

The eleven-story office and showroom building at 33 Union Square has been purchased by Thomas Moffa, operator, from the Eclipse Management Company (Henry Hof, president). This building is on a plot 30 by 150 feet and is assessed for $150,000.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 20 -- Balked by Federal opposition to the levying of general tolls on Westchester parkways, County Executive Herbert C.
