Gerlach said this afternoon that he would go to Washington to urge the Pubic Roads Administration of the Department of Agriculture to withdraw the objections.

LONDON, March 20 -- Without waiting for the formal approval of three great allied powers the exiled Governments in London are hastening to complete the organization of civil affairs units that will take over the administration of their homelands as they are liberated in the coming invasion.

ALGIERS, March 20 -- Declining to be blindfolded and himself shouting the command to fire, Pierre Pucheu, former Vichy Interior Minister, died at dawn today as a firing squad carried out the sentence of a special French military tribunal that had found him guilty of treason.

Rolling forward along the whole 500-mile front from the Pripet Marshes to the estuary of the Ukrainian Bug River, the tireless Russian armies continue to pursue the beaten German forces in a fashion which begins to resemble the spectacular German advance in France in 1940.

LONDON, March 20 -- The most extensive and most restrictive coastal ban of the war, which Britain hopes will be the last, was imposed by the War Office today, to be effective from April 1 "for operational reasons."

The State of California Veterans Welfare Board will offer for sale on March 22 a block of $3,400,000 of the board's own bonds now held in its investment portfolio. The bonds carry coupons ranging from 2 1/4 to 4 1/2 per cent and mature from Feb. 1, 1946, to 1956.

Two communities in Queens, Malba and Regency Park, gained the distinction yesterday of being the first in the entire city to attain their quotas in the 1944 Red Cross War Fund drive, it was announced yesterday at the city-wide headquarters of the campaign at 130 West Forty-second Street, where the effort to raise $22,386,000 in the city is being directed.

In an effort to facilitate stabilization of employment where employers appeal statements of availability granted to employes by the Employment Service of the War Manpower Commission or other designated agencies, the area management labor manpower committee of the WMC voted yesterday to put into effect on March 27 a new regulation affecting appeal procedures.

Four shows already are listed to arrive here the week of April 2 and there is a possibility of a fifth. It's 'I'll Be Seein' You." The premiere of the George Seaton comedy had been announced for April 11 at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre, but advance reports have been so encouraging that John Golden, co-producer, is being urged to bring the play here either on Monday night, April 3, or Friday night, April 7.

LONDON, March 20 (AP) -- Lieut. John Cary Morgan, Amarillo, Texas, pilot who received the Congressional Medal of Honor for fighting a dying pilot away from a bomber's controls to complete the mission and bring the crippled plane home, is missing from a recent Berlin attack, United States headquarters announced today.

A concert in honor of the people of France, one of three "Concert-Salutes," was given at the French Institute last night, under the direction of Lazare Saminsky, with Sir Thomas Beecham as guest conductor. The concert was presented under the auspices of Congregation Emanu-el and its choir committee and the American Friends Service Committee.

The Prudential Insurance Company of America has sold the two walk-ups in New Rochelle, Westchester County, 110-20 Stonelea Place, known as Pinebrook Lodge, and 435-39 Webster Avenue, known as Webster Gardens.

The five-story modern apartment house on a plot 32 by 100 feet at 430 East Eighty-seventh Street in the Yorkville section has been sold by Sterner Estates, Inc., (Eric Sterner, president), to a client of J.W. Gerrish, broker, for cash above a first mortgage of $34,000 held by the Central Savings Bank.

AN ADVANCED NEW GUINEA AIR BASE, Tuesday, March 21 (AP) -- The air-sea battle off the New Guinea coast that cost the Japanese five ships began last Wednesday night, ninety miles northwest of Hollandia and ended late Sunday afternoon forty miles off the coast of Wewak, which is 250 statute miles southeast of Hollandia, as the last battered Japanese ship went down before the hard blows of thirty-five low-flying medium and light bombers.

Profit taking struck the higher-price railroad issues and produced yesterday an irregularly lower trend in the stock market, with losses fairly widespread. Technical observers felt that some of the carriers had pushed ahead too fast to find immediate confirmation from the remainder of the list, and this factor was set down by brokers as the major contribution for the selling, although the low-price rails showed independent strength.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -A proposal to revive and expand Federal crop insurance was submitted to Congress today by Representative Hampton P. Fulmer, chairman of the House Agriculture Committee.

Armed with cameras and butterfly nets, fifteen Boy Scouts of the Kips Bay Boys Club dug through four inches of snow and sleet yesterday and found sure signs that spring had arrived. The occasion was the seventeenth annual First Day of Spring Field Expedition to the New Jersey section of the Palisades Interstate Park.

The two-story business building 50 by 100 feet at 251 Nineteenth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Figge Hutwelker Company, Inc., pork packers and provisioners, to the Postpar Products Company, headed by Henrik Ipsen. Frank W. Harris was the attorney for the seller.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -Thirteen Democrats joined twenty-five Republicans in the Senate today in voting to put further curbs upon some war functions of the Federal Communications Commission.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- A Senate Interstate Commerce subcommittee sought new means today of forcing James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, to lift his ban on radio broadcasts by school orchestras and bands.

LONDON, March 20 -- The long-awaited and often-postponed weding of King Peter of Yugoslavia and Princess Alexandra of Greece, one that may further stir up political developments in the Balkans, took place today at the Yugoslav Legation amid circumstances unique even to royal-wedding conscious London.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 20 -- German troops were reported tonight to have marched into Hungary in a move to prop Adolf Hitler's weakened southeastern flank. The Germans acted after a demand for more aid against the advancing Russian armies had been refused by Hungary's leaders, it was reported here.
PASSAIC, N.J., March 20 -- Survivors of the Comfort Line bus who miraculously escaped death when it crashed into the Passaic River told late today their stories of the crash and of their rescue.

The upshot of the so-called soldier-vote compromise, as ascertained by replies to the President's telegram of inquiry to the Governors, is that fewer than half the States will make any use of the Federal ballot. Almost all of them have or will have absentee-voting provisions of their own.

BERKELEY, Calif., March 20 -Mrs. Pauline Venard, University of California junior who has offered to give one of her eyes to an American soldier blinded by shell fragments, told reporters today that she should think any one would give an eye if they had two and someone else did not have any.

CHICAGO, March 20 (AP) -- Eugene Casey, an executive assistant to President Roosevelt, stated tonight that Americans can enjoy economic security after the war, but "it will take the same courage and enterprise that brought this country out of its worst depression in history."

Ending a protracted monthly decline in comparison with the preceding year inventories of New York City department stores at the end of February were 12 per cent higher than on the same date in 1943, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Substantial progress in production and delivery of component parts for essential war materials, and for facilities producing these materials, was reported today by the War Production Board.

All of us have forgiven the obliquity of the ecliptic and as friends of equality look kindly on the equinoxes, and especially on the vernal equinox. Yet the descriptive adjective may be deceptive and the alternative name for the spring crossing, First Point of Aries, is grossly false.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -The Census Bureau reported today in its last ginning report on the 1943 cotton crop that 11,120,512 running bales, or 11,420,561 equivalent 500-pound bales of cotton, exclusive of linters, had been ginned.
PASSAIC, N.J., March 20 -- The dead in the Passaic River bus crash today were:

Another defeat for Communists in their efforts to capture administrative positions in the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, headed by David Dubinsky, was recorded yesterday with announcement of the results of elections in the cutters' union, an I.L.G.W.U. affiliate.

From Elizabeth Bowen's novel, "The House in Paris," E. Mawby Green and Edward Allen Feilbert have taken a play of the same name, which opened last evening at the Fulton but did not get anywhere in particular. The novel was one of mood; the play is one of words.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended March 15:
BOSTON, March 20 (U.P.) -- The new novel "Strange Fruit," which Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt termed "a very moving book and an extraordinary one," has been banned in Boston because of obscene language.

The great majority of boys and girls picked up on charges of juvenile delinquency in the Eighteenth Patrol Precinct, which includes the Times Square area, come from other parts of the city and from outside New York, it was revealed yesterday by a spokesman for Robert Christenberry, executive chairman of the Coordinating Council of the Eighteenth Precinct.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, March 21 -- The Red Army, smashing forward on six sectors in the Ukraine and in Bessarabia, yesterday captured the important industrial and railroad center of Vinnitsa, the Dniester River city of Mogilev-Podolski and 115 other populated points, further reducing the chances of any large-scale withdrawal of German troops remaining in southern Russia.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 20 (AP) -- A new German-Turkish commercial treaty has been concluded that, according to the best information here, calls for an exchange amounting to 14,000,000 Turkish liras.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20 -- A brief charging that Judge Robert M. Pollard of the Federal District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia erred and abused his discretion in refusing to order an investigation of the affairs of the Central States Electric Corporation was filed today by the Securities and Exchange Commission in the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals in Richmond.

CHICAGO, March 20 -- The grain markets made an easy start and a firm close today on the Board of Trade. Trading in rye overshadowed operations in other grains, prices breaking around 1 cent early on selling attributed to professional traders and on reports that a large holding of cash rye was available for purchase if it was needed.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -Asserting that "very serious and difficult problems" dealing with military planning would confront the nation after the war, Secretary of the Navy Knox endorsed today legislation to set up a special Congressional post-war military planning committee.

PEARL HARBOR, March 20 -Pacific Fleet battleships and carrier planes shelled and bombed Mili, one of the four remaining Japanese major bases in the Marshall Islands, on Saturday, headquarters of Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, announced today.

HEADQUARTERS, ELEVENTH UNITED STATES ARMY AIR FORCE, March 16 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The Army Liberator bombers that attacked Matsuwa Island in the Kuriles today caught the Japanese completely by surprise, an Eleventh Air Force headquarters announcement said.

The increase of the subway fare to ten cents will benefit a small group of real estate owners by means of a reduction of real estate taxes, and no one else. True, the owner of a one or two family house will also get a tax reduction, but the extent of it will not equal the expenditure for increased fare.

Ariana Bronstein, 18-year-old New York-born violinist, who had appeared at both Carnegie Hall and Town Hall, gave a recital last night at the latter auditorium before a large and appreciative audience. Miss Bronstein, whose only teacher has been her father, Raphael Bronstein, plays exceptionally well, although she can scarcely be said to have "arrived" as an important concert artist.

AT A CHANNEL PORT IN ENGLAND, March 20 -- If there is any doubt of what happened to the once high-flying Brooklyn Dodgers baseball team, you could have heard it settled in this little Channel town last Saturday night.
The Mayor in a recent broadcast said that New York real estate men are trying to create a bear market.

All signs to the contrary notwithstanding, spring arrived at 1:49 P.M. yesterday. Today, at the start of the new season, we pause to review the old one, and to mention some of the outstanding good products discussed in this column during the past winter.
A new museum is to be built in Fifth Avenue to house the collection of non-objective art of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, which now has galleries at 24 East Fifty-fourth Street.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY AT CASSINO, March 20 -- New Zealand infantry, including brown-skinned guttural Maoris, smashed into the battered Continental Hotel on the southern outskirts of Casino after it was thoroughly blasted by tanks and artillery and thus eliminated an important German strongpoint in this weird and terribly intimate battle.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -W.L. Clayton, Federal Surplus Property Administrator, said today that he had the power and intended to use it to put a stop to loose disposition of excess government-owned materials and to bring about coordination among the numerous agencies involved.

The six-story apartment house at 36-19 Bowne Street, Flushing, Queens, has been sold by the 36-19 Bowne Street Corporation to Charles Walzer, operator. Sale was subject to a mortgage of $332,250 and the property was immediately resold by the buyer to Harry Lefrak.

LONDON, March 20 -- German military occupation of Hungary, reported from neutral capitals tonight, was regarded here as a military step essential for the defense of Rumania and as a political gesture intended to discourage any other satellite states from toying with ideas of a separate peace.

Shouting that she was a patriotic American, Mrs. Mary Costa, 56 years, 236 East Fifty-ninth Street, was sent to jail for five days yesterday when she refused to pay a $25 fine assessed by Magistrate Morris Rothenberg for charging 42 cents more than the ceiling price for a pound and four ounces of meat.

Service women of the Waves, Wacs, Spars and Marine Corps led the Fashion Academy's list of the best-dressed women of the country when awards to the winners were presented yesterday at a tea held at the Cafe du Bois, with Emil Alvin Hartman, director of the academy, officiating at the presentation.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 20 -The vexing problem of "who's on first," which plagued Mel Ott during most of last season reared its head again today as Phil Weintraub hurriedly packed his grip and made a hasty departure for Chicago.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, March 21 -- Hundreds of Japanese perished when more than a hundred American land-based bombers sank an entire convoy consisting of two transports of 6,000 and 4,000 tons and three corvettes apparently carrying troop replacements to Wewak, Gen. Douglas MacArthur reported today.

The chief problem faced by this country is now public opinion and the representatives of public opinion can move forward "on a program of action for world organization for the maintenance of security and an expanding economy," Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, said yesterday.

The Continental Oil Company reported yesterday for 1943 a consolidated net income of $14,080,702 after charges, taxes and reserves, including a provision of $1,200,000 for the cost of changing from wartime to peacetime operations. This was equal to $3 each on the 4,682,561 capital shares outstanding.

New York City's school administrators hailed yesterday the last-minute action of the State Assembly in passing the Coudert bill, which virtually abolishes the Board of Superintendents, while teachers' groups vigorously condemned not only the measure but the methods used to put it through the Legislature.
The Regional Office of Price Administration disclosed yesterday that it had initiated a check on New York motorists in Florida and that it expected soon to make a public announcement about them.
FRENCH LICK, Ind., March 20 (AP) -- The pitching staff of the Chicago Cubs received two staggering blows today.

An application for a permanent injunction restraining the Sylvania Electric Prodoucts Company, Inc., from erecting an office building and laboratory on property fronting on the Cross Island Parkway near Little Neck Bay in Bayside, L.I., was denied yesterday by Justice Charles W. Froessel in the special term of the Queens Supreme Court and the complaint dismissed.

SAN SEBATIANO, Italy, Tuesday, March 21 -- At 12:30 o'clock this morning a giant tongue of lava from Vesuvius crashed into the stone house where Giuseppe Battaglio has lived for years with his wife, Maria, and their six children.

The 1943 annual report of the United Gas Improvement Company and subsidiaries, released yesterday, shows a consolidated net income for the year of $10,735,324 after expenses and charges. This was equal, after preferred dividend charges, to 38 cents a share on the outstanding common stock, and compares with $15,838,818, or 52 cents a common share, in 1942.

PASSAIC, N.J., March 20 -- As the twisted, water-soaked wreckage of a bus used to transport war workers here was lifted from the Passaic River shortly before 10 o'clock tonight, a toll of thirteen dead was counted in one of the worst such tragedies recorded in this State.

Appreciable conservation of shipping space vital to the war effort can be effected by the dehydration of foods shipped to the armed forces overseas and to other recipients among the United Nations, A.A. Giannini of the Carrier Corporation declared last night in an address before a meeting of the metropolitan section of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers at 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

The defense of Lieut. (j.g.) Adam Rother of the Coast Guard, on trial for the murder of Miss Rita Costello, 28-year-old secretary, opened yesterday before Judge Thomas J. Walsh and a jury in Richmond County Court.

LONDON, March, 20 -- Between 250 and 500 Flying Fortresses and Liberators of the United States Eighth Air Force, escorted by 500 to 750 Thunderbolt, Lightning and Mustang fighters, hammered targets in the area of Frankfort on the Main today.

The report for 1943 of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., released for publication today, shows a consolidated net profit of $31,127,204 in United States currency after all charges, taxes and reserves, equal, after preferred dividend payments, to $2 each on the 14,584,025 common shares outstanding.

MESSRS. FRED MANDEL of the Detroit Lions and Harry Thayer of the Philadelphia Eagles have proposed that the coaches of the National Football League be permitted to have sideline assistants who will transmit signals from the master-minds on the bench to the quarterbacks on the field. If the coaches have any sense -- which they have -- they will fight this fiendish suggestion to the bitter end.

A month and a half ago Allied troops penetrated the outskirts of Cassino. Today we are still fighting in the outskirts, though now on the other side of the town. If anyone thinks the German will to fight has been shaken let him consider the prolonged and savage battle we have been forced to fight to win those few miles of blasted rubble.
Our City Center of Music and Art is truly reaching an entirely new audience, as was stated in an article in the Magazine section of THE TIMES last Sunday.
fajor Arthur A. Houghton, US, and Mrs. Houghton have arrived from their home in Queens.own, 1VioL, and are at the SavoyPlaza.

It will be Kentucky vs. St. John's and the Oklahoma Aggies vs. De Paul in tomorrow night's semi-final round of the seventh annual national invitation college basketball tournament. For last night, before a crowd of 16,273 at Madison Square Garden, the Wildcats of Kentucky and the Aggies came through as expected in their quarter-final encounters.

LONDON, March 20 (AP) -- Five members of the exiled Polish National Council raised the question today whether the provisions of the Atlantic Charter applied to Poland in her boundary dispute with Russia.

MEXICO CITY, March 20 -- Ambassador George S. Messersmith indicated today that the Mexican Government was studying the possibility of asking American experts and capital to cooperate in oil exploration and production.

Though Secretary Stimson points out that the Burma campaign is being fought for limited objectives, fighting has spread over a 700-mile front and developed certain spectacular aspects unmatched in any other theatre of the war. Moreover, Japanese objectives may not be so limited.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 21 (AP) -- Superior Court Judge William H. Comley, branding the plaintiff's case "preposterous," dismissed from the bench today the $50,000 alienation of affections suit brought by Paul Zanowiak, 60-year-old factory worker of Union City, N.J., against John H. Hill, 80, of Shelton, former State Republican leader.

SOME spy novels are only that, melodramatic thrillers that tell of dashing supermen who foil and thwart the dastardly and chuckleheaded Nazis with consummate ease. Their grisly violence and gory brutality are not in themselves improbable in these cataclysmic days when nothing is improbable. The tragic suffering that now engulfs so much of the world has not excluded opportunities for personal heroism, romantic feats of daring and sinister intrigue.

CHICAGO, March 21 -- May wheat showed increased tightness today on the Board of Trade, advancing 3/8 cent at one time to $1.73 1/8 a bushel, or within 1/4 cent of the ceiling price. Short covering and closing of spreads were noted.

According to Senator Clark of Idaho, Congress is "thoroughly out of sympathy" with Mr. Petrillo and wants to curb his extraordinary and irresponsible private power to order people off the air and tell the American public what music it can and cannot hear, but it doesn't know how.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The foreign policy of the United States was defined by Secretary of State Cordell Hull tonight in terms of our fundamental national interests and our responsibility for cooperating with other nations in a statement issued through the State Department.

LONDON, March 21 (AP) -- Adolf Hitler was reported maneuvering to establish a Quisling regime in Hungary tonight as a Nazi army of 100,000 men ranned out over the troubled nation and seized all rail junctions and other communications centers.

LONDON, March 21 -- Finland announced the rejection of the Russian armistice terms today and a few hours later an official Soviet statement broadcast from Moscow declared that the refusal placed full responsibility for the consequences on the Fin nish Government. Together the two declarations indicated a complete and final breakdown in peace negotiations.

The Southern Pacific Company, in 1943, reduced its outstanding debt by $49,361,147 and also made provision for the payment on Jan. 1, last, of all its outstanding $29,009,000 of 3 3/4 per cent ten-year secured bonds, due July 1, 1946, according to A.T. Mercier, president.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The State Department emphatically denied today reports from Algiers, said to have been based on views expressed in French official circles, that the United States might collaborate with officials of the Vichy regime as well as with the French Committee of National Liberation in the administration of liberated France.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The biggest problem of the Surplus War Property Administration which was set up as a result of the Baruch-Hancock report will be raised by industrial and labor pressure groups opposing sale of any Government surpluses because they may compete with new production, Will L. Clayton, head of the new agency, asserted today.

The State Department denied yesterday, with more than its usual vehemence, the truth of reports emanating from Algiers to the effect that our Government intends to deal again with Vichy when France is liberated. The Department described these reports as "absurd" and "evidently inspired."

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The Senate Military Affairs Committee tabled today, by 14 to 4, legislation designed to prevent the promotion of any regular Army officers to permanent grades above colonelcy for the duration of the war.

CERCOLA, Italy, March 21 -Smashing through San Sebastino and Massa di Somma on a broadening, though generally slowing, front, the Vesuvian lava flow tonight had resulted in complete evacuation of this town of 7,000, two miles to the northwest.

PEARL HARBOR, March 21 (U.P.) -- Army, Navy and Marine planes of the Central Pacific Command teamed on Sunday and attacked four Japanese positions in the Marshall Islands, running to ninety-five the number of separate air assaults so far this month.

Interest in the second annual Garden Week, which opens at 2 o'clock this afternoon at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, is so great that the Friday afternoon session on flower arrangements has been completely sold out.
NEW DELHI, India, March 21 (U.P.) -- Japanese troops have driven in force to within less than fifteen miles of the Indian border, Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten's headquarters announced today.

The 1944 War Fund campaign of the American Red Cross has passed the half-way mark in its drive for $200,000,000, it was announced yesterday in Washington by Leon Fraser, national campaign chairman. The public was warned, however, that it must quicken its response if the remaining $100,000,000 is to be collected within "a reasonable time."

Among those reported yesterday as having leased apartments was H.W. Hirs, vice consul of Switzerland, who took a six-room suite at 1045 Park Avenue through the M. Morgenthau-Seixas Company, broker, Other leases included:
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 21 -- What Berlin wants from Hungary was indicated by Wilhelm-strasse statements made today to Swedish newspaper correspondents. The demands are believed to be:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, March 22 -- With planes strafing the beaches before them, United States Marines landed on Emirau Island, potential air and sea base less than 600 miles from Truk, and quickly overran the Japanese scattered, ineffective opposition. Elomusao, an islet hall mile offshore, was also occupied.

The five-story apartment and store building at 13-15 East Sixtieth Street has been sold by the Union Dime Savings Bank to an investing client of Byrne, Bowman Forshay, Inc., the brokers in the deal. This building contains fifteen apartments, two stores and two showrooms and is assessed for $173,000.

For the first time since repeal of the Prohibition Amendment in 1933 there will be no bock beer this spring. This fact, saddening to quaffers of the brown brew, was revealed yesterday in a search of the truth about beers, their alcoholic content and whether beer these days was being "thinned out."

Triple damage actions against seventeen wholesale candy dealers charged with ceiling-price violations were started in the Federal courts in Manhattan and Brooklyn yesterday by the Office of Price Administration's regional office.

Carrying the hopes -- slim though they be -- of this area, the St. John's basketball team will clash with the Wildcats of Kentucky in one semi-final of the seventh annual National Invitation tournament at Madison Square Garden tonight. After this contest De Paul and the Oklahoma Aggies will meet in the other semi-final. De Paul and Kentucky are favored.

A plan for consolidation of the Detroit Steel Corporation and the Reliance Steel Corporation, whose assets are $5,365,000 and $4,000,000, respectively, has been approved by the directors of both companies and will be submitted to the stockholders at special meetings soon, it was announced yesterday.

Plans for the presentation of "The Voice of the Turtle" in nearby Army and Navy centers have been revised by Alfred de Liagre Jr. Instead of a tour of the camps, the John van Druten comedy will be performed the week of June 26 at the Morosco especially for men and women of the armed forces.

LONDON, March 21 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Sir Alan Gordon Cunningham was removed as commander of the British Eighth Army in Africa in November, 1941, because he felt that an order to sweep the enemy out of Cyrenaica could not be accomplished, it was officially stated tonight.

NAPLES, March 21 -- Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton Jr., known in the field as "Old Blood and Guts," has been replaced by Maj. Gen. Alexander M. Patch, a veteran of the Pacific fighting, as commander of the American Seventh Army, headquarters announced today.

Urging that architects and engineers be put to work throughout the country preparing plans and specifications for the post-war building program of necessary bridges, highways, industrial structures and homes, Robert T. Brooks yesterday said that the structural steel industry is prepared to meet the stiffest war-recovery demands the nation can make.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The War Production Board decided without argument today that there was no need for coupon rationing of coal to consumers because supplies were ample enough to permit continuation of the present system of allocating coal to dealers on a restricted basis.

A Navy pilot and his turret gunner have won two decorations each, the Navy Department announced yesterday, for their participation in attacks on three German submarines, one of which was sunk and the others damaged. They were Lieut. Asbury H. Sallenger of Florence, S.C., and Aviation Machinist's Mate James H. O'Hagan Jr. of Washington.

In gratitude for the privilege of living in the United States, Mrs. Corrine St. Jacques of 332 West Seventy-first Street, who died on Nov. 16, left her real property valued at $9,000 to the United States Government. This was disclosed yesterday in Surrogate's Court where her will, drawn on Oct. 14, 1942, is on file.

A public ofering of 80,000 shares of common stock of the Diana Stores Corporation will be made today at $7 a share by an underwriting syndicate headed by Van Alstyne, Noel Co. The Diana company operates twenty-six retail women's apparel stores in the Southeast.
CHICAGO, March 21 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:

With the American Red Cross sharing in the proceeds, a crowd of 3,000 turned out at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, last night and saw Frankie Terry, 154 1/2, Bensonhurst, outpoint Larney Moore, 157 1/2, Valley Stream, L.I., in the feature eight-round bout. The loser was floored for a count of nine in the fourth.

Pointing out that the trend abroad is toward the use of Government controls and of group organizations in the promotion and conduct of foreign trade, Philip Young, assistant to the administrator of the Foreign Economic Administration, yesterday urged that American exporters prepare to use the "instruments of Government'' to cope adequately with such practices and to insure the nation's full participation in world trade opportunities.

The apparent paradox of a record sale of deer-hunting licenses last season despite the absence in the armed forces of an estimated 50,000 former hunters is revealed in figures announced by the New York State Conservation Department.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -Some clarification was furnished by officials today of the plan by which, it has been reported, the President intends to allow Gen. Dwight D Eisenhower freedom to deal with French groups other than the Committee of National Liberation after the Allies begin their occupation of France.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 21 (AP) -- Dutch Harrison, $78-a-month sergeant in the Army Air Force, hit the rainbow's pot of gold and he rich Charlotte open golf tournament today. He beat Jug McSpaden by a single stroke with a seventy-two-hole total of 275.

At the annual meeting of the Handicap Yacht Racing Class last night in the New York Yacht Club it was brought out that the owners expect not only to be out in full force this summer but that a number of the larger craft, which have added materially to the colorfulness of Sound racing for several years, will be among the first under canvas.

ALGIERS, March 21 -- What is described in the American press as President Roosevelt's plan for the creation of civil authorities in liberated regions of France has not been mentioned in the press here and probably will not be until it has been officially announced.

MEXICO CITY, March 21 -- Mexico celebrated with a national holiday yesterday the sixth anniversary of the ousting of foreign oil companies from the country. At the same time Petroleos Mexicanos (Pemex), the Government-controlled oil monopoly, emphasized in its annual report the unfavorable circumstances created by the war and its repercussions on the Mexican oil industry, such as deficient transportation and difficulty in obtaining sufficient drilling, refining and other equipment.

HEADQUARTERS, PACIFIC WING, AIR TRANSPORT COMMAND, March 21 (AP) -- Arrival of the first company of Wacs assigned to active duty in the Central Pacific area was announced today by Brig. Gen. William Ord Ryan, commanding general of the ATC Pacific Wing.
ALBANY, March 21 (AP) -- Arthur Femea, 18, an American citizen turned down twice as a volunteer in Italy after escaping Nazi detention, was inducted into the Navy today.

DETROIT, March 21 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks cracked a four-year Detroit Olympia jinx tonight, beating the Red Wings, 2 to 1, in the first game of their Stanley Cup semi-final series before a crowd of 10,897.

The New York State Senate has unanimously passed a resolution urging the immediate development of the St. Lawrence hydroelectric power resources to keep and attract industry to New York State. Governor Dewey is reported to favor the resolution.

After opening yesterday 2 points lower to 1 point higher than Monday's close, futures on the New York Cotton Exchange broadened out and finished at about the best levels for the session, or 9 to 22 points net higher. May and July old contracts and December and March new contracts established new highs for the season.

While flares burned and delayed action bombs exploded, 2,500 Queens residents watched one of the most extensive air raid drills to be staged in the city at a special demonstration held last night under the auspices of the City Events Service at Queens Boulevard and Forty-eighth Street, Sunnyside, Long Island City.

MEXICO CITY, March 21 -- Foreign capital for the industrialization of Mexico will be welcomed, President Manuel Avila Camacho told a group of about twenty American correspondents today in a written reply to a series of questions.

PASSAIC, N.J., March 21 -- The death toll in the Market Street Bridge bus disaster had reached a total of sixteen tonight, with ten persons believed to have been passengers on the ill-fated vehicle still reported missing by the police.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday were 1,010, compared with 1,347 in the preceding week and 1,013 in the similar period of last year, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals numbered 389, against 480 last Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -The text of a State Department statement on United States foreign policy:

One gets rather fired of the complaints that have been made by such people as your correspondent Glenn G. Munn, who would have us believe that he spent 140 hours over his Federal income-tax form. If he really spent all that time I am glad he doesn't work in my office.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 21 -- Selective Service's wheel of fortune has swept around again to the Yankees' kingpin pitcher, Spud Chandler.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 21 (AP) -- The Finnish stand apparently was predicated on the thesis that the Russian terms -- which involved the withdrawal of Finnish troops from their present positions as well as internment of all German armed forces now in Finland -- were not consistent with the demands of national security.

LONDON, March 21 (AP) -- A British Navy surgeon left a destroyer to board a United States freighter in an Allied convoy, treated an 18year-old American seaman and then lost his life three days later when the vessel was torpedoed and sunk, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -Thirty-eight escort-carriers -"baby flat-tops" -- have been delivered to the British under lend-lease, Secretary Knox disclosed today.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 21 -- If the fans of Flatbush are palpitantly eager to be told just how good the Dodgers are going to be, they'll just have to palpitate until they see for themselves when the season opens.

The P. Daussa Corporation, importers and exporters, have leased from Arthur Smadbeck, as president of the Anahma Realty Corporation, a large part of the sixteenth floor in 52 Vanderbilt Avenue through the Charles F. Noyes Company, brokers.

A strike of eight engineers and firemen in the Flatiron Building, Fifth Avenue and Broadway, at Twenty-third Street, which had tied up elevator, lighting and heating service and inconvenienced 1,000 tenants and employes for several hours yesterday, ended late in the afternoon with an agreement between representatives of the International Union of Operating Engineers, Local 94, an American Federation of Labor affiliate, and the Equitable Life Assurance Society, owner of the building.

Distressed by symptoms of stock market ignorance among those who actually have bought stocks, Know Your Exchange, the weekly news sheet of the Brew York Curb Exchange, suggests the need for an educational campaign or a Wall Street question-and-answer bureau.

" Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs," the first feature-length cartoon produced by Walt Disney, which had its premiere at the Radio City Music Hall in January, 1938, will start an unlimited revival engagement at the Manhattan Theatre, Broadway and Fifty-first Street, on Tuesday, April 4, it was announced by the company.

The thirteenth annual exhibition presented by An American Group, Inc., opened with a private view yesterday afternoon at the American British Art Center, 44 West Fifty-sixth Street. Beginning today the assembled work may be viewed by the public. The show continues through Saturday, April 8.

Asserting that the Anti-Trust Division of the Department of Justice is "seemingly striving to coerce'' other nations to adopt the competitive system of the United States, T.J. Miley, secretary of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, yesterday urged Congress to review the Webb Export Trade Act of 1918 and enact amendments which would bring the law "up to date."

Truk was the topic. Four heroes, home from the Pacific front, sat yesterday in the Navy's public relations office, 90 Church Street, and casually discussed two days out of their lives, Feb. 16 and 17.

A new novel by Constance Robertson will be published by Henry Holt on April 26. "Fire Bell in the Night" is a story of the underground railroad in up-State New York in the days before the Civil War. Mrs. Robertson spent three years in research for the book, which is the first of three to be set in the same period.

Some of the difficulties attendant on the war-food rationing, servant shortages and so on -- have necessitated that entertaining be done on the informal side. As a result most parties nowadays either are designed along the lines of a buffet supper or are late afternoon gatherings for cocktails or tea.

MONTREAL, March 21 (AP) -- The third-place Toronto Maple Leafs tonight upset the National Hockey League's champion Montreal Canadiens, 3 to 1, in the first game of their four-out-of-seven semi-final Stanley Cup play-offs. It was the first defeat for the Canadiens at the Forum this season.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 21 -- On his return from an Army camp tour in Italy John Garfield will be starred by Warner Brothers in "This Love of Ours," a romantic film to be based on the story of Marine Sgt. Al Schmid, who, blinded in action in the Solomons, has since married.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- An impasse between American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations members of the National War Labor Board prevented the board from reaching an agreement today on the scope of the argument scheduled for tomorrow when the United Steel Workers of America (CIO) and the Basic Steel Industry spokesmen open their case before the steel panel.

LONDON, March 21 -- Although the stock markets here today were steady in tone, trading continued quiet except in the Argentine rails which, after a somewhat irregular opening due to profit-taking, forged ahead, a shortage of stock being held responsible.

Village elections held yesterday in Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland Counties produced fewer contests and less general public interest this year than probably ever before. The condition was attributed largely to the war.

In a pamphlet issued by British Information Services is an account, interesting to American as well as to British makers and readers of newspapers, of the effects of the war upon the British press. In 1938 newspapers and periodicals were using between 21,000 and 23,000 tons of newsprint weekly.

LOS ANGELES, March 21 (AP) -In the first day of Charlie Chaplin's trial on Mann Act charges seven men and five women were seated tentatively as jurors. It is alleged that the film comedian and producer transported 24-year-old Joan Berry to New York City and back for immoral purposes.

SEATTLE, March 21 (AP) -- One of the first instances of the escape of an American civilian from the Philippine Islands since their fall to Japan was reported today upon the arrival of Chester M. Peters, 32, formerly of Seattle.

NEWARK, N.J., March 21 (AP) -- Don't expect a marvelous new world with a great number of labor-saving devices immediately after the war, two scientists cautioned today at a "fact forum" of the Industrial Marketers of New Jersey at the Essex House.
LONDON, March 21 (AP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin:

One of the fundamental concepts of physics, taught to all school children -- that a magnet when broken gives two separate magnets with equal north and south poles and that these parts may again be broken up ad infinitum with the same result -- was branded as a "fairy tale" last night by Professor Felix Ehrenhaft, former director of the famous Institute of Physics of the University of Vienna.
OTTAWA, March 21 (AP) -- Canadian National Railways set new records in traffic and revenues in 1943, R.C. Vaughan, chairman and president, reported today to parliament.

CHICAGO, March 21 (AP) -- Edward Foss Wilson, president of Wilson Co., meat packers, said today that Government ceiling prices and controlled cattle prices had created a situation where meat packers were unable to compete with what he called "black market operators" in buying livestock.

Lieut. (jg) Adam Rother, on trial in the Richmond County Court at St. George, S.I., for the murder of Miss Rita Costello, took the witness stand yesterday in his own defense and denied that he shot and killed the 28-year-old secretary last July.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE PACIFIC, Wednesday, March 22 (AP) -- A communique:

Accusations of pro-communism are no novelty in Representative Marcantonio's life. That is why he is content to dismiss the charges by ALP Right Wingers as only one more exercise in Red herring salesmanship.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, March 21 -- After having cleaned up Nissan Island in the Green Islands, New Zealand troops have secured the Green Island atoll by liquidating the Japanese forces on Sau Island, the Government said today.
Mrs. C. Whitney Carpenter of Mayfair House will return tomorrow from Hot Springs, Va.

Efforts to control inflation have been reasonably successful so far, according to a group of leading economists whose views are given in a bulletin of the life insurance companies of America. Those questioned were Walter E. Kemmerer, George B. Roberts, John H. Riddle, Bradford B. Smith, Rufus S. Tucker, Marcus Nadler, B.H. Beckhart, Clair Wilcox, Ray Westerfield, Fritz Machlup and Lionel D. Edie.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -Nathaniel P. Davis, chief of Foreign Service Personnel in the State Department, predicted today that after the war there would be increased opportunity for women in the diplomatic career service.
PHILADELPHIA, March 21 -General Dwight D. Eisenhower is going to get a hand-knitted sweater, size 40, which he thinks "would be just about right."

The annual report of the Pepsi-Cola Company for 1943 shows net income of $6,441,518, or $3.36 a share, comparing with $6,274,776, or $3.30 a share, earned in 1942. The figures do not include any profits from the wholly owned British subsidiary owing to exchange restrictions.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Conditions in the smaller countries of Europe where political and military developments are moving rapidly, presented an uncertain picture to the State Department today. Secretary of State Cordell Hull said candidly at his press conference that his reports were so incomplete and vague that he had no adequate basis for commenting upon them.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -Items now being rationed will be removed from controls as rapidly as the supply situation permits, Colonel Bryan Houston, deputy administrator of the Office of Price Administration in charge of rationing, told the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today.

Raymond Massey, the 47-year-old actor who is an adept at registering restraint for the movies and on the stage -- as in his portrayal of "Abe Lincoln" -- showed a notable inability to restrain himself yesterday. He arrived an hour and a half too early for the ceremonies by which he became a citizen of the United States.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- President Roosevelt gave an indirect promise to industry today that chemists and men of related scientific skill, regardless of age, would receive special consideration in future administration of the Selective Service Act.

PHILADELPHIA, March 21 (AP) -- The Circuit Court of Appeals penalized a committee of stockholders of Midland Utilities Company today for taking what it termed a "frivolous" appeal from an order of the Federal District Court of Delaware in litigation involving the utility company.
The proportions of the Russian victory in southern Russia were still increasing yesterday as the Red Army continued rolling across Bessarabia toward the Prut River.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -The House Appropriations Committee refused to recommend the inclusion of $50,000,000 for operation of the school lunch program in the $567,885,779 Agriculture Department supply bill for the fiscal year starting July 1, which it reported today.

The 1943 annual report of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., released yesterday by Ralph H. Tapscott, president, shows a consolidated net income of $30,357,683 for the year, after expenses, taxes and other charges.

In honor of twenty years of service to the organization, Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, was the recipient last night of a set of resolutions and an appropriately inscribed watch at the meeting of the board of governors of the association at the Hotel Astor.
WITH THE FIFTH ARMY AT CASSINO, March 21 -- The Allies' third major attack on Cassino appeared today to have bogged down temporarily after seven days of sharp and continuous fighting.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- The Senate passed and sent to the House today compromise legislation pledging United States participation in the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- Moving to effect more complete control of increasingly scarce lumber, the War Production Board today announced that all major consumers must file applications on or before April 25 for second and third-quarter requirements.

NAPLES, March 21 -- The Allies' heavy artillery boomed on the beachhead below Rome on Sunday morning as ground troops carried out two successful raids in force near the western border of the occupied area. Enemy casualties were believed to be heavy.

Fifteen members of the public health committee of the Women's City Club heard Dr. Leona Baumgartner, director of the child hygiene bureau of the New York City Health Department, outline its program yesterday in the Hotel New Weston.
NEW DELHI, India, March 21 (UP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Eric A. Johnston, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, has accepted an invitation from Premier Stalin to visit Soviet Russia. Tentative plans call for his leaving about May 12 and returning to the United States June 20.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The War Production Board said it was ready to authorize textile manufacturers to use dyestuffs over their regular quotas if the additional supply was deemed necessary in the production of either military or essential civilian fabrics.

LONDON, March 21 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement of the Finnish-Russian negotiation signed by the Soviet Information Bureau and broadcast today by the Moscow radio, as reported by the Soviet monitor:

BERNE, Switzerland, March 21 -- Overwhelmed by developments for thirty-six hours in which German forces seized most of the key objectives in the occupation of Hungary, internal resistance in that country since early this morning has coalesced into what may develop into an "Army of Liberation," information from the Balkans indicated tonight.

After some softening, due to rumors that large Government stocks might be released, the wholesale grocery market has firmed up in the last week, it was reported in the trade yesterday. Slowing down of the Italian campaign and delay in the European invasion have led wholesalers to believe that an early peace is not likely.

MONTREAL, March 21 (AP) -The National Hockey League released the final official scoring statistics of the season today, showing Boston's Herbie Cain with a new league record of eighty-two points, nine above the former record.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -The President, confined to his quarters with a cold, prepared a statement of policy on deferment of young men from military service.

Sears, Roebuck Co. reported yesterday in its annual statement for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31 a net profit of $33,866,087, equal to $5.80 a share on 5,837,968 shares of capital stock outstanding. The net profit for the previous fiscal year was $33,946,989, or $5.87 each on 5,780,744 shares then outstanding.

Out of the welter of confusing and contradictory reports about Hungary there emerges this one certainty: Hitler has taken over another country. He has converted another ally into a vassal and is rapidly wiping out any distinction between those who hoped to share in his victory and those he has conquered.

A jury complete with alternates to hear evidence in Wayne T. Lonergan's trial for the murder of his wife, Patricia Burton Lonergan, was chosen yesterday in General Sessions Court before Judge James G. Wallace.

OTTAWA, March 21 -- Canadian armament contracts have now totaled about $9,500,000,000, with a capital expenditure of $850,000,000 by the Government, Munitions and Supply Minister C.D. Howe told the House of Commons today when presenting the annual appropriations of his department.

Books consigned for auction by the estate of J.P. Morgan brought $21,845 yesterday afternoon at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc. The sale included color-plate books, books of general literature, books on birds and an extensive series of elaborate catalogues of the art collection of the elder J.P. Morgan.

WITH THE UNITED STATES PACIFIC FLEET, March 21 -Hundreds of thousands of dollars in United States currency have been 1ost in the Pacific since the start of the war -- payroll funds carried aboard men-of-war that have been sunk.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Mach 21 -With his infield a bit unsettled pending the outcome of Phil Weintraub's draft board examination in Chicago Saturday and his outfield plans awaiting determination of his own military status, Manager Mel Ott today concentrated his attention upon his pitching staff.
A nine-day Victory meeting at Belmont Park is among the events planned by the Turf Committee of America in its program to contribute to war relief and other charities in 1944.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -Lieut. Comdr. Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota and now flag secretary on Admiral Halsey's staff in the South Pacific, has notified Secretary Knox that, while he would not seek the Republican Presidential nomination, he would accept it if it were offered to him.
LONDON, March 21 -- Submarines that were once part of the Italian Navy have been employed by the Germans for blockaderunning from Japan, it was learned tonight.

Saul Cohn, president of the City Stores Company, last night warned against cancellation of commitments by retailers, and urged stores to make cautious timing of deliveries to forestall this possibility.

J.H. Garish Smith, president of the Shipbuilders Council of America, issued yesterday a statement on behalf of East Coast employers denouncing the action of the Shipbuilding Commission, a panel of the National War Labor Board, in reclassifying wage rates in shipyards on this coast.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -Lieut. Charles L. Austin, a chaplain at Keesler Field, Miss., has been verbally reprimanded by the Army for writing letters to Congressmen on the soldier-vote issue, Representative Scott, Republican, of Pennsylvania, said today.

Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, co-author of the resolution before the Senate Foreign Affairs Committee recommending the use of the good offices of the United States to obtain free Jewish immigration into Palestine, took issue last night with military critics of the proposal who suggested that the action might weaken the position of Allied troops in North Africa and the Middle East.

PHILADELPHIA, March 21 -Twenty-five underwriters were listed here today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Universal Pictures Company, Inc., as handlers of its offerings of $7,500,000 of 3 3/4 per cent sinking fund debentures due on March 1, 1959.

The seven-story loft building on a plot 80 by 103 feet at 153-59 West Fifteenth Street has been bought by Samuel Resnick, operator, from Louis Cowan Associates through Henry Kantrowitz, broker. It has an annual rental of $30,750 and is assessed for $150,000.

The strict quota control on imported rum, gin, whiskey, cordials and beverages made from cane sugar will have no effect on advertising plans of American firms dealing in these items, large importers reported yesterday. Budgets for the whole year were made up Jan. 1 and importers said there was no reason to change their advertising programs.

The need for a bill of particulars of America's views on the far-reaching questions posed by the present war increases with the imminence of the military campaigns that will probably decide the issue in the European theatre.

Heretofore Hungary has played a comparatively minor and passive role in the war. This country that stands "in the middle of the middle" of Europe, as Count Teleki, its geographer premier, used to say, was almost forgotten until the wall of the German armies broke to the east and the victorious Russians appeared on the other side of the Carpathians.

LONDON, Wednesday, March 22 (AP) -- American four-engined Liberators bombed the Pas-de-Calais area of northern France yesterday without losing a plane, and swift Mustangs of the United States Eighth Air Force made an unprecedented sweep over 450 miles of occupied France, shooting up Nazi airdromes and destroying twenty enemy planes.

LONDON, March 21 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav Partisan forces of Marshal Tito [Josip Broz] have attacked a German motorized column escorted by fifty tanks, which was believed driving into Hungary from the south to aid Nazi occupation of that satellite State, it was disclosed today.

Preceded by an interim amendment to the present regulation which may be effective until Oct. 1, an over-all price rule establishing cost-plus historic mark-up on furs for manufacturers, retailers and jobbers is being considered by the Office of Price Administration, according to reports in the trade here yesterday.
Following is the text of the Finnish communique rejecting Soviet armistice terms, as broadcast yesterday by the Finnish home radio and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
WASHINGTON, March 21 -Conviction that some form of relief for the liquor shortage is in prospect in the next few months grew among distillers and others here today.

Housewives from the Parkchester area of the Bronx were active on two fronts yesterday -- the headquarters of their Consumer Committee at 1380 Metropolitan Avenue, and the hearing chambers of the Office of Price Administration at the Empire State Building.

TRENTON, N.J., March 21 (AP) -- More than 13,000 State employes will receive a flat cost-of-living bonus of $132 during the fiscal year beginning next July 1, Senator Bruce A. Wallace, chairman of the joint legislative Appropriations Committee, announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Sixteen proposed "economy" amendments to the Tennessee Valley Authority section of the $8,000,000,000 Independent Offices Appropriation Bill became entangled in Senate debate today with the long-standing feud between Senator Kenneth McKellar, acting chairman of the Appropriations Committee, and David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the board of TVA.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- I have still to meet anyone conversant with Balkan affairs who can bring himself to think that Prince Barbu Stirbey, the Rumanian emissary to Ankara and to Cairo, will succeed in approaching the Russian Government and in obtaining for his country terms of armistice and peace that improve upon what the expression "unconditional surrender" commonly suggests.

Newbold Morris, president of the City Council, called upon the State yesterday to grant sovereign taxing powers to New York City, or to relieve the city of the obligation of supporting the administration of education, justice and elections without getting full authority over what it supports.

Sales by the International Harvester Company in 1943 reached the largest volume in history, increasing to $448,035,000 from 1942 sales of $364,527,000, Fowler McCormick, president, reported in the annual statement to stockholders released for today.

With furnishings as scarce as they are, the best thing to do right now in the way of decorating a room is to make the most effective use of color, according to Altman's decorators. They recommend a three-color scheme -- one for the primary shade of the room, the two others for accents.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 21 -- Hungary is not yet completely occupied and the Nazis are encountering many difficulties, reports reaching Stockholm diplomatic circles indicated today.

There has been widespread condemnation of the action of the medical societies of the metropolitan area for alleged dilatory action in connection with the charges of violation of the Compensation Law. May I state for the Medical Society of the County of Queens, Inc., that as soon as charges of such violation were brought before our compensation board investigation into them was begun.

The New York City Housing Authority awarded yesterday a new issue of $2,980,000 of notes, dated April 20 and due Oct. 20, 1944. The Bessemer Trust Company of Jersey City, N.J., received $2,480,000 of the issue at rates ranging from 0.415 to 0.43 per cent. The balance of $500,000 went to the United States Trust Company on an 0.42 per cent basis.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, March 22 (AP) -- Emirau Island, known also as Squally Island, is the smaller of the two principal islands in the St. Matthias Group. Mussau, fifteen miles northwest, is the other.

Demand for railroad issues reached such proportions yesterday on the stock market that values for the carriers were enlarged from 1 to 3 points. The buying wave in the rails was not repeated in the industrial section. Many leaders in the latter group were drawn higher, however, by the very force of the rally.

ABOARD GENERAL MONTGOMERY'S HEADQUARTERS TRAIN, Somewhere in Britain, March 21 -- "The second front has already begun" with the tactical and strategic bombing of northwestern Europe and Germany, General Sir Bernard L. Montgomery declared in an interview today.

The borers from within who have worked so hard to capture American labor unions are having bad luck with David Dubinsky's International Ladies Garment Workers. In the cutters' union, which has just had an election, the Communist-supported candidates got 30 per cent of the votes cast in 1939 but only 15 per cent of those cast this year.

MARSHALL ISLAND, March 4 (Delayed) (AP) -- The possibility that Amelia Earhart Putnam, world-famed flier, ran out of gasoline in the Marshall Islands and was taken to Japan has been revived by a remark of a mission-trained native to Lieut. Eugene T. Bogan of 325 East Seventy-second Street, New York.

The Daily News (St. Thomas, Virgin Islands) dedicates its issue of March 13 to "Dr. Robert Morss Lovett, a gentleman of high order, a great public servant, a leader, a friend." Such is the impression Dr. Lovett made on the people of the islands during more than four years as Government Secretary and a few months as Executive Secretary.

As it happened, the date of the concert given by Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall was also an anniversary of Bach's birthday, March 21, 1685 and it was surely not mere coincidence that Mr. Ormandy opened the program with his own orchestra version of the organ Toccata in C major.

Charles Garbus, 32-year-old messenger, was walking along the east side of Park Avenue between Fifty-eighth and Fifty-ninth Streets on his way to work yesterday morning when he spied in the slush a broken string of pearls.

CHICAGO, March 21 (U.P.) -- Senator Edwin C. Johnson, Democrat, of Colorado, broke formally with President Roosevelt tonight in a speech at North Park College in which he charged that "history will name the fourth term, if it ever materializes, as 'the term of defeat and frustration.'"

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Upholding the controversial proposal that the United States construct a petroleum pipeline from Saudi Arabia to the Mediterranean, Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, asserted today that the project would be both sound economy and wise national insurance and that the proposal marked the virtual "birth of a genuine foreign policy" regarding oil.
LONDON, March 21 (UP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

CHICAGO, March 21 (AP) -- Post-war expansion of rural electrification can provide 2,227,000,000 man-hours of work and market $3,500,000,000 in goods and services, William J. Neal, deputy administrator of the Rural Electrification Administration, said here today.

Development by private investors of an extensive moderate-rent, modern housing center in downtown Manhattan to serve workers in the financial and City Hall districts was suggested last night by George A. Sloan, chairman of the Mayor's Business Advisory Committee and head of the City's Department of Commerce, as one major means of bringing residents back to the city.

Moscow, Wednesday, March 22 -- The Red Army, capturing more than 310 inhabited points in its sustained advance in six sectors on the southern Soviet-German front, was reported last night to have cut the Beltsy-Cernauti railway, fifteen miles beyond the Dniester at its Mogilev-Poolski crossing and the only rail line leading directly to Germany from central Bessarabia.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -United States submarines, relentlessly pressing the war against the Japanese lines of communications in the Pacific and Far East, have sunk fifteen more enemy vessels, increasing the total sunk or damaged since the beginning of the war to 646, Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox announced.

Zino Francescatti was heard in a recital last night in Carnegie Hall. As his principal offering the French violinist had selected the Sonata in A major of Bach and the "Kreutzer Sonata" of Beethoven. He also performed the Saint-Saens "Introduction and Rondo Capriccioso," his own version of the Tartini "Variations on a Theme of Corelli," Paganini's "I Palpiti" and shorter pieces by Debussy and Shostakovich.

A UNITED STATES FIFTEENTH AIR FORCE BASE, in Italy, March 22 (AP) -- An American dentist willing to be his own experimental "guinea pig" has flown almost five miles above the earth to test his invention for eliminating facial frostbite, the painful affliction of heavy-bomber crews.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The Foreign Economic Administration disclosed today plans for extending to the Middle East use of the private export trade in the shipment of iron and steel products.

Furniture retailers yesterday expressed fear of a forthcoming black market in inner-spring mattresses as an outgrowth of the recent amendment by the War Production Board to inventory limitation order L-49, which permits production of these items on a repair or reassembly basis if inner-spring units were included in manufacturers' inventories prior to the imposition of the original order on Sept. 1, 1942.

PASSAIC, N.J., March 22 -- The bodies of three more passengers of the bus that plunged off the Market Street Bridge into the Passaic River during the snow and sleet storm Monday morning were recovered today, bringing the count of known dead in the accident to nineteen.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, March 23 (UP) -- A communique:

Inventories of scrap metal needed for war production have "shrunk to a critical point," Robert Wolcott, chairman of the American Industries Salvage Committee, said yesterday. He spoke at a meeting in the Hotel Roosevelt preceding a preview of a motion picture.
James H. Nixon, treasurer of the J.H. Dunning Corporation, boxes, has leased an apartment in 930 Fifth Avenue through Wm. A. White Sons, brokers.

THE reviewers of Anne Morrow Lindbergh's "The Steep Ascent"* have done the girl wrong. Knowing that Mrs. Lindbergh is the wife of a certain aviator, and knowing, too, that she is the author of that intellectually vulnerable book called "The Wave of the Future," they have read all sorts of fantastic political and social implications into what is actually a slender novel built around the experiences of flying.

LONDON, March 22 -- The British are beginning to wonder whether the United States is aware of potential commitments in the Near East which are involved in building 1,250 miles of oil pipeline from the Persian Gulf to the Mediterranean.

Net profit of the Childs Company for 1943 amounted to $685,180, more than eight times the $83,515 earned in 1942, according to an unaudited report filed with the Federal Court yesterday by John F.X. Finn, trustee for the company.

ALBANY, March 22 -- The battle over a fourth-term nomination for President Roosevelt, which is opposed by some elements in the Democratic party, came into the open today in a call for the election of a new Democratic State chairman to replace James A. Farley.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 22 (U.P.) -- All hope for an early Finnish-Russian peace was killed by Finland's rejection of Soviet armistice terms, informed observers here believed today.

The old First National Bank Building at 36 Middle Neck Road, Great Neck, L.I., was sold to a syndicate known as 36 Middle Neck Road, Inc. The structure contains a store with four apartments above. Sale was for cash above a ten-year purchase money mortgage of $24,000. Hosinger Bode, Inc., and John Sahm were the brokers.

A diamond ring with a twenty-eight carat center stone, valued at $100,000 by its owner, Mrs. Paul-Louis Weiller of 21 Sutton Place, was lost on Tuesday night in Le Pavilion, a restaurant at 5 East Fifty-fifth Street, but later was found there by police under puzzling circumstances.

LONDON, March 22 -- Full of fun and erudite wisecracks after his winter's illness, Prime Minister Churchill today talked the House of Commons out of proposals that he said eventually might entitle 16,000,000 of the nation's 45,000,000 persons to wear the first two British overseas campaign medals of the war.

Walter D. Hoag of the Yale Club, the top-seeded player, defeated A. Ewing of the New York A.C. last night at the Harvard Club in the second round of the Red Cross tournament of the National Squash Tennis Association.

LONDON, March 22 (U.P.) -- The British Government has asked Russia for full particulars on reports that former German war prisoners captured by the British in North Africa and repatriated to Germany had been sent into action and captured on the eastern front, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the House of Commons today.

The State of California Veterans Welfare Board sold yesterday from its investment portfolio $3,400,000 of the board's own bonds, due from Feb. 1, 1946 to 1956, bearing coupons ranging from 2 1/4 to 4 1/2 per cent.

A program to protect the post-war future of American aviation in both domestic and foreign spheres was outlined last night by Captain Eddie Rickenbacker at the first annual dinner of the Wings Club at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Advance proofs of the second section of prizes for Field and Stream's thirty-third annual fishing contest, received yesterday, reveal the names of the metropolitan district anglers who were successful in the weakfish, striped bass and bluefish divisions.

CHICAGO, March 22 -- Secretary of Agriculture Wickard predicted today American farmers will break production records again in 1944, and said that with good demand and effective education they will surpass in 1950 the pre-war level of 1935-39 by 60 per cent.

LOS ANGELES, March 22 (AP) -- A jury of seven women and five men, most of whom appeared to be in their forties and some in their graying or balding fifties and sixties, was selected today to try Charlie Chaplin on a Mann Act indictment.
A bold thief pried a painting from a wall of the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday afternoon and escaped with it before guards detected the loss.

By forcing out of storage some frozen foods held in bulk for reprocessing, the War Food Administration's order to commercial holders to withdraw 20 per cent of warehouse stocks within the the next thirty days is likely to result in an increase in the consumes supply of fruits for jams and preserves and of certain vegetables for soup manufacture, Bert C. Olney, president of Birdseye-Snider, Inc., said yesterday.

An agreement was signed yesterday under which American Airlines, Inc., will acquire control of American Export Airlines, Inc., for $3,000,000, subject to the approval of the Civil Aeronautics Board, it was announced jointly yesterday by A.N. Kemp and W.H. Coverdale, presidents of the lines.

A pleasant change from the standard recital was offered at Town Hall last night by Celius Dougherty and Vincenz Ruzicka, duo-pianists. There are all too few first-rate duo-pianists on the musical scene at the moment and the repertoire for the combination is fairly limited.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Capitol, the attraction will be "The Heavenly Body," a romantic comedy produced by Metro and co-starring William Powell and Hedy Lamarr. In supporting roles are James Craig, Fay Bainter, Henry O'Neill and Robert Sully . . .

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, March 23 (U.P.) -- Allied bombers sank a Japanese destroyer and two small cargo ships off the northern New Guinea coast Monday night, halting another possible enemy attempt to send reinforcements to their battered coastal garrisons, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's communique announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- London dispatches this morning stating that President Roosevelt's proposals for the civilian administration of France had gone to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower directly through Army channels, instead of the customary diplomatic avenues, caused speculation today in diplomatic circles whether unilateral action by the United States Government in the matter was contemplated.

Mayor La Guardia proposed yesterday a four-point program for restoring peace within the American Labor party, of which he is a member. It was promptly accepted "unconditionally" by Sidney Hillman, who is spearheading a movement to oust the present right wing State leadership of the party.

The return of racing to New York with the Metropolitan Jockey Club's spring meeting at Jamaica will set a new high in the value of the purses to be distributed for the first thirteen days of the twenty-five-day session, starting April 8.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 22 -Events in Hungary and the Balkans were having repercussions in France today, all the more weighty since the passing of the spring equinox might have a bearing on the next Allied moves.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Continuing the defense of the Federal Communications Commission before the special House committee investigating that agency, Charles Denny, FCC counsel, said today that far from having been guilty of "Gestapo methods," the commission had been so lenient in its dealings with the foreign-language broadcast "problem" as to invite criticism and censure from critics who favored much more drastic action than ever was taken by it.
LONDON, March 22 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Because he felt that he "could contribute little more at present" in his special field of taxation, Randolph Paul resigned today as general counsel of the Treasury Department and had his resignation accepted by the President.

SOMEWHERE IN SOUTH ENGLAND, March 22 -- Could Alfred the Great drop in tonight on a famous South England estate where, legend holds, he used to spend many pleasant week-ends, he would see a strange sight.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -Senate forces supporting Senator Kenneth McKellar, acting chairman of the Appropriations Committee, claimed sufficient votes today to impose rigid restrictions on the Tennessee Valley Authority and force it to come to Congress for its operating funds, and friends of the TVA turned to parliamentary tactics designed to prevent the issue from reaching a vote.

LONDON, March 22 (U.P.) -- Outnumbered Yugoslav Partisans have captured two vital communications points in Montenegro, but are under heavy enemy pressure in eastern Bosnia, a broadcast communique from Marshal Tito [Josip Broz] headquarters reported today.

LONDON, March 22 -- Britain has decided, after consultation with the United States, against following Russia's lead in recognizing Premier Pietro Badoglio's Government, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the House of Commons today.
That night the bombs were exceptionally thick over Berlin, but the aged diarist in his air-raid cellar kept on working by the dim illumination of his pencil flashlight.

One point in the recent announcement that the Government will resume consultation with the Passenger Car Advisory Committee of the automobile industry requires emphasis. The discussions in prospect do not mean the early production of motor vehicles for civilian use.

This morning's TIMES reported unanimous approval by the Senate Finance Committee of an omnibus war veterans' aid measure providing for hospitalization, education, vocational training, loans for homes, farms and businesses, employment service and unemployment benefits.

Continuing a settlement project it began ten years ago, the Jewish Agricultural Society last year placed 102 families, made up of 500 members, on farms in six States, it was disclosed yesterday with publication of the society's forty-third annual report.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The United States submarine Scorpion, the twentieth lost in action against the enemy since the war, is overdue from patrol and must be presumed lost, the Navy Department announced today.

The stock market reacted yesterday under profit-taking in the closing hour, but only after prices had made new peaks for the current phase. The oil section came in for most attention and gains in the petroleum issues were maintained in some measues to the finish.

MOSCOW, Thursday, March 23 -- Pervomaisk, heavily fortified railway junction on the southern Bug River, which until recently had been Field Marshal Gen. Fritz Erich von Mannstein's headquarters for the slow retreat of the hard-pressed German forces in the southern Ukraine, fell yesterday to Marshal Ivan S. Koneff's troops after what the Soviet High Command described as two days of hard battles.
NEW DELHI, India, March 22 (AP) -- A communique:

The three four-story apartment houses at 148-52 Parkside Avenue and 5 St. Paul's Place, Brooklyn, have been sold by Frederick Brown, operator, in a quick resale. The buildings contain sixty-seven apartments and are fully rented. They are on a plot 209 by 225 feet.

CHICAGO, March 22 (AP) -- Prices of hogs broke sharply today under the weight of another heavy run and a good-sized hold-over from the preceding session. With lightweight offerings suffering the widest losses, prices were down 25 to 50 cents.

NAPLES, March 22 -- On the beachhead below Rome the situation was unchanged yesterday. German artillery was active around Padiglione, just to the left of the center of the line. A near-by cross-roads was also heavily pounded, but otherwise the entire sector was generally quiet.

A spring garden profuse with blooming lilacs, azaleas, dogwood and masses of other early flowering plants greeted visitors yesterday at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, at the opening of the second annual Garden Week, sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES, the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, Inc., and the Garden Club of New Jersey.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 22 -After several days of bad news and climatic conditions to match, things began to take on a decidedly brighter hue in the training camp of the Giants today. Together with the energetic labors of Groundkeeper Mickey McMahon, the sun cleared the snow from a sufficient area on the ball field to permit the first outdoor workout since last Sunday.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Mar. 22 -- With its economic life revolutionized by wartime industries, California started a conference on post-war planning today with a challenge by Governor Earl Warren to the planners to seek their objectives without leaning on Government "to do all the thinking and the pushing."
Reductions of 8 to 25 per cent in the ceiling prices of apples, white potatoes, carrots and green peas were announced for this city yesterday by the regional Office of Price Administration.
