Declaring that the Starnes bill to give preference in Federal civil service to returning veterans "fails to impose certain minimum requirements that ought to be part of any scheme of preference for veterans," the National Civil Service Reform League appealed yesterday to President Roosevelt not to urge Congress to adopt the bill in its present form.

Adolf Hitler is celebrating his last victories these days. Unable to conquer his foes, he is conquering his allies. This is being done with the same treachery and ruthlessness, but also with the same decisive speed and display of power, that overwhelmed many European nations in the past.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 22 -- The Middle East Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, the British organization known as MERRA, which is expected to be amalgamated with the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration following conversations being held in Cairo this week, announced today that 150 relief workers destined for the Balkans already were in training in the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The work being done by women in forty-one steel mills has little future in it, except perhaps for laboratory work and office work, according to a report, "Women's Employment in the Making of Steel, 1943," issued today by the Women's Bureau.
ANGRI, Italy, March 22 -- The laval flow from the northwest slopes of Vesuvius grew sluggish today after enveloping half of the houses along the San SebastianoCercola Road.

The nation's stocks of major oil products declined last week, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. At the close of the period lash Saturday, supplies of gasoline amounted to 86,185,000 barrels, a drop of 374,000 from the 86,559,000 at the end of the previous week.

As a first step toward mending Democratic political fences in New York City, Col. Richard C. Patterson Jr., former Undersecretary of Commerce, has invited a large group of influential leaders to a private dinner for an "off the record" discussion of the problems the party will face in this year's elections.

The three jurors of the Fifty Books of the Year exhibition, sponsored annually by the American Institute of Graphic Arts, will be the speakers at the meeting of the Trade Book Clinic, Wednesday at 6:15 P.M. at the Town Hall Club. They are Boris Artzybasheff, artist, Daniel F. Bradley of Harpers and A. Hyatt Mayor of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Another speaker will be Paul A. Bennett of the Mergenthaler Linotype Company.

Infants' and children's underwear is still scarce and seems likely to continue so, regardless of War Production Board orders aimed at increasing production, and new shortages can be expected next season in girls' cotton dresses and blouses.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Preliminary concessions, subject to ratification by the entire National War Labor Board, were made to the demands of independent unions for representation on the board today at a conference held by public members of the board with spokesmen for independent unions claiming a membership of 1,250,000.

The German declaration about Rome is a delusion, a mockery and a snare. "So that responsibility for the bombing of Rome will remain entirely with the Allies" -- piously begins the statement broadcast yesterday -- "the German command in the next few days will scrupulously withdraw from Rome every installation which could serve as the slightest pretext for an air terror and will still further deviate military transports from the Eternal City."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 22 -- So far as the Yankees are concerned, that classroom bit might just as well have been written: "Count that day lost whose low, descending sun, sees not another Yank called up to tote a gun." Or words to that general effect.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Induction of loyal American citizens Japanese descent into the Army is gradually getting under way, War Department and Selective Service spokesmen said today.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The National Labor Relations Board is facing the problem of deciding whether an employer who refuses to deal with a union representative lacking a State license is guilty of violating the National Labor Relations Act.

WASHINGTON, March 22--With the Army Air Forces approaching "complete air supremacy" in every theater at a much faster pace than the Army dared to hope and with air combat losses "considerably less" in per cent than was expected, the AAF will be able to release 36,000 ground and service forces personnel, who had been earmarked for flying training, Gen. H.H. Arnold stated today.

In an effort to supply more trained men and women for work in war plants to meet the manpower shortage expected under the new regulations affecting younger workers, the Board of Education is preparing to expand its War Industries Training Program to accommodate thousands of additional persons, it became known yesterday.

The Celanese Corporation of America filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement for a new issue of 350,000 shares of $4.50 series no par first preferred stock and for 139,622 no par shares of common stock.

Secretary Knox tells us that the Navy has lent the British thirty-eight escort carriers and has some fifty left, besides our regular carriers add cruiser carriers. The Americans, who invented them, call them "baby flat tops." To the British, who set great store by them, they are "Woolworth carriers."

MOSCOW, March 22 -- Soviet scientists reported today new experiments in which bees produce honey rich in vitamin C or containing medicine, such as quinine, sulfidin and streptocide. The Moscow News describes the development and credits it to the bee expert, E. Arefyeff of the Maikop Agricultural Research Station.

Within the shadow of the towering skyscrapers of the downtown financial district, the Catholic Archdiocese of New York has chosen a large plot as the site for the first major religious edifice to be constructed in the Wall Street area in a century.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Motors Corporation, recommended today to the House's Special Committee on Post-War Policy that the reconversion of industry begin immediately rather than on the day of armistice.

Bror G. Dahlberg, chairman of the boards of the Certain-teed Products Corporation and the Celotex Corporation, received a clean bill of health yesterday in the 120-page report filed in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn by John P. McGrath, referee in a stockholders' suit against those two companies, the Phoenix Securities Corporation and twenty-six individuals.

Although the largest number of mills ever to participate in bidding on an Army contract have responded to the call of the Philadelphia Quartermaster depot for 5,300,000 high neck sweaters, the bids so far are 1,500,000 short of the goal, it was estimated in trade circles here yesterday.
LONDON, Thursday, March 23 (AP) -- The Russian Wednesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

LONDON, March 22 -- Today's stock markets here were quiet and except for a few isolated features showed little important change. A few profit-takers appeared in the Argentine rails, with the result that declines occurred in both prior and ordinary issues.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Opposition to the $40,000,000 appropriation voted by the House to carry forward the Lanham act child-care program under the Federal Works Agency was voiced today before a Senate Appropriations subcommittee hearing by Mrs. Harriet Ahlers Houdlette of the American Association of University Women, speaking in behalf of ten national women's and educational organizations.

Frank Jaro, 24 years old, and his wife, Julia, 23, were convicted yesterday in Special Sessions of endangering the lives of the two youngest of their four children last Jan. 4 when they left them alone for twelve hours in their squalid, water-soaked apartment on the top floor of the tenement at 251 East Seventy-seventh Street.
WITH THE FIFTH ARMY AT CASSINO, March 22 (AP) -- This is the scene of the battle of Cassino:

The acute situation facing the corn refining industry because of the shortage of corn was emphasized yesterday by the announcement of the Corn Products Refining Company that it has started closing its plant at Kansas City. Other plants in the industry generally are operating on a curtailed basis with a corn supply sufficient to last for a few days up to two weeks.

Meritorious Civilian Service Emblems in recognition of ten or more consecutive years of faithful and satisfactory service to the War Department were presented yesterday to fifty civilian employes of the Second Service Command headquarters by Maj. Gen. Thomas A. Terry in ceremonies at Fort Jay Theatre, Governors Island.

Because of the growth of new services provided by the United States to recipients of lend-lease aid and the war-spurred development of material substitutes which will curtail future availability of dollar exchange in other countries, the outlook for foreign trade "is not good for a long period of time," W.E. Knox, assistant general manager of Westinghouse Electric International Company, declared yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, March 22 (AP) -- William M. Hickey, president of the United Corporation, told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that United's plan to retire half of its outstanding $3 cumulative preference stock was the first step toward compliance with a SEC order to recapitalize on a single-stock basis and cease to be a holding company.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 22 -- After an inquest into a highway fatality involving a mail truck operated at night by a 17-year-old youth who lacked a State driver's license, Dr. Amos O. Squire, medical examiner of Westchester County, criticized today the Government regulation that permits persons to drive mail trucks without possessing drivers' licenses.

Arguments for and against an increased fare on the city's unified transit lines were presented last night in a broadcast from radio station WEVD, with Peter Grimm, vice chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission, advocating a fare rise and Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs of Manhattan defending the five-cent rate.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -American bombers now devote an average of 60 per cent of the loads they drop on Germany to incendiaries and are using a new type of 500-pound oil-magnesium bomb, known as the "Goop," that is virtually inextinguishable, the War Department reported today.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federation Communications Commission:

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 22 -- There hasn't been a Grade A Dodger-Giant feud since Col. Bill Terry audibly wondered whether the Dodgers were still in the league. One was engendered today, however, when President Branch Rickey read the aspersions cast upon his club by President Horace Stoneham of New York.

Offerings will be made today of a new issue of $7,500,000 of Universal Pictures Company, Inc., 3 3/4 per cent sinking funds debentures due on March 1, 1959, by a banking group headed by Dillon, Read Co. The offering price will be 99 and accrued interest.

NAPLES, March 22 -- Allied infantrymen, after a day of fighting off fierce counter-attacks by reinforced German parachutists, pushed slowly forward in the ruins of Cassino tonight, battling from house to house with every type of weapon from the most modern lethal arms to bush-knives.

WITH CHINESE-AMERICAN FORCES IN BURMA, March 21 (Delayed) -- The capture of Sumprabum, ninety miles north of Myitkyina, represents another important stride forward in the campaign to retake northern Burma. Sumprabum was occupied Sunday by British forces of Gurkhas and Kachins which had had the place surrounded for months.

Expansion of the program of the Bureau for Intercultural Education on a national scale, with the establishment of three summer workshops in colleges and introduction of experimental projects in various parts of the country to find ways of eliminating intolerance, was voted yesterday at a special meeting by the board of directors of the bureau.

American business contributed $352,650,000 in advertising during 1943 to supply information on home-front problems and urge the American people to support the men on the fighting fronts, according to the second annual report of the War Advertising Council, issued yesterday.

ON THE FIFTH ARMY BEACHHEAD, South of Rome, March 22 (U.P.) -- Between thirty and forty shells from German long-range guns exploded in the American field hospital area here today, sending huge chunks of shrapnel ripping through ward tents and killing five patients. Eleven others were wounded.

J.H. Garish Smith, president of the Shipbuilders Council of America, sharply criticizes the action of the Shipbuilding Commission, a panel of the War Labor Board, in reclassifying wage rates in shipping yards on the East Coast. Mr. Smith contends that the reclassification really involves raising wage rates for all classifications except the top bracket, but in varying and discriminatory degrees.

The Brooklyn Appellate Division reversed unanimously yesterday a decision by Kings County Judge Louis Goldstein in which the criminal court jurist held that Acting District Attorney Thomas Cradock Hughes lacked the constitutional powers granted to District Attorney William O'Dwyer, now a colonel in the Army.

Leo Silver, builder, who fourteen years ago erected and sold the one-story taxpayer at 1832-34 Westchester Avenue, in the Bronx, has bought it back from Joseph Petchers. He was represented by Joseph Howard Katz, attorney. The building is on a plot 50 by 120 feet and is assessed at $17,000.

Bidders paid $57,306 yesterday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., for objects of art from the estate of J.P. Morgan, sold at auction by order of the executors. The first session of part two of the auction of furniture and art objects, held in the afternoon, consisted of Egyptian, Roman, Byzantine and other antiquities, Gothic, Renaissance and Near Eastern art, and Chinese porcelain and pottery.

Calling for "setting aside our creeds and our rituals for the moment," Rabbi Isaac Landman of Temple Beth Elohim, Brooklyn, urged at a Brooklyn Lenten service yesterday noon under inter-denominational auspices that all religions in the United Nations act together to "be heard at the peace table."

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 22 -- Bertie S., one of the biggest bargains of the 1943 yearling sales, set a new track record for four and a half furlongs today at Tropical Park to win the 3,000-added Viscaya Stakes for 2-year-old fillies.

ALGIERS, March 22 -- The State Department's declaration yesterday repudiating the "ridiculous charge" that the United States Government might again deal with Vichy or individuals supporting its collaboration policy was broadcast today to the French people by the Allied and French stations here.
MOSCOW, March 22 -- Gregory Ryklin, a writer for the Russian Army newspaper Red Star, aptly expressed the mischievous jubilation felt here as a result of the plight of Germany's best generals.

Announcing a new total of $11,246,000 in New York City's drive to raise $22,386,000 toward the national goal of $200,000,000 for the 1944 Red Cross War Fund, Bernon S. Prentice, vice chairman of the appeal in this city, declared yesterday that this progress was not good enough.

LONDON, March 22 (AP) -- The Germans said today that they would completely demilitarize Rome in an effort to place the responsibility for bombings on the Allies, but it was regarded as unlikely that the Allies would take any cognizance of this unilateral declaration of an "open city."

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The National War Labor Board gave orders today to its panel considering the wage demands of the United Steel Workers of America, CIO, to receive arguments for a wage increase of 17 cents an hour, even though the demand goes beyond the Little Steel formula, which is the basis of the Federal wage stabilization policy.

A group of fifty leaders of the Northern Baptist Convention was urged yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Walter W. Van Kirk, secretary of the department of international justice and good-will of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, to "stop passing more resolutions on world peace and racial brotherhood and do something about the resolutions they have adopted in former years."

The seizure by American Marines of Emirau Island in the St. Matthias group near New Ireland cuts off large enemy forces to the south and brings our bombers within 600 miles of Truk. That important Japanese base is now brought under cross-fire from this newly conquered base and Eniwetok in the Marshalls.

New three-year agreements providing for health insurance financed by employers were signed yesterday by the Dressmakers Union, an affiliate of the International Ladies' Garment Workers, and four of the five employer associations in the industry.

ALBANY, March 22 -- Governor Dewey vetoed today, for the second time in two years, legislation requiring boards of parole to discharge any prisoner under their jurisdiction receiving an honorable discharge after service with the armed forces in the present war.
HOLLYWOOD, March 22 -- Democratic and Republican national conventions will be shown by television this year, President Niles Trammell of the National Broadcasting Company said today.

A dramatic scene took place at the murder trial of Lieut. (j.g.) Adam Rother of the Coast Guard in the Richmond County Court late yesterday afternoon when District Attorney Farrell M. Kane had the defendant re-enact the fatal shooting of Miss Rita Costello in a taxicab on July 17.

In common with a large number of similarly minded citizens, I am hoping that a candidate for the Presidency may be found whose strength of character and ability will equal his high principles. He should be a courageous man, unafraid to speak so simply that no man will doubt his meaning.

Today's events: "Aida," Metropolitan Opera House, 8:15 P.M.; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Artur Rodzinski conducting; William Kapell, pianist, assisting artist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; "The Barber of Seville," Creatore Grand Opera Company, Windsor Theatre, the Bronx, 8:30; Sylvia Marlow, harpsichord, Milton Prinz, 'cello, recital, Frick Collection, 3 o'clock.

The five-story bank and office building formerly owned by the National Bank of North Hudson at 701-7 Summit Avenue, Union City, N.J., has been sold by the Serout Holding Company (Charles Serventi, president) to the Realty Operating Corporation. It is assessed for $130,000.

MOSCOW, March 22 -- The Russian Army paper Red Star, in a lengthy article about the impending elections in the United States, concluded that President Roosevelt would be a candidate for a fourth term and that the most likely Republican candidate would be Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, Wendell Willkie or Gov. John W. Bricker.

All active months in the cotton futures market moved yesterday into new high ground or the season, and final prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were at about the best levels of the day, 8 to 17 points net higher than Tuesday's close.

The housewives of Parkchester, whose consumer committee has undertaken to run black market practices out of that section of the Bronx, won their first victory yesterday when Mrs. Minnie Levine, proprietor of a meat market at 2050 McGraw Avenue, was suspended by the Office of Price Administration from dealing in meat for sixty days.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 22 -- After three days of futile negotiations in search of a puppet Government to assume administration of Hungary following the bloc resignation of the Kallay Government last Sunday, Bela Imredy was forced to announce his failure late this morning.

The window of the Casserole Kitchen, at 782 Madison Avenue, near Sixty-sixth Street, holds an assortment of varicolored market baskets waiting to be packed with casserole dinners and sent on their way. Meals that need only be heated at home before serving are the specialty of this establishment, which opened about six weeks ago.

The Citizens Budget Commission called upon the Board of Estimate yesterday to require Mayor La Guardia's executive budget for 1944-45 to show in detail which city employes would not be paid salaries because of absence in the armed forces.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- The House passed and sent to the President today the conference report, already approved by the Senate, authorizing the United States to provide $1,350,000,000 of an international pool for the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration.
CHUNGKING, China, March 22 (UP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

The Mazur Brothers and Jaffe Fish Company, wholesale fish dealers now at 233 Front Street, will move to new quarters in the five-story building they have leased across the street at Nos. 232-34. The building is in the block north of the Fulton Market and was rented through the Charles F. Noyes Company.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -Casualties of the United States armed forces since the outbreak of the war total 165,061, the Office of War Information reported today on the basis of figures available from the War and Navy Departments.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- A bill to provide for the appointment of women to the Army Air Forces as pilots and aviation cadets was approved today by the House Military Affairs Committee after it heard Gen. H.H. Arnold, commander of the AAF, testify in support of the proposal.

Premier General Hideki Tojo warned the Japanese Diet yesterday that Japan had reached the "most critical stage in the history of the Empire" and that the situation demanded a total effort by the people to increase the nation's military power without "even one second's delay."

" I did" is the answer, sir, to your I take it not entirely rhetorical question, "Did any human boy learn or speak the whole of it?" (i.e., Macaulay's "Lays of Ancient Rome") in your editorial '"Declamation Day." Yessir, and you'll have to take this parson's word for it, since I'm not sure whether any survivors are today alive to tell the tale.

Credit collections showed a decrease of 1.87 per cent in February, compared with the 1943 month, according to the index of twenty local stores, issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York. The average collection percentage for the month was 54.65 against 56.62 a year ago. Eleven reporting stores had increases. For the two months of 1944, sixteen reporting stores had a decrease of 1.83 per cent.

New Jersey's two leading lightweights, Allie Stolz of Newark and Tippy Larkin of Garfield, will head the boxing card at Madison Square Garden tonight. These gladiators, whose paths have never crossed in the ring despite their natural sectional rivalry, will clash in a ten-round battle.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 22 (AP) -- Taking a cue from Sgt. Dutch Harrison's victory in the Charlotte open golf tournament, Freddie Corcoran, tournament manager of the Professional Golfers Association, proposed today a ten-man team match between leading civilian pros and those in service.

The benefit bridge party to be given this afternoon at the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, has been so largely oversubscribed that a similar fete has been planned for the afternoon of May 3, it has been announced by Mrs. Harry W. Hoskins, chairman of the event.

Magnificent is the word that beat describes the rally of St. John's University's basketball team, which last night at Madison Square Garden upset Kentucky in their semi-final struggle in the seventh annual national invitation tournament

SEVENTH USAAF HEADQUARTERS, Hawaii, March 21 (Delayed) -- Army fliers who made the first attacks by land-based bombers on Truk on March 15 reported here today that they were impressed by evidence of new construction going on at that principal Japanese base in the Caroline Island.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- With stocks of grain dangerously depleted, the United States will face a grave food-supply situation this year if it has a drought, Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, asserted today at a meeting of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

PHILADELPHIA, March 22 -The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a series of steps preparatory to divestment by the National Power and Light Company of its interest in the Birmingham Electric Company as part of the parent's dissolution program.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Congress took steps today to obtain a more precise definition of United States foreign policy than that given yesterday by Secretary of State Cordell Hull in his seventeen-point public statement.

SHEBOYGAN, Wis., March 22 -- Declaring that he wanted the Republican party to be a liberal, forwarding-looking party that wanted America to take its true position in the world, Wendell L. Willkie asked Wisconsin Republicans tonight to repudiate false leadership and the political philosophy of Col. Robert R. McCormick, publisher of The Chicago Tribune, and elect delegates pledged to support himself for the nomination for President.

CHICAGO, March 22. -- Governor Dewey of New York leads as the Presidential choice of Republican delegates to the 1940 National Convention, who answered the poll made by James S. Kemper, Chicago insurance man.

Plans international in scope were announced yesterday by the Rachmaninoff Memorial Fund, Inc., to honor the memory of the famous Russian musician who died last March 28 in Beverly Hills, Calif., at the height of his fame.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 22 (AP) -Gerald L.K. Smith, organizer and director of America First, declared today that a representative of Wendell Willkie promised him anything he wanted in return for his support.

CHICAGO, March 22 -- May wheat showed strength in the early trading today on the Board of Trade, advancing 1/4 cent a bushel and coming within 1/8 cent of the ceiling level before profit-taking by professional traders checked the upturn.
It was with great interest that I read in THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 4 the article of Cyrus Sulzberger on his interview with Count Sforza in Naples.

LONDON, Thursday, March 23 (AP) -- The Red Army hurled back the Germans at the southeastern end of the Ukrainian battle line yesterday by capturing Pervomaisk, driving to the approaches of Voznesensk to the southeast and reaching a point six miles from Nikolayev on the Bug estuary, Moscow announced today.

Hollywood has been paying Max Gordon banner prices recently for his stage properties, and there seems to be no let-up in that procedure. Yesterday Mr. Gordon confirmed the sale of Ruth Gordon's hit comedy, "Over 21," to Columbia Pictures for $350,000. The probable release date of the film is March 15 of next year.

A continuation of the pressure of rising costs against the Government-imposed price ceilings may prove serious to the United States Steel Corporation and ultimately to the nation, according to the annual report to stockholders by Irving S. Olds, chairman of the board, issued yesterday.

The International Business Machines Corporation, in its annual report for 1943 mailed to stockholders yesterday, showed an increase of $11,955,129 in earnings before taxes to $36,974,884 from $25,019,755 for 1942 after renegotiation settlement.

Four witnesses went to the stand in General Sessions Court yesterday as the State began to lay the foundation for its case against Wayne Thomas Lonergan, on trial for the murder of his wife, Patricia Burton Lonergan.

Artists for Victory announces an exhibition and prize competition of contemporary American paintings, sponsored by the Pepsi-Cola Company, the theme of which will be a picture of present-day America and American life. The competition is open to all artists throughout the country. Entries must be received between May 1 and May 15.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York says that the defense of constitutional government is a timely subject for discussion and hints that he may consider speaking engagements outside of New York at some future date.

Four witnesses went to the stand in General Sessions Court yesterday as the State began to lay the foundation for its case against Wayne Thomas Lonergan, on trial for the murder of his wife, Patricia Burton Lonergan.

Artists for Victory announces an exhibition and prize competition of contemporary American paintings, sponsored by the Pepsi-Cola Company, the theme of which will be a picture of present-day America and American life. The competition is open to all artists throughout the country. Entries must be received between May 1 and May 15.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York says that the defense of constitutional government is a timely subject for discussion and hints that he may consider speaking engagements outside of New York at some future date.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., March 22 -- The members of the Boston Braves are quartered most handsomely these days in the infirmary of the very exclusive Choate School. The infirmary location, however, is purely a coincidence. It merely seemed like a much more satisfactory spot than the dormitory houses they were in a year ago and has not even a remote reference to the 4-F operatives on the roster.

MONTREAL, March 22 -- A new international charter of social rights, based on the Four Freedoms and designed to encourage lifting of social and labor standards in all countries, will be presented for consideration of the International Labor Organization at its conference which is to open April 20 in Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The White House made public today more answers from Governors to President Roosevelt's questions regarding the Soldier Vote bill, which showed that while the majority of States clearly preferred using their own instead of the proposed Federal ballots, many of them liked the bill because of its requirement that Federal officers facilitate the delivery and collection of State ballots.

NEW DELHI, India, March 22 (AP) -- Japanese columns have made their first penetration of India and are pushing on westward through the Manipur mountain country in the direction of the key road junction of Imphal, thirty miles away.

Educational and group-work leaders must help young people to broaden and deepen their awareness of democracy not only in the schools but also in community activities, speakers agreed yesterday at the annual meeting of the Young Women's Hebrew Association, Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second Street.

MEXICO CITY, March 23 -- Former King Carol today expressed the certainty that he would return to the Rumanian throne in a statement to the press of Guadalajara, where he is vacationing. In the statement, which was reproduced by the local press, the former monarch denied charges of being a Fascist and asserted that the 800,000 Rumanians living in the Western Hemisphere were supporting him.

There is a familiar sound about a new Tokyo broadcast in which the Japanese people are told that they "are at the crossroads of life and death" and are urged to "die brilliantly" to save their nation. Of course, this is what the Berlin radio has been telling the German people for a year or more.

MUSKOGEE, Okla., March 23 -- Senator W. Lee O'Daniel of Texas declared tonight in a speech attacking New Dealers "from the President on down" that the tax-payers were being smothered under a public debt that would reach $10,000 a family before the war ended.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -The State Department is seeking information about a reported ousting of pro-Allied elements in the Paraguayan Government, Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today. According to the reports, younger Army officers with nationalist and pro-Argentine leanings have forced the sinisters out of office.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- If the War Labor Board's investigation into the operations of the "Little Steel" formula disclosed that the program "we created has been inequitable in its effect by working hardships upon employes, we will tell Congress, the President, or anyone else who is interested," William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, said today.

The effects of the March 15 tax collections were reflected in the Federal Reserve System figures covering the week ended Wednesday, released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Deposits were down sharply and excess reserves of the member banks contracted sharply.

LONDON, March 23 (U.P.) -- An Allied amphibious spearhead, in its deepest penetration up the Yugoslav coast, has smashed the German garrison on Solta Island, blocking the Nazi U-boat base of Spalato, while Yugoslav Partisans have crippled enemy communications in heavy fighting extending all the way to the Bulgarian frontier, it was announced today.

Broadway and Hollywood circles yesterday were discussing with considerable interest the unprecedented price placed by Alfred de Liagre Jr. on the screen and all other rights inherent in "The Voice of the Turtle." Mr. de Liagre admitted asking $3,000,000 for the "basic copyright" to John van Druten's three-character comedy.

NEW DELHI, India, March 23 -- Japanese forces driving northward from Burma into India up the Manipur River Valley have pushed to a point less than twenty-five miles south of Imphal, key road center already threatened by another Japanese army moving westward through the jungles into India, it was announced today by Allied head-quarters.

ALBANY, March 23 -- Police Justice Edward S. Kampf, overriding the objections of the State Law Department, issued John Doe warrants today for the arrest of six persons accused by Sonny Jones, a Negro, of beating him in the State Office Building headquarters assigned to the State staff in charge of the investigation of alleged crime in Albany County.

Tippy Larkin of Garfield, N.J., dropped Allie Stolz of Newark three times in the third of their scheduled ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden last night. The last knockdown occurred shortly before the bell ended the round, and Stolz was lifted to his chair.

Contributions totaling $7,423,742 for the 1944 Red Cross War Fund have been raised by the Manhattan Commerce and Industry Committee, it was announced yesterday by Eugene W. Stetson, chairman of the committee. The amount raised to date is 56.6 per cent of the committee's quota of $13,110,000, the largest goal ever accepted for the Red Cross drive by the committee.

NEW DELHI, India, March 23 (U.P.) -- Allied troops may have severed the Mandalay-Myitkyina railroad, main supply line of thousands of Japanese in northern Burma, thus threatening the rear of other enemy forces moving across the Indian border toward Imphal, Admiral the Lord Louis Mountbatten's headquarters indicated today.

James A. Moffett, former Federal Housing Administrator in the Roosevelt Administration, said yesterday that he was puzzled at the statement made on Tuesday by Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox, defending the construction of a pipeline across Arabia in order to insure adequate oil supplies.

Studies on mouse cancer cells cultured in a test tube have revealed that penicillin has a selective killing action on these cells in doses that leave normal cells growing in the same test tube unharmed. This is reported in the current issue of Science, official organ of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, by Dr. Ivor Cornman of the Wistar Institute of Anatomy and Biology in Philadelphia.

Chaplains in the armed forces are not only spiritual comforters but the trusted advisers of the men, to whom they give good offices of many sorts. Ranking as officers, they are unarmed among fighting men and often on the fighting line. Chaplains go down on torpedoed ships. They work under fire.
LONDON, March 23 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

NEWARK, N.J., March 23 -- The will of Louis Bamberger, founder of the department store of L. Bamberger Co., of this city, specifying cash bequests of $1,053,000 to relatives, employes and institutions, was probated today with the Essex County surrogate.

Acting to prevent a repetition of the serious shortage of children's snow suits, legging sets, separate leggings and snow pants which developed last year, the War Production Board has sent questionnaires to manufacturers of this merchandise as the initial step in setting up priorities and directives for 6,000,000 yards of melton and knit-back fleeces to produce about 4,500,000 garments, it was learned here yesterday.

While cameramen and a delegation of well-wishers waited, the swearing in of Special Sessions Justice Myles A. Paige as chairman of a new local rationing board that is to be opened in Brooklyn was called off yesterday afternoon because of a doubt as to the legality of Justice Paige's holding the city and Federal posts at the same time.
DETROIT, March 28 (AP) -- The Red Wings drew even with the Black Hawks at one game each in their Stanley Cup hockey play-off series tonight, winning 4 to 1, before a crowd of 12,757.

"Ave Sin Nido" ("Bird Without a Nest"), a Mexican importation, will have its local premiere today at the Belmont. Isabela Corona, Rene Cardona and David Silva are featured in the drama, the dialogue of which is Spanish. There are no English titles.

Four floors in the building at 83 Beekman Street have been leased by the Manhattan Splicing Company for office and store of wire and rope splicing. The Charles F. Noyes Company was the broker and William A. White Sons were the agents in the deal, the latter having recently sold the building for the Trinity Corporation to the American Reed Craft Corporation.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Henry J. Kaiser, the shipbuilder, said today that his company would make thirty coastwise cargo vessels for the Netherlands Indies Government. The ships will be used first in the Pacific war and then, after liberation of the Netherlands East Indies, for transport of relief supplies.

Twenty-three hundred student-journalists took possession of the Columbia University campus yesterday for the opening day of the twentieth annual Columbia Scholastic Press Association convention. Their spirits undampened by the steady downpour, they milled about the university grounds attending thirty-one clinics and conferences devoted to the analysis of elementary and high school publications.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- A sergeant hero from New York City, whose father and grandfather were members of the New York police force, is recovering use of his paralyzed lower limbs through what the War Department today described as "one of the medical miracles of the war."

HACKENSACK, N.J., March 23 -- Robert T. Deegan, 26 years old, of Dumont, and Martin A. Hoffman, 18, of Dorchester, Mass., were found guilty tonight in Oyer and Terminer Court here of the murder of Mrs. Ethel Herrmann, 40, of Dumont, but Hoffman was saved from the electric chair by the jury's recommendation for mercy, a recommendation that is mandatory upon Judge A. Demorest Del Mar, who presided.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The War Production Board, with the approval of the armed forces, is testing a plan to protect key industrial workers under 26 years of age, engaged in eight essential industries, from the sweeping demands of the draft.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -Maine and Louisiana will lead off tomorrow in a seven-State series of political conventions and primaries which will name 217 Republicans and 142 Democratic delegates for the national conventions by April 1.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -Representative Wadsworth said today that under the lend-lease legislation approved by the Foreign Affairs Committee "both Congress and the Executive are assured that any commitments which are made by the United States to post-war economic or post-war military policies will be made by both branches of the Government in areas which are properly within the province of each arm of the Government."

The stock market made another bid yesterday for a resumption of the advance, but selling in the final hour again set the list back for fractional losses among the most active issues and wider declines in the higher-price issues. For the tenth consecutive five-hour session, business on the Stock Exchange exceeded the million-share mark.

For the seventh time since opening of the trial of Lieut. (jg) Adam Rother of the United States Coast Guard, for the murder of Miss Rita Costello, 28 years old, a secretary, of 140 Crescent Avenue, New Brighton, in the Richmond County Court at St. George, Staten Island, Emil Reigi, a defense lawyer, yesterday demanded a mistrial following another clash with Judge Thomas J. Walsh.

LONDON, March 23 -- At least 326 factories, of which 103 were in the first four priorities of importance to the German war effort, were either destroyed or damaged by heavy bombers of the Royal Air Force in the first phase of the Battle of Berlin from Nov. 18, 1943, to Feb. 15, 1944.

The help of householders in exposing coal dealers who cheat in weight, price or quality was asked yesterday by the coal trade in the wake of a Department of Markets drive to convict dealers guilty of irregularities.

QUEBEC, March 23 (Canadian Press) -- The Quebec legislative assembly today gave first reading to a bill involving expropriation of Montreal Light, Heat and Power Consolidated and establishment of a provincial hydroelectric commission.

RACINE, Wis., March 23 -- Wendell L. Willkie characterized today as completely ineffective to prevent future wars the post-war alliance with Great Britain recently suggested by Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York, his rival for the Republican Presidential nomination.
Permit me to add a postscript to your timely editorial of March 17.

Only that part of income which is spent should be taxed while the part saved should be exempt, Dr. Irving Fisher, professor emeritus, Yale University, declared last night at the first symposium of the Federal Bar Tax Law Institute in the Federal Court House, Foley Square.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 23 -- A rain-drenched, fog-laden Yankee training camp was made more depressing today for Manager Joe McCarthy with the latest word from draft authorities affecting two of the athletes under his tutelage.

There is one thought on the very old promise of a simplified tax law which may perhaps be worth some consideration. Cordell Hull was the draftsman of the first law. In 1917 he was the chairman of the Business Men's committee (am not sure of the name) appointed by Secretary McAdoo which drafted the regulations under which the unworkable and dangerous 1917 excess profits tax law became tolerable and effective.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 23 -- In Rumania the situation is obscured a bit today following confirmation of last night's reports that Premier Antonescu had proceeded to Hitler's headquarters for "instructions." According to Rumanian sources, the Marshal had pleaded urgent military business having prior claim on his presence in the country but had been overruled by the Fuehrer and is now in Berchtesgaden.

Vegetables and Victory gardens occupied the spotlight yesterday, the second day of the annual Garden Week program held by THE NEW YORK TIMES in cooperation with the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State and the Garden Club of New Jersey at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Fortyfourth Street.

Government agencies must be left in command of any planning or controls necessary to stimulate high production in the post-war era, Mordecai Ezekiel, economic adviser to the Secretary of Agriculture, declared last night before the bimonthly open forum of the National Industrial Conference Board.

To furnish the 200 capable farm hands sought for summer-long jobs by up-State farm families, the Farm Recruitment Office of the local War Manpower Commission has enlarged its training program for city women over 16 years of age, it was announced yesterday.
LONDON, March 23 -- Most sections of the stock markets here were quiet and the tone remained firm today although not much business was done.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -Whether any substantial number of men under 26 in railroading, coal mining, lumbering and other essential non-munitions industries will keep their occupational draft deferments hang in the balance tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -Senator Kenneth McKellar, acting chairman of the Appropriations Committee, decided today to seek a compromise on the amendments to the pending independent offices supply bill which would restrict the operations of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- During the week ended March 18 the Bureau of Labor Statistics' Index for commodity prices in primary markets advanced 0.2 per cent, principally because of much higher prices for grains, livestock and cotton.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- A "comprehensive program" designed to rreduce consumption of Pennsylvania hard coal and coke by householders and other domestic consumers to seven-eighths of their annual requirements will go into effect on April 1, the beginning of the 1944-45 "coal year."

Employment and payrolls in General Motors, keeping pace with production needs, rose to new levels in 1493, according to a statement issued yesterday by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman, preliminary to his annual report to the stockholders.

TORRE DEL GRECO, Italy, March 23 -- The worst of the most awesome show provided by Mount Vesuvius in seventy-two years seemed over tonight. This coastal town between Naples and Torre Annunziata bore the brunt of the last day of the eruption, which began Sunday.

ALBANY, March 23 -- Governor Dewey vetoed today the Mitchell bill which provided that upon the death of a member of the New York County General Sessions Court Retirement System his accumulated deductions should be paid to his estate or heirs.

Most shipments of apparel intended for pre-Easter selling will be completed next week, reports in the wholesale markets here yesterday indicated. Cancellations, placed on past-due orders or shipments, are not likely to have been made in time.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull expressed gratification at his press conference today over the atttention given by Congress and the public to the principles of foreign policy to which he has been giving utterance for two years.

Thirty-two shoe wholesalers and jobbers, who do an annual business of $10,000,000, were ordered yesterday by Federal Judge Murray Hulbert to stop selling or delivering shoes after five days unless they have, within that time, filed with the Office of Price Administration records the Federal price control agency requires to protect consumers.

A business appraisal of post-war markets on a scale exceeding all surveys heretofore conducted by the Government has been undertaken by the Committee for Economic Development, T.A. MacGowan, chairman of the group's marketing committee, announced yesterday.

Need for the cotton textile industry to accelerate its production, which fell off last year as compared with the 1942 peak, was highlighted this week at meetings of trade representatives in Washington with the Army. Industry representatives invited to the gatherings included association executives as well as individual leaders and representatives of the National Association of Manufacturers.

New records in electric power and natural gas production were established last year by the Cities Service Company system, according to the company's thirty-fourth annual report to stockholders, released yesterday by W. Alton Jones, president.

LOS ANGELES, March 23 (AP) -Joan Berry testified in Federal Court today of a long series of intimate relations in Beverly Hills and New York City with Charles Chaplin, on trial on two charges of Mann Act violation.

In this month when the Red Cross asks every American to support its 1944 work for our fighting men and their loved ones, some of us are late with our contributions. Perhaps we do not see clearly what a gift to the fund will accomplish; what it will mean to a wounded soldier, to a war prisoner, to a homesick lad in a strange land beyond the sea.

Mayor La Guardia's peace plan for the American Labor party was rejected yesterday by right wing leaders, who described it as an evasion of the issues and an attempt "to confuse the party's enrolled voters." It had been previously accepted by Sidney Hillman, who is spearheading the drive to oust the present party leadership.

One million copies of a War Department booklet outlining essential steps that men about to be inducted in the armed forces should take for the protection of their own and the legal rights of their dependents are now being distributed to selective service local boards throughout the country, it was announced yesterday by John Kirkland Clark, member of the War Work Committee of the New York Bar Association and co-author of the booklet.

Two local officials of the War Production Board were among four persons arrested on charges of soliciting bribes to get WPB permission for a new manufacturing plant. Federal Bureau of Investigation agents, acting on a complaint by Joseph Brandwen, assistant United States attorney, took the three men and a woman before United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter, who released each in bail of $1,000.

Certain products of the Republic Steel Corporation are being sold at ceiling prices that do not cover works manufacturing costs, Tom M. Girdler, chairman, and R.J. Wysor, president of the company, declare in their annual report for 1943.

Twenty-four first-term Republican members of the House of Representatives, all friendly to the idea of post-war international cooperation, are to talk today with Secretary Hull about American war aims. They wrote him a week ago, requesting information "as to the objectives of American policy and the steps currently being taken in furtherance of these objectives," and the present conference is the result.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- In a continuation of its policy to loosen its grip on war materials as they become less critical to military output, the War Production Board listed a number of industrial articles "essential to the war effort" today which may use aluminum in limited quantities.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 23 -- A post-war end of "so-called progressive education," whose "helpless victims," the students, were described as sufferers from "all manner of educational dyspepsia and malnutrition," was predicted tonight by Dr. Robert G. Sproul, president of the University of California.

No poll or straw vote is unanswerable. There is always a great body of silent voters on whom one can fall back, more than enough to make an argument. This latest poll of the 1940 Republican delegates who nominated Wendell Willkie shows them today two-thirds for Governor Dewey.

LONDON, March 23 -- In a desperate demonstration of Nazi power, Adolf Hitler, holding Hungary under his thumb, today launched a campaign of bullying the other southeastern European nations into a stand-or-perish position with Germany against the onrushing Red Army.

Substantial reconversion of many war plants to production of civilian lines within the next six months is regarded as a "distinct probability" by the retail furniture trade and many merchant, believing that such action will result in unemployment and also in income reduction because of decreased or eliminated overtime wage payments, have insisted recently on more stringent requirements in extending credit to war workers, a dealer spokesman disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull looked with a friendly eye today upon a London report that Premier Joseph Stalin, in announcing his intention to recognize the Badoglio Government in Italy, had in mind establishing direct contact with that government rather than actually according diplomatic recognition to it.

Newbold Morris, City Council president, disclosed yesterday that the directors of the City Center of Music and Drama had been negotiating with representatives of two large motion picture companies with a view to inducing the motion picture industry to underwrite drama presentations at the center.

ALGIERS, March 23 -- In its debate tomorrow the French Consultative Assembly will reach the heart of the question of what will follow in France if the Allies finally accept Gen. Charles de Gaulle and the French Committee of National Liberation as the instruments of civil authority in liberated territory.

The Polish Telegraph Agency released Yesterday an official statement by the Polish Minister of Social Welfare, Jan Stanczyk, replying to charges made in an article by James Aldridge which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES last Sunday dealing with conditions in the Polish settlement in Teheran.

Four Army Air Force fliers, whose combined actions include the bombing of Mount Cassino Monastery, raids on German industrial centers and forays against the Japanese in the New Guinea and Solomon Islands area, related their experiences in an interview at Army Public Relations, 90 Church Street.

Recalling the early days of the war when New York City lacked sufficient military protection, Mayor La Guardia yesterday urged volunteers to keep up their war work "until the order for demobilization comes." The request came at a luncheon held by the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office in the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway, to pay tribute to the city's volunteer workers.

NOTTINGHAM, England, March 23 -- Amid all the red-robed ceremony this ancient city could supply, forty-eight GI's from forty-eight States drank toasts, ate luxurious food and rubbed shoulders with generals today in celebration of American-British friendship.

The wholesale produce markets in this city, which have been closed on Saturdays for the last month or more, will return to the six-day business week on April 1 because of the heavy influx of perishable fruits and vegetables that will start next month.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, March 24 (U.P.) -- Two Japanese freighters, seven coastal vessels and twenty-three barges were sunk off Wewak Wednesday as Allied bombers blasted another Japanese attempt to ship supplies to their isolated New Guinea coastal bases, it was announced today.

The Nazi occupation of Hungary portends catastrophe to hundreds of thousands of Jews in Europe, Dr. Israel Goldstein, president of the Zionist Organization of America, who has just completed a five-week trip to England, declared at a press luncheon held yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

To counteract undue optimism resulting from our mounting air assault on Germany let me quote from a letter received from my cousin only today. He is 20 years old and the radio operator on one of our B-24 Liberator bombers, which, when it is not dropping bombs over Europe, is based in England:

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- A week ago there was published in this space a summary of the general principles which guide the administration on major problems of foreign policy. These were compiled from utterances made during the past two years by Secretary of State Hull. Two days ago the State Department issued the full phraseology of these statements, making an array of seventeen points.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 23 -- Miss Matilda Mendelson of Highland Park, N.J., a senior at the New Jersey College for Women and managing editor of the college's weekly newspaper, received today the annual $25 award of The Jersey Journal of Jersey City for her essay on "The Contributions of Newspaper Advertising to the War Effort."

The Ruppert Brewery, New York, has mailed to its dealers along the Atlantic Seaboard, a full color broadside outlining its 1944 advertising program, J. Kingsley Gould, advertising director announced yesterday. The Ruppert advertising budget is 10 per cent larger than last year and plans include the use of newspapers, magaines, outdoor painted posters, and radio, he said.

Two questions are answered by the swift and ruthless moves to put all the countries of southeastern Europe under military occupation. It is clear that Hungary is only the first of the Danubian states to be deprived of any semblance of self-government. The same treatment will be applied to the neighboring nations.
It is just one basketball tournament after another in Madison Square Garden these nights, for, with one nearing its end, another is on the verge of starting in the house that Tex Rickard built.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Senator Francis Maloney of Connecticut was unanimously elected today chairman of a special eleven-man Senate committee created to work out an oil policy for the United States. It will investigate the international oil situation and incidentally the Middle East pipeline projected by the Petroleum Reserve Corporation.

MOSCOW, Friday, March 24 -The Soviet High Command announced last night a new offensive by Marshal Gregory K. Zhukoff's troops on the First Ukrainian Front in the Tarnopol-Proskurov direction, which netted a gain of twenty-five to thirty-seven miles, including the capture of more than 200 populated points in the southern Ukrainian territory above the Dniester.

LONDON, Friday, March 24 (AP) -- The Russian announced last night a thirty-seven-mile deep break-through in the stubbornly defended Tarnopol hinge area of the Eastern Front and Berlin reported that other Red Army forces to the northwest, in a forty-three-mile advance deep inside Poland, had broken into the town of Kovel on the main road to Warsaw.
LONDON, March 23 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Force in Europe communique:

HICKHAM FIELD, Hawaii, March 23 -- One hundred and forty Wacs, the first assigned to a Pacific area, want it to be known that they object to having any "glamour" attached to their service here with the Army's Air Transport Command, Lieut. Lois Burton of Athens, Ga., informed the press after the girls held their first review here this morning.

Prize winners in the ninth annual exhibit of the Press Photographers Association of New York will receive their awards tonight from the hands of Governor Dewey at the Museum of Science and Industry, Rockefeller Center. The ceremonies will be broadcast on a coast-to-coast hook-up over WEAF from 10:45 to 11 P.M.

One of the basic questions that will be faced after the war is whether or not savings in this country are to be invested and managed within the private enterprise system, or whether they will be turned over to the Government. A.L.M. Wiggins, president of the American Bankers Association told 700 bankers attending the Savings Conference of the association yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, March 23 -- One of the most notable contributions to the success of the American Red Cross in the welfare service to the armed forces overseas is the assistance, voluntary and paid, of citizens of the countries where these forces are operating.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -President Roosevelt today proclaimed April 6 as Army Day in honor of "the valiant soldiers" who have been welded by the fire of battle into "a mighty army of liberation."

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Chairman Doughton of the Ways and Means Committee introduced legislation today to increase the Federal debt limit to $260,000,000,000. The limit now is $210,000,000,000, raised from $125,000,000,000 last March.

LONDON, Friday, March 24 -- Well over 500 Fortresses and Liberators hammered five important targets in Germany yesterday under the protection of approximately 1,000 American fighters in the final blow of a twenty-four-hour air assault that has been the heaviest of the war.

MEXICO CITY, March 23 -- The lifting of trade barriers after the war was advocated by Foreign Minister Ezequiel Padilla in a speech he delivered to the members of the Swedish Economic Mission, which is at present discussing with the Mexican Government post-war trade questions between the two countries.

Models dressed to illustrate social activities and representing several age groups took their place in a novel fashion show yesterday. They took the part of the young society woman, the suburban wife, "Miss Subways," the young business executive and the army wife.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total holdings of United States Government securities to have increased $132,349,000 during the week, while note circulation for the system as a whole decreased $61,732,000.

George E. Dyke, president of Robert Gair Company, Inc., said at the annual meeting of stockholders here yesterday that while the decline in the supply of waste paper has been arrested in recent weeks, there has not yet been an appreciable improvement, with the current available supply still well under demand.

OTTAWA, March 23 -- An attack on monopolies and cartels was made in the House of Commons today by M.J. Coldwell, leader of the Cooperative Commonwealth Federation, with particular reference to Canadian Industries, Ltd., which he claimed was jointly owned and controlled by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. in the United States and Imperial Chemical Industries in the United Kingdom.

BALBOA, C.Z., March 23 -- Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt took time off today from her many visits to servicemen here to meet the press of Panama and foreign correspondents at the residence of Lieut. Gen. George H. Brett and tell of her trip through the Caribbean area, the Atlantic South American coast and Panama.

PEARL HARBOR, March 28 (U.P.) -- Army and Navy Liberator bombers, teaming up in a renewed assault on the island approaches to the Japanese base at Truk, bombed Ponape and Kusaie on Tuesday for the thirty-seventh air strike against the enemy in the Carolines since Feb. 14, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz reported today.

The five-cent fare emerged victorious yesterday from a sham battle in the Board of Estimate, in which the main casualties were the blossoming campaigns of business and civic groups for higher charges on the city's unified transit lines.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The White House reported that it had heard by noon today from 856 individuals demanding that President Roosevelt veto the soldier vote bill and from only four who wanted him to sign it.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- During the week ended March 22 member bank reserve balances decreased $300,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves rose from an increase of $418,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve banks and a decrease of $70,000,000 in gold stock, offset in part by an increase of $79,000,000 in reserve bank credit and decreases of $72,000,000 in money in circulation and $29,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts.

Arguments of the Securities and Exchange Commission to get Canadian authorities to check sales of unregistered securities by Canadians in this country have now been reinforced by Canadian voices and something seems about to be done.

MOSCOW, March 23 -- The Moscow newspapers refrained again today from making editorial comment on Finland's refusal to accept the Russian armistice terms -- an omission that Allied diplomatic observers thought highly significant and perhaps indicative that all hope for Finland's early withdrawal from the war was not completely gone.

LONDON, March 23 (AP) -- The condition statement of the Bank of England for the week ended March 22 reported an increase of 2,159,000 in note circulation, which established a new all-time high of 1,093,621,000.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, March 24 (UP) -- A communique:
The Hill-Williamson bill, passed by the Legislature and now awaiting action by Governor Dewey, involves several questions of direct interest to hundreds of thousands of car owners.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 23 -Although the reason that prompted baseball's guiding genius to dictate that this year's spring training must again risk the hazards of March weather in the north may be a trifle obscure, there can be no doubt of the results that are being obtained.
NEW DELHI, India March 23 (UP) -- A communique:

An exciting concert given by Artur Rodzinski and the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall packed the auditorium and brought the audience to its feet at the last with a royal greeting to young William Kapell, who had played the Rachmaninoff Second Concerto as one of the memorials to the composer, who died last March 28 in California.

The Gillette Safety Razor Company earned $10,030,449 before taxes last year, or $1,282,541 more than in 1942, according to the annual report of J.P. Spans Jr., president, mailed to stockholders yesterday.
MONTREAL, March 23 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens, winning tonight's game, 5 to 1, tied their four-out-of-seven Stanley Cup semifinals with the Toronto Maple Leafs at one-all.

WASINGTON, March 23 -- Department-store sales in the third week ended March 18 were 17 per cent above sales in the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following table shows percentage changes from corresponding periods of last year:

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 23 -- Two Dodger holdouts arrived overnight, but only one remained today. He was Fritz Ostermueller, veteran southpaw pitcher, who signed his contract and participated in his first workout.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -Aroused by charges that farmers have been compelled to sign up with the Triple A or risk losing their gasoline rations and draft deferments, the House late today wrote into the Agriculture Department Appropriation Bill a ban on such practices.
The Burma operations have taken a sudden new turn.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Friday, March 24 -- Jules S. Bache of New York, banker, philanthropist and patron of art, died here at 12:10 A.M. today in his winter home, 148 Barton Avenue, after an illness of several weeks. His age was 82.

ALBANY, March 23 -- Appropriations of about $4,400,000 by the Legislature, apart from items scheduled by Governor Dewey in his budget message, served to bring the scheduled State expenditures for the fiscal year starting April 1, to within a million dollars of expenditures of the previous year, according to a summary issued by Chairman D. Mallory Stephens of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson severely reprimanded today an American war correspondent who wrote from overseas that the air forces had been operating, independently of a joint Army-Navy command in the Sicilian action in which twenty-three of our transport planes were shot down, some by our own Army and Navy guns.

Seven more State witnesses added bits of oral mosaic to the People's case against Wayne Thomas Lonergan yesterday in his trial in General Sessions Court for the murder of Patricia Burton Lonergan, his wife.

An early reaction yesterday that carried prices in the local cotton market to net losses of 4 to 9 points was followed by an upturn that lifted the active months to new high levels for the season, with the finish near the best levels of the day unchanged to 7 points net higher on the New York Cotton Exchange.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The supply of newsprint this year may drop 217,000 tons below the low 1943 total, according to a report issued by the Office of War Information today on the basis of data received from the War Production Board, the War and Commerce Departments, the Government Printing Office and the Bureau of the Budget.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Development of necessary inter-regional and feeder highways in the New York-New Jersey area after the war will require an expenditure of about $150,000,000 a year, Guy Kelcey, highway analyst of the Port of New York Authority, told the House Committee on Roads today.

The movement launched by John J. O'Connell Jr., Albany County chairman, for the unseating of James A. Farley as Democratic State chairman showed signs of a quick collapse yesterday. Doubt was expressed by local Democratic leaders that it had any substantial backing and in Washington spokesmen for the White House and the Democratic National Committee denied any connection with it.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Retailers of luxury items, subject to a new 20 per cent Federal excise tax on April 1, were provided by OPA today with a number of alternative methods of posting or stating their new prices to buyers.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -Legislation to extend the Lend-Lease Act another year was approved by the House Foreign Affairs Committee today, but it wrote in an amendment to give Congress a check on any post-war military or economic obligations to which the President might attempt to commit the United States in writing off lend-lease contracts as paid.

NAPLES, March 23 -- All German attempts yesterday to knock out Allied bridges over the Rapido River in the Cassino battle area failed, while Gurkhas holding isolated high points on Hangman's Hill were again successfully supplied by air.

LONDON, March 23 -- The recoil of Germany's armies on the Eastern Front and political upheavals in the Balkans have presented to Adolf Hitler the prospect of a first-class food crisis. The good harvest of last year is expected to tide him over the greater part of this year, but from next September on the problem of finding food is bound to be acute, according to the best-informed quarters here.

The Lane Realty Company, an investing syndicate represented by D. George Levine has bought the six-story apartment house at 967 Ocean Avenue, near Ditmas Avenue, in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, through Ludwig M. Bier, broker.

The latest from Harlan Major about the avocation of supplying fishing tackle to overseas service men is that the work is booming, he now has thirty-five volunteer assistants to keep the gear rolling and this week a thousand fishing kits are being shipped to Uncle Sam's far-flung outposts.

The Baltimore, Md., Commissioners of Finance will offer for sale on Tuesday a block of $2,311,000 of the city's 3 1/2 per cent water-system bonds, due from Nov. 1, 1970 to 1981. The bonds, which have been held by various city sinking funds, do not represent new financing by the city.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Secretary Stimson said today that organized labor representatives were now satisfied that the Army was giving a fair picture of labor activities through its information media distributed to troops.

NAPLES, March 23 -- The biggest field guns in the Allied arsenal, giant 240-millimeter cannon, opened up a heavy bombardment against German strongholds on the edge of Cassino today and destroyed one large fortress, while New Zealand troops ground steadily forward through the ruins in bloody combat.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 23 -- Ellen Drew has been signed by Pine and Thomas for the lead in their Paramount picture, "Dark Mountain," a drama of the Northwest, in which Chester Morris and Robert Lowery will have the male leads.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -Warning that the road to Rome would be blocked by "many Cassinos," Brig. Gen. William H. Wilbur, deputy commander of the Thirty-sixth Infantry Division, the first high officer to report back from the Cassino front, explained today that Allied troops cannot risk by-passing the stubbornly defended Italian mountain stronghold because it would be virtually impossible for supply lines to move around it.

CHICAGO, March 23 -- Wheat showed a relatively firm undertone on the Board of Trade here today, although July was under some pressure early as the result of continued favorable weather and crop reports, but offerings dried up when rye strengthened and a good rally followed May continues to act tight and sold within 1/8 cent a bushel of the ceiling at one time, the bulge being checked by profit taking.

A CENTRAL PACIFIC BASE, March 23 -- The coming of American armed forces to the low green atolls of the Central Pacific, where few white men besides traders and missionaries had been seen before, has enriched the folklore of these islands with many a spicy tale.
Dorothy Canfield Fisher has received the Parents' Magazine 1943 medal for her book "Our Young Folks" published last October by Harcourt, Brace.

Rear Admiral William R. Munroe, USN, former commandant of the Seventh Naval District, Miami, and commander of the Gulf Sea Frontier, will become commandant of the Third Naval District, effective April 1, the Navy announced yesterday. Admiral Munroe will replace Rear Admiral Edward J. Marquart, who will be placed on the retired list.

The unprecedented supply of fresh eggs in the city has resulted in a near state of "demoralization" in wholesale dairy trading, according to the New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets. Heavy receipts from Eastern areas are creating a difficult situation in view of the shortage of storage space.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 24 -- Manager Joe McCarthy of the Yankees today looked over his 1944 squad with an appraising eye -- and came across a paradox. The smallest group of athletes he has ever directed in training is the "biggest" he has ever clustered under his paternal wing.

LONDON, Saturday, March 25 -- Establishing a new United States Air Force record for attacks against Hitler's Continental fortress, Flying Fortresses and Liberators blasted away yesterday at the Reich and other European points for the nineteenth time this month.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 24 -- The public debt of Westchester County and its cities, towns, villages and school districts has been reduced to $197,600,000, a decrease of $70,000,000 in the last ten years and $13,000,000 since a year ago, William B. Folger, county budget director, said today in a report to the Board of Supervisors and the County Executive.

LONDON, Saturday, March 25 (U.P.) -- Moscow's midnight communique announced that the Germans were fleeing down the western side of the front abandoning tanks, cannon and trucks before the crushing Soviet offensive. Moscow spoke of the German divisions as being "thoroughly defeated."
Effective at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow first-class local postage rates will increase from 2 to 3 cents an ounce and the cost of air mail will be 8 cents, compared to the present rate of 6 cents an ounce.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Representative Martin of Massachusetts, House minority leader, was reported in line today for the permanent chairmanship of the Republican National Convention but the choice of a keynote speaker appears to be wide open.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Extension of the present Price Control Act for two years after the war ends, as a means of combating "the most dangerous" inflationary threat that the war has created, was advocated today by Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

BUENOS AIRES, March 24 -- The Government has ordered a 1,000-peso fine and twenty-four-hour suspension for the All America Cables Company, charging it tried to elude Government control of international communications by unlawfully delivering three cables from Lima, Peru, to The United Press on March 8.

WASHINGTON, March 24 The United Steel Workers of America, affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, opened its argument today for revising the "Little Steel" formula, cornerstone of the wage stabilization program, by presenting to a panel of the War Labor Board a brief of 166 pages summarizing demands for wage increases totaling $341,000.000.

NEW DELHI, India, March 24 -- British Imperial troops have driven the Japanese from three positions covering the Tiddim-Imphal invasion road into India and smashed enemy attacks in the Kabaw Valley border sector, inflicting heavy casualties, Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten's headquarters announced today.

On the tenth anniversary yesterday of his signing of the act that provided for the independence of the Philippines, President Roosevelt sent a message of faith and hope to the people of those islands. It reaffirmed the solemn pledges we have given to lift from their shoulders the heavy yoke of the Japanese invaders.

Sustained demand, but of a limited nature, returned yesterday to the stock market and permitted a resumption of the rallying movement, although the comeback was selective and of fractional range for the most part. SelIing was ?, countered only in the final, ho"j ana some irregularity, develo but the general list still em-alhci on the higher side at the elose

PITTSBURGH, March 24 -- Continuing the rise which started in early March business in the Pittsburgh district last week reached the best levels since mid-February, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -Eleven more enemy vessels have been sunk by United States submarines operating in the Pacific and Far East, increasing to 653 the announced total of ships sunk or damaged in the unceasing war against Japanese supply lines, the Navy announced today.

Every boy of 16 or 17 should be trained in some occupational skill, since the 100,000 young men reaching the age of 18 each month will make up a substantial portion of groups to be inducted into the armed services in the next two years, Maj. Ralph C. Wenrich, executive officer of the Pre-Induction Training Branch, Army Service Forces, declared yesterday.

A loan exhibition of paintings, prints, drawings and sculpture, titled "Five Centuries of Ballet," will pen at the Wildenstein Galleries on the evening of April 12 for the benefit of the French Hospital. An admission of $5 will be charged for the opening night and 55 cents thereafter.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES ON BOUGAINVILLE, SOLOMON ISLANDS, March 20 (Delayed) -- The American beachhead on Empress Augusta Bay is a roughly semi-circular area of about thirty square miles, bounded behind by the seas and ahead by a seventeen-mile line through jungle, swamp and foothills.

So many women have asked us about the new system of ration stamps, confessing utter inability to budget their points under the program, that we went to the Office of Price Administration for an authoritative explanation.

The President's vigorous statement on war victims yesterday took in the crimes of the Japanese as well as those of the Nazis. Its timeliness, however, is due to Hitler's advance into the Balkans and to the probability that many thousands of refugees in those regions, who until lately have suffered only a comparatively mild form of persecution, will now feel the full weight of the Nazi revenge.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 2d -- It wasn't exactly a heat wave that cracked down on this training camp today, but the sun did shine. It was dry underfoot and the result was a three-hour outdoor session for both Mel Ott's Giants and Gabby Hartnett's Little Giants.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Higher excise taxes effective April 1 will add 2 to 4 cents to the by-the-drink price of liquor or sparkling wine and 1 cent to the cost of an eight-ounce glass of beer, ale, porter or stout, the Office of Price Administration stated today.
An exceptional program of old music was offered at the first of Adolph Busch's chamber music concerts last night in Town Hall.

Mayor La Guardia last night asked 1,500 citizens from the eighty-four police precincts of the city to cooperate with the authorities in closing candy stores and poolrooms which, through gambling devices or the sale of salacious literature, "entice" 'teen-age children and thus cause juvenile delinquency.

Herbert E. Gaston, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, will speak at the fourth annual communion breakfast of the United States Treasury Department Chapter of the St. George Association at 10:30 A.M. tomorrow at the Hotel Commodore. Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, will preside.
A communique, as broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
