BRISTOL, Pa., March 24 -- Henry J. Kaiser made it plain today that he was available for drafting by the 5,000 stockholders of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation to remain as president of the company and chairman of its board of directors.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- President Roosevelt renewed his pledge of freedom to the Philippine people today on the tenth anniversary of the signing of the Tydings-McDuffie Act, and reminded them that "the Philippine Government residing here possesses all the attributes of an independent nation."

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- President Roosevelt said today that he had accepted the resignation of Lowell Mellett, one of his administrative assistants, to become a columnist for The Washington Star, adding that he might have "to eat some of the things I've said in the past about columnists and publishers."

LONDON, March 24 (AP) -- The Rumanian Legation in Ankara, Turkey, announced today it had confirmed the German occupation of Rumania, and diplomatic quarters in London agreed that Adolf Hitler's Balkan grab had forestalled any effective peace move by the Nazis' nervous satellite nations.

Asserting that much important news from abroad has been released only after it leaked out and became the subject of widespread gossip, Governor Dewey charged last night that the Roosevelt Administration seemed to have embarked on "a deliberate and dangerous policy of suppression of news at home."

With oil deliveries to the East Coast now running at record rate of around 300,000 barrels daily more than in the pre-war period, there should be no necessity of further reducing the amount of gasoline available to civilian users. Ralph K. Davies, Deputy Petroleum Administrator, announced yesterday that deliveries to the East Coast last week averaged 1,790,960 barrels daily, compared with the previous high of 1,710,000 in the week ended Dec. 4, 1943.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- A program to curb the "mounting loss and damage to scarce commodities while in transit" was embarked on cooperatively today by the War Production Board, the Association of American Railroads, the American Trucking Association and other shippers' organizations.

LONDON, Saturday, March 25 (U.P.) -- Reports in diplomatic quarters here said today that the Germans, apparently trying to strengthen their northern defenses against Russia, had landed in the strategic Aaland Islands, covering the entrance to the Gulf of Bothnia between Sweden and Finland.

NAPLES, March 24 -- Stubbornly fighting Germans, infiltrating the ruins of Cassino by subterranean passages and hidden gullies, have recaptured one-fourth of the town after winning possession of six strong points, front dispatches disclosed tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- President Roosevelt announced today his acceptance of the resignation of Leo T. Crowley as Alien Property Custodian and named to the post James E. Markham of Lowell, first assistant to Mr. Crowley.
The section of governor Dewey's address last night dealing with Government information and censorship follows:

RICHMOND, Va., March 24 -Patents for an air-conditioning system for automobiles, a rubberless automobile tire and a system for sterilizing air stand out among the 452 listed as granted in this week's issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

Two new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At Loew's Criterion the new attraction will be "The Impostor," a topical adventure drama presented by Universal and starring Jean Gabin. The film was produced and directed by Julien Duvivier, who also wrote the screen play.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- A manufacturers' price increase of 1 cent a yard for the most popular weight of shirting chambray and covert and 3/4 cent for basic denim, with related increases for other weights and finishes of denim, was announced today by the Office of Price Administration.

A decision handed down Thursday by the United States Customs Court, Appellate Term, First Division, upheld a lower court ruling won by Alfred Dunhill of London, Inc., importer, and decided against the Attorney General's contention that the British purchase tax forms part of dutiable value.

The appearance of the first industrial financing in a month and the first offering of railroad securities since January brought a moderate expansion in activities in the new investment market here this week. Three issues of bonds aggregating $10,700,000 were offered to the public, compared with a single flotation for $1,750,000 last week and three loans totaling $13,493,000 in the comparative week a year ago.

Characterizing the trend toward increased purchases of farm real estate and other investments in land as an incipient "land boom" and "close to the No. 1 problem of America today," William I. Myers, dean of the New York State College of Agriculture, Cornell University, recommended yesterday the investment of excess farm revenue in War Bonds.

What to do with the Ottens, Kurlands and other cloud-buster centers who function as "goalies" was one of several problems taken up at yesterday's session of the National Association of Basketball Coaches in the Hotel Belvedere. The meeting was preliminary to today's conference, at which several points under discussion will be framed for presentation to the rule-makers.
NEW DELHI, India, March 24 (AP) -- A Southeast Asia communique: In the Hukawng Valley American-trained Chinese forces, after repulsing three counterattacks, continued their advance.

War, emptier of the colleges, is suspending one by one their periodicals and newspapers, dear to the old graduates. Surprising descendants of those stuffy and short-lived magazines, rich in Hebrew and Greek, that once came from the older colleges, these modern publications are sprightly spoofers and have a promontorious nose for news that sometimes gets them into trouble with the libel laws.

Mayor La Guardia mollified right wing leaders of the American Labor party yesterday by explaining that his peace plan, which they had rejected, upheld them on their two fundamental contentions in the current primary fight for control of the State party machinery.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- President Roosevelt said today that he would wait until the middle of next week to act on the Soldier Vote Bill. He has until midnight of next Friday to approve it, veto it or let it become law without his signature.

Prospects for the shirt and pajama manufacturing industry to supply minimum civilian requirements this year hinge on governmental action under which specific yardage would be earmarked for producers. Hope is felt that the Office of Civilian Requirements will offer relief as it recently did in the knitting industry by allocating yarns for production of specific lines for fabrication during the second quarter of the year.
LONDON, March 24 (AP) -- Following is the text of the remarks of Prime Minister Churchill yesterday during a review of United States air-borne soldiers:

The defense in Wayne T. Lonergan's trial for the murder of his wife, Patricia Burton Lonergan, tried to prove yesterday that 20year-old brandy, denial of sleep and promises of light prosecution were employed to force a murder confession from the defendant.

Six "masterpieces" of floral art were created yesterday on the stage at The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, by experts in flower arrangement for the benefit of an audience of garden enthusiasts -- the final event in the second annual Garden Week held by THE NEW YORK TIMES in cooperation with the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, Inc., and the Garden Club of New Jersey.

Bacardi Imports, Inc., H. Bartol Estrada, president, has leased for a long term a floor in the Fuller Building at Madison Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street for executive offices for the importation and distribution of Bacardi rum in this country.

LEWISTON, Me., March 24 (AP) -- Maine's Democrats in convention today adopted unanimously a resolution instructing their delegates to Chicago to vote for the renomination of President Roosevelt "so long as his name shall be before the Democratic convention."

Approximately 300 friends and members of the American Women's Voluntary Services gathered at the Hotel Pierre yesterday to witness the first public showing of an official movie, "How Strong Is the Enemy." This picture was produced by the War Department for American war plants, so that its workers could visualize how their efforts, in turning out equipment, are translated into effective implements on the fighting fronts.

JANESVILLE, Wis., March 24 -- Asserting that the thinking of the American people might be changed and the result of the Presidential election might be determined by the coming invasion of Europe, Wendell L. Willkie repudiated today a recent statement by Harrison E. Spangler, Republican national chairman, and declared that he did not wish to win the Presidency by capitalizing on the discontent of American citizens, native or foreign-born.

ALBANY, March 24 -- Governor Dewey vetoed without comment today the Sullivan bill providing for readjustment of the pensions of former policemen who retired prior to enactment of the present schedules of compensation and retirement pensions. The bill was designed to help such persons meet the rise in living costs which has occurred since they left public service on comparatively small pensions.

A surprise witness called by District Attorney Farrell M. Kane at the trial of Lieut. (jg) Adam G. Rother of the United States Coast Guard in the Richmond County Court at St. George, S.I., for the murder of Miss Rita Costello of 140 Crescent Avenue, New Brighton, late yesterday afternoon testified that the defendant told him that he shot the 28-year-old secretary when she demanded more money than he could give her for an abortion.

A low-flying plane or planes buzzing perilously close to the Empire State Building, the R.C.A. Building, the Chanin Building and other lofty midtown structures at about 3:50 o'clock yesterday afternoon brought complaints to police and military authorities.

CHICAGO, March 24 (AP) -- Philip R. O'Brien, president of the Chicago Board of Trade, asserted today that wheat reserves are being drained at an "alarming" rate which cannot be continued "without facing the necessity of bread rationing."

Within a few blocks of the Yorkville theatre where, in ante-bellum days, the Nazi picture, "Victory in the West," played to crowds, the curtain was rung down yesterday on a different kind of display -- the household and art effects of a group of banished Nazi propagandists.

On June 1, 1942, the anti-Axis world was electrified by the news of the one-thousand-plane raid on Cologne, the first mass raid of such dimensions. This was the air war on a giant scale that had been so long predicted. This was the most dramatic evidence that had yet been offered that the scales of air superiority had now turned in favor of the Allies.

Laird Archer, for many years foreign director of the Near East Foundation, has written an account of his years in Greece and the Balkans, to be published Wednesday by Norton. "Balkan Journal: An Unofficial Observer in Greece," covers the period from June, 1934, to August, 1941, when the last Americans under Mr. Archer's care left Greece after the country was occupied by the Germans.
Mrs. Adolphus Staton, wife of Rear Admiral Staton. USN, and Miss Lucy Staton, accompanied by Miss Anne Commons, have come to the Biltmore from Chevy Chase, Md.

LONDON, March 24 (U.P.) -- A daring rescue by a United States Navy blimp of two Canadian officers of the Atlantic group of the Royal Air Force Transport Command, lost in the steaming tropical jungle at the mouth of the Amazon River after their plane crashed, was described today by the Air Ministry.

Operations last year of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana resulted in a net income for 1943 of $50,591,371, equal to $3.31 a share of capital stock, according to the annual report announced yesterday by Edward G. Seubert, president.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Twenty-three first-term Republican members of the House, seeking clarification of United States foreign policy, were told by Secretary of State Cordell Hull today that he took a specific plan to the Moscow conference for the post-war disposition of Germany, but that the subject was ruled out of consideration.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 24 (AP) -- Actual experience of war, Eastman Kodak Company declared today, has "fully established the critical importance of aerial photography."

The Liebmann Packing Company of Green Bay, Wis., and two of its officers were fined a total of $25,020 yesterday by Federal Judge Robert A. Inch in Brooklyn. Previously, through an attorney, they had pleaded guilty to an information charging them with violations of the Office of Price Administration ceiling levels on the sale of meat.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 24 -- Jockey Eddie Arcaro was lucky to escape serious injury today when his mount in the seventh race at Tropical Park, the favored Middle Watch, bolted while leading just inside the furlong pole and jumped the inside rail tossing the veteran rider into the infield.

LONDON, March 24 (AP) -- British mine owners' representatives and miners' leaders announced today that they had agreed to stabilize coal-field wages until Dec. 31, 1947, and to eliminate anomalies of the Porter award, which led to the recent strike of 100,000 Welsh miners and the current walkout of more than 50,000 in South Yorkshire.

Directors of Bloomingdale Brothers, Inc., declared yesterday a dividend of 22 1/2 cents a share on the common stock, payable April 25. A similar amount was paid on Jan. 25, last, while year stockholders received 20 cents in April.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Industrial activity in the United States was at about the same rate in February as in January, and when adjusted for seasonal influences the Federal Reserve Board's Production Index advanced 1 per cent to 243 per cent of the 1935-39 average, the board reported today.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, March 25 (UP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- President Roosevelt made public today a statement given him by Leo T. Crowley, head of the Foreign Economic Administration dealing with farm machinery and other problems of help to needy peoples.
Resigned to the fact that no Nazi lawyer could be obtained to defend him against charges of draft evasion, 25-year-old Ivar Haug, a Norwegian seaman, offered yesterday to accept a "Gentile lawyer."

There is more dynamite in the suggestion of economic sanctions against Argentina than could be carried in a battleship. It is the sure way of making the Peron-Farrell Government a fixture. It is the sure way to consolidate the people of Argentina against us.

Lieuh Comdr. John D. Bulkeley, naval hero of the Philippines, was] disclosed yesterday to have participated in a new adventure in the' South Pacific in which his Motor Torpedo Boat squadron depth charged three Japanese barges, then boarded them and overcame their 'crews in hand-to-hand fight~ Lug.

King Fisher, Hollywood director, expects to try his hand at Broadway producing in the near future. For this purpose he has acquired a comedy by Herm Wolff entitled "Win, Place and Show." As the title implies, it concerns horse racing.

New issues of municipal bonds and notes aggregating $5,412,500 have been scheduled for award next week through competitive bidding, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. This compares with this week's revised total of $9,513,000 and with the weekly average for the year to date of $16,400,793.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 24 -- Prophesying a Republican victory in November, Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio declared for immediate liquidation of unessential Government bureaus today in his bid here Friday for Alabama's twenty-two delegates to the Republican convention.
Housing properties, a vacant plot and a machine shop are among Manhattan parcels in new ownership, as the result of deals reported yesterday.

WAR produces some strange psychological states that will seem incomprehensible to the next generation that is born and reared in peace. And not the least among these strange states is that of the young man whose draft board keeps shuffling him from category to category, preventing him from taking a civilian job, yet refusing to give him an induction notice.

The power to thrill and inspire the world with heroic deeds is not reserved to the mighty among men or nations. So it was that on this day of March in 1821 the valor of one of the humblest of little peoples set hearts to beating faster wherever freedom and justice are honored.

Quick change artistry for spring suits has been developed by a famous glove designer in the form of matching dickey and glove sets. Soap and water fabrics such as pique, seersucker, ginghams and chambrays are featured in these accessories and they should prove a boon to the career girl who likes to change the appearance of her suit as often as she can.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Compulsory service in war industries by 4F's and men too old for the armed forces was endorsed today by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, as preferable to a universal draft of manpower.

There were few whistle stops in last night's N.C.A.A. Eastern regional double-header in Madison Square Garden, with the result that two fast expresses, Dartmouth and Ohio State, swished into tonight's final round at full speed.

Supplies of containers and other shipping materials will continue tight during the next several months, according to the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers, which states that "in our contacts with other trade associations and some of our recent correspondence with members of our industry, as well as information secured in discussion in Washington," it is led to believe that hosiery and comparable industries must be prepared to face continuing difficulties.

RECEIVING mail is always pleasant. It is the answering of it which is the chore. Perhaps the strangest part of getting letters is that often a correspondent will start discussing a column as though it had been run only a day or two before, when actually it may have appeared months previously.
LONDON, March 24 (AP) -- A communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The people of Hungary were urged by Secretary of State Cordell Hull today through a statement to rise against the Nazis and demonstrate their right to independence.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's statement today promising help to rescue the "victims of brutality" of the Nazis and Japanese:...

Broadening trade carried cotton prices early in the session of the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday to new highs for the season, and to net gains of 10 to 16 points, but the advance attracted heavy hedge selling and liquidation that broke the market in the late trading, and final prices were 3 points to 8 points net lower.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -Internal revenue receipts for the first eight months of the present fiscal year, from July 1, 1943, to Feb. 29, 1944, totaled $22,795,908,322, an increase of $12,919,335,064, or 133 per cent, over the same period of the previous fiscal year, the Treasury reported today.

BUENOS AIRES, March 24 -- Direct rail communications between Chile and Argentina by the Transandine Railroad were re-established today after remaining interrupted for more than ten years as the result of a flood that on Jan. 11, 1934, washed away many miles of the permanent way.

Today's events: "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci," 2 P.M., and "Die Walkuere," 8, Metropolitan Opera House; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; George Copeland, piano, Carnegie Hall, 3; Dorothy Maynor, soprano, Town Hall, 3; Victory Concert, New York Public Library, 5:30; Maria Gall, soprano, Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, 8:30; Glauco D'Attili, piano, Barbizon-Plaza Concert Hall, 8:30.

WITH THE MEDITERRANEAN ALLIED AIR FORCE, March 24 -- The question as to how successful all-out close support of air power can be in helping ground troops launch offensive operations was tested in the Cassino battle, and a certain amount of argument is still going on as to how conclusive the results were.

The "red tape" of the New York City educational system, which makes it difficult to create parent participation and arouse community interest in school activities, was denounced yesterday by Mrs. Samuel A. Lewisohn, director of the Public Education Association.
The Cardinal Hayes Literature Committee announced yesterday its spring list of 100 recommended current books.

Retail trade here continued active this week, but the average increase in department store volume did not measure up to the 19 per cent rise reported for the previous week. Bad weather on several days was a factor. Demand for Spring apparel and accessories continues to broaden.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- America may as well get ready to absorb interior decoration stimulation from the four corners of the globe, according to Gladys Miller, consultant on decoration to the Public Buildings Administration, who has kept track of some 300 former students in her New York University classes who entered the armed services.

TRENTON, N.J., March 24 (AP) -- Gov. Walter E. Edge today called upon Lieut. Col. Edgar N. Bloomer, State Selective Service Director, to give a written report covering allegations made by Local Draft Board 36 of Kearny that State headquarters had repeatedly overridden the wishes of the board and granted occupational deferments to men of 28 and younger.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 24 -- Warner Brothers announced today the acquisition of the screen rights to Ellin (Mrs. Irving) Berlin's first novel "Land I Have Chosen," which is scheduled for publication in May by Doubleday Doran.
WILMINGTON, Del., March 24 (AP) -- Let's get it straight for the records. It's still the Phillies, although they'll wear a blue jay emblem on their shirts.

The ten-story building containing seven stores and thirty-eight apartments at 3926-38 Broadway, southeast corner of 165th Street, has been leased by the New York Savings Bank to a client of Quinto Herbst, brokers. The building, which is on a plot 100 by 110 feet and contains 260 rooms, was leased for a long term at an aggregate rental of $150,000.

LONDON, Saturday, March 25 -- London had its longest and most intense air attack in many months last night when an unannounced but probably sizable number of German bombers darted over the city for more than one hour, showering a mixed load of high explosive and incendiary bombs on this capital.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 24 -- Alan Ford, the Panama phenom from Balboa who has broken Johnny Weismuller's former world mark for the 100-yard free-style four times, scored a glittering double for Yale tonight in the twenty-first annual swimming championships of the National Collegiate Athletic Association in the Payne Whitney Gymnasium pool.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The "GI Bill of Rights," providing for veterans of this war hospitalization, education and vocational training, loans for homes, farms and businesses, employment service and unemployment benefits, was passed by a 49-to-0 vote of the Senate this evening and sent to the House, where early concurrence is expected.

Benjamin L. Greenberg, attorney since 1926 and chairman of a local draft board, was suspended from practice of the law for two years yesterday by the Appellate Division because of his activity in behalf of a Selective Service registrant.

CHICAGO, March 24 (AP) -- The Dodge Chicago plant of Chrysler Corporation, largest airplane engine plant in the world, is "now producing and shipping in substantial and increasing quantities 2,200-horsepower Wright air-cooled engines," K.T. Keller, president of Chrysler, told directors of the company who met in Chicago today.

LONDON, March 24 -- All sections of the stock markets here were generally quiet today, the only feature being the fall in prices on dividend-paying South African gold shares following publication of the report of the Native Wages Commission recommending an increase in wages and allowances. The decline was a result of precautionary downmarking in London, there being not much selling.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 24 -- Political leaders of Rumania and Bulgaria were able today to pause from the intensive nerve war directed against them by Germany and to take stock of the situation obtaining at the northern end of the Balkans since the occupation of Hungary last Monday.

CLEVELAND, March 24 (U.P.) -- Gil Dodds, with virtually no competition, tonight ran away with the Columbian two-mile run at the fourth annual Cleveland Knights of Columbus track meet. The bespectacled Boston divinity student, returning to the longer race for the first time in two years, finished in 9 minutes 5.3 seconds, far above the world indoor record of 8:51 set at this meet last year by Greg Rice.

The Bank for Savings will conduct a prize contest March 27 to July 3 to celebrate its 125th birthday. Newspaper advertisements of 1,000 lines appearing the first week of the contest will announce details of the 600 prizes in war bonds and stamps.

News of the death of Jules S. Bache focuses public thought anew upon one of the finest private collections of art formed in this country. The Bache Collection has long been famous, not because of its size and comprehensiveness, but because in assembling it the collector manifestly had set and maintained so high a critical standard.

A shipowner who permits a man of known "vicious and belligerent character" to remain a member of his crew is liable to other members of the crew for any injuries such a man may inflict on them, according to a ruling by Judges Jerome N. Frank, Harrie B. Chase and Charles E. Clark of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Details of the prescribed form of the consumer declaration that domestic users of Pennsylvania anthracite and of "Eastern" coke must file with their retail dealers at the time of or before receiving their first deliveries in the 1944-45 coal year, were made public today by the Solid Fuels Administration.

Application of the "nucleus plant" idea in reconversion is expected to begin within a fortnight, when electric appliance manufacturers believe they will receive material allocations from the War Production Board for the manufacture of 2,000,000 flatirons, producers stated yesterday.

BOSTON, March 24 (AP) -- Henry Armstrong, former triple champion, gained his third decisive triumph in ten nights by outpunching Ralph Zanelli of Providence tonight for a unanimous ten-round decision before 12,941 fans at the Boston Garden. Armstrong weighed 142 1/2 and Zanelli 148 pounds.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Senate, after a week's controversy, passed the $8,000,000,000 Independent Offices Appropriations bill this evening and sent it back to the House loaded with provisions forced into it in one of this year's bitterest political floor fights.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 24 -- Since this so-called Dodger spring training camp has been transformed by the presence of so many lads of tender years the observer is almost forced to devote attention to Dodgers of the future rather than those of the present.
WASHINGTON, March 24--The Rules Committee of the House approved today the Wadsworth resolution providing for a special committee to study post-war military policy and needs.

Under date of March 8, 1944, you published an editorial with respect to naturalization proceedings in the United States Courts, and I was glad to read it. A day or two thereafter you published a letter addressed to you by Herbert Schrank, which dealt with the same subject-matter, and was entitled, in your correspondence column, "Our Naturalized Citizens."

DURHAM, S.C., March 24 (AP) -- The veterans Craig Wood and Jimmy Hines trapped out four-under-par 67s over the short, muddy Hillandale golf course today to lead the field at the end of the first 18-hole round of the $5,000 Durham open tournament.

Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente dismissed yesterday the application of The Uniformed Firemen's Association to restrain Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh from enforcing an emergency decree issued last Dec. 30 that imposes three additional tours of duty in every twenty-day cycle and virtually eliminates the three-platoon system.
LONDON, March 24 (AP) -- A United State Air Force communique:

Louis H. Pink is resigning his post as area rent director of the Office of Price Administration effective April 1, according to reports current late yesterday afternoon at OPA headquarters in the Empire State Building.

HOLLYWOOD, March 24 (U.P.) -Joan Berry emerged from two days of cross-examination late today unshaken in her contention that Charles Chaplin violated the Mann Act by transporting her to New York for the specific purpose of indulging in intimate relations with her.

The United States should use its good offices to obtain a solution of the dilemma of Finland and enable that nation to fulfill its desire of withdrawing from the war, former President Herbert Hoover said yesterday.

A USAAF HEAVY BOMBER STATION, Somewhere in Britain, March 2 -- When a Flying Fortress group based on this field bombed Berlin last Wednesday it marked the group's 100th attack on Nazi targets. It is believed this was the first group in the Eighth Air Force to reach the century mark.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Costello bill, which would give full military status to the Wasp (civilian women pilots and aviation cadets serving with the Army Air Forces), struck a snag today when Representative Charles A. Halleck, Republican, of Indiana, raised the question before the House Rules Committee of whether the women pilots really wanted to be militarized.
LONDON, Saturday, March 25 (AP) -- The Russian Friday midnight supplemental communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

National headquarters of the Willkie for President Committee, which is seeking to obtain the Republican Presidential nomination for Wendell L. Willkie, the 1940 candidate, were opened yesterday in the Grand Central Terminal Building at 70 East Forty-fifth Street.

In all this talk about abolishing income-tax returns the fact must not be overlooked that about 15,000,000 persons will receive tax refunds even though only a 5 per cent withholding rate was in effect for six months of 1943. Now that the 20 per cent withholding rate is for the entire year 1944, perhaps 30,000,000 persons will be entitled to refunds in 1945.

CHUNGKING, China, March 24 (AP) -- Chinese official quarters kept silent on the Japanese invasion of India, but there was no mistaking the shock created there. The newspaper Ta Kung Pao said that if the Allies had struck aggressive and powerful blows at the Japanese in the Far East and the Pacific "there would be no time for Tojo to take any interest in India."

MOSCOW, Saturday, March 25 -- Spearing southward between Tarnopol and Proskurov, the Red Army yesterday made a spectacular thirty-mile gain to reach the Dniester River at the town of Zaleshchiki, twenty-five miles from Cernauti.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, March 25 (AP) -- American bombers defied Japanese anti-aircraft fire and bad weather to carry their offensive against enemy bases at Rabaul, New Britain, Wewak, New Guinea, and other scattered Bismarck Sea points Wednesday, Gen. Douglas MacArthur reported today.

CHICAGO, March 24 -- Kept a closely guarded secret until recently, although found effective in the fighting in Italy and Sicily, the Army's fast M-8 armored car which carries a .37mm. gun that will stop all but the largest enemy tanks was demonstrated today near Gary, Ind.

The new 2,200-ton destroyer Hubbard, named in honor of the late Comdr. Harry Ensor Hubbard, United States Navy, who took part in the Doolittle air raid on Japan and later sacrificed his life in an effort to take supplies to marines on Guadalcanal, was launched yesterday at the Bethlehem Steel and Shipbuilding Company yard in Mariners Harbor, S.I.

Shouldering wooden guns made in the prison workshop, a continfent of 165 inmates of the city penitentiary on Riker Island executed a risk military drill yesterday afternoon before the approving eyes of Mayor La Guardia; Col. Arthur V. McDermott, city Selective Service-head, and Dr. Peter F. Amoroso, Commissioner of Corrections.

A "welcome-home letter" that every man honorably discharged from the armed forces and about to return to civilian life will receive henceforth from the Bureau of Selective Service was made public yesterday by Col. Arthur V. McDermott, New York City draft director.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- President Roosevelt took the unusual step today of appealing to the German people, as well as the peoples of all subjugated Europe, to do all in their power to assist the escape of Jews and other victims of Nazi persecution.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Five major rules which must be followed by State Directors of Selective Service in inducting men in the age group under 26 were sent out tonight by Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Director of Selective Service.

Hope springs eternal in the human breast, not excluding civic and trade organizations opposed to the five-cent fare. After that unanimous vote in the Board of Estimate it will probably take some time for the higher-fare advocates to re-form their shattered ranks and return to the fray, as return they will.

LONDON, March 24 -- Prime Minister Churchill has reviewed thousands of American air-borne troops and told them yesterday of the great part they will play "soon" in the invasion of Europe. Mr. Churchill, with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Allied Com mander in Chief, and Lieut. Gen. Omar N. Bradley, senior United States ground commander in Britain, inspected what the Prime Minister called "the most modern expression of war" -- airborne soldiers.

NAPLES, March 24 -- The Germans are believed to have suffered severe casualties in the fighting around Castle Hill, in which Allied pressure has been stiffened by tanks, artillery and mortar fire. Since British troops repulsed a German counter-attack on Castle Hill Wednesday morning, little enemy activity has been observed northwest of Cassino.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -Col. Charles F.H. Johnson, Specialist Reserve, of Passaic, N.J., president of the Botany Worsted Mills, has been awarded the Legion of Merit for exceptional and outstanding service, the War Department announced today.

Frank S. Hogan, District Attorney of New York County and a political protege of Governor Thomas E. Dewey, one of the leading possibilities for the Republican Presidential nomination, was agreed upon tentatively yesterday as a delegate-at-large to the Democratic National Convention which is expected to renominate President Roosevelt for a fourth term.

RICHMOND, Va., March 25 -- Politics is warming up in the South -- both the Presidential variety and the more sectional and personal type, represented by the assault of Senator Kenneth McKellar of Tennessee on the Tennessee Valley Authority.

Disinfecting soils by sub-irrigating with a formaldehyde solution after the seeds are planted in flats or boxes offers a safe, inexpensive, and effective new method of preventing both pre-emergence and post-emergence, damping-off disease of vegetables. Formaldehyde not only sterilizes the soil and seeds, killing harmful bacteria and fungi, but appears to stimulate germination.

February furniture shipments remained practically unchanged from those in the previous month and in contrast to the normal peacetime increases which often run as high as 30 per cent, according to a monthly report issued yesterday by Seidman Seidman, accountants for the furniture trade.

There was no sign of truce last night between right and left wings of the American Labor party, locked in a bitter struggle for control of the State organization. This situation was emphasized as the left wing, acting through the Committee for a United Labor Party, sent out 200,000 pieces of mail to enrolled party members setting forth the twelve-point program on which they hope to win party control in Tuesday's primary.
LONDON, March 25 (AP) -- A communique broadcast from Berlin:

The population of northwestern and central Europe will decline within the next generation. Most of the countries of this region will attain their maximum populations by 1955 if the trends of the inter-war period continue. The population of southern and eastern Europe will increase for a tune.

ALL the pangs of a small girl growing up -- all her childish bewilderment and joys too -- are recounted with freshness and charm in Skulda V. Baner's story of little Stumpastina, whose father Gustaf kept a store in Iron Valley.

A GREAT many men are ready to drop a book like a hot potato if it is labeled a woman's story. "Wait for Mrs. Willard" is definitely that. But don't be surprised if the first man who picks up your copy hangs on to it. There are good reasons for this.

CHICAGO, March 25 -- Although May wheat, oats and barley held at or slightly under ceiling prices today on the Board of Trade, a fairly liberal business was under way, with longs securing profits and many replaced by purchases of the deferred deliveries.

On Christmas Day, 1914, the Cossacks surrounded my machine-gun company in the Carpathian Mountains and I became a prisoner of war. Frozen feet and a swollen forehead from a timber which had fallen made me weak. As I was hidden, a bullet whizzed by me. Fever, from having eaten snow and dysentery added to my misery.

WITHIN the last fortnight two decisions have been handed down in court cases involving the right of studios to suspend players under term contract, and in each case the actor was victorious. These decisions are expected to influence considerably the future relations between players and studios.

The bulk of people in the United Nations have expected the Atlantic Charter to be the basis for the Allies' post-war program to insure peace. Last week this supposition was being, reviewed in the light of new disclosures on both sides of the Atlantic.
THE poems of Winifred Welles, now published post humously, are adorned with the wreaths of friends; but kindness cannot give body to these echoes. The poems are mainly watered Wylie and Millay:

TOWNSVILLE, Australia, Sunday, March 26 (U.P.) -- Four American soldiers and a merchant seaman, all Negroes, have been condemned to death by a United States Army court martial for raping an American Red Cross worker, it was announced today.

FORTY years ago France fell into fighting segments over the Dreyfus affair. "Treachery to the nation," "justice to the individual." the "honor of the army" -- all these were elements of that far-off battle which rent families, broke up friendships and established a part of the pattern of thinking of the men who have been responsible for governing France for the last twenty years.

The Red Army surged toward the Carpathians last week. The Battle for Russia that Adolf Hitler had launched thirty-three months ago was drawing to its end. The Battle for the Balkans, perhaps the opening phase in the Battle for Germany, was about to begin.

One reason why our national wage policy is so vague and uncertain is that the War Labor Board has acted and continues to act as if it were a policy-making agency. But WLB obviously ought not to be a policy-making agency. Its proper function is to be an administrative agency to carry out a national wage policy laid down by the Administration and by Congress.

ALTHOUGH the United States has formally indicted eight renegade American broadcasters for treason, Great Britain has not yet made an official pronouncement about the seven traitors who have broadcast against the British Empire.

JERUSALEM, March 25 -- Jewish political terrorists belonging to a minority group struck Thursday night in a series of coordinated land-mine and shooting outrages that killed six British police officers and injured at least a dozen in Jerusalem, Tel Aviv and Haifa.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 25 (AP) -- Arizona Democrats, in convention today, praised the accomplishments of President Roosevelt at home and abroad, and endorsed "the war and post-war policies of the present national Administration," but did not commit themselves to a fourth term.

ALGIERS, March 25 -- A sudden bright light has been thrown this week on the diplomatically bogged down French situation. To those who prefer light to obscurity and frankness to pretense this represented a notable progress toward the long overdue showdown which now can hardly be far off.

Teamwork and air discipline are essential to good piloting and if observed will insure even a mediocre flier a fine record, Major Frank J. (Spot) Collins, Army Air Forces fighter pilot, who sank a medium German cruiser in the Mediterranean and is credited with shooting down nine German fighters, declared yesterday.

College has announced the opening of two separate programs of study on its campus this summer, the Wellesley School of Community Affairs, and the Summer School of Techniques. The inauguration of the two schools marks a new endeavor in the field of education.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman ordained a group of twenty-four priests at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning, two months ahead of the usual date for ordinations of candidates from St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Seminary, Dunwoodie, from which they came. The early ceremony was necessitated by a need for replacing priests who have become chaplains with the armed services.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 25 -- Employes of the municipal railways, which carry 440,000 passengers daily, went ahead today with plans to leave their street cars and buses for a meeting at 4 A.M. tomorrow to discuss their next step in a wage dispute with city officials.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- How a camel track centuries old has been remodeled into a broad motor highway over which 7,000 tons of supplies are rolling every month from India to Russia was revealed today by the Agency-General for India.

ST. LOUIS, March 25 (AP) -- Senator Allen J. Ellender of Louisiana, chairman of the sub-committee on education and labor which has handled slum clearance and low-rent housing legislation, today urged delegates to the National Public Housing Conference that they join hands with private enterprise in a comprehensive approach to the national housing problem.

ROBERT KEITH, one of the troubled daddies in "Kiss and Tell," is on the way to joining the growing ranks of actors turned producer-director. Mr. Keith is contemplating putting on the Owen Davis script, "No Way Out," next fall.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Mrs. Brehon Somervell, wife of the commanding general of the Army Service Forces, was named national chairman today of the Women's Volunteer Committee to the new Personal Affairs Division which will aid service men and their dependents in the solving of personal problems.

THE American Youth Hostel season for 1944 has been inaugurated with the opening of the Great Smoky Mountain hostel loop. John E. Jones, American Youth Hostel chairman for North Carolina and chairman of the Cosmic Club's AYH committee, has issued a new map for visitors wishing to take the Smoky Park hostel trip.

THE defensive value of "covering an honor with an honor" is soon learned by most students of bridge. Much later comes their realization that a ten or nine is often the equivalent of a higher honor and should be covered with a jack, queen or even with a king.

The General Motors Corporation is prepared to make an aggregate expenditure of $500,000,000 in the post-war period to reconvert, modernize, and retool for the resumption of automobile production, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman, said in a statement issued yesterday in advance of the forthcoming annual report.

Celebrating its 125th anniversary, Colgate University typifies the hardy spirit of the liberal arts tradition. Although reduced to a bare eighty-nine civilian students -- two years ago Colgate found it difficult to limit its enrollment to 1,000 -- Presiden Everett Case has emphasized that his institution will continue to function as a university and will not neglect the teaching of the humanities.

"Social security and industrial democracy cannot be achieved without international security," Arthur Wauters, former Belgian Minister of Labor and of Public Health and present chairman of the Belgian Social Reconstruction Committee, said yesterday at a luncheon of the League for Industrial Democracy at The Parkside Hotel, 18 Gramercy Park South.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 25 -- The West Coast, which long has regarded the war against Japan as "the" war, but which has bowed without undue criticism to the decision of military strategists to take care of Hitler first, is beginning to squirm over the prosecution of the war in Europe.

A muddy station-wagon ambulance from the airfield pulled up at the receiving ward of the Navy hospital at a South Pacific Base not long ago. It was during the fighting days on Guadalcanal. Out of the rear climbed several walking wounded. One of the youngsters, attired in a pair of hospital pajama pants, unlaced shoes, a bloody bandage and a blanket, asked a passerby: "Hey, Mac, where's the Red Cross tent?"

LONDON, March 25 -- In probably the fiercest night sky battle of the war, more than 1,000 big Lancaster and Halifax bombers of the Royal Air Force fought through the stiffest opposition the RAF has ever encountered over the Reich and dropped 2,800 tons of high explosives and incendiaries last night on Berlin.

NEW ORLEANS, March 25 -- Theodore ("The Man") Bilbo, United States Senator from Mississippi, pointed probably to the most authoritative political trend of the Deep South when, in addressing the joint session of the Mississippi Legislature, he urged the renomination of President Roosevelt for a fourth term.

NAPLES, March 25 -- It was six months ago next Saturday that Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark's Fifth Army captured this metropolis, Italy's second greatest city and one of the greatest single prizes of the entire campaign that began with the North African landings of November, 1942.

The three fliers who played tag around the Empire State and other lofty buildings in the midtown area Friday afternoon, to the consternation of the tenants, were identified yesterday as Navy Ferry Command pilots.

For their contribution of 2,354 pints of blood during 1943 and an additional 400 pints since the first of the year, the personnel of the United States Naval Armed Guard Center received yesterday the Red Cross Certificate of Merit. Nearly 1,000 sailors, officers and Waves stood at attenitno during the presentation ceremony at the captain's weekly inspection of the center, First Avenue and Fifty-second Street, Brooklyn.

WHAT Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer had in mind when it bought the screen rights to Dale Carnegie's "How to Win Friends and Influence People" is one of Hollywood's minor mysteries. But that abortive project had one tangible result -- it succeeded in introducing Ogden Nash and S.J. Perelman, whom, in a moment of majestic lucidity, the studio selected for the task of molding the Carnegie homilies into the form of a motion picture script.

Dewey of New York, now appear to be the leading contestants for the Republican nomination for President, with Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio the runner-up.

Reid of Long Beach, Calif., as head of this international wildfowl restoration organization. Mr. Reid was named chairman of the board of trustees.

THE departure of "Good Night, Ladies," from the Blackstone Theatre after 100 weeks of occupancy, has left Chicago somewhat forlorn. The citizens had come to depend upon it as the perfect answer to their most common problem in entertainment.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 25 -- The best workout the 1944 Yankees have had since pitching their training camp here a fortnight ago was dulled today by the news that Johnny Murphy has retired from baseball. President Ed Barrow relayed the information to the clubhouse at Bader Field.

THROUGH the increases now being set up over last year due to the early Easter, merchandise trade for the quarter will be on the plus side by a small percentage. Touch-and-go fighting continued in the main Japanese offensive across the border toward Imphal, India, where in the first tank clash the Japanese lost five machines.

IT is good to have Paul Haakon back in action again ,hereabouts. "Mexican Hayride" does not offer him as many opportunities as it might, but he manages to squeeze in between the elaborate costumes and the hilarities of Bobby Clark and June Havoc a stunning bullfight solo and a tricky and effective acrobatic adagio with Eleanor Tennis.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 25 -- The solution of America's No. 1 domestic problem at the end of the war, providing employment at a high level, can only be solved when the stranglehold of New Deal regimentation has been broken, Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio, candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, declared here tonight.

A detailed plan for basing post-war British international trade policy on a program calling for State-directed exchanges within a regional grouping around the sterling bloc, aimed at promoting a large and rapid expansion of commerce as an aid to domestic economic planning for full employment, is now being discussed in British industrial and fianncial circles.

WAUKESHA, Wis., March 25 -- Reading a letter from Bernard De Voto, editor of the Easy Chair department of Harper's Magazine, Wendell L. Willkie declared tonight that Mr. De Voto was representative of millions of "tired New Dealers" whose votes the Republican Party could have for the asking if it adopted a liberal platform and nominated a forward-looking candidate for President.

CHUNGKING, China, March 25 -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz's recent statement about the need for opening a port in China does not remove the necessity for reopening the Burma Road, according to Gen. Ho Ying-chin, Minister of War, in an interview today.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- The State Department charged today that Argentina's action in suspending operations of All-America Cables, Inc., in Buenos Aires for twenty-four hours "would appear to indicate a complete failure" to appreciate the importance of the communications facilities.

A RECENT study shows that only 14 per cent of the women living in a representative district of this country are saving all the fat they can. A mere 46 per cent are conserving more than half of what they should. Those conducting the survey report that failure to cooperate in the salvage campaign does not spring from a lack of understanding concerning its importance.

Dorothy Maynor gave her postponed recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. When the soprano was heard here a year ago she was too concerned with tone production to make headway as interpreter. Yesterday, the interpretive side of her art received due consideration, and in the second half of the program, where the greatly gifted singer permitted her tones to flow forth effortlessly, she accomplished the best work of her local career.

A comprehensive training course covering the principles of successful merchandising of rugs and carpets will be launched immediately after the conclusion of the war by all elements within the soft surface floor coverings industry in an effort to provide adequate distribution of an anticipated substantial increase in post-war output, a spokesman for a leading manufacturer disclosed yesterday.

THIS is a disarming book, and a pleasure to read. The first-person story of a young hired man on a farm in Alabama twenty-some years ago, its authenticity is worth something and the pleasure it takes in life is worth more.

In an effort to prepare students for post-war work in devastated European and Asiatic countries, American colleges and universities have introduced special courses designed to train specialists in selected fields of reconstruction and rehabilitation. When victory comes, hundreds of young men and women will be ready to go abroad and work with the nationals of foreign lands.

The political spotlight centered last week on Wisconsin, where Wendell L. Willkie, 1940 Republican Presidential candidate, was stumping the State in his campaign for the 1944 nomination. Traveling mostly by automobile, he was moving from town to town on a trip which, when it ends next Thursday, will have taken him 1,500 miles through the State's ten Congressional districts and to all its important cities.

Charging that the American Youth for Democracy organization was camouflaged communism, Harry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College, defended yesterday his institution's refusal to charter the group, despite a renewed campaign for recognition on the part of AYD leaders at the school.

LONDON, March 25 -- Until now the nearest approach to a statement of United Nations' war aims has been contained in the Atlantic Charter. This document, issued jointly by Prime Minister Churchill and President Roosevelt in August, 1941, when the United States was still at peace, has been indorsed subsequently on more than one occasion by Soviet Russia.

I HAVE read in THE TIMES radio section of March 12 the article under the heading of "One Thing and Another." The matter to which I refer is the "racket" mentioned with regard to forwarding information about American prisoners of war.

SIXTEEN-YEAR-OLD Elspeth prided herself on being almost as good a son to Sir Robert Kent as was her brother. Being kidnapped in his place, however, for reasons best known to King Charles I, put a severe strain on her courage and wits, but she was lucky.

IN a recent discussion at The New York Times Hall on the topic "Conversion Without Depression," Walter P. Reuther, vice president of the United Auto Workers, CIO, urged "the universal application of a thirty-hour week" after the war. He was challenged by the other speakers, Eric A. Johnston, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, and Henry J. Kaiser, the industrialist.

HONOLULU, March 25 -- Pearl Harbor Central Pacific Air Forces struck north of the Marshalls Thursday for the first time since March 11, bombing Wake Island, Pacific Fleet Headquarters announced today. On March 11 Wake Island was hit with fifty tons of bombs by Army and Navy planes.

ACCORDING to latest unofficial advices, young mothers of first babies are as worried as ever about "doing the right thing." A mother of two, who has been hearing their troubles, reports that they feel, "scared, ignorant and inept" -- and that they have her sympathy because only a few years ago she felt the same way.

Thirty-one young officers of the Netherlands Merchant Marine qualified last week for advancement after an examination conducted at Bronxville, N.Y., by a commission headed by Rear Admiral G.W. Stoeve of the Royal Netherlands Navy.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 25 -- Big Rube Melton, the promising but never fulfilling right-hand pitcher, made a surprise appearance at the Dodgers' camp today.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- A contract for the construction of a 14,000-ton floating drydock to be turned over to the Navy will be awarded the Kaiser Company, Inc., Vancouver, Wash., the Maritime Commission announced today.

While retail trade here last week was handicapped by inclement weather, department store volume showed an increase over the like week of last year. The rise, however, will be smaller than the 19 per cent gain reported for the preceding week.

OMAHA, Neb., March 25 -- Interest in the Middle West is focused quite sharply on national politics, particularly on the Republican situation. This stems from the imminence of the Wisconsin and Nebraska primaries, the presence of Wendell Willkie, making his campaign tour, and the approach of conventions in Minnesota, Iowa and Kansas.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 25 -- Acting on what were described as Adolf Hitler's instructions to dispel internal dissension or any possibility for it in Germany's southeastern domain, the German High Command today ordered withdrawal of the large Rumanian forces in the neighborhood of Kolosvar since March 10.

SUCCESS, it has been said, often is a matter of perspective. Take John Philliber, for instance. Mr. Philliber is a veteran thespian who will be 71 years old in July, and appears to be about 60. He is just over five feet tall, weighs 100 pounds, more or less, and the crow's feet around the corners of his twinkling cobalt eyes are the result of much smiling.

Dr. Alexander S. Wiener, Miss Eve B. Sonn and Mrs. Ruth B. Belkin of the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner, New York City, suggest in the Journal of Experimental Medicine that the recently discovered Rh factor in human blood need not cause infant deaths and childless marriages.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (U.P.) -- The United States Commerce Chamber's Committee on Post-War Problems urged tonight the immediate formation of an international commission to draft a world peace plan, based on the principles of the Four-Power Moscow Declaration.

Stocks drifted narrowly yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange and closed mixed in the second dullest and narrowest trading session of the month. Bond dealings, although slightly larger than in the previous two-hour session a week ago, were comparatively steady.

IT would be difficult to lavish too much praise on the recording of Mozart's Divertimento in E-flat major for violin, viola and 'cello (K. 563) which Jascha Heifetz, William Primrose and Emanuel Feuermann have made for Victor (Album DM 859, four twelve-inch records).
DETROIT, March 25 -- Three women and two men who confessed that they conspired to violate the Wartime Espionage Act were sentenced in Federal court today to prison terms of from five to twenty years.

James A. Farley, back from a business trip to Pittsburgh, saw reporters yesterday, chatted with them about politics generally, announced that the Jefferson Day Dinner would be held May 8 at the Hotel Commodore, but flatly declined to comment on efforts, originating up-State, to depose him as Democratic State Chairman.

Some hedge-selling and a desire to take profits after the recent sharp advance was followed by a narrower market for cotton locally yesterday, and, after trading in a range of about 10 points, prices ended 1 to 3 points net lower on active months.

PHILADELPHIA, March 25 -- Conclusions as to the teaching of history, including more emphasis on the chronological plan for American history and the requirement of one year's study of world history in high schools, were presented today to educators at closing sessions of the annual Schoolmen's Week at the University of Pennsylvania.

Andrew Jackson High School's basketball team is the new champion of the Public School Athletic League. The athletes from the St. Albans school assumed the title yesterday when they defeated the Benjamin Franklin quintet in the league's final-round match at Madison Square Garden by 39 to 27.

MIAMI, Fla. -- year's local observance of Pan-American Day on April 14 will be on a scale in some measure proportionate with Miami's steadily growing importance as a connecting link between the United States and the countries of Latin America.
CLEVELAND, March 25 -- The tremendous job of moving 90,000,000 tons of ore from upper lake ranges to steel mills in the Great Lakes area will get under way next week, vessel owners predicted today.

Sally MacDougall, feature writer for The New York World-Telegram, and Dorothy Dunbar Bromley, women's page editor of The New York Herald Tribune, received yesterday the eighth annual awards of the New York Newspaper Women's Club.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (U.P.) -- Two American destroyers sank a scrappy German submarine in the Mediterranean recently after more than an hour's battle, in which one of the surface craft fired almost 100 rounds of large-sized ammunition, the Navy revealed tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Secretary of State, Cordell Hull, sought all this week to allay and satisfy questions that have arisen in Congress and in the country with respect to our diplomacy and its specific application to various international problems that the war has posed and its victorious conclusion will multiply. The questions can be roughly summarized as follows:

IN this curious interim between two ages, when history has dropped the curtain upon one of them but seems in no hurry to give the next one its definite shape and color, Saul Bellow's "Dangling Man" swings aimlessly about in space and searches his soul.
Last night's Soviet communique, as broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communication Commission:...

TWO large exhibitions of American art opened here last week. The Whitney Museum offers another generous segment of its permanent collection, including scores of water-colors and drawings, and featuring the accessions of the last two years or so.

Farmers' gross income this year will soar to twenty-three and one-half billion dollars, a total twice that of five years ago, Robert W. Coyne, field director of the War Finance Division of the Treasury Department, told the closing session yesterday of a regional agricultural conference of the division at the Park Central Hotel.
CHARLSTON, W. Va., March 25 (AP) -- Alben W. Barkley, majority leader of the Senate, said in a speech here tonight:

The issuance of "invasion currency" such as the Allied military lira, which is admittedly fiat money, is proceeding rapidly, but the general public, and that includes Wall Street, has no more than a hazy idea of what is being undertaken.

THAT the constantly increasing complexities of war often make it difficult to perceive the obvious is the justification for this review by a veteran admiral of the course of the conflict down to mid-August, 1943.
MISS MEYER'S story is a first novel that is at times overwritten, that is at times fuzzy and is inept technically, but that rings with a conscientious honesty.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 25 -- Equaling his world record time of 0:49.7 set a week ago, Alan Ford of Balboa won the 100-yard freestyle title for Yale in the National Collegiate A.A. swimming championships in the Payne Whitney Gymnasium pool tonight to become the first triple winner in this meet since 1936 and enable Yale to succeed Ohio State as the team champion.

IT is among the curious traits of the rich radio industry that, while it lives by the spoken word, it frequently assembles the words into radio shows with little or no concern for their value as good writing, or, if you will, as literature.

TORONTO, March 25 (Canadian Press ) -- Dr. Smirle Lawson, chief coroner for Ontario, said today that, after having conferred with officials of the Attorney General's department, he had ordered an inquest into the death of a Toronto man from the effects of a sulfanilamide drug.

BORROWING a phrase from the field of color, one might call Arthur Dove's latest paintings "primaries in thought." In his recent work, shown at An American Place, Dove has carried simplification of forms and arrangements about as far as possible.

St. Timothy's League, Inc., has taken over as a benefit for the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary the special preview performance on Thursday night of Zoe Akins' play, "Mrs. January and Mr. Ex," starring Billie Burke and Frank Craven, at the Belasco Theatre. The play will have its official premiere the next night.
LONDON, Sunday, March 26 (UP) -- A supplement to the Russian communique as broadcast from Moscow:
PITTSBURGH, March 25 -- The steel industry was assured today of peak production for the rest of this year through plans of the Army to ship loaded artillery shells abroad in steel tubes.

The Czechoslovaks of the homeland have at last heard the signal to rise against their oppressors. They have been listening for it a long while. They are resolute and ready through knowing that the Czech spirit is not confined within the little "Protectorate" beneath the German heel.

A simplified technique for translating skills acquired by men and women in the armed services to related jobs in civilian life is now being effectively utilized in handling a part of the thousands of veterans being discharged for various reasons, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional head of the War Manpower Commission, revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The desperate need for young men under 26 for the armed forces has moved into a new phase by the creation of a special committee in the War Manpower Commission to pass upon the deferment of this group.
EVANSVILLE, Ind., March 25 (AP) -- The Tigers opened their exhibition season today by defeating the White Sox, 5 to 3, in the first of a two-game series.

BEN HECHT says that he "lived forty years in my country without encountering anti-Semitism or concerning myself even remotely with its existence," and he adds, "this is, perhaps, a record for a Jew or, more likely, for a country."

MISS MacINNES, weaving another expert pattern of espionage and counterespionage, has selected occupied Poland as the background for her latest novel "While Still We Live" and has thus sacrificed a great deal of the urbanity and humor of her earlier books.
EVANSVILLE, Ind., March 25 (AP) -- The Tigers opened their exhibition season today by defeating the White Sox, 5 to 3, in the first of a two-game series.

BEN HECHT says that he "lived forty years in my country without encountering anti-Semitism or concerning myself even remotely with its existence," and he adds, "this is, perhaps, a record for a Jew or, more likely, for a country."

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 25 (AP) -- A wounded Memphis sailor disclosed today he was one of the Navy gunners who shot down twenty-three United States transport planes last July at Gela, Sicily, and he declared: "No one can blame the Navy gunners, for we were just a watch tick from death that night."

One hundred and fifty-four scholarships, valued at $800,000, have been offered by colleges and universities of this country to qualified students from Greece. These scholarships, to provide tuition and maintenance, are to be supervised by the Anglo-American Hellenic Bureau of Education.

Lawrence Cowell, who last week captured the national title, last night carried off the 145-pound Metropolitan A.A.U. wrestling championship at the 'New York Athletic Club. The West Side Y.M.C.A. mainstay went through the qualifying rounds without a defeat, and pinned Nick Kunlund of the New York A.C. to gain the final with John Jenson of the New York Institute for the Blind.

In a virtual ultimatum to C. Chester Du Mond, New York State Commissioner of Agriculture, Daniel P. Woolley, regional administrator of the Office of Price Administration, revealed yesterday the seriousness of the clash between Federal and State authorities over a referendum on a proposed rise in the price of milk for dairy farmers up-State.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- A House committee has tentatively decided to recommend legislation sharply curtailing the powers of the Office of Price Administration, informed sources said today.

LONDON, March 25 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill, in a message to the Greeks on the 123d anniversary of Greek Independence Day, which will be celebrated tomorrow, said today the day of Greek liberation is approaching.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., March 25 (AP) -- Michigan's mighty Wolverines, scoring in all except one event for a total of 49 points, culminated the indoor track season tonight by sweeping to victory in the university division of the second annual Purdue Relays.

NO matter what his creed or sect the child of our civilization who grows up without a familiarity with the Bible has a meager background. Aside from its values of the spirit, he has missed one of the fundamental cornerstones of our literary heritage -- a whole world of allusion is closed to him.

PRICKING off is the term applied to the first transplanting of seedlings which have been started indoors and are now seen to be crowded. These tiny plants may be transferred to flats or pots, or even directly to the open ground, depending upon the season and the particular kind of plant.

JUST to see Eamon de Valera today sitting at question time in his place in the Dail Eireann might make one think that he had changed since his early days of battles, prisons, humiliations and arduous triumphs. His hawklike face is softened, his long angular body has filled out a little.

LIKE ancient Gaul, "The Loom of Language." is divided into three parts, though this feature of its makeup is obscured by the presence of thirty pages of introductory matter, and the inclusion at the end of more than 150 pages under the arresting title of "Language Museum."

The Japanese offensive into India on the Burma frontier cut the road to the rear of an American Field Service medical unit attached to British forces, and some of the members barely escaped while under snipers' fire, Lieut. John Patrick of the service informed his headquarters in a message from Bombay yesterday, according to The Associated Press.

ALBANY, March 25 -- Governor Dewey signed the Mitchell bill today. The measure authorized an additional $35,000,000 loan for public housing in New York City. A similar bill was passed last year by the Assembly, but it was allowed to die in the Senate.

WHAT was this thing she called "texture" or "consistency"? Didn't it make up life, the very stuff of living? At least, wasn't it the top crust of living that most people broke through and never noticed at all, never enjoyed?

In one of the best-played games of the campaign, Dartmouth outdrove, outshot, outplayed and outscored the favored Buckeyes of Ohio State and roared to a merited 60-53 victory in the Eastern regional final of the National Collegiate A.A. basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden.

SUPERLATIVES seem inevitable in any consideration of California or Californiana. Nothing there is large or long or tall; always it is largest or longest or tallest. California's skies are the bluest, her sunshine the brightest, her dews the heaviest.

LIEUT. COL. VTNCENT SHEEAN, whose last book was the best-selling "Between the Thunder and the Sun," has just finished translating a new book by Benedetto Croce, the Italian philosopher, which Random House will publish late this spring.

LONDON, March 25 (AP) -- Maj. Voislav Lukatchevitch, one of the commanders in the Yugoslav Army, said in an interview today that Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch had 30,000 troops armed and ready in the mountains of Serbia ready to strike at a signal from the Allies to clear a path for invasion.

John Corigliano, concertmaster of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, was assisting artist with the orchestra at Carnegie Hall last night, playing the Beethoven D-major Violin Concerto before an audience that filled the house to the standing line and gave him an ovation at the end of performance that deserved it.

I CAN'T help feeling a little sorry for the theoretically lucky children who will own "The Tall Book of Nursery Tales." They are going to have, if my own experience with it to date means anything, such a hard time getting it away from the grown-ups.

Although few buyers were in town last week, ready-to-wear departments were quite busy filling last-minute Easter requests and canceling outstanding orders which could not be delivered, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Sunday, March 26 (AP) -- American destroyers have shelled Pityilu Island in the Admiralties, on the northern fringe of Sea Eagle Harbor, which United States soldiers took under their control when they captured Lorengau, on Manus Island, Mrch 18.

Awards to outstanding student journalists were presented yesterday at the final sessions of the twentieth annual Columbia Scholastic Press Association convention. Amid rousing football cheers of the elementary and high school delegates, the winners were announced at a luncheon meeting at the Hotel Astor.

The appointment of two well-known physicians to fill the newly created posts of Director of Clinical Research and Director of Graduate Medical Education was announced yesterday by Waldemar Kops, acting president of Mount Sinai Hospital, as a step toward a wide post-war expansion of the institution's activities.

BOSTON, March 25 (AP) -- Robert E. Hannegan, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, challenged the Republican party tonight to bring its prospective Presidential nominees out into the open to discuss current questions.

James W. Lees has been appointed traffic manager of the Fruit Dispatch Company, Pier 3, North River, J.A. Werner, president, announced last week. The appointment carries with it the duties of assistant traffic manager of the United Fruit Company.

That something should be done in the way of legislation against the "tall man" in basketball, the lanky lad who plants himself underneath the basket and proceeds, in his role of goal-tender, to bat away potential field goals, was agreed upon by the National Association of College Basketball Coaches in session yesterday at the Belvedere Hotel.

After an absorption by several clubs on Long Island Sound of the open dates in the championship schedule of the Yacht Racing Association, the program for the coming summer was filled tentatively yesterday. The schedule will be put before the club delegates in a meeting at the New York Yacht Club Wednesday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 25 -- A beautiful fawn boxer bitch who created a sensation on the show circuit last season by taking five straight best-in-show awards came back into the spotlight this evening by winning her sixth, triumphing at the initial exhibition of the Naugatuck Valley Kennel Club.

FIFTH ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Italy, March 25 -- In view of the complete inability of the Allies' troops to register any advances in the Cassino area or the rugged rock formations rising immediately west of the town, it is no exaggeration to state that the third major attack on the bastion of the Gustav Line is so far an utter failure.

Man is not an aquatic animal, but from the time we stand in youthful wonder beside a spring brook till we sit in old age and watch the endless roll of the sea we feel a strong kinship with the waters of this world. We marvel at the magnificence of a snowflake, a water crystal.

Having sat by idly while the National Collegiate Athletic Association was engaged in determining its Eastern champion, St. John's and De Paul return to the Madison Square Garden boards tonight to meet in the final of the seventh annual national invitation basketball tournament. In the preliminary, Kentucky and Oklahoma A. M., the semi-final losers, will tangle.

LONDON. March 25 (Canadian Press) -- The greatest crowd of the English soccer season today thrilled to some of the best play seen in wartime as eight teams emerged as quarter-finalists for the League North Cup and the League South decided cup semi-finalists.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 25 -- Last night's RAF attack on Berlin was one of the worst the city has suffered and the British bombs set "the biggest fires ever," said travelers who arrived in Stockholm late today on the plane from the Reich capital.

SOUTH SAN FRANCISCO STOCKYARDS, March 25 (U.P.) -- The Treasury Department has put on the auction block here 510 horses of a cavalry regiment which has switched to jeeps, tanks and armored cars, leaving its horses as "surplus merchandise."

A "SNO-BUS" carrying a group of skiers is plowing through the drifts on the way to a "sno-lodge" somewhere in the Province of Quebec. The driver announces that one of his tire chains is loose and steps out to attend to it.

Miss Anne Morgan, who has been a member of the national board of the Frontier Nursing Service since its inception in 1926, has donated the use of her resident at 3 Sutton Place for two spring vacation parties for children, which will be held Wednesday as a benefit for the service.

NOT long ago Mr. Robeson and "Othello" set up the long-run record for Shakespeare in New York, a circumstance which was noted in all Rockland County homes of polite breeding. No doubt it was the doctor who, as usual, made the first misquotation of the Bard, thereafter refusing to listen to his betters and at one point threatening to go home to look up his sources, or, darkly, just go home.

A GARDENER who understands how the growth of grass is affected by temperature and soil moisture knows that spring is not the best time of year to put down a new lawn. All the perennial grasses which help to make good turf require a high content of moisture in the soil and a temperature close to 60 degrees Fahrenheit if there is to be optimum growth.

FRANKIE CARLE, the piano player, who has proved the season's major new "discovery" in the band business, and his orchestra have been engaged for the program heard at 8 P.M. Wednesdays over CBS (WABC), beginning April 5.

NAPLES, March 25 -- The Allies' artillery on the beachhead below Rome knocked out several German tanks in the period ended at noon yesterday. Two were accounted for east of Aprilia and five west of Cisterna.

Only one new film is scheduled to reach Broadway during the week. "Her Primitive Man," a Universal comedy costarring Louise Albritton and Robert Paige, will open on Thursday at Loew's State. Among the featured players are Robert Benchley, Edward Everett Horton, Helen Broderick, Walter Catlett and Ernest Truex.

JERUSALEM, March 26 (U.P.) -With at least seven dead and ten injured as a result of last week's outbreaks by Jewish terrorist groups, the official Jewish Agency for Palestine today accused the Sternists of committing crimes that were "unwittingly or maliciously helping the enemies of the Jewish people."

Dr. John F. Erdmann, a great surgeon, who has become a legendary figure in his lifetime, will be 80 years old today. To him it will be just another day of work in saving life and alleviating pain. After the day's work he will attend a tea given for him by several hundred nurses at the nurses' home across the street from the New York Post Graduate Hospital.

Although we watch as carefully as anyone for Trends, we nearly missed one in the Treasury regulations covering the estimate to be made on April 15 on income for 1944. This is the penalty provided for those who are overly pessimistic about the future.
NAPLES, March 26 -- The battle for Cassino continued yesterday on a slightly less intense scale.

GUADALCANAL, Solomon Islands, March 25 (Delayed) -- Fifty Navy nurses arrived here today -the first to make Guadalcanal their permanent station -- completely unimpressed by the physical appearance of this early battleground.
Initial payments of overtime bonus will be made to members of the Police Department on or before April 15, it was revealed yesterday morning by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 26 -- With four days of his Wisconsin campaign remaining, Wendell L. Willkie enters its final phase satisfied that he has made progress in his fight for the election of Republican National Convention delegates pledged to support him for the Presidential nomination, particularly in the last few days.

LONDON, March 26 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav Partisans have fought two crack German Nazi divisions "to a standstill" in the sixth German offensive this year, and now have taken the counter-offensive in the struggle for Bosnia's communications, reports from the headquarters of Marshal Tito (Josip Broz) said today.
