Te text of Prime Minister Churchill's broadcast address as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday follows:

The thirty-second anniversary of the founding of the Young Israel movement in the United States was marked last night at a dinner in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria attended by 1,500 persons. Founded in 1912, the organization has 100 branches throughout the country.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 26 -- Champion Ali Khyber, 3-year-old Afghan hound, won the highest honors tonight in the twenty-third annual all-breed show of the Elm City Kennel Club.

The Commercial Trust Company, as trustee of the Harry Jasper estate, sold the one-family dwelling at 88 Highland Avenue, in Jersey City, N.J., to Dr. Frank Figurelli. The house is on a plot 37 by 132 feet and contains eleven rooms. It was sold through the A.F. Roe Company, broker.
The Fourth Antiques Exposition opened yesterday afternoon in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria for a run of six days.

HARRY GRAYSON has written a book. That is astonishing in itself because none of his fellow scribes in the world of sport ever could picture the indefatigable and bustling Harry pausing long enough in one place to hammer out a product such as his "They Played the Game," which A.S. Barnes is publishing today.

Resignation of eight members of the Committee on Discrimination, named by Governor Dewey last fall, was branded last night by James C. Hagerty, executive assistant to the Governor, as an evasion of "an important wartime task for political purposes."

The gross earnings of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company in 1943 reached the record total of $297,107,791, compared with $256,864,091 in 1942, according to the annual report issued for publication today. Net earnings from operations were $49,211,567, an increase of $1,023,878 over the preceding year.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 26 -- The vanishing Yankees neared complete exhaustion with respect to last year's veteran regulars today as the result of the latest draft operation.

LONDON, March 26 -- Declaring that the "hour of our greatest effort and action is approaching," Prime Minister Churchill called on the British people tonight to face the coming trials, which, he said, might include new forms of attack by the enemy, with the "same cool, strong nerves, the same toughness of fiber" they showed in the days when their country stood up alone to the Nazi blitz.
Pastors in Protestant churches west of Central Park preaching on "Modern Sins and Their Cure," the general Lenten theme, devoted their sermons yesterday to the topic, "The State Without Religion."

Three years ago today the people of Yugoslavia rose and overthrew the Government which by a shameful pact had tied them to the Axis chariot. The little nation was defying the conqueror of Europe, and all the world knew it meant war. It was indeed war, swift and terrible.

Before the war fewer than 350 planes carried all aviation passengers and cargo in this country. What of the future? The factories are producing over 10,000 planes of various types a month. It seems improbable that more than 1,000 commercial planes will be in service here for some years after peace comes.

PITTSBURGH, March 26 -- A sustained high volume of steel orders, continued pressure for production of flat-rolled steel products and maintenance of an unchanged ingot rate at 98.5 per cent featured news of the steel industry last week.
The cancellation of six licenses, the revocation of four others, the suspension of eleven licenses and the revocation or one permit were announced yesterday by the New York State Liquor Authority.

With no contests of consequence in either of the two major political parties, the fight for control of the American Labor party is holding the center of the stage in New York as voters prepare to cast their ballots tomorrow in the quadrennial spring primaries at which delegates to the Presidential nominating conventions and party officials are elected.

Ray Josephs, Buenos Aires correspondent for PM, The Chicago Sun and Variety, is announced as the author of "Argentine Diary: The Inside Story of the Coming of Fascism," to be published by Randon House late this season, Mr. Josephs has now left Argentina.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, March 27 (AP) -- Two thousand Japanese hurled themselves against the American perimeter at Torokina on Bougainville Island last Thursday in another suicide offensive, but were thrown back after heavy fighting that left 300 Japanese dead and abandoned on the jungle battlefield.

A conference of that section of the food industry that takes care of the Passover trade will be called this week by Daniel P. Woolley, regional chief of the Office of Price Administration, to head off any profiteering in foods in heavy demand for the Jewish religious festival beginning April 7.

CHICAGO, March 26 -- Higher temperatures and an ample supply of moisture have resulted in improving the outlook for the new winter wheat crop in the West and Southwest, but there has not been sufficient growing weather to permit experts to determine how much of the 47,127,000 acres seeded last fall will remain for harvest.

Representatives of the building trades of the American Federation of Labor in this city and of the Greater New York Industrial Council, central body of the unions affiliated with the Congress of Industrial Organizations, signed yesterday in Mayor La Guardia's office an agreement to create a joint committee on industrial relations to settle jurisdictional disputes and to avoid stoppages.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 26 -- Lester Cowan has announced that he has closed the deal with Greta Garbo for the actress to be starred in a film tribute to the women serving in the Norwegian Merchant Marine. The Swedish star, who has been absent from the screen for more than three years, will play a boat captain.

LONDON, Monday, March 27 -Driving the Germans over a border of the Soviet Union for the first time since the start of the Russo-German war 1,009 days ago, the Second Ukrainian Army has advanced to the narrow Prut River frontier of Rumania on a fifty-three-mile front, Moscow announced last night.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The Office of Price Administration lifted today is restrictions on inventories of tires and tubes held by dealers because the purpose of the ruling -- better distribution of obsolete and out-sized tires -- has been achieved.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 26 -Still abed with the flu, Manager Mel Ott had to direct his regular Giants by remote control today, and somewhere in an otherwise most pleasant afternoon something went wrong with the controls.

In a leaflet just issued by the New York State Emergency Food Commission, available on request to the commission's offices at 247 Park Avenue, New York 17, N.Y., the hows and whys of preparing green vegetables are explained virtually to the last detail.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 26 -- A small cloud from Buchanan, Ga., cast a shadow on sun-bathed Durocher Field today as Lippy Leo sent his Dodgers through their first outdoor workout within a stone's throw of Bear Mountain Inn.

An increase of 855,000 jobs in the New York metropolitan region compared with 1940 will be needed in the first post-war year, assumed to be 1946, to maintain the economic activities of this area on a prosperous level, the Regional Plan Association declared yesterday.

Two large group annuals and a retrospective show are included in the dozen openings here scheduled for this week in the art galleries. The 118th annual exhibition of paintings and sculpture opens to the public at the National Academy of Design on Wednesday with a preview reception to be held on Tuesday evening when the various prizes are to be awarded.
DURHAM, N.C., March 26 (AP) -- Husky Craig Wood of Mamaroneck, N.Y., won the $5,000 inaugural Durham open golf tournament today with a 72-hole total of 271.

Cotton prices continued their upward movement last week and all active future deliveries established new life-of-contract highs. Toward the end of the week part of the earlier gains were erased through profit-taking and hedge selling. At the close of trading Saturday on the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts showed net advances for the period of 16 to 47 points.

NEW DELHI, India, March 26 (AP) -- The battle for northern Burma expanded into the strategic aspects of a major campaign today as the Southeast Asia Command announced a British Commando force had slashed within fortyseven miles of Myitkyina, main Japanese base above the Burma Road.

LONDON, March 26 -- Unconfirmed British press dispatches reported tonight from the Swiss-Italian frontier that the 300 Italians executed on Thursday in the Colosseum at Rome had included 83-year-old Vittorio Orlando, former Premier and one of the Allies' "Big Four" at the Versailles Peace Conference; Mario Badoglio, son of Premier Pietro Badoglio, and Count Paolo Thaon di Revel, former Finance Minister.

New York City police, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and Army Intelligence have been conducting an intensive search for 22-year-old Vals Mapphai, a native of Bombay, India, since last Tuesday, following her disappearance from her one-room apartment at the International House, 500 Riverside Drive, it was disclosed yesterday by the Missing Persons Bureau at Police Headquarters.

The municipal council of Tel-Aviv and the General Federation of Jewish Labor instantly expressed their abhorrence of the outrages committed by the few extremists against British police officers and police stations in Palestine. Responsible Zionist leaders are naturally the first to condemn these terroristic acts, because no one is more keenly aware that the lunatic fringe is the worst enemy of their cause.

MOSCOW, March 26 -- A big drive is in progress for the welfare of servicemen's dependents. Last year 6,500,000,000 rubles was paid in the Russian Republic to servicemen's families who also were privileged regarding taxation, rent and education.
KEARNY, N.J., March 26 -- The U.S.S. Ault and the U.S.S. Waldron, twin 2,200-ton heavyweight destroyers, were launched at the United States Steel Corporation's Federal Shipyard here today.

Tuberculosis will be a post-war problem that the nation must be prepared to face, State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein declared last night at the fortieth annual dinner of the Jewish Consumptive Relief Society in the Hotel Astor.

The purple grackles come back with their customary clatter and begin to look over the bare trees for building sites. Like most new arrivals stimulated by a journey, they talk at the top of the voice. There is a touch of human nature in them. They walk the wet lawn and jaw about the chilliness thereof, as if saying, "We might have known it would be this way.

The possibility that Wayne Lonergan, on trial in General Sessions for the murder of his wife last October, might be called to the witness stand this week was admitted last night by his attorney, Edward V. Broderick.

CHICAGO, March 26 (U.P.) -- The Chicago Black Hawks scored on two long shots tonight to defeat the Detroit Red Wings, 2-0, and move into the rail position for final competition in the National Hockey League Stanley Cup playoffs before a crowd of 17,138 fans.

Your editorial on hens in THE TIMES, March 18, with its appreciation of the merits of the layers and suppliers of many meals, is surely raising the plane of the flighty fowl to the level of Charles Lamb's "Roast Pork."

Calling upon Danish patriots to give up sabotage of military installations and devote themselves to "more dignified ways of protesting," a speaker on the German-controlled Danish radio said he had received permission to reveal that monthly bomb sabotage attacks had reached a peak monthly figure of 120 in November, or about four a day, it was reported yesterday by the United States Foreign Broadcast Intelligence Service.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Sick and wounded of the United States and Allied forces to a total of 173,527 were evacuated by American military aircraft throughout the world last year, the War Department announced today. Only eleven died during flight.

The "Bund Deutscher Offiziere" (Association of German Commissioned Officers) was founded in Moscow on Oct. 11 and 12, 1943. It was three months after the foundation of the National Committee for a Free Germany, the president of which is the Communist writer Erich Weinert.

The Ives Committee, New York State's bipartisan legislative committee that has made the State's labor policy for the last six years, has warned labor unions not to place obstacles in the path of war veterans seeking jobs in industry in the post-war period.

MOSCOW, March 24 (Delayed) -- Although the United States has sent thousands of planes, tanks, guns and other weapons to the Red Army, the most obvious of these supplies to the people of Russia and the average Russian soldier are the American truck and the jeep.

Some British exporters, who hope for a vigorous foreign trade policy in that country after the war, expect that British manufacturers, on a basis of fair competition, will be the first among the world's suppliers to get to the market when victory is won.

Characterizing some signers of the recent protest against obliteration bombing as "blue stocking clergymen," the Rev. A. Hamilton Nesbitt, Police Department chaplain, yesterday declared himself a follower of a "militant Christ" and in favor of blasting Berlin and Tokyo until the Axis "archcriminals are forever wiped from the face of the earth."

Celia Saloman, pupil of Ernest Hutcheson and Carl Friedberg at the Juilliard School of Music and for many years head of the piano department of Greenwich House, gave a recital late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall, where she had appeared in 1928, before a large and appreciative audience.

Activity in stocks continued last week, but with more signs of heavy sales to realize profits. Each of the four first business days of the week exceeded a million shares, following an unbroken series of six million-share transactions for five-hour days and making twelve in all during March.

When the time comes for reconstruction and rehabilitation many nations will look to us for guidance and assistance. To prepare students to help in post-war work abroad, a large number of American colleges and universities have introduced special courses designed to train men and women for reconstruction work.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

ALGIERS, March 26 -- The lack of a decision on the political relations of the French and the Allies has resulted in a deadlock in economic plans for France, which, experts contend, should be finished without delay, it was said today. For this deadlock the United States Government is considered chiefly to blame by the French, since they believe that Washington has blocked a political accord favored by the British.

In many of the newspapers and magazines there have been since the outbreak of the war almost unbelievable stories of German mass atrocities. Yet there are thousands of smaller incidents which occur almost daily in German-occupied territory.

A Greenwich Village property passed to new control with the sale by Josephine McDermott, Clara E. Nutini and Florence O. Clement of the six-story apartment house for twenty-four families at 207-09 West Eleventh Street. Assessed at $70,000, the property is 41 by 78 feet and was purchased by Walter W. Weber for cash over a mortgage of $39,250.

Lining the basement walls of the neat, green-trimmed, gray-shingled house at 139-02 Fourteenth Avenue, College Point, Queens, are huge posters proclaiming: "Victory Begins at Home!" The emphasis seems somewhat unnecessary, for in this case "home" shelters not only William A. Young and his family but his thriving war plant as well.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- A recommendation that post-war highway and airport development programs be based on comprehensive Federal-State-local surveys of need, and that States and municipalities carry their full share of the cost of these projects, will be put before the United States Chamber of Commerce at its meeting May 3 to 5 in New York.

Net profit of the American Airlines, Inc., for 1943 amounted to $3,192,969 after providing $1,750,000 transition reserve, according to A.N. Kemp, president. This is equal after preferred dividends to $5.18 a share on 574,848 common shares, and compares with $3,851,714, including $834,846 received from the sale of flight equipment at Government direction, in 1942.

In volume of business, both electric and gas, the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation system set new records in 1943, according to the annual report released yesterday by Stuart M. Crocker, president.

LONDON, Monday, March 27 -The suggestion that Anthony Eden, who holds two of Britain's top political posts, might abandon the Foreign Secretaryship to concentrate on leadership of the House of Commons has come sharply to public notice after having been discussed in political circles for several months.

Seven hundred high school freshmen have visited New York furniture stores during the last few weeks to gather ideas on furniture styles and interior decoration. This display of interest in home furnishings among the 'teen-age crowd has been prompted by a competition now in full swing under the auspices of the Art Department of New York City public schools in cooperation with the Furniture Stores Guild.

PHILADELPHIA, March 26 -The Securities and Exchange Commission has held for the first time that the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., has "ample power" under its code of fair practices to "discipline a member for charging prices bearing no reasonable relation to prevailing market prices."

ESPIRITU SANTO ATOLL, March 20 (Delayed) -- If a radio popularity poll could be taken out here among American fighting forces a surprisingly large number votes would go to "Tokyo Rose" and other of the programs beamed from the Land of the Rising Sun to the advancing American bases in the south and southwest Pacific.

LONDON, Monday, March 27--American heavy bombers and American and Allied medium bombers and fighters went out in force yesterday over France and the Netherlands and smashed strategic Nazi coastal and inland targets.
NEW DELHI, India, March 26 -- There was a definite connection between two apparently separate items issued today from different headquarters.

The Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick in his sermon yesterday in the Riverside Church pointed out that the hope of the present era is in profound and transforming insight and not in wild, frivolous and irresponsible life brought about through war strain and tension and a wild desire to forget it all.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 26 -- Induction into the enlisted reserve to await the War Department's call is proceeding here without incident among 1,000 unmarried American-born Japanese at the Rivers Relocation Center, east of this city, it was learned today.

National advertisers say they were not alarmed over the prospect of the barring of national advertising in line with the action taken last week by St. Paul newspapers. Spokesmen for the advertisers said they were aware that the great majority of newspapers in the country were in a position to publish all the advertising, local and national, that is offered to them.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -Prime Minister Churchill's reassertion of British determination to see the Pacific war through to the end brought a quick response tonight from Congressional leaders in Washington.

A St. John's aggregation that never for an instant doubted itself or its right to its rule in the national invitation college basketball tournament conquered the favored Blue Demons of De Paul, 47 -- 39, in the final at Madison Square Garden last night.
BOSTON, March 26 -- Vice President Wallace, speaking today at the 123d anniversary of Greek Independence Day, advised that a hand in shaping the nation's destiny be allowed minority groups.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 26 (Reuter) -- The Hellenic News Agency said today that the Greek Government could not approve any unilateral effort by the five-man Greek guerrilla committee to form a government "of broader coalition."

Stressing the need for "revitalizing and strengthening international law" and for speedy action to assure an enduring peace through an international organization, 200 judges, professors and officials of national and international experience made public yesterday a report setting forth proposals for "the international law of the future."

ALBANY, March 26 -- The Baum bill providing for consolidation of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City and the Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities was signed today by Governor Dewey.

Lucie Bigelow Rosen, thereminist, of this city, gave a recital last night in Town Hall. The theremin on which she played was of the latest type, far more sensitive than the earlier models, which it exceeds greatly in range, and permitting the performance of rapid music not possible on the electrical instrument in the first stages of its development.
DALLAS, March 26 -- Business men of this State are swinging into action with an eye on the post-war period and are investigating the possibilities for a great industrial empire in the Southwest.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -Senator Harry S. Truman, Democrat, of Missouri, today called for the re-election of President Roosevelt in a public statement expressing complete confidence in the readiness of preparations for the crucial period of the war.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices was 113.02, a rise of 0.1 per cent over the previous week's level of 112.89. The raw materials index and the farm products index rose 0.3 per cent and 0.5 per cent respectively as a result of increases in the prices of wheat, livestock cotton and potatoes.

Abraham Herman, president of the Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society (HIAS), has been re-elected for the nineteenth successive time, it was announced yesterday by the National Board of Directors. Mr. Herman is controller of the National Container Corporation.

With their stocks now adequate for the expected large Easter and Mother's Day trade, retailers are turning to fall lines, according to resident buying offices in their summaries of the markets prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

PEARL HARBOR, March 26 -- Three islands in the Kurile chain, some 1,200 miles northwest of Tokyo, were attacked before dawn yesterday by Army and Navy planes based in the Aleutians, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz' headquarters announced today.

Asserting that "we are living in an age of paganism" and that "paganism in its worst days was never worse than that stalking the streets of our cities today," Mgr. John L. Belford of the Roman Catholic Church of the Nativity, Brooklyn, declared yesterday that "The Voice of the Turtle," a play at the Morosco Theatre, was "rotten" and indicative of immoral tendencies in the theatre.

The naturalization ceremony for new citizens can be perfunctory and listless, as it too often is, with no more spiritual warmth in it than in the process of getting an automobile license. Or it can be made a thrilling event, one which the new citizen will remember proudly through the years.

LONDON, March 26 -- The Board of Trade index of commodity prices for February, based on 1930 as 100, stood at 164.6, a new wartime high, comparing with 164 for January and 162.1 for February, 1943. The aggregate rise since August, 1939, now is 68 per cent, food and tobacco being 68 and industrial materials 63 per cent higher.

LONDON, March 26 -- The stock markets here continue their quiet, uninteresting course. There is a veritable flood of company reports of dividends to regale the shareholders, and sometimes to stir up moderate activity in selected stocks, but over all broods the coming Western offensive and the start of the national savings drive in London's great effort to gather funds for final victory.
AT A UNITED STATES AIR BASE IN CHINA, March 26 -- An American pilot has seen a mountain in Sinkiang Province of western China which he believes is higher than the 29,000 feet of Mount Everest.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -Lindsay Warren, Controller General, who has been described as the watchdog of the Treasury and the taxpayers' friend, asserted tonight that the war profiteer is on the loose.

To Patricia Kirkland will go the central feminine role in the untitled F. Hugh Herbert play, which Gilbert Miller will produce shortly, it became known yesterday. This will mark Miss Kirkland's Broadway debut. She is the daughter of Jack Kirkland and his former wife, Nancy Carroll, and is now acting the chief part in the Chicago duplication of "Kiss and Tell"

Asserting that the Coudert-Wicks bill, now awaiting Governor Dewey's signature, transforms the office of school superintendent into that of "an educational autocrat," Local 2 of the New York Teachers Guild called yesterday upon Superintendent of Schools John E. Wade to make public his conception of what he believed his new role would be under the bill.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, March 27 (UP) -- A communique:

The first group of wage earners to exceed its quota in the 1944 Red Cross War Fund drive is made up of employes of the apparel industry, it was announced yesterday by Eugene W. Stetson, chairman of the Manhattan Commerce and Industry Committee.

MOSCOW, March 26 (AP) -- The German armies, which Premier Stalin announced today had been hurled across the Prut River -"our State frontier" -- once were more than 800 miles inside the Soviet Union from the starting point of their 1941 attack.

CHICAGO, March 26 -- Stocks of lard in cold storage in leading markets continue to accumulate at a rapid rate despite determined efforts to relieve the shortage of cooler space. Packers expect that only moderate improvement in the storage situation will result of a Government order issued recently designed to move out commodities that have been held for some time past.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Seventeen American airlines attacked today Senator Pat McCarran's world airline bill as "monopolistic" and declared that they wanted the opportunity in the post-war world to compete for international air business.

Sacrificial efforts of huge proportions will be required in the post-war world to meet the need of peoples and countries wasted by the war, the Very Rev. Hughell E.W. Fosbroke, dean of the General Theological Seminary, said in his sermon yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

The War Production Board is financing the plans of Grosvenor Atterbury, director of research for the Yale Department of Architecture, to reduce the cost of building homes through new processes and mass-production methods. It is encouraging to learn that these plans are so promising as to induce Government wartime support.

Steam shovels will break no new ground for additional Government war housing in New York State, and thousands of workers who have been busy with hammer and saw for months on these emergency projects already are turning to other jobs.

LONDON, March 26 (U.P.) -- The Archbishop of Canterbury and Free Church leaders today offered an eight-point program for peace and a warning against "breaches of basic human rights" in dealing with Germany.

The Savings Banks Trust Company, 14 Wall Street, central organization for the mutual savings banks of this State, announced yesterday that with the increased rates on postoffice money orders, effective yesterday, the savings banks will launch a campaign to popularize savings bank money orders by means of newspaper advertising and posters.

The 1943 annual report of the General Aniline and Film Corporation, issued for publication today, shows a net income of $3,624,800 after all charges, including $9,003,562 taxes and $1,000,000 provision for special accruals due to wartime operations.

This is a condensation of the third in a series of lectures arranged by the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross for home nursing instructors in preparation lot reception of returning war veterans. The lecture, by Dr. Henriette R. Klein, instructor in psychiatry at the College of Physicians and Surgeons and associate in Neurology and Psychiatry at Long Island Medical College, is on "Pychoneuroses and Proposed Attitudes Toward Discharged Service Men."

It was a pleasant surprise to read Senator Walter F. George's report on the tax-simplification feature he is sponsoring in the Senate Finance Committee, which would give consideration to the broker or commission man. All of the alphabetical agencies of the Government have reviled and castigated the broker as an unnecessary evil, as a parasite, and much worse.
LONDON, Monday, March 27 (AP) -- The Russian Sunday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

R. J. Dearborn, president, Texaco Development Corporation, in accepting chairmanship yesterday of the committee on patents of the National Association of Manufacturers, declared that strong patent protection is vital to provide postwar jobs and creation of new small business.
LONDON, March 26 (AP) -- From United States Strategic Air Force in Europe, a communique:

AS the great wire services grew and supplied the world's news in identical packages to newspaper customers in every county of the country; as the great metropolitan dailies, like this one, stressed more and more complete and objective coverage of news, and as the editorial pages of the nation became more and more dignified and institutional, numerous good citizens began to view the press with considerable alarm.

The Russians' tactics in their great and successful offensive battles that are now ending the winter campaign are of major importance to the Allies as Britain and the United States prepare for the invasion of western Europe.
To aid in the waste paper drive, Superintendent of Schools John E. Wade ordered yesterday a clean-up of useless records in the city schools.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 26 -- With a real breath of spring out on the water, seven races were sailed this afternoon in the dinghy regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club, and Jack Sutphen came through them in his craft Rum Dum with a top score of 127 points, six more than his nearest competitor, Arthur Knapp, with Popcorn.

Representative Martin Dies of Texas, utilizing radio time alloted by the sponsors of Walter Winchell and following the columnist on the air, last night called him the "tool" of a "smear Bund" of powerful and organized interests and promised that the Congressional committee investigating subversive activities that he heads would tell the American people "who is supplying the brains and who is paying the bills."

The eleven-story store and loft building on a plot 40 by 98.9 feet at 109-11 West Twenty-seventh street was sold by Julie G. Wolff to Charles Beneson, operator, through Walter Samuels. It is assessed at $90,000 and was sold subject to a first mortgage of $85,000 held by the Central Savings Bank.

LONDON, Monday, March 27 -Germany is pouring troops across occupied Hungary into Rumania to strengthen the defenses of the lower Danube against the Soviet Army's advance, Ankara, Turkey, dispatches said today, and German broadcasts said Rumania was calling up more troops and specifying evacuation areas for the citizens of Bucharest.

A UNITED STATES BOMBER BASE in England, March 26 (AP) -High over occupied Europe in a plane from which the rest of the crew had bailed out, the pilot and co-pilot of a Flying Fortress shook hands and agreed to bring their bullet-riddled ship home or die trying.
NAPLES, March 26 -- In the first six months of their occupation of this metropolis, the Allied authorities have learned several lessons that should be helpful when the next great city is taken over.

Rome must be spared from aerial destruction, Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the Catholic University of America at Washington, declared yesterday at the unveiling of an oil painting of Our Lady of the Rosary of Fatima, which will be presented to the Pope when conditions permit. Archbishop Francis J. Spellman presided at the ceremony in the East Ballroom of the Hotel Commodore.
NEW DELHI, India, March 26 (UP) -- A communique:

Opposition to the bills recently passed by the New York State Legislature designed to give corporations protection against minority stockholder suits, was voiced yesterday by the Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut in a resolution that termed the legislation "against public policy."

The man with the explosive adjectives is in town. 'Gather around and hear about the most magnificent and exhilarating spectacle ever beheld by mortal eye, unparalleled in amusement annals," he boomed. He should know. He is Roland Butler, the head press agent of Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- Civilians will have more butter and cheese, but slightly less meat, during April, May and June, compared with the first three months of the year.

The week's list of film newcomers rose to three with the announcement yesterday of two additional openings. At the Radio City Music Hall "Cover Girl," a musical comedy in Technicolor produced by Columbia, will have its premiere on Thursday.

A bolt of lightning struck a transformer in the powerhouse under Central Park West at Eighty-second Street during the thunderstorm yesterday afternoon, burned out eight switches and caused a tie-up on the Eighth Avenue Independent Subway for an hour and nineteen minutes.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Great respect for the stubbornness of the German soldier and for his mastery of the art of fighting delaying actions was voiced today by an official Army observer, just back from the Italian fronts, in a report to Lieut. Gen. Lesley J. McNair, Commanding General of the Army Ground Forces.
LONDON, March 27 (UP) -- A United States Strategic Air Force in Europe announcement:

In October, 1888, Mark Twain wrote from Hartford to his brother Orion in Keokuk, "Today I pay Pratt Whitney $10,000." This shows how a person today can keep up with the times by turning off the radio and pulling an old friend from the bookshelves, like this second volume of Mark Twain's letters published twenty-seven years ago.

BALTIMORE, March 27 (AP) -- Sixty-five 3-year-olds, including most of last season's juvenile stars, have been nominated for the $25,000-added Chesapeake Stakes, the Maryland Jockey Club announced today.
NAPLES, March 27 -- While the ground troops were more or less static on the Cassino front, two localized German thrusts were broken up yesterday on the beachhead below Rome.

Service men ordering Easter flowers for their wives, mothers and friends have received unofficial priorities on this season's limited supply, the Florists Telegraph Delivery Association reported yesterday.

Coffee on the house was the news that merchant seamen at Wilshire House, 134 West Fifty-eighth Street, circulated yesterday in the lobby, as the American Women's Voluntary Services opened a snack bar adjoining the game room. Conducted by the Manhattan AWVS canteen corps, the sandwich-cake-and-coffee counter was established at the request of the United Seamen's Service, the hotel's sponsor.

Jane Courtland, a young pianist who made her debut in February, 1943, gave another recital in Town Hall last night and, though she plays with a certain charm and poise, the concert was, on the whole, a disappointing affair. Miss Courtland has an agile enough technique and a not unmusical sense of what she plays, but all too often her playing was loud without being sonorous, thin without being transparent and unorthodox without being imaginative.

An action for $90,000 against James C. Petrillo as president of the American Federation of Musicians was disclosed yesterday in Supreme Court when Justice Horris Eder reserved decision on a motion of Opera On Tour, Inc., to examine Mr. Petrillo before trial.

CHICAGO, March 27 -- Grain markets showed a strong undertone in the early trading today on the Board of Trade, with December oats and rye and July barley selling at new seasonal high prices, but the bulge brought heavy profit-taking, part of which was attributed to a professional trader.
The beginning of April, as any good gardener knows, is "digging time." As soon as the frost is out of the ground and the earth has had a chance to dry forking and clod-breaking begin in earnest.

A new issue of $5,350,000 of refunding bonds was announced yesterday by Lakeland, Fla., for award on April 12. The issue, dated July 1, 1944, will mature serially from July 1, 1946 to 1970, and will become callable on July 1, 1959. Bidders are asked to stipulate the rate of interest at not to exceed 3 1/4 per cent.

A pale yellow powder that furnishes a delicious ice cream when beaten with water and frozen in a mechanical refrigerator is to be found in this city for the first time today at Altman's. Trade-named Frizz and manufactured by the Kraft Cheese Company, it costs 32 cents for a package that results in a quart of the finished product.

The War Production Board reported yesterday that production fell off in five of the seven major categories of war equipment during the latest month for which figures are available. Guns were down. Ships were down. Combat and motor vehicles were down. Radar was down. Miscellaneous supplies were down. This was not planned.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Government agencies, grappling with a cloth shortage likely to mean 15 per cent less cotton goods for civilian use in 1944 than in 1943, declared today that they were doing their best to channel the supply into the low-cost necessity shortage items such as work clothes and children's clothing.

TRENTON, N.J., March 27 -- Efforts of the Hudson County Bar Association to obtain a reappointment for Common Pleas Judge Thomas H. Brown, a Republican reputably in the good graces of Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, the State Democratic leader, failed today when Gov. Walter E. Edge nominated August Ziegener to succeed him on April 1.

Wayne Thomas Lonergan fingered his chin, absent-mindedly pinched his nose and passed long, thin fingers through his hair in General Sessions Court yesterday while a stenographer read into the record the Lonergan confession of the murder of his wife, Patricia.

There was plenty of concentration on bows and flowers yesterday in a collection of hats by Mme. Pauline that stressed youthful coquetry. The exhibition took place at the luncheon hour in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis.

LONDON, March 27 -- In a quiet stock market today speculative Kaffirs showed a firmer trend, the market being relieved by the news that gold realization charges be used to meet higher native wages and price changes, however small.

Women are handling anti-aircraft guns, land mines and booby traps in at least one spot in New York. They took over yesterday morning as demonstrators, attendants and guides at the Army Ordnance Exhibition of War Weapons at the Chrysler Salon, Forty-second Street and Lexington Avenue.

ALGIERS, March 26 -- Referring to the French Committee of National Liberation as, "the Provisional Government of the Republic," Gen. Charles de Gaulle told the Provisional Consultative Assembly today that the Government "does not need any lesson from anyone but the French nation that it is entrusted to lead.

A delegation from the State, County and Municipal Workers of America, New York District, left at Mayor La Guardia's office at City Hall yesterday a petition signed by 25,000 municipal employes in eighteen departments asking for a cost of living adjustment, a $1,500 minimum salary, and time and a half for overtime in the budget on which the Mayor is working.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- While emphasizing that manpower would become "a more and more critical problem," Donald M. Nelson of the War Production Board reported today that output of aircraft, acknowledged to be the spearhead weapon of the forthcoming invasion of Europe, rose 4 per cent during February although munitions production as a whole dropped 1 per cent.

NAPLES, March 27 -- Three of the most important Italian officials in the Neapolitan administration are about to be replaced, it was confirmed today. But whether they are being punished, kicked upstairs or just mildly but firmly put out of the way of possible trouble is a nice question.
LONDON, March 27 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

In one of the largest East Side industrial realty transactions of recent months Benjamin Winter, operator and investor, has acquired from the Pavonia Building Corporation the seven-story and penthouse loft building at 141-55 East Twenty-fifth Street. The deal was negotiated by Herbert L. Williams, Inc.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Office of Price Administration removed the expiration dates of all red and blue stamps in War Ration Book Four today in a step which Chester Bowles, administrator, said would provide "major relief for the nation's 600,000 retailers from the burdens of food rationing."

Twelve witnesses were called by the prosecutor yesterday at the start of the Special Sessions trial of Harry Craig Cooper, president of the Century Travel Service Corporation at 655 Fifth Avenue, and one of his employes, Miss Mary Tosti of 636 Crescent Avenue, Brooklyn, on a thirty-two-count "information" accusing them of conspiring to violate the section of the City Administrative Code against charging more than $1 for services in the sale of a railroad ticket.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The President's approval was both implicit and explicit when he read to his last press conference a letter from Mr. Crowley, head of the Foreign Economic Administration. It was an outline of the policy that governs our lend-leasing of farm machinery and was proposed as general post-war policy also in all matters of material assistance to allied peoples ravaged by war.

By a coincidence rare in warfare the Allies driving from India into Burma and the Japanese driving from Burma into India appear to be closing in simultaneously on their immediate objectives. Three Allied columns converging on Myitkyina are within thirty-two miles of that central enemy base, while Japanese forces have fought their way about as close to Imphal, provincial capital of Manipur.

There was a hum of activity in the Irving Gaumont office yesterday as preparations went forward for the production of 'Stovepipe Hat." Mr. Gaumont imparted the information that rehearsals will commence on April 17 under the guidance of Robert Ross and that Helen Tamiris will be responsible for the choreography.
Wendell L. Willkie's speech of yesterday at Ripon Wis., reported in today's paper, revives the claim of Ripon as the birthplace of the Republican party.

A crowd of 18,630 turned out to witness the seventeenth annual intercity Golden Gloves amateur boxing tournament at Madison Square Garden last night. The program brought together a team representing New York and an aggregation wearing the colors of the city of Chicago, the latter group winning.

Will H. Hays praised the motion-picture industry yesterday for its many war activities and in his annual report to the board of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, Inc., urged freedom of the screen everywhere. The meeting, at which Mr. Hays was elected president for the twenty-third consecutive year, was held in the organization's headquarters, 28 West Forty-fourth Street.

The stock market plodded through an uneventful session yesterday, to the accompaniment of the second smallest volume of the month. There was a marked absence of interest in the pivotal industrial issues, a show of strength in some of the liquors and a short-lived burst in the aircrafts.

Major distillers and Albert E. Driscoll, commissioner of the New Jersey Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, yesterday served joint notice that they intended to take immediate steps to wipe out "tie-in" sales whereby tavern owners and package store operators were compelled to overstock on unknown blackstrap rums to obtain small deliveries of standard ryes and scotches.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Underground travel for iron ore miners constitutes working time and must be paid for under the Fair Labor Standards Act, the Supreme Court ruled today.
LONDON, March 27 -- The statement of Secretary Cordell Hull that he is opposed to "political censorship" raises the question of what he means by "political."

Construction of privately financed dwelling units for war workers showed a slight rise in February over the preceding month, according to Abner H. Ferguson, commissioner of the Federal Housing Administration. Work was started on 8,658 new units by private builders during the month, as compared with 7,899 in January.

MILWAUKEE, March 27 -- Asserting that through fault of the Roosevelt Administration the American people had lost their sense of direction in this war, Wendell L. Willkie called upon the Administration tonight to put into effect its declared foreign policies as expressed in the Atlantic Charter.

In a last-minute effort to prevent the American Labor party from disintegrating in factional bitterness, Mayor La Guardia announced last night that he would renew his efforts to effect a reconciliation between the rival groups after today's primary elections, in which control of the party machinery is at stake.

The Governor's office announced in Albany last night the filling of one of the vacancies on the State Labor Relations Board and the naming of Father William J. Kelley of Buffalo, presently a member, as chairman.

Construction of an air fleet in wartime of necessity subordinates the interests of an aircraft company to that of the Government, but it in turn has an obligation to the company, Donald W. Douglas, president of the Douglas Aircraft Company, said yesterday in his annual report

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 27 -- If the present reluctance of Arky Vaughan to report for baseball duty persists until April 18 and thereafter, the Dodgers seem likely to present a complete 4F infield when they open the 1944 campaign against Freddy Fitzsimmons' Blue Jay-Phillies.

A lot of people who do not belong to the American Labor party will watch with interest today's primary fight for its control. It is, in fact, almost the only thing there is to watch. The fight is personal and in some respects confusing. However, the essential issue is clear.

Norton has just published a definitive edition of St. John Perse's "Eloges and Other Poems," containing both the French text and an English translation by Louise Varese. The introduction is by Archibald MacLeish, Librarian of Congress.

BESSEMER, Ala., March 27 (U.P.) -- Union officials today called a Supreme Court ruling in favor of iron ore miners who sued three Jefferson County steel concerns for underground travel pay, "one of the outstanding gains made for the underground miner in the last half century."

Designed to avert heavy loss to the raw-skin branch of the fur industry which would result from price rollbacks for the present season, the interim price regulations for the industry are expected to be issued by the Office of Price Administration within the next three weeks.

NEW DELHI, India, March 27 -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's Americans and Chinese, using grenades and bayonets to wipe out Japanese suicide squads, were closing in on an encircled force in the Mogaung Valley of northern Burma today, as a new threat to Allied life lines developed from the enemy's tank-supported invasion of India.

Tennessee has mountains to switch off air currents and valleys for them to take their harmless exercise in. Storms shouldn't be looked for there, but when they come they show an original genius. At least in Memphis, where on Sunday night the sky gods broke windows with the recklessness of small boys.

ALBANY, March 27 -- Governor Dewey signed today the Wallace Bill permitting public officers and employes to absent themselves while on military duty with the New York Guard without loss of compensation or vacation privileges.

Theodore Dreiser will be honored in May at the annual ceremonial of the American Academy of Arts and Letters with the Award of Merit Medal and $1,000 cash prize for 1944. Dr. Walter Damrosch, president of the academy, notified Mr. Dreiser of the award in a letter praising his contribution to American letters.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (UP) -- A Pacific Fleet announcement:
CHICAGO, March 27 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 27 -- Departing from precedent, County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach of Westchester recommended today to the Board of Supervisors that $300,000 of a surplus from the 1943 county budget be "frozen" as a capital reserve for post-war construction work.

CHICAGO, March 27 -- The selection of St. Louis University as the school which will receive a bequest of $1,350,000 under the will of Henry E. Sever, eccentric Chicago publisher who left an estate of $3,318,000 at his death in 1941, was made public today by Judge Joseph A. Graber of the Cook County Superior Court.
AKRON, Ohio, March 27 (AP) -- P.W. Litchfield, chairman of the board of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, today called 1943 a year "of record-breaking accomplishments" for Goodyear.

Your news articles concerning food rationing and food price control, generally written by Jefferson Bell, have been consistently fair and accurate. It is apparent that Mr. Bell has not been content with rewriting the usual Government handouts, but has endeavored to approach members of the industries and trades involved and obtain their views.

Some unusually colorful figures were rounded up as draft delinquents by the Federal Bureau of Investigation last week. E.E. Conroy, local FBI chief, listed a man who never had heard of Adolf Hitler and thought fighting Germany would bring him into conflict with the Kaiser, along with a young man who tired of trying to be sent to jail for traffic offenses and sought to disguise himself with a big red mustache.
It is good to see you keeping "Draft of Fathers" on the front page.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Secretary Hull denied today the statement made by Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York in his address Friday night that the State Department had requested the British censor to suppress political news sent to American newspapers by American correspondents abroad.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 27 -- The Rev. Emerson S. Schwenk, 38 years old, of 85 Cottage Street, pastor of the First Universalist Church here for four years, prepared today to give up his pulpit after the Easter services rather than preach in a church where a service flag for men in the armed forces is displayed.

TENAFLY, N.J., March 27 -- Five hundred of the 700 students at Tenafly High School staged an orderly walkout at the close of the 11:05 class period this morning in protest against refusal of the School Board to issue a new contract to Leonard V. Kachel, who teaches history and English and coaches the football team.

OMAHA, March 27 (AP) -- Col. Robert R. McCormick contended tonight that "Communists not only dominate the Democratic party but are actively trying to control the Republican National Convention as the New Deal did in 1940."

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Enactment of pending Senate legislation to abolish cost-plus-fixed-fee war contracts would "seriously hamper" aircraft production, the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce declared today in a statement to the upper house Military Affairs Sub-committee on War Contracts.

LONDON, Tuesday, March 28 (AP) -- The Daily Mail in a column-long editorial characterized Britain's foreign policy today as one of expediency, varying from day to day, and called for an authoritative definition of the policy.
Your letter column of March 22 contained favorable endorsement of the St. Lawrence seaway and power project by the executive secretary of the Community Councils of the City of New York.

ALBANY, March 27 -- Despite agitation in and out of the Legislature for scrapping of the 1925 Friedsam Formula, under which State aid for education is apportioned, Miss Alice McCormack, who has supervised the annual allotment of State aid since 1918, said today that the formula should be retained. She will retire Saturday.

ORANGEBURG, N.Y., March 27 -- New York stare hospitals have become the "repositories" of old-age mental patients, due in large part to changed social conditions and improvements in medical science, which have increased the individual's life span ten to fifteen years, Dr. Russell H. Blaisdell, superintendent of the Rockland State Hospital here, declared today.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 27 -- With the Russians at the Rumanian frontier, their onward march unchecked, Premier Ion Antonescu is determined to mobilize Rumania's entire manpower -- and even woman power -- for staging a last desperate battle of survival.

The nations of the Western Hemisphere, deprived of the clinics of Paris, Berlin and Vienna, will turn to New York for advanced medical training, Dr. Arthur F. Chace, recently retired president of the New York Post-Graduate Medical School and Hospital, predicted in the institution's annual report for 1943, made public yesterday.

Appointment of two additional aides in the drive to get the Republican Presidential nomination for Wendell L. Willkie was announced here yesterday by Ralph H. Cake, Mr. Willkie's manager, and Mrs. Grace B. Reynolds, director of women's activities of the Willkie for President National Committee.

LONDON, March 27 -- Following its traditional function of rendering every possible aid to the innocent victims of war, the American National Red Cross, on its own responsibility, or as the agent of the Government in Washington, has distributed tens of millions of dollars' worth of food, clothing and medical supplies to the stricken civil populations throughout the world since hostilities started.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 27 -- Marc Platt, leading dancer in the stage musical "Oklahoma," who has just arrived here under contract to Columbia, will have one of the two male featured roles in "Tonight and Everynight," the forthcoming technicolor musical based on the Lesley Storm play, "The Heart of a City."

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- Spokesmen for three Federal agencies declared today if any attempts have been made to use the draft or ration restrictions to force farmers into Government crop programs it was done without official knowledge.

A rising volume of "beat-the tax" buying is being done by consumers on liquors, cosmetics, furs, jewelry and to a smaller extent on handbags and luggage in anticipation of the higher Federal excise taxes which become effective on Saturday, it was reported here yesterday.

JERUSALEM, March 27 -- With the curfew maintained at its fullest severity upon the Jewish areas of Jerusalem, Haifa and the entire all-Jewish city of Tel Aviv, high-ranking representatives of the leading Jewish organizations met in Jerusalem this morning with a view to considering action against the small terrorist group whose sabotage activities have led to a new and grave situation.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY ON THE CASSINO FRONT, March 27 (AP) -- When Allied troops went into Cassino they found pillboxes under many of the piles of rubble, anti-tank guns in cellars and the debris alive with snipers. One German sniper was credited with killing thirty-four Allied soldiers.

LINDEN, N.J., March 27 -- In accordance with a directive by R.J. Thomas, its international president, Local 595, United Automobile Workers, will hold a new election of officers April 6, 7 and 8 despite a temporary injunction issued last week by Vice Chanceller Alfred A. Stein banning such action, it was announced today. A hearing on the temporary restraining order is scheduled for April 3.

The shipment of hundreds of carloads of Maine's huge potato surplus from last year's crop to Midwestern beet sugar plants has come to a temporary halt this week, it was disclosed here yesterday by Carl R. Smith,, Commissioner of Agriculture of Maine.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- In a six-to-three split decision the Supreme Court sustained today a rate increase granted to the Washington Gas Light Company which the Administration had opposed as inflationary and against the policy of the war stabilization program.

Accidents, during the last year, have dropped from fourth to fifth place as a cause of death among this country's civilian population, it is revealed in a report by the trustees of the National Safety Council on its expanded accident prevention program.

Officers and members of the board of the Bargain Box, a permanent thrift shop maintained to raise funds for various charitable agencies in the city, will open the organization's annual drive for rummage on Saturday. Useful and decorative articles suitable for resale later at the shop, situated at 1175 Third Avenue, are needed to replenish stocks.

After a winter of research on price control and rationing, sixty-five school children have drawn up five recommendations for Daniel P. Woolley, regional Office of Price Administration chief, it was learned yesterday. The boys and girls, members of Youthbuilders Clubs at Public School 3, at 490 Hudson Street, and Public School 43, Amsterdam Avenue and 129th Street, will submit their reports within the next few days.

After preliminary distribution tests extending over a period of ten months, Isbrandtsen Lines of 26 Broadway, announced yesterday that it would embark on a national merchandising program for Isbrandtsen "26" Coffee, using newspaper and radio advertising in principal metropolitan areas.

There are many ghost words in modern vocabularies that it would be a relief to have exorcised. Among them is "Erse." "When we say that nearly all the teachers in Eire are qualified to teach the Erse language, it still leaves open the question of its popular use," says an editorial comment in THE TIMES.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- Full responsibility for approving virtually all types of non-farming construction was lodged today in the National Housing Agency.

The air war over Nazi Europe is still growing in scope and intensity. Every passing day establishes new records for the number of Allied planes that roam the Nazi skies, for the weight of bombs and incendiaries dropped on Nazi targets, for the number of Nazi planes destroyed, and for the relentless frequency of the attacks.

LONDON, March 27 (U.P.) -- Aneta, official Netherland news agency, quoted a report today that Field Marshal Gen. Erwin Rommel, commander of the German invasion defenses in the west, had established headquarters in Breda, the Netherlands.

The National Container Corporation has completed with Van Alstyne, Noel Co. arrangements for public sale of $4,500,000 of 5 per cent fifteen-year sinking fund debentures due in 1959, it was announced yesterday upon filing of a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, March 28 (AP) -- Bombers from Allied bases in the Solomon Islands, concentrating their attention on buildings in a new phase of the air campaign to smash the Japanese base at Rabaul, New Britain, damaged or destroyed 145 structures of all types and sizes in raids Friday and Saturday.

Driving ahead in the National Squash Tennis Association's Red Cross tournament yesterday at the Harvard Club, Walter D. Hoag of the Yale Club went through the quarter-final round with a defeat of his clubmate, Kenneth Ward, 15 -- 7, 15 -- 3. Hoag, seeded No. 1 in the tourney, with bomb sight pick-ups and a spattering of his hard smashes, reigned throughout.

AMERICAN AIR COMMANDOS' HEADQUARTERS, Burma Frontier, March 19 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- One of the hardest-working units in Col. Philip Cochran's Air Commando force is the light-plane section, whose job it is to transport British wounded from the north central Burma jungles.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Consumer declarations for persons who seek to use Pennsylvania anthracite or Eastern coke will be available through retail dealers by the end of this week, the Solid Fuels Administration made known today.

LONDON, March 28 -- The Soviet thrust toward Hungary and into Rumania threatens Germany with economic losses as important as the ensuing political disruption, according to well informed sources here. These impending losses include 3,500,000 tons of oil sent annually from Rumania to Germany and a half-million tons of Hungarian bauxite.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- An inquiry into the reasons for Army and Navy reluctance to accept a plan for the drafting of 4-F's and men over 38 who are not holding essential jobs was scheduled today by the House Military Affairs sub-committee on the draft after it heard testimony that such a proposal had been discussed by the services.

IF Man o' War were human, they would be, saying that he is getting along in years and is an old man. Big Red will be 27 years old tomorrow, but when the sun strikes that handsome coat of his and clings there like burnished gold he still looks to be what he is, a majestic figure of a horse who is the king of the thoroughbreds.
LONDON, March 27 (Reuter) -- All civilian passenger trains may disappear from British railways at any moment during the final preparations for the second front, authoritative sources said today.

Lieut. (j.g.) Adam A. Rother, resting his hope of acquittal on a final argument that the State has failed to prove him guilty of any degree of homicide, came to the end of his defense yesterday in Richmond County Court, where he is charged with the murder of Miss Rita Costello.

The ration token system ran into difficulties because consumers hoarded the tokens. This situation arose because the tokens had no expiration date, while the 10-point coupons were good only to specified dates. By converting the coupons into tokens, consumers could accumulate a stock of usable claims to rationed goods.

LONDON, Tuesday, March 28 (U.P.) -- An order of the day from Premier Stalin and Moscow's war communiques announced another series of notable triumphs for the three Ukrainian armies, which drove the enemy from more than 324 towns and settlements yesterday on all sectors of the long front stretching from the Black Sea to Poland.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The House of Representatives adopted by voice vote today a bill which removes Federal employes from "the double jeopardy" of multiple income taxes in States to which many have become subject through removal from their home commonwealth to the District of Columbia or other States.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Supreme Court affirmed twice today the price-control authority written into war legislation, based in one case on the sale of meat above ceiling prices and in another on a challenge of authority to freeze rents.

Regardless of the outcome of tonight's East-West final for the N.C.A.A. basketball championship at Madison Square Garden, when Dartmouth opposes Utah, the latter team will clash with St. John's, national invitation ruler, in Thursday night's charity game for the American Red Cross.

One of the most critical reconversion problems after the war will be that of the aircraft industry, the Guaranty Trust Company said yesterday in its monthly news letter, The Guaranty Survey. The magnitude of the problem, the bank held, would depend upon the size of the post-war market for aircraft.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- The House was thrown into an uproar today when Representative Hoffman, Republican, of Michigan renewed his attacks on the radio broadcaster, Walter Winchell, declaring "the truth just isn't in Winchell."

The report of the Crane Company and its domestic subsidiaries for last year, issued for publication today, showed a net profit of $6,909,382, after charges and an appropriation of $4,500,000 for contingencies. The net was equivalent to $2.53 each on 2,348,628 shares of common stock after allowing for dividend requirements on the preferred.

New Yorkers were quick to adjust themselves to the penny increase in the cost of sending local mail, but postal officials throughout the city were near despair yesterday at the vast amount of domestic air mail that is coming through with inadequate postage.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended March 22:

In a cabled exchange of greetings, the Boy Scouts of America and their fellow-Scouts from Yugoslavia, who are fighting to help rid their country of the Germans, yesterday marked the third anniversary of the revolt of the Yugoslav people against their government, which had agreed to cooperate with the Nazis.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- In what was described as "the most sweeping synthetic rubber conversion order so far," the Office of Rubber Director has specified that all civilian truck and bus tires of the eight most widely used large sizes, manufactured after April 1, must contain at least 35 per cent synthetic rubber, it was learned today.

OKLAHOMA CITY, March 27 -- Senator Albert W. Barkley's participation in Oklahoma's Second District Congressional race was criticized here tonight by Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio, who said that the Kentucky Democrat "would be rendering a better service to his country and be more consistent with himself if he were here urging the election of the anti-New Deal candidate."

CAIRO, Egypt, March 27 -- A detailed memorandum regarding Algeria is being prepared here by the newely created committee of Arabs who are seeking to promote nationalist aspirations of Algerian Arabs. The statement will be presented to all Arab Governments who adhered to the Atlantic Charter.
PHILADELPHIA, March 27 -- The Chicago Stock Exchange became today the sixth national exchange to receive approval of a special-offering plan from the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Bids totaling over $350,000 were tendered yesterday for fabricated items, component parts and materials offered for sale as surplus inventories of five Eastern aircraft manufacturers. Approximately 600 prospective buyers visited the sale, which is being held at the Hotel McAlpin under the joint sponsorship of the manufacturers and the War Production Board.

PEARL HARBOR, March 27 -- Japan appears to be tightening her defenses in the Carolines after successively falling back before aggressive American thrusts into the Central Pacific over the past four months. Today's press release from Admiral Chester W. Nimitz's headquarters told of stiff aerial and anti-aircraft resistance to United States planes that attacked Ponape Saturday.
LONDON, March 27 -- The American "invasion" of Britain has whetted the curiosity of England about the United States, according to the Office of War Information.

A test survey, now being conducted in the Flushing area, by a committee of the North Shore Food Dealers Association, with Ernest Herrman, secretary of the association as chairman, and which is expected to be completed this week, reveals that 14 per cent of the proprietors of independent food stores, who are fathers under thirty-eight years of age, have been inducted or classified 1A this month.
The food industry in Manhattan led contributors to the Red Cross 1944 War Fund as the week opened yesterday. The motion picture industry also made a good showing.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, March 28 -- The Soviet High Command announced last night the capture of the German Dniester River bastion of Kamenets-Podolsk, while at the other end of the southern Ukrainian front the forces of Gen. Rodion Y. Malinovsky broke into the outskirts of the Black Sea port of Nikolayev, where street fighting was in progress.

LONDON, Tuesday, March 28 -- More than six hundred Flying Fortresses and Liberators swept down on nine Luftwaffe bases in central and southwestern France yesterday to deliver one of the heaviest blows yet struck at advanced German airfields. They also bombed the strategic rail yards at Tours.

With the termination of wartime emergency traffic conditions, the Fifth Avenue Coach Company again will be faced with recurring deficits "which eventually will force the company out of business unless one-man operation of double-deck buses is begun as quickly as possible," John A. Ritchie, chairman, declared yesterday in his 1943 annual report to stockholders, employes and the public.

When the sixth annual spring maiden steeplechase series closed on March 20 thirty-five subscriptions were on hand, it was announced by the New York Racing Association yesterday. This is an increase of four over last year and will mean that each of the three races in the series will gross $3,750.

CHUNGKING, China, March 23 (Delayed) -- After boarding around at random, the United States Department Embassy in Chungking is to have two buildings that it can call home. Although they are being slapped together out of the familiar bamboo laths and mud plaster of the casual Chungking building, they are beginning to acquire the look of American public buildings -- a strange and welcome sight in this higgledy-piggledy Chinese city.

LONDON, March 27 (U.P.) -- Swiss dispatches reported today that the Hungarian puppet goverment had undertaken to pay Germany the maintenance costs of the occupation army that the Germans have established on Hungarian soil.
Two large West Side loft properties figured in a three-way realty transaction and resale which were placed on the records of the Register's Office in Manhattan yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (U.P.) The Navy, if requested, is ready to present to Congress a plan for the merger of all American international communication services into one privately owned system.

All commanders of units of the Polish underground have been ordered to establish contact with the Soviet army so as to coordinate military operations against the German forces in Poland, the Polish Telegraph Agency announced yesterday.

LONDON, March 27 (AP) -- A communique from the headquarters of Marshal Tito [Josip Broz] announced last night that the Yugoslav Partisans, aided by "Allied air forces and Navy and a detachment of Commandos" had captured the Adriatic island of Lesina [Hvar], twenty-five miles south of the port of Spalato.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- Legislation designed to clear the way for sale of Government-owned ships to "facilitate the adjustment of the merchant marine to peacetime operations" was introduced today by Chairman S.C. Bland of the House Merchant Marine Committee.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Men become soldiers in the Army when they receive the oath of induction and not when accepted for duty after a physical and mental examination, the Supreme Court held today in an eight-to-one decision.

LONDON, March 27 -- Maj. Walker M. Mahurin of Fort Wayne, Ind., second highest ranking American fighter ace in the European theatre, brought his bag of German planes to twenty-one today over France and several other top-rung United States pilots added to their scores.

WITH GENERAL STILWELL'S CHINESE-AMERICAN FORCES in North Burma, March 26 (Delayed) -- While Chinese and American troops struck at the Japanese flank, Chinese troops attacking down the main Mogaung valley road yesterday and today completed defeat of the Japanese force at the head of the valley that for the last week has tried desperately to stem the tide of the Chinese-American offensive in north Burma.

A continued narrowing of differences between old and new cotton crop months on the New York Cotton Exchange brought trading to a close yesterday with prices for the staple 2 points lower on May, but 6 to 9 points higher on other months.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 20 per cent last week over the like week of last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week, sales had shown a rise of 17 per cent over 1943.

Two Norfolk (Va.) men, who kidnapped the operator of a Washington airport limousine and a woman passenger and brought them to New York, were sentenced yesterday to long prison terms by Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz.

Thomas L.J. Corcoran, who was counsel to Governor Herbert H. Lehman, was named yesterday chairman of the law committee of Tammany Hall to succeed Andrew M. Lawler. The appointment was announced by Edward V. Loughlin, Tammany leader, at the 331 Madison Avenue headquarters.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Eric A. Johnston, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, told the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today that controls over prices must continue as long as conditions arising out of the war unbalance the relationship between supply and demand.

MUSKOGEE, Okla., March 27 -- Oklahoma became a battleground of national politics tonight, eve of a Second District special Congressional election which politicians the country over will watch for any possible clue as to what may be expected in the Presidential election next fall.
ALANTIC CITY, N.J., March 27 -- The harassed Joseph Vincent McCarthy had a respite today from draft-board drives on his once-powerful Yankee baseball machine, but found little else to soothe him.

Women have reached a higher degree of efficiency than ever before and as a result will be well prepared to shoulder their share of the load in the difficult post-war reconversion period, according to speakers yesterday at the opening sessions of the two-day conference on 'Women's Contribution to the Future" at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, with the Advertising Women of New York, Inc., as sponsor.

The National Academy's 118th annual exhibition of paintings and sculpture will open with a preview reception at 9 o'clock this evening in the academy's galleries, 1083 Fifth Avenue, between Eighty-ninth and Ninetieth Streets. Prize-winners will be announced at that time.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 27 (AP) -- Victim, a 4-year-old son of Mate from the Oak Hill Stable, scored his first success in seven Florida starts this winter when he led in a field of high-class platers in the Normandy Isle Purse at Tropical Park today.

Declaring it a "physical impossibility" to re-mark the price tickets of thousands of merchandise items by Saturday when the new Federal excise taxes become effective, Leonard Mongeon, manager of the traffic group of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said yesterday that the Washington office of the association is urging the Office of Price Administration to permit retailers to use their present method of showing the price and the tax.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., March 28 (AP) -- Former Gov. Joseph B. Ely declared today at the annual stockholders' meeting of the American Woolen Company that "the real reason the company has been unable to pay more back dividends is because it had to pay $28,000,000 in taxes."

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Bureau of Census Estimates place the population of continental United States, exclusive of the armed forces abroad, at 134,633,028 on July 1, 1942, as against 133,922,537 for 1941 and 132,816,672 for 1940, Director J.C. Capt said tonight.

Driving ahead in what Berlin describes as battles of unabated fury ragging along the whole winding 500-mile front from Brody in Poland to Nikolayev on the Ukrainian Bug River, the victorious Russian armies have now smashed across what Marshal Stalin himself describes as the "Soviet state frontiers" and launched their own invasion of enemy territory.

Judge Owen W. Bohan signed yesterday in General Sessions an order committing Louis G. Padgett, 39 years old, a former investigator for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, to the Matteawan State Hospital for the Criminal Insane. Padgett, a lawyer, who as an investigator had been lent by the Government to Governor Dewey when he was District Attorney, is under indictment on a statutory rape charge, made by a 16-year-old girl.

Unless hotel and restaurant men as well as major figures in the liquor industry take more effective steps to combat efforts of the drys "to bring prohibition back," there is every indication that the return of the gangster, the bootlegger and a racket-controlled liquor industry is not far off, Paul Henkel, president of the Society of Restaurateurs, warned last night.

There has been much talk about the swollen profits allegedly made by the airplane manufacturers at work on war orders. There are, of course, some variations in the experience of different companies, but the annual report of Douglas Aircraft which was published yesterday broadly reflects conditions in an industry which certainly has made a major contribution to the war.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- That airlines of the United States receive larger payments from the Government for carrying first-class mail than the railroads, although the latter carry eighteen times as much mail, according to a railroad-sponsored survey issued today.

In the outstanding apartment deal of the year in New York, Anthony Campagna, as president of the Campagna Construction Company, has sold to an investor the imposing multi-family building at 530 Park Avenue, at the southwest corner of Sixty-first Street.

Some time ago you had an editorial in which you deplored the proposed plan to permit only war veterans to take over civil service positions; and a few days ago, in Letters to the Editor, a writer stated that we veterans are only doing our duty, that we merely happened to be picked because we were in the required age group, and that we should not expect any advantages because of it.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Negotiations of new Anglo-American lend-lease arrangements designed to facilitate a return to something like private trade when and if the war situation permits, both by United States and British exporters, has been almost completed by the experts.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- After several Senators had taken the floor today to argue that the ban imposed "for military reasons" on the Wagner-Taft Palestine Homeland Resolution by the War Department, endorsed by the State Department and accepted by the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, had been overruled by the President's authorized statement to the same effect two days later, Mr. Roosevelt was asked at his press conference how the two courses "stacked up."

To help in problems of post-war city planning and residential building, the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, opened yesterday afternoon a traveling exhibition called "Look at Your Neighborhood."
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, March 29 (AP) -- A communique:

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 28 (AP) -- Apprentice Jockey Bobby Permane of Camden, N.J., took the spotlight at Tropical Park today. He rode four winners, including Mrs. E. McEvoy's Paragram, in the featured mile and 70-yard Golden Beach Purse. In addition, he was runnerup in two other races.

Safety turbans and acid-proof hand cream proved yesterday -- if proof still be needed -- that women are making their mark on American industry. At an exhibit that opened at the Pennsylvania Hotel as part of the three-day Safety Convention and Exposition there were twice as many booths of special appeal to women as at any of the fifteen previous annual meetings, according to a convention spokesman.
