LONDON, March 28 -- There is no way of foretelling, of course, what significance historians will give to Monday, March 27, 1944, in this great global war. But for five British tots whom we were permitted to call only Pearl, Patricia, Daphne, Billy and Keith, and for the men of an American Air Forces fighter group in Midland England it will be one of the greatest days.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 28 -- Phyllis Brooks has been named by Paramount for the "heavy" role in the forthcoming "Fear," a picture to be based on Ethel Lina White's mystery novel "Her Heart in Her Throat." The story is scheduled to begin production April 15 under the direction of Lewis Allen, with Gail Russell in the lead.
In Prime Minister Churchill's speech on Sunday his usual buoyancy was not found, and the reaction of Parliament and of the general public is not too favorable.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 28 -- The oldest and hardest working Dodger in camp is going to give everybody, including Manager Leo Durocher, a bit of a line on his 1944 potentialities tomorrow. Curt Davis has asked that he be the first pitcher in the exhibition game with Capt. Paul Amen's West Point Cadets.

Before the Teheran Conference, when the big war councils were still dialogues, Mr. Churchill once suggested that meetings between himself and President Roosevelt should take place every three months. No doubt he was thinking in terms of the changes wrought by the war itself, so swift and unforeseeable in a struggle as complex as this that plans have to be constantly adapted to fit new facts.

Buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday were 806, which compares with 1,010 in the preceding week and 983 in the corresponding period last year, according to the listings published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Arrivals yesterday totaled 325 as against 389 a week ago.

In this newspaper yesterday a picture of General Ho Ying-chin, Chinese Minister of War, taking tea with Huang Cheng-ching, head of a Tibetan delegation from Labrang Monastery, pleased the eye and refreshed the mind. In the midst of war here was a return to the benignities of peace.
Winston Churchill's broadcast has left a large number of people dissatisfied because of its failure to touch on a great many subjects.

St. Paul's Evangelical Lutheran Church has assembled through Henry Waltemade, Inc., brokers, a plot 175 by 100 feet at the northwest corner of McGraw and Virginia Avenues, in the Bronx, as the site for a church building, parish house, school and parsonage to be built soon after the war.

Another reorganization in the top Japanese army command, with the unification of the air and land arms under one central authority, was disclosed yesterday in a Tokyo announcement that Gen. Jun Ushiroku, recently appointed war councilor and vice chief of the Army General Staff, had been named to the concurrent posts of Inspector General of Army Aviation and Chief of Army Aviation Headquarters.

Dramatic testimony, including a nurse's story of how she stood out-side Mrs. Patricia Lonergan's bed-chamber, knuckles poised to rap -- a knock that might have saved a life -- brought to swift climax in General Sessions Court yesterday the State's case against Wayne Thomas Lonergan, on trial for first degree murder.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 28 -- Coincident with the arrival of Bill Zuber today to become the fourth of last year's pitching regulars at camp, the Yankees purchased from Kansas City Infielder Michael Milosevich, who, according to the club's public relations counsel, Jackie Farrell, hereafter will be known conveniently as Michael Molly.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- President Roosevelt, in a jovial mood and looking much better than he did last Friday, told his press conference this afternoon that he had been suffering from a mild case of bronchitis for the last two or three weeks.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The "news article" distributed among American troops in England which stated that President Roosevelt's opponents were ready to spend $50,000,000 to defeat him if he ran for a fourth term was based on the unsupported "estimate" of a staff writer for the British United Press, Senator Harry F. Byrd of Virginia, told the Senate today.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The "doughboy" is coming into his own.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Office of Price Administration has reached the conclusion that motorists confined to the two gallons a week provided in the A ration books have been "cut to the bone" in the national distribution of gasoline, and that, whenever further cuts are necessary they will be taken from the "B" driver's share, Col. Byran Houston, deputy OPA administrator for rationing, declared today.

Gil Dodds of the Boston A.A., the star of the indoor track season, yesterday was named as the New York track writers' unanimous choice for its "man of the year" award, while to Col. Charles J. Dieges, 78-year-old dean of timers, went the votes for the man who has done most for track.

The Trumpeter is sounding the charge, all over the world. Yet never before in any war were our soldiers so puzzled as to what they are fighting for. From letters, conversation, magazine articles at home and from correspondents abroad, we are able to discern a strange perplexity.

LONDON, March 28 -- Worn and weary after almost four years as Prime Minister and two serious attacks of pneumonia in the past year, 69-year-old Winston Churchill, political quarters believe, is contemplating shifting a large share of his increasingly heavy burdens to Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, whose departure from the Foreign Office is understood to be pending.

LA CROSSE, Wis., March 28 -- Reiterating that the Republican party to win the coming election must take a definite stand for post-war international cooperation to prevent recurrence of war, Wendell L. Willkie made an appeal today for the support of Wisconsin voters because of the character of the isolationist forces opposed to his nomination for President.

Opposing factions in the fight for control of the Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line (Mokan) Company yesterday compromised their differences at the annual stockholders' meeting of the company in Wilmington, Del. R.B. Hand, Arthur G. Logan and H. Harper McKee, representatives of a proxy committee opposing the Mokan management, were elected to the board of directors.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Representative John W. McCormack, Acting Speaker, in a statement today criticized Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's charge that the Administration has been guilty of suppressing political news.

Eight buildings of three and four stories in height at 246-52 Plymouth Street and 257-63 Water Street, has been sold by the Reliable Steam Power Company, after an ownership of fifty-eight years, to an investing client of James S. Kleiman, attorney.

PHILADELPHIA, March 28 -- In moves apparently designed to bring pressure upon President Roosevelt to make his decision concerning American labor's representation at the conference of the International Labor Organization beginning here April 20, the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations have withdrawn speakers scheduled to appear tomorrow night at a pre-conference orientation program.
The group known as American Abstract Artists is holding its eighth annual exhibition at the Mortimer Brandt Gallery, 15 East Fifty-seventh Street. It will be on through April 8.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Retention of price controls and of the stabilization program, "substantially in their present form," was urged upon Congress today by Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of War, who told the Senate's Banking and Currency Committee that the country was approaching the crisis of the war effort, and that the scrapping of anti-inflationary controls at this time would upset the morale of the soldier in the field.

LONDON, March 28 -- A startling flareup in the House of Commous this afternoon over a technicality in the Education Bill led to the first defeat of the Churchill government since it was welded together by the major parties in 1940.

The Citizens Housing Council, through Harold S. Buttenheim, president, has asked Louis H. Pink, OPA rent director for the New York area, to oppose the request by New York landlords for a general rise of 10 per cent in residential rents in this district.
LONDON, March 28 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

PHILADELPHIA, March 28 -- A plan for the sale by the North American Light and Power Company of all of its investment in the Missouri Power and Light Company to the Continental Gas and Electric Corporation for $3,729,800 was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board said today that it had been unable to determine whether premiums for aviation insurance were "fair and reasonable," and suggested the designation of a single Federal agency to collect additional information.

LONDON, March 28 -- The German High Command has sent six divisions from Germany to the southern sector of the Rumanian front to stem the tide of Russian soldiery bursting over the Prut River on a sixty-mile front. According to a highly placed, reliable source, "there is no strong organized German resistance in this area at present."

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 28 -- In his first statement to the press since he took office five months ago, Gen. Luis C. Perlinger, Argentine Minister of the Interior, predicted that all the present belligerents would soon unite to fight Russia because the middle classes in the United States and Great Britain are so alarmed at the Soviet military successes that they are almost more anti-Russian than anti-German.

Three seconds before time ran out in the second half, Dick McGuire's desperate angle set shot hit the target and lifted Dartmouth into a 36-36 tie with Utah in the East-West play-off for the National Collegiate A.A. basketball championship at Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- General de Gaulle's statement yesterday that the French Committee of National Liberation "does not need any lesson from anyone but the French nation that it is entrusted to lead" was explained by the French delegation here today as having been addressed to Algiers and Paris and not to Washington and London.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The United States Army Air Forces told today how and why our bombers from Britain are striving -- with success -- to wipe German fighter plane strength and production off the map.

Mrs. F. Nicholson, through Dwight, Voorhees Helmsley, penthouse in 246 E 46th St; Thomas Cox, through Tishman Realty and Construction Company, ;in 983 Park Ave; Mrs. Olive E. i Wyckoff, from Series Management Corp, in 333 Central Pk West -- Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc, brokers.

"Follow the Boys," a Charles K. Feldman-Universal picture, will have its local premiere at Loew's Criterion late next month, it was announced yesterday. Heading the cast of the musical are George Raft, Vera Zorina, Orson Welles, Marlene Dietrich, Jeanette MacDonald, W.C. Fields, Donald O'Connor, Dinah Shore and Ted Lewis, Freddie Slack, Charlie Spivak and Louis Jordan and their orchestras.
Dr. Joseph Goebbels, German Minister of Propaganda, has fashioned German resistance in the ruins of Cassino into a major propaganda weapon in German broadcasts of the last week.

While some twenty-five bills covering contract termination and surplus disposal problems have been introduced in Congress, little hope can be held for the passage of definitive legislation on these problems this year, L.F. Dahling, legal counsel for the Automotive Council for War Production, stated yesterday.

Don Herold yesterday announced plans for a participating advertising column which he will call "Man-to-Men." It will run in the sports sections of approximately fifty Sunday newspapers as soon as newsprint rationing eases up. The column will feature nationally advertised products and services appealing to men.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., March 28 -- Less than two weeks after their marriage, a young couple, both war workers, were found dead in each other's arms inside a locked automobile near an abandoned reservoir here today, after apparently carrying out a suicide pact.

Vandals, believed to be young children, entered the Western Queens Nursery School in Queensbridge Houses, one of the New York City Housing Authority projects, stole a radio and an electric clock, smashed phonograph records, broke the shell of a large pet turtle and smothered four smaller turtles in the dirt of the victory garden, it was learned yesterday.

A further postponement of the opening of the second, or north tube, of the Lincoln Tunnel was announced yesterday by Frank C. Ferguson, chairman of the Port of New York Authority. Mr. Ferguson said the delay was the result of shifts in fabrication schedules at plants manufacturing equipment for the tunnel.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- An appropriation of $10,000 to be divided among the three children of the late Republican Senator W. Warren Barbour of Locust Point, N. J., was included yesterday in a $531,000,000 deficiency appropriation bill recommended to the Senate by its Appropriations Committee.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY BEACHHEAD FORCES, in Italy, March 27 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- German shells shook the tent which served as a church and nearly drowned out the wheezing organ music. But there were flowers and candles on the crude altar and the bride and bridegroom were the happiest couple on the Anzio beachhead.

NAPLES, March 28 -- Signor Cavalieri, who announced the suspension of 690 Italian officeholders, is himself scheduled to be replaced, as are Mayor Giuseppe Solimena and Giovanni Lauricella, director of public safety.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The thirsts of the White House, State Department and members of Congress constitute "hardship cases" which give them top priorities on the capital's scant liquor supply, liquor dealers say.

Answers given by college girls to a recent questionnaire on their expectations for the future "reflect poignantly the confusion of our society with regard to the status of women," Dr. Mirra Komarovsky, instructor in sociology at Barnard College, said yesterday at the conference on "Women's Contribution to the Future," held at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, by the Advertising Women of New York, Inc.

The case of Lt. (j.g.) Adam A. Rother of the Coast Guard for the first-degree murder of Miss Rita Costello was given to the jury of seven women and five men for deliberation at 5:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon after they received the charge of Judge Thomas J. Walsh in the Richmond County Court at St. George.

LONDON, March 28 -- The powerful British battle fleet now concentrated in the Indian Ocean must be regarded as a defensive force until the Japanese are driven from the Andaman and Nicobar islands, according to well-informed naval observers here.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- A division of opinion among Administration officials over the advisability of a universal manpower draft at this time became increasingly apparent today when Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, declared he was not in favor of national service now.

WICHITA, Kan., March 28 -- Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio carried his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination into the heart of the Wheat Belt tonight with a declaration that the farmer must be freed "of Government domination" and have parity with business.

The first annual report of the Consolidated Natural Gas Company, released yesterday by F.H. Lerch Jr., president, shows for last year a consolidated net income of $11,305,275 after all expenses, taxes and other charges. This was equal to $4.14 a share on the company's outstanding capital stock.

NEWARK, N.J., March 28 -- A former official of the German-American Vocational League linked that organization today in a contractual relation with the German Labor Front at the trial in Federal court here of nineteen men and two corporations accused of conspiring to cause the league to act as a propaganda agency for the German Reich and the Nazi party without registering their intention with the State Department and the Department of Justice.

Verdi's Manzoni Requiem was performed last night in the Metropolitan Opera House by artists and chorus of the Metropolitan Opera Association under the direction of Bruno Walter for the benefit of the American Red Cross. All gave their services for the occasion.

A tragic incident in the rescue of Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker in the Southwest Pacific more than a year and a half ago was recalled yesterday when Captain Rickenbacker met for the first time the parents of Sgt. Alexander Kaczmarczyk, a crew member of the plane that was lost in that area in October, 1942.

LONDON, March 28 -- A postwar Europe in which all nations, great and small, will be free to express opinions and state grievances but in which the great powers that must bear the brunt of preserving peace will have a greater voice in deciding on action to be taken in the general interest was foreshadowed today by Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, in an address to the Free Church Federal Council.

Dillon, Read Co. and associates will offer today $38,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, 3 1/2 per cent series, due in 1969, of the Michigan Consolidated Gas Company at 106 1/4 and accrued interest. The same group also will offer 40,000 shares of $100 par 4 3/4 per cent cumulative preferred stock of the same utility at $105.50 a share.

Maj. Gen. Sanderford Jarman, head of the Anti-Aircraft Artillery Command of the Eastern Defense Command, received yesterday an Oak Leaf Cluster to add to the Distinguished Service Medal that he won during World War I. Lieut. Gen. George Grunert, commander of the Eastern Defense Command, presented the award during a regimental review at Fort Torten, Bay-side, Queens.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- Elmer Davis denied today that the Office of War Information employed any "Communists or fellow travelers," or that the agency was engaging in partisan political activity.

NEW DELHI, India, March 28 -- The first great battle of the Indian campaign raged today at the edge of the Manipur Plain, where one of four Japanese invasion columns launched fierce assaults to break through British defenses guarding the northeastern approaches of Imphal, key supply center for Allied forces on the Burma border front.

Officers and directors of the American Woolen Company have given a great deal of thought to a possible recapitalization equitable to both classes of stock that would eliminate the heavy arrears on the preferred shares, Moses Pendleton, president, said at the annual meeting at Springfield, Mass., yesterday.

I wish to ask J. W. Cooper if he realizes that the only reason he is able to write a letter to any paper is because several thousand of the nation's finest have given up their lives and because hundreds of thousands more are suffering untold hardships to preserve his right to exist.

An unusual realty deal in Trenton, N.J., has just been closed whereby two of the leading department stores there will exchange locations. They are the Goldberg and Swern department stores, occupying for several years opposite corners on South Broad Street.

The Pan American Trust Company, as agent is notifying holders of various Mexican Government securities of arrangements under which they may request exclusion of their holdings from the status of "enemy bonds" into which the holdings fell automatically upon failure to be registered by Aug. 31, 1943, the deadline originally set by the Mexican Government debt plan.

Warning that reliance upon Government to provide employment in the post-war period will mean "stepping back to feudalism," James F. Lincoln, president of the Lincoln Electric Company, yesterday urged that industry through incentive plans bring out the latent talents of workers as "the greatest step forward" in strengthening private enterprise.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Office of Price Administration ruled today that packers and sellers of meat who have an inventory of beef and veal cut to "old specifications" could apply for adjustments in their price ceilings to sell these stocks to war procurement agencies.

The House of Representatives now has before it the $8,000,000,000 Independent Offices Appropriations Bill, to which the Senate has tacked two amendments proposed by Senator McKellar of Tennessee. To get these amendments into place the Senate majority had to maintain that they were not new legislation, just as it might have voted, had another sort of parliamentary question arisen, that two and two do not make four.

Fifteen prizes and four honorable mentions were awarded last night to artists whose work is shown in the 118th annual exhibition of the National Academy of Design in its galleries at 1083 Fifth Avenue, between Eighty-ninth and Ninetieth Streets.

LONDON, Wednesday, March 29 -- The Red Army yesterday crushed the German garrison of Nikolayev, former Soviet Black Sea Fleet base at the mouth of the Bug River, and in a surprise night crossing sixty miles upstream joined other Russian forces striking swiftly southward across the flat steppes on a 175-mile front toward Odessa, seventy-five miles away, Moscow announced today.

Improved safety measures and devices added the equivalent of thousands of skilled workers to war production plants in the United States in 1943, according to data presented yesterday at the annual safety convention and exposition of the Greater New York Safety Council in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Frederick Brown, operator, has purchased from the Roosevelt Hospital the seventeen-story business building at 37 West Forty-seventh Street, near Rockefeller Center, in a continuation of his recent buying activity in the midtown district.

TORONTO, March 28 (AP) -- Montreal took a commanding 3-to-1 lead over Toronto in their best four-of-seven game semi-final series in the Stanley Cup Hockey play offs tonight by beating the Leafs for the third straight time, 4 to 1.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Charges of attempted domination of the broadcasting field by the major networks were reiterated today by James Lawrence Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, before the special House committee investigating the FCC.

LONDON, March 28 -- Although the stock markets here generally remained quiet today fresh interest was displayed in steel shares as a result of Prime Minister Churchill's statement regarding prefabricated houses in the post-war era.
LOS ANGELES, March 28 (AP) -- The Government rested its case this afternoon in the trial of Charlie Chaplin on two counts of violation of the Mann Act.

THIRD POLISH DIVISION HEADQUARTERS, Village of "N," Russia, March 27 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Two young Poles, marveling at the good fortune that helped them escape the fate of most of the 140,000 Jewish residents of German-occupied Lwow, told today the story of the "forest of death" to which, they said, the Germans shipped Jews from every section of Europe for execution.

The saturation bombing of Cassino, which reduced the unfortunate town to rubble, is still being widely discussed and interpreted. From most of the comment in print and on the radio it is sadly clear that even today, in the fifth year of the war, the role of air power continues to be misunderstood.
LONDON, March 28 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Force in Europe communique:

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Renewed demands in the Senate for immediate action on the Wagner-Taft Palestine Homeland Resolution, which was withheld from consideration on the urgent appeal of the Army high command, was followed today by an elaboration by President Roosevelt of his recently authorized statement on the British White Paper of 1939.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- After Senator Taft, Republican, of Ohio, spoke against continued expansion of the national program for the care of children of working mothers, conducted by the Federal Works Agency with Lanham act funds, the Senate today cut $15,000,000 more off a Lanham act appropriation previously pared by the House.

Having written "Emily Brady," formerly called "Men at Work," Donald Ogden Stewart will direct the melodrama, marking his first attempt in that field. It will be presented as soon as possible under the auspices of Eddie Dowling and Halsey Raines,

LONDON, March 28 -- While the utmost discretion has been exercised here by responsible officials regarding details of the agreement reached at the Moscow and Teheran conferences, too many persons have had to be consulted and informed for all the secrets to be kept indefinitely. Thus, while no source can be cited, it is possible to give a rough idea of some of the plans that are shaping up for Europe's reconstruction.

The chances are that those who descend upon the trout when the season opens in most of New York State on Saturday will find the fishing good, according to reports received by the Conservation Department. The stocking of legal-sized trout and those of near legal size has been heavy and the streams are generally in good condition.

HONOLULU, March 28 (AP) -- The United States Army has given Purple Heart medals to the Japanese-American families of fifty-eight soldiers who died in action in Italy -- because, the Colonel said to each of his little audience, "Your boy was an American."

German appeals for the "loyal collaboration" of the Polish people in the Axis attempt to halt the advancing Russian armies and to the Rumanian people for greater military aid against the Red Army were reported yesterday by United States Government monitors.

Earnings of the Schenley Distillers Corporation for the six months ended with February rose to $33,519,158 before taxes from $18,482,117 on the same basis in the corresponding period of the previous year, according to a report announced yesterday.
This is the first of two columns on saving time in the kitchen.

The efficient use of equipment has enabled domestic airlines to conduct financially successful operations in spite of the reduction of their fleets by the Army from 359 to 176 units in the spring of 1942, according to a pamphlet published yesterday by the Railroad Committee for the Study of Transportation, a research organization of the Association of American Railroads.

The five-story apartment building at 656 West 179th Street, on a plot 37.6 by 100 feet, has been sold by Abraham Rosenstein to an investing client of Nehring Brothers, brokers. Felsenstein Rosenstein were attorneys for the seller.

There was a capacity audience on hand at Carnegie Hall last night to greet the Oratorio Society's annual presentation of Bach's Mass in B Minor, a performance dedicated to the memory of Albert Stoessel, the society's conductor, who died last year.
NAPLES, March 28 -- The stalemate on all fronts in Italy continued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Expansion of facilities for making penicillin was officially ended today as the War Production Board disclosed that 95 per cent of new plant construction under the emergency penicillin program begun last June had been completed and 90 per cent of the operating facilities delivered.

LAKEWOOD, N. J., March 28 -- For a few minutes it looked as though the Pied Piper of Hamlin had come back to town bringing all the youngsters with him. But closer investigation revealed that the piper was only Carl Hubbell greeting his army of infant hopefuls as the Giants today launched their "baseball school of the future."
A break in the stock market here yesterday carried prices on the New York Cotton Exchange to net losses of 1 to 4 points at the close.

ALGIERS, March 28 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Col. Pierre Cristofini, on trial for his life before a special military tribunal, testified today that he had gone to the Tunisian front with the Germans to capture five American prisoners, in return for which the Germans had promised to remobilize the French army of the armistice.

No. 13 is coming up for Beau Jack in his non-title ten-round bout Friday night at Madison Square Garden with Juan Zurita, world lightweight champion, under the aegis of the National Boxing Association.

Sidney Hillman and the left wing groups allied with him won control of the American Labor party in yesterday's primary elections and immediately held out an olive branch to the defeated right wing groups that had sought to retain the party's helm in a bitterly fought campaign.

LONDON, March 28 (AP) -- The Berlin radio said today that Field Marshal Gen. Erwin Rommel had inspected defensive positions on the Netherland coast that were hit Sunday by hundreds of Allied medium bombers attacking an E-boat nest at Ijmuiden.
WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, In Italy, March 28 -- These particular thirty-six hours in the life of Sgt. Robert Christine would under ordinary circumstances receive a minimum of recorded attention.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The United Steel Workers of America, CIO, set forth severance pay today as important among its demands on the steel corporations to be embodied in a new contract.

The most telling blow against the stock market since early last November was administered yesterday under an avalanche of selling on the New York Stock Exchange which lifted volume for one hour alone -- the closing period -- to almost 750,000 shares.
BUENOS AIRES, March 28 -- The Argentine Government today rescinded a decree dated Dec. 31, 1943, which placed many restrictions upon the local and foreign press.

Director, American Institute of Public Opinion PRINCETON, N. J., March 28 -- Indiana Republican voters lean toward Thomas E. Dewey for the Republican Presidential nomination at present, with Wendell L. Willkie second choice and General Douglas MacArthur third.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- B.E. Hutchinson, vice president of the Chrysler Corporation and chairman of the contract termination committee of the Automotive Council for War Production, offered today a glimpse of problems awaiting, industry in reconversion to civilian production after the war when he staged for members of the House Special Committee on Post-War Economic Policy a motion picture presentation of the reverse of the process -- the shift from peace to war production.

BOUGAINVILLE (Delayed) -- Though ill and unable to swim, Capt. Andrew S. Macreadie Jr., 40, of New York City, braved high waves and treacherous reefs in a small rubber boat to assist in the rescue of a soldier stranded on a South Pacific reef.

LONDON, Wednesday, March 29 -- Striking in a campaign of mounting intensity against bases from which the Luftwaffe defends Europe, 250 to 500 United States heavy bombers rained explosives and incendiaries on four airfields in France yesterday.
LONDON, Wednesday, March 29 (AP) -- The Russian Tuesday midnight upplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

The Constance Lindsay Skinner award for 1944 goes to Mildred Smith, editor of Publishers Weekly. Given annually to an outstanding woman in the book trades, it was presented last night at the dinner of the Women's National Book Association at the Pennsylvania Hotel. Irita Van Doren, editor of The New York Herald Tribune Books, who received the award in 1942, made the presentation.

ALGIERS, March 28 -- Although Russia alone among the Allies has recognized the claim of the French Committee of National Liberation to be the trustee for the French State, diplomatic circles here understood today that Moscow had just declined to accept Gaston Palewski, the chief of Gen. Charles de Gaulle's political staff, as the committee's diplomatic representative to the Russian Government.

The Special Sessions trial of Harry Craig Cooper, president of the Century Travel Service Corporation, 655 Fifth Avenue, and one of his women employes on the charge that they violated the City Administrative Code by charging more than $1 a ticket for service on railroad passenger transportation to Florida, came to a close yesterday with the defense calling as its only witness the co-defendant, Miss Marie Tosti of 636 Creston Avenue, the Bronx.

LONDON, March 28 -- Netherlanders in London are debating the wisdom of annexing a strip of German territory to make good their own loss if the Nazis should flood the Netherlands and thus render between 3,000,000 and 4,000,000 persons homeless, and ruin, possibly for years, nearly 50 per cent of the surface soil.

Kings County Judge Louis Goldstein and Acting District Attorney Thomas Craddock Hughes of Brooklyn yesterday requested the March Grand Jury to conduct a thorough inquiry into crime conditions in Brooklyn. The request came as a result of a series of newspaper articles in which Mayor La Guardia and Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine were quoted as saying conditions were not satisfactory.
Strengthening of the nation against anti-Semitism within and extension of aid to victims of Nazi aggression in the occupied countries of Europe were urged here yesterday by Governor Dewey.

American and Dutch educators met yesterday to honor those who have given their lives to the Nazi tyranny and to protest against the suppression of freedom of teaching in the occupied territories of the Netherlands and the Netherlands Indies.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Secretary Hull tacitly admitted at his press conference today that the British Government may have prevented the transmission of diplomatic news to the United States because of the views of the State Department against premature publication which might complicate negotiations, but he stood on his statement of yesterday that Governor Dewey was 100 per cent inaccurate in charging in his address last Friday evening that political news had been held up.

NAPLES, Italy, March 28 (AP) -- King Victor Emmanuel has pledged himself to form a government with "a larger base" after the Allied capture of Rome, with an Italian Parliament to be elected within four months after peace is established, it was disclosed today.
NEW DELHI, India, March 28 (UP) -- A oomunique:...

MUSKOGEE, Okla., March 28 -- The Democrats won the special Congressional election in the second Oklahoma district today in the face of an aggressive Republican challenge. Both sides had proclaimed the Roosevelt Administration on trial.

The results of the playwriting contest, sponsored by the National Theatre Conference for members of the armed forces, were announced yesterday. Of the 423 who participated, the Army was represented by 406, the Navy by 12, the marines by 4 and the Coast Guard by 1.

Contributions to the Red Cross and expressions of gratitude for its services were received yesterday from New Yorkers who are as deep in the war as anyone -- the Twenty-seventh Infantry Division, now stationed in the Central Pacific.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
Four major rule changes were enacted by the National Basketball Committee of the United States and Canada, better known as the joint rules committee, yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, March 29 (AP) -- Allied bombers dumped 292 tons of explosives in swings over enemy bases around the Bismarck Sea areas, headquarters announced today.

Apparently the press and the underwriting fraternity -- or a portion of the latter -- need a conference to agree on definitions of terms which they use. A week ago yesterday the underwriters of the 704,000-share secondary distribution of Chesapeake Ohio common stock called up blithely to report that it had been "substantially over-subscribed."

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- On the basis of a poll of its national board, State presidents and chairmen of national and State committees, the American Association of University Women went on record today in favor of drafting women for the women's branches of the military services, "provided the need for such a draft exists and is demonstrated by the War and Navy Departments."

CHICAGO, March 28 -- Philip K. Wrigley announced today his resignation as president of the William Wrigley Jr. Company because of differences of opinion between himself and other directors. James C. Cox, executive vice president and treasurer, was elected president at a directors' meeting.

The plan to resume Saturday dealings in the wholesale produce markets of the city on April 1 ran into a snag yesterday when a trade committee decided to retain the five-day market week that was instituted last month.

Liquidation by brokers with Southern and New Orleans connections brought about yesterday a slightly easier market on the New York Cotton Exchange and closing prices were 2 to 8 points net lower than on Tuesday.

A UNITED STATES BOMBER BASE in Britain, March 29 (AP) -- Seven airmen rode a Flying Fortress all but cut in two 300 miles back from Reims, France, yesterday, then parachuted to safety before the bomber crashed with the bodies of the two waist gunners killed by anti-aircraft fire.

Lieut. (j.g.) Adam A. Rother of the United States Coast Guard was convicted yesterday of murder in the second degree by a jury of seven women and five men in the Richmond County Court at St. George for the slaying in a taxicab on July 17 of Miss Rita Costello, 28 years old, a secretary, of 140 Crescent Avenue, New Brighton.

LONDON, March 29 (AP) -- Until today's battle over Brunswick the Germans had not for six days made such an attempt to interfere with daylight operations. On March 23 Luftwaffe fighters rose to defend Muenster, Hamm and Brunswick against American attack, the escorting United States fighters shooting down twenty, while twenty-seven American bombers were lost.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 29 -- Unable to do much with his ball club on the playing field because the weather again took a turn at acting up at its worst, Manager Mel Ott took to putting his ball club down on a piece of paper today and on paper at least, he had to admit his Giants, all things considered, shaped up surprisingly well.
FINSCHHAFEN, New Guinea, March 26 (Delayed) -- Fuzzy-Wuzzy history was made today with the greatest sing-sing held by New Guinea's black natives in many centuries.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Lindsay C. Warren, the Controller General, told the House Naval Affairs Committee today that studies of war contracts "up to this hour" had shown charges of about $5,000,000 on cost-plus contracts on behalf of contributions to the Red Cross and Community Chest drives.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Belief that the stay of American prisoners in Japanese prison camps will be "made more bearable" because the Japanese Government will allow some conditions to be improved was expressed over short-wave radio to the Philippines by Commander Melvin McCoy today.
" . . . and on the card please write, 'Happy Easter, Mom, from your son Bill.'"

NAPLES, March 29 -- Giuseppe Solimena, acting mayor of Naples who is being considered for a high post in the Italian Ministry of the Interior, said today that he had "always been an anti-Faseist at heart."

MOSCOW, March 29 -- Here on Russian soil a new Polish army is steadily growing in strength and significance. Here is a report on the motives and intentions of the new army, as given by responsible officers:

Holders of Alabama Great Southern Railroad Company first mortgage 3 1/4 per cent bonds, Series A, due Nov. 1, 1967, have been notified by the Guaranty Trust Company, trustee, that $94,000 of the bonds has been drawn for redemption on May 1 at 100 5/8 and accrued interest.

LOS ANGELES, March 29 (AP) -- Chapters of Joan Berry's private life and acquaintances with other men were unfolded today before a Federal court jury by the defense at Charlie Chaplin's trial on Mann Act charges after the defense failed in a motion for a directed verdict of acquittal.
BARI, Italy, March 3 (Delayed) (AP) -- American combat troops specially trained for guerrilla warfare are operating with Yugoslav Partisans and British forces in the Dalmation coastal zone.
LONDON, March 29 (UP) -- A United States Strategic Air Force in Europe announcement:

LONDON, Thursday, March 30 -- The German fighter force, battling desperately to save itself from extinction under Allied bombs, rose to defend its home targets in the Brunswick area yesterday against Flying Fortresses of the United States Eighth Air Force, accompanied by a strong escort of Mustang, Thunderbolt and Lightning fighters.

The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, one of the country's largest manufacturers of war material, appears to have reached its production peak, with output now maintaining the same level month after month, A.W. Robertson, chairman, announced yesterday.

A further improvement was recorded last week in the nation's supplies of gasoline and heavy fuel oil, but light fuel oil stocks were down slightly, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the close of the period gasoline stocks amounted to 87,287,000 barrels, an increase of 1,102,000 over the 86,185,000 a week earlier.

Nine new colors for fur and wool felt and three new colors for wool felt only have been adopted for fall and winter by the millinery color committee of the Textile Color Card Association, it was announced yesterday by Margaret Hayden Rorke, managing director.

To allay "widespread apprehension" among manufacturers that an arbitrary profit ceiling on the production of consumer goods has been established or is planned by the Office of Economic Administration, Lyle H. Boren, Democratic member of the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce, called yesterday upon Fred M. Vinson, stabilization director, to publish his "2 per cent profit directive."
LONDON, Thursday, March 30 (AP) -- The Russian Wednesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

BERNE, Switzerland, March 29 -- The Gestapo has sent a French gendarme to a concentration camp for the duration because he did not raise an alarm sufficiently quickly when patriots dynamited a dam at Plombieres, in the Vosges Hills. The incident is typical of conditions in France today; they are likely to grow worse now that Marcel Deat, arch-collaborationist, virtually directs the Cabinet.

ONE by one they go until it begins to seem as if the Yankees of 1944 will not even be a reasonable facsimile of the original and genuine article. Johnny Murphy is one of the latest to depart from the ranks of the Bronx Bombers. Johnny of the jug-handle curve and the nerves of steel. Johnny the fireman, who always extinguished the blaze of an enemy rally with his artfully controlled pitching.
Two large West Side apartment houses were reported yesterday to have passed into new hands.

I note in today's TIMES in regard to the withdrawal of eight members of the Committee on Discrimination a statement of Mr. Hagerty of Governor Dewey's staff. Mr. Hagerty says, "They have resigned on the flimsy pretext that a bill some of them submitted just before adjournment of the Legislature was not passed."

Four young men who were arrested yesterday confessed, according to the police, that they had robbed at least thirty stores in this city and its vicinity of furs and other valuables worth $40,000. The police nicknamed them the "stanchion gang" because they said the young men made a practice of using police traffic stanchions to break the windows of the stores they robbed.
NEW DELHI, India, March 29 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today for $64,390,000 for operations of the Office of War Information in the fiscal year starting July 1, of which $59,562,101 -- an increase of $25,000,000 over the present year -- is for the Overseas Branch.

The building at 480 Tonnele Avenue, Jersey City, occupied by the International Harvester Company, has been sold by the owner of the property, Herbert Pontery, to Irving L. Weiner, manufacturer of truck and bus bodies, The deal was closed through the J.I. Kislak Brokerage Agency.

A reduction of 25 per cent in the retail price of cabbage, both white and red, goes into effect today as that vegetable comes under the flat ceiling prices set up for New York City by the Office of Price Administration. Up to now retail ceiling prices for cabbage, computed on the mark-up basis, varied in retail stores.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- As Speaker pro tempore of the House, Representative John W. McCormack from Massachusetts announced today the membership of the Special Committee on Post-War Military Policy, created through the passage of a resolution sponsored by Representative James W. Wadsworth, Republican of New York.

MADRID, March 29 (AP) -- Tens of thousands of German "carpetbaggers," civilians and officials who went east for easy plunder of occupied territories, are swarming back across the Carpathian Mountains into Hungary to escape the Red Army.

The fur industry has not accepted the proposed interim price regulation for raw furs setting a base period from October, 1941, to March 31, 1942, it was made known yesterday by the National Federation of the Fur Industry. The federation, it was stated, has received many protests against acceptance of such a regulation and has been encouraged by the fact that the Office of Price Administration is giving consideration to counter-proposals.

LONDON, March 29 -- Britain has spent more than $1,526,170,000 on goods and services given to the United States under reverse lend-lease, according to statistics released here. This amount -- spent in the eighteen months ending December, 1943 -- provided a third of the supplies required by the American forces in the United Kingdom, thereby saving more than 1,360,000 ship tons.

LONDON, March 29 -- The serious nature of juvenile delinquency in this country since the outbreak of the war was debated in the House of Lords today. Out of 7,000,000 children between the ages of 5 and 17 years nearly 200,000 have been found guilty of indictable offenses during the five war years, Lord Southwood said.

NEWARK, N.J., March 29 -- Dr. Robert W. Kempner, chief legal adviser of the Prussian State Police until 1936 and a former judge in Germany, appeared as a Government witness today at the trial of nineteen alleged Nazi propaganda conspirators and dramatically challenged claims of defense counsel that the German Railroads Information Office's foreign branches were "innocent travel agencies."

MUNCIE, Ind., March 29 -- Ford Frick, president of the National League, dropped in on the Pirates today and consoled Manager Frankie Frisch by pointing out that all major league camps had been held back by bad weather which had forced training almost entirely indoors.

LONDON, March 29 (U.P.) -- British and German light naval forces fought two sharp actions off the Netherland and French coasts during the night, with one engagement taking place within two miles of Dieppe, the Admiralty announced tonight.

Participation in efforts to solve world problems was advocated yesterday at the opening of the 249th annual session of the New York Yearly Meeting of the Religious Society of Friends, held at the meeting house at 221 East Fifteenth Street.

While sales of the National Steel Corporation and subsidiaries advanced 16 per cent in 1943 to $256,168,340, comparing with $219,851,176 in 1942, earnings declined to $11,698,362, or $5.30 a share on 2,206,267 capital shares, from $11,929,867, or $5.41 a share, in 1942, Ernest T. Weir, chairman of the board of directors, reported yesterday.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The most eagerly awaited quadruple birth in medical history took place yesterday morning at the Sloane Hospital for Women, 620 West 168th Street, when three girls and a boy were born to Mrs. Harry Zarief. Anticipation had run high at the hospital since December, with doctors, nurses and other staff members looking forward to the event with as much interest as the parents.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Congress prepared today to postpone its Easter recess until the weekend, if necessary, to await President Roosevelt's action on the soldier vote bill. Plans were made in the Senate before it recessed until tomorrow to amend the resolution adopted by the House under which the Easter holiday would have begun tomorrow.

ST. LOUIS, March 29 (AP) -- The Monsanto Chemical Company's post-war operations will call for about $40,000,000 for new plant and another $25,000,000 for additional working capital, according to preliminary studies announced to stockholders by Gaston DuBois and William M. Rand, vice presidents.

CHICAGO, March 29 -- Increased tightness in the feed grain situation continued today to dominate the action of the wheat market on the Chicago Board of Trade. At no time was there any selling pressure of consequence and later, when reports of a better milling, distilling and feed demand began coming in, the market firmed up quickly.

Members of the Democratic State committee elected at Tuesday's primary will meet at the National Democratic Club at 11 A.M. on April 12, State Chairman James A. Farley announced yesterday. In addition to re-electing Mr. Farley as State chairman, the new committee will select delegates and alternates at large to the Democratic National Convention.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, at Cassino, March 27 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The Gurkhas came down from Hangman's Hill tonight, thirsty and half-starved but still full of the fighting spirit of India's famous warriors.

Jules S. Bache, banker, philanthropist and art patron, who died last Friday at Palm Beach, Fla., disposed of a large part of his estate during his life, it was learned yesterday, when his will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court.

How many of those who voted the left-wing ticket in the American Labor party primaries on Tuesday were Communists one can't tell. Their leader, Sidney Hillman, says that they were "bona fide members of trade unions, genuine liberals and progressives, farmers and middle class."

Effective today, reports of changes in insiders' holdings of equity securities will be available at the New York Stock Exchange upon receipt. No longer will the public be required to wait a month after the close of the month in which the trades are made to permit the Securities and Exchange Commission to collate the individual reports and publish them in its official summary.
This is the second of two columns on saving time in the kitchen.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, at Cassino, March 29 -- The Allies' troops have been withdrawn from their footholds on the eastern slopes of Mount Cassino, it was revealed today. Thus the Germans are left in complete control of that dominant and important feature, and the possibility of any immediate threat to the ruins of the ancient Benedictine abbey has been eased.

Two thousand members of the Uniformed Firemen's Association voted yesterday to accept the $420 a year cost-of-living bonus offered by Mayor La Guardia but not to withdraw their suit against Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh, in which they seek to prevent him from forcing them to work overtime without being paid for it.
The defense rested with startling abruptness yesterday in Wayne Lonergan's trial in General Sessions Court for the murder of his wife, Patricia Burton Lonergan.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- A bill designed to put into effect and supplement the recommendations of the Baruch-Hancock report for post-war reconversion of the national economy without violent declines in production or wide scale unemployment was introduced today by Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, Democrat of Wyoming, on behalf of Senator Harley N. Kilgore, Democrat of West Virginia, chairman of a subcommittee on war mobilization.

The first reapportionment of Assembly districts in New York County since 1917 has been completed, and lines have been submitted to the City Council, for certain approval, carving sixteen new Assembly districts out of the six new State Senate districts in place of the present twenty-three Assembly seats and nine Senate seats.

American Machine and Metals, Inc., has purchased for an undisclosed sum in cash virtually the entire common stock of the United States Gauge Company from Josiah W. Place, president of the company since its formation in 1904, it was announced yesterday by P.G. Mumford, president of American.

LONDON, March 29 -- Questions in the House of Commons today concerning Secretary of State Cordell Hull's outline of American foreign policy a week ago drew from Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden a renewed assurance of unity of action by Britain and the United States.

Problems of manpower, contract termination, war bond sales, postwar consumer credits, investments and the general banking situation will be discussed at the annual meeting of the New Jersey Bankers Association, to be held here on May 12 and 13 at the Hotel Pennsylvania, it was announced yesterday by Joseph G. Parr, president of the association.

An order by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine, issued at 6:51 o'clock last night, shifted the commanders of four major detective districts in the city and appeared, by its phrasing, to re-establish on a permanent basis the office of "night chief."

The Herbert N. Straus mansion at 9 East Seventy-first Street -- one of the most imposing of the dwindling group of private family homes on the upper East Side of Manhattan -- has been acquired by the Roman Catholic Archbishopric of New York after having stood empty and unfinished for thirteen years.

PHILADELPHIA, March 29 (AP) -- The proposed sale of securities of the Gulf Plains Corporation, Corpus Christi, Tex., by the Chicago Corporation to the Lehman Corporation, New York, was exempted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission from provisions of the Investment Company Act which forbids transactions in securities among affiliates.

EAU CLAIRE, Wis., March 29 -- Driving almost 200 miles through and after a drifting two-inch snowstorm, Wendell L. Willkie carried his fight for Wisconsin delegates today into the Ninth Congressional District and spoke to capacity crowds at Menomonie, Chippewa Falls and in this city.

A cordial reception was extended Leonard Bernstein, the young assistant conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, when he appeared at its head last night in the double role of conductor and composer. For Mr. Bernstein, in addition to his task as interpreter, included in his program the New York premiere of his "Jeremiah" symphony.

LONDON, March 29 -- Steel and shipping shares were the most actively traded securities in today's stock market, which was generally slow. The home rails again were neglected, but prices kept steady, while in the foreign section Argentine rail ordinaries hardened.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- Federal and State expenditures for public assistance last year dropped to $979,000,000, less than one-third the amount spent in 1938, when relief was at a peak, the Social Security Board reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- A message from the Polish Government in London, presumably making a fresh appeal for American help in settling political and territorial disputes with Russia, was presented to Secretary of State Cordell Hull today for delivery to President Roosevelt.
All the literature -- including the Government's -- about pigs being pigs is of no help to the housewife in telling one part of the animal from another on a meat counter, it developed yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 29 -- A dramatic new turn in the Finnish-Russian armistice negotiations appeared imminent tonight. Reliable quarters said Juho K. Paasikivi, Finnish diplomat, was making a new contact with Soviet officials, perhaps in Moscow.

Predicting an increase in travel and a shift to a long distance East-and-West journey pattern for both military and civilian groups, Donald S. Stralem, president of the Travelers Aid Society of New York, yesterday ranked that organization as best fitted to cope with these new trends because of its social work program.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The United States has sold to its Allies for cash or under the Lend-Lease Act, which started in March, 1941, 65 per cent of all the tanks and other motor vehicles which it produced, Leo T. Crowley, head of the Foreign Economic Administration, revealed today.

WINDSOR, Canada, March 29 (AP) -- Harry F. McLean, wealthy Toronto contractor, whose hobby is giving away his money, halted traffic on a Windsor Street this morning by opening the window of his fourth floor room in the Prince Edward Hotel and tossing $5,000 in dollar notes and silver into the street.

Emery Darcy's triumphant performance in the title role of Wagner's "Parsifal" last night at the Metropolitan Opera House was the big surprise of the local opera season. In the 36-year-old artist, who sang the extremely difficult part for the first time in his career, the Metropolitan has discovered a heroic tenor fully capable of meeting the exactions of the music, a man who looked and acted the role as convincingly as he sang it.

The president of a Queens oil company and one of his truck drivers, who had been arrested in 1942 as principals in a ring that the Government charged with supplying black market gasoline to Long Island filling stations but acquitted three weeks ago by a jury after a trial on a conspiracy indictment, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal Court to illegal possession of gasoline ration coupons.
LONDON, March 29 -- Aroused and angry, Prime Minister Winston Churchill went before a mildly repentant House of Commons today and demanded a showdown.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PAICIFIC, Thursday, March 30 (AP) -- A communique:

Although subjected daily to Japanese bombings, an operating room built in the side of a hill was one of the safest spots on New Georgia Island last summer, Lieut. Comdr. Garrett Duryea, naval medical officer, said yesterday at the Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street

Modern art acquired two young disciples yesterday when Tommy and Eileen Breheny, aged 5 and 6, visited the Durand-Ruel Galleries at 12 East Fifty-seventh Street, where an exhibition of paintings is being held for the benefit of the Children's Aid Society's Homemaker Service.

Maj. Gen. J.A. Ulio, Adjutant General of the Army, indicated that complete elimination of Nazi discriminatory legislation and regulations in countries liberated by the United Nations is a basic policy of the United States Government, in a letter to Dr. John Slawson, executive vice president of the American Jewish Committee, 386 Fourth Avenue, made public yesterday.

OMAHA, March 29 (AP) -- Senator Joseph H. Ball of Minnesota opened the campaign for support of Harold Stassen in the Nebraska Presidential preferential primary election April 11 with a declaration here today of five fundamental issues which he said faced the country in the coming election.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, March 30 (U.P.) -- American bombers heaped ninety-three more tons of explosives on the battered Japanese base of Rabaul, New Britain, Monday in the face of fierce anti-aircraft fire and destroyed at least sixteen buildings, it was announced today.

NEW DELHI, India, March 29 -- Japanese troops invading India have forced a British withdrawal in the Ukhrul area, thirty-four miles northeast of Imphal, and another enemy column has driven even closer to Kohima, key communications center above the Manipur State capital, Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten's headquarters announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- Newspapers in the last three Treasury war loans carried a total of 386,609 sponsored or donated advertisements occupying an aggregate of 138,322 pages having a space value of $21,053,052.

The National City Bank won yesterday the award of a new issue of $1,000,000 of Utica, N.Y., certificates of indebtedness dated March 31 and payable on July 31, 1944. The bank bid an 0.37 per cent basis, plus a premium of $14.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 29 (U.P.) -- Freddie Archer, 22-year-old Newark (N.J.) fighter, gained a decisive ten-round victory tonight over Fritzie Zivic of Pittsburgh, former welterweight champion, who was handicapped by a chipped bone in his left hand that he had suffered in his last bout.

LONDON, March 29 -- The use of plasma is no longer an experiment in the treatment of battle casualties. After experience in the Southwest Pacific, North Africa, Italy, Russia and even Germany, it is now an "absolute necessity." If the people of the United States but half realized the reliance doctors place upon it there would be no question of an adequate supply when the Allied troops start the inevitable cross-Channel invasion of Europe.
LUSTY Annie Scanlon's ma Cleaned houses, while her drunken pa Bought gin instead of bread and butter And often woke up in the gutter.

ALGIERS, March 29 -- The Provisional Consultative Assembly spent three hours today discussing plans proposed for the revival of the French press from the Allies' landing to the end of the Provisional Government period.
Dr. W.P. Mortenson, formerly a research economist with the War Food Administration, has joined the New York technical staff of the Sheffield Farms Company, Inc.

Far from being pinched for food, the civilian population of this country is consuming more meat, eggs, citrus fruits and other important foods than in many of the pre-war years, 400 farmer committeemen of the Agricultural Adjustment Agency were told yesterday by Francis D. Cronin, regional director of the office of distribution of the War Food Administration.

As a result of new regulations by the War Department, medical and dental schools throughout the country will suffer a 50 per cent reduction in the Army quota of students scheduled to enter next year, it was learned yesterday. Instead of assigning 5,800 medical and dental students, as originally planned, the Army will admit only 2,800 for the term beginning in January.

From New Jersey comes the report that there, too, the work of preparing for the trout season is going on apace. New Jersey's season begins on April 15 and will run until July 15, then will be reopened during the thirty days of September.

Worth Street yarn merchants voiced the opinion yesterday that the Government directive on cotton duck production for the quarter beginning April 1 would cause a serious mix-up in priority orders. They pointed out that duck yarns now on AA2X rating would take precedence over all AA1 ratings now in effect on yarns used in such items as camouflage cloth, insulating material and fish netting.

Among the bills now on Governor Dewey's desk there are at least three on which he could use the pocket veto to good advantage. One permits the Superintendent of Public Works to "retain and employ private engineers, architects and consultants," not only for preparing designs and giving advice on projects but also for "services * * * in the administration of the Department."

The stock market managed yesterday a last-hour recovery effort, but only after another selling wave had made further inroads on values. The list gave early indications of some support on the New York Stock Exchange, but it was not until the liquidation subsided going into the closing hour that prices steadied and part of the previous losses were recovered.

The Committee for Economic Development yesterday offered a six-point program for the encouragement of small business on a national scale in the transition and post-war periods. The program, according to the committee's statement, is designed to "remove obstacles which impede the establishment of new business" and "to afford positive aid in the reduction or elimination of differential handicaps from which small business often suffers."

TENAFLY, N.J., March 29 -- High school students here declared this morning a truce in their three-day strike and returned to classes. They declared, however, that unless the Board of Education renewed the teaching contract of Leonard V. Kachel or made a satisfactory explanation they would walk out again.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 29 -- George Weiss, secretary of the Yankees and boss of their far-flung farm system, will pay his first visit to the training camp tomorrow -- and the incident is fraught with significance.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Reading national political significance into yesterday's Democratic victory in the special election in Oklahoma's Second Congressional District, Democratic Administration Democrats said today it was "a myth" that the country was "going Republican," predicted that the Senate would remain Democratic in November, and contended that the voters were unwilling to abandon the New Deal.

LONDON, Thursday, March 30 (AP) -- Recent assertions by Cordell Hull, Secretary of State of the United States, that there had been a leakage from Great Britain to the United States of diplomatic news, is hotly resented by Government officials and journalists here, The News Chronicle said today.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 29 -- If grapevine reports from the Pacific Coast are true, it may be known within a couple of weeks whether Augie Galan, still a holdout, will play second base for the Dodgers this year.

Two five-story and one six-story brick and stone loft buildings with four stores at 411-13 Broadway and 64-68 Lispenard Street, at the southwest corner, have been sold by the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company, as trustee, to Bernard London and Henry Weitzner, for cash above a purchase-money mortgage of $50,000.

BETHPAGE, L.I., March 29 -- Eleven young Navy fliers, veterans of virtualy every military engagement in the South Pacific, stood awe-struck today as the new twin-engined Grumman fighter was put through a few of its paces at the Grumman factory field here.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Charges that as a result of the dissolution of the Communist party in the United States, the members of that faction would throw all their weight in the 1944 election into the Political Action Committee of the CIO and that their leader would be, "in effect," Sidney Hillman instead of Earl Browder, were made today in a report issued by the Dies Committee on Un-American Activities.

The German-controlled Paris radio reported yesterday that nine Frenchmen, described as "terrorists," had been executed at Lyon following their conviction by a court-martial. The domestic broadcast was reported by United States Government monitors.

Twenty-five-year-old Roger Lewis Gardner, who has made a career of polygamy and had long been sought by the Federal Bureau of Investigation as the "Gardenia Murderer," was in Federal custody yesterday. This was largely because of a chance encounter between two women, both of whom were planning to marry him.

It is now disclosed that the President has been fighting a mild bronchitis the last two or three weeks, and still coughs a bit, though he is feeling much better. Winston Churchill at his recent appearances in Parliament impressed observers as a tired man.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Whether or not the President seeks re-election, the votes of organized labor will be continually solicited by both major candidates, and it is highly improbable that either will offer to labor any such catalogue of its faults as was recently recited by Eric A. Johnston, head of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

LONDON, March 29 -- Naval bombardment will play a major part in support of the landing operations in the coming invasion of Europe, according to military observers here. Recent operations in the Mediterranean and reports of great strength of German coastal defenses in western Europe have emphasized the importance of high-velocity, armor-piercing projectiles in the reduction of the most modern fortress system in Europe.

NAPLES, March 29 -- Photographic-reconnaissance pictures made available today indicated that the Allies' recent repeated aerial attacks on rail communications in northern Italy had again cut all lines leading to the German front lines.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 29 -- RKO has borrowed Ella Raines from Universal for the lead with John Wayne in the forthcoming "Tall in the Saddle," a Western based on Gordon Ray Young's novel of the same title. Production will start on April 17.

The entire student body of the Hunter College Elementary School, comprising 3-to-11-year-olds, attended a musicale yesterday and offered a lively applause as their classmates performed for the first time in the Assembly Hall before an audience of 700. Without a rehearsal, the youngsters from "The School for Gifted Children" assumed a professional air and, accompanied by their parents, played a variety of instruments, including the recorder and 'cello.

Widening of community medical and hospital service in the city after the war was urged by speakers yesterday at the annual meeting of the New York City Visiting Committee of the State Charities Aid Association at the Colony Club, 564 Park Avenue.

First Lieut. Stanley Greenhouse, bombardier of an Army Liberator bomber, has won the Silver Star, the Distinguished Flying Cross and the Air Medal, but his most treasured possession is a medal of the Blessed Virgin, which, he said yesterday, saw him safely through forty-six combat missions against the Japanese in the South Pacific.

HEADQUARTERS OF THE AMERICAN AIR COMMANDO FORCE, the India-Burma Border, March 26 (Delayed) (AP) -- Flight Officer Jackie Coogan of the American Air Commando Unit, first glider pilot to land Allied troops behind the Japanese lines in Burma, came back to his base today to relate how he was "taken for a god" by Burmese when they saw him alight on their paddy fields.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- The Weather Bureau reported today that Midwestern and Eastern farmers, already hindered by shortages of labor and of machinery, are two weeks and even more behind in their spring soil preparation and planting schedules due to excessive wet weather. The seeding of spring wheat, oats and barley was reported to be three weeks late in the East-Central Plains region.
LONDON, March 29 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

WASHINGTON, March 29 (U.P.) -- A poll of veteran Washington correspondents showed tonight that a majority believe President Roosevelt not only will win the next election but that he is the man best qualified for the Presidency.

I would like to comment on the letter of Mr. Francis Kingsley, dated March 5, 1944, which indicates a good deal of misunderstanding regarding social security taxation, although to my mind your editorial of Feb. 21 had presented the issue quite clearly.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Attacking subsidy payments as a substitute for a fair price ceiling on dairy products, Charles W. Holman, secretary of the National Cooperative Milk Producers' Federation, told the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today that he would like to see the subsidy programs discontinued.

DOSWELL, Va., March 29 (AP) -- Sun Beau, 19-year-old bay thoroughbred who had earned $376,744 for the late Willis Sharpe Kilmer of Binghamton, N.Y., died today at Meadow Farm. The horse was buried shortly afterward on the front lawn of the estate of Christopher T. Chenery, where a monument will be erected to his memory.

Having lost control, Alex Rose, David Dubinsky and other right wing leaders decided at a two-hour conference yesterday to withdraw from the American Labor party, abandoning it to Sidney Hillman and the coalition of left wing groups that won Tuesday's primary by electing about 620 of the 750 members of the party's State committee.

In these days of rising tension, when the supreme risk of the Western war is about to be taken, there is something almost too allegorical to be real in that strange eyrie in the Austrian Alps, accessible only through a secret elevator shaft bored through the rocks, where Hitler hides as the siege of Europe tightens.

Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines, administrator of retraining and reemployment of veterans; Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission; Mayor La-Guardia and others will participate in the dedication of the New York City Veterans Service Center at 10 East Fortieth Street on Saturday at 12:30 P.M., it was announced yesterday.

Spurred by the success of "Carmen Jones" and his recent acquisition of the Ziegfeld Theatre, Billy Rose yesterday announced plans for a revival of "Henry VIII" next season. Margaret Webster, an expert in her field, has been commissioned to streamline and direct the Shakespearean production, which will be designed by Robert Edmond Jones.

Style knows no age limitation and outstanding trends in mother's 1944 spring wardrobe have their young editions. Boleros, toppers, checks and gray flannel, all important factors in spring fashions for women, will play their part in daughter's Easter parade. Matching accessories, seen at all the showings, have been developed in gay and amusing ways for the small fry.

A client of George Lodes, Inc., broker, has bought from a client of Charles Lubin the five-story, twenty-five-family apartment building at 2358 Webster Avenue, in the Bronx. The assessed valuation of the property is $46,000.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Point values on all frozen varieties of processed fruits and vegetables, which account for about 6 per cent of all foods in the rationing program, will be reduced to zero between Sunday and April 29, the Office of Price Administration said today.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., March 29 (U.P.) -- Top-seeded Mrs. Helen Pedersen Rihbany of New York and Miss Katherine Winthrop of Hamilton, Mass., ranked second, will meet tomorrow in the singles final of the Women's National Indoor Tennis championships on the Longwood covered courts.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The War and Navy Departments made it known today that they approved drafting of 4-F's for essential civilian work as soon as Congress enacted legislation for it, and the House Military Affairs subcommittee on the draft prepared to consider drawing up such a bill.

The switch-stance style of Juan Zurita which baffled Sammy Angott on the Coast and brought about his decisive defeat by the Mexican lightweight in their fifteen-round bout for the N.B.A. title, is expected to be a problem for Beau Jack in their ten-round over-the-weight meeting at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night.

Loss of manpower through accidents in 1943 reached the equivlent of 900,000 workers withdrawn from war plants, Maj. Gen. Thomas A. Terry, commanding general of the Second Service Command, reported last night at the annual dinner meeting of the Greater New York Safety Council in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
CANBERRA, Australia, March 29 (U.P.) -- An appeal by Australian Catholic leaders that the Allies spare Rome and Vatican City met a somewhat cool reception today in Government and press circles.

The tremendous sales job done by the banks in the Fourth War Loan Drive is well known, but it remained for the Treasury to point out yesterday just how great the showing was. According to the official figures, the banks of the nation handled $13,556,000,000, or more than 80 per cent, of the $16,730,000,000 sold in the drive.

NAPLES, March 29 -- In the vicinity of Terelle, northwest of Cassino, the Germans made a sharp raid yesterday with artillery and mortar preparation, but nothing came of it. In the lower Garigliano River sector, four enemy machine guns were silenced by artillery southwest of Minturno.

It was on Sept. 3 that Allied troops landed on the Italian mainland and therewith set foot for the first time on Axis territory. Behind them lay two triumphant campaigns crowned by the victory in Tunisia which resulted in the annihilation of the proud Africa Corps and the liberation of the whole African continent, and by the record conquest of Sicily after the most ambitious amphibious operation yet undertaken.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Production quotas for paper and paperboard during the three months beginning April 1 were established by the War Production Board today at 4,335,353 tons, an increase of 138,842 tons above the previous quarter.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- As a result of the "carry back" provisions of Federal tax laws, American corporations hold a "lien" on the Federal Treasury amounting to billions of dollars, according to Philip Murray, president of the United Steel Workers of America, CIO, who ended that union's case before the War Labor Board's steel panel today.

LONDON, Thursday, March 30 -- The Red Army yesterday smashed over the upper Prut River and into the outskirts of the Balkan gateway city of Cernauti, while forty-two miles to the northwest in Poland a Soviet tank and infantry spearhead cut the Bucharest-Lwow railroad, last direct German rail link to Cernauti and the entire southern front.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc., will offer today 180,000 shares of 4 3/4 per cent $50-par cumulative preferred stock of the Oklahoma Natural Gas Company at $52 a share.

MOSCOW, March 29 -- A plain warning was delivered today to the peoples of Finland, Rumania and Bulgaria that the only way they can save their countries from becoming battlegrounds is to break immediately with Adolf Hitler, using their own armed forces to resist any attempt by him to occupy their territories as he did Hungary.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Joseph V. Moreschi, president of the International Hod Carriers, Building and Common Laborers Union, a unit of the American Federation of Labor; John W. Garvey, general representative; Achilles Persion, secretary-treasurer; Moreschi's son, Faust, and nine others, principally labor union figures, were indicted by a Federal grand jury today, on charges which the United States Attorney asserted would show that at least $500,000 was embezzled from the union's organizations in three years.

Sales of ordinary life insurance in the British Isles rose 7 1/2 per cent last year, according to the Institute of Life Insurance. The 1943 year-end total was 35 per cent greater than at the end of the first year of the war.
St. John's and Utah, the two underdog quintets in advance of the national invitation and N.C. A.A. tournaments that have been concluded in Madison Square Garden, will meet there tonight.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 29 -- Charles M. Bernstein, central figure in a 1927 fracas in New York that cost four lives, is still unfit mentally to stand trial on first-degree murder indictments, Supreme Court Justice Gerald Nolan ruled here today in dismissing his application for release from Mattewan State Hospital for the Criminal Insane.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 29 -- Denying any ideological motive or desire on the part of the Swiss to prolong ill-balanced foreign relations, Marcel Pilet-Golaz, chief of the Diplomatic Department [Foreign Office], in a seventy-minute address before the National Council this morning, swung the Social Democratic party back into line long enough for the withdrawal of a motion for a debate on the subject of immediate renewal of diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union.

Reports on 1942 operations of the Standard Oil Company of California and its subsidiaries, H.D. Collier, president, informed stockholders in the statement released today, that total sales far exceeded those of any previous year. While gross income increased substantially, the change in net income was less marked, due to considerably heavier Federal taxes.

TRENTON, N.J., March 29 -- Another of Gov. Walter E. Edge's projected reforms was laid before the Legislature today when he submitted to the Senate the nominations of Dr. William S. Carpenter of Princeton and Mrs. Pearl Bride-gum of Hainsport as members of the Civil Service Commission.
