The Regional War Labor Board awarded yesterday hiring rate increases of $3 to $6 a week to eighty-two Rockettes and ballet girls of the Radio City Music Hall. At the same time, the board approved salary rises for sixty-six girls of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The Spanish Government has again assured the State Department that its Blue Division, which has been fighting with the Germans against the Russians, will be completely withdrawn from the eastern front.

The keynote for the June, July and August "Food Fights for Freedom" advertising campaign sponsored by the War Advertising Council in cooperation with the War Food Administration and the Office of Price Administration, will be conservation of food, Lennen Mitchell, Inc., task force for the council, announced yesterday.

The first prize of $1,500 in The Saturday Review of Literature Anisfield Awards has been given to "The World of Sholom Aleichem," by Maurice Samuel, and the second prize of $500 to Roi Ottley's "New World A'Comin'." Mr. Ottley's book was published by Houghton, Mifflin, and Mr. Samuel's by Knopf.

Publication of the proposals of Judge Manley O. Hudson and others for international organization presents once more the question whether it is possible to develop in the United States a politically formidable public opinion in favor of a peace settlement dictated by reason, justice and good-will.

An exhibition of Mexican folk art and of paintings by Ceferino Palencia, former assistant curator at the Museum of Modern Art in Madrid, will open at the Brooklyn Museum this afternoon with a tea and reception for representatives of the Mexican Government and trustees of the museum.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 29 (AP) -- Declaring that it would be "foolhardy" for Connecticut to drop civilian defense activities at "this indecisive stage of the war," the State War Administrator, Harold F. Woodcock, took issue today with Mrs. George A. Wyeth of the New Hampshire Defense Council, who advocated yesterday in Washington the curtailment of OCD operations in the twelve Eastern States from Maine to Virginia, including New York.

CHUNGKING, China, March 29 -- "Now is a grand time and a good opportunity for us to attack with initiative," says the Chinese Communist newspaper Sin Hua Jih Pao today in an editorial that urges the Chinese armies to start an offensive to relieve pressure on the United Nations forces in India and Burma.
The National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue, one of the oldest organizations of artists in the country, announced yesterday the election of twenty-one new associate members.

Four hold-up men, two of them armed with sawed-off shotguns, last evening robbed the jewelry store at 620 Nostrand Avenue, in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, of $5,000 worth of watches, rings and trinkets while the owner, Harry Brown, and his wife Sylvia stood under guard facing a wall in the rear of the shop.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 29 (UP) -- At least four persons were drowned today and hundreds were left homeless as Southern rivers continued on a rampage, flooding towns, washing out bridges and causing crop and highway damages estimated at millions of dollars.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- John A. Barr, manager of labor relations of Montgomery Ward Co., told the National War Labor Board today that the company would refuse to obey a board directive because it had pending in the Federal District Court for the District of Columbia a move to have the board's directive declared illegal and to enjoin the board from taking any steps toward its enforcement.

A sharp drop in the production of fabrics for upholstered furniture, already only 10 per cent of normal output, was predicted yesterday within the next three months by a representative of a large manufacturer of upholstery pile fabrics unless cotton yarn requirements of the armed forces, lend-lease agencies and the UNRRA are curtailed appreciably.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Announcing his resignation from the House to enter the armed service, Representative James Domengeaux, Democrat, of Louisiana, assailed bureaucratic administration today, criticized those who stir up "happy and contented" Negroes and accused the administration failing to consult sufficiently with Congress on foreign policy.

Delegates of the clubs in the Yacht Racing Association yesterday adopted the full schedule for the championships on Long Island Sound this summer. They met in the New York Yacht Club and approved a full program that will start on May 28 and carry through to Sept. 24.

NEW DELHI, March 30 -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's American and Chinese troops in northern Burma have slaughtered at least 400 Japanese in repulsing five savage counter-attacks launched in an attempt to rescue a force of about 1,000 Japanese trapped by a roadblock north of Leban in the Mogaung Valley.

MOSCOW, Friday, March 31 -- Soviet troops under the command of the assistant commander in chief, Marshal Gregory K. Zhukoff, yesterday captured Cernauti, a powerful German bastion protecting the approaches to Rumania and Hungary, and drove within fifteen miles of the border of Czechoslovakia and within fifteen miles of what the Soviet Union considers the Rumanian border northeast of the Carpathian Mountains.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Department store sales in the week ended March 25 were 17 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following shows percentage changes from like periods a year ago:
SAN FRANCISCO, March 30 -- Speaker Rayburn said here today in reply to an inquiry about the Democratic Vice Presidential nomination:

Four two-story store and loft buildings at 138 to 142 1/2 Reade Street were sold by the Excelsior Savings Bank to a client of E.J. Feinberg, attorney. They are assessed at $63,000 and were sold subject to a mortgage of $24,000. James Felt Co. were the brokers.

February furniture store sales in New York City showed a decrease of 3 per cent compared with those in the corresponding month last year, according to a report yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Total sales in the Second Federal Reserve District, the report stated, were off by 4 per cent.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, March 31 (U.P.) -- American Navy and Army bombers from the Southwest Pacific struck their first blows of the war against Truk and Woleai atolls in the Carolines and also scored one of their greatest air victories over New Guinea in a series of smashing raids that destroyed at least 172 Japanese planes, it was announced tonight.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman announced yesterday that the unfinished Herbert N. Straus mansion at 9 East Seventy-first Street, just acquired by the Roman Catholic Archbishopric of New York, would be transformed into a convalescent hospital as an adjunct to St. Clare's Hospital at 415 West Fifty-first Street.
NEW YORK AfLrs. John Jay Ide has come to [he Plaza from Washington.

ANZIO BEACHHEAD, Italy, March 30 (U.P.) -- Six deaths during the night raised to eight dead and seventy-two wounded today the toll of a German bombing attack on two American hospitals last night that riddled thirty tents and injured thirty-eight soldier patients already under treatment as battle casualties.
BUENOS AIRES, March 30 -- The Subsecretariat for Information and the Press issued an official statement today giving its version of what the Minister of the Interior, Gen. Luis C. Perlinger, said

Educators and business leaders were urged last night by Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker to give more realistic thinking to plans for the educational future of American1 youth. He declared it would be "a great day when our schools become schools of practical learning as well as theoretical learning."

Joseph J. Krajicek bought for light manufacturing the garage building on a plot 100 by 200 feet at 478-80 Westfield Avenue, in Roselle Park, N.J., from the Newsted Building and Loan Liquidating Association. David Cronheim was broker in the sale of the property, which formerly was owned by the Elizabeth Sash and Door Company.
WITH THE THIRTY-SECOND DIVISION IN THE SAIDOR SECTOR, New Guinea, March 30 -- On her recent visit to Australia Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt climbed into an Army tank for a look.

LOS ANGELES, March 30 (AP) -- Charlie Chaplin, choking up at times, but speaking in tones that rang through a stilled court room, gave his version today of the incident when Joan Berry went to his home in Beverly Hills and threatened him with a pistol.

Soldiers have been blinded not only in the battle areas but from injuries accidentally incurred in the Army's extensive training program, Lieut. Col. James N. Greear Jr. of the Valley Forge General Hospital declared here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- A sweeping modification of regulations controlling imports, chief effect of which will be to remove a long list of commodities from control measures altogether, was announced today by the War Production Board.
LONDON, March 30 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin:

When the war is over aviation will have much to say about the dinner table. For perishable foods the airplane may indeed be able to use the atmosphere itself for quick freezing. Immediate ascent from a tropical growing field to an altitude of 15,000 to 20,000 feet would make the cargo plane a flying refrigerator car.

LAKEWOOD, N. J., March 30 -- The season's first "No Baseball Today, Two Tomorrow" sign was hung up here this afternoon as perverse weather conditions which provided nothing but cold and more rain held the Giants' training activities at a standstill for the second successive day.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Simplification of procedures retailers may use to display or state the 20 per cent excise on luxury goods which goes into effect on April 1 was provided by the Office of Price Administration today "so that merchants may comply with the requirements without difficulty and yet consumers will be informed that prices have been increased only to the extent of the tax."

Moriz Rosenthal, 81-year-old pianist and one of the last remaining pupils of Liszt, became an American citizen yesterday. Despite a recent illness and the rainy weather he appeared an hour and a half before the scheduled time of 10:30 A.M. at the Immigration and Naturalization Service quarters, Sixty-third Street and Columbus Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Following an executive session with the special House committee investigating the Federal Communications Commission, Charles R. Denny, chief counsel for the FCC, replied today to two questions which he had refused to answer yesterday regarding the exclusion from the broadcasting field of Stefano Luotto of New York, Italian language radio announcer.
LONDON, March 30 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Force in Europe communique:

Rumors about the Zarief quadruplets were rife yesterday. The facts that emerged when the gossip was sorted were scanty and to the effect that the three girls and their brother were in excellent condition, as was their mother, Mrs. Eleanor Zarief.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The Japanese drive into India in the Imphal area encountered some checks today, but the enemy was still making slow progress.

Almost 78 per cent of the Americans who go blind at present are losing their sight needlessly, according to studies presented yesterday at the closing sessions of the annual convention and exposition of the Greater New York Safety Council at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Record attendance during the first three days of the Boston furniture market, despite previous predictions that merchants outside of New England would not appear at the exhibition, was attributed here yesterday to the extensive showing of spring-filled upholstered furniture, metal baby carriages and dual purpose sleeping equipment which attracted dealers from New York, Chicago, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Atlanta, Ga.

Citing "a possibility that renegotiation of war contracts may be discontinued," Maj. John M. Gibbons, contracting officer for knit goods at the Philadelphia QM Depot, said yesterday that "it is incumbent upon the Army to take steps to avoid the need for renegotiating contracts."

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Although the Army reports that comparatively few United States soldiers stationed in foreign countries are marrying aliens, the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service and the House Immigration and Naturalization Committee have received several letters from alien brides of American soldiers asking for a definition of their status.
NEW DELHI, India, March 30 (AP) -- A communique:

Warnings of dangers to the country from within and of weaknesses in the national fabric going unheeded in the midst of war were voiced last night by three speakers at the third book meeting of the season, sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and held at The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

According to reports from London yesterday, the South African Government will insist on a "free gold market" after the war and does not propose to sell its gold at a fixed price for either "unitas" of the White post-war currency plan or for "bancor" of the Keynes plan.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Opposition to food subsidies and demands for delegation of all Federal responsibility for food production and pricing to the War Food Administration were voiced by spokesmen for farm groups who appeared today before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee considering a bill to extend the Emergency Price Control Act and the Stabilization Act beyond June 30.

The Public Education Association believes that citizens reading the newspaper accounts of the passage of the Superintendents' Bill by the Legislature will be confused, not enlightened and that, therefore, there is need for clarification of the issues involved.

In this newspaper yesterday a delayed dispatch told how a force of Gurkhas with the Fifth Army crept up Hangman's Hill on the night of March 15; in an unprotected position were subject to severe mortar and artillery fire: were without water or food a good deal of the time.

The Office of Defense Transportation issued a reminder yesterday to over-the-road-truck operators that, under new regulations which became effective this week, they must register with the nearest ODT district office empty or partly loaded vehicles and freight which can not be moved within a limited time.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 30 -- Eleanor Parker will play the lead in Warners' "The Very Thought of You," replacing Ida Lupino, who withdrew because of illness. Miss Parker recently completed the feminine lead in "Between Two Worlds," a remake of the play "Outward Bound."

Mass bombing of enemy cities is a military necessity and should be continued, Norman Cousins, editor of the Saturday Review of Literature, and Maj. George Fielding Eliot, military analyst, said last night in a debate at "America's Town Meeting" in Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Seldom have Ambassadors of foreign powers had to put up with such offensive words as were uttered to the press by the Argentine Minister of the Interior, Gen. Luis C. Perlinger. But seldom also have offensive words been received with such indifference.

LONDON, March 30 -- Negotiations for conciliation of the differences between the Tito and Mikhailovitch forces in Yugoslavia have come to a dead stop and the government of Prime Minister Bozidar Pouritch, refusing the only basis for settlement that seemingly is acceptable to the British Government, is stubbornly declining to yield its position.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- A Congressional committee called on the Army, Navy and Selective Service System today to prepare for administration of a 4-F draft law which it plans to present to Congress next month if the need is still apparent.

It will be like tearing up old roots when the city's new Assembly districts come into effect. People whose memories and affections have twined themselves around the Eleventh Assembly District; people who have been born and grown up and married in the Seventeenth Assembly District; people who have watched the lengthening shadows fall on the sidewalks of the Eighteenth Assembly District -- they must now start life anew, so to speak.

The growing shortage of manpower in the Fire Department may force a return to the two-platoon system, with its 84-hour week, or even to continuous duty, Commissioner Patrick Walsh predicted yesterday.

Although the joys of furnishing a new home or redecorating an old one are denied to many women today because of temporary living arrangements, shortages of materials or the necessity to save money for war bonds, the increasing attendance at classes in home decoration and related subjects indicates that they are using this time to collect ideas for the future.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The United States Army Air Forces, "blasting a relentless Allied path toward Tokyo and Berlin," destroyed 11,042 enemy planes in 1943, against its own losses of 2,885, the War Department announced today.

LONDON, March 30 (AP) -- The Bank of England's condition statement for the week ended yesterday showed an increase of u11,013,000 in note circulation to the new record of u1,104,634,000. This increase reflected an almost similar loss in reserves.
CHICAGO, March 30 -- Almost $1,500,000 in currency was added to the estate of William Hale (Big Bill) Thompson, former Mayor of Chicago, when two safe-deposit boxes were opened today.

Reluctance on the part of nurses to enlist in the Army and Navy prompted a statement yesterday from Miss Emma L. Collins, State vice chairman of the Nurses Procurement and Assignment Service of the War Manpower Commission, that a compulsory service act was "the only hope of filling the quota."

Jose Gomez Esparza predicted yesterday that his appointment not only as the first Mexican Ambassador to China but as the first Ambassador to that country from any Pan American republic would be a forerunner to similar actions by the other republics.
LONDON, March 30 -- Following today's parade Lieut. Gen. John C.H. Lee spoke at an Anglo-American luncheon in the County Hall. He said:

Net sales of General Motors Corporation in 1943 totaled $3,796,115,800, eclipsing all previous records by a wide margin and were better than two-thirds greater than the 1942 volume of $2,250,548,859, according to the pamphlet report for the year, signed by Alfred H. Sloan Jr., chairman, and Charles E. Wilson, president.

If there is a national intercollegiate basketball champion, the baby-faced Utes from the University of Utah are it. For last night, before 18,125 fans at Madison Square Garden, the youthful visitors from Ogden upset St. John's University, 43 to 36, and earned unofficial recognition as the top team in the country.

LISBON, Portugal, March 30 (AP) -- Little girls and grandmothers are being harnessed to Germany's war production tasks as the Germans seek to overcome new manpower problems created by the destruction of thousands of factories by Allied planes.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, March 31 (AP) -- A communique:

SUPERIOR, Wis., March 30 -- "Hoping the voters of Wisconsin not buy a pig in a poke," Wendell Willkie completed today a thirty-day campaign in this State reelection of delegates to the Republican National Convention urged to vote for his nomination as President.

Several of the considerations that he said would not excuse restaurant owners for violating Office of Price Administration ceilings were listed yesterday by Judge John Bright in Federal court. The court granted the injunction sought by the OPA against further price violations by the Coronet Restaurant Corporation.

The Bronx, with 71.1 per cent of its quota of contributions already in hand, is leading all other boroughs in the Red Cross 1944 War Fund appeal of Greater New York, it was announced yesterday by Raymond L. Korndorfer, chairman of the Bronx Red Cross War Fund Committee.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine disclosed yesterday that an investigation of "The Voice of the Turtle," a three-character comedy at the Morosco Theatre, is being conducted by "appropriate officials" as a result of a complaint registered against the attraction by Mgr. John L. Belford of the Roman Catholic Church of the Nativity, Brooklyn.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March 30 (AP) -- Harold (Jug) McSpaden of Philadelphia took top honors today with a seven-under-par 63 in the pro-amateur event preceeding Knoxville's first $6,000 open golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The latest reports on American war casualties set the total at 173,239 for the Army and Navy, an increase of 4,947 in a week.

LONDON, March 30 -- An order calling in all diaries kept by Allied soldiers in the European theatre of operations was issued tonight by the censor's office in a pre-Western Front tightening of the rules.

Assistant District Attorney Jacob Grumet, trying to establish yesterday premeditation in the Lonergan murder case, paced seventeen feet from jury box to clerk's table, and back, in General Sessions Court to prove that in the time it takes to cover thirty-four feet twice, Wayne Lonergan had opportunity to consider his act.

Further progress on the road to recovery was made yesterday in the stock market as prices on the New York Stock Exchange retrieved fractions to more than a point of their recent losses. A firmer note was evident throughout the list, with a strong demand for the liquor issues.

Improvement in the technical position of the cotton market carried prices yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange to the best levels of the day at the close, or to net gains of 7 to 13 points. The market opened 2 to 3 points down, eased to losses of 2 to 5 points, and then recovered because of scarcity of contracts and continued price-fixing.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 30 (AP) -- The Buffalo, Niagara Eastern Power Corporation reported today a net loss of $23,411 for 1943 as a result of cessation of dividend payments to it by three subsidiaries. The deficit was in contrast to a net income of $3,473,640 in 1942.

James Ronald, who wrote "Old Soldiers Never Die," is the author of a new novel, "The Night is Ending," coming from Lippincott on April 26. Mr. Ronald was born in Glasgow, Scotland, and left school at 14 to work. He now devotes his time to writing and is living in Connecticut.

After more than a quarter of a century the Russians are back in Cernauti, or Czernowitz, as it used to be called. Taking the city in June, 1916, they held it until the imperial armies broke up after the revolution of Nov. 7, 1917. A forgotten imperial general, Kaledin, commanding the Eighth Army, ruled there, and later it was General Korniloff.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 30 -- A Secret Supreme Committee for the Liberation of Lithuania was established in Kaunas in December, 1943, according to trustworthy information received here, through private channels. The committee represents all Lithuanian, democratic and fighting organizations "unanimous in the determination not to recognize any foreign occupation of Lithuania and to fight for a free, independent Lithuania, reconstructed on democratic principles as proclaimed by the Atlantic Charter."

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on March 25 over 778,925 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 7,517 cars or 1 per cent less than for the preceding week, 8,415 cars or 1.1 per cent less than for the corresponding week last year and 29,361 cars or 3.6 per cent less than during the corresponding week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (U.P.) -- Frederick W. Dusing of Newburgh, N.Y., business representative of Local 17 of the International Hod Carriers Building and Common Laborers Union, AFL, charged tonight that Governor Thomas E. Dewey "soft-pedaled" an investigation of international officers of the union who were indicted here yesterday.

LONDON, March 30 -- Hundreds of thousands of Britons lined London's streets today in their greatest turnout since the coronation to watch American fighting men and machines parade as part of the "Salute to Soldier Week" celebration. It was no dress parade. It was a grim show of United States fighting strength. There were only a few flags flying and very little music.
LONDON, Friday, March 31 (AP) -- The Russian Thursday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., March 30 -- News that Arky Vaughan would not join the Dodgers until July at the earliest, the arrival and signing of Augie Galan and Les Webber, and the holdout of Frenchy Bordagaray all dropped into the background today because of the Army-Navy legislative recommendations to put all 4-F men into essential work.

LONDON, March 30 -- Varying its tactics to the extent of using speedy maneuverable Thunderbolt fighter-bombers rather than heavy four-engine Flying Fortresss and Liberators, the United States Strategic Air Force based in Britain continued its offensive against the Luftwaffe today by raking and blasting air bases in the Netherlands and the Netherlands-German border areas.

LONDON, March 30 -- Packed into a chamber where it was hard to find standing room, members of the House of Commons today handed Prime Minister Winston Churchill the vote of confidence that he sought and by the overwhelming margin that he is accustomed to receive.

MONTREAL, March 30 (AP) -- The Canadiens captured their best-of-seven Stanley Cup semi-finals series tonight by beating Toronto, 11 to 0, for their fourth victory in five contests. The Canadiens scored seven goals in the third period.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- A resolution to direct the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee to investigate to determine whether the Reconstruction Finance Corporation or its head, Jesse H. Jones, Secretary of Commerce, has engaged in activities designed to influence the management of the Kansas City Southern Railway Company was introduced today in the Senate under the joint sponsorship of Senators Clyde M. Reed, Republican, of Kansas, and Bennett C. Clark, Democrat, of Missouri.

Park Tilford, distributor of Tintex Tints and Dyes, launches tomorrow the largest advertising campaign in its history to publicize the fact that Tintex has been developed into an all-fabric dye that can be used for all synthetic fabrics, as well as cotton, silk, linen and wool.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company reduced its funded debt last year from $208,656,000 to $200,060,000, a net decline of $8,596,000, according to the annual report for 1943, issued for publication today. The reduction was accomplished by paying off before maturity $13,796,000 of bonds and notes and issuing in the year $5,200,000 of 1 3/4 per cent equipment-trust certificates.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., March 30 -- Once upon a time baseball men wailed plaintively, "Break up the Yankees!" They even tried to legislate against them but the connivers never thought then that there was only one law that could break up the New York club. Selective Service finally did the trick and now the team is not even a pale carbon copy of what it once was.

BOSTON, March 30 (AP) -- Joseph W. Martin Jr., House minority leader, declared tonight that the Republican party would lead the world back to "sanity, peace and prosperity" by keeping "faith with the men and women on the fighting fronts and protecting at home those sacred ideals they are so gallantly protecting all over the world."

The editorial captioned "The Firing Squad," in which you point out that "the trial and execution of Pucheu have raised doubts among Frenchmen themselves in Algiers," does THE TIMES everlasting credit as an example of fairness and sober thinking on a subject which concerns all sincere friends of France who hate to see a repetition of the horrors of the French Revolution.

Earmarking of cotton goods for export under conservation order M-317 was protested yesterday by the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers in a letter to the War Production Board, in which immediate relief from the present under-supply of fabrics for the industry was asked.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- President Roosevelt's bronchitis was reported today as "clearing up nicely" by White House Secretary Stephen T. Early, but the President continued to be confined to his quarters under his physician's orders.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine continued his shake-up of the police in Brooklyn yesterday by sending an inspector with a reputation as a strict disciplinarian to take command of the uniformed force in Brooklyn East, which includes Brownsville, East New York and Flatbush, and by returning sixteen Brooklyn plainclothesmen to uniformed duty.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- As chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee, Representative Bloom of New York released today a report on legislation extending for another year lend-lease aid to Allied nations with a unanimous recommendation of the committee members that it be adopted.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The suggestion today of Izvestia, Soviet Government newspaper, for a review by the Soviet Union, Great Britain and the United States of their attitude toward Italy, with the view of possibly acceding to some changes in the Badoglio Government, raised a question that presumably only President Roosevelt could answer.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., March 30 -- Manager Joe McCarthy officially announced the Yankees' line-up today for their first spring exhibition against the Phillies here Saturday, and brought into bold relief the radical changes wrought in the once powerful world champions in just a few months.

MOSCOW, March 30 (AP) -- The Soviet newspaper Izvestia declared today that the Soviet Union's recognition of the Badoglio Government in Italy was undertaken to establish direct relations with that government and to put Russia on an equal basis with the United States and Great Britain.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson formally acknowledged today that the Allied attack on Cassino must be regarded "for the time being" as a failure, but he also asserted that the affair must be viewed in its "proper perspective" and that it never had been a real test of Allied power.

Intrepid American pilots in this war already crowd the record of individual victories of our aces in the First World War. Indeed, if we take into consideration only airplanes shot down, and leave out of account balloons, the achievement of Captain Rickenbacker, leading American ace of the first conflict in which air power played a part, already has been surpassed.

So far as Broadway is concerned, all roads lead to the Belasco tonight. There first-nighters will greet two top-flight stars, Billie Burke and Frank Craven, in Zoe Akins' oddly titled comedy, "Mrs. January Mr. Ex."

The six-story apartment building on a plot 100 by 140 feet at 601 East Twenty-first Street, corner of Ditmas Road, in Brooklyn, has been sold by Anna Siegel through Frederick Zittell Sons, brokers. It was held at $225,000.

LONDON, Friday, March 31 (AP) -- Battering down the barriers of Hitler's cringing satellite States, the Red Army yesterday seized Cernauti, German fortress that had guarded the path to Rumania and Hungary, and climbed up the Prut River banks into the Carpathian Mountains to a point only fifteen miles from the Hungarian-held corner of Czechoslovakia.

Taking a peek into what the impending trout season has in store, Gordon L. Trembley, assistant professor of fish culture at Penn State, comes up with the observation that the number of men whipping the streams will be about half of normal, but that there will be a sharp increase in the number of woman anglers.

Five civilian employes of the New York Navy Yard, Brooklyn, were indicted yesterday by the Federal grand jury on charges of making false claims for additional wages. A total of $1,200 was involved. The defendants will appear for pleading next week.

PHILADELPHIA, March 30 -- A registration statement covering 696,702 shares of $6.50 par value common stock of the Compania Azucarera Vertientes-Camaguey de Cuba (Vertientes-Camaguey Sugar Company of Cuba) was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The 1943 annual report of the Mead Corporation, issued for publication today, reveals an increase of 8.92 per cent in net sales to $36,878,042 from the 1942 volume of $33,858,432. The company attributes the improvement to the inclusion in 1943 of a full year's sales of the Escanaba Paper Company and those of the Manistique Pulp and Paper Company since its acquisition in September, 1943.
CHICAGO, March 30 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:

NAPLES, March 30 -- The largest force of four-engined bombers ever sent over one target by the United States Fifteenth Air Force studded the Sofia railyards and industrial installations today with explosions and fires after the same target had been battered last night by Wellingtons and Liberators.

The Office of Price Administration has informed business organizations applying for certificates to purchase specially built typewriters that it intends to abandon "shortly" rationing of all typewriters, it was learned yesterday. Since the stock of used typewriters in office machinery dealers' hands is almost fully out on rental, dealers stated they were unable' to understand why the agency is taking the step except to curtail typewriter black - market activities.

LONDON, March 30 (U.P.) -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden appealed today from the House of Commons to European Quisling officials to help Jews escape persecution by the Nazis, and implicitly promised that they would be rewarded with special Allied consideration "on the day of reckoning."

ALGIERS, March 30 -- In influential French circles here there is a feeling that the differences between Washington and Gen. Charles de Gaulle go far deeper than a diplomatic or personal plane and involve divergences that may determine the future of American and European relations.

PEARL HARBOR, March 30 -- Pacific Fleet sea forces are attacking Japanese positions in the Palau Islands, about 550 miles due east of the Philippines and more than a thousand miles west of Truk. This attack, representing a giant stride toward Japan, is by far the deepest penetration made up to now in the central Pacific offensive.

Excess reserves of all member banks of the Federal Reserve System throughout the nation fell $300,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a total of only $600,000,000, lowest since Aug. 30, 1933, according to figures released yesterday. This drop was due mainly to a shift of funds for Treasury account from the member banks to the central Federal Reserve Banks.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Florists, facing several holiday buying rushes, received permission from the Office of Defense Transportation today to make four retail deliveries by motor vehicle during the week preceding Easter Sunday, providing three are made on Thursday, Friday and Saturday.

CHICAGO, March 30 -- Existence of a widespread "black market" in innerspring mattresses was disclosed here today when the executive committee of the National Association of Bedding Manufacturers metto devise ways of stamping out illegal sales.

In a series of moves to protect Passover celebrants against profiteering in holiday foods, the Office of Price Administration and the city's Department of Markets sought yesterday to hold down prices on live poultry, matzohs, whitefish, yellow pike, and spices.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, March 30 -- An average quiet day at front in this particular sector nowadays means clear, cold sunny weather and relatively few shells. It means that forward infantry units lie back dozing in their slit trenches taking good care to avoid mortar fire by keeping out of sight of the Germans on the heights above.

The fact that the designated beneficiary of a Series E War Savings Bond cannot be altered by the owner thereof save with legal consent of that beneficiary has led one of your correspondents to name this provision "another instance of the way in which the people are being victimized by dictatorial bureaucracy."

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The Ways and Means Committee, hurdling the next-to-the-last barrier to formal approval of a simplified income tax bill, agreed today on a provision designed to relieve 15,000,000 to 20,000,000 persons from the necessity of making a final revision of their estimated income during each taxable year.

Housekeepers making their rounds of city shops on week-end marketing trips will find an abundance of vegetables, fish and eggs; good stocks of meat and enough butter to meet the demand. Generally speaking, the only foods in restricted supply today are fresh fruit and all kinds of poultry except, possibly, that sold for the kosher trade.

NAPLES, March 30 -- Twenty-seven States are represented among the fifty-nine Wacs, including two officers, who are closer to the front than any other American service women and New York is best represented with seven, it was learned today from a study of the first available records on the communications platoon now on duty somewhere between here and the battle line.

MOSCOW, March 30 -- Moscow laid before the world today a story of joint Anglo-American political decisions affecting Italy, including retention of the Badoglio government in its present form until Rome is recaptured, in which, it is charged, the Soviet Government's views were not sought and its complaints were not heeded to the detriment of the most effective Allied collaboration for a speedy defeat of Adolf Hitler.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 30 -- Stockholders of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company voted today at a special meeting to amend its charter to authorize issuance of 3,050,000 shares, of which 300,000 will be preferred stock of the par value of $100 each and 2,750,000 shares will be common stock without par value.

Further relief for conscientious objectors now in Federal prisons and an improved status for those in the ranks of the civilian public service camps directed by the Army authorities were recommended at yesterday's session of the New York yearly meeting of the Religious Society of Friends at the meeting House, 221 East Fifteenth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- A Government policy that "all men are entitled to credit" at low interest rates and easy terms eventually may drive small banks, loan agencies and cooperatives from the credit field, A.L.M. Wiggins, president of the American Bankers Association, predicted today to the House Committee on Agriculture.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The willingness of the War and Navy Departments to approve legislation subjecting 4-F's to a draft for essential civilian work brings up at once the question what that work is. Last year the War Manpower Commission listed thirty-five categories, which have since been somewhat amended, and published a questionnaire defining personal activities vital to this production.

After being held almost even in the first quarter, the Andrew Jackson High School basketball team, holder of the New York City Public Schools Athletic League championship, gained complete control of the situation and romped to a 54-to-40 victory over Cardinal Hayes High School quintet, C.H.S.A.A. ruler, at Madison Square Garden yesterday.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total holdings of United States Government securities to have increased $54,698,000 during the week to a new high record.

CHICAGO, March 30 -- May wheat on the Board of Trade here and also in Kansas City and Minneapolis held at ceiling prices throughout the day with cash interests and shorts on the buying side. As the result of the tightness that prevails in the May future, July is coming in for more attention from cash interests and there was a fair run of buying orders.

Thanks to the crocus, spring seems near at hand. Parks and dooryards still bleak and gardens still wintry are ablaze, all of a sudden, with crocus gold and crocus lavender, and the heart of the passer-by is gladdened.

LONDON, March 30 (AP) -- "The Atlantic Charter and its principles remain our dominating aim and purpose," Prime Minister Churchill told the House of Commons today under the prodding of R.W. Sorensen, Laborite.
DENVER, March 30 -- In three speeches today Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio outlined the things for which he stands as a candidate for the Republican nomination for President.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The preliminary parleys of the United States, Canada and Great Britain to explore possibilities for a world aviation agreement have begun, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Congress was kept on tenter-hooks about its Easter holiday today when Representative Clare E. Hoffman, Republican, of Michigan, blocked final approval by the House of the recess resolution by insisting on a quorum to act on a Senate Amendment.

Because Mr. Churchill turned the issue into a vote of confidence or lack of confidence in his own leadership, the House of Commons reversed itself yesterday and voted overwhelmingly against the amendment to the educational bill which would have required that women teachers receive the same pay as men.

LONDON, March 30 -- With more than 115,000 workmen idle in a series of spreading strikes, the harried British Government cracked down today by issuing military draft papers for 25,000 apprentices striking at northern shipyards.

FOR twenty-one years Laird Archer lived in the Balkans, for thirteen of them as foreign director of the Near East Foundation with headquarters in Athens. His duties as head of that great institution, which did much to raise the economic level of the Balkan peoples by teaching and demonstrating new and more scientific methods of agriculture, brought him into direct contact with vast numbers of people.

Rear Admiral Edward J. Marquart, who is retiring as commandant of the Third Naval District, expressed yesterday his appreciation to the press, citizens and officials of New York for their cooperation during his tour of duty here and reviewed his experiences as wartime head of the New York Navy Yard and the "world's busiest port."

Details of a long list of transactions in the preferred stock of Consolidated Film Industries, Inc., by the Setay Company, Inc., between April 1, 1941, and May 31, 1943, were made public yesterday at the New York Stock Exchange, where reports of insiders' trading were released on receipt for the first time.

As part of a campaign to end intolerance and interracial tensions in the city and in the municipal school system, the Board of Education and the United Parents Association have formed an educators' institute to study problems of interracial and intercultural relations faced by teachers, parents and school administrators, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON, March 30 -- For those who are not clear on the current Eire problem and President Roosevelt's "intervention," lend an ear to George Bernard Shaw, who, with tongue in cheek and a well-polished crystal ball, has determined the ultimate result, namely, Eire has won again and President Roosevelt has made his first really stupid mistake.

BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, B.W.I., March 30 (Netherlands News Agency) -- The Anglo-American Caribbean Conference, which opened here March 21, closed today after adopting reports and recommendations on the six major items of its agenda.

" Weird Woman," a melodrama produced by Universal and starring Lon Chaney Jr., will have its local premiere this morning at the Rialto. The supporting cast of the film, which was directed by Reginald LeBorg, includes Anne Gwynne, Ralph Morgan, Evelyn Ankers and Elisabeth Risdon.

DETROIT, March 30 (AP) -- The Black Hawks, who finished fourth in the National Hockey League, sailed into the Stanley Cup play-off finale tonight by winning their third straight game from the Red Wings, 5 to 2, before a crowd of 12,791 and taking the series, four games to one.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Thirty-one Democratic Senators, representing every shade of party opinion, contributed letters of commendation to a folio which was presented to Senator Wagner today by the Affiliated Young Democrats of New York State.

LOS ANGELES, March 20 -- Efforts on the part of New York directors to unseat Harris Hammond as president and a director of the Dominguez Oil Fields Company have been disclosed in a letter by Mr. Hammond to stockholders soliciting their proxies for the annual meeting on April 19.
ANKARA, Turkey, March 29 (U.P.) -- Germany may soon name a Nazi overlord for Hungary as the result of widespread defections from the new Quisling government, Hungarian quarters reported tonight.
Things will seem normal again at Madison Square Garden tonight. Beau Jack, the Augusta (Ga.) Negro will be back in the ring, facing Juan Zurita of Mexico City in the main bout of ten rounds.

LONDON, March 30 -- All sections of the stock markets here were generally cheerful today. With the shipping shares in best demand, many small gains were recorded. Among other industrials, Courtaulds was prominent among the rayons, while steels kept firm.

" Beat-the-tax" buying of so-called luxury items in anticipation of the 20 per cent Federal excise taxes which become effective tomorrow has helped produce sales gains ranging up to 300 per cent over last March in departments handling these goods, merchants here reported yesterday.
Samuel A. Shaw has been appointed sales manager of the silver brazing alloy division of Sherman Co., dealers in gold, platinum and silver.

Today's report from Chungking of the aerial discovery of a mountain in Sikang (Sikong) Province, West China, believed to be higher than Mount Everest comes with especial interest to the writer, who happened to be a member of that American scientific expedition which in 1932 made a year-long exploration of that region, with official Chinese Government permission, and concluded by climbing and surveying what is believed to be the highest mountain peak of Sikang Province.

The program given by Dr. Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall, almost exactly on the anniversary of Rachmaninoff's death last March 28, and coincidently with the establishment of the memorial society which bears his name, began with that lamented composer's Second Symphony and continued with the "Death and Transfiguration" of Richard Strauss.

The six-story apartment building for sixty-five families at 3111 Heath Avenue, in the Bronx, sold by Aaron Rabinowitz, James L. Clare and Adrian P. Burke, trustees for Series F-1, to Otto Spitz for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $165,000.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Back from a 24-day, 14,000-mile trip to Caribbean outposts and South American bases, Mrs. Roosevelt told her news conference today that her journey had given her "a tremendous realization of what the whole of the war requires and what it takes out of men."

ALBANY, March 30 -- Governor Dewey resumed work today on thirty-day legislation after an absence from Albany of several days, and signed more than a score of bills, including the supplemental budget and a measure permitting the Saratoga Racing Association to retain a larger share of pari-mutuel betting pools than other racing associations.

NAPLES, March 30 -- All major activity appeared to have ceased on the three Italian battle fronts yesterday. The Allies broke up two small-scale attacks on the left flank of the beachhead below Rome, while fighting in Cassino tended more and more to become a clash of fixed guns rather than moving men.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Commodity prices in primary markets rose 0.1 per cent during the week ended on March 25, principally because of further advances in prices for hogs and rye and upward adjustment by the Office of Price Administration in ceiling prices for Southern pine boards and dimension lumber.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- In a move to impress legislators and the public with the imperative need of salvaging waste paper and halting its destruction, Representative Calvin D. Johnson, Republican, of Illinois, introduced a concurrent resolution in the House today urging the States to adopt legislation making it unlawful to destroy this strategic war material.

The Spingarn Medal for 1943 "for the highest and noblest achievement by an American Negro during the preceding year or years" has been awarded to Dr. Charles R. Drew, Professor of Surgery at the Howard University College of Medicine, Washington, it was announced yesterday by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, announced yesterday that he was advising the 162,000 members of his union in New York to follow his example in quitting the American Labor party. He also is recommending that the union cease its financial contributions to the party, which amounted to $532,999.39 from 1936 through 1943.

OMAHA, March 30 (AP) -- Seventy-five western Nebraska Republicans attending a Stassen-for-President rally were on record today with a resolution promising support to any Republican in the Presidential primary who could defeat Wendell Willkie for the nomination and any candidate who could defeat a fourth term for President Roosevelt.

LONDON, March 30 (AP) -- George Bernard Shaw declared today that he was willing to bequeath his entire fortune to establish a new forty-two-letter English alphabet that would represent all speech sounds in the language.

CHUNGKING, China, March 30 (Delayed) -- After returning from a visit to the United States, Dr. Wang Shih-chieh, member of a recent good-will mission to England, felt in good spirits this morning. Honest, sincere, temperate and industrious, Dr. Wang is one of the most creditable public servants in the Chinese Government and what he says can be trusted.

MOSCOW, March 31 -- The Soviet Government announced today that the Japanese had been required to carry out their 1941 agreement to liquidate immediately all oil and coal concessions in the northern section of Sakhalin Island twenty-six years in ad vance of their legal deadline, as a condition for renewal yesterday for five years of the restricted convention covering Japanese fishing in Pacific waters adjoining Soviet territories.

The largest amount of public utility securities in a year lifted the total of new bond financing here this week to $56,000,000, the largest weekly figure for new bonds since mid-January, when $79,155,000, representing three diversified flotations, reached the market.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Service Men's Voting Bill draws sharp distinctions between the use of the Federal (short ballot) and the full State ballots. Service members stationed in the United States are restricted, with a few stated exceptions wherein the States cannot provide their own, to the use of the State ballot and are required to apply for it on application forms furnished by the armed services.

DETROIT, March 31 -- Three authorities on anthropology, psychiatry and sociology presented the findings of their branches of education on racial differences at the opening session of the two-day conference of the Intercultural Council of Southeastern Michigan here today.

Work clothing manufacturers will turn from the production of low-end lines, on which they claim ceiling prices do not permit them to make a profit unless immediate relief is granted by OPA, it was asserted by industry spokesmen yesterday.

The Greater New York Fund campaign for $4,500,000 open Tuesday, April 18, under the leadership of J. Stewart Baker, chairman of the board of the Bank of the Manhattan Company. The money will be distributed among 403 voluntary hospitals, health and welfare agencies in New York.

Voicing opposition on constitutional grounds to the bill adopted by the Legislature creating a Tenth Judicial District in Nassau and Suffolk counties, the New York State Bar Association stated yesterday there were also "substantial practical objections" to the legislation now before Governor Dewey for signature.

Old scripts of radio stars have added 4,000 pounds of scrap paper so far to the drive being conducted throughout the nation, it was announced yesterday by the Waste Paper Salvage Committee of New York.

The attack on the Palau Islands is a new high point in the American Pacific offensive. It marks by far the deepest penetration toward Japan that our forces have yet made. The Palau islands are some 4,600 miles southwest of Pearl Harbor, more than a thousand miles west of Truk, and only about 550 miles due east of the Philippines.

Aware that members of the New York Curb Exchange dislike leaving the vicinity of the trading floor to consult the financial records available in the securities department on the eighth floor, the Exchange has installed a library within view of market activity.

According to press reports, the Senate Judiciary Committee has decided to permit the Gillette resolution, to amend the Constitution to permit Senate ratification of treaties by a simple majority, to "just rest in the committee." The chairman of the committee, Senator McCarran, is quoted as saying that "apparently most of the committee favors retention of the present constitutional provision requiring that two-thirds of the Senate ratify all treaties."

Sakhalin, whose fisheries, coal and oil deposits were the subject of a Russo-Japanese agreement renewed Thursday, is separated from the Asiatic mainland by the Strait of Tartry and is 1,000 miles north of Tokyo. It is 600 miles long, sixteen to 105 miles wide and has an area of 24,560 square miles, The Associated Press said.

ALBANY, March 31 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission denied today the Niagara Hudson system's petition for reconsideration of the commission's refusal to permit merger of six of the system's operating utilities and one holding company into a single operating unit.
Mrs. John P. Tilden of the Carlyle will leave today for a fortnight's stay at the Marlboro-Blenheim in Atlantic City.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 31 -- The German legation in Lisbon, Portugal, is spending $6,600 a month for American and British newspapers, magazines and books, a wellinformed traveler from the heica said today. This printed matter is used not only for culling such items as may provide military information for the Germans, but also to use suitable pictures and text for Nazi propaganda.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- More than 40,000 civilian victims of Nazi oppression have escaped as far as Rumania from the path of Germany's retreating armies in the Russian area between the Dniester and Bug Rivers, and several hundred, mainly children, already have received transit through neutral Turkey in their flight from Rumania and Bulgaria, into Palestine, John W. Pehle, executive director of the War Refugee Board, disclosed today.

More than a third of Germany's total supply of oil comes from the Ploesti fields in Rumania. This is the lifeblood which keeps the German war machine roiling on the ground and moving through the skies.

A FORWARD BASE IN NEW GUINEA, March 31 -- At an airfield here, one of the most advanced in New Guinea, I saw a hundred planes leave in an hour, while others like them were rising from other airfields on their way to neutralize Hollandia, last remaining major Japanese air base in New Guinea, just as Rabaul, Kavieng and Wewak have been made unusuable by the enemy.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31 -- A plan for redemption of the Mississippi River Power Company's outstanding $15,161,900 of bonds was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Union Electric Company of Missouri, parent of Mississippi River Power.

Following the recent adoption of the championship schedule of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound, the special regatta series was completed yesterday by the committee headed by C.H. Vanderlaan of the Horseshoe Harbor Club of Larchmont. It consists of eighteen Saturday regattas throughout the season.

No longer compelled to lead a cloistered existence, the Zarief quadruplets were taken from their incubators yesterday morning as they began the third day of their lives. From now on their food, clothing and shelter will resemble that of the other infants at the Sloane Hospital for Women, 620 West 168th Street, and consist, respectively, of formula containing evaporated milk, water and sugar, the usual diaper and shirt combination and cribs in the regular nursery.
Holding within a comparatively narrow range, prices of cotton on the New York Cotton Exchange were somewhat irregular yesterday and closed 3 points lower to 2 points higher than on Thursday.
ALBANY, March 31 -- More frequent physical examinations of civil service employes, retired because of disability, is required under a bill signed today by Governor Dewey.
LONDON, March 31 (AP) -- A broadcast communique:

NEW DELHI, India, March 31 -- Japanese forces invading India along a front of nearly 200 miles have thrust into the vital Manipur Plain above Imphal and have forced the British to abandon Tiddim, their forward base 100 miles below Imphal in Burma, it was disclosed today, but Gen. Sir Claude J.E. Auchinleck, Allied commander in India, said there was no cause for alarm.

President Roosevelt took the logical course yesterday in allowing the Service Vote Bill to become law without his signature. He could not be sure whether more service people or fewer would be able to vote because of this measure. No one could be sure. The bill's sponsors certainly weren't.

LONDON, March 31 -- Two more disquieting incidents were disclosed tonight to have been interpolated in the tragi-comedy of errors that has occasioned widespread fear in Britain and the United States that the ambitious consultative machinery created in the Moscow and Teheran conferences has been steadily deteriorating, with resultant fits of ill temper in Anglo-American-Russian relations.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March 31 (AP) -- Philadelphia's Harold (Jug) McSpaden, gallery favorite, led the first-round parade in the $6,666 Knoxville open golf tournament today but a drove of dark horses and at least one well known shotmaker were dogging his putts.

Brooklyn raised $2,450,077 or approximately 74 per cent of its quota of $3,331,000 and thus claimed first place yesterday in the five-borough drive to raise the city's quota of $22,386,000 for the Red Cross 1944 War Fund. The campaign will continue until the national and local quotas have been met.
The New York Stock Exchange has suspended from dealings Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company common stock, no par value, and has admitted to dealings the new common stock, $3 par value.

A FEW weeks ago very casual mention was made in this corner of Two-Top Bruskin, the two-headed pitcher, who attracted so much attention when he once appeared in a dinner jacket that he asked: "Ain't nobody ever seen no tuxedo before?" Apparently Joseph M. Lazarus of New York reacts the same way about Two-Top because he writes:
LONDON, March 31 (AP)--Britain's war industry strikes spread to 135,000 men idle in the coal mines and shipyards today despite union pleas and a Government crackdown voiding draft deferments.

Price reductions applied to 1943 sales and total taxes of the Aluminum Company of America in 1943 were nearly six times the net income of $42,901,570, according to the annual report to stockholders, announced yesterday. The net income is equal, after preferred dividends, to $7.95 each on 4,496,415 shares of common stock outstanding and compares with $33,361,762, or $5.93 a share earned, in 1942.

Malcolm Muir Jr. of the Yale Club won the Red Cross tournament of the National Squash Tennis Association at the Harvard Club yesterday, scoring an unexpected victory over the top-seeded player, Walter D. Hoag, also of the Yale Club.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Federal Trade Commission today charged five manufacturers of liquid and solid carbon dioxide, the latter commonly known as dry ice, with conspiring to eliminate price competition in violation of Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act.

Miss Elizabeth Spellman, 77 years old, who was struck on the head with a pair of iron blacksmith's tongs by an intruder attempting to rob her home at 172 West 167th Street, the Bronx, died at 2:15 P.M. yesterday in Morrisania Hospital from a fractured skull.

NEW DELHI, India, March 31 (U.P.) -- Admiral Lord Louis Mount-batten's headquarters announced that a small Japanese raiding party striking down from the Somra Hills established a road block between Kohima and Imphal on Wednesday, but that the raiders were forced off the road after damaging a bridge and ambushing "one or two motor transports."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 31 -- Columbia has named Janis Carter for the starring role in "Hero's Girl," a comedy to be based on J. Robert Bren's original screen story of a flying hero and a burlesque actress who had been his "pin-up girl."

AN ADVANCE SOLOMONS BASE, March 29 (Delayed) (AP) -- Liberator bombers gave Truk its "best bombing" today, but in doing so encountered far stronger Zero opposition "than over Rabaul on its worst day."

A quart of milk costs 6 or 7 cents on the farm, and two or three times as much in the grocer's or at the kitchen door. A ton of coal costs three or four times as much in the cellar as it does at the pit mouth. A tank costs so much at the factory in Detroit or Flint and so much at Stalingrad a year ago, or on the Rumanian front today.

LONDON, Saturday, April 1 -- The Bomber Command of the Royal Air Force suffered its heaviest loss in four years and seven months of war Thursday night when in an attack on Nuremberg, spiritual home of national socialism, ninety-four bombers out of close to 1,000 aircraft involved in the operation and 658 trained airmen were lost.

Rear Admiral Edward J. Marquart read orders from Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox that retired him from active service, and turned over command of the Third Naval District to Rear Admiral William R. Munroe at a simple ceremony yesterday on the drill area of the Navy Receiving Station, Pier 92, North River.

For a realistic understanding of the campaign which Wendell Willkie has been making in Wisconsin, as well as a means of measuring what is at issue there in next Tuesday's primary election, it is useful to glance back briefly at the record of the Republican party in Wisconsin as written by its spokesmen on the floor of the House of Representatives.

At the concert given yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra a repetition of Wednesday night's program was presented with Leonard Bernstein, assistant conductor, again on the podium. The list featured the young leader's "Jeremiah" symphony, with Jennie Tourel, mezzo-soprano, as soloist, and also contained the overture to Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro," Mendelssohn's "Italian" symphony, Tschaikovsky's "Romeo and Juliet" and Copland's "El Salon Mexico."

CHICAGO, March 31 -- Many unfilled orders to buy May and cash wheat were reported today in the market on the Board of Trade, and the situation generally is said to be tightening rapidly. May wheat here and in Kansas City and Minneapolis held again at the ceilings prices throughout the day, and in Minneapolis July advanced 1/4 cent a bushel and closed at the permissible maximum.

A storm of protest from tavern owners greeted the twelfth-hour ruling of the Office of Price Administration in Washington yesterday turning down their appeal for a five-cent increase in rye, Scotch and rum drinks. The tavern men had submitted the proposal some time ago to take care of the $3-a- gallon rise in tax, agreeing in turn to absorb the new Federal excise taxes on beers, ales, wines, cordials, liquors and other non-distilled beverages.

In its third wartime survey of the ownership of demand deposits in banks in the Second Federal Reserve District, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday in the April 1 issue of its monthly review that two-thirds to three-quarters of the wartime expansion of these deposits has been accounted for by business balances, and one-quarter to one-third by personal accounts.

LOS ANGELES, March 31 (AP) -- Charlie Chaplin's recital of his relations with Joan Berry ended late today, and a few minutes later, after the prosecution had recalled Miss Berry for brief testimony, the Mann Act case against the actor was ready for final arguments.

A Technicolor motion-picture telling the history of New York's Carnegie Hall will be produced shortly by Boris Morros for United Artists release at a cost of approximately $1,500,000, it was learned yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, March 31 (AP) -- "Game postponed, wet grounds," may disappear from baseball language if a chemically treated resin combination developed by a powder company performs as well on the baseball diamond as it has for the armed forces.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's message to Congress concerning the service vote bill:

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- A program which officials said may prove to be a guilding policy for assuring equitable distribution of scarce merchandise in many fields is being worked out by the War Production Board with an advisory committee from the umbrella industry, it was learned here today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, April 1 (UP) -- A second attack within twenty-four hours on the Japanese base of Woleai and also on Eauripik in the Caroline Islands by Army and Navy bombers from South Pacific bases was announced today by Gen. Douglas MacArthur, who also revealed that Wednesday's attack on Truk included a heavy assault on Dublon Island.

PORTLAND, Ore., March 31--Governor Dewey of New York insistently requested by telephone and telegraph today that petitions to place his name on the Oregon Republican Presidential preference primary May 19 be withdrawn.

LONDON, March 31 -- Maj. Gen. Orde Charles Wingate, leader of an Imperial air-borne Commando force in Burma and one of the most colorful figures in modern warfare, was killed in an airplane crash in Burma last Friday, the War Office announced here today.

Smaller amounts of bonds and larger issues of stock, with public utility financing accounting for more than half of the new securities, featured the new investment market here in March. A total of $82,654,000 in ten new bond issues was offered to the public, against $101,375,000 for sixteen flotations in the preceding month and $120,651,000 for twenty-two emissions in March, 1943.

Marriage is the oldest and most universal of all human institutions. Its ideal condition is the voluntary union of one man and one woman for life. But all marriages are not ideal, and so we find that divorce is almost as ancient as marriage.

The meals for next week, designed for two adults and a school-age child, are built around the "no point, low point" foods that the Government is asking us to consume as a way of using supplies to the best advantage. As a result there is expended only twenty-six of the family's quota of forty-five points in red stamps.
At least eleven attractions will make their debut on the local stage this month, according to the present plans of the Broadway producers. In chronological order they are:
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, April 1 (AP) -- A communique:

NAPLES, March 31 (AP) -- Day and night assaults by American and British heavy bombers on the Bulgarian capital of Sofia have "definite political aspects" and are closely tied up with the Russian advance into the Balkans, a high Allied air officer disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- President Roosevelt permitted today the "States' Rights" Servicemen's Voting Bill to become law without his signature, but in a special message to Congress he called it "wholly inadequate" and appealed to the Senate and House to amend it in order to provide for a wider and freer use of the short Federal ballot.
NEW DELHI, India, March 31 (AP) -- A communique:

Ten hours and thirty-six minutes after it began deliberation in General Sessions Court yesterday, a jury at 10:22 P.M. found Wayne Thomas Lonergan guilty of murder in the second degree. He faces sentence on April 17 of 20 years to life in State's prison.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 31 -- Brazilian expeditionary forces, 12,000 strong, marched through Rio de Janeiro streets today giving the public its first glimpse of the men soon to go overseas. These men are the vanguard of the 100, 000 whom the War Department plans to incorporate into the expeditionary force.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., March 31 -- Wendell L. Willkie rested today at the home of John Cowles, publisher of The Minneapolis Star-Journal and Tribune, and with Mrs. Willkie and the others of his party departed tonight for Lincoln, Neb., where tomorrow he will open his campaign in that State with luncheon and evening speeches.

Wearing a uniform may have thwarted their desires for a new Easter bonnet, but most service women still want "something feminine" for spring. Their preferences, compiled in a series of surveys, range from lipsticks to frilly housecoats--although certain utilitarian individuals prefer pass cases and dictionaries.

Lewis W. Douglas retires from public service for a needed rest, resigning from his post as deputy administrator of the War Shipping Administration. With the President, the country hopes that his retirement is only temporary and that he will return to some wartime or peacetime responsibility.
From New York's haughtiest mink and ermine salons to the lowliest movie at a prairie whistle stop, spending for pleasure goes on a premium basis throughout the nation today.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- Regulations designed to assure each retail coal dealer a fair share of anthracite in the 1944-1945 coal year which begins tomorrow, were announced today by the Solid Fuels Administration.

Answering the question, "After the war, do you intend to move from the city or town you now live in?" 19 per cent said "yes," it was revealed by the Reader-Consumer Panel survey of The American Home. On purchases, when available, 39 per cent voiced a preference for automobiles.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- Walter Winchell, radio commentator, was not stripped of his Navy uniform, Representative Warren G. Magnuson, Washington Democrat, told the House yesterday in taking issue with statements made earlier this week by Representative Clare E. Hoffman, Michigan Republican, a Winchell critic.

Forty-six crates, filled with children's dresses, sweaters, ski suits and layettes, stood yesterday in the Save the Children Federation's workroom at 55 East Eighth Street. This marked the first shipment of clothing, bound for neutral Sweden, being sent to aid some 30,000 young war refugees there through the federation's recently formed overseas activities committee.

A comprehensive collection of the work of the Puerto Rican artist Esteban Soriano will go on view on Monday at the new building of the Institute for International Democracy, 23 West Twenty-sixth Street. It will include oils, water-colors, temperas and ceramics.

The strategic location of the Pacific Islands will make their administration by military officers the object of worldwide attention, Ralph A. Bard, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, told forty-seven graduates of the Naval School of Military Government and Administration yesterday.

LONDON, March 31 -- News of large-scale battle by a Polish underground army in central Poland against an Elite Guard brigade of 4,000 Germans reached London Simultaneously with the release of an appeal by Polish Socialists for arms to combat the mass removal of Poles for slave labor in the Reich.

A delegation of 102 high school and college students from twenty State yesterday declared their 100 per cent support of a strong world federation plan at a meeting at Teachers College, Columbia University. The meeting, attended by students from seventy-five school groups, opened a three-day convention of the Student Federalists, an affiliate of Federal Union, Inc., organized by Clarence K. Streit, author of "Union Now."

ALGIERS, March 31 -- Neither complete freedom of labor nor a forty-hour week will be possible for some time after the liberation of France, Adrien Tixier, Commissioner of Social Affairs, warned the Consultative Assembly today in a long review of the social problems that will face any provisional government.

LONDON, Saturday, April 1 -- Russian troops hurling thousands of exhausted Germans back into the Odessa bottleneck on the Black Sea yesterday captured the ancient fortress of Ochakov, thirty-eight miles east of the big port, and to the west cut the main Axis escape route into Rumania by seizing Sipotyany on the Odessa-Kishinev-Jassy railway, Moscow announced today.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 31 -- Postponement of the Democratic National Convention, which is scheduled to open in Chicago on July 19, was urged today by party leaders of California and Texas on the ground that the present plans conflict with the Democratic State Convention in California and the party primaries in Texas.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Adolf A. Berle, assistant secretary of state, and Edward Warner, vice chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, are going to London for exploratory talks about civil aviation with the British Government. The official announcement today said similar exploratory conversations with the Russian Government would take place in Washington within the next two weeks.

LAKEWOOD, N.Y., March 31 -- Determined to make up for lost time regardless of cost or consequence, Manager Mel Ott drove his Giants through a double workout today that reminded one of the arduous sessions an unrelenting John McGraw used to prescribe for his men under a broiling Texas sun years ago.

Unable to agree with the owners on terms for leasing the Manhattan Towers Hotel at 2162-8 Broadway, the United States Navy is taking over the entire building under court order to help solve the problem of housing hundreds of Waves now unable to find suitable living quarters here.

The teachers of the city of New Haven are mostly women and white. Where a man is employed he receives substantially more per year than the women who occupy the same kind of position. In the high schools we have women of experience, they are stable and capable, but let a man appear and a reward of $500 is put upon his head.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Incomes of dependents would be exempt from Federal taxation and age would no longer be a criterion for determining dependency, under proposals which the Ways and Means Committee approved today in completing informal consideration of a simplified income tax bill.

ST. LOUIS, March 31 (AP) -- Politics in art started a controversy today over the removal of eleven paintings, most of them critical of the New Deal, from an exhibition at the Artists' Guild by two St. Louis women painters.

The report of the Borg-Warner Corporation and its subsidiaries for last year, issued by C.S. Davis, president, for publication today, shows a net profit of $7,841,359, or $3.36 a share on the outstanding common stock. In 1942 net income was $7,215,599, equal to $3.09 a common share.

Sales of municipal bonds through competitive bidding scheduled for next week aggregate $7,010,500, compared with this week's revised total of $7,712,500, according to the Daily Bond Buyer. The weekly average for 1944 to date now stands at $15,732,463.

" Ukraine in Flames," a feature-length Soviet documentary dealing with the battle for the liberation of the Ukraine, will have its local premiere this morning at the Stanley. An official record, the picture was filmed by twenty-four camera men, who advanced with the troops in the field.

Retail trade here this week reflected the combined influences of Easter shopping and "beat-the-tax" buying of merchandise coming under the 20 per cent Federal excise levies today. The result was an increase over last year estimated as high as 40 per cent by some store executives. Sales gains in taxable items ranged up to 300 per cent or more.

Cash purchases of luxury goods, such as antiques, paintings, jewels and furs, have increased steadily in recent weeks, even before the rush to avoid payment of the new excise taxes, a survey showed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 31--The State Department said today that it would collaborate with the Conference of Allied Ministers of Education in London in forming a United Nations organization for educational and cultural reconstruction in the war-torn countries outside the Axis.

The third Palm Sunday since the United States has been in the war will be celebrated tomorrow. Pastors in their sermons will point out that palm branches are waved as a signal of victory. Tomorrow will usher in Holy Week, culminating in Easter on April 9.

Bonds called for payment in March before maturity dates aggregated $69,675,000, compared with $78,446,000 in the preceding month and $32,384,000 in March, 1943. Last month's prepayments were the smallest for any month since November and the least for a March since 1942.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The college air crew training phase of the Army Air Forces program, in which eighty-one colleges and universities have taken part, will be ended June 30.

Since politics are in the air, along with April, list Frank Craven and Billie Burke as among Broadway's favorite sons and daughters. Unfortunately in most elections, there is more to the matter than just the candidates; there also are platforms.
Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month was the largest since May of 1943, and the most active of any March since 1937, with the exception of the corresponding month of last year.

All of a sudden quadruplets and then triplets are born in the same New York hospital. In addition we have the recent unauthenticated announcement that quintuplets have appeared in Argentina. For a time a war always raises the birth rate. Can it be that it does as much for twins, triplets, quadruplets and quintuplets?

Sitting as a Board of Reapportionment, the City Council received yesterday maps and boundary descriptions of sixty-seven new Assembly districts in the city, replacing the present sixty-two. The Council fixed April 18 at 1 P.M. as the date for final action on the new set-up, which will apply in the Aug. 1 primary election and the general election in November.

Following is the text of the Soviet-Japanese protocol on the liquidation of Japanese oil and coal concessions in northern Sakhalin, as recorded by the United States Foreign Broadcast Intelligence Service from an English-language wireless transmission by the Tokyo Domei agency:

Gunnar Pihl, Berlin correspondent for the Swedish paper Sydsvenska Dagbladet, who was expelled from the Reich in August, 1943, has contracted to write his story of Germany at war for Alfred Knopf. The book, now titled "Germany: The Last Phase," will be brought out June 12.

Russian parachutists, "with the help of some Rumanian citizens, have destroyed a six-kilometer stretch of an important railway running westward from the River Sereth, below Cernauti, the British Broadcasting Corporation reported yesterday in a broadcast recorded at the Columbia Broadcasting System short-wave listening station.

Further progress on the comeback trail was made yesterday by the stock market, producing an irregularly higher closing, but there was no appreciable enlargement in business.
