Caution remained the market's dominant characteristic, with only a further slight response to the technical implications furnished on Thursday.

WEST POINT, N.Y., March 31 -- Belting out seventeen hits, including three home runs and five doubles, the Dodgers today overwhelmed Capt. Paul Amen's West Point Cadets, 18 to 4, in the twice-postponed exhibition game on Doubleday Field.

COUNT CARLO SFORZA'S "Contemporary Italy: Its Intellectual and Moral Origins"* is a book that eludes clear definition. Part history, part autobiography, a helter-skelter mingling of millennial perspectives and easy, intimate anecdotes, it leaves the reader wondering whether to be exasperated by its chaotic form or delighted by the quality of Sforza's character.

Failure of mills that do not spin their own yarns to keep within dollars-and-cents ceiling prices in their bids submitted to the Quartermaster Corps of the Army on flannel shirtings has resulted in an effort on the part of the QMC to have exceptions made by the Office of Price Administration for the mills concerned, it was learned yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 31 -- Dr. Henry F. Grady, ranking American member of the Allied Control Commission in Italy, asserted today that there was "complete unanimity" among the peoples of occupied Italy for the ousting of King Victor Emmanuel.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 31 -- Chuckle, Sam Feinberg's 5-year-old mare, scored a head victory over H. A. Catalano's Zacabrand today in the six-furlong Clearwater Purse at Tropical Park. W. W. Crenshaw's Joe Burger took the show, two lengths behind.

OTTAWA, March 31 -- The forthcoming London meeting of British Commonwealth Prime Ministers will take the form of a general exchange of views on the war situation, on war policies and post-war matters, Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King told the House of Commons today.

Lieut. (jg) Adam A. Rother of the Coast Guard was sentenced to twenty-five years to life at hard labor in Sing Sing Prison yesterday by Judge Thomas J. Walsh in Richmond County Court for the slaying of Miss Rita Costello, 28 years old, a secretary, of 140 Crescent Avenue, New Brighton.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Representative John M. Coffee, Democrat, of Washington, urged in the House today a Department of Justice investigation of Miss Vivien Kellems of Westport, Conn., who some months ago in an address at Kansas City advised business men to refuse to pay their income taxes.

Persecution of Jews in German-occupied Hungary began yesterday with official publication of severe restrictive measures based on the Nazi Nuremberg Laws, the German radio reported in a broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York.

More than 7,000,000 questions have been answered during the last twenty-two years by John W. Cooper, clerk in the Information Bureau of Grand Central Terminal, who will retire today on his seventieth birthday.

The average New York City mother was named as "one of the greatest food experts and one of the greatest financiers" by Mayor La Guardia yesterday in a talk to students at Brooklyn Technical High School on the importance of obeying price ceilings.

Centralized power, red tape and a "multiplicity of orders and directives" in the Office of Price Administration are seriously handicapping the administrative work of the Federal agency and adversely affecting New York rent control, Louis H. Pink declared last night as he relinquished his job as rent director for this area.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- A 10 per cent increase in production of landing craft in the next two months to make sure that we have more than enough for "the invasions to come" was urged today by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, after an inspection of amphibious training bases in Maryland and Virginia.

NAPLES, March 31 -- The Germans have extended their hold in Cassino, sending troops from dominating positions east of Abbey Hill to occupy Hill 146, below Hangman's Hill. [Hill 202 and Hangman's Hill were evacuated by the Allies on Monday.]

An air crash in the IndiaBurma theatre has robbed the United Nations of one of their most brilliant leaders in the war against Japan, Maj. Gen. Orde Charles Wingate, Britain's eccentric bearded soldier- genius, whose fabulous exploits had established him as the "Lawrence of Arabia" of this war.

ALBANY, March 31 -- The State closed its 1943-44 fiscal year tonight with a Treasury surplus of about $163,000,000, or $15,000,000 more than Governor Dewey expected when he submitted his executive budget on Jan. 31.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Measures to freeze in war-important jobs men qualified for limited service in the armed forces have been taken by the Selective Service system, according to Col. Francis V. Keesling Jr., its legislative representative.

MOSCOW, March 31 -- The Red Army's sweeping gains along the whole front, from the Carpathians to the Bug estuary, indicate that the Russian Command is determined to exploit its advantages fully. In no sector has the enemy been able to disengage.

What's left of the New York State trout fishermen after the depredations made by another year of war will have their big day in all but eighteen of the northern counties today. Dawn will find them ranging the lakes and streams in pursuit of browns, rainbows, brooks and lakers, and if predictions have any value the fishing should be good.

The British Royal Air Force celebrates its twenty-sixth birthday today, and all the world that values freedom salutes it. For to it goes the credit for having saved the flame of liberty in the British Isles when everywhere else in Europe it was being extinguished by the flood of modern barbarism.

An indictment alleging the making of false statements was handed up in Federal court yesterday against Thomas V. De Lorenzo, who in February was re-elected to the presidency of Local 365, Brewster Aeronautical Corporation unit of the Automobile Workers.

LONDON, March 31 -- The last business day of the week saw the stock markets here cheerful and with activity greater than usual. Further rises of 1/16 each were recorded in the gilt-edge market, which was pleased by the latest report on public savings figures.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -Another instance in which an American transport plane was accidentally shot down by friendly guns was revealed today by the War Department and the British Admiralty.

A society of nations wherein all nations rank equally was proposed last night by Dean Harry Carman of Columbia College, Columbia University, as the only type of international organization offering any hope for lasting peace. He spoke at a meeting sponsored by the Associations of Teachers of Social Studies and English held in the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- The Senate Banking Committee, considering the bill to extend the life of the Federal Price Control Act beyond June 30, was told today by A.L.M. Wiggins, president of the American Bankers Association, that "the welfare of the banks is at stake in this question before you."

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Although eliminated from a House appropriations bill, the Federal school luncheon system was a live subject on Capitol Hill this week, with two bills for its continuance introduced in the Senate, and Representative Jerry Voorhis, Democrat of California, defending the program on the House floor.

" La Republique n'a pas besoin desavants," declared Coffinhal of the National Convention of "Friends of the People" during the Reign of Terror of the French Revolution in 1794, when he sentenced Antoine-Laurent Lavoisier the creator of modern chemistry, to confiscation of his property and execution within twenty-four hours.

The March Kings County grand jury was continued as a working panel yesterday by Judge Louis Goldstein until April 28 at the request of Acting District Attorney Thomas Cradock Hughes. Judge Goldstein and Mr. Hughes directed the jurors last Tuesday to investigate charges made recently by Mayor La Guardia and Police Commissioner Valentine that "things have not been satisfactory in Brooklyn."

The second of the three Concert-Salutes to the United Nations being given by the congregation of Temple Emanu-El in its Assembly Hall was presented yesterday afternoon in honor of England. The first Salute was for France, and the last will be for Russia.
A comiqld brooxtcaot from Moscow and reportea by the Eederl Oornmutications Ootsion :

The Wabash Railroad Company retired $19,213,382 of its outstanding funded debt last year and $1,890,000 of bonds of a subsidiary guaranteed as to principal and interest by the Wabash, according to Norman B. Pitcairn, president, in the company's annual report for 1943.

Mobile control forces to deal with possible outbreaks of malaria in any area are being organized under the auspices of the United States Public Health Service as a measure for the protection of the civilian population against returning malaria carriers among the armed forces, according to reports in The American Journal of Public Health.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 31 (AP) -- Adolph Kiefer, chief specialist at the Bainbridge (Md.) Naval Training Station, tonight smashed his American record for the 300-yard individual medley by almost five seconds in the men's national A.A.U. indoor swimming championships. He was clocked in 3:23.9.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- American sea and air power must be maintained after the war as a guarantee of peace, James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy, declared tonight before the National Geographic Society.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 31 -- With the first exhibition game for his reconstructed ball club scheduled tomorrow, Manager Joe McCarthy put the finishing touches today on the training of the Yankees -- indoors.

Beau Jack had a tough workout with Juan Zurita in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. The Augusta (Ga.) Negro won the decision all right, but he had to go through some confusing times with the tricky Zurita before the clash was over.

LONDON, March 31 (U.P.) -- Allied air chiefs prepared today to close their records on the greatest month in the history of air war -- a month in which American planes bombed Berlin for the first time and the Royal Air Force introduced a six-ton blockbuster.

PEARL HARBOR, March 31 -- Day and night bombing of Truk, initiated this week in an unprecedented junction of separate air forces under the command of Gen. Douglas MacArthur and Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, has been continued.

Charles D. Sloat, paymaster for the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation of Long Island City, Queens, was accused last night of appropriating to his own use petty cash and money he had collected from plant workers for Red Cross and other charitable drives.
WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, March 30 (Delayed) (AP) -- Thousands of New Jersey troops are in action on the main Italian front.

Promise of a "dream" fabric that we won't have to wait for until after the war was held out yesterday in an announcement by the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation that a new line of curtain and drapery fabrics made of drawn-glass yarns will be available to home decorators within the next few months.
Martin J. Porter, in 784 Park Ave; Harry Green, in 888 Park Ave -- Frances R. Jaffin, broker.

RICHMOND, Va., March 31--Patents on potential materials for post-war prefabricated buildings and one on a "pistol rocket" stand out among the 611 listed as granted in the current issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BOMBER BASE, Thirteenth United States Air Force, March 29 (Delayed) (AP) -- American airmen raced over 1,000 miles of ocean in two night reconnaissance Liberators to see which land-based United States planes from the South Pacific would drop the first bomb on Truk.

In your columns today, in "Colleges Train for Peace," you mention several out-of-town colleges that are preparing students to help in post-war work abroad. It may interest your readers to know that Columbia University is sponsoring a course organized at the request of ORT in the School of International Administration.

HONOLULU, T.H., March 31 -- Judge Delbert E. Metzger of the Federal court ruled today that martial law was no longer necessary in Hawaii. He issued a writ of habeas corpus freeing Lloyd C. Duncan from the city and county jail, where he had been held under a ruling of the Provost Court.

Postponed because of the fire that damaged the Thirteenth Regiment Armory, the forty-first annual P.S.A.L. indoor track and field championships will be staged this afternoon in Brooklyn's Jefferson and Sumner Avenue drill shed, with New Utrecht High favored to keep the title it regained last year after a lapse of ten years.

The stores are "on the beam" this spring when it comes to fashions for the coke crowd. The fashions are "hep," which means that 'teen-agers actually have a wide selection of clothes from which to choose that are up-to-the-minute styles appropriately designed for them.

The application of the field of osteopathy toward relieving the strain of war for both civilians and members of the armed forces was emphasized yesterday at the opening of the twenty-fourth annual convention of the Eastern Osteopathic Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 1 -- The attitude on the West Coast now is different from the mood shown in the early days of the war when Japanese submarines were patroling the coastwise shipping lanes, in the period just before the battle of Midway, when some kind of enemy attack, even an attempt at invasion, was looked upon as a strong probability.

That the United States will cooperate with other nations after the war to help rebuild the school systems of Europe became evident yesterday with the publication of the State Department's position on this question. In a detailed statement of policy, Secretary Hull announced that this country would join with the United Nations in sponsoring an international educational and cultural program.

The draft-Roosevelt movement took on new impetus and greater authority last night as Senator Robert F. Wagner, leading proponent of the New Deal in Congress and close personal friend of President Roosevelt, made a ringing speech urging his renomination at a Democratic unity dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ERNEST HEMINGWAY himself, much less his readers, will not likely recognize the author's story of Cuban insurrection, "To Have and Have Not," when it reaches the screen some months hence under the Warner Brothers banner.

The first group of 125 "temporary" patrolmen, all over the draft age of 38 and who will receive $2,000 a year for service for the duration and six months after the war, were sworn in by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine at ceremonies in the Line-up Gallery at Police Headquarters yesterday.

SALVADOR DE MADARIAGA is a serious man. He has dedicated his life to a number of exacting pursuits -- including mining engineering, pacifism, the League of Nations, and the writing of poetry, biography, history and books on the flux and flow of international affairs.

MANY readers must have asked themselves, Why is so much of modern poetry and a certain amount of modern prose, unintelligible? And when I say unintelligible, I do not mean merely difficult, but actually unintelligible.

Seventy thousand tons of "enchanted cargo" rumbled into the Mott Haven yards in the Bronx late yesterday afternoon. "A page out of the Arabian Nights," said Roland Butler, the purveyor of fact and fancy. He said a mouthful.

An Easter Sunday "brunch," incorporating a picturesque feature for the traditional Easter parade, is being planned by the Monte Carlo restaurant, Madison Avenue at Fifty-fourth Street, in cooperation with the Pan-American Coffee Bureau, to raise funds for the American Red Cross.

BOSTON, April 1 -- New England worried more than normally this week about a place in the post-war aviation sun. Eyes of air-minded millions in a region that pioneered in commercial airlines after the first World War turned anxiously toward Washington, where Civil Aeronautics Board hearings were held on augmented service to and from the Boston Airport.

WHAT is meant, or rather should be meant, by the formula "Music is international"? For anyone familiar with music, it seems to me that it cannot mean anything else but that the alphabet and vocabulary of music are universal.

THE story begins in novel fashion. Valerie Martin is the first heroine we Can remember who finds her own true love in the person of a fellow inmate at a home for mental eases. It is a very elegant establishment , to be sure.

OTTAWA, April 1 -- After the liveliest debate in a long time, the Quebec Legislature by a vote of 37 to 10 last night passed the Government bill expropriating the electrical and gas distribution system of Montreal Light, Heat and Power Consolidated as a first step toward setting up a Quebec hydroelectric commission.

LONDON, April 1 -- Much current diplomacy is directed toward minimizing the usefulness of enemy listening-posts in neutral territory. The object is to decrease the dangers of espionage at a time when great and decisive military operations are being prepared.
Competitive situations which may be emphasized because of the new Federal excise taxes, which became effective yesterday, are receiving attention in retail circles.

The proposal that Germany and Japan be throttled industrially, that is, prevented from producing material that could be used in war, meets with strong editorial disapproval in Industrial and Engineering Chemistry. The editor maintains that a potential enemy cannot be "disarmed for keeps" by rationing his oil and nitrogen, as R.E. McConnell, special assistant to the Secretary of the Treasury and former president of General Aniline and Film Corporation, thinks.

To meet the war-induced spread of juvenile delinquency to all economic segments of the population, the Jewish Board of Guardians will extend its guidance work among children and parents to middle-income group families, it was announced yesterday by Herschel Alt, executive director of the agency.

THIS short book introduces the general reader to the orthodox religio-cosmic background of Elizabethan thought. It attempts to clarify and systematize an exceedingly complicated subject: the great universal synthesis inherited from medieval scholasticism, built up through centuries from various elements of Christian, Classic and Eastern philosophy, science, religion, folklore, magic and superstition.

EDWARD DMYTRYK, who came up out of a maze of twenty-seven B pictures last year to direct "Hitler's Children," "Behind the Rising Sun" and the soon-due "Tender Comrade," specializes in making great lovers out of cowboys, suffering women out of jitterbugs, and Japs out of Mexicans.

I enjoyed "Humor From the Underground" in THE TIMES Magazine, though most of it is old stuff. (And good stuff, at that.) Those little pickups show how jokes wander. The one ascribed to Holland I have known for years -- from Norwegian sources.

Retail trade here last week reflected the combined effects of active Easter shopping and the climax of "beat-the-tax" buying of so-called luxury items subject to the 20 per cent Federal excise levy. Estimates indicated that department stores here had increases ranging up to 40 per cent or more over the like week last year.

BREWSTER, N.Y., April 1 -- The New York State trout season opened too early this year. That was the concensus of fishermen in this neighborhood when the first day was over and, as nearly as could be ascertained from a preliminary check, the results were on the meager side.

FROM Florida comes confirmation that Philip Barry is at work on a new play for next season. Theresa Helhurn of the Theatre Guild is down there, and while Mr. B. reports it's too early to say much, he did say that he and Miss Helburn are "having a good time talking and walking about it."

LONDON, April 1 -- The unrelenting Red Army drive into Poland and the efforts of the Russian High Command to safeguard the flank of the more important northern advance by knocking Rumania out of the war and seizing the Ploesti oil fields have given a good indication in the last week of Soviet military strategy during the decisive months of 1944.

ALBANY, April 1 -- Controller Frank C. Moore announced today a new schedule permitting increased traveling expenses for State employes, effective immediately, and to be in effect for the duration of the war and six months thereafter.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- With a twelve-day recess before them members of the Senate gave scant attention today to consideration of the message of President Roosevelt explaining that he had permitted the "States' Rights" Service Men's Voting Bill to become law but calling the measure "wholly inadequate" and urging Congress to amend the law to provide for a wider use of the short Federal ballot.

The city's shopping and theatre crowds paid their shares in the increased luxury taxes, which went into effect yesterday, with a mixture of willingness and resignation, offering scarcely any protests.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 1 (AP) -- It is for the people at home, Gov. John W. Bricker declared today, to see that the way of life for which our soldiers fight shall not become "a battlefield illusion."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sunday, April 2 -- After two days of new peace negotiations in Moscow, Dr. Juho K. Paasikivi of Finland has obtained moderation in Russia's armistice terms, it was reported reliably today, and the Finnish Parliament will meet tomorrow to hear what was described as "an important Government announcement."

ONE of the more startling surprises that has bug-eyed film experts of late has been the peculiar reaction of the public to "Tunisian Victory." This film came supremely recommended. It is the first joint screen release of the United States and British Governments.

A SUDDEN awakening to what the new excise taxes meant on many purchases put Christmas crowds into the stores last week and sales totals soared in jewelry, liquor, toilet goods and handbag sections. The rush was not as large in customers or volume as the big beat-the-tax stampede of October, 1942, but percentage gains were magnified by two factors.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 1 -- Harold (Jug) McSpaden, Philadelphia pro, maintained mastership of the field today by a back-nine rally that netted a one-under-par 69 in Knoxville's first annual war bond golf tournament.

LIKE Bulldog Drummond, Destry, and a whole grist of Hollywood perennials, W.C. Fields has returned. The bland visage of the famed comedian, too long absent from the screen, will be seen again shortly in "Follow the Boys," which concerns itself with the activities of USO-Camp Shows and the Hollywood Victory Committee.

THE Moscow radio is silent except for a steady hum from a multitude of loudspeakers located at many corners throughout the vast city. On the streets you see people whose costumes reflect their origin in every corner of the U.S.S.R., which in territory covers one-sixth of the earth's surface, and whose population totals 190,000,000, ranging from the slant-eyed, dark-haired, yellow-skinned people of Asia to blond huskies of the North, with nearly every variation in between.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- In the hope of speeding a decision on methods of terminating war contracts, the Special Committee on Post-War Economic Policy and Planning of the Senate announced today that it would recommend the creation of an Office of Director of Contract Settlements, to be set up in the Office of War Mobilization.

THERE are only four men in the forward observer detail of a field artillery battalion: The forward observer himself, who is a commissioned officer; an instrument corporal, a wire telephone operator and a radio man.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., April 1 -- With Frenchy Bordagaray, sole remaining holdout, appearing today for his third visit and signing his contract shortly after his arrival, the Dodgers added one out-fielder, only to be faced with the threat of losing another.

Harvard University's first major wartime group of appointments to strengthen its faculty of arts and sciences for the demands of the post-war years has been announced by President James B. Conant with the naming of seven men to permanent professorial rank.

NAPLES, April 1 -- A possible sequel to the Russian recognition of Premier Pietro Badoglio's government came today when the Italian Communists, headed by the newly arrived "Ercole," waived the issue of King Victor Emmanuel's abdication until such time as "the entire nation" will have an opportunity freely to consider it.

Two hundred distinguished judges, professors and officials of national and international experience have made public a 173-page report setting forth proposals for "the international law of the future" and for the organization of a world community of states. The report is the result of discussions in various parts of the United States and Canada over a period of almost two years.

James A. Burke, Borough President of Queens, attacked yesterday Mayor La Guardia's suggestion for a new $50,000,000 transportation tax as "nothing more" than imposition of a 10-cent subway fare. In a statement added before broadcast time to a prepared address over the municipal station, WNYC, Mr. Burke termed the proposal a "red herring" and the climax to a "perfect April Fool's day."

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., April 1 -- A stately Afghan hound was given the highest award in the eighteenth annual exhibition of the Springfield Kennel Club this evening. Best in show went to Champion All Khyber, owned by Mrs. Leah P. McConaha of Great Neck, L.I., and handled by John H. Hill.

The traditional calm of Lotos Club elections has been shattered this year by a dispute over the management of the organization, which has caused two groups to nominate rival slates, it was learned yesterday.
The British White Paper, stopping Jewish immigration to Palestine, was denounced by rabbis in sermons here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (U.P.) -- The Army and Navy Journal, unofficial service magazine, editorially criticized the Allies' conduct of the war in Italy today, asserting that the campaign had "not only provided us with lessons, but has furnished the enemy with them."

WILL HAYS' annual report on the state of the cinema, and in particular his advocacy of a free world market for films after the war, was easily the most significant development of an otherwise exceptionally quiet week along the movie front.

LONDON, April 1 -- Prime Minister Churchill has had his vote of confidence. It was overwhelmingly in favor of his continuing to lead this country in war. Any other outcome of the artificially created Parliamentary crisis was unthinkable. But it is doubtful if in making the recalcitrant members swallow their principles the Prime Minister has enhanced his prestige with either the House of Commons or the people.

ONE of the outstanding oneman shows of the season is made up of ten paintings -- recent oils by Russell Cowles, at Kraushaar's. The artist, who began as an illustrator and Prix de Rome winner, is one of the growing number of American top-flight painters who have worked through abstraction as a training and discipline and incorporated what it had to give in subsequent representational work.

According to Nature, a French stamp-collector's periodical, L'Echangiste Universel, a four-franc postage stamp has been issued to commemorate the anniversary of the birth of Lavoisier in 1743. The information is also imparted that since 1942 the bronze statue of Lavoisier, which stood at the north end of the Madeleine in Paris, has fallen prey to the "service de la recuperation des metaux."

CONVENIENTLY, if a little ironically, fate contrived openings last week that served to focus attention upon two academies, one right-wing, the other left. Reference is made to the 118th annual of the National Academy, now current, through April 25, in that venerable organization's home, 1083 Fifth Avenue, and to the eighth annual of the group called American Abstract Artists, which may be visited through next Saturday at the Mortimer Brandt Gallery.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Sales of wholesalers, as reported by 2,554 establishments, gained 5 per cent in February over February of last year, according to an announcement released today by J.C. Capt, Director of the Census. Sales volumes were virtually the same in January and February this year, but the combined sales of the first two months of 1944 were 6 per cent over the volume recorded for the same period in 1943.

After a five-month lapse during which time followers of the sport of kings have been reluctantly obliged to believe what they read from afar rather than what they see at first hand, racing returns to New York next Saturday with the spring meeting of the Metropolitan Jockey Club at Jamaica.

LONDON, Sunday, April 2 -- Red Army forces pushing westward along the marshy Black Sea coast rolled to within twenty-four miles east of Odessa yesterday, capturing the town of Koblevo, while to the northwest other Soviet troops hurled the reeling Germans fifteen miles southward across the Ukrainian steppes to Serbka, thirty-three miles north of Odessa.

Ethelbert Smith said that sometimes time moves as fast as a Mustang P-51 or a Thunderbolt P-47, and sometimes time just stands still. Here, for instance, it is April 2, 1944, but he finds that in the matter of Clausewitz and our smashing the Axis time has been standing still since August, 1943, when he first set down a few words on the subject.

OMAHA, Neb., April 1 (AP) -- Palmer Hoyt, Oregon publisher and former domestic director for the Office of War Information, urged today the establishment of a Senate committee to investigate "the whole matter of war news."

As its twentieth annual benefit production of Gilbert and Sullivan operettas, the Blue Hill Troupe -- one of New York's best-known companies of amateur Savoyards -- will present performances of "H.M.S. Pinafore" and "Trial by Jury" on the evenings of April 20, 21 and 22, as well as a children's matinee on April 22, at the Heckscher Theatre.
LONDON, Sunday, April 2 (AP) -- The Russian Saturday midnight supplementary communique as broadcast from Moscow:

Seventy to seventy-five per cent of the United States soldiers transported to overseas destinations, between Dec. 7, 1941, and Feb. 29, 1944, have been carried in American flag vessels, according to an announcement made here yesterday by Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute.

The nation this time will not "suffer the humiliation of seeing veterans in breadlines or selling apples in the street," Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, declared yesterday, but he warned that the Government alone could not do the full job of rehabilitation and re-employment without aid from industry, labor and private social agencies.

To help defray the increased wartime cost of free care given at the New York Infirmary for Women and Children, the Auxiliary of that institution has taken over as a benefit the performance of Lillian Hellman's new play, "The Searching Wind," for the night of April 14 at the Fulton Theatre.

Eighteen hundred delegates representing 8,000 city firemen were instructed yesterday by the executive board of the Uniformed Firemen's Association to advise the men not to sign a contract that would grant a $420 cost of living bonus and waive any right to contest by litigation or otherwise payment for overtime work or extra tours of duty.

ALBANY, April 1 -- By authority of a law implementing a constitutional amendment approved by the people in November, the division of commerce of the executive department became today a full-fledged department of the State government, the first new department since 1927.

The Hotel Continental at Cassino seems to be quite new and well built. Perhaps it is, or was, one of those shining architectural faces that fascism liked to present to the foreign visitor. Mussolini, as is well known, did not much care for ruins. He liked his Italy to live in the present.
CAMBRIDGE, England, April 1 (AP) -- Dr. J. Frank Dobie said tonight that Texas was "badly in need of a new Governor," but in the words of the late President Coolidge he "did not choose to run."

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Dean C. Mildred Thompson of Vassar College has been appointed a member of the United States delegation to the Conference of Allied Ministers of Education in London, the State Department announced today.

THIS is a discussion of seasonings -- wine vinegars and dried herbs -- which, though not essential, do much to make eating enjoyable. The use of such things, pleasant at any time, is particularly desirable at present as a means of imparting interest and variety to rationed menus.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 1 -- At least fifty persons were killed and more than 150 seriously wounded when thirty American four-motored bombers in three waves swooped out of a cloud formation at 15,000 feet just before 11 o'clock this morning and rained explosive and phosphorus incendiary bombs on the north-eastern Swiss town of Schaffhausen.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Dies Committee is back in the national spotlight and with its latest appearance it is stepping boldly and deeply into the 1944 Presidential-Congressional campaign. Its targets are still the American Reds, Bundists and Fascists and others who, it contends, would destroy Congress and the country, but the lines of its fire point directly into the political arena. This is conceded in Washington.

Vice President Henry A. Wallace declared yesterday that "the people of the United States are overwhelmingly for a peace which can be enforced under international law, which has definite authority behind it."

The Japanese fleet last week refused the most daring challenge the American Navy has yet offered. In another spectacular foray in force into Japanese waters, carriers and battleships attacked the Palau Islands, westernmost end of the Carolines chain. The Navy was within 550 miles of Mindanao in the Philippines.

VIGNETTES of a recent Southern trip remain vivid. In Palm Beach convalescent service men and women in sandals and monk-like robes of rough, brown material, shuffle through the spacious halls of the Breakers, de luxe hostelry of the East Coast, where the leisured made merry before the war.

ALGIERS, April 1 (AP) -- The Assembly finished its third general session today and adjourned until May after having adopted a bill embodying new controls over the management and editing of newspapers in liberated France.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration announced today that, effective immediately, lightweight newsprint may be sold by producers in the United States at a maximum of $4 a ton above "ceiling" prices for standard weight paper.

With the proposed construction of a pipe line across Arabia by a United States Government agency, the question of the actual cost of moving oil through large diameter pipe lines over great distances, when all charges have been taken into consideration, has come up.

JACK BENNY gives his last program of the season on June 4, and his choice half hour -- 7 to 7:30 P.M. -- on Sundays over NBC will be immediately occupied thereafter by the American Tobacco Company, which is to assume sponsorship of the comedian's efforts next year.

" A Challenge to the College Woman," by Margaret B. Pickel in THE TIMES Magazine, recalls my own experience as director of the War Work Information Bureau of the New York City branch of the American Association of University Women.

Immediate discontinuance of the community ceiling price charts, being distributed to consumers in the metropolitan area by the New York Regional Office of the Office of Price Administration, was demanded yesterday by the New York State Food Merchants' Association.

STOCKHOLM, April 1 -- The announcement today of the resignation of Kjstaa G. Vilkuna, Chief of the Finnish Information Bureau, indicated a softening in Finland's attitude toward a peace with Russia. Mr. Vilkuna was an uncompromising censor, taking the German "line" on most occasions.

IT was time somebody came right out and said that being a civilian isn't all beer and skittles. True, civilians are out of danger. They are moderately warm and often sheltered. They don't have to eat K-rations. But they feel humiliated.

Today there comes into force a policy of excluding all Jews from Palestine, the land set aside for the development of the Jewish National Home in 1917. I am writing you as a Christian American to protest that policy. This policy was set forth in a White Paper issued in May, 1939, by the Chamberlain Government.

The appointment of Donald E. Lawrence, formerly director of the Examining Division of the United States Maritime Commission, Washington, D.C., as treasurer of the Sea Shipping Company, Inc., better known as the Robin Line, was announced yesterday by Arthur R. Lewis Jr., president of the firm. Mr. Lawrence has already resigned his commission post, but no successor has yet been named.

CHICAGO, April 1 -- Announcement that the War Food Administration had increased from 35 to 60 per cent the quantity of corn that grain elevators are required to set aside for sale to essential industries came today as a complete surprise to the grain trade.

ONE may be tempted out of hand to apply to our contemporary multiplication of anthologies the accusation that Elizabeth Barrett Browning hurled at the writing of books in general. Professional critics and scholars are prone to dismiss these collections forthwith as not much more than burglar tools for forcing the back door of literature.
NEW DELHI, India, April 1 (AP) -- A Southwest Asia Command communique:

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- President Roosevelt appointed Senator Homer T. Bone of Washington today a judge of the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals, and the Senate confirmed it unanimously twelve minutes after the nomination was received.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Fred M. Vinson, Director of Stabilization, made a "report to the nation" today before the Federal Bar Association in which he asserted that the Administration had "held the line" with no hardship to any major economic group.

Some irregularity developed yesterday in the market on the New York Cotton Exchange and prices at the close of trading were unchanged to 10 points lower than on Friday, with the May position relatively firm.
Statement showing executive budget recommendations for 1944-1945, together with comparisons between the budget for 1943-1944, as modified to March 15, 1944, and executive budget for 1944-1945.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra, under Serge Koussevitzky, gave the final concert of its New York season yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. For the event the conductor had chosen three sharply contrasted masterpieces by Haydn, Debussy and Brahms, each of which gloried in a superlative reading.

The Office of Price Administration here is extending to used cameras and other photographic equipment its flat dollars and cents ceiling prices. The ceilings are designed to protect consumers from paying "inflationary prices" to dealers, or even to other consumers.

FEW of the millions of students in our high schools, colleges and Army or Navy training programs know the historical background of Boyle's famous gas law or the vital issues surrounding its formulation.
A communique broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WICHITA, Kans., April 1 -- The Beech Aircraft Corporation of Wichita has arranged a thirty-month revolving credit of $50,000,000 under Regulation V, giving a 90 per cent Government guarantee, from a group of thirty-six banks in nine States, most of which are in the Middle West, but four of which, the Chase National Bank, the Manufacturers Trust, the Irving Trust and the Marine Midland Trust Companies are in New York City.

NAPLES, April 1 -- The battle of Italy has flared up in a sector quiescent for weeks and the Allies' troops in the mountainous sector north of the Colli-Atina road have pushed forward about a mile to occupy Mount Marrone, 5,840 feet high and three miles west of Rocchetta and thirteen miles northeast of Cassino.
Front page Times Magazine, March 5.

THIS collection is, as the authors doubtless figured out, timely. It is also, as anyone who knows the authors will agree, authoritative. Professor Nevins has earned his spurs among our new school of middle-aged historians.

THE concert and radio world await with bated breath the premiere this afternoon for the Americas, the Western Hemisphere -- and omniscience only knows how much of Europe, Asia and Africa by short wave -- of Dmitri Shostakovich's Eighth Symphony.

LINCOLN, Neb., April 1 -- Wendell L. Willkie, in starting his Nebraska campaign today, found good reason for repeating his assertion that the Republican party, to win this year's Presidential election, must depend on principles and policies instead of upon personalities and old-fashioned politics.

All hope of reconciliation shattered, warring factions within the American Labor party moved yesterday on their separate ways, the defeated right wing launching plans for a new liberal party while the victorious left wing prepared to take over the party reins won in Tuesday's primary and strengthen its State organization.
THOMAS MORGAN, who reported battlefront news during World War I, subsequently spent eighteen years "on Vatican Hill" for the great American news agencies. It is apparent that he enjoyed the work.

PUTNAM'S "The Dyess Story" will contain the unrevealed story of the late Colonel Dyess' escape from the Japanese. . . . Mildred Smith, of Publishers Weekly, received the Constance Lindsay Skinner Award for 1944 at the Women's National Book Association annual dinner last week.

SHE came in, and her wide smile and her blush did not make it easy to tell her why I came: it was a greeting for myself alone. And when we sat before the fire I felt immediately a live thread begin to spin itself between us, just as it did one night in Youghal, like a cobweb spinning across the road of a spring day.

BALTIMORE, April 1 -- Under cover of a leaden sky that occasionally sprinkled Oriole Park with rain the Giants today launched their spring exhibition campaign and from what Manager Mel Ott could see as he peered through the mists from his dugout matters got under way quite swimmingly.

Capt. George J. Barendse has been appointed Commodore of the Holland-America Line fleet, upon completion of thirty years as master out of a total of forty-one years' service with the company, Peter van den Toorn, managing director of the line, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The steel workers lit the fuse to a bomb designed to smash the Little Steel formula this week as they closed their case before a War Labor Board panel for wage increases which would add $341,000,000 annually to payrolls.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration today announced a revised procedure for granting supplemental food rations for persons who are ill.

SCATTERED through Victor Herbert's operettas are songs which he composed with children in mind -- although they are songs about children, touched with wistful memory, rather than songs for children to sing.

At the annual meeting of the American Palestine Association Senator Taft announced it as the primary purpose of his bill "to find a place of refuge for the 4,000,000 surviving Jews of Europe." To achieve this end extraordinary means are proposed.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., April 1 -- Delegates from twenty-eight eastern colleges and universities adopted at the close of the intercollegiate United Nations' Council today a resolution urging the establishment after the war of an international organization, including a world court and police force

ON THE NORTH COAST of New Guinea, March 31 (delayed) -- Snakes nineteen feet long, bats with a six-foot wingspread that chatter like monkeys, sharks and mud make life interesting and "different" for American soldiers garrisoned in this New Guinea jungle while awaiting their time to go into action.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- New Easter finery will be the rule a week from Sunday on New York's Fifth Avenue and other promenades, but the First Lady of the land will not be wearing any.

Bruno Walter conducted Mozart's "The Magic Flute" in its fourth and last presentation of the season yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. After the performance, the Board of Directors of the Metropolitan Opera Association presented a Queen Ann coffee set to Mr. Walter, commemorating his fiftieth anniversary as a conductor.

At Harvard is Prof. Edwin J. Cohn, known to every physician as a chemist who has been studying blood in a new way. Harvard has been supporting him, and so has the Rockefeller Foundation. The total contributions to date have been about $200,000. What he has done is retailed in the last annual report of the Rockefeller Foundation.

HARVEY SMITH in this novel tells the story of the people working in a typical American office. The author will be beloved by that unsung heroine, the stenographer, whom he shows to be a vital person in American business -- as well as a decorative one.

The New York Yacht Club has decided to reverse its decision not to have any racing for the duration of the war. As a result of reports from all over the country of a widespread return to sailing, it will hold a contest on Long Island Sound the coming summer. The decision was announced yesterday.

ROBERT REUD grows tightlipped, resorts to evasive action when pressed about his birthday. This eccentric conduct stymies his random biographer, for by Reud's own credo any comprehensive estimate of his achievements must hinge on the date of his initiation, even its hour and minute.

HEADQUARTERS OF GENERAL STILWELL IN INDIA, April 1 (AP) -- Ground troops witnessed and wildly cheered as twenty-six Japanese bombers and fighters one after another fell flaming into the Assam jungle Monday in the greatest of a series of air battles that clinched Allied control of the air over Burma.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Despite assertions of "editorial writers and others" to the contrary, the National War Labor Board has a definite wage policy, according to Chairman W.H. Davis, who summarized the board's policy today by making public its "stabilization code" with an explanation of how it is applied.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 30 (Delayed) -- Allied reluctance to bomb Rome had led the Germans up to about a fortnight ago to wink at their own "regulations for the demilitarization of the open city," according to an account in the Journal de Geneve today by a correspondent who recently left Italy.
Recreation centers for youth are not the answer to juvenile delinquency, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday in opening the new Robert H. Holmes Police Athletic League Center at 152 West 126th Street.

The School of Engineering at the Pennsylvania State College has taken the initial step in a plan designed to assist returning servicemen in resuming their pre-war education or career. Although this plan isof primary interest to students' of architecture, officials see in it the model for like preparation in other fields.

A sweeping change is being made in Soviet Russia in Marxist economic dogmas as they have been officially taught in the schools, the press, and on the platform and radio. Marx's theory of the exploitation of the proletariat is completely revised and capitalism is declared a "progressive," not a "backward" system.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Sunday, April 2 (AP) -- A communique:

MOSCOW, April 1 -- In a dispatch from Beltsy a correspondent of the army newspaper Red Star described today how slight has been the damage done in Bessarabian towns and villages as a result of present operations. In the villages a damaged house is the exception.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 1 (AP) -- State Republicans in their biennial convention, put forth Lieutenant Commander Stassen tonight as the man "who can lead the Republican party to victory in the November presidential election."

A work-study course in industrial problems, which will give the students not only the opportunity of exploring concrete industrial problems but also of participating directly in the war production program, is being offered at Sarah Lawrence College in its summer session.

Representative Howard J. McMurray, Wisconsin Democrat, yesterday endorsed post-war international cooperation as the only method of maintaining our present economic policy. He spoke at a luncheon meeting of 102 delegates of the Student Federalists, student affiliate of Federal Union, Inc., organized by Clarence K. Streit, author of "Union Now."

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Red Cross War Fund campaign will continue into April until the fund has been oversubscribed, Leon Fraser, national campaign chairman, announced today in revealing the drive was approaching final success.

Dullness continued on the stock market and yesterday's session on the New York Stock Exchange, with 322,730 shares traded, was the second smallest of the year. The preceding Saturday had seen 447,730 shares traded. The market was narrow as well, with 637 issues appearing.

LONDON, April 1 -- It begins to look as if four years of neutrality had become a habit with Turkey. The Russians have crossed the Dniester and Adolf Hitler's influence in the Balkans is waning and yet the Turks have shown not the slightest inclination to join in the fray.

A YOUNG man and a young woman meet by accident at a spot overlooking the Hudson in New York City and are immediately plunged into a series of perilous adventures beginning with an attempt to murder them.

AFTER throwing planes at the Japanese since 1937, Maj. Gen. Claire L. Chennault ought to be tired. Only a few of those years have been really stimulating. Excepting the reckless days when his AVG's were pouncing on the Japanese with deadly virtuosity, his time has been full of teaching, planning and strategical routine.

GAY and spirited oils and gouaches by Gerard Hordyk make up the current members' invitation exhibition at Contemporary Arts. Hordyk, a native of Holland, worked in France and his painting has the taste and lively touch expected of the more personal pre-war Paris group.

SUPERSTITIONS are unpatriotic, at least in some cases, the War Production Board stated recently. To refuse to light three cigarettes with one match is a waste of paper, lumber and glue. Accordingly, the WPB urged match manufacturers to undertake an advertising campaign to persuade people that "three on a match" was not really unlucky.

THE stage is a rough board affair, supported by freshly hewn logs. On it a girl, dressed in a simple cotton dress like those you see on the boardwalk at Jones Beach on a summer afternoon, is singing. Behind her two other entertainers are sitting on camp stools and to the right an accordionist pumps his arms.
INTEREST in home-centered games and entertainment and in things for families to do together has been reported here from time to time since the American automobile went on a gas ration.

TORONTO, April 1 (AP) -- Miss Vivian Kellems of Westport, Conn., war contractor, challenged Representative Coffee of Washington today to make outside of Congress his charges that she was the sweetheart of a Nazi agent in Argentina and was a "menace to the American war effort."

SOMETHING has happened to Sergeant Buck -- softening of the heart, perhaps. At any rate he appears to be relenting, and it now seems possible that he may permit Colonel Primrose to marry Grace Latham.

Drummers and dog shows, orchids and name bands will be Eastertime features at this resort, where everyone hopes the sun will shine for the annual dress parade. Prize canines will be on show Saturday and Sunday, when two kennel clubs will display their finest animals
LONDON, April 1 -- Long-suffering Chelsea reached a football cup final today for the first time in eighteen years when it battled to a 3-2 overtime victory over flashy Reading.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- The Solid Fuels Administration listed today some war industries which will have first call on the country's bituminous coal supply during the coal year 1944-45, which begins today, but said that the list might have to be revised if many miners are taken by the armed forces.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The decision of the Selective Service System to abandon the "war unit plan" for measuring aricultural activities as a base for draft deferment, has been sent out to all State draft directors to become effective immediately.

I[X$SN'G A'I'UX'E; There wa a unexpected change in the progTam one night last week at the Palladiums Copenhagen's largest cinema. Danish patriots forced their way into the projection room and removed the reel of German propaganda film scheduled for that evening. The patriots escaped.

LONDON, April 1 -- Starting the April air offensive, American Liberator bombers with long-range Thunderbolt and Mustang fighter escort, but for the first time over the Reich without accompanying Flying Fortresses, attacked targets in southwestern Germany today.

THE story of the Allied military expedition to north Russia in the last war is an extraordinary footnote to history. In its detail it is the material of farce and, like farce, it skirts tragedy. For the anti-Bolshevik Russians who thought at its inception that it meant their reconquest of the country, it was tragic indeed; yet it developed into an absurdity precisely because its great pretentions were from the beginning based on make-believe.

THE hoot of an owl means coming disaster Ann Wentworth knows that because her grandfather has told her so. The first thing that greets Ann as she enters the grounds of Tamac, the old MacDonald place, is the hoot of an owl.

THOMAS YOSELOFF and Lillian Stuckey have retold in easy, readable style thirteen tales of that nimble-witted rascal who is a perennial favorite with boys and girls, and William Brady's drawings are full of humor and details suggesting the period.

NEW DELHI, India, April 1 -- The Japanese have advanced from the northeast in their offensive into India toward Imphal, but Allied troops have battled the enemy to a standstill in other sectors of the fluid north Burma battlefront and are inflicting increasingly heavy casualties, a Southeast Asia communique indicated today.

ENGLAND, London's North American spring schedule finds new station on 11.93 megacycles coming in during early evening. After 8 P.M. a choice of 9.58, 7.26 or 6.11 megacycles is offered. Week program preview is Saturday at 9:30 P.M.

TEN paintings by George Bellows have been placed on view at the Allison Gallery, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street. Several of them have never before been shown, among these the "Nude With Red Hair," which was painted at Woodstock in 1920. Bellows did two or three canvases based on tennis tournaments at Newport

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The War Damage Corporation has extended automatically for one year all policies in force on March 31 in consideration of premiums previously collected, Secretary of Commerce Jesse Jones announced today. The announcement said no action of any kind was required of policyholders to keep the insurance in force for the additional year.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The United States Weather Bureau will offer twenty full tuition scholarships in the department of meteorology of the College of Engineering at New York University, and twenty in the Institute of Meteorology of the University of Chicago.

LONDON, April 1 -- Broad Anglo-American diplomatic conversations embodying the first positive steps toward a final determination of post-war relationships between the two countries will be started very soon with the arrival in London of Edward R. Stettinius Jr., United States Under-Secretary of State, and Adolf A. Berle Jr., Assistant Secretary of State.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 1 -- Mrs. Giuseppa Campanelli, of 44 Bergen Avenue, North Brunswick, celebrated her 106th birthday today by blowing out the lone candle on her cake and uttering a wish that her native Italy soon would be liberated from Nazi and fascist domination.

New Utrecht retained the P.S.A.L. indoor track and field championship at the Thirteenth Regiment Armory in Brooklyn yesterday, but it required a victory in the final event on the program, the 1,200-yard relay, to do it.

IN 1918 high hopes filled the hearts of the victors of the greatest war yet recorded in history. The menace presented by Germany to eastern Europe and to the Atlantic nations alike had been thwarted. But few were aware of the shadow thrown across the future path of peace.

MOSCOW, April 1 -- Reduction of the old fortress town of Ochakov on the Black Sea aided by Red Fleet marines, completes the victories achieved at Kherson and Nikolayev. It means that to the quickly mounting menace of attack by land over the steppes to Odessa, the Russians now are able to add the threat of their sea power.

JERUSALEM, March 31 (Delayed) -- Formal dissociation from acts of terrorism was expressed in a memorandum that the leaders of the New Zionist Organization, Dr. Arieh Altman of Palestine and Dr. Abraham of London, submitted to the chief secretary, John Valentine Shaw, at the Palestine Government offices yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Secretary Stimson pledged today the "utmost strength" of the Army to victory in a statement on Army Day, April 6.

ALBANY, April 1 -- Governor Dewey signed today fourteen bills eliminating legal obstacles to ready assistance for the aged, the blind, dependent children and other persons in need. In a memorandum announcing his action he said that the new laws "indicate the progressive humane approach of the State administration toward the great problem of providing assistance to the less fortunate members of the community."

Congress recessed last week for the Easter holidays. Some Congressmen remained in Washington to catch up on their work. Others hurried home to mend political fences. The activity of a campaign year was gathering momentum, with the primaries beginning and the conventions less than three months away. There were straws to observe in the political winds.

Pre-Easter retail activity was brisk in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey made for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Accessory departments were crowded and there was a strong demand for coats, dresses, suits and children's wear.

DETROIT, April 1 (AP) -- Dr. Harry Shulman, a company-union labor disputes court umpire, has rejected a union demand that two employes of the Edgewater, N.J., plant of the Ford Motor Company be dismissed by the firm.

SEEKING new ways to restore the confidence of airmen disfigured by burns and war wounds, the Royal Air Force, with the cooperation of the Ministry of Aircraft Production, has been experimenting with a new idea -- that of placing patients in factory jobs while still undergoing treatment.

The Autocar Company reported yesterday that in 1943 it made a net profit of $1,971,394 after having provided $10,389,000 for taxes and estimated refunds for renegotiation. This was equivalent to $4.20 a share on its common stock.

PHILADELPHIA, April 1 (AP) -- The Curtis Publishing Company reported today net profit of $4,361,415 for 1943, after taxes of $3,876,201 and including excess profit credit carry-overs from previous years.

SOONER or later every home gardener grows roses. It only takes a perfect bloom at a flower show, a neighbor's success with this "queen of flowers," or the mere description of a new variety in a catalogue to start one off in search of space in the garden in which to begin a rose collection.

The Allied air offensive against Hitler's Europe last week produced the strange contrast of American bombers operating almost unhindered against a wide range of targets, while the RAF suffered its highest loss of the war in a single attack. In one day of operations against French and German objectives the Americans lost only nine bombers.

Patrons of night clubs and hotels in the Broadway and midtown area where dancing and floor shows are the rule felt the first impact of the new 30 per cent Federal tax levied on their checks last night and appeared to be taking it in their stride, especially in the more expensive spots, where the customary Saturday night crowds were in evidence.

RECONDITIONING treatments for the hair, once an almost negligible aspect of the hairdresser's business, have assumed a sudden importance since the war. The new demand for such services -- reported by most of the large city salons -- is explained in terms of "war nerves," neglect of diet and general fatigue on the part of their customers.

FROM hate, hunger, faith and fortitude a song has been born in France -- "Les Partisans" -- "Chant de la Liberation.'' It has become the "Marseillaise" of the resistance. A well-known French author wrote it four months ago in a small village of Provence, a friend of his put it to music on the spot.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Because the American railroads have been successful on the whole in managing their share of the tremendous war transportation job by themselves, there is an all but forgotten war bureau in Washington -- the Railroad Division of the Office of Defense Transportation.

AIR COMMANDO HEADQUARTERS, Burma Frontier, April 1 (U.P.) -- The last chapter in the unorthodox career of Maj. Gen. Orde Charles Wingate, who had captured the imagination of the United Nations as another "Lawrence of Arabia," was a blazing plane crash against a Burma mountain.

A large number of arrests of bogus officers found wearing United States Maritime Service uniforms illegally here have been reported by the USMS Investigations Division's shore patrol units, who are under orders to stop every maritime officer they meet.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The new 30 per cent excise tax on the gross dollar revenue of night clubs, cabarets, hotel grills and other places where entertainment is provided for diners cannot be included in the dollar revenue figures supplied the Office of Price Administration in connection with the allocation of rationed foods to food-serving establishments, that agency announced today.

AMERICAN planners of the peace have now offered every possible solution, it would seem, from two refrigerators in every home to the decortication of all Germans. But Mr. Baron, ably assisted by Mr. Grosz, has attacked the problem from a new angle.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Sunday, April 2 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's air forces have struck increasingly heavy blows at the Japanese from Truk in the Carolines to Hollandia in New Guinea, while Solomons-based destroyers of his command have bombarded the Greenwich (or Kapingamarangi) Islands, 335 miles northeast of Kavieng, New Ireland, his communique today disclosed.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., April 1 -- W.W. Crenshaw's French-bred veteran Grasshopper II, carrying top weight of 120 pounds, raced to a length-and-a-half triumph over the Christopher Ranch's Argonne Woods in the mile and a sixteenth Ponce de Leon Handicap before 7,043 fans at Tropical Park today.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark, April 1 -- Challenge Me, carrying the colors of the Brolite Farm, raced to a popular victory today in the ninth running of the $10,000 added Arkansas Derby before one of the largest crowds ever to attend a racing card at Oaklawn Park.

SAIDOR, New Guinea, April 1 -- Ensign Cedric Janien of Boston, former Harvard football player and a big husky fellow, was known in the motor torpedo boat command as a chap inclined to regard discipline as virtually nonexistent. For that reason, although he begged and cajoled, he did not get his own PT boat but was made second in command of one under another officer.

AROUND Radio Row, a couple of weeks ago, the rumor went that Milton Berle's new program, "Let Yourself Go" (Tuesdays, WJZ-Blue, 7 P.M.), would mark the unveiling of a new Milton Berle, a report which raised some hopes along with a few eyebrows.

Lest the salt-water fishermen be overlooked in the excitement attending yesterday's opening of the trout season, it must be recounted that this breed of angler is beginning to stir out of his winter hibernation, also.
WALLINGFORD, Conn., April 1 -- Bob Quinn of the Braves is not one to beat around the bush so when he says big league baseball definitely will go on he isn't qualifying it with any may or if clauses.

TO give post-war America the finest transportation the world has ever seen is the goal of the railroads as officially stated by the Association of American Railroads. Extensive research toward this end has been under way for some time with all phases of operation, new methods and new types of equipment being examined.
Mayor La Guardia sent to the Board of Estimate yesterday an executive budget of $737,333,148 for 1944-45, representing a decrease of $13,568,283 from the current budget total of $750,901,432.

ADVANCE HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, April 1 (AP) -- While Allied naval, air and ground forces slash their way across the vast island chains of the Pacific, American engineers follow them to carve from the jungle elaborate bases that will support the advance on the Philippine Islands and ultimately Japan.
At the close of March business, most retail stores had made up their February decrease, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.
A MISCHIEVOUS fate pursued the hotel's official portrait of the Fuehrer; another cataclysmic air raid had rocked Berlin, and this was the third time in two weeks that Hitler had fallen on his face.

A planned program of scrapping finished and unfinished war material which would maintain employment in the United States until full peacetime production of civilian goods is attained was urged yesterday by Max Stern, manager of the metals recovery division of Loma Machine Manufacturing Company, Inc., 580 Fifth' Avenue, who submitted an outline of his proposals.

CHICAGO, April 1 -- In this Central West area of the nation, center of pre-war isolationists and presently of their successors, the nationalists, concern is felt over what many view as a crisis in United Nations' politics despite gratifying military triumphs against Axis forces.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- The Army, Navy, War Production Board and Maritime Commission endorsed today a combined forty-eight-hour maximum work-and-school week for students 16 and 17 years old.

ALGIERS, April 1 -- By making public today the text of a law that it had adopted to this effect, the French Committee of National Liberation asserted its right to control both the military and the civil administration of every part of French territory immediately on its liberation from the Germans.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- Secretary Ickes' insistence upon a public defense of the proposed 1,250-mile trans-Arabian pipeline appeared likely today to force the Senate's special petroleum committee to hold open hearings.

The American Labor party was created in 1936 as the New York branch of Labor's Nonpartisan League. It was the direct political brain-child of Franklin D. Roosevelt, who asked James A. Farley to take the new political machine to the bosom of the New York State Democratic organization.

Although no calls have yet been issued by the Controller of the Currency or by the State Banking Superintendent for banks' quarterly statements of condition, most institutions plan to publish reports based on figures as of the close of business on March 31.

" SHERLOCK HOLMES is more than a book," wrote the late William Bolitho. "He is the spirit of a town and a time." Bolitho's words are even truer today than when he wrote them. For the growth and perpetuation of the Baker Street legend -- the care and worship, if you will, of a myth -- constitutes a unique chapter in literary history.

Judging from four cases presented by Dr. Abraham Myerson in the New England Journal of Medicine, electric shock can do some good in allaying grief caused by the sudden death of a relative or close friend.

It would be conceivable that if there were the slightest apprehension of our winning the war it would be highly inadvisable to take legislative steps to reduce to ownership of the United States the vast amount of enemy-owned property seized by the Alien Property Custodian.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 1 -- Bill Smith, 19-year-old Hawaiian seaman at the Great Lakes Naval Training Station, powered to triumphs in the 100 and 440-yard free-style races in the University of Michigan pool tonight to fashion a triple as the two-day national A.A.U. indoor swimming championships ended.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 1 -- Two hundred thirty-nine Jewish refugees from Rumania and who arrived illegally in Istanbul last night left by train for Palestine at noon today. Their landing and departure was made possible only through the intervention of United States Ambassador Laurence A. Steinhardt.

SINCE the reader of daily news stories concerning the plans for increasing the output of civilian goods is pretty hard put to it these days to translate official proposals and orders into terms of when she can count on finding an actual frying pan at the store down the street, it might be profitable to review the home equipment situation as it exists at this moment.

SONGS and games, like folktales, serve as a bond of interest between boys and girls of different countries and not only children but their elders will enjoy the gay and childlike illustrations made by a 14-year-old Chinese girl.

MOSCOW, April 1 -- The Communist party organ Pravda today bluntly described Japan as an ally of Germany who had failed for nearly three years to carry out her solemn promises to give up the last capitalist concession on Soviet soil because her leaders believed Adolf Hitler's boast that his armies would smash the Red Army and conquer the U.S.S.R.

NEW YORK'S Station WNYC, as quick as the next one to accept a notion with a cultural aroma about it, has been projecting Shakespeare onto its quota of the airwaves these recent Sunday evenings, and -- as is not always the case with Shakespearean broadcasts -- the airwaves have not fought back.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Regular Army infantryman and veteran of two wars, who won the country's highest military award, was born in Czechoslovakia and came to this country at the age of 7.

NEW ORLEANS, April 1 -- Following the Mississippi Legislature's passing of a bill taxing bootleg and moonshine liquor, whenever found, 12 per cent, several other States in the South are considering taking similar action.

TODAY it is oil and inventions and corporate schemes which incite the American's profit motive. In an older day, from the first breaching of the Alleghanies onward until land ceased to be cheap and plentiful, the land itself was the prime speculation.

PEARL HARBOR, April 1 -- The day and night bombing of Truk continued Thursday night, carrying the sustained aerial pounding of Japan's principal Caroline Islands base through forty-eight hours, according to a press release this morning from Pacific Fleet Headquarters.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The stunning attack this week by formidable forces of the United States Pacific Fleet on Japanese positions in the Palau Islands, only 550 statute miles east of the Philippines, opened a new vista of Pacific strategy and again exposed the Japanese Navy as still shrinking from a showdown with American forces.

HOW is the poor Victory gardener to know when to plant, since climate varies markedly even within a few miles and varieties of vegetables differ in their hardiness to frost? May bean seed be planted as early as that of beets? Should lettuce plants be set out as soon as lettuce seed may be sown ?

At 82, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University for forty-three years, expressed yesterday his conviction that Germany could be made a valuable member of a world union of nations. In the library of his home at 60 Morningside Drive, where he expects to celebrate his birthday today quietly, Dr. Butler advocated the transformation of imperialistic Germany into a nation of states similar to the United States.
BECAUSE Britain now has a smart up-to-date new army it has been said again that Colonel Blimp is dead. Such wild rumors could not arise except out of three misconceptions.

IN this section of New York's southern tier there is a grimly held opinion that Nyack has replaced Boston as the Athens of America. The argument runs that the flowers of New England have had their day and now lie faded between the pages of history books, whereas in Nyack they are just bursting into bloom.

OAKDALE, L.I., April 1 -- Cold weather this morning was no deterrent for the hardy anglers of the South Side Sportsmen's Club who, led by their president, Guy Carey, took their limit of brook trout and rainbows despite the fact that guides on fishing rods iced almost solidly in the 26-degree temperature that greeted them at sun-up.
With three Beaver pitchers collaborating to allow one hit, City College's baseball team beat Drew University, 3 -- 0, in its opening game yesterday at Lewisohn Stadium.

As a young social scientist on his first visit to America back in the Twenties, Gunnar Myrdal was challenged on all sides to say what was "wrong with this country." Like Bryce before him, he saw in our eagerness to be criticized, however embarrassing to a visitor, a healthful and hopeful sign in a young nation.

CHUNGKING, China, March 31 (Delayed) -- During the past month the black-market rate for the United States dollar dropped from 315 Chinese dollars to one United States dollar, which was the highest rate ever reported, to 230 to 1, which is reported to be the rate today.
CHICAG0, April 1 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestoclc markets here by the war Food Administration follows:

WHEN I wrote "Chicken Every Sunday," a story about my family, I wasn't exactly reticent And as my mother and brothers and sisters-in-law got carbons of the chapters one by one, there were anguished wails of "Please, do you have to put that in ?"

A MURDER trial like that of Wayne Lonergan or any other person accused of murder is essentially dramatic. The life of a man is at stake, and, within the rigid rules of the game, two other men, prosecutor and defense lawyer, play for that stake, using all their wit, subtlety and ruthlessness to win.

Federal and municipal officers dedicated yesterday Bellevue Hospital's new rapid-treatment center for syphilis and gonorrhea at an outdoor ceremony before the institutional administration building, First Avenue and East Twenty-eighth Street. Forty-eighth in the national total of such projects, the clinic was said to be the first to incorporate a rehabilitation program.

BOUGAINVILLE, Solomon Islands, March 29 (Delayed) (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Oscar W. Griswold, commander of Allied forces on this island, today reported indications that "the Japs have had about enough" of Bougainville.

NAPLES, April 1 -- There is no doubt that slow Allied military progress in Italy has complicated the problems of civil administration of the former Axis nation. They were complex enough to begin with, but failure to occupy Rome has made everything much more difficult.

FOR two of the most thoroughly rewarding dance performances of the season thus far it has been necessary to go, of all places, to the Museum of Natural History. There, recently, Reginald and Gladys Laubin presented two very small fragments of their large knowledge of the dances of the Indians of the Great plains.

In an effort to broaden the market for surplus materials, officials of Eastern aircraft manufacturers will endorse and support appeals made by small manufacturers to the War Production Board for relief from existing limitation orders, it was learned yesterday.

ONE hundred years ago an artist clambered to the top of the Duke of York's column to make a drawing of that new and promising quarter of London. In the foreground the corners of his composition were firmly pegged down by two buildings on Pall Mall, notable for their symmetry and solid good taste: they were, reading from left to right, the Athenaeum and the United Service Club.
Well, that's the end of March, and here is April. Lovely April, with a squirt gun in one hand, a bunch of violets in the other, and an icicle in its pocket.
Methods by which the youth of America could preserve democracy at home were considered yesterday in the next to the last in a series of panel discussions at the New York Times Hall.

Soviet Russia last week scored what appeared to be an important diplomatic victory over Japan. By an agreement signed in Moscow the Japanese surrendered valuable coal and oil concessions in the Soviet half of Sakhalin, the big island that lies like a bridge between the Japanese archipelago and the coast of Siberia.
United States Senator Ralph O. Brewster of Maine and Mrs. Brewster have arrived at the Waldorf-Astoria from Washington.

AFTER reading Virginia Dale's book "Nan Thursday" it might be easy to start getting ideas about every glamour girl singing team you see and hear. Who would think that tragedy could stalk so close to pretty Nan and her radio singing partner saucy Poppy Dublin?

THERE are indications that the forthcoming spring tour of the Metropolitan Opera is going to be the most successful in the organization's history. From Cleveland comes word that mail order sales for the week of May 1, when the opera company will be in town, are record-breaking.

GENERATIONS come and go, and life goes on, with attendant mischief to the ancient landmarks -- like the well on the Marshall farm. Some remember, some never knew; some care, some don't. Anyway, it's gone -- filled up with ashes, sawdust, dirt, and probably tin cans.

A Frenchman, Guillaume Deschapelles, who died in 1847, first discovered the play which alone could defeat the contract in the following deal. After 100 years and more, most experts and all casual players miss opportunities to use it.
