The Red Army last week split in two the German forces fighting on the Eastern front. That was the meaning of the Russian capture of Cernauti in Bukovina, a city that is both a gateway to the passes of the Carpathians and a railway junction commanding the lines of communication between the northern and southern sectors of the Russian fighting front.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, April 1 -- Whatever else may be said about the Italian campaign -- and plenty is being said these days -- it has proved to be an invaluable if costly battle school and experimental laboratory during these months when the final preparations are being made for the assault on the western wall of Hitler's Festung Europa.

FROM numerous neutral sources in Europe, Africa and Asia since the start of the global war the publishers of the Standard Postage Stamp Catalogue have been receiving information, much of it yet to be authenticated, which presents a fairly over-all picture of stamp-issuing activity behind the lines of battle.

IT has been customary to speak pityingly of Lamb, and the phrase "poor Lamb" (which Coleridge, who may have coined it, once used to his regret) has become part of the language. Yet he was anything but poor, either in gifts or spirit, and for all his external suffering he seems to have had much the best of it.

HERE is a story of an old wrong and an old grief as sordidly planted between character and circumstance as the trees of Max Kenney's farm. Young and casting scant shadows in Benjamin Kenny's time, those trees form wide aisles of green the morning his 30-year-old son goes out to dig a grave for his dog and his wise old friend Jacob.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 1 (AP) -- The assault on the Japanese naval stronghold in the Palua Islands, near the Philippines, by a powerful American task force was "described as one of the greatest surface and naval bombardments ever staged by the Navy," stated a New Guinea Air Base dispatch received today from Olen Clements, Associated Press correspondent.

HERE is a curious case of literary St. Virus -- an ill-written story of American merchant seamen that somehow comes alive through the sheer warmth and depth of its characters. The writer achieves the same effect in letters that an amateur motion picture addict gets by jerking his lens from one scene, or subject, to another.

The vital need for salvaging waste paper so the public may continue to read this and other newspapers weekdays and Sundays, was emphasized yesterday by the newspaper industry. It is an endless chain, this process of printing a newspaper, and the link supplied by waste paper is an essential one.

MOSCOW, April 1 -- Although the lifting of Leningrad's siege shut off regular dispatches describing life in the city, the Russian capital still is thrilled by the tales of grit and tenacity of Leningrad's residents. Travelers from Leningrad tell how the solidarity achieved through the common danger is lasting in easier conditions.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 1 -- Representative Clare Boothe Luce appears assured of being one of the two delegates to the Republican National Convention from the Fourth Congressional (Fairfield County) District, it was reported in authoritative Republican quarters tonight.
ON THE NORTH PACIFIC FRONT, April 1 (AP) -- This far north region is on guard with the arrival of an Aleutian "good weather" period for possible Japanese attack.

THE "Navy buff" is a peculiar individual, who pores for hours over the pages of Jane or Fahey. His joy is comparing tables of gunpower, noting a one-foot difference in beam between two ships that are otherwise sisters and speculating endlessly on the results of possible encounters between naval vessels.

" HOUR OF TRIUMPH" -- Major Eliot's panorama of the possible transition from world war to world peace -- which is even now beginning -- is to this reviewer the ablest fusion of "realism" and "idealism" which has yet been published on the subject.

About the time the sap season closes, the drummer of the woodlands sends his rhythmic, staccato challenge pulsing through the air. The cock ruffed grouse is a lilliput monarch in size but a Richard the Third in confident persistence.

Federal Judge John C. Knox signed yesterday an order approving a settlement in the debt of the American Bemberg Corporation to the Algemeene Kunstzijde Unie, N.V. (General Artificial Silk Union), the Dutch holding company for the German Glanzstoff interests.

An extensive survey of New York's secondary education program has been undertaken by the Board of Regents, in an attempt to evaluate the high school program of this State. The study, expected to be completed by the end of the year, may bring about "helpful changes" that would improve the system of secondary education here, William J. Wallin, vice chancellor of the board, indicated.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 1 -- A 520-foot homer by towering Johnny Lindell and a triple by George Stirnweiss crowned with success today the first spring exhibition game of the Yankees in the draft-riddled 1944 campaign. With these blows the world champions downed the Phillies on windswept Bader Field before a gathering of 2,678 paying fans.

With these blows the world champions downed the Phillies on windswept Bader Field before a gathering of 2,678 paying fans.

IN Louis Bromfield's latest dramatic production "What Became of Anna Bolton," the curtain rises on a Graustark setting which Mr. Bromfield tells us is pre-war Europe, with kings and courtesans, statesmen and Ambassadors all engaged in a mad, doomed carnival of corruption.

Physical science can deal with unemployment in the post-war world, Dr. Albert W. Hull, assistant director of the General Electric Research Laboratory, recently declared before the American Physical Society at Columbia University. As outstanding examples of the need of physical research he cited food and shelter.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Russian victories in Southern Russia during March have been aided by freakish and unseasonable weather.

Channing Pollock's letter in a recent Sunday TIMES on the passing of Robert Vivian recalled the latter as Ferguson in "The Sign on the Door" when played here some years ago at the Majestic Theatre, with Marjorie Rambeau featured.

PEARL HARBOR, April 2 -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz disclosed today that thirteen men were killed and forty-six wounded in the accidental shelling of three LCI's (landing craft, infantry) by an American destroyer in a landing assault on Parry Island in Eniwetok Atoll of the Marshall Islands on Feb. 22.

It will probably interest your readers to know that on Dec. 11, 1644, there were baptized in the Dutch Reformed Church in New Amsterdam (now the City of New York) "vierlingen" (quadruplets), the father being recorded as Henry Piesse and the mother Sara Brut, the children being Sara, Elizabeth, Thomas and Jan.

CHICAGO, April 2 -- Wet and cold weather prevailed in the winter Wheat Belt last week, a condition unfavorable for growth of the crop, and reports indicate an immediate change in the weather is needed for more rapid growth, especially in areas where the wheat was seeded in the dust last fall and did not germinate until recent weeks.

The action of Great Britain in restricting immigration in Palestine was characterized as unjustifiable by Senator Guy M. Gillette of Iowa in an address last night at the thirty-sixth annual dinner of the Order Sons of Zion in the Hotel Commodore.
LONDON, April 2 (AP) -- The Swiss prepared today a mass funeral for the victims in the bombing of Schaffhausen.

Bishop Henry St. George Tucker, president of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, urged Christians "to set themselves against any resort to vindictiveness," in a message for Holy Week, issued yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 2 -- Wheat for May delivery went to the ceiling price in leading markets last week and held the advance, comparatively little trading being done at lower prices. The cash wheat situation is reported to have tightened considerably, and at times, brokers said, they had orders which could not be filled because no grain was offered.
Six new films will open this week at Broadway theatres. The schedule follows:

Municipal authorities were called upon to stop "pussyfooting" about desecration of churches and synagogues, in a resolution adopted yesterday at the ninth annual convention of the New York County Council of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States, held at the Hotel Commodore.

From 1921 until 1934 he was the Moscow correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES and in 1936 and 1937, and later in 1940, he returned to Russia for further sessions filing dispatches to this paper. TUSKEGEE, Ala., April 2 (AP) -- The Negro in the United States has "compressed the most progress in the shortest time of any race in human history," Dr. Frank P. Graham, president of the University of North Carolina, declared today.
New York school children who have painstakingly rummaged through cellars, attics and buildings to collect waste paper will be rewarded for their efforts, it was made known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The Council of State or upper chamber of the Government of India passed an unofficial resolution last week recommending that early steps be taken to obtain United States citizenship rights for East Indian residents in this country, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- The Senatorial inquiry into the Government's handling of war news, proposed by Palmer Hoyt, Oregon publisher and former domestic director of the Office of War Information, received today the support of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, chairman of the Republican Steering Committee.

The boundary of Rumania proper -- the Prut River -- referred to in Mr. Molotoff's declaration Sunday was established by agreement of the Soviet Union and Rumania in 1940, after Russia had insisted upon the return to her of Bessarabia Province, situated between the Dniester and Prut Rivers.

A news item says that the demand for puppies is at a record high. This is a comforting bit of news. If there are puppies enough it will help hold inflation in check. It means boys and girls, men and women, will have something to do to compensate for the lack of gasoline.

On the basis of a reading of the score made possible through the courtesy of Am-Rus, also of the final rehearsals and the performance yesterday afternoon by Dr. Rodzinski and the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, it can be said that Shostakovich's Eighth Symphony, on the occasion of its American premiere, received a superb presentation.

National advertisers in the farm market received last week a booklet prepared by the Office of War Information in cooperation with the War Food Administration entitled "How Farmers Can Make Food Fight for Freedom by Meeting 1944 Food Production Goals."

Contrasting the American "life of ease" with war conditions that Europeans must endure, Dr. Lena Madesin Phillips took American women to task yesterday for the luxuries they buy, their complaints on taxes, and the 5,000,000 war jobs they have failed to fill.

PORT NEWARK, N.J., April 2 -- Two destroyer escorts were launched here today at the yard of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation. Forty-six of the type have gone down the ways at the yard.

A psychopathic, personality usually has normal and sometimes superior intelligence. In some forms of psychoses and in certain neuroses, insight and logic are missing, but there is no intellectual defect in the majority of psychopaths.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 2 -- An absence of "resentment" at the "American invasion" of British colonies was found by four members of Parliament who are winding up a Caribbean and Bermuda tour. The opinion was expressed by Capt. Peter D. MacDonald, chairman of the committee.

Those who, like Pontius Pilate, refuse to make a positive decision about their beliefs are more dangerous to religion than its open and avowed enemies, the Rev. Dr. Russell F. Auman, the pastor, said yesterday in a sermon in St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street.

Net sales of the United Aircraft Corporation for 1943 reached a new high record of $733,590,668, a gain of 41 per cent over the previous record volume of $518,970,578 in 1942, according to a report issued for publication today. Total revenues were $736,638,984, comparing with $519,419,666 in 1942 and with $307,389,494 in 1941.

The New York State convention of the Socialist Labor party, at the Cornish Arms Hotel, Eighth Avenue at Twenty-third Street, nominated two State candidates and forty-seven Presidential electors to select candidates at the national convention here on May 1.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 2 -- Byron Nelson clipped seven strokes off par figures in today's final thirty-six holes to win the Knoxville war bond golf tournament.

DALLAS, April 2 (AP) -- The giants of the court who made themselves troublesome the past season by batting well-aimed shots away from the hoop, and thereby returning the game to stalling tactics, won't be so valuable to their teams next campaign, thinks James W.T. Clair, chairman of the national basketball rules committee.

Through its war industries training program the Board of Education has provided instruction for 275,000 men and women who sought to improve their skills in order to aid the war effort. Many of these adults were civilians who were thus enabled to find jobs in war plants and are now productive workers in key industries.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- Despite his insistence that he is not seeking the Republican Presidential nomination, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey is away out in front with 106 delegates pledged to him or claimed by his supporters, although 207 of the 234 so far selected in ten States are free to vote as they please.

LONDON, April 2 -- Suspicion that subversive elements are fomenting the strikes among Britain's war workers was loudly voiced tonight on the eve of another sharp reduction in gas and electricity supplies to industry resulting from the acute coal shortage.

It is evident from the subsequent cabled comment that Mr. Churchill's overwhelming technical victory in the House of Commons last week did not end the matter. The House had passed, by a majority of one vote, an amendment to the Government's educational bill.

ALGIERS, April 2 (AP) -- Members of "the Association of French Liberation of Nov. 8" adopted a resolution today asking President Roosevelt to abrogate the Clark-Darlan agreement as infringing French sovereignty and to recognize more fully the French Committee of National Liberation.

PITTSBURGH, April 2 (AP) -- Organization of a post-war transcontinental air-borne professional football league was virtually completed today when representatives from eight cities elected temporary officers to handle operations until a permanent set-up is perfected, possibly at a December meeting.

NORWALK, Conn., April 2 -- The job of auctioning 60,000 quarts of liquid assets was described today by Deputy Internal Revenue Collector Frank Lattanzi of New Haven as the toughest which has faced him in his career.

Since the circus does not open until Wednesday evening, it is too soon to pass judgment on it. Presumably it will be a success as usual, but only in spite of the unwarranted attacks made on the tuba in Mr. Roland Butler's erudite advance publicity.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- Nine persons narrowly escaped death from carbon monoxide poisoning early today when a porter on a Pullman car awoke to discover gas escaping from a break in the air-conditioning system of the train as it was pulling out of Union Station here.

Increased cooperation between government, civic and social work agencies in the effort to curb juvenile delinquency was reported yesterday by Charles L. Chute, executive director of the National Probation Association, 1790 Broadway. He noted also improvements in juvenile and probation work, and action by youth itself to combat delinquency.

Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information, will write the foreword for Simon Shuster's "War Atlas for Americans," to be brought out next month. Prepared under the supervision of the Book Bureau of the OWI, the atlas includes eighty-four new maps designed and executed under the supervision of Emil Lowenstein.

The Catholic Bishops of three large Polish regions -- Kielcki, Czestochowski and Sandomierski -- have refused a German demand to issue a pastoral letter attacking the Russians, the Polish Telegraph Agency reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- New draft procedures which will permit the deferment of some men under 26 win avoid the "national disaster" to the rubber program which would result were these men taken, Col. Bradley Dewey, the rubber director, reported tonight.

Additional quarterly statements of condition issued by leading banks, based on figures as of the close of business on March 31, generally show small to moderate gains in deposits and consequently in total resources. Banks showing deposit increases also have increases in holdings of Government securities.

Charles Weidman's new dance work, "The Heart Remembers," had its premiere last night at the Humphrey-Weidman Studio Theatre in West Sixteenth Street as the latest addition to the very active repertory season down there. It would be pleasant to be able to report that it is a welcome addition, but such, unfortunately, is not the case.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (U.P.) -- Thirsty seamen on cargo vessels plying southwest Pacific routes have the Seabees to thank that plenty of fresh water is waiting for them on a certain island in the Solomons group, the Navy said tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 2 -- Regis Toomey has been signed by Pine and Thomas, Paramount producer, for the lead in "Dark Mountain," a mystery drama with a Northwest forest locale, for which Chester Morris had been announced previously.

LONDON, April 2 -- President Roosevelt's plan for letting Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower appoint the civil authorities in the wake of the liberating armies in France is being studied carefully by the British in the hope of working put some other formula that will be acceptable to the American authorities.

The Moscow radio said yesterday in a domestic broadcast that Chinese troops from Sinkiang had "violated territory" of the Mongolian People's Republic "at the end of 1943" and quoted "leading Mongolian authorities" as saying that the Soviet Government would have to aid Mongolia under the Moscow-Mongolia treaty if "such violations recur."
LONDON April 2 (U.P.) -- Text of a broadcast from Moscow on the Red Army's entry into Rumania proper:

A warning against surrendering to cynicism regarding the results of our present sacrifices was sounded yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street. In his morning sermon he declared that if we give away to pessimism, we "shall throw away the fruits of victory."

ON THE NORTH COAST OF NEW GUINEA, April 2--American troops "over the hump" of the Owen Stanley Mountain Range of the jungle-wrapped north coast of New Guinea are as hungry for immediate news of what's going on in the rest of the world--particularly at home--as they are for meals.

PITTSBURGH, April 2 -- Raw-steel output last week for the country was unchanged at 98.5 per cent of rated capacity. There were indications that the steel tonnage to be turned out this week will be equally as heavy as a week ago. Although steel officials expect that production schedules will be affected by new draft quotas and the cancellation of deferments, no serious decline is expected in the immediate future.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today the appointment of five men with "wide business experience" to assist the agency in its price-control program for foods and beverages.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Reinforcement by the railroads serving Louisville of plans worked out by the Office of Defense transportation and the management of the Churchill Downs race track to restrict travel and still not interfere with the running of the Kentucky Derby were announced today by ODT.

Holdings of gold and foreign exchange, chiefly dollar balances of South Central America increased approximately $1,125,000,000 in 1943 to a total of $2,700,000,000 and now amounts to at least $3,000,000,000, the National City Bank of New York reports in a special survey of this subject in the April issue of its monthly bank letter.
More than twenty openings are scheduled this week in New York museums and art galleries, with work by children featured at two museums.

Mayor La Guardia continued yesterday to withhold details of his proposed "transportation tax" to provide an annual revenue of $50,000,000, earmarked to wipe out subway deficits and provide transit improvements. The proposal, he said, would be made public some time in May and in the meantime those now disposed to criticize it could get rid of their "spleen and bile" so that they can consider the plan objectively when its details are revealed.
LONDON, April 2 (AP) -- The world's largest Army mess is operating in what was the skating rink of one of London's most exclusive hotels.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 2 (AP) -- With Parliament summoned to meet Monday, instead of the usual Tuesday, to discuss new Russian armistice terms, the question arose as to what counter-move the Germans might be prepared to make in the event of peace.

LONDON, April 2 (Canadian Press) -- Betty Walker, a young Canadian teacher in Turkey, incurred the displeasure of the British Ambassador when she told him to stop wagging his finger at her during a Christmas Day reception and as a result was banished to a lonely teaching post, The Sunday Dispatch said today in a cable from its Ankara correspondent.

Only eight contestants appeared for the metropolitan district qualifying round in the national electric epee fencing championship yesterday at the Fencers Club. Thus, the competition for the four places was held in the form of one final round-robin.

Listening yesterday to Winston Churchill's radio address, anyone interested in housing must have been struck by the fact that Great Britain is far better organized than the United States for meeting post-war housing needs. It is true that their experience in this field is longer than ours, and that their problems are in some ways less complex.

CHICAGO, April 2--Very little oats or barley is being offered in the open market and there were no sales of oats last week on the Board of Trade. Receipts of this grain for the week were 70,000 bushels, against 40,000 a year ago.

Only forty-two of the city's 7,800 uniformed firemen have signed waivers of their right to challenge the validity of the extra tours of duty ordered by Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh in December, according to an unofficial report yesterday.
Charles J. Weedon has been elected president of J.C. Eno, Inc., Bloomfield. N.J., makers of effervescent salts.

The recent German defensive victory at Cassino has been in some ways a blessing in disguise. The Allies' unsuccessful efforts to take Cassino and break through the Gustav Line have now been succeeded by a lull in which both sides are recouping their strength and regrouping their forces.

CHICAGO, April 2 -- Stocks of lard continue to accumulate due to relatively small shipments, and further congestion in storage room is reported. Purchases of lard for lend-lease purposes have slowed up and the Government is reported to have ceased buying refined lard, taking the prime steam article in preservative-treated tierces which can be stored in warehouses not suited for holding the refined product.

MOSCOW, Monday, April 3 -- The Soviet Foreign Commissar, Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff, announced late Sunday night that troops of the Red Army had crossed the Prut River and entered Rumania at several points.

Freight carloadings in the second quarter of this year are expected to be about 3 per cent above those in the similar period last year, according to estimates just compiled by the thirteen Shippers Advisory Boards. On this basis, loadings of the twenty-eight principal commodities will be 9,209,507 cars, compared with 8,943,554 for the same commodities in the second quarter last year.

Mr. Frank Cist in a letter to THE TIMES, published March 20, advocated an international treaty pledging nations not to raise tariffs. He argued that Secretary Hull's reciprocal trade agreements policy is unsuited to post-war needs "because it commits nobody to anything."

Germans troops occupied Hungary while Admiral Nicholas Horthy, Hungarian Regent, was on his way from Adolf Hitler's headquarters to Budapest on a special train deliberately sent on a round-about route, United Press advices from a neutral European capital said yesterday.

LONDON, Monday, April 3 (AP) -- The Russia Sunday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow: Troops of the First Ukraine Front continued their offensive. Our tankmen and infantry' advanced and captured the towls of Koeov and Kuty, district centers of Stanislav Province, and the town of Gertza, district center of Cernauti Province.

Declaring that racial and religious discrimination are being fostered here by the enemy to divide the American people, speakers at a dinner last night of the National Federation for Constitutional Liberties called for united and aggressive action by all groups of society to combat discrimination.

BALTIMORE, April 2 -- Atrocious weather conditions which have been dogging nearly all the major league clubs training in this northeastern sector this spring again dealt the Giants a mean turn today when an ideal Palm Sunday morning vanished as if by magic around noon.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices was 114.94, a rise of 1.7 per cent over the previous week's level of 113.02. The raw materials index and the farm products index both declined 0.5 per cent, because drops in the prices of eggs, cattle, hogs and cotton were more important than the price increases in wheat, apples and oranges.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Robert E. Hannegan, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, today officially called the Democratic National Convention for July 19 in Chicago and announced the distribution of a total of 1,176 delegates among the States and Territories.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- So effective has been our blockade of islands in the South and Southwest Pacific, the War Department said today, that some 100,000 Japanese troops face the hopeless future of fighting until their ammunition gives out or of fleeing deeper into the jungles to die by starvation or disease.

CHICAGO, April 2 (AP) -- Declaring that many anti-Administration Democratic leaders "appear too timid, politically and economically, to stand up and be counted," Harry H. Woodring announced tonight that he had resigned as chairman and withdrawn as a member of the American Democratic National Committee.

The ingredients of a curry, the native dish of India, are as numerous and varied as the regions of that country, and a diversity of spices, oils, vegetables, fruits, poultry, meat or fish may go into its making. An authority on the subject--the proprietor of the East India Curry Shop, a restaurant at 122 East Fifty-seventh Street--tells us that the basic seasoning, which is curry powder, is a blend of many spices.

Since many of the handyman jobs around a house and garden are falling to the lot of women these days, a set of instructions on the care and upkeep of garden tools issued by the New York State Colleges of Agriculture and Home Economics is appropriate for the housewife who is also the gardener of the family.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 2 -- Out of the welter of Stockholm rumors regarding Dr. Juho K. Paasikivi's trip to Russia the only certainty was that he had been there during the week and yesterday was back in Helsinki.

The much-heralded premiere performance in the Western Hemisphere of Dimitri Shostakovich's new Eighth Symphony was given in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, conducted by Artur Rodzinski.

During the first half of last week stocks declined under large sales, to take profits on the month's earlier rise. On Monday prices were bid up, nearly to the high level of 1944; but from the figure then reached the averages declined in the two ensuing days 2 1/8 points, to the lowest since March 7 -- since when they had advanced 3 points to the highest of the month.

Who is charged with the responsibility for naming the vessels of the United States Navy? Isn't it time that the responsible person is made aware of the great battles of the War Between the States? Is the Navy Department still fighting the Civil War? In any event, we are building a great fleet of aircraft carriers, which vessels are to bear the names of famous American battles.

" This day of crisis is bringing home to us with fresh reality the divine meaning of the cross and the divine power of our religion." Bishop William T. Manning declared yesterday in his Palm Sunday sermon in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The Fifth War Loan will undertake to raise an "urgently needed" fund of $16,000,000,000 between June 12 and July 8, of which $6,000,000,000 will be sought from individuals, Secretary Morgenthau announced today.

Cotton prices moved irregularly last week, with day-to-day movements decidedly moderate. At the close of trading on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net changes ranging from a decline of 4 points to an advance of 9 points.

NEW DELHI, India, April 2 (AP) -- Glider-borne Allied commandos have cut all north-south communication arteries to Myitkyina, main Japanese base in North Burma, and have smashed enemy efforts to infiltrate their air strip far behind Japanese lines, front dispatches said today.

TRENTON, April 2 -- There will be a contest for places in the New Jersey delegation to the Republican National Convention after all. Hopes of Gov. Walter E. Edge and other leaders of the regular Republican organization for an uncontested delegate primary were dashed at 11 o'clock last night, an hour before the deadline for filling petitions, when an incomplete slate pledged to Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York was entered.

Mayor La Guardia served notice yesterday, in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall, that vigorous action would be taken against all places failing to cooperate in his campaign to abate juvenile deliquency and truancy.

With ancient ritual, the crucifixion of the Son of God for the sins of men was commemorated yesterday in the solemn blessing of palms, the chanting of St. Matthew's Passion and Palm Sunday solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
Following is the text of Mayor La Guardia's budget message submitted on Saturday to the Board of Estimate:

TO a baseball writer the harbinger of spring is not the first robin but the arrival of statistical compendiums which are supplied to the Gentlemen of the Press by Bill Brandt and Earl Hilligan, the respective propaganda chiefs of the National and American Leagues. The Green Book contains practically every known fact about the players in the senior circuit and the Red Book has similar information about the chattels in the junior league.

LONDON, April 2 (AP) -- American and British forces have staged another commando-type raid on Solta island off Yugoslavia, the French radio in Algiers declared today, destroying installations and capturing 111 Germans in a strike made with naval and air support.

A revolutionary change in the official economic philosophy of Soviet Russia, which seeks to adapt Communist dogma to the practical requirements of a country whose very existence depends on utmost production, has just been propounded by Russia's reading economists.

Many of the country's best-known jazz artists -- singers, dancers, composers -- appeared at Carnegie Hall last night in "A Salute to Thomas (Fats) Waller" to pay tribute to the memory of the famous Negro jazz musician who died last December.

NEW ORLEANS, April 2 -- Increasing prospects for a higher loan for cotton of the new crop and war reversals in Italy which led to some softening of opinions of an early peace in Europe combined last week to stiffen the new crop positions in futures on the New Orleans Cotton Exchange.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (U.P.) -- Senator Elbert D. Thomas, Democrat, of Utah, favors a two-point Congressional program to increase the incomes of "white collar" workers in the lower-wage brackets, whom he describes as the nation's "forgotten men and women."

Due to pre-Easter retail activities the number of buyers in the market last week was smaller than had been the case previously. Some good spot orders were received for fill-ins, however, mainly on ready-to-wear and handbags, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

LONDON, April 2 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill's broadcast statement on the war situation and certain aspects of British domestic policy generally was regarded as calling last week for no direct reaction from the stock markets.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (U.P.) -- The Eniwetok tragedy was the third -- and possibly fourth -- instance of American service men perishing as a result of accidental fire from American or Allied guns.

A UNITED STATES LIBERATOR BASE in England, April 2 (AP) -- It was unusually quiet today at this base from which planes yesterday accidentally dropped their bombs on the Swiss border city of Schaffhausen while on a mission to southern Germany.

LONDON, April 2 -- Nearly 2,000 liberals and leftists met in London today under Communist auspices in an effort to form a left-wing alliance in the first post-war general election against the dominant Tory party whose leadership made the dissidents in the House of Commons eat crow in Thursday's vote of confidence.

PEARL HARBOR, April 2 -- Seventh Air Force Liberators pounded Dublon, central island in Truk Atoll, before dawn Friday (United States time) in their fourth strike at the enemy's big base in the central Carolines in four straight nights, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today.

A dour picture of the future of all but a few luxury night clubs was emerging last night as operators looked mournfully at empty tables and predicted that the new 30 per cent Federal tax would defeat its own purpose.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, April 3 (AP) -- A complete report on the midday bombing of Truk last Tuesday, United States time, by Solomons-based bombers, showed greater damage to the enemy than that previously listed, today's communique disclosed.

LONDON, April 2 -- The list of American and British correspondents killed on the various fronts in this war rose to twenty-nine tonight with the announcement that two prominent London newspaper men had been killed with Maj. Gen. Orde C. Wingate when his plane crashed against a mountain in Burma March 24.

NAPLES, April 2 -- Another major assault by Maj. Gen. Nathan F. Twining's United States Fifteenth Air Force took strong formations of our heavy bombers today over the Nazis' Daimler Puch plane parts factory and ball-bearing plant at Steyr, Austria, ninety miles west of Vienna.

WITH THE AEF, in Corsica, March 25 (Delayed) (AP) -- Before last September, probably the worst thing that the Germans held against Corsica was a historical resentment because Napoleon was born there. But today it is a thorn in the enemy's side, largely because of Spitfires based there.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 2 (AP) -- Victor Paz Estenssoro, head of the Bolivian revolutionary movement, announced last night that he and two other Cabinet members would resign Monday in compliance with a decree requiring candidates for office to quit their present positions at least three months before the election.
NAPLES, April 2 -- Another recurrence of sharp enemy raids on the Allies' beachhead below Rome has forced a slight withdrawal of one and a half miles southwest of Aprilia, it was announced today.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 2 -- It's a long way off to the next national A.A.U. swimming championship, but a choice spring book entry would be the Bainbridge Naval Station.

LONDON, Monday, April 3 (AP) -- Fresh newspaper criticism of British foreign policy coincided today with reports that Prime Minister Churchill had decided to appoint Sir Alexander Cadogan as Foreign Secretary succeeding Anthony Eden.

MONTREAL, April 2 (Canadian Press) -- Tommy Gorman, general manager of the Canadian Arena Company, revealed today that the Canadiens of the National Hockey League had turned down a cash offer of $18,000 from the Toronto Maple Leafs for outright purchase of Goalie Paul Bibeault.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- Second Lieut. Raymond J. Narwid, whose dangerous job is to take the bang out of booby traps, remembers Pantelleria as the scene of his greatest success.
LONDON, April 2 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin:

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 2 -- It took the Yankees eleven innings at Bader Field this sunny afternoon to down the pesky Dodgers and give Manager Joe McCarthy his first triumph over the Flatbush clan since 1942. Appropriately enough, a couple of the prize rookies on whom he must depend this year combined to fashion this second victory in a row on the Yankee spring exhibition calendar.

CHICAGO, April 2 -- Movement of cash corn in the West last week was the smallest since last fall, and the Government's set-aside order to country elevators to offer 60 per cent of fresh receipts of that grain to essential industries did virtually nothing to relieve the shortage of that grain.

The Civil Service Reform Association yesterday condemned as unwarranted, and probably unconstitutional, the Wicks bill permitting appointments to be made to jobs in post-war public works construction without regard to the Civil Service Law.

The drastic rationing of gasoline and other oil products to civilian consumers along the Atlantic seaboard is no longer necessary from the standpoint of supply. With current shipments into the area running at the rate of almost 1,800,000 barrels daily, the highest on record, the quantity of oil products available to civilian consumers is not far from that in the pre-war period.

Mayor La Guardia again urged New York City consumers yesterday to refuse to pay exorbitant prices for fresh-water fish normally in heavy demand for celebration of Passover throughout the week begining April 7.

Method of caring for dependent children in institutions in the United States are being studied for possible application in the Cidade das Meninas, a "girls' town" in Brazil, Sennorita Maria Junqueira Schmidt, who recently arrived here from Rio de Janeiro, said yesterday in an interview in the office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, 444 Madison Avenue.

Determined "that the political future of Greece shall not be planned by groups abroad," Greek underground forces have formed a united political front and drafted a new Constitution to eliminate the weaknesses of the country's old parliamentary system, Andre Michalopoulos, former Minister of Information, said yesterday in a radio speech on the Columbia Broadcasting System network.

Under its modified ruling the Army has reduced its quota of medical and dental students by 50 per cent. Instead of allocating 5,600 trainees to these schools, as had been planned originally, only 2,800 are to be admitted. Coupled with the growing difficulty of obtaining occupational deferments for students, this reduction may prove serious.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, April 3 (AP) -- A communique: NORTH'WggI" N SECTOR I Ceram: Our heavy units at night at- I tacked Lautem, starting fires. NOIrrTR S-C'l'Oa New Ireland Oue Solomons-baed torpedo bombers attacked installations at Cape St. George. New Britain Rabaul: Our medium and light bombere from the Solomons attacked the enemy base on successive days with approximately 200 tons of explosives.

The election of Isidor Leviton, acting president of the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn, as president was announced last night at the hospital's forty-second annual meeting at the Dr. Leon Louria Memorial Hall, St. Marks and Classon Avenues, Brooklyn.
" Grackles," did you say, "come back with their customary clatter' and with "a touch of human nature in them"? Well, sir, you just haven't met up with the right sort of grackles.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- The joint chiefs of staff have put final approval on a new policy on stockpiles of strategic war materials which will curb this country's imports of such items.

ALBANY, April 2 -- Governor Dewey signed today the Heller bill making it a felony, punishable by a prison sentence up to three years, to do malicious injury to places of religious worship and instruction or to cemeteries.
CAIRO, Ill., April 2 (AP) -- It took the National League champion Cardinals ten innings to eke out a 5-4 victory over the Fourth Ferrying Group's fine draft-evolved baseball team today.

The Rev. Dr. William J. Mahoney, president of St. John's University, added his voice yesterday to the thousands of clerics and laymen asking that Rome be declared an open city by both sides in the Italian campaign, thus avoiding the destruction of "its cultural beauty and treasures which belong to all nations, all creeds and all ages."
SAN FRANCISCO, April 2 -- Old "Red" Killifer's son is net bothered by wildness any more, but he has kept right on beaning Japanese.

NEW DELHI, India, April 2 -- Japanese forces advancing through northern Manipur, in India, have cut across the Imphal-Dimapur road and are pushing their attack against Kohima, key point on the road. The well-surfaced Imphal-Dimapur road, linking Imphal with the Bengal-Assam Railway, is a main supply route for the Imphal front.

CLEVELAND, April 2 -- Wives and daughters of well-to-do men here discuss acute labor shortages while attending tea parties and sitting around bridge tables, but surprisingly few will take a war job, according to recruiters from the area office of the War Manpower Commission.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- America's role in the smashing offensive of the Red Army into eastern Europe was pictured today by Leo T. Crowley, Foreign Economic Administrator, as consisting primarily of 9,500,000 tons of vital weapons, war supplies and food shipped from the United States to Soviet Union under lend-lease agreements.
Lady Charles, wife of Sir Noel Hughes Havelock Charles, Bart., British Ambassador to Brazil, is at the Ritz-Carlton.

SCHAFFHAUSEN, Switzerland, April 2 (U.P.) -- Fires were still burning in this northeastern Swiss town today from yesterday's mistaken United States Eighth Air Force attack, but the task of clearing debris and rubble was progressing briskly.

NEW DELHI, India, April 2 (AP) -- A communique: On the Arakan front there Is no Important change. Near the eastern tun. nel on the Maungdaw-Buthcdaung road there was an exchange of mortar fire. South of Buthedaung a minor Japanese attack on one of our positions was repulsed with loss to the enemy-on March 31.

JERUSALEM, April 2 (AP) -- Indicating that the backbone of Jewish extremist gangs may have been broken, British authorities suddenly lifted the rigid curfew in Palestine today and announced that police had made more than sixty arrests in a round-up in all major Palestine cities.

PHILADELPHIA, April 2 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the issuance and sale by Atlantic City Electric Company of 55,000 shares of $100 par value cumulative preferred stock.

YORK, Neb., April 2 -- Faced with the opposition of much of the Republican organization and supporters of other aspirants for the Presidential nomination, Wendell L. Willkie today carried his Nebraska campaign to the grass roots of Seward, Butler and York Counties.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal communications Commission:

Increased buying of the Canadian free dollar to put it fractionally higher on the week, and an irregular trend in the Argentina peso which put that unit at the lowest since April, 1943, were the only diversions of an otherwise firm array of values for the foreign currencies last week.

CHICAGO, April 2 (AP) -- Harrison E. Spangler, chairman of the Republican National Committee, predicted today that his party's 1944 farm plank would call for the elimination of "the bureaucracy" of the New Deal's Agricultural Adjustment Agency farm program if not the entire program itself.

" Lovers and Friends," starring Katharine Cornell, will close after its 168th performance at the Plymouth on April 22. The Dodie Smith comedy wil take to the road on April 24, opening in Boston. As indicated, George Abbott's presentation of "A Highland Fling" will come to the Plymouth on April 28.

The Soviet Government is taking the tides of fortune at the flood. As the Germans are driven out of Russia and the Allies wait to launch their grand offensive on the Continent, Moscow fills the interval of suspense with diplomatic activities of great significance, not only as indications of a readiness to capitalize at once on her military victories but as a clue to Russian post-war policy in Europe and Asia.

NAPLES, Italy, April 2 (AP) -- Count Carlo Sforza, one of liberated Italy's foremost political figures, indicated today he would refuse any offer of a post in the Badoglio Government while Victor Emmanuel remained King, regardless of a Communist proposal that all parties collaborate in making it a "war Government with authority as well as power."

The tragic error through which the peaceful and friendly Swiss town of Schaffhausen was laid waste by American Liberators shows that our precision bombing is not always as precise as we have assumed. Our fliers, blown off their course by unexpectedly high winds, were eleven miles from their objective in southern Germany.

A man was killed and two other persons were cut and bruised at Fifth Avenue and Twenty-first Street at 8:30 o'clock last night when the driver of a stolen automobile, who was being chased by policemen riding the running board of a taxicab, crashed into another taxicab and caused it to turn over twice.

LONDON, April 2 (AP) -- Mosquito bombers of the RAF struck last last night in another of their "reminder" assaults on German industrial centers that have recently shown new signs of life. Their targets were Hanover, Krefeld and Aachen. No RAF plane was lost.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull expressed "deep regret" today over the accidental bombing by American airmen of Schaffhausen, Switzerland, and said that "appropriate reparation" would be made as far as "humanly possible" for the "unfortunate event."

A letter published in your Sunday issue, March 26, and signed by Prof. Frederick L. Schuman of William College begins with the statement the "News reports, editorials and columnists have all agreed that (1) the U.S.S.R. granted diplomatic recognition to the Royal Italian Government on March 13; (2) this was the first instance of the recognition of that Government by any of the United Nations," etc.

May I add a little to the scientist discussion on the hail which fell Memphis last Sunday night from the point of view of one who over made years can recall the chill of terms which recurs even to this day at the report of an unusual hailstorm.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- A war-caused shortage of "smokeless" bituminous coal from Southern Appalachian mines next winter was predicted tonight by Dr. C.J. Potter, Deputy Solid Fuels Administrator, who said this would "come as a shock" to Eastern States and would also be "bad news" throughout the Middle West.

The total amount of "off-grade" butter moved out of storage by the War Food Administration since WFA began storing it a year ago rose to 550,000 pounds yesterday when that Federal agency announced an additional offering of 135,000 pounds.

LONDON, April 3 (U.P.) -- The Finnish Riksdag [Parliament] met in Helsinki tonight, but apparently it did not discuss the acceptance of new Russian armistice terms, and Scandinavian dispatches turned abruptly pessimistic on the possibilities of an early peace.
WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- Curiously, men who never have shown any undignified haste in giving women workers equal pay for equal work, are now scrapping for that same principle.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 3 -- Following a Greek Cabinet meeting lasting most of this morning, Prime Minister Emmanuel J. Tsouderos, who has been Premier since the few days before Greece's evacuation, resigned.

DETROIT, April 4 (AP) -- The United Automobile Workers (CIO) in a monthly research report asserted that the immediate post-war period would find manpower, material and machine capacity for an annual production of more than $200,000,000,000 worth of goods and services for the American people and for shipment abroad.
Several additional resignations and appointments in the Office of Price Administration's regional rent control offices here were announced yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, April 3 (AP) -- Opposing attorneys thundered five hours of final pleas to the Charlie Chaplin jury today, the prosecution contending that the comedian transported Joan Berry to New York and back with immoral intent and the defense counsel shouting:

CHICAGO, April 3 -- American business will find itself perched atop an economic "keg of dynamite" that may explode at any time in the next ten years unless sound plans are formulated at once to avoid post-war repercussions, James L. Palmer, first vice president of Marshall Field Co., told 700 business men here today.

To supplement "V" and "VT" type loans, which provide for termination financing in cases where loan agreements can be completed prior to contract cancellations, the Government is preparing a "T" type loan which will be designed primarily to meet the requirements of small concerns and which will permit the making of loans after termination, George S. Dively, secretary-treasurer of the Harris-Seybold-Potter Company, Cleveland, disclosed yesterday.

The old guard, led by Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase of New York University, retained control of the venerable and staid Lotos Club last night in a heated election contest -- first in the seventy-four-year history of the group -- that saw the "ins" forced to run on an insurgent ticket to win.

Since its inception in 1938 the American Actors Theatre, first called the American Actors Company, has been operating off Times Square. Tonight it will achieve its goal, the Broadway presentation of "Only the Heart," by Horton Foote, at the Bijou.

PANAMA, April 3 -- A rising against the Government of El Salvador resulted in the ousting of Gen. Maximilano Hernandez Martinez from the Presidency, according to reports received today from reliable sources.
NEW DELHI, India, April 3 (UP) -- A communique:

The National City Bank issued yesterday its quarterly condition statement as of March 31, showing total resources of $4,168,876,487, compared with $3,967,819,349 on Dec. 31, 1943, and $3,568,434,805 on March 31, 1943. Total deposits were $3,929,474,644, against $3,733,649,246 three months before, and with $3,352,958,745 one year before.

Many fathers drafted before July 1 will receive a substantial refund from the Department of Internal Revenue -- probably around mid-July, 1945 -- because income tax experts yesterday discovered, after careful study of the current tax law, that these selectees should get back from the Government the major part of the taxes withheld from their salaries by civilian employers during the first half of this year.

The spring redecoration of W. J. Sloane's "House of Years" has been completed, and the exhibit was opened to the public yesterday. It is evident that the family occupying the model dwelling has increased in size. A baby carriage stands in the front hall closet and the nursery upstairs has been outfitted.

Fifty Bronx housewives, most of them with baby carriages, marched yesterday afternoon in a Parkchester Victory parade, the victory being over a neighborhood butcher shop found guilty by the Office of Price Administration of violating price ceilings.

TRENTON, N.J., April 3 -- The Senate passed tonight, and sent to the Assembly for approval, a bill to establish a State department of taxation and finance as proposed by Gov. Walter E. Edge's Commission on Administrative Reorganization.

Ferdinand Eberstadt, president of F. Eberstadt Co., Inc., and formerly vice chairman of the War Production Board, was elected a director of Braniff Airways yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders held at Dallas, Tex.

More than a hundred American colleges and universities have offered scholarships valued at $800,000 to the Anglo-American-Hellenic Bureau of Education for the training of Greek students in this country. This will permit many deserving scholars from Greece to study in our institutions of higher learning.

ALBANY, April 3 (AP) -- Lieut. James S. Collins, 44, night police chief of Cohoes, was arrested by State troopers tonight on the basis of the first indictment to be handed up by a special grand jury investigating crime in Albany County.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Negotiations are continuing with Spain on an agreement to limit her aid to Germany, the State Department said today, but in saying this it gave no encouragement in support of a report that the negotiations might be concluded this week.

LONDON, Tuesday, April 4 (U.P.) -- The Soviet Second Ukrainian Army has penetrated eleven miles into Rumania after having gained two bridgeheads on the Prut while the First Army yesterday carried to within twenty-two miles of the southeastern corner of German-annexed Poland, Moscow announced last night.

In a statement accompanying the annual report of the American Safety Razor Corporation, mailed yesterday to stockholders, Milton Dammann, president, announced the general release of Gem razors to the trade after a two-year stoppage of production owing to Government restrictions.

PHILADELPHIA, April 3 -- A plan for the liquidation and dissolution of the Connecticut River Conservation Company and its two subsidiaries, the Essex Storage Electric Company, Inc., and the Mascoma River Improvement Company was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
DANBURY, Conn., April 3 (UP) Rose Wilder Lane, novelist and individualist, has gone into retirement until the American scene produces "a politician who'll stand up and tell the truth."

Suzanne et Roger provided food for conversation for their luncheon audience at the St. Regis yesterday. They launched the most extreme of the season's hats. They were larger than any that have been seen hereabouts in many a day.

It is not only in lands overrun by armies that populations have been dislocated and set adrift. Here in the United States, far from battle zones, thousands of people are wanderers today as a result, direct or indirect, of the war.

A long-awaited final argument that may have a decisive effect in international policies with respect to foreign exchange rates and customs valuations is scheduled for hearing today before the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals in Washington.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Steps were taken at the Capitol today to expedite plans designed to supplant or supplement the Office of War Mobilization, formed by Presidential Executive Order, and convert it into a single-head statutory agency to handle economic mobilization and demobilization.

The Equitable Securities Corporation, John Nuveen Co., and associates, won the award yesterday of a new issue of $393,000 McMinnville, Tenn., electric system revenue refunding bonds at a price of 101.58. The issue consisted of $1,320,000 of 2 per cent bonds, due June 1, 1945 to 1950 and $261,000 of 1 3/4 per cent bonds due June 1, 1951 to 1959.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 3 -- For a number of years, both in St. Louis and after he took over in Brooklyn, it had become something of a spring custom with Professor Branch Rickey to forecast, after innumerable transcontinental tours and telephonic conversations, that the baseball world was about to see a new Joe Medwick.

Another indication of desires on the part of leading Democrats to present a picture of party unity in this State, in preparation for the November election, came yesterday, when State Chairman James A. Farley announced the speaking list for the Jefferson Day dinner, State party fund-raising affair, to be held at the Hotel Commodore May 8.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Secretary Harold L. Ickes, as Petroleum Administrator, today denied there is sufficient gasoline in the East, or in any other part of the country, to warrant larger rations for motorists.

ON THE NORTH COAST OF NEW GUINEA, April 3 -- Complaining or "griping," an Army practice and privilege that permits blowing off steam, is on the whole healthy. Occasionally, however, one runs across a man who concedes matters are just what he wants them to be.

ATLANTA, April 3 (AP) -- Southern reaction to the Supreme Court decision holding that Negroes may participate in Democratic primary elections ranged today from cautious non-committance to stubborn determination to preserve traditional white control of election machinery.

Under an arrangement of the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association, the midshipmen of Annapolis and the cadets of the Coast Guard Academy in New London are to have a dual competition in Star Class sloops on the Thames, New London, April 22.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The War Ballot Commission at its first meeting today asked State election officials for "full cooperation" in making the new soldier vote machinery work.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- A large segment of the construction industry was permitted by the War Production Board today to return virtually to its pre-war standards in the use of reinforced concrete which has been restricted to conform to the supply of metals.

WITH A POLISH CORPS OF THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Italy, April 3 -- When General Dabrowski, during the Napoleonic Wars, created a Polish legion to fight for the liberation of partitioned Poland, the song that is now that country's national anthem was written.

ALGIERS, April 3 -- The political difficulties that have been growing for three weeks seemed about to come to a climax tonight after a day of prolonged conferences among Gen. Charles de Gaulle and member of the Committee of National Liberation and the Provisional Consultative Assembly.

NAPLES, April 3 -- Large formations of the heavy bombers of Major Gen. Nathan F. Twing's Fifteenth Air Force, winging their way deep into southeastern Europe, pounded the rail center at Budapest and an important factory just south of that city.

LONDON, April 3 -- Five members of the American delegation to the conference of Allied Ministers of Education arrived in London today and began preliminary discussions looking toward the eventual creation of a cultural "United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration" to reconstruct the wrecked and plundered educational systems of German-occupied Europe.

Nathan Gordon, a member of the viola section of the NBC Symphony, made his recital debut at Town Hall last night. Mr. Gordon is a musician of unusual gifts and of great promise. And he needs only experience on the recital platform to bring a deeper approach to the interpretive side of his playing.

Despite the fact that Colombia will be one of the important postwar markets in South America for American machinery, its purchases after the war of consumer and consumer-durable goods in this country will be limited, Ralph Johnson, general sales manager of the International General Electric Company in Colombia, predicted here yesterday.

Sale for cash of the large factory property formerly occupied by the United States Rubber Company, comprising four buildings on a two-acre plot in Jersey City, is announced by J.I. Kislak, Inc., brokers in the deal. The property occupies the block frontage on Wilkinson Avenue, between Arlington and Garfield Avenues.

The Russian invasion of old Rumania, beyond what Marshal Stalin has designated as the "Soviet state frontiers," has now been confirmed by Foreign Commissar Molotoff. The invasion began more than a week ago with a Russian surprise attack on the important railway junction point of Jassy, but Moscow withheld the announcement until the movement had developed in full force.

Judge Saul S. Streit, on the recommendation of Assistant District Attorney Harold Sussman, dismissed yesterday an indictment for rape on which a jury three weeks before had been unable to agree in the trial of Anson W. Chandler, 24 years old, a Navy chief petty officer.
LONDON, Tuesday, April 4 (AP) -- The Russian Monday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

BERNE, Switzerland, April 3 -- Official irritation over the facility afforded airplane passengers and other travelers between Berlin and Stockholm ot give information concerning damage inflicted by air attacks on Berlin and other German points was expressed by Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop's spokesman at the Wilhelmstrasse press conference today.

MONTREAL, April 3 (Canadian Press) -- The Chicago Black Hawks went through a light workout today and Pilot Paul Thompson pronounced them all set to take on the Canadiens in the opening game of the Stanley Cup finals tomorrow night.

MOSCOW, April 3 -- The biggest news in today's Soviet newspapers was the entrance of Russian troops into Rumania, an event that apparently has been in progress since shortly after the arrival of the Red Army at the Prut.

Confident that the total of $581,061 raised for war relief a year ago will be increased considerably and possibly doubled, the five New York racing associations are formulating plans for the 1944 contributions, it was announced yesterday.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 3 -- Most golfers on the winter tournament circuit will remember 1944 as the year the P.G.A. winter bond tour sold $20,000,000 worth of war bonds. But Jonnny Bulla, the golfer who turned airline pilot, will remember it for a misplayed quarter-inch putt.

LONDON, April 3 (U.P.) -- United States war planes, flying 29,016 sorties over Germany and Naziheld Europe, dropped 30,176 tons of bombs on enemy targets and destroyed 1,081 German planes during March, the greatest month in the history of air war, it was announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Only 314,000,000 pairs of shoes, instead of 360,000,000, are to be made for civilians this year and the allotment of half soles for civilian repairs has been cut to 135,000,000 from 150,000,000.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, April 4 (AP) -- A communique:
On a recent round of city stores we found the following festive foods for use at Easter:

Tammany Hall has recommended the appointment of James Pemberton, political protege of Clarence H. Neal and Representative Vito Marcantonio, as chief confidential clerk to the Supreme Court Justices in the First Department, at $5,500 a year, it became known yesterday.

In a total of 748 transactions, sales of excess inventories by five eastern aircraft manufacturers who are staging a surplus materials exhibit at the Hotel MeAlpin, last week exceeded $1,320,000, it was announced yesterday. The figures were given out as the exhibit, held under the auspices, of the New York regional office of the War Production. Board, entered its second and final week.

PHILADELPHIA, April 3 -- A registration statement covering $1,702,260 of 5 per cent cumulative income debentures (subordinated) of the South Coast Corporation, already outstanding and owned by the Celotex Corporation, was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Negroes cannot legally be barred from voting in the Texas Democratic primaries, the Supreme Court ruled by eight to one today in a decision of far-reaching significance which upset a nine-year-old ruling and brought a lone but sharp dissent.

Investment buyers contributed to the Brooklyn realty activity by purchasing two apartment houses. The larger of the two was the four-story house at 78-82 East Eighteenth Street with five stores, assessed at $80,000, purchased by the 82 East Eighteenth Street Corporation from Loomis J. Grossman. Irving Schatz was the broker in the deal.

The letter which appeared in this morning's paper entitled "The Draft of Fathers" calls for a response to point out that as against fathers in essential work there are many times the number who are engaged in unessential work and who shield themselves behind the petticoats of a wife and family to escape any share in the war effort.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. April 3 -- Obviously convinced, despite triumphs in two exhibition games by his 1944 Yankees, that no time must be lost to bolster the club wherever opportunity offers, Manager Joe McCarthy today announced that Bill Drescher, backstop for the Newark Bears, will join the club tomorrow when the Yanks tackle the Dodgers again in Trenton, N.J. An all-night rain prevented the game listed for today.

LONDON, April 3 -- The stock markets have started the week with a firm tone today, although the turnover in most sections remained small. The shipping section again was most prominent but business was less active than during last week.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, April 3 -- It is a virtual certainty that a concentrated sea and air attack on Japan proper will be hastened, perhaps started within several months, if the Japanese persist in their current attempts to drive into India or knock out China.

NAPLES, April 3 -- After its slight penetration into the Allies lines southwest of Aprilia, on the Anzio beachhead, the German Army attempted the heaviest attack since the collapse of its major offensive on March 1, it was announced today.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, April 4 -- Red Army forces driving into Rumania last night were reported only eight miles from Jassy, rail junction city, recently reported as having been German headquarters for the southern front. More than fifty Rumanian villages have been captured and the lateral railroad between Jassy and Dorohoi severed, Soviet headquarters announced.
LONDON, April 3 -- Mr. Molotoff's statement about Rumania has gone a long way toward reassuring doubters that the Atlantic Charter is still the guiding star of all the major Allies.

The situation between our Government and the French Committee of National Liberation brings to mind the observation of Herbert Spencer that what is tragic is not the conflict between right and wrong but the conflict between right and right.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, April 3 -- Replying to a query by the insular House of Representatives, Chancellor Jaime Benitez of the University of Puerto Rico said today that he knew Robert Morss Lovett was being investigated by the Dies Committee when he appointed him Professor of English a few days ago, following Mr. Lovett's resignation as Secretary of the Virgin Islands Government.

Six large store leases in the midtown section of Manhattan were reported yesterday in buildings owned by Charles F. Noyes. The series of deals led Arnold L. Steinfeld, associated with the midtown rental division of the Charles F. Noyes Company, who negotiated them, to predict that this activity presaged a record upswing in this type of realty business after the war.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., April 3 -- War Page, finding a track to his liking, coasted home to his first score of the Florida season when Jockey J.R. Layton led the Boblyn Stable's colorbearer all the way in the six-furlong fifth and feature event, titled the Oleanders, at Tropical Park today.

PITTSBURGH, April 3 -- An argument over the display of an American flag provoked a strike of 859 members of the CIO United Steel Workers of America today at the Aliquippa (Pa.) works of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation.

LONDON, April 3 -- Earl Winterton provided plenty of publicity for songstresses and, incidentally, showed spontaneous rhetorical eloquence when he informed the House of Commons that female crooners reminded him "of the caterwauling of an inebriated cockatoo."

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The loss of the Balkans would so impair Germany's ability to continue the war that she may be expected to make every effort to prevent the capitaulation of individual states and to defend the area against the Russian invasion that is now beginning, Leo T. Crowley, Foreign Economic Administrator, said today.

Marking the climax of "beat-the-tax" buying of items subject to the 20 per cent Federal excise levies, and purchasing of Easter apparel, sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 45 per cent last week over the comparative week of 1943, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Add to the list of films opening this week, "The Lady and the Monster," a Republic adaptation of the Curt Siodmak novel, "Donovan's Brain," which will arrive Friday at the Rialto. Richard Arlen, Vera Hruba Ralston, Erich von Stroheim, Helen Vinson and Sidney Blackmer head the cast of the melodrama.

The business properties at 119-123 East Twenty-seventh Street, through to 118 East Twenty-eighth Street, in Manhattan, comprising ten-story and three-story buildings containing seven stores, three lofts and seventy-nine offices, have been sold by the Brooklyn Savings Bank to the 119 to 123 East Twenty-seventh Street Corporation.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., April 3 -- Voicing his "proud confidence" that victory over both Germany and Japan was assured, Field Marshal Sir John Greer Dill, senior British member of the Combined Chiefs of Staff, reaffirmed today Great Britain's pledge to "fight on" at the side of America after Germany's defeat, "however long and difficult the road may be, until the Japanese are destroyed."

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The eligibility requirements for voting in the Texas Democratic primaries are a device to keep Negroes from participating. But the candidates chosen in these primaries have many legal and other advantages embedded in State law, and the source of the eligibility requirements -- the Democratic State Convention -- is a State agent.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., April 3 (AP) -- Governor M.M. Neely issued a proclamation today directing West Virginia's State Police to assume the responsibility of law enforcement in the steel town of Weirton, where the county authorities recently arrested representatives of the CIO-United Steel Workers Union who were distributing organization literature.

The city-wide campaign of the 1944 Red Cross War Fund has reached 85 per cent of its goal of $22,386,000, with $15,862,000 cash in hand and pledges of $3,200,000, John P. Stevens Jr., city chairman, announced yesterday.

FIFTEENTH AIR FORCE, Liberator Base in Italy, March 2 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Three American fliers gave their lives in the flaming funeral pyre of a Liberator bomber today in a futile effort to save an injured crewmate unable to parachute to safety.

GRAND ISLAND, Neb., April 3 -- In speeches at Hastings, Kearney and Grand Island, Wendell L. Willkie warned leaders of the Republican party today that any repetition of the deals and combinations which resulted in the nomination of Warren G. Harding for President in 1920 at this year's national convention in Chicago would bring about the party's inevitable and overwhelming defeat.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- American aircraft producers reached an all-time monthly record with their output of 9,118 planes in March and attained a peak which will probably not be equaled again, Charles E. Wilson, chairman of the Aircraft Production Board, said today.

As is customary each Monday, the Treasury announced yesterday afternoon its plans for withdrawing funds during the latter part of the week from Government war loan accounts in the principal commercial banks of the nation. The call issued yesterday is effective on Thursday, Friday and Saturday and is considerably smaller than many of the recent ones.

CLEVELAND, April 3 -- The same principle used in gas masks for protecting the lives of our armed forces against possible attacks with poison gas can be applied to construct simple, sturdy and economical air-conditioning units for homes, automobiles and other places, it was reported today at the meeting of the American Chemical Society by Dr. Donald F. Othmer, head of the Department of Chemical Engineering at the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn.

LONDON, April 3 (AP) -- A Conservative reform committee proposed tonight a drastic reorganization of the British coal industry, with a miners' charter guaranteeing a minimum wage based on a 37 1/2-hour week the year round as a means of preventing strikes such as the present one which already had cut deeply into war production.

THEY were just a couple of country boys from Oklahoma getting together again in the big city. For five years they had been inseparable companions and then life shunted them off in opposite directions. But a week or so ago they were together once more, reminiscing with relish about the past and living anew "bright college years."
LONDON, April 3 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berin and recorded by The United Press:

At the same time that Col. Bryan Houston, National Deputy OPA Administrator for Rationing, announced here yesterday that there would be "no startling changes in the rationing of gasoline in the next few months," the Automobile Club of New York declared that Eastern motorists "welcome the spotlight turned on the gasoline situation" by THE NEW YORK TIMES of yesterday.

On March 14, 1942, a destroyer called the O'Bannon was launched at the Bath Iron Works Yard. Her name, warlike in itself, was an inheritance from Lieutenant O'Bannon, who with a sergeant, six marines and a variegated force of Arabs, Greeks and Italians picked up on the way marched from Alexandria through the Libyan Desert to the Tripolitan seaport Derne.

LONDON, April 3 -- The battleship Tirpitz, most formidable unit in the Reich's dwindling fleet and once a deadly hunter on the high seas, lies crippled anew tonight in Alten Fjord on Norway's North Cape, after a successful bombing attack, presumably by carrier-based aircraft.

Mayor La Guardia urged New Yorkers again yesterday to make a habit of cooperating with the regular Wednesday collections of waste paper by the Department of Sanitation. He expressed the hope that improved weather this week might help to boost tomorrow's total over last Wednesday's pick-up by sanitation trucks of 579 tons, with an estimated additional collection of between 300 and 400 tons by the trucks of welfare agencies and the carts of junk dealers.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended March 29:

PEARL HARBOR, April 3 -- Ten more atolls in the Marshall Islands have been occupied by United States forces, Pacific Fleet headquarters announced today. These and Wotho, whose seizure was announced on March 12, were taken after the capture of Kwajalein, Eniwetok and Majuro Atolls in February.

The changes that shortages and rationing have brought about in cooking will be the basis for a Wartime School for Housewives, sponsored by the New York State Emergency Food Commission, to open on April 24. Nutritionists on the staff of the commission will instruct the classes, to be held from 7:30 to 9 P.M. each Monday and on Tuesdays from 2 to 3:30 P.M., for four weeks, at the American Common, 40 East Fortieth Street.

LONDON, April 3 (AP) -- Yugoslav Partisan troops were driving rapidly into the interior of Serbia, Marshal Tito (Josip Broz) reported today, as other Partisan forces fought Axis troops to a standstill in Montenegro and Slovenia.

Hamilton Shea, formerly with the Chase National Bank and more recently secretary-treasurer of the TelAutograph Corporation, has joined the Emerson Drug Compan, Inc., as assistant controller, with headquarters in Baltimore.

The book clinic of the American Institute of Graphic Arts has named four books as its April selections, chosen on the basis of "purposeful typographic design and excellence of production." The books are "From Wilderness to Empire: A History of California, 1542-1900," by Robert Glass Cleland (Knopf); "Silly Girl," by Ahgna Enters (Houghton Mifflin); "The Broken Arc," by Mayette Meyneng (Harpers), and "The Sword Is Drawn," Andre Norton (Houghton Mifflin).

The weight of trading on the stock market yesterday was on the lower side although a partial recovery from the lows ensued when selling lifted. News of an important market character was absent so that proponents of a technical correction had freedom of action.

LONDON, April 3 (Reuter) -- Mrs. Helen Duncan, who claims to be a spiritualistic medium, was sentenced today to nine months imprisonment at Old Bailey criminal court after a seven days' trial under the 200-year-old witchcraft act.

CHICAGO, April 3 -- May wheat continued today to hold at ceiling price on the Board of Trade, but a fair business was transacted in that delivery largely in the way of selling attributed to a professional trader who took July at 2 3/4 cents a bushel discount.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The Army Navy production award for excellence in the manufacture of war materials has been given to twenty additional firms. They are:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 3 -- Warner Brothers have named Ida Lupino, Paul Lukas and Sidney Greenstreet to star in "One Man's Secret," a magazine story by Rita Weiman. Thomas Job has been assigned to write the screen play, which Jerry Nald will produce.

CHICAGO, April 3 (AP) -- The American Democratic National Committee, an organization opposed to a fourth term for Franklin D. Roosevelt, declared today that it would function "right up to election day."

The Japanese invasion of India is becoming a matter of increasing concern. The influx of this enemy "army of liberation," which the British have been unable thus far to repel, may stir waves of political unrest. It threatens to isolate General Stilwell's Chinese American forces deep in the heart of Burma.

CHICAGO, April 3 -- Condemnation of "political exploitation of farmers," recommendation of effective price supports and arguments for and against subsidies were voiced by farm leaders who met here today to present suggestions for a farm plank to the Committee on Agriculture of the Republican Post-War Advisory Council.

LONDON, Tuesday, April 4 -- Cooperation between the Anglo-American and the Russian fighting services reached a new high level yesterday when United States air power dealt a heavy blow to German supply lines in Hungary on the vital Balkan front.

The twenty-eighth annual exhibition by Brooklyn artists at the Brooklyn Museum -- a large and uneven show including oils, watercolors, sculpture and work in black-and-white -- will open with a private showing from 4 to 6 o'clock this afternoon for museum members, exhibiting artists and their guests.

German military authorities have served notice on the Rumanian Government that civilians and peasants fleeing from the Russians would be shot if they jammed roads and highways and thus blocked German troops headed for the front, the Swedish newspaper Social Demokraten said in a dispatch reported to the Office of War Information Monday.
