The time which people in this country and Great Britain devote to thinking about foreign policy may be said to be divided into two parts. Half the time we puzzle about the foreign policy of our own Government, American or British, as the case may be.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 3 -- In a quarrel over the bill pending before Governor Dewey that would open Westchester County again to the killing of deer with bow and arrow, representatives of 4,000 sportsmen clashed here today with spokesmen for 1,000 residents who would restrict archers to the use of straw targets.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull accepted today the statement of V.M. Molotoff, Russian Foreign Commissar, concerning Russia's objectives in Rumania as meaning that the Russian Army's main business was to defeat the enemy in the field.

Accusing the Soviet Government of a "double-faced" foreign policy with respect to its professed desire for collaboration with the United States and Great Britain and denouncing the Stalin regime for failure to grant political and civil liberties to the Russian people, Victor A. Kravchenko, an official of the Soviet Purchasing Commission in Washington, announced his resignation yesterday and placed himself "under the protection of American public opinion."
A dictator in the traditions of Hitler and Mussolini, Gen. Maximiliano Hernandez Martinez held the Presidency of El Salvador, second smallest Central American nation, for more than twelve years.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., April 3 -- John Whitlow Wyatt, 35-year-old star right-hand pitcher, arrived today, and nothing so important to the fortunes of the 1944 Dodgers has happened since they began spring training on March 15.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Cash income and expenditures of the Treasury reached new peaks last month, but a record of $6,573,000,000 in receipts failed by $1,952,000,000 to match spending.

NEW DELHI, India, April 3 (AP) -- Japanese invasion forces have cut supply roads into the big Allied base at Imphal, capital of Manipur State in eastern India, it was disclosed today as fighting raged in the wild hills of the Naga headhunters east of Kohima, sixty miles north of Imphal.

MILWAUKEE, April 3 (AP) -- A major test comes tomorrow for Wendell L. Willkie in his quest for another Republican nomination when Wisconsin holds the first Presidential primary offering any basis for appraisal of his 1944 Midwest strength. The Republicans will elect twenty-four national convention delegates and the Democrats twenty-six.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, contended today that the McKellar amendment to the Independent Office Supply bill, which would force the TVA to come to Congress for all of its operational funds, would deprive that agency of the freedom of technical decision and emergency action necessary to enable it to meet its power and other programs.

A resolution calling for the ouster of Irving D. Neustein as Democratic leader of the Sixth Assembly District was adopted last night at a meeting of Democratic workers in the district in the Lenox Assembly Hall, 256 East Second Street, presided over by Assemblyman Sidney Moses.

Mayor La Guardia's budget message naturally led straight to a discussion of the rapid-transit deficit and what to do about it. A review of the document shows that the city is hemmed in by absolutely necessary expenditures. The Mayor has whittled at various possible economies until, as he believes, he can't whittle away any more.

Renewed commission house liquidation, spurred by Allied war successes, tended yesterday to carry cotton prices lower on the New York Cotton Exchange. They closed 2 to 10 points lower than Saturday's final quotations on active months.

Reflecting the combined effects of "beat-the-tax" and Easter buying, sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 23 per cent in March over the like month last year, according to the monthly survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

ALBANY, April 3 -- Governor Dewey signed today three bills which he described as the substantial, principal parts of a great program to fulfill the obligations of the State "to its sons and daughters in the armed forces."

To understand the conduct of French employers under German occupation, it is necessary to have some knowledge of the economic and financial strangle-hold that the Germans established over French production from the start.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 3 -- Two deaths here from botulism, a sequel to the eating of home-canned vegetables, were reported today by the Board of Health. The victims were Mrs. Rose Lapero, 54 years old, who died yesterday at noon in the brew Rochelle Hospital, and her mother, Mrs. Frances Cioffari, 80, who died there last night.

ASHER BRYNES' "Revolution Comes of Age"* never quite lives up to its promise. In language that is sometimes startlingly suggestive, sometimes opaque, it argues that peace and war are all bound up together, that one inevitably conditions the other, and that generals and statesmen who fail to understand this must of necessity doom their countries to failure.

Acquisition of manufacturing facilities by the nation's floor covering distributors in the post-war period in order to combat the loss in sales volume to retailers resulting from the trend toward direct rug and carpet distribution was predicted yesterday by Dr. Joseph J. Klein, senior partner in the firm of Klein, Hinds Finke, certified public accountants, and former president of the New York State Society of Public Accountants.
PITTSBURGH, April 3 (AP) -- Billy Miller, Pittsburgh lightweight, gained a split decision over Lulu Costantino of New York in the ten-round feature at the Gardens tonight.

The use of a wartime advertising theme which, with minor changes, will enable the manufacturer to resume peacetime advertising, is advocated by H.E. Warren, advertising manager of the Edison General Electric Appliance Company, Chicago, makers of Hotpoint appliances.

It was little Anna Cassinelli's day yesterday at the Hospital for Special Surgery, 321 East Forty-second Street, where she has spent forty-five of her fifty-two years. Two hundred of her friends, all co-workers there, gathered in the lecture hall to tell her that her shy cheerfulness had come to be as much a part of the institution as the bustling of nurses and the signaling of bells.

Rabbi Israel Goldstein, president of the Zionist Organization of America, who returned recently from a five-week trip to England, denounced the British White Paper restricting immigration to Palestine, in an address last night at the B'Nai Jeshurun Community Center, 270 West Eighty-ninth Street.

LONDON, April 3 -- Two audacious British naval officers have succeeded in escaping from a German prisoner of war camp with no other aid than nerve and a six-week course in German. They didn't even bother to disguise themselves, wearing for their twenty-two-day trek through enemy country their Royal Navy uniforms.

BUENOS AIRES, April 3 (AP) -- The Argentine Government decreed today that all commercial radio stations in the country must subscribe to the services of the Argentine News Agency, Andi, at a cost ranging from 5 to 15 per cent of their gross income.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- A program calling for 100 per cent utilization of the country's machine tool industry even after war production requirements have leveled off was proposed today by the industry's labor advisory committee of the War Production Board in a report to the WPB.

A group of twelve table settings, each designed by a real homemaker who might conceivably have turned it out for one of her own parties, will be on display in the linen department of James McCreery from today until the end of the week.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, April 4 -- United States troops have captured Ndrilio and Koruniat islets north of Los Negros in the Admiralties, Gen. Douglas MacArthur reported today. Only 400 to 500 Japanese soldiers now remain effective in the Admiralties of more than 5,000 there at the time of the American landing, it was stated.

The Sixty-ninth Regiment of the New York Guard joined the fight alongside the old "Fighting Sixty-ninth" last night when 100 members of the First Battalion donated blood in their headquarters, the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, 68 Lexington Avenue.

LONDON, April 3 -- The possibility of an Anglo-American agreement that would assure the United States of the post-war use of not only airfields built with lend-lease funds but any British terminals on agreed international air routes was foreseen in aviation circles as Adolf A. Berle Jr. and Lord Beaverbrook began their talks on civil air policy today.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- All physically fit coal miners between 18 and 26 years of age should be drafted into the armed forces despite protests that an already serious fuel shortage would be aggravated, the Committee on Manpower Claimants was reported to have decided today.
A special communique, as broadcast yesterday from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

TRENTON, N.J., April 3 (AP) -- The Trenton Jockey Club, which had its application turned down last year, applied to the New Jersey Racing Commission again today for a license to run horse races with pari-mutuel betting at the State Fair Grounds.

Seven prominent men have accepted posts as honorary chairmen in the $4,500,000 campaign of the Greater New York Fund, which will be opened on April 18 at a dinner at the Hotel Astor, it was announced yesterday by J. Stewart Baker, general chairman of the appeal.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The Office of Defense Transportation today authorized the granting of special priorities for railroad trains to carry delegates, and press, radio and newsreel representatives to and from the national political conventions in Chicago.

More than 87,000 votes were cast in the American Labor party primary in New York City a week ago, it was disclosed yesterday. The total, which falls just short of 50 per cent of the enrolled Labor party strength in the city, probably sets a record for percentage of primary vote when compared with enrollment.
Chinese children are thoroughly war-conscious, according to evidence that will be displayed this morning at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, and remain on view through May 7.

Your account on March 24 of a speech by Dr. Robert G. Sproul, president of the University of California, quoted his prediction that the peak of enrollment in colleges and universities had been reached. This view is contradicted by most current analyses of the prospects of American higher education.

Protesting Mayor La Guardia's action in not providing in his executive budget for 1944-45 cost-of-living bonuses for lower paid employes of the Election Board, the four election commissioners appealed yesterday to the Board of Estimate to grant to the fifty-two employes "the same humane consideration as all other departments under the control of the city administration.''

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY ON THE ANZIO BEACHHEAD, April 4 (AP) -- Digging in of the Anzio beachhead hospitals in recent weeks paid dramatic dividends today when more than twenty German shells combed the packed hospital area without killing or wounding anyone.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- The Treasury Department, making public its salary stabilization rules, tonight, included a 15 per cent a year limit, with certain exceptions, on "merit" raises for "white-collar" workers.

Before an invited audience of 400 theatrical producers, agents and radio and movie scouts, forty-eight stage aspirants displayed their talents yesterday at the Longacre Theatre. They were the finalists in the second annual John Golden series.

"TELL me a story, Daddy," begged the importunate child. "It must have knights in it and a beautiful princess and lots of fighting and some magic and pirates and harems and torture and white men making savages think they are gods by tricks and cannibalism and treachery and everything else that I like." So the already exasperated father flung the 640page book he was reading into the fireplace and began.
The Japanese reaction to our carrier raid on Palau and other near-by islands in the western Pacific indicates that the Pacific enemy has been greatly shaken by his defeats of recent months.
LOS ANGELES, April 4 -- With lips trembling as he clutched at the knot of his necktie, an emotion-choked Charlie Chaplin tonight heard himself acquitted of Mann Act charges.

The Henkim Realty Corporation, Henry Kimmel, president, plans a twelve-story apartment house after the war at 51-63 East Seventy-sixth Street, near Park Avenue according to Herbert Charles Co., brokers, who sold the property to the new owner for the Bank for Savings.

A UNITED STATES NAVAL AIR STATION, in England, April 14 (U.P.) -- Eleven naval airmen crowded into a Nissen hut today to divide the "spoils" -- a $1,700 jackpot set up for the first Britain-based Navy crew to score a submarine kill.

The National War Labor Board is establishing a dangerous precedent in its handling of the current steelworkers' union cases. In these cases the board is experimenting with union-wide bargaining. All of the companies in the country which have expired or terminated contracts with this union have been summoned to appear before the board in Washington to show cause, in effect, why the steelworkers' well-publicized twenty-four demands should not be applied to each one of them.

STOCKHOLM, April 4 (AP) m Soup, chicken and ice cream made up the Sunday dinner served prisoners of war in one American camp he recently visited, Hugo Cedergren, general secretary of the International Y. ]VI. C. A., told Swedish newspaper men today.

LONDON, April 4 -- After a campaign of nearly three months, approximately 2,700 German planes have been destroyed in the air by bombers and fighters of the United States Eighth, Ninth and Fifteenth Air Forces and on the ground by strafing from fighters of these commands, according to a competent air source.

Speaking yesterday at the second annual meeting of the United Seamen's Service, Mayor La Guardia declared that the caliber of our American merchant seamen was rising so rapidly that he fully expected, in the near future, to hear them called "gentlemen of the sea" instead of just plain seamen.

ALBANY, April 4 -- Governor Dewey signed today a series of amendments to the Workmen's Compensation Law which, he said, represents "a renewal of the guarantee of the security" provided by the law for injured workers.

CHUNGKING, China, April 4 -- It has been known in Chungking since the middle of March that there had been fighting on the border of Sinkiang and Mongolia but no one in the Government was willing to talk for publication.

Seven youths ranging from 16 to 20 years of age were arrested as burglars and four adults were taken as receivers of stolen goods in Brooklyn's Bath Beach-Bensonhurst district yesterday with what police described as the $10,000 loot of 100 burglaries.
French labor, though there are few workers with any sympathies with the Germans, finds itself in the position of the French employers -- bound to collaborate with the Germans.

The replacing of recently sold-out lines of cotton futures brought a rise of 4 to 16 points on active months on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, the strength being most pronounced in the new crop positions.

Al Davis, 142 3/4, Brownsville, scored a technical knockout over Oscar Suggs, 147 3/4, in the scheduled ten-round feature bout before a turnaway crowd of 4,000 last night at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn.
Seven large apartment buildings were among the Bronx properties listed yesterday as having passed into new hands.

TRENTON, N.J., April 4 -- Private Marius Russo came over from Fort Monmouth today to see what Joe McCarthy's 1944 machine looked like and returned to his barracks keenly disappointed. For, the Yankees didn't look so good today as they tangled with the Dodgers before a gathering of 2,500 at Dunn Field.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, April 5 -- Trim formations of United States fighter planes were patrolling the air over New Guinea today ready to pounce on Japanese strays after Lieut. Gen. George C. Kenney's Fifth Air Force smashed Hollandia, the last remaining big Japanese air base in New Guinea, on Monday in the greatest single raid in the Pacific war theatre.

NEW DELHI, India, April 4 (U.P.) -- Japanese troops invaded India to within ten miles of Imphal, Manipur State capital and key Allied base on the central India-Burma front, but were hurled back into the near-by hills by a British artillery and aircraft attack, front dispatches reported today.

More than the full quota of $540,000 assigned to the life insurance division of the Red Cross war fund campaign has been raised, it was announced yesterday by George S. Van Schaick, vice president of the New York Life Insurance Company, chairman of the division.

CHICAGO, April 4 (AP) -- Spiegel, Inc., has purchased for about $1,725,000 the forty-six retail women's ready-to-wear stores in fourteen States of the Sally Stores, Modie J. Spiegel, president of Spiegel, Inc., told stockholders at their annual meeting today.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, withdrew today a demand made to President Roosevelt that his organization be recognized in naming delegates to the conference of the International Labor Organization, opening in Philadelphia April 20.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Despite a substantial reduction expected in the output of cotton textiles this year, clothing will be adequately distributed without resort to rationing, J. Spencer Love, director of the Textile, Clothing and Leather Bureau of the War Production Board, predicted today.

BOSTON, April 4 (AP) -- Philip C. Thibodeau, general manager of the Automobile Legal Association, declared today that it was "about time that the discrimination which has existed against the East Coast ever since the 'phony' gasoline shortage of 1941 should cease."

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The Army, Navy and War Shipping Administration said today that machinery was being set up to make the most effective possible use of the new armed forces voting law in primaries this summer, in the general election in November and in special elections.

A revolutionary type of household heater no larger than an office waste basket but capable of heating a ten-room house was described as one of the possible postwar adaptations of aircraft heating principles by Lynn A. Williams, vice president of the Stewart-Warner Corporation, at a press demonstration at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

Payrolls of sixty-eight major war plants in Union County, N.J., surveyed by the Elizabeth Chamber of Commerce, were disclosed yesterday to have shown a decline for February of 25 per cent as compared to January.

ALGIERS, April 4 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle enlarged the French Committee of National Liberation today to give it more the character of "the Provisional Government of the Republic," as he recently called it -- that is, a Government of national unity that is expected to last without great change until the liberation of France.

MELBOURNE, April 4 -- Although she has never before accompanied her husband on an official mission outside Australia, Mrs. John Curtin will be with the Prime Minister when he arrives shortly in the United States en route to the confer ence of Empire Prime Ministers in London. They will be guests of the White House.

Tonight the biggest city on earth will greet the biggest show on earth in what promises to be "the most prodigious, most gorgeous, most spectacular spectacle ever." The adjectives were picked up casually yesterday -- in front of a lion's cage, at the heels of a sideshow giant or beside an elephant's trunk.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (U.P.) -- Representative Thomas E. Martin, Republican, of Iowa, charged today that service decorations were being awarded by the Army at such an "indiscriminate" rate, 175,000 thus far, that their value in the public esteem was being threatened.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- An authorized spokesman for the Soviet Embassy said today that he personally did not know Victor A. Kravchenko, a member of the Soviet Purchasing Commission who has resigned in protest against what he charges is the "double-faced" foreign policy of Moscow, and, the spokesman added, the embassy has nothing to say about it at the present time.

AUSTIN, Tex., April 4 -- Gov. Coke Stevenson announced today that Attorney General Grover Sellers will file a motion for rehearing with the Supreme Court on yesterday's ruling that Negroes must be allowed to vote in Democratic primaries in Texas.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- About 6,000 air fields and airports, ranging from L-shaped village fields with 1,800-foot runways to complex fields with paved runways a mile or more in length, are being planned by the Civil Aeronautics Authority to expand air transport after the war, it was learned today.

LONDON, April 4 -- The chief interest in today's generally quiet stock market centered around South African gold shares, prices of which were marked up following the statement by Jan Smuts, Prime Minister of the Union of South Africa, that the British Government had no objection to the Union participating in the higher price paid for gold in the Indian and Egyptian markets.

Your recent editorials urging warmer and more meaningful ceremonies welcoming new citizens are most timely. Anyone in close touch with newcomers to our shores knows that the transfer of allegiance is a high point in their lives.

A new product of Brazil, recently made available in sufficient quantity for commercial use, is dried bananas packed for the first time in whole form. Previously this fruit has been dehydrated and then flaked or sliced for packaging.

Parents Magazine announces three awards for outstanding books for parents, to be presented at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel tomorrow. Dr. Arnold L. Gesell and Dr. Frances L. Ilg, authors of "Infant and Child in the Culture of Today," published by Harpers, and Dorothy Canfield Fisher, author of "Our Young Folks," published by Harcourt Brace, are the winners.

Four former officials of the defunct Madison Personal Loan Corporation were found guilty by a jury in General Sessions at 11:25 o'clock last night of conspiracy, making false entries and forgery, after an eight-week trial. The jury had been out since 4:30 P.M.

CLEVELAND, April 4 -- Discovery and concentration of two new members of the Vitamin B complex, royal family among the vitamins, was announced here today before the annual spring meeting of the American Chemical Society by Drs. G.M. Briggs Jr., T.D. Luckey, Conrad A. Elvehjem and E.B. Hart of the Department of Biochemistry of the University of Wisconsin.

A young naval officer, who has been in much heavy action in the southwest Pacific since Pearl Harbor and who has been unable to visit his family for nearly four years, arrived at his suburban home on Sunday morning. On Monday he started to Manhattan to purchase a wedding present for his brother who had been married in his absence.

ADMIRAL HALSEY'S ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, April 4 (UP) -- Admiral William F. Halsey, the first American naval commander in this war to wind up a complete campaign, may be assigned to a new and important command in the near future, informed sources predicted today.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., April 4 -- Valdina Malden, owned by J.M. Hutchins, earned an impressive victory in the Dinner Key Purse today at Tropical Park. The bay son of Osculator was a length and a half better than I. Gushen's Leo McLaughlin and negotiated the six furlongs in 1:14 4-5, best time for the day.

There may be a shortage of colored candies and Easter eggs but there will be no shortage of beauty for Easter this year. The shops report a plentiful supply of perfumes, colognes and powders in the traditional floral fragrances plus new cosmetics introduced especially for the season.

Selectivity continued to rule yesterday in the stock market with prices in a narrow range and mixed at the close. Bidding appeared in a handful of issues and so slack was the demand for pivotal stocks that United States Steel appeared on the ticker tape only at scattered intervals over a two-hour period.

From the Joint Committee of Public Library Staff Organizations comes a statement that ought to jab the civic pride of New Yorkers. In the years 1928 to 1932 the annual appropriations by the city for the New York Public Library (Circulation Department), Brooklyn Public Library and Queens Borough Public Library averaged $460,000.

Timely figures on production, broken down by dollar volume, units and by price ranges, types of distribution and geographical areas are vital to more scientific research in the retail field, Alfred C. Thompson, in charge of the Retail Research Association and assistant to the managing director of the Associated Merchandising Corporation, representing the largest group of stores in the world, declared yesterday.

NAPLES, April 4 -- Activity on both the Anzio beachhead and the Cassino front tapered off yesterday, but a major artillery action appeared to be gradually building up in the long quiescent sector between the Garigliano River bend and the south bank of the Liri River.
LONDON, April 5 -- Russia, the United States and Britain are united in one campaign.

LONDON, April 4 -- Polish authorities here have appealed to the British and United States Governments for their guidance in preventing a series of "incidents" between the underground movement in Poland and the advancing Soviet armies.

PEARL HARBOR, April 4 (U.P) -- American Liberator bombers of the Seventh Army Air Force on Sunday night bombed Dublon and Eten Islands, in Truk Atoll, carrying one of the Pacific war's greatest aerial offensives through the fifth day, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today.

A gala concert under the baton of Maestro Arturo Toscanini, and featuring the combined forces of the Philharmonic-Symphony and the NBC Symphony Orchestras, will be given at Madison Square Garden on May 25 in aid of the American Red Cross, it was learned yesterday.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, April 5 (UP) --A coun{qu: ]

LONDON, Wednesday, April 5 (AP) -- The Red Army's capture yesterday of Bakalovo, near-by Ponyatovka, and the rail station of Vesely Kut, north of Razdelnaya, practically destroyed the usefulness of the Odessa-Razdelnaya-Kishinev trunk route, forcing the Germans to rely solely on a small line running from Odessa to the ferry terminus of Ovidiopol.

Despite the efforts of the War Food Administration to make more corn available for corn refiners by requiring Midwestern grain elevators to earmark 60 per cent of their receipts for that industry, the order has not produced any substantial additional quantity of that cereal so far.

From "Chicken Every Sunday," the Rosemary Taylor book containing the author's amusing recollections of her mother's boarding house in Tucson in 1916, comes the comedy of the same name opening tonight at Henry Miller's. More than interested in its reception are three gentlemen from Hollywood: the brothers Epstein, Julius J. and Philip G., who collaborated on the dramatization, and Edward Gross, producer.
A new brand of distilled liquor containing only 5 per cent rye whisky two-and-a-quarter years old, blended with 95 per cent cane neutral spirits, has made its appearance on the market.

Plans have been completed for a two-year technical institute on the junior college level for the needle and apparel trades, to be operated by the Board of Education in cooperation with representatives of industry and organized labor, it was learned yesterday.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
CHICAGO, April 4 -- July wheat advanced today 1 1/4 cents a bushel to a new seasonal high on the Board of Trade on aggressive buying. Brokers attributed this to a professional operator.

LONDON, April 4 (AP) -- In the midst of a world war, "international American and British cartel interests" are dealing secretly in Switzerland to preserve their ties with "German monopolists" for post-war monopolies, the Russian magazine, War and the Working Class, declared in an article broadcast from Moscow today.
LONDON, Wednesday, April 5 (AP) -- The Russian Tuesday midnight supplementary communiqe, as broadcast from Moscow:

Lack of shipping instructions by the Treasury Department has caused a pile up of cotton textiles intended for export in many finishing plants in the South, Worth Street commission merchants disclosed yesterday. Unless these goods are moved, the plants may be forced to slow their production or shut down altogether, they said.

The vacant plot at the southeast corner of Greenwich and Gansevoort Streets has been sold by the Lawyers Trust Company to a client of Tankoos, Smith Co., brokers, who will erect there a one-story freight terminal when the war ends or as soon as materials are available.

MONTREAL, April 4 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens overpowered the Chicago Black Hawks, 5 to 1, to win the opening game at the Forum tonight in the final four-out-of-seven series in the Stanley Club hockey play-offs for the world professional championship.

Officially recognized by the Allied Governments or not, the National Committee in Algiers is rapidly putting itself in position to take over the de facto government of liberated France. This is the import of the drastic decisions taken at yesterday's extraordinary session of the Committee.

Delegates from regional trade association of rainwear manufacturers throughout the nation yesterday voted unanimously to form a national organization to be known as the National Rainwear Manufacturers Association at a meeting in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 4 -- Both The Associated Press and The United Press have been hard hit by yesterday's Argentine Government decree compelling all radio stations to subscribe to the service of the Government news agency, Andi.

LONDON, April 4 -- Debrett's Peerage for 1944, published today, listed eighteen peers and one baronet as having lost their lives in active service and five peers killed in air raids. One baronet died a prisoner in enemy hands.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 4 (AP) -- An air alert sounded in Berne this afternoon while United States Minister Leland Harrison called on Foreign Minister Pilet Golaz to deliver the State Department's official apology for the accidental bombing of Schaffhausen on Saturday and assurances that every effort would be made to prevent a recurrence.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 4 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has announced plans to star Carmen Miranda in a Technicolor musical "Rio" with a background of Rio de Janeiro. The picture will follow Miss Miranda's appearance in "Something for the Boys" and supplant "Chica Chico" on the schedule.

WITH THE POLISH CORPS OF THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, In Italy, April 4 -- The Polish corps now fighting the Germans in Italy is perhaps the biggest jail breakers' club in history. Almost every man has a tale, like a Hollywood fantasy, of his adventures in reaching a recruiting center in Allied territory.

With practically all manufacturers of work clothing having withdrawn low-price lines since the Office of Price Administration granted mills price rises on chambrays, coverts and denims, without extending covering relief to garment fabricators, production will drop to the point where there will develop even more drastic shortages of these cost-of-living items unless presently effective price ceilings for the industry are raised, according to a resolution adopted by the industry yesterday.

HILL 129, BOUGAINVILLE, Solomon Islands, March 26 (Delayed) (AP) -- A Japanese superior private captured two days ago made a dramatic broadcast today to his former comrades in the Sixth Imperial Division "to give up the futile fight against superior American forces and equipment."

LONDON, April 4 -- The British Government is considering taking drastic action to prevent all strikes in this country which interfere in any way with preparations for invasion. It was reported late tonight that the Cabinet is seriously considering enacting new legislation whereby officials would be empowered to take stringent measures to prevent the hampering of production on the industrial front due to work stoppage.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- Sammy Angott, former N.B.A. lightweight champion, tonight pounded out a ten-round decision over Aaron Perry, 18-year-old Washington hopeful hailed as a future fistic great.

CHICAGO, April 4 -- The adage that "woman's work is never done" promises to lose some of its age-old meaning in the post-war era if predictions made at the meeting here of the Edison Electrical Institute are fulfilled.

When an American naval and air armada estimated by the enemy at more than a dozen battleships and aircraft carriers, as well as numerous cruisers and destroyers, sailed to the very heart of Japan's Pacific empire to strike at Palau it flung down its boldest challenge to the Japanese Navy to come out and fight.

A paper conservation and salvage drive intended to reach every New Yorker who buys food for home consumption will be launched next week in 48,000 retail food stores, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Charles E. Copeland, Greater New York salvage chairman of the American Women's Voluntary Services.

Events on the borders of Manchukuo and Russia have brought the Tartars back into the news. They are described as descendants of the Golden Horde. In the thirteenth century Tartars raided eastern Europe. Under the leadership of a grandson of Genghis Khan, they overran Russia and invaded Silesia, Poland and Hungary.

CHICAGO, April 4 (AP) -- John Brandt, president of the National Cooperative Milk Products Federation, told the concluding session of a Republican farm plank committee today that the nation must adopt post-war policies assuring high levels of wages, prices and profits if it is to prevent collapse under the national debt.

PHILADELPHIA, April 4 -- The plan of reorganization of the United Gas Corporation was praised and condemned today as a hearing on its merits was opened before William W. Swift, a trial examiner of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Dispatches from London indicate that our delegation is pursuing a middle course in negotiations with the British on post-war international air transport.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- More than 250,000 tons of idle and excess stocks of steel have been listed with regional offices of the War Production Board and are available to buyers whose needs are not met from regular mill and warehouse sources, the WPB announced today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 4 -Following the irritation expressed yesterday by Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop of Germany over disclosures of Allied bomb damage made by plane travelers from Berlin and a threat to impose severe penalties, Paul Schmidt, Wilhelmstrasse spokesman, today hade this special announcement at a news conference:

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 4 -- Rigorous training conditions of the sort to bring the full flush of health to the cheek, although they might well ruin the delicate muscles of a pitching arm for good and all, greeted the Giants today as Manager Mel Ott drove his players through another precarious workout.

CINCINNATI, April 4 (AP) -- William J. Ratchford, former Wright Aeronautical Corporation inspector, testified today at a court-martial of three Army Air Force officers on charges of neglect and conspiracy that in July, 1942, 250 defective engines were accepted by the Army despite rejection by civilian Army inspectors.

WHEN Bill Smith, the 19-year-old Hawaiian wonder, captured three events at the National A.A.U. swimming championships over the past week-end, mention was made in the news story that the Great Lakes sailor had scored the first triple since Johnny Weismuller thrashed to three titles sixteen years previously. That statement provoked some curiosity in this corner.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Egg-drying establishments under contract to the War Food Administration are expected to pay not less than $9 a case, or 30 cents a dozen, for the eggs that they purchase for processing, Lee Marshall, Director of Food Distribution, warned today in telegrams sent to all plants holding Government contracts for powdered eggs.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The British and American Governments made a diplomatic move in the Italian situation today that, notwithstanding official disclaimers, was widely construed as an effort to regain lost ground in the face of the Russian program of exchanging representatives with Premier Pietro Badoglio's Government.

The Philco Corporation had high record sales of $116,395,598 in 1943, according to its annual report, issued for publication today by John Ballantyne, president, and Larry E. Gubb, chairman. The total was an increase of 70 per cent over sales of $68,505,979 in 1942.

The American Sugar Refining Company has contracted to purchase the refinery, business, trademarks and substantially all other assets of the W.J. McCahan Sugar Refining and Molasses Company of Philadelphia, subject to approval of stockholders of the latter company, it was announced yesterday by J.F. Abbott, president of the former concern.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The Office of Price Administration freed civilian passenger car owners today from its requirement to undergo periodic inspection of their tires. Inspection now will be required only when the motorist applies for a tire replacement, but checking of motor truck tires is to be continued.

Buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday were 597, compared with 806 in the preceding week and 954 in the similar period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals numbered 205, against 325 last Tuesday.

NAPLES, April 4 -- The Allied air offensive against the Balkan capitals through which the Germans must supply their troops opposing the Red Army on the southeastern front swung today into an unprecedented heavy bomber attack on Bucharest.

In a short letter on votes for service men, published today in another column on this page, "F.G." wonders "why the Administration should want to prevent their voting for their city, county and State officials, with whom they will have to live in much closer contact than they will with the President of the United States."
NEW DELHI, India, April 4 (UP) -- A communique:

A resolution of protest by a group of Harvard professors has brought into the open a recent decision by the Chinese Government that has already aroused considerable concern in quarters here in which it has been privately known for some time. This is a decision to establish Government control over all young Chinese who come to this country to study.

The task of shifting 150 tons of coal in the sub-basement of the International House, 500 Riverside Drive, was started yesterday by the police as authorities intensified their search for Valsa Matthai, 22-year-old Columbia University student and daughter of a Bombay, India, industrialist, who disappeared March 20.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- President Roosevelt's health was reported "satisfactory" today by his personal physician, Vice Admiral Ross T. McIntire, in an unprecedented report to the press on the physical check-up the President underwent a week ago in the Naval Hospital at Bethesda, Md.

Since 1938 the American Actors Theatre has been wooing the muse good naturedly in studios, meeting halls and such places as the Provincetown Playhouse. Last evening it took the plunge and came uptown to the Bijou, where it offered Horton Foote's "Only the Heart," which it had tried out a year or so ago down on Macdougal Street and with another cast.

Miss Vivien Kellems, executive of a war plant at Westport, Conn., made public here yesterday copies of letters she had sent to Postmaster General Frank C. Walker and Representative John M. Coffee of Washington.

A field of ten or so is expected to start in the Paumonok Handicap, traditional opening-day feature at Jamaica, where the Eastern racing season will be ushered in Saturday. According to Racing Secretary John B. Campbell, everything is shaping up fine for the six-furlong stake.

LONDON, April 4 -- The controversy between the United States and Britain on one side and Spain on the other over shipping supplies of wolfram -- tungsten ore -- to Germany spilled over onto Portugal today in a debate in the House of Commons.

Advertisirig in all New York daily newspapers during March totaled 8,194,608 agate lines, a deI crease of 5.5 per cent from the corresponding month of a year ago, I according to figures compiled from Media Records. Automotive advertising showed the greatest percentage of loss (53.9), followed by classified advertising with 21.1 per cent, general advertising with 6.1 per cent, and retail advertising with 4.0 per cent.

The regional Office of Price Administration announced yesterday that it had launched a drive to curb eating places throughout the city that had increased their prices, in some cases more than 25 per cent above OPA ceilings. Legal ceilings are based on prices charged in the week of April 4-10, 1943.

MILWAUKEE (Wednesday), April 5 -- Candidates pledged to Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York built up a commanding lead early today in incomplete returns from Wisconsin's Presidential primary, with Wendell Willkie's last in a four-way race.

The American Bosch Corporation is operating solely as an American company and from an American standpoint in all respects, George Murnane, chairman, declared at the annual meeting of stockholders here yesterday. Control of 77 per cent of the company's shares are vested in the Alien Property Custodian.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Use of the machinery and experience of the League of Nations as a foundation upon which to build the pledged post-war collaboration among the United Nations was recommended today by Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- Attorney General Francis Biddle asked Congress today to reduce the statutory quorum of the Supreme Court from six to five justices.
Theatrical interests, accountants, publicity and advertising firms figured in many of the commercial renting contracts reported by brokers yesterday in Manhattan.

American air attacks on Budapest and Bucharest link the eastern and southern fronts for the first time. They are direct blows against the communications of the same enemy armies that confront the Russians on the frontiers of Hungary and Rumania.

Daniel Webster said one day in the first week of June, 1852, when he learned that the Democratic National Convention in Baltimore had selected Franklin K. Pierce of Vermont as its candidate, "After this no man is safe from being nominated for President."

The Supreme Court's decision in the Texas primary case is being discussed in some quarters, by those who approve of it as well as by those who do not, as though the Court had just passed a new law. This is beside the question. The Court is not a legislative body. It is an agency, representing the whole nation, whose function it is to pass final judgment on certain categories of cases.

NORFOLK, Neb., April 4 -- To refute the charge being circulated in Nebraska that he is not a Republican because he advocates an organization of nations to promote world trade and preserve world peace, Wendell L. Willkie today quoted three Republican Presidents and Elihu Root to show that this was the historical position of the Republican party.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -Secretary Knox, praising the work of chaplains on the fighting fronts, declared today that they were "taking their duties extremely seriously and undergoing the hardships and risks with the men."

Ted Collins, owner of the Boston franchise in the National Football League, said yesterday that the other club owners in the loop had given him first selection in the gridiron draft and that his opening choice would be Angelo Bertelli, Notre Dame quarterback of last fall, The Associated Press reported.

The Secret Service announced yesterday the arrest of two men and a woman accused of stealing $1,800 in Government dependency checks in the last few months from tenement mail boxes in Harlem. A second woman is to be arrested when she leaves the hospital where she is a patient.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Coordination of war mobilization and post-war economic problems by governmental machinery operating under policies and directives laid down by Congress was advocated by spokesmen of the legislative branch and labor today as the Senate Military Affairs subcommittee on war contracts opened hearings on two measures drafted to carry out and implement the BaruchHancock report on post-war planning.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- After their fiery outbursts yesterday against the 8-to-1 Supreme Court decision that overrode the Texas device by which Negroes are excluded as members of the Democratic party, Democratic members of Congress from the Deep South took counsel, and the impression seemed to grow among them that new legal strategies will be difficult to find.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 4 (AP) -- Willie Pep, 133 1/2 pounds, Hartford, won a ten-round decision tonight on a Red Cross benefit card from Leo Francis, 132 1/2, Panama, but it was no picnic for the lad who is recognized in New York State as world featherweight champion.

LONDON, April 4 -- Efforts are being made to obtain agreement among all the Allies on just how the Atlantic Charter is to be applied to the practical problems of peace. This was disclosed today in the House of Lords by Viscount Cranborne, Government leader, who is expected soon to replace Anthony Eden as Foreign Secretary, in urging members not to expect the Government to make a "unilateral statement which might impede pending discussions."

"Four Jills in a Jeep," Twentieth Century-Fox's film version of the tour of foreign army camps made by Kay Francis, Carole Landis, Martha Raye and Mitzi Mayfair and featuring those players, will have its local premiere this morning at the Roxy. Phil Silvers, Jimmy Dorsey and his orchestra and Dick Haymes also are in the film, with Betty Grable, Alice Faye, Carmen Miranda and George Jessel appearing as guest stars.

CHICAGO, April 4 -- War demands for electricity in the Chicago area apparently are leveling off, but consumption is being maintained at a high point and the situation with respect to generating capacity in reserve is only fair, Charles Y. Freeman, chairman, today told stockholders of the Commonwealth Edison Company at their annual meeting.

Shoe manufacturers will be penalized unduly while the shoe repair trade will be benefited greatly this year under the program of the Office of Civilian Requirements, which has announced drastic limitation of new shoe production, according to opinions expressed in the manufacturing and retail trades yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Food relief will be increased to Greece under a program announced tonight.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, April 5 -- The Soviet High Command reported last night the capture of the larger part of the town of Tarnopol, where the blockaded enemy has lost 3,000 dead and 300 prisoners in three days' fierce street fighting, and declared repeated attempts by the remnants of fifteen encircled enemy divisions to break out near Skala, above the middle Dniester River, had been repulsed with heavy losses.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- All Japanese ships at anchorage were sunk or damaged, and three others were sunk while apparently attempting to flee, in daring raids against Palau, Woleai and Yap islands carried out by a great task force of the Pacific Fleet between March 30 and April 1, Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox announced today.

NEWARK, N.J., April 4 -- Additional support of the Government's theory that the German Labor Front was in direct control of the German-American Vocational League in the United States was entered in the record of testimony today at the trial of nineteen allegedly unregistered propaganda agents for Germany, which is in its second week before Judge Thomas F. Meaney and a jury in Federal court here.

Two women who signed testimonials in 1938 for Camel cigarettes testified yesterday that they were not regular smokers of that brand. They appeared at a Federal Trade Commission hearing at 45 Broadway on a complaint charging the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, Inc., with misleading advertising.

The report on the New York State conservation program that Governor Dewey sent to Conservation Commissioner John A. White, and read to those who attended the department-sponsored trout trip to Bath, N.Y., over the weekend, was received here yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 4 -- The evacuation from Berlin of the Reich Ministries and other Government and Nazi party offices [previously reported several times since December as Berlin has been increasingly devastated by Allied bombings] has now begun, the Stockholm Aftonbladet will say tomorrow.
WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, April 4 -- At the opening session of the Legislative Assembly today the Governor, Pieter A. Kasteel, stated that Curacao would be glad to do its utmost as the price of freedom.

Failure of the public to take stringent measures to wipe out the current black market in gasoline may result in the abolition of A coupon allotments, officials of the Office of Price Administration warned yesterday in describing the situation as having become a "big time racket" involving ruthless murder.

LONDON, April 4 -- Prime Minister Churchill gave the House of Commons today figures showing that the first four years of the war have cost the United Kingdom much more casualties in fighting men than Britain's dominions and colonies combined.
Lars J. Jorstad, counselor of the Norwegian Embassy, and Mrs. Jorstad have arrived from Washington and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

ST. LOUIS, April 4 (AP) -- Thomas E. Dewey, Governor of New York, was indorsed as Republican candidate for President today at two Congressional district meetings held to elect delegates to the party's national convention.

An exhibition of Czechoslovak graphic art of the twentieth century opens at 8:30 o'clock tonight with a private view, in Room 213, at the New York Public Library. It is being held under the auspices of the Czechoslovak Government Information Service.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Enemy spies and saboteurs were defeated in their plans against this country during the fiscal year ended June 30 last, Francis Biddle, Attorney General, reported to Congress today.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The American Federation of Labor attacked the National War Labor Board's "Little Steel" formula today, contending that living costs have gone up far more than reported by the Bureau of Labor Statistics and that the workers' living standards have deteriorated since 1941.

PHILADELPHIA, April 4 (AP) -- An appeal by two creditors of the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company from Federal Judge William H. Kirkpatrick's refusal last December to order the company to distribute $8,000,000 surplus cash among its creditors was taken under consideration today by three judges of the United State Circuit Court of Appeals.

Thomas V. De Lorenzo, president of the Brewster Aeronaufical Corporation local of the United Automobile Workers, was released in $2,000 bail yesterday after pleading not guilty in Federal court to a charge of having made false statements in a civil service application.

The doors of Palestine "must be opened and opened permanently" to the homeless Jew, Governor Dewey declared last night in an address at a dinner at the Hotel Plaza launching the United Jewish Appeal campaign for $32,000,000. He urged that the United States take the lead in finding means to scrap the White Paper.

A group of Midwestern business men headed by R. Crosby Kemper, president of the City National Bank and Trust Company of Kansas City, Mo., succeeded yesterday in obtaining control of the management of the Kansas City Southern Railway Company from the group represented by C.P. Couch, the present chairman, who will resign.

The Chase National Bank reported yesterday in its quarterly condition statement, as of March 31, that deposits were $4,457,581,731 and that total resources were $4,765,999,575, both new record highs. Three months ago deposits amounted to $4,375,581,740 and one year ago, to $4,203,291,330.
LONDON, April 4 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin:

Harry Craig Cooper, president of the Century Travel Service Corporation at 655 Fifth Avenue, and Miss Marie Tosti, one of his employes, were found guilty yesterday in Special Sessions in the first case under the City Administrative Code section that was put into effect Jan. 1 to break up the black market in railroad passenger tickets.
How the negotiations for the stopping of all Spanish wolfram exports to Germany has come to a deadlock can easily be explained.

There are definite signs that the United States has reached and even passed the stage of most acute pressure on its national economy, according to the twenty-ninth annual report of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, released yesterday by Allan Sproul, president.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- A Supreme Court test of the constitutionality of the poll tax was announced today as an aim of a new organization of service men's parents and wives which has the backing of Senator Joseph F. Guffey, Democrat, of Pennsylvania.

There are definite signs that the United States has reached and even passed the stage of most acute pressure on its national economy, according to the twenty-ninth annual report of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, released yesterday by Allan Sproul, president.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- A Supreme Court test of the constitutionality of the poll tax was announced today as an aim of a new organization of service men's parents and wives which has the backing of Senator Joseph F. Guffey, Democrat, of Pennsylvania.

NEW DELHI, India, April 4 -- Fires set in the tinder-dry jungle by Japanese invaders east of the threatened Allied base of Imphal in Eastern India have forced desperately resisting British and Indian troops to withdraw onto the Manipur Plain after having killed at least 900 Japanese in a week of hard fighting, it was reported today.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, March 30 (Delayed) (AP) -- The 240-mm. howitzer, the biggest American field gun used in this war, has proved its worth after fifty days of shooting at bridges, guns and other targets far behind the German lines, artillery officers say.

I have just returned from dinner and, while eating, was having a chat with a few of my pals, one of whom had just returned from leave. He was saying how decent, jolly and good-hearted were the American lads who were traveling back with him.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 5 (AP) -- Governor Bricker of Ohio, a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, declared tonight that Wendell Willkie had stimulated interest in the 1944 campaign by "freely and courageously discussing his conception of the issues that are facing us in this very serious situation."

ELKTON, Md., April 5 (AP) -- Joseph Ben Decker, 58, former executive of the Triumph Explosives Company, who was Under a three-years' sentence for mail fraud, died today in a hosiptal of shotgun wounds which a United States marshal said were inflicted by Decker himself a few hours before he was to go to prison.

An 18-year-old is drafted in Ohio, a corporal gets married in Tennessee, a soldier's wife in New York has a baby. Events like these, all part of the normal business of living in America, add up to 21,000 new accounts a day at the Office of Dependency Benefits, Newark, N.J., where five and a quarter million checks are prepared each month for Army's men's families.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Reports made here by persons returning from Moscow indicate a high degree of "inflation" in the Soviet capital, sugar selling at the equivalent of $200 official rate and $83 diplomatic rate per kilogram [kilogram is 2.24 pounds].

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 5 (Netherlands News Agency) -- Smashing of the big Japanese air base at Hollandia, in Netherland New Guinea, not only has nullified a major Japanese impediment to the advance of Allied ground forces along the northern coast of New Guinea, but greatly strengthens the position of Netherland and Australian forces holding lines along the Eilanden River to the south.

PEARL HARBOR, April 5 (U.P.) -- Two Navy Liberator bombers on Monday made the seventeenth American raid of the war on Japanese-held Wake Island, bombing and sinking a small Japanese cargo vessel there, while other American planes attacked Japanese positions in the Marshalls, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today.
LONDON, April 5 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Starting in September, the Board of Education will conduct six nursery centers in New York City's elementary school buildings. The program is the result of favorable action by the board at its regular meeting yesterday. This is the first time that the school system has gone into the pre-kindergarten level on an official basis.

It was easy to get into the war on the side of Hitler, but it is very hard to get out. Hitler used every form of bribery, corruption and coercion to win allies in southeastern Europe. He gave pieces of Rumania, Czechoslovakia and Yugoslavia to Hungary, Bulgaria and Italy.

Hitler's belief that the most effective way to deal with democracies is to sow confusion of thought now is confirmed by the raucous clamor of ill-considered attacks on the foreign policy of the United States. Some of the broadcasts by radio commentators might well have been the artful product of a "Lord Haw-Haw."

LONDON, April 5 -- In a room just off Piccadilly this afternoon this correspondent talked with a blue-eyed, earnest young Pole of 27 who had just returned from his own country where he had been sent in February, 1943, by the late Premier Wladislaw Sikorski to serve as liaison officer between the exiled government in London and their underground followers.

One of the most serious problems facing the Chinese army today is the lack of trained medical personnel to serve in the field Lieut. Gen. Robert Kho-sheng Lim, chief of the supervisory and planning commission of the Chinese: Army Medical Service, declared yesterday.

WITH THE SEVENTH AAF IN THE MARSHALLS, March 29 (Delayed) (AP) -- Officers and men at this advanced American airfield saluted a medium bomber squadron today for an unprecedented series of attacks upon Ponape, on the bomb-marked sky run to Truk.

The wheels of retribution were turning yesterday -- slowly at first, but turning -- for the barkeepers and restaurateurs who since last Saturday have been defying the Office of Price Administration by increasing the price of their drinks a nickel instead of the 2 or 3 cents allowable under the new Federal taxes.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 5 -- A bit stunned by the promptness of Wendell Willkie's decision following the Wisconsin primary, his friends and opponents in Indiana said tonight that his withdrawal from the campaign would result in most of the State's delegation voting for Gov. Thomas E. Dewey at the Chicago convention.

LONDON, April 5 -- The tightening of the restrictive bans around the coasts of Britain, in view of "training, or other naval, military and air force operations," was announced today by the War Office at the same time as the Government disclosed that the isolation of Ireland had been pushed still further through the severance of telephone connection with that country.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, April 6 (AP) -- The once heavily gunned Japanese air stronghold of Wewak, New Guinea, did not fire one anti-aircraft gun at big American bombers that virtually erased its remaining planes with 206 tons of explosives, headquarters reported today.

ALBANY, April 5 -- Governor Dewey today signed the Coudert bill stripping the New York City Board of School Superintendents of all but advisory power and placing in the hands of the Superintendent of Schools full executive responsibility in the administration of the schools.

The passing of the two- cent stamp for local postage is a gain for national unity. It has always seemed odd that people should speak of One World in which Manhattan feels itself at one with Chungking, but when it came to writing a letter Manhattan was not in the same two-cent world as Brooklyn and Queens, not to mention Chicago and San Francisco.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., April 5 -- If Manager Leo Durocher's statements today are to be taken at face value, the Lip may start the season for his Dodgers at second base.
Churches of various faiths will observe Maundy Thursday today and Good Friday tomorrow. Lent will end at noon on Saturday.

A radio announcer who advertises Old Gold cigarettes and a mechanic who smoked Lucky Strikes both signed testimonials for Camels, according to testimony given yesterday before Webster Ballinger, trial examiner, at a Federal Trade Commission hearing on a complaint charging that the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company used misleading advertising.

Warning that the production job of the United States is far from complete, while Russia has surpassed expectations and England is tired but holding up in amazing fashion, William L. Batt, vice chairman of the War Production Board, said yesterday that the danger here arises from the complacent belief that "the end is in sight."

Somewhere after 3 A.M. Wednesday the drums of heaven crashed mightily on the eardrums of sleepers. A little reflection told them that this was the not infrequent winter thunder. An old bucolic saw says that "when April blows his horn, it's good for both hay and corn." There is a shortage of corn now and we hope the early morning fireworks will increase the supply.

CHUNGKING, China, April 5 (U.P.) -- Fourteenth United States Air Force Lightnings destroyed two large gasoline dumps and twelve trucks during an offensive reconnaissance yesterday over Wan Mongpang, in northern Burma, Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters announced today.

The twelve-story business building at 140 West Forty-second Street, adjoining the Knickerbocker Building, formerly the Knickerbocker Hotel, at Broadway and Forty-second Street, in Times Square, has been sold by the estate of Cornelius J. Ryan to an investor.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Blair-Lee House, a second Government guest house, adjacent and supplemental to Blair House on Pennsylvania Avenue, was completed by the Public Buildings Administration today and was turned over to the Department of State for the use of distinguished visitors from abroad.

Women who know where nylon stockings are for sale at black market prices were asked yesterday to inform the Federal authorities so that the culprits can be prosecuted. This request was made by Amedeo L. Lauritano, assistant to United States Attorney James B.M. McNally, following the sentencing in Federal Court of a dealer who had pleaded guilty to buying 2,240 dozen pairs of nylons at illicit prices.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 5 (AP) -- The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, with eleven other interested parties, joined today in an appeal from a decision of Judge Carroll C. Hincks of the Federal District Court here approving the plan of the Interstate Commerce Commission for reorganization of the New Haven system. The appeal will be taken to the Circuit Court of Appeals in New York.

The Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus unfolded its 1944 edition last night in Madison Square Garden before a packed assemblage of 14,212, who bought as admission tickets war bonds estimated at $3,144,600. It was the familiar gaudy illusion of yesteryear -- as enthralling as ever, still captivating old and young alike.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- The withdrawal of Wendell L. Willkie from the Presidential race prompted supporters of Governor Dewey to predict tonight that Mr. Dewey would be nominated on an early, if not the first, ballot at Chicago.

A drop of 90 per cent as compared with four years ago in the number of homeless men in this city sleeping and eating in free lodgings provided by the Department of Welfare and by voluntary social agencies was disclosed yesterday in a report by the Welfare Council of New York City.

The Writers War Board and the Overseas Press Club joined forces yesterday in starting a campaign to gain recognition for American war correspondents who have seen active and dangerous duty with the United States combat forces. A resolution to that effect was adopted at a press club luncheon in the Lotos Club Building, 110 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Vladimir Horowitz's second piano recital of the season at Carnegie Hall last night was for the benefit of the American Red Cross and, according to an announcement from the stage, netted more than $10,500. For the occasion, the platform was draped with a huge Red Cross flag and several hundred nurses in bright yellow uniforms were seated on the stage during the performance.

ATLANTA, April 5 (AP) -- Kiki Cuyler, whose given name (Hazen) appears only in such things as last testaments, baseball contracts and National League records, says hitting the dirt is the key to successful base stealing.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Severe criticism is leveled at the Petroleum Reserve Corporation's handling of the Saudi-Arabian pipeline undertaking by Herbert Feis, economic adviser to Secretary Hull until fall, in a study just published by the Food Research Institute of Stanford University.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Fear that a shortage of copper might appear at the end of the year as a result of present and anticipated manpower troubles was expressed today by the War Production Board in an official forecast of the 1944 brass and copper situation.

LONDON, April 5 -- The successful attack by British Barracuda bombers on the Tirpitz early Monday morning left the German battleship on fire and so badly damaged that she will probably be unable to take any part in the German Navy's counter-measures against the Allies' invasion fleet.

Reversing its previous stand upon the administration of the Emergency Price Control Act, the Food Industry War Committee will support re-enactment of the act when it is called to testify before Congressional committees, it was learned yesterday.
Mrs. Pelham St. George Bissell is at the Waldorf-Astoria, accompanied by Mrs. Pelham St. George Bissell 3d and Corp. George H. Bissell, USMCR.

The American Center of P.E.N. has sent a letter to all the booksellers of Boston protesting the ban in that city on Lillian Smith's book, "Strange Fruit." The letter was signed by Carl Carmer, president of the American center, and Fannie Hurst, Dorothy Thompson, Will Irwin, Clifton Fadiman, Manuel Komroff and William Sloane.

PHILADELPHIA, April 5 -- Through the expenditure of $22,400,000 in the redemption of 309,700 shares of $5 and $6 preferred stocks, the Electric Bond and Share Company has cut its stock liability by nearly $31,000,000, it was stated today by S.W. Murphy, president of the holding company, in a hearing before a trial examiner of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

ADVANCED SOLOMON ISLAND BASE, April 2 (Delayed) (AP) -- A Japanese Zero pilot who dropped an aerial phosphorous bomb at a Liberator formation near Truk overran the bomb and was blown to bits when it exploded.

Despite the unseasonable snowstorm, yesterday's collection of waste paper by the Department of Sanitation was maintained at the weekly average level of slightly less than 600 tons, Commissioner William F. Carey announced.

The Tide Water Associated Oil Company reported yesterday for 1943 a consolidated net income of $14,902,640 after charges and taxes and reserves of $2,500,000 against wartime uncertainties and of $650,000 for possible decline in inventory values.

Thomas J. Watson, president of International Business Machines Corporation, will pay out in taxes to the Federal and State Governments on his 1943 income and for "unforgiven" taxes more than he received from all sources, according to officials of the company. He received $427,349.
ALBANY, April 5 -- Dr. Frederick MacCurdy, commissioner of mental hygiene, announced twelve appointments today, nine of which were promotions. They were:

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Miss Vivien Kellems, Westport (Conn.) war plant executive, charged at a press conference today that the excerpts from personal correspondence between her and Count Karl Frederick yon Zedlitz of Buenos Aires, which were quoted recently from the floor of the House of Representatives, over the radio and in a newspaper column, were taken from letters which had not been allowed to reach the addressees.

CHICAGO, April 5 -- Buying of July wheat attributed to cash interests lifted that delivery 1/2 cent a bushel today to a new high price for the season. Despite profit-taking, the upturn was well maintained. Deferred deliveries were firmer with the July and the continued tightness in the cash and May.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 5 (AP) -- Sophocles Venizelos was recommended as the new Premier of Greece today by the Cabinet of the Greek Government-in-Exile after a stormy session, at which all Ministers resigned and then decided to continue in office provisionally.
LONDON, Thursday, April 6 (AP) -- The Russian Wednesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:
I should like to offer this comment on your editorial of March 30 criticizing the bill now before Governor Dewey which provides for the reorganization of the State Department of Public Works.

MUNCIE, Ind., April 5 (AP) -- Jeff Heath, the Seattle shipyard worker, still is the strong, silent man of the Cleveland roster, although Vice President Roger Peckinpaugh said today he had offered to meet the big outfielder's bonus terms.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Wendell L. Willkie lost Wisconsin but he kept his word. He told the Republican voters of that State, during the uphill battle he fought for Wisconsin delegates, that their response to his plea for support would determine the fate of his candidacy for the Presidential nomination of the party.

The stock market emerged yesterday on the higher side for a small rebound, although best gains were reduced in the final hour when bidding slackened. Helped by a special offering during the lunch hour preceded by an active morning session, business on the Stock Exchange increased to 772,390 shares, heaviest in almost a week, compared with 572,400 shares on Tuesday.
LONDON, April 5 (AP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin:
One of the most unusual gifts received by the Opportunity Shop, 46 West Forty-seventh Street, an activity of the Community Service Society, was reported yesterday.

More than 8,000,000 persons will be unemployed after the war if the Government pursues economic policies such as grade labeling, Emil Brisacher, president of Brisacher, Van Norden Staff, advertising agency, said yesterday before the American Marketing Association.

DETROIT, April 5 (AP) -- Gerald L.K. Smith, organizer and director of the America First party, today called the Wisconsin Presidential primary, in which delegates for Wendell L. Willkie trailed those favoring Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, Lieut. Comdr. Harold E. Stassen and Gen. Douglas MacArthur "a great victory for the America First people."

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Col. Paul E. Howe, director of the nutrition division in the office of the surgeon general of the War Department, told a press conference today that he had made the rounds of England, Italy, North Africa, Egypt, Persia, India and China, and had found that American fighting men wanted and were getting American food.

The nation's gasoline stocks at the close of last week totaled 89,162,000 barrels, a gain of 1,875,000 over the 87,287,000 reported a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A year ago they were 93,840,000 barrels.

Col. Vladimir S. Hurban, Czechoslovak Ambassador to the United States, officially opened last night an exhibition of the Czechoslovak graphic arts of the twentieth century at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

Yesterday's snowstorm might cut down the supply of cut flowers for Easter by as much as 20 per cent unless we have a warm, sunny day before Sunday, wholesale florists here predicted yesterday. Since all flowers need sunlight, they explained, a layer of snow on the roofs of greenhouses is apt to delay the blooms that were scheduled for tomorrow and Saturday.

NAPLES, April 5 (AP) -- Crown Prince Humbert said tonight that he was prepared to act as deputy for his father, King Victor Emmanuel, as King, thereby clearing the way for a coalition war Government of all the major political parties.

Adverse weather in the Cotton Belt was a steadying influence yesterday in the late trading on the New York Cotton Exchange and prices at the close were 4 points lower to 7 points higher than on Tuesday.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

An intensive spring drive to increase enlistments in the Women's Army Corps is scheduled to open within the next two weeks to strengthen the Army and release more men for active duty. The campaign has the special endorsement of General George C. Marshall, who urged that women give their first preference to military service before any other war effort.
Starting today, citrus fruits in this city will be under flat dollars-and-cents price ceilings for the first time.

"None Shall Escape," a Columbia drama about post-war trials of Nazi offenders in Europe, will have its local premiere this morning at Loew's State. Alexander Knox, Marsha Hunt, Henry Travers, Dorothy Morris, Erik Rolf, Richard Crane, Ruth Nelson and Richard Hale head the cast.

Purchase of a Series E War Savings Bond at any New York track this season will entitle the buyer to one complimentary admission to the track, according to an announcement made yesterday by the Sports Section of the War Finance Committee for New York.

India's huge war program on the home front and in the armed forces has caused Japan to launch her "desperate invasion" of northeastern India, two Indian legislators who have just arrived in the United States declared yesterday.

GUADALCANAL, March 21 (Delayed) -- Radio today was extending its war-reporting frontiers to the very fringes of the south Pacific's front lines, and the scions of one of the biggest names in radio have had a part in the pioneering.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., April 5 -- Apprentice Bobby Permane completed a riding triple at Tropical Park today when he took Lyle Phillips' Tetra Rock to the front at the break in the Shawsheen Purse and kept the son of Rolls Royce there.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 5 -- Army and Navy procurement agencies in Washington were accused today by West Coast manpower officials of "ignoring" or "violating" the Byrnes directive of September by placing many millions of dollars' worth of contracts in this region, calling for thousands of men for construction jobs, without consulting the local priority and urgency committees set up here to balance manpower and production.
OMAHA, Neb., April 5 -- Following is the prepared text of the dress made by Wendell L. Willkie this evening:

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 5 -- In the opening engagement of the collegiate season for each institution, the Naval Academy baseball team today took the measure of New York University in a game called in the seventh inning because of extreme cold.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., April 5 (AP) -- Bill Nicholson, Cubs' outfielder who led the National League in runs-batted-in last year with 128, arrived in camp today but said he may quit baseball for the duration and return to his Chestertown, Md., farm.

NEW DELHI, India, April 5 -- Increasing their pressure along the entire 200-mile India invasion front, Japanese forces have seized a fifteen-mile stretch of the Imphal-Kohima highway and are thrusting through the Naga Hills above Kohima within eighty miles of Dimapur on the Bengal-Assam railway, American Army-operated lifeline into upper Burma.

LONDON, Thursday, April 6 -- The Soviet Third Ukrainian Front Army smashed yesterday to a point seventeen miles north of Odessa by capturing the rail station of Kubanka and in a flanking drive to the northwest slashed the last major rail and highway escape routes for an estimated 100,000 Germans facing encirclement in the Odessa area.

The residence at 118 East Fifty-seventh Street, occupied for nearly half a century by the late artist, Louis Eilshemius, who lived there as a recluse to the time of his death three years ago, has been sold to a client of Samuel I. Levine, attorney, through the brokerage office of L.V. Hoffman Co.

ALGIERS, April 5 -- Allied observers were more impressed today by the act of the French Committee of National Liberation making Gen. Charles de Gaulle the supreme chief of all the French armed forces than by shifts in the Committee announced at the same time.

Prospects for industrial reconversion to peace-time operations indicate an orderly procedure with little hardship to business, according to Howard Bruce, deputy director of materiel, Headquarters Army Service Forces, even though plant values of manufacturing organizations have increased from a sixty-billion-dollar pre-Pearl Harbor value to eighty billion dollars today.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, April 6 (AP) -- A communique:

Cases of juvenile delinquency in the metropolitan area have increased 15.4 per cent for the first three months this year over a similar period in 1943 and those of neglected children have risen 21.8 per cent for that time, according to figures made public yesterday by W. Bruce Cobb, acting president justice of the Domestic Relations Court.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., April 5 -- The ski slide loomed impressively alongside the Bear Mountain Inn. The hills were blanketed with a beautiful layer of snow and every tree seemed clad in white lace, dainty and delightful. In the main hall of the inn a huge fire blazed on the huge hearth while gleaming flakes drifted down lazily outside.

Mrs. Louise Untermyer, wife of Justice Irwin Untermyer of the Appellate Division, Second Department, left her residuary estate in trust for the benefit of her three children. This was disclosed yesterday in Surrogate's Court, where her will was offered for probate.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- The Board of Immigration Appeals today withdrew an order of deportation it issued in 1940 against Mrs. Raissa Berkman Browder, Russian-born wife of Earl Browder, American Communist leader.

Today, the twenty-seventh anniversary of our declaration of war against Germany in the First World War, is also our seventeenth Army Day. The observance of this occasion has had in part a memorial quality and in part a forward-looking aspect. The least military of nations had to be reminded that an army was necessary, and that a few divisions scattered among a number of obsolescent posts were not adequate.

A father and son pleaded guilty before Federal Judge Marcus B. Campbell in Brooklyn yesterday to an indictment charging them with conspiracy to defraud the Federal Government in the manufacture of insulated field wire for the Army Signal Corps. They may receive prison sentences of two years and fines of $10,000 each.
