Like postmen, the kindergarten and nursery-aged youngsters of the Avenue B Center of the Children's Aid Society, at Sixteenth Street, do not permit vagaries of the weather to interfere with business. Yesterday's scheduled business being an Easter egg hunt, twenty-six determined children proceeded to find candy eggs in unlikely places, although the unseasonal snowstorm compelled them to do so indoors, rather than out in the playground.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Responding to requests for home canning last year, housewives of the country came within 25 per cent of matching the volume of canned vegetables put up by commercial packers for civilians, according to figures compiled on behalf of the commercial packers.

NEWARK, N.J., April 5 -- Friedhelm Draeger, German Vice Consul in New York from 1934 to 1941, was identified by a Government witness today as the "American leader of the Nazi party" at the Federal Court trial here of nineteen men and two corporations accused of a propaganda conspiracy in behalf of Germany.

TRENTON, N.J., April 5 -- Bills to provide a bonus of $132 for State employes paid not more than $5,200 a year and to establish a department of taxation and finance and the appropriation bill authorizing expenditure of more than $44,000,000 from the general State fund were sent to Gov. Walter E. Edge tonight as the Legislature recessed until next Monday.

The Province of New Brunswick, Canada, which has not been in the New York market with new bonds since 1939, has completed arrangements with a banking group headed by Smith, Barney Co. for the sale of a new issue of $5,500,000 of 2 1/4 per cent debentures, dated April 15, 1944, and due April 15, 1948.

Coe Glade will sing the title role of "Carmen" when the San Carlo Opera Company opens its season at the Center Theatre with the Bizet opera on Wednesday night, April 26. Mary Henderson will appear as Micaela, Tandy Mackenzie as Don Jose and Mostyn Thomas as Escamillo.

All employers of men under 26 years old will be required to give "exceptionally convincing arguments" for their continued draft deferment after May 1 as irreplaceable workers, Col. Arthur V. McDermott, New York City director of Selective Service, announced yesterday.

The Junior League will open an art exhibition, the second of "Contemporary American Masters," on April 17 at their clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street, for the benefit of the Junior League Welfare fund. The exhibition will be open to the public from 10 A.M. to 9 P.M. daily, including Sundays, with an admission charge of 50 cents.

As a means of eliminating many of the disputes which have arisen in the past over apartment lease renewals, and "for the protection of both tenants and landlords," Daniel P. Woolley, Regional Administrator of the Office of Price Administration, yesterday issued the rules to be enforced by the OPA in renewals of written leases for residential accommodations in the New York City rent-control area, comprising the five boroughs and Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

The right of women to choose whatever type of employment they prefer has been officially recognized by the International Labor Organization and will be included in problems to be considered at the twenty-sixth convention of the organization, which will open April 20 in Philadelphia, with representatives from forty nations attending.

All the leading securities and commodity markets in the United States and Canada will be closed tomorrow in observance of Good Friday. Banks in New York State and in most of the States of the Union will remain open as usual, but those in New Jersey, Connecticut, Pennsylvania, Illinois, Indiana, Delaware, Louisiana, Maryland, Minnesota and Tennessee will be closed.

The hundreds of thousands of Jews in our armed forces will have the opportunity, military exigencies permitting, to attend services tomorrow at sundown, ushering in the festival of Passover, according to reports from Jewish chaplains and National Jewish Welfare Board representatives in the camps and battlefronts throughout the world.

The situation in the raw fur market has shown little change in the last two weeks. It can hardly be expected that there will be any improvement until manufacturers start working on next season's orders from retailers and from the coat and suit trade for fur trimmings, which probably will not be for another month at least, according to the report of the United Fur Brokers.

THE League of Nations may have failed in its primary function of keeping the peace of Europe, but from its post of exile at Princeton, N.J., it continues to issue some very useful publications. The latest of these, "The Future Population of Europe and the Soviet Union,"* will be combed over for many years to come by the prophets in search of the secrets of war and peace.

The American attack on Hollandia, reported yesterday, was air warfare approaching the European scale. For destructiveness it set a record in the southwest Pacific. No enemy planes escaped. Two hundred and eighty- eight of them in the air and on the ground were either destroyed or damaged beyond repair.

Louis J. Grossman, operator, has resold the four-story remodeled apartment house on the southwest corner of Church Avenue and East Eighteenth Street, Brooklyn, to an investing client of Irving Schatz. The building occupies a plot 78 by 58 feet at the Church Avenue Station of the BMT subway.

A U.S. LIBERATOR BASE in England, April 5 (AP) -- Hit by flak and abandoned by its crew, a Liberator flew 150 miles in formation back toward its home base after a recent raid on Germany. The story was told by Lieut. Albert I. Bell of Ogden, Utah, pilot of another Liberator, Boys-Howdy.

NAPLES, April 5 -- Columns of smoke 16,000 feet high billowed skyward over rail yards and an adjacent oil refinery at Ploesti, Rumania, today following an attack on that vital Nazi target by heavy bombers of Maj. Gen. Nathan F. Twining's United States Fifteenth Air Force, their fourth blow at major Balkan war centers in seven days.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- The House Military Affairs Committee requested Major Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, director of Selective Service, today to ask the War Manpower Commission for a list of "appropriate activities" in which employment would qualify a 4-F registrant for an occupational deferment.

LONDON, April 5 -- While Anthony Eden is prepared to relinquish his post as Foreign Secretary to devote his whole time to leadership of the House of Commons, it was learned tonight that it would be weeks, perhaps months, before Viscount Cranborne succeeded him.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 5 -- Swirling snow today did a thorough job of bringing the Giants' training activities to a complete standstill. It buried the scheduled exhibition game with the Red Sox, who, advised in time of the state of affairs, did not leave their base in Baltimore.

The Union City Warehouse Corporation has sold to Robert and Charles Benenson the square block of five-story loft buildings bounded by Twenty-third Street, Bergenline Avenue, Twenty-second and West Streets, in Union City, N.J., together with an annex building on West Street at the corner of Twenty-fourth Street. L.V. Hoffman Co. were the brokers.

As a result of wartime technical advances in the aviation industry the world will see a vast expansion in air travel at the end of the war, with new routes across the Arctic linking many of the large cities of the earth, it was predicted yesterday at the opening session of a three-day national aeronautics meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers at the Hotel New Yorker.

Mr. Willkie's announcement last night of his withdrawal from the campaign takes out of the contest for the leadership of his party the candidate who in the judgment of this newspaper has been best fitted by experience, by ability and by conviction for the Republican nomination for the Presidency.

CHICAGO, April 5 -- Utah and Aberdeen, S.D., were named 1943 grand prize winners today in the traffic safety contest conducted by the National Safety Council, in which all the States and 1,297 cities participated.

LONDON, April 5 -- Charges in the House of Commons today that Jews serving in the Polish Army in Britain are subjected to "virulent anti-Semitism" drew from Foreign Minister Anthony Eden the promise that he would discuss the matter with the Polish Government.

Sixty-four women ranging in age from the early fifties to the late sixties were graduated yesterday from the city Department of Welfare's household training project. The second class to complete the ten-week course in homemaking skills, they received their diplomas from Acting Welfare Commissioner Harry W. Marsh in ceremonies at the school, 325 East Thirty-eighth Street.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 5 (AP) -- Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, urged tonight a revision of Federal tax laws affecting corporations to become effective when the war ends and placed repeal of the excess profits tax "in the vanguard of tax revision."

Charles A. Lindbergh completed on Monday at the Marine Hospital, 67 Hudson Street, a series of injections against yellow fever and other diseases necessary for persons going overseas, it was learned yesterday.

YOUNGSTOWN, April 5 (AP) -- Shareholders of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company will be asked at the annual meeting April 25 to authorize the beard of directors to issue up to 300,000 additional shares of common stock within one year from the date of authorization.

LONDON, April 5 -- The turnover in most sections of the stock market here today was restricted but South African gold shares again attracted attention. Cape interests were active in these issues but prices eased on profit taking, it being realized that mining companies will derive little benefit from gold sales to India and Egypt at increased prices.

Almost two years ago, on April 30, 1942, Frederick P. Walter, a butcher who lived at 85-06 Ninety-sixth Street in Woodhaven, Queens, unwittingly left his car in restricted zone in front of 83 Liberty Street, Manhattan.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 5 -- The Westchester County Chapter of the American Red Cross announced today the receipt of $912,240 in the war fund drive, amounting to 97 per cent of the $987,000 quota. Twenty-six of the thirty-eight branches of the chapter have reached their quotas.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 5 -- The occupation of Hungary had been planned by the Germans since April, 1943. Originally timed for June, it was first postponed because Italy's impending collapse gave the Germans something more important to think about.

The right wing elements that formerly ruled the American Labor party took another step yesterday in the process of withdrawing from their old party, which they say is now Communist-dominated, and toward the formation of a new party under whose emblem they will unite to back President Roosevelt in the November election.

Two Hollywood luminaries, more or less recognizable, are the leading characters in "Public Relations," which has its premiere tonight at the Mansfield. They will be impersonated by Ann Andrews and Philip Merivale, whose supporting cast features Frances Henderson, Michael Ames and Betty Blythe.

CHICAGO, April 5 -- The hoarded estate of William Hale (Big Bill) Thompson, former Mayor of Chicago, was increased by $112,000 today with the opening of a third safety deposit box, this one in the First National Bank.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Because of the demands of the armed forces for young men, the War Shipping Administration has ordered a halt of the recruiting of draft eligibles under 26 for training in the merchant marine.

PHILADELPHIA, April 5 -- The Northern Indiana Public Service Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan to issue $22,007,800 par value of new securities in connection with an exchange or redemption program involving a like amount of three outstanding issues of preferred stock.

Newspaper editorial comment in various parts of the country on Wendell Willkie's withdrawal pointed in general to the regret which millions of persons would feel over the decision, but at the same time conceded that Mr. Willkie could hardly do otherwise in view of the Wisconsin primary returns.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Preliminary figures on supplies which the Army will need for civilian populations when the invasion comes are being worked out in conferences between the Foreign Economic Administration and Army officials.

A list of the Putnam County waters that were stocked with brown, brook, lake and rainbow trout just issued by the Putnam County Fish and Game Association shows that those who plied the streams without success over the week-end just weren't lucky.
NEW DELHI, April 5 (UP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The National War Labor Board's "bracket" system denies to pattern makers the wage rates to which they are entitled and in effect sets aside wage rates arrived at by collective bargaining, according to George Q. Lynch, president of the Patternmakers League, American Federation of Labor.

In previous articles the problems of French industry and labor under the German occupation have been examined. Economic causes have also contributed to two other phenomena powerfully influencing present-day life in France -- the black market and "terrorism."

FREDERICK, Md., April 5 -- Reacting with all the enthusiasm of polar bears to a couple of snowstorms that came with blinding fury to add to the discomfort of a chilly afternoon, Connie Mack's Athletics downed the Yankees today on McCurdy Field before a gathering of about 1,500.

NAPLES, April 5 -- The Italian troops who, a few days ago, swarmed up Mount Marrone, southwest of Castel San Vincenzo, without opposition showed yesterday that they could stand their ground under German fire.

BUENOS AIRES, April 5 (AP) -- The Argentine Government last night granted The United Press and its Argentine affiliate, the Prensa Unida, permission to resume the use of communications facilities that were barred to the news agencies on March 18 for an alleged violation of regulations governing the use of such facilities.

From all standpoints, the question whether the United States can make an equitable post-war trade with Great Britain, involving some of our surplus transport planes, for rights to use her far-flung empire system of air bases, is one of the most important practical problems before the international aviation negotiations that have just begun in earnest with Anglo-American exploratory conversations in London.

Irving Chernev of Brooklyn and Stephen J. Shaw of Stamford, Conn., won their matches as the preliminaries of the biennial tournament for the United States chess championship got under way last night at the Manhattan Chess Club. The former vanquished M.E. Schillay in a queen's pawn opening after thirty-one moves in their Group A. test.

For nearly four years Britain has had to maintain in the home island a considerable force of men who were not in combat. The number may be smaller since so many American troops have arrived for the invasion. It has never been large enough to preclude hard service in fighting zones for great armies of British and Dominion soldiers, as well as many from the colonies.

Marshal Ion Antonescu, Premier of Rumania, has issued a proclamation deploring the American air attack on Bucharest Tuesday and calling on the Rumanian people to stand united, DNB German news agency, said yesterday in a wireless dispatch to the controlled European press.

A conspiracy among producers of 95 per cent of this country's wood alcohol to eliminate competition and sustain high prices was alleged in a Federal indictment handed up here yesterday. Defendants named included a trade association, twenty-one corporate defendants and thirty-two officials of the accused organizations.

The victory scored by Dewey delegates in Wisconsin Tuesday, followed last night by Wendell L. Willkie's withdrawal from the Presidential race, was regarded here yesterday as a further building up of the lead the Governor of New York has had for the Republican nomination, and possibly bringing to fruition the hopes of his supporters that he would be nominated on the first ballot at the Chicago convention.

Filariasis has been successfully treated with anthiomaline, indicating that 95 to 99 per cent of soldiers and sailors contracting this parasite-bred disease in tropical combat areas can be cured, it was declared last night by Dr. Harold W. Brown of Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Sensitivity of the country's capital to world events is being faithfully reflected in the impact of every news bulletin of the war on the popularity of foreign-language courses.

LONDON, April 5 -- Strong formations of Mustang fighters of the United States Eighth Air Force swept over the Berlin and Munich areas on flights 600 miles from their bases today and destroyed "several dozen" German planes on the ground and five enemy fighters in combat.

MILWAUKEE, April 5 (AP) -- Governor Dewey of New York held his lead as late returns showed tonight he might have won eighteen of Wisconsin's twenty-four Republican delegates in yesterday's Presidential primary -- against none for Wendell L. Willkie.

The Daily Worker, official organ of the Communist party, yesterday attacked Victor A. Kravchenko, an official of the Soviet Purchasing Commission here who resigned in protest against Soviet Russia's foreign and internal policy, as a "petty traitor" who is "enmeshed in Hitler's nets."

Charles H. Schoch, New York State Deputy Superintendent of Banks, will be the principal speaker at a dinner meeting of the New York Safe Deposit Association, to be held next Wednesday in the Hotel Pennsylvania. Frank O. Brand, president of the association, who is vice president and general manager of the Empire Safe Deposit Company, will preside.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Special gasoline rations will be granted, with some provisions, to persons tending victory gardens away from their homes, the Office of Price Administration said today.

In an attempt to discover the extent to which scarce whiskies and other liquors are being hoarded by package stores, bars, grills, night clubs and hotels, the State Liquor Authority yesterday ordered all its retail licensees to file with it not later than May 1 an inventory of their floor stocks as of April 1.
The city and its environs, with a good part of the Eastern seaboard, were transformed unexpectedly yesterday into a snowy winter wonderland.

Net asset value of the Lehman Corporation on March 31 was $75,955,651, equal to $38.97 a share on 1,948,877 shares of stock, the highest figure in nearly seven years, according to a report issued yesterday. Net asset value on Dec. 31, 1943 was $37.71 a share.

A new issue of 40,000 shares of no par $4.75 dividend cumulative preferred stock of the Consolidated Cigar Corporation is being offered today by an underwriting group headed by Eastman, Dillon Co. at $97.50 a share. Consolidated is one of the largest manufacturers of cigars in this country.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 5 -- Joel McCrea, who had been doing special work for the Department of Agriculture, has been signed by Paramount for the lead with Gail Russell in "Fear," the adaptation of Ethel Lina White's mystery novel, "Her Heart in Her Throat."

Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop of Germany yesterday entered the Nazi counter-propaganda drive aimed to offset the effects of Soviet Foreign Commissar Vyacheslav M. Molotoff's assurance that Russia had no territorial or political ambitions in Rumania.

LONDON, April 5 -- As the wave of strikes, principally in the coal fields, continued today to show little or no abatement, the British Government let it become known that any further stoppages on the country's industrial front at this critical stage in the hostilities, when invasion plans are nearing their fulfillment, will be dealt with summarily.

HOLLYWOOD, April 5 (U.P.) -- War Production Board compliance officials today filed a criminal information against Lawrence W. Zonker, charging illegal sale of butane carburetor and tank sets to Hollywood film notables as means of sidestepping gasoline rationing.

The Collegiate Chorale, under its gifted young conductor, Robert Shaw, gave a concert of American choral music last night as the final event in the season's Town Hall Endowment Series. An elaborate program was offered, which was well devised to display the wide variety of music written for local ensemble in this country from the Revolutionary period to the present day.

PHILADELPHIA, April 6 -- The Houston Gulf Gas Company, a subsidiary of the United Gas Corporation in the Electric Bond and Share Company System, asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to sell its production properties, all in Texas, to the Union Producing Company for $3,049,155.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The National War Labor Board directed Montgomery Ward Co. today to restore "forthwith" the status quo which existed with the United Mail Order, Warehouse and Retail Employes, CIO, on Jan. 13, 1944.
LONDON, April 6 -- All sections of the stock markets here were quiet today, but the general tone remained steady.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total holdings of United States Government securities to have increased $54,698,000 during the week to a new high record.
Four apartment houses and several small dwellings were among the Bronx properties reported yesterday to have passed into new ownership.
AT UNITED STATES NAVAL BASE, Bermuda, April 6 (AP) -- A large-scale renewal of the German U-boat attacks on Allied shipping is "possible soon," Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox said today.

Engineers of the Civil Aeronautics Administration have designed a light plane that may be built by students in any high school vocational shop in connection with courses in aeronautics, Dr. Harry Ganders, educational consultant of the administration's educational service division for this region, said yesterday.

Miles of fine fabrics from department store piece goods counters are being purchased by women who never before have made their own clothing or employed a seamstress. That last year's record sale of yard goods is being maintained and in some cases bettered, was revealed yesterday in a survey of five large city stores.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, April 6 (AP) -- Gen. Douglas Mac- Arthur will continue in complete direction of Southwest Pacific offensives, it is believed in reliable quarters here, regardless of changes that may be made in the status of the South Pacific area or its command.

Driving ahead with unrelenting vigor, a Russian army is closing in on Odessa and has already reached its suburbs. Once more the roar of battle is echoing through this great Black Sea port that fell to the Germans and Rumanians in the dark October days of 1941 when Nazi armies were hammering at the gates of Moscow.

One would be inclined to think, beholding the rapt features and gestures of Bruno Walter when he conducted the uncut Matthew Passion of Bach last night in Carnegie Hall (and this is one of the culminating features of the season, which is his fiftieth as a conductor), that the event was in some way the realization of a great musician's dream.

In its first change of ownership since 1877, the four-story business building at 43 West Twenty-first Street was sold by the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, as trustee for the Gould estate, for cash over a mortgage of $6,000. Walter B. Hass was the broker.

Three new films will arrive in midtown theatres today. At the Strand, the attraction will be "Uncertain Glory," a Warner Brothers topical melodrama set in France. Errol Flynn and Paul Lukas are co-starred, with Jean Sullivan, Douglas Dumbrille, Lucile Watson, Sheldon Leonard and Dennis Hoey among the featured players. . . .
WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -The United States today called on the people of Albania "to unite their efforts against the Nazi enemy."

Consolidated net income of the Aviation Corporation for the quarter ended Feb. 29, 1944, amounted to $1,460,863, equal to 25 cents a share, comparing with $1,103,218, or 19 cents a share, in the same period a year ago, according to Victor Emanuel, president.

A syndicate of investors has purchased from-the Bowmark Realty Corporation the six-story apartment house at 345 East Eleventh Street, northwest corner of Second Avenue, for cash over a first mortgage of $216,400. There are seven stores and fifty-five suites in the building, which is 115 by 124.2 feet.
LONDON, April 6 (AP) -- Note circulation for the week ended yesterday as reported today by the Bank of England increased 14,594,000 to the new high record of 1,119,228,000.

LONDON, April 6 -- The United States delegation to the conference of Allied Ministers of Education stepped today into the leadership of efforts to organize a United Nations organization for educational and cultural reconstruction in post-war Europe.

Waldemar Johnsen, a young Norwegian baritone who made a dramatic escape from the Nazis in a fishing smack two years ago, made his American debut at Town Hall last night. He has a voice of fine, even quality and a sense of musicianship which enables him to put it to good use.

LONDON, Friday, April 7 -- The Soviet Third Ukrainian Front Army advanced to points less than fourteen miles northeast of Odessa yesterday by capturing Sverdlovo, while on the northwestern side of the long southern front the First Front Army seized Skala in the ring of encirclement around the remnants of the fifteen German divisions trapped north of the Dniester River.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 6 -- The absorption of the MERRA (Middle East Relief and Rehabilitation Administration) by the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration will become effective about May 1, subject to the approval of the British Government, it was announced here today by Herbert H. Lehman, director general of UNRRA, who gave his first press conference after two weeks of discussions involving Balkan relief.

LONDON, April 6 -- The long-pending crisis in the Greek Government has developed into such a muddle that King George of Greece has decided to give up his efforts to deal with the situation at long distance and return to Cairo, the seat of his Government in exile.

There may have been moments in the annals of mankind as big with drama as the present, but when before have the same men witnessed at the same time the beginning of one operation and the end of another which deserve to be classed as the greatest military adventures in history?

Two factors of current importance in the affairs of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company are the refunding of the company's bonds and the dividend outlook for the capital stock, Clifford E. Paige, chairman, informed stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday. He said that possibilities for refunding the company's bonds are being studied, but that details are not yet available.
Nazi propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels declared yesterday that the "history of mankind" could have gotten along very well without any nation in the world -- except Germany.

MEXICO CITY, April 6 -- In a decree published today President Manuel Avila Camacho announced that the Mexican Government had temporarily requisitioned all the facilities of the Mexican Telephone Company, a subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph, in an effort to settle a strike that has paralyzed the public utility since March 13.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today on the second anniversary of its V loan program, that nearly a third of its $7,484,000,000 in guaranteed loan authorizations involved canceled war contracts.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Illinois will be the scene Tuesday for the kick-off for the Presidential campaign, so far as the majority of women voters are concerned. The primary contests there list five Congressional competitions in which women candidates figure, as against a lone entrant in Nebraska, which also holds its primaries on the same day.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Sharp reductions in primary market prices for steers, hogs, eggs and cotton and for quicksilver and naval stores were principally responsible for the 0.1 per cent drop in the general level of prices for the week ended April 1.

MILWAUKEE, April 6 (AP) -- Late Wisconsin election returns indicated tonight that Lieut. Comdr. Harold E. Stassen had gained another delegate, raising his total to four who will support his nomination for President at the Republican National Convention at Chicago in June.

Fitz Harvey, 15 years old, received from Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yesterday a $25 war bond donated by Paul Robeson, singer and actor, to the winner of a city-wide contest for a new name for the Colored Orphan Asylum at Riverdale. Young Harvey, who gave the Mayor a wooden utility tray, the gift of the children at the institution, submitted the name "Riverdale Children's Association."

MEDITERRANEAN ALLIED AIR FORCES Headquarters, Italy, April 5 (delayed) -- The primary him of the Mediterranean Allied Air Forces is the destruction of enemy air power and that destruction unqualifiedly is being accomplished, Lieut. Gen. Ira C. Eaker declared here today in a long, candid press conference in which his most important aides took part.
Second Lieut. John Hylan Sinnott, grandson of the late Mayor John F. Hylan, was reported missing in action in a War Department telegram received by his family on Monday, it was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- In terms of economic power the Nazis can still wage a tough fight, but another year's resistance will produce an exhaustion of Germany without parallel since the Thirty Years War and load "terrible economic privations on the German people," Foreign Economic Administrator Leo T. Crowley said today.
LONDON, Friday April 7 (AP) -- The Russian Thursday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

MOSCOW, April 6 -- Russian newspapers estimated today that the Germans had killed between 350,000 and 450,000 persons during nearly three years of occupation of the Baltic states and had deported to Germany or to the rear, or had put into forced labor more than 1,000,000 other residents of the Lithuanian, Latvian and Estonian Soviet Republics.
LONDON, April 6 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Fort-four girls, who during the course of the day are stenographers, secretaries, auditors and accountants, at special ceremonies last night received citations from the War Finance Committee of the United States Treasury Department for having sold a total of $4,500,000 in war bonds during the Fourth War Loan Drive.

PEARL HARBOR, April 6 -- Shore batteries on Wotje Atoll, one of the four big bases still held by the Japanese in the Marshall Islands, scored two hits on an American destroyer that was picking up a marine flier shot down by enemy anti-aircraft from the same atoll Tuesday, Pacific Fleet headquarters revealed today.

Millions of school children must have suffered because they did not know the difference between Guinea, which is part of the western bulge of Africa; the three Guianas, which lie on the northeast coast of South America, and New Guinea, which lies north of Australia and is the largest island in the world.

The placing of dollars and cents ceilings on used cameras and other photographic equipment and the recent revision in the liquor price ceilings call attention to the fact that we are still extending price fixing for luxury products. It is widely agreed that the prices of basic necessities of life should be fixed in order to protect those in the lower income groups against a serious deterioration in their living standards.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (U.P.) -With parades and demonstrations banned by Gen. George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff, the Army today observed Army Day by intensifying its preparations for the invasion of western Europe.

LONDON, April 6 (U.P.) -- Powerful German armored forces have smashed to within five miles of Jajce, headquarters of Marshal Tito (Josip Broz), after a three-day battle in which both Yugoslav and Italian defending forces and the enemy lost heavily, a Partisan communique announced today.

WINFIELD PARK, N.J., April 6 -- The Federal Government, effective April 16, will resume direct control of the Government-owned Winfield Park defense housing project. The management of the 700-unit $4,000,000 development will be taken from the Winfield Mutual Housing Corporation, through which tenants were participating in a mutual ownership plan, and lodged in the New York Regional Office of the Federal Public Housing Authority.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 6 -- Two sailors were accused here today of grand larceny for an alleged automobile theft and were held for grand jury action by City Judge Thomas N. Fasso. The police said the sailors, arrested last night in an automobile taken from the Russian Embassy in Washington, admitted stealing eleven automobiles and breaking into a Peekskill jewelry store.

ATLANTA, April 6 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell, chief of the Army Service Forces, said today that America should pass a National Service Act immediately because "we have a hell of a lot of war left."

A broad program to train 3,000 to 4,000 foreign technical graduates from Europe and Asia in American engineering colleges so that they can return after eighteen months of study to help in the reconstruction of their own lands during the post-war period has been adopted by the general engineering staff of the Foreign Economic Administration, it was learned yesterday.

A preview of post-war television, from the studio camera to the home receiver that projects a large image on a wall screen, including a design for a huge studio with a revolving stage and seats for hundreds of persons, was presented here yesterday by engineers of the General Electric Company.
A number of Congressmen who disapprove of some phases of present American strategy recently expressed the wish for "another Billy Mitchell" to speak up on the subject.

PHILADELPHIA, April 6 (AP) -- New securities offered to the public during January totaled $1,911,149,000 -- slightly more than half the average monthly offerings during 1943 -- the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

NEW DELHI, April 6 (U.P.) -- The crack Seventeenth Indian Division, hacking its way through a series of Japanese road blocks that had cut it off for three weeks, has fought its way to Imphal, capital of India's Manipur State, and has joined the garrison preparing to defend the city in a decisive battle, it was made known today.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Mobilization and demobilization will be equal in July and will continue on that plateau until the situation permits or requires the demobilization of men in greater numbers than they are mobilized, Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Director of Selective Service, said tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- President Roosevelt has approved 277 new war public works and services projects for which the Federal Works Agency has alloted about $16,000.000 of Lanham Act funds. The projects are situated in forty-two States, Alaska and Hawaii.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on April 1 were 787,525 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 8,600 cars, or 1.1 per cent more than for the preceding week; 15,423 cars, or 2.0 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 41,513 cars, or 5 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

ALBANY, April 6 -- Governor Dewey, at his first press conference since Wendell Willkie withdrew from the race for the Republican Presidential nomination, declined today, as he has in the past, to become an avowed candidate.

CHICAGO, April 6 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens took a 2-0 lead in the Stanley Cup hockey finals for the world professional championship tonight by defeating the Chicago Black Hawks, 3 -- 1, before 16,003 spectators at the Stadium.

With the aid of a growing staff of investigators, the Office of Price Administration has within three weeks stepped up its prosecution of food, gasoline and clothing black markets by more than 25 per cent in this five-State region.

With contributions totaling $159,278, the New York Stock Exchange exceeded yesterday its Red Cross 1944 War Fund Campaign quota by $9,278, it was announced by Henry C. Brunie, president of the Empire Trust Company, chairman of the financial section of the campaign.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- Secretary Cordell Hull will make a full-dress speech on American foreign policy Sunday night, coupling a new reply to his critics with a discussion of current international political questions.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., April 6 -- Augie Galan no longer seems a possibility to play any second base for the Dodgers but Leo Durocher still seems minded to transform an outfielder into an infielder.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Mrs. Roosevelt ruled herself out today in favor of a younger woman as a possible delegate to the peace conference.

LONDON, Friday, April 7 -- Liberators of the United States Eighth Air Force hammered military installations in the Pas-de-Calais area yesterday, while Thunderbolt fighter-bombers of the Ninth Air Force struck a series of telling blows against enemy airfields in northern France.

NEWARK, N.J., April 6 -- Three leaders of the German-American Vocational League youth groups made a trip to Germany in 1937, during which they received a six-weeks' indoctrination course and listened to speeches by Adolf Hitler, Rudolph Hess, Hermann Goering and other Axis notables, according to testimony today at the Federal court trial of twenty-one defendants accused of a pro-German propaganda conspiracy.

So we went day before yesterday and deprived New Hampshire -- a small State, but there are those who love it, including Daniel Webster and Robert Frost -- of its only President of the United States in the person of Franklin Pierce, and transplanted him to Vermont, and didn't we hear about it in the first mail next morning!

WASHINGTON, April 6 -Swifter action in adjusting price ceilings of cotton textile manufactures under conditions set forth in the directive issued by Fred M. Vinson, director of Economic Stabilization, was promised by the Office of Price Administration today in a new statement on price-adjustment policy.

NAPLES, April 6 -- Following yesterday's vital stab at the Ploesti railyards, the Mediterranean Allied Air Forces for the first day in four did not attack new and important targets in the Balkans. Yesterday's over-all air offensive in this theatre totaled 1,000 sorties that cost the Allies twelve heavy bombers, while more than forty German planes were destroyed.
WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- Representatives of farmers' organizations won the right today to hold C gasoline ration cards as "preferred" drivers.

Miss Edith Kemper, formerly assistant buyer of furniture at Lord Taylor, has been appointed buyer of furniture, beds and bedding, succeeding Ralph Camp, who has been made merchandise manager of the home furnishings division of the store.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- Interstate Commerce Commission examiners recommended today that the ICC authorize a merger of the properties of the New York, Lackawanna Western Railway Company into the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad Company, with the latter railroad in control.
Tonight's papers carry a story from Washington about General Hershey's proposal to draft 4-F's for military service, to be assigned noncombat duty.
NAPLES, April 6 -- The campaign in Italy seemed yesterday to have become primarily a battle of artillery and mortar crews.
LONDON, April 6 (AP) -- Wendell Willkie's withdrawal from the Republican Presidential contest left many persons in Britain both concerned and confused.

HASTINGS, Neb., April 6 (AP) -- An explosion which came today forty minutes before the night shift was to have been replaced by a skeleton crew took eight lives at the Hastings Naval Ordnance Depot. It was the second fatal explosion at the 48,000-acre plant in two and one-half months.

SORRENTO, Italy, April 6 -- King Victor Emmanuel has assured Count Carlo Sforza and Benedetto Croce through an intermediary that he is willing to "retire" on a "lieutenancy" basis but still prefers to wait until the Allies reach Rome, it was revealed today at a special meeting here of the junta, or six-party executive committee of the opposition to the Badoglio Government.

Dale Eunson steadfastly clings to the belief that multiple marriages in Hollywood form pretty hilarious stuff for the East Coast stage. Maybe so, maybe so. But in his "Public Relations," which Robert Blake brought to the Mansfield last evening, he has failed to prove the point.
LONDON, April 6 (U.P.) -- The German radio said today that powerful formations of American bombers had attacked Austria and rail centers in northern Yugoslavia.

With the opening of "Allah Be Praised!" at the Adelphi on Wednesday night, April 19, that house will come under Shubert management, it was announced yesterday. Appearing in the Alfred Bloomingdale musical are Patricia Morison, Mary Jane Walsh, Joey Faye, John Hoysradt, Edward Roecker, Milada Mladova, Evelyne and Beatrice Kraft, Anita Alvarez, Pittman Corry and Jayne Manners.

American mills shipped 130,600,000 pounds of rayon filament yarns during the first quarter of 1944, according to the Rayon Organon published by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc. This is an increase of 9 per cent, compared with the 119,700,000 pounds shipped in the corresponding quarter of last year.
A special Federal grand jury will convene on April 17 to consider evidence concerning liquor black market activities here, it was announced yesterday by United States Attorney James B.M. McNally.

A sort of reverse rationing, whereby grocers and produce retailers would give housewives red stamps with each purchase of eggs or potatoes, was proposed yesterday to the War Food Administration by a delegation of food merchants.

Scoring his second victory in Group A of the national chess championship preliminaries, the second round of which was contested at the U.S. Chess Federation headquarters in Brooklyn last night, Irving Chernev of the Hawthorne Chess Club of Flatbush assumed the lead with a score of 2-0.

The fear that this country is on the verge of exhausting its oil resources is needless, Eugene Holman, vice president and a director of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, declared yesterday at the monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York at its headquarters. 65 Liberty Street.

Enlistments in the Waves have increased to the rate of 1,000 a week in the last three months, Capt. Mildred H. McAfee, USNR, director of the Women's Reserve, reported yesterday at the Naval Training School (W.R.), the Bronx.

A fast track for the start of the Eastern racing season at Jamaica tomorrow was the forecast yesterday of Thomas Maher, superintendent of the pear-shaped Long Island track. Hedges in Maher's prediction were that snow and rain storms must stay away from his door until 1:45 P.M. tomorrow, when the barrier will be sprung, and that Aeolus, mythical god of the winds, must supply some.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 6 -- Welcomed by moderate weather and sunshine, the Yankees returned "home" late today, relieved that the freezing temperature and snow of Trenton, N.J., and Frederick, Md., were behind them.

Two Tammany Hall district leaders issued a joint attack yesterday on the present leadership of Tammany Hall, charging that it has "obligations" to Representative Vito Marcantonio, left wing leader of the American Labor party, and that these obligations are working to the detriment of the Democratic organization.

The spirit of Easter arrived yesterday with attendance at Maundy Thursday services and the trooping home of thousands of school children beginning their annual Easter holidays. Today will be Good Friday and its usual religious devotions will be conducted in the churches.

ALBANY, April 6 -- The Coudert-Mitchell bill, authorizing New York City to finance the new Idlewild airport as a self-liquidating project, was signed today by Governor Dewey. It provides that a thirty-year bond issue may be issued for the project, which is estimated to cost between $60,000,000 and $100, 000,000.
Banks and the Home Owners Loan Corporation disposed of repossessed houses in Brooklyn deals reported yesterday.

More than 3,500 youngsters, ranging in age from 12 t8 18, descended on the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon for a special matinee performance of Thomas' "Mignon" sponsored by the Metropolitan Opera Guild. It was the third performance this season sponsored by the Guild for school children and as usual the youngsters applauded the artists with all the enthusiasm of veteran opera-goers.

A sharp cleavage developed yesterday between the teachers' groups and Ellsworth B. Buck, president of the Board of Education, as to the value of the Coudert bill, signed by Governor Dewey on Wednesday, which strips the Board of Superintendents of all but advisory powers and places full executive responsibility in the hands of the Superintendent of Schools.
WITH THE EIGHTH ARMY IN ITALY, April 6 -- There are two roads leading to this particular Indian unit. One of them is called "The Mined Road." The other is "The Mad Mile."

LONDON, April 6 -- The coordination of Russian and Anglo-American operations in the Balkans campaign, which began with the bombings of Budapest and Bucharest by the United States Fifteenth Air Force and Royal Air Force squadrons, will be increased in scope and weight as the campaign continues, according to a reliable source in London.

Continued large purchasing power in many sections of the country and absence of competitive durable goods items are expected to cushion any post-Easter decline in ready-to-wear sales at retail, reports here yesterday indicated. Sales comparisons for the next two weeks will be with the peak Easter shopping of last year, and it is anticipated that decreases, at least for this period, are inevitable.

MADISON, Wis., April 6 -- If the America First organization had been responsible for the result of Tuesday's Presidential preference primaries in Wisconsin, the delegates pledged to Gen. Douglas MacArthur would all have been elected, Secretary of State Fred R. Zimmerman declared today.

It is the aim of the American Theatre for Young Folks, recently organized by Henri Leiser, to establish a permanent children's theatre in the amusement district. With the presentation yesterday afternoon at the Adelphi Theatre of a musical play entitled "Bobino" the group took a step in the right direction.

Member banks of the Federal Reserve System throughout the country regained the $300,000,000 of excess reserves in the week ended Wednesday that they had lost the week before, when their excess funds sank to the lowest level in more than ten years, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

From Sullivan County, where thousands of New Yorkers spend a part of the summer, comes word that the streams will have about as many trout as they contained last year. The season opened there last Saturday, as in most of the rest of New York State, and was marked by cold weather.

Beauty and barber shops, with a gain of 35 per cent, led gains in sales during February in department stores in this reserve district, compared with a year ago, according to the Federal Reserve Bank yesterday. Other departments showed substantial gains, with towels up 34; laces, embroideries, 32; wines and liquors, 31, and linens, 20 per cent.

WHEN baseball men get together for two consecutive minutes, they do not discuss economics, Chaldean history or the habits of the duck-billed platypus. They talk baseball. Not so long ago this eavesdropper kept his mouth closed and his ears opened as the general staff of the Boston Braves punched the conversational bag. Want to listen in?

MOSCOW, April 6 -- The present operations in the south tend to confirm Red Star's recent statement that the war has reached a phase in which the Red Army is beating the Wehrmacht in a field where the Germans previously excelled -- mobile mechanized warfare.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 6 (AP) -- Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio, candidate for the Republican nomination for President, said tonight the results of the Wisconsin primary election and the withdrawal of Wendell Willkie would mean "an intensified campaign for delegates" for himself.

In answer to an inquiry sent to Republican Presidential candidates: "Will you support any candidate nominated by the Republican national convention," the North American Newspaper Alliance has received the following replies:

CHICAGO, April 6 (AP) -- Daniel W. Creeden, president of Libby, McNeill Libby, food canners, told stockholders in his annual report today that the company "expects to be sold out of seasonal products before new packs become available."

LONDON, April 6 -- There were strong indications today that the Yorkshire strike, which has reduced Britain's war effort by 100,000 tons of quality coal, may be well on the way to a satisfactory settlement when the Easter holidays are over.

Yesterday the Lee house on Pennsylvania Avenue was handed over to the Department of State to be, like its neighbor, the Blair house, a guest house for distinguished foreign visitors. The Blair house came into the possession of the elder Francis Preston Blair in 1836. He built the Lee house for a daughter upon her marriage to a son of Henry Lee, Light Horse Harry.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Planning for post-war industry readjustments in terms of days and weeks, rather than in months and years, was urged upon the Senate Military Affairs subcommittee studying such problems today by Dr. Melvin T. Copeland, chairman of the Massachusetts Committee on Post-War Readjustment.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 6 -- The man who now has openly betrayed Hungary by assuming the "premiership" there under Adolf Hitler and Heinrich Himmler always has been a Quisling, conspiring with equal unconcern against both Hungary and Yugoslavia.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERE IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, April 7 (AP) -- A communique:
NEW DELHI, India, April 6 (UP) -- A communique:

High school student winners in the tenth annual Baird Memorial Interscholastic Latin Sight Reading Contest were announced yesterday by Irving M. Hayward of the Classics Department of New York University's Washington Square College of Arts and Science.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, whose strict adherence to banking tradition has won it the supplementary title of "The Old Lady o Liberty Street," confounded the banking community yesterday by deliberately breaking one of its own long-standing traditions.

Revision by the War Production Board of its fabric export program so that clothing, garments and apparel manufactured here may be shipped abroad instead of the piece goods, is not desirable, according to the Textile Export Association of the United States.

Eight local housing authorities throughout the country will open bids on April 19 on new issues of notes aggregating $39,799,000. The issues range in size from $13,531,000 to $324,000. All except that of the Bethlehem. Pa., Housing Authority, which is dated May 31, will be dated as of May 10.

Allied air forces are achieving mastery of the skies over Europe, essential to invasion, and "it is apparent that the time for the kill is at hand," Maj. Gen. Frank O.D. Hunter, commanding general of the First Air Force, asserted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- The Soviet Embassy tonight branded Victor Kravchenko, employe of the Russian Purchasing Commission who charged the Soviet Government with a "double faced" foreign policy, a "deserter" from the Russian Army who "refused to return to his motherland for military service."

CLEVELAND, April 6 -- Discovery and concentration of a chemical substance, present in minute amounts in raw cream, that prevents muscle-stiffness in guinea pigs and relieves lameness and calcification of body tissues developing in animals fed on a diet deficient in this food factor, were announced at the meeting of American Chemical Society by Prof. Willem J. Van Wagtendonk of Oregon State College.

ALGIERS, April 6 (U.P.) -- Gen. Henri Giraud has offered his resignation as Commander in Chief of the French Armies, but Gen. Charles de Gaulle, in an attempt to avoid a public break. is trying to get him to accept the post of "Inspector General of the Armed Forces," it was understood tonight.
BUENOS AIRES, April 6 (AP) -- The Dionnes appeared today to have an authentic set of rivals for quintuplets honors.

HOUSTON, Tex., April 6 (AP) -- Former Gov. Dan Moody and Wright Morrow, representing the Texas Democratic Executive Committee, will ask the United States Supreme Court for a rehearing on its decision that Negroes can vote in Texas Democratic primaries, the committee chairman, George A. Butler, said today.

Pre-holiday evening up in the local cotton market brought out selling at times yesterday, but prices held within a narrow range all day, May closing 8 points higher and other active months 2 to 6 points lower.

The new advertising campaign for Laundromat, Westinghouse Electric's automatic washing machine which was developed shortly before the war, will describe proper laundering technique for clothes and fabrics with present equipment, in addition to featuring pictures of the machine, Roger H. Bolin, advertising manager of the appliance division, explained yesterday.

The Federal Trade Commission heard yesterday that cigarettes have a considerable value on big-game hunting expeditions. The testimony came from James L. Clark, 1192 Park Avenue, director for preparation and installation of exhibits at the American Museum of Natural History, a witness before Trial Examiner Webster Ballinger, in a hearing on charges of misleading advertising against the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company.
Mrs. Vanderbilt Phelps has arrived from Carmel Valley, Monterey, Calif., and is at the Ambassador.

Tricolor, the American edition of La France Libre, a monthly magazine devoted to the cause of French liberation, made its appearance here yesterday under the editorship of Emile Bure, Henri Torres and Andre Labarthe.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., April 6 -- Apprentice Bobby Permane became the first jockey of the Florida season to ride five winners in one day when he achieved that feat at Tropical Park today. Permane's fourth victor was M. Shagrin's Red Dock in the Wakefield Purse.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- Restrictions on use of coal probably will have to be tightened still further next winter, Secretary Ickes predicted today, because drafting of younger miners will increase the gap between production and needs.

Expecting an increase in the number of production "holds" ordered by procurement agencies, controllers of companies engaged on war contracts are seeking establishment of procedures by which reimbursement for costs resulting from such stoppages can be achieved, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- Dr. Melvin T. Copeland, director of research of the Harvard School of Business Administration, predicted today the nation will enjoy an indefinite period of post-war prosperity in which industrial employment and production will maintain their wartime levels.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- Evening up for the Good Friday holiday tended today to hold grain prices within relatively narrow limits on the Board of Trade. Longs took profits and there was a lack of aggressive buying as shorts had covered freely yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 6 -- Paramount has named Ray Milland for the lead in the picturization of the Ferenc Molnar play, "Olympia," to be made in the autumn as a romantic musical. Ingrid Bergman will be borrowed from David O. Selznick for the feminine lead if her other commitments can be arranged.
A man who has won more decorations in this war than any other officer in the naval service confessed yesterday that he "didn't exactly relish fighting."

A committee of nationally prominent educators, headed by George H. Chatfield, member of the Board of Education, called yesterday for public support of a $50,000,000 Federal-sponsored program to provide school lunches in 25,000 communities in the United States.

Information reached Washington on Wednesday that Gen. Henri Giraud had submitted his resignation as Commander in Chief of the French Army, but it was not allowed to leak out as British and American representatives in Algiers tried to make him reconsider his decision.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Army has now attained its planned peak strength of 7,700,000 men and the Navy is within 400,000 of the goal of 3,600,000 which it expects to attain by Sept. 1, the Office of War Information disclosed tonight.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 6 -- Georges Roussos, former Vice Premier, said today that he would accept the Premiership if he were asked, but allowed it to be understood that he would do so because an emergency existed calling for immediate action.
The sky assault upon Germany and her satellites continued yesterday as the Russian armies approached the formidable barrier of the Carpathians and the marshy estuary of the Danube.

LAKEHURST, N.J., April 6 -- Flashing a drumfire attack of twelve hits, plus some excellent pitching that proved altogether too much for their Jersey City farm hands, Mel Ott's Giants regaled a gathering of sailors and Waves at the Lakehurst Naval Station today by drubbing Gabby Hartnett's Little Giants, 12 to 3, in a seven-inning game.

Encouraged by the progress of the United Nations in the fight against the Axis, but at the same time saddened by the sufferings of victims of Nazi persecution, Jews in all parts of the world where freedom of worship still obtains will attend services today at sundown, ushering in the Jewish festival of Passover, commemorating the deliverance of the ancient Hebrews from servitude in Egypt.
We may confidently expect a labor draft confined to the 4-F's. The scheme has all the virtues which appeal to the type of mentality now in control of such matters:

FARMINGDALE, L.I., April 6 -That Yankee ingenuity isn't dead by a long shot, particularly when ways and means of shooting up the enemy are involved, has again been demonstrated by the exploits of a veteran fighter plane squadron, the members of which recently returned home after a series of missions over north Italy and Yugoslavia.

LONDON, April 6 -- Britain's casualty figures of people killed or injured in highway accidents since the war began exceeds that of the country's casualties on the fighting fronts by 200,746, it was revealed today.

LONDON, April 6 -- Sir John Anderson, Chancellor of the Exchequer, sidestepped a question in the House of Commons today as to whether American film producers were evading the income tax of this country by charging through agents and producers here such high prices that no profit appeared to arise in Britain.

Proposals by the "British Imperialist wing" looking to the political and economic integration of the British Empire by which the dominions and all component parts would be in future in unison on foreign policy and defense were assailed yesterday by Eugene P. Thomas, president of the National Foreign Trade Council, in his introduction to the official report of the thirtieth annual National Foreign Trade Convention.

Further recovery of a selective list of shares was registered yesterday by the stock market with interest centered in medium-priced issues. The fact that the holiday today will bring a halt in all markets argued against any broad movement, and there were several pauses in the course of the session in the upward swing.
CHICAGO, April 6 (AP) -- Today's report

Several high officers observed Army Day yesterday by appealing to the home front to get "fighting mad," as one general put it. The need to back the fighting men with an iron will at home was reiterated again and again at a ceremony during the noon hour on the steps of the Sub-Treasury Building, Wall and Nassau Streets.

TRENTON, N.J., April 6 -- Completing the translation into law of an important phase of his legislative program, Gov. Walter E. Edge signed today the bill creating a State Department of Economic Development to deal with post-war problems.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Civilian shoppers face the prospect of carrying most of their purchases unwrapped within a few months, officials of the War Production Board warned today.

One controversial issue about American policy in post-war international aviation is how much freedom of the air we should allow foreign planes in flying over and landing on American territory. Here, as in the problem of broad or limited powers for the prospective international air transport authority, our representatives in the international negotiations that have started with exploratory Anglo-American conversations in London may be expected to tread a middle ground.

Applying their ingenuity to promoting the war effort on the home front, the Girl Scouts in the metropolitan area turned in a record of 460,880 hours of service during last year, according to the annual report of the organization's service bureau just issued.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Department store sales in the week ended April 1 were 31 per cent above sales in the corresponding period of last year. The following table shows percentage changes from corresponding periods of last year.

The principle of portal-to-portal pay, or pay for travel time, for which the United Mine Workers has contended in the coal industry and that has been approved by the United States Supreme Court in the case of iron ore miners now applies also to homeworkers employed by concerns in interstate commerce.

A collection of American antiques that is said to be the largest ever formed by one person is to be sold at auction here. It comprises thousands of items and required more than sixty years to assemble.

Holiday shoppers should have no difficulty in getting just about what they want in the meat line this week-end, according to a spokesman for the War Food Administration, for good supplies of almost all kinds are available. Those planning on an Easter ham will find liberal stocks of smoked varieties, and lamb, which has been somewhat scarce for the last few weeks, is now in good quantity, with some spring lamb on hand.

In observances of Good Friday, all the principal securities and commodity exchanges in the United States and Canada will be closed today, but all will reopen for business tomorrow except the New York cotton and wool markets and the New Orleans Cotton Exchange.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, April 7 -- More than 250 Allied planes, striking continuously for fifty minutes Wednesday, tore up the town and harbor of Hollandia with 320 tons of explosives and 250,000 rounds of ammunition -- and that New Guinea air base of the Japanese was helpless to resist.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The "Little Steel" formula is "an iron barrier" which prevents the remedying of injustices in the national wage structure, Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, told a special panel of the National War Labor Board today.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Admiral Harold R. Stark, Commander of United States Naval Forces in Europe, sent a special message from London today to the millions of men and women in the 30,000 plants and sixty-seven shipyards producing landing craft for the Navy, urging the workers to "give us the craft -- we'll do the rest."

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- To prevent undue penalizing of transportation companies in cases of aliens barred from entering this country, although bearing passport visas, a Senate Immigration subcommittee is preparing legislation to provide "proper safeguards."

LONDON, April 6 (U.P.) -- A columnist for The Evening Standard suggested today, on the basis of advices from "my correspondent in New York," that Wendell Willkie might announce that President Roosevelt "owed it to the American nation" to seek a fourth term.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The arrival in Chungking, China, of A. Eugene Staley and Owen L. Dawson, American members of the staff of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, was announced today.
OMAHA, April 6 (AP) -- A tired man sat in his suite at a hotel here early today after a momentous night that saw him walk out of the Republican race for the Presidential nomination.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- Wendell Willkie, smiling broadly and saying he felt "wonderful," declined today to amplify his announcement that he had stepped out of the race for the Republican Presidential nomination.

Intimation of Washington's refusal to recognize the French Committee of National Liberation worries not only the British and the Russians, who know Hitler better than we do, it worries Americans who have been near the front.

The Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League will comprise five teams this season. Columbia, Cornell, Dartmouth, Pennsylvania and Princeton will compete for the championship in a twenty-game double round-robin schedule. The race will present the unusual picture of two defending champions, Penn and Cornell having tied for the title last year.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -Notwithstanding loss of their European markets, Latin-American republics exported goods of a higher aggregate value in 1942 than in any years since 1937, and during 1943 they exported more than $1,300,000,000 worth of goods to the United States, a still greater increase.

JERUSALEM, Palestine, April 6 -- With the aim of formulating a constructive approach to the whole problem of reparations by Germany for the property and assets plundered from Jews in Germany and Austria, exploratory talks have been proceeding for some time among leading Jews from those countries who now are living in Palestine.

The Dollars Savings Bank has sold the two-story building for four families on a plot 25 by 120 feet at 1260 Bronx River Avenue, in the Bronx, through Elroy, Clark Co., brokers. The same bank also sold the four-story apartment building with sixteen suites on a plot 40 by 100 feet at 462 East 186th Street through P.C. D'Onofrio, broker.

MOSCOW, April 7 (AP) -- Everything that appears in the Soviet press now is not necessarily an official expression of the Russian Government's point of view. This may help to answer the questions of some followers of Soviet foreign policy who have been puzzled by stories and editorials in Moscow papers and accepted abroad as official expressions of opinion.

CHICAGO, April 7 -- Many of the 100,000 railroad workers who must be recruited this year will be women. The Chicago District Employment Office of the United States Railroad Retirement Board has its own quota of the total figure to fill, and has a staff on duty daily to interview prospective workers.

Maxwell Henry, Associate Professor of Electrical Engineering at City College and one of the designers of the new Hunter and Queens College buildings, died yesterday morning at his residence, 136 West Sixteenth Street. He was 47 years old.
I Walter T. Tobin, formerly with 'the Allied Purchasing Corporation, has been appointed vice president of Hirestra Laboratories, makers of beauty products.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, April 8 (AP) -- A communique:

The OPA has reached the conclusion that "A" gasoline coupons "have been cut to the bone" and that further reductions will be imposed upon the "B" drivers. Has it occurred to the OPA that "A" driving is largely pleasure driving and should be completely abolished throughout the country for the duration of the war?

HIGHLANDS, N.J., April 7 -- Karl R. Anderson, 43 years old, a dredge captain employed on the naval munitions depot construction at Leonardo; his wife, Jessie, 29, and their two children, Rudolph, 9, and Alice Marie, 7, went to bed Wednesday night in their newly rented bungalow at 83 Barberrie Avenue with all the windows closed, all the jets in the gas range ignited and with the flame of an oil burner turned high.

Easter trade here continued active this week, despite the handicap of a snowstorm and a letdown in purchasing of toilet goods from the heavy "beat-the-tax" buying of the previous week. Estimated gains over last year ranged to 30 per cent or more, with the average gain for local department stores put at 22 to 25 per cent for the week.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The War Labor Board cleared the way today for the return of anthracite mines to private operation by approving a wage contract to take the place of the one which expired May 1.

ALBANY, April 7 -- Governor Dewey signed the Desmond bill today imposing standards of safety for a type of lodging house which he said was characterized as "a flop-house." These have been unregulated heretofore.

The three-story business building at 752-54 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold for Max Greenberg to an investing client of David Jaret Co., brokers. The property is assessed for $60,000 and was sold for cash above a first mortgage of $54,000.
BERNE, Switzerland, April 7 -- Dr. Joseph Goebbels, who captured the Reich capital for National Socialism in 1926, was today appointed "President of Berlin" by a special decree of Adolf Hitler.

NEW DELHI, India, April 7 -- Japanese invasion troops in India have driven westward across the Imphal-Kohima highway in the heart of the Allied defense zone and are being hotly engaged in the jungles thirty-five miles east of the Bengal-Assam Railway, American-operated supply lifeline for Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's forces in northern Burma, it was announced today.

Prof. John Hanna writes you a letter entitled "A Program for Peace." He says that what is needed is a realistic minimal program which will unite the maximum numbers. He inquires if an association of nations with a world court and court of arbitration of disputes not settled by adjustment would find substantial support.
BOSTON, April 7 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow of the Boston wool market:

SCRANTON, Pa., April 7 -- The prospect of a grave slump in anthracite production over the Easter week-end increased today when about half of the 70,000 miners in the eastern Pennsylvania field remained away from work in observation of Good Friday.

An industry educational drive to precede a nation-wide consumer campaign to promote acceptance of candy as an energy food in the post-war era is planned by the National Confectioners Association, it was announced yesterday. The trade will present data at a series of regional meetings to be opened in Chicago on April 12, with other gatherings slated in Boston on April 17, New York on April 19 and Philadelphia on April 21.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., April 7 -- Dixie Walker and Leo Durocher made their respective debuts at third and second base today in a seven-inning contest waged on Durocher Field, which was won by the Dodgers, 7 -- 0, from Montreal.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- James C. Petrillo's dictum as president of the American Federation of Musicians which has blocked new musical recordings by two major record companies since Aug. 1, 1942, went before the full National War Labor Board today, where counsel for the union and the recording companies argued for almost five hours the merits and demerits of the order.

Through a variety of media, Van Camp's, Inc., has launched its spring and summer campaigns for Tenderoni, Van Camp's Beans and Chili Con Carne. Ray N. Peterson, advertising manager, described the campaign as the largest in the company's history.

According to figures on the recent primary election now available, the left-wing coalition between Sidney Hillman and Earl Browder captured the machinery of the American Labor party by polling less than 57,000 votes, of which more than 52,000 were concentrated in New York City.

WITH AN AMERICAN INFANTRY DIVISION, Somewhere in England, April 7 (AP) -- When the Americans storm Adolf Hitler's ramparts from the west they will not wade into a blood bath, but will go "in there punching backed by massed naval fire and air power."

MOSCOW, April 6 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Metropolitan Sergius of Moscow, Patriarch of the Russian Orthodox Church, today challenged the fundamental basis for the Pope's authority as the "vicar of Christ on earth."
LONDON, April 7 (U.P.) -- Royal Air Force Mosquito bombers hurled two-ton blockbusters on battered Hamburg, Germany's largest port, and hammered targets in the Ruhr and Rhineland last night.

Unusually long lines have been forming all week in front of the "shoe" window at the Midtown War Price and Rationing Board, 1775 Broadway. The increase of several hundred applications a day above normal for extra shoe ration stamps was termed yesterday by Office of Price Administration aides as a sort of by-product of traditional pre-Easter apparel buying.

A FIFTH ARMY REST CAMP NEAR THE ITALIAN FRONT, April 7 -- More than a thousand members of the Fifth Army, including three nurses and one Wac who attended with her husband, whom she outranked, tonight shared their Passover service with Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark, their Commander in Chief, at a seder.

City draft headquarters disclosed yesterday that an estimated 3,000 youths reaching 18 years of age in the five boroughs are being inducted into the armed forces each month and that one out of every three men drafted last month was pre-Pearl Harbor father.

" Follow the Girls," a new musical comedy featuring Gertrude Niesen, Frank Parker and Irina Baronova, makes its local debut this evening at the renovated Century Theatre (formerly the Jolson), Fifty-eighth Street and Seventh Avenue.

Charged with attempted burglary at Nathan Pintchik's paint store at 478 Bergen Street, Brooklyn, and discharged by the grand jury Wednesday on the owner's plea, Victor Seaholm of 1773 Park Place, Brooklyn, was arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Abner C. Surpless in Felony Court -- accused of attempting to rob the place again Wednesday night.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 7 --"The time has now come for plain speaking," the newspaper Piccolo said yesterday in keynoting the capital's press campaign for the "voluntary" evacuation of an estimated 1,000,000 persons within a fort-night.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (U.P.) -- The War Department told honorably discharged soldiers today that "numerous privileges" awaited them in civilian life and that "you can always be proud you were once a member of America's armed forces and that you served with honor."

Orders from service men here and overseas for Easter flowers still are pouring into the New York office of the Florists Telegraph Delivery Association at the rate of 25,000 a day, and as no deadline was set for the placing of Easter orders, they probably will continue to arrive until next Wednesday, a spokesman for the association said last night.

When a man says "all the comforts of home" he usually means a good deal more than a room with a fireplace and deep chairs. Most men want rooms that can stand being mussed up, rooms that can accommodate their pet collections, whether they're books, stamps, or broken-down pipes, and rooms that have color without being faddish.
NAPLES, April 7 -- The Anzio beachhead grew more restless yesterday when heavy shelling continued from both sides on the Italian fronts and localized fighting tended to increase.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- President Roosevelt went to the executive offices today for the first time since March 28 to hold his Friday morning press conference. Correspondents thought he looked better than when they last saw him a week ago Tuesday.

The death of Percy Selden Straus brings to a close the career of a merchant whose intellectual qualities won him the admiration and respect of the business world. In any review of his life one thinks first of these intellectual qualities, for they invariably impressed those who came in contact with him.

Today's issue of your paper carried the news of the resignation of the Hon. Louis H. Pink as OPA Rent Administrator for New York City. Mr. Pink will be missed as a public officer. His rich experience, broad understanding. ability for judging and kindly dealing make him ideally fit for office of great trust.

ALGIERS, April 7 -- The position of Gen. Henri-Honore Giraud, Commander in Chief of the French Army since shortly after the Allied landing in North Africa in November, 1942, semed in doubt tonight since Gen. Charles de Gaulle, head of the French Committee of National Liberation, had offered him a lesser post and there were indications that he might refuse it.

The British Government has submitted proposals for the establishment of an International Air Transport Authority (IATA) for discussion at the international negotiations that have started with Anglo-American exploratory conversations at London preliminary to a United Nations Aviation Conference.
Gardeners at Rockefeller Center set out a thousand Easter lily plants yesterday, after being delayed four hours by a stiff wind that threatened for a time to nip blossoms in the bud.

Various aspects of post-war planning will be discussed by leaders in government, education, agriculture and industry at the spring convention of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, to be held in St. Louis April 25 to 28.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Here is the text of a report to the President on the administration's "hold-the-line" economic stabilization plan, made by the Office of Economic Stabilization, Office of Price Administration, War Food Administration and the War Labor Board:

In all the discussion of international aviation little attention has been paid to the air tramp. Most of the talk is about liners. Thomas Olsen, partner in a Norwegian shipping company, pleads for the air tramp in The Aeroplane, a British periodical devoted to aviation.

RICHMOND, Va., April 7 -- Among the 574 patents listed as granted in the current issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office are three for a method of treating wood to make its grain stand out clearly; one for a new composition of matter, a phenol rubber-containing material and another for a machine to make coffee cake.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- A survey by the United States Women's Bureau of union policies for women members resulted today in the recommendation of six clauses for union contracts. Union women of both the AFL and CIO assisted the bureau in drafting these clauses, and will work for their inclusion in contracts.
LANSING, Mich., April 7 -- A draft-Dewey movement was gathering momentum today in the Governor's former home State as Michigan headquarters, sponsored by more than 150 Republicans, was opened here.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- Legislation to give statehood to Alaska should be delayed until after the war, four Government departments told Delegate Anthony J. Dimond of the Territory in reports he made public today.
LONDON, April 7 (AP) -- The coming invasion of Europe will have the most comprehensive news coverage of any military event in history.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 7 -- Charles H. Beckwith, 68 years old, operator of a trucking firm, killed his wife, Ruth, 41, in a gasoline station she operated at Park Avenue and State Street here, at 10:30 A.M. today and died of a heart attack soon afterward at the wheel of his car in which he was fleeing the scene.
