PITTSBURGH, April 7 -- Slightly better industrial operations aided by pronounced gains in originating freight shipments and in the volume of trade boosted the index of business in the Pittsburgh district to new high levels last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

CHICAGO, April 7 -- Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio, candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, made a plea before the Union League Club tonight for the retention of bases and installations throughout the world as "an absolute essential to the future safety" of the United States.

HEADQUARTERS AAC FORCE, India-Burma Border, March 23 (Delayed) (AP) -- The story now can be told of the slim American farm boy, when only a few yards from safety, drowned rather than cry for help and give the position of his American and British friends to the enemy.

The American Locomotive Company reported yesterday for 1943 a consolidated net income of $6,626,515 after charges, taxes and a provision of $2,700,000 for postwar adjustments, equal, after dividend requirements on the new 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock and sinking fund requirements on that issue, to $2.27 each on 1,364,415 common shares outstanding.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 7 -- It was decided at a Greek Cabinet meeting today that Sophocles Venizelos, Minister of Marine, whose appointment as Premier was recommended by Emmanuel J. Tsouderos at the time of the latter's resignation, should form a government despite Mr. Venizelos' decision yesterday that even if King George II asked him to become Premier he would refuse.

Victor A. Kravchenko denied here yesterday the charge by the Soviet Embassy in Washington that he was a deserter from the Russian Army. Earlier this week he said that he had resigned from the Russian Purchasing Commission in protest against the "double-faced political maneuvers" of his Government and the embassy took notice of his statement Thursday, declaring that he lied about his position in the purchasing commission.

A bill providing for one year of compulsory military training after the war for American boys at the age of 17 or after finishing high school is now before the House Military Affairs Committee in Congress (H.R. 3947). It appears to me that this bill does not take full advantage of the experience of other countries with military training and service.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, April 8 (AP) -- Allied planes in widely separated attacks have sunk an oil-laden enemy vessel, set fire to a 7,000-ton merchantman and hit Wakde Island off the northern New Guinea coast for the first time, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.

PEARL HARBOR, April 7 (U.P.) -- Liberators of the Army's Seventh Air Force flew 500 miles north of the enemy's beleaguered Marshall and Caroline Islands Wednesday to blast Wake Island with forty-four tons of explosives, it was announced today.

Lieut Gen. Omar N. Bradley takes occasion to tell American officers in England that "this stuff about tremendous losses" in the invasion of Europe is "tommyrot." Of course, General Bradley doesn't really know.

ABOARD A BRITISH WARSHIP, April 6 -- The British naval force whose planes knocked Germany's superbattleship Tirpitz out of the war for months -- perhaps for good -- returned to its home base today to be greeted by resounding salutes from other warships already at anchor.

PHILADELPHIA, April 7 (AP) -- The Cudahy Packing Company of Chicago registered today with the Securities and Exchange Commission $14,000,000 of Series B 3 per cent first mortgage sinking fund bonds due in 1964.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- President Roosevelt said today that the question of official recognition of the French Committee of National Liberation as a provisional government was essentially one involving a definition of "self-determination," and he was not prepared to say whether anybody outside France knew what the French people wanted.

Production of wood household furniture will be held at current levels for the next sixty days pending completion of a War Production Board survey of stocks on hand of end users of lumber but informed manufacturing sources yesterday predicted that "a probable rationing of lumber to all factories" after that period will result in output "decidedly less than the present 84 per cent of 1941 production.''

CHICAGO, April 7 (AP) -- Mervyn (Red) Dutton, president of the National Hockey League, declared today that a repetition of last night's missile-throwing episode by fans during the Stanley Cup game between the Canadiens and the Black Hawks would result in a forfeit to the visitors.

IN his "The Robber Barons" Matthew Josephson wrote of the Vanderbilts, Harrimans, Hills, Rockefellers and Morgans as men who seized the "economic narrows" of society to exploit the development of a continent for themselves. The tone was pejorative, and the fact that both the American population and its standard of living rose to new levels during the time of the "robber barons" did not soften Mr. Josephson's indictment.

FIFTEENTH ARMY AIR FORCE, Headquarters Italy, April 7 -- American heavy bombers have now started a coordinated campaign to cut the remaining rail arteries linking the German armies in the southwest Ukraine and Rumania with production centers in the Reich.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- A movement toward "rehabilitation of disabled men of the armed forces and preparation of wives and families for their return," which was recently started at a closed conference in New York City, gathered impetus here today in a discussion between Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines of the Veterans Administration and Mrs. Carter Collins, editor of Army and Navy Woman, published by the Association of Army and Navy Wives.

LONDON, Saturday, April 8 -- Russian troops attacking northwest of Odessa have trapped the remnants of five or six German divisions -- perhaps 25,000 to 50,000 men -- and begun wiping them out, Moscow announced last night, while other mobile units racing around Odessa's western flank smashed to within fifteen miles of the last German escape route into Rumania with the capture of Mayaki at the head of the Dniester estuary.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Tighter restrictions on the use of liquefied petroleum gas equipment and a prohibition against the use of liquefied petroleum gas as a motor fuel in passenger automobiles were announced today by the Petroleum Administration for War.
Notes from the fish and game front:
WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- A Pacific Fleet announcement:

The probability that all international crossings on the Canadian and Mexican borders would be closed on Sundays after May 1 was forecast yesterday by Mitchel J. Valicenti, legal representative of the Mexico-Texas Bridge Owners Association, unless the Treasury Department rescinds its order of Feb. 21 that requires the bridge owner to pay triple-time on Sundays to customs guards employed on the crossings.

LONDON, April 7 -- An American Liberty ship, forced out of a convoy, straddled a reef less than sixty yards from shore and cracked into three parts, it was learned tonight. Sixty-two crew members perished, most of them in trying to reach land from the short but hazardous distance through a mountainous sea.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 7 -- A ninth-inning single by Steve Filipowicz with the bases full and two out enabled the Giants to defeat the Jersey City Giants by 3 to 2 in their exhibition game today at an Atlantic seaboard camp.

TORONTO, April 7 (AP) -- The sensational net-minding skill rookie Bill Durnan of the Canadiens has shown all season had its climax today in his unanimous selection as goalie for the fourteenth annual Canadian press All-Star hockey team.

One of the greatest problems of the post-war period will be the restoration and maintenance in Europe of stable democracies. It would be a tragedy if the terrible lessons of the last quarter century were still unlearned, and if Europe were to return to the type of unstable democracies that fell prey to internal dissensions and proved such easy victims for fascism and dictatorship.

NEW ORLEANS, April 7 (U.P.) -- Richard Bienvenu, 33-year-old broommaker who has suffered from impaired vision since birth, now sees well from one eye, following a delicate operation in which the damaged cornea of his left eye was replaced by the cornea from the eye of a woman who heard of his condition.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Suspension of the Army order that the Breakers Hotel at Palm Beach shall be abandoned as an Army hospital April 30 was asked of President Roosevelt in a telegram today from Senator Pepper of Florida. Copies of the message were released at the Senator's office.
LONDON, April 7 (AP) -- A communique broadcast from Germany:

HEADQUARTERS OF THE BRITISH FOURTEENTH ARMY, in India, April 7 (U.P.) -- Military thorities today minimized the Japanese invasion of India, and although acknowledging that it had some "nuisance value," they asserted confidently that the Japanese were playing into Allied hands.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- Chops, stews, steaks and roasts were served on American dinner tables in the last three months at a slightly higher rate than any year since 1908, and will drop only slightly during April, May and June.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Senator Clyde M. Reed of Kansas said today that he would demand that the Senate Postal Committee, of which he is ranking minority member, trace the official source which permitted excerpts from letters written by Miss Vivien Kellems, Connecticut war plant executive, to a German Count in Argentina to get into the hands of persons who quoted them from the House floor, over the radio and in a newspaper column.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- President Roosevelt commended as of real importance a report made today on the eve of the first anniversary of his "hold-the-line" order by the four men responsible for fighting inflation. In it they declared that they had not only stemmed the rise in the cost of living but also had stabilized wages.

A UNITED STATES FIGHTER BASE in England, April 7 (AP) -- Capt. Don S. Gentile, 23-year-old Mustang pilot from Piqua, Ohio, claimed today twenty-seven enemy planes destroyed, of which at least eight were on the ground, and if his claim is allowed he will take undisputed leadership among American aces in the European theatre of operations.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, director of Selective Service, and Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, in a joint request tonight called upon men classified 4-F in the draft to check with their local offices of the United States Employment Service office on whether they were employed in work essential to the war.

A collection of exclusive Easter bonnets was shown yesterday by a group of talented new designers. At a fashion show on the roof playground of the Childrens Aid Society's James Children's Center, 154 Hester Street, seven little girls, ranging in age from 7 to 13, modeled their original creations before fifty fascinated playmates.

Today's events: "Tosca," 2 P. M., and "Goetterdaemmerung," 7:30, Metropolitan Opera House; Eddie Condon Jazz Concert, Town Hall, 5:30; Gloria Perkins, violin, and William Schatzkamer, piano, in Victory concert, New York Public Library, 5:30; Jefferson Ensemble Jefferson School, 575 Sixth Avenue evening.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 7 -- Joan Blondell, who recently returned to Hollywood after her appearance in the New York stage show "Something for the Boys," has signed a term contract with Twentieth Century-Fox, under which her first role will be that of Aunt Sissy in the forthcoming "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn."

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Eloquent tribute to the contributions of Jews to the country's past and current history, including the present war in which he said 2,500 had received the Purple Heart and other citations, was paid in the House today by Representative Curley, Democrat of Massachusetts.

EAST PATERSON, N.J., April 7 -- A few hours after she had bade a tearful good-by to her husband, who had been called back to naval duty, Mrs. Helen Parsch, 26 years old, of 35 Church Street, this borough, went to her death in the Passaic River, with her 2-weeks-old daughter, Carol.

The State Department's action in sending a delegation to London to cooperate in an international education program was hailed yesterday by Dr. Harlow Shapley of the Harvard Observatory and president of the American Association for an International Office for Education as a "significant step" in the direction of world peace and security.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- The shortage of containers, both for transport of munitions overseas and domestic shipments of essential food and goods, is "one of the most serious questions facing the country," the War Production Board (WPB) reported today.
The Soviet communique, as broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The wine and liquor industry has exceeded by $11,000 its $190,000 quota in the Red Cross 1944 War Fund drive, with a considerable number of gifts yet to be reported, Charles A. Tattersall, chairman, of the campaign section, Food, Drug and Beverage Industries, announced yesterday.

By providing paid jobs for service men recovering in hospitals from physical disabilities including battle injuries, private industry for the first time is taking a "working" part in the Government's program to get such patients on their feet again and back to active duty, it was revealed yesterday.

Worshipers thronged churches in the city by thousands yesterday for Good Friday devotions. Uniforms of members of the armed services were everywhere. Congregations were particularly large at noon, overflowing in many cases.

CHICAGO, April 7 -- War-created problems, especially shortages of merchandise and manpower, are becoming more serious in the operation of Marshall Field Co., Hughston M. McBain, president, told stockholders today at the company's annual meeting.

New financing was at a slower pace here this week, following last week's large flotations of public utility bonds and stock. Only one new issue of bonds, $2,500,000 in amount, was offered to the public, along with three fair-sized issues of stock, compared with two bond flotations amounting to $56,000,000 and four stock issues last week.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Southern Senators preparing to prevent enactment of the Marcantonio Anti-Poll Tax Bill, approved by the House and scheduled to be called up in the Senate after the Easter recess, served notice today that even if the measure comes up for formal consideration, which they will fight, it will face an avalanche of amendments which may reach 1,000 in number.

The Archbishop of York said yesterday in his first interview in this country, that the Nazi hatred of religion had been responsible in part for a great religious resurgence among the people of Russia.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., April 7 -- A group of fathers called up for induction today by Selective Service Board 13 declined the opportunity of getting a three-day Easter delay because they already had said farewell to their families and wished to avoid facing the heart-tugging ordeal again.

The first anniversary today of the Administration's Hold-the-Line order finds organized labor contending that only spendable income -- that is, earnings after deduction of taxes and war bond purchases -- should be taken into consideration in determining the need for wage increases.

LONDON, April 7 -- Polish sources here said today that their underground army in Wolyn [Volhynia], east central province in Poland, was helping the Red Army drive the Germans out of territory that Poland claims is hers, but which the Soviet Union holds is part of Russia.

NEWARK, N.J., April 7 (AP) -- The New Jersey State open golf championship will be held over the Montclair Golf Club course again this year, with the State amateur championship slated for the Essex County Country Club, the New Jersey State Golf Association announced today.

Cigars available for civilian consumption will be cut drastically Monday, with 32,000,000 additional monthly being taken off the market and earmarked for the Army and Navy, it was learned yesterday. So that all units of the armed forces and all branches of the cigar industry -- manufacturer, distributor and retailer -- may be guaranteed fair treatment, the Army is issuing a priority under which each manufacturer will contribute to a quarterly pool of 97,156,000 cigars.

The Jewish festival of Passover, commemorating the deliverance of the Jews from bondage in Egypt, was ushered in yesterday at sundown, with services in temples and synagogues, on battlefronts and at naval stations throughout the world

The Concordia Collegiate Institute of Bronxville has purchased the old colonial home with a large plot at 230 White Plains Road, Tuckahoe, Westchester County, for a girls' dormitory through Schmiedel McCarthy, brokers.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 7 -- Feasting on inept pitching, the Yankees today swamped the Athletics on Bader Field, 13 to 5.

PITTSBURGH, April 7 (AP) -- "Commando" Kelly's mother is lonesome these days and wants to see the most famous of her seven sons who are in the services. This she told President Roosevelt in a letter asking that he allow Tech. Sgt. Charles E. Kelly, now in Italy, to come home to see her for a few days.

NAPLES, April 7 -- A small force of heavy bombers attacked the air field at Zagreb, Yugoslavia, yesterday in a blow at one of the three centers of Luftwaffe strength in that country mentioned Wednesday by Air Marshal Sir John C. Slessor in discussing the Balkan offensive at Mediterranean Allied Air Force headquarters.

PENSACOLA, Fla., April 7 -- Lieut. Comdr. Joseph L. Seligman, USNR, member of a New York banking family, who had been in charge of a naval station in Chicago and was on leave here, died yesterday from a bullet wound said by the coroner to have been self-inflicted. His age was 56.
LONDON, Saturday, April 8 (AP) -- The Friday midnight supplementary communique as broadcast from Moscow:
BUENOS AIRES, April 7 -- The official Socialist organ Vanguardia reappeared today after exactly three months of voluntary closure.

Prices of fresh-water fish have been raised to such exorbitant levels by dealers taking advantage of the heavy demand for the Jewish Passover festival that Daniel P. Woolley, Regional Office of Price Administration head, announced yesterday he was urging Washington to set immediately price ceilings on white fish, yellow pike and carp.

A reader of this column is good enough to add his own contribution to this question of escape literature that fails to work. We spoke some time ago of picking up a volume of Mark Twain's letters and finding him doing business around 1890 with the Hartford manufacturers who now make a large part of our airplane engines.
DNB, German news agency, yesterday quoted Japanese Imperial Headquarters as saying it expected that "the so-called enemy general offensive will still take place during the first half of this year."
NEW DELHI, India, April 7 (AP) -- A Southeast Asia communique:

This week the menus for our family of two adults and a school-age child call for a six-pound ham and a pound of bacon -- both meats that yield a good quantity of fat in the form of drippings. It occurred to us that as a way of showing how these might be conserved -- and all fat must be employed to advantage nowadays -- we might trace their use in the meals.

Magdalena Petit, whose novel "La Quintrala" was pulished here by Macmillan, will be the Chilean delegate to the conference hero of the Inter-American Commission of Women, to be held from Monday to April 20.

Eighteen thousand five hundred men, women and children will march down Fifth Avenue this afternoon in the annual Army Day parade, held under the auspices of the New York chapter, Military Order of the World Wars, it was announced yesterday by Rear Admiral Reginald R. Belknap, retired, chairman of the chapter's Army Day committee.

Contrary to public opinion no more iron kitchenware will be available to the public than previously as a result of the recent War Production order permitting an "increase" in the manufacture of such items, a spokesman for the trade declared yesterday.

Under the auspices of the Greater New York Federation of Churches the fifth annual Easter Dawn Service in Radio City Music Hall will take place tomorrow from 7 A.M. to 8 A.M. The hall is used through the courtesy of John D. Rockefeller Jr.

LONDON, April 7 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav Partisans battled desperately today to stem a German two-way offensive threatening their Bosnian stronghold of Jajce, while Allied air and naval forces sought to draw off pressure with intensified attacks on German sea and land supply routes and airfields.

PEARL HARBOR, April 7 -- The Pacific Fleet carrier task forces that attacked Palau, Yap, Ulithi and Woleai over a three-day period beginning March 29, sank twenty-eight Japanese ships, damaged or beached eighteen others, including a battleship, destroyed or probably destroyed 214 enemy planes and wiped out many installations and docks.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Attorney General Biddle absolved the Congress of Industrial Organizations political action committee today of charges by Representative Howard Smith of Virginia that the labor body had committed a "flagrant violation" in connection with campaign contributions.

Senator Burton K. Wheeler, chairman of the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce, was asked yesterday by V.V. Boatner, a director of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad, to investigate the activities of Jesse Jones and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in connection with that road.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., April 7 (AP) -- Bobby Permane, young New Jersey apprentice who had ridden five winners at Tropical Park yesterday, improved on that record today by whipping home five consecutive mounts.

With fourteen entered for the $7,500 added Paumonok Handicap, everything is in readiness for the opening of the New York and Eastern racing season at Jamaica, home course of the Metropolitan Jockey Club, today.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- Men of draft age were divided into three age groups today and local boards were instructed to go easier on the men in the 30 to 38 bracket, following a policy laid down by Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey.

PITTSBURGH, April 7 (AP) -- Stockholders of the National Supply Company today sustained the management in a proxy fight against an opposition group by upholding a change in the by-laws which staggers the terms of directors.

Delivery of mail containing shipping documents covering exports to the United States may be expedited if the foreign shippers mark the cover envelope "Shipping documents only -- urgent," the National Council of American Importers, Inc., announced yesterday.

ALBANY, April 7 -- Eventual State aid for the construction and maintenance of arterial highways in New York and other cities was indicated by Governor Dewey today in signing bills transferring from the counties to the State the cost of acquiring rights-of-way for State highways and providing for State payment of plans for post-war construction of city arterial highways.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Senate's Special Committee on Post-War Economic Policy and Planning, headed by Senator Walter F. George, reported today on amendments to the George-Murray Bill on demobilization which limit the scope of the measure to contract termination, and largely embody the recommendations made on that subject early this year by Bernard M. Baruch and John Hancock of the Office of War Mobilization.

An important addition to the industrial activity of Newark, N.J., is indicated in the announcement by Abeles-Stevens, brokers, of the purchase by the Gulf Oil Corporation of a vacant plot at the corner of Broad and Marshall Streets. The property, 117 by 170 feet, was formerly owned by the Prudential Insurance Company of America and was the site of St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, which was torn down in 1934.

LONDON, April 7 -- Several members of the Polish Army, whose anti-Semitic demonstrations helped to drive more than 170 of their Jewish comrades to desertion, were reported in Polish quarters today to have already been dealt with by courts-martial. The number of cases and the judgments of the courts were not disclosed.

Reporters in Jerusalem think it worth while to cable that the tension of the last few weeks abates in Palestine as Christians, Jews and Mahommedans turn to the observance of their great spring festivals. This is a small item of news to set beside the stories of three-dimensional battles raging without pause from the Ukraine to the South Pacific.

WITH every muscle straining and every nerve taut for the springing of the barrier, they tensely await the opening of the New York racing season at Jamaica today. The horses? Not particularly. The reference is to the horse players, an incorrigible breed which has been taking its sport of kings in most vicarious fashion for the past five months.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- Men of draft age were divided into three age groups today and local boards were instructed to go easier on the men in the 30 to 38 bracket, following a policy laid down by Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey.

Into its logbook of the Pacific war the Navy last week wrote the most spectacular entry so far, a story whose implications were as startling as its facts. It was the account of the carrier task force operation against four Japanese bases in the western Carolines, deep in enemy waters, 2,400 miles away from the Marshalls, only 550 miles from the Philippines.

IT was no surprise to Canadians to learn that Harry F. McLean, who not long ago gave away big checks to war victims in Halifax, was at it again in Windsor, throwing money out of a hotel window. He is one of the fabulous builders of Canada.

ALMOST certainly the news of the week was the guest appearance of John J. Anthony as a sort of comedian on the Frank Sinatra program, after which there isn't much more to say about Mr. Anthony as a comedian, unless he persists.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Enemy torpedoes cut short the war careers of two Liberty ships in the Mediterranean a few weeks ago, the War Shipping Administration disclosed today, and took the life of one crew member.

With a complete absence of Federal combat units, which disappointed Mayor La Guardia, but was characterized by Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commander of the New York Guard, as symbolic of the extent to which the home front is dependent on the State militia, the police and civilian defenders, the Army Day parade was cheered by 150,000 New Yorkers as it swung down Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon.

DETROIT, April 8 (AP) -- Henry Ford announced tonight that a 300-acre camp in suburban Dearborn which has been used as a trade school and farm project for high school age boys had been converted into a rehabilitation center for disabled war veterans who had medical discharges.

Some weeks ago this newspaper editorially deplored charges directed by Vice President Wallace against what he called "American Fascists." In response to our invitation to define what he meant by a "Fascist" in this connection Mr. Wallace has written an article which is published today in our Magazine.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., April 8 -- Eddie Arcaro dipped the last of the cream off Florida's racing season that ended at Tropical Park today. The jaunty little saddle artist rode the Greentree Stable's Four Freedoms to a convincing victory in the $10,000 added Tropical Handicap and thus pulled down first money for the three richest races of the 100-day season.

THAT the relation of the United States with the countries to the south of us is the laboratory in which we may hope to work out an enduring world foreign policy is the theme of Virginia Prewett's book.

HAVING just been to the store for butter and returned without because the points had gone for something else, we seemed to remember having read something, somewhere, sometime, about some method of making butter from sea-water -- which doesn't seem so unreasonable nowadays, when practically anything we don't have can be made from anything we do have if we try hard enough.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 8 -- Far Westerners are growing restive under what they look upon as management of most of their affairs from Washington, at the expense, they believe, of reduced efficiency in the war effort.
A communique broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
Russell P. Hunter, superintendent of the Connecticut State Board of Fisheries and Game, sends along some information on what to expect in his State when the season for trout opens next Saturday.

Hershey, Director of Selective Service, ordered draft boards to suspend induction calls in such cases until all men in the age group under 26 had been processed.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The State Department and the Foreign Economic Administration denied today that Sweden had been threatened with a withdrawal or curtailment of navicerts for importation through the Anglo-American blockade unless she ceased the export of ball bearings to Germany.

POCONOS, Pa. -- Streams in the vicinity of Skytop and Ski Run Lodge promise good fishing when the trout season opens in this State Saturday. Old-timers hope for a rising and not a falling temperature, as trout bite better, they say, when it's warm.

RICHMOND, Va., April 8 -- The upper South is much less disturbed than the deep South by the United States Supreme Court's ruling that Negroes must be admitted to Democratic primaries. Virginia, North Carolina, Kentucky and Tennessee have admitted them for years, and have had no interracial disturbances or other complications.

Wendell Willkie withdrew last week as a candidate for the Republican party's 1944 Presidential nomination. ST. PAUL, April 8 (AP) -- Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio, who passed through St. Paul today on the way to the West Coast, said in an interview that the issue in the coming Presidential campaign, closest to the American people, would not be that of foreign policy but "the needless expansion of Governmental costs and bureaucracy under guise of wartime necessity."

THE dizzy weeks begin today, with two ballet companies in action simultaneously during three of them, Martha Graham coming to town for the fourth one while one of the ballets is still running, and a score of other interesting events on the schedule.

CHICAGO, April 8 (AP) -- Chicago Stadium is expected to be packed with nearly 19,000 fans -- the largest hockey crowd in history -- tomorrow night when the Black Hawks and Canadiens meet in the third game of the Stanley Cup play-offs.

ALGIERS, April 8 -- Both sides said tonight that Gen. Charles de Gaulle and Gen. Henri-Honore Giraud still hoped to come to an agreement about General Giraud's proposed departure from the post of Commander in Chief of the French Army, on which the Committee of National Liberation decided on Thursday.

MOSCOW, April 8 -- The straight-forwardness with which the Soviet press has been calling Japan the past and present ally of Germany -- the Soviet Union's No. 1 enemy -- is the best key currently to the state of U.S.S.R.-Japanese relations.

LONDON, April 8 -- Americans looking toward Britain this week saw a familiar and disquieting spectacle -- a coal strike which, although involving less than 2 per cent of the nation's total labor force, had slowed down the entire war effort and even appeared to be jeopardizing victory itself.

Easter trade closed actively here last week, with most stores showing substantial increases over last year. The average gain for the week among department stores was estimated at from 22 to 25 per cent, with the increases ranging to 30 per cent or more.

ON a string of personal travel -- on what, in the more passive past, we might have called "personal adventure" -- Mr. Price has threaded together more information on the vast ocean world of Micronesia than has ever before been assembled.

WILLIAM FOX, the former motion picture magnate who has been almost constantly involved in court actions since losing control of his $300,000,000 film empire fourteen years ago, declared in an interview last week that he was preparing to stage a comeback.

Ethelbert Smith said that as the climax of the war draws near he finds himself thinking how large a share of the victory will be due to our pre-Pearl Harbor fathers. The visitor said how pre-Pearl Harbor fathers?

One of New York's most popular subscription parties -- the annual Gay Thirties Dinner Dance for the benefit of the Boys Club of New York -- will take place Friday night on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Leap year features will be incorporated into the divertissements of the evening.
WHEN Wendell Willkie first arrived as a student at Indiana University his sister pointed out to him the monument which marked then the exact center of the population of the United States.

A sharp reversal in the sales' trends of chains and independent grocery stores, indicating that chains have turned their losses of last year into gains for the first quarter of 1944, while independents' monthly increases have been declining since early last fall, is revealed by current trade figures.

THE conditions of the White Foundation lectures, of which two delivered in 1942-43 by Attorney General Francis Biddle compose this slender volume, require that they be delivered by a jurist or publicist specially distinguished in some branch of jurisprudence and that the lecturer present some fresh or unfamiliar aspect of his subject.

WASHINGTON -- The oriental flowering cherry trees along the Tidal Basin are in their first bloom this Easter day; the double blossoms will put on their brief showing about two Sundays hence. Pink magnolias and yellow forsythia are brightening the White House lawn and the capital's many small parks.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- The Greyhound Corporation filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission an application for authority to issue $10,000,000 in 3 per-cent sinking fund debentures to increase its working capital and furnish funds for other requirements.

Eighteen faculty members from fourteen departments participating at Colgate University have introduced a social science discussion course on "Problems of the Peace," meant to acquaint students with specific problems expected to make for post-war unity or disunity among the United Nations.

DR. B. is imprisoned by the Nazis, as they attempt to extract information from him, in physically comfortable but mentally agonizing solitary confinement. Then one day, as reason and will are about to crumble, he steals what seems to him a prize beyond all earthly value -- a book.

LILLIAN SMITH'S best-selling novel "Strange Fruit," which is running away with Reynal Hitchcock's paper reserve, will be in its hundred-thousandth when this is in print. The publishers have definitely decided against any deletions or changes that might make a "Back-Bay Special" acceptable to Boston.

NAPLES, Italy, April 8 -- The first Easter in Italy since the fall of Fascism and the last before the expected invasion from the United Kingdom will be observed tomorrow in the farthest front-line areas as well as in dusty churches in the small towns throughout the southern peninsula.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 8 (AP) -- The Russian armistice terms offered to Finland are "such that even those most eager to get peace in Finland consider it impossible to come to an agreement now," a correspondent for the Stockholm newspaper Dagens Nyheter wrote tonight on returning from Finland.

Racing, sport of kings and pastime of millions whose only castles are their homes, made a sensational start at Jamaica yesterday when the New York and Eastern season opened for a 181-day stand to be followed by a nine-day victory meeting.

DETECTIVE PAT CAMPBELL of Los Angeles is summoned to Gulf Cove because Senator Wolfskill has found human blood on the carpet of his bedroom. The Senator is not sure whether this is evidence of a crime already committed or a threat of something yet to come.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Public and court access to files and documents of the Office of Price Administration is restricted under terms of a new order promulgated by the Price Administrator, Chester Bowles, last Thursday.

Shoe manufacturers this year will not be able to meet basic civilian requirements, due principally to drains being made by the shoe repair industry on sole leather supplies, according to L.E. Langston, executive vice president of the National Shoe Retailers Association.

Any one reading for the first time the four Gospels of the New Testament could not help being deeply moved by the simple pathos of the accounts of the Resurrection. It is particularly so now. The soldier, troubled by what is before him, may read a new meaning into the story of the disciples who came upon their risen Lord on the road to Emmaus:
NAPLES, April 8 (AP) -- A communique:

LONDON, April 8 -- Since Russia and the United States entered the war against Germany the British have seen themselves as a sort of link between the Soviets and America. Thus they hoped to build out of the grand alliance for prosecution of the war a strong and lasting coalition of great powers which together would guarantee political stability in Europe and insure an era of economic security for all.

MOSCOW, Sunday, April 94 -- Moscow's guns roared last night to salute the Red Army's feat on reaching what Premier Stalin in an order of the day described as the southwestern State frontiers. Armored forces and many infantry units struck deeply into the broad-backed Carpathians to reach the Czechoslovak frontier in the region of sub-Carpathian Ruthenia, seized by Hungary during the dismemberment of the Czech Republic.

Rosario and Antonio, the team of briliiant young Spanish gypsies who have been dancing hereabouts in revues and night clubs for several years to the pleasure of all concerned, last night took the plunge into the concert field with a long and fairly elaborate program, involving the services of a dance group, at Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The Federal Public Housing Authority announced today it is halting the Government's mass purchase of plumbing, lighting and other equipment. Hereafter, contractors on publically financed war housing projects will do their own buying.

THE trouble with many columnists is that they work on the theory that facts are dull and a sentence without a wisecrack is wasted. But most wisecracks are exaggerations and straining for them frequently results in distortion and a sense of cheapness.

NOW that it is Easter the theatre season is about to start on its last lap, which does not necessarily mean downhill. The most courteous adjective possible for the first three-quarters is uneven, but Broadway sometimes is one of the better money players and it may manage to close its somewhat strange year with a burst of glory.

THE transport rose and fell only slightly in the deep blue water. Beyond her white wake the endless sea fanned out toward the vast arch of the horizon. Gentle eddies of warm morning air drifted across the fantail as the Coast Guardsmen and troops straggled to the after deck around the mount of the 5-inch gun for religious services.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The letter by Maurice Leon sounds plausible on the surface, but if analyzed the method of governing France between the day of occupation and the day that a general election can be held is extremely dangerous to the cause of democracy and of feminism everywhere.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY in Italy, April 8 (AP) -- Pvt. Alfred Tornetto, a slim, 24-year-old former printer of 75 Fourth Place, Brooklyn, N.Y., was described tonight by his comrades as having given one of the greatest displays of personal devotion of the Italian campaign.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The defeat of Wendell L. Willkie in the Wisconsin primary and his subsequent withdrawal as a Republican Presidential candidate were regarded by many Washington analysts of political trends in the farm States as a sweep of political tides which have been resurgent since 1938.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 8 -- This shipbuilding center, into which many thousands of Negroes have poured from the South and East since the war began, was advised in a report made available today by the Young Women's Christian Association to expect increased racial tensions if a tendency persists to restrict non-white groups to special and limited housing areas.

It is not surprising that our present income tax system is complex. In the last decade the Congress passed upon seventeen revenue measures, each of which, with few exceptions, was superimposed on existing statutes. Except for administrative changes, the only real simplification of tax laws was the adoption of the Internal Revenue Code.

FROM the Grotto of Capri to the atolls of Fiji have come books by doctors about doctors. This addition to a long list is at one and the same time the autobiography of an able practitioner and a survey of pediatrics for the past half century.

The Nationalities Division of the Red Cross 1944 War Fund of Greater New York yesterday revealed that thirty-four nationality groups have contributed $272,565 toward the city-wide appeal for $22,386,000. About $3,324,000 still is needed to complete the city-wide quota "and discharge New York's responsibility to the armed forces during the current year."

ALASKA doesn't need an exciting writer. Almost any aged sourdough, wintering in Seattle, could talk into a dictaphone with a fair chance of hitting the best-seller list. But Alaska has an exciting writer in Thames Williamson and his "Far North Country."

OTTAWA, April 8 -- Twenty-seven years ago this Easter Sunday, April 9, 1917, the Canadians took Vimy Ridge and held it against repeated German attacks. It was the first time that four Canadian divisions had fought as a unit and their achievement on that day has been an inspiration and example for all Canadian forces since this war began.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Equal representation of women with men on the Resolutions Committee at the Republican National Convention for the first time in the party's history is indicated in the report of a special committee on the subject, released today by Chairman Harrison Spangler.

LONDON, April 8 -- Lord Beaverbrook, Lord Privy Seal, acknowledged today to the press that the British Government had been obliged to make concessions to the United States in the post-war civil aviation conferences that he and Adolph A. Berle Jr., United States Assistant Secretary of State, have just concluded, but the nature of the concessions were not forth coming. ed they were not so great as Lord Beaverbrook's solemn announcement implied.

Unprecedented and entirely unexpected was the rush to purchase war bonds yesterday at Jamaica, where any follower of the sport of kings could gain admittance to the track by merely buying a bond. A $25 or $50 bond was good for a grandstand seat and one for $100 qualified the purchaser for the inner circle, more familiarly known as the clubhouse, where the tips are just as bad.

The Diamond Jubilee season of the Metropolitan Opera Association closed yesterday with capacity audiences both in the afternoon and evening that have been numerous this season. The company will leave tomorrow for a month's tour, opening in Boston for a week, and then going to Chicago for two weeks and to Cleveland for the annual week there.

LOCKING the barn door after the horse has been stolen is what fruit tree spraying amounts to, if it is done after the bugs and fungi have given up keeping their presence a secret. Now is the time, therefore, to start controlling the insects and diseases which later can be so troublesome.

A Canteen Ball under the military sponsorship of Field Marshal Sir John A. Dill and Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum will be given Thursday night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria as the annual dance for the benefit of Madison House, 226 Madison Street, a forty-six-year-old neighborhood center on the lower East Side.
EASTERTIME is indisputably the time for flowers. Fresh, fragrant blossoms are as inseparable a part of the Easter parade tradition as milan straw and veiling and patent leather pumps.

AN AMERICAN AIR BASE, Italy, April 8 -- The Allies' air forces are now operating the biggest photographing, processing and printing plant in the world. One of its officers estimates that, in civilian life, it would represent a $100,000,000 business in terms of personnel and equipment.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Criticizing today what he termed a country-wide "small loan racket," Representative Harry R. Sheppard declared that Leon Henderson, former Price Administrator, and Rolf Nugent, former director of the OPA credit policy office, were among those "solely responsible" for conditions which led up to it.

LONDON, April 8 (U.P.) -- King Haakon VII of Norway tonight promised his people that the "hour of liberation soon will strike" as underground reports indicated that Hitler's once arrogant northern garrison stood mentally beaten and a prisoner in the country they tried to conquer.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The potential seriousness of the Japanese thrusts in northeast India was not minimized by military experts in this capital today. In British and American military circles real concern was evident, although there was a general disposition to expect ultimate success by the Allied forces.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The premiere showing in this country of 160 winning paintings and sketches in an Allied service men's art contest sponsored in New Guinea by the Army and the American Red Cross began today in Red Cross headquarters in Washington.

ALBANY, April 8 -- Brig. Gen. Ames T. Brown, State Director of Selective Service, halted today the induction of all Selective Service registrants over the age of 26 scheduled to enter the armed forces on Monday and Tuesday of next week.

The peepers were out early last week, tuning up for spring's first full moon. And then came the snow, which not only silenced the peepers but gave the fox sparrows and robins and blackbirds and grackles a few very miserable days. One flock of birds, however, seemed to know what was coming.

Tonight at 8:30 the two leading contenders for the heavyweight ballet championship of America will trip into the local ring for a contest which has been aptly nicknamed by some wag, "le War des Ballets." In the corner above are shown several of the reasons why "Battler" S. Hurok's Ballet Theater, opening at the Metropolitan Opera House feels confident of winning by a knockout.

HOUSES, old and new, all mysterious, play important parts in each one of this handful of new mystery stories for older boys. Around the "Thunderbolt House" of Howard Pease's new book hung a half-whispered legend of old tragedy.

SANDWICHES are easy and quick to make, and so fit into the kind of hurry-up cookery in which most women are interested nowadays. Despite their hasty aspect, however, they can be delicious, nourishing and of enormous variety -- hot or cold, sweet or hearty, containing vegetables or meat, made with bread or rolls, and so on.

GREENVILLE, Ohio, April 8 (AP) -- A group of farmers antagonistic to policies of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration abandoned today their attempt to force the resignation of the Darke County AAA chairman, Ora R. Fellers, who had been advised to quit by noon today "or else." As the deadline arrived policemen stood guard there and thirty auxiliaries were ready for duty.

The Bethlehem-Fairfield shipyard at Baltimore will undertake soon a production schedule that calls for the construction of fifty-three Victory ships, all but eleven of which are expected to be completed before the end of this year, according to a statement by J.M. Willis, vice president and general manager of the yard, released here yesterday.
ELEANOR KITTREDGE'S interesting review of the "French Colonies, Past and Future" in THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review of Feb. 13, 1944, calls for a few answers.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Southerners in and out of Congress are hot with indignation as the result of the eight-to-one Supreme Court decision smashing down barriers which excluded Negroes from voting in Texas Democratic primaries, and which is construed in most quarters as applicable to similar situations in other States.

WE American women are chiefly responsible for the supreme and self-centered individualism that is the curse of our nation. We think about women's rights but have not yet defined for ourselves with clarity and conviction what are women's responsibilities.

CHICAGO, April 8 -- The Illinois preferential primary campaign drew to a close tonight. More than 4,000,000 Democrats and Republicans are eligible to cast ballots Tuesday, but observers are forecasting a new low mark in primary ballots.

Reversing the trend of the previous quarter, deposits, total resources, holdings of United States Government securities and loans and discounts of the fifteen leading banks in Wall Street expanded during the three months ended on March 31.

AS A background for a comedy of manners, a wedding is, I suppose, pretty nearly perfect. Certainly, the idea has always proved tempting to novelists and playwrights, what with the possibilities it offers of drama behind the scenes.

The New Jersey Shipbuilding Corporation, under the management of Todd Shipyards Corporation, is turning out an almost unbroken line of LCI (L)'s, Landing Craft Infantry (large), at its Barber, N.J., plant, which is applying automotive mass production methods to the shipbuilding industry.

The third Easter celebration since the start of the war will be favored today by mild weather, and while thousands are expected to take advantage of it and merely display their new finery in the Fifth Avenue parade other thousands will crowd the churches, most of which have arranged special musical programs.

The present World War is on the verge of being a trillion-dollar war, measured solely in financial cost to the belligerent Governments, and there is every likelihood that the monetary cost will far exceed this figure.
EXHIBITIONS came so thick and fast last week that there will be space only to call attention to the newly opened attractions without treating several of them at the length they richly deserve.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Please accept my appreciation of your fair, logical and informed policy with respect to air power. Your leading editorial of March 28, "The Role of Air Power," was clear and accurate. Its last paragraph, which opens, "The Mahan of air power is still to come," is a challenge in which many so-called experts will see their own names written in high-intensity neon.

Count Lutz Schwerin von Krosigk, German Finance Minister, told the German people yesterday to stop being concerned about Germany's debt because, after the war, private economy would be "thriving again."

Henry J. Kaiser, the Western contractor who has built plants for the production of magnesium and steel and erected shipyards in furtherance of the national war effort, will, under no conditions, be a candidate for re-election as president of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation, nor will he accept an appointment if the stockholders should renominate him, he declared last week.
NEW DELHI, India, April 8 (AP) -- A Southeast Asia communique:

IT was the day of Big the Snow. Tecumseh fell to musing -- deep, disturbing thoughts about the current season's traffic jam in theatre bookings; about history repeating itself. Seems he was thinking of another day, of the Shuberts and how they had so courageously bucked the great, hard-fisted Klaw-Erlanger combine -- and successfully -- of how the Shuberts have reached the same powerful estate their late rivals once enjoyed.

MANY of us now hurrying to get our seed orders filled are looking for the latest improvements among vegetable varieties. The plant breeders have been as hard at work as ever, and there are a number of brand-new kinds available which may mean success this year with a crop that failed last time.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Senator White of Maine, acting minority leader, asserted today that "good faith" dictated that Senator Homer T. Bone, Democrat, of Washington, take office without delay as judge of the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals, the post to which he was appointed a week ago by President Roosevelt.

Improvised City College banners flew conspicuously and strains of "Lavender," the college anthem, resounded through Number Three Grosvenor Club, London, in a unique reunion recently of the college's graduates serving in the European Theatre of Operations, according to word received here yesterday.

A YOUNG fisherman known as Red Blake catches a huge sea bass and becomes assistant to Dan Wheeler, a private detective who has been hired to protect a gambler named Paul Rachenour. As protectors Wheeler and Blake score a failure when Rachenour is murdered in their presence.

MANY of us now hurrying to get our seed orders filled are looking for the latest improvements among vegetable varieties. The plant breeders have been as hard at work as ever, and there are a number of brand-new kinds available which may mean success this year with a crop that failed last time.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Senator White of Maine, acting minority leader, asserted today that "good faith" dictated that Senator Homer T. Bone, Democrat, of Washington, take office without delay as judge of the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals, the post to which he was appointed a week ago by President Roosevelt.
LONDON, April 8 (Reuter) -- Results of football games played in the British Isles today:

THE performance of Handel's opera "Julius Caesar" in concert form next Wednesday in Town Hall will probably be it's first concert performance in this city. The version used is that of Oscar Hagen, who revived the work in 1922 in Goettingen, in the course of a wave of Handel operatic revivals which swept Germany of the Nineteen Twenties, and spread from there to other lands.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- A proposal that President Roosevelt take the lead in a move to demilitarize Rome through creation of a commission of United Nations and Axis representatives under the chairmanship of Pope Plus XII was advanced today by Senator Styles Bridges, Republican of New Hampshire.
Dr. and Mrs. A. Murray Fisher of Towson, Md., have arrived at the Vanderbilt.

NEW ORLEANS, April 8 -- From Georgia to Texas, in virtually every Southern State, demands are growing for wider application of the States' rights doctrine. This is because of the decision of the United States Supreme Court which holds that Negroes cannot be barred from Texas primary elections.

Turkish chrome exports to Britain have shown a "pronounced decrease," while those to Germany have been "constantly increasing," The Times of London was quoted in a British broadcast reported yesterday by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

AT A U.S. BOMBER BASE in England, March 15 (Delayed) (AP) -- Liberator waist gunners are now able to get better shots at attacking German fighters because of an automatic deflection sight invented by Lieut. John Driscoll, 28 years of age, of 3824 Bronx Boulevard, New York City, gunnery officer of this bomber group.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- A suit to prevent a wage increase of seven cents an hour to 4,000 motortruck drivers in the Midwest was filed in the United States District Court here today by the Midwest Operators Association of St. Paul, Minn., and 112 motor freight transportation firms.

To meet the technical needs of the post-war era, many of America's foremost engineering schools have readjusted their programs to train students for foreign service. A plan for the training of foreign engineers in this country, as well as American students who may wish to work abroad, has been prepared by the general engineering staff of the Foreign Economic Administration.
The Giants and the Yankees will have their first home unveiling of the baseball season Thursday at the Polo Grounds.

A two-day conference on labor and the post-war world, attended by delegates from hundreds of labor unions, will be held next Sunday and Monday at the Hotel Commodore under the auspices of the American Federation of Labor.

Artkur Foote: Suite lot trings in E Major, Op. 63. Serge Koussevitzky conducting the Boston Symphony Orchestra (Victor, Album DIK-692, two twelve-inch records). Dr. Koussevitzky and the string section of his incomparable orchestra give a performance of this music which is fully up to Boston standards.
BETWEEN Appomattox and the World War the country store was, with the possible exception of the church, the most important social institution in the South. It was always more than a mere shop.

MADRID, April 6 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- An article published April 1 in the Hamburger Fremdenblatt quoted Benito Mussolini as saying that as soon as he saw a German plane fly over a house in Maddalena where the Allies held him in detention he knew that he would be rescued by Adolf Hitler.
CHESS, often described as "a game of war," will take the spotlight on April 15 when the men's and women's national championship tournaments open for three weeks at the Park Central Hotel in New York.

BUCKY will undoubtedly find a large number of sympathetic friends among young humans who don't like naps either. For Bucky, with bland disregard of ursine conventions, simply waked up in the dead of winter, wandered out of his mother's cave and went frolicking in the snow.

BATAVIA, N.Y., April 8 (AP) -- "One of the good things I get out of this war -- if one can get any good out of it -- is confidence in our youth," declared Representative James W. Wadsworth of Geneseo today in an address at the Graham Manufacturing Company plant during the award of the Maritime Commission "M" pennant.

Committees representing the East Side House Settlement and the Winifred Wheeler Day Nursery are completing plans for their springtime benefit theatre party at the performance of Lillian Hellman's new play, "The Searching Wind," on the night of April 17 at the Fulton Theatre.

MEMPHIS, April 8 -- Southern Association President Billy Evans thinks baseball is in for an unprecedented boom after the war. He predicts "fifty minor leagues will be in full operation two years after the fighting ends."

LONDON, April 8 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav Partisans, regrouped after repulsing a three-day German drive on the headquarters of Marshal Tito (Josip Broz) at Jajce, lashed back today to cut off and surround the Nazi salient.

WITH increases which topped the 1943 gains for the pro-holiday period, it was safe to assume in the week that Easter trade this year has made a new high record. The two months of March and April will be averaged up, however, f r purposes of comparison and it is yet to be determined just what the next few weeks will show.

Seventeen chain and independent food stores in the city will exhibit this week war material made from waste paper, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Charles E. Copeland, local chairman of salvage of the American Women's Voluntary Services, and M.J. Pesson, chairman of the Food Industries Committee of Greater New York.

With the induction of all men 26 years old and over in New York City temporarily stopped pursuant to an order telegraphed by Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, national draft director, to State Selective Service directors, Col. Arthur V. McDermott, city head of Selective Service, yesterday ordered the city's 280 local draft boards to speed up the induction of men under 26.
In general the living costs for the average family remained unchanged from February to March, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- With the production of implements of war fairly well stabilized except for design changes and detail improvements that must continue until the last day of fighting an increasing amount of sober thought is being given here to the question whether the Government -- which means the public -- is getting a dollar's worth of weapons for each of the billions of dollars being spent.

MY attention has been called to a review in THE NEW YORK TIMES for Oct. 17, 1943, of my "Essentials of College Algebra" (forming part of "First Year College Mathematics" by Hart, Wilson and Tracey; D.C. Heath Co.).

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The War Production Board's clothing branch today announced that it has extended to April 14 the time in which manufacturers of popular-priced snowsuits, legging sets and ski pants for children may file applications for prioritites assistance.

THERE is a play on Broadway that is drawing as much attention as if it were a lavish, tuneful musical comedy. It is called "Jacobowsky and the Colonel," and although the audience laughs through to the end, beneath the comedy there runs deep conflict between two minds.

In agreeing to cooperate with other United Nations in forming a worldwide educational and cultural organization, the State Department has announced a policy which should receive wholehearted support. The war has destroyed the school systems of many of the occupied countries.

WITH increases which topped the 1943 gains for the pro-holiday period, it was safe to assume in the week that Easter trade this year has made a new high record. The two months of March and April will be averaged up, however, f r purposes of comparison and it is yet to be determined just what the next few weeks will show.

Seventeen chain and independent food stores in the city will exhibit this week war material made from waste paper, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Charles E. Copeland, local chairman of salvage of the American Women's Voluntary Services, and M.J. Pesson, chairman of the Food Industries Committee of Greater New York.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 8 -- Inspired, no doubt, by the presence of Gov. Walter E. Edge, the Yankees today buried the Athletics for the second time in two days on Bader Field under a shower of extra-base blows. The count was 8 to 5 at the end of a struggle witnessed by 1,516 fans.

LONDON, April 8 -- United States Under-Secretary of State Edward R. Stettinius Jr. spent his first day in Londay today consulting with United States Ambassador John G. Winant. He is expected to begin his discussions with Prime Minister Churchill and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden in an informal atmosphere over the most festive week-end of the spring.

CHICAGO, April 8 -- Business in the grain markets on the Board of Trade was at a minimum today, operators regarding the situation as unusually uncertain. Wheat futures held within narrow limits and the active months finished 3/8 cent a bushel up to 1/8 cent down, with May holding at the ceiling.
ALBANY, April 8 -- Governor Dewey signed today the Janes bill continuing the mortgage moratorium for another year, with the rate of amortization increased from 1 to 2 per cent.

LONDON, April 8 -- While the guns of the Kremlin were still thundering a salute tonight to the Red Army's new victories, the Czechoslovak Government in London broadcast a call to the Czech underground forces to go into full action against their Nazi oppressors.

BLACK MOUNTAIN COLLEGE, the small, progressive institution near Asheville, N.C., is making ambitious plans for a summer of informal music lectures, concerts and discussions. The scheme, which was the brain child of Frederic Cohen, the conductor, composer and choreographer, who is a member of the faculty, has been called a "Music Institute" and will be dedicated to Mrs. Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge.

THIS is the afternoon that the winners of the Metropolitan Opera Auditions of the Air are announced. There will be, of course, appropriate ceremonies at the Metropolitan attendant to the award to the successful candidates of contracts and checks for $1,000.
There may be racing today at Jamaica and then again there may not. It's entirely up to the grooms and the horse-owners, for the Metropolitan Jockey Club has washed its hands of the whole business.

Aside from a second baseman and a third baseman, what the Dodgers are most in need of is work. At Ebbets Field yesterday they got lots of the latter, but little of the former as they turned back the Red Sox, 3 -- 2, in a twelve-inning struggle before 2,104 fans.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- The Washington Senators squeezed out a 2-1 victory over the Philadelphia Phils today behind the tight hurling of a pair of their best knuckleballers, Mickey Haefner and Dutch Leonard.

In some phases of the economic stabilization program the Administration has undoubtedly done a good job. But the joint report submitted to the President by Messrs. Vinson, Bowles, Jones and Davis exaggerates in some respects the extent to which stabilization has been achieved. It is true that in the last year the cost-of-living index has been held down.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, April 9 -- Witnesses of the revolt in El Salvador last Sunday, who have just arrived here, said today that an uprising by the strongest military garrison in San Salvador was joined by two smaller garrisons, the flying force and troops in the Santa Ana district.

The war-time construction program of the American Gas and Electric Company was close to completion at the end of 1943, according to the annual report signed by George N. Tidd, president, who declared the expansion "has always been several steps ahead of the increase in demand and has anticipated the expanding power requirements" of the war program.

CHICAGO, April 9 -- Large imports of oats from Canada are expected to start soon in an effort to relieve the shortage of feed grains, a Government program calling for the shipment of 20,000,000 bushels prior to May 15. Some of the Canadian oats will go into Iowa, which is the largest producer of that grain in the country, tending to emphasize the grave shortage that has developed recently.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, April 9 -- Thousands of American soldiers knelt in foxholes within 400 yards of German infantry in a spectacular Easter service today that was broadcast through loudspeakers to the Nazi troops as well as the doughboys by three American chaplains.

Had the writer of "Challenge to the Railways," in the March 19 issue of THE TIMES, been more fully informed as to what has been done and what is planned by the railways in meeting the situations described I feel sure that the editorial would have been very different.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 9 -- In sprinkles but eventual sunshine, the sailing dinghies at the Larchmont Yacht Club struggled through four races today in failing winds.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 9 -- Usually by this time of the year the men who claim to know can tell you just how the horses will finish in the Kentucky Derby.

The cotton market was rather quiet last week, with prices holding within a narrow trading range. At the close of trading on Thursday, the Exchange having been closed on Friday and Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net changes for the week ranging from an advance of 5 points to a decline of 14 points.

The report for 1943 of the Sinclair Oil Corporation, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $23,083,709 after charges, taxes and reserves, equal to $1.85 each on the 12,484,265 common shares outstanding. This compared with $18,060,598, or $1.43 a share, in 1942. Sales were $326,899,073, against $276,666,418.

With Governor Dewey's signature of the Coudert bill which strips the Board of Superintendents of all but advisory powers and places executive control in the hands of the Superintendent of Schools, the New York City school system is no longer handicapped by divided responsibility.

Stimulation of maximum preparations by individual companies for re-employment of returning service men is sought by the National Association of Manufacturers, with the organization's committee on veterans' employment problems giving nation-wide distribution to a comprehensive checklist covering fall in-plant phases of the subject.

A syndicate headed by Samuel Derfner Sons has purchased the twelve-story loft building at 140-48 Lafayette Street, northwest corner of Howard Street, from Joseph G. White and Bertram F. Bonner, who bought the property in 1936 from the East River Savings Bank, which at the time took back a first mortgage.
LONDON, April 9 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Force in a Europe communique:

Mady Christians, who has been missing from the Broadway stage since 1941, when she appeared as Paul Lukas wife in "Watch on the Rhine," will return to this sector early in the fall as the star of "Mama's Bank Account," it was announced yesterday by Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, sponsors of the forthcoming attraction.

CHICAGO, April 9 -- The tight situation that developed recently in May and cash wheat showed in the last few days no evidence of loosening up, with May holding at the ceiling price and July edging up to sell within 1 cent of the May and going to a new seasonal high.
The State Liquor Authority announced yesterday it had revoked six licenses and one permit, canceled four licenses and suspended fourteen at its meeting Thursday, as follows:
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Secretary Cordell Hull defined United States foreign policy tonight as calling for the complete uprooting of nazism and fascism in all countries.

NEW DELHI, India, April 9 -- Japanese forces prodding into the outskirts of Kohima, thirty miles inside India and sixty miles north of the big Allied base of Imphal, have been repulsed, the Southeast Asia Command announced today, but the Plain of Imphal is virtually under siege as the invaders seek to establish themselves before next month's monsoon puts a stop to most military operations.
Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices was 112.74, a drop of 0.2 per cent from the previous week's level of 112.97.
SOMEWHERE IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC (Delayed) -- In a palm-fringed cocoanut grove here I witnessed the goofiest boxing match I have ever seen.

Three benefits and an annual are included among the more than two score exhibitions scheduled to open this week in the New York art galleries. The Lee Ault collection of modern paintings will be shown at the Valentine Gallery for the benefit of the American Field Service.

ALBANY, N. Y., April 9 -- Governor Dewey signed today the Stephens Bill providing for State licensing and regulation of individuals and agencies other than banks, engaged in the business of check-cashing for profit.

A new attack on the "alliance" between Representative Vito Marcantonio, left wing leader of the American Labor party, and the present leadership of Tammany Hall, was made last night by John L. Buckley and Dennis J. Mahon, Tammany leaders of two important districts on the West Side of Manhattan.

TOPEKA, April 9 (AP) -- A "Republican Byrd-for-President organization" was set up today by a group of Kansans who said they wanted to unify the country behind Senator Harry F. Byrd, Virginia Democrat, and a coalition Cabinet.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- Post-war transfer of surplus United States fighting ships to South American republics, particularly Brazil, will be recommended by a House Naval subcommittee recently returned from a 13,000-mile air tour of United States naval bases off South America.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 9 -- Champion El Wendie of Rockland, boxer owned by the Rye Top Kennels of Harrison, N.Y., and handled by Nate Levine, gained the chief award at the twenty-fourth annual fixture of the Kennel Club of Atlantic City tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- Australia's decision to cut the size of its army in the midst of war was labeled "shocking," "startling" and "almost unbelievable" today by Senators on the Military Committee.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- More than thirty cases will stand available for rulings when the justices of the Supreme Court ascend the bench tomorrow on one of the few remaining decision days of the present term.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill jointly reported tonight that sinkings by U-boats in March were a little higher than in February and stressed that the Allied anti-submarine campaign still faced a foe of considerable strength.

Despite constant and unselfish efforts by welfare and religious agencies and whole-hearted cooperation by hotels, the problem of finding sleeping accommodations for service men and women and their families in this city is far from solved, a survey has disclosed.

The New Century Theatre, nee the Jolson and up near the park, rejoined the human race on Saturday evening, when Dave Wolper offered a pleasant enough if not distinguished musical comedy called "Follow the Girls." In the Broadway tradition of color and noise, of dance steps, familiar comedy and songs, it is big and always active.

It is difficult to decide whether crows learned how to conduct a convention from watching the procedures of major political parties or whether, in olden days, political leaders watched crows in session and decided to pattern their meetings on this model.

ALGIERS, April 10 (Monday) -- The speech made last night by Cordell Hull, Secretary of State of the United States, on international relations is regarded in circles of the French Committee of National Liberation as changing the whole outlook on French-Allied relations and as involving virtually that practical degree of recognition which the committee has long asked for in vain.

NAPLES, April 9 -- German tanks, both of the orthodox type manned by crews and the crewless robot kind operated by remote control, lumbered toward the Allied lines on the Anzio beachhead but Allied gunners knocked out three of the explosive-laden robots, damaged a fourth and shattered a Mark VI Tiger and another "live" tank.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, April 10 (UP) -- A communique:

Three large organizations will start today a special week-long drive to impress upon the residents of the New York area the seriousness of the paper shortage. More than 2,000,000 housewives and others who buy food for home consumption will be asked to fulfill a four-point pledge to conserve paper.

LONDON, Monday, April 10 (AP) -- The address of Secretary of State Hull received top front-page display in British morning papers today. The London News-Chronicle noted "with regret" that he reiterated American non-recognition of the French Committee of National Liberation.

PEARL HARBOR, April 9 -- Truk and seven other objectives in the Caroline and Marshall Islands were bombed Friday by Central Pacific air forces operating from our own bases in the Marshalls, according to a Pacific Fleet press release this morning that opened with the unprecedentedly frank sentence: "Operations to soften up Truk continued."

Capital expenditures for equipment and improvements to property last year by the Class I railroads amounted to $454,282,000, a decrease of $80,615,000 below those made in 1943, according to the Association of American Railroads. Of these expenditures, $255,981,000 was for equipment and $198,301,000 was for roadway and structures.

(Delayed) -- The rival forces continue to concentrate for the decisive battle in Manipur in northeastern India. The Japanese now have semicircular positions in the hills fifteen to thirty miles away from Imphal on the north and east.
Three new films and the Army Air Forces documentary pictorial account of a bombing mission over Germany, "The Memphis Belle," win arrive on Broadway this week. The openings follow:

How war interrupts civilized life, sparing no one, is seen in the annual report of the Guggenheim Foundation, issued today. The foundation grants fellowships to research scholars and creative workers of promise, enabling them to accomplish fine tasks in the arts and sciences. At present more than half of its 125 fellowships of record are postponed for reasons connected with the var.

Spring vacation marks the beginning of the homestretch in the school year, and parents who have not already done so will need to begin thinking of the social call they should pay at the classroom of Junior or Mildred.
LONDON, Monday, April 10 (AP) -- The Russian Sunday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:
LONDON, April 9 (U.P.) -- Thousands of American fighting men and women gathered today beneath the trees of historic Hyde Park to pray at Easter sunrise service.

Ellin Berlin's first novel, "Land I Have Chosen," has been bought by Warner Brothers for film production, for what is said to be the largest price yet paid for movie rights to a first novel -- $150,000. The book will be published by Doubleday, Doran May 19.

Admiral Mitscher's attack on Palau and its neighboring islands was in some ways the most successful demonstration of air and naval power we have made in the Pacific. Here was a fleet sailing against a strong enemy land base fully forewarned of the impending attack. Yet not one of our ships was even damaged.

Strength in the Canadian free dollar featured business in the foreign exchange market last week. In the early trading the Dominion currency was valued around 89.38 cents, but beginning on Thursday and continuing for the remainder of the week buying orders in good volume drove the price up to 89.93 cents, highest since Dec. 28, last. Saturday's closing price of 89.87 cents, reflected a gain of 7/16 cent over the preceding week.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Before 10,000 worshipers who attended Easter sunrise services at Arlington National Cemetery today Gen. George C. Marshall, Army Chief of Staff, prayed for strength to secure "the freedom of all peoples."

LONDON, April 9 -- There is an increasing number of signs that the political coalition on which the British Government is based is beginning to break up, even though all principal parties are satisfied with Prime Minister Churchill's war leadership. The Labor party, after the Conservative party the largest and most important group in the coalition, has lately moved toward independence of action.

Net income of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company for 1943 amounted to $33,760,801, equal to $3.89 each on 8,674,339 shares of capital stock, compared with $36,464,030, or $4.30 a share in 1942, according to the annual report issued for publication today by Cornelius F. Kelley, chairman, and James R. Hobbins, president.

LONDON, April 9 -- Despite the imminence of the Easter Holiday, the stock markets here became more active last week. War news and purely investment factors were equally responsible for this modest revival, which carried many leading industrials to this year's best levels.

LONDON, Monday, April 10 -- In one of the deepest penetrations they ever made into enemy territory from Britain, large formations of American Flying Fortresses and Liberators with swarms of escorting fighters made a wide sweep over the Baltic yesterday and bombed Posen, in Poland, and four other aircraft factories and transportation centers in the German-Polish border areas.

God has given to America a sacred mission -- as yet unfilled -- to bring unity to men of all races and creeds, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in an Easter sermon broadcast from his desk at City Hall.

MOSCOW, Monday, April 10 -- Soviet troops drove yesterday to within three miles of the Black Sea port of Odessa, while other Red Army forces were reported to have captured more than 200 inhabited points inside Rumania, mainly between the Prut and Siretul Rivers.
