Playing a courageous, uphill game and coming up level from a 4-1 deficit, the Brookhattans held the New York Americans to a 4-4 tie in the opening round of the Lewis Cup competition of the American Soccer League at Starlight Park before a crowd of 1,500 fans yesterday.

Two detectives observing that one professional Easter worshiper seemed to have his hand in another worshiper's pocket at 8 o'clock mass in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue and Eighty-fourth Street, resulted in Sol Bauman, 65-year-old professional thief, being arrested yesterday for at least the thirty-second time since 1907.

On the eve of great events, when mighty armies are poised for their main assault on Hitler's fortress and the Allied world awaits the hour of decision, Secretary Hull has undertaken again to make clear to the American people and to the world at large the purposes for which we fight.

The Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, preaching yesterday morning in the Riverside Church, challenged those who contend that the desire for life after death is ego-centric, "an inflated self-centeredness that thinks the meaning of the universe dependent on our going on."

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- Leon Henderson, former Price Administrator, asserted today that Representative Harry R. Sheppard, Democrat, of California, "lied about me" in ascribing to Henderson part of the responsibility for conditions that led to what Mr. Sheppard called "a small-loan racket."
Lieut. Col. Edward F. MacNichol, AUS, and Mrs. MacNichol have come to Hampshire House from South Hamilton, Mass.

A UNITED STATES FIGHTER STATION IN BRITAIN, April 9 (UP) -- America's ace of aces, Capt. Don Gentile, said today he was not satisfied with breaking Capt. Edward V. Rickenbacker's World War record by destroying thirty enemy planes, because his bag includes seven wrecked on the ground.

Closely following the outlines of the Constitution of the Swiss Confederation, a group of political scientists at New York University's Research Seminar for European Federation made public yesterday a broad Constitution for a proposed United States of Europe to insure a lasting peace.

In subdued mood New Yorkers celebrated their third war Easter yesterday with a parade that was solemn in spirit in contrast to the flashing colors of the holiday finery. The fervor of religion intensified by war, the gray clouds that started to sprinkle as the turnout of fashion was nearing its height and the prominence of olive drab and navy blue combined to create a quiet parade.

Four singers living in New York City -- three men and a woman -- won Metropolitan Opera Company contracts, cash prizes of $1,000 and silver plaques yesterday afternoon at the end of the ninth annual Metropolitan Auditions of the Air, broadcast from the stage of the opera house over Station WJZ and the Blue network.

Last week's volume in the wholesale markets was highlighted by last-minute demands for Easter merchandise, with reports indicating that shortages were in evidence on most of the wanted fill-ins, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

PITTSBURGH, April 9 -- A continuation of the heavy influx of new orders, a further tightening in the flat-rolled steel picture, a pick-up in shell steel production, and an increase in raw steel output, were news highlights in the steel industry last week.

CHICAGO, April 9 (AP) - The Montreal Canadiens swept to their third straight victory over the Chicago Black Hawks in the Stanley Cup hockey finals tonight, winning by 3 to 2 on a pair of goals in the final period.

For his research on the growth of animal cells, with particular reference to cancer, Dr. Alexander Lipschutz, director of the department of experimental medicine of the Chilean National Health Service at Santiago, Chile, has won the second $2,000 prize given by Dr. Charles L. Mayer and administered by the National Science Fund of the National Academy of Sciences, the academy announced yesterday.

Distribution of merchandise by areas in war time is as good as in peacetime, Dr. Theodore H. Brown of the Harvard Graduate School of Business and consultant to the Office of Civilian Requirements said last week before the American Marketing Association.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. April 9 -- Celebrating their first taste of major league strife today the Giants staged their own Easter parade at Bader Field in a procession of runs with which they downed the Yankees 8 to 3, before a gathering of 2,502 fans.

CHICAGO, April 9 -- The shortage in supplies of corn became more pronounced last week. The Government is paying close attention to conditions surrounding this market, and country elevator interests now are forced to set aside 60 per cent of their receipts for sale to essential industries.
ON THE ANZIO BEACHHEAD, April 9 (AP) -- Easter came to Anzio today despite the war, wind and rain, and thousands of soldiers celebrated the Resurrection rites.

In view of the fact that Victory gardening has yet to get started in earnest it may seem decidedly premature to talk about the canning we are to do next summer. Nevertheless, authorities in this State already have begun discussing the subject, and have set the wheels in motion for a successful program of home food preservation this season.

A record contribution of free advertising space, donated by advertising organizations, magazines and newspapers, was reported yesterday by the headquarters of the Red Cross 1944 War Fund of Greater New York.

Naceep S. Maloff has purchased for investment the six-story apartment house at 54 Audubon Avenue, near the Medical Center at 168th Street, through Darling McDonald, brokers, who recently sold the apartments at 1 Audubon Avenue to the same buyer.

There was little change last week in prices on financial markets. Trading also was lighter. As against the fourteen million-share days of March, last week's transactions did not reach 773,000 shares on any five-hour day, and on Tuesday sank to 572,400 -- a total only twice matched since the beginning of 1944. On Saturday, after the Good Friday holiday, stocks made moderate recovery.

In a setting marked by the pageantry of Easter, 7,500 worshipers filled the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday morning and heard Bishop William T. Manning preach on "The Message of Easter to All the World."

One of the biggest bugaboos that try the housewife's patience these days is hours of precious time consumed by shopping -- whether it is for food, household items or clothes for herself and her family. Between the spotty assortments of merchandise and lack of help it is inevitable that neither grocery nor department stores can give the same efficient service they did before the war.

A one-story factory building on a plot 100 by 100 feet and an adjoining plot of 50 by 100 feet at 317 to 335 Moffat Street, in Brooklyn, have been purchased by the Danesi Realty Corporation through Kalmon Dolgin, Inc., broker. The building will be used for a dye house and the balance of the property improved when materials are available. The buyer paid cash over a first mortgage of $12,300.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, April 10 (U.P.) -- United States Fifth Air Force bombers, sweeping the length of the Japanese-held northern New Guinea coast line Saturday, heaped 281 tons of explosives on the shattered enemy bases of Hollandia, Wewak and Hansa Bay, leaving shipping, buildings and other installations wreathed in flames, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (U.P.) -- The War Labor Board announced today a general wage policy which it said would be used in determining approvable rates for local transit industries.

LONDON, April 9 (AP) -- In reaching Marienburg today, the Flying Fortresses made a twelve-hour round-trip flight of 1,600 miles to equal the deepest Allied aerial penetration of Europe. The targets at Marienburg had been rebuilt, United States headquarters here said, since they were hit before by Eighth Air Force bombers on Oct. 9, 1943.

LUCKNOW, India, April 9 (Reuter) -- Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru, Indian liberal leader, presiding at a non-party conference here yesterday, urged the Indians to give Viscount Wavell every chance to solve the Indian constitutional deadlock.

Irving Chernev and Sven Almgren of Brooklyn and Louis Persinger of Manhattan led in their respective sections, still undefeated, after the games of the third round in the United States championship preliminaries had been concluded, yesterday, at the U.S. Federation headquarters in Brooklyn and the Manhattan and Marshall Chess Clubs.

Consolidated net retail sales of $165,631,161 are reported for the two half-year periods ended on Jan. 29, 1944, by R.H. Macy Co., Inc., and its affiliated stores, L. Bamberger Co., Newark; Davison-Paxon Company, Atlanta and the Lasalle Koch Company, Toledo. This compares with $161,326,056 sales for the preceding year, according to Jack I. Straus, president.

A united effort on the part of all communities in the metropolitan area to promote the over-all advantages of the region will be necessary if the port of New York is to gain the full measure of its potential commerce after the war, the Port of New York Authority declared yesterday in its annual report.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 9 (AP) -- Arthur H. Madison, a New York Negro lawyer, is free today under $2,500 bond on charges growing out of his court intervention in attempts to make some Negroes eligible to vote in Alabama. He was arrested yesterday. No hearing has been set.
LONDON, Monday, April 10 (AP) -- Russian troops half-encircled the Rumanian rail center of Jassy yesterday in an avalanche of power that swept over 200 more villages, Moscow announced last night.
A congregation estimated at 4,000 packed St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday as Archbishop Francis J. Spellman pontificated at the solemn mass of Easter Sunday.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The address of Secretary Hull on this nation's foreign policy, broadcast by radio tonight, was as follows:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 9 (AP) -- The Swedish Foreign Office said today that the export of ball bearings to Germany had been considerably reduced this year and flatly denied published reports that Sweden had sent technical experts to help repair the Schweinfurt works in the Reich smashed by American daylight air attacks.

Two million New York State taxpayers are scheduled to file State income tax returns on or before Saturday. Two-thirds may use the simplified "Optional Form 200," introduced for the first time this year. Although the reduction is not specified on the forms, taxpayers should reduce by 25 per cent their State income tax and net capital gains tax as computed.
The American strike against Palau and other Japanese island bases in the southwestern Pacific has cost the enemy heavily in merchant shipping -- his greatest weakness.

This is a condensation of the fifth in a series of lectures given for instructors of home nursing by the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross in preparation for the reception of returning war veterans. Dr. Alexander Reid Martin, practicing psychiatrist and psychoanalyst, consulting psychiatrist of the Children's Aid Society and chairman of the Lower West Side District Health Committee, discussed "Available Resources."

Creation of a $200,000 fellowship fund, earmarked for men and women now serving the nation in the war and distinct from other fellowship funds also designed to advance research and creative work, was announced yesterday by the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation as it made public the names of sixty-nine fellowship winners for the current year. Stipends under the fellowships total $155,000.
The second day of Passover was marked yesterday by sermons on a variety of topics in synagogues and temples of the city.
NEW DELHI, India, April 9 (UP) -- A communique:

NAPLES, April 9 -- There is an increased feeling that liberated Italy is on the verge of momentous political changes. Broadening of the Badoglio Government is now a matter officially "hoped for" by the Allied Advisory Council and is virtually certain to be forthcoming within a week or ten days.

ALBANY, April 9 -- Governor Thomas E. Dewey vetoed today a bill involving a compromise of real estate tax penalties. The measure would have permitted the waiver of penalties on delinquent taxes which, he said, "penalizes the prompt taxpayer to the benefit of the dilatory one."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 9 -- Casey Robinson, who produced "Days of Glory," the Soviet guerrilla picture, for RKO, has signed a contract to write and produce exclusively for International Pictures, the Leo Spitz-William Goetz organization.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- The British Embassy described Secretary Hull's foreign affairs address tonight as "a fine statement, full of meat," which "will be warmly welcomed everywhere except in the enemy countries."

ALGIERS, April 9 -- Friends of Gen. Henri-Honore Giraud said tonight he had finally and categorically refused to accept his dismissal as Commander in Chief of the French Army at the hands of Gen. Charles de Gaulle, chairman of the French Committee of National Liberation, who earlier today cut short negotiations on the issue and burned his bridges by publishing his decree naming General Giraud Inspector General of the armed forces.

DEER LODGE, Mont., April 9 (U.P.) -- Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio, candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, on his way to Spokane, said here today that the withdrawal of Wendell L. Willkie from the Presidential race had not changed his plans or those of the Republican party.

Easter dawn services were attended by thousands of worshipers at various points throughout the metropolitan area yesterday morning. The largest was that attended by 8,000 persons in the Radio City Music Hall. It was the twenty-fifth annual service under the auspices of the Greater New York Federation of Churches and the fifth year that the observance was held in the Music Hall.
LONDON, April 9 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin:

" LIFE is full of uncertainties," said Jimmy Conzelman, the homespun philosopher, when momentarily mouse-trapped recently on one of his many flying visits to the big town. The man who once was a mere football coach but whose handsome white locks now wear the impressive tiara of assistant to the president of the St. Louis Browns, has been fraternizing of late with more Navy gold braid than he ever believed existed.

The United States' policy of freeing the Philippine Islands should serve as an example to all powerful nations of the future, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in an address to 1,500 persons at the American Museum of Natural History observing the second anniversary of the fall of Bataan.

Both major parties in this State will complete this week their lists of delegates to the national conventions, and also will hold organization meetings of the State committee members elected at the uncontested primary on March 28.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Retailers may advance the cost of electric light bulbs to consumers only to the extent the new Federal excise tax on manufacturers' prices has increased the cost, the Office of Price Administration ruled today.

CHICAGO, April 9 -- One trade in May lard was made last week on the Chicago Board of Trade at $13.60 a hundred pounds. It was the first transaction in lard futures since last December, when $13.75 was paid, and was to liquidate the only outstanding contract.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The American tanker Murfreesboro is in an Atlantic port for repairs after surviving a convoy collision which engulfed it in flames and sank the other vessel, the War Shipping Administration disclosed tonight.

PALO ALTO, Calif., April 9 -- As the United States faces increased world responsibility it is more essential than ever that Americans obtain a clearer understanding of their own heritage and aims through the study of American history, according to reports and speeches made during the two-day conference of college and university history professors drawn this week-end from all parts of California by the Stanford Institute of American History.

A FIGHTER BASE in England, April 9 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Col. David Schilling of Traverse City, Mich., added three more planes to his string today, and on the way home escaped from a German pursuer though his plane was damaged. His victories today brought his total to sixteen.

MOSCOW, April 9 -- Pravda published today a sharp, satirical personal attack upon Hanson W. Baldwin, military commentator of THE NEW YORK TIMES, labeling him "admiral of the ink pool." Mr. Baldwin, according to Pravda, relies exclusively upon German information for news of the Soviet-German front, and thereby has put himself and his newspaper in a ridiculous position.

A NINTH AIR FORCE BOMBER STATION, Britain, April 7 -- In nine months of operation in the European theatre, which airmen call the "big league," United States Marauder B-26 groups have compiled a record of losing less than one half of 1 per cent of all planes employed.

LONDON, April 9 -- The Czech Government, which may well be the first of the exiled governments in Europe to resume control of its own territory, already has prepared detailed plans for the progressive restoration of normal civil administration in territory expected to be liberated by the Red Army.

LONDON, April 10 (AP) -- The racing season opened today at the Windsor track -- twenty-six miles up the Thames from London -- and a record-breaking crowd of 50,000 saw Miss Dorothy Paget's Derby favorite Orestes lose by a neck to The Solicitor.

CHICAGO, April 10 -- Traders spent a good part of today's trading session evening up commitments prior to the issuance of an estimate by the Department of Agriculture on the winter wheat crop and farm reserves as of April 1.

LONDON, April 10 (U.P.) -- Powerful German armored forces, beaten back in their latest attempt to capture Jajce, headquarters of Marshal Tito, have launched a second offensive, correlated with a diversionary attack from Banja Luka to the north, a Yugoslav partisan headquarters communique reported today.

Three premieres were on the local ballet schedule last night, two of them presented by the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the City Center and the other on the bill of the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House. By a close timing schedule and plenty of enthusiasm it was possible for the eager commuter to see all of them, though, truth to tell, the total result was not too rewarding.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Merchandise exports, including lend-lease shipments, totaled $1,086,000,000 during February, the Department of Commerce Bureau of Census reported today. The figure does not include shipments to our armed forces abroad.

I have read with interest your editorial in the issue of April 3, 1944, concerning the shortage of doctors. This editorial ends with the following sentence: "Unless a sufficient supply of civilians is permitted to enter the medical schools the country faces a shortage of doctors."

SAVANNAH, Ga., April 10 (AP) -- Col. Lucius B. Manning, base commanding officer at Hunter Field, and six other airmen from the air base were killed yesterday when their medium bomber crashed nine miles northwest of Hartselle, Ala., the Hunter Field public relations office announced today.

NEWARK, N.J., April 10 -- Because she is writing "the great American novel" and expects her signature to be of great value some day, an elderly woman has refrained from registering her rooming house with the rent division of the Office of Price Administration here, it was disclosed today by H. Russell Phillips, area OPA rent director.

Shantung tops the list of fabrics in summer smartness and versatility, its use ranging from active sportswear to evening gowns. While pure silk shantung is still in existence it is rare and the distinctive weave has been developed in rayon without losing its attractiveness. The jewel-like colors originated in China for the silk have been faithfully copied in the rayon versions.

Three new members have been elected to the board of managers of the Presbyterian Hospital in the City of New York, it was announced yesterday at the annual meeting of the corporation and the board at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., April 10 -- Very probably it isn't even a good jest. A sense of humor gets slightly warped in time of war but at any rate there is one room in the Hotel McCurdy, the current quarters of the Detroit Tigers, which is used as a dormitory for all late arrivals. Rudy York was dumped unceremoniously in there one evening, dropped off to slumber and had a dream.

WITH THE PACIFIC FLEET IN THE CAROLINE SLANDS April 1 (Delayed) -- Japan is hesitant, uncertain and desperately on the defensive against American air strength, which has been the principal reason for the reversal of the roles throughout the Pacific's long blue-water miles. This has just been brought to light by the thrust at Palau.

OTTAWA, April 10 (Canadian Press) -- The Dominion's Bureau of Statistics reported today that by a tentative computation Canada's national income averaged 3.2 per cent greater in January and February than in the same period of 1943.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The Supreme Court knocked down as unconstitutional today a Florida "peonage" law enacted in 1919 under which a Negro laborer was sent to jail for sixty days for lack of $100 to pay a fine imposed by the State court as penalty for not working off $5 advanced to him by an employer.

ALBANY, April 10 -- Governor Dewey signed today the Duryea bill carving a new Tenth Judicial District, consisting of Republican-controlled Nassau and Suffolk Counties, out of the Second Judicial District, leaving in the latter the counties of Kings, Queens and Richmond.

Add to the list of new films arriving this week, "Address Unknown," a drama produced by Columbia from the story by Kressman Taylor and starring Paul Lukas, which will open at the Globe on Saturday. K.T. Stevens, Carl Esmond, Mady Christians, Peter Van Eyck and Morris Carnovsky are among the featured players in the picture, which was produced and directed by William Cameron Menzies.

The Rev. Dr. Theodore Cuyler Speers, pastor of the Central Presbyterian Church, 593 Park Avenue, was elected to a two-year term as Moderator of the Presbytery of New York at the annual spring meeting of the Presbytery in the parish house of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The Senate Military Affairs Committee was advised by its military consultant, Col. Lewis Sanders, today, that interpretations that had been given the proposed reduction of Australia's army were inaccurate and likely to cause misunderstandings in this country.

The Treasury notified the principal commercial banks throughout the country yesterday that it will make withdrawals from Government war loan accounts in these banks on Thursday, Friday and Saturday. For the Second Federal Reserve District these withdrawals will total $80,058,000 on each day, and for the nation as a whole, to $188,279,000 on each day.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Two million gallons of relief from the beverage alcohol drought was offered today in a War Production Board decision to permit unlimited importation of rum three years or more old.

James Grafton Rogers, vice president of the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., 90 Broad Street, will leave by plane today for Lima, Peru, to represent the council in discussions with Peruvian officials of plans for the resumption of service on Peru's external dollar bonds which have been in default since 1931.

Several Senators who should know better expressed surprise and indignation at the news that Australia plans to return 90,000 soldiers to civilian life within the next twelve months. For instance, Senator Edwin C. Johnson of Colorado thought the announcement startling "in view of the all-out effort we are making to send our Army all over the world to save Australia and the other countries from the common enemy."

INDIANAPOLIS, April 10 (AP) -- Max Butcher whitewashed the Indians, 6 to 0, today in an abbreviated exhibition game which was ended by rain just as the Pirates completed their half of the seventh inning.

The Standard Oil Company (N.J.) announced yesterday that it will ask stockholders at their meeting on June 6 to elect Jay E. Crane and Chester F. Smith as additional directors. Mr. Crane has been treasurer of the company for several years and Mr. Smith is president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, incorporated in Delaware, the company's principal domestic refining and marketing subsidiary.

A student confession of sole guilt for recent illegal procedures in electing student government officers at Columbia College has led to the appointment of a faculty-student investigating committee, Associate Dean Nicholas McD. McKnight disclosed yesterday.

Although recognizing the value of the treatment of infantile paralysis devised by Sister Elizabeth Kenny, Australian nurse, the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis expressed regret yesterday at the "unprecedented publicity" given to the new method.
A communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Two of America's seven leading aces in the European theatre were shot down in air combats March 27 when powerful formations of American planes smashed nine French air bases, the War Department revealed yesterday in messages to the fliers' families, The United Press said.

In 1934 an English translation of an Italian novel since rendered into at least nineteen more languages was published in this city. Its author wrote under the name Ignazio Silone. His actual name, as yet thoroughly obscure, is Secondo Tranquilli. He was born in the Abruzzi in 1900, an aristocrat, son of a landed proprietor.

Nelson A. Rockefeller, Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, will be the principal speaker at a special conference to be sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES, in cooperation with the National Council of Women, at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, tomorrow evening.

NAPLES, April 10 -- The tank-busting proclivities of the Fifth Army continued on two fronts and six more were knocked out, making eleven in two days, according to official reports here covering the twenty-four hours ended yesterday noon.

The attack made by John L. Buckley and Dennis J. Mahon, West Side Tammany district leaders, on the present leadership of Tammany Hall because of its "alliance" with Representative Vito Marcantonio, drew a prompt reply yesterday, not from the Tammany leadership, but from Mr. Marcantonio.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- Marked improvement in winter wheat prospects owing to good rains was noted today by the Department of Agriculture in estimating a 1944 crop of 601,759,000 bushels on the basis of April 1 conditions, or 72,153,000 bushels more than last year's production.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The War Production Board, in a further effort to assure production of essential cotton textiles, has established a production "floor" for output of cotton yarn which fixes a manufacturer's minimum quota at the level of his production on a quarterly basis last year, it was learned today.
ANKARA, Turkey, April 10 -- The eighty-ton steamship Maritza arrived in Istanbul yesterday from Constanta, carrying 245 refugees from Rumania, and only five of them possessed Turkish transit visas.

LONDON, Tuesday, April 11 (AP) -- In Rumania another Russian army was declared to have forced the Siretul and Suceava Rivers in a sixty-five-mile penetration of that wavering nation's territory, capturing 150 towns and villages and smashing to within fifteen miles of the Campulung oil fields in the north and to within 160 miles of the Ploesti wells in the south.

Several vegetables that we associate with warm weather have begun to arrive in the market, and for the most part prices are reasonable. Four of the outstanding "springlike" varieties -- asparagus, eggplant, dandelion greens and summer squash -- served as the basis for the following recipes, which have been tested in THE NEW YORK TIMES' kitchen.

Declaring that enforcement of price control in New York City is "much more difficult than in any other city in the country," Daniel P. Woolley, regional administrator of the Office of Price Administration, yesterday announced the opening of an "experiment in price control" in Jackson Heights, Queens.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The fight for equal pay for women in Great Britain will continue and will win, Prime Minister Churchill to the contrary notwithstanding, according to Mrs. Ethel M. Wood, secretary of England's Committee on Womanpower, which has in its membership all women members of Parliament.

Imphal, in the east of India, is now under virtual siege by the Japanese invaders. Enemy forces have cut the roads to the north and south and are thrusting toward the rear of the town, which is isolated except from the air. Its garrison is strong and was recently reinforced by an Indian division which fought its way through enemy road blocks.
NEW DELHI, India, April 10 (UP) -- A communique:

LONDON, Tuesday, April 11 -- The United States Eighth and Ninth Air Forces and the Royal Air Force struck a series of devastating blows with probably nearly 3,000 planes Sunday night and yesterday at airfields, aircraft repair plants, rail yards and junctions and military installations in western Europe on which the Germans depend for air and ground defense against Allied invasion.

Reviewing the racial tensions engendered by wartime industrial and social conditions, which resulted in violent flareups in widely separated cities during 1943, the National Urban League in its annual report yesterday called for more intelligent leadership on the part of both whites and Negroes in the fields of community organization and planning, industrial and labor relations, and public education for inter-racial cooperation.

A NINTH AIR FORCE BOMBER STATION, Britain, April 10 -- A group of air-force officers and enlisted men who are going to make a film record of the Allies' invasion of Europe so that Americans may drop in to their neighborhood movie and see what a difficult and horrible job the invasion was are now working on this Marauder station.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, has asked a "small and representative" group of leaders in the several aspects of the country's economy to serve on an Advisory Committee for Civilian Policy, which will deal with problems of reconverting industry to civilian production.

Hundreds of his associates and friends in the fields of business, education and the charities paid tribute to Percy Selden Straus at a funeral service yesterday in Temple Emanu-El. Simple rites were held for the chairman of the board of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., who died late Thursday night in his home at the age of 67.
LONDON, April 10 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin:

Behind the scenes in Washington and New York political and economic circles a great struggle is going on for control of the United States' share in the anticipated wide expansion of international commercial aviation after the war.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, April 11 (AP) -- A communique:

MONTREAL, April 10 -- Appointment of labor commissioners in Axis territories liberated by the United Nations and restoration in such territories of normal collective bargaining relations will be recommended in a draft resolution to be presented to the international conference opening April 20 in Philadelphia, it was announced at the headquarters of the ILO today.

CLEVELAND, April 10 (AP) -- Increasing by nearly one-third the revenue freight tonnage handled last year as compared to 1942, the Pere Marquette Railway Company's gross operating income for 1943 was $55,052,804, an all-time high, the road's annual report disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The State Department expressed itself today as being much gratified over the reaction, at home and abroad, to the broadcast last night in which Secretary of State Cordell Hull defined this country's foreign policy.

Two new amendments, one providing for the payment of unemployment compensation during re-conversion, and the other giving the Controller General power to investigate broadly and to report Congress on waste and extravagance disclosed in post-settlement audits of cancellations, will be incorporated in Senate bill 1718, Senator James E. Murray, Democrat, Montana, disclosed yesterday.

OTTAWA, April 10 -- Ninety-eight thousand more men will be added to the Canadian armed forces during the next twelve months, it has been announced here. Most of them will come from the ranks of those who reach the age of eighteen and a half, but there is going to be a good raking out of fit men who have until now been deferred because of employment in essential industries.

Allotments again will be the rule on fall orders as buyers come into the local wholesale markets next month to cover a substantial portion of their requirements for the new season, a survey here yesterday indicated.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 10 -- Intercepted and attacked by British warships and naval aircraft, two large enemy supply ships have been scuttled by their crews in the Indian Ocean, a British communique announced today.

LONDON, April 10 -- Under-Secretary of State Edward R. Stettinius Jr. came to London officially to repay the visits of British Foreign Office dignitaries to Washington. He brought with him specialists in geopolitics and an expert on French affairs but no hard and fast agenda.

President Roosevelt's common cold and his subsequent trouble with his bronchial tubes link him with millions of his fellow-citizens. We have had colds and bronchitis, too. Some of us have stayed home, as we should do, and some of us have made the mistake of going to the office. Mr. Roosevelt may have gone to the office when he shouldn't have done so.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Unprecedented tax receipts may reduce the anticipated net deficit in Government funds for the fiscal year 1944 by $1,500,000,000, it was indicated today.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The War Manpower Commission, with the encouragement of labor and management, today ordered a forty-eight-hour week throughout the cotton textile industry, beginning May 14. Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the WMC, said these mills are operating on an average of 41.5 hours a week.
CHUNGKING, China, April 10 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:
WILKES-BARRE, Pa., April 10 -- Anthracite production slumped to a new low for 1944 today, when only 94,000 tons were mined.

Inductees being examined at Grand Central Palace yesterday afternoon gazed perplexedly at some youngsters undergoing the same searching physical tests and muttered under their breaths, "Boy, the manpower situation really can't be as bad as this!"

LONDON, April 10 -- Pressure for the formation of a Greek coalition government, including representatives of the militant leadership of Leftist resistance groups inside the country, increased today as the Government in Cairo awaited the imminent return of King George II to settle the taut political crisis.

CHUNGKING, China, April 10 (U.P.) -- American Mitchell bombers, on a sea sweep off the south China coast, destroyed a 1,200-ton Japanese tanker off Hainan Island and downed our Japanese fighters attempting to break up the attack, Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Congressional action to place Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Selective Service director, in command of the proposed labor corps of nonessential 4-F's was suggested today by Chairman John M. Costello of the House Military Affairs subcommittee investigating draft problems.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The finding of the Southern District Court of New York, holding the Soft-Lite Company of New York guilty of anti-trust violations in wholesaling pink-tinted optical lenses, was sustained by the Supreme Court today, but by a 4-to-4 division the tribunal automatically affirmed dismissal of anti-trust charges against the Bausch Lomb Optical Company of Rochester.

SPOKANE, Wash., April 10 -- Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio accused Secretary of State Hull today of leaving many questions unanswered in his talk on foreign policy last night and declared the public "is fed up with the New Deal's back-room diplomacy."

Characterized only by dullness, the stock market plodded yesterday through another session as prices hardly moved except in a few scattered instances. Activity was confined almost entirely to issues selling around $15 or under, but despite the trading in these stocks dealings dropped to the lightest in approximately two months.

The New York City Defense Recreation Committee, 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street), through the generosity of the entertainment world, offers a partial list of free amusements available today. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M.; evening tickets after 4 P.M. Apply 99 Park Avenue for tickets.

Edward V. Broderick, counsel for Wayne T. Lonergan, was served yesterday with specifications detailing the contempt of court charges he must answer when he appears Friday before General Sessions Judge John J. Freschi, who presided at the first Lonergan trial, which ended without a juror having been chosen.

CHUNGKING, China, April 4 (Delayed) -- Because of the inflation Chang Lin-chu, the enterprising messenger, announced this morning that he was afraid he would have to take another job that would pay 2,500 Chinese dollars a month.
MOSCOW, April 10 -- The British Ministry of Information began distribution today of approximately 60,000 copies of a Russian translation of Prime Minister Churchill's Feb. 22 speech.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., April 10 -- Leo Durocher, his playing days probably ended by his thumb fracture in yesterday's game with the Red Sox, was given another bit of infield insurance for his Dodgers today when President Branch Rickey signed young Clancy Smyres, 21-year-old shortstop, to a Brooklyn contract.

Odessa has been liberated. Once more the busy victory guns of Moscow roar forth to salute a Russian triumph, and their thunder is echoed this time by the guns of the Russian Black Sea fleet returning to its home port. First major prize to be enveloped by the Axis armies, Odessa is also the last of pre-war Russia's major cities to see the invaders driven out.

The thirty-eighth annual report of the Stewart-Warner Corporation, released for publication today, by James S. Knowlson, president and chairman of the board, shows record sales of $115,064,408 in the year ended last Dec. 31 and a net profit of all charges of $2,011,085, equal to $1.58 each on 1,272,920 shares of common stock.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The Army-Navy pennant, an award for excellence in the manufacture and delivery of war materials, has been given to the following twenty concerns:

Col. Arthur V. McDermott, City Director of Selective Service, took what steps he could yesterday to relieve the confusion resulting from Washington's latest directive which over the week-end halted temporarily the induction of men over 26 years old, who had made all necessary preparations for entering the armed forces.

The Fifth Avenue branch of Yamanaka Co., which before Pearl Harbor was one of the leading Oriental art firms in the country, was closed yesterday by order of the United States Alien Property Custodian, under whose direction the store had been operated since the United States declared war against Japan.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Chain store and mail-order sales totaled $1,071,000,000 in February, the Department of Commerce estimated today. The total represented an increase of 2 per cent over February of 1943, without allowance for the effect of the extra day in the month.

Federal and local authorities in the metropolitan area speeded their drive against violators of food rationing regulations yesterday when jail sentences, fines and suspension orders were pronounced here and preparations were begun to press scores of suspension proceedings in northern New Jersey.

CHICAGO, April 10 (U.P.) -- Democratic and Republican campaign managers said tonight they expected less than 50 per cent of the State's 4,104,937 voters to go to the polls tomorrow for the primary election of a full slate of candidates for State officers, twenty-six Representatives and one Senator.
Bonus payment demands on the part of the grooms threatened a cancellation of the entire program at the Jamaica race track yesterday.

Frederick Brown, the operator, has purchased from a client of Leon Finley a group of eight six-family apartment houses on the entire blockfront on the north side of Thirty-fourth Avenue, between Seventy-first and Seventy-second Streets, in Jackson Heights, L.I.
ABOARD AN AIRCRAFT CARRIER OFF YAP, March 31 (delayed) (AP) -- This American carrier task force today brought a moment of agony to the island of Yap.

Mrs. Irene Kelly of Pittsburgh got news the other day that her son, Sgt. Charles Edward Kelly, first winner of the Congressional Medal of Honor in the Italian theatre of war, is coming home soon. A photograph published in this newspaper showed Mrs. Kelly on her doorstep passing the news along to some of her neighbors.

AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC AIR BASE, April 2 (Delayed) (AP) -- With both waist gunners wounded, one fatally, during the first minutes of battle, the crew of an American Liberator bomber shot down five Japanese fighters during a forty-five-minute aerial duel over Truk March 30.

NEW DELHI, April 10 -- The British troops evacuated from Tamu have fought their way back to positions about fifty miles from Imphal. This withdrawal follows a similar move by the Seventeenth Indian Division which last week fought its way from Tiddim at the end of another road running south from Imphal.

Cuts totaling $12,777.057 were recommended yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission at the first hearing before the Board of Estimate on Mayor La Guardia's executive budget of $737,333,149 for 1944-45.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, April 11 -- The Soviet High Command announced last night the recapture of Odessa, vital Black Sea port and industrial center, as new Red Army drives were launched against the Crimea with a break-through on a seventy-five-mile front to a depth of approximately fifteen miles.

TRENTON, N.J., April 10 -- Police and firemen, descending en masse on the Capitol here today to protest against passage of bills affecting their pension funds, won at least a partial victory when Gov. Walter E. Edge and leaders of the Republican majority in the Legislature decided to defer action pending "further study" of the proposals.

NORTH TONAWANDA, N.Y., April 10 (AP) -- First Lieut. Charles W. Walters, former Temple University end, who, with six other American airmen, trudged through occupied Europe and reached England two months after their bombers crashed in southwest Germany, said tonight that the escape was "just a case of a lot of work and a lot of luck."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 10 -- The news that Spud Chandler and Tiny Bonham will join the Yankees before the end of the week acted like a shot in the arm for Joe McCarthy's champions at Bader Field today, and they went out and beat the Giants, 5 to 4, in their fastest game of the spring exhibition campaign and evened the series.

It is news when Tammany leaders raise their voice against the tyranny of the machine and in defense of principles. At the same time it is an enormous tribute to machine efficiency when two Tammany leaders declare there is a plot on foot to sell the Organization to the Communists.

Non-economic family problems are on the increase in New York City, Walter S. Gifford, chairman of the Community Service Society, declared yesterday in his annual report. Thousands of families have been "thrown off balance" by wartime factors, despite increased employment and higher earnings, and are facing serious difficulties in maintaining homes, it was said.
Operators were active in the purchase of apartment properties in the Bronx yesterday.

Having read the letter to your paper from Mr. P.P. Stally regarding the genuine atmosphere of good-will and friendliness that exists between the American lads and the people of Great Britain, I felt that I must add a few words on the sincere and unstinting hospitality I have received during my several visits to this country.

AN ADRIATIC VILLAGE IN ITALY, April 10 -- The Yugoslav National Liberation Movement represented militarily by the Partisan Army of Marshal Tito, is in no sense seeking to impose any specific form of government or political doctrine upon the various peoples of that land, and will leave the question of type of rule and the future selection of leaders to the free change of Yugoslavs after the war.
LONDON, April 10 (AP) -A United States Stratagic Air Force in Europe communique:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, April 11 (UP) -- Eleven days after the Arawe landing, marines invaded the Cape Gloucester area across New Britain and steadily pushed eastward after retreating Japanese who gave up supply dumps and prepared positions with only a few attempts at resistance.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- Population shifts, including both civilians and fighting men and women, added more than 2,500,000 residents to the south and west portions of this country between July 1, 1940, and July 1, 1942, while the North Central and Northeastern States were losing 450,000.

It seems to me unfortunate, at this time, that the Russian Patriarch, echoed later in this country by the Anglican Archbishop of York, should have raised the question of what they call the "Papal claims."

NEW DELHI, India, April 10 -- Japanese jungle patrols have filtered across the Tiddim Road at a point eighteen miles southwest of Imphal, menacing the right flank of the Allies' big East Indian base, while the main enemy attack, due north along the road, has increased in power, it was disclosed tonight.

First to attain a score of 4 -- 0 and thereby qualify for a place in the national chess championship finals, starting at the Park Central on Saturday, was Persinger Louis of the Marshall Club. Persinger won his fourth-round game in Group C of the preliminaries at that club yesterday, from John Mager, president of the Plainfield Chess Club. The game went sixty moves.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The Supreme Court, through Chief Justice Harlan F. Stone, ruled seven-to-two today that an employer who had recognized a union as bargaining agent was unfair in negotiating with individual employes on wages without union intervention, and thereafter refusing to deal with the union.

Despite the fact that the manufacture of metal furniture has been sharply curtailed and that rattan and bamboo are unobtainable, production of summer furniture has been held up to about 70 per cent of the pre-war level, a spokesman for the industry declared yesterday. Nevertheless, according to one large retail outlet, the number of styles obtainable has been cut about 80 per cent.

Little more than half the service men from Genesee County, N.Y., expect to return to their old jobs after the war, according to a survey conducted by Carlton A. Sears of Batavia, community chairmain for the Committee for Economic Development, it was brought out at an all-day meeting of New York State district chairmen at the University Club here yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 10 -- Dread, the largest single ingredient in national demoralization, gripped the Rumanian people tonight as that war-weary nation prepared to be sold down the river by her German allies despite Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop's heartening asservations last week, private reports from sources in Bucharest late tonight said.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 14 per cent for the week ended April 8, marking the end of Easter buying, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

A tall apartment house opposite Mount Sinai Hospital has passed to new control with the purchase by Simon Bros. of the fifteen-story and penthouse building at 1200 Fifth Avenue, northeast corner of 101st Street, from the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., April 10 -- Embarking on a post-war planning program that was described today as a model for other communities, the Middletown Post-War Planning Council is emphasizing two main points: (1) Local initiative and responsibility and (2) the need for adequate information on present, past and prospective economic conditions as a preliminary to making intelligent plans for meeting post-war conditions.

HOLLYWOD, Calif., April 10 -- Howard DaSilva, who is playing the "heavy" role of Judd in "Oklahoma" on Broadway, has been signed by Paramount to portray the martinet sea captain in "Two Years Before the Mast." Brian Donlevy, originally announced for the part, will be seen as Richard Henry Dana, the author-seaman.

"Blessed Are the Meek," the historical novel about St. Francis of Asissi by Zofia Kossak, published by Roy, has been chosen by the Catholic Book Club as its May selection. It was the April choice of the Book-of-the-Month Club.

PORTLAND, Ore., April 10 (AP) -- Release of 18 per cent of its employes because of persistent tardiness and absenteeism was announced today by the Albina Engine and Machine Works, a contractor for the construction of naval vessels.

Louise Cameron, soprano, from Harrisburg, Pa., who made her debut in this city last May in the Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, gave another recital here last night, appearing in Times Hall before a large audience that gave warm response to her excellent singing.

New York City's Red Cross 1944 War Fund campaign will fall short of success unless there is "prompt and generous action" by residents of this city, John P. Stevens Jr., general chairman, warned yesterday in a special message to Mayor La Guardia, honorary chairman, and to the people of New York.
MEXICO CITY, April 10 -- President Manuel Avila Camacho escaped unhurt from an attempt made on his life this morning by an army officer in the National Palace.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Congress was in brief recess when the Secretary of State delivered last night the most explicit speech he has yet made on the administration's foreign policy. But enough members were in Washington today to indicate that his account of our diplomacy satisfied many who were anxious about its courses and implications and a number who were outright critics.

LONDON, April 10 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull's speech yesterday was accepted in London as the United States final word on at least one troublesome issue of inter-Allied relations -- the recognition of the French Committee of National Liberation -- and was widely welcomed for its clarification of other riddles of American foreign policy which had baffled Europeans no less than Americans.

" -- But Not Goodbye," which is a comedy by George Seaton, will open this evening at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre under the auspices of John Golden of Broadway and Harry Joe Brown of Hollywood. In the cast are Harry Carey, Elizabeth Patterson, J. Pat O'Malley, Sylvia Field and Wendell Corey.

OXFORD, Pa., April 10 (AP) -- The Rev. Dr. James Carter, professor emeritus of church history, sociology and homiletics at Lincoln University, died Saturday at his home on the university campus. He was 90 years old.

One of the most interesting revelations in Secretary Hull's address on foreign policy was that he has requested the chairman of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations to designate a "representative, bipartisan group" to offer its "advice and help" in formulating plans for the organization to maintain peace.

IF a majority of our soldiers are "fighting to get the war over and go home," the same cannot be said for Alfred M. Bingham, formerly the editor of Common Sense and now a captain in the Specialist Reserve of the Army. For Captain Bingham has a detailed, fully integrated idea of what he personally thinks the war is about.

Henry C. Bernard, vice president of Park Tilford, Inc., said at the annual meeting of stockholders here yesterday that no definite statement could be made now about a plan for the sale of whisky to the stockholders.

MONTREAL, April 10 (Canadian Press) -- Walter (Babe) Pratt, the big, dark ice general who helped Hap Day weld a bunch of youngsters into the third-place Toronto Maple Leafs, today was announced the Hart Trophy winner for being the man most valuable to his National Hockey League team this season.

There are hundreds of thousands of refugees in the Soviet Union who fled there at the time of the Nazi invasion. These refugees are scattered all over the vast territories of Russia. Many of them have relatives in the United States and turned to them for help. Various traveling agencies established some contacts with Soviet authorities here, who enabled them to forward food and clothes parcels to the U.S.S.R.

A new issue of $1,000,000 of tax anticipation certificates was announced yesterday by Minneapolis, Minn., for award today. The issue will be dated April 20, 1944, and will be payable on June 19, 1944.

Not to be outdone by the Brooklyn committee in the festivities it is arranging for the Dodgers-Phillies benefit game at Ebbets Field the same day, the promoters of the Giants-Yankees Red Cross game at the Polo Grounds Thursday have added additional talent to their show.

Berlin and Tokyo radio propagandists made it clear yesterday that the section of Secretary of State Cordell Hull's address Sunday night on United States foreign policy that gave them the greatest concern was the part explaining the American Government's attitude on the question of continued trade of neutral nations with the Axis, singling it out for particularly strong verbal attacks.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 5, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

ALGIERS, April 10 -- While de Gaullist circles acknowledged today that Gen. Henri Honore Giraud had sent a letter yesterday flatly declining to accept the decree removing him as Commander in Chief of the French Army, there was no sign today of further action on Gen. Charles de Gaulle's side.

BOSTON, April 10 (AP) -- Cleveland's talented and well-balanced team dominated the opening of the two-day national A.A.U. boxing championships tonight at Boston Garden by qualifying six of seven aspirants for semi-final bouts.

ALBANY, April 10 (AP) -- Men over 26 engaged in "war-supporting" occupations may receive an induction delay of at least sixty days, Brig. Gen. Ames T. Brown, State Selective Service director, said today, as boards throughout the State reported many volunteering, despite a national directive staying their calls.

The nominating committee of the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday its selection of John A. Coleman, the incumbent, as its candidate for chairman of the board for an additional year. The annual election will be held on May 8.

Exhibition of the collection of modern paintings, drawings and sculpture formed by Lee Ault, opened yesterday at the Valentine Gallery, 55 East Fifty-seventh Street. Proceeds of the show go to the American Field Service, operating ambulances in the Middle East.

Total advertising for the first quarter of 1944 in all New York daily newspapers amounted to 23,779,879 agate lines, a loss of 9.7 per cent from the corresponding period last year, according to figures compiled from Media Records. Financial advertising gained 17.9 per cent, retail 2.1 per cent and general advertising 1.8 per cent.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- President Roosevelt has gone South for two weeks for rest and relaxation in the sun to speed his recovery from his recent series of colds, sinus and respiratory ailments.

Wendell L. Willkie will not give his support to any candidate for the Republican nomination for the Presidency prior to the Chicago convention, and is reserving the right to decide for himself later, in the post-convention period, whether he will support the winner.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Selective Service director, said tonight a list of those occupations that would entitle men under 26 in key jobs to draft deferment would be made public tomorrow. The Inter-Agency Deferment Committee, which determines the various categories, is expected to meet to complete the list, for submission to State draft boards.

NAPLES, April 10 -- Sgt. James Raley, 27-year-old farm boy from Henderson, Ky., is positively the only man in Uncle Sam's Army to travel a 19,000-feet dash down without the benefit of motors, wings or a parachute and land with only a scratch on the chin and 150 rounds of .50-caliber machine-gun bullets draped around his unbroken neck.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The slack season has ended at national headquarters here for the women's groups of both the principal political parties, and from now until November a brisker momentum will be apparent in all their activities.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Quincy Adams, former manager of the sales research division of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., today was appointed chief of a new division of small business in the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, Secretary of Commerce Jesse Jones announced.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, April 11 -- The Japanese are in full retreat from central New Britain and are headed for the Gazelle Peninsula at the northeast tip, where they are preparing for a last stand before Rabaul, Gen. Douglas MacArthur reported today.

Airlines in the United States are expected to purchase 1,700 new transport planes valued at $512,000,000 within two years after the war ends. This prediction was made last night by E. Earl Lothrop, manager of the research and statistical department of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America at a meeting of the alumni of the Harvard Business School at the Harvard Club here.

Five States, including New York, are scheduled to take official action this week to facilitate voting by members of the armed forces in this year's Presidential elections. Three other States have called special sessions of their Legislatures to achieve the same goal and in four additional States special sessions on soldier voting are under consideration but have not yet been called, according to a survey made by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
The large garage and stores at 45 to 49 Harrison Street, in East Orange, N.J., have been sold by the Federal Trust Company to H. A. Roff, Inc., through Feist Feist, brokers.

It is a tradition in Florence that when Cimabue finished a painting the city stopped work to admire it which indicates the social importance of art in the fourteenth century. Today it is the newest scientific discovery or invention that commands interest. It is easy to understand, then, why the tenth anniversary of America's first streamlined Diesel train, the Burlington's "Zephyr," has been celebrated with considerable ceremony.

Steel production of 7,804,704 net tons in March came within 15,000 tons of setting a new monthly record, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute; it would have topped the high of 7,819,061 tons set last October had it not been for the shortage of manpower.

Lakewood wasn't anything like Miami, but compared to the freeze the Giants ran into in Brooklyn yesterday, when they dropped in at Floyd Bennett Field to engage the naval air station nine in diamond combat, the pines at Lakewood were Paradise.

Secretary Hull expressly associated the President with himself in two important statements in his address on American foreign policy. One was on secret commitments. "As the President has said," he declared, "neither he nor I have made or will make any secret agreement or commitment, political or financial."

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The Office of Price Administration removed today the time limits before which members of the shoe trade previously have had to use their shoe purchase certificates for replenishing their stocks. Also eliminated were the expiration dates of shoe certificate which are used by employers and other buyers of shoes in quantity at retail, and by members of the armed services who need extra shoes.

Brooklyn fans have subscribed more than $4,000 to buy seats for service men at the Ebbets Field game tomorrow between the Dodgers and Phillies for the benefit of the Greater New York 1944 Red Cross War Fund, it was announced yesterday.

The "no coffee, no overtime" dispute continued yesterday in the ship repair yards of the Bethlehem Steel Company in Brooklyn and in Hoboken, N.J., with several thousand men quitting at the end of their regular day shift rather than work two hours extra at time and a half because the company would not allow them time out for coffee and cake.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11 -- The Central-Penn National Bank announced today that the Pensylvaia Title Insurance Company, which it acquired in 1938 in connection with the liquidation of the Central National Securities Company, has been merged with the Commonwealth Title Company of Philadelphia, under the name of the latter.

Cost-of-living bonuses for employes of the Board of Education, including teachers, are a matter of negotiation between the board and Mayor La Guardia, it was revealed yesterday by Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools. Speaking at the Board of Estimate hearing on the Mayor's executive budget, Dr. Wade said that it "seems some adjustment can be made."

Mrs. Alice Chase of Fall River, Mass., got back her 2-year-old son, Jimmy, last night after she had conferred with Mrs. Crystal Potter, director of the Bureau of Child Welfare of the city Department of Welfare.

Because men nave failed to end wars women should demand a voice in making a peace that will last, Frederick E. Hasler, president of the Pan American Society of the United States, yesterday told members of the Inter-American Commission of Women at a luncheon given in their honor at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 11 (AP) -- Arkansas tonight counted thirty-four dead, one missing, more than 100 injured and many homeless as a result of a tornado that last night devastated a number of widely separated communities.
ALBANY, April 11 -- The Republican State political organization moved today to "put Governor Dewey over the top" in delegate strength for the national convention well in advance of the gathering.

The War Manpower Commission's order for a mandatory forty-eight-hour work week in the cotton textile industry, and the War Production Board's directive to yarn mills to maintain production at not less than the 1943 level, inspired increased trade support in the local cotton market and prices on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced early in the session to new highs for the move, closing unchanged to 11 points higher.

James A. Farley is scheduled for re-election as State chairman without opposition when the Democratic State Committee assembles today at the National Democratic Club for its organization meeting. Thomas J.V. Cullen, Orange County chairman, who had been mentioned as a possible opponent, said last night that his name would not go before the meeting and that, so far as he Knew, Mr. Farley would be renamed unanimously.
A lot of neighborhood reputations hung yesterday on a pinch of salt.

It is the season of the year, and the particular week of the season, when the average age of the Times Square population declines sharply. The reason is the circus. During its stay in Madison Square Garden the neighborhood is taken over by the kindergarten-age classes and their elders up to 4A.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- The Army transport President Coolidge, which was reported lost in the South Pacific more than a year ago, struck a mine and sank on a reef while approaching the American base at Espiritu Santu in the New Hebrides Islads, northeast of Australia.

An international organization to maintain and enforce peace, together with a detailed program for world and national economic reconstruction, is recommended in a report made public yesterday by the American Federation of Labor through its Post-War Reconstruction Committee headed by Matthew Woll, vice president of the federation.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Activities so important to prosecution of the war that irreplaceable men engaged in them are eligible for exemption from the general policy of drafting for military service all qualified registrants under 26 years of age were listed today by Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Selective Service director, in instructions telegraphed to State directors.

Next Sunday fifteen to twenty thousand members of the Russian Orthodox Church in this city will celebrate Easter. Following a strict seven-week fast, during which time no meat or meat products are eaten, the day is one of great rejoicing, celebrated with a feast that far surpasses in scope the American Thanksgiving dinner.

In 1943, the Weston Electrical Instrument Corporation and its subsidiary had a net profit of $820,556, equal to $3.86 a share on the outstanding common stock after deducting a reserve of $200,000 for post-war adjustments. Net income in the preceding year was $727,906, or $3.29 a common share after a similar provision for post-war adjustments.
LONDON, April 11 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin:

A little over five years went by between Hitler's violation of Czechoslovakia on the morning of March 15, 1939, and the arrival of Field Marshal Zhukoff's First Ukrainian Army at the foot of the Tatar Pass. Hitler marched in from the west with no opposition except from ice and snow.

Agnes de Mille's latest ballet, "Tally-Ho," had its local premiere last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, where the Ballet Theatre presented it in fine style with Miss de Mille in the central role. Its music is gleaned from various operas of Gluck in an arrangement by Paul Nordoff, and its scene is the eighteenth century of Watteau.

The eleven-story loft and office building at 12-23 West Sixtieth Street, on a plot 73 by 100 feet in the Columbus Circle district, has been sold by a client of Engel, Judge Miller to an investing client of Byrne, Bowman Forshay, Inc., brokers.

Reports that the Germans were shifting younger troops out of Norway and older men into the country to replace them in the occupation forces as well as "strengthening their Gestapo forces" there were brought here yesterday from London by Dr. Carl J. Hambro, President of the Norwegian Parliament, who arrived at La Guardia Field aboard a transatlantic clipper.

Allen L. Billingsley, president of Fuller Smith Roos, Inc., Cleveland, was re-elected chairman of the board of the American Association of Advertising Agencies for a third consecutive term at the organization's annual meeting yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The Russell Sage Foundation, replying to statements made by Representative Harry R. Sheppard, Democrat of California, accusing it of a part in a "country-wide small loan racket," asserts, through John M. Glenn, formerly General Director of the foundation, that "Representative Sheppard's attack on the foundation and on Leon Henderson and Rolf Nugent, and others, arises either from lack of knowledge of the facts of the case or from deliberate desire to mislead the public."

A Fifth Army Association is in active process of formation in Italy for the purpose of keeping up the friendships formed there during the war. When the association was started it was brought to the attention of all ranks through a memorandum circulated by Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark, commanding the army.
CHICAGO, April 11 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:

Seven hundred and seventy thousand gallons of gasoline were recovered from the black market in March as a result of checking the accounts of filling stations in 850 of the 3,600 ration banks in this jurisdiction, Daniel P. Woolley, Director of the Regional Office of Price Administration, announced yesterday.

In the first change of ownership in nearly a century, the large garage property at 438-54 West Eighteenth Street, between Ninth and Tenth Avenues, has been purchased by the 440 West Eighteenth Street Realty Corporation, Louis Butensky, president, from the Consolidated Edison Company.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (U.P.) -- The War Production Board has authorized an over-riding priority putting heavy artillery on a par with invasion landing craft as the most urgent items in the war production program.

CAMP POLK, La., April 11 -- Saying that prompt recognition of heroic action in battle was one of the best methods of bolstering morale, Lieut. Gen. William H. Simpson, commanding general of the Fourth Army, declared tonight that Gen. George C. Marshall had voiced his approval of a liberal award system as far back as 1927.

CHICAGO, April 11 -- Asserting that it noted "the repudiation of indorsement of Wendell Willkie by Wisconsin newspapers," The Chicago Tribune stated tonight that the Tribune Company had applied today to the War Production Board for newsprint to start a morning newspaper in Milwaukee.
BOSTON, April 11 (AP) -- The midwest dominated the national A.A.U. boxing championship, but Joe Gannon, Washington welterweight, stole the show tonight at the Boston Garden.

Frank D. March, city salvage coordinator for the War Production Board and the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, reported yesterday that the total delivery of waste paper by trucks and railroad cars to the mills in the metropolitan area was 69,584 tons in March, an increase of 3,236 tons over the previous month's collection.

Establishment of international joint boards of trade to regulate and coordinate commerce in Europe after the war, as a means of insuring a permanent peace while also preventing "dangerous expansion" of German industry, was recommended here yesterday by Lieut. Col. John Jacob Astor, chairman of The Times Publishing Company of London and member of the British Parliament.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 11 -Alfred Marchev, president of Republic Aviation, told stockholders at their annual meeting here today that in less than twenty-four months since the first production model was completed, 6,500 P-47 Thunderbolts have been delivered to the Army Air Forces by the company.

When the Japanese decide to yield without a fight the bulk of New Britain, the largest land mass they still controlled in South Pacific waters, it can only mean that Tokyo regards the outer barrier of its defenses as basically untenable. The Gazelle Peninsula to which the enemy is now withdrawing comprises only about one-fifth of the great island.

FLORA, Miss., April 9 (Delayed) -- The War Department opened today a week-long tour by correspondents of Army installations in six southeastern States in which the Army is placing on review what Lieut. Col. Larry S. MacPhail, assistant to Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War described as a cross-section of training important to operations which are developing.

HONOLULU, April 11 -- A frank appraisal of the military situation in Hawaii, with emphasis on the vulnerability of the islands to bomber and commando raids, was given by Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, and Lieut. Gen. Robert C. Richardson Jr., Army Commander of the Hawaiian Department, when they testified in Federal court today in a habeas corpus proceeding.

A UNITED STATES FIGHTER BASE, in England, April 11 -- American fighter pilots were told today by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower that their role in the great three-way invasion of Europe soon would be the flying of a dawn-to-dusk death express against the German Air Force.

The need for more widespread public information about cancer was emphasized yesterday by speakers at the fifth annual meeting of the Women's Field Army of the New York City Cancer Committee in Old Memorial Hospital, 2 West 106th Street.

The electrical power industry should set as its objective an annual rate of production of 200,000,000,000 to 220,000,000,000 kilowatt-hours at the point of generation by the end of the first post-war year, Leland Olds, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, told 1,000 officials of the country's leading electric power and public utility companies last night.
Sales of residential property in Yonkers featured the reports of Westchester deals yesterday. Victor Cantor, who announced several transactions, cited "rising activity" in that section.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Vice President Wallace announced tonight that he planned a trip to China in the late spring or early summer and aides said he would go as President Roosevelt's personal representative.

NEW DELHI, India, April 11 -- Hurled back with sharp losses in their first direct assault on the Allied base of Kohima in eastern India, Japanese invasion forces have swung around through the jungles north of the town and already have planted snipers along the thirty-five-mile supply highway between Kohima and the station of Dimapur, on the American-operated Bengal-Assam railway, it was reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Edward V. Loughlin, leader of Tammany Hall, called for the drafting of President Roosevelt for a fourth term in a statement issued here today after conferences with party leaders. Mr. Roosevelt is not in Washington.

Eight admirals were present yesterday when the Navy E pennant with an added fourth star was raised at the yard of the Consolidated Shipbuilding Corporation in Morris Heights, the Bronx. The PC 1550 also was launched and the hull for a similar vessel was laid.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, April 12 -- For the first time the Soviet High Command has announced an air raid on the town of Lwow, Poland, important German railway center and defense point which already is threatened by an outflanking maneuver by Soviet armies.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 11 -Governor Dewey vetoed today, on the ground that they inadvertently "reopen the doors to improper practices," a series of six lien law amendments that were part of the legislative program sponsored by the New York State Bankers Association.

Herman Shumlin will unfold Lillian Hellman's new play, "The Searching Wind," at the Fulton Theatre this evening. Cornelia Otis Skinner, Dennis King and Dudley Digges are co-starred in the company which also includes Barbara O'Neil, Arnold Korff, Montgomery Clift, Joseph de Santis and Eugene Earl, among others. It is the fifth of Miss Hellman's plays which the producer has staged and sponsored.

TACOMA, Wash., April 11 (AP) -- Gov. John W. Bricker, candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, berated "government by secrecy and double-talk" in a speech prepared for delivery tonight at the Pierce County Republican convention.

The Kings County Democratic Committee at its biennial meeting last night in the Brooklyn Academy of Music unanimously adopted a resolution calling for the election of "a Democratic Congress and a Democratic President" next November, but failed to recommend a fourth-term nomination for President Roosevelt or to mention a move to draft him as the party's candidate.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Fear lest John L. Lewis run up the United Mine Workers membership from 600,000 to 1,000,000 and thus within a year or two dominate the American Federation of Labor is the "real reason" ascribed in informed quarters here for failure of the federation to take final action on the miners' application for readmission, made nearly one year ago.

WRITERS are peculiar people. That has been the general opinion of most of mankind for several thousand years, an opinion supported by abundant evidence. Although there have been plenty, perhaps even a majority, of writers who lived eminently respectable lives, good family men who toiled meekly and industriously to support their wives and educate their children, there have been altogether too many of the other kind.

LONDON, April 11 -- The commission appointed by Lieut. Gen. Marjan Kukiel, Polish Minister of National Defense, has recommended disciplinary action toward all Polish soldiers found guilty of showing anti-Semitic feelings, according to a statement issued today by the Polish Ministry of Information.

The National Association of Women Artists opened its fifty-second annual show with a reception last evening at the American Fine Arts Galleries, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. Invited guests of honor were Anne Morgan, Fannie Hurst and Ernesta Beaux Barlow.

A UNITED STATES FIGHTER BASE, in Britain, April 11 (AP) -Capt. Don S. Gentile, America's leading fighter pilot and "one-man air force," was rewarded for his deeds today by the Supreme Allied Commander for the Western Front invasion.

First Lieut. Peter Gerald Lehman of the United States Army Air Forces, eldest son of former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Director General of The United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, was killed on March 31 during acrobatic maneuvers in a fighter plane over his home base somewhere in England.

Consolidated net profit of the International Paper Company and subsidiaries for 1943 amounted to $8,413,808, equal to $2.07 a share for the common stock, comparing with $7,814,319, or $1.74 a share, in 1942, according to the annual report signed by Richard J. Cullen, chairman, and John H. Hinman, president.

ZAGORSK, Russia, April 11 -- A Polish children's home has been opened in this ancient Russian market town, fifty miles from Moscow. It is one of fifty that have been established during the last twelve months for 4,000 to 5,000 Polish children.

The confused situation in the current Burma fighting, with the Japanese threatening Allied supply lines and the Allies threatening enemy supply lines, is in some sense symptomatic of the confused and confusing canvas of Southeast Asia.

Our Washington dispatches report disappointment in the House of Representatives because the proposed bipartisan Congressional group to confer with Secretary Hull on large questions of foreign policy is to consist solely of members of the Senate. Thus Mr. Bloom, chairman of the House Committee on Foreign Affairs, contends that if the House has the right, with the Senate, to declare war, then it should have a similar standing and function in planning for peace.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 11 -Twentieth Century-Fox has named Don Ameche for the leading role of Major Victor Joppolo in its forth-coming adaptation of John Hersey's current novel of occupied Italy, "A Bell for Adano." The picture will be put into production early in June.
LONDON, April 11 (AP) -- A United State Strategic Air Force in Europe communique:

In " -- But Not Goodbye," which opened last evening at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre, George Seaton has written what presumably could be called a ghost story. At all events some of his characters are living on this sad old planet and the rest are living amid the shades, although they are interested in what goes on among relatives and friends here-about.
