Bankers' dollar acceptances outstanding in the United States on March 31 aggregated $129,358,000, a decline of $5,414,000 on the month and a decline of $460,000 from one year ago, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday in its regular monthly survey of this market.

LONDON, April 11 -- Under-Secretary of State Edward R. Stettinius Jr. saw Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden this afternoon. He was accompanied by Ambassador John G. Winant when he made his first official visit at the Foreign Office.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11 -- The United Gas Improvement Company has asked the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to pay a fee of $100,000 to the legal firm of Morgan, Lewis Bockiu here for services in preparation and execution of the holding company's plan of reorganization.

MEXICO CITY, April 11 (U.P.) -- An army physician operated today on Lieut. Antonio E. de la Lama Rojas in an effort to save the life of the man who attempted to assassinate President Manuel Avila Camacho -- an attempt that, Mexican newspapers asserted, has united the nation "more than ever."

Establishment of a Federal machine tool agency to dispose of the more than 500,000 machine tools estimated to be owned or controlled by the Government within two years after Congress has declared a state of emergency no longer exists, was urged yesterday by Herbert I. Segal, chairman of the Machinery Dealers Institute.

BALTIMORE, April 11 (AP) -- Racing will return to Maryland tomorrow, and officials predicted today a crowd of 15,000 for the opening program of a twenty-eight-day meeting at Pimlico. Eleven 3-year-olds and upward, headed by the Calumet Farm's Sun Again, were named overnight for the $7,500 added Rowe Memorial Handicap, a six-furlong sprint feature.

LONDON, Wednesday, April 12 (U.P.) -- Two orders of the day from Premier Joseph Stalin and the regular Moscow war bulletins announced the triumphs in the Crimea, according to broadcasts received here. Moscow dispatches said it was estimated unofficially that eleven German divisions -110,000 to 165,000 men -- were facing death or surrender in the Crimea.

CLEVELAND, April 11 (AP) -- The body of George W. Plaisted, 51, vice president and general sales manager of the Austin Company, was found by his wife early today in a garage at their home, Coroner S.R. Gerber reported. Dr. Gerber called the death a suicide from carbon monoxide poisoning.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -Secretary of Labor Perkins declared today that the general cost of living declined six-tenths of 1 per cent during the first two months of 1944.
Plans for a four-story laundry for Kings County Hospital were filed by the city yesterday. The cost of the building was estimated at $1,200,000. Details of this and other building plans follow:
LONDON, Wednesday, April 12 (AP) -- The Russian Tuesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow.

ALGIERS, April 11 -- At a meeting of the French Committee of National Liberation today, where apparently little was said about Gen. Henri-Honore Giraud, two military appointments were made -- that of Lieut. Gen. Emile-Marie Bethouard as Chief of Staff and that of Brig. Gen. Joseph-Pierre Koenig as "military delegate of the Government for the northern theatre of operations."

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- A 31 per cent increase in juvenile delinquency, from 72,000 cases in 1942 to 94,000 cases in 1943, was stated today by Miss Katharine F. Lenroot, chief of the Children's Bureau for the 145 juvenile courts annually reporting to the bureau.

Sales of leading mail-order and chain-store companies increased 7 per cent in March, compared with the corresponding month of 1943, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The volume of twenty-nine reporting companies for the month was $407,763,044, as against $381,204,939 last year.

Draft inductions here of all men over 26, regardless of their occupations, were suspended yesterday pending clarification of the phrase "war supporting activities," by order of Col. Arthur V. McDermott, City Director of Selective Service, who pointed out that the new list of critical war jobs just announced by Washington applied only to men under 26.
Federal, municipal and private agencies were mobilized yesterday behind a plan to move the nation's unprecedented egg and potato surpluses.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., April 11 -- Bill Hart today became the most probable second baseman of the Dodgers when they open the 1944 campaign against the Phillies one week hence.

NEWARK, N.J., April 11 -- Two Government propaganda experts, testifying today at the Federal court trial of twenty-one defendants accused of failing to register with the State Department as agents of a foreign principal, linked the publishing activities of the German American Vocational League with the objectives of Hitler Germany's propaganda.

CHICAGO, April 11 -- Grain traders placed a bearish construction today on Government estimates of the winter wheat crop and of farm reserves of wheat, corn and oats as of April 1. A fair run of buying orders in wheat early held prices on the Board of Trade here close to yesterday's finish.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 11 -- A British medical officer who arrived from Yugoslavia described today the hardships borne by 550 Partisan army doctors and hundreds of untrained nurses to give treatment to an army that he estimated at 250,000.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Representatives of industry here are worried by what they assert is the inability, until Congress appropriates the necessary funds, of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, to acquire stockpiles of food, clothing, medicines and small machinery for those areas of Europe which may be liberated.
The following letter was received by an American history class at Tilden. It resulted from a project in which Corporal Boardman was chosen "Hero of the Week" because he is a typical G.I. Joe.

Seeking establishment of outlets for its war-time developed penicillin production capacity, Commercial Solvents Corporation, is offering wholesalers distribution contracts for the drug on an "if, as and when available basis," it was learned yesterday. The contracts, many of which have already been accepted by wholesalers throughout the country, are only being made to full-line jobbers, a spokesman for the company stated.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora, in a decision handed down yesterday, invalidated ten of fifteen appointments made by Mayor La Guardia last June when he promoted battalion chiefs to the rank of deputy fire chiefs with a salary of $6,300 a year.

Plans for an extensive "goodwill" exhibition of Mexican arts and crafts in the United States were announced here yesterday by Dr. Alejandro Buelna Jr., chief of the Mexican Department of Tourism and personal representative of Miguel Aleman, Mexican Secretary of the Interior.

The report of the United Corporation, public utility holding company, for the first quarter of this year, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $943,089 after taxes and other charges. This was equivalent to 38 cents a share on the outstanding $3 preference stock and compares with a profit of $911,131, or 36 cents a share, in the March quarter a year ago.

The most comprehensive outline of the program of Marshal Tito's Yugoslav Liberation Movement offered thus far has been given by Dr. Josip Smodlaka, its Foreign Minister, in an interview with our correspondent C.L. Sulzberger. At the moment, he declares, the movement has only one war aim and that is victory.

PANAMA CITY, Fla., April 11 -- The Richard V. Oulahan, a Liberty ship named for the former Washington correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, was launched today at the Wainwright yard of the J.A. Jones Construction Company here.

The First Boston Corporation and the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, bidding jointly, won the award yesterday of a new issue of $5,000,000 Boston temporary loan notes, dated April 14 and due Nov. 2, 1944. The bankers bid an 0.42 per cent basis, plus a premium of $38.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, April 12 -- The Soviet High Command announced last night that counter attacking German forces had broken through to join the encircled group of German divisions in the vicinity of Skala, where fierce battles have been progressing for several days.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The National War Labor Board's Shipbuilding Commission awarded today wage adjustments of between .033 cent an hour to 4.5 cents an hour at three major East Coast shipyards employing about 28,000 workers. Eventually sixty shipyards on the East Coast employing 470,000 workers may be affected.

To all the pleasant places from which the young men have gone to war the casualty lists come back to remind us of the cost of freedom. There is no complacence in this land today if there ever was. There is a grim pride. There are memories along the streets of a thousand towns and cities from which men went to face the foes of all their homes stand for.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Expressing confidence that the British would be able to rally, Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox minimized today the danger to Allied strategy in the Japanese invasion of India. Mr. Knox told his press conference that, while he lacked detailed information on the Indian campaign, he did not regard the operation as "heavy."

GREAT MEADOWS, N.J., April 11 -- Five hundred residents of this area voted tonight, at a mass meeting in the consolidated school, to seek legal means of removing five Japanese-American farm laborers sent here by the War Relocation Authority for work on the farm of Edward Kowalick.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- United States banks are getting out of debt to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation by selling common stock and redeeming their preferred stock with the proceeds. According to a statement today by Preston Delano, Controller of the Currency, more than 200 national banks increased their common stock during the first quarter of 1944 and forty of them sold new common stock for cash to the amount of $5,300,000.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 11 -- King George II of Greece arrived from London today to review the tangled political situation that developed into a crisis last week following the resignation of Premier Emmanuel Tsouderos.

ALBANY, April 11 -- Governor Dewey signed today the CoudertMitchell bills which he said represent an effort to meet the problem created by "strike" stockholder suits against corporation directors and officers.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today set April 27 for a hearing on the plan of the United Light and Power Company to sell all outstanding common stock and 3,298 shares of $6 cumulative preferred stock of the Missouri Power and Light Company to the Continental Gas and Electric Corporation for $3,400,000.

PEARL HARBOR, April 11 (AP) -- United States sovereignty has been established over five more land clusters in the Marshall Islands and American airmen have stepped up their assault on remaining isolated Japanese positions, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today.
Comdr. Walter S. Burrage, USNR, and Mrs. Burrage have come from Brookline, Mass., to the Waldorf-Astoria.

Announcement of a "realistic tax program free of all social and economic experimentation" is the prime assurance business seeks for the post-war years to enable it to "provide the jobs for our fighting men when they return from the war," Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, declared last night at a dinner of the New York Group of the Investment Bankers Association at the Hotel Pierre.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, April 12 (AP) -- A communique:

PHILADELPHIA, April 11 -- Declaring that betting was not a necessary attendant of horse racing, the Pennsylvania Supreme Court, in an opinion handed down today, directed the State Public Utility Commission to see that telephone and teletype services were supplied to Pennsylvania Publications, Inc., which gives horse-racing information from the tracks all over the country.

LONDON, Wednesday, April 12 -- Close to 2,000 American heavy bombers and fighters continued the Allied air offensive in unprecedented power and scope yesterday. They fought their way deep into Germany through the massed strength of the Luftwaffe and blasted aircraft factories at Oschersleben and Bernburg, industrial targets at Rostock and Arnimswalde, near Stettin, and other war plants in the Reich.

NAPLES, April 11 -- The Germans attacked twice in Italy during the period ended at noon yesterday, but the British on the beachhead below Rome and the Italians on the Mount Marrone sector above Cassino drove them back with losses.

NAPLES, Italy, April 11 -- The reception of the Polish underground army by Soviet troops advancing into eastern Poland has not been the same in all sectors and has evoked "some disquieting rumors which are being investigated," it was said today by Gen. Kazimierz Sosnkowski, who is on a tour of inspection of Polish forces whom he commands.

Preservation of the free enterprise system as the basis of the nation's social and economic structure, with only such measure of Government control and intervention as may be necessary to avoid the abuses of monopoly and concentration of wealth, was urged as the guiding principle in a report on post-war reconstruction made public yesterday by the post-war problems committee of the American Federation of Labor.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported, by the Federal Communications Commision:

To provide for an anticipated crowd, seventy-two extra boxes are being built in Madison Square Garden for the Red Cross benefit concert on May 25, at which Arturo Toscanini will conduct the combined forces of the NBC Symphony and the Philharmonic - Symphony orchestras.

Mayor La Guardia, in a sharply worded letter, told Surrogate Albert H. Henderson of the Bronx yesterday that he would take "every lawful means" to fight the salary increases the Surrogate proposes to give John J. Knewitz, Republican leader of the Bronx, as Commissioner of Records, and Edward Rose, deputy commissioner.

In reference to your editorial in your issue of April 8, 1944, concerning government through political parties, did it ever occur to you that our election laws, which are the legislative statutes furnishing the authority for the creation of political parties, are seriously defective?

Farmers should never be drafted or permitted to enlist at a time like this, and should not be permitted to leave this essential war activity. The same holds true as to the miners, and those engaged in other very important duties connected with the proper distribution of the coal output of our country.

Presentation yesterday of a Purple Heart, awarded posthumously to Robert R. Lindergren, did not take place exactly according to schedule. The original plan had been to present the medal to the Children's Aid Society for safekeeping until the decoration could be claimed by Robert's brother, James, a Navy gunner on transport duty.

Charles J. Stewart, vice president of the New York Trust Company, will head the seventh annual drive of the Manhattan Committee of the Greater New York Fund, J. Stewart Baker, general campaign chairman, announced yesterday.

John L. Buckley and Dennis J. Mahon, district leaders who are spearheading a drive to "purge" the Tammany executive committee of members said to be over-friendly to the American Labor party, yesterday described as "a malicious falsehood" and "a damnable lie" the statement of Representative Vito Marcantonio, Labor party leader, that both had solicited his help in the past.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., April 11 -- Mr. James I. Dykes glanced at the sign and failed to be properly impressed. The meaning was clear, however. It said: "Chicago Cubs' Spring Training Field." But once Mr. Dykes appeared satisfied that the greensward was in attractive condition, he promptly staked his claim to the Cub diamond, and his Chicago White Sox have been cavorting there ever since.

CHICAGO, April 11 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur received a vote in the Republican Presidential preference primaries today that was close to that polled by the leading candidates for State office on the party organization slate.

LONDON, April 11 -- Adolf Hitler has summoned a conference of Axis countries at Which Japan will be asked what "immediate effective assistance she is able to offer Germany," the Berne newspaper Bund said today in an article reported to Reuter.

CANBERRA, Australia, April 11 -- Newspapers are criticizing Army Minister F.M. Forde because of his announcement that the Australian Army will be reduced by 90,000 without explaining Australia's war commitments and thus, saving her from being placed in a false light overseas.

Two professors of Norwegian universities who are now refugees, have written a book interpreting their country's history and literature and emphasizing Norway's long democratic tradition. They are Halvdan Koht and Sigmund Skard. Dr. Koht was Norwegian Minister of Foreign Affairs at the time of the German invasion.

LONDON, April 11 -- Although the stock markets today here opened 'the week in a cheerful mood the turnover in most sections was small. The chief interest centered in the Kaffirs, which went ahead on Cape buying and talk of a higher price for gold.

Lenny Mancini, 143 1/2 pounds, Youngstown, Ohio, knocked out Tiger Nelson, 146 1/4, Washington, in 51 seconds of the first in their scheduled eight-round bout at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, last night. Nelson just failed to beat the count of ten after he had been floored by a left hook to the jaw.

Tranquility was restored to the racing scene at Jamaica yesterday, and matters went off without the faintest trace of unevenness. Although the attendance did not approach the record dimensions of the two previous programs, it was large enough to occasion surprise.

Paul Robeson, Negro actor and singer, declared yesterday afternoon in an interview that the temper of the American Negro had changed during this war and that the Negro now "wants his freedom." Mr. Robeson warned of the danger of exploitation of Africa after the war, and declared that we in this country must listen to President Roosevelt's interpretation of African affairs and not to Prime Minister Churchill's.

Economic progress in the post-war period will depend mainly on a realistic return to private enterprise and upon "the kind of world we are to live in after the war," according to industrial leaders who participated yesterday in a meeting sponsored by the Committee for Economic Development at the Hotel Biltmore.

Amendments to the Federal Constitution limiting the President to one six-year term, Senators to one six-year term and Representatives to three terms totaling six years were urged yesterday by A.H. Cosden, president of the Union League Club, in a letter sent to the club's 1,700 members and to a number of others.

An atmosphere of mutual trust and esteem has developed between the Icelandic people and American soldiers stationed there, the Most Rev. Sigurgeir Sigurdsson, Bishop of Iceland, declared yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel New Yorker given in his honor by the United Lutheran Church in America.

The fourth round was completed in the United States championship preliminaries at the Marshall Chess Club last night. The only adjourned game, in Group C, was played off, preparing the way for the games of the fifth and final round tonight.

Furs will be promoted more intensively than ever this year to offset the 20 per cent excise tax, according to the research division of Meyer Both Reports. Newspaper advertising will be the chief media. A survey revealed that 78 per cent of the department and specialty stores in the country contemplate a major fur promotion this fall and two-thirds of the stores will start in July.

Field Marshal Sir John Dill, senior British member of the Combined Chiefs of Staff, and James F. Byrnes, director of the Office of War Mobilization, will speak tonight at a semi-annual dinner meeting of the Academy of Political Science at the Hotel Astor. Lewis W. Douglas, president of the Academy and deputy administrator of the War Shipping Administration, will preside.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 11 -- This city will have a 1944 tax rate of $61.66 for each $1,000 of assessed valuation, according to an announcement by the Hudson County Tax Board. The rate is the highest in this city's history and it is believed to be the highest for any city of its size in the nation.

OMAHA, Neb., April 11 -- Lieut. Comdr. Harold E. Shassen maintained a wide lead over Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, write-in candidate, and Wendell Willkie tonight as the vote count of Nebraska's Presidential preference primary proceeded slowly.

Stone Webster, Inc., reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $1,733,343, or 82 cents a capital share, compared with a net of $2,478,029, or $1.18 a share, in 1942. Consolidated gross earnings were $13,130,897, or $1,775,534 less than the year before.

LONDON, April 11 -- Several British young people who have just returned home after living in the United States as evacuees "talked American" today in typically frank American terms at an Anglo-American youth conclave in a Westminster College hall.

While considerable criticism has been leveled by plastics molders against the recently issued Office of Price Administration regulation covering plastics products, G.K. Scribner, president of the Society of the Plastics Industry, Inc., yesterday defended the provisions of the order and voiced opposition to any attempt to have the order amended.

New York's quota for the Red Cross War Fund is short by two million and a quarter of dollars. So John P. Stevens Jr., general chairman, told the Mayor and the city yesterday. There are just four days in which to raise this sum. Raised it must be. Taxes are high, campaigns for war bonds are frequent.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 11 (AP) -- Pfc. Alec Thomas of Pittsburgh and Camp Mackall and Jim Fownes of the Fox Chappel Club of Pittsburgh played eight extra holes today in the opening round of the forty-fourth North and South amateur golf championship and had to quit because of darkness.

LONDON, April 11 (AP) -- A communique broadcast from the headquarters of Marshal Tito (Josip Broz) said tonight that Yugoslav Partisans had repulsed another attempt by the Germans to recapture Mrkonjicgrad in the Jajce area, but acknowledged that reinforced Germans had gained in a thunderous two-day battle in Slovenia.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, April 12 -- A fleet of American destroyers, protected by an umbrella of Lightning fighter planes, sailed boldly along thNew Guinea coast Monday, bombarding the Japanese bases of Hansa Bay, Madang and Alexishafen, already blasted by hundreds of tons of Allied bombs, it was revealed today.

"Lady in The Dark" today enters its eighth week at the Paramount thereby equaling the theatre's long-run record set by "Star Spangled Rhythm" in January and February, 1943. . . . "The Song of Bernadette" starts its twelfth week today at the Rivoli. . . . "Four Jills in a Jeep" begins a second week today.

MOSCOW, April 11 -- The demand of Marshal Tito [Josip Broz] for representation on the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration Council was published in the Russian press today in the form of a Tass dispatch from Istanbul, Turkey.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The future of synthetic rubber may be decided at the coming international oil conferences, the first of which, between representatives of the United States and British Governments, will begin in Washington next week.
Following is the Post-War Plan of the American Federation of Labor to be presented at the forum that opens at the Commodore today:

NAPLES, April 11 -- The most important Allied diplomatic and political officials in Italy spent today in private conferences somewhere near King Victor Emmanuel's villa, it was reported tonight, and there is considerable reason for suspecting that at least some of them spoke directly with the King, presumably on the subject of his possible retirement in the near future in favor of his son, Crown Prince Humbert.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- On Bougainville, a South Pacific "Miami Beach," where "you sit in an easy chair in a screened hut, listening to the radio and drinking cold beer, while the enemy's artillery shells whistle over your head," the visiting Marine general noticed a gang of Japanese prisoners in a stockade within sprinting distance of the commanding general's headquarters. The stockade gate was open.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Congress returns tomorrow from its ten-day holiday, facing a varied list of war and post-war economic problems, some of them controversial. These it has to solve before the expected longer summer recess for the political conventions and the campaign.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 11 -- The Yankees closed their visit to the seashore today with a display of fireworks. They were facing their first shut-out of the exhibition campaign with amazing docility on Bader Field until the eighth inning, when a noisy clatter of base hits, with a generous gesture by Note Andrews, enabled them to defeat the Braves, 5 to 4.

The Philadelphia Orchestra, under the baton of Eugene Ormandy, brought its New York season to a close at Carnegie Hall last night with an all-Brahms program and with Marian Anderson, the distinguished contralto, as soloist. It was an evening of serious music seriously played, and marked especially by a richness of tone production peculiar to the Philadelphia group.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Confidence in the final rout of Hitler's armies through decisive battles in which Americans will participate was voiced today by Andrei A. Gromyko, Russian Ambassador, in presenting through Secretary Hull decorations from the Soviet Government to members of the American armed forces and of the merchant marine.

Buyer registrations in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 752, against 597 in the preceding week and 986 in the like period of last year, according to the listing appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals numbered 527, which compared with 205 last Tuesday.

Harry Rosalinsky, 49 years old, of 3115 Brighton Fourth Street, Brooklyn, was sentenced to the Matteawan State Hospital for Criminal Insane yesterday by Kings County Judge Nathan R. Sobel after he had received a report from Bellevue Hospital psychiatrists that the defendant was mentally unbalanced.

This is presented in an attempt to clarify the question of whether service men need hunting and fishing licenses in New York State. The answer, given by Conservation Commissioner John A. White, is yes and no. The law was designed by the Legislature to aid visiting service men and at the same time help prevent undue pressure on the State's fish and game resources in areas near Army and Navy camps.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Following are the activities in industry which the Selective Service System designated today as of sufficient importance to warrant making exceptions to the general policy of drafting all qualified registrants under 26 years of age:

A violin and piano recital of unusual interest was given last night at Town Hall by Mischa Mischakoff and Nadia Reisenberg, playing together for the first time. The program consisted of the Beethoven Sonata in G major, Opus 30, No. 3; the Brahms Sonata in A major, Opus 100; the Schubert "Rondeau Brillante," Opus 70, and the Franck Sonata in A major.

Following the plea made by John P. Stevens Jr., general chairman of New York City's Red Cross 1944 War Fund campaign, to the people for "prompt and generous action" to assure success, the campaign was resumed with vigor yesterday throughout the five boroughs.

A Royal Air Force raid on Nuremberg, on the night of March 30-31, cost the British ninety-four aircraft. This is the biggest loss suffered by the Bomber Command in any single operation. It is estimated on good authority at 10 per cent of the forces involved in the undertaking.

WITH GENERAL EISENHOWER ON TOUR OF AIR BASES, in England, April 11 (U.P.) -- General Eisenhower expressed grim satisfaction today as he studied strike pictures taken by Ninth Air Force Marauders in recent attacks on railway yards at Creil, France, and Hasselt and Haine-St. Pierre, Belgium, important links in the Nazi defense system until Gen. Brereton's medium bombers hit them.

The dream of every novice writer -- fame and fortune on a first venture -has been realized by Dorothea Cornwell of Louisville, Ky., winner of the Redbook-Dodd, Mead $10,000 fiction prize, who is in New York to receive the award announced yesterday by the donors.

A strong demand for railroad issues sprang up yesterday but the remainder of the stock market, except in isolated instances, sagged into lower territory. The chemicals were beaten back for major losses although the pressure proved relatively light and the heavy industrials suffered fractional inroads.
LONDON, April 11 (AP) -- Has Army life cost Sgt. Joe Louis Barrow, in private life Heavyweight Champion Joe Louis, any of his fistic ability?

The management of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation intends to appeal to the State courts the recent refusal of the New York State Public Service Commission to permit the Niagara system subsidiaries to consolidate into a single operating unit, Earle J. Machold, president, informed stockholders yesterday at their annual meeting.

WITH LIEUTENANT GENERAL STILWELL'S FORCES in Upper Mogaung Valley, Burma, April 10 (Delayed) (AP) -- Aided by American-made tanks manned by American-trained crews working on the right flank, Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's Chinese troops have made substantial gains against Japanese units, which are resisting so desperately that several have attempted suicide when capture seemed imminent.

After an ownership of nearly sixty years the last remaining parcel of the old Ely farm in the lower Flatbush section of Brooklyn has been sold for the estate of Charles and Edward Ely. They purchased a tract of 180 acres in the late Eighties, when a large part of Flatbush was still a prosperous farming community.
NEW DELHI, India, April 11 (UP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, April 11 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Comdr. Harold E. Stassen is in the campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination "to the end" and will not withdraw before the national convention in June to climb aboard the bandwagon of Gov. Dewey of New York, Senator Joseph H. Ball of Minnesota, leader of the pro-Stassen forces, said tonight.

The first civilian Chinese to be naturalized here since the Chinese exclusion acts were repealed last December renounced his British citizenship yesterday and was sworn in as an American by Federal Judge John C. Knox. He is Dr. Rupert C. Sancho, 45 years old, of 59 West Seventy-first Street. His Spanish name is a result of his Roman Catholic religion and his birth in Trinidad.

"Tomorrow's Home Designed for Tomorrow's Living' is the subject of the fourth annual Institute of the Decorators Club, which opened yesterday at the Parsons School Auditorium with a session devoted to architecture. The speakers included Jedd Reisner, New York architect; Harwell Hamilton Harris, Los Angeles architect, and Mary Davis Gillies, House Furnishings Editor of McCall's Magazine.

The show that Altman assembled yesterday morning was workmanlike, practical and good-looking. The models were shown on a stage, erected at one end of the Charleston gardens. The clothes were for summer wear, and took in everything from evening gowns (ginghams lightly sprinkled with sequins) to bathing suits -- the briefest things imaginable, with bra and shorts hand-painted in brightly colored flowers.
Mrs. Tobin Clark, who had been staying at the Savoy-Plaza left yesterday for her home in San Mateo, Calif.
The address of Breckinridge Long, Assistant Secretary of State, before the AFL Forum on Labor and the Post-War World last night follows:

Far too few women use soap in cleansing the skin, according to foremost dermatologists. It seems that the ever-growing popularity of cleansing creams over the last twenty years has made women forget almost entirely the virtues of plain soap and water.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 12 (AP) -- Forty-four officers and men were reported missing and twenty-six rescued when the Standard Oil tanker H.D. Collier was sunk by an enemy submarine in the Arabian Sea in March, the Twelfth Naval District announced today.

ALBANY, April 12 -- Governor Dewey signed today without comment the bill providing for a legislative study of racial and religious discrimination. A commission will be named by the Governor to make recommendations to the 1945 Legislature.

Sgt. Barney Ross, marine hero of Guadalcanal, said last night he had been advised that his discharge from the corps had arrived, but that it would be several days before he could be mustered out into civilian life, according to The United Press.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (UP) -- A Pacific Fleet announcement:

The A.F. Roe Company acted as brokers in the recent sale of the thirty-family apartment house at 137-9 Kensington Avenue in Jersey City for the Provident Institution for Savings to the 137-39 Kensington Avenue Corporation.
NAPLES, April 12 -- It is now permissible to indicate the nature of the propaganda appeals that the Germans have been directing at American troops in the beachhead below Rome and the Cassino front.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission denied today the petition of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company for reconsideration and re-argument of its application to issue $76,573,700 of preference stock (series of 1943) as a stock dividend to holders of common stock on the basis of one-tenth share of preference for each common share held.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- It was reported today on usually good authority that Vice President Henry A. Wallace would visit not only Chungking in the late spring or early summer, as his office has announced, but would also take a swing around the capitals of others of the United Nations.
NEW DELHI, India, April 12 (AP) -- A. communique:

LONDON, April 12 -- Germany has been forced to scrap her economic treaty with Japan, signed in Berlin with fanfare fifteen months ago, it was stated here today by experts familiar with the success of the Allied blockade by sea and air.

LONDON, April 12 -- The destruction of the railroad system of northern France and Belgium and German airfields in the same area, which constitute two of the foundations of the enemy's anti-invasion strategy, was continued today with Marauders of the United States Ninth Air Force leading the assault.

Organized labor can be proud of the statesmanlike quality of the post-war program submitted to the American Federation of Labor yesterday by a committee headed by Matthew Woll. With most of the specific recommendations few thoughtful Americans will quarrel.

North American production of newsprint during March fell off slightly compared with the similar month of last year, while shipments declined somewhat more heavily and stocks remained almost the same, the News Print Service Bureau revealed yesterday.

LONDON, Thursday, April 13 (U.P.) -- dicattng that the German might be attempting to evacuate f some troops from the Crimea, Soviet planes bombed the Rumaniar port of Constanta, closest port to the Crimea, Tuesday night, set-i ring huge fires in the port district, rail centers and oil depots.

The opening day of the New Jersey trout season on Saturday will also be the first day of the fourth annual New Jersey Governors fishing tournament, according to an announcement from Trenton yesterday. Both salt and fresh-water species may be entered in the contest, which is again sponsored by the New Jersey Council.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange continued its moderate advance last month, going to 1,028,489 shares from 960,617 at the end of February. Short positions in the odd-lot accounts of odd-lot dealers, excluded from both totals, were virtually unchanged, being 34,923 shares at the end of March and 34,322 at the end of February.

The ten clerks of the Ninth District Municipal Court at 152 East Fifty-seventh Street have so little work to do that they spend most of their time playing pinochle, President Justice Keyes Winter told the Board of Estimate yesterday at the last of three public hearings at City Hall on Mayor La Guardia's executive budget of $737,333,148 for 1944-45.
CHICAGO, April 12 (AP) -- Leaders of both major parties found signs today of a November victory in the results of the State primary election yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- Republicans split ranks today as two Senators broke away from their party's stand for adoption of the drastic cloture rule to balk an expected Southern filibuster against anti-poll tax legislation.

I read both your editorial and Vice President Wallace's article in last Sunday's TIMES Magazine and should like, first of all, to thank THE TIMES for making available Mr. Wallace's article and definitions on fascism and, secondly, I should like to take issue with your editorial on the same.

As the Red Cross 1944 War Fund campaign to raise the $2,250,000 needed to reach the city quota of $22,386,000 continued yesterday, announcement that the Manhattan block canvass section had raised $847,412 was made by W. Lawrence McLane, chairman.

Qualification of nine aspirants who will meet the same number of seeded experts in the United States chess championship finals, Saturday at the Park Central, was completed last night when the games in the fifth and last round of the preliminaries were played off at the Manhattan and Marshall chess clubs and the federation headquarters in Brooklyn.

Opposing proposals to pay dismissal wages to war workers, James F. Byrnes, Director of War Mobilization, declared last night that he favored enactment of a Federal demobilization law that would provide Federal payments to supplement existing State unemployment benefits during the period of transition from war to peace.

LONDON, April 12 -- More than 500 enemy vessels are known to have been sunk or damaged by mines dropped from British bombers on a 1,300-mile front extending from the Bay of Biscay to the Gulf of Danzig on the Baltic Sea. This outstanding success was announced tonight by the Air Ministry.

CHUNGKING, China, April 12 -- P.H. Chang, counselor of the Executive Yuan, denied that the Government intended to control the thought of Chinese students going abroad when he was questioned at his press conference today.

TOLEDO, Ohio, April 12 (AP) -- A net profit of $2,412,470, equivalent to 95 cents a share, in the first quarter of this year, was reported today to the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company at its annual meeting by John D. Biggers, president. He said this was after all taxes but before renegotiation.

NAPLES, April 12 -- After a week's inactivity following their strong attacks on Budapest, Bucharest and Ploesti, the United States Fifteenth Air Force's heavy bombers renewed the offensive today against sources of Nazi air power with a blow "in great strength" on the Messerschmitt production center at Wiener Neustadt, Austria.
Several town houses in Manhattan passed to new owners in deals reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- The Congressional Medal of Honor has been awarded to Major Gregory Boyington of Okanogan, Wash., 31-year-old Marine ace missing in action after shooting down twenty-six Japanese fighter planes. He was the second American flier to tie the record of planes shot down by Captain Eddie Rickenbacker in the first World War.

In connection with your excellent criticism of Vice President Wallace's use of the term "fascism," I should like to quote (from the New English Weekly of London, Dec. 9, 1943) a definition of this term which was given in a context discussing the case of Sir Oswald Mosley:

For the first time since the twin ballet seasons by the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo and the Ballet Theater opened, last night's schedule was free from premieres and both companies could get down to good, straight dancing. The results, or those sections of them seen by this reviewer, were definitely on the bright side.

LONDON, April 12 (AP) -- Widening the scope of his mission, United States Under-Secretary of State Edward R. Stettinius Jr. today conferred with Fedor T. Guseff, Soviet Ambassador to Britain -- probably to discuss the position of the tottering Axis satellites -- and then established contact with diplomatic representatives of six exiled Governments.

The epic story of the cruiser Marblehead, which limped home after battle for 14,000 miles, 4,000 of them without a rudder, will be the subject of a new book by George Sessions Perry and Isabel Leighton called "Where Away: The Odyssey of the Marblehead."

MOSCOW, Thursday, April 13 -- A forty-three-mile advance in the Crimea to within eleven miles of the capital, Simferopol, the capture of Tiraspol and the last important German-held positions on the left bank of the Dniester River were the highlights of yesterday's news in Moscow's communique.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) --The end of the war is not yet in sight, the House Appropriations Committee has been told by naval leaders.

Almost at the end of a season given over mainly to trivialities -- some of them charming, of course -- Lillian Hellman finally has brought the theatre down to eases. In her latest play, "The Searching Wind," she is exploring the current state of the world and the causes which brought about its miserable condition.

The General Motors Corporation has provided re-employment for 13,000 rehabilitated service men, it was revealed here yesterday in an interview in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria by Dr. C.D. Selby of Detroit, who coordinates the health program for the corporation's 116 plants in the United States.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 12 (AP) -- King George II of Greece promised today for the first time to establish a Government "largely composed of Greeks who have lived in their country under enemy occupation." It was the King's first statement since returning yesterday to Cairo, the seat of his exiled regime, for an effort to solve the Greek political crisis.

Some irregularity attended price movements on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. The market closed steady, 2 points higher to 10 points lower than on Tuesday, with the March position showing relative easiness.

The concealment of selective service records of her fiance in the hope of delaying his induction, brought 26-year-old Mrs. Carmela Topazio of Yonkers a sixty-day jail term yesterday. The penalty was imposed by Judge Alfred C. Coxe in Federal court.

ATLANTA, April 12 -- Pointing out that cotton textile requirements for 1944 might well exceed output by two billion yards, Donald M. Nelson, chairman War Production Board, today called upon millmen to "inch up" on production by every means which managerial skill can devise to overcome the "extremely serious situation" that looms ahead.
CHICAGO, April 12 -- More than 1,000 employes of Montgomery Ward Co., mail order and retail concern, struck today and set up picket lines at the company's plant on the North Side.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- A limited increase in the production of replacement parts for trucks and buses will be permitted to "keep essential civilian transport in operation," the War Production Board announced today.

BALTIMORE, April 12 (AP) -- Pensive, one of the triple crown hopes from the Calumet Farm of Warren Wright, scored his first stakes triumph today with a nose decision in thirteenth Rowe Memorial Handicap before 15,331 persons at the opening of a twenty-eight day meeting at Pimlico.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- In what appeared to be sharply divergent actions, the War Production Board today cut back the program for the proposed manufacture of 2,000,000 electric flatirons for civilian use to a maximum of 200,000, and at the same time announced that it was undertaking on April 17 another survey to determine what items of household and durable goods of which consumers are particularly short at the present time.

PHILADELPHIA, April 12 (AP) -- The long-postponed oral argument attacking the legality of price-maintenance agreements in the underwriting and sale of securities issues was held before the Securities and Exchange Commission today, with counsel for the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., the Department of Justice, an intervenor, and the SEC participating in the six-hour session.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Carrying his fight to the House today for continuance of the Price Control Act in substantially its present form, Chester Bowles, head of the Office of Price Administration, warned the Banking Committee that price control would be "blasted" and price chaos would ensue if three proposed amendments were adopted.

Regulated competition under private ownership and management, but with government super-vision to protect the national security and the public interest, is the program of the seventeen domestic air lines fighting for the right to participate in this nation's share of post-war international air transport.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
LONDON, April 12 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Theodore Roosevelt Jr., who went through the North African campaign and later served in Italy, is in Britain recovering from a severe illnesss.

! 1VIen between the ages of 26 and 38 were warned yesterday by Col. Arthur V. McDermott, city Selec- tire Service director, not to ex- pect'permanent draft deferment to result from Washington's latest instructions. Meanwhile, 280 local boards in the five boroughs speeded up the processing for induction of men under 26.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 12 -- Barbara Stanwyck, who recently completed the starring role in "My Reputation" for Warner Brothers, has been named by the studio for the lead in "Christmas in Connecticut," Aileen Hamilton's comedy about a newspaper columnist and her soldier sweetheart.

Discarded pieces of furniture can become attractive additions to the home if householders follow Peter Hunt's advice and give them a coat of bright-colored paint plus one of his simple peasant designs. Mr. Hunt gave a demonstration yesterday of the ease with which this transformation can be achieved at the Sherry-Netherland Hotel under the auspices of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., April 12 -- A strange air of peace and serenity has settled over this famous spa. The birds chirp cheerfully and not a wisp of a storm cloud hovers overhead. Jimmy Dykes has departed. The lethargic leader of the not very lethargic White Sox has hauled his heroes off to Chicago, but before he departed he sprayed the landscape with a few last harpoons.

Herbert L. Bruce, Tammany leader of the old Twenty-first Assembly district, announced yesterday that he would not support the Rev. Dr. Adam Clayton Powell for Congress "under any circumstances because he believed that the Representative from a Negro district should not be a "Communist-controlled rabble-rouser" who might foment racial discord.

The letter by B.R. Robbins in THE TIMES of April 10, suggesting a new scheme for subway fares, reminds me of the early days of the old steam-engined elevated roads on the Second, Third and Ninth Avenue lines.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Final touches were being added today to a plan for reorganizing the War Production Board to shape it for the task of dealing with the problems of reconverting war industry to civilian production.

Frank V. Kelly, who has been Democratic leader of Brooklyn for ten years, was re-elected yesterday for another two-year term when the members of the Kings County Democratic Executive Committee met in the Jefferson Building, 4-5 Court Square.

The most authoritative pronouncement on the role of airpower, all the more important because it will determine Allied invasion strategy, has just been made by General Eisenhower. In "briefing" American fighter pilots at their British bases he declared that the land army can do nothing until the airmen have knocked out the German air force.

THE NEW YORK TIMES has given prominence and considerable editorial comment in its issues of April 2, April 3 and April 4 to an account by Will Lissner of an article, "Political Economy in the Soviet Union," from the Russian periodical Pod Znamenem Marksizma, whose essential parts I translated for the spring issue of Science and Society.

While net income of the Western Union Telegraph Company in the first two months of this year increased to $1,075,000 from $375,000 in the same period a year ago, it is unlikely that such a showing will continue, A.N. Williams, president, told shareholders yesterday at their annual meeting. Part of the increase, he said, reflected the business acquired by the merger with Postal Telegraph, Inc.
The Polo Grounds today will be the scene of a major league preview that promises to attract a banner crowd.

LONDON, April 12 -- Business on today's stock markets remained small but values were well maintained. The chief interest was among the diamond shares, prices of which showed fresh gains on the issuance of the De Beers report.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 12 -- Informed Stockholm political circles refused today to become too alarmed over the talks of British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and United States Under-Secretary of State Edward R. Stettinius Jr. even though they followed hard on the heels of Secretary of State Cordell Hull's appeal to neutrals to cease helping the Axis powers.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Officially Congress returned today from its Easter holiday, but with fewer than a quorum present in either chamber, the sessions were devoted to brief speeches and introduction of bills and reports.

TRENTON, April 12 -- As the Legislature met today to bring to a close its annual session, Gov. Walter E. Edge's Commission on State Administrative Reorganization submitted three bills to consolidate in one department seven boards and agencies having to do with New Jersey's educational and cultural services.

The soft drink industry's post-war advertising expenditures will break all past records as the country's 6,000 soft drink manufacturers undertake to restore normal distribution, according to Thomas Moore, Minneapolis soft drink manufacturer and chairman of the public relations committee of the American Bottlers of Carbonated Beverages.

It took a jockey wearing Cinderella slippers, with a game horse under him and a weight concession of eighteen pounds, to defeat Col. C.V. Whitney's Kentucky Derby favorite, Pukka Gin, who was making his 1944 debut at Jamaica yesterday.

NAPLES, April 12 -- The Germans kept punching on the Cassino front yesterday, with particular and understandable pressure on Castle Hill, where the Allies retain a bastion challenging the dominating enemy heights of Abbey Hill.

A floor in the building at 221 West Fifty-seventh Street has been leased by the Pratt Secretarial School, which will move there on April 24 from its present quarters in 400 Madison Avenue. Byrne, Bowman Forshay arranged the lease. Other leases of business quarters follow:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, Naples, April 12 (AP) -- Second Lieut. Ernest Childers, 26-year-old sharp-shooting Indian from Broken Arrow, Okla., received his country's highest award today, the Congressional Medal of Honor, given only once before in the Italian campaign.

LONDON, April 12 -- The British public was warned today there would be big changes in the distribution of food when the invasion of the Continent started, as troop and armament movements would interfere considerably with the general transport of foodstuffs.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Mrs. Roosevelt made to her press conference today a report on her husband's health and his heavy responsibilities. She thought he needed a vacation some time ago, was glad he was getting one now, and predicted that he will return from his treatment of sunshine somewhere in the South "in better condition than when he left."

Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and Estabrook Co. head an underwriting group which will offer today 230,000 shares of the American Optical Company's no-par common stock at $32.25 a share, a total of $7,417,500. The offering comprises 167,490 newly issued shares and 62,510 outstanding shares, owned by ten vender trusts.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, will consult on international affairs with the members of the House as well as those of the Senate, he told the Speaker of the House, Sam Rayburn, in a telephone conversation this morning.

OMAHA, April 12 (AP) -- Strong support of Lieut. Comdr. Harold E. Stassen, winner in the Nebraska Republican Presidential preferential primary, by perhaps six of the State's fifteen convention delegates was indicated tonight in compilation of unofficial returns on the delegate vote.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., April 12 -- Winding up their spring training here with a three-hour workout today in the West Point field house, when the cold and rain prevented all outdoor activity, thirty-one Dodgers prepared to hop off for Ebbets Field early tomorrow.

NAPLES, April 12 -- King Victor Emmanuel announced today that he had finally and irrevocably decided to withdraw from public affairs in favor of his son, Crown Prince Humbert, on the day when the Allies' troops enter Rome.

NEW DELHI, India, April 12 -- Counter-attacking British and Indian troops have eased Japanese pressure around Kohima in eastern India, it was announced today amid mounting belief that the entire Japanese force invading India was being caught in a gigantic Allied trap and might face eventual extermination.

Wine industry inventory and production figures indicate another year of shortages of California wines, according to a study by the Wine Institute, which yesterday stated that stocks of both table and dessert wines on hand in California bonded wineries and storerooms at the end of 1943 were slightly less than for the same date a year previously.

A thousand girls eager to join Camp Fire groups must remain on the inactive list for lack of leaders, Mrs. Grace Eberhardt, executive director of the organization's Greater New York Council, said yesterday. Women from 18 years old up who like children and "have the patience to work with them" are sought by the council to act as group leaders after six two-hour instruction periods.

The stock market followed yesterday the line of least resistance, and although the list on the New York Stock Exchange was not subjected to more than normal pressure, losses ran from fractions to more than a point in the higher-price issues.

CHICAGO, April 12 (AP) -- Federal Judge Michael L. Igoe today began hearing the suit of five residents of this city, who alleged that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation had deprived stockholders of the Maryland Casualty Company of their rights by gaining control of the company through a series of loans.

GREAT MEADOWS, N.J., April 12 -- Yielding to public protest over his employment of five Japanese-American laborers supplied by the War Relocation Authority, Edward Kowalick, 23-year-old farmer here, agreed today to dismiss the workers by Saturday.

When Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas was chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, he came forth with a suggestion for underwritings which was debated hotly. He wanted what he called "real underwritings," with the enterprisers representing large blocks of investment trust-type capital and with price-fixing agreements outlawed. Almost seven years later, the SEC is moving along these lines.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Bolstered by a favorable committee report, the Navy Department appropriations bill for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1945, was submitted today to the House of Representatives, incorporating contemplated expenditures to the unprecedented total of $32,647,134,336.

Meeting yesterday at the National Democratic Club, the New York Democratic State Committee unanimously re-elected James A. Farley for an eighth term as State chairman and unanimously approved a resolution calling for President Roosevelt's continued direction of America's contributions toward winning the war.

The story of how one Flying Fortress, on a mission over Bremen, destroyed nine German fighter planes and destroyed or damaged six others, a near-record according to War Department files, was related yesterday by Staff Sgt. Edward S. Yevich, an Eighth Air Force waist gunner.

NEW DELHI, April 12 (U.P.) -- Opening a long-expected westward push from their Salween River bridgehead in Yunnan Province, Chinese troops have captured heights overlooking the terminus of a seventy-five-mile highway to the Burma city of Myitkyina and are a similar distance from Allied units driving down through north Burma from Iidia, a Chungking dispatch disclosed tonight.

The announcement by King Victor Emmanuel III of his intention "to withdraw from public life," though not to abdicate, as soon as the Allied armies enter Rome follows by a few days a conference of Allied diplomatic representatives in Naples. It is denied that Allied pressure was exerted to bring about this move.

Meat and grocery prices in current newspaper advertisements were compared yesterday with those of a year ago by Daniel P. Woolley, regional Administrator of the Office of Price Administration, in support of his contention that the cost of living in the metropolitan area was "down a little" from what it was twelve months ago.

Charging the Office of Price Administration with violation of the Price Control Act in not allowing adequate margins to meat wholesalers in New York, Joseph Cohn, counsel of the Meat Trade Institute, yesterday sent a letter of protest to Price Administrator Bowles.
LONDON, April 12 (UP) -- A German communique as broadcast from Berlin:

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Less than half of an estimated 350,000 Selective Service registrants under 26 who are engaged in activities listed yesterday as indispensable to the prosecution of the war can look forward to continued deferment from military service, it developed today.

WITH THE PACIFIC FLEET, April 7 (Delayed) -- Units of the big fleet that raided Palau and other Caroline bases of the enemy have retired from enemy territory as peacefully as if returning from a tourist cruise and are now at their bases awaiting the next assignment.
Yesterday's city-wide collection of waste paper by the Department of Sanitation fell to 485 tons, far below the average of 600 tons previously maintained.

Handel's opera, "Julius Caesar," was performed in concert form at Town Hall last night by a capable aggregation of musicians under the able direction of Ernst Gebert. Aside from the purely musical interest of the occasion it was a performance which deserves considerable praise for the care and intelligence with which the work was prepared and the expressiveness and sensitivity with which it was given.

Elsewhere on this page we publish a letter by the translator of part of an article from the Russian periodical Pod Znamenem Marxizma contending that this newspaper in a news report and in editorial comment has presented a misleading idea of the substance of that article.

Your editorial on the protest of a group of Harvard professors against a decision of the Chinese Government to establish control over young Chinese who come to this country to study suggests the possibility that China is drifting toward fascism. This action of the Chinese Government is not evidence of a totalitarian policy.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- When the umpire cries "play ball!" this summer, American troops overseas will be transplanted to the scenes of the major league games via short wave radio, the War Department announced today.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 12 -- The State War Ballot Commission rejected today a move made by the Democratic party to liberalize the rules for soldier voting in the State. Friends and relatives of soldier voters, under the plan proposed, could apply for ballots for the soldiers and Federal ballots received from soldiers who had not mailed State ballots would be accepted at the polls.

Dollar sales of the General Foods Corporation in the first quarter of 1944 were 12 per cent ahead of those in the same period of 1943, Clarence Francis, chairman of the board, said at the annual meeting of stockholders here yesterday. Net earnings for the period were about 66 cents a common share, against 65 cents a share, in the first quarter of last year.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- At least a dozen women technical advisers will be on hand next week in Philadelphia to furnish factual background to their delegations on problems before the International Labor Conference.

NAPLES, April 12 -- A shake-up of high Neapolitan officials largely based on Lieut. Col. Charles Poletti's conviction that stronger measures are needed to rid Italy of fascism, will formally begin tomorrow, when Francesco Selvaggi will succeed Enrico Cavaliere provincial prefect, it was learned tonight.

PEARL HARBOR, April 12 -- Army Air Force Liberators from the Aleutians went deep into the Kurile Islands Monday to bomb Japanese bases at Onnekotan and Matsuwa, the latter 960 miles from Tokyo and 500 miles northeast of the Japanese home island of Hokkalto.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- President Roosevelt today nominated Joseph P. Marcelle of Brooklyn to be Collector of Internal Revenue for the First District of New York to succeed Joseph D. Nunan Jr., who was recently appointed Commissioner of Internal Revenue.

Appropriately enough, with rival ballets in progress at the Metropolitan Opera House and the New York City Center, a large exhibition, "Five Centuries of Ballet," opened with a fashionable preview last evening at the Wildenstein Galleries, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street.

In an address last night at the Hotel Commodore before the American Federation of Labor forum on labor and the post-war world, Breckinridge Long, Assistant Secretary of State, gave assurance that the United States would not deviate from the announced purpose of seeking a just and durable peace.

The nation's gasoline stocks at the close of last week were 88, 011,000 barrels, a decline of 1,151, 000 from the 89,162,000 a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A year ago, they were 93,410,000 barrels.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (U.P.) -- The National Labor Relations Board promised men in the services tonight that when they return to their jobs they will have a chance to "affirm or change" the selection of a union bargaining representative chosen during their absence.

PANAMA, April 12 -- Gen. Maximiliano Hernandez Martinez, President of El Salvador, suppressed the revolt that started April 2 and had complete control within forty-eight hours, although there were several thousand casualties, according to information received here.

The Institute of Carpet Manufacturers of America yesterday adopted a standard color card containing from ten to twelve basic colors for use in floor coverings, styles and patterns as the first concrete step in the rug and carpet industry's plans for better post-war merchandising of its products. The colors were developed by the organization's color committee, of which William Brown of Alexander Smith Sons Carpet Company is chairman.

In the report of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, operator of various department stores, released for publication today, Robert J. McKim, president, notes that sales for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31, at the record total of $92,365,833, were 15.6 per cent above the volume of $79,931,136 in the preceding year.

Robert Montgomery, 34 years old, who on April 1 was appointed a temporary policeman and assigned to the Police Academy, was a bewildered man yesterday in Special Sessions. He merely muttered, "Gee," when sentenced to three months in the workhouse for stealing a $24 radio in 1936.

A new course to train adults as group recreation leaders for 'teenage boys and girls is being offered by the Sixth Precinct Coordinating Council, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Mary K. Simkhovitch, director of Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street.

Declaring "the magnificent war cooperation record of the American republics gives us tremendous promise for the future," Nelson A. Rockefeller, Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, asserted last night that "with intelligent planning and continuation of the determined spirit of cooperation" the American nations could develop a pattern of uninterrupted progress in the development of their material and spiritual riches.

Three new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At the Capitol the attraction will be "Broadway Rhythm," a musical produced by Metro. George Murphy, Ginny Simms, Charles Winninger, Lena Horne, Gloria De Haven, Ben Blue, Nancy Walker, Eddie (Rochester) Anderson, Hazel Scott and Kenny Bowers are among the featured players....

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 12 -- The Finnish Parliament was reliably reported tonight to have given the Government a vote of confidence during the day's second secret session after Premier Edwin Linkomies outlined the Cabinet's view of the latest Russian armistice proposals.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 12 -The scene of so many of Adolf Hitler's triumphal mistakes, Vienna, has been chosen by him for another conference of his Quisling leaders that may well turn out to be the last meeting of the wavering satellites before the battle of Germany gets under way.

For the third day, 5,000 employes of the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Company yard at Hoboken, N.J., refused to work two hours overtime yesterday after they had finished their regular shift. Word had reached headquarters of Local 15, Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, that negotiations at the company's office, 25 Broadway, New York, had failed to resolve the dispute over the "coffee-time" period.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The "big four" of the Administration's fight against inflation were accused today by Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, of telling President Roosevelt one thing in their report of April 7 on successfully "holding the line," while giving the public "a totally different story" in previous "announcements and acts."

WELLINGTON, N.Z., April 12 -- A widespread health plan covering the western and southern Pacific has been prepared by the Fijian Government, which is now seeking the cooperation of other administrations in applying it after the war.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations has refused President Roosevelt's request that it submit the names of three representatives for nomination as technical labor advisers at the forthcoming conference of the International Labor Organization in Philadelphia on April 20.

ALBANY, April 12 -- David Dows of Locust Valley, L.I., today became a member of the State Racing Commission by appointment of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey. He succeeds Col. John Hay Whitney, who resigned last year. Dows will serve the remainder of Whitney's term until May 1 and then begin a six-year term.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Attorney General Biddle has reopened the investigation by the Department of Justice into charges that the political action committee of the CIO had violated criminal provisions of the Connally-Smith Strike Control Act by accepting campaign contributions from CIO unions, it was disclosed today.

Acting upon that education law which says that the funds for our city's colleges are to be determined by the enrollment, Mayor La Guardia has cut more than $400,000 from the higher education budget. It is true that the student registration has declined and that City College, in particular, has suffered a 26 per cent decrease.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -National banks last year had net profits of $350,457,000 before dividends, an increase of 44 per cent, or $107,114,000 over 1942, Preston Delano, Controller of the Currency reported tonight.

LONDON, April 12 -- A statement by a Royal Air Force commentator today that the first-line fighter strength of the German Air Force has increased by about 250 planes since last November is arousing considerable comment in London tonight.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 12 -- Under the caption "the art of waiting" the Voelkischer Beobachter of Berlin explains why the German High Command has been fighting on the defensive in the East for more than a year.

The exigencies of summer were met attractively in the fashion show presented yesterday by Arnold Constable at the Waldorf-Astoria. In a collection that included clothes for play, for hot days in town and for summer nights, no one was neglected.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses yesterday decried the decreasing ranks of men willing to do "constructive public work," declaring that "for every person willing to work, there are a hundred ready to attend meetings and write papers."

Whenever in the course of human events the American people find themselves confronted with a glut of eggs and potatoes it is in the national tradition to organize a Potato Week, beginning next Monday, and an Egg Week, beginning the following Monday.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Application of strict quotas to drug stores in any locality in which there is evidence of the diversion of narcotics to illegitimate channels was provided for today by the Treasury to safeguard the drug supply for military purposes.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, April 13 (AP) -- Escorted heavy bombers followed up Monday's heavy naval and air assault on Hansa Bay with a 210-ton bombing the next day, causing considerable damage at that Japanese base on the northeast coast of New Guinea.

Rolland B. Marvin, Onondaga Republican leader, and Wendell L. Willkie conferred for an hour yesterday in Mr. Willkie's offices at 15 Broad Street after agreeing at the outset to refrain from discussing the contest for the Republican Presidential nomination and the personalities involved in it.

CHICAGO, April 12 -- A combination of clear skies, higher temperatures and official comment that rain recently had been very beneficial for the winter wheat crop, especially in western Kansas, led today to scattered selling of the deferred deliveries of wheat on the Chicago Board of Trade and gave the market an easy undertone.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Federal buying organizations and labor-supervising agencies began a concerted campaign today against fake "engineering service" companies which exist only to supply contract labor unobtainable otherwise to Government contractors at fees in excess of allowable wage rates.
NAPLES, April 12 -- The text of King Victor Emmanuel's statement follows:

GREAT books can sometimes be pernicious books, and I fear that Karl Polyani's "The Great Transformation" belongs to this category. For this beautifully written essay in the revaluation of a hundred and fifty years of history adds up to a subtle appeal for a new feudalism, a new slavery, a new status of economy that will tie men to their places of abode and their jobs.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Two of the three members of the President's committee named to determine the facts regarding portal-to-portal travel time of bituminous coal miners made a second interim report today which drew charges of "half-truths" from Thomas Kennedy, secretary-treasurer of the United Mine Workers, the third member.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Republican Senators are indignant over the failure of President Roosevelt to sign the appointment of Senator Homer T. Bone, Democrat of Washington, to a place on the Circuit Court of Appeals, which the Senate confirmed unanimously scarcely two hours after it was submitted to them April 1.

LONDON, April 12 (U.P.) -- The Allies carried out a two-front offensive against a main Nazi communication line in the Balkans today when large forces of American heavy bombers smashed at enemy positions in western Yugoslavia, and Marshal Tito, in an order of the day, summoned 50,000 Serb Partisans to an all-out attack "to help our allies."
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, April 13 (AP) -- A communique:
SEATTLE, April 12 (AP) -- Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio, seeking the Republican Presidential nomination, asserted today that he did not think a business slump was inevitable after the war.

A UNITED STATES BOMBER BASE in England, April 12 (AP) -- A freak accident that left six live bombs tumbling around loose in the bomb bay made a hero of Lieut. James W. Murray, 22, a Fortress bombardier, from 455 Eighth Street, Brooklyn, on his first mission.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Industry members of the President's Cost-of-Living Committee made public today a report of the National Industrial Conference Board challenging the validity of the cost-of-living report made by the committee's two labor members, and, in general, supporting the findings of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Before leaving for Miami a week ago, J.J. Shubert acquired from Capt. Jefferson Davis Cohn the rights to "Ball at the Savoy," an operetta by Alfred Gruenwald and Fritz Loehner-Bada, it was learned yesterday. Mr. Shubert, who is reported quite enthused over his acquisition, is expected to return in about ten days to start production activities.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (U.P.) -- New neuro-surgical techniques for treating sciatica, which has become serious among soldiers, are sending about 60 per cent of the afflicted men back to duty.

To effect the release of several million yards of cotton and rayon textiles purchased in the last quarter of 1944 but held up by export restrictions, Cuban business men have sent an expediting commission to this country, it was learned yesterday.

Nearly everything, from the Giants' viewpoint, was a washout yesterday. Rain prevented them from playing the Army Air Base team at Newark Airport, besides canceling the scheduled morning workout at the Polo Grounds.

WITH ALLIED FORCES IN NORTHERN BURMA, April 10 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's Chinese forces, spurred on by the slogan "We'll be in Myitkyina by May," are fanning out in a steady southward drive through north Burma, with the worst terrain behind them.

In a three-way crackdown on "hidden" price increases in the garment industry, the Office of Price Administration announced yesterday the filing of a $218,110 treble damage action and an injunction suit against a women's wear manufacturer accused of skimping on material and workmanship; the payment of a $40,000 treble damage claim by another large concern, and the start of injunction proceedings against twenty-five jobbers of paper boxes.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Though the vote in the Republican preference primary in Illinois was light -- something more than half the week-day circulation of The Chicago Tribune, as recorded by Editor Publisher last January -- it far exceeded in numbers similar polls in New Hampshire, Wisconsin and Nebraska, the only others conducted thus far in the Presidential campaign of 1944.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, April 14 (AP) -- Well over 200 American bombers and fighters hit Hollandia, Netherland New Guinea, Wednesday with 322 tons of bombs and 89,000 rounds of machine gun and cannon fire, sinking a 2,000-ton freighter and setting fire to nine smaller vessels.

Furniture dealers are besieging manufacturers for maximum allotments of merchandise and are attempting to purchase from new sources of supply despite the long standing manufacturers' quota system. They are concerned about the serious supply shortages which will result from a probable curtailment of lumber allocations for end users of consumer durable goods which all sections of the trade new regard as "practically certain," market observers stated yesterday.
LONDON, April 13 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 13 -- Warner Brothers will co-star Paul Lukas, Helmut Dantine and Geraldine Fitzgerald in a remake of the play, "The Petrified Forest," which the company produced in 1938 with Leslie Howard and Bette Davis.

MOSCOW, April 13 -- In a statement to the Moscow News, Andrzej Witos, vice chairman of the Union of Polish Patriots, said today that thousands of Poles in the western Ukraine are volunteering for the Polish Army in Russia.

Joseph P. Day, real estate broker, appraiser and auctioneer, who died last Tuesday in the Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital at the age of 70, left his estate in trust for the benefit of his children and the issue of any child who may be deceased.

Arrangements for the New York Yacht Club's distance race on Long Island Sound this summer, which will mark its resumption of racing since it was shelved because of the war, were completed yesterday by the committee appointed by Commodore George E. Roosevelt.

A survey of city markets this week-end indicates that the number of fresh fruits available is still decidedly limited as compared with pre-war years. Bananas, the War Food Administration tells us, are hard to come by, and are selling at ceiling prices.

Increased competition from local and sectional brands of food products emphasizes why national advertisers must use local newspapers to maintain consumer loyalty, according to American Association of Newspaper Representatives.

LONDON, April 13 -- United States Under-Secretary of State Edward R. Stettinius Jr. spent a busy day conferring with British officials in a broad survey of policy today, amid mounting evidence of a toughening attitude on the part of this country toward neutrals and nations tied nominally at least with Britain who are, as Secretary of State Cordell Hull said, still supplying the enemy with war materials to kill Allied soldiers.

Salvador Ocampo, secretary of the Confederation of Chilean Workers and a delegate to the International Labor Organization meeting next week in Philadelphia and to the Congress of World Trade Unions in London next June, said yesterday the workers of Central and South America were surprised to learn that the American Federation of Labor had decided not to participate in the London conference.

ALGIERS, April 13 -- Gen. Henri-Honore Giraud will quietly withdraw from the post of Commander in Chief of the Army, remaining technically on active service but actually going into retirement, it was indicated tonight, while Gen. Charles de Gaulle will rapidly become the real head of the Army and devote himself more to military than to political affairs.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total holdings of United States Government securities and note circulation for the system as a whole to have increased during the week to new high records.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur, in correspondence with a Republican Representative from Nebraska, who urged him to accept the party's nomination if tendered and who denounced the domestic and military policy of the President, made no comment on his attitude toward the Republican nomination but referred to the denunciatory passages as "complete wisdom and statesmanship."

Antony Tudor's "Romeo and Juliet" returned to the repertoire of the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House last night with Alicia Markova and Hugh Laing in the title roles and with Sir Thomas Beecham in the pit as guest conductor.

SEVERAL of the worst historical novels of recent years have dealt with New Orleans during the Civil War, when "Beast Butler" affronted haughty Southern sensibilities and lovely Creole ladies hid the ancestral silver from the ravening Yankees.
