A fine specimen of such lush fare was "Wild Is the River," by Louis Bromfield.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The monthly production of naval torpedoes now exceeds the entire output of the first World War, while other materials manufactured under the supervision of the Bureau of Ordnance continue to show remarkable increases, the Navy Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The War Production Board praised the beverage distilling industry today for its "overnight conversion" to the production of industrial alcohol, but warned that producers must run at full speed if 1944 requirements for 630,000,000 gallons of war alcohol were to be met.

Increased numbers of taxpayers filing their State income tax were noticeable at the State Building, 89 Center Street yesterday, where about 5,000 taxpayers appeared before noon to file their 1943 returns. Nine lines of taxpayers formed outside windows of examiners and three lines were at cashiers' windows where payments were received.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The United Mine Workers Journal, in an approving foreword by the editor, published an article today on the trend of racial animosities and their direct effect upon organized labor, prepared by Max D. Danish, editor of Justice, organ of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 13 -- King George of Greece has asked Sophocles Venizelos to form a new Government, it was announced tonight.

LONDON, April 13 -- The American Red Cross clubmobiles, especially fitted out to accompany the ground forces in the invasion of Europe, were recently handed over by Harvey D. Gibson, American Red Cross representative in London, to Lieut. Gen. Omar N. Bradley, senior American ground commander in Britain.

Discussions of the population problems of Japan, India, the Near East and eastern and southern Europe marked the twenty-second annual meeting of the Milbank Memorial Fund, at the New York Academy of Medicine Wednesday and yesterday, with about 100 experts in the fields of population, public health and nutrition in attendance.

EGLIN FIELD, Fla., April 12 (delayed) -- For the first time in its history, the principal proving grounds of the Army Air Forces were thrown open today to correspondents who were permitted to observe and write of the methods practiced here which have brought improvements in every type of United States combat plane.

A banking group headed by Blyth Co., Inc., has won the award of a new issue of $2,000,000 Tacoma (Wash.) electric light and power revenue bonds, Series B, dated May 1, 1944, and due semiannually from July 1, 1945, to Jan. 1, 1964. The bonds are callable on any interest payment date, beginning Jan. 1, 1955.

An appeal to speed the success of the Red Cross 1944 War Fund's city-wide campaign for $22,386,000 still short $2,200,000 of its goal, was made at a meeting of 300 leaders of Manhattan women's clubs, political, college and professional groups yesterday afternoon in the Hotel Astor.

LONDON, April 13 -- Although business on today's stock markets here was small, a firm tone was seen throughout. Gilt-edged issues and home rails showed no change but a few gains were recorded in the foreign rail section.

Joseph H. Hazen, vice president and member of the board of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., has submitted his resignation to the company to take effect tomorrow, it was learned yesterday. He is the second top executive to leave the company within a two-week period, the first being Hal Wallis, whose contract as executive producer was abrogated by the studio on April 4.
Manhattan's apartment buildings show the highest level of occupancy on record, with vacancies virtually non-existent.

The board of trustees of the Police Pension Fund will be asked to end the sleuthing careers of two of the department's most famous detectives when it meets this afternoon at headquarters to pass upon the retirement application of 153 members of the force.

BUENOS AIRES, April 13 (U.P.) -- The Supreme Military and Naval Court sentenced Lieut. Col. Tomas A. Duco, leader of the recent abortive coup against the Argentine Government, to two years in prison and expelled him from the Army today.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 13 -- Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., minority leader of the House, called tonight for greater Republican representation on American delegations negotiating with Allied Governments on post-war settlements, and asserted that New Deal domestic policies had brought the country to the brink of state socialism in opening the Connecticut Republican State Convention.

Felix Adler, famous clown of the Ringling Brothers Barnum and Bailey Circus, will appear tomorrow morning at the Pan American Book Festival, sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES, in cooperation with the Association of Children's Book Editors and Junior Programs, Inc., at The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

In any account of the fine achievements of the American Air Force the effective and highly important work of the medium bombers against both the Germans and the Japanese ought not to be overlooked. It will be remembered that North American Mitchell B-25's were the vehicles of General Doolittle's raid on Tokyo.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- Senator Nye, Republican, of North Dakota, gave reporters today this interpretation of the Miller-MacArthur letters:...

BERNE, Switzerland, April 13 -- Faced by German troops the French resistance movement has practicaly ended in Savoie. But it is an empty victory, since the majority of the resisters have been able to escape to other parts.

A forty-six-year-old lower East Side neighborhood center and a hospitality club for visiting Australian and New Zealand service men were joint beneficiaries of a Canteen Ball given last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria under the military sponsorship of Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, USA, and Field Marshal Sir John A. Dill.

What is fascism? What is not fascism? If a person really wants to find out he cannot do better than start out from certain remarks by David Dubinsky, head of the International Ladies Garment Workers, at the AFL forum on post-war problems night before last.

Officers of the Greater New York Fund, 11 West Forty-second Street, presented yesterday to the first of 6,000 Boy Scouts, helping in the fund's 1944 drive, campaign posters which the Scouts will distribute in every borough.
NAPLES, April 13 -- The battle of Italy continued desultory yesterday. There were patrol jabs and counter-jabs on all fronts, but the general picture was utterly unchanged.

South American women now look to New York as the fashion center of the world and are "hungry" for all types of clothing designed here, Winifred Ovitte, fashion editor of Women's Wear Daily, who recently returned from a two-month tour of six Latin-American nations, told 400 members of the Fashion Group at a luncheon yesterday at the Murray Hill Hotel.

LONDON, April 13 -- The Germans came up today with a new story about the "secret weapon" they are saving for use against the Allies. This time it was a projectile containing a chemical that freezes everything within a radius of 500 yards by a temperature of 332 degrees below zero Fahrenheit.

Frank McLaughlin, president of the Puget Sound Power and Light Company, minced no words yesterday in informing the Bonneville Power Administration, the huge Federal power project of the Northwest, that the electric properties of the company are not for sale under the terms of a so-called $90,000,000 offer recently made by Dr. Paul Raver, Bonneville admi nistrator.

The League of Present Day Artists (formerly the Bombshell Group) invites painters, sculptors and graphic artists, especially those working along new trends in art, to submit three representative works to a jury today and tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. at the studio of C.B. Moss, 217 West Twenty-ninth Street.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, April 13 -- Coincident with the great aerial onslaught on German-held Europe, Japanese bases in New Guinea are being subjected to the biggest aerial offensive of the Pacific war, with gun positions ammunition, gasoline and food dumps being ripped to pieces by the Fifth Air Force.

A proxy fight for control of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad Company developed yesterday with the announcement by Victor V. Boatner, a director and member of the road's executive committee, that he was soliciting proxies to be voted at the annual meeting, scheduled for May 12 in Chicago.

Legislation permitting quota immigration of nationals of India, and making them eligible for United States citizenship was urged in speeches and in a resolution last night at a meeting in Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street.

Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran, New York County Republican chairman, announced yesterday the designation of Lieut. Comdr. William I. Lehrfeld, USN, for the party nomination for Representative in the new Nineteenth Congressional District.
NEW DELHI, India, April 13 (AP) -- A communique:

ALBANY, April 13 -- Brig. Gen. Ames T. Brown, State director of Selective Service, estimated today that about 95 per cent of the men in New York State outside of the city who were over 26 would qualify for draft deferment because of employment vital to the war effort.

LONDON, April 13 (AP) -- A Yugoslav Army of Liberation communique said tonight that Partisans of Marshal Tito had killed 1,000 enemy soldiers in one sector and reported that hard fighting had taken place in Slavonia, eastern Bosnia and Serbia.

The Pressed Steel Car Company announced yesterday that 1,959 shares of 5 per cent convertible first preferred stock had been converted into common stock between Nov. 30, 1943, and March 31, last, leaving 25,463 preferred shares outstanding.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 13 -- The Swedish Government in a joint communique issued here and in London tonight announces it has concluded an agreement with the Norwegian Government in London for credits under which the latter Government can order and stock in Sweden various merchandise necessary for the reconstruction of Norway after her liberation from the Nazis.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 13 -- "Totalitarian ideals will never be ours." Foreign Minister Joaquin Fernandez declared today at a luncheon offered by the Chamber of Deputies to delegates to the conference of American Parliaments that opens tomorrow.

So few retired nurses have registered for the new series of refresher courses offered by the Nursing Council for War Service on Long Island that one such course has had to be canceled, it was disclosed yesterday.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., April 13 -- Augustus W. Bennet, who unsuccessfully opposed Representative Hamilton Fish in the Republican primaries two years ago, will run against Mr. Fish again this year in a reconstituted Congressional district in Orange, Rockland, Sullivan and Delaware Counties.

Joseph Dunninger, 47 years old, of 1860 Caldwell Avenue, the Bronx, who makes a profession of mind reading, was fined $4 by Magistrate Anna M. Kross in Uptown Traffic Court yesterday for parking overtime in front of 711 Fifth Avenue on March 18.

The five story loft building at 62 Cliff Street, near Beekman Street, in the downtown leather district, has been purchased by John Cherkas, a leather dealer, from the 62 Cliff Street Realty Corporation for cash. It is on a lot 20 by 75 feet and for more than twenty years has been used as a warehouse by the E.J. Barry Drug Company. Edwin B. Conklin was the broker in the sale.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 13 -- Road building funds of $2,500,000 that Westchester County accepted a decade ago from the Federal Government caused today the defeat of the county's current attempt to levy parkway tolls that would have compelled motorists instead of local real estate owners to pay for the county's $65,000,000 park and parkway system.

The manpower situation as it concerns the war is "relatively good" but all needed workers must remain on their jobs in essential and vital industries and the Government must have a free hand to make such shifts and changes as may be required to meet the tasks that will confront the armed forces in the critical invasion months, Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, declared last night.

PORTLAND, Ore., April 13 (AP) -- Governor John W. Bricker of Ohio, seeking Oregon's fifteen Republican National Convention votes for the Presidential nomination, declared tonight that reconversion of industry to peacetime goods production should wait "until the last Jap is crushed into the ground."

The Sinclair Oil Corporation has purchased about 700,000 shares of its capital stock from the Rockefeller interests. This was virtually the entire holding of the group in the Sinclair organization. For the time being the stock will be placed in the corporation's treasury.

LONDON, April 13 -- Yielding to their leaders' pleas and public opinion, 200 delegates of the nation's mine workers voted by more than five to one to accept the proposed four-year pact among the Government, the mine owners and the miners, fixing a national weekly minimum wage of $20 for underground workers.
B.W. Young has leased a cottage on West Street, in Harrison, N.Y., from Walter W. Stake through E.V. Siedle, broker.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

MOSCOW, April 13 -- The arrival here of a military mission representing Marshal Tito, headed by Lieut. Gen. Volimir Terzich, in conjunction with a similar Soviet mission that has already reached Marshal Tito's headquarters, represents the normal development of the Russian decision to follow the Allies' example of establishing contact with Marshal Tito's liberation army.
Mr. and Mrs. Walter F. Kingsland have come to the Ritz-Carlton from Redding, Conn.

NEW DELHI, India, April 13 -- British and Indian troops have driven the Japanese from a hill position northwest of Imphal in bitter hand-to-hand fighting and are engaging the invaders in a "battle of the clouds" outside Kohima, it was announced today as the Japanese pressed their attacks on the two main Allied bases in eastern India.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 13 -- Thirteen-more American Bombers -- one of them shot down by Swiss pursuit planes -- landed in Switzerland today after intensive attacks on southern Germany. The official Swiss Army communique has released no details, but it is understood that the loss of life was minimal.

Two youths, one a resident of Brooklyn and the other a resident of a Long Island village who had received a medical discharge from the Army, were held for investigation last night by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on suspicion of having harbored a deserter from the Army, in the case of the former, and of having provided duplicate identification papers for the deserter, in the case of the latter.

PHILADELPHIA, April 13 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today International Utilities Corporation's amended plan of recapitalization providing for the merger of Domion Gas and Electric Company into International.

Outstanding representatives of labor and industry joined yesterday in declaring that the free enterprise system constitutes the base of the democratic way of life and advocated voluntary cooperation by industry, workers and agriculture, with Government acting only as the umpire, as the most desirable method for achieving the greatest possible measure of post-war prosperity.

Fifty years ago this evening, in a converted shoe store at 1155 Broadway, the world's first commercial exhibition of motion pictures was placed on public view. The device for exhibting the pictures was Thomas A. Edison's Kinetoscope, which permitted only one spectator at a time to view its picture through a peep-hole.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Employment of women, which now stands at 16,400,000, must be increased by one and a half to two millions, chiefly in agricultural and food processing industries, according to a summary issued today by the Office of War Information.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (U.P.) -- The Army is discontinuing the use of steel for making artillery cartridge cases and is going back to brass in a move expected to increase production by about 30 per cent and save $100,000,000 in 1944, the War Department revealed today.

As a father praying that my three boys and three girls in Army service and presently in dangerous positions may return home victorious and unharmed from this great fight to insure future freedom for all people of goodwill, I hail the spirit expressed in your admirable editorial "Victory, Not Death."

Word was received here yesterday that Lieut. Everette J. Dearman Jr., Army Air Forces, was killed in an automobile accident last Monday while on duty at the Will Rogers Air Field, Oklahoma City, Okla.

Up to 10,000 servicemen and women in a day will be able to eat, read, write letters, or sleep, in the enlarged, refurnished and redecorated servicemen's lounge in Pennsylvania Station, formally reopened at 12:30 o'clock yesterday. The snack bar, serving coffee and doughnuts, soup and crackers, has been doubled in size.

The enviable record of the United States Navy in this war has been achieved through the actions of leaders, "naval officers in the fullest sense of the word," Capt. James L. Holloway Jr., director of training of the Bureau of Naval Personnel, yesterday told 1,090 new ensigns of the Naval Reserve Midshipmen's School at Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Office of Price Administration made several revisions in the regulation controlling prices of woolen and worsted apparel fabrics today which, consumers were assured, would raise slightly ceilings for sales by manufacturers and jobbers but not by retailers.

CHICAGO, April 13 -- The letters between General MacArthur and Representative Miller of Nebraska was a signal today for intensified activity by the MacArthur national association of MacArthur-for-President Clubs.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Chairman Robert L. Doughton of the Ways and Means Committee promised rapid action on the tax simplification bill as he announced today that his group will meet Tuesday to receive the bill proposed by legislative draftsmen according to committee specifications.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Twice passed by the House -- once by voice vote and again by a division -- the $32,647,134,336 Navy appropriations bill ended the day in a state of suspended animation, having been blocked of passage by a last-minute objection from Representative Wright Patman of Texas, Democrat, on the ground of "no quorum."

CHICAGO, April 12 -- Traders placed a bearish construction on the war news from southeastern Europe and, with favorable weather conditions, liquidation in wheat developed today on the Board of Trade which disclosed a lack of aggressive support and closing sales in the active futures were about the bottom with losses of 1 1/4 to 1 7/8 cents a bushel.
In New York Captain Rickenbacker issued a statement through his office:

BUENOS AIRES, April 13 -- The Interventor, or Federal Commissioner, of the Province of Entre Rios has issued a decree demanding the payment of 10,100,000 pesos, or more than $2,500,000, from the Jewish Colonization Association, which for more than a half century has done valuable work in settling Jewish colonists, mostly from England, on the land in Argentina.

PEARL HARBOR, April 13 (AP) -- A spring aerial offensive against the Kurile Islands, enemy bases nearest Tokyo to be bombed by United States warplanes, apparently has opened, with attacks for three consecutive days against that island chain northeast of Japan.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The text of the correspondence between Representative Miller and General MacArthur is as follows:

Warners' biographical drama, "The Adventures of Mark Twain," starring Fredric March, will have its local premiere at the Hollywood on May 3. Alexis Smith, Donald Crisp, Joyce Reynolds, Alan Hale, C. Aubrey Smith and John Carradine are among the featured players.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The National War Labor Board ended today the probationary period of the Johnsville, Pa., local of the United Automobile Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, at the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation and continued the union shop provision of the contract until its termination.

Disclosing that exportation of automotive spare parts and equipment to the Middle East is now largely confined to shipments made by automobile manufacturers, exporters attending a meeting of the Overseas Automotive Club at the Hotel Woodstock yesterday called upon Government officials to protect the position of independent manufacturers, who normally shipped 70 per cent of the volume of such exports.

TRENTON, N.J., April 13 (AP) -- New Jersey's highest court upheld today a decree of the Court of Chancery dismissing in 1933 a suit instituted against the American Tobacco Company by a minority group of stockholders who objected to a plan for allotments of stock to officers.
The recent intensification of Gen. Douglas MacArthur's air blows against Japanese bases in the New Guinea area may indicate a quickening of what has been a slow and protracted campaign.

The rediscovery of a forgotten episode in the life of Abraham Lincoln, even though it be trivial, awakens interest, and in this mid-April season, so full of tragic memories of Lincoln and of dark anxiety for ourselves, any new revelation of Lincoln's great soul will come like cheering sunlight.
CHICAGO, April 13 -- The strike against Montgomery Ward Co., marked today by a minimum of picket line disorder, was referred tonight to the White House by the War Labor Board.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, April 13 -- Capt. Richard Ira Bong, 23-year-old farm youth of Poplar, Wis., became the leading United States combat ace yesterday when he shot down his twenty-seventh Japanese plane over Hollandia, New Guinea.

ALBANY, April 13 -- The Democratic leaders of the Legislature demanded today that Governor Dewey call a special session to liberalize the soldier-vote law adopted last month on the Governor's recommendation. Senator John J. Dunnigan and Assemblyman Irwin Steingut, heads of their party in the respective houses, made the request in a telegram to the Governor.

An action was started in Supreme Court yesterday by five members of Local 32-B, Building Service Employes International Union, to compel its president, David Sullivan, individually and as president of the local, and James J. Bambrick, a former president, to make an accounting of $300,000 of the local's funds, alleged to have been diverted from the treasury.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Seventeen-year-old students may go into Army uniform as members of the enlisted reserve under a new plan, now receiving serious consideration in the War Department, to build up the Army Specialized Training Reserve Program in order to balance the recent drastic cut therein.

HONOLULU, T.H., April 13 (AP) -- Despite testimony of Admiral Chester W. Nimitz and Lieut. Gen. Robert C. Richardson that martial law in Hawaii was essential for the prosecution of the war, Judge Delbert E. Metzger ruled today that military government in the islands was invalid.

Playing for the Red Cross War Fund, the Phillies and Dodgers staged for nearly three hours at Ebbets Field yesterday a seriocomic battle, which Brooklyn finally won, 13 to 11 -- and at the end it seemed fitting that the Red Cross should rush to the relief of both teams.

LONDON, Friday, April 16 The greatest concerted aerial operation of history smashed at the German aircraft industry, the Luftwaffe airfields and supply lines of Festung Europa yesterday in the climax of a six-day offensive.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Artur Rodzinski, gave its final Thursday concert of the season last night in Carnegie Hall. For the Occasion Dr. Rodzinski had devised a program featuring the Third piano concerto of Prokofieff, with Nadia Reisenberg as soloist, and also containing the First symphony of Beethoven and the First symphony of Brahms.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- A general revamping of proposed "hardship" amendments to the Emergency Price Control Act is being worked out by the special House committee named to investigate activities of executive agencies.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, April 14 (AP) -- A communique:

MONTREAL, April 13 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens, National Hockey League champions, won the Stanley Cup and world professional title tonight by defeating the Chicago Black Hawks, 5 to 4, in a "sudden death" period at the Forum to sweep the final play-off series in four straight games.

The Germans are showering leaflets on American soldiers in the Cassino and Anzio sectors. They are also offering radio programs for entertainment in those warm areas. Likewise the Japanese have a radio program beamed on our South Sea positions, although for reasons beyond their control they are not able to drop as many leaflets as they might wish.

The vicissitudes of wartime conditions may have raised havoc with the Yankees, but the world champions still are able to sit up, take nourishment and, as the time approaches when the shots count, deal a blow with the same old jarring effect.
POPLAR, Wis., April 13 (U.P.) -- There was too much excitement for normal pursuits in Poplar today because the boy from the Bong farm was America's new "ace of aces."

SAN FRANCISCO, April 13 -- Secretary Ickes served notice today on California, Oregon and Washington, from which 112,000 persons of Japanese ancestry were evacuated in 1942, that the War Relocation Authority, operating now under his jurisdiction, would "not be stampeded into undemocratic, bestial, inhuman action" toward the evacuees.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull today branded as infamous any thought that Britain and the United States should join Germany in the war on Russia.

The report of a student-faculty committee investigating recent irregularities in the election of student government officers at Columbia College and originally scheduled to be released next Monday will be postponed, Associate Dean Nicholas McD. McKnight said yesterday.

GREAT MEADOWS, N.J., April 13 -- The threat of violence to the five Japanese who were placed on the truck farm here of Edward Kowalick by the War Relocation Authority was removed this afternoon when representatives of the Federal agency packed the farm workers into automobiles and took them to Philadelphia.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 13 -- The National Catholic Educational Association, representing 3,000 elementary schools, high schools, colleges and seminaries, expressed concern today over the activities of the Federal Government in the field of education, asked that Rome be spared from military operations and made a plea for a peace that would be just to individuals and nations, in resolutions adopted at the closing session of the forty-first annual conference.

The prospect that Gundar Haegg would run in the United States this spring was vouchsafed by Dan Ferris yesterday at a luncheon of the Metropolitan Association of the A.A.U. at the New York Athletic Club.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The general level of wholesale prices advanced 0.1 per cent during the week ended on April 8. Most of this advance was owing to higher prices for grains, eggs and apples. The balance was accounted for by higher Federal excise taxes, particularly for alcohol, effective April 1.

Any day is a good day to give some thought to Pan-American relationships, and today, being especially designated as Pan-American Day, is an especially good one. Observance of the occasion is only thirteen years old. The idea of a peculiar relationship among the independent nations of this hemisphere is as old as the Monroe Doctrine, which was promulgated in 1823.

ATLANTA, April 13 (AP) -- Answering union demands for higher wages, twenty-three Southern textile mills declared through a spokesman today that "any substantial wage increase" would have to be passed on to the public in the form of higher ceiling prices "on practically all cotton products."
CHICAGO, April 13 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:

Condemning the advocacy in some United States quarters of increased internationalism and free trade as endangering post-war production and employment in this country, Fredric E. Schluter, president of the Thermoid Company, said in his annual report to stockholders, which was made public yesterday:

Nearly 200 cities and towns embracing more than 86 per cent of the population of the New York region now have the necessary machinery for local planning and many already have laid the ground-work for unified community building and development when peace comes, the Regional Plan Association of New York reported yesterday, on the basis of a survey of organizations dealing with postwar planning in the district.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Department store sales in the week ended April 8 were 23 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The coffee uprising continues -- neither side, management nor labor, will give an inch, with the result that the Bethlehem Steel Company's Hoboken and Fifty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, yards have few, if any, overtime workers. Efforts of the United States Conciliation Service and other interested Government groups have failed to bring the contesting parties any closer together.
LONDON, April 13 (UP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Senator Burnet R. Maybank of South Carolina gave notice in the Senate today that "regardless of any Supreme Court decision and any laws that may be passed by Congress, we of the South will maintain our political and social institutions as we believe to be in the best interest of our people."

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Back in 1940 when the Army wanted thirty to fifty service club hostesses, and several thousand women applied, an understandably distracted War Department made a rather poor prophecy. A War Department press release was issued urgently requesting no further applications, and stating that not more than 200 hostesses would be needed at peak.

NEW LONDON, Conn., April 13 (AP) -- Richard F. Hancock, administrator of the Lawrence Memorial Hospital, said today that an error by an employe of the hospital's pharmacy had resulted in the deaths of four infants. Six other babies are seriously ill, he said, and ten more are under observation.

That was a pleasant picture in this paper yesterday of Alfred E. Smith giving a medal to Robert Moses. Both are wits and humorists. Mr. Moses with his somber distinguished face has the tragic look commonly ascribed to the humorist. The Governor looks summery and handsome, as usual.

A shortage of newsprint is one of the "most acute" problems in South America today because it deprives the people of a full knowledge of world events, Alfredo Silva of Valparaiso, Chile, publisher and editor of La Union, declared here yesterday.

NAPLES, April 13 -- Four-motored bombers roared over both new and old targets in Hungary today in the expanding Mediterranean offensive against the sources of German air strength less than twelve hours after night-flying Wellingtons gave the Budapest rail yards the first taste of two-ton bombs.

The United Negro College Fund, which launches its drive next month to raise $1,500,000 for the furtherance of Negro education in this country, is considering touring an all-Negro version of the Broadway comedy "Three's a Family" as part of its national campaign, it was learned yesterday.
Heaviness continued to prevail in equity issues on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday until the final hour, when a moderate improvement reduced some of the losses.
Prices of cotton on the New York Cotton Exchange turned slightly easier yesterday, influenced by freer offerings of spot cotton in the South. At the close futures were 2 to 12 points net lower.

CHICAGO, April 13 -- The American Democratic National Committee, which was organized in Chicago in February to "redeem the Democratic party from its alien-minded overlords," announced today that it would hold a caucus six weeks before the Democratic National Convention to draw up an anti-New Deal platform and select a Presidential candidate.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., April 13 -- The postman delivered this morning to Mrs. Eunice B. White of 275 Engle Street a package containing a pocketbook and $35.06 she had lost two years ago in a local food market. The bills in the purse were of different denominations from those Mrs. White had put in, but they came to he same total.
ITHACA, N.Y., April 13 (AP) -- A squad of sixty service men and twenty civilians is working out for Cornell's 1944 football season which, it was announced today, will include nine games.

TRENTON, N.J., April 13 -- New Jersey's highest tribunal, the Court of Errors and Appeals, concurred today in the ruling of a New York State Appellate Court that in creating OPA Congress did not intend "to put its stamp of approval upon unfair trade practices by permitting violators of a State fair trade law to profit at the expense of those who in good faith complied with its provisions."

BANGOR, Me., April 13 (AP) -- Maine Republicans heard in their opening convention session today from Representative Margaret C. Smith a word of caution against underrating President Roosevelt. Mrs. Smith, who will be chairman of the delegation of thirteen at the Chicago convention, after asserting that "the Republican party is on the road to victory," warned that "we must not allow the glamor of apparent victory to blind us."

Protesting instructions by Major Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Selective Service Director, dropping deferments of pre-theological students on and after July 1, the executive board of the United Lutheran Church in America announced yesterday at the close of an executive session it was sending a telegram to General Hershey voicing disapproval.

NAPLES, April 13 -- The next move in Italian politics is up to Premier Pietro Badoglio. Tonight there were reports -- unconfirmed at the seat of the Italian Government and denied by Count Carlo Sforza -- that the Premier was formally taking steps to call in the executive junta of the six opposition parties for momentous discussions that would lead to scrapping the present Government and forming another on a broader base, with Communist participation.

Maj. Jeanette Bloch, chief nurse at the Halloran General Hospital at Willowbrook, S.I., shared honors yesterday afternoon with Col. Ralph G. Devoe, commanding officer of the hospital, in the presentation of awards, including the distinguished Service Cross, the Silver Star and two Purple Hearts to wounded soldiers.

RICHMOND, Ind., April 13 -- From force of habit the baseball experts generally shy away from picking the Cleveland Indians as probable pennant winners. Invariably a first division club and a prime challenger, the Tribe seems to have developed a complex not unlike the unfortunate lass who was "always a bridesmaid but never a bride."

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The man over 26 who was ordered to report to his draft board for induction, severed his civilian ties, and was then told by his board he wasn't wanted just yet but might be any time, is undoubtedly wondering where the fault lies for this confusion.

CHUNGKING, China, April 13 -- In a world of death and violence, Miss Chang Yun-sie of Shanghai decided to take a trip to Tokyo last September. She felt that she needed to study Japanese to widen the scope of her services as an international secretary.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson, in his weekly war review today, took a hopeful view of British ability to defeat the Japanese invasion of India and was definitely optimistic about Allied gains in Pacific areas, where, he said, nearly 26,000 Japanese dead have been counted in the past three months.

As a result of greatly improved fuel oil inventories on the East Coast, the Petroleum Administration for War is trying to induce the Office of Price Administration to speed up its issuance to the public of 1944-45 ration coupons so that home tanks may be filled at once, thus relieving the strain on the storage tanks of the oil concerns, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Negotiation for a new Anglo-American lend-lease agreement designed to allow a return to normal trading arrangements when the war situation permits has been concluded. The British negotiators have returned to consult their Government.

There is nothing to indicate that General MacArthur knew, when he was writing to Representative Miller of Nebraska, that his letters would be given out for publication. Since this has been done by Mr. Miller on his own responsibility, General MacArthur may well be a victim of circumstance in this respect.

It must be an ill wind indeed that blows no good, for yesterday, with the mercury not far removed from the freezing point and a stiff breeze blowing out of the north, another 20,000-odd crowd made Jamaica's turnstiles add another chorus to the season's song of success.

In his column of April 4 Mr. Arthur Krock states that the real reason for the Supreme Court's overturn of its former decision about voting in the Texas Democratic primaries is "that the common sacrifices of wartime have turned public opinion and the court against previously sustained devices to exclude minorities."

Streams in New Jersey capable of holding trout and located near centers of population have been heavily restocked with brook, brown and rainbow trout in preparation for the State's season, which opens tomorrow, says George C. Warren Jr., president of the New Jersey Fish and Game Commission.

Manufacturers of enamel kitchenware who before the war made in some instances as many as 300 different-sized items but who are now limited by the War Production Board to twenty-five, undoubtedly will never return to their old practice of producing a large number of various-sized products, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON, April 13 (AP) -- The Bank of England's weekly condition statement, issued today, reported a new high record for note circulation at 1,123,548,000, an increase of 4,320,000 in the week ended yesterday.

The address of James F. Byrnes, the War Mobilization Director, before the Academy of Political Science is interesting both for the questions it answers and for those that it implicitly raises but does not answer. Mr. Byrnes clearly endorses the "constructive report" of Messrs.

Steady progress in the orderly liquidation of the Central States Power and Light Corporation was reported yesterday by B.H. Brewster, president, in his 1943 annual report to stockholders. Liquidation of the company has been under way under the terms of a plan formulated in December, 1941, with progress in 1943 reaching the point where the only property remaining to be disposed of is the Iowa-Minnesota electric system.

LONDON, Friday, April 14 (U.P.) -- In less than a week of fighting the Russians had liberated nearly three-fourths of the peninsula's 10,000 square miles, sweeping through more than 600 towns and villages on Thursday alone. Thousands of additional German and Rumanian prisoners were being taken hourly. The announced total of 20,000 included only those counted up to late Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Special interest groups who put their immediate post-war problems ahead of the over-all problem of maintaining high production after the war are cutting their own throats, William L. Batt, vice chairman of the War Production Board, told a special House committee on post-war planning today. He appealed for "mature thinking" by the leaders of these groups to achieve full employment after the war.

An underwriting group headed by Lehman Brothers and Wertheim Co. will offer publicly today 60,000 shares of 4 1/2 per cent convertible preferred stock of Bond Stores, Inc., at $105.50 a share and accrued dividends from April 1.

STOCKHOLM, April 13 -- Britain and the United States demanded in a note delivered to the Swedish Foreign Office today that Sweden halt the exportation to the Axis of ball-bearings and the raw materials and machines used in making the bearings,

MOSCOW, Friday, April 14 -- Moscow's first triple salute of the war was fired last night to mark the capture of the Crimean capital of Simferopol and the two ports of Yevpatoriya and Feodosiya as the enemy's resistance crumbled on the Crimean steppes.
WEST POINT, N.Y., April 13 -- The annual convention of the Association of Military Colleges and Schools of the United States opened here today with forty-three institutions represented.
TORONTO, April 13 (Canadian Press) -- The war "is far from won," Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox warned tonight.

LONDON, April 13 (U.P.) -- American heavy bombers, coming to the aid of Marshal Tito's embattled Partisans for the second consecutive day, today bombed the rail and highway junction of Brod in eastern Bosnia, where a Yugoslav communique reported that heavy fighting was under way.
The "complete pictorial history" of Tarawa, published by U.S. Camera Magazine, will be distributed April 28 by Duell, Sloan Pearce.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- A national bituminous coal bill was introduced in the House today by a bipartisan group. Support for the measure was announced immediately by about 1,700 operators, mining 73 per cent of the country's commercial tonnage, and by the United Mine Workers of America.

For home sewers who may have been timid about tackling slipcovers a step-by-step demonstration is offered in the two-day "Slipcover Clinic" that opened in the upholstery department of L. Bamberger Co. in Newark yesterday afternoon.

To aid member banks in bolstering their reserve positions, the twelve central banks of the Federal Reserve System, operating through the Federal Open Market Committee, bought a total of $316,332,000 of Government securities, chiefly Treasury bills, in the week ended Wednesday, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

ALBANY, April 13 -- Governor Dewey rounded out today a program for statutory assistance for returning veterans by signing the Ives bill requiring the State to pay workmen's compensation benefits to disabled veterans, injured in the course of their employment, to the extent that such injury is aggravated by the previous disability.

LONDON, April 13 -- There is some mystification here over an intimation made by Secretary Knox before a Naval Appropriations Subcommittee that the United States desired to build the pipeline across Saudi Arabia to protect American oil companies from possible competition with the British Government.

A total of 33,116 men between the ages of 18 and 26 will be available here for induction into the armed forces between now and July 1, Col. Arthur V. McDermott, City Director of Selective Service, announced yesterday after scanning complete reports from 280 local boards in the five boroughs.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The human welfare phases of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation program are getting under way, not as a peace-time reconstruction job, but as a part of the strategy of winning the war.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Representative A.L. Miller, who yesterday disclosed correspondence with Gen. Douglas MacArthur in which the latter gave the impression that he was receptive to the suggestion that he run for President on an anti-New Deal platform, revealed today that he had written another letter within a few days urging the General to state definitely that he was available for the Presidency.

In recent years writers of biographies for children have made some astonishing choices of subjects among composers, painters and minor historical figures. The trend reaches a new high with today's announcement from the University of Minnesota of regional writing fellowships.

Close upon the arrival of spring and balmy weather, Federal and private agencies yesterday worked on plans to expedite deliveries of next winter's coal to consumers' bins. The authorities are seeking to avert a repetition of last winter's suffering caused by heatless homes.
Trout will become legal prey in New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennsylvania today and also in the eighteen New York State northern counties, which were excepted from the general April 1 opening.
A slightly easier tone developed yesterday in the market on the New York Cotton Exchange and final prices were 3 to 7 points net lower than on Thursday.
LONDON, April 14 (AP) -- A communique:

The Philharmonic Women's Club and members of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra will give a supper party followed by a satiric playlet tomorrow night at the Horizon Club, 23 West Fifty-third Street, to mark the close of the orchestra's regular subscription season in the afternoon at Carnegie Hall.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., April 14 (AP) -- Stockholders of the St. Regis Paper Company approved today a recapitalization plan which provides for discharge of arrears of $3,012,310 of dividends on outstanding shares of the concern's 7 per cent cumulative stock.

The Fidelity Union Trust Company sold 383-87 Main Street and 8-10 South Walnut Street, in East Orange, N.J., consisting of an apartment house and two one-family buildings, to an investor through M.I. Sientz, broker.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 14 (U.P.) -- The Farmer-Labor party, once called the "Core of Revolution. in the Middle West," met in State convention today to vote itself out of existence so that its remnanest can merge with Minnesota Democrats to help re-elect President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- In a new move to speed the flow of war news to the public, the Army, Navy and Office of War Information agreed today on a policy whereby decisions of theatre commanders to hold up news will be subject to review here.
ST. LOUIS, April 14 (AP) -- Despite home runs by George McQuinn and Vernon Stephens, the Cardinals defeated the Browns today, 3 to 2, in a game called after five innings because of rain.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14 -- The New Jersey Power and Light Company asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to carry out a $12,000, 000 bond and preferred stock refunding program.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 14 -- Secretary Ickes proposed today that the billions of dollars' worth of Government-built war plants, representing "a giant segment of American industry," be turned over after the war as "a bonus payment" to veterans for ownership and operation in competition with existing private industries.

The thoughtful comments of Prof. Henry Walter Brann and Mr. Peter B. Olney in response to my proposal of a minimal program for a post-war organization seem to me deficient in not analyzing more precisely what is involved in an international police force.

MOSCOW, April 14 -- The desperate, heroic struggle of the Jews of the Vilna ghetto against the Germans, who reduced their numbers from 80,000 to 3,000, was described today by the poet Abraham Sutskever, a Partisan in a Lithuanian detachment which he had joined with a few hundred other Jews who crawled from the ghetto via sewers.

OTTAWA, April 14 (Canadian Press) -- Canada concluded today a treaty with China formally relinquishing extraterritorial rights and other privileges which, under treaty provisions, Canada together with other nations previously exercised in China.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- John L. Lewis made a formal demand today on Secretary Ickes, as Administrator of Coal Mines, for aid in compelling bituminous coal operators to pay $18,000,000 allegedly due to the mine workers as retroactive "portal-to-portal" pay of $40 each approved by the National War Labor Board Oct. 26.

Loomis Grossman, operator, has purchased from Sofia Bros., moving and storage company, the five-story warehouse building at 435 West Nineteenth Street for cash over a mortgage of $33,500. The property is assessed at $70,000 and was sold through Louis Carreau, Inc.

LONDON, April 14 -- The stock markets here ended the week on a cautious note, and most sections recorded little business. Some investment demand strengthened gilt-edge stocks, both war loans recording gains of one-sixteenth each.

OAKLAND, Calif., April 14 (AP) -- Staving off a last-lap sprint by her nearest rival, Miss Brenda Helser, 19-year-old star of the Multnomah Club, Portland, Ore., tonight won the 100-yard free-style in the first final of the women's national A.A.U. swimming and diving championships.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The American republics were called upon by Secretary Hull tonight, in a Pan-American Day address, to continue their collaboration after the cessation of hostilities and "to foresee and prepare for the ever greater common task of the peace." Mr. Hull spoke during a concert of Latin-American music in the Pan-American Union at the annual observance, devoted to the theme of inter-American unity and understanding.

Asserting that establishment of ceiling prices on end products does not provide sufficient control over the price of logs, the lumber division of the Office of Price Administration has informed lumber manufacturers in the Northeastern area that it will announce specific ceilings on logs next week, it was learned yesterday.

Juan T. Trippe, president of the Pan American Airways System and pioneer in international aviation, is the leading advocate of a single "chosen instrument" to represent the United States in commercial air transport on the world airways, as against the regulated competition urged by the domestic airlines which desire to participate independently in post-war international operations.

STOCKHOLM, April 14 (AP) -- Arne Andersson and Gunder Haegg, Sweden's middle - distance stars, told reporters today they would be delighted to compete in the United States national A.A.U. track and field championships June 17 and 18 but only on condition that air transportation be provided each way.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 14 -- Connecticut Republicans elected sixteen uninstructed delegates to their party's national convention at the closing session of their State convention today and unanimously approved a resolution suggesting that Governor Raymond E. Baldwin, who will head the delegation, be considered for the Presidential nomination.

Defending the operation of the Federal Housing Administration because of its yearly gains in insurance reserves, Earle S. Draper, deputy commissioner of that bureau in Washington, advocated yesterday its expansion in the post-war period with the retention of a competent staff "to meet the demands of accelerated home building."

NAPLES, April 14 -- The Luftwaffe sent fifty planes over the Anzio-Nettuno port area Wednesday night in one of the heaviest of the recurrent air attacks that together with shelling have made life precarious on the beachhead below Rome.

The public demand for newspapers is so great, it was reported yesterday by the American Newspaper Publishers Association, that most of the papers which had increased their prices last year had either suffered no loss in circulation or had regained temporary losses which followed the price rises.
LONDON, April 14 -- Belgium will remain a monarchy with Leopold, now interned in his country, again enthroned, Premier Hubert Pierlot of the Belgian Government-in-exile said today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 4 -- A plan for the joint reorganization of the Associated Gas and Electric Company and the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation, the product of four years of involved litigation in bankruptcy proceedings in the Federal District Court in New York, was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

BANGOR, Me., April 14 (AP) -- Maine Republicans in State convention today chose thirteen unpledged delegates to the national convention, at least three of whom lean to Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York as the Presidential nominee.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo last night presented George Balanchine's "Serenade" at the City. Center for the first time this season. This charming and characteristic little work was created for the quondam American Ballet in its very beginnings and as a result it has about it predominantly the qualities of youth.

NAPLES, April 14 -- In twenty-four hours without the Allies' control, the people of at least nine provinces in Italy would throw out the Badoglio Government, Lieut. Col. G.H. McCaffrey told an Allied Control Commission meeting today.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The text of the radio address delivered by Secretary Hull tonight in connection with the observance of Pan-American Day was as follows:

Imperial Oil, Ltd., a Canadian concern controlled by the Standard Oil Company (N.J.), reported yesterday for 1943 a net income of $15,548,873 after all charges, taxes and a reserve of $1,543,809 for future shrinkage of inventory values, equal to 58 cents each on the 26, 965,078 capital shares.

In what Wall Street described generally as a "pre-invasion market," stocks drifted narrowly yesterday and closed mixed in the dullest full-day session in six months. Volume on the Stock Exchange was only 477,220 shares, against 659,590 on Thursday.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 14 (AP) -- Carroll Widdoes completed today a three-year climb from high school assistant football coach to head mentor of Ohio State University.

Captain William J. Pedrick, Collector of Internal Revenue of the Second New York District, was the guest of honor at a reception yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria to mark the completion of his twenty-fifth year as an executive and director of the Fifth Avenue Association.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The use of something less than a billion dollars to finance black-market transactions and the large amounts of money that have been discovered on captured foreign agents have played their part in a steady increase of public demand for coin and paper money, according to the Federal Reserve Board's April bulletin, issued today.

Governor Dewey may well be right in his assertion that New York has "the simplest and best soldier vote law in the United States." Still, he does seem overly optimistic when he says that under the New York law "every soldier who wants to vote can vote." There are factors in the situation beyond the Governor's control.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The first case which the National War Labor Board has had involving the proposed use of a wage award as a ground for resisting a decrease in utility rates was decided by the board today when it directed an increase of five cents an hour for employes of the Indianapolis Street Railways Company.

Members of Locals 13 and 15 of the Industrial Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, agreed yesterday afternoon to resume the disputed two-hour overtime trick at the Bethlehem Steel Company's Hoboken and Fifty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, shipyards while the "coffee" question is being arbitrated by the union's grievance committee and the company.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 14 -- Secretary Ickes said here today that he was opposed to the national bituminous coal bill introduced in the House yesterday, but not for the reason ascribed in dispatches from Washington.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The War Production Board's Controlled Materials Plan division issued today an interpretation of rules governing deliveries of materials and parts as the result of discovery of some misunderstandings of these provisions.

ALGIERS, April 14 -- Gen. Henri Honore Giraud ceased to be Commander in Chief of the French Army today when the French Committee of National Liberation placed him "en reserve de commandement" or on a kind of active reserve list in consequence of his refusal to accept the post of Inspector General of the Army offered him by the Committee when it dismissed him last Sunday as Commander in Chief.

CHICAGO, April 14 -- Indication that the Office of Price Administration will announce shortly some course of action aimed at relieving the "beef price squeeze" was given today by John J. Madigan, assistant director of OPA's Food Price Division.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The War Department moved today to increase the infantry force by issuing an order permitting some enlisted men under 32 years of age, now serving in other branches of the service within the United States, to request transfer to the infantry.

I read recently in THE SUNDAY TIMES comment on the redbird, a very pretty tribute. I have outside of my study window a bird cafeteria. The grain consists of crushed corn, millet, wheat, sunflower seed, etc. Hundreds of birds feed there, mostly sparrows, but also some steady feeders, such as redbirds, mockingbirds, blue jays, blackbirds, cedar birds and many other travelers between North and South. On the board are placed also table scraps and bread.

LONDON, April 14 (U.P.) -- German forces, trapped within a huge rock fortress overlooking the strategic town of Cazin, in western Bosnia, are battling desperately against repeated Yugoslav onslaughts, a Partisan communique reported today as fighting increased for control of important communications south of Zagreb.

A thinly veiled threat of political action by Americans of Italian descent against the Roosevelt Administration was made yesterday by Luigi Antonini, president of the Italian-American Labor Council, in a statement denouncing "any American support to communist-inspired Government coalitions in Italy or deals with the monarchists."

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- With Admiral Ernest J. King, Commander in Chief of the United States Fleet, reaffirming the belief that it would be unwise to hold a "Pearl Harbor" court-martial at present, Secretary Knox again made it plain today that there was no intention of bringing Rear Admiral Husband Kimmel to trial at this time.

May I add my voice to Mr. Follett Bradley's congratulations on your excellent editorial "The Role of Air Power"? The one exception I take is contained in the last paragraph -- i.e., "The Mahan of air power is still to come." It is my considered opinion that the "Mahan of air power" has been born -- namely, Gen. Giulio Douhet.

Fearful that interests more powerful than their own may be in a position in the post-war era to monopolize available raw materials, manufacturers of kitchenware are in favor of some system of Government allocations until such time as enough materials are available for all, it was learned yesterday.

The latest flare-up in the intermittent war between New York City and Westchester County over toll charges brought a rejection by the Triborough Bridge Authority yesterday of Westchester's contention that the 10-cent toll on the Henry Hudson Memorial Bridge over Spuyten Duyvil be lifted.

"Address Unknown," a topical drama starring Paul Lukas and produced by Columbia from the novelette by Kressmann Taylor, will have its local premiere this morning at the Globe. The picture, which was produced and directed by William Cameron Menzies, includes K.T. Stevens, Carl Esmond, Mady Christians, Morris Carnovsky and Peter Van Eyck among its supporting players.

Correspondents in England were asked not long ago not to speculate about the coming invasion of Europe. The request was reasonable, for though the reporters do not know what date is D-Day, they do know a good many facts not familiar to the public or to the enemy.

LONDON, April 14 -- Backing up its recent promise to feed the Finns if they would get out of the war, the Swedish Government has let it be known that it is prepared to institute much more drastic rationing regulations than are in existence today. Such a move on the part of Sweden would fill the gap presently taken care of by Germany.
The growing strength of Pan Americanism as an important potential influence in shaping the post-war world was hailed at a Pan-American luncheon yesterday in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

RICHMOND, Va., April 14 -- Patents for a thermoplastic lacquer, a thermostat for regulating temperatures inside a building by adjustment to changes taking place on a window pane and for two tough new lubricants stand out among the 513 listed as issued in the current Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

A new interdenominational InterCouncil Committee on Post-War Planning headed by Dr. Herman; N. Morse of the Presbyterian l Board of latio.nal Missions is at! work on problems that will coni front American churches after the war.

The biggest problem confronting the Treasury Department in its lend-lease buying program is its inability to get 35,000,000 yards of gray sheeting for the Middle East, it was revealed in the market yesterday. Demands upon gray sheeting production by bag makers will consume all but 20 per cent if they are to provide sufficient bags to meet the demands of this summer's food crops, it was said.

From the metal mesh "rat catchers" that protect a ship's pipes to the waist-high container in which used cooking fat is salvaged, housekeeping practices aboard the United States Maritime Service training ship American Mariner were inspected yesterday by twenty-one women newspaper and magazine writers.

Thirty-six contract bridge experts, all among the highest-ranking on the lists of the American Contract Bridge League, began play at the Park Central Hotel last night in the fourteenth annual masters' individual championship tournament.

This is the day of the double deadline for income taxpayers, who began yesterday such a stampede to get under the wire that Wesley M. Dawson, district tax supervisor at the State Building, 80 Center Street, said he had not seen such a busy day in the seventeen years he has been in charge of State tax collections here.
ALBANY, April 14 -- Governor Dewey signed the Todd bill today, guaranteeing women equal pay for equal work and setting up penalties where employers discriminate in the rate of pay because of sex.

Traffic accidents, already taking a heavy toll of lives, will soar far above current totals during the post-war era when automobiles will once again fill roads and highways unless adequate measures to counter them are devised now, leading traffic and safety engineers warned yesterday at an all day conference on the problem at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

With Cliff Melton relegated to the position of a deferred starter by reason of his second successive drubbing at the hands of the Yankkees in the Red Cross game last Thursday, Bill Voiselle, the strapping right-hander from Ninety Six, S.C., has now moved into the No. 1 post on Mel Ott's hurling staff and will be the opening day pitcher when the Giants face the Braves at the Polo Grounds next Tuesday.

PRINCESS ANNE, Md., April 14 (AP) -- A criminal libel indictment against Rives Matthews, editor of The Somerset News, based on his criticisms of use of rationed gasoline by State Controller J. Millard Tawes, was ordered nolle prossed today by Harry C. Dashiell, State's Attorney.

Robert F. Hennig has been appointed director of purchases of the Sherwin-Williams Company, paint manufacturers, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Hennig succeeds the late Frank E. Davis, and has been with the company since 1927.

There are to be seen here at the moment two exhibitions dealing entirely, on the subject side, with Paris. Both are one-man, shows: Camille Pissarro's at the Carroll Carstairs Gallery, 11 East Fifty-seventh Street, current through April 26, and Bernard Lamotte's at the Bignou, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street, through April 22.

ALBANY, April 14 -- Governor Thomas E. Dewey declared tonight in a radio report to the people on State affairs that he has striven to establish in Albany "a genuinely competent and progressive government, in sharp contrast with that type of government which talks fine phrases of liberalism while seeking to impose its will and its whims upon the people through centralized bureaucracies issuing directives from a distance."

CHICAGO, April 14 -- Judge John J. Lupe, in Cook County Superior Court, issued a temporary, anti-violence injunction today against strike pickets at the plant of Montgomery Ward Co., mail order and retail concern.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 14 -- The Swedes will discuss the United States note on sales to the Reich at a secret sitting of the Riksdag next week, it was learned today.

MUNCIE, Ind., April 14 -- Up to this time Frank Frisch, the Jean Lafitte of the Pirates, has always been considered a swashbuckler of the old school. Hence it is a painful duty to have to report that the Fordham Flash has softened up dreadfully. His new phobia -- and don't whisper a word of this to any members of his former Gas House Gang -- is a daily pine bubble bath.

PITTSBURGH, April 14 -- Business in the Pittsburgh district last week receded from the record levels reported at the beginning of April, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. Most of the decline resulted from a slowing down in the pace of retail buying, although the volume of shipments was somewhat smaller, also.

The three-story building containing two stores and five apartments at 7724 Thirteenth Avenue, in Brooklyn, was sold by the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, which also sold the one-family house at 1420 Avenue I.
LONDON, Saturday, April 15 (AP) -- The Moscow radio announced today that Gen. Nikolai F. Vatutin, commander of the First Ukraine Army, died last night in Kiev after an operation.

The surplus left from last year's unprecedented crop of potatoes is presenting a problem inasmuch as the supplies in storage are beginning to show signs of spoilage. In an effort to move excess stocks, { the Food Distribution Administra-I tion has designated next week as "Potato Week" in New York State, and consumers, especially in this area, are urged to cooperate in the campaign by using as many old potatoes as possible,

COLUMBIA, S.C., April 14 -- "We will maintain white supremacy, let the chips fall where they may," Gov. Olin D. Johnston declared tonight to an extraordinary session of the Legislature, called by him to repeal all State primary laws.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- A movement was under way in the Senate today to postpone further the impending fight over the Marcantonio anti-poll tax bill in the interest of two Adlministration Democrats, Senators Lister Hill of Alabama and Claude Pepper of Florida, who are engaged in concededly close primary contests for renomination on May 2.

Obituaries of Hugh Cecil Lowther, fifth Earl of Lonsdale, are like a peep into an extinct world. Ever since the thirteenth century Lowthers have been great folks in Westmoreland and Cumberland. This earl must have enjoyed all his long life; his lives, we might say, so various was his experience.

LONDON, April 14 (Reuter) -- Pierre Ryckmans, Gvernor Gen-I eral of:tle Belgian .C'6hgo, who at present .is in.'Britain,has been in-J [vited .by. the: .UnitedStates State Departmerit" to" go tS' the United'I States. He .will be guest of the[ StateDepartment '

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, April 15 -- Australian troops captured Bogadjim Thursday and are in contact with enemy patrols on the road to the Japanese supply base at Madang, eighteen miles to the north.

Pleasant, indeed, was the day that the Yankees spent in Brooklyn yesterday. Not only did the world champions beat the Dodgers, 7-5, in a 10-inning exhibition at Ebbets Field, but when they arrived they learned that their catching problem had been solved by Rollie Hemsley.

Still $2,000,000 short of its citywide quota of $22,386,000, the Red Cross 1944 War Fund of Greater New York announced yesterday that the aviation division of the fund had crossed its victory line with contributions of $102,200.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 14 (AP) -- In a press conference whose tenor was taken to indicate that Turkey would seek to compromise with the Allies on the question of Turkish-German trade, Foreign Minister Numan Menemencioglu declared today: "We will, in the general direction of our foreign policy, aid the Allies to the limit of our material possibilities."

Coming here for the first time to seek support for Lieut. Comdr. Harlod E. Stassen for the Republican Presidential nomination, Senator Joseph H. Ball of Minnesota declared last night that the former Minnesota Governor, now in active service with the Navy, "possesses to a remarkable degree the qualities America needs so desperately in our next President."

NEW DELHI, India, April 14 -- Front dispatches said tonight that Japanese troops had reached the Bishenpur-Silchar Trail running southwest and west of the Allied Indian base of Imphal and suffered a dozen casualties in an engagement with Allied troops there.

The American-Hawaiian Steamship Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries, the Transport, Trading and Terminal Corporation and Williams, Dimond Co., had a net profit of $1,292,478 last year, after Federal income and excess profits taxes and adjustments relating to prior years, including charter hire previously withheld and applicable to 1942, according to a report issued yesterday.

The six-story apartment house at 27-29 West Eleventh Street, on a plot 40 by 103.3 feet, has been sold by the Redan Corporation to the Property Liquidation Corporation through Fred Berger Co., brokers. The house contains twelve apartments of six and seven rooms.

It is to be hoped that your article of April 5, "Starved Libraries," resulted in many friends of our public libraries doing what you suggested -- write letters to the city budget authorities asking that the pitiful allowance of one and one-half cents per capita for buying circulation books be increased.

SYDNEY, Australia, April 14 (Reuter) -- Exactly a year after his death in a plane crash the story can now be told of how Flight Lieut. Lee Vial of Melbourne kept a six months' vigil in 1942 from a hilltop behind the Japanese held town of Salamaua in New Guinea.

Daily newspapers throughout the country have reduced sharply their use of newsprint paper as their contribution to the necessary wartime conservation of all kinds of paper. The American Newspaper Publishers Association announced yesterday that its members had reported a total newsprint consumption last month of 201,708 tons, compared with 237,111 tons in March, 1943, and 258,518 tons in March, 1941.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Creation of a Department of National Defense will be the first item considered by the new Special House Committee on Post-War Military Policy, which held its first meeting today at the request of Representative Clifton A. Woodrum of Virginia.

Retail trade here this week experienced the usual post-Easter let-down, but volume was said to have held up well. The fact, however, that comparison was with the sharply rising pre-Easter volume of last year was responsible for sales decreases for most department stores.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The War Food Administration lowered today the percentage of beef which packers operating under Federal inspection are required to set aside for purchase by the armed forces and war services.
NEW DELHI, India, April 14 (AP) -- A Southeast Asia communique:

TRENTON, N.J., April 14 (AP) -- A bill creating a State Department of Taxation and Finance, which will take over the functions of several existing branches of the State government, has been signed by Gov. Walter E. Edge.

"Too little and too late" can never be said of the daffodil. "Much and early" are the words for this advance agent of spring. It lifts its green fingers to feel the air before the frost is out of the ground. In these parts it forms its buds amid the snow flurries of March, and now, in chilly April, it opens its cheery flower to the first honest sunshine of the year.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- President Roosevelt directed the Secretaries of War and Navy today to take over two war plants whose management had declined to obey directives of the War Labor Board ordering wage increases. The President said interruption of work at the plants was threatened.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 14 (AP) -- Jurors in the $5,450,000 suit of Prefect Theatres, Inc., against eight motion picture distributors, were directed today by Federal Judge Carroll C. Hincks to return a verdict for all the defendants because of "fatal defects" in the plaintiff's proof.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- A board of Army officers is reconsidering the decision to return the Breakers Hotel at Palm Beach to civilian use, the War Department advised Senator Harry S. Truman, chairman of the Special Committee Investigating the War Program, today.
LONDON, April 14 (AP) -- A communique from the European Theatre of Operations of the United States Army:
The Excelsior Handicap, most venerable of the Metropolitan Jockey Club's stake events, today may be the lure that will shatter Jamaica's records, both for attendance and betting.
BOSTON, April 14 (AP) -- The Red Sox came from behind in the ninth inning today to defeat their hometown rivals, the National League Braves, 6 to 5, in the first of a three-game city series.

Sales of all food brokers continue to fall off heavily and the market is quiet, Bacon Truenback, brokers, reported yesterday. Standard and substandard canned carrots, peas and string beans are not moving in the metropolitan market, though tomatoes are doing a little better.

Hearings by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee on the Maybank bill which would permit Federal Reserve member banks to absorb exchange charges on checks and drafts imposed by non-par banks throughout the country are expected to begin within a fortnight.

For two and a half hours Detective Patrick Fitzgerald of the Herbert Street Station crouched in a sandbox on the Kosciusko Bridge over Newtown Creek between Greenpoint, Brooklyn and Queens yesterday afternoon, waiting to catch a blackmailer who had directed a Greenpoint baker to deposit $300 in the box before 5 P.M., or suffer stabbing and bombing.

CHUNGKING, China, April 14 -- Dr. Sun Fo, president of the Legislative Yuan, who is a son of Sun Yat-sen, founder of the Chinese Republic, emphasized the importance of promoting democracy by the Kuomintang [Nationalist party] in a speech delivered recently before the Central Training Institute.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- An advisory committee for civilian policy for major problems of re-conversion was named today by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 14 -- A Greek Government that "will consider its mission ended as soon as its unique aim has been achieved" was formed today by Sophocles Venizelos, whom King George appointed yesterday as Premier to succeed Emmanuel Tsouderos, who resigned last week over the question of collaboration with resistance groups and political factions within Greece.

The peacetime system of price control under which the movement of prices is regulated by the balance of supply and demand is almost destroyed by a great war. This is because the supply of many necessities is cut down and at the same time the demand for them is pushed up, a fact which lies at the root of a universal demand for price control.

Leo Koke, well-known composer and singer in Continental capitals between the years of 1932 and 1938, who has been a resident of this country for three months, is the author of an operetta entitled "Flower of Algiers," which will make its Broadway debut here in October under the auspices of Walter Brooks, it was announced yesterday.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, April 15 (AP) -- A communique:

When New York's National Guard went into the Federal service in 1940 the State Guard was organized to perform the duties of home protection thus left uncovered. Ever since, the officers and men who make up the State Guard, serving without pay and at their own expense in time and transport, have taken over the armories all over the State, attended drills twice a week, and hiked out for field exercises at intervals.

Margarine manufacturers who make the cheaper and less advertised brands could increase their sales by a little more advertising and by cultivating better consumer acceptance, it was suggested in the trade yesterday, in view of the high point value and the high price of butter.

Very likely the thought has already occurred to President Roosevelt, whose mind works much faster than most men's, or to his advisers, who are many in number and well read in history. But if Mr. Roosevelt considers it at all necessary to comment on General MacArthur and the Republican nomination he might say what President Lincoln once said about General McClellan.

The distilling and other divisions of the liquor industry cannot be held responsible as a class for black market activities, spokesmen for producers said yesterday, with the blame placed upon individuals in the related trades who "fall" for opportunities to make relatively large profits through such operations.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14 -- Declaring that national isolationism had become an utter impossibility," Francis B. Sayre, diplomatic adviser to the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, said tonight in an address before the American Academy of Political and Social Science that "any agenda for a lasting peace must be built upon the growing concept of international understanding and cooperation."

Mayor La Guardia revealed yesterday that an investigation was being held to determine how many city employes were holding outside jobs in violation of departmental regulations. The Mayor said he had ordered the inquiry after veterans' organizations and labor unions had complained that some of their members were deprived of employment opportunities because city employes were doing such outside work.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- An hour and twenty minutes after Second Lieut. Harvey Metcalf's torpedo bomber crashed into the sea, a Navy blimp hovered overhead, dropped a line, pulled him aboard and started him off to a hospital.
A communique broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

CENTER MORICHES, L.I., April 14 -- With a little aid, a 71-year-old man stepped out of his automobile this afternoon after it had been carried, pushed and bounced a distance of 650 feet by a Long Island Railroad train at the Brookfield Avenue grade crossing, here.

No Hollywood producer could do what the United States Eighth Air Force has done with a film called "Memphis Belle," which is being shown for the first time in this city under the auspices of OWI and Paramount Pictures. To make this picture ten "actors" and a photographer had to risk their lives.

ALBANY, April 14 -- Governor Dewey completed action today on the last of the 891 thirty-day bills left with him by the Legislature by signing a bill aimed at black markets" in transportation accommodations. He vetoed two bills which would have made it impossible for licensees under the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law to have interlocking interests in the manufacture and distribution of liquor and wine or liquor and beer.

PEARL HARBOR, April 14 (AP) -- The spring aerial offensive on the Kurile approaches to Tokyo was carried through its fourth straight day with strikes Thursday at Paramushiru, Shashikotan and Matsuwa, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz reported today in a press release.
Following is the text of Governor Dewey's radio report to the people of the administration of the State Government as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

The operating technique of an accomplished philanderer was described in some detail yesterday by one of his victims.
