The story was told in Federal court by Miss Bernita Arnold, a smart and attractive brunette artist, at the trial of Roger Lewis Gardner, to whom she had given $1,500 in cash and a check for $350.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, April 14 (AP) -- To further an understanding of their respective problems, an exchange of combat personnel of the infantry and air force has been effected, with ground soldiers going on bombing missions and pilots living in foxholes and going on patrols.

LONDON, Saturday, April 15 -- Russian troops, advancing as much as fifty-three miles in one day, cleared the eastern and western corners of the Crimea yesterday and drove the main German and Rumanian forces southward into a 1,000-square-mile pocket extending up from the historic battleground city of Sevastopol.

LONDON, April 14 -- Royal Air Force Mosquitos bombarded Berlin last night, probably with two-ton blockbusters, and American Thunderbolt fighter-bombers made a spectacular attack on a German air field in northeastern France today at the end of an historic week-long, two-way Allied aerial assault on Axis continental targets.

Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker's job now is to produce a case of Scotch whisky he promised the aviator in the southwest Pacific who bettered the combat record he set in the first World War, The Associated Press said.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- A Pacific Fleet announcement:

A summary of Congressional Proceedings compiled from the Congressional Record for the information and guidance of members of the Parliaments of the British Commonwealth, has been received here. Authorized by the Empire Parliamentary Association (United Kingdom and Dominion of Canada Branches) the volume of 145 pages is the first of a quarterly series designed to promote a fuller understanding of one another's problems on subjects of interest to the United States and the British nations.

A UNITED STATES FIGHTER BASE IN ENGLAND, April 14 (AP) -- Capt. Don S. Gentile of Piqua, Ohio, America's top European fighter ace, may have trained his deadly Mustang guns on swastika-marked fighters miles over Europe for the last time.

LONDON, April 14 (U.P.) -- Headquarters of the United States Strategic Air Forces said today that approximately three-fourths of the extensive Messerschmitt fighter works at Augsburg, bombed Thursday and eight times previously, had been damaged, and some of its principal workshops, assembly and machine shops had been totally destroyed.

An intensive campaign to recruit women citizens of the Netherlands now living in the United States for service with the Netherlands Indies Army has just been launched, it was announced yesterday by the head of the recruiting office for the Royal Netherlands Indies Army in New York.

The International Labor Organization will convene April 20 in Philadelphia for its twenty-sixth meeting. Pierre Waelbroeck, assistant director of the ILO, speaking before a group of civic organizations in regard to the purpose of the forthcoming conference, said that first and foremost comes the question of how we can maintain full employment in the post-war world. The meeting will be a significant one.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 14 -- Patrice Munsel, the 18-year-old Metropolitan opera soprano, has been signed to a term contract by Warner Brothers and will report at the studio early in May. The singer, who is also proficient as a ballet and tap dancer, will be featured in musicals.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Put to vote for the fifth time in two days, the Navy Appropriation Bill passed the House today on a roll-call, 257 to 0.

THROUGHOUT her lifetime Virginia Woolf wrote occasional short stories. Her habit was to sketch them out in rough form, then put them away in a drawer until some editor came asking for something. Then, if she happened to be in the mood for it, she would take a sketch out of the drawer and rework it. She did this, so her husband, Leonard Woolf, tells us, to rest her mind from preoccupation with writing novels.

LONDON, April 14 -- Russia has agreed with the United States and Great Britain on the principle of post-war military government for Germany and those of her satellites that fight to the end, it was reported on high authority tonight.

MOSCOW, April 15 -- The Soviet Union's attitude toward post-war Germany is essentially simple -- a firm determination that there shall be no repetition of the events which twice in less than thirty years have forced the best youth of Russia by the millions to shed their lifeblood to halt the marches eastward of two totally different German Governments, each intent on world empire.

It is said that the Nazis enable some of their fighter pilots to fly higher by removing part of the thyroid gland. The same effect may be achieved by small doses of the chemicals thioureau and thiouracil. Experiments with these were reported by Drs. Harry A. Charipper, Albert S. Gordon and E.D. Goldsmith (New York University), in Science, earlier in the year.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- A petition to quash a temporary injunction prohibiting violence and limiting the Montgomery Ward Co. pickets to forty-two was denied today by Superior Judge John J. Lupe.

A reception in honor of the eighty-fifth birthday of Hugo Heimann, former honorary freeman of the city of Berlin, former member of the German Reichstag and chairman of its budget committee, and founder of the first public library in Berlin, was held yesterday at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

BELGIAN CONGO, Leopoldville, doubles length of North American English program which includes many European underground bulletins not heard elsewhere. Signale cellent: 9.785 mcls, 8:15 to 9:15 P.M. News at 8:30, 8:50, 9:00 and 9:10 P.M.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- Curtailment of production of penicillin, sulfa drugs, surgical dressings, adhesives, vitamins and other products important to the war is threatened by an industrial shortage of corn, the War Food Admintration said today in urging farmers to release their stocks.

Canadian Air Marshal W.A. (Billy) Bishop, noted flying ace of World War I, told members of the New York Post of the Canadian Legion at their installation of officers last night at the Hotel Roosevelt that there is a real danger in "trying to win the peace before the war is won."

The present program of processing the blood collected by the Red Cross Blood Donor Service assigns three-quarters of the blood to the production of dried plasma and one-quarter to the production of serum albumin. Each of these blood derivatives has the same beneficial effect when transfused and each has the property of drawing fluid from the body tissues back into the circulation.

NEW DELHI, India, April 15 (U.P.) -- Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten, on his recent visit to Imphal, congratulated Maj. Gen. A.T. Cowan's Seventeenth Indian Division for smashing its way into the beleaguered city "in one of the best battles of the war."

THE good old summertime seems about to burst upon us as resorts and camps in one State and another take down their shutters. From Maine comes word that most play centers of the area plan their usual programs, the exceptions being those places that catered solely to automobilists.

PEARL HARBOR, April 15 (AP) -- Defending interceptors are reported rarely over the Kurile Islands, bombed every day this week by long-range planes from the Aleutian Islands, flying to within 500 miles of Japan proper.

As all but the most inveterate radio haters know, Col. Lemuel Q. Stoopnagle is an exceedingly comical gent -- and has been since the fateful day in 1930 when he and Budd Hulick fell into conversation at a microphone in a Buffalo station, whence they went on to national fame as the team of Stoopnagle and Budd.

Nelson Eddy, screen and radio star, gave his first song recital at Carnegie Hall last night before an audience that filled the house and was eagerly demonstrative throughout the evening, breaking into prolonged cheers and shouts during the four encores that followed the printed list.
PHOENIX, Ariz., April 15 (AP) -- Arizona's eight-member delegation to the Republican National Convention will go uninstructed but with leanings toward Governor Dewey.

Francis E. Wheaton, blind worker at the International Business Machines Corporation, Endicott, N.Y., has received an honorable mention from the Board for Individual Awards, War Production Drive Headquarters, Washington, D.C., it was announced yesterday by the New York Regional Office of the War Production Board.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 15 (AP) -- J. Kenneth Bradley, Republican National Committeeman from Connecticut, said tonight that he would recommend to the arrangements committee that it choose Representative Clare Boothe Luce to be keynoter at the national convention in recognition of the part that women have taken in politics.

JAPANESE beetles were fast beginning to be regarded as inevitable. Every time the gardener looked at his roses or grapevines, or other succulent favorites of the pests, he found that he was right back where he started, no matter how many beetles had been disposed of.
A communique broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

RAY HEINDORF, one of the busiest musicians in Hollywood and winner of two Academy Awards for his arranging and conducting of the scores for "Yankee Doodle Dandy" and "This Is the Army," has just completed the score for a forthcoming motion picture biography of George Gershwin.

The first anniversary of the uprising of the Jews in the Warsaw ghetto, who resisted the Nazis for forty-two days, was commemorated in services in several synagogues here yesterday, the final day of the orthodox observance of the festival of Passover.
LONDON, Sunday, April 16 (UP) -- The Saturday midnight supplemental communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- Joe Cambria,. baseball scout for the Senators, said today that all Latin-American players on the Washington roster entered the United States on six-month visas and were immune to any draft regulations in this country.

The Globe American Corporation's new all-metal, non-inflammable reversible life rafts are being installed on American vessels at the rate of 600 a month, with most of them going to newly constructed tonnage, it was disclosed here yesterday by Gosta Morner, general manager of the Approved Marine Devices Company, eastern representatives of the Globe American organization.

IT was indeed a crowded week. Among the important shows that cannot now receive all the attention they merit are two that the Metropolitan Museum is opening to the public today. One of them illustrates Greek painting and the other is made up of Russian ikons.

Capt. Daniel Butler McCook, former assistant district attorney under Thomas E. Dewey and a son of former Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook, died "outside the continental limits of the United States" while serving with the Army of the United States, according to word received here yesterday.

Great Britain's preparation of "alternative" post-war trade plans, which suggest maintenance of empire preference agreements, bilateral trade pacts and bulk buying, will continue until the United States Government details the commitments it will make to aid in the reconstruction of Britain, well-informed exporters and foreign trade bankers stated yesterday.

THIS is a posthumous volume to which Leonard Woolf attaches a note saying many of the stories are incomplete or unperfected. It includes six out of the eight stories in "Monday or Tuesday," published in 1921, seven stories subsequently published in magazines, and five unpublished stories, which Mr. Woolf lets go with some hesitation since they were never revised and are only in the stage "beyond that of her first sketch."

Recommendations designed to bring about orderly disposal of war surpluses both in this country and abroad, compiled by the eight industry committees of the Utilization of Surplus War Materials Committee of the New York Board of Trade, Inc., with which twenty-five national associations are cooperating, call for eliminating the speculative elements found after the last war, and utilization of regular channels of trade for such disposal with a minimum of destructive effects upon normal business.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 15 -- When it rains at Wilmington it pours. The Giants learned that today upon arriving for an exhibition meeting with Freddy Fitzsimmons' Blue Jays, Phils or what-have-you. And not even the du Ponts could save the situation.

BLUEBERRIES are among the twice-blest shrubs whose value as ornaments is as great as the popularity of their fruit on the table. Grapes trained over a shade-giving arbor, strawberries in a gaily painted barrel at the kitchen door, espalier trees with their interesting forms along a wall, and even the pear tree tossing its petals on the lawn, welcome the addition of blueberry bushes to their beauty-dispensing ranks.

FRANK TAYLOR, editor for Reynal Hitchcock, was in Cambridge the day Bernard De Voto bought a copy of "Strange Fruit" to bring the "test" court action sought by the Civil Liberties Union. Wishing to keep the unpleasantries at a minimum, Mr. Taylor asked all parties involved to lunch -- Mr. Isenstadt, the bookseller (University Law Book Exchange), and the officer of the law who had just served him with a summons.

RICHMOND, Va., April 15 -- Even though Senator Byrd has discouraged the Byrd-for-President movement, started last autumn by John U. Barr, New Orleans manufacturer, a meeting was held at Greensboro, N.C., this week of delegates advertised as representing Virginia, West Virginia and the two Carolinas.
I'm mad -- but I'm not mad at you, so you're the fellow who's getting this letter. I'm mad at a full two-thirds of the motion picture critics, commentators and columnists. And I'll tell you why.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- President Roosevelt named the United States delegation to the International Labor Office Conference today with Robert J. Watt, International Representative of the American Federation of Labor since 1936, as sole representative of organized labor.

ON April 21 Princess Elizabeth, heir presumptive to the British throne, will be 18 years old, and according to British law she then comes of age, three years earlier than the ordinary citizen. At 18 she is subject to call under the National Service Act, but she will not join any of the women's war services.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 15 -- O.J. Christgau, State superintendent of the Iowa Anti-Saloon League, wired Capt. Edward V. Rickenbacker today asking if his recent promise to buy Major Richard Bong a case of Scotch whisky was "incorrectly quoted."

WASHINGTON, April 15 (U.P.) -- A rationing official disclosed tonight that plans were progressing for increasing the "B" gasoline ration provided that various "economies," including curtailment of black-market operations, were effected within the current gasoline allocations.

Pressing its campaign against alleged violators of price-ceiling regulations, the Regional Office of Price Administration announced yesterday that it had collected $71,000 in treble damages from one New York City wholesale dry goods concern, and that it had filed treble damage suits for $48,000 against three additional concerns in the Federal Court in Manhattan.

QUITE the most impressive show thus far of paintings by George Constant is the new attraction at the Ferargil. Admitting Constant to be an able painter, I have never been impressed by his fat, large-eyed, somewhat Byzantine babies; but this show has variety of both subject-matter and manner.

The voice of America assumed new authority in world affairs during the past week when Secretary Hull, supplemented by Assistant Secretary Long, spoke up to explain anew the foundations, the aims, the ideals -- and the limitations -- of American foreign policy.
OAKLAND, Calif., April 15 -- The Multnomah Club 400-yard freestyle relay team of Portland, Ore., broke its record in the Women's National A.A.U. senior swimming and diving meet tonight.

JOSEPH BARONE'S New York Little Symphony gives its fourth, and possibly last concert of the season at the Carnegie Chamber Music Hall Friday evening. Mr. Barone, whose main object is to introduce young talent to New York concertgoers, reports that thus far in the season he has presented eleven artists, including one 'cellist, two pianists, one violinist, two conductors (one of each sex), one composer, one soprano, one baritone and two composer-conductors.

The pattern for the Battle of Europe was being set last week. From the east, the west and the south heavy blows were being rained on Germany, its satellites and its conquered area, and new blows were to come.

EDWARD GROSS, who produced the dramatization of Rosemary Taylor's book, "Chicken Every Sunday," with what appears to be happy results, is on the verge of purchasing the dramatic rights of another book, this a novel.

It is to be regretted that the well-deserved tribute to Major General Chennault appearing in THE TIMES Magazine did not also include a few words of praise for William D. Pawley. For it was this energetic and patriotic American who, as early as 1937, emphasized the importance of defending the Burma Road.

NAPLES, April 15 -- A six-party Junta of Italian opposition parties effected the link between the King's announcement of his pending retirement ond a shake-up in the Badoglio Government by voting four to one, with the Socialists abstaining, to participate in a new Government along the indicated lines.
WASHINGTON, April 15 (U.P.) -- Several American merchant ships have disappeared during this war without any trace ever being found of the vessels or their crews, it was learned tonight.

NEITHER Colonel Wickham of Scotland Yard nor Dr. Eustace Hailey of Harley Street wishes to believe that Pilot Officer Tom Brooke, R.A.F., murdered Sir Andrew Miles, father of the girl Tom intended to marry.

BOSTON, April 15 -- Manpower sources in New England are running dry. Not only draft boards, with their strangely fluctuating requirements, but manufacturers of war materials are scraping the bottom of the barrel in a hunt for more men.

THE evenings are still lovely with starlit skies. The earth, as always, is beautiful. As my life draws to a close I now perceive the very oneness of time and earth. My mind is peopled with the folk of history; I know now that Chaucer was a virtual contemporary of John Keats, Attila of Adolf Hitler.

THE past week's development in Italy with regard to the promised retirement of King Victor Emmanuel conceivably foreshadows new Italian postal paper. Even should the sovereign retain his title as King, the circumstance of Crown Prince Humbert's heading the state would, in the opinion of philatelic observers, result in the issuing of a new series of stamps, with Humbert's picture as the design.

SOUTH PORTLAND, Me., April 15 (AP) -- Three Liberty ships, two of which are to be assigned to the British Ministry of War Transport by the United States Maritime Commission, were formally named today at the yard of the New England Shipbuilding Corporation.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The Russians do not use American lend-lease butter to grease their boots nor do the British charge up Washington whisky parties against lend-lease funds, Leo T. Crowley, Foreign Economics Director, said in a statement to the House Foreign Affairs Committee which was published today.
Bare backs and bare shoulders are important factors in the spring and summer styles. This holds good for casual hours in the country and sophisticated evenings in town.

FOR several weeks now the art season has, we might say, been running true to theme. There was the recent week when the whole town, virtually, went abstract. This was followed by the blithe arrival upon the local scene of Cuba.

LIKE a rich cake, made richer by the addition of currants and topped off with a thick frosting, there is a lavish amount of reading fare offered in "All in Good Time." The author has a penetrating knowledge of New England, its history and its people.
CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, April 15 (AP) -- Relatives of Mrs. Mary Jane Drummond who died here two days ago, reported yesterday finding in two pieces of canvas her savings of $20,321.

AS a nation at war we have, in the press, made more of our grievances than of our grief. But our writers, if good at all, have been concerned with the real values for which we fight. For this reason we have had little old-fashioned patriotic verse.

NAPLES, April 15 -- The attack in great strength by American four-motored bombers on Bucharest and Ploesti today renewed the smashing offensive against the Axis in the Balkans by Lieut. Gen. Ira C. Eaker's Mediterranean Allied Air Forces.

Drastic revision of this country's present policies with regard to the Italian situation and assurance that the United States will not take part either directly or indirectly in forcing the "inclusion of Communist or pro-Fascist elements in a coalition government in Italy" were urged in a resolution adopted yesterday at an emergency meeting of the Italian-American Labor Council.

SLIPCOVERS have long since graduated from the summer-protector class to rank as one of the decorator's most versatile devices. Besides being the ideal expedient for prolonging the life of precious prewar upholstery, a new slipcover may also be the key to a whole new color scheme.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Selective Service Director, told farmers today that their "first duty" was to make available for Army or Navy service every possible draft-deferred man under 26.

LONDON, April 15 (U.P.) -- Eire's economic and geographic isolation tightened tonight when the Allies' policy of cracking down on neutrals that might give direct or indirect aid to the Axis was implemented by two new actions.

ALBANY, April 15 -- Governor Dewey left Albany today for his Pawling farm where, for the next ten days, he will enjoy his first vacation since last November. He plans to return here April 28, the day after he addresses the American Newspaper Publishers Association in New York City.

MELBOURNE, April 11 (Delayed) -- Through lend-lease provision of engineering plans and material and the skill and resourcefulness of American and Australian technicians, the war has brought an undreamed development to Australia's empty north and her territories in Papua, Hew Guinea.

Chemical developments in non-woven fabrics will cause no revolutionary change in the textile industry, research men stated yesterday. But if the industry does not take the offensive in the field of research, chemical companies doing pioneering work with fabrics made by paper and plastics techniques would take the play away from them, they said.

Marlyn Eugene Wissinger, former Marine who was wounded and saw service at Guadalcanal, was scheduled to be married yesterday in Amsterdam, N.Y., but his wedding plans were held in abeyance until a grand jury tomorrow reviews a Sullivan Law charge against him.

Final arrangements have been completed for the annual Red, White and Blue Dinner Dance for the benefit of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York, which will take place Friday night in the ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton.

CAMP SIBERT, Ala., April 13 (Delayed) -- Newspaper correspondents saw the chemical training unit give a demonstration today of the Army's ability to retaliate with poison gas if and when it becomes necessary.

It could be that Colonel McCormick of The Chicago Tribune wrote that letter with tongue in cheek. He has applied to the War Production Board for a supply of newsprint to operate a new morning paper in Milwaukee.

With the enactment into law of the Coudert bill to give more power to the Superintendent of Schools the New York City school system has witnessed the most important change that has taken place since its consolidation more than forty years ago. For the first time the pedagogical problems of the city will be determined by the chief school executive and not by a board of nine members.

MISS MABEL COBB painted a lurid picture in your columns last Sunday of prevailing trade customs in the field of radio writing. One supposes that there may be almost as many "release" forms as there are competitive advertising agencies, networks and local stations and perhaps some standardization of trade practice in this area is desirable.

ALTHOUGH the number of children's books published annually exceeds, with the exception of fiction, the number published in any other class, most adult readers have never discovered that books for children are not a side issue but an integral, rewarding part of the whole field of literature and art.

AKRON, Ohio, April 15 -- From now until the end of the war any Seiberling Rubber Company employe who leads a strike or incites other workers to strike will not be permitted to enter the plant or resume work for the company, J. Penfield Seiberling, president, said today in letters to the company's 2,000 workers.

The celebration of Easter in accordance with the traditional liturgical usages of the Eastern Orthodox churches beginning at midnight or shortly before, continues today and will end this afternoon in Easter vespers. The Gospels will be ready in several languages to depict the universality of the Christian religion.
The Government launched widespread attacks in the Federal courts in this area yesterday against price ceiling violators.

THIS is a "purely technical volume." Its purpose is to examine, critically, the "sampling techniques" used by the Gallup Poll and similar barometers of public opinion. "It is imperative," Mr. Cantril explains, "that the methods used by those who take upon themselves the responsibility for reporting opinion be carefully and constantly reviewed."

IN its annual statistical report on the season which ends today, the New York Philharmonic-Symphony revealed that it has given 113 concerts, including ninety-eight regular subscription concerts, six Young People's Concerts and nine special concerts.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 15 -- The speeches delivered yesterday in Buenos Aires by President Edelmiro Farrell and acting Foreign Minister Diego Mason during the celebration of Pan American Day were a grave disappointment to all those who believed, or at least hoped, that they would seize the occasion to make some special gesture of friendliness toward the United Nations in general and the United States in particular.

NEWARK, N.J., April 15 (AP) -- The whipping of hundreds of rods and the singing of reels indicated today that devotees of Izaak Walton do not let threatening skies or unseasonable cold deter them in their pursuit of the elusive trout in New Jersey's streams.

As the city-wide campaign for $22,386,000 for the Red Cross 1944 War Fund stood at slightly less than $2,000,000 short of its goal at the week-end, five communities of central Queens led the field in last-minute contributions. Total contributions in Queens of $1,047,183 were announced by Ambrose B. Acker, campaign chairman for the area. The quota is $1,083,000.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- Aside from Gen. Douglas MacArthur's continuing military triumphs against the Japanese in the Southwest Pacific, two events this week served to focus public discussions by Central Westerners on him. The first was his demonstration of strength as a possible Republican Presidential nominee in Tuesday's Illinois preference primary.

SOME one of these days, when I am completely out of range of actors, directors, playwrights and critics, unable to dig a garden or play a set of tennis, I shall settle down in that proverbial armchair and "tell all" about the Theatre Guild.

THE old adage that a woman can throw out more with a teaspoon than a man can bring in with a shovel is substantiated by the War Food Administration, which tells us that 15 per cent of the food purchased in this country is discarded. It urges housekeepers to make the most of what they buy, and recommends to their attention a survey conducted by the engineering research laboratory of New York University.

REBECCA WEST, the British novelist, once wrote of certain men who seemed to move only in pale moonlight where their forms were dimly visible, the details of their actions being obscured. Ten years ago that could have been said of the nine justices of the Supreme Court, whose Olympian detachment appeared as their outstanding characteristic.

In his final public speech on Feb. 17 the late Director of the Office of Defense Transportation, Joseph B. Eastman, presented a "primer" on governmental administrative tribunals. For twenty-nine years Mr. Eastman served on such tribunals; from 1915 to 1919 on the Massachusetts Public Service Commission and from 1919 until his death (except for temporary leaves to do other governmental work) on the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Although sodden, weeping skies washed out the Yankees-Dodgers game at Ebbets Field yesterday, some entirely unexpected and bright rays of sunshine flooded the Montague Street offices of the Brooklyn Club. For, believe it or not, the Brooks came up with three more valuable ball players.

It occurs to me that the editors and readers of THE TIMES will be interested in certain facts concerning this marine, since no mention of him is made in the Tarawa piece.

Despite the war, there has been no major change in the curriculum of either the elementary or secondary schools of England, although many regular subjects are now studied in the light of wartime problems and developments. In a report on the "British Schools and the War," the British Information Service reveals that the children are receiving an adequate education, and that schooling is not neglected.

ANGLO-AMERICAN relations, though variable, are unlike the weather. Everyone not only talks about them but tries to do something about them. It may seem at times that, as Shaw says, we really are two nations divided by the same language, but actually we are both aware that we shine or fade together.

When the war ends, vast sections of Europe and Asia will be in need of reconstruction and rehabilitation. Engineers will be called upon to rebuild houses, roads, parks, bridges and utilities that have been destroyed. Recognizing this fact, American educators are prepared to take an active hand in post-war work.

Dorothy Holcomb, young American conductor, led the New York Chamber Symphony, composed of members of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, in a concert last night in Town Hall. Miss Holcomb, who is on the music faculty of St. Mary's College, Holy Cross, Ind., made her New York debut directing the New York Little Symphony, but her appearance yesterday evening was her first here in a full-length program.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- A week after their joint plea to all those classified 4F in the draft to get into work essential to the war, Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Director of Selective Service, and Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, were without definite word as to how effective their request has been.

A new organization, the Vermont Council on Higher Education, has been formed under the chairmanship of Dr. John S. Millis, president of the University of Vermont. The council has evolved from a conference of heads of higher education in the State, called to consider post-war educational problems.

The Russian Armies drove to the vicinity of the Carpathian passes last week, broke through the principal German defenses of the Crimea and were completing the task of mopping up remaining enemy resistance in all of southern Russia.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Travel to and from children's summer camps again will be restricted this year, the Office of Defense Transportation announced today.
ALBANY, April 15 -- Governor Dewey announced today the appointment of Magistrate Nicholas H. Pinto of Brooklyn as county judge of Kings County to succeed the late Judge Peter J. Brancato.

A larger number of buyers were in the market last week to replenish stocks badly depleted by the unusually active Easter business, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

ONE of the most rewarding group shows the Downtown Gallery has put on opened last week with recent oils, water-colors, sculpture and drawings by a score of artists whose names are associated with the gallery.

MAURICE ZOLOTOW, an elongated guy who, to the casual spectator, seems to be nothing much but eyeglasses and Adam's apple, has become an important fellow in the slick magazines as the historian of Broadway.

Retail trade was generally good last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main floor accessory departments continued active and children's sections were crowded.

The Easter holidays moved slowly to a close last week in Washington. The President was away, resting at an undisclosed place in the South, but since the official theory is that the White House is where the President is, messages started flowing toward the Capitol signed "Franklin D. Roosevelt, White House."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Sunday, April 16 (U.P.) -- Australian jungle fighters on the northern New Guinea coast are pushing toward the large enemy base of Madang from captured Bogadjim while Allied airmen swept over scattered Japanese airfields and sank at least five small ships, it was announced today.

THIS book, by a recognized authority on physical anthropology, is the best attempt which has been made to date to present the facts of man's development in simple, readable form. The style is smooth and informal with many amusing asides, and only a specialist can appreciate the care required in sorting and arranging this mass of material.

At the conclusion of a survey of all available data on aviation insurance, the Civil Aeronautics Board has decided that it cannot at this time determine whether the premium rates charged are "fair and reasonable"; that continued observation of the aviation insurance market is in order, and that the only efficient way to collect such information is to vest appropriate authority and responsibility in a single agency of the Federal Government.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Representative Sol Bloom, chairman of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, called on both major parties today to insert a platform plank pledging that peace treaties concluded after this war would be validated by a majority vote of both Houses rather than by a two-thirds majority of the Senate.

Leaders of civic and labor groups here met yesterday to endorse immediate action in the United States Senate in favor of the Anti-Poll Tax Bill, which is scheduled to come up for debate this week. The delegates met under the auspices of the Negro Labor Victory Committee in the Hotel Capitol.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Admiral Ernest J. King, Chief of Naval Operations and Commander in Chief of the United States Fleet, today described the crippled condition of the Japanese fleet and merchant marine and promised to demonstrate within the "next few months" that our Navy could create opportunities "to strike whenever we can get within range of their warships or bases."

ST. LOUIS, April 15 -- Eighteen horses appear certain to start in the Kentucky Derby, Betting Commissioner James J. Carroll said today in announcing that Stir Up had taken the favorite's spot at 4 to 1 in his winter book.

New York State has taken purgative action against those stockholders' derivative actions which are known commonly as strike suits. After submission of a report by a special committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York on Feb. 5, the Legislature and Governor Dewey moved so rapidly that the opponents of the measure hardly had time to make a plan of campaign.

THE fifty-second annual exhibition presented by the National Association of Women Artists opened last week in the American Fine Arts Galleries, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. The long list of prize-winners was published in our Wednesday column.

The American Field Service will be aided by the performance of George Abbott's new production, "A Highland Fling," on the night of May 1 at the Plymouth Theatre. Ambulances and their volunteer drivers of the Field Service are serving in Italy, India and Burma.

Women have been faring well in the George Ruppert fishing contest, according to the latest report on that piscatorial marathon, and one of them, Mrs. Rose Saul Montgomery, hails from New York City. Mrs. Montgomery leads in the shark division with a hammerhead weighing 158 pounds, which is still a long way from last year's winning 282.

OMAHA, Neb., April 15 -- There is doubt in the Middle Western farm States that the draft respite given men over 26 years of age will be of long duration. A good many local boards are near the end of their reserve of men in the younger group. Some may not be able to forward their full current month's quota to the induction camps.
CHICAGO, April 15 (AP) -- The very uncertainties which face baseball as it opens its third wartime season could produce one of the most interesting and exciting campaigns the sport has ever known.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- States' rights issues have boiled over anew in Congress, with threats that the recurring controversies which raise them will have cumulative effects far-reaching and serious, not only in the legislative branch of the government but in the general political picture of the country.

LONDON, April 15 -- An outline of the pre-invasion air strategy in western Europe has been revealed in the Anglo-American operations of the last three weeks in which, for the first time since 1940, the majority of bombing missions from these islands has been directed against enemy railroads and air fields rather than heavy industry, heretofore the chief objective of the Allied air effort.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 15 -- Down through the great central valley of California there was developing this week a bitter controversy over irrigation policy, with repercussions reaching into arid regions throughout the Far West.

CANCER has been described as both the great mystery and the continuing failure of medicine. Even its very name is shrouded in mystery, for no one knows what caused Hippocrates, more than two thousand years ago, so to name it.

IF you hear balletomanes wandering around babbling about having seen Bronislava Tchaikovsky as the Blackamoor in Leonide de Mille's "Princess Aurora and the Wolf," think nothing of it. With two ballet companies going full blast and hurling premieres at each other by the twos and threes, confusion is simply the normal state of mind.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., April 15 -- The Chimneys, sixty-seven-acre estate of the late Mrs. Christian R. Holmes in Sands Point, L.I., has been turned over to the War Shipping Administration for the duration and six months thereafter, to be used as a rest and recreational center for members of the American Merchant Marine who have been on sea duty for long stretches.

Botanists call them Erythronium, but country folk know them as dogtooth violets, spotted adder's tongues, or trout lilies. Whatever the name, they will soon be doing April justice in the moist woodland, their butter-yellow blossoms reaching on long stems toward the midday sun.

MR. BRYNES has written a book which is not devoid of stimulating thoughts, but which on the whole leaves, at least this reader, without any definite conclusions. He envisages a world of the future that will be a world of continental units -- America (sometimes he seems to treat the United States as a continent, sometimes the whole hemisphere), England and Western Europe, Russia and China-Japan.
SOMEWHAT less than the usual post-Easter let-down in trade was reported last week and it was remarked that the sale of articles, on which higher excise taxes must now be paid, was still quite active.

CHICAGO, April 15 (AP) -- Hogs weighing more than 270 pounds composed the bulk of offerings today in the livestock markets here and prices on these broke 25 to 50 cents a hundredweight as a result of the removal of Government support from these weights. Swine in the 200 to 270-pound bracket were steady at $13.75, the top.

Before the Fifth War Loan drive is ended on July 8, it is expected, the twelve central banks of the Federal Reserve System will be called upon to help their member banks, and the Government bond market generally, by purchasing about $3,000,000,000 of Government securities from the banks and in the open market.

MOSCOW, April 15 (AP) -- American-made jeeps and trucks have arrived with the Red Army in Rumania and are playing their part in the advance into the Balkans, a Red Star correspondent with Marshal Gregory K. Zhukoff's First Ukrainian Army reported today.

The Pennsylvania-Central Airlines Corporation has called for redemption on May 15, at $27 a share and accrued dividends, its 52,088 shares of preferred stock, which is convertible into common stock at the rate of two common shares for each preferred share.

BOSTON, April 15 -- "If we do not have international education we shall not have peace or trade or law or any internationalism at all, for human institutions reside in people's minds," Prof. Ralph Barton Perry of Harvard said this afternoon at the opera victory rally broadcast from the Boston Opera House during the third intermission of "Faust."

PEARL HARBOR, April 15 -- Three admirals were decorated today by Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet and Pacific Ocean areas, for brilliancy and valor in command of recent Central Pacific actions.

ALGIERS, April 15 -- Among members of the Consultative Assembly today there were discreet murmurs of opposition to recent actions taken by Gen. Charles de Gaulle and the French Committee of National Liberation without consulting or informing the Assembly.

Seventeen thousand income taxpayers filed their returns in person at the State Office Building, Worth and Centre Streets, yesterday, and in Brooklyn another 5,300 filed theirs at the office of the third district, comprising Long Island, at 320 Schermerhorn Street.

WHEN Private Peter Marrell, on furlough, is asked to go to Cliff End, on Long Island, to investigate the death of a Great Dane, he is sure that there is another reason for the invitation, but he does not know what that reason is.

FRIENDSHIP'S ALBUMS bound in blue or green plush lay on the parlor tables in Jackson, Tex., in 1873, and every one of the cushiony little books was stuffed with pretty quotations -- just such lines as this one which Louise Mally has chosen as the title of her first novel.

Even without the presence of Devil Diver in the Excelsior Handicap, headlining the card at Jamaica yesterday, the 30,129 racing enthusiasts who braved the rain witnessed a race they won't forget for many a day.

BOSTON, April 15 -- A resolution demanding immediate enactment of legislation that would prohibit the undertaking of any Federal Water Resources project which involved land-taking without first receiving the consent of States concerned was unanimously adopted today at the final session of the Eastern States Conservation Conference.

HOW many visitors to the zoo take notice of the expressions of the animals excepting those of the monkey tribe? Mr. Perkins, who is curator of the Buffalo Zoological Gardens, believes that very few persons do.

THE International Labor Conference will open in Philadelphia on Thursday with delegates from about forty nations attending. The preparation of the program has required a vast amount of additional correspondence from the International Labor Office and the League of Nations, each with headquarters in Geneva, to persons who will attend the meeting and to the United States offices of the two organizations.

LONDON, April 15 -- The Allied air support for American and British troops invading the Continent will act on the enemy as an anaesthetic, enabling the attacking force to strike while the foe is stunned and rendered ineffective as a fighter, it was said tonight by two airmen in an Anglo-American broadcast from here to the United States.

Two graceful performers from the host club, 12-year-old Donna Jeanne Pospisil and 19-year-old Robert Swenning, dominated the twenty-third annual Middle Atlantic figure-skating championships held yesterday before an enthusiastic crowd at Iceland rink, atop Madison Square Garden.

THE nostalgia many Americans feel for the Paris that was may be assuaged by a visit to one of the little theatres in New York which periodically revive "Sous les Toits de Paris." But Rene Clair, who directed this and other musical films with the same background, seems less impressed than his audiences by his skill at recording the petty crooks and artists and their girlfriends, the cautious bourgeoisie, the shabby gaiety of the bistros.

LONDON, April 15 -- Charlton Athletic sprang one of the greatest surprises in two decades of big league football at Wembley Stadium today in winning the League South Cup by defeating favored Chelsea, 3 -- 1.

DURING the sixteen performances of seven works to be presented by the New York City Center Opera Company during its two-week spring season, starting Monday, May 1, at City Center, a number of new singers will be heard.
NEW DELHI, India, April 15 (AP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

Pre-season baseball predictions, even in normal times, border somewhat on the nonsensical. In wartimes that is doubly true. For no one can say what the future of baseball will be. The start of this third wartime season finds the problems of the first two years accentuated. But those problems are not insurmountable.

DAVY CROCKETT weighed 200 pounds 14 ounces when he was born and was frisky as a wildcat. So that he would "grow proper," his family planted him in good Tennessee earth and watered him with wild buffalo's milk, with boiled corncobs and tobacco leaves mixed in.

OMAHA, April 15 (AP) -- Giving way to rising Missouri River flood waters, the John Young levee southwest of Modale, Iowa, went out today, inundating an estimated 15,000 acres of farmland and threatening Highway 30 between Missouri Valley, Iowa, and the Blair (Neb.) bridge.

LONDON, April 15 (U.P.) -- Heavy fighting has broken out in the heart of Yugoslavia where German forces axe attempting to drive the Partisans of Marshal Tito from the Fruska Gora hills, thirty miles northwest of Belgrade, the Partisans announced today.

NEW ORLEANS, April 15 -- Here in the Deep South, public-spirited citizens are becoming more and more insistent that opportunity be afforded to soldiers, not only overseas but in camps in this country, to cast their votes. It is safe to say the demand has become so great in Louisiana for balloting to be made easier for those in the armed services that the present State law will be amended.

After months of trepidation and no small amount of misgivings, major league baseball, which has operated without interruption since the founding of the National League in 1876, goes to the post this week for its third successive championship campaign under wartime conditions.

SOMEHOW the belief has got around that living in the country is something like a perpetual vacation. Probably country folk themselves are to blame, because so many of them put on their second-best bib and tucker when visitors arrive from the city and devote the whole week-end to enjoying life.

Hungary's army, drawn up before Russian forces poised at the Hungarian border, was told in a grim order of the day by Admiral Nicholas Horthy, the Regent, yesterday that "the war is now approaching its final phase and has reached a decisive stage, particularly as regards the fate of Hungary."

CAIRO, Egypt, April 14 (Delayed) -- American troops in the Middle East were reminded by this week's issue of Stars and Stripes, which appeared today, that the initiative remained with them if they wanted to participate in the Presidential election.

London last week was the center of a new phase of Anglo-American diplomatic activity. Groups of American and British experts headed by Under Secretary of State Edward R. Stettinius Jr. and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden began a fortnight's series of conferences on mutual problems of the war and the peace.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 15 -- American industry must prepare now "to establish our peacetime society on the solid foundation of an enlightened system of free enterprise," Donald K. David, Dean of the Harvard Business School, said today in his annual report.

ATLANTA, April 15 -- By and large, Southern politicians, in Congress and out, like Captain Reese of the mantelpiece, have seen their duty and done it in the matter of vehement declaration against the Supreme Court decision giving the vote to Negroes in Texas primary elections.

The Catholic rural life movement, a nation-wide group of laymen, religious leaders, priests and Bishops dedicated to maintaining and restoring family life on the farm, will hold summer schools and institutes in thirty-six communities of the East, the Midwest and the Southwest during May, June, July and August, it was announced yesterday.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday reported for the three months ended on March 31, the March figures partly estimated, a net income of $40,464,000 after charges and taxes, equal to $2.14 each on the average of 18,875,000 shares of capital stock outstanding.

At the sixth and last concert of the season's Young People's Concerts of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall yesterday morning, Rudolph Ganz conducting, Artur Rodzinski, musical director of the orchestra, presented medals, ribbons and special prizes to thirty-five boys and girls ranging in age from 4 to 16 years, for superior notebooks based on this season's concerts.

An increase of 6 per cent last year in the number of children given care by the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York was reported yesterday by the Rev. John J. Lennon, director of the children's division.

PEARL HARBOR, April 15 -- One outstanding factor in the successful sea-air war against the Japanese in the Pacific has been the score of the senior carrier group of fighter, torpedo and bomber pilots now in the Pacific. The air group has just finished at Palau its eighth major action.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 15 -- President Getulio Vargas told a press conference today that after the war Brazilians would have the opportunity to choose their own democratic representative government.

Cornell University will again be one of the leading centers of Russian instruction in the United States this summer, conducting a comprehensive study of the civilization of Russia in a twelve-week session from July 3 to Sept. 23. Sixteen staff members, authorities on different aspects of present-day Russia, have been employed.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade fluctuated today in a nervous manner. Short covering resulted in a fair rally after an early break, but late in the session houses with Southwestern connections sold wheat futures and the market eased quickly.

At the regular meeting of the board of directors of the American Kennel Club held last Tuesday, approval was given to the plan adopted by the delegates at the annual meeting of the club in March for the collection of a recording fee for each dog entered at future member and licensed dog shows, including field trials, where championship points are competed for.
ALGIERS, April 15 -- Having been for months in what may be called a state of effervescent obscurity, the French situation became suddenly clearer this week as a result of two oddly timed events.

THE ten American soldiers and two Filipinos had been fighting their way through the swamps and jungles of the Philippine island of Mindanao for several days after their escape from the Japanese prison camp at Davao.

"HIGH TIDE AT NOON" is a kind of novel we rarely see in these days, perhaps because most novelists are too harassed and battered by the claims of the present to remember the past in tranquillity. There is room and to spare for this sort of evocative writing.

Charles Grutzner's story on Axequebracho wood in THE TIMES Magazine was very interesting to anyone familiar with foreign hard woods. It aroused dormant memories of an industry now almost wholly replaced by vulcanized rubber, i.e. bowling balls, which used to be turned out of hard heavy woods imported chiefly from Central and South America and the West Indies, and to some extent from the Near East.

Dr. Louis Mark of Columbus, Ohio, led a field of thirty-six contract bridge masters into the third of five sessions in the American Contract Bridge League's fourteenth annual masters' individual tournament at the Park Central Hotel here last night.
Eight promotions in the faculties of the Graduate School, School of Education, and Fordham College were announced yesterday by the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- Chairman Paul V. McNutt of the Manpower Commission told regional directors today that although some war production cutbacks were coming, "we anticipate little unemployment in the near future."

STUDIO executives have estimated that the major companies will take a loss of at least $2,000,000 on war story properties that were acquired during the last two years and since have been shelved because of the fast-changing status of the conflict and the decreasing theatregoer interest in war plots.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. James H. Marshall of Newton Center, Mass., are at Hampshire House.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Emphasis on youth threw the manpower situation this week into a crisis that probably will keep the long-vexing problem painfully in the forefront for some months to come.

MARK J. GAYN'S autobiography is the story of a Russian boy who discovered his vocation at the age of 13 and pursued it with undeflected singleness of purpose through five systems of formal education, two revolutions and almost perpetual war.

THE books we read in our adolescent years, I suspect, have a stronger influence on our attitude toward life, and a larger share in forming our tastes and preferences than those whose acquaintance we make earlier or later.

WHEN Professor Macdonald lost his position at the university and financial reverses came to the family, it seemed a wise plan to send the four young Macdonalds to a rundown farm willed to him by a cousin and let him see what they could do with it, while he finished the textbook he was writing and the children's mother gave a series of lectures on interior decorating to help the family exchequer.

A YUGOSLAV NAVAL BASE, Italy, April 15 -- The tiny Yugoslav Partisan fleet has established a small naval base in Italy from which the limited supplies furnished by the western Allies to Marshal Tito are transshipped across the Adriatic Sea.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 15 -- Whether Pan-Americanism is to remain at its present stage as a concept of continental union or is to take on a more definite significance as an economic structure on a basis mutually advantageous has been the outstanding point of the debates at the Conference of American Parliaments, which closed here today.

HAVANA, April 14 (Delayed) -- The National Commission for the Study of Post-War Problems, created last May by President Fulgencio Batista, today made public its agenda and appealed to the press for cooperation.

THE quondam wunderkind, Erich Wolfgang Korngold, is back on Broadway. If you have any nostalgic inclinations for the Vienna of the lilting waltz, wienerschnitzel, creamed coffee -- pre-Hitler, of course -- you may satisfy them, figuratively speaking, by viewing this moonfaced, well rounded gentleman.

BALTIMORE, April 15 -- Tola Rose, 7-year-old campaigner carrying the silks of A.J. Sackett of Jacksonville, Fla., defeated four younger horses today to win the sixth Bowie Handicap at Pimlico. The son of Head Play, once conqueror of Whirlaway, earned $5,875 in his first start since last November, boosting his lifetime total to $79,045.

LONDON, April 15 -- It is difficult for the British to view Wendell Willkie's withdrawal from the Presidential race, Secretary Cordell Hull's broadcast speech on the outlines of the American foreign policy and Under-Secretary of State Edward R. Stettinius' visit to this country as separate and unconnected incidents.
Miss Helena Mroczkowska, national fencing champion, retained her metropolitan open title by defeating five opponents in the final round-robin yesterday on the strips of the Fencers Club.

The home of Mrs. Donald S. Stralem at 941 Park Avenue will be the setting Tuesday for a preliminary tea to launch plans for an auction to be held next month at the Plaza Art Galleries, 9 East Fifty-ninth Street, under the auspices of the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy, of which Mrs. Junius S. Morgan is chairman.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 15 (AP) -- H.W. Voorhees of Skillman, N.J., who has been re-elected president of Free Farmers, asserted today that the organization had succeeded in its announced aim to "stop John L. Lewis in his scheme to take over dairymen against their wishes."
KEARNY, N.J., April 15 -- The destroyer Haynsworth, ninth "pocket cruiser" to slide down the ways at United States Steel's Federal shipyard here, was launched at 2:52 P.M. today.

THE skeptics who said that vegetables could not be grown in New York City were wrong. Four hundred thousand Victory gardeners proved that tons of vegetables could be harvested last year in the five boroughs of the metropolis.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 15 -- Outstanding among the hunters in the opening sessions of the annual spring indoor horse show of the Boulder Brook Club in its riding hall on Old Mamaroneck Road today was the Kentucky-bred thoroughbred bay gelding Mathematician, owned by Mrs. Elizabeth Correll of Scarsdale, and ridden in his most important competition by Mrs. W. Haggin Perry.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., April 15 (AP) -- With a crowd of close to 25,000 building up a million-dollar handle for the first time at a spring race meeting in New England, Mrs. H.P. Bonner's Defense today won the $5,000 added Spring Handicap at Narraganset Park.

WHEN Anna Catherina, Miss Fries' real-life heroine, came at nearly 90 to lie under her numbered marker set flat in the grass of "God's Acre" at Salem in North Carolina in 1816, the congregation must have had a summary of her life drawn up, read aloud and deposited in its archives, where lay already the four similar "Memoirs" compiled successively at the deaths of her four husbands.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The situation in India, which had been somewhat more encouraging until the renewal of extreme Japanese pressure on Imphal, continued to dominate the spotlight in the Far Eastern war this week, although the steady progress of American and Allied forces in the Southwest and Central Pacific probably was of more immediate importance to the Allied cause.

Walt Whitman lived in a stirring time and heard much talk of democracy. But he wasn't content with talk of it. He wrote: "Did you, too, O friend, suppose democracy only for elections, for politics?" He looked forward, he said, to its flower and fruit "in the highest forms of interaction between men and their beliefs in all public and private life."

LORIC and Minoche are two young people in France who met and fell in love in Pors Gwen (a seaside town in Brittany) during the war-clouded days of the summer of 1938. In any other year in any other more tranquil era the story of their love would have been remarkable only as any young love is remarkable -- for its freshness, its innocence, its joy in living.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 15 -- On the basis of market figures for the San Francisco Bay area, Federal authorities estimated today that Californians, preferring meat to butter, and unable to get all they wanted of either under the point rationing system, were using less than one-fourth as much butter per capita now than in the pre-war years pf 1940 and 1941.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- Representative Joseph Martin of Massachusetts, minority leader of the House, appeared to be the unanimous choice for permanent chairman of the Republican National Convention as members of the Committee on Arrangements began arriving here today for their meeting Wednesday.

THE crisis of our times, writes the French philosopher Jacques Maritain, has come about because modern man has drawn away from his God and from the Christian principles which assure the dignity of personality.

NEW DELHI, India, April 15 -- The Japanese have blocked the road to Dimapur out of Kohima and still hold stretches of the Bishenpur-Silchar track out of Imphal, Allied headquarters acknowledged today as Allied forces fought jungle battles to clear these land connections between the Bengal-Assam railroad and the two threatened Allied strongholds in northeastern India.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 15 (AP) -- One of about fifty foreign planes that passed over southern Sweden today crashed in flames near Laholm, the Swedish defense staff announced, and a man in an American uniform who had jumped from the plane was killed.

The Government's plan to build and operate a pipeline from the Arabian oil fields to the Mediterranean is fraught with dangers to world peace after this war unless an agreement is reached with all other nations that might be affected, Herbert Feis, former economic adviser to the State Department, told the Foreign Policy Association at a luncheon yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

OCCASIONALLY we in this corner have had some sad comments to make upon the generally disheartening manner in which American fact films have shown the war. Or perhaps we should say the manner in which they haven't shown it to us, for the fault has been more of omission than of commission, most of the time.

AFTER filling a number of weeks with somewhat dubious enterprises, the Broadway theatre pulled itself together in the final few days before Easter and offered some shows for a change. In all, the week before the holiday had five openings, and since three of them boasted merit of one sort or another the whole thing resembled nothing so much as the beginning of the millennium.
The sophomores of Barnard College defeated their freshmen sisters, 63 to 37, at the forty-second presentation of the traditional Greek Games yesterday in the college's gymnasium.

A three-cornered race for the office of president-general of the Daughters of the American Revolution is a highlight of the national congress of the organization which opens tomorrow evening. The first formal meeting will be at the Waldorf-Astoria, with other sessions tomorrow through Thursday at the Hotel Commodore.

More than 800 reservations have been made for the tea, cocktail dance and fashion show to be given Thursday in the main ballroom of the Pierre as the twenty-fourth annual springtime fete for the benefit of the Nearly New Shop and its affiliated philanthropic agencies.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 15 -- Sitting in an extraordinary emergency session called early tonight, the Bulgarian Regency Council, according to reports in Bulgarian circles here, is understood to be examining the text of an urgent Russian communication brought from Moscow by plane today by the Soviet envoy, Alexander Lavrideff, as well as a second even more pressing communication just received from Berlin.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- Rear Admiral E.S. Land, War Shipping Administrator and Maritime Commission chairman, said today the Battle of the Atlantic might have been "seriously prolonged, or even lost for the time being" if "we had endeavored to follow the views of the Controller General" on ship repair contracts.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 15 -- The proposal to draft 4-F's for jobs in war industries, now being weighed by Congress, meets with the overwhelming support of voters in this country. This is indicated by evidence gathered in a nationwide survey of public opinion during the last few days.

Experiments on rats, in which a large percentage of highly susceptible animals were protected against inoculation with leukemia (cancer-like disease of the white blood cells) by injection of hormones from the adrenal or pituitary glands, are reported in the current issue of Science, official organ of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 15 (Reuter) -- Today's American air attacks on Bucharest and Ploesti foreshadow more massive destruction to Axis facilities in the Balkans as the gap between the Russians and the Mediterranean Allied Air Forces narrows.

WITH sundry sages, orators and candidates warming up their tonsils in anticipation of the forthcoming political campaigns, America's Town Meeting of the Air lately served a healthy purpose (an old habit it has, and a fine one) with a discussion of freedom of speech on the air.

LONDON, Sunday, April 16 -- Red Army forces pushed to within three miles north of Sevastopol yesterday by capturing Lyubimovka in a fifteen-mile advance, and thrust a flanking spearhead down the east side of the historic fortress city to a point eight miles from the Black Sea.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The whole question of the status of Rome in connection with Allied bombing operations is "again being actively considered by the interested governments and the military authorities," Secretary of State Cordell Hull informed Senator Styles Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, in a letter today.

LAST Monday night the National Broadcasting Company and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer joined forces for the presentation of the first premiere of a motion picture over television. James L. Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, came up from Washington to be televised and serve as guest of honor and sundry other souls were invited to have a look and then partake of refreshments at the Ritz-Carlton.

A "Pan American Book Festival," devoted to the literature, customs and national life of the republics of Central and South America, was held yesterday morning in the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, under the auspices of THE NEW YORK TIMES in cooperation with the Association of Children's Book Editors and Junior Programs, Inc.

Commenting on the announcement of Augustus W. Bennet, Newburgh lawyer, that he would be a candidate for the Republican nomination for Representative in the new Twenty-ninth Congressional District, Representative Hamilton Fish said yesterday he expected no difficulty in either the primary or general election.

Caceres, Ambassador of Honduras to the United States, delivered a message of unity yesterday on behalf of Latin-American republics participating in a Pan-American Day ceremony arranged by the Good Neighbors Center of New York.

LONDON, April 15 -- Czechoslovakia, which first showed Europe what it meant to yield to Hitler, is now setting out to show the Continent how to live again. As it was the first country to be invaded and dismembered, so it may also fittingly be the first to be rescued and reconstituted.

Organized labor has been attempting to show that the proportion of national income received by labor has been declining, while the proportion received by corporations has been increasing. PEARL HARBOR, April 15 -- Far-flying bombers and shorter-ranged fighter planes of the Army, Navy and Marine Air Forces have scattered destruction over enemy bases from the Kuriles to the Marshalls during the past two weeks, attaining a new peak of effectiveness and power.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 15 -- Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio told the Commonwealth Club of California today that a change of administration at Washington would make the United States stronger in international affairs "because the people of the world would know that America is a self-governing nation and that any commitments we make must rest on the majority opinion of the people of this country."

WHITE HAVEN, Pa. -- What is known as the fishermen's "Dream Mile" on Tobyhanna Creek, near here, is a busy hive of dry-fly enthusiasts these days. From Split Rock Lodge and other inns they are deploying along Hickory Run, Trout Creek and diverse streams in search of speckled and brown beauties.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Suggestions for improved procedures by Congress which would enable its members to give more attention to vital matters and less to detail will be discussed at the national convention of the League of Women Voters in Chicago April 25 to 28.

THE Victory garden goal for 1944 in New York City is a total of 450,000 gardens which will produce 125,000 tons of food. Ready to help all city gardeners achieve these results are the Victory garden offices of the CDVO in the five boroughs.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 15 (AP) -- One hundred and thirty Americans, who made up the crews of twelve bombers that landed in Switzerland and of another that was shot down by the Swiss, arrived today at the mountain resort of Adelboden for internment.

AN ADVANCED ALLIED AIR BASE, New Guinea, April 15 (AP) -- A deep craving for more combat flying is the answer of America's top air ace of World War II, Maj. Richard I. Bong, to an order grounding him indefinitely at this New Guinea base.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- An increase to 4 per cent in the percentage of fine acetate rayon yarn required to be set aside to meet export orders, including those of the Canadian Commodities Price Stabilization Corporation, was announced today by the War Production Board.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Vice President Wallace's trip to Chung-king on a diplomatic mission is designed primarily to reassure Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and the Chinese people that any delay in an all-out Allied attempt to retake Burma is only temporary.

LONDON, April 15 (AP) -- The Axis announced that an important council of war was held today at Premier Hideki Tojo's home in Tokyo at which the conferees, after discussing the Allied offensive of the past year and the promised invasion of the west, proclaimed a firm determination to fight together to the end.
The biennial congress of the United States Chess Federation opened yesterday at the Park Central Hotel, with eighteen competing in the men's finals.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Baseball, about to start on its third wartime season despite loss of players to the armed services and other difficulties, got an official nod of approval from the White House today.

LONDON, April 15 (U.P.) -- Official Norwegian sources disclosed today that King Haakon VII plans to return to Norway immediately after the first section of the country has been liberated to administer an elaborate reconstruction program designed to restore Norway to normal within a twelve-month period.
Unfavorable weather in the Cotton Belt and continued delays in preparations for the new crop steadied prices for cotton yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange and they gained 2 to 7 points net.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- The automobile industry's first conference on reconversion with the director of war production, scheduled to start on Monday, finds the manufacturers disagreeing among themselves on one major issue, and with Donald M. Nelson, head of the WPB, on another.

Latest estimates of American merchant marine manpower requirements for this crucial war year call for a minimum of 18,351 additional experienced seamen in all ratings to be recruited in Atlantic Coast ports alone. Craig S. Vincent, Atlantic Coast representative of the War Shipping Administration's Recruitment and Manning Organization, disclosed here yesterday.
SAN SALVADOR, April 15 (AP) -- Official reports today said fifty-three persons were killed and 134 wounded in the abortive revolt here two weeks ago.

The thirty-six-piece "brassiest fall-brass band in existence" kept up an incessant blare that had the notes and modulations bouncing off the Madison Square Garden rafters with explosive results all through yesterday afternoon. The newly developed musicologist, Roland Butler, observed that "it has the roar of a trio of charging fire engines and the artistic finesse of a symphonic group."
Although trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday was the dullest and narrowest in six months, stocks improved toward the close and ended fractionally higher on the day.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The Office of War Information announced today it will add 450 persons to its foreign staff in expectation of the increased psychological warfare which will come with the channel invasion and already has recommended 337 such applicants.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (U.P.) -- The National Council of the National Women's party adopted a resolution today calling on President Roosevelt to use his influence for the adoption of the proposed equal-rights constitutional amendment.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- As the Japanese hammer at the eastern gateway to India, not the least effective weapon in their arsenal is propaganda. By every device known to the modern experts at war with words, they are striving to make the Indian masses believe that the designing conqueror at their door comes in the role of liberator.

THE Theatre Guild will be twenty-five years old this week. It has a distinguished record of achievement and has just given New York the one hundred and fiftieth item on that record. Three of the top hits on Broadway bear its label.

ASK anybody in the film business what the average weekly attendance at movie houses is and the answer will be between 90,000,000 and 100,000,000 persons. Nice round figures, those, but seemingly more fanciful than factual when stacked against the findings of Audience Research, Inc., the Dr. George Gallup bureau which keeps tabs on public opinion anent the movies.

MOSCOW, April 16 (AP) -- The Soviet Government, in an "exchange of views" with the United States and Britain, has suggested the immediate formation of an Italian Government representing all democratic elements of the country, Andrei J. Vishinsky, Assistant Commissar of Foreign Affairs, announced tonight at a press conference.

As prelude to the fifty-third Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution, which opens officially today at the Commodore Hotel, a memorial service for the 2,510 members who died during the last year was held yesterday afternoon in the grand ballroom of the Commodore.

In yesterday's TIMES "Experience Coal Man" makes sweeping and damning accusations against the Solid Fuel Administration for War without eve making a pretense of presenting fact to support his conclusions. Such loos charges, if unchallenged, are dangerous.

The appointment of Supreme Court Justice Frank Murphy as honorary chairman of the revived Committee of Catholics for Human Rights was announced yesterday by Professor Emmanuel Chapman of Fordham University and Hunter College.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The National Council of the National Woman's party finished the drafting of a program today to direct the attention of the national and State political conventions to the Equal Rights Amendment, and pledged the support of women to candidates favoring the proposal.

LONDON, April 16 -- The City has recovered its breath after the effort of raising 166,000,000 within a week in the national savings campaign but the stock markets failed to get into anything like their normal stride. This continued slackness was due almost solely to the increasing tension prior to the opening of the Allied attack on Hitler's Europe.

NOT only will the baseball season open tomorrow, but the 1944 football campaign also will get under way -- only, however, conversationally. The moguls of the National Football League will hold their spring meeting in Philadelphia and, since they are face to face with a wartime emergency, the spirit of the City of Brotherly Love may creep into their discussions for a change.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, April 17 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur decided today that Maj. Richard I. Bong should not receive a case of Scotch or champagne as a "reward" for knocking down twenty-seven Japanese planes.

The thrilling victories being rolled up by the gallant Red Army provide plenty of vital lessons for military thinkers all over the world. The Russian campaigns will be admired and studied for generations. It is extremely risky business, however, to apply the Russian experience arbitrarily to other nations, as so many observers unfortunately are inclined to do today under the psychological impact of those victories.

In view of the creation of the Woodrum committee of the House to study the protection of the United States from the perils of future wars and to see that the post-war military mistakes of the last war are not repeated, I suggest the following steps which our country should take toward the formation and effectuation of a post-war military policy.

Two hundred lay chairmen, who will direct the New York Archdiocese Catholic Charities drive during the week of April 30, were thanked in advance for their work "in the name of those whom you help" by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman, who put in an unexpected appearance yesterday at their communion breakfast at the Park Lane Hotel.

CHICAGO, April 16 -- The movement of cash corn throughout the Central West continues small and below industrial requirements. This forced further withdrawals from the small reserve held at various points, and warehouse men are of the belief there is little prospect of a material increase in the movement from farms until possibly late in May, by which time corn planting is expected to be completed.
Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices was 112.96, a rise of 0.2 per cent over the previous week's level of 112.74.

NAPLES, April 16 -- The Allies' food policy in Italy, which is fraught with the most delicate political and psychological complications, is now tied to the coming harvest for which the earliest auspices are good.

Praise for our fighting men and a plea for racial tolerance and true democracy were sounded by speakers yesterday at the annual communion breakfast of the Fire Department Holy Name Society at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. The breakfast was attended by 1,000 uniformed firemen, while 1,500 heard the mass celebrated by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The inner details of the historic conference between former President Hoover and then Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald of Great Britain at the Rapidan Camp in Virginia, when the two Government heads sat on a log in October, 1929, are revealed in diplomatic records published by the State Department tonight.

The Allies put military considerations first and neglected political factors in Italy after Mussolini's fall, throwing away to the enemy all the militant anti-Fascists, Dr. Max Ascoli, former professor of the philosophy of law in Italian universities, charges in a critique of Allied policy in Italy that will appear in the May issue of Social Research.

Unable to do much in the matter now, the railroads are expressing concern about the comfort and convenience of their patrons after the war. For instance, the Boston Maine, in cooperation with the Heywood-Wakefield Company, has set up a specially designed chair in Boston's North Station to test and measure 3,000 persons in an effort to determine the dimensions of the train seat of the future.
