Prints of "To the People of the United States," a two-reel educational film dealing with the subject of venereal disease, will be made available for theatrical exhibition by the California State Department of Public Health, it was announced yesterday by Walter Wanger, who produced the subject at the request of the United States Public Health Service.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Action to reduce substantially prices paid to foreign sellers for imported natural menthol was taken today by the Office of Price Administration. However, retail prices are not affected as the product is ordinarily not sold directly to consumers at retail, but is used at the retail level chiefly as an ingredient in druggists' prescriptions.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Immediate organization of labor unions in territories occupied by armed forces of the United Nations must be undertaken as a means of assuring the full liberation of their peoples and of guaranteeing a lasting peace, Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, declared today in a letter to Sir Walter Citrine, General Secretary of the British Trade Union Congress.

SAN JOSE, Calif., April 16 -- Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio, campaigning in the Far West for the Republican Presidential nomination, conferred today at Sacramento with Gov. Earl Warren, who will lead California's fifty-member delegation to the national convention and who frequently is mentioned for a place on the national ticket.
The following article is the first in a series on the results of a food-rationing survey conducted by this department. The next article will appear tomorrow.
Four new films will arrive on Broadway this week. The schedule follows:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 16 -- After knocking many times at the door of dog-show fame and missing highest honors by narrow margins, Champion Warland Warboy tonight achieved his first best-in-show award, gaining his greatest triumph at the fifth annual show of the Saw Mill River Kennel Club, held in the county center building. More than 700 dogs were benched.

LONDON, April 16 -- Instructions for the reinstitution of local self-government in the first of the occupied European countries went out from London tonight to secretly elected committees throughout Czechoslovakia.

LONDON, April 16 (AP) -- Five war correspondents representing a large block of the British press in Burma announced today they would not file news from that theatre until censorship restrictions were relaxed.

The Zionist Organization of America, in an all-day session at the Hotel New Yorker, yesterday issued a manifesto urging immediate action of the United Nations to rescue the "remaining two million Jewish survivors trapped in Hungary, Rumania and other Balkan countries."

PITTSBURGH, April 16 -- A combination of repairs, losses induced by strikes and some manpower shortages was responsible last week for a 1-point drop in the steel ingot rate to 98 per cent of rated capacity. This fluctuation was said to be not necessarily significant of a trend yet.
The high proportion of "beggar's prayers" in the average person's devotions was deplored yesterday by the Rev. Robert E. Woods at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

ATLANTA, April 16 -- At least thirty-eight persons were killed and more than 500 were injured by a tornado which cut a 100-mile path of destruction across northeast Georgia and western South Carolina early today. Property damage was high.

Another week of convention delegate choosing opens today with Governor Dewey leading the race for the Republican Presidential nomination with 168 delegates compared to thirty-four for Lieut. Comdr. Harold E. Stassen, six for Gov. Dwight Griswold of Nebraska and three for Gen. Douglas MacArthur.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The Most Rev. and Right Hon. Cyril Forster Garbett, Archbishop of York and Primate of England, declared in his first sermon in the United States today that, while these were "black and anxious days," the day would soon come when "justice will triumph and evil be defeated."

The operation of the War Relief Services of the National Catholic Welfare Conference, a participating service in the National War Fund, was revealed for the first time yesterday as 325 cases of religious, educational, recreational and occupational supplies were shipped from an East Coast port destined for thousands of American and Allied prisoners of war now in German prison camps.

A 7-day-old girl, brought here from Puerto Rico by Pan-American Airways clipper in the hope that surgeons here can correct a rare spinal ailment, became a patient at Neurological Institute of Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center last night.

NAPLES, April 16 -- An American raiding party lanced out yesterday from the eastern flank of the Anzio beachhead, struck the Germans at points about three miles southwest of Littoria and two miles inland and came back with sixty-one prisoners.

A UNITED STATES AIR SERVICE COMMAND STATION, in Britain, April 16 -- The thin stream of American military planes, guns, bombs, spare parts and special air equipment that trickled to Britain eighteen months ago has now become a spring flood.

Food companies have been the main backers of advertising to promote Victory gardens and they will continue to endorse the food conservation and home canning programs, even though their efforts may affect the sale of their own products to some extent, according to sources close to national advertisers.

The 1944 campaign pamphlet of the Greater New York Fund, 11 West Forty-second Street, is being mailed to hundreds of contributors, executives of corporations and campaign workers, J. Stewart Baker, general chairman of the campaign, announced yesterday.

LAURINBURG-MAXTON ARMY AIR BASE, N.C., April 14 (Delayed) -- How airborne troops of the Army Air Forces can swiftly and effectively land behind enemy lines was shown here today by units of the First Troop Carrier Command in a demonstration of their latest tactics and equipment, including some that have not as yet been announced publicly.

Dunninger, the magician and "Miracle Mentalist," who reads thoughts on the radio as well as in person, will tell all about the science and technique of thought reading in "What's on Your Mind." The book will be published in June by the World Publishing Company.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, April 17 (AP) -- A communique:

In impressive services held yesterday afternoon at the Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue at Fifty-fifth Street, three American Jewish leaders received the honorary degree of Doctor of Hebrew Letters from Hebrew Union College.

Confirmation of the belief that the withdrawal of Wendell L. Willkie as a candidate for the Republican nomination for President would result in the nomination of Governor Dewey, probably on the first ballot, has been obtained in a survey made by supporters of the Governor since the Dewey victory in the Wisconsin primary election, it was learned yesterday.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 16 -- Mrs. Elizabeth Correll's big bay gelding Mathematician, outstanding in the hunter division yesterday, continued its excellent performances through the second day at the Boulder Brook Club's annual indoor spring horse show and early this evening was awarded the championship ribbon.

LONDON, Monday, April 17 (U.P.) -- Moscow's broadcast war bulletins gave no report on Gen. Feodor I. Tolbukhin's Fourth Ukrainian Army, which on Saturday captured Lyubimovka, three miles north of Sevastopol across Sevastopol Bay, and Shuli, nine miles east of the besieged city.

Members of the New York Post of the Canadian Legion paraded up Fifth Avenue to the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street to attend memorial services yesterday afternoon for the late Venerable Archdeacon Frederick George Scott, chaplain during World War I to the First Canadian Division.

After advancing early last week, cotton prices turned reactionary and closed the period with irregular net changes. At the close on Saturday active old-crop futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 14 points on the week, while the active new-crop months showed net losses of 1 to 4 points.

ONEIDA, N.Y., April 16 (AP) -- A prediction that the United States would have "industrial and agricultural prosperity" never seen before in its history following the period of reconversion after the war was made tonight by James A. Farley New York State Democratic chairman.

Lieut. Col. Charles Poletti, regional Allied commissioner for the Naples area, said in a Columbia Broadcasting System broadcast yesterday that fascism had made the people of Italy so distrustful of government they "don't quite know what to make of a government that is really set up for their own benefit."

An influx of buyers of men's and boys' clothing is expected in the market this week, timed to the opening of fall and winter lines. Additional numbers also are being looked for in succeeding weeks, as well as furnishing buyers.

ROYSTON, Ga., April 16 (U.P.) -- A young mother, whose husband and two young children were killed in front of her, told today how the tornado, which sounded like a "wild roaring thing," swept through Hartwell.

Possibly because of renewed predictions that invasion of the European Continent is near at hand, transactions in last week's stock market were light, and prices yielded a point or more. Beyond the continued advance by Russia, its recapture of Odessa and its movement into the Crimea, there was no important war news.

On April 2 THE NEW YORK TIMES reported that Marxist economic dogmas as they had been officially taught in Soviet Russia were undergoing sweeping revision, citing an article in Pod Znamenem Marxizma (Under the Banner of Marxism), Russian economic journal, the essential parts of which appear in English in the current issue of the Marxist quarterly, Science and Society.

LONDON, April 16 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 115.2 on April 4, compared with 115.1 a fortnight before, 115 a month before, 114.3 a year ago and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.
A model of one of the earliest monuments planned to honor aviation has been acquired by the Metropolitan Museum of Art and will go on exhibition there tomorrow in the great hall.
KANSAS CITY, April 16 (AP) -- Alfred M. Landon proposed tonight that both American political parties reverse their tariff policies to help maintain future peace.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The National Labor Relations Board took the unprecedented position in a decision today that an employer who discharged union employes who struck because the employer would not pay wage demands exceeding the level fixed by the Stabilization Act had not violated the National Labor Relations Act.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The War Department, largest purchaser of military supplies, has begun a campaign to eliminate excess profits from work done by subcontractors under prime contractors.
LONDON, Monday, April 17 (AP) -- The Russian Sunday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- A program of "realistically high" taxes designed to balance the postwar budget as quickly as possible will be proposed to the Republican National Convention by its advisory committee on finance, taxation and money, Senator Taft, who is chairman of the advisory committee, predicted today.

Community post-war planning should strive for the greatest number of jobs in private industry and business and beware of public works projects that are unnecessary or that the community cannot afford to maintain, the Regional Plan Association advised in a bulletin issued yesterday.

John Moses and Ralph Bellamy will present "Pretty Little Parlor" tonight at the National Theatre. Stella Adler and Sidney Blackmer, lately returned from filmdom, have the featured roles. Others in the mall cast are Marilyn Erskine, Joan Tetzel, Kip Good, Paul Parks, Edward Begley and Mel Roberts.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 16 -- As long ago as last December the Germans saw the handwriting on the wall, admitted they had lost the war and made attempts to obtain a negotiated peace. In the early evening of Dec. 17, 1943, Baron Manfred von Killinger, German Minister to Rumania, telephoned to a neutral diplomat in Bucharest to make an appointment to discuss a most urgent matter.

The long-drawn-out struggle of General de Gaulle for supremacy over the French Committee of National Liberation has ended with his complete victory. Acting on his own authority, with the reluctant consent of the Committee which he now dominates, but without consultation of the Assembly which has undertaken to represent the democratic forces of resistance within France, he has brusquely dismissed General Giraud as Commander in Chief of the French Army.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, April 17 (UP) -- Lieut. Gen. George C. Kenney's Fifth Air Force threw Liberators, Mitchell and Boston bombers against the Aitape airdrome, 90 miles northwest of Wewak, on Friday in the heaviest attack ever made against that target, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's communique reported.
ALBANY, April 16 -- Governor Dewey has appointed Miss Mary H. Donlon of New York City chairman of the State Industrial Board at $8,500 a year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 16 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has named Dick Haymes and June Haver for the starring roles in "Michigan Avenue," a musical about Chicago in the early Nineteen Hundreds. The Technicolor picture will be produced by William Le Baron.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., April 16 -- In a northeast leftover breath of the storm-break from yesterday, the national dinghy championship was started today at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club, and in this first session, Pat O'Gorman, from across Long Island Sound at Larchmont, came in the leader, scoring 74 points to 69 for Arthur Knapp.

Bronislava Nijinska's newest ballet, "Ancient Russia," received its second presentation by the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo last night at the City Center. Since its premiere last week took place at the same time that Agnes de Mille s "Tally-Ho" was having its initial performance elsewhere, last night provided the first occasion for this reviewer to see it.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 16 -- A total loss was the ill-timed trip here by the Giants, who today were forced into idleness again by the rain. The scheduled exhibition against the Toronto Maple Leafs went the way of yesterday's Giant-Philly fray, and the plight of the New Yorkers is not a light matter.

The National Bureau of Economic Research, a private organization whose work has been marked by an impartial and scientific spirit, publishes today a study under the authorship of Geoffrey H. Moore of production of industrial materials in the two World Wars. What is interesting about this study is that it does not show nearly as great a rise in production as previous estimates.

Two hundred radio "hams," members of the War Emergency Radio Service, put on a city-wide demonstration yesterday afternoon for officials of the Army, Navy and city protective agencies to show how the metropolitan area's communications system might be maintained if the regular channels were blocked by a major disaster.
BERNE, Switzerland, April 16 (AP) -- Up to thirty-two Frenchmen were reported shot in Paris today after a German announcement that a vast anti-Axis sabotage organization had been uncovered there.

OAKLAND, Calif., April 16 Miss Patricia Sinclair, 13-year-old member of the New York Women's Swimming Association team, won the 100-yard breast-stroke title in the National A.A.U. women's indoor swimming and diving championship at the Athens Athletic Club tonight.
Dr. Julian R. Caceres, Ambassador from Honduras to the United States, is at the Waldorf-Astoria.

CHICAGO, April 16 -- Deposits in Chicago's national banks on April 13 showed a gain of about $125,000,000 over the total on Dec. 31, 1943, indicating that funds taken out for the April 1 tax date largely have been redeposited, it was disclosed here.

LONDON, April 16 (AP) -- Fighting in Yugoslavia reached a new pitch in intensity today with the forces of Marshal Tito battling a powerful advance of German and satellite troops toward Montenegro, a communique broadcast by the Free Yugoslav radio said tonight
When peace comes Times Square lighting will extend natural twilight in a pastel glow that will exceed in volume and in color variation anything in the area's previous light history.

MOSCOW, April 16 (AP) -- Great crowds filled Moscow's churches today for the Russian Orthodox Easter services in one of the gayest and happiest week-ends for the Russian people since the beginning of the war.

A public celebration of the forty- sixth birthday of Paul Robeson, singer and actor, brought a throng estimated at 8,500 persons to the Seventeenth Regiment Armory, Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue, last night. Representatives of the Council on African Affairs, arrangers of the celebration, said that tickets had been unavailable for several thousand others.

At the conclusion of play in the second round of the United States chess championship tournament in the Colonial Room at the Hotel Park Central last night, Benjamin Altman of Flushing, Arnold S. Denker of Forest Hills, and Israel A. Horowitz of Manhattan were in a triple tie for first place, each with two consecutive victories to his credit.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, April 16 -- Allied glider-borne troops are operating only fifty miles northwest of Mandalay, creating a serious situation for the Japanese in the India-Burma offensive, it was disclosed today as Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten transferred his headquarters to this base, closer to the scene of future campaigns.

In their recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon Jane and Joan Rosenfeld, duo-pianists, proved themselves competent musicians with enough technique to surmount most of the difficulties their program presented. They have not as yet, however, reached the stage where two-piano playing becomes a genuine and inspiring vehicle for artistic expression.

The attitude of the Senate toward meeting President Washington half way in his desire for face-to-face consultation about an Indian treaty, which you recall in an editorial of April 11, entitled "Calling In Congress," takes on a very lively interest along with the opening of the question whether the precedent set by Secretary Hull's recent address to the two houses of Congress might not well become a practice.

A soldier on furlough won the most coveted of all contract bridge championships here last night when Corp. George Rapee outstripped a field of thirty-six top-ranking bridge stars, thirty of them men and five of them women, to take the national masters' individual tournament at the Park Central Hotel.

The Rev. Dr. J. Howard Callahan, pastor of the Methodist Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street, protested in his sermon yesterday morning that Christianity had made too much of "mere, beautiful good-will."

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Representing more than half a million stores thirty national and eighteen State retail trade associations have endorsed extension of the Price Control Act for one year, according to the American Retail Federation in announcing today a poll of its members, but amendments are asked that would better protect retailers.

MOSCOW, Monday, April 17 -- In a more than thirty-mile sweep down the eastern coast of the Crimea, the Independent Maritime Army yesterday scooped up forty villages, including the important port of Yalta, and plunged southward to within twenty-three miles of besieged Sevastopol.

Freedom of international communications must be supported by the entire press and radio industries and discussed publicly at the next peace conference, Dean Carl W. Ackerman of Columbia University's School of Journalism said yesterday in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.
KANDY, Ceylon, April 16 (AP) -- A Southeast Asia communique:

WASHINGTON, April 16 (UP) -- Republicans will recapture the House of Representatives in November "with seats to spare," but it is too early to predict how many Democrats will be defeated, Representative Joseph W Martin Jr., minority leader, said tonight.

LONDON, April 16 (U.P.) -- The Italy-based aerial offensive against Germany's rail lines through the Danube-Balkan region roared into its second straight day today with attacks on Belgrade and Brasov, according to German radio reports, as rail and waterway installations near the Iron Gate of the Danube still smouldered from an RAF attack last night.

QUEBEC, Que., April 16 -- For the first time in fifty-five years of existence of the Pan American Union, Canada observed Pan-American Day with receptions in Montreal, Quebec and other cities in honor of the Latin-American consuls. This is the logical sequel to the recent appointment of Canadian envoys to the South American republics.

A RICH and rewarding field for the biographer's labors is the exploration of the lives, not of the great and important but of the queer, the sinister, the eccentric and the slightly touched in the head. Such people rarely make history, but their deviations from the human norm often do much to make history entertaining.

NAPLES, April 16 -- Large formations of the Royal Air Force's Wellington bombers kept up last night the Allied offensive from this theatre against Nazi traffic centers in Rumania -- which United States "heavies" carried on by day Saturday over Bucharest and Ploesti -- with a blow at the rail town of Turnu Severin, near the Iron Gate of the Danube.

During the first six months of the post-war period, China's requirements for emergency relief will exceed 840,000 tons of cotton and cotton cloth or 3,200,000 bales of raw cotton and it is likely that most of this material will be purchased from American cotton producers and mills, according to Richard C. Patterson Jr., president of the China-America Council of Commerce and Industry.

Three museums and two department stores are opening art shows this week along with more than a score of regular gallery exhibitions and a benefit. The Metropolitan Museum will show for an indefinite period Greek paintings from archaic to Greco-Roman times and a large number of Russian icons.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 16 -- One of the largest deals to be made in the motion-picture industry in the last several years, the purchase by United Artists Corporation of the entire block of stock held by Sir Alexander Korda in the corporation, was announced today by Edward C. Raftery, president.

Plans are well advanced for the opening next autumn of a unique technical college to train high school graduates for the apparel and needle trades of this city. Probably the first institution of its kind to be found anywhere, it will provide students with a cultural program in addition to specific skills needed in the garment trades.

The chairman of the Committee on Foreign Affairs in the House, Representative Sol Bloom, has declared his opposition to the system under which treaties must be ratified by two-thirds of the Senate. He urges instead that they be ratified by a simple majority of both houses of Congress.
If the boys who write baseball pieces for the papers are correct, the Cardinals are a-shootin' for their third straight National League pennant in the campaign starting Tuesday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 16 (AP) -- President Roosevelt, in a message to the Knights of Columbus, today said "the wise counsel and example of all men of good will is needed everywhere to preserve the balanced judgment and single-minded purpose essential to the winning of this war."

Recent Congressional action in establishing a twenty-three-member post-war military policy committee to conduct a coordinated study of the nation's future military organization is a constructive and important step.

Charging that Governor Dewey's refusal to call a special session of the Legislature to make it easier for persons in the armed services to obtain war ballots was because he was "mortally afraid" of their votes, Joseph Curran, president of the Greater New York Congress of Industrial Organizations Council, announced yesterday plans for a campaign intended to give every service man and woman a chance to vote.
LONDON, April 16 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin:

PEARL HARBOR, April 16 -- The most widespread air attacks announced to date in the Central Pacific spread destruction at Japanese bases from the Kuriles in the far north to Nauru below the Equator Friday, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz disclosed today.

The Army Airways Communications System is a busy service. Concerned with technical problems in radio, meteorology, code interpretation and a half dozen other special skills, it has grown from a handful of men before Pearl Harbor to more than 20,000 officers and enlisted personnel, stationed wherever the air lanes of our combat fronts extend.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- A complaint charging the American Waxed Paper Association of Philadelphia and its twenty-four member manufacturers with engaging in a combination and conspiracy to restrain trade and fix prices in the interstate sale and distribution of waxed paper and waxed paper products has been issued, the Federal Trade Commission announced today.

LOS ANGELES, April 16 (U.P.) -- Representative Hamilton Fish misused his franking privilege when he permitted Leon C. De Aryan, publisher of the San Diego weekly, "The Broom," to rise his postage-free envelopes while under Federal indictment for sedition, the Seventeenth District California American Legion asserted today.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 15 (Delayed) -- The sight of the Stars and Stripes carried by some school children in the parade held on Pan-American Day in the Argentine city of Catamarca so enraged Dr. Ricardo Baldrich, acting federal commissioner of the province of the same name, that he demanded immediate resignation of the police chief for permitting the flag of the United States to be exhibited in public.

If competition is the life of trade, the Yankees and Dodgers are on the verge of bankruptcy. For the second successive day a drenching downpour washed out their scheduled battle at Ebbets Field yesterday, but -- shades of the Florida Grapefruit circuit! -- they're going to play off the postponement this afternoon.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, April 16 -- To clarify his position in connection with his exchange of correspondence with Representative A.L. Miller of Nebraska, Gen. Douglas MacArthur issued a statement today saying that his "sole ambition" was to assist in winning the war "by the fulfillment of such duty as has been or may be assigned to me."

OMAHA, April 16 (AP) -- A line of levees seven miles long protecting the Hamburg area was being bolstered by Army engineers tonight as the crest of Missouri River floodwaters passed Omaha and bore down on communities downstream.

Mayor La Guardia advised New York City consumers yesterday to insist on "bargain prices" for both potatoes and eggs when they respond to the Federal Government's appeal to buy these food commodities to ease the current glut. Some major dealers recently have insisted that current retail prices should be halved, and would be halved except for the Government's support program.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- A policy of pricing goods at "what the traffic will bear" might easily cost this country its system of free enterprise after the war, the Brookings Institution warned today.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:...

CLEVELAND, April 16 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Leonard P. Ayres, economist and vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company, observed today that "probably it will prove to be true that the peak of industrial production in this war period was reached last October and that the worst of our labor stringencies are behind us."

From "Somewhere in New Guinea," Chaplain Frederick P. Gehring, USNR, has penned a letter that is not only striking testimony to the courage of the American armed men but also a record of the vital role that Red Cross blood plasma plays in this war.

MOSCOW, April 16 -- The joint press-reading service set up here by representatives of the English-speaking countries has now had made a complete translation of the article in "Under the Banner of Marxism" of August, 1943, a version of which was referred to in THE NEW YORK TIMES editorial columns on April 3 under the heading "Russia's New 'Capitalism.'"

Mayor La Guardia gave his blessing yesterday to the major league baseball season of 1944 in his weekly radio talk from City Hall. Admonishing the fans to "approach the season in a good, sportsmanlike attitude," he urged them not to attend games at the Yankee Stadium, the Polo Grounds or Ebbetts Field in a critical frame of mind, prepared to find fault, but to go prepared to give the players a "boost."

Admiral King's conviction that the battle fleets of the United States and Japan will meet in due course is backed by facts and figures which indicate a constantly waning enemy strength. His views are supported by recent Japanese naval strategy. No war was ever won by avoidance of battle.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period April 12 to 14 are given in the appended tabulation:

CAIRO, Egypt, April 16 -- Trans-Jordan's sole post-war demand is for formation of a Greater Syria, Premier Newfik Abu el Hoda said in an interview with Akher Saa, Arabic weekly, during his visit to Cairo last week.

Consular representatives of ten United Nations, together with civic and labor leaders, paid tribute yesterday to the 684 American merchant seamen who have been killed in service, at a ceremony at headquarters of the National Maritime Union, 346 West Seventeenth Street.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Forty-four thousand Bethlehem Steel shipyard workers in three Atlantic Coast ports received an average wage increase of 4 cents an hour from the National War Labor Board today in a decision which is still subject to approval by the Office of Economic Stabilization.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16 -- With preliminary sessions of the first wartime conference of the International Labor Organization beginning here tomorrow morning, no word had been received tonight as to whether the Soviet Union would avail itself of the opportunity to be represented at meetings where a post-war social policy will be drawn up for the United Nations.

The countryman knows when spring has arrived. It is always a beautiful day, warm and sunny; the sky's blue counterpane is splotched with masses of cumulus clouds. The bluebirds carol from the apple trees in the back yard; cock pheasants crow from the edge of the mowing, and the farm collie is exploring woodchuck holes along the pasture wall.

LONDON, April 16 -- The Allies' terms for Rumania's withdrawal from the war were reported to have been completed today as United States Under-Secretary of State Edward R. Stettinius Jr. continued conversations in London with Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden after he had seen Prime Minister Churchill for the second time over the week-end.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 17 -- It was officially announced tonight that Eam, political organization in Greece of Communist direction, had accepted an invitation of the newly formed Hellenic Government to send as soon as possible three representatives who, it is said, will take part in the negotiations for a broader national government than hitherto existed.
Sy Rosenblatt drove in three runs with a double in the fifth inning to give the City College nine a 6-to-4 victory over Brooklyn College at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 17 -- Because of the failure of several British, Indian and Dutch delegates to arrive on schedule, the first preliminary session of the twenty- sixth meeting of the International Labor Organization was postponed today until tomorrow.

A relenting weather man having finally permitted Greater New York's three major league clubs to put a feverish finish yesterday to a badly scrambled spring training campaign, the Giants, Yankees and Dodgers go to the post today in the opening of the championship season with feelings akin to those of a man who has had only fifteen minutes to dash into his dinner clothes and isn't certain whether his tie is on fore or aft.
CHICAGO, April 17 (U.P.) -- Designed for civilian "super luxury" but drafted into wartime duty, that's the story told today by the men behind the Constellation.

MOSCOW, April 17--While the combined Russian armies of the Crimea last night were making their dispositions for overwhelming Sevastopol and Chersonese Cape an important development was in progress on the Bessarabian front.

LONDON, April 17 -- Although not much business was recorded, most sections of today's stock markets here remained firm with share prices showing a tendency to record gains of a few pence where changed.

In discussing the subway fare one of your readers recently raised a question often asked. The question is this: If the fare were raised, would not so many people resent the increase or be unable to pay it that there would actually be less net income as a result? Such a proposition was also stated by City Councilman Stanley Isaacs in a debate with the writer recently.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., reported yesterday for 1943 a consolidated net income of $35,944,983 after charges, taxes, reserves and provisions of $3,000,000 for future reduction in inventory values, equal to $1.15 each on 31,178,323 capital shares outstanding in the hands of the public.

A new chemical process that transmutes all types of soft wood into wood of any desired hardness, thus providing a chemical magic wand with which hundreds of millions of acres of American forests of pine and other soft woods can be transformed into woodlands yielding the best of timber, was announced yesterday by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- A new giant of the air paths, the Lockheed Constellation, crossed the continent today in 6 hours 58 minutes, an average speed of about 355 miles an hour, a speed well beyond anything flown previously for a similar distance.

Lippy Leo Durocher unveiled another second baseman at Ebbets Field yesterday in the person of Luis Rodriguez Olmo, an outfielder, but the Yankees still walked away with the ball game by an 8 -- 5 score.

Carnegie Hall has been sold out to war bond purchasers for tonight's concert by Arturo Toscanini and the IBC Symphony Orchestra sponsored by the Associated Musicians of Greater New York, Local 802, American Federation of Musicians.
LONDON, Tuesday, April 18 (AP) -The Russian Monday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

Indeterminate penetentiary terms were imposed yesterday in Special Sessions on Frank Jara and his wife, Julia, for leaving the two youngest of their four small children alone in their East Seventy-seventh Street apartment last January 4 while they attended a movie and went visiting.
LONDON, April 17 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

The war cripple in his grim plight can always look back with pride to years when he was as strong as the next and perhaps better than most, and when his strength served his country in its need. The child crippled at birth or in infancy has no satisfaction like that. He can remember only pain and helplessness.

LONDON, April 17 -- The visit of United States Undersecretary of State Edward R. Stettinius Jr., to London has set the stage for a renewal of the efforts to re-establish diplomatic relations between the Soviet and Polish Governments. It was widely reported today that Mr. Stettinius and Prime Minister Churchill had regretfully but firmly informed Polish Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk their Governments could not support him in continued antagonism toward Moscow.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, April 17 -- The elimination of absentee control and the "evils of monopoly" in favor of "a responsible, capable local banking machinery", was demanded today by Ganson Purcell, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, in an address before the Texas group of the Investment Bankers Association of America.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 17 (AP) -- Manager Mel Ott of the New York Giants was ordered today to report for his draft physical examination on April 24 at Camden, N.J., as a member of the Lakewood, N.J., contingent. The 35-year-old right fielder had requested a transfer from his Metairie, La., board when originally called during spring training at Lakewood.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Senator James M. Mead, of New York, returning after a brief illness to take charge of the Marcantonio Anti-Poll Tax Bill, said today that it would be called up as soon as the Senate resumes daily sessions. He predicted that the legislation would have more support than during the last test two years ago, but expressed uncertainty that it would be enough to break the threatened filibuster.
A hundred thousand pieces of mail and $12,000,000 in cash and checks were received yesterday at the second district office of the Federal Collector of Internal Revenue in the Custom House.

Yesterday a flash of bright green from the narrow crevice between two rocks attracted my eye; approaching, I saw a velvety patch of common moss, but in a significantly different guise. Borne aloft from each tiny, individual plant was a hairlike thread, about a half inch in length, supporting at its apex a minute, globular spore-case about the size of a pinhead.

Government aid, and participation in the nation's post-war foreign trade as a measure to step up domestic economic life, insure world peace and assist in rehabilitation of foreign countries was urged last night by Robert R. Nathan, former chairman of the War Production Board's planning committee, in an address before a meeting of the Industrial Advertising Association at the Biltmore Hotel.

A jury in Federal court yesterday took less than five minutes to convict Roger Lewis Gardner, 26 years old, of impersonating a Government lawyer while "borrowing" $1,500 from a young woman. With equal celerity Judge John C. Knox sentenced the defendant to three years' imprisonment, the maximum term for the offense.

ST. LOUIS, April 17 (AP) -- Outfielder Danny Litwhiler of the Cardinals may not be in the lineup when the National League champions open the season with the Pirates tomorrow. He has been ordered to take his pre-induction physical examination at Jefferson Barracks.

NAPLES, April 17 -- Because Allied post-war planning groups like the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration realize the chaotic conditions with which they will be confronted by legally unidentifiable persons following the German collapse, leading British and American archivists are here on a tour that will probably lead to a redefinition within the framework of military necessity of a system of handling damaged or newly occupied properties, it was learned today.

The first degree murder indictment returned against Pancranzio Ferrera, 51 years old, a gardener, of 105-15 Walton Street, Jamaica, Queens, in the murder of Mrs. Marie Pearson of 144-08 Liberty Avenue, Jamaica, in a lot near her home on the night of Oct. 10, was dismissed yesterday afternoon before Judge Thomas Downs in Queens County Court.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -Secretary Hull is scheduled to begin discussions this week with a bi-partisan Senate committee in an apparent effort to keep the main lines of American foreign policy out of the channels of political controversy.

FORT BRAGG, N.C., April 15 (Delayed) -- The 397th Infantry Regiment of the 100th Infantry Division expended 110 tons of live ammunition today in a realistic version of an attack in a European "No Man's Land" and at its conclusion these troops were declared by their commanding officer to be at "their psychological peak, ready for combat duty overseas."

A three-way scrap for the 1944 American League pennant, with the world champion New York Yankees finally nosing out Washington and Chicago, was predicted yesterday by the country's baseball writers for the season starting tomorrow.

Dr. Harold Stuart, head of the child hygiene department of Harvard University, reported yesterday to a meeting of the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies at the Hotel Plaza that an estimated 50 per cent of the children of France were seriously undernourished.

TRENTON, N.J., April 17 (AP) -- The New Jersey Racing Commission rejected today the application of the Trenton Jockey Club for a license to conduct horse racing with pari-mutuel betting at the Trenton fair grounds.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 17 -More unpopularity is coming to Vichy because of the "metal" tax that it is now attempting to levy, with the population showing great reluctance, if not absolute opposition. One newspaper, despite the censor, even goes so far as to write:
BOSTON, April 17 (AP) -- Big league baseball gets its 1944 inaugural in Boston tomorrow with the world-champion Yankees facing the Red Sox before an expected throng of 10,000 at Fenway Park.

With the same apparent indifference that characterized his conduct during both his trials, Wayne Thomas Lonergan heard General Sessions Judge James G. Wallace sentence him yesterday to "thirty-five years to imprisonment for the rest of your natural life" for the slaying of his wife, Patricia.

Favored teams took an early lead last night as the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup tournament for the national contract bridge team-of-four championship got under way at the Hotel Pierre here. Twenty-seven teams were entered. In a second preliminary round tonight they will be cut to a field of sixteen teams that will play knockout rounds ending Saturday night.

Public offering of a new issue of $4,500,000 National Container Corporation 5 per cent fifteen-year sinking fund debentures will be made today by a nation-wide banking group headed by Van Alstyne, Noel Co. The debentures will be priced at 100 and interest from April 1, 1944.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- A group of British Government experts and oil men named to confer with an American group, arrived today. The parley will begin tomorrow.
KANDY, Ceylon, April 17 (U.P.) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

The informed beauty knows how to use color in her costume to bring out the best features of her hair, lips, eyes and complexion. She knows well that the old tried-and-true beauty formula of matching your dress to your eyes is sound in principle -- it is true that a color is emphasized when it is repeated -- but she knows, too, that there are many subtle twists in the application of this theory.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, urged Congress today to set up an "Office of Reconstruction" as a central economic post-war planning agency to provide for "full production" and continued high wages.

CHICAGO, April 17 -- While Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Machigan was apparently in the leading position to be chosen temporary chairman and keynoter of the Republican National Convention here June 26, with Representative Charles A. Halleck of Indiana still a contender, the names of two women were advanced as the vanguard of the party's subcommittee on arrangements arrived today for executive sessions tomorrow and Wednesday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, April 18 (AP) -- One of the heaviest bombing raids yet centered on Hollandia, Netherland New Guinea, was staged Sunday, when bombers and fighters of the Fifth Army Air Force left great columns of smoke rising from Japanese fuel and supply dumps.

A 5 per cent wage increase and other benefits affecting 15,000 film studio workers have been incorporated in a new five-year contract agreed upon yesterday by the motion-picture producers and the International Alliance of Theatrics Stage Employes.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Representative A.L. Miller, who last week released an exchange of correspondence he had had with Gen. Douglas MacArthur, without permission from the latter, predicted today that the General would make an announcement regarding his "receptiveness" to the Republican Presidential nomination "within six weeks."

The regular use of helicopters or patrol and rescue assignments by the Coast Guard in this district was revealed yesterday by its Public Relations Office, 42 Broadway. By eliminating the ambulance stage of the rescue, it was pointed out, delivery "from the sea practically to the hospital door" is speeded up, and unnecessary handling of the patient is avoided.

LONDON, April 17 -- Britain took an action, unprecedented in international law, tonight to safeguard the lives of Allied troops who will soon be hurled against the battlements of Adolf Hitler's Festung Europa.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -An order prohibiting manufacturers of all types of clothing and textiles for civilian use from exceeding their 1943 output or changing from one price range to another is in preparation by the War Production Board, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Correspondence with Daniel J. Tobin, chairman of the negotiating committee, in connection with the application of the United Mine Workers of America for readmission to the American Federation of Labor, indicated today that John L. Lewis would probably withdraw the request for reaffiliation.

A UNITED STATES ARMY AIR FORCE SERVICE COMMAND STATION, Somewhere in Britain, April 17 -- If you know, how to find a certain Nissen hut here and if Pfc. Caper La Rosa Jr. and his barracks mates think you're a good guy, then right at this base you can get the best plate of spaghetti with marinara sauce this side of your own favorite pre-war Italian restaurant.

While American plants continue to convert millions of pounds of last year's butter into so-called Carter spread and civilian consumption is held to a minimum primarily by the 16-point ration value, Russian fighting men balk at eating this butter spread, which comes to them under lend-lease.

PEARL HARBOR, April 17 (AP) Pre-dawn raiders of the Seventh Army Air Force unloaded thirty-eight tons of bombs on Truk Atoll in the Caroline Islands Sunday, according to an announcement from Pacific Fleet headquarters today.

Confirmation of Washington reports that a two-ply Congressional investigation into the operations and financing of the New Jersey Shipbuilding Corporation, near Perth Amboy, N.J., has been in progress for several months was obtained here yesterday from Samuel B. Stewart, investigator for the Senate Truman Committee.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Under suspension of the rules the House approved and sent to the Senate today the bill sponsored by Representative Joe Starnes of Alabama, giving preference in civil service posts to service men and women.

A debut recital of exceptional merit was given by Grant Johannesen, young American pianist, at the New York Times Hall last night. Mr. Johannesen, 22-year-old pupil of Robert Casadesus, displayed a crisp, clear technique and a feeling for musical style and structure which made his performances clear of intent and transparent of execution.

MEXICO CITY, April 17 -- The Spanish Committee of Liberation in Mexico through its president, Diego Martinez Barrio, voiced its approval of a general nation-wide election in Spain so that the present political aspirations of the Spanish people might be defined once and for all.

Mrs. Edward Perry Townsend was elected president of the Young Women's Christian Association of the City of New York at the annual meeting yesterday of the board of directors at the Studio Club, 210 East Seventy-seventh Street.

Dividing forces in American life, inciting hatred between classes, races and creeds, constitute a serious threat to democracy, J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, told the Daughters of the American Revolution at the opening of their national congress last evening at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decrease of 11 per cent last week under the like week of 1943, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week the bank had reported an increase of 16 per cent over last year.
CHICAGO, April 17 (AP) -- The Cubs defeated the White Sox, 7 to 6, in their final spring series game today, with the White Sox winning the series, three games to two.
ALLIED HEADQUAITERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, April 18 (AP) -- A communique:

PEORIA, Ill., April 17 -- The State of Virginia, in a deal completed here today, became the largest purchaser of bulk whisky so far under the American Distilling Company's plan for distributing 237,000 barrels of whisky at cost to its stockholders.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Women who lose war production jobs in cut-backs are inclined to go home and clean house or sew rather than to try for another job, according to a report based on Bureau of Labor Statistics field trips, issued today by the Office of War Information.

NEWARK, N.J., April 17 -Stockholders cheered today when Thomas N. McCarter, chairman of the board of Public Service Corporation, announced at the company's annual meeting held at the Public Service Terminal Building here that he will not retire while there remains a controversy with the Federal Power Commission.

In a tabulation issued yesterday the New York Curb Exchange listed 194 issues traded there that have paid dividends in every year for ten years or more. Of these seventy-three have paid dividends for twenty-five years or more and fourteen for fifty years or more.
PINEHURST, N.C., April 17 -- Two Southern girls tied for medalist honors today in the qualifying round of the forty-second annual North and South women's golf championship.

LONDON, April 17 -- Another cloud over Anglo-American-Russian relations rolled away today with the resignation of Premier Pietro Badoglio to make way for the formation of a new Italian Cabinet more in accord with the terms of the Moscow declaration for democratic government in Italy.

Closer coordination of sales policies and advertising departments in food manufacturing companies was urged by B.C. Ohlandt, president of Grocery Store Products Sales Company, yesterday before the Manufacturers' Representatives at the Hotel Pennsylvania. He compared advertising to the air force and artillery of an army, but said salesmen were the infantry who gained ground and held it.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- The Senators, rated one of the American League's best pennant bets, take on the Athletics, the circuit's poorest choice for success, in the season's opener here tomorrow.

One of the leading market letters declares that "if the invasion is a success it is estimated that the industrial production index (which is around 240 at present) can drop down to the 120-150 level," and adds that such a sharp decline in business activity "would hardly be conducive to a booming stock market.''

PHILADELPHIA, April 17 -- The Southern Union Gas Company received an additional six months today in which to comply with an order of the Securities and Exchange Commission that the company divest itself of ownership and control of certain companies and properties in order to comply with the geographical integration provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935.

CHICAGO, April 17 (AP) -- Montgomery Ward Co., again charging that the War Labor Board "has illegally ordered" the company to extend an expired contract, announced tonight that it "stands ready to recognize the union when proof of its representation has been presented."
An 11-month-old baby in Brooklyn narrowly escaped death or serious injury yesterday afternoon when a runaway horse stumbled over a curbstone and fell on the child's carriage.

ALBANY, April 17 -- The State War Ballot Commission, in a liberal interpretation of the new State soldier vote law ruled today that war ballots may be sent to members of the armed forces who, in letters to relatives, give "any indication of a desire to vote."
Given a smart ride by Jockey Nick Jemas, Mrs. Louis Lazare's bay filly Smart Sheila had little trouble taking the Coquette Handicap, feature race on the card at Jamaica yesterday.

General MacArthur has done himself and the rest of us a service by issuing a clarifying statement in the matter of his widely published correspondence with Representative Miller of Nebraska. In the first place, he makes it clear that his own letters "were never intended for publication" and were therefore made public without his knowledge or approval.

The Ballet Theatre's program at the Metropolitan Opera House last night contained the season's first presentation of Anton Dolin's "Romantic Age," the second performance of Antony Tudor's "Pillar of Fire," and repetition of the two new works of the season thus far, Argentinita's "El Amor Brujo" and Agnes de Mille's "Tally-Ho."

LOS ANGELES, April 17 -Stressing four main objectives of the American people -- victory in the war, a lasting peace, retention of a free enterprise system and a speedy return to the Republican form of Government -- Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio, in an address to more than 6.000 in Shrine Auditorium tonight, said all four aims can be realized best by a Republican victory at the elections this fall.

The second annual membership exhibition of work by the Artists League of America opened last evening with a preview at the Peikin Galleries, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, and will be open to the public today. Sixty-five paintings were selected by a jury consisting of Rockwell Kent, Robert Gwathmey, Minna Citron, Philip Evergood, Ladislas Segy, Raphael Soyer, Chaim Gross, Rose Blattner and Lena Gurr.

Scenes along the New York waterfront a century ago, when saloonkeepers had a profitable sideline in shanghaiing sailors, will go on exhibition tomorrow at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue between 103d and 104th Streets, to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the founding of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York.

CHICAGO, April 17 -- Although May wheat continues to sell at ceiling prices there was an enlarged business in the near-by delivery today on the Board of Trade, longs selling rather freely to cash interests that bought to remove hedges.

LONDON, April 17 -- The Germans have completed a mine belt three miles wide along the west coast of Jutland in Denmark as part of their invasion defenses, and preparations to meet the Anglo-American onslaught from the west have been reviewed in Berlin where Adolf Hitler and Field Marshal Gen. Wilhelm Keitel, chief of staff to the Supreme Command, met Field Marshal Gen. Karl von Rundstedt, commander of the Wehrmacht in France.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- The shifting gasoline supply picture was back on the gloomy side today, when a spokesman for the Office of Price Administration said that a tabulation of March gasoline consumption figures showed that an increase in the "B" ration "is not warranted in any part of the country."

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -Henry Ford has pledged that war veterans will get job preference in Ford Motor Company plants after the war and voiced the hope that "other employers will do the same thing."
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -The question of how "tough" is the skin of Albert Barkley, majority leader, was injected into a Senate debate today.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today that Robert D. Murphy, American representative on the advisory commission in Italy, had led in urging the democratization of the Italian Government.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- The White House has informed Mrs. W.R. Hubbard of Arrow Rock, Mo., that it is not true that Mrs. Roosevelt owns four automobiles and has a gasoline ration of 2,000 gallons a month. The facts, the White House made known, are that the President's wife has only one car and basic A gas card.

Friends and associates of Prof. Paul Hazard of the College de France and former visiting professor at Columbia University were trying to confirm reports yesterday of his recent death in Paris. These reports were said to have been heard on Sunday on Both the Berlin and Paris radios, although no official announcement was made by the Office of War Information.

A new issue of $3,180,000 of refunding bonds has been scheduled by the New Orleans Levee District, La., for award on May 16. The issue will be dated June 1, 1944, and will mature serially from June 1, 1947 to 1952, and will be callable beginning June 1, 1954. Bidders are to name the interest rate at not to exceed 2 1/4 per cent.

LONDON, April 17 (AP) -- Liberator bombers of the United States Eighth Air Force attacked Nazi military installations in the Pasde-Calais area of France today without encountering a single German fighter, Strategic Air Forces headquarters announced.

All sorts of interesting and valuable information will turn up in a thorough study of the morning paper; like the fact, for example, that in 1742 it was eight days by coach from Edinburgh to London. By the Flying Scotsman train it has been eight and a half hours for a good many years now.

NAPLES, April 17 -- The Allied aerial offensive against rail centers and Nazi aircraft production centers in the Balkan-Danubian region continued in full swing today, with the heavy bombers of the United States Fifteenth Air Force attacking the Sofia and Belgrade rail yards and two plane plants at Belgrade in full strength.

ALGIERS, April 17 -- It is understood that Gen. Charles de Gaulle now expects some official communication from Washington to give diplomatic effect to the new attitude that he believes is represented by Secretary of State Cordell Hull's address on April 9.

NAPLES, April 17 -- Fifth Army patrols from the Anzio beachhead blew up an enemy ammunition dump two miles southwest of Cisterna with a hand-set fire after fighting a small arms duel with the defenders.

Establishment of specific procedures by the Foreign Economic Administration to govern the exportation of surplus steel products was accepted yesterday by foreign traders as a wartime step to prevent the use of foreign markets as a "dumping ground" for surplus materials.

LONDON, April 17 -- The impression that Dr. Bozidar Pouritch may soon be replaced as Yugoslav Premier gained currency today as King Peter renewed his conversations with Yugoslav politicians in another effort to broaden his disunited country's Government.

Last week's attempt by a young Mexican Army officer to assassinate President Manuel Avila Camacho was part of a conspiracy by a fascist army group to overthrow the present Government of Mexico and establish a fascist dictatorship on the Argentine model, according to Vicente Lombardo Toledano, Mexican labor leader and president of the Latin-American Confederation of Labor.

PHILADELPHIA, April 17 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission turned down today for the second time a plan to give shares of the preferred stock of the Federal Water Service Corporation, purchased by its senior officers in the course of reor ganization, equal recognition with stock held by public investors.

Your readers may be shocked to learn that New York lags last on the list of States trying to recruit their quotas of nurses for the armed forces. By April 1 the State had recruited only 27 per cent of the quota it was asked by the Army and Navy to raise in the first half of 1944, or 537 of its 1,957 quota.

In a time when bills of rights and charters of liberty occupy the minds of statesmen and plain folk the world over, a cross-section of the electorate of this nation is asked by the National Opinion Research Center of Denver "What do you know about the American Bill of Rights?" Twenty-three per cent of those questioned say they have never heard of it, or aren't sure whether they have or not.

SOMEWHERE IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC (Delayed) -- Pfc. Charles O. Powley, USMC, of Niagara Falls, N.Y., who single-handedly manned a machine gun on Bougainville while a tourniquet kept him from bleeding to death, wears the silver star today.

Cotton prices moved over a narrow range yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange and finished unchanged to 4 points lower. Traders were in a state of suspense, awaiting legislative action on the Price Control Act and war developments in Europe.

Allotments of summer and fall footwear were quickly snapped up yesterday as buyers jammed trade shows at several hotels and showrooms here. Manufacturers found allotments necessary even on non-rationed shoes.

Officials of the Jacobs Aircraft and Engine Company believe that recent research "shows possibilities for wide development of helicopter power application, including engines and drives," according to the annual report for 1943 issued yesterday.

Summer cottages, porches and terraces fortunately are the most likely spots for bizarre color schemes and fantastic flights of decoration and it looks as if such tricks will have to be the home decorator's mainstay this year, with summer furniture of metal and rattan gone from the scene and comparable alternatives quite expensive in view of their seasonal use.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The War Department has completed new rules for renegotiation of contracts designed to carry into full effect a program to reward efficiency or unusual risk and to penalize profiteering.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- Secretary Knox testified today that failure to renew price controls "would have serious and unpredictable consequences for the Navy."

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Independent retailers have reported their March sales as 9 per cent above sales for the corresponding month a year ago, J.C. Capt, Director of the Census, reported today. The March sales were 19 per cent above the February, 1944, level.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 17 -- Ruth Warrick, who is playing the wife role opposite Ralph Bellamy in Hunt Stromberg's United Artists production of "Guest in the House," has been signed by that producer to a contract calling for one picture a year for five years. The film will be in addition to her commitments to Radio-Keith-Orpheum.

It is quite apparent that Claiborne Foster, the actress, has an opinion of the human race which is slightly lower than that usually credited to Satan. In her new play "Pretty Little Parlor," she has filled the stage of the National with as pretty a collection of the wayward as the season thus far has looked upon.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -Counsel for the United Mine Workers of America informed the Supreme Court today of plans to ask immediate review of a Federal District Court decision that coal miners are not entitled to portal-to-portal traveling time wages.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 12, the Federal Reserve Board Announced today:

SAN JOSE, Calif., April 17--Gov. Earl Warren charged today that the Roosevelt Administration was relying for victory in the fall "almost entirely on the great, corrupt political machines of Hague, Kelly and Tammany."
LONDON, April 17 -- The Luftwaffe has suffered its most serious defeat of the war in the past six months, according to a reliable source here today.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -The automobile industry was asked today by Donald M. Nelson chairman of the War Production Board, to prepare studies showing the possibilities and the difficulties of reconverting "at some future date" to the manufacture of passenger cars on both a sharply limited and an unrestricted scale.
" That will be $60," the operator said, "six minutes at $10 a minute."

The Greater New York Fund's 1944 campaign to raise $22,250,000 to maintain voluntary hospital, health and welfare agency services at their present levels is being formally opened tonight with a dinner at the Hotel Astor, at which the principal speakers will be Arthur A. Ballantine, president of the fund, and J Stewart Baker, general chairman.

NEW LONDON, Conn., April 17 (AP) -- Beardsley Ruml, chairman of the board of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and formulator of the pay-as-you-go income tax plan, in an address to the student body of Connecticut College today advocated a prompt lowering of tax rates after the war as "a giant arm to lift us to high peacetime production."

LONDON, April 17 -- The tasks and opportunities facing the English-speaking peoples in the postwar world were dwelt on today by two distinguished British spokesmen in speeches in London and Manchester.

LONDON, Tuesday, April 18 -- A Red Army flanking column swept twelve miles down the southern Crimean coast yesterday to capture the key highway junction of Varnutka, eleven miles southeast of Sevastopol, while other Soviet forces driving in from the north and east were meeting stiffened resistance from enemy troops fighting in fortifications built by the Russians during the 1941-42 siege.

Confidence that he could again get the nomination of the City Fusion party for Mayor in 1945 was indicated last night by Mayor La Guardia. Interviewed at La Guardia Field on his return from a trip to Washington, the Mayor was questioned about the thirteen names, including his own, listed the day before by the City Fusion group as 1945 Mayorality possibilities.

The Russians do not use American lend-lease butter to grease their boots. (No sensible man would use salted butter for that purpose, anyhow, no matter how plentiful it was.) The Russians do not trade American lend-lease planes to the Japanese in exchange for rubber.

" Coastal Command," a featurelength British documentary account of the RAF guardians of convoys, will have its local premiere today at RKO first-run neighborhood theatres in Manhattan, Bronx and Westchester. The film was made by the Crown Film Unit for the British Government with the cooperation of the Air Ministry and the Admiralty.

What may have been a premonition that the Interstate Commerce Commission would, after the close of the stock market, pave the way to extend to Jan. 1, 1945, its suspension of the rail rate increase provided the only action on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

ALBANY, April 1 -- Five suggestions for a more even distribution of the work of the Legislature and for broader consideration of proposals were submitted today to Senator Floyd E. Anderson, chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Legislative Procedure, by the Citizens Public Expenditure Survey: The group would do these things:

NAPLES, Italy, April 17 -- The short-lived government of Premier Pietro Badoglio fell today. But it fell easily; and, as expected, King Victor Emmanuel accepted the resignation with the request that the marshal, who gave the Allies the armistice last September, form a new Cabinet on "a broad foundation" taking account of the wishes of "all the parties."

SYDNEY, Australia, April 17 (AP) -- Cries of "Gestapo" came from a street crowd and marching university students sang "Freedom of the press lies a-smouldering in the grave," as the censorship controversy that suppressed Sydney's four daily newspapers reached court today.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- Secretary of War Stimson said tonight that the Army's requisitions for men had been consistent with the job it has to do. He replied to "implied criticism" of Selective Service uncertainties.

KANDY, Ceylon, April 17 (AP) -Japanese invasion forces that cut the important Allied supply road between Kohima and Dimapur in eastern India last week have been thrown from important positions and have suffered "very heavy" losses by counter-attacking British and Indian troops, an Allied communique announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The trial of thirty alleged seditionists charged with campaigning to overthrow the United States Government and set up a Nazi State, chiefly by means of demoralizing the American armed forces, began today, but little progress was made.

Many New York concerns that before the war sent representatives to Paris fashion displays have been receiving by mail elaborate publications detailing original French styles of the winter 1943-1944, it was learned yesterday.

One of the most notable and potentially most important developments of this war has been the close harmony and cooperation in all fields between the United States and the British Empire. Beginning long before America was actually involved in the fighting, it has blossomed and ripened into full fruit, and is today one of the major factors in world affairs.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Opening of debate in the House today on renewal of lend-lease for another year brought from Representative Earl R. Lewis, Republican, of Ohio, the exhortation that as shrewd Yankee traders, this Government should begin to insure post-war foreign air bases for the United States in return.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 17 (AP) -- Two more American fliers reached southern Sweden today after escaping from enemy-occupied territory, raising to sixteen the number of United States airmen who have made their way to this neutral country in the past two days after their planes had been forced down.

In what is correctly described as an "unprecedented position," the National Labor Relations Board, by a 2 to 1 vote, has held that an employer who discharged union workers who struck because the employer would not pay wage demands exceeding the level fixed by the Stabilization Act had not violated the National Labor Relations Act.

Martha Albrand's "Endure No Longer," which will be published by Little, Brown tomorrow, marks the author's graduation from spy stories to serious fiction. To celebrate the occasion her publishers have followed the old American tradition that calls undertakers morticians and barbers tonsorial artists -- they now call Miss Albrand's previous books "suspense stories."

Certain amendments to the plan for consolidation and merger of the Virginia Electric and Power Company and the Virginia Public Service Company were filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, D.C. Barnes, president of the Engineers Public Service Company, parent concern of Virginia Electric, announced.

LONDON, April 17 (U.P.) -- Apparently alarmed by the rising Allied threat to the Yugoslav coastal flank of their Bankan armies, German bombers again have raided Vis Island, Allied base in the Dalmatians, while Nazi air-supported armored columns have scored an initial success in the Lim River Valley of Montenegro, it was reported today.

The Southern Railway Company reduced its funded debt last year by $8,317,473, to $304,064,434, including $5,000,000 of the Atlanta Charlotte Air Line Railway Company's second mortgage bonds, dated Nov. 1, 1943, now held in its treasury.

CHUNGKING, China, April 17 -- Although no one in the Government pretends that China is now a democratic state, increasing criticism from abroad of anti-democratic tendencies here has created considerable concern and anxiety. As one of the four leading United Nations powers, China covets her good reputation and does not like being called totalitarian, Fascist, reactionary.

On its face the news from eastern India is more encouraging. The British report that they have recovered control of the entire plain around Imphal and driven the enemy once more into the wooded hills. They are attacking road blocks north and south of the town, while a relief column is pushing toward Kohima from the Assam-Bengal railway.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Prime Minister Peter Fraser of New Zealand said at a news conference today that the recently signed South Pacific pact between Australia and New Zealand was not intended to cut across cooperation with the United States or other nations and that he would be highly pleased to see Secretary of State Cordell Hull summon a Pacific conference as soon as possible.

Of the 18,048 boys and girls who failed to return to school last fall after taking summer jobs, 5,366 are known to have discontinued their formal education because of lack of interest, it was revealed yesterday in a report by Walter E. O'Leary, director of the Bureau of Attendance, to Superintendent of Schools John E. Wade.

The City Council's committee on finance approved yesterday a compromise bill designed to prevent race discrimination in future housing developments operating under tax exemption and approved amending the capital budget for a $126,360 playground in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The recent short-lived flurry of American criticism over the news that Australia has reduced the size of its Army was the consequence of uncoordinated publicity methods, both Australian and Allied. The flurry ended when some of the facts were made known.

The W. Somerset Maugham play "Sheppey" will be presented tonight at the Playhouse. Edmund Gwenn, who has been active in Hollywood, has the leading role. Heading the supporting cast is Barbara Everest, and others include Doris Patston, Gerald Savory, Frances Heflin, Anthony Kemble-Cooper, Victor Beecroft and Cathleen Cordell.

An additional Federal grand jury was impaneled here yesterday. United States Attorney James B. M. McNally said it would hear evidence on the black market in liquor and "any type of case I see fit to present to it." He had announced earlier that the extra investigating body would conduct an all-inclusive study of price and other violations in the liquor industry.

The increased use of margarine as the result of the butter shortage was the biggest change in food habits reported by those who complied with our request that they send their opinions on rationing to THE NEW YORK TIMES. Approximately 46.8 per cent said that they had been employing more of this food since the start of the war.
A new threat loomed yesterday for next Saturday's Wood Memorial and the Kentucky Derby on May 6 in Stymie, a bargain colt picked up by Hirsch Jacobs from the King Ranch for $1,500 last year.

DELAWARE TOWNSHIP, N.J., April 18 (AP) -- Warren E. Buck learned today how much fun there is in a barrel of monkeys. Someone left several barrels of them -- 100 by actual count -- out of their cages at Buck's animal farm.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- While informal surveys indicated today an increasing belief among House Republicans that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York would be their party's next Presidential nominee, Representative A.L. Miller of Nebraska continued to insist that Gen. Douglas MacArthur's name be presented as the Republican choice.

CINCINNATI, April 18 (AP) -- Behind Hank Wyse's five-hit hurling, the Cubs blanked the Reds, 3 -- 0, today before a standee crowd of 30,154, the largest opening day attendance, as baseball went into its third wartime season.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 18 -- Blue Sash, owned by O.S. Jennings and trained by Don Yates, scored a smashing victory over seven rivals, mostly Kentucky Derby and Preakness eligibles, at Pimlico today before a crowd of 12,405.

In the first change of ownership since 1910, the property at 148 West Sixty-seventh Street, corner of Amsterdam Avenue, has been sold by Hubert and James McNally to Solomon Siegel. The apartment building there is on a plot 50 by 100 feet, and the sale was made for cash above a first mortgage of $64,500 held by the Mutual Life Insurance Company.

MOSCOW, April 18 -- The Union of Polish Patriots in Russia has put on record in its official organ, Wolna Polska, a protest against statements made publicly during the past three months by official Ukrainian spokesmen who considered certain regions inhabited mainly by Ukranians but west of the Curzon Line as part of the Ukraine.

KANDY, Ceylon, April 18 -- Allied infantry and tanks are locked in heavy fighting against Japanese invasion troops around the entire jungle perimeter of the rich Imphal plain in eastern India, with the Japanese either being stopped or thrown back at every point of contact, Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten's headquarters said today.

ALBANY, April 18 -- The success of a movement, long under way, by the Dewey forces in the Republican State organization to drive Rolland B. Marvin from a position of influence in the party was indicated here today. Mr. Marvin, former Mayor and long-time leader of Syracuse and Onondaga County, is scheduled to be dropped as a member of the Republican State Executive Committee, governing body of the party in the State.

NAPLES, April 18 -- British Liberators and Wellingtons of the Mediterranean Allied Air Forces last night kept up the aerial pounding of Balkan key points by bombing the rail yards at Plovdiv, or Philippopolis, seventy miles east of Sofia in south central Bulgaria.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Complaints of its hiring policies, some of them involving charges of labor piracy, have been received by the Office of War Information, with the result that the agency is now in the process of revising its practices.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 18 -- After his return from a tour of American Army camps in England in about six weeks, James Cagney will be starred for his own company in "Blood of the Sun," a mystery story with a background of Japanese politics and military aggression. The screen story, written by Garrett Fort, will take precedence over the recently announced "Only the Valiant" by Charles Marquis Warren.

ST. LOUIS, April 18 (AP) -- The southpaw who pitched the pennant-winning game for the Cardinals last season started them off with a victory today in their race for a third straight National League championship.

Commercial Paper The volume of open-market com-i mercial paper outstanding in the, United States at the end of March was $194,800,000, according to the monthly survey of this market re- leased yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This represented a decline of $18,900,-! 000, or 9 per cent, in the month.

All accounts of the Constellation's flight from California to Washington in 6 hours 58 minutes were well written, as they could hardly help being in the nature of the case. But in all the stories there is one striking omission.

All available facts about the Nazi-inspired fashion magazines that have been delivered by mail within the last few days to members of the trade here are being submitted to the Federal Bureau of Investigation and to postoffice authorities, John M. Keating, counsel for the Millinery Stabilization Commission, announced yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 18 -If Hitler is counting upon public opinion in the United States to keep Allied forces from bombing Rome or any other area where religious buildings are located, should he try to use them to protect German troops, he is guessing wrong.

German propaganda for home and foreign consumption sought yesterday to represent Britain's pre-invasion restrictions on the diplomatic corps in London as an act of "astonishing ruthlessness" and "crude brutality" toward neutral States.

ALBANY, April 18 -- A clash between the State Department of Agriculture and the Office of Price Administration occurred today when the Commissioner of Agriculture, C. Chester Du Mond, issued a determination increasing to $4.60 per 100 pounds the price of fluid milk in the Hudson-Mohawk milk-marketing area, effective May 1.

In a spring setting that contrasted sharply with the sleet and snow of their training campaign, the Giants opened the championship season at the Polo Grounds yesterday with a performance that likewise seemed to surpass all expectations.
