F.B. Davis Jr., chairman of the board of the United States Rubber Company, said yesterday at the annual meeting in Passaic, N. J., that the value of all production by the company last year was $790,000,000, or 120 per cent more than in 1942, with war production accounting for $652,000,000, or 83 per cent of the total.
In reply to certain inquiries about Allied war aims put to him yesterday in the House of Commons, Mr. Churchill said:

THE weather was perfect and, although the Giants were not that good, they looked slick enough in scalping the Braves in the season's inaugural at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Don't look now, but our local heroes are tied for first place -- not bad for a team which finished an inglorious last the campaign before. And there are only 153 games to go.

The City Council unanimously approved yesterday the first reapportionment of Assembly districts in the city since 1917. The redistricting, carried out under the Legislative Reapportionment Act passed by the 1943 Legislature, sets up sixty-seven Assembly districts in this city instead of sixty-two.

Fifteen hundred members of the New York chapter of Hadassah, women's Zionist organization of America, gathered yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel for their annual donor luncheon. Affiliation with the American Council of Voluntary Agencies for Foreign Service, cooperating with the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, was announced.

On Monday of this week Adolf Hitler took the trouble to attend a funeral in Munich. The dead man was Adolf Wagner, just one year younger than Hitler himself, an old comrade but not one of the very oldest. Wagner was typical of the sort of men thrown to the surface of German society by the Nazi revolution.

Two new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At the Roxy, the new attraction will be Twentieth Century-Fox's "Buffalo Bill," a Western drama filmed in Technicolor and starring Joel McCrea in the title role. Maureen O'Hara, Thomas Mitchell, Linda Darnell, Anthony Quinn and Edgar Buchanan appear in supporting roles in the picture, which was directed by William A. Wellman.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission granted today a motion of the United Gas Corporation that the record be closed on its application for exemption from competitive bidding in the proposed sale of $100,000,000 of first mortgage and collateral trust bonds.

Mrs. Zorah W. Gristede, wife of Charles Gristede, of Gristede Brothers, Inc., chain grocers, picked a beautiful day for her tiff with Park Commissioner Robert Moses over the merits and cleanness of Central Park, as compared with parks in other countries.

Loud clapping of hands, disturbing the quiet of the Colonial Room at the Hotel Park Central late last night, greeted the triumph of Reuben Fine of Washington, famous international master, and holder of the national speed title, when he checkmated George Shainswit of the Bronx, in a Queen's Gambit in the fourth round of the biennial tournament for the championship of the United States Chess Federation.
LONDON, April 18 (UP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

Rodney Gilbert, editorial writer for The New York Herald Tribune, has been appointed dean of the Post-Graduate School of Journalism of the Central Political Institute of Chungking, China, it was announced yesterday by Dean Carl W. Ackerman of Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism.

Jean Harper, contralto, who was born in this city but has been soloist in Temple Israel, Boston, and sung over radio station WMEX in Boston, gave her first New York recital last night in the New York Times Hall before an appreciative audience.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Evacuation of patients from the Ream General Hospital at Palm Beach, Fla., has been halted pending an investigation by a special board of Army officers, the War Department announced in a six-line statement today.

LONDON, April 18 -- The substantial increase in Turkish exports of chrome to Germany is now the subject of diplomatic discussions in Ankara, Dingle M. Foot, Parliamentary Secretary of the Ministry of Economic Warfare, revealed today.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Among 750 casualties announced today by the War Department were the following from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:

An appeal to New York City householders to shut down furnaces now or face the consequences of an acute coal shortage next winter was sounded yesterday by Brig. Gen. Brice P. Disque, retired, president of the Coal Consumers Protective Association.

Professor John Hanna in his letter in the April 15 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES makes a number of dogmatic and sweeping assertions on the problem of the international police force which should not be left unanswered.

The new regulations governing the taking of deer in forty-nine New York State counties next fall recently passed by the Legislature, were announced yesterday by the Conservation Department. The law divides the State into four areas, with different regulations for each.

Discussing the possibility of dividends on the common stock of the American Water Works and Electric Company, .. S. Thompson, president, told the shareholders at their annual meeting yesterday that the company's policy of not paying common dividends "has not been a hit-or-miss proposition" but part of a definite program to improve the position of the equity stock.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Congress backed away today from the task of forcing draft-age men in the 4F classification into essential war jobs under threat of induction for necessary activities and passed the problem back to the executive agencies.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, April 19 -- Balaklava, historic town nine miles southeast of Sevastopol, fell yesterday to the Red Army troops of Gen. Andrei I. Yeremenko, the Russian midnight communique announced today.

Charitable, religious and public institutions will receive more than $3,400,000 of the $3,481,055 net estate left by Miss Anne Depew Paulding, niece of the late Chauncey M. Depew, who died Oct. 20. This was disclosed yesterday in a transfer tax appraisal passed yesterday by Acting Deputy Tax Commissioner David Krakauer. The gross estate was $3,744,743.
LONDON, April 18 (AP) -- Brendan Bracken, Minister of Information, told the House of Commons today he did not believe that American generals "want to set themselves up as censors of publications."

The first hostel in the metropolitan area for the relocation of Japanese-American evacuees seeking permanent homes and jobs here will open in Brooklyn on May 10, it was announced yesterday by George Rundquist, executive secretary of the Committee. An Resettle, ment of JaPanese-Americans or:ganized by the Federal aouncil of' Churches of Christ in America.

CHUNGKING, China, April 18 (AP) -- The Japanese have launched a new drive in Honan Province just east of Chengchow, strategic junction of the north-south PeipingHankow and the east-west LungHai railways, the Chinese command announced tonight, and there were indications that the invaders may be attempting to drive the Chinese from their section of the PeipingHankow line.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 18 (AP) -- Dates for six harness racing meetings, including one at Saratoga Springs, were announced today by the State Harness Racing Commission.

A decade or so after it first was done in London, Somerset Maugham's "Sheppey" finally has wandered over the troubled waters to Broadway. In offering it last evening at the Playhouse, Jacques Chambrun has given it a pleasant cast, but neither he nor they have been able to change the fact our allies and ourselves do not always see eye-to-eye on the drama.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Senate Postal Committee was called today by its chairman, Senator Kenneth McKellar of Tennessee, to meet Friday and decide whether to investigate formally how excerpts from personal correspondence between Miss Vivien Kellems, Connecticut war plant executive, and a German count living in Buenos Aires fell into the hands of a House member and a newspaper columnist.

The certificate holders with an interest in the Hotel Taft, twenty-story hostelry occupying the block front on the east side of Seventh Avenue, from Fiftieth to Fifty-first Street, are due to receive payment in full on the principal of their holdings as the result of successful conclusion of a refinancing plan for that property, it became known last night.

LONDON, April 18 -- The punishment devised by the British Government to fit the crime of fomenting strikes in essential war industries is to be five years' penal servitude or the equivalent of $2,000 fine, or both, it was announced today. These drastic powers are incorporated in a new defense regulation under the Government's emergency powers.

LONDON, Wednesday, April 19 (AP) -- One of the largest hospitals in London was blasted and set ablaze by a direct bomb hit early this morning as German raiders attacked the British capital for the third time in April's "dark of the moon" period.

Breaking as a result of increased nervousness over the supposed imminent invasion of Continental Europe from the west by the armies of the United Nations, stocks, bonds, wheat and cotton weakened and closed sharply lower yesterday, with trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange crossing the million-share mark for the first time this month.

Cotton dropped yesterday after discussion of Great Britain's order preventing uncensored diplomatic dispatches from leaving that country, which was taken as an indication of possible easy invasion of Continental Europe and the contemplated order of the War Production Board to freeze production and prices of civilian cotton goods at the 1943 levels.

LONDON, April 18 -- At question time in the House of Commons today Prime Minister Winston Churchill said that details of the plans that are being made for the establishment of machinery to maintain peace would have to await the conclusion of the war for final decision but he indicated a hope that something might be salvaged out of the League of Nations.

NAPLES, April 18 -- Four miles from the coast on the western flank of the beachhead below Rome, a former Allied outpost that had been taken by the Germans was attacked and recaptured, it was officially announced today.

FORT WORTH, Tex., April 18 (AP) -- Custody of the three children and half the community property were given to Mrs. Ruth Googins Roosevelt in a divorce from Col. Elliott Roosevelt, second son of the President.

The urgent need for an immediate "holiday" to permit some liquor production if the expanding black market and other "prohibition-day evils" are to be curbed was emphasized yesterday by Mrs. John S. Sheppard, a member of the New York State Liquor Authority, and other speakers at the mid-year conference of the National Alcoholic Beverage Control Association.

Opposition to the proposed War Production Board order aimed at freezing production and price lines of apparel and textiles to the 1943 base period was voiced yesterday in several important branches of the industries which may be affected.

Final solution of the problem of Palestine must "necessarily await the peace which victory will and must insure," Senator Alben W. Barkley, majority leader, said last night at a dinner in the Hotel New Yorker, opening the Queens section of the national campaign of the United Jewish Appeal for $32,000,000.

YONKERS, N.Y., April 18 -Murray Norman, 48 years old, of 219 West Eighty-first Street, NewI York, and Peekskil4 N. Y., wasI injured fatally and five others were l hurt at 6:50 o'clock tonight wheni two automobiles collided head-on at Palmer Avenue on the Saw Mill River Parkway here.

DETROIT, April 18 (AP) -- Jack Kramer, a Navy dischargee, was one strike from a shut-out today when he ran into a home run by Pinky Higgins, but he was the winning pitcher as the Browns defeated the Tigers, 2 to 1, before 28,034 opening-day spectators.

Although every American woman who reads newspapers and listens to the radio ought to have a conviction that she is doing a war job "in order to live with her conscience," at this stage of the war a woman must apply a measuring stick to gauge the relative importance of her work, Col. Oveta Culp Hobby, director of the Women's Army Corps, declared yesterday.
The recent decision by Australia to cut slightly the strength of her army should not be interpreted as a slackening of the Australian war effort.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, April 19 (U.P.) -- American Liberator bombers, attacking the Japanese airdrome on Satawan Island in the Carolines, dropped thirty-one tons of explosives Sunday without encountering interception or anti-aircraft fire, a communique announced today.
NAPLES, April 18 -- The Italian Cabinet crisis will not be resolved simply, it was indicated tonight.

Three slates for the new cabinet of the Daughters of the American Revolution were offered last night at the organization's fifty-third congress, meeting at the Hotel Commodore. The program was given over to nominating speeches, which were held to a time limit of four minutes for nominees for president general and two minutes for others.

The effectiveness of cigars as "morale builders" among the men of the armed services will be "put to the test" again early next month, it was revealed yesterday at the regular luncheon of the New York Tobacco Table, members of which are engaged in the tobacco trade and allied industries.

LONDON, April 18 -- Something new in the way of children's clothing exchanges has just been started by the Woman's Voluntary Services in Britain. These are the mobile exchanges which travel to the outlying villages and deep into the heart of rural districts where children's static clothing exchanges are impracticable.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, April 19 (UP) -- A communique:

LONDON, Tuesday, April 18 (AP) -- The Daily Sketch, in a featured article on its editorial page, said today that "anti-British Empire propaganda" in America was "worth several divisions to the Japanese" and "might ultimately tip the scales in India if the Allies' military position in the Orient should ever be gravely in jeopardy.

The seventeenth floor of the Bush Building at 130 West Forty-second Street, in the Times Square district, has been leased for the new regional offices of the Department of Commerce, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce and of the Bureau of the Census, for which John F. Sinnott is regional manager.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The strange meanderings of American labor in a war economy presenting abundant job opportunities, and its effect in redistributing the population, was traced today in a detailed report made public by the Office of War Information.

While representatives of the Government and of the egg trade yesterday privately denounced Mayor La Guardia's proposal that consumers boycott potatoes and eggs to force price reductions, he made another move for lower prices. The Mayor invited Government and trade spokesmen to City Hall on Friday morning to discuss the egg situation.

Eleven of twenty-seven teams that started play in the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup tournament for the contract bridge team-of-four championship were eliminated in a second qualifying round at the Hotel Pierre last night, and the sixteen surviving teams will begin a series of knockout rounds tonight.

Religious and civic leaders opened last night the drive for the $4,500,000 needed to fill the gap between the endowments and other income that provide the principal support of member organizations of the Greater New York Fund and the entire sum required for this year.
KANDY, Ceylon, April 18 (UP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

The concert given last night in Carnegie Hall by Arturo Toscanini and the NBC Symphony Orchestra, under sponsorship of the Associated Musicians of Greater New York, Local 802. American Federation of Musicians, was impressive in sight and sound.

The Declaration regarding Italy adopted by the Moscow Conference last November provided that, in addition to the complete suppression of fascism and the restoration of primary civil liberties, "the Italian Government should be made more democratic by inclusion of the representatives of those sections of the Italian people who have always opposed fascism."

DETROIT, April 18 (AP) -- K. T. Keller, president of the Chrysler Corporation, told stockholders today at their annual meeting that while the corporation had manufactured a billion and a half dollars' worth of war material in the last two years profits averaged only slightly more than half the per-share level of pre-war years.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 18 -- After only two months' tenure in office as Argentine Minister of Justice and Public Instruction, Dr. J. Honorio Silgueira, who resigned yesterday, did so because he disapproved of the present Government's religious policy, it was learned here today.

Settling post-war problems and establishing lasting peace in the world will be impossible "if the women of America go to sleep and ignore their political and social responsibilities," Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told the New York City League of Women Voters yesterday.

QUEBEC, Que., April 18 -- The central problem of Canada is not French Canada any more than it is British Canada. The problem is to make one Canada out of two civilizations, two cultures, two states of mind, that have lived side by side in the same environment for nearly three centuries without losing a shade of their sharp distinctness.

Four of the country's leading detective story writers will dissect the technique of this type of thriller at the final meeting of the book series sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES to be held at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, on May 2.

Although tuberculosis was the chief cause of disability leading to discharges in World War I, the disease dropped to tenth place in causes for discharge from the Army in 1943, Col. Esmond R. Long of the surgeon general's office said last night at a meeting in the Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street.

LONDON, April 18 -- Dealers in South American securities on the stock markets here received a stock today from the reported terms announced by the Argentine government in its decree expropriating the Primitiva Gas Company. Argentine rails were unsettled sympathetically and prices declined.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18 -- The National Football League's rules committee recommended today two major changes in the pro code and several minor alterations, after sifting through a list of forty-three suggestions made by the coaches and club owners who will open their annual meeting here tomorrow.

Moyle C. Randall, a Nova Scotia fishing boat captain, was committed yesterday to the Federal House of Detention to await another hearing before Federal Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in Brooklyn on the question whether he shall serve twenty months in jail for a prohibition law violation back in 1930.
LONDON, April 18 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

LONDON, April 18 -- Reports circulated in London tonight that Marshal of the Reich Hermann Goering was contemplating a trip to Madrid to visit Gen. Francisco Franco. There was no confirmation in British or Spanish circles here, but the report aroused considerable interest.

ALBANY, April 18 -- State employes were informed today by J. Edward Conway, president of the State Civil Service Commission, that they are covered by employment stabilization programs of the War Manpower Commission as of April 7, and that they may not accept other employment except under WMC regulations.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Whether Mrs. Hilda D. Shea, former chief of the special studies section of the Federal Communications Commission's War Problems Division, ever was affiliated with any alleged Communist-front organizations was delved into at some length today by the Special House Committee investigating FCC.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -Proponents of price-control and wage-stabilization legislation were active today on Capitol Hill, where Congress is considering extension of the two laws, scheduled to expire June 30.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- Connie Mack started his fiftieth year as a manager in baseball's big time by piloting his Athletics to a 3-2 victory in twelve innings over Washington before 27,000 opening-day fans.
LOS ANGELES, April 18 -- Resettlement of the Japanese after the war is a matter best left to each Community, Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio said today.

Four executives of the Madison Personal Loan, Inc., which was the second largest small-loan concern in the country when it was forced out of business by Governor Dewey in 1939 when he was District Attorney, received prison sentences yesterday in General Sessions.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Foreign Economic Administration advised exporters today of a list of commodities they can ship under a single "blanket" license to more than one buyer in any Latin-American country for which import recommendations, another trade restriction, are not required for these specific items.

CHICAGO, April 18 (AP) -- Senator Vandenberg of Michigan appeared to be the leading candidate tonight for keynoter at the Republican National Convention after party leaders reportedly had discouraged a move to give the honor to Representative Clare Boothe Luce.

LONDON, April 18 -- Fifteen months ago the sleek new Italian cruiser Ulpio Traiano shuddered under a violent explosion and sank in the harbor of Palermo, Sicily. A few moments later the 8,500-ton transport Viminale, lying alongside in a near-by jetty, was rent by a second thunderous blast and began to settle at the stern.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Uneasiness over the recent treaty between Australia and New Zealand as it may affect post-war interests of the United States in the Pacific was voiced yesterday in the House by Representative James P. Richards, Democrat, of South Carolina.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Edward James Smythe, fugitive defendant in the largest sedition trial in American history, was arrested today in Ausable Forks, N.Y., near the Canadian border, and was hurried here. His absence had delayed the proceedings in the Federal District Court.

ALBANY, April 18 -- The State War Ballot Commission approved today the form of the postcard applications for war ballots to be sent to New York State members of the armed forces under the Soldier Vote Law. Copies are being printed and distribution will begin as soon as they are ready.

New York City will face stiff competition after the war and will have to fight for its business, Grover Whalen, chairman of the Mayor's Committee for the World Fashion Center, said yesterday in a talk at the luncheon meeting of the National Shoe Fabric Association at the Hotel McAlpin.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18 -- Opening day was a marked success for the Phillies and a crowd of 11,910, said to be the largest ever to witness a curtain-raiser for the Phils. The Blue Jays beat the Dodgers, 4 -- 1, rather easily, with Kewpie Barrett scattering six hits, only one for extra bases.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, April 18 -- America's ace of aces, Major Richard I. Bong of Poplar, Wis., has just left our press camp after several days' stay, and I for one am not entirely sorry to see him go.

Merchants who take advantage of "people who obviously have to rely on their honesty" by removing too many ration stamps for the purchase of rationed items were warned yesterday by Daniel P. Woolley, regional administrator of the Office of Price Administration, that they face suspension for the duration of the war.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Representative John J. Cochran of Missouri, chairman of the Accounts Committee, submitted to the House today what he called evidence of waste, extravagance and duplication of effort in the legislative branch of the Government.

THE young man was a hero, thrice wounded in the terrible war that had killed so many of his friends. He had come to a decision about his life work and he knocked on the door of his celebrated father's study. "I am going to the law school," he said. His father had tried the law and found it as dull and tasteless as sawdust.

NAPLES, April 18 -- The ever-present problem of venereal disease among military personnel is admittedly worse in Italy than in the United Kingdom or even in North Africa, but not quite so bad as in Sicily, it was learned today.

CHICAGO, April 18 -- Favorable weather and crop comments from the West and the fact that seeding of spring wheat was making fair progress, combined with easiness regarding the European situation, led to increased pressure on the deferred deliveries of wheat today on the Board of Trade.

VANCOUVER, B.C., April 18 (AP) -- Vancouver newspapers again are publishing labor news freely after a four-week ban by the Vancouver Labor Council against release of labor copy to non-union reporters.

In celebration of its twenty-five-year history, the Theatre Guild will award this fall fifteen scholarships to the most promising actors, actresses and playwrights. Lawrence Langner and Theresa Helbrun, administrative directors of the Guild, revealed the scholarship plans yesterday in the Guild's offices at 245 West Fifty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Congressional legislative proposals aimed at protecting private industry by giving a Federal administrator the right to determine how and when war-developed properties should be sold after the war "may lead to dangerous results," Attorney General Francis Biddle said here today.

The Negro colleges are making a valuable contribution in the war and have a still greater contribution to make in the post-war period, President Roosevelt declared in a statement made public yesterday by Walter Hoving, national campaign chairman of the United Negro College Fund.

PHILADELPIA, April 18 -Workers' delegates to the international labor conference hope the meeting opening Thursday will lay the basis for expansion of the ILO into a truly world economic congress. This was the view expressed today at a news conference of the advance guard of delegates.

LONDON, April 18 -- Science will be called on to render Germany impotent to wage another war of aggression, Lord Cherwell, Paymaster General and close friend of Prime Minister Churchill, told the House of Lords today.

WAR DOG CENTER, San Carlos, Calif., April 18 (U.P.) -- Eight dogs trained at Army remount centers nine months ago as an experiment led patrols which accounted for 200 Japanese, the Army disclosed today.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday were 1,560, which compared with 752 in the preceding week and 690 in the like period a year ago, according to the lists printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 788, against 527 last Tuesday.

LONDON, April 18 (U.P.) -- Heavy fighting throughout Yugoslavia was reported today, with the Germans pressing a four-sector spring offensive despite the loss of 1,500 troops in the last few days, while Marshal Tito's Partisans attempted to stem the drives with intensified raids against the enemy's rail lines.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- At the end of 1943 assets of commercial banks represented by United States Government securities amounted to more than half of their total assets for the first time, according to statistics made public today by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 18 -- Evidence that the morale of German troops stationed in northeast Finland is declining was furnished over the week-end by the desertion of the chief physician at the German base hospital at Kemi. With a Finnish nurse from his hospital he arrived at the Swedish-Finnish border city of Haparanda after having covered the eighteen miles from Kemi on skis.

LONDON, Wednesday, April 19 -- Close to 2,000 American bombers and fighters brushed aside sporadic Nazi fighter opposition and penetrated to Berlin yesterday to hammer targets in the German capital and vicinity in the sixth and heaviest assault of the United States Eighth Air Force on that area.

DETROIT, April 18 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission filed in Federal court here today a complaint accusing Leonard A. Young, president of the L.A. Young Spring Wire Corporation, his wife, and a personal holding company of violating commission regulations and asking an injunction restraining Young from filing false reports with the commission.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Declaring that the Navy now is "importantly concerned" with the problem of shore bombardment, Rear Admiral George F. Hussey Jr., Chief of Naval Ordnance, acknowledged today that United States battleships have not yet been up against the "formal defenses" of a coast line such as they might encounter in supporting an invasion of Europe.

According to the recent report of the Rapp-Coudert committee, 60 per cent of the teaching staffs of the city colleges hold positions below the professorial rank. The distribution of faculties by rank in the local institutions differs markedly from that of most other colleges.

Thirty-seven downtown office buildings in Brooklyn already have yielded twenty-five tons of waste paper for conversion into wrapping paper and containers for war material, and their participation in the salvage drive will continue indefinitely, Aaron L. Jacoby, head of the Brooklyn Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, announced yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, April 18 (AP) -- An undercurrent of carnival spirit pervaded the Shawano Street area of Pittsburgh's North Side today as young and old friends of Tech. Sgt. Charles E. (Commando) Kelly prepared a welcome for the kid "we knew when."

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 18 -- The suppression, either partly or wholly, of issues of six leading daily newspapers published in three State capitals has brought prominently into the open a long-standing difference between the newspapers and the censorship controllers concerning the application of publicity censorship.

LONDON, April 18 -- The battle of the Warsaw ghetto began a year ago tomorrow. Tonight, at the headquarters of the Polish Government in exile, a courier from the Polish underground forces gave the first detailed, connected account of those six weeks of desperate fighting.

A decision whether the plan of the American Distilling Company to distribute 237,500 barrels of its whisky inventory to stockholders shall be extended beyond tomorrow in the interest of stockholders residing in this State appeared last night to rest on whatever action may be taken in the Federal court at Peoria, Ill., today by Gilbert B. Geiger, trustee appointed to handle the liquor distribution.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The next three weeks, in the opinion of informed sources here, will be extremely important in regard to the India-Burma situation. In this period the British will decisively defeat the Japanese threat to Imphal and other outposts of the railway line to the Ledo Road or it will be shown that the Japanese caught the British off balance.

BOSTON, April 18 -- Johnny Lindell drove a home run into the right-field bullpen at Fenway Park today and pointed the Yankees in the right direction as they opened the season with a 3 -- 0 victory over the Red Sox before 9,973 fans.

The public hearing in the case of Jockey Bobby Merritt against the Jockey Club and the New York State Racing Commission began last night at 7:30 o'clock in the State Building on Center Street and after a session lasting more than four hours was adjourned until the same time tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox, answering questions today concerning the intensification of bombing attacks against Japan's northern bases in the Kuriles, conceded that occupation of these bases might be a future American goal.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Administration is giving consideration to the establishment of a system of "free ports" in this country for the admission of war refugees who are barred from entrance by immigration laws.

OTTAWA, April 18 -- Air Minister C.G. Power told the House of Commons tonight that the Royal Air Force is recalling all its instructors and maintenance crews who have been in Canada cooperating in the British Commonwealth Air Training Plan.

The body of John Flaherty, 46-year-old Brooklyn union leader who had been the subject of a nine-State search since he disappeared on Feb. 18, was found floating in the Gowanus Canal at the foot of Third Street, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon.

The Flintkote Company and its subsidiaries had a net income of $317,883 in the three periods of four weeks each ended on March 25, after providing $692,075 for Federal income and excess profits, State and foreign taxes and after deducting $50,000 for contingencies arising out of war conditions, including possible renegotiation, according to a report issued yesterday.

The new officers of the undergraduate association of Barnard College, which includes the twelve members of the student council and the thirty delegates to the representative assembly, were installed yesterday in the gymnasium of Barnard Hall.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- A charge that the Partisans in Yugoslavia under the command of Marshal Tito have aided the Axis by conducting a reign of terror to promote communism and by attacking the forces of Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch when they were in battle with the Germans, was made today by Capt. Borislav Todorovitch, who recently came to this country from Yugoslavia as an emissary of General Mikhailovitch.

Net profit of the General Electric Company available for dividends for the first three months of this year was $10,384,405, or 36 cents a common share, Gerard Swope, president, informed stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday in Schenectady.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 18 -- The Argentine press rejoiced on March 28 when the Government issued a "journalists' statute," which was widely advertised as introducing a new era of greater freedom for newspapers. But later events proved the Argentine Government had not abandoned its dictation to the press.

Eugene Istomin, the 18-year-old pianist and winner of the 1943 Leventritt Award, gave his first New York recital at Town Hall last night. Mr. Istomin, who is a pupil of Rudolf Serkin and Miccio Horszowski, first appeared in this city with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony last November, playing the Brahms Piano Concerto No. 2.

The extensive use of neglected recreation facilities was urged yesterday as the answer to juvenile delinquency and inter-racial problems. The suggestions were made at a luncheon meeting of the recreation committee of the Community Councils of the City of New York, held at the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue.
LISBON, Portugal, April 18 -- A pair of shoes in Greece today costs 20,000,000 drachmas, a German newspaper said today in discussing the runaway inflation in that unhappy country.

KANDY, Ceylon, April 18 (UP) -- Allied fliers continued to give strong support to the ground forces in India and Burma, blasting enemy troop concentrations and positions in the border area. RAF fighters intercepted a Japanese formation near Palel, southeast of Imphal, yesterday, shooting down at least one plane and damaging three.

As the campaign to raise an additional $2,000,000 needed to complete the city quota of $22,386,000 for the Red Cross 1944 War Fund of Greater New York continued, a check for $170,000 was presented to the fund yesterday by the cloak and suit industry of the city.

BOSTON, April 18 (AP) -- Senator Burton K. Wheeler, Democrat of Montana, thinks that President Roosevelt's health will keep him from seeking a fourth term, that no military man can be elected President, and that Governor Thomas A. Dewey of New York will be elected to the White House next fall.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Specific dollar-and-cent mark-ups to be used by retailers in pricing seven food items, three of which are under price control for the first time, were established by the Office of Price Administration today in an order corresponding to the regulation now in effect only for fresh fish and sea foods.

The Coordinating Committee of the New York City Food and Nutrition Program voted yesterday to form subcommittees on use of abundant foods, 1944 home canning and school lunches. The group met in the headquarters of the Health Department, at 125 Worth Street.
This article is the third in a series on the results of a food-rationing survey conducted by this department. The next article will appear tomorrow.

Four men who have played a major part in a series of hijackings in the last two years, according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, were arrested yesterday by FBI agents and police of the safe and loft squad. E.E. Conroy, local FBI chief, said that some of the four had been linked to eight thefts from interstate commerce.

A. Philip Randolph, President of the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters, declined yesterday to make the race against the Rev. Adam Clayton Powell, prospective Democratic and American Labor Party nominee for Congress in the new Harlem Congressional district.
Leslie L. Fery, formerly with the Sperry Gyroscope Company, has been elected vice president in charge of sales of the General Tool and Die Company.

When the Government began to draft men for the Army it rejected those who had both actual and potential hernias. Many of us who had served in the last war protested in vain. When the problem of manpower became more pressing men with potential hernias were accepted, doubtless for operation -- all in accordance with our recommendation.

To come right to the point without any ifs, ands, ands, buts, Jerome Robbins' "Fancy Free," which the Ballet Theatre presented in its world premiere last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, is a smash hit. This young Robbins' first go at choreography, and the only thing he has to worry about in that direction is how in the world he is going to make his second one any better.

As the campaign to raise an additional $2,000,000 needed to complete the city quota of $22,386,000 for the Red Cross 1944 War Fund of Greater New York continued, a check for $170,000 was presented to the fund yesterday by the cloak and suit industry of the city.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The campaign to enlist women in the Women's Army Corps is one of the most urgent of the twenty-seven program the War Advertising Council has developed in cooperation with Government war agencies, T.S. Repplier, advertising director of the council declared yesterday at a luncheon at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
A preview of Joan Kenley blouses by Stem's at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday gave a round-up of styles covering every occasion and appealing to women of all ages, from teen-agers to grandmothers.
RICHMOND, Va., April 19 (AP) -- The National Distillers Products Corporation adopted today a selfadministered, uninsured retirement plan for employes at its annual meeting of stockholders.

MOSCOW, April 19 -- The Red Fleet was reported today in action in Crimean waters. Two cruisers, including the Krasny Krim, have poured shells into Sevastopol and bombarded other parts of the twenty-mile strip of enemy-held coast, and dispatches say that the Red Army is hearing the constant boom of naval guns as it masses for a final sweep on the port.

Eight contract bridge teams, survivors of twenty-seven teams that started Monday night, won their way last night to the quarterfinal round of the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup tournament for the national bridge team-of-four championship at the Hotel Pierre.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, April 19 -- British and Indian troops, in bayonet fighting, have broken through Japanese road blocks and relieved Kohima where a surrounded English Home Counties regiment held out against enemy attacks for a week, it was announced tonight.
KANDY, Ceylon, April 19 (AP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

It's hard to get help at 4:55 A.M., especially when it's an emergency. This was learned yesterday by Mrs. Jacqueline Hawkins, 32 years old, of 995 Cauldwell Avenue, the Bronx, when she dashed into the street for a policeman or telephone because, she said, her husband had threatened to beat her.

NAPLES, April 19 -- Capt. Robert D. Workman, chief chaplain of the United States Navy, who is making an inspection tour of naval religious installations throughout the Atlantic and Mediterranean, said today that "the Protestant churches of America are falling down in providing the clergymen needed to meet the needs of the men in the nation's naval service."

Despite the difficulties Racing Secretary John B. Campbell is having in filling races at Jamaica, another large crowd was on hand yesterday for a program topped by a split Class C event -- the Hazelwood Purse.

Lieut. Col. Thomas Hitchcock, a flying hero of two World Wars and perhaps the greatest polo player ever developed in the United States, was killed yesterday in a plane crash at Salisbury, England, according to a personal cablegram received by his family yesterday from Ambassador John G. Winant.

A Navy V-12 medical student at Columbia, Dick Ames, was outstanding at Baker Field yesterday as he notched sixteen strike-outs in hurling the Lions to victory over City College, 7 to 2. It was the opening intercollegiate triumph of the season for Columbia.

WITH THE RED ARMY ON THE THIRD UKRAINAN FRONT, April 19 (AP) -- Now that the Red Army is operating inside Rumania, it has been learned in Soviet military quarters that the Germans have assumed entire power over the Rumanian front-line areas in an effort to bolster the defense.

There are many Congressmen who have publicly deplored the multiplication, overlapping and duplication of administrative agencies. But while Congress has been quick to see the mote in the Administration eye, it has been slow to notice the beam in its own. Representative Cochran, chairman of the Accounts Committee, is to be congratulated for submitting to the House evidence of waste, extravagance and duplication of effort in the legislative branch itself.

In silence, in prayer and in memorial speeches the Jewish observances here yesterday commemorating the battle of the Warsaw ghetto, on the first anniversary of the day when Polish Jews rose against their Nazi oppressors, centered in ceremonies at the Warsaw Synagogue, 58 Rivington Street, and at City Hall.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Post-war plans must set a goal of from 7,000,000 to 10,000,000 more jobs than were available in the banner peace year of 1940, Paul G. Hoffman, president of the Studebaker Corporation, told the House Post- War Policy Committee today. Production, he said, would have to be 30 to 45 per cent above the 1940 level.
ALGIERS, April 19 -- There was an air of expectancy in political circles here today. To some extent it reflected similar nervousness in England and France.

Organization of community projects to combat religious and racial prejudices was discussed yesterday at a conference in Hunter College to create closer cooperation between churches and synagogues in development of such programs. Dr. Harry J. Carman, dean of Columbia College, presided.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Complete endorsement of price controls and a plea for re-enactment of the Emergency Price Control Act in its present form were given by spokesmen for the Congress of Industrial Organizations, the American Federation of Labor and the Railway Labor Executives Association who appeared today before the Congressional committee considering renewal of price and stabilization legislation beyond the scheduled expiration date of June 30.

LONDON, April 19 -- Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Under-Secretary of State, has been here eleven days surveying with British statesmen wartime and post-war problems in which the United States and Britain have common interests.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -The armed services are studying the unusual case of William B. Murphree, 26 years old, from Old Hickory, Tenn., who, officers said, went AWOL from the Army and joined the Marines, to win the Navy Cross for heroism in the Pacific.

This year will mark a critical period in the boys' wear industry, according to Jerome W. Blum of Cohn-Hall-Marx Company, with probabilities that major difficulties in maintaining retail volume will be encountered during the third or fourth quarter of the year.

LONDON, April 19 (U.P.) -- Increasingly violent fighting is raging throughout Yugoslavia, with the Germans launching widespread attacks in an attempt to retain the initiative and prevent broader Partisan offensive operations, a communique from the headquarters of Marshal Tito said.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- A movement developed in Congress today to take some of the wartime tax load off of recreation. Representative Harold Knutson, Republican, of Minnesota, introduced a bill to cut the cabaret tax from 30 to 10 per cent.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The Office of Price Administration announced five revisions today to its order fixing maximum prices for sale of second-hand machine tools and extras.
BERNE, Switzerland, April 19 -France expects an early landing by the forces of the United Nations. Every item of news points that way, especially those relating to massive bombings.

Gen. Alberto Romero, Minister of National Defense for Ecuador, paid tribute to the efficiency of American military training yesterday in an interview at his suite in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. He predicted that American armed might would contribute tremendously to an early victory over the Axis nations.
LONDON, Thursday, April 20 -- American air power struck another punishing blow at the Luftwaffe yesterday in an attack by 1,750 to 2,000 planes on its sources in the Reich.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 19 (AP) -- The Administration had knowledge of the preparations Japan was making for war in the Pacific and took no steps to prepare against attack, Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio, candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, asserted in a speech today.

The squabble between Park Commissioner Robert Moses and Mrs. Charles Gristede of 12 East Eighty-eighth Street, over conditions to the children's playground in Central Park, in the vicinity of Fifth Avenue and Eighty-fourth Street, moved into City Hall yesterday, but moved right out again.

James A. Farley, Democratic State Chairman, will criticize New York's soldier vote law tomorrow night in a radio talk in reply to Governor Dewey's praise of the measure. Mr. Farley's address will be broadcast from 11:05 to 11:30 over the same State-wide network of the Columbia Broadcasting System over which Governor Dewey spoke last Friday.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- John L. Lewis' demand for prompt payment of $18,000,000 to members of the United Mine Workers Union in settlement of claims for back pay for "portal-to-portal" travel time was reported to have been accepted today by the bituminous mine operators involvech

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 19 -- When word is flashed here that D-Day has arrived in western Europe the residents of this city will be summoned by church bell and telephone to a prayer meeting in historic Trinity Episcopal Church, the Rev. Philip M. Styles, rector of the church, announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19 -- Organized labor, through its claim for higher wages, was described today by Fred M. Vinson, director of the Office of Economic Stabilization, as a would-be "short-time winner at the economic roulette table" whose victory would be won at the cost of every form of security in the nation.

For personally collecting fifteen tons of waste paper and aiding in numerous other civilian war activities, Life Scout Ronald Tissot, 16 years old, of 5917 Avenue O. Brooklyn, yesterday received a $100 war bond as "Home Front Hero of the Week."
TOLEDO, Ohio, April 19 -- A Federal Trade Commission hearing was held today on the "paternity" of the famed Army jeep.

The Tokyo radio recently comforted the Japanese with the thought that "no matter what stormy winds may blow, Japan will have power and standing as a nation because of her increasing birth rate." Prof. Jesse F. Steiner in The American Journal of Sociology takes issue with this optimism and presents an analysis which shows that the population trend in Japan is no different than in the West.
THE NEW YORK TIMES printed a poem about a little dog the other day that reminded me of an ancient allegory.

A UNITED STATES NINTH AIR FORCE BOMBER STATION, in Britain, April 19 -- The Douglas A-20 medium bomber, which can be used as either a middle-altitude or a low-level bomber and strafer, is now being employed by the Ninth Air Force Bomber Command against German targets in occupied Europe.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo last night presented George Balanchine's "Serenade" at the City Center with Ruthanna Boris in the central role for the first time. Miss Boris' style is clean and crisp but with a lyrical quality that fits excellently into Balanchine's rather delicately formal little confection.

"Allah Be Praised!", a new musical comedy, will make its Broadway debut this evening at the Adelphi Theatre under the auspices of Alfred Bloomingdale. The book and lyrics are by George Marion Jr. and the songs by Donald Walker and Baldwin Bergersen.
LONDON, April 19 -- The Vatican flag may soon fly over a fleet of twenty-one coastal vessels supplying food to Vatican City and Rome, according to a German broadcast of a Rome dispatch today.

ALBANY, April 19 (AP) -- Edwin F. Jaeckle, Republican State chairman and strong supporter of Governor Dewey, declined today to intervene in a move to oust Rolland B. Marvin, Onondaga County leader and an avowed Wendell Willkie admirer, from the Executive Committee of the State Committee.

ALBANY, April 19 -- Appointment of Miss Esther Dorn Longstreet of New York City as Deputy State Industrial Commissioner at an annual salary of $8,500 was announced today by Edward Corsi, Industrial Commissioner.

NAPLES, April 19 -- Thirty-ton, fully loaded Royal Air Force Liberators virtually skimmed the surface of the flooded Danube River to lay mines that have caused Balkan radios to announce that the stream has been closed to all traffic, it was disclosed today.

Consolidated earnings of the Johns-Manville Corporation and its subsidiaries, manufacturers of building supplies, were $1,451,566 for the first three months of this year, equal to $1.66 a common share, after preferred dividend requirements, Lewis H. Brown, president, reported yesterday.

Wartime brides and "new money girls" will figure prominently among the purchasers of home furnishings after the war, Arthur P. Hirose, market research director of McCall's, told the home furnishing division of the Fashion Group at a luncheon in the Murray Hill Hotel yesterday. Mr. Hirose spoke on "How Will War-Learnt Lessons Affect Post-War Merchandise, Promotion and Distribution in Home Furnishings?"

LONDON, April 19 -- Although the records, which would make an exact comparison possible, are not available here, there is little doubt that the G.I. of this war is a more orderly and much better behaved soldier than the doughboy of World War I.

Interrogation of witnesses at the public hearing in the case of Jockey Bobby Merritt against the Jockey Club and the New York State Racing Commission because of refusal to grant a 1943 riding license to him following his rides on Peep Show at Empire City two years ago continued in the State Building on Centre Street last night.

The Jewish people of New York City paid tribute last night to those of their faith who defied German troops a year ago yesterday in the epochal battle of the Warsaw ghetto, and took occasion to urge that all democracies grant temporary asylum to any Jew still able to escape Hitlerite Europe.

Lillian E. Smith will discuss her book "Strange Fruit" in Harlem Friday evening at 8:30 at a book forum at the 135th Street Library. The discussion is sponsored by the Schomburg Collection of Negro Literature.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Significant evolutions in Army ground forces training policies have taken place quietly within the last six months as the natural result of the Army's reaching its goal of 7,700,000 officers and men.

A government based on self-reliance rather than the planning of "starry-eyed boys" was advocated yesterday by John A. Zellers, vice president of Remington Rand, Inc., at the fifteenth annual meeting of the Twenty-third Street Association.

LONDON, April 19 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg was appointed deputy Commander in Chief of the Allied Expeditionary Air Force by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower today, succeeding Maj. Gen. William O. Butler, who received an undisclosed new assignment.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Six of the nation's oil companies that hold patent rights for the development of high-octane aviation gasoline and toluene, a necessary element of high explosives, have agreed on terms under which other American refining plants may use the patented processes for the manufacture of those war items, the Petroleum Administration for War announced today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., April 19 -- Prime Minister John Curtin of Australia, arriving here today as head of an official party en route to Washington and London, declared himself opposed to wartime censorship except "that which security makes necessary."

The summer advertising campaign of The Best Foods, Inc., will stress the nutritional value of their products and at the same time boost Victory Gardens, according to Albert Brown, director of advertising. The company winds up a two-day semi-annual sales meeting today.
COLLEGEVILLE, Pa., April 19 (AP) -- The bride used a G.I. helmet to bathe and her gown was cut from a bed sheet, but she "looked like a magazine cover," her parents were informed today.

CHUNGKING, China, April 19 (AP) -- Chinese censorship was defended by Information Minister Liang Han-chao today on the ground that it had been necessary to "exercise a good deal of caution and precaution in the interests of national survival, particularly since the outbreak of Sino Japanese hostilities."

NAPLES, April 19 -- Yielding to the opposition junta's protest about the difficulty of maintaining contact during negotiations, Premier Pietro Badoglio has agreed to come tomorrow from the seat of the Italian Government and continue interviewing oppositionists here with a view to forming a new Cabinet.

LONDON, Thursday, April 20 (AP) -- The Germans, lashing out fiercely to save their big base at Lwow, have launched a large-scale attack in the southeastern corner of old Poland, and some towns have changed hands south and east of Stanislav, the Russians announced last night.

Mary Allison, 27 years old, a housemaid, was held in $1,000 bail for the action of the grand jury in the Felony Court yesterday in the alleged theft of $4,500 in banknotes the night before from her employers, Mr. and Mrs. Irving Weissberger, at 40 West Seventy-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- Distinguished Flying Cross awarded to 265 members of the Fifth Air Force for "extraordinary achievement while participating in aerial flights in the Southwest Pacific area." The recipients included Captains Ernest J. Wells, 129 Brookside Road, Darien, Conn.; Joseph R. Petronis, 432 Augustine Place, Perth Amboy, N.J.; Alfred Retsky.

NEWARK, N.J., April 19 -- A Federal Bureau of Investigation agent who was assigned in 1935 to investigate subversive activities, told a jury in Federal Court here at the propaganda conspiracy trial that he had written a pamphlet entitled "America's Jew Deal," to obtain membership in German-American organizations.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Chief Justice Edward C. Eicher today arraigned Edward James Smythe before the bar of the United States District Court here and bound him by $10,000 bail, despite his loud insistence that he had been innocently absent from the Government's trial against him and twenty-nine other alleged seditionists.

An interesting program of vocal and piano music, combining in nice balance the classic, romantic and modern schools, was given last night before an audience that filled the Carnegie Chamber of Music Hall by Nora Dinkov, mezzo-soprano, and Lucy Brown, pianist.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The Women's Division of the Citizens' Committee for a National War Service Act was started today with visits to and endorsements by Secretary Stimson and Secretary Knox.

New issues of short-term notes aggregating $39,799,000 were awarded yesterday by eighteen local housing authorities throughout the country. The awards were as follows: Salomon Bros. Hutzler, $26,836,000; the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, $5,297,000; the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, $2,525,000; R. W. Pressprich Co., $2,371,000; Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., $1,531,000, and Harvey Fisk Sons, Inc., $1,239,000.

A serious misstatement was made in your first-page article in THE TIMES on March 23, 1944. The article was headed "Big Catholic Chapel to Rise in Wall Street Area After the War." In the article you refer to St. Andrew's Church at Cardinal Hayes Place and Duane Street, of which the Right Rev. William E. Cashin is pastor.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The debate on a one-year extension of lend-lease, which is about to progress from the House to the Senate, has revealed Congress for the first time thinking of this service of war supply in post-war terms. On every previous occasion when aspects of lend-lease were being considered, the heavy accent was on their contribution to a successful outcome of the war.

Further improvement was recorded last week in the nation's stocks of major oil products, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the close of the period, gasoline stocks amounted to 88,778,000 barrels, 678,000 more than the 88,100,000 reported at the end of the previous week.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- A Treasury Department census of American property abroad has disclosed that it amounts to $13,300,000,000, the largest foreign investment by any country except Great Britain, Secretary Morgenthau said today.
CHICAGO, April 19 -- Gov. Earl Warren of California was appointed today temporary chairman and keynoter of the Republican national convention, which opens here June 26.

ALBANY, April 19 -- The State Liquor Authority, acting under a recently enacted law, announced today that it had decided to issue permits enabling stockholders of the American Distilling Company to exercise the privilege of acquiring whisky under the dividend plan of the company. The Authority conducted a special meeting today to act upon information received from Gilbert B. Geiger, trustee appointed by the American Distilling Company to handle the liquor distribution to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- President Roosevelt laid the responsibility for the safety of Rome squarely with the German Government in a message to Prime Minister Eamon de Valera of Eire, made public today by the Department of State.

DETROIT, April 19 (AP) -- The Browns got three-hit pitching today from Steve Sundra to defeat the Tigers, 3 to 1, for a 2-0 series edge. Rudy York homered for Detroit's run in the fourth. It was York's 1,000th major league hit.
Prices for cotton broke early in the session yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, but they recovered and finished at about the best levels of the day with net gains of 8 to 14 points.

Adolf Hitler was born fifty-five years ago today in the town of Braunau on the Inn, near the German border of Austria. We cannot positively say that everything would be well in the world if he had not been born, but we can be fairly sure that things would not be worse than they are.
LONDON, April 19 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Ber lin and recorded by The United Press:

Delegates to the annual congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution cast their votes at the Commodore Hotel yesterday in a three-cornered race for the office of president general, in which the winner will succeed Mrs. William H. Pouch, the incumbent.

Asserting that the "nation's jails would not be large enough to hold all the persons who are violating the price control law," Benjamin Siegel, attorney, yesterday urged that the act be amended o permit the granting of immunity from Government liabilities to companies who voluntarily disclose any black market activities in which they may have engaged.

BOSTON, April 19 (AP) -- Gerard Cote of Montreal outlasted Johnny Kelley of West Acton ina grueling duel through the last five miles today to win his second successive Boston A. A. Marathon and the third of the last five of these Patriots' Day classics.

Consolidated net income of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and subsidiaries aggregated $5,528,939 in 1943, compared with $2,142,545 in 1942, an improvement of $3,386,394, or 158 per cent, Sosthenes Behn, president, disclosed yesterday in his annual report to stockholders.

CHUNGKING, China, April 19 (U.P.) -- Japanese troops of two crack armies, swiftly developing a spring offensive designed to clear central China railroads, attacked the Honan Province railroad junction of Chengchow from the east and no today and are expected to open coordinated attacks from south and southeast Honan.

ALBANY, April 19 -- The extraordinary grand jury investigating legislative spending handed up an indictment today charging Surrogate Roy M. Page of Broome County, former Republican Senator, with grand larceny and corrupt bargaining for appointment.

LONDON, April 19 (AP) -- German planes stabbed at England tonight for the second successive night but avoided London's bristling defenses, which claimed thirteen raiders in a pre-dawn attack earlier today. Bombs fell in three districts in southeast England.
BOSTON, April 19 -- The Yankees backed out of Back Bay tonight a chastened crew after seeing two of the club's rookie hurlers hammered into submission in two Patriots' Day games at Fenway Park.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 19 -With Liberator bombers and Flying Fortresses crisscrossing the coastal areas and hinterland of the Reich on the eve of Adolf Hitler's fifty-fifth birthday and the specter of an Allied invasion by land, sea and air looming permanently on Germany's troubled skies, the German people today were admonished to hold fast to their loyalty to the Reichsfuehrer.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 19 -Admiral Thomas C. Hart, back from a tour of the Pacific during which he took depositions on the circumstances of the Pearl Harbor attack, said here today that he found the morale good among the fighting men he had talked to, although some voiced apprehension about the spirit of the people in their homeland.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (U.P.) -- The War Department, disclosing that ten American transport planes had been shot down over Catania, Sicily, with a loss of forty-four men on the night of last July 13, announced tonight that it estimated that five of the planes had been victims of the Allies' gunfire.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The Marine Corps disclosed today that Lieut. Col. James Roosevelt, eldest son of the President, was promoted to colonel April 13.

ALBANY, April 19 (AP) -- The Most Rev. Edmund F. Gibbons received today a gift of $492,717, as prominent clergymen and laymen of the State joined in celebration of his twenty-fifth anniversary as Bishop of the Albany Catholic Diocese.

Social welfare improvements for Bolivian workers are stalemated because the United States has not recognized that South American country's new revolutionary government, and the people feel "bitter" that official relations have not been established, Victor Andrade, Bolivian Minister of Labor, declared yesterday at a press conference at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Resumption of fighting in China may mean merely that spring has come again. But the direction of the present Japanese attack suggests that the invader is being forced by necessity to open an alternate land route to supply his armies in Burma. General Chennault's bombers and our American submarines have made the convenient sea lanes through the Formosa Strait too hazardous.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The Very Rev. Angus Dun was consecrated fourth Bishop of Washington today in a ceremony clothed with historic dignity, filled with color and ritual and conducted in the impressive setting of the Cathedral of St. Peter and St. Paul.

Pointing out that market prices for used machine tools are now 30 to 70 per cent below ceiling prices, the Machinery Dealers Institute last night called upon the Office of Price Administration to eliminate price orders which "have outlived their basic usefulness but still place an onerous burden upon the industry."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 19 -- The Finnish answer to Russia's revised armistice terms, now in Moscow, makes the question of the internment or expulsion of German troops in Finland conditional on the possibilities of compliance with the balance of the terms, according to well-informed political circles in Helsinki.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Authorization of the light blue Army hostess uniform for the use of United States civilian women employed in war areas overseas was announced today by the War Department.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19 (AP) -- The Boston Yankees received first pick in the National Football League's draft of college players tonight, and the new league member chose Angelo Bertelli, last year's Notre Dame backfield star.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

One of the nation's large food canning concerns, from which the Office of Price Administration is seeking $1,277,733 in treble damages for alleged price violations, was charged in Federal court yesterday with having set up a dummy corporation for the sole purpose of adding the 20 per cent mark-up in price allowed under OPA regulations to legitimate wholesalers.

Justice Bernard L. Shientag dismissed yesterday in the New York Supreme Court a stockholders' suit against the Celanese Corporation of America and its directors, holding that the directors had merely exercised business judgment in hiring Jean Tennyson, wife of Dr. Camille Dreyfus, president, to sing on a radio program and in signing an employment contract with Dr. Henri Dreyfus, chemist.

Organized labor, for the first time in corporate history, made yesterday a concerted attempt to obtain direct representation on the board of directors of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the nation's largest single corporate enterprise.

Daniel P. Woolley, regional administrator of the Office of Price Administration, said yesterday that he was conferring with OPA district directors in the Hudson-Mohawk area as a result of the State Department of Agriculture's defiance of OPA price ceilings in announcing a price of $4.60 per 100 pounds for fluid milk in that marketing area, to go into effect May 1.

Probably no other large company has been more aggressive in the last few years in acquiring its stock than has the Sinclair Oil Corporation. Yesterday the company announced that, with the closing of the transaction for the purchase of 716,323 shares of its stock from the Rockefeller interests, it had in its treasury 1,104,119 of its shares.

LONDON, April 19 -- Distrust of the motives underlying the British Government's latest defense regulation imposing stringent penalties on those who instigate strikes was voiced today by angry Labor members of Parliament who demanded that it be annulled.

Selling of shares on the Stock Exchange was less aggressive yesterday than on Tuesday, but stocks continued to sag. It appeared as if a few attempts were made to stop the downward course of the market, but they came to little and the list closed at about the lowest levels of the day -- down fractions.

NAPLES, April 19 -- The Germans struck four staccato blows on the beachhead below Rome in the period ended at noon yesterday, apparently intending to crack the Allies' line at the sensitive area southwest of Aprilia and around the crisscrossed gullies feeding out of Moletta Creek.
PANAMA, April 19 -- All newspapers in El Salvador except the Diario Nuevo, the Government mouthpiece, have been suspended since the attempted overthrow of the Government.

For a club supposed to be weak and uncertain in the pitching department, the Giants are doing all right. At least, they have survived the first two days of the season without help from the bull pen, because yesterday at the Polo Grounds Ewald Pyle gave a mighty fine performance, while twirling the New Yorkers to their second straight 2-1 victory over the Braves.
CHICAGO, April 19 (AP) -- The White Sox handed the Indians a 3-to-1 trimming in the delayed season opener at Comiskey Park today before 5,705 fans. Orval Grove held the Tribe to seven hits.

The issuance of Federal Court injunctions against thirty-three additional restaurants, grills and cafeterias charged with having illegally increased food and liquor prices was announced yesterday by the regional Office of Price Administration.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Halsey Stuart Co., Inc., will offer today to the public $17,000,000 of first mortgage 3 per cent bonds of the Louisiana Power and Light Company due in 1974. The price will be 103 and accrued interest.

Disregarding personal safety and a most-prized possession -- a last pair of nylon stockings -- Mrs. Muriel Shaffer, teacher in a private school, yesterday afternoon entered a sewer opening in West Thirty-fourth Street and plucked a struggling maltese tomcat from the water.

Control agencies in fourteen of the seventeen liquor monopoly States were recorded unanimously in favor of permitting a resumption of beverage alcohol distillation, if consistent with war requirements, at a meeting yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
LONDON, April 19 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

While yesterday's city-wide collection of waste paper by the Department of Sanitation showed an increase over the previous Wednesday's regular weekly pick-up, officials of the salvage drive said the figures could be much higher if there were full cooperation from the public.

Arnold S. Denker, on hand last night at the Manhattan Chess Club to finish his game with Israel A. Horowitz, adjourned from the fourth round of the United States chess championship, received Horowitz's resignation by telephone. His rival had satisfied himself that his position held no hope.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, April 20 (AP) -- Four-engined Liberators based in the Solomons bombed the Nomoi Islands in the Carolines for the second successive day Monday and again met neither anti-aircraft fire nor opposition from enemy interceptors at that southern guardian of their Truk fortress.

Rose Dercourt, soprano, gave her first New York recital last night in Town Hall. Born in Poland, Miss Dercourt was brought to this country as a child and after preliminary vocal studies here, returned to Europe, where she received her chief training in Paris.
As the war effort approaches the climax our thoughts turn to the days of peace to come. This is as it should be.

The resignation of W.H. Cowles, publisher of The Spokane (Wash.) Spokesman-Review, from the board of directors of The Associated Press was accepted yesterday. He had been on the board for thirty-three years and asked that he be relieved for reasons of health.

Seven ships are how making regular trips between the United States and Europe carrying exclusively Red Cross cargo and mail for prisoners of war and civilian internees, according to the April issue of the Prisoners of War Bulletin published by the American Red Cross for the relatives of prisoners.

The commanding generals of the Army's nine service commands and the Military District of Washington will meet here today at the Hotel Astor "for an informal discussion of mutual problems," the Army announced last night.

The help provided by the social agencies of New York is keeping a check on juvenile delinquency, District Attorney Charles P. Sullivan, honorary chairman of the Queens 1944 appeal of the Greater New York Fund, declared yesterday.

The week beginning July 31 was chosen yesterday as Fall market week by the joint standing committee of the Corset and Brassiere Association of America and the Associated Corset and Brassiere Manufacturers, Inc. The date set is slightly later than was the case last year.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -Padded mileage estimates of applicants for C gasoline ration books rank alongside the black market in draining gasoline from essential uses, Charles Phillips, director of the Automotive Supply and Rationing Division of the Office of Price Administration, told a petroleum subcommittee of the House Interstate Commerce Committee today.

LONDON, April 19 (U.P.) -- The German High Command spread an urgent alarm along more than 2,000 miles of European coast from Arctic Norway to the Spanish border today, ordering its garrisons on the alert to repel a gigantic Allied amphibious assault that might strike "at any place at any hour," according to Stockholm advices.

CINCINNATI, April 19 (AP) -- Backed by Elmer Riddle's three-hit hurling, the Reds trimmed the Cubs today, 2 -- 1, on the strength of Ray Mueller's fourth-inning double with two mates on file bases, and evened the series at one game each.

LONDON, April 19 -- The war situation and the coming Government budget caused the stock markets to mark time today. South American securities, following yesterday's flurry caused by the Argentine Government's reported terms of expropriation to the Primitiva Gas Company, were slightly firmer.
The following article is the fourth in a series on the results of a food-rationing survey conducted by this department. The next article will appear on Monday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19 -- After being nice to the Phillies on their opening day, the Dodgers bounded back today to register their first triumph of the season, 5 -- 4, in the tenth inning. Fred Fitzsimmons' forces made it uncomfortably close, though, tying the count at 4 -- all in the ninth, when they drove Ol' Dan'l Boone Davis away and prevented him from chalking up his first victory.

CHICAGO, April 19 -- Professional operations resulted in nervous fluctuations in the wheat market today on the Board of Trade. Local operators who sold yesterday covered their lines on the dips, taking profits, and there was little actual pressure.

CHICAGO, April 19 -- Professional operations resulted in nervous fluctuations in the wheat market today on the Board of Trade. Local operators who sold yesterday covered their lines on the dips, taking profits, and there was little actual pressure.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- The State Department made public today the text of a letter addressed to President Roosevelt by Prime Minister Eamon de Valera of Eire, appealing to the United States to spare Rome, and of President Roosevelt's reply.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, April 20 -- A communique:

Doubt regarding tax regulations for corporations in liquidation forced yesterday adjournment of the annual meeting of the Phoenix Corporation in Wilmington, Del. No action was taken on the plan to liquidate, now approved by more than 85 per cent of the outstanding stock.

Tribute to the Jews of Warsaw who staged a desperate uprising against their German rulers a year ago was paid yesterday at the annual donor luncheon of the Manhattan Women's Division of the American Jewish Congress. Dr. Stephen S. Wise, president of the congress, told 450 women gathered at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria that posterity "will hear the young heroes and heroines of Warsaw grouped together with the Maccabees."

THE Man From Down Under, M.P. Greenwood Adams, arrived as usual amid a cloud of pipe smoke and an aura of jovial good nature. He had just returned from a three-month lecture tour and seemed more than anxious to talk about sports for a change.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The House today approved extension of lend-lease legislation for another year by a roll call vote of 334 to 21, thus renewing its active phases until June 30, 1945, and postponing the date of the system's appointed dissolution to July 1, 1948.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19 -- The international economic and financial policies and measures" in the light of its objective of economic and social security probably will be subjected to considerable criticism, it was reported here on the eve of the ILO's twenty-sixth session, which opens tomorrow at Temple University.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 19 -- Uncertainty has developed over the proposed leasing of the Westchester County Center here as a war factory, and prize fights and other entertainments are being booked for May appearances in the building, County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach said today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19 -- An American and a Russian shared tonight the highest award bestowed by the Franklin Institute for scientific achievement. The 1944 Franklin medals went to Dr. William David Coolidge, vice president and director of research of the General Electric Company, and Dr. Peter Kapitza, director of the Institute for Physical Problems of the Academy of Sciences, U.S.S.R.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19 -- The international economic and financial policies and measures" in the light of its objective of economic and social security probably will be subjected to considerable criticism, it was reported here on the eve of the ILO's twenty-sixth session, which opens tomorrow at Temple University.

LONDON, April 20 -- In the first major blow struck by the British Eastern naval forces in the Indian Ocean since the tragic fall of Singapore, bombers and fighters from aircraft carriers that formed the nucleus of a powerful Allied fleet carried out a devastating surprise attack on northern Sumatra at dawn Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The importance of problems surrounding international cartels in the post-war world was recognized by Secretary of State Cordell Hull today through the establishment of an industry branch in the commodities division of the Office of Economic Affairs.

Mayor La Guardia's executive budget of $737,333,148 for 1944-45 will be amended to restore most of his cut of $410,000 in the appropriation for the Board of Higher Education, it was indicated yesterday after a three-hour executive session of the Board of Estimate.
A call to industry to "retool its thinking" before its machinery for post-war production was issued here yesterday by Dr. Thomas Parran, Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service.

WINDSOR, Ont., April 20 -- An hour after employes of the Ford Motor Company of Canada, Ltd., members of the United Auto Workers, CIO, walked out this morning in what they called "a work holiday," the management served notice on Local 200 of the union that it had terminated its contract with the organization.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- An increase in the price of poultry that will cost consumers an estimated $15,000,000 has been authorized by the Office of Economic Stabilization and will probably be put into effect by the Office of Price Administration this weekend, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Commodity prices in primary markets rose 0.1 per cent during the week ended April 15 as a result of higher prices for farm products -- especially hogs, eggs and citrus fruits.
