WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Immediate steps to assure full ownership of the Atlantic bases leased from Great Britain in 1940 for ninety-nine years in exchange for fifty over-age destroyers was urged today by a three-man subcommittee of the House Naval Affairs Committee, which recently ended a tour of these bases.

A warning that the spirit of unity that inspired the nation immediately after Pearl Harbor has gradually dwindled away under the influence of the complacent belief that the war is already as good as won was sounded last night by Robert P. Patterson, Under Secretary of War, in an address in The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

LONDON, Friday, April 21 -- The full fury of the American air offensive struck yesterday at German military installations in northern France, where the enemy has been hurriedly strengthening his fortifications and reinforcing his garrisons against an invasion from Britain.

The six-story apartment building for sixty-five families at 135 West 238th Street, adjoining the corner of Bailey Avenue, in the Bronx, has been purchased by Isadore B. Geller, operator, for cash over a first mortgage of $211,000 at 4 per cent. It was held at $245,000 and was sold through the Sonn-Saalberg Company.

Three new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning At the Gotham the attraction will be "Up in Mabel's Room," a comedy produced by Edward Small for United Arists release. Marjorte Reynolds, Dennis O'Keefe, Gall Patrick, Mischa Auer, Binnie Barnes, Lee' Bowman, Charlotte Greenwood and John Hubbard are among the featured players....

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- An all-American effort to provide play programs this summer for children 7 to 14 years old as a preventive for juvenile delinquency and an aid for war-working mothers is being urged by the Office of Community War Services.

Michael J. Quill, City Councilman from the Bronx and president of the Transport Workers Union, an affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, was characterized yesterday by Edmund J. O'Keefe, Bronx County commander of the American Legion, as a "master faker" and a labor leader of "absurd arrogance."

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Separate ceiling prices for new synthetic rubber tires and tubes covering sales at both the wholesale and retail levels were established today by the Office of Price Administration in an action which provides for the first time minimum prices for the synthetic articles apart from the ceilings for natural rubber tires and tubes.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 20 -- Berlin decorated its miles of glassless windows with the national colors today and placarded the walls of ruined buildings with slogans that defied a world of enemies as they reasserted faith in Adolf Hitler and ultimate victory.

Defeating David Gladstone of the Queens Club of Woodside in the fifth round at the Park Central Hotel, Reuben Fine of Washington regained the lead, at any rate temporarily, in the United States chess championship with a score of 4 1/2 -- 1/2 last night.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Allied "air invasion" of Europe has cost the Germans 20 per cent of their first-line fighter plane strength since January, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson estimated today, adding that the Luftwaffe's ability to resist, though still alive, was steadily "weakening."

From all accounts it would appear that our Fuel Administration officials leave entirely out of consideration the fact that those households which have no other adequate heating medium must necessarily use oil in summer to heat water for bathing and laundry purposes.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The War Department disclosed today that it has begun an efficiency screening of its rapidly expanded officers corps.

LONDON, April 20 -- The feature of today's generally quiet stock market here was the support afforded the insurance shares, interest in these being increased by a big expansion in marine underwriting profits.

While trade of South America with the United States rose to about $800,000,000 last year, it may fall to half that amount immediately after the war and may take a decade to get back to the 1943 figures. Milton Reynolds, chairman of the board of the Printasign Corporation of America, Chicago, said in an interview here yesterday.
Joseph M. Barr, assistant general manager of the Chance Vought Aircraft Division of the United Aircraft Corporation, has been named manager of the export department, effective May 1.

NAPLES, April 20 (U.P.) -- The Allies' commanders, regrouping their forces in Italy as the Germans rushed reinforcements through Rome, have replaced veteran British troops along the lower Garigliano River with American units of the Fifth Army, it was announced today.

Dr. Anthony Renda, 56 years old, of 98-20 Allstyne Avenue, Corona, Queens, was found guilty by a General Sessions jury last night of first degree manslaughter in the death of Mrs. Amelia Cardito after an abortion last Feb. 14. Judge George L. Donnellan remanded him to the Tombs pending sentence May 11.
LONDON, April 20 (UP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

NAPLES, April 20 -- Premier Pietro Badoglio, who eight years ago was on the final lap of his triumphant march to Addis Ababa, returned to Naples today as an utterly unhailed man in a big car flying a blue flag with four red stars signifying his rank.
BOSTON, April 20 (AP) -- The condition of William Cardinal O'Connell, dean of the Roman Catholic hierarchy in America, who is suffering from bronchial pneumonia, was reported tonight to be unchanged.

The one-story taxpayer and four-story apartment building in the rear at 184-86 East Seventy-third Street and 1260 Third Avenue, the southwest corner, have been sold by the Bank for Savings to a client of Benjamin L. Leinhardt, broker, for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $105,000 for ten years.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- A committee of bondholders of the Central Railroad of New Jersey, represented by T.R. White of Philadelphia, is proceeding with plans to propose a reorganization plan for the railroad, for which no plan has been filed during the four and a half years it has been in the hands of trustees.

LONDON, April 20 -- The rule that prevents Ministers of Cabinet rank from engaging in journalism still applies to the present British Government, Prime Minister Churchill declared today, but does not apply to Lord Beaverbrook, owner of The Daily Express and The Evening Standard.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- The loss of a big Navy flying boat in the Caribbean area was announced by the Navy today. It reported fourteen of the crew and passengers missing.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- Early Wynn shut out the Athletics with two hits today, while his mates combed the efforts of Russ Christopher, Jack McGillen and Carl Scheib for ten hits to give Washington a 5-0 victory. This was Wynn's eighth straight victory over Connie Mack's squad.

THE lads and lassies who are devoted to the improvement of the breed -- at $2 and up per mutuel ticket -- will gather at Jamaica in such numbers tomorrow that the biggest race of the day will not be the Wood Memorial, the technical feature, but the brisk competitive struggle to get to the windows in time to plank down a bet.

A plea for compliance with safety regulations by motor carriers was made yesterday by John L. Rogers, a member of the Interstate Commerce Commission of Washington. He pointed out that the loss of life caused by all motor vehicles was greater than that incurred by our army forces so far.

The Red Cross 1944 War Fund awarded a citation yesterday to 550 members of Local 273, United Cannery, Agricultural, Packing and Allied Workers of America, an affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, in recognition of an "additional gifts" campaign carried out to help raise the balance needed to complete the city's $22,386,000 goal.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- Editors of America's larger daily newspapers will talk over wartime problems with Government officials in off-the-record discussions tomorrow and Saturday.

DETROIT, April 20 (AP) -- The Republican State Convention today commended Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York as the "overwhelming" favorite of Michigan voters for the Republican Presidential nomination.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20 -- The Chicago Sun, 2-year-old newspaper founded by Marshall Field, was announced tonight as the winner of the F. Wayland Ayer Cup in the fourteenth annual exhibition of newspaper typography conducted by N. Y. Ayer Son, Inc., of this city.

NEWARK, N.J., April 20 (AP) -- Tom Sunkel, veteran southpaw, threw a wet blanket on Newark's opening festivities by hurling Montreal to a four-hit, 7 to 1 victory, before a paid attendance of 4,186 today.
Yesterday, the eleventh day of the Spring meeting of the Metropolitan Jockey Club, set itself apart from the preceding ten days in three distinct ways.

In your editorial on the approval of treaties you say that "it is illogical * * * that while a majority of both branches of Congress is sufficient to declare war, two-thirds of the Senate is required to effect the subsequent peace." You do not state why it is illogical to treat two subjects of widely varying nature in different ways.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- "A wide and impassable gulf" separates the cotton textile industry's conceptions of sound and legitimate prices and the ideas of the Office of Price Administration, Dr. C.T. Murchison, president of the Cotton-Textile Institute, Inc., told the Senate's Banking and Currency Committee today.
Although yesterday's session on the New York Stock Exchange was the third dullest of the year, stocks improved and closed moderately higher. Sales were 533,790 shares, against 904,395 on Wednesday.

LONDON, April 20 (U.P.) -- A powerful political tug-of-war for the possession of Rumania raged tonight as Russia was believed to be offering the war-weary Rumanians the tempting reward of a restored Transylvania for their desertion from the German ranks.
Mrs. Muriel Shaffer, who entered a sewer Tuesday and rescued a half starved and almost drowned tom cat, tearing her last pair of nylon stockings in the process, was smiling much brighter yesterday.
Leases in buildings on Fifth Avenue by out-of-town concerns featured rentals of business quarters in the city yesterday.

All elevator service in the thirty-eight-story Singer Building, 149 Broadway, was interrupted for forty minutes yesterday when the power was shut off by union technicians, whose representatives met shortly thereafter with the building's manager asking for a contract.

MEMPHIS, April 20 (AP) -- Dr. George E. Biggs, a member of the Social Security Board, disclosed today that the board had sent to Congress a far-reaching program which would extend the social security system to include all employed persons, regardless of occupation, and include such additional benefits as free medical care and hospitalization for workers and their families.

Many of the "Ballet Backstage" paintings by Gladys Rockmore Davis, from her recent exhibition at the Midtown Gallery, will be shown in the Bonwit Teller store windows beginning on Monday. On Tuesday afternoon Mrs. Davis will sketch at the store some of the star performers of the Ballet Theatre Company, the sketches to go to purchasers of War Bonds.

W. H. Lawrence in his article in THE NEW YORK TIMES April 15, wired from Moscow, gives the formulation of postwar foreign policy of the Soviet Union. In the first place, he points out that the Soviet Union is concerned about ways and means to prevent recurrence of the devastation wrought upon its territory twice during the last thirty years; to halt in the future any march of German hordes eastward.

The public hearing in the case of Jockey Robert Merritt against The Jockey Club, following its refusal to grant him a riding license in 1943 and again this year, ended early this morning when the joint board, consisting of Ashley T. Cole and Herbert Bayard Swope, representing the New York State Racing Commission, and Alfred H. Morris and Joseph Davis acting for The Jockey Club, reserved decision in the case.

FORT DIX, N.J., April 20 -- German prisoners of war working at jobs on this military reservation still believe that they are supermen and that the Nazi army is invincible. Their attitude is expressed by a sign in one of their barracks which translated reads: "Who will win the war? We."

Edgar Bromberger, Commissioner of Investigation, revealed yesterday that he is investigating alleged fee-splitting between "certain doctors" at Queens General Hospital and the operators of private ambulance services. The inquiry, ordered by Mayor La Guardia on March 20, at the request of Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, Commissioner of Hospitals, may be extended to include city hospitals in other boroughs.

The oil conference now going on in Washington "is just a smokescreen for the formation of a gigantic international cartel through which the American oil industry would be put in bondage under British control." This was the charge made at a press conference yesterday by James A. Moffett, one of the nation's leading oil executives for the past quarter of a century and formerly Housing Administrator in the Roosevelt Administration.
PHILADELPHIA, April 20 (AP) -- The National Football League voted against any wartime expansion today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 20 -- Drawing attention to the necessity of adopting measures to safeguard the national economy, President Juan Antonio Rios today effectively warded off an impending attack -- principally from the Radical party to which he belongs -- designed to overthrow the present Cabinet.

Worth Street commission houses selling rayon gray goods are re-checking all orders and cutting off customers to whom any suspicion of black market operation can be attached, it was revealed here yesterday. The action resulted from charges of rampant black market operations made by Benjamin Siegel, attorney, in an address on Wednesday before the Downtown Textile Credit Group, Inc.

ALBANY, April 20(AP) -- Dr. Edward Spencer Cowles, director of the Park Avenue Hospital, won a complete victory today against the Board of Regents of the State of New York when the Court of Appeals, in a 5-to-1 decision, affirmed the order of the Appellate-Division upholding Dr. Cowles on every count.

Asserting that the majority of post-war plans for business are predicated on "rosy visions" of an expanded national income or on some guarantee of full employment, Richard H. Grant, retired vice president in charge of sales for the General Motors Corporation, last night called upon management "to lend a more attentive ear to sales forces" who will have to provide customers to supplant the huge wartime purchases of the Government.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20 (AP) -- The Third United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled today that the Securities and Exchange Commission had authority to define the trading "vicinity" of the New York Curb Exchange as it applied to a particularly security.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- The War Production Board today rejected an application of The Chicago Tribune for paper to start a new daily newspaper in Milwaukee, Wis.

The greatest post-war problem facing American industry is how to reconvert our great organizations to the old way of thinking on which they were built, Dr. Walter S. Landis, vice president of the American Cyanamid Company, told 275 members of the Columbia Engineering Schools Alumni Association last night.

The time is right for those favoring asparagus and artichokes to buy all they want of these two vegetables, for this week's fresh produce market offers a good quantity of both, and at reasonable prices. Largely because of liberal receipts and a limited demand at its former price, asparagus is less expensive than it has been so far this year, the War Food Administration reports.

So a person takes his life in his hands, perhaps, and submits a few thoughts on the Moses-Gristede episode. Such remarks are intended to be of the mildest character. They would consist chiefly in suggesting that Mr. Moses has missed an opportunity.

Although the twelve central banks of the Federal Reserve System helped out their member banks by buying from them approximately $85,000,000 of Government securities in the week ended Wednesday, figures released yesterday showed that excess reserves of the member banks in New York City declined $15,000,000 in the week to $25,000,000, and those of the system as a whole dropped $100,000,000 to $900,000,000.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20 (AP) -- Glucose, one of the common sugars, can be substituted partly for water to save castaways and aviators adrift in rubber boats from dying of thirst. This sugar serves as both food and drink, by saving some of the body's water which otherwise would have to be excreted.

Not much to report yet on the striped bass situation out on Long Island. Some of the boys who might have done a bit of surf casting last week-end just to see whether anything was stirring didn't venture near the water because there was altogether too much water pouring down from the skies.

Thomas Hitchcock Jr. won as a boy the regard, it is not too much to say the affection, of the public. He left St. Paul's School in the hope of getting into the British Air Force. He was an accomplished horseman who had begun his riding lessons at 3. He was a boxer, tennis player, football player.

A broad plan to reduce juvenile delinquency and improve youth conditions in this city was discussed yesterday morning at a meeting called by William M. Kent, sixth deputy police commissioner, head of the Juvenile Aid Bureau and president of the Police Athletic League.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, April 21 -- Solomons-based bombers attacked Rabaul, New Britain, for the sixteenth consecutive day of assaults on that enemy base. The attackers lost three planes.

LONDON, April 20 -- To the Allied powers that have been supplying Marshal Tito with arms and advocating a compromise between his supporters and those of the exiled Yugoslav Government King Peter of Yugoslavia made an indirect appeal today for more weapons for Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch, Marshal Tito's rival, and for non-interference in Yugoslavia's internal affairs.

MOSCOW, April 20 -- Russian storm groups -- among them many that fought in Stalingrad -- are reported to be in action with bayonet and grenade, forcing the enemy from his mountainside positions on the slopes running down to the Sevastopol plain.

Coming up like thunder out of India across the bay, a powerful Allied fleet of aircraft carriers, battleships, cruisers, destroyers and submarines has just struck a hard blow at Japan's inflated sphere of conquest from the west. Sailing boldly through waters which the Japanese Admirals have told their people they control, it hit at the Japanese island base of Sabang on the periphery of the Dutch East Indies and at airfields on Sumatra.

Jan Masaryk, deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister of Czechoslovakia, arriving yesterday at the Marine Terminal at La Guardia Field, expressed the belief that the European war might have been prevented if his country had been supported during the crisis of 1938.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- So strong was the prejudice of four Americans against membership in the German-American Bund that it caused them to be excused from jury duty in the sedition trial when the impanelling started today.

Although the city's 280 local draft boards were authorized yesterday to resume induction of men 26 years old or over, if their occupations cannot reasonably be considered as "war-supporting activities," Col. Arthur V. McDermott, City Selective Service Director, emphasized again that a sufficient number of New Yorkers under 26 will be available to meet induction quotas until July 1.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 20 (AP) -- Executors of the estate of William P. Stymus, once wealthy interior decorator who died April 7 at Port Chester at the age of 83, are instructed in his will, filed for probate today in Surrogates Court, to:

The Treasury continues to lose no time in making withdrawals from Government war-loan accounts in the leading commercial banks of the nation. Yesterday it indicated that it will make further withdrawals on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The rationing of used typewriters and such new typewriters as may be in the hands of dealers will end Saturday, the OPA said today, since military requirements have been met and civilian supplies have been increased by the limited production of new machines. Distribution of new typewriters in hands of manufacturers, however, will still be controlled by WPB.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 20 -- A "jump-takeoff" autogiro, built by G. A. Aircraft, Inc., a subsidiary of the Firestone Aircraft Company, was presented by the manufacturers today to Princeton University's Department of Aeronautical Engineering.

The first new financing for a Canadian province to be done in the New York market in five years will take place today with the offering of a new issue of $5,500,000 Province of New Brunswick, Canada, 2 1/4 per cent debentures, dated April 15, 1944, and due April 15, 1948, by a syndicate headed by Smith, Barney Co.

LONDON, April 20 -- Foreign Minister Numan Menemencioglu of Turkey announced today that his country would stop chrome exports beginning tomorrow. This news came as a complete surprise here. Only yesterday a note was received from the Turkish Government in reply to Allied representations urging curtailment of trade in this ore vital to German steel industry in which not the faintest suggestion was given of any such contemplated action.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20 -- The Dodgers found the proper success formula -- more hitting, errorless play and a pitcher who could go the distance -- and beat the Phillies today, 8-2, to take their first series, two games to one.

Awards in sculpture and architectural rendering were made last night at a dinner at the Architectural League of New York, 115 East Fortieth Street, for works now on public exhibition at its galleries.

ST. LOUIS, April 20 (AP) -- Morton Cooper of the Cardinals, who was injured in an exhibition game last week, said he was ready and asked for the pitching assignment against the Pirates today. That was a mistake on his part.

Twenty-two New York pier operators received yesterday security S pennants and certificates for outstanding efforts in the interest of port security in New York harbor at a ceremony in the Maritime Exchange, 80 Broad Street. A special S award also was made to the New York Board of Fire Underwriters.

LONDON, April 20 -- There are signs that the Red Army is preparing a large-scale offensive, which expert military opinion here believes will be launched just before or simultaneously with the opening of the Anglo-American invasion of western Europe.

The chief portions of the addresses delivered last night by Robert P. Patterson, Undersecretary of War; Major General Lewis B. Hershey, director of Selective Service, and Rear Admiral C.M. Cooke Jr., deputy chief of staff to the Commander in Chief, United States Fleet, follow.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

MOSCOW, April 20 -- The Russian Army newspaper, Red Star, devoted more than a third of a page today to a glowing account of the accomplishments of the United States as the arsenal of democracy, declaring that the main German miscalculations that produced defeat instead of victory were the failure to realize the strength of the Red Army and the inability to see how fast the United States could mobilize its industrial and military strength.
WASHINGTON, .April 20 -- The joint statement on manpower needs in the armed services and industry issued by Secretaries Stimson and Knox and Admiral Land reads as follows:

MARK GAYN is only 35, but he has written an autobiography crammed with more dramatic personal experiences and more close-up views of world history than those of many a public figure who does not begin recording his memoirs until he has reached the conventional threescore and ten. Mr. Gayn is Manchurian by birth, Russian in heredity, cosmopolitan in his lifelong environment, American and democratic in his political faith.

The two-story garage building at 526-34 West 134th Street running through to 553-59 West 133d Street has been resold by Frederick Brown, the operator who acquired it recently. Assessed at $110,000, the property fronts 117 feet on 134th Street and 85 feet on 133d Street, east of Broadway.

L.A. Van Bomel, president of National Dairy Products Corporation, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders here he hoped that conditions at the end of the year would make it possible to declare an extra or increased dividend on the common stock. Earnings before taxes for the first half year will be in line with the 1943 period, he said.

A striking analysis of the many steps which have been taken to make the deadly business of war safer for our armed forces has been made by Julien H. Harvey, managing director of the National Conservation Bureau. Our offensive and defensive weapons both show great advances in safety features over those of previous wars.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- Clarence K. Streit, leader of the movement for a world-wide federal union, declared tonight at a dinner in his honor that American soldiers are about to embark on the invasion of Europe lacking for the first time in the nation's military history the force of a "great idea" to inspire their effort.

Several hundred unskilled laborers at the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's ship repair yard at the foot of Fifty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, failed to report for work yesterday and last night in what appeared to be a demonstration against their non-inclusion in a recent War Labor Board wage award.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 20 (AP) -- A general strike has closed every tin mine in Bolivia in a new repercussion of the Catavi strike disorder in December, 1942, when nineteen persons were killed and thirty wounded.

CENTRAL PACIFIC ARMY HEADQUARTERS, April, 20 -- Army authorities will soon announce a limited schedule of furloughs for soldiers in the Central Pacific on a percentage basis, this correspondent learned today.

KANDY, Ceylon, April 20 -- The month-old battle for Manipur State appeared to have turned in favor of the Allies today following the relief of the once-encircled British Imperial garrison in Kohima and new successes against the Japanese invaders in the hills northeast of Imphal plain.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Casualties of the American Armed forces, on the basis of latest available reports, total 189,309, including 43,808 dead; 70,948 wounded; 41,330 missing and 33,223 prisoners of war, the Office of War Information said today.

ST. LOUIS, April 20 -- Stressing the importance of American history for the training of better citizens and the development of a common bond of culture, educators attending the annual conference of the Mississippi Valley Historical Association urged today that greater emphasis be put on this subject in the colleges and universities of the United States.
KANDY, Ceylon, April 20 (AP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

A pretty quarrel has developed in hearings conducted by the Federal Trade Commission to settle the paternity of the jeep, an invention worth more to the Army than most of the "secret" weapons of which we hear so much. The Commission seems inclined to give credit to the American Bantam Car Company, but two automobile companies and a manufacturer of farm implements are stubborn contenders.

ALBANY, April 20 -- The Court of Appeals in a four-to-three decision today voided the 1941 convictions of Charles H. Mullens, former assistant State Controller, and William Solomon, former Tammany leader of the Seventeenth Assembly District, north, on bribery charges growing out of an investigation into State printing contracts, and ordered new trials for both defendants.

Having exhausted all the houses down by the Square, the legitimate theatre has been stretching out a beckoning hand, and last evening reclaimed the Adelphi, up on Fifty-fourth Street. Unfortunately, the good news of this morning's report probably must stop there.

A comparatively quiet session on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday left prices at the close 3 points higher to 1 point lower than on Wednesday. A slight dip in prices early in the day brought in sufficient price-fixing to hold the market within narrow limits.

Two of the favored teams were eliminated last night from the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup tournament for the national contract bridge team-of-four championship in surprise results as the contestants completed the quarter-final round of their contest at the Hotel Pierre.

LONDON, April 20 -- Forty to fifty German soldiers were wounded or killed yesterday while they were running to man anti-aircraft guns when a Mustang pilot made a one-man bombing and strafing attack on an enemy airfield in northern France, a United States Ninth Air Force announcement said today.

LONDON, April 20 -- Britain and the United States have massed in this island an armada of heavy bombers, medium bombers and fighters such as no country in the world has ever seen. It is being used independently now -- or at least part of it is -- to weaken the German powers of resistance, and later it will be called on to support the ground forces in their final onslaught against Europe.

ALGIERS, April 20 -- To judge by the latest news reaching Algiers, the nervous strain of waiting for the invasion of the Continent is no more severe for anyone concerned than for the resistance forces in France.

LISBON, Portugal, April 20 (AP) -- The Nazis seem to be getting ready to proclaim some kind of charter for Europe, with the double purpose of persuading Europeans that their best chance of escaping post-war social and economic chaos will be under German leadership and convincing the impoverished German masses they will not have to go bolshevik to get social justice.

A citation of the New York Round Table of the National Conference of Christians and Jews was presented last night to former Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Proskauer, president of the American Jewish Committee, as "a valiant fighter in the cause of goodwill" in ceremonies broadcast from station WHN. The presentation was made by District Attorney Frank Hogan.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Department-store sales for the week ended April 15 were 11 per cent below sales in the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following table shows percentage changes from like periods of last year:
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, April 21 (AP) -- A communique:...

" Pretty Little Parlor," a first play by Claiborne Foster, the actress, which opened at the National Theatre last Monday under the auspices of John Moses and Ralph Bellamy, will end its career after tomorrow evening's performance, it was disclosed yesterday. Stella Adler and Sidney Blacker are the featured players in a company which includes Marilyn Erskine, Joan Tetzel, Kip Good, Paul Parks, Edward Begley and Mel Roberts.

Elwyn Carter, baritone, was heard in his first New York recital last night in Town Hall. With Stuart Ross at the piano he presented a program which opened with the excerpts, "O God, Have Mercy" from Mendelssohn's "St. Paul" and "Confutatis Maledictis" from Verdi's "Requiem."

What is believed to be the first weekly radio book program to be sponsored by a publisher will be started next Thursday evening at 9:15 o'clock over Station WQXR. It will be called "Everyman's Reader" and will be conducted by Boris Todrin, a poet, critic and staff writer on PM.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 20 -- After completion of his part in "Thirty Seconds Over Tokyo" Robert Walker will be co-starred with Judy Garland in the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer picture, "The Clock." The film, based on a story by Paul and Pauline Gallico about a soldier's last forty-eight hours in New York before going overseas, will precede Walker's appearance in "Taps For Private Tussie."
LONDON, April 20 (UP) -- A German communique as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

LONDON, April 20 (AP) -- The first decrease in note circulation in England since late Tanuary was reported today by the Bank of England in its condition statement for the week ended yesterday. The drop of 2,791,000 from the preceding week left a total of 1,120,757,000.
i LONDON, April 20 o/P) -- Foreign j liinister IV[enemencioglu announced in the Turkish Assembly today i Turkey's decision to halt all i chrome exports to Germany.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20 -- President Roosevelt, in a message to the opening session of the International Labor Organization, declared today that "the conditions of a lasting peace can be secured only through soundly organized economic institutions fortified by humane labor standards, regular employment and adequate income for all the people."
PEARL HARBOR, April 20 -- While no comment is available here on enemy reports that we have bombed positions in the Marianas there is no reason to discount them.

Fred M. Vinson, the Economic Stabilization Director, has been the most courageous and outspoken opponent in official Washington of the attempt to break through such wage ceilings as exist. If labor, he declares, were successful in its effort to smash the Little Steel formula, it would be a "short-time winner at the economic roulette table"; everyone would be the loser in the price rise and inflationary period sure to follow.

The interesting feature of the compilation of civil engineering construction contracts for this week is the upturn in private buiding projects, which have been slow for more than two years because of war restrictions.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- A nationwide program of encouraging term loans, backed where necessary by a credit pool, is about to be launched by the American Bankers Association as a major contribution toward meeting the needs of business for money in the post-war period.

DETROIT, April 20 (AP) -- The Browns remained atop the American League standings today by hanging a third straight defeat on the Tigers, 8 to 5, for Pitcher Sigmund Jakucki's first major league victory.

A UNITED STATES ARMY AIR FORCE SERVICE COMMAND STATION, Somewhere in Britain, April 20 -- Perhaps it is just as well that British motorists do not have gasoline for pleasure driving, for Britain's narrow winding roads with their hedgerow borders and air of leisurely intimacy in peacetime are no place today for civilian touring.

Extra helpings in England's wartime menu have been responsible in large part for a record low in infant and maternity mortalities, according to Miss Florence Horsbrugh, Parliamentary Secretary to the Ministry of Health.

CINCINNATI, April 20 (AP) -- Making his first big league start, Tomas de la Cruz of Cuba hurled the Reds to a five-hit 2-1 victory over the Cubs today. Cincinnati took the season's initial series by the same margin.

JERSEY CITY, April 20 (AP) -- Toronto's pennant defending Maple Leafs picked up the visitors' end of a 51,206 ticket sale today, then proceeded to spoil the opener for Jersey City by defeating the Little Giants, 8 to 1. Actually, there were approximately 26,000 fans on hand.

OTTAWA, April 20 -- A letter from President Roosevelt stressing Canadian-American friendship to United States Ambassador Ray Atherton was read to the House of Commons today by Speaker J. Allison Glen, who declared that Canada "affirms and endorses these utterances of President Roosevelt articulating as they do the ideals which link our two countries."

LONDON, April 20 -- The Right and Left in British politics united in the House of Commons today to reject any suggestion that the wartime unity of the British Empire and its attendant advantages should be sacrificed after the war to ambitions of other nations.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., April 20 (U.P.) -- Archie S. Woods, 50, philanthropist and vice president and treasurer of the John and Mary R. Markle Foundation of New York, died today of injuries received when a Navy automobile crashed into the rear of a heavy truck fifteen miles north of here.

LONDON, April 20 (AP) -- The Yugoslav Partisans announced tonight that a German counteroffensive in Montenegro, employing tanks and planes, had recaptured Sahovici and that in eastern Bosnia the Germans had advanced to the town of Dreznica.

PEORIA, Ill., April 20 -- A Federal court order for thirty days' extension of purchase time in the American Distilling Company's whisky-distribution plan for stockholders was signed today in Quincy, Ill., by Judge J. Leroy Adair of the United States District Court, under whose direction the trustee, Gilbert B. Geiger, is administering the plan.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The services and the War Manpower Commission have all the legislation needed to meet current manpower problems, the House Military Affairs Committee reported today after a study by a subcommittee.

LONDON, Friday, April 21 (U.P.) -- Russian air and sea forces have sunk or left blazing eighteen large German ships off Sevastopol, smashing at a last-minute "Dunkerque'' evacuation of the scarred Crimean port that is still savagely defended by German rear guards driven into its inner fortifications, Moscow reported last night.

The Shell Union Oil Corporation reported yesterday for the three months ended on March 31 a consolidated net income of $6,808,358 after charges, taxes, reserves and provision of $1,500,000 for postwar contingencies, equal to 51 cents a common share.

Alexander's department store, the Bronx was awarded a judgment of $235,491 against Ohrbach's department store, Siegel Brothers, Inc., and Leeds, Limited, Coats, Inc., yesterday by Richard Lydon, who was appointed last July by the Appellate Division to fix the amount to be awarded, after it had reversed an earlier decision against Alexander's store which had been made by the Supreme Court.
The Japanese operations against Imphal, Kohima and Dimapur in India are still indecisive and the monsoon rains are now not far off.

LONDON, April 20 (U.P.) -- The British Army took over operation of many of London's far-reaching bus routes today after more than 2,000 drivers and conductors, in flat defiance of drastic new anti-strike regulations, ignored a "back-to-work" call by union officials.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The liveliest topic that will arise in the sessions of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, which begin here too morrow, will probably be military editing of the news of the war. What will I be proposed, and what proposals will be adopted, to put this editing on-a higher as well as a more efficient level cannot in detail be foreseen.

The site for the city's proposed World Fashion Center may be revealed at the opening session of the annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, to be held June 12 at the Hotel Pennsylvania, Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the Mayors World Fashion Center Committee, said yesterday.

Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn last night officially launched his borough's appeal for $500,000 as part of the $4,500,000 which the Greater New York Fund is seeking for the support of 403 voluntary hospitals, health and welfare agencies.

The Cuban Commission sent to this country to expedition the shipment of several million yards of textiles tied up by export restrictions will appeal first to the State Department instead of the Foreign Economic Administration, it was disclosed yesterday. Before going to Washington, the commission spent considerable time in New York compiling data from 238 New York exporters on all unshipped orders bought and paid for in the last quarter of 1943.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Warning the nation that it faces a manpower crisis which may imperil the mightiest military undertaking in history, the heads of the armed forces renewed their demand for labor draft legislation today. Such a law, they said, was urgently needed to keep vital war plants staffed with replacements for workers gone to war.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Keen interest was expressed in military and naval circles this afternoon over disclosure of the Allied sea and air attack on the island of Sabang in the Southeast Asia theatre, and naval sources interpreted the blow as a tightening of the pincers on Japan's extended occupied outposts.

Off winging to a 5-0 lead, following homers by Mel Ott and Ernie Lombardi, the Giants seemed well on the way to their third straight conquest of tile Braves at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Subsequently, when the margin became 9 -- 2 in the sixth, none in the crowd of 5,248 gave a second thought to Boston's chances against Cliff Melton.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total holdings of United States Government securities and note circulation for the system as a whole to have increased during the week to new high records.

Prospective contestants and handlers in a Mark Twain Frog Jumping Championship Contest, to be staged on April 29 by the Police Athletic League at Manhattan Center, became acquainted last night, to their mutual amazement.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- Harold L. Ickes, Petroleum Administrator for War, announced today a daily allowable production rate of 4,818,500 barrels of petroleum liquids for oil-producing States during May, a net increase of 93,500 barrels over the rate certified for April.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, April 21 (U.P.) -- Allied Liberators struck against the Japanese held Caroline Islands again Tuesday and Wednesday, blasting Woleai for the fifth time and destroying six Japanese planes, it was announced today.

Three men who know at first hand the resources and the strategy of the armed forces of the United States spoke last night in Times Hall on the theme, "We Still Have the War to Win." They agreed that the unfinished task that lies ahead is still formidable enough to require every ounce of effort and devotion that we as a nation can put into it.

MADISON, Wis., April 20 -- The rescue at sea of Lieut. Comdr. Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota and Republican Presidential possibility, was revealed tonight by the letters of a Wisconsin sailor who was on the rescue craft.

The work of adult group leaders in preventing tensions of race prejudice and intolerance among teen-aged youngsters was described as an important part of wartime group-work activities yesterday at the annual meeting of the Committee of Field District 2, Camp Fire Girls, Inc.
Belatedly, but with all the traditional trimmings, the lid will be lifted off the baseball season, officially in the Bronx and Brooklyn today.

Mrs. Julius Young Talmadge of Athens, Ga., was elected president general of the Daughters of the American Revolution on the second ballot yesterday at the national congress in the Hotel Commodore. The first Southern woman to head the society, she received only one vote more than the 814 required for election.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 20 -- When Allied military authorities enter the Balkans following a German collapse or evacuation a program, for relief for those distressed peoples will be ready for immediate effective implementation, it was made clear here today following a conference of Middle East war correspondents with key personnel of the Allied military liaison mission.
Hope that the United States will preserve the freedom of the individual by adherence to the principles of Thomas Jefferson was expressed last night by James A. Farley, Democratic State Chairman.

ODESSA, April 15 (Delayed) -- Maj. Gen. Alexander S. Rogoff, 43-year-old professional soldier who has been in the army twenty-five years, told foreign correspondents today that 90 per cent of the German soldiers and officers were confident that an Axis victory was possible.
LONDON, April 20 (U.P.) -- Princess Elizabeth will receive for her eighteenth birthday tomorrow a horse from the King and Queen and a diamond brooch from her grandmother, Queen Mary.

It is not only Jews who, this week, observe the first anniversary of the Battle of the Warsaw Ghetto. All faiths and creeds thrill at the heroic story. All the free world stands uncovered in profound respect for those brave men, women and children who, almost barehanded, fought the tanks and the guns of the Nazi beast through thirty-five days of horror and died rather than yield.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, has expressed disapproval of a strike called by James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, to force a radio station to hire additional musicians, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- The printing and publishing division of the War Production Board reported today an agreement with the Canadian Newsprint Administrator to permit experimental production of thirty-pound as well as thirty-two-pound newsprint by Canadian mills in May and June.

CHUNGKING, China, April 20 (U.P.) -- Heavy fighting was in progress in the Yellow River Valley of north-central China today as the Japanese, supported by swarms of planes, threw reinforcements into their two-pronged drive on the Honan Province railroad junction of Chengchow.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- The printing and publishing division of the War Production Board reported today an agreement with the Canadian Newsprint Administrator to permit experimental production of thirty-pound as well as thirty-two-pound newsprint by Canadian mills in May and June.

CHUNGKING, China, April 20 (U.P.) -- Heavy fighting was in progress in the Yellow River Valley of north-central China today as the Japanese, supported by swarms of planes, threw reinforcements into their two-pronged drive on the Honan Province railroad junction of Chengchow.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Roy A. Roberts, managing editor of The Kansas City Star and president of the American society of Newspaper Editors, urged members of that organization today to protect the rights of the press, especially at the peace conferences.

The unanimous decision by the United States Circuit Court in Philadelphia in the case of the United Light and Power Company gives complete backing to the Securities and Exchange Commission's position in the matter of corporate simplification and distribution of assets of holding companies under the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

NAPLES, April 21 -- Flying more than 2,000 sorties yesterday, Mediterranean Allied Air Force bombers continued their assault, principally upon the railroad network in northern Italy. Hits were observed on targets in the Venice Harbor area and Monfalcone shipyards near Trieste.

NEWARK, N.J., April 21 -- Federal Judge Thomas F. Meaney, before whom two corporations and nineteen individuals are being tried on charges of conspiring to avoid registering with the State Department as Nazi propaganda agents, and the jury were force today to view 9,000 feet of sound film glorifying Adolf Hitler and other Nazi bigwigs at the 1934 Nuremberg Congress.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, KANDY, Ceylon, April 21 (AP) -- The Japanese have thrown reinforcements, including tanks, into their invasion of India, but they still are being knocked back in hard fighting around the big Allied bases of Imphal and Kohima, thirty-five miles from the Burma border, Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten's headquarters announced today.

Edward V. Broderick, a lawyer in the Criminal Courts of the city for a quarter of a century, was convicted yesterday of contempt of court and sentenced to a thirty-day workhouse term by Judge John J. Freschi in General Sessions.

Characterizing the present state War Ballot Law as a "monstrosity, a reservoir of ambiguities and a deception of the men and women in the armed services," James A. Democratic State Chairman, called upon Governor Dewey last night to call a special session of the Legislature to amend the law to make it workable.

The Office of Price Administration has become lost in the maze of difficulties attending the fixing of mark-ups for middlemen engaged in distribution and seldom arrives at the main goal, a limit to retail prices definitely known to housewives, according to consensus of opinion developed yesterday at a meeting of the Cooperative Fruit and Vegetable Association's vegetable commodity committee in the Hotel New Yorker.

A FLYING FORTRESS BASE IN ITALY, April 20 (Delayed) -- A new silver Flying Fortress, Screamin' Eagle, returned from an attack on northern Italy communications centers today after its first combat mission with a ten-man crew representing nine nations.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 21 (AP) -- Mrs. Estelle Lawson Page of Chapel Hill, N.C., defeated Miss Kay Byrne of Rye, N.Y., today and won the women's North and South golf championship for the sixth time. That equalled the record of Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare of Philadelphia.

A new election of three student officers at Columbia College, necessitated by the recent discovery of fraud in a previous balloting, has been scheduled for Monday through Wednesday, it was announced yesterday. The voting wlil take place in Hamilton Hall on the campus under the auspices of the elections commission and will be held from 12 to 2 P.M. and from 4 to 6 P.M.

Taking advantage of his adversary is incorrect handling of the defense to the Zukertort-Reti opening, Reuben Fine of Washington, national speed champion, gained another point in the sixth round of the United States chess championship at the Hotel Park Central last night.

The Gottfried Baking Company has sold the large two-story and basement bakery plant at 1037-45 Prospect Avenue, running through to 1032-54 Union Avenue, in the Bronx, to the Lilyan Realty Corporation, a subsidiary of the Irresistible Cosmetic Company, which will occupy the building for manufacturing purposes.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 21 -- The Yugoslav Peoples Army of Liberation led by Marshal Tito is in direct air contact with the U.S.S.R. and receiving a small quantity of military equipment flown in Soviet aircraft.

Character and ability are the major factors that must be considered in the election of public officials, Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley declared last night at the tenth annual dinner of the Staten Island Savings and Loan League at the Meurot Club at St. George.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Additional authority to act upon applications by Group 3 and 4 retail stores for permission to use Group 1 and 2 price ceilings for meat was granted today by the Office of Price Administration.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, April 22 (U.P.) -- Liberator bombers of the South Pacific Air Force struck Satawan Island in the Carolines for the fourth consecutive day Wednesday with a forty-nine-ton raid, while other big four-engined bombers blasted Woleai Island with more than fifty tons of explosives the same day, it was announced today.

WASHINGT0N, April 21 -- Conceding that New Jersey Office of Price Administration officials, on the basis of a technical violation of rationing regulations, had deprived an aged couple of the right to carry on a gasoline service station business for two weeks last winter, Shad Polier, OPA executive in charge of enforcement of gasoline rationing, promised a House committee today that he would thoroughly investigate the case.
Trading was rather limited yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, but the undertone was steady and closing prices were 1 to 5 points net higher than on Thursday.

The charter of Catholic Charities seeks freedom from want for the poor committed to its care, Archbishop Francis J. Spellman declares in a pastoral to be made public today, in which he asks prayers and sacrifices to help provide this freedom for as many as possible who are in need.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- Despite U-boats and the closure of many normal trade routes, offshore imports into the United States totaled 31,000,000 long tons in 1943, a tonnage greater than in peacetime 1938, it was announced today.
PITTSBURGH, April 21 (AP) -- Joe Beggs allowed just eight scattered hits as he pitched the Reds to a 4-2 triumph today in the Pittsburgh home opener.

The nation's vast glut of foodstuffs is overtaxing its storage, facilities to such extent that prices have begun to tumble. Food-trade spokesmen yesterday continued to appeal to the authorities to help move stocks.

The Hercules Powder Company reported yesterday a net income of $1,137,958 for the three months ended March 31 after estimated Federal taxes of $2,962,832 and a provision of $100,000 for contingencies. This income is equal to 76 cents each on 1,316,710 common shares outstanding after the payment of preferred dividends.
CHICAGO, April 21 (AP) -- Montgomery Ward Co. demanded today that the postoffice provide it with the type of postal service it said it had received for more than thirty years.

The Archbishop of York will preach tomorrow at the 11 A.M. service in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Bishop William T. Manning will preside and make an address welcoming the Primate of England to the cathedral and to the Episcopal Diocese of New York.

CHUNGKING, China, April 21 -- Still resentful of the former injustice in charging the American Army the official exchange rate of twenty Chinese dollars to one United States dollar, United States soldiers in China continue to regard every Army expenditure with professional cynicism.

Dr. Sylvan D. Broder, 51 years old, a chemist of 137 Riverside Drive, who is president and treasurer of Vitaplus, Inc., at 110 West Fortieth Street, manufacturer of a tablet that was represented to decrease by 20 to 39 per cent the gasoline consumption of automobiles, was arrested yesterday outside the Criminal Courts Building with Kalman Greenberg, 42, a lawyer, of 262 Central Park West, vice president of the concern.

Setting a goal of $125,000 as its share in the Greater New York Fund's seventh annual campaign, the borough of the Bronx launched its drive yesterday with a luncheon at the Concourse Plaza Hotel. Several hundred campaign workers, chairmen and committee men heard speakers emphasize the importance of the fund's drive for $4,500,000 to support 403 voluntary hospitals, health and welfare agencies.

Except for such special pastimes as embroidering monograms on club linen or sitting in on "charm courses," service women at United Service Organization clubs throughout the country enjoy the same things the boys like, Miss Sylvia M. Dailey, USO club director scheduled to leave soon for Hawaii, said yesterday.

Several prominent men were named yesterday as disappointed participants in a "pool" to purchase $3,132 worth of liquor that never materialized when Carlyle F. Straub, 47 years old, who said he was a publisher and gave the Imperial Hotel as his home, was held in $2,000 bail for the grand jury on the complaint of Jules Glaenzer, vice president of Cartier, Inc., jewelers at 653 Fifth Avenue.

Women must take their home-front war work as seriously as do men fighting on the war fronts, Margaret Bourke-White, photographer and war correspondent, told 350 members of the Borough of Manhattan division of the American Women's Voluntary Services yesterday at the Hotel Plaza.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21 -- A failure to recognize that the economic unity of the world is the plainest lesson of the last twenty-five years will preclude the possibility of a lasting peace, it was stated tonight by Harold B. Butler, Minister from Great Britain to the United States, in delivering the R.A.F. Penrose Jr. Memorial lecture before the American Philosophical Society.

CLEVELAND, April 21 (AP) -- Paced by Pat Seerey's home run with two mates on base, the Indians ran up a total of twelve hits to defeat the Tigers, 7 to 4, today, opening the home season before 13,643 fans in Municipal Stadium.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Roll-back subsidies had an immeasurable effect in helping to "hold the line" against rising prices, Jesse H. Jones, Secretary of Commerce, told the House Banking and Currency Committee today. He urged renewal of current price control and wage stabilization legislation due to expire June 30.

Definite post-war planning for the most effective utilization of wartime technological advances in the chemical and dyestuff industry must be evolved now to avoid a post-war "orgy of overproduction and another needlessly costly period of readjustment," Henry F. Hermann of the General Dyestuff Corporation warned last night.
Major Sherman C. Amsden, after nineteen months in the southwest Pacific with the Fifth Air Force, has returned to his post of managing director of Telephone Answering Service.
LONDON, April 21 -- Princess Elizabeth was 18 today and moved a long step toward the British throne, which she almost certainly will occupy some day.

LONDON, Saturday, April 22 -- The Royal Air Force carried out the heaviest air assault of history Thursday night when more than 1,000 heavy bombers blasted four vital rail centers in Europe with a record load of 5,040 tons of bombs.

An investor has purchased from Leslie L. Le Veque of Columbus, Ohio, the five-story store and apartment building on a lot 20 by 100 feet at 362 West Fifty-seventh Street, adjoining the Parc Vendome apartments. The Charles F. Noyes Company was the broker in the sale of the property, which is assessed at $60,000 and was remodeled into small suites.

There is one certain thing about the present stage of the war. It is not necessary for a German spokesman to warn a German audience, as Under-Secretary Patterson warned an American audience the other night, against a "smugly optimistic assumption of assured victory."

CHICAGO, April 21 -- The National War Labor Board today telegraphed a request to the Chicago Federation of Musicians, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, to call off its week-old strike against radio station WJJD in observance of labor's wartime no-strike pledge.

OUT in Pittsburgh a steel worker was talking about the chances for labor and management getting together in the post-war world without dragging in the Government at every turn to settle their problems. The steel worker seemed particularly fascinated by the figure of Eric Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, who had been making speeches on that very subject.

There can be few more difficult tasks in the world than trying to visualize California in the role of Cinderella. When the Republican management selected Governor Warren for keynoter at the national convention somebody said it was about time California had some recognition.

NEWARK, N. J., April 21 -- Sentences of a year and a day and fines of $10,000 each were imposed by Federal Judge Thomas F. Meaney today on Emanuel Kremer of 120 Park View Terrace, this city, and Harry Sorowitz of 720 West End Avenue, New York, who had pleaded guilty recently to black-market operations in liquor.

This has been said before but it is important enough to bear repetition. It's about the danger of forest fires. Conservation Commissioner John White has just issued a general appeal to prevent, whenever possible, the burning of brush, hedgerows and grassland, a practice that is always a sure harbinger of spring.

The 100th anniversary of the founding of the Unitarian Church of the Saviour, Pierrepont Street and Monroe Place, Brooklyn, will be celebrated at 11 A.M. and 8 P.M. tomorrow and at 4:30 P.M., Monday. The minister, the Rev. Dr. John Howland Lathrop, will preach tomorrow morning.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Milk prices to the producers in the twelve Northeastern States, which supply most of the residents in this densely populated region, cannot be increased at this time, Chester Bowles, Federal Price Administrator, today told spokesmen for dairymen in the area.

" Enlightened self-interest" is the key thought to hold in mind when analyzing an advertising policy under present conditions, Charles G. Mortimer Jr., vice president of General Foods Sales Company, said yesterday before a meeting of the War Advertising Council at the Hotel Biltmore.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21 -- Exclusion of the tripartite government-industry-workers delegation of Argentine from the conference of the International Labor Organization was proposed today by Vicente Lombardo Toledano of Mexico, president of the Latin-American Federation of Labor.

CHICAGO, April 21 -- Professional buying of July wheat developed today on the Board of Trade, and although sentiment was generally bearish there was no material pressure and the active deliveries finished 1/8 cent a bushel higher to 3/8-cent lower than yesterday, the former on July.

CHUNGKING, China, April 21 (U.P.) -- The Japanese, again resorting to gas warfare, are closing in from two sides on Chengchow. The gravest threat was from an enemy column that had driven beyond Nanfung, nine miles away, and begun to pour shells into the town.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif, April 21 -- Warner Brothers plan to star Joan Crawford in a film remake of the Somerset Maugham story "Of Human Bondage." The picture, which will be directed by Edmund Goulding and produced by Henry Blanke, will take the place of the postponed "Never Good-bye" in which Miss Crawford was to have been starred under Goulding's direction.

RICHMOND, Va., April 21 -- Three among the 525 patents listed as issued in this week's Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office have wartime applications and another deals with a light-polarizing plastic.

LONDON, April 21 -- The first impression made this country by the announcement of the proposed international monetary fund was one of some anxiety lest the Government had committed the nation to something it might live to regret.

MOSCOW, April 21 -- German attacks on Marshall Zhukoff's Carpathian salient are now in their fourth day. If they run true to type and the Russians continue to hold on stubbornly to their ground, the crisis will probably be reached within the next forty-eight hours.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Principles on which a program for world currency stabilization can be based have been agreed on by most of the experts of some thirty Allied and associated nations, it was announced today by Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 21 -- Chile will soon supply demands for copper from Latin-American countries that so far have not been satisfied because of strict restrictions imposed by the "copper agreement" with the United States if plans being considered by the Ministry of Economy and Commerce are successful.

LONDON, April 21 (AP) -- Counter-attacking Yugoslav Partisans have checked a German offensive in two sectors of Montenegro, reoccupying a number of places, including the town of Mojkovac, headquarters of Marshal Tito announced today.

CLEVELAND, April 21 -- The M A. Hanna Company, holder of stocks in shipping and mining companies, announced today that it will ask stockholders to approve a program under which the present issue of $5 preferred stock, of which $12,853,100 stated value is outstanding, would be retired and a new $10,000,000 preferred issue created with annual dividends of $4.25 a share.

LONDON, April 21 -- Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton Jr., one of the most spectacular of American generals and center of a great public controversy last year, has been assigned to the European Theatre of Operations and a command which was not specified in tonight's announcement by the Supreme Headquarters of the Allied Expeditionary Force.

In addition to involving a roll-back in raw fur prices that may constitute a serious threat to invested capital in the fur industry, the decision of the Office of Price Administration to push its own proposals for the price control of furs may tend to spur black market operations in this field, according to comment here yesterday.

ALGIERS, April 21 -- Making his first comments on American foreign policy since Secretary of State Cordell Hull's speech April 9, Gen. Charle de Gaulle at a press conference today spoke of that policy in friendly terms accompanied by a firm reassertion of France's sovereign rights and of the intention of his Committee of National Liberation to administer France after her liberation.

Prompt Congressional action in dealing with the American service men's post-war problems, both economic and social, was urged here yesterday by Warren H. Atherton, commander of the American Legion, who charged that the delay caused by Representative John E. Rankin in approving such legislation would reflect itself in the morale and well being of the armed forces.

Paramount's "If I Had A Million" and "Animal Crackers," both of which have been absent from local screens for several years, will start an exclusive revival engagement today at the Little Carnegie. "If I Had a Million," which was one of the first of the multi-starred productions including in its cast Gary Cooper, Charles Laughton, and W.C. Fields, had its premiere at the Rivoli in December, 1932.

AT SEA IN THE PACIFIC with a United States Carrier Task Force, April 12 (Delayed) (AP) -- In one of the first night torpedo attacks launched by the United States Navy a single bomber squadron sank eight Japanese ships and damaged five others with direct hits.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, April 22 (AP) -2A oo.mniqd:

MOSCOW, April 21 -- Ambassador W. Averell Harriman reported to the press today that he had recently visited the Soviet Union's northern ports of Archangel and Murmansk and had been highly impressed by the speed and efficiency with which the Russians were handling United States lend-lease supplies, arms and food for the Red Army and the civilian population.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Integration of activities of the War Refugee Board, a Federal agency, and the Intergovernmental Committee on Refugees, composed of representatives of thirty-seven Governments, was announced today by John W. Pehle, Executive Director of the WRB, and Sir Herbert Emerson, director of the intergovernmental organization.

LONDON, April 21 -- The dramatic action of the Turkish Government in cutting off its exports of chrome to Germany means that at 7 o'clock tonight, when the decision became effective, the Reich suffered an immediate drop of 30 per cent in its supply of the metal.

The frontier between Canada and the United States is as nearly invisible as any boundary yet established between nations. In some respects it is as imaginary as the Equator. Canadians say they know the United States better than Americans know Canada because they tune in on American broadcasts, see American movies, read American magazines, get so much of their news through American agencies and so much of their opinion from American syndicated columnists.

CHUNGKING, China, April 21 (AP) -- The Japanese, using a force of 50,000 to 60,000 men, including crack reinforcements drawn from the Manchurian garrison, are swiftly encircling the north Honan railway junction of Chengchow, Chinese advices said tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Edward James Smythe was sent to jail today after Federal Justice Edward C. Eicher described as "willful" his failure to appear Monday at the opening of the trial of thirty defendants on charges of sedition. Mr. Smythe brings to ten the number of defendants who are held in prison.
LONDON, Saturday, April 22 (AP) -- Union representatives early today told London transport officials that 2,200 striking bus drivers and conductors had voted to return to their jobs this morning.
LONDON, April 21 -- The Berlin radio said today that the American and British navies were massing "the greatest concentration since Dunkerque" in British home waters for the western invasion.

Today's events: Program of works by Harry Martch, presented by League of Composers, Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, 5 P. M.: Lonny Epstein, piano; Robert Rudie, violin, and Gerald Warburg, 'cello, in Victory concert, New York Public Library, 5:30; concert of Viennese music, Town Hall, 8:30; Erica Morini, violin, Washington Irving High School, 8:30; Alexander Kipnis, bass, McMillin Theatre, Columbia University, 8:30; "Lucia di Lammermoor."

WASHINGTON, April 21 (U.P.) -- Abe J. Greene, president of the National Boxing Association, today urged quick matches to settle title disputes in the lightweight and featherweight divisions. His plea was a preamble to the N.B.A.'s quarterly ratings of boxers.

The new 30 per cent entertainment tax that went into effect three weeks ago has already thrown 5,000 performers out of work and it is expected that this figure will mount to 15,000 by May 1, Matt Shelvey, national administrative director of the American Guild of Variety Artists, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Criticizing President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull for what he termed this country's lack of a foreign policy, Senator Harlan J. Bushfield, Republican, of South Dakota, enumerated to the Senate today what he said were "necessary and fundamental" requirements for peace.

How does it feel to be a French patriot in France on this April day? What must be his thoughts, his longings, his expectations as he sees the invasion storm-cloud looming in the west? The world can make a close guess. The world is not ignorant of what goes on inside France.

Through the application of prefabrication methods Brazil is beginning to utilize her vast forest resources more effectively for the war effort and in planning for post-war construction needs, Alvin Johnson, director of the New School for Social Research, reported yesterday on the basis of studies made by Paul Lester Wiener, architect and designer.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 21 -- The Argentine Government issued a decree this morning forbidding all popular manifestations that had been planned for May Day. This apparently was done to spare the Government the embarrassment that would undoubtedly be created by two simultaneous mass meetings, one organized by the Nationalists under the name of the "March of Sovereignty" and another by the labor unions.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, April 21 -- Farm production objectives announced by the Government for the next production year show that New Zealand hopes to step up considerably her output on the food front to help the Pacific offensive and maintain British supplies.
CHICAGO, April 21 (AP) -- The Cardinals swept to their third straight victory today when they beat the Cubs, 4 to 0, spoiling Chicago's home opener before a meager crowd of 4,783.

Despite the announcement that modification of the lend-lease agreement which would permit Britain to re-export lend-lease materials will not become effective until the new arrangements have been ratified by that country and the United States, exporters charged yesterday that Britain is processing lend-leased carbon black into news ink and exporting the product to India, while controls prevent American exports to that market.
LONDON, April 21 (AP) -- The German communique:

ABOARD AN ALLIED AIRCRAFT CARRIER OFF SABANG, Sumatra, April 19 (Delayed) -- Allied carrier-based planes -- Hellcats, Dauntless dive-bombers, Avengers, Corsairs and Barracudas -- pinned down the Japanese air force and destroyed military installations at Sabang to their hearts' content in a furious fifteen-minute attack this morning.
Dr. and Mrs. Reginald Burbank of 6 East Seventy-eighth Street have gone to the Claridge, Atlantic City.

Ben Ames Williams' forthcoming novel, "Leave Her to Heaven," which he describes as a study of possessive jealousy, will be the June selection of the Literary Guild. Mr. Williams' "Strange Woman," which was published in 1941, is still selling well and, including its Book League and Dollar Book Club editions, has passed the half-million mark.

ON THE FIFTH ARMY BEACHHEAD, South of Rome, April 21 (U.P.) -- Four German "human torpedoes," released from enemy E-boats southwest of Rome, were washed ashore on the Anzio beachhead today after the charges they were piloting toward objectives in the harbor ran out of fuel.

PERHAPS that heading is incorrect. Immortals never die. But in another sense it is justifiable, because Tommy Hitchcock was an athletic immortal if there ever was one. He was one of the never-to-be-forgotten heroes of sport's Golden Age, a full partner with Babe Ruth, Jack Dempsey, Bobby Jones and Bill Tilden in the most glamorous era ever known to sport.

Pointing to governmental expenditures in 1944, which are expected to reach $99,000,000,000, Theodore R. Gamble of the Treasury Department informed a group of New York management and advertising executives yesterday that the Treasury was counting on their assistance to accomplish the task of selling over 70,000,000 individual bonds in the forthcoming Fifth War Loan Drive, for which the goal is $16,000,000,000.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- The House Military Committee stuck to its guns today in opposition to labor draft legislation in the face of a renewed drive by the Army, the Navy and the Maritime Commission.

After a fourth and final ballot required to select the last of eight vice presidents in its triennial election, the Daughters of the American Revolution closed its fifty-third congress yesterday at the Hotel Commodore. The session ended with installation ceremonies for Mrs. Julius Y. Talmadge of Athens, Ga., newly elected president general.

Larger offerings of bonds and a smaller amount of stock featured new financing here this week. Three issues of bonds, one an industrial loan, another for a public utility corporation and the other a Canadian flotation, aggregating $27,000,000, were offered for public subscription, compared with four small bond issues totaling $6,500,000 last week.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21 (U.P.) -- The National Football League today voted against transfer of headquarters to the east and, by the margin, of a single vote, defeated a resolution to locate the main office in New York for alternate five-year periods.

The National Office of Price Administration has purchased digests and analyses of its own regulations from a concern that makes a specialty of simplifying administrative regulations for the aid of business men.

WINDSOR, Ont., April 21 (Canadian Press ) -- Government conciliation officers, acting under instructions from the National War-time Labor Relations Board, conferred today on an approach to problems of settling a dispute at the Ford Motor Company of Canada plant here which has left more than 14,000 employes idle since yesterday.

It had rained through most of the morning. The thermometer in the sheltered nook of the abbreviated balcony outside the office window showed 47 degrees. It was raw and damp. Besides, there was no one clamoring at the gates for admittance.

The five-story loft building at 317 Halsey Street, northwest corner of Court Street, Newark, N.J., has been purchased by the Cedar Lane Corporation, Julius Vinik, president, from the Prudential Insurance Company of America. David Cronheim acted as broker.

Maintenance of a high level of employment, somewhere between 53,000,000 and 57,000,000 individuals, will be essential in the post-war period to the standard of living heretofore enjoyed, Beardsley Ruml, chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank, declared yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 21 -- Interest among the Middle East's Arabic-speaking students to continue their studies in the United States as soon as travel conditions permit has been heightened as the result of recent articles in the press indicating the American Government's desire to provide full scholarships and to make available every facility to encourage the best students.

The International Labor Organization's conference, which has been in session at Philadelphia, is proof that some lively wreckage has survived from the League of Nations. Technically the ILO was affiliated with the League rather than a part of it. All League members are members of the ILO, but states not members of the League, such as the United States and Brazil, have been admitted to the ILO lists.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Through an inquiry by Senator White of Maine as minority leader, the Senate took note today of rumors that Senator Homer T. Bone of Washington, appointed three weeks ago to the post of Judge of the Court of Appeals of the Ninth Circuit, proposes to hold his seat until the end of the session, despite confirmation of his nomination.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Administration's troubles with Montgomery Ward Co. appeared to be on the way toward "solution" today through a plan to have Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce and chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, take over the company for the Government. Such action would be unprecedented.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 21 -- The United States is "approaching the peak of its belligerent power" and our forces in the Pacific are "increasingly able to take our bases with us in our westward drive" to the Asian mainland for a final assault on Japan, Vice Admiral David W. Bagley told the Commonwealth Club today.

Non-rationed shoes take to city streets in high style and adaptability and well-shod feet will step blithely through summer in shoes of black and bright hues. Plastic soles are the answer, and the shortage of leather has been overcome by the introduction of cotton drill and synthetic fabrics that take its place.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- Details of new withholding levies against wages and salaries, which may become effective Jan. 1 if Congress approves the tax simplication bill now being shaped by the Ways and Means Committee, Were disclosed tonight by a dependable tax source.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 21 -- Marcel Blum and his wife, respectively brother and sister-in-law of former Premier Leon Blum, have been sentenced to twenty years' imprisonment for the possession of forged identity papers, it was learned today.

Set in a patriotic decor, the annual Red, White and Blue Dinner Dance for the benefit of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York was given last night at the Ritz-Carlton. The entire ballroom suite of the hotel was taken over for the entertainment, which in recent years has become one of the outstanding fetes of the spring season.

Under cover of a leaden sky that in the late afternoon finally broke down and wept outright, Melvin Ott's astonishing Giants marched stealthily into Brooklyn yesterday to continue their extraordinary early season adventures.

ANZIO BEACHHEAD IN ITALY, April 21 -- The toughest little radio station in the world -- JJRP -- goes on the air Sunday with its first program from Anzio beachhead to the folks back home, 4,400 miles away.

NAPLES, Italy, April 21 -- On the day the fascist regime had set aside as the anniversary of the founding of Rome, Marshal Pietro Badoglio this evening announced the formation of the new Italian Cabinet. It consists of seventeen men, including the marshal as Premier and Foreign Minister and at least twelve who could never have held similar posts under Benito Mussolini.

ST. LOUIS, April 21 (AP) -- The surprising Browns became the only undefeated team in the American League today by winning their fourth game, 5 to 3, from the previously unbeaten White Sox. Mike Kreevich lead the St. Louis attack with two home runs, twice as many in one day as he had hit in the past three seasons.

LONDON, April 21 -- Allied patience with Rumania is wearing thin. Britain, the United States and Russia have agreed among themselves on what is regarded here as reasonable and even generous terms and they are now awaiting some sign of rejection or acceptance by Rumania, it was disclosed today.
