WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Republican membership of the Senate began today a long-range study of legislative possibilities. Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, chairman of the Republican Steering Committee, submitted a list of topics with the request that each member also prepare a list and participate with the Steering Committee in discussions looking to the development of an "affirmative" program to be followed by the Republican members through 1944 and 1945.

NAPLES, April 21 (U.P.) -- In ground fighting in Cassino the Germans increased their activity and hurled heavy barrages of artillery and mortar fire against Allied positions, while the Luftwaffe raided the Anzio beachhead with its heaviest assault to date, striking at harbor areas and anti-aircraft installations four times in four and one-half hours.

PEARL HARBOR, April 21 (AP) -- Japanese positions from Wake Island, 620 statute miles north of the American base of Kwajalein, to Ponape in the Carolines, 625 miles southwest of Kwajalein, were hammered by American war planes Wednesday in the sustained central Pacific aerial compaign.

Anley Loran, New York pianist, and Corp. Dimitry Markevitch, Swiss-born 'cellist, were the young musicians accorded a debut appearance with the New York Little Symphony, under Joseph Barone, at its concert last night in Carnegie Chamber Music Hall. Miss Loran performed the Shostakovich piano concerto and Corporal Markevitch, who was granted special leave from his post in Camp Lee, Va., for this event, was heard in the Boccherini concerto in. B flat major.

Yesterday Princess Elizabeth, heiress presumptive to the British throne, was 18. She becomes automatically by the Act of Regency a member of the Council of Regency, and she begins to have a household staff of her own, a controller, a secretary and a lady-in-waiting.

LONDON, April 21 -- Four great assaults, two of them by the United States Eighth Air Force and two by the Royal Air Force Bomber Command, have destroyed more than 100 war factories in Frankfort on the Main and have left 1,100 of the city's 2,200 acres destroyed or severely damaged, according to an Air Ministry statement tonight.

OTTAWA, April 21 -- Financial arrangements between Canada and the United States under the Hyde Park declaration of 1941, made to safeguard Canada's exchange position, have been abrogated and a series of measures adopted to reduce Canada's balances of gold and United States dollars to within an agreed range.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 21 -The Cedar Farm's Spare Man, a cast-off from the Vanderbilt Stable, won his second straight at Pimlico today by drawing out in the stretch to score by two and one-half lengths. The son of Kantar and The Spare turned in his smashing effort in the Mainmast Purse, best offering on a program witnessed by some 12,000 fans.

Arrangements have been completed whereby "Hickory Stick," the Marjorie Ewing and Marie Louise Elkins production, will make its Broadway. debut at the Mansfield Theatre on May 8, it was learned yesterday. "Public Relations,'' present tenant of that house, either will be moved to another theatre or closed, depending, says Robert Blake, sponsor of the show, on how good business is within the next two weeks.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -Following is the text of the joint statement by the monetary experts meeting here to discuss the establishment of a proposed International Stabilization Fund:
Mayor La Guardia served notice on the world yesterday that the United States would not allow any territorial gains in the Western Hemisphere by other nations.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 21 (AP) -- Viscount Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States, asserted today that the Allied powers must "revolutionize" their attitudes in post-war approaches to world "economic disorders."

For reasons of health, John L. Clark, president of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, is resigning. His successor will be elected at the next meeting of the governors of the association, to be held in Cincinnati on May 22 and 23.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- The Maritime Commission announced today that a renegotiation agreement with the Oregon Shipbuilding Corporation, scaling $6,322,954 in excess profits from the Portland shipyard's first five contracts, has been adopted as a "basic formula" for renegotiation with all yards in the original Liberty ship construction program.

ST. LOUIS, April 21 -- Recommendations for the improvement of American history teaching in the schools and colleges of this country to create greater interest in it were presented today at the annual conference of the Mississippi Valley Historical Association, meeting here with the National and Missouri Councils for the Social Studies.

In the second dullest session of the year stocks on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday held steady and closed with mixed price changes. What movement there was was upward, for 333 of the 801 issues traded advanced, 210 declined and 258 held even.

The first two sessions of "Conservation Please," a forum at which homemakers' questions concerning the rehabilitation of clothing and furniture are posed to a group of experts, were held in a classroom at the Greater New York headquarters of the American Women's Voluntary Services, 11 East Fifty-eighth Street, yesterday morning and evening.

CHICAGO, April 22 -- Despite conferences at Washington and various attempts to coax farmers to release farm held stocks of corn, the corn syrup and candy situation is becoming more acute, trade sources reported here today.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -The fact that women quite generally are not desired as roomers, for reasons that are fairly uniform, is stated in a report today by the Women's Bureau on the housing of women war workers.
MINEOLA, L. I., April 21 -- Robert Moses touched off a controversy of global proportions today, following closely his debate with Mrs. Charles Gristede over cleanliness in Central Park, New York.

LONDON, Saturday, April 22 (U.P.) -- Troops of Marshal Gregory K. Zhukoff's First Ukrainian Army killed more than 1,500 Germans and knocked out sixty-eight tanks yesterday in turning back powerful counter-attacks by reinforced enemy units in the Stanislav area of southeastern Poland, where the Russians were reported massing large forces for a new westward thrust.

A community center, organized by the Forty-second Precinct Coordinating Council, one of eighty-one groups organized in police precincts throughout the city to combat juvenile delinquecy, was opened last night in Public School 51 at 158th Street and Trinity Avenue, the Bronx.
LONDON, April 21 -- The turnover on today's stock markets was again on a small scale, most sections being quiet pending next Tuesday's statement on the Government budget.

Given clear skies and pleasant weather today, the Jamaica track quite likely will record the first $3,000,000 betting handle in the history of horse racing. With the Wood Memorial as the lure, a crowd of 50,000 is expected to cram its way into the Metropolitan Jockey Club course, and this gathering may crack all records for mutuel play the world over.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- The House Agriculture Committee voted today to report favorably legislation providing for a reduction from 5 to 4 per cent in the interest rate on Federal Farm Mortgage Loans, commonly known as Land Bank Commissioner's Loans.

Miss Irene Lewisohn, founder and co-director of the Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theatre, who also was a founder and president of the Museum of Costume Art, left bequests of $540,000 to thirteen institutions and fifty-four individuals, and her residuary estate of undetermined value to her trustees for educational, charitable and benevolent purposes.

In commenting editorially On April 14 on the recent address of James F. Byrnes before the Academy of Political Science you criticized the operations of the Commodity Credit Corporation, under the apparent impression that its loans are paid for out of taxes or increase the budget deficit.

ODESSA, April 16 (Delayed) -- A Russian Orthodox priest wrote this epitaph today for the attempted Rumanian administration of Premier Ion Antonescu's dream empire in the rich region between the Dniester and the Bug Rivers:

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Senator Clyde M. Reed of Kansas, Republican, introduced a resolution today providing for "a full and complete study and investigation" of unauthorized disclosures of immigration obtained through censorship channels.

Trade Here Active in Week Retail trade here this week recovered from the post-Easter letdown noted last week. Department store sales were estimated as running about 3 per cent ahead of the like week last year. Consumer demand for handbags and jewelry continued active, despite higher excise taxes, although cosmetic volume still shows the effects of the recent "beat-the-tax" buying.
LONDON, April 21 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Of plans for a better world there seems to be no end. Our professors, our bureaucrats, our politicians and the Quiz Kids have given their plans; but business, labor and the consuming public have not spoken. In general, these plans look for perpetual peace, full employment, stabilization of money and a higher standard of living all over the world.
Two teams won their way to the finals in the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup tournament for the national contract bridge team-of-four championship at the Hotel Pierre last night.

LONDON, April 21 -- Prime Minister Churchill, who declared in 1942 that he had not become the King's first Minister to preside over the liquidation of the British Empire, asserted today that even in the drafting of the Atlantic Charter he had sought to safeguard the Empire's commercial system.

The export demand for textiles after the war will total approximately 3,000,000,000 yards annually, but whether or not this huge amount is shipped will depend upon finding a way to finance the export of all goods sold through other than regular commercial channels, according to New York exporters yesterday.

ABOARD AN AMERICAN CARRIER OFF SABANG, Sumatra, April 19 (Delayed) (AP) -- Under the smoking guns of Japanese coastal batteries, a British submarine made one of the most dramatic rescues of the war today, picking up an American pilot, Lieut. (j.g.) Dale Christian (Klondike) Klahn, shot down in the task blow against Sabang and Lho Nga.

The steel industry has begun to feel the effect of the Selective Service draft to a marked degree, and any further depletion of its manpower is likely to be reflected by a corresponding fall in production, according to a study of employment conditions of key companies.

The War Production Drive has given 1,788 awards for suggestions emanating from within American industry which have resulted in speeding production of war equipment, T.K. Quinn, director-general, announced yesterday. He explained that the awards comprise three types -- honorable mention, certificate and citation -- and added that 1,377 honorable mentions, 335 certificates and sixteen citations have been issued to groups throughout the nation.

ST. LOUIS, April 22 -- Ending a three-day conference, American history teachers representing every part of the country reached the conclusion that schools and colleges should put greater emphasis on teaching methods in an effort to make American history more interesting and meaningful to the student.

In the Citizens Union's annual appraisal of the Legislature, George H. Hallett Jr., secretary, in a review made public yesterday credited the 1944 session with having passed a number of helpful bills and comparatively few bad measures.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 22 -- Hammering two Colgate pitchers for a dozen hits, Princeton opened its baseball season today with a 10-to-1 victory. Jack Friel, who gave nine runs in the first four innings, was charged with the defeat. Dick Armstrong was the winning hurler.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 22 -- Temporarily blinded by oil and "more than half dead," forty-eight of the survivors of the troop trans port Cape San Juan, were picked up from stormy seas by civilian fliers of Pan American Airways, operating a twin-motored Martin Marauder for the Naval Air Transport Service, it was related here today.

The British Ministry of War Transport has entered negotiations with private foreign freight forwarders for the purpose of returning forwarding activities to commercial channels and has proferred a tentative plan to accomplish this objective by May 1, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- Judge Irvine L. Lenroot, 75 years old, former Wisconsin Republican Senator, resigned from the Federal bench today after thirty-five years in the capital.

The national offices of the American Guild of Variety Artists were deluged again yesterday with hundreds of additional telegrams, from all over the country, painting a tragic picture of the plight of thousands of performers who have been thrown out of work by the 30 per cent cabaret tax and demanding immediate Congressional action to reduce the levy.

Millions of tons of allied shipping casualties are being reclaimed as a result of the vast ship salvage program being carried on by the United States and British navies, by far the most pretentious long-range operation of its kind ever undertaken, according to B.B. Williams, chairman of the board of the Cooper-Bessemer Corporation and a leader in the Diesel engine-building industry.

An annual sales volume well in excess of $200,000,000 will be maintained by the soft surface floor coverings industry for a minimum of two years following complete re-conversion to production of normal civilian lines, a trade spokesman predicted yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, April 22 (AP) -- The semi-annual report of the United Steel Workers of America, CIO, listed today membership of 936,500 and a net worth of $3,313,077.20, including $2,174,313.37 cash.

More than thirty cities in various parts of the country have already applied for participation in the school course in retail advertising which has been developed by the sales promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, it was announced yesterday.

ERIC JOHNSTON describes his book as "the ease for a people's capitalism." Since the author has been mentioned as a possible Republican candidate for Vice President and his volume issues in an election year it might not strain the probabilities to interpret it as the ease for a people's Eric Johnston.

The Regional Office of Price Administration announced yesterday that it had filed actions for triple damages of $825,000 against two large wholesale lumber dealers in the city accused of charging over-ceiling prices. At the same time the regional office disclosed that it had collected $48,096 from three wholesalers of interlining flannels for ceiling violations.

The Office of Price Administration and the Emergency Price Control Act were criticized by Special Master Peter B. Olney in a report filed yesterday in the United States District Court, in which he recommended judgment in favor of two candy manufacturers against which the OPA had filed suits to compel compliance with record-keeping provisions of its regulations.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Secretary Henry L. Stimson made a solemn plea for national unity tonight before the closing session of the annual meeting of the American Society of Newspaper Editors. He said that all symptoms of disunity on the home front must disappear as a prerequisite for the invasion of Europe.

There is much talk nowadays of "the traditional isolationism" of the United States. But alongside the isolation current of public opinion in the country there has long been a strong counter-current favoring participation in a world union for establishing and maintaining peace.

The agenda of the third wartime gathering of the nation's newspaper publishers and editors, which will be held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel here this week at sessions of the American Newspaper Publishers Association and The Associated Press, emphasizes looked-for developments in the industry after the war.

Representatives of small and large business in Brooklyn have formed an advisory committee to aid the Smaller War Plants Corporation solve problems of subcontracting, reconversion and priorities in the borough, it was announced yesterday by F.J. Herbert, district manager for the Government organization.

The annual spring festival and bazaar of the parish of St. James Episcopal Church will be held on Friday afternoon in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Proceeds will aid the work of Episcopal clergymen, doctors, nurses and teachers serving in missionary fields. Miss Florence Courtenay Martin heads a large committee in charge of the plans for the event.

BOSTON, April 22 (AP) -- With the news of William Cardinal O'Connell's death today, condolences poured in from many quarters. Among the first received were from the Right Rev. Henry K. Sherrill, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Massachusetts, and Gov. Leverett Saltonstall of Massachusetts. Bishop Sherrill said:
LONDON, Sunday, April 23 (UP) -- The Saturday midnight supplementary communique broadcast from Moscow:

WASHINGTON, April 22 (U.P.) -- The War Shipping Administration and the Navy revealed tonight that an American troop transport, with 1,429 soldiers, seamen and naval gunners aboard, was sunk by enemy action in shark-infested Pacific waters late last fall with a loss of seventy lives.

YOU ask in last Sunday's issue: "By 'bias' did Mr. Seldes mean all personal opinion, however enlightened, and would he entirely eliminate the latter from news interpretation, because an occasional analyst abuses his position?"

The Creole Petroleum Corporation, controlled by the Standard Oil Company (N.J.), reported yesterday for 1943 a consolidated net income of $11,636,700 after charges, taxes and reserves and after writing off $8,653,644 as the cost of oil concessions surrendered.

GOOD news for the post-war traveler pressed for time comes with the announcement of a new cross-country record (seven hours less two minutes) made last week by the airliner Constellation. Designed for "civilian super-luxury but drafted into wartime duty," the big ship will; for the duration, transport men and war materials, but with the coming of peace it and others like it are scheduled to go into civilian service.

ONCE upon a time, so the legend goes, the streets of Golden City were paved with silver -- or maybe it was gold. Mr. Weatherbee, who owns most of Golden City and a goodly share of Colorado, says it was gold, and he should know, for he is a real old-timer.

LONDON, April 22 -- Britain's wartime sports boom reached a new attendance peak today when 133,000 jammed Glasgow's Hampden Park, where England beat Scotland by 3 -- 2 in an international soccer match, while an aggregate of 105,000 at two English League North games saw Blackpool and Aston Villa qualify for the final round.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The suggestion that post war armament for the enforcement of world peace may be organized on a regional basis is discussed by The Army and Navy Journal this week.

LONDON, April 22 (U.P.) -- Netherlands fishermen have been forbidden to sail farther than one mile from the Netherlands coast and in some zones have been prohibited from entering the open sea at all as the result of German efforts to protect the secrets of their minefields and anti-invasion defenses, the Netherlands news agency Aneta said today.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The hectic developments within the Republican party in recent weeks -- withdrawal of Wendell L. Willkie as a candidate, and the teapot tempest over Gen. Douglas MacArthur's correspondence -- leaves the leadership fairly well assured that, with the exception of one factor, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York will be nominated in June as the party's candidate for President, possibly on the first ballot.

The events in the air war during the past few months, and especially during the past week, throw a sardonic light on two prophecies by experts. The first of these experts was the Nazi air boss, Marshal Goering, who said in 1939: "We will not expose the Ruhr to a single bomb dropped by enemy aircraft."

THIS is the story of a German town. The town is Baden-Baden, in the Black Forest district of the Rhineland, where the writer of this article was interned with the American diplomatic group from Vichy for thirteen months from Jan. 16. 1943, to Feb. 19, 1944.

The sun shone brightly in Brooklyn yesterday, according to eyewitnesses and authentic weather reports, but so far as the denizens of Flatbush were able to make out a topsy-turvy world remained in total darkness.

NOT to get scrappy about it, but simply to state the case, let us note that the current crop of musicals is pretty conventional -- again. That's a theme on which this corner is provokingly tempted to expand almost every time that two or more musicals are gathered together on the screens of Broadway.

The Allies launched the greatest air assault in history against Adolf Hitler's Fortress Europe last week. Its purpose was to soften up the Continent in preparation for the day of invasion. The Germans fished for information as to when all-out attack would come.

NAPLES, April 22 (U.P.) -- The Anzio beachhead, never beyond reach of Nazi long-range artillery since British and American troops drove ashore just three months ago, rocked under a new barrage today, with the Germans evidently trying to discourage our increasingly bolder offensive thrusts.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 22 -- The Ninth Federal Circuit Court of Appeals today asked the Supreme Court for instructions on how to decide four questions raised in a case which will test the right of the Federal Government to hold loyal citizens of Japanese ancestry in relocation centers.

The Turkish home radio said yesterday that an unintentional omission of a sentence from a Turkish report on the banning of chrome shipments to Germany was responsible for reports that Turkey had stopped all chrome exports.

Two philanthropic organizations with welfare projects of wide appeal will benefit this week from performances of "Helen Goes to Troy" at the Alvin Theatre. Wednesday night's performance has been taken over as the annual springtime theatre party in aid of the Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

CHICAGO, April 22 -- Forecasts of an immediate opening of the second front in the European war led today to fairly general evening-up of open commitments in grain futures by many smaller professional traders on the Board of Trade, but prices moved within comparatively narrow limits.

PEARL HARBOR, April 22 -- A force of land-based Army and Navy heavy bombers attacked Saipan and Tinian Islands in the Marianas group, less than 1,400 miles south of Tokyo, in a daylight raid Monday, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., April 22 -- The theory held by Robert Moses, president of the Long Island State Park Commission, that the average American soldier knows nor cares nothing about golf and would not "know a divot from an Attic tomb inscription" if he saw one, does not appear entirely to be borne out by the facts, a survey of private golf clubs in Nassau County disclosed today.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 22 -- The feeling grew among Far Westerners this week that perhaps their campaign for greater recognition in the country's councils was making progress.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Between January, 1942, and the end of February this year the War Manpower Commission has managed to relocate 2,955 physicians to areas where their private practice is more acutely needed, the agency announced today.

For those who would look, the woodlands now have a prime display of what the specialists in that industrial problem would call packaging. Buds are opening, and if any professional packer ever stowed half as much into as small a space as the trees and bushes reveal in their buds he could rightly cry triumph supreme.

THE startling regression to savagery which has marked our time is a challenge to the spirit which literature cannot ignore. We may look in fiction as elsewhere for efforts to set up a faith that can stand against the tides of history, supporting the will and conscience of man against all dismal demonstrations of Malthusian economics and Machiavellian ethics.

NAPLES, April 22 -- Liberator bombers of the United States Fifteenth Air Force pounded the Rumanian rail yards near Bucharest yesterday, flying through thick fog, and also bombed Nazi communications targets at Turnu Severin on the Danube below the Iron Gate.

Enthusiasm generated by the magnificent achievement of the American shipbuilding industry in creating the world's largest merchant marine is producing false ideas regarding the peacetime value of ships. For service in future wars the national defense value of a merchant marine is great, but this must not be confused with the market value of American ships as investments.

THE "literary fallacy" is that disposition of writers and critics to judge a society solely in terms of its literature. According to Mr. De Voto, this leads not only to historical inaccuracy but to pessimism, misanthropy, the Ivory Tower, defeatism, fascism, and to a certain megalomania on the part of literary critics by which literature comes to be a "measure of life, and finally * * * life is subordinate to literature."

ON the day that Wendell Willkie withdrew as a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, a visitor called at the offices of E.P. Dutton Co. and paid down $1,025 -- the full price, plus postage, for 300 copies of "Under Cover," by John Roy Carlson.

THERE'S no known law preventing an actress from having red hair and green eyes. But when she's a Swedish actress and soon to be seen in her first Technicolor picture, that particular combination could do with a bit of explaining.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- War news of the Allied invasion of Europe will move from beachheads to the American public more directly than ever before, the Office of War Information said today in disclosing some of the arrangements being completed with the Allied High Command, the British Ministry of Information and military censorship and communications officials of both countries.

THE Philharmonic Women's Club, which is made up of the wives of the orchestra men, put the finishing touch to the season last Sunday with their annual supper party in the stately halls of the Horizon Club on East Fifty-third Street.
The Yankees lifted the lid on the 1944 baseball season at the Stadium yesterday in approved style.

Retail activity was brisk last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main floors were busy selling jewelry, handbags, neckwear and accessories.
AFTER the early spring storms are past, there will be several jobs of repairs and reconditioning to be clone before the calendar is free and clear for Victory gardening.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- The Government was reported tonight to be preparing an order tying up all sales of corn in 124 commercial corn producing counties in five Midwestern States except to the Government to meet needs of war industries facing shutdown because of a shortage of that grain.

ONE day in March, 1933, the new President, Franklin Roosevelt, visited Mr. Justice Holmes and found him reading Plato. "Why do you read Plato, Mr. Justice?" Mr. Roosevelt asked. "To improve my mind, Mr. President," said Justice Holmes, who was then 92 years old.

Retailers are watching closely the course of manufacturers' post-war plans with respect to the development of direct selling or important revision of the manufacturer-distributer-retailer set-up, particularly in the home wares and electrical appliance fields.

NAPLES, April 22 -- Italy now has the Cabinet that the "people were waiting for" as the Mezzogiorno, a newspaper published in Bari, noted this morning but it would be much more realistic to consider the first meeting of the new body this week as the beginning rather than the end of the problem.

What might be called the season's most "sophisticated" concert or the most boring or the funniest according to the point of view, was given late yesterday afternoon at the Carnegie Chamber Music Hall by Harry Partch, American composer, under the auspices of the League of Composers.

A new deficiency disease, marked by muscular stiffness and deposits of calcium phosphate in all organs and parts of the body, was described before the Cleveland meeting of the American Chemical Society by Prof. William J. Van Wagendonk of Oregon State College. The preventive dietary factor is present in cream in very small quantities.

Government is supported solely by taxes. When tax collections are insufficient to meet the cost of Government it resorts to borrowing. Emergencies, like war, unavoidably necessitate Government borrowing. Now there is a school of thought which holds that rising national debt does not adversely affect the national economy; that, on the contrary, a constantly increasing debt may be beneficial.

IN a manner surprisingly modest for a business so prone to display, the motion picture industry is celebrating its fiftieth birthday this month. The war has occasioned circumspection; the anniversary is but passingly observed. It is curious how ironically consistent this is with the celebrated event.

Records of school children leave no doubt that dental caries (decay) is widely prevalent. Despite the attention that the problem has received, there is no remedy except periodic visits to the dentist. Some hope is held out by the observation that when fluorine is present in the water supply there is less dental decay.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Sunday, April 24 -- Some 500 tons of bombs were dropped on Wewak, Aitape and Hansa Bay as Allied airmen increased the power of their strategic attacks to knock out Japanese bases on the northern New Guinea coast.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- At business sessions today the members of the American Society of Newspaper Editors declared that world freedom of press and communications was vital to avoidance of future wars and decided to explore the possibility of getting guarantees of such freedom into international agreements, possibly the peace treaty.

Mrs. A.M. Sobel and B. Jay Becker of New Yorw and Charles H. Goren and Sidney Silodor of Philadelphia won the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup and the national contract bridge team-of-four championship here last night, bringing to a close the tournament that has been in progress at the Hotel Pierre since Monday.

FATHERS are in the services, mothers have jobs, families move to strange communities; these are wartime circumstances in which many mothers of young children now deal with the old familiar perplexities concerning "crying it out," whether to spank or not to spank, concerning eating, and play, and all the rest.
BOSTON, April 22 (AP) -- The Phillies profited by Al Javery's wildness today to take the National League opener at Boston from the Braves, 3 to 2.

EVERY now and then in the English universities there arises some don or teacher who is so clear-headed and expresses himself so well that not only his own college or university but all England is eager to listen to him. It was so with Benjamin Jowett; it was so earlier with the man who subsequently became Cardinal Newman.

THE Mexican Symphony Orchestra is to be brought regularly to listeners in the United States this summer in an international program that will run from 9 to 10 P.M. Sundays, beginning next week, over the Mutual network and WOR.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 -- The Pittsburgh Steelers and the Chicago Cardinals agreed late today to merge for the 1944 National Football League season. The league, which had asked the merger as one way to avoid schedule problems attendant upon an eleven-team circuit, immediately gave its blessing to the move.

ALBANY, April 22 -- Governor Dewey today appointed Mrs. Leopold K. Simon of 141 East Eighty-eighth Street, New York, as a member of the State Industrial Board for a six-year term. She will receive a salary of $8,500 a year.

IN Holland, in June, 1940, 18-year-old Lorens Van Norreys, heir to an ancient firm of jewel merchants, is summoned to his dying grandfather. Just before Lorens escapes to England he follows the old man's last directions and leaves the Flowers of Orange -- a priceless family necklace -- in a safe that can be opened only after two years, and then only by one word.

The ball that Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia tossed to Rollie Hemsley, officially launching the season at the Yankee Stadium yesterday, and which Hemsley tossed back to the Mayor, will be sent overseas to a group of American soldiers who requested it in a V-mail letter, dated March 17.

THERE is a curious misapprehension abroad that torch singers, with their limited versatility, succeed only in smoldering vocals sung to rhythmic melodies. In the case of Gertrude Niesen, the sultry young lady who has just returned to Broadway after an absence of seven years, the misapprehension is righted.

A priest for sixty years, Bishop for more than forty-two years and a member of the Sacred College of Cardinals for thirty-three years, William Cardinal O'Connell was credited with playing a vital, if not decisive, role in the election of Pope Pius XII at the conclave which took place in Rome in March, 1939.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 22 -- American women serving in the armed forces are a "grand lot of girls" and their morals are on an unimpeachable plane, Mrs. Henry A. Ingraham of New York, president of the National Board of the Young Women's Christian Association and vice president of the National United Service Organizations, declared today.

Retail trade here last week was active, with sales comparing well with the wind-up of Easter trade last year. Department store volume was estimated as running about 3 per cent ahead of 1943. Consumer demand for seasonal accessories was heavy, with little retarding effect shown of the new excise taxes on handbags and jewelry.
CHUNGKING, China, April 22 (AP) -- Japanese attacking from the east have reached the suburbs of Chengchow, which is being shelled and bombed, the Chinese High Command announced tonight.

BALTIMORE, April 22 -- The Calumet Farm's Sun Again gained a measure of revenge for his Widener Handicap defeat as he scored a two-length victory today over the Greentree Stable's Four Freedoms in the tenth Southern Maryland Handicap before 21,231 persons at Pimlico.

THE censorship situation in Argentina regarding American motion pictures of an anti-Axis nature has shown some signs of improvement in recent weeks. In some instances the censor has done a complete about face, approving pictures which had been unconditionally banned a few months ago; in other cases the censor has displayed willingness to compromise the drastic cuts originally ordered in certain pictures dealing with Nazi and Japanese brutalities.

EVER since the publication of his "White Spirituals in the Southern Uplands," ten years ago, George Pullen Jackson has been known as an indefatigable student of American religious folksong. Through various stages his work has led him to the theory that the Baptists, not the Methodists, brought their folk hymns to this country from Britain some 200 years ago.

LONDON, April 22 -- About thirty Jewish soldiers who attempted to quit the Polish Army and join the British forces to avoid what they called anti-Semitic treatment have been sentenced to one to three years in prison on charges of desertion.

A revision of requirements for the doctorate, or the creation of an intermediate degree between the master's and the doctor's, is suggested by Dr. S.L. Pressey, Professor of Psychology at Ohio State University, in an article prepared for the current Journal of Higher Education.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- Larger supplies of fuel oil available for commercially operated steamboats will permit more pleasure cruising in most parts of the country this season, the Office of Price Administration said today.

LONDON, Sunday, April 23 (AP) -- The Yugoslav Partisans broadcast a communique today saying that Chetnik forces of Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch, with German support, lost 200 dead in an unsuccessful attack at Jablonica and Toplica.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Secretary Hull asserted today in comment on the proposals for a world currency stabilization plan disclosed yesterday by Secretary Morgenthau that "if such programs can be put into operation before the end of the war, we will save much time in the task of bringing about domestic and worldwide prosperity when hostilities cease and immeasurably strengthen the prospects for an enduring peace."
A LARGE group of bridge players has recently adopted a new method of dealing with an opponent's opening pre-emptive bid, and particularly an opening three-bid.

THIS is a collection of twenty-two sketches printed between 1928-1942 in The Saturday Evening Post, first published in 1943 by the University of Georgia Press. In several instances the subjects of these sketches have much less right to the designation "famous journalist" -- at least as the average reporter understands the term -- than the men who wrote them.

A STRAWBERRY barrel is not a stunt, nor a merely decorative accessory for the garden or terrace, but a practical way of growing this popular fruit on a small scale and in the least possible space. The chief difficulty in trying this very old method of fruit growing is finding a suitable barrel.

GEOPOLITICS is a name in bad repute with many Americans, because German scholars built it up as a new science on which much typically "deep" German thinking was spent. Under the hands of these metaphysical magicians, space, one of the many elements influencing human history, became an almost mystical force which irresistibly determines our fate.

The veteran's bitterness is likely to be the dominant political force in the United States in the next twenty years, Professor Willard Waller, Associate Professor of Sociology at Bernard College, predicted yesterday. He spoke at a four-State conference of 130 college administrators, personnel and guidance workers at Teachers College, Columbia University.

The sedition trial in Washington "confirms the suspicion that hate-mongering and sedition are twin sisters," Rabbi Israel Goldstein declared yesterday in a sermon in Temple B'nai Jeshurun, Eighty-eighth Street, near Broadway.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- For over two years the military, naval, economic and manpower resources of the United States and the British Empire and -- through them -- of most of the anti-Axis world have been controlled and coordinated by six integrating bodies known as "Combined Boards."

Mr. Dewey's Delegates The national political scene was dominated last week by the growing strength of New York Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's unannounced candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination. Already leading the field with 168 pledged delegates, Mr. Dewey was picking up support steadily.

WHEN the historians of the theatre poke their grimy fingers into the records of this particular season, the chances are excellent they will use as a chapter heading the word Tinsel. Not that there is anything wrong with tinsel, either, for when it settles down to cases, the theatre can dress up a bauble so that it looks like a whole Christmas tree.

Flying his thirty-ton American Export Flying Ace at an average of 211 miles an hour, Capt. Edward A. Stewart of Roslyn, L.I., covered the 3,329 statute miles between New York and Ireland in 15 hours 51 minutes, non-stop, for a new record, it was disclosed yesterday when he arrived at La Guardia Field on the return trip.

BOSTON, April 22 -- William Cardinal O'Connell, Archbishop of Boston, spiritual sovereign of more than a million Massachusetts Catholics and New England's first and only prince of the Church of Rome, died at 5:45 P. M. today of bronchial pneumonia at his residence in Brighton.

NOT every young artist whose painting has been a sensation has the courage to break away in both medium and subject-matter before his work becomes formula and goes adventuring in other fields. Darrel Austin has done just this.

THE Government's 1944 program for issuing special postage stamps is beginning to take shape. An announcement by Postmaster General Frank C. Walker brings the first official confirmation of a story published in these columns on Feb. 6 that another "Overrun Countries" series of commemoratives, this time paying tribute to Asiatic lands under Japanese domination, was in prospect.

A new threat to the over-extended Japanese empire in the Pacific loomed last week, when an Allied naval task force, operating in the Indian Ocean, made an air attack upon Japanese positions in northern Sumatra.

In addition to building 19,000,000 deadweight tons of merchant ships and repairing 23,000 vessels, our privately operated shipyards built last year most of the new Navy ships commissioned, according to a report given By H. Gerrish Smith, president of the Shipbuilders Council of America, to members at their annual meeting last week.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- The Circuit Court of Appeals refused today to interfere with the trial of thirty persons accused of participating in a Nazi conspiracy against American democracy.

MARTHA ALBRAND is the author of two excellent adventure novels, "No Surrender" and "Without Orders." In her new book, as always, she tells a good story, with sincerity and imagination and holds the reader to the end.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., April 22 -- Mrs. William R. Fleming's mare Loveday, now 8 years old, scored a thrilling victory in the $5,000 added Roger Williams Handicap today at Narragansett Park.

An Institute of Inter-American Affairs has been established at Loyola University, with initial classes scheduled for the summer quarter starting June 26. The university will call upon its own staff of Inter-American scholars and writers. In addition, arrangements are being made with the Department of State to obtain a visiting professor from an outstanding Latin-American university.

DETROIT, April 22 -- If the Rev. Gerald L.K. Smith, the self-styled "rabble rouser," is on his way toward becoming the voice of isolationism in the United States and a power in national politics, he is the traditional prophet without honor among his own people.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- Calling for a united national front on peace problems, Chairman Tom Connally named today a "bipartisan" committee of eight Senate Foreign Relations Committee members to confer with Secretary of State Hull on plans for an international organization. He acted at Secretary Hull's invitation.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, KANDY, Ceylon, April 22 (AP) -- Allied headquarters today declared its forces were prepared to meet any Japanese threat in the Imphal and Kohima areas of eastern India where infantry and tanks continued to push outward from the Manipur plain and that the "situation continues to develop favorably."

There are sincere friends of international cooperation who must be aware of a growing threat. It is the danger that internationalism may become confused in the public mind with mere restlessness. The trouble lies in this exaggerated stress on the airplane as the prime architect of the new world.

SEATS on planes bound for foreign countries are scarce nowadays as seats for "Oklahoma." Before you can get space on a Pan American Airways Clipper you have to convince the War Department that you have a vital reason for going abroad by air.

In "Soldiers Are Superstitious," Ruth Adler in THE TIMES Magazine really gives the lowdown on Hitler, who, we are told, is the "most superstitious man in Europe," and that he "always plays seven, the gambler's lucky number."

TO the desk at which this sabbath report is penned there came last week a gentleman who introduced himself as Cuthbert S. Kilocycle and whose opinions are presented here without prejudice and merely for what they may be worth, which almost certainly is nothing at all.

THE May Festival of the University of Michigan will be held at Ann Arbor May 4-7 and with consist of five concerts by the Philadelphia Orchestra with assisting artists. Eugene Ormandy, music director of the festival, will conduct all of the concerts except the two on the third day, which will be led by Saul Caston, the orchestra's associate conductor.
JERSEY CITY, April 22 (AP) -- Toronto made a sweep of its two-game series with Jersey City, winning by 7 to 0 behind the superb five-hit hurling of Lefty Tom Ananicz at Roosevelt Stadium today.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- American food authorities said today that Russia's food-supply situation still was poor, despite the recent opening of a number of unrationed-food stores in Moscow and other Russian cities.
BUFFALO, April 22 -- Joe McCarthy, manager of the Yankees, recovering from an attack of influenza complicated by neuritis, will move Monday with his wife to their ranch-like farm.

Courageous play on the part of Arnold S. Denker of Forest Hills, champion of the Manhattan Chess Club, against Reuben Fine of Washington, not only provided the sensation in the seventh round of the tournament for the United States chess championship at the Hotel Park Central yesterday, but also enabled the youthful New Yorker, still undefeated, to recover the lead with a score of 6 -- 0.

LONDON, March 26 (By the United Press) -- Unconfirmed British press dispatches reported tonight from the Swiss-Italian frontier that the 300 Italians executed on Thursday in the Colosseum at Rome had included 83-year-old Vittorio Orlando, former Premier and one of the Allies' "Big Four" at the Versailles Peace Conference.

HARRISON, N.Y., April 22 -- Running over new grounds for the first time in a number of years, the Southern New York Field Trial Club began its seventeenth annual meeting in this village today, with two stakes on the program.

HERE is a new kind of humor -- new and astonishingly simple. Carlos Bulosan is a pure manifestation of the Comic Spirit. He is also a Filipino, born and raised in the village of Binalonan, on the island of Luzon.

LONDON, April 22 -- Within a few days a family reunion will be held in London, a reunion of the world's greatest family of nations, the first meeting during the war of the British Empire's Prime Ministers.

VINCE DIMAGGIO stepped out of the dugout, picked up his glove and went into the outfield for a bit of practice in shagging flies. Manager Frank Frisch watched him in sorrow. "I'm getting tired of telling him to throw that glove of his away," he moaned. "If he could only learn to hit he'd be as great a ball player as his brother Joe."

RICHMOND, Va., April 22 -- The fulminations from certain South Carolina politicians apropos of the recent Supreme Court ruling on white primaries, should be kept in proper perspective. Although the fact was widely publicized that the South Carolina House adopted a resolution upholding "white supremacy" and demanding that "damned agitators from the North" keep out, scarcely any publicity was given the fact that this same resolution died in a Senate committee.

NAPLES, April 22 -- In the course of negotiations leading to the resolution of the Italian Cabinet's crisis yesterday the delegate of one left-wing party in the Junta was received affably by Marshal Badoglio, who reminded him of the time an uncle of the visitor had received some government honor.

A fortnight ago it was pointed out in this column that the brilliant advances of the Red Army had opened an opportunity for the use of strategic bombing by the Russian aviation force. It was emphasized that while the American bombers flying from Foggia had to make a round trip of some 1,800 miles to bomb the oil fields of Ploesti, for example, those oil fields were only 200 miles from the Russian front.

Resentment against the Government's wartime control of necessities extends to a substantial percentage of the nation's population and is driving a wedge between the home and the fighting fronts, Council President Newbold Morris declared yesterday, in welcoming thirty members of the Old Guard to annual exercises at City Hall.

Lansing Warren, member of the Paris bureau of THE NEW Y0RK TIMES until the German occupation, will be the second speaker in a series, being conducted at Occidental College, Los Angeles, through a gift of $10,000 from an anonymous donor. Mr. Warren will remain on the Occidental campus for addresses during the first two weeks in May.

ANOTHER tough Nevada town is cleaned up by that hardboiled private detective, Rex McBride. This time it is San Gorgonio, a wide-open town with seldom equaled facilities for relieving wealthy tourists of their money.

Thirty-four years ago Andrew F. Howe, employe of a steel company now defunct, invented a sand mold to cast in one piece heavy parts for locomotives and cars. After fourteen and a half years of patent litigation, The Associated Press reports that a special master appointed by a Federal court has awarded him the princely sum of $3,681,382 plus 5 per cent interest.

NEW ORLEANS, April 22 -- There has been a decided drift in sections of the Deep South in the past week toward the selection of a Democrat other than Franklin D. Roosevelt as the party's standard-bearer. This move has centered around Senator Harry F. Byrd of Virginia.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- Byron Price, Censorship Director, today urged that hearings in connection with any Congressional investigation of wartime censorship be opened to the public.

In its first start ha defense of the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference championship, the New York University nine turned in a steady workmanlike performance against C.C.N.Y. at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday. With Ralph Branca, one of six Violet basketball stars in the line-up, in command virtually all the time, N.Y.U. blanked the Beavers, 3 -- 0.

NOTHING could be more timely and more pleasantly provocative than Warwick Deeping's theme in "The Cleric's Secret." We all know how significant is the role of chaplains in the present global conflict; some of us remember how stoutly the "padres" of 1914-18 bore practical testimony to their faith.

" HEAVEN Is Too High" is an adventure novel of stupendous proportions, based on the early efforts of the Russian American Company to conquer the coast of Alaska and found a rich fur-trading colony in the years from 1790 to 1810.

FORT LEWIS, Wash., April 22 (AP) -- Fort Lewis authorities disclosed tonight that German prisoners at the fort's prisoner-of-war camp had demonstrated Thursday in celebration of Hitler's birthday and that in accordance with the Geneva Convention the entire camp was put on a diet of bread and water for a day.

FORT DEVENS, Mass., April 22 (AP) -- Having both legs blown off by a mortar shell does not make a hero out of a man, according to the viewpoint of Pvt. Leo Emmett of Chelsea, who underwent just such an experience and lived to tell about it.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 22 (AP) -- Five Army airmen were killed and five civilians were seriously burned -- three of them small children -- when a light bomber spun out of control and crashed at a busy street intersection in East Phoenix today.

MR. JONES is being wise, not lazy, when he waits till now to start his Victory garden, though his impatient neighbor planted two weeks ago. By mid-May his seedlings will be just as big as those on the other side of the fence.

THEODORE PRATT started this novel with a good idea. He collected a group of characters representative of a good many phases of human thought and activity, put them on a mountain, isolated them from the rest of the world and had the makings of an allegorical novel about history, civilization, dictatorship, isolationism and human passions.

ST. LOUIS, April 22 -- A recommendation that our schools and colleges establish more history courses dealing with Latin America as a means of promoting closer relationships now and in the post- war period was made by Prof. Arthur S. Aiton of the University of Michigan at the closing sessions today of the Mississippi Valley Historical Association Conference.

WHEN Chinook, a half-starved and lonely mongrel, drifted into the Field Artillery Replacement Center at Fort Bragg, startling the sentry by his wolflike howl, inherited from his Alaskan husky ancestor, he was lucky enough to arouse the interest of two dog lovers, Sgt. William Andrews and Lieutenant Glen.

The Red Army last week was setting the stage for new and perhaps conclusive developments. Through hundreds of miles of re-won territory stretching from the Black Sea to the Gulf of Finland vast movements of troops and supplies were believed to be under way. Russians were strengthening depleted divisions, regrouping reserve armies, laying up stores of munitions for future battles.

The Italian Government last week underwent a reorganization. On the heels of King Victor Emmanuel's announcement that he would relinquish power to Crown Prince Umberto when the Allies take Rome, Marshal Pietro Badoglio resigned as Premier and at the King's request set about forming a coalition Cabinet.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, April 22 -- Powerful American warships -- including a sizable force of deadly carriers -- were disclosed today to be operating in the Indian Ocean and to have teamed up with other Allied naval units in the blow that caught the Japanese off guard at Sumatra at dawn Wednesday.

HEADQUARTERS OF THE SCREWBALL ESCADRILLE, Italy, April 22 (U.P.) -- Eight Piper Cub pilots today carried out probably the most unsuccessful raid in aerial history and returned without losses after encountering no enemy fighters or anti-aircraft fire.

MOSCOW, April 22 -- Finland has rejected Russia's revised terms for an armistice and broken off conversations on the subject, it was announced tonight. Replying to the Finns' assertion that the Soviet Union's demands would deprive their country of its independence, Vice Foreign Commissar Andrei Y. Vishinsky said at a press conference that the Finns no longer were independent.

LONDON, April 22 (U.P.) -- Dr. Eduard Benes, President of Czechoslovakia, predicted tonight it was "not at all unlikely" that Germany would collapse within three months after a successful Allied invasion of Western Europe.

CHICAGO, April 22 -- Irrespective of party affiliation, the populace of the Central West this week was studying the results of the Chicago deliberations of Republican national leaders for indications as to who would be chosen as Presidential and Vice Presidential candidates at the convention here in June.

When the well-known future historian, perhaps already cooing in his bassinette, begins to accumulate data for his monumental tome on the United States during the Second World War (and, one hopes, the Last) he may wonder how we did so well. He will read the Congressional Record, yellow, crumbling and dusty.

Reviewing some of its own constructive efforts for individual boys and girls, the New England Home for Little Wanderers says a few words on "Juvenile problems" in its current bulletin. "There is much talk in the press and in meetings of all sorts about juvenile delinquency," the leading article starts off.

BOSTON, April 22 -- To those thousands of New Englanders who celebrated the opening of the baseball season this week, war temporarily seemed far away. Only the existence of a black market in gasoline could explain the presence of so many pleasure cars on New England roads.

CHICAGO, April 22 -- Two teamster locals of the American Federation of Labor, which had given passive support to the strike of CIO mail order workers in Montgomery Ward Co.'s main plant here, moved their trucks in and out through picket lines today to protect their own position against volunteer drivers.

CHUNGKING, China, April 22 -- Not everyone in the Kuomintang [Nationalist party] is satisfied with the assumption that China is not ready for self-government. Although the official party attitude is that constitutional democracy must be postponed until after the war, some Kuomintang members believe more progress could be made now.

THOSE long-suffering Mae West fans need suffer only a little longer. Michael Todd, the irrepressible man with the plans, disclosed to us that Miss West's opus, "Catherine Was Great," is ready to go, with the lady herself abursting for action.

THIS is the sixth in a series of seven volumes which Professor Latourette of Yale is preparing on the "History of the Expansion of Christianity." The first three volumes brought us down to the nineteenth century.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Candidates for the Army Specialized Training Reserve Program who took the qualifying test given March 15 at most high schools and colleges will be informed soon of the results, the War Department announced today.

IN the two preceding issues this department set down some personal memories of reading done during childhood and adolescence, and drew some general conclusions regarding the effect that books may have in those formative periods.

ODESSA, April 17 (Delayed) -- Rear Admiral S.F. Belovsoff disclosed today the inspiring story of a suicide battalion of fifty-five Soviet marines who made an amphibious landing at Nikolayev and captured several buildings, which they held for forty-eight hours. The battalion fought to the last man against a German infantry regiment, a tank company, several artillery batteries and flame-throwers.

Newbold Morris, president of the City Council, urged the representatives of eleven Brooklyn high schools at the final session of the fourth annual Brooklyn High School Model Congress yesterday to see that American institutions keep pace with the country's growth in spirit.

Democracy can default in America if women fail to work for its preservation, two men active in political life yesterday told a group of girls from fifteen Eastern colleges, attending an experimental day-long college forum held by Mademoiselle in the Chanin Tower Meeting Room, 122 East Forty-second Street.

CHICAGO, April 22 (AP) -- Ralph Budd, president of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad, announced today that the road had filed a refunding plan with the Interstate Commerce Commission to call all of its outstanding Illinois Division mortgage bonds.

OMAHA, Neb., April 22 -- The correspondence between Representative A.L. Miller of Nebraska and Gen. Douglas MacArthur has claimed the lion's share of attention during the week. The reaction, a good deal of it expressed after a few days of deliberation, has been anything but flattering to either party to the interchange.

KANSAS CITY, April 22 (AP) -- A terrific rain, resembling a tropical storm, brought to many communities in Kansas and Missouri today the threat of the worst floods in their history. Many towns ordered evacuation of lowland areas and flood warnings were posted as far east as the Mississippi River.

Lillian Hellman's new play, "The Searching Wind," is an indictment of a generation -- the generation of appeasers and faint-hearted liberals. Through a series of flashbacks to historic moments in the rise of fascism and nazism, she reaches a verdict of "Guilty!" against those who watched it happen and did nothing to stop it.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The spotlight which recent events fixed on the Republican party temporarily obscured the area where the Democratic party is faced with much more difficult problems that must be solved somehow before the Presidential campaign begins.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- Equestrian events lead the list of sports to which vacationists are giving energetic attention, with most of the guests in riding togs from morning till night. Horseback parties leave the Carolina Hotel each forenoon, taking visitors on a tour of the woods trails in search of the best, spring blossoms.

Then too much centralization of power causes the blossoms to grow smaller, branches to shrink and weaken and the oldest center portion to become hollow and useless.

A FULL century has passed since the birth of Anatole France, on April 16, 1844. By the time he died, some eighty years later, he had run the gamut of all beliefs and sampled all the philosophies from Epicurus to Karl Marx. His life, tossed about on the winds of many doctrines, found anchorage in none of them, except perhaps in that one which held for him the essence of all of them socialism.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 -- Its unique study of profits and operations of more than 1,000 listed American corporations completed, the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today that such concerns, although taking in more than twice as much in 1942 as in 1936, were able to retain little more than half as much of each dollar of income in 1942 as they were six years earlier.

Extraordinary food gluts in the New York metropolitan area were further complicated yesterday by additional huge hauls of mackerel. Catches of 400,000 pounds off Cape May, N.J., and 100,000 pounds off Maryland will be added tomorrow to the record-breaking 1,500,000-pound arrivals of last Friday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 22 -- The Swedish Foreign Office late this evening handed Herschel Johnson, United States envoy here, Sweden's reply to Washington's request for cessation of Swedish ball bearing exports to the Reich.

ASLIGHT but pleasant spring offering is an album of "Four Favorite Waltzes" recorded by Howard Barlow and the Columbia Broadcasting Symphony (Columbia album X-240, two twelve-inch records). It includes two Strauss Waltzes -- On the Beautiful Blue Danube and Tales From the Vienna Woods -- plus Sibelius' Valse Triste and the Waltz of the Flowers from Tchaikovsky's Nutcracker Suite, all of which are given sumptuous performances under Mr. Barlow's very capable direction.
Week-end liquidation and continued evening-up in the May position prior to first notice day on April 25 brought about yesterday declines of 3 to 8 points in prices on the Cotton Exchange.

Thomas L.L. Ryan, chairman of the publishers, printers and visual arts section of the Manhattan Commerce and Industry Committee, announced yesterday that his section has contributed $435,000, or 125 per cent, of its quota in the Red Cross 1944 War Fund campaign of Greater New York to raise $22,386,000.

Col. Raymond P. Cook, commandant of the Army Specialized Training and Reserve Officers Training Corps units at City College, where he has been Professor of Military Science and Tactics since 1942, will go on terminal leave today prior to his official retirement on account of age on Aug. 31, it was announced yesterday.

GREENWICH VILLAGE is undergoing a change. The cigar-box ukuleles, Rumaman blouses, gypsy earrings, sandals, paint-smeared corduroys, Borsalino hats, batiks, bobbed hair and other conventional impedimenta associated with the Village are obsolete. No longer hampered by the dictates of Montparnasse and Chelsea, our own "left bankers" have rejected these symbols of an earlier age and replaced them with contemporary conventions.

With representatives of various branches of the service as well as boxing commissioners from neighboring States on hand, the National Boxing Association held the opening session of its first wartime meeting of the executive committee yesterday at the St. Moritz Hotel.

More money than had ever been flashed in a single day at a race track was in evidence at the Jamaica course yesterday. While the crowd, numbering 41,412, fell short of the Jamaica record by some 5,000, those who did turn up showed no hesitancy whatever in making their way to the mutuel windows, into which they poured the staggering total of $3,176,553.

LONDON, April 22 -- Every little while someone in the United States agitates the teacups with the accusation that England is meddling in American politics.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 22 -- Although events of the next five months will be all important in deciding who is elected President this fall -- as they were in 1940 -- Republican chances of winning the election look better today than most observers are inclined to believe.

Because of the current mess in "when, as and if issued" trading in new Missouri Pacific Railroad securities, Wall Street is seeking a uniform contract in deals which concern both members and nonmembers of the New York Stock Exchange.

THE Affair of the 1943 Connecticut Potatoes, one of the meanest tricks ever played by a Victory crop, stands every chance of being repeated this year unless long-suffering gardeners know what to expect and take steps accordingly. The potatoes insisted on playing host to the European corn borer in addition to the usual assortment of bugs, blights and beetles.

A racial-tolerance campaign designed to make New York's children, parents, teachers and administrators "immune and impregnable" to the specter of hatred has been started throughout the city's public school system by the Board of Superintendents, it was learned yesterday.

One of the largest and most difficult war emergency tasks ever undertaken by an American museum has been completed with the return to the Metropolitan Museum of Art of some 15,000 precious works of art removed outside the city for safekeeping after the United States declared war on Japan and Germany.

Senator W. Lee O'Daniel, Texas Democrat, declared yesterday that although he believed a majority of the Texas delegation to the Democratic National Convention would support President Roosevelt for re-nomination, he would do everything he could to defeat the President for re-election.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- The issue of maintenance of union membership, which had been dormant in the War Labor Board for more than a year, reappeared during the week with an intensity that threatened to rend the agency asunder.

Stocks continued yesterday to drift in narrow ranges. They closed mixed on the New York Stock Exchange, which had the second smallest session of the year. On the New York Curb Exchange sales were 64,385 shares, the smallest volume since Sept. 4.

THE next skirmish in Hollywood's own ideological war will be staged Tuesday night, a week, when representatives of some forty talent guilds, labor and producer groups will meet to devise ways and means to "protect the industry's patriotic efforts and the freedom of the screen from unprincipled attacks . . . so that picture making and picture workers no longer will be convenient scapegoats for pressure groups."

In the thirteenth century the Frenchman, Peter de Maricourt, better known as Peter Perigrinus because of a pilgrimage that he had made to the Holy Land, described some experiments with magnets. He cut a loadstone in two and noted with astonishment that each part became a complete magnet with two poles.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, today announced appointment of an automobile industry-labor advisory committee to consult with WPB on eventual reconversion of the industry to peacetime production.

Remarks of J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, at the recent national congress here of the Daughters of the American Revolution, expressing his concern over divisive forces in American life, were cited yesterday as reason for new emphasis on love of one's neighbors, in an address by Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the Catholic University of America, Washington.

THEODORE SPENCER presents, in "An Act of Life," three long meditative poems, read before the Phi Beta Kappa societies at the College of William and Mary, at Tufts College and at Harvard University. Interspersed between these are two sections entitled "Lyrics" and "Challenges."

LONDON, Sunday, April 23 -- From dawn to sundown yesterday armadas of Allied bombers and fighters penetrated Hitler's West-wall on the sixth straight day of the greatest aerial assault ever delivered against the Germans.

CONFLICTING reports regarding Abyssinia's 1943 stamps commemorating the thirteenth anniversary of the coronation of Haile Selassie I are reconciled through information received from Addis Ababa last week by J. H. Stolow.

JESS BENTLEY married Beth Ford and took her to his ranch on Horse Prairie. The neighbors welcomed the bride with a shivaree. Beth wanted children, but her boy lived only a day. And Beth, too, died. She died during the hard winter when all the hay was gone and the cattle died in the willows and the colt which Jess had brought home across his saddle died behind the stove.

LONDON, April 22 (AP) -- The Soviet High Command, in its shortest communique in months, said tonight that "no important changes" had occurred on any sector of the Eastern Front today. The Germans explained this brevity by declaring that the Red Army was forming its lines for a big new offensive in Poland to coincide with an Allied invasion from the west.

CANBERRA, Australia, April 22 -- Australia's social services will cost her 42,750,000 in 1945. This amount includes a minimum estimated new charge of 10,500,000 for unemployment and sickness benefits under legislation passed a few weeks ago and effective Jan. 1, 1945.

Dr. J.F.T. Berliner, du Pont chemist, electrified a meeting held in New York last week with the news that instead of impregnating wood with resins it is now possible to change compounds in the wood to resins with startling results.

LONDON, April 22 -- The most important members of the Polish underground yet to reach Great Britain have arrived in London after having very recently left their jobs in the homeland to report to the exiled Polish Government here.

NEW ORLEANS, April 22 (AP) -- Army, Navy and Coast Guard crews today discovered the wreckage of a storm-downed Navy blimp in the Gulf of Mexico off the Mississippi River, but nine members of the ten-man crew still are missing, the Eighth Naval District Headquarters announced.

KANDY, Ceylon, April 22 (AP) -- Taking note of complaints of five British correspondents over censorship out of Burma, Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten said tonight an entirely new public relations division had been organized and explained that the Britons' censored dispatches contained information "it was undesirable that the enemy should know."

LONDON, April 22 -- Some day an Anglo-American Army from Britain is going to descend on the Continent, which for four years has been under German domination. That much is known to Hitler and his general staff. It has been shouted from the housetops of all Allied capitals since Teheran.
PHILADELPHIA, April 22 (AP) -- Making his first start for the Athletics, Louis (Bobo) Newsom shut out the Red Sox today, 4 -- 0, allowing them five hits, before a home opening day crowd of 5,000.

AMONG the oddities of up-State New York history, nothing can be odder than the case that a Dr. David Little reported to the Albany County Medical Society in the early years of the last century. It is a truthful old wives' tale, which forms the cornerstone of this novel.

Emanuel List, basso, and Ella Flesch, soprano, both of the Metropolitan Opera company, and Robert Goldsand, Viennese pianist, featured the concert of "Immortal Viennese Music" presented last night by Leo Rice at Town Hall.

Whole communities among the nations of Europe are cooperating to avert social chaos after the war by preserving the social institutions that Germany has attempted to destroy, Miss Mary Craig McGeachy, director of the division of welfare of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- A simplified tax program designed to "tailor" withholding more nearly to income after Jan. 1, 1945, and thus relieve about 30,000,000 of the 50,000,000 taxpayers of the necessity of making returns, was unanimously approved today by the Ways and Means Committee.

WE do not care one farthing about the adherence of Canada to England." declared John Roebuck, member for Sheffield, in the House of Commons in 1862. Roebuck had passed his youth in the Dominion, had been educated there, and knew as well as any man could what he tossed lightly away.

A VERY instructive show is being held at the Jacques Seligmann Gallery, 5 East Fifty-seventh Street. It spreads before us the entire evolution of "Les Plongeurs" by Fernand Leger. Numerous drawings, gouaches and oil sketches lead up to the large and dynamic canvas bearing that title.

ASIGNIFICANT feature of the third and last of the "concert-salute" programs dedicated to Allied nations and given under the auspices of the Congregation Emanu-el and its choir committee, next Sunday, will be an extensive group of Russian folksongs, coming principally from the Caucasian region and neighboring territories which are prominent today in the dispatches.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., April 23 -- One woman was killed and seven persons, including three children, were critically injured at 5:46 this evening when a passenger train passing east on the main line of the Erie Railroad struck a baggage truck and sent it hurtling into a crowd of fifty men and women hurrying across the tracks to board a train for up-State points.

Cottons lead a rarefied existence these days, accepted as they are for high-style daytime and evening fashions, but their role in the housekeeping picture is brighter than ever. Housedresses take their cues from trends outside their special field, and emerge in up-to-the minute fabrics with authentic style notes.

LONDON, April 23 -- Suspended animation best describes the condition of the stock markets in London. Although next Tuesday's budget statement is a restrictive influence, it ranks as a comparatively trifling factor. No taxation surprises are expected, and apart from the enormous figures with which it will deal, it probably will prove to be colorless.

From a "studio" in a villa whose roof shook under enemy fire, Anzio Beachhead called the United States yesterday morning by direct radio broadcast for the first time. Beginning shortly after 9 A.M. (Eastern war time), correspondents of the four major American networks took turns at the microphone of the Army radio station JJRP ("Jig Jig Roger Peter"), from which their voices were transmitted to Naples, amplified and beamed by short wave to this country.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) Individual income tax collections totaled $12,869,000,000 in the first nine months of this fiscal year, more than triple the amount for the same period a year ago and nearly double the take for the entire twelve-month period ended last June 30, a Treasury statement showed today.

MOSCOW, April 23 -- The declarations on Soviet-Finnish relations made by the Vice Foreign Commissar, Andrei Y. Vishinsky, made a little before midnight yesterday before a very large gathering of newspaper men, manifest Russian anger and astonishment.

To the various novel prize contests now can be added a novelette award offered by Partisan Review in collaboration with the Dial Press. There will be a first prize of $500, a second of $250 and a third of $100. Manuscripts must be between 10,000 words and 25,000 words and must be submitted by Dec. 1.

TRENTON, N.J., April 23 -- Showman's Conchita, owned by Mrs. Edward G. Prost of the Bronx and handled by Mrs. Emily Shire through her classes, was crowned queen of the annual specialty show of the Triangle Boston Terrier Breeders Club, held today in the War Memorial Building in this city.
LONDON, April 23 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

NAPLES, April 23 (AP) -- Flying Fortress Gunner Gregory Mangin has acquired 1,000 hours in the air and a few gray hairs -- and lost the touch of his backhand and his interest in the condition of the turf at Forest Hills.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 23 -- A mutiny in the Greek fleet which, according to an official British naval communique, had lasted three weeks, was partly quelled last night when Greek officers and men, acting under orders from their Commander in Chief, Vice Admiral Petros Voulgaris, boarded three warships and, after some fighting, assumed control.

The Canadian free dollar moved irregularly lower last week, slipping from 90.38 cents at the outset to 90.12 cents at the close, for a loss of 1/8 cent from the preceding week. Several of the South American currencies also sagged, but all other descriptions remained firm.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday in his weekly broadcast from City Hall that he hoped to be able to make public next Sunday a plan of health insurance for persons in the middle-income brackets. The special committee named by him a year ago to prepare such a plan has filed its report, the Mayor said, and it will be made public after a few "refinements."

Your editorial entitled "Mrs. Kelly's Doorstep" in the April 11 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES has been brought to my attention. Allow me to compliment you very highly upon this editorial and upon the fine spirit of which it is evidence.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Civilian motorists, some in the lower brackets of essentiality, will soon begin to feel the first effects of the progressing synthetic-tire program as quotas to local ration boards are enlarged to follow the increases in production.

Relatively little change was shown in prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange last week, although they moved over a somewhat wider trading range than in recent weeks. At the close on Saturday active futures were unchanged to 20 points lower for the week.

HAVING returned recently from a tour of the Western clubs, this correspondent was slightly aghast to see the way the mail had piled up in his absence. Many letters had to do with topics almost forgotten but by casting aside those which had become outdated some choice nuggets remained. Here are a few:

Sixteen new exhibitions will open in the local art galleries this week. Both group and one-man shows are included with all of the work being in oil and water-color. In addition, the Brooklyn Museum will open on Thursday an exhibition of French fashion sketches from 1919 to 1940.

Attention is drawn in a recently published book to the extent to which the syndicated newspaper columnists have succeeded to the place once held by "personal" journalism of another day. News columns today carry many a by-line, and the world is efficiently covered by these signed stories.

The Rev. Dr. Donald B. Aldrich, rector of the Episcopal Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue at Tenth Street, now a Chaplain in the Navy, in a sermon at the evening services yesterday, urged union of the Protestant Episcopal and Presbyterian Churches.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period April 15 to 21 are given in the appended tabulation:

A twenty-to-thirty-mile ride every week-end or a vacation round trip to a place no more than 200 miles from home is all the pleasure driving that the average motorist, with a basic gasoline ration, is likely to do in the summer of 1944, provided he uses his automobile for no other purpose.

CHUNGKING, China, April 21 (Delayed) -- When Maj. D.T. Cowen of Columbus, Ga., swings around from his desk full of operational reports he sees something that makes him feel very fine indeed. He sees a row of early scarlet globe radishes obligingly springing out of the ground -- no doubt somewhat surprised to find themselves in China.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Treasury announced today an offering through the Federal Reserve Banks of 7/8 per cent Treasury certificates of indebtedness of Series D 1945, open on an exchange basis, par for par, to holders of certificates of Series C, 1944, maturing May 1. No cash subscriptions will be received.
