The Eastern contingent for the May 6 running of the Kentucky Derby narrowed to eight or nine yesterday as horsemen reviewed the performances of their horses in Saturday's Wood Memorial at Jamaica and the Sagamore Purse at Pimlico.

LONDON, April 23 -- A plan for international post-war settlement that will probably be adopted by the Labor party, Britain's second largest, proposed today that the beginnings of a single international armed force should be made "as soon as the war ends."

The Rev. Russell F. Auman, pastor of St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Fifty-fourth Street and Lexington Avenue, stressed the need in his sermon, yesterday of building up spiritual forces to form a better world. He declared most of the modern world is spiritually impoverished.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 23 (AP) -- Senator Claude Pepper and his four opponents have made his outspoken support of most of the Roosevelt Administration's objectives the chief issue in the May 2 Florida Democratic Senatorial nomination race.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -A big-scale gamble to knock China out of the war and cut American bombers off from bases threatening the Japanese homeland is the most authoritatively supported interpretation here of the Japanese drive on Chengchow.

Americans in all sections of the country are grimly intent on winning the war, and are determined to let nothing stand in the way of attaining victory as speedily as possible, according to publishers who are in New York for the annual meeting of The Associated Press today and the fifty-eighth annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association on the three succeeding days.
The urgent need of the present is not alone for a new world organization but for a new spirit on which to build it, Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick declared yesterday in his sermon in Riverside Church.

The Italian front was quiet in most sectors yesterday. The armies of both sides, exhausted by months of unremitting effort and the rigors of winter war in the Apennines, rested on their arms, probably preparing for new operations in Italy that spring and the invasion of western Europe are certain to induce.

Vivian Rivkin, piano, and Eudice Shapiro, violin, gave a joint recital last night in Carnegie Hall. The two young American artists, favorably known in this city through former appearances, pooled their talents in several of the offerings on the varied program, and also were heard separately in the course of the evening.

Harry Kaufman, pianist, made one of his infrequent appearances in recital at Town Hall last night. Mr. Kaufman, who is widely known as an ensemble player, provided an evening of music which was characterized by bravura playing of bravura pieces.

Every garden should have a tree near by. A tall tree with broad bole and spreading branches, preferably with branches that start well down the trunk or with a low crotch from which a boy might climb. A tree which spreads its roots where it springs from the earth, firm-based and strong against the storms.

With retail trade increasing considerably, indicating an end to the post-Easter lull, buyers continued to arrive in the New York market in large numbers last week to place orders for fall clothing and furnishings wherever lines were open, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

The New York City Newspapers Wastepaper Salvage Committee yesterday commended school children for scouring cellars, attics and buildings in their neighborhoods for waste paper and bringing it to their schools for delivery to the mills.

United States tariffs, contrary to opinion recently expressed in many quarters, are actually among the lowest of the world's trading nations, according to the findings of a study made public yesterday by the American Tariff League, with offices at 19 West Forty-fourth Street.

NAPLES, April 23 (AP) -- America must help devastated Italy in her task of reconstruction, according to Crown Prince Humbert, who is scheduled to take over the royal powers as his father's lieutenant general when the Allies enter Rome.

PITTSBURGH, April 23 -- Technical Sgt. Charles E. (Commando) Kelly is back in this country on furlough after winning the Congressional Medal of Honor in Italy, but his mother, Mrs. Irene Kelly, says that she will "believe it when I hear from Charles."

Nowhere will international cooperation be more imperative after the war than with regard to national monetary systems and stable exchanges. Unfortunately, the proposal now announced for an $8,000,000,000 international stabilization fund misconceives the real nature of the problem to be solved.
ABOARD A UNITED STATES CARRIER -- It was too hot for a long speech. This baby flat-top had just headed for enemy waters. On the flight deck it was 101 degrees. In the engine room it was 110.

GEOPOLITICS, in the mind of its originator, Sir Halford Mackinder, was a method of studying geography and power politics so as to find out the best way of preserving the interests of the British Empire. In the mind of its most infamous master, Gen. Karl Haushofer of Munich and the Hitler brain trust, geopolitics is a justification of and blueprint for German world conquest.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Monday, April 24 -- With many warships of the mighty United States Fleet protecting the landing by pouring shells on the beaches, Gen. Douglas MacArthur hurled large forces ashore along a 150-mile stretch of northern New Guinea early on Saturday, cutting off the Japanese Eighteenth Army, estimated to number 60,000 men.

Under the critical eyes of three detectives a calm, 40-year-old house painter jimmied his way into the fashionable home of Prince and Princess Serge Belosselsky-Belozersky at 124 East Sixty-second Street at 9:30 P.M. Saturday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- The National Football League announced a ten-game schedule for each club, opening next Sept. 17 and closing Dec. 10, as the league's six-day meeting finally ended late today.

LONDON, April 23 -- The Boy Scout of 18, who accompanied Sir Ernest Shackleton's last voyage in the Quest -- now Lieut. Comdr. J.W.S. Marr of the Royal Naval Volunteer Reserve -- is back in the Antarctic leading the most secret expedition of discovery ever to leave Britain.

CHICAGO, April 23 (AP) -- Twenty-five hundred striking employes of the Pullman Standard Car Company's ordnance plant in Hammond, Ind., remained away from their jobs today, despite an order from the War Labor Board to resume production pending negotiations with the management.

A start in the organization of a new political party, probably to be known as the Liberal party, was announced yesterday by Dean Alfange, chairman of the Liberal and Labor Committee and former nominee of the American Labor party for Governor.

J. Lawrence Bacon, general superintendent of the Millville (N.J.) plant of Armstrong Cork Company, has been appointed consulting engineer, effective May 1. Mr. Bacon will assist the research, engineering and production organization in general glass development.

A survey of dry goods wholesalers in the Mountain and Pacific States shows that they enjoyed the widest gross margins and best rates of net profit on sales despite a slow inventory turnover, according to data released yesterday. The survey was undertaken by Dun Bradstreet for the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute, Inc.

LONDON, April 23 -- The widening campaign on behalf of some thirty Jewish soldiers who were recently imprisoned for attempting to leave the Polish Army, in which, they said, they had been subjected to anti-Semitism, began to assume an international character today.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (U.P.) -- Maritime Commission sources disclosed tonight that increasing numbers of C-2 cargo ships had been ordered converted to troop carriers, presumably for use in forthcoming invasions.

Efforts of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., to prevent unlisted trading in the Kentucky Utilities Company's 4 per cent bonds on the New York Curb Exchange are regarded in Wall Street largely as a boomerang since the text of the decision of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals in Philadelphia, handed down last week, has been received and studied.

LONDON, April 23 -- Thousands of British glider and parachute troops have completed one of the biggest and most dramatic maneuvers yet held in cooperation with the Royal Air Force and the American troops, who, like them, are poised for the invasion of western Europe, it was disclosed tonight.

The Allied landings at Aitape and Hollandia, announced last night by General MacArthur, mark the beginning of the end of the New Guinea campaign and set the stage for the Battle of the Philippines, Establishment of an air base at Hollandia -- and that should come in short order, as the enemy had a good one there that needs only repairing -- brings Mindanao within the range of Allied bombers.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, April 24 (UP) -- A communique:

NAPLES, April 23 (AP) -- Operating from new Corsican bases within 100 miles of the German-held Italian coast, American medium bombers blasted the San Stefano harbor and rail targets on the Rome-Florence line yesterday in continuation of the Allies' air offensive against German communications.
A gift for post-war construction of a research laboratory at Mount Sinai Hospital was announced yesterday by Waldemar Kops, its acting president.

NEWARK, N. J., April 23 -- With the young widow of the hero for whom the ship was named officiating, the destroyer escort vessel Charles E. Brannon was launched this morning at the yards of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, Port Newark.

The New Opera Company, of which Yolanda Mero-Irion is general manager, presents this evening at the Alvin Theatre "Helen Goes to Troy," the latter-day version of the famous Offenbach operetta, "La Belle Helene." Jarmila Novotna, Czech soprano of the Metropolitan, will sing the title role and Ernest Truex will essay the leading comedy part, that of Menelaus.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 23 (AP) -- Allied counter-measures, possibly a restriction on the valuable safe-conduct for Swedish imports, appeared likely today in view of Sweden's rejection of a request by the United States that Sweden halt the flow of ball bearings and machinery to Germany.

Terming the issue of Palestine the yardstick of the rights of small nations to security after the war, Senator Styles Bridges of New Hampshire called last night for a "clear enunciation by America of a just and workable foreign policy."

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, April 23 -- The backstop was made from a camouflage net. The bases were sandbags. The setting was the placid Italian countryside, with even a flock of sheep to lend a pastoral touch. Yet just beyond the mountainous horizon were German guns -- and the players did not have to see them to know they were there, because the sounds were unmistakable.

PITTSBURGH, April 23 -- Order volume in the steel industry last week was higher than ever. Some companies reported new business running 8 to 10 per cent ahead of that of a month ago and one was said to show bookings about 20 per cent larger than at this time last year.
LONDON, April 23 (UP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 23 -- Herbert Marshall has signed with Paramount to star with Joel McCrea and Gail Russell in "Fear," based on Ethel Lina White's mystery novel, "Her Heart in Her Throat," Production will begin May 8, under the direction of Lewis Allen.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Emphasizing the enormous strategic and material gains made by the United States Navy since the beginning of the war, when, he frankly admitted, it was powerless to launch an offensive, Admiral Ernest J. King declared in an unprecedented report, made public tonight, that the future is "as dark and threatening to Japan as it is full of promise to us" and that "the encirclement of Germany is in sight."

The first full story from the Navy of the first of the great night surface battles off Savo Island during the Solomons campaign, the battle of Aug. 9, 1942, is given by Admiral Ernest J. King in his report to Secretary Knox on the conduct of his command during the first twenty-seven and a half months of the war.

The first great battle of the air was fought over England in 1940-41. History will probably rank that defeat of the Luftwaffe with the Battle of the Marne in the First World War. The second major battle of the air is still in progress. It is being fought for control of the air over western Europe.

CLEVELAND, April 23 (AP) -- Hank Miller, rookie catcher, pulled the second game of a double-header out of the loss column for the Detroit Tigers today with a home run that accounted for three scores as the Tigers defeated the Cleveland Indians, 4 to 3.

Prompt action now in reconversion from wartime to peacetime production to avoid widespread unemployment, unnecessary shortages in civilian goods when the war ends, and black markets was urged in a statement made public yesterday by eight leading economists who have joined together as the Economists Committee on Reconversion Problems.

When I was a little girl in faraway Sweden I used to listen entranced when my elders talked of that great new country in the West, America. At such times a feeling of wonder pervaded the atmosphere. Could it be true that all men were equal there? That there were no class distinctions, that any individual with talent and perseverance could achieve greatness and wealth?

CHICAGO, April 23 -- Seeding of oats and barley has been delayed seriously by the weather and a reduction of 5 to 10 per cent in the expected acreage of the former grain is regarded as likely unless there is a great change in weather conditions this week.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- Jennings Perry, chairman of the National Committee to Abolish the Poll Tax, made public today a list of fifty Senators, one more than a majority, who, he said, had pledged themselves against the levy. He said that others had taken the same position orally.

A dividend of $2.25 a share for 1943 was announced yesterday by the Union Labor Life Insurance Company, owned by unions of the American Federation of Labor and other labor organizations, through Matthew Woll, president of the company and vice president of the AFL.

CHICAGO, April 23 -- A sharp break last week in prices for hogs incident to the withdrawal of Government support on offerings weighing more than 270 pounds and a lessened demand for pork products for lend-lease purposes gave the markets for lard and cured meats an easier undertone.

WINDSOR, Ont., April 23 -- An estimated 10,000 strikers of the Ford Motor Company of Canada, Ltd., crowded the Windsor City Market this afternoon to hear two members of the Ontario Parliament and Mayor Arthur Reaume of Windsor urge them to continue their strike, which started last Thursday after the company had declared void its contract with the UAW-CIO.

The influence of William Cardinal O'Connell extended far beyond the church which so signally honored him. Mourned by Catholics, Protestants and Jews alike, he was recognized not only as a great prince of the church but as a leading figure in the contemporary life of New England and the nation. He combined the prelate and the patriot.

CHICAGO, April 23 -- Heroes, complete with medals, were being made in Highwood, Ill., for $3.50 a hero without the discomfort of a boat ride or the danger of battle, according to Pfc. William Zack, editor of a Fort Sheridan weekly newspaper.
ST. LOUIS, April 23 (AP) -- The Browns ran their winning streak to six today by taking a double triumph, 5 to 2 and 4 to 3, over the White Sox.

LONDON, April 23 (AP) -- In a taunting sweep to bait the Luftwaffe during today's operations, United States Ninth Air Force Mustangs and Thunderbolts ranged the Continent from the Netherland coast to Bremen and the Ruhr Valley for almost four hours without finding a single German plane aloft.

The report of Admiral King, Commander in Chief of the United States Fleet and Chief of Naval Operations, presents a record of magnificent achievement of which the Navy and the country can be justly proud. Beginning the war in weakness and disaster, the Navy has grown mightily in size and strength beyond what either friend or foe believed possible.
Elsie Madsen, 15 years old, pupil of David Zalish, gave a piano recital last night at New York Times Hall. Her first recital was given five years ago at the Carnegie Chamber Music Hall.

WITH UNITED STATES ARMY FORCES AT AITAPE, NEW GUINEA, April 22 (Delayed) (AP) -- Under cover of a furious naval barrage and carrier-launched bombardment, swift-moving troops quickly occupied two island's off Babelsberg Strait preceding the drive on Aitape.

LONDON, Monday, April 24 (AP) -- A Crimean dispatch said yesterday the Red Army had captured a summit overlooking besieged Sevastopol, while the conviction grew in Moscow, London, and even in Berlin that re-formed Russian armies on the Polish-Rumanian fronts soon would launch another offensive, perhaps coordinated with Allied lunges in the west and south.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- The question whether some proposals on the agenda of the twenty-sixth session of the International Labor Conference might, if approved, interfere with national sovereignty will furnish part of the discussion at the two-day plenary sessions which begin tomorrow.

Fritz Kreisler, violinist, will be the soloist, and Sir Thomas Beecham will conduct the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the opening performance of the twenty-seventh season of Lewisohn Stadium Concerts on Monday night, June 19.

Charity is the outstanding quality of the spirit and heart that will help believers to bring other souls to God, the Rev. Michael J. Deacy declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. He scored the "smug complacency of the faithful who make no effort to share the priceless possession of faith."

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, April 23 -- Air-borne troops have captured the jade center of Lonkin in the course of their attacks on Japanese communications in North Burma while in eastern India the defeated besiegers of Kohima have fallen back to regroup, it was disclosed tonight.

Mayor La Guardia urged New York City consumers yesterday to stage a one-day boycott of fish today as the market struggles to move phenomenal hauls of 2,000,000 pounds that arrived here over the week-end.

Held to an even position for forty moves until adjournment time, Arnold S. Denker of Forest Hills, champion of the Manhattan Club, finally defeated Weaver W. Adams of Boston in the eighth round of the United States chess championship at the Hotel Park Central yesterday.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

LONDON, April 23 -- American and British air forces have at last turned the corner of their long and desperate battle to knock the Luftwaffe out of the skies and are within sight of victory. The Germans, who converted their aircraft construction from bombers to fighters in a confidence bred of their own defeat in the Battle of Britain that fighters were the answer to the Allied bombing, are losing another gamble.

CHICAGO, April 23 -- Continued favorable weather and crop comments from the winter wheat area and a belief that the Department of Agriculture's coming estimate of the crop will show an increase of 25,000,000 bushels or more over the 602,000,000 bushels indicated on April 1 are having considerable effect as price-making influences in the market for that grain.
A rare occasion in court tennis -- the appearance in the court of the world champion, Pierre Etchebaster -- is offered today at the Racquet and Tennis Club on Park Avenue.

LONDON, April 23 -- Not enough time has elapsed for the City to express any considered comment on the international monetary plan published at the week-end, but the first reactions appear to be favorable. It clearly is a compromise between the White and Keynes plans, making good use of both and proposing what certainly are drastic amendments.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 23 -- The Rumanian Government -- apparently on German inspiration -- has sent a strongly worded protest to Ankara, demanding the release for passage into the Black Sea through the Dardanelles of two Rumanian passenger ships at present in Istanbul, the Transylvania and the Bukovina, which the Turkish Government has just refused, according to direct information from Bucharest received here tonight.

A program of physical preparedness in which cooperation of the Selective Service and various State boards of education will be requested was put forth at the meeting of the National Boxing Association, which ended a two-day session at the Hotel Moritz yesterday.

Frank C. Walker has been Postmaster General of the United States since Sept. 11, 1940, but he still has a hard time convincing people that James A. Farley no longer is in charge of the nation's mail delivery.
A communique, as broadcast yesterday from Ckungking in English to the United States and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, April 23 (U.P.) -- Senator Tom Connally of Texas, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, asserted tonight that the Senate rule requiring a two-thirds vote for treaty ratification was essential to a stable foreign policy and that he would fight any and all attempts to abolish it.

Seven out of every ten war marriages are "headed for trouble," Eduard C. Lindeman, Professor of Social Philosophy at the New York School of Social Work, said yesterday at its fifth annual scholarship meeting under the auspices of the Harlem committee of the Community Service Society in Riverside Church.
BERNE, Switzerland, April 23 -More reprisals were foreshadowed in Vichy today by Joseph Darnand, Secretary for the Maintenance of Order.

Six billion dollars' worth of aviation represents a lot of aircraft -- how much can be judged from the fact that planes range from $10,000 trainers to $250,000 heavy bombers. And six billions in airplanes is what the ferrying division of our Air Transport Command has delivered from American assembly lines to battlefronts clear around the globe.

CHUNGKING, China, April 23 (AP) -- Sanguinary fighting in the suburbs and on two sides of Chengchow, where the Lung-Hai and Peiping-Hankow railways once crossed to form a strategic junction, was announced by the Chinese today, with the Japanese apparently making progress in their aim of loosening the Chinese grip on another leg of North China's communications.

Net income of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation for the first quarter of 1944 amounted to $9,009,071, equal to 97 cents a share on 9,277,788 shares of stock, comparing with $9,382,021, or $1.01 a share, in the first quarter of 1943.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 23 -- Turkey's stoppage of chrome shipments to the Axis not only is a victory for the American State Department but also is a most important challenge to Germany. Turkey's action is a jolt to Germany's prestige the world over and represents, in part at least, the result of many months of inconspicuous, untiring effort by Ambassador Laurence A. Steinhardt to persuade the Turks to throw in their lot with the Allies.
This article is the fifth in a series on the results of a food-rationing survey conducted by this department. The sixth and last article will appear tomorrow.

The metropolitan area, taking in New York City and seventeen other counties in New York State, New Jersey and Connecticut, is inadequately prepared to meet post-war problems and needs of the communities, the Regional Plan Association declared yesterday in a bulletin urging the towns to set up planning boards with authority and funds to act effectively.
Four film openings are listed for the week along Broadway. The schedule follows:

LONDON, Monday, April 24 -- On the seventh day of the greatest sustained air offensive the world has even known, seemingly unending streams of Allied planes shuttled back and forth yesterday between Britain and the Continent, blasting the military installations and traffic centers of western Europe that are the backbone of Hitler's defenses against impending invasion.

The peace of the world for many generations will depend at first upon the closest cooperation among the United States, Russia and the British Commonwealth, the Archbishop of York declared last night at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., April 23 -- Pat O'Gorman today sailed his boat, Felix, into the national dinghy championship, winding up with a remarkable 200 points, only 9 off a clear sweep of a perfect score. The series ended today with two more sessions at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

LONDON, April 23 (AP) -- Marshal Tito threw his hard-pressed Yugoslav Partisans into the paths of three new German offensives and threw back two of them altogether, although forced to yield the town of Sahovici in Montenegro for the second time this week, a Partisan communique reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- President Roosevelt today set Tuesday noon as the deadline by which Montgomery Ward Co., which has refused to comply with an order by the National War Labor Board, and the company's union employes, who are on strike, must take initial steps which he laid down for the settlement of their dispute.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- A detailed picture of the Navy's part in the landings by our forces in North Africa in the winter of 1942, including the names of the naval craft that participated in that successful operation, was given by Admiral King in his exhaustive report on the Navy in the war.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The construction miracle accomplished by the United States industrial machine in building our Navy to its present strength, including the metamorphosis of a fifty-acre cornfield into a producing turbo-electric propulsion machinery plant in eight months, is described by Admiral King in laudatory terms in his report to Secretary Knox.
The Board of Education has failed to offer any substantial aid in combating juvenile delinquency, it was charged yesterday by a city legislator and a group of students from the city schools.

SEATTLE, April 23 -- The Liberty ship John Straub, laden with explosives for the Alaska war theatre, broke its back and sank with a presumed loss of sixty-five of the eighty men aboard, E.M. Murphy, superintendent of the Alaska Steamship Company, announced today.

The first adult education scholarship to be given to a foreign student by Teachers College, Columbia University, has been awarded to Ellwood Hsin-pao Yang, junior agricultural attache to the Chinese Embassy in Washington, Dr. Milton C. Del Manzo, provost of the college, announced yesterday. Scholarships and fellowships to students from fifteen States and Canada also were announced.

NAPLES, April 23 -- The Wiener Neustadt plant thirty miles south of Vienna, which is said to have been turning out more single-engined fighters for the Luftwaffe than any other works in Europe, was pounded again today by strong formations of heavy bombers of the United States Fifteenth Air Force escorted by American fighters.
LONDON, April 23 (AP) -- Following is the text of a joint statement by the British Air Ministry and the United States Strategic Air Forces:

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The 17,000,000 women now in the labor market must have more community services if they are to be kept on the job, Miss Mary Anderson, Director of the Women's Bureau, warned yesterday on the basis of a bureau survey of thirty-seven warindustry communities.

Black markets and their customers were denounced yesterday by Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, at the seventh annual communion breakfast of the St. George Association of the Fire Department at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The health of the Navy has been excellent, treatment and prevention of battle casualties have become progressively better and air evacuation of sick and wounded from forward areas has increased the efficiency of treatment by one-third, Admiral Ernest J. King said today in his report on the Navy and the war.

It would seem as if the most logical solution of the subway fare problem would be to charge 10 cents on express trains. It is only reasonable that people having a faster and generally longer ride should pay more.

CHICAGO, April 23 -- Whitey Kurowski's home run with two on in the sixth inning powered the Cardinals to a 5-to-4 victory over the Cubs today in the second game of a double-header after the National League champions had walloped the Chicagoans, 11 to 3, in the opener.
Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices was 112.82, a drop of 0.1 per cent from the previous week's level of 112.96.

Adventure -- in the shape of a bus that was taking on a load of shipyard workers -- beckoned to a couple of 5-year-olds, Thomas Quinn and Daniel Hellems, in their native Hoboken, N.J., early Saturday morning. The result was an uninterrupted twenty-four hours of worry to their respective parents, one a policeman.

Thousands of homeless were being cared for by the Red Cross today throughout Missouri and Kansas as weather bureaus in the area hopefully predicted that the rivers bulging from their banks would begin to fall by Wednesday if the rains subsided, The Associated Press reported yesterday.
Discussing post-war problems, one expert in Japanese affairs exclaimed almost hopelessly: "The peculiar Japanese qualities will exist even after the most crushing defeat of the Nipponese."

BOSTON, April 23 -- A tract of 6,000 donums, about 1,320 acres, has been acquired in Palestine through the Jewish National Fund of New England for the settlement of 600 Jewish families now facing danger in Hungary and Rumania.

Officials of the American Guild of Variety Artists will carry their plea for Congressional action in reducing the present 30 per cent cabaret tax direct to the House Ways and Means Committee in Washington tomorrow, Matt Shelvey, national administrative director of AGVA, said last night.

On the Stock Exchange last week trading was light, falling nearly to 500,000 shares on Monday and Thursday, though there was a one-million-share day on Tuesday, when speculators sold. Prices were lower. Beyond reiteration of plans for invasion of the European continent later on, there was little military news.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -Prime Minister John Curtin of Australia and Mrs. Curtin arrived in Washington today, and, following a brief reception at the Union Station by Secretary Hull, Lord Halifax, the British Ambassador, and other dignitaries, spent the day quietly in preparation for the series of conferences and social engagements in their honor beginning tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The American Communications Association (CIO), union of telegraph workers, today made public a protest to the Board of War Communications against a request of the Western Union Telegraph Company for permission to resume transmission of congratulatory telegrams.

BOSTON, April 23 (AP) -- Jim Tobin's sparkling one-hitter gave the Braves their initial victory of the season as they defeated the Phillies, 5 to 0, in the first game of a double header today, but in the nightcap they lapsed into their old ways and were blanked, 3 to 0.

NAPLES, April 23 (U.P.) -- The British light cruisers Spartan and Penelope and the destroyers Janus and Laforey sank in flames under a shower of German bombs during the establishment of the Anzio beachhead, it was disclosed tonight in a naval summary of the campaign.

Time, effort and money can be saved through the use of advertising-type presentations which conform to high agency standards by Government officials and others who appear before Congressional committees, advertising men point out.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Admiral Ernest J. King reported tonight that Nazi submarines in the Atlantic had been reduced from a "menace" to a "problem," while our submarines in the Pacific are seriously threatening the Japanese.

LONDON, April 23 -- Soaring currency circulation in all countries has become such a commonplace that it arouses little public comment here, while even in official circles the alarm that was expressed some time ago at the rapidly mounting circulation in Great Britain appears to have completely subsided.

PEARL HARBOR, April 24 -- Swiftly striking planes launched by Pacific Fleet carriers destroyed an even 100 Japanese aircraft and damaged another seventeen in attacks on three enemy airfields preparatory to the landings Saturday at Hollandia, Aitape and Tanahmera Bay by forces under General MacArthur, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- These awards have been made to personnel of the Eighth Bomber Command and the Eighth Fighter Command stationed in England:

NAPLES, April 24 (U.P.) -- Allied and German forces exchanged another sharp thrust-and-parry on the tensing right flank of the Anzio beachhead and waves of Royal Air Force Liberators pounded Italian west coast supply harbors throughout last night, it was announced today.

LONDON, April 24 (U.P.) -- Marshal Tito today joined the Allied campaign to throttle Germany's war industry with a broadcast appeal to Yugoslav miners and railway workers to sabotage the flow of chrome ore to the Reich, thereby cutting off the enemy's last main supply source of the mineral essential to the manufacture of armor plate.

LONDON, April 24 -- Gold mining issues were marked up on today's stock markets here, following publication of the new monetary proposals but the best prices were not maintained in all cases. Other sections of the markets generally were quiet but a firm tone was seen throughout.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The United States Civil Service Commission has rejected 1,011 persons in the Federal service in the last four years because of doubts as to their loyalty to the Government of the United States, Arthur S. Flemming, Civil Service Commissioner, disclosed tonight.
LONDON, April 24 (Reuter) -- Two German generals who were directing operations against men of the Maquis -- France's underground army -- in the Ain Department have been captured by French patriots.

Pierre Etchebaster, the world open court tennis champion, gave a demonstration of his rare skill in the ancient game of kings for the benefit of the Red Cross yesterday and convinced his opponents that, if anything, he is better than ever, sixteen years after he first won the crown.
When is a treaty not a treaty?

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- In pursuit of the Government's policy to relax restrictions on foreign trade operations to permit pre-war practices when the progress of the war justifies it, the War Shipping Administration announced a simplified procedure which will govern exporters in their booking of civilian commodity exports to Latin America.

An organization known as The Escholiers took over the Shubert Theatre yesterday afternoon to offer an experimental production of "War President," by Nat Sherman. A drama about Lincoln and his relationships with his Cabinet, the politicians, General McClellan and others, it went on under the auspices of the Experimental Theatre, created by Equity and the Dramatists Guild to give players and playwrights a chance "to exhibit their wares."

CHUNGKING, April 24 (U.P.) -- American fliers sank six Japanese ships, including three tankers, in their first attack of the war Saturday on the Saigon area, in southern Indo-China, Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters announced today.

Americans must have been thrilled by the April 13 dispatch of Frank L. Kluckhohn, NEW YORK TIMES correspondent in the South Pacific, reporting the recognition by General MacArthur's headquarters of Capt. Richard Ira Bong as "the American Ace of Aces." For his heroic exploits in shooting down twenty-seven enemy planes so far in this conflict this modest farm lad has truly earned this coveted title.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today set May 8 for a hearing on proposals by the New Mexico Public Service Company and Highland Utilities Company to sell properties as a step in the liquidation of their parent, North Continent Utilities Corporation.

DETROIT, April 24 -- Chester Bowles, the OPA administrator, declared today that this country must decide now that deflation of the present price and wage structure will not be permitted after the war, and that it will be necessary to protect prices and wages to prevent disastrous deflation during reconversion.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- High praise for American leadership and fighting qualities in the southwest Pacific campaign against Japan was expressed at a press conference today by Prime Minister John Curtin of Australia.

One of the major problems that the United States will face at the end of the war will be that of using or disposing of the vast fleet of merchant ships built under the emergency shipbuilding program at a cost of about $16,000,000,000, according to the Guaranty Trust Company, in the current issue of the Guaranty Survey.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The War Production Board revoked a two-week-old directive forbidding expansion of civilian production in tight labor areas today with the explanation that the order, which was in the form of "a staff memorandum," was essentially "a trial balloon."
KANDY, Ceylon, April 24 (UP) -- A communique:

KANDY, Ceylon, April 24 -- Substantial Allied air-borne reinforcements have been landed more than 200 miles inside Burma by Col. Philip Cochran's American Air Commando force and joined thousands of other Chindits in tearing the core out of the enemy's central Burma supply system, it was disclosed today.

The report for 1943 of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $121,327,773 after charges, taxes, reserves and a provision of $6,000,000 for post-war contingencies. The net was equal to $4.45 each on the 27,283,587 capital shares.

Technical Sgt. Kurt J. Hermann 2d has the signature of another general. Anyone familiar with the history of the Army sergeant, who hitchhiked his way home by air from North Africa with the aid of a furlough order signed by Lieut. Gen. James H. Doolittle, knows that a written word from a general means adventure for Sergeant Hermann.

Shelby McCracken, 40 years old, of 148-05 Sixtieth Avenue, Flushing, Queens, was killed and two other men received injuries requiring hospitalization when a hit-and-run driver ran his auto through a crowd standing in the rain at 148th Street and Horace Harding Boulevard, Flushing, Queens, at 6 P.M. yesterday.

The two-story factory building on a plot 83 by 170 feet at 828-34 Main Avenue, corner of Chestnut Street, in Passaic, N.J., has been sold by the Fidelity Union Trust Company of Newark, as trustee, to the Central Realty Holding Company.

LONDON, Tuesday, April 25 -- American aerial gunners knocked 103 German aircraft out of the skies when an armada of close to 2,000 of our warplanes hammered Luftwaffe factories at Friedrichshafen and airfields in the Munich region yesterday.
Despite increased Government requirements of canned fruits for 1944, a 5 to 10 per cent increase in the supply available for civilian use was predicted by canners yesterday.

The first of a series of three fashion shows sponsored by the Millinery Fashion Bureau was held yesterday at the Monte Carlo Restaurant. Different exhibitors will be represented at each of the shows. Those who showed yesterday were Peg Fischer, Florence Reichman and Laddie Northridge.

Sixty questions, determined by a poll of publishers of small dailies in all sections of the country, have been selected for discussion at the opening sessions of the fifty-eighth annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, meeting at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria today and continuing through Thursday.
WINDSOR, Ont., April 24 -- An offer by the Ford Motor Company of Canada, Ltd., to enter into negotiations for a new agreement was rejected today by officials of the United Automobile Workers, CIO.
I read your fine editorial on the subject of dogtooth violets. I was surprised at the idea of an editor writing about a violet. Not only surprised but pleased.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 24 -- Enlarged consumer incomes and the absence of durable goods have caused a 51 per cent reduction in the volume of consumer credit since Sept. 1, 1941, J. Gordon Dakins, manager and research director, credit management division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, declared today.

Again Finland has refused terms of peace with Russia. Moscow is surprised and annoyed. In other United Nations capitals there is keen disappointment. Before the present war Finland and the Finnish people were popular in this country. Like Sweden they seemed to have found a democratic "middle way" in some respects ahead of our own and the British systems of democracy.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (U.P.) -- The State Department regards post-war ownership of lend-lease air bases as relatively unimportant but will insist that United States airlines have access to them on equal terms with any other country, it was disclosed tonight.

Capture by air-borne troops of the Lonkin mines in northern Burma was announced Sunday. They are the source of the most beautiful specimens of jade. Chinese jade-carving goes back to the eleventh century B.C., but the emerald green jadeite from the Mogaung district in Upper Burma began to be imported into China just at the opening of the period of elaborate carving called K'ien Lung, beginning in 1644.

WITH CANADIAN FORCES IN ENGLAND, April 24 -- Canada's youthful army of veterans has finished its pre-invasion training and is primed to avenge that August day of 1942 with the grim battle cry, "Remember Dieppe!"

An underwriting group headed jointly by Eastman, Dillon Co. and McDonald-Coolidge Co. will offer today 20,000 shares of Cornell-Dubilier Electric Corporation no-par $5.25 cumulative Series A preferred stock at $100 a share.

It must be said that no one in the steel industry or close to it anticipated the perfect score of 100 per cent of capacity to be set this week, although by coincidence exactly the same thing happened exactly a year ago, in the same week.

Mel Ott, playing manager of the Giants, who is married, the father of two children and who reached his thirty-fifth birthday last month, yesterday passed his pre-induction physical examination at Camden, N.J., and was assigned to the Army.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- The creation of an international labor committee with power to make decisions binding upon the member governments was urged today by J.A. Easley, Australian Government delegate to the conference of the International Labor Organizations, as a means of stabilizing high levels of employment throughout the world after the war.

The three-day conference of the Association of National Advertisers, Inc., at the Westchester Country Club, Rye, N.Y., beginning Monday, May 1, will review the fundamentals of advertising administration and re-examine advertising practices in the light of wartime and post-war developments.

BOSTON, April 24 (AP) -- The Harvard crew which rowed to victory at the Henley regatta on the Thames in England thirty years ago will observe the anniversary of that event by pulling a shell on a Charles River course on May 13, Gov. Leverett Saltonstall, a member of that crew, announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- Protesting against what he termed the "unjust treatment of Jewish soldiers in the Polish Army," Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat, of New York, wrote to the Polish Ambassador today that many Americans "are outraged by the proceedings."

Establishment of a hostel in the Brooklyn Heights residential section for the relocation of Japanese-American evacuees was protested yesterday by 136 tenants and property owners in a petition to Representative John J. Delaney in a telegram to the War Relocation Authority.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, April 24 -- Netherland New Guinea, where the first Netherland territory to be recaptured from the Axis is situated, is believed to be rich in petroleum deposits. How these are to be developed raises an interesting international problem.

The text of the annual report of the board of directors of The Associated Press, which was approved unanimously by the membership at its annual meeting at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, follows:

BERNE, Switzerland, April 24 -In Vichy today Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain had a birthday -- his eighty-eighth. There was practically no observance of the event beyond the issuance of a new postage stamp bearing his picture. Petain, like Vichy, belongs to the past, and the future is elsewhere.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Eulogies of the late Cardinal O'Connell of Boston Were voiced today on the floor of the House by Majority Leader John iVfcCormack and iVfrs. Edith Nourse Rogers, both of his home State of Massachusetts, and by Repisentative i Adolph ft. Sabath of Illinois, dean of the House membership.

The scanty arrays of new lamps and shades to be found in the stores -- resulting both from restrictions on materials and labor shortages -- have sent many a would-be buyer to attics and junk shops for potential lamp bases and salvageable frames.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- High strategy determined at Quebec last August, secret plans laid in hotel rooms here without any organization committed to paper, removal of a heterogeneous air force to India, and finally the first crashing, helter-skelter landings of gliders on a dark, gully-pitted and un-surveyed flat in Burma -- ironically named Broadway.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Senate voted today, 38 to 28, against reconsidering its approval in January of legislation to give exclusive use of the "Red Cross" name and emblem in this country to the American Red Cross after July 1, 1950.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decrease of 2 per cent for the week ended April 22, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week the Bank had reported a decline of 10 per cent.

A double-barreled exhibition of American portraits opened-yesterday. This event should perhaps be referred to as two exhibitions, since the painting are installed Knoedler's, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street, and at Portraits Incorporated, 460 Park Avenue.

The city's fourth annual celebration of I Am an American Day will be held Sunday, May 21, on the Mall in Central Park, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday. Chief Judge Irving Lehman of the State Court of Appeals will administer the oath of allegiance to thousands of new citizens.

Coley Welch, 164, Portland, Me., outpointed Vic Dellicurti, 157 1/4, Harlem, in the feature bout of eight rounds before 2,500 persons at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. The contest was hard fought with Dellicurti's left eye, over which a cut was opened in the initial stanza, a target for Welch throughout the battle.
CHICAGO, April 24 -- A four-day session to determine the National League of Women Voters' program for the next two years opens tomorrow with detegates from thirty-five States.

One of the largest leasing contracts in recent years in the Thirty-fourth Street retail shopping zone was disclosed yesterday when Bond Stores, Inc., announced a long-term lease of large space in the Marbridge Building at the northeast corner of Thirty-fourth Street and Broadway for a new post-war shop.

Using dried eggs and powdered milk in meals cooked on coal stoves in kitchens without refrigerators tests the ingenuity of Army dietitians in hospitals overseas, Lieut. Dorothy M. Brannon of the Army Medical Corps said yesterday. Lieutenant Brannon was flown here from England several weeks ago to sponsor last Sunday a destroyer escort named for her husband, Ensign Charles E. Brannon, Navy flier, killed in the Battle of Midway.

Active participation of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in the Greater New York Fund's 1944 campaign was assured yesterday at a meeting at which an employe solicitation organization was set up under the direction of K.L. Wilkinson, assistant vice president of the company.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Forty-five prospective jurors were relieved of duty today in the sedition trial of thirty defendants here because of fixed opinions after hearing and reading about it. Sixteen others of a venire of eighty-seven remained to be interrogated. Impaneling was delayed thirty-eight minutes while James True, elderly defendant, kept a noon-time dental appointment.

HANS KOHN was born in the Austro-Hungarian Habsburg monarchy, a belated "universalist" state that was destined to sunder on the rock of particularist nationalism. Since his background also includes participation in the Zionist student movement and a long, close study of the neo-romantic nationalism of German youth before the first World War, it is perhaps only natural that the subject of nationalism has become Professor Kohn's all-absorbing life work.

LOS ANGELES, April 24 -- An informer's suit asking $1,976,000 damages was filed against three contracting firms today, alleging conspiracy to present false claims to the Government in construction of Pearl Harbor defenses.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Court reviews for regulations of the Office of Price Administration and orders of the War Labor Board are called for in suggested amendments to the Emergency Price Control and the Wage Stabilization Acts submitted to the House today by its committee on the investigation of executive agencies.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- A post-war economy of full production and world-distribution is seen by Mrs. Roosevelt as the answer to the problem what to do after the war with great numbers of women in the labor market.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 24 -- A full-scale, Nazi-inspired hate campaign has been turned on American airmen throughout the Balkans as the Axis satellite States reel under the impact of far-flung Allied bombings.

KANDY, Ceylon, April 24 (U.P.) -- Indicating that the second Allied Air Commando landings in Burma were carried out some time ago, official dispatches said that Colonel Cochran conferred with the late Maj. Gen. Orde Charles Wingate, Maj. Gen. W.D.A. Lentaigne's predecessor as commander of the Chindits, during the operations.

CHICAGO, April 24 -- The official announcement that at midnight tonight the Commodity Credit Corporation would become the only lawful buyer of cash corn that leaves farms in 125 designated counties in Indiana, Illinois, Minnesota, Iowa and Nebraska was not a surprise to the grain trade, having been forecast early last week, and had no effect today as a price-making influence.

As a reward for their success in bond selling "commando raids" into Washington night clubs, twelve girls ranging in age from 17 to 24 started a three-day vacation here yesterday. Members of United Nations Girls, a club of 300 young women who either work or attend school in the capital, they told at the Hotel Victoria about their volunteer service for the Treasury and the Red Cross.

Creation of a Governmental or private organization to study the problems of foreign trade, advise American concerns on them and aid or even facilitate the extension of short and long-term credits was urged last night by Egydio Camara de Souza, Brazilian commercial counsellor and director of the Brazilian Government's Trade Bureau.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The War Food Administration today ordered farmers in 125 commercial corn producing counties in the midwest to sell their corn only to the Government in an effort to channel all surplus into war uses. At the same time the WFA appealed to the farmers to sell whatever supplies they may have which are not absolutely essential to their livestock feeding operations.
BRITISH FOURTEENTH ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Burma Front, April 22 (Delayed) -- British forces continued to make steady progress in their counter-attack against the Japanese invaders of Manipur.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (UP) -- A Pacific Fleet announcement:

Twelve hundred and fifty-one prominent Protestant clergymen and laymen from every State in the Union addressed yesterday to President Roosevelt, Congress and the people of the United States an appeal that practical steps be taken immediately to form the nucleus of a general world organization as envisaged in the Moscow Declaration and the Connolly resolution adopted by the Senate.

A new municipal structure that was attacked by Park Commissioner Robert Moses as an example of "horrible modernistic stuff" has been singled out by the Museum of Modern Art as one of the buildings throughout the entire country that best represent progress in design and construction during the last twelve years.
A Chinese communique, as broadcast yesterday from Chungking in English to North America and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 24 -- The Official organ of the Argentine Socialists, The Vanguardia, has been closed by the police for an indeterminate, period as the result of its repeated criticisms of various points of the Government's policy, especially compulsory religious instruction in the schools.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, April 25 (AP) -- A communique:

Six appointments to the faculty of Columbia University were announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, after action by the board of trustees. The changes included the naming of two departmental heads, seven retirements and two resignations.

The bold stroke at Hollandia is like that of a scythe blade through a field of grain. It cuts down everything within its sweep and is also part of a swinging motion threatening what lies immediately beyond. Within the sweep of the blade are 60,000 Japanese troops, now isolated with little hope of rescue, and a whole series of airfields which will ultimately be ours.

The arrest of three more members of an organized ring that printed counterfeit gasoline coupons in Meriden, Conn., and distributed them in New York City, is mminent, it was learned yesterday, as a sequel to the seizure on Saturday in Meriden of a printing plant equipped with paper and ink sufficient to be converted into spurious coupons covering 1,000,000 gallons of gasoline.

Two hundred persons, mostly women, waited impatiently yesterday for the opening of the Eastern States Antiques Fair at the County Center in White Plains. C.J. Nuttall, the manager, said that the fair has attracted greater interest this year than ever before and that he expects the attendance to exceed the 10,000 mark of last year by 25 per cent.

Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, director of the Selective Service System, informed the National War and Peace Fitness Conference at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night that recent changes in standards of acceptability for military service would require a rescreening of large numbers of the 3,600,000 men in the age group 18-38 that have been rejected as physically unfit.
The figure filberts took advantage of today's baseball lull to check up on how the boys performed during the first week of the campaign.

LONDON, April 24 -- The British Government took a final step in safeguarding the security of Anglo-American invasion forces and their plans for an offensive against Western Europe tonight when it announced the suspension of all overseas travel, except on business of national importance, after midnight Thursday.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Sufficient food supplies for all civilian health requirements exist in Great Britain, Canada and the United States but the British diet is greatly restricted, according to a survey by the Combined Food Board.

LONDON, April 24 -- Sweden has replied to the British suggestion that she reduce her exports of iron ore and ball bearings to Germany. The note, which is believed to have contained a courteously worded explanation of why Sweden cannot comply with the British request, is being studied carefully at the Foreign Office and it is expected that the reply will be the subject of discussion among the British, United States and Russian Governments.

Phenomenal shipments of fish continued to pile up in the New York City markets, with the Fishery Council estimating yesterday's receipts at 1,500,000 pounds, duplicating Friday's mark. The latest hauls, mostly of Hudson River shad and salt water mackerel, were in addition to 7,000,000 pounds of fish and shellfish delivered to the New York market last week.

A recent news item in THE NEW YORK TIMES states that about 78 per cent of Americans who go blind are losing their sight from preventable causes. No less an authority than Harry Best in his scholarly work, "The Blind," has emphasized that with the aid of science and education the number of blind can be reduced to at least half the present total.

ALGIERS, April 24 -- Those responsible for the morale of Allied troops in North Africa should consider among other things the merits of cold beer, copiously supplied. It is worthy of the consideration also of those who may be concerned for international relations.

A continuation of trade support and buying of cotton by brokers with New Orleans connections carried prices upward yesterday. Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange at the close were near the best levels of the day, 8 to 12 points higher than Saturday's final prices on active months.

A list of 2,500 jobs that can be filled by persons with physical handicaps has been drawn up here by the United States Civil Service Commission to aid discharged war veterans. This was disclosed yesterday by James E. Rossell, regional director of the commission for New York and New Jersey.

Sale of the fifty-family apartment house at 740 Cauldwell Avenue, northeast corner of 156th Street, featured Bronx realty activity yesterday. The structure, erected in 1930 by the A.J. Schwarzler Company, was sold by the latter to David S. Meister, operator.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, April 25 -- American troops captured the Hollandia township, administrative center of Netherland New Guinea, while other forces driving rapidly forward from the west reached a point five miles from the main Hollandia airstrip, where a battle impends, according to the Allied communique today.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- Chairman Harry S. Truman of Missouri disclosed today the re-opening of the Senate War Investigating Committee's inquiry into newsprint shortages after asserting that the committee was "not satisfied" with the War Production Board's efforts.

LONDON, April 24 -- A Russian charge that Ukrainian and White Russian soldiers in the Polish Army had been tortured after an attempt to quit the Polish forces for the British Army was denied in detail tonight by the press bureau of the Polish forces.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (U.P.) -- Dr. Thomas Parran, Surgeon General of the United States, charged today that some American food and drug exporters were placing "their own self-interest above the welfare of their fellow-men" by shipping "adulterated and inferior foods and drugs" abroad.

Selling was resumed yesterday in the stock market, and, while the list received a minor jolt, it was in no way comparable to the pressure of the first half of last week. In effect, the resumption of pressure, persistent though quiet, eliminated the small recovery scored in the three preceding sessions.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- Backed unanimously by the tax-framing Ways and Means Committee, Chairman Doughton presented formally to the House today a "painless tax" bill for 50,000,000 income taxpayers.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 24 -- Interracial committees to bridge the gap between Negroes and white persons and full civil rights for Negroes were advocated here today by a delegate to the Eastern regional conference of the Young Women's Christian Association.

WITH THE UNITED STATES ARMY AT HOLLANDIA, April 22 (Delayed) -- Only four hours have passed since the first wave of assault troops hit the thin strip of sandy beach chosen as one invasion point for this greatest of all Southwest Pacific military operations.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY ON THE GARIGLIANO FRONT, April 24 -- Private First Class Harry Venetianer hasn't been in the line very long, but he already has two souvenirs. One is an unfired 45 caliber revolver cartridge and the other is an empty casing of a 30 caliber rifle cartridge.

PEARL HARBOR, April 24 (U.P.) -- The Seventh Army Air Force, driving an aerial wedge across the central Pacific to cover Gen. Douglas MacArthur's developing offensive in western New Guinea, bombed Japanese island bases along a 900-mile front in the Carolines Saturday and Sunday, it was announced today.

In his foreword to "The Mixture as Before," published in 1940, Somerset Maugham said: "I have now written between eighty and ninety stories; I shall not write any more." That was a collection of short stories, and he may have meant that he was through with the shorter medium.

CHICAGO, April 24 -- In compliance with a Presidential order, striking Montgomery Ward Co. employes voted today to return to their jobs from the walk-out that was called April 12 by a CIO union. The company made no statement on its attitude toward the order to extend its contract with the union temporarily.

Stockholders of the Sinclair Oil Corporation will be asked at their meeting on May 17 to approve an offer by H.F. Sinclair, president, to purchase 150,000 shares of the company's treasury stock at $13.25 a share, according to a letter to stockholders.
CHUNKING, China, April 24 (UP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

WITH THE DUTCH FIGHTING FORCES in the Indian Ocean, April 23 (AP) -- The "Lost Battalion of Timor" -- weak from malaria and dysentery and weary from relentless year-long guerrilla warfare with the Japanese -- was rescued more than a year ago by a Dutch destroyer that steamed three times into the Japanese-infested waters of the Timor Sea, it now can be disclosed.

NAPLES, April 24 -- Strong formations of the United States Fifteenth Air Force's heavy bombers escorted by fighters stuck anew at the Nazis' vital communications centers in Rumania today, blasting the rail yards at Bucharest and Ploesti.

It was comparatively simple to make one's way around the Jamaica race track yesterday. With the rain coming down as it did, only 16,331 devotees of the sport turned out for the program, and this hardy group had no trouble watching what went on or finding the way to the windows to put down the customary "flutter" for any of the seven events.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 24 -- Roscoe R. Rau, executive vice president of the National Retail Furniture Association, tonight accused the War Production Board of contributing to the waste of millions of dollars in critical war materials by issuing limitation orders which "either compel or inspire manufacturers of consumer durable goods to turn out inferior quality products."

The road to Tokyo will be by way of the Carolines, the Marianas and the Bonin Islands, Lieut. Gen. Alexander A. Vandegrift, commandant of the Marine Corps, declared yesterday at the annual luncheon of The Associated Press at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

ABOARD A UNITED STATES DESTROYER OFF TANAHMERA BAY, Netherland New Guinea, April 23 (Delayed) -- Behind a rim of fire from a vast force of cruisers and destroyers, the greatest amphibious invasion of the southwest Pacific speared into Netherland New Guinea in three prongs yesterday, driving the Japanese back into the jungles of the Cyclops Mountains.

FIVE of the eight managers in the National League -- Mel Ott, Freddie Fitzsimmons, Bill McKechnie, Billy Southworth and Frank Frisch -- played under John J. McGraw. Frisch still will remark on occasions: "Did you notice that play? It was a trick I learned from McGraw." The idol-worshiper, Ott, will comment: "Mister McGraw taught me that."

The grand strategy of the American naval and air forces has been clarified in the report of Admiral King and in the joint statement issued by the United States Strategic Air Forces and the British Air Ministry on their battles against the Luftwaffe. In these reports the record of two and a half years of war has been subjected to official analysis in both concept and results.

The National Orchestral Association, Leon Barzin conducting, gave as its sixth and last concert of the season at Carnegie Hall last night a novelty, "The Dance and Its Relation to Music." The Duncan Dance Guild, the American Dance Group, the Julia Levien Dance Group, the Bernice Livingston Dance Group, the Ethel Mandell Group, the Lillian Rosenberg Dance Group and the Anita Zahn Dancers participated.

The membership of The Associated Press approved unanimously yesterday, at the forty-fourth annual meeting of the news-gathering agency at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, a report made by the board of directors that asserted that "The Associated Press will resist to the utmost every effort to bring about Government control of the news."

LONDON, Tuesday, April 25 -- Soviet Army and Navy planes sank seven more medium-sized German troop transports trying to run the Russian gantlet out of Sevastopol yesterday, while in southeastern Poland Red Army forces turned back enemy counter-attacks on two sectors, Moscow announced early today.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- The War Labor Board sent telegrams to officers of Local No. 73 of the American Federation of Musicians (AFL) at Minneapolis today saying that a strike at radio station KSTP there "must be terminated immediately."
Harold Brayman, formerly assisant director of the public relations department of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., has been appointed director, succeeding the late Theodore G. Joslin.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 24 -- The United States and Britain have been exporting considerable quantities of gold to the Middle East for sale on local markets to help countries in that area combat inflation, it was revealed here today by Lord Moyne, resident British Minister in the Middle East, who convened the first financial conference that is being attended by representatives of fourteen countries.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 19, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

WASHINGTON, April 24 - In a case which may have radiations in the newspaper publishing field, the Supreme Court held by 8 to 1 today that full-time street vendors of Los Angeles newspapers at established spots are "employes" under the National Labor Relations Act and entitled to the benefits of collective bargaining.

ALGIERS, April 24 -- Broadcasts from Vichy threatening reprisals against the families of members of the French Committee of National Liberation were considered by some here today as possibly designed to prevent the treason trial of Admiral Edmond Derrien, who is accused of surrendering Bizerte to the Germans on the orders of Vichy just after the Allies' landing in North Africa.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Wood Robert Jr. of Washington are at the Ritz-Carlton.

A school for housewives sponsored by the New York State Emergency Food Commission opened last night with a capacity crowd at a demonstration of all-in-one-dish cooking and salad making at the American Common of the Common Council for American Unity, 40 East Fortieth Street.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 24 -- During one of the heaviest air attacks ever made against industrial centers in southwestern Germany, twelve American heavy bombers landed in Switzerland early this afternoon and another was shot down by Swiss defenses.

The annual report of the American Cable and Radio Corporation, released yesterday by John L. Merrill, chairman, shows a consolidated net income for 1943, after expenses and charges, of $1,957,655. This was equal to 64 cents a share on the corporation's capital stock and compares with $830,249, or 27 cents a share, in 1942.

ROSELLE PARK, N.J., April 24 -- Two persons were killed and another was seriously injured when a Trackless Transit Company bus was cut in two by a Lehigh Valley Railroad express at the Chestnut Street grade crossing here shortly before noon today.

Acting Welfare Commissioner Harry W. Marsh warned the public yesterday to be constantly on guard against unscrupulous charity racketeers and said that in the last week the Welfare Department's Division of Public Solicitations had halted the activities of a group of racketeers who, allegedly working for a reputable charitable organization, had pocketed more than 75 per cent of the contributions received.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 24 -- The mutiny among Greek armed forces in the Middle East was ended today when the First Brigade of the army, which had revolted against the government, the High Command and its British superiors, as well as the remaining Greek warships that had held out against orders laid down their arms and surrendered.

The indications are that Billy Rose will be one of Broadway's busy persons this summer. Besides having "Money, Money, Money," the Nathaniel Curtis farce, in preparation for a June opening, Mr. Rose disclosed yesterday that he has purchased "Emily Brady," Donald Ogden Stewart's melodrama, for "immediate production."
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Army-Navy production award for excellence in the manufacture of war materials has been given to the following companies:

CHUNGKING, China, April 24 (AP) -- The jaws of a Japanese trap have almost closed on the escape corridor for Chinese troops in the Chengchow area of northern Honan Province where fighting has spread and both sides have suffered heavy losses, the Chinese indicated tonight.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 24 -- American enlisted naval men do not like to talk about the war -- their chief topics of conversation are home and the people they love, according to Capt. Robert D. Workman, chief of Navy chaplains, who is visiting the Middle East.

New York night club and cafe business has hit a new low with a 60 per cent slump and hotel supper room and dinner business is off 21 to 47 per cent as a result of the new 30 per cent cabaret tax that has thrown thousands of entertainers out of work, spokesmen for the clubs and hotels said yesterday.

Post-war continuance of present high corporate income tax rates will seriously curtail the expansion of small business that will be necessary to maintain a high level of employment and national income, according to a study issued yesterday by the Harvard Business School.

First detailed disclosure of plans of the Aviation Corporation to enter the home appliance field after the war came with the announcement yesterday that Col. Philip J. Reilly, managing director of the Associated Merchandising Corporation, has been appointed to direct a distribution program for Avco's post-war production of household appliances.

CHICAGO, April 24 -- The Refrigeration Equipment Manufacturers Association will emphasize product design, market research and job preference for ex-service men, if the deliberations of its post-war planning committee here today are any criterion.

AT GENERAL M'ARTHUR'S ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, April 22 (Delayed) (AP) -- The United States fleet made its Southwest Pacific debut -- previously only small elements have been active here -- with many hundred thousands of tons of fighting ships in the Hollandia and Aitape landings.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Postwar plans in the War Department have reached the point where blueprints are ready for far-flung changes when Germany capitulates, Brig. Gen. William F. Tompkins, head of the Special Planning Division, told the House Post-War Committee on Military Policy at its first hearing today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 24 -- An expansion of "mobile recreation" in Westchester County for the benefit of residents who are kept away from regular recreation centers by gasoline and rubber shortages was announced today by the County Recreation Commission.

Three midtown theatres will present new films this morning. At Loew's Criterion the new attraction will be "Follow the Boys," an all-star picture produced by Charles K. Feldman in association with Universal Pictures. Among the featured personalities are George Raft, Sophie Tucker, Vera Zorina, Marlene Lietrich, Orson Welles, W.C. Fields, Jeanette MacDonald, Donald O'Connor, the Andrew Sisters and the orchestras of Ted Lewis, Charlie Spivak, Freddie Slack and Louis Jordan.

MOSCOW, April 24 -- Though the enemy is continuing his costly frontal attacks on Russian positions in Estonia and in the western Ukraine, these assaults now are beginning to assume the character of forestalling actions. In both regions considerable activity in the air has been reported and for the fifth successive day the enemy's plane losses have exceeded fifty.

Without our immense productive effort neither Britain nor Russia could have gained the upper hand over Hitler. The Selective Service Act recognizes the importance of that effort, but not its relation to technicians under 26 who conduct research and keep the wheels of industry spinning at high speed.

What does it take to be a citizen of a democracy? Kurt Lewin, writing in the Public Opinion Quarterly of the Princeton School of Public Affairs, gives an answer in discussing the difficulties in the way of establishing democracy in Germany. Now at the University of Iowa, Dr. Lewin was a pre-Hitler Professor of Psychology at the University of Berlin, and so knows his Germans.

PITTSBURGH, April 24 (AP) -- Technical Sergeant Charles E. (Commando) Kelly, his face in a big broad grin, came home tonight to his "mom" and to a city which has waited anxiously for days to honor the first enlisted man to receive the Congressional Medal of Honor in the second World War.
LONDON, April 24 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Antony Tudor's "Lilac Garden" had its first presentation of the season last night by the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House, with a cast including Nora Kaye, Maria Karnilova, Hugh Laing and Mr. Tudor. The work was beautifully danced, and retains its romantic conviction and freshness of emotional force remarkably well after its numerous seasons in the repertory.

Stockholders of the Foster Wheeler Corporation approved yesterday an amendment to the company charter that eliminates a provision preventing the payment of common dividends when the ratio of net current assets to current liabilities is less than two to one.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 24 (AP) -- Around Churchill Downs the experts are saying that the horse which wins Wednesday's running of the Blue Grass Stakes will be the one Stir Up will have to beat to win the Kentucky Derby here May 6.

Col. Augustus Thorndike, director of the reconditioning division of the United States Surgeon General's office, in an address yesterday afternoon at the opening of a three-day reconditioning conference at Halloran Central Hospital, Willow Brook, S.I., said the Army hospitals throughout the United States are prepared to recondition 372,000 wounded soldiers a year and put them back in the fight.
The following article is the sixth and last in a series on the results of a food-rationing survey conducted by this department.

Net profit of the International Business Machines Corporation and its subsidiaries increased $1,447,925 in the first quarter of this year to $9,654,529 before taxes from $8,206,604 for the corresponding three months of 1943, according to a report released today.

LONDON, April 24 -- Air-borne operations by Anglo-American forces in the invasion of Western Europe will be on a more massive scale than anything ever before attempted by any army. Air-borne troops -- parachutists and transport-glider infantry -- will constitute not just a menace to enemy communications, but a means of establishing a front behind the enemy's "Atlantic's Wall."

BOSTON, April 24 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Comdr. James H. Crowley, former head coach of football at Fordham University, has been engaged to coach the Boston National (professional) League football team, owner Ted Collins announced today.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Commando Kelly, Pittsburgh hero who punched a large hole in the ranks of the German Army at Salerno last September, is home at last.
Small houses formed the bulk of realty deals in Brooklyn reported yesterday.

Having earlier taken up Strauss and Lehar -- in turn and with success -- the New Opera Company has moved along to Offenbach, and once again it is giving Broadway a generally pleasing evening. This time the name is "Helen Goes to Troy," and as it opened last evening at the Alvin, it obviously was offering one of the most spectacular productions of the season, along with singing to match.
Floods in five midwestern States have caused at least eight deaths and heavy loss of property and livestock.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Manufacturers of knitted underwear, through their industry advisory committee of the War Production Board, has recommended that the present system which allocates specific quantities of yarns for specific purposes be replaced by a single order setting aside the total quantity of all yarns for use by the industry under limitations already set forth in a regulation covering the number and types of fabrics which may be produced, the WPB reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The United States shipped 30,000 planes, 25,000 tanks and 800,000 other military vehicles to its Allies in three years of lend-lease which has played a crucial part in the destruction of the German Luftwaffe, the smashing land offensive by Russia and successes against the Japanese in Burma and the southwest Pacific, Leo T. Crowley, Foreign Economic Administrator, said today.

Robert McLean, publisher of The Philadelphia Evening Bulletin, was re-elected yesterday to the presidency of The Associated Press by its board of directors. His predecessor, Frank B. Noyes, publisher of The Washington Star, who was president from 1900 to 1938, was continued as honorary president.

CHICAGO, April 25 (AP) -- The Commodity Credit Corporation's office here today announced machinery by which corn frozen in 125 Midwest counties will be funneled into essential industry. It provides that no elevator or grain purchaser may sell or deliver corn originating in the designated areas to any person other than the CCC or its designated agents.

CINCINNATI, April 25 (AP) -- Scoring five runs in the first inning, the Reds sent Mort Cooper to an early shower today and with the help of five errors handed the Cardinals their first defeat of the year, 10 -- 3, behind Elmer Riddle's eight-hit hurling.

TACTICAL AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, on the Burma Front, April 23 (Delayed) -- Since the first of the year the Japanese have had to bring a complete new air force into Burma. The air fleet with which they started the year had by mid-April been completely wiped out by American and British planes of Air Marshal Sir John Baldwin's Third Tactical Air Force.

The United States Steel Corporation's income for the first quarter of 1944 was $17,027,616, or $1.23 a share on the common stock, comparing with $15,406,597, or $1.04 share, a year ago, it was announced yesterday by Irving S. Olds, chairman, at the conclusion of a meeting of the board of directors.
