WASHINGTON, April 25(AP) -- Johnnie Hutchins is dead in New Guinea, but to his memory there is a Congressional Medal of Honor, a homestead in Texas and a proud new fighting ship.

LONDON, April 25 -- Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton said at the opening of a British Welcome Club for United States soldiers somewhere in England today that it was the destiny of the United States and Britain to rule the world.

In a move designed to provide post-war outlets for small manufacturers, sponsors of the Greater New York Manufacturers' Pool are developing plans to promote the sale of over forty different products in Asia, Europe and Africa, George H. Salmon, export manager of the International Banding Machine Company, announced yesterday.

Apartment dwellers, who have only a few rooms with nondescript furnishings to serve as a summer retreat from the city's heat, might glean some inspiration from the newly decorated model apartments previewed yesterday at Abraham Straus. "Summertime, When the Livin' Is Easy," is the announced theme of the new decor of the three units -- designed as two room, three room and four room apartments, respectively, but all minus kitchens.

The stock market managed yesterday to adhere to a steadier course, but influences of the war were felt. Mixed changes in prices prevailed at the close, the majority being fractional. Interest in individual issues narrowed as business contracted to 553,450 shares from 688,450 on Monday.

LONDON, April 25 (AP) -- Adolf Hitler was reported to be giving the Atlantic Wall defenses an eleventh-hour inspection tonight in preparation for the Allies' invasion, and his deputy in Denmark moved swiftly to crush rising sabotage that might provide the Allies with a crumbling breach in these defenses.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 25 (AP) -- Andy Hansen, 19-year-old rookie right-hander, scattered seven Montreal hits today to give Jersey City its initial International League victory as the Little Giants topped the Royals, 3 to 2.

An experimental food center for working mothers began operation yesterday at 786 East 156th Street, the Bronx. The project is sponsored by Melrose House and Juvenile House, two settlements in East 156th Street, and by the canteen service of the Bronx American Women's Voluntary Services.

CHICAGO, April 25 -- A proposal to drop the State organizations of the National League of Women Voters came into the open today at the first session of its convention. Debate has been simmering within delegations here from thirty-five States and the division of opinion was clearly evident today when a motion was made from the floor to allow Miss Ruth Mitchell to speak on the subject. Further discussion and action is scheduled for tomorrow.

Unable to agree on the best American play of the season, the members of the New York Drama Critics Circle decided yesterday to omit their annual award this spring. Lillian Hellman's "The Searching Wind" came close to winning, receiving seven votes and lacking only one for a majority.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Senate passed unanimously today the $32,600,000,000 Navy appropriation bill, with its 61 to 0 vote, accompanied by a succession of appeals from members that the scrapping of warships which followed the first World War in hope of future peace never be undertaken again.

MUROC ARMY AIR BASE, Calif., April 25 -- Major is a St. Bernard dog attached to this base, but he is not the snow-plodding type with a bottle of rum tied around his neck. As a "parapooch" he is introducing a new and exciting role for St. Bernards.

Surf fishermen who had been hoping that they would be allowed to go after the big ones at night this season were disappointed yesterday. For security reasons, the beaches have been closed to fishermen at night, but various interested parties have sought to have the ban lifted.

Great Britain will meet its obligations to the Jewish people, Dr. Israel Goldstein, president of the Zionist Organization of America and Rabbi of Congregation B'nai Jeshuran, declared last night at a dinner of the food division of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York in the Hotel Astor.

A $10,000 open golf tournament has been announced by the sports committee of the Greater New York Red Cross War Fund. The dates fixed for the 72-hole event are June 15 to 18 and the site is the Wykagyl Country Club, New Rochelle.

The second Badoglio government just announced deserves to be called more appropriately the first Togliatti government. This is a triumph of the Communist policy for Italy, which called, first, for a political united front of Communist inspiration, and second, for a coalition Government of Communist inspiration and with Communist participation.

For a twenty-day period, beginning May 1, children's shoes selling at retail for $1.60 or less a pair, may be purchased without a ration coupon, the Office of Price Administration announced yesterday. William McKenna, regional rationing executive, estimated that several hundred thousand pairs of these shoes would be put on sale.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Nine men and three women were seated in the jury box for the sedition trial today, but are subject to dismissal tomorrow when the Government and the thirty defendants in the case start to exercise their right to ten peremptory challenges each. The defense has two in the selection of the two alternate jurors; the prosecution one.

Governor Bricker's address last night before the Ohio Society of New York was the first extensive statement on foreign policy he has made in this community, and what he said was, on the whole, much to the point and reassuring. To be sure, the political touch was not absent.

Henry Morgenthau, former Ambassador to Turkey, who will be 88 years old today, predicted yesterday that the war would end in a victory for the United Nations and that there would be a period of great prosperity for the United States after the conflict.

Industry cannot view optimistically a recent statement by Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell, Commanding General, Army Service Forces, "that he expected the Army would soon be in a position to make its contracts for textile items 'not subject to renegotiation,'" Arthur Besse, president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers, declared yesterday, because after analysis it is indicated "the Army seems to be offering a nice, shiny gold brick for sale.

LONDON, April 25 -- The prison terms imposed on Jewish soldiers who deserted from the Polish Army and refused to go back on the ground that anti-Semitism was practiced in it may never be served, it was indicated today in a statement of the Polish Government reviewing the problem.

A favorable balance between wages and commodity prices to prevent inflation during the war and to establish a sound economy afterward was advocated yesterday at a Catholic conference on industrial problems sponsored by Bishop Thomas E. Molloy and the Catholic Charities of Brooklyn.

The Most Rev. Cyril Forster Garbett, the Archbishop of York, declared yesterday that it was the duty of the church to denounce social wrongs such as widespread unemployment and poor housing, but not to undertake detailed schemes for their reform.

Senator Tom Connally of Texas, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, declares that the present constitutional requirement of a two-thirds vote of the Senate for treaty ratification is essential to a stable foreign policy, and that he will fight any and all attempts to abolish it.

The Mozart Chamber Orchestra, which is composed of thirty-five pupils of the Music School of the Henry Street Settlement, aided by a sprinkling of faculty members, made its uptown debut at the New York Times Hall last night. The orchestra, which is directed by Robert Scholz, has given concerts regularly at the Neighborhood Playhouse on Grand Street, but this was its first excursion on the more beaten paths of the city's musical life.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 -- Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor and chairman of the United States delegation to the conference of the International Labor Organization here, rebuked the official Soviet newspaper Izvestia today for an editorial attack on the ILO as a "bankrupt" association of nations that should be divorced completely from the League of Nations.

Making up in enthusiasm what they lacked in skill, the Schermerhorn Indians, aged 6 to 10, began spring training yesterday on a hastily improvised diamond in the playground of the Children's Aid Society's West Side Center, 409 West Thirty-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Operators producing more than 70 per cent of the country's bituminous coal stated today in a letter to William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, that they were willing to pay each miner $40 in settlement of claims for retroactive portal-to-portal pay if this provision of a pending contract is approved by the board.

Contrary to recent reports of the danger of spoilage for lack of cold storage space in New York, there is adequate space for all foods, except a few specialties, William Muller, vice president of the Merchants' Refrigerating Company, stated yesterday.
The Allied attack upon the Ai-tape and Hollandia area in New Guinea appeared to be progressing favorably and with considerable speed yesterday.

Overcast skies held the threat of more rain for the flooded Midwest yesterday, giving little surcease from rampaging rivers which caused twelve deaths, forced thousands from their homes, washed out vast acreages of crops and snarled rail and highway travel.
ON THE BRITISH SEACOAST, April 25 -- When the Allied forces launch an invasion of the Continent the United States Navy will be in it all the way.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 25 -- Esther Fernandez, Mexican film star, has been signed in Mexico City by B.G. DeSylva for the romantic lead, opposite Alan Ladd, in Paramount's current "Two Years Before the Mast." Miss Fernandez, who was previously under contract to Paramount for two years, without appearing in a picture, is scheduled to arrive here in two weeks.

Manned by a predominantly Negro crew, the PC 1264 was placed in commission yesterday morning after a brief ceremony at a Navy pier in New York City. The craft, second naval vessel to be thus manned, is a sleek 173-foot vessel of a type used largely for escort duty.

A new issue of $14,000,000 of first mortgage 3 per cent bonds of the Cudahy Packing Company, Series B due in 1964, will be offered today at par by an underwriting group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.

If the homes of injured service men or women are not properly prepared to receive them, "our whole program of retraining may fail," Dr. Oswald R. Jones declared yesterday at the Conference on Convalescence and Rehabilitation at the New York Academy of Medicine.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- Destruction of a German submarine in two minutes of concentrated action by American carrier-based planes was reported today by the Navy.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (U.P.) -- Some members of Congress tonight were displeased by Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton's statement that it was the destiny of the American and British people "to rule the world," and one of them, Representative Jessie Sumner of Illinois, said General Patton's remarks were "as balmy as Hitler's."

LONDON, April 25 -- A Tass dispatch broadcast from Moscow tonight said that a German administration had replaced Finnish authorities in Petsamo and declared it a restricted area, permitting no one to enter or leave the Barents Sea port city.

LONDON, Wednesday, April 26 (AP) -- An authoritative Soviet war review broadcast by the Moscow radio last night declared the Red Army had killed or captured more than 500,000 Axis troops in less than two months on the lower Russian front as a prelude to a drive on Berlin by Soviet forces collaborating with the Allies in the west.

The War Labor Board has telegraphed to the leaders of a Minneapolis local of Mr. Petrillo's musicians' union that the strike at radio station KSTP "must be terminated immediately." "This strike is contrary to the national policy," says the board, "and is in violation of the no-strike pledge of your organization." William Green, president of the A.F. of L., has also condemned the strike.

Through a succession of rulings by the Department of Justice, the part that the American oil industry will play in the United States-British oil conferences now going on in Washington has been reduced to a minor role, according to the current issue of The NAM News, published by the National Association of Manufacturers.

ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Central Pacific Area, April 25 -- There is to be no lessening of the Pacific offensive as a result of the events impending in the European theatre, despite the obvious demands on American production and supply facilities entailed in an operation of such magnitude as a cross-Channel invasion, military authorities said here today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, April 26 (AP) -- All types of Fifth Air Force bombers and fighters were using the seized Tadji airfield, captured Saturday on the first day of the invasion near Aitape. From more remote bases, long-range bombers hit everywhere that the Japanese might muster an aerial counter punch.

NAPLES, April 25 (U.P.) -- In a series of sharp punches with tanks, American troops have advanced more than a mile on the east flank of the Anzio beachhead and are within two miles of the vital Appian Way at a point southeast of Cisterna, it was disclosed tonight.

PEARL HARBOR, April 25 -- American forces have occupied and taken possession of Ujelang Atoll in the Marshalls, moving our sea frontier 125 miles nearer Ponape and other enemy bases in the central Carolines.

Each man in the armed forces stands a 1,000 per cent better chance of coming back if his school has made him physically fit, Capt. Lyman S. Perry, aide to Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox, declared yesterday in a plea to physical education instructors to revise and improve parts of their program.
Patrolman Irving Abrams, at the wheel of a police patrol car, and Patrolman Abraham De Klade, lolling beside him, rolled slowly through Central Park at 12:30 P.M. yesterday.

LONDON, April 25 -- The Chancellor's budget statement was made too late to have any appreciable effects on today's stock markets where, as usual on budget day, business was small, with a generally firm tone.

Speculation in this country as to when the invasion of Europe will begin can be answered truthfully out of information available to any newspaper reader: it has already begun. The air attacks, rising in fury day by day, are invasion. Every thousand planes is at least the equivalent of an armored division roaming at will through the enemy's country.

Best Foods has begun its summer campaign week with an advertisement in daily newspapers throughout the nation featuring H-O Oats, Force Wheat Flakes and Heckers' Farina, the first time that these foods have been grouped in a single advertisement.

Paul Henkel, president of the Society of Restaurateurs, criticized sharply last night the statement made here recently by Tom C. Clark, assistant United States attorney general in charge of the criminal division, that the black market must be stamped out by the liquor industry before there is any "holiday" for the production of beverage alcohol.

The dairy products sector of the food front disclosed yesterday its jitters over the impending annual milk flush that may flood a food market already swamped with fish and eggs. Milk industry representatives revealed that they had appealed to the War Food Administration to sanction the manufacture of more ice cream as one way of averting the possible loss of large quantities of milk.

Employes who deliberately provoke their own discharges as a means of obtaining certificates of availability to take better jobs will not get such certificates, the New York area office of the War Manpower Commission announced yesterday from its headquarters at 11 West Forty-second Street.

LONDON, April 25 -- American fighter-bombers with range and striking power equal to, if not greater than, those of the twin-engined bombers that Britain and Germany employed during the first years of this war are ready and waiting for the day.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill's recent statement that the British Government had retained the right to grant imperial preferences implied no abandonment of the principle that international trade should be expanded rather than restricted, Secretary of State Cordell Hull said at his press conference today.

CHUNGKING, China, April 25 (AP) -- The Japanese offensive in north Honan Province is believed to have overrun the rail junction of Chengchow. The invaders are fighting far west of the city in a campaign that appears to be aimed at the heart of China.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The White House today staged a war of nerves on the news-gatherers of the capital and their editors, which left room for the impression either that the war has given the President's immediate circle an exaggerated idea of the importance of anything Mr. Roosevelt may do or that a course in public relations would be useful.
CHICAGO, April 25 -- General short covering developed in the grain markets today on the Board of Trade. This caused a rapid upturn after a small dip early. There was no pressure on wheat.
Governor John W. Bricker of Ohio and Mrs. Bricker are at the Ambassador.
An interim dividend of 40 cents a share was declared yesterday by directors of the Borden Company. This is the same as the March 1 payment but 10 cents more than that of June 1 last year.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The first national conference for intensive coaching of a new profession, the industrial feeding specialist, is now under way at the War Food Administration.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Unification of the armed forces under a single command at the end of this war was advocated today by Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of War, and Gen. Joseph T. McNarney, Deputy Chief of Staff. They voiced their belief in the principle to members of the Post-War Committee on Military Policy of the House.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Army purchases this year will match those of 1943, while the Navy's procurement program is still mounting and will not reach peak levels until the end of the year, under-secretaries of the two departments told a subcommittee of the Senate's Special Committee to Study Problems of American Small Business today.

New issues of short-term notes, aggregating $7,397,000, were announced yesterday by twelve local housing authorities throughout the country for award on May 10. The issues range in size from $1,410,000 to $97,000. Under the terms of sale each issue must be bid for separately.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Sweden's reply to our appeals to her to stop shipping ball-bearings to the Nazis was described as unsatisfactory by Secretary of State Cordell Hull today. Her note has not been made public here, but it has been described in Stockholm as negative.

A woman who told the police that she believed her automobile 'hit somebody' in Horace Harding Boulevard, Flushing, Queens, on Monday evening, yesterday was held in $1,500 bail by Magistrate Peter M. Horn in Felony Court. She is accused of causing the death of one man and injury to three others in a hit-and-run accident to which detectives had found no clues.
Following is the text of Governor Bricker's prepared address delivered last evening before the Ohio Society at the Hotel Pennsylvania:

An active demand for business quarters in the downtown financial district of Manhattan was reflected in the lists of office rentals reported by brokers yesterday. Several contracts were made for expansion. Wall, Rector, Broad, John and West Street space figured in the rentals.

It takes more than courage and daring to win battles. Imagination must be linked with sound planning and split-second execution. The Chindits are winning in the Burma jungle because they are masters of all these. Glider-borne troops, British, Americans and Indians, dropped from the sky are slicing through the lines that tie the enemy to his bases.

Private automobiles must be kept running lest mass transportation facilities be subjected to further demands that will prove backbreaking, Edward A. Roberts, associate director of the Division of Local Transport of the Office of Defense Transportation, told members of the American Transit Association yesterday.

For the first time in more than a year all shortenings, except butter and margarine, are ration free and home baking may be undertaken once more without sacrificing meat stamps. The following recipes -- for lemon meringue pie, peanut butter cookies and a busy day cake -- will take advantage of the "point" holiday. All have been tested in THE NEW YORK TIMES kitchen.

The fifteen-story building on the west blockfront on Sixth Avenue between Fifty-fifth and Fifty-sixth Streets has been acquired by Max N. Natanson and immediately resold by him to a client of Charles Gadofcky for investment.

A grant of $100,000 by the Greater New York Fund to the Welfare Council of New York City was announced yesterday at a reorganization meeting of the council in the Roosevelt Hotel by Albert G. Milbank, a member of the special committee on council structure, which has been working for eighteen months on reorganization plans for the organization, composed of more than 500 health and social agencies.

BOSTON, April 25 (AP) -- Massachusetts Democrats favor a fourth term for President Roosevelt, balloting in the Presidential primary indicated clearly tonight as returns showed delegates pledged to former Governor Joseph B. Ely trailing by as much as four to one.

NEWARK, N.J., April 25 -- A charge that "Nazi propaganda was reaching directly into the court room," highlighted today the propaganda conspiracy trial involving nineteen men and two corporations, which is in its fourth week before a jury and Judge Thomas F. Meaney in Federal Court here.

Michael Todd, who, like all the other Broadway producers, has been beset by the current dearth of theatres, has obtained a house of his own, it was learned yesterday. It is the Forty-eighth Street Theatre, formerly owned by the Bank for Savings and the Leblang Estate.

SAMPSON, N.Y., April 25 -- Lieut. Comdr. James H. (Sleepy) Crowley was assigned today as officer in charge of athletic programs at the Sampson Naval Training Station, a post from which he will conceivably direct the Tars' 1944 football team.

LONDON, April 25 -- The United States State Department mission, headed by its Under-Secretary, Edward R. Stettinius Jr., has just about finished its work in London. The members are leaving this capital soon satisfied that their visit, while it has settled nothing finally, has helped to bring nearer to realization that complete unity of action among the big powers that the conferences at Moscow, Teheran and Cairo foreshadowed.

A quota of 21,000,000 surgical dressings for delivery to the armed forces by Oct. 1 has been assigned to the New York Red Cross Chapter, whose activities are restricted to Manhattan and the Bronx, it was announced yesterday by Maj. Gen. Robert C. Davis, executive director.

ST. LOUIS, April 25 -- A demand for representation for women at the peace table was made today at the opening of the triennial conference of the General Federation of Women's Clubs. Mrs. John L. Whitehurst of Baltimore, retiring president, was put forward as the federation's candidate.

LONDON, Wednesday, April 26 -- Seven important Luftwaffe bases in France and Belgium and German defenses and communications throughout northwestern Europe were pounded yesterday as the great Allied pre-invasion air offensive continued through a ninth day.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The award of decorations by the Soviet Government to twenty-nine officers and four enlisted men of the United States Army was announced today by the War Department.

" Every aggressor nation has learned that our country must be the first to be attacked and the airplane of the future will make this possible. The initial assault will come, not on Pearl Harbor but on Washington, Detroit and Pittsburgh."

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, April 25 (U.P.) -- Seizing the full initiative north of Imphal, British Imperial troops have cleared out twenty-two miles of the road to Kohima and the Japanese were reported in full retreat from that sector tonight after losing nearly 10,000 men killed in their ill-starred invasion of India.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, April 26 -- American troops driving from west and east neared the three fighter strips inland from Hollandia against still scattered opposition, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's communique announced today. Driving inland over a swampy jungle trail beyond Sabron, captured yesterday, the infantry that landed at Tanahmera Bay neared Hollandia strip, while the troops that captured Pim on Humboldt Bay after slight opposition neared Sentani strip.
BOSTON, April 25 -- Out of the fog and mist over Braves Field today, the Dodgers exploded an eight-run ninth inning that smothered the Braves, 11 -- 3, in the opener of a three-game series.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARSTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, April 26 (AP) -- A communique:
CHUNGKING, China, April 25 (UP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Montgomery Ward Co., Chicago mail order and chain retail merchandising concern, ignored President Roosevelt's deadline of noon today for taking steps to settle the company's labor dispute, and in a telegram signed by Sewell Avery, the company's chairman, challenged the President's authority to take over its properties.

One of the most pressing problem facing the public utility industry today is the "discriminatory and unjust" tax burden that it carries, while Federal and municipal power systems enjoy wide tax exemptions, Edward L. Shea, president of the $1,000,000,000 North American Company system, declared yesterday at the company's annual meeting of stockholders.

Four hundred student, cadet and graduate nurses of New York Hospital were told of ways to achieve today's standard of natural beauty last night at the nurses' residence of the hospital by Miss Bernice Peck, health and beauty editor of Mademoiselle. Miss Peck demonstrated to her audience that almost every physical asset can be magnified and that almost every physical liability can be minimized.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The deposit committee for owners of the first and refunding 5 per cent bonds of the Florida East Coast Railway Company today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to make certain changes in its plan of reorganization for the road to meet tests of fairness under the changed conditions cited by a Federal court in referring the plan back to the commission.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Secretary Cordell Hull and a Senate group began today an innovation in foreign relations. They discussed for an hour and a half the groundwork for a cooperative movement, initiated by Mr. Hull in his recent world broadcast, to translate Congressional and Administration expression for post-war peace collaboration with the United States into a working machine.

The final defeat of Germany this year is possible, and should that happen the United States and Great Britain already have completed plans for the immediate transfer of the full might of Allied fighting power to the war against Japan, Admiral Ernest J. King, Commander in Chief of the United States Fleet, declared last night.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Steel producers opened their attack today on the wage demands of the United Steel Workers of America, CIO, by offering a series of briefs and arguments to prove that abandonment of the present national wage stabilization policy would be an economic disaster of the first magnitude and lead to an uncontrolled inflationary race between wages and prices.

The single-family dwelling at 1151 Schenectady Avenue, Brooklyn, in the lower Flatbush section, has been bought by R. Trebatch for occupancy from Mrs. B. Barnard. contains six rooms. Ohnewald Denlinger were the brokers in the sale.

The report of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on March 31, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after operating expenses, taxes and other charges of $30,208,294.
Anzac Day, the Australian and New Zealand equivalent of our Fourth of July, was observed here yesterday, with Prime Minister Peter Fraser of New Zealand the central figure in two memorial programs.

That something must be done to restore wounded and sick veterans of this war all agree. But what? We have the Convalescent Training program of the Army Air Force, the studies which have been undertaken by the National Research Council's Committee on Convalescence and Rehabilitation and various proposals of Government and private agencies.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Joseph W. Henderson of Philadelphia, president of the American Bar Association, has appointed a special committee to study and report on pending proposals for the post-war organization of the nations to maintain peace and enforce law and the settlement of international controversies by adjudication.

LONDON, April 25 -- Presenting his first budget to an apathetic House of Commons, Sir John Anderson, Chancellor of the Exchequer, stood today in the happy situation of a man whose predecessor had planned so well that he had naught to do but follow in his footsteps.

The directors of the United Aircraft Corporation elected William P. Gwinn as general manager of the Pratt Whitney aircraft division yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders at East Hartford, Conn. He joined the division in January, 1927, and has been acting general manager several months.

LONDON, April 25 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav Partisan troops, supported by Allied planes and naval forces, have invaded the strategically important Dalmatian island of Mljet, flanking the German-held supply port of Dubrovnik, and "very heavy fighting" is under way, a communique from Marshal Broz's headquarters announced tonight.

A message from Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower declaring that public opinion wins wars and pledging his help in facilitating the flow of news from the invasion was read yesterday at the opening session of the fifty-eighth annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, held at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Jefferson's last years were harassed by debt, much of it incurred for the benefit of a distant kinsman, but at least he died without the knowledge that "dear Monticello" was to pass out of the hands of his family. It was owing to Stuart Gatswood Gibboney, who died in Charlottesville Monday, that Monticello, the house that Jefferson designed, and its ample acres were restored to a larger family, the American people.

Expressing his concern over the American youth's lack of physical preparedness for war, Comdr. Jack Dempsey of the United States Coast Guard made a plea yesterday for a general physical development program, with a stress on college and high school athletic contact competition.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- The Red Sox slugged out a 5-4 victory over Washington with a sixteen-hit attack today, but it took them fourteen innings to make the grade.

Harry T. Klein, executive vice president and general counsel of the Texas Company, was elected president of the company yesterday to succeed W.S.S. Rodgers, who was made chairman. Mr. Rodgers will remain as chief executive officer of the company.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- President Roosevelt's memorandum of Feb. 26 calling for review by local draft boards of all occupational deferments, resulted in sharp decreases in such deferments in March, the Selective Service System reported today.

PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, April 26 -- Pennsylvania Republicans indicated a strong preference for Governor Thomas E. Dewey as the party's Presidential nominee on the basis of returns early today from the State primary. Returns gave the New York State Executive a lead of almost 15 to 1 over his three leading potential opponents, Governor John W. Bricker of Ohio, Gen. Douglas MacArthur and Lieut. Comdr. Harold E. Stassen.

Trading in cotton futures was quiet yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange and fluctuations were narrow. Closing prices were 2 points higher to 4 points lower than on Monday, with the near months relatively firm.

CHICAGO, April 25 -- Washington dispatches to Chicago tonight quoted sources close to the Montgomery Ward dispute as saying that Department of Commerce officials were on their way here to take over the mail order house for the Government tomorrow.

A Norwegian Nazi seaman named Ivar Haug, or Ivar Hang, or Iver Heuj, went to trial in Federal court yesterday. He was accused of failing to furnish his local Selective Service board with an address at which mail would invariably reach him.

Your recent editorial, "The Youthful Lawbreaker," makes several points with which I, and the agency with which I am connected, are in considerable accord. Certainly, the increase in delinquency during the war period emphasizes the importance of concerted community action to plan for and to meet the problem.

Of the leaders in the tournament for the United States chess championship, play in which was resumed with the ninth round at the Hotel Park Central last night, Herman Steiner of Los Angeles, Albert S. Pinkus of Brooklyn and Israel A. Horowitz of Manhattan scored victories.

OTTAWA, Ont., April 25 (Canadian Press) -- Hope for early settlement of the work stoppage at the plant of the Ford Motor Company of Canada at Windsor, Ont., centered tonight on a four-man conciliation committee of the National Wartime Labor Relations Board.

Furniture shipments in March were 8 per cent greater than for the preceding month and unchanged compared with those in the corresponding month last year, according to a report yesterday by Seidman Seidman, accountants for the industry.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Although Secretary of State Cordell Hull refused, at his press conference today, to comment upon Finland's rejection of Russia's peace terms, it appeared that Stockholm reports that the United States, in consequence, would sever diplomatic relations with the Helsinki government, were at least premature.

WITH AMERICAN ARMY AT TANAHMERA BAY, Netherland New Guinea, April 25 (AP) -- Army engineers fought mud and clay today in building a road through the hills on the route to a chain of airstrips behind the Cyclops Mountains as Netherland Indies colonial administration officials sought to entice natives back from the jungles, where they fled from the naval bombardment preceding the landings here.

Again yesterday 21,700 persons defied the threat of continued rain and traveled their now well-beaten path to the egg-shaped Jamaica racing plant operated by the Metropolitan Jockey Club. All must have had money in their jeans, too, for the handle was $1,859,159, which averaged close to $90 per person.
LONDON, April 25 (AP) -- The assault on Adolf Hitler's Continental fortress since April 15, the greatest aerial bombardment in history, has cost the Americans and Britons 2,300 airmen.

JACKSON, Miss., April 25 -- Millions of dollars to lease virtually worthless farmland in Jasper County as oil-well possibilities and to pay for labor at oil drilling is being spread among white or Negro owners of small, meager farms, H.M. Morse, State oil and gas director, said today.
LONDON, April 25 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,270, against 1,560 in the preceding week and 690 in the similar period of last year, according to the listings published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 511, which compared with 788 last Tuesday.

Again yesterday 21,700 persons defied the threat of continued rain and traveled their now well-beaten path to the egg-shaped Jamaica racing plant operated by the Metropolitan Jockey Club. All must have had money in their jeans, too, for the handle was $1,859,159, which averaged close to $90 per person.
LONDON, April 25 (AP) -- The assault on Adolf Hitler's Continental fortress since April 15, the greatest aerial bombardment in history, has cost the Americans and Britons 2,300 airmen.

The "new member department" of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York does not campaign actively for new member banks of the Federal Reserve System, but it does stand ready to supply all of the information concerning the advantages of membership, and each month sees the goal of 100 per cent membership a little nearer.

LONG BEACH, L.I., April 25 -The meeting of the Committee for Arbitration of Military Rental Problems here tonight settled sixteen out of eighteen cases that came before it and announced that of about 150 cases handled since it started sessions five weeks ago 95 per cent had been arbitrated successfully.

MONTREAL, April 25 (AP) -- A four-engined Liberator bomber which had taken off only a few minutes earlier on a flight to England crashed in downtown Montreal today, smashing brick buildings as if they were paper and killing fifteen or more persons, including all five crew members.

Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio, aspirant for the Republican Presidential nomination, making his principal Eastern pre-convention address, attacked the Roosevelt Administration last night for having failed to stop the dictator nations in their drive for power during the Nineteen Thirties, and came out for a policing of the postwar world by the united military strength of Russia, China, Great Britain and the United States.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, April 25 (AP) -- Shareholders of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company authorized its directors at the annual meeting today to issue up to 300,000 additional shares when and if the directors feel additional capital is needed.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 25 -- The status of the United States bases abroad after the war made news here today, newspaper editorials comparing Admiral Ernest J. King's declaration concerning Brazil's participation in the war and the recommendation of Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio that the United States keep such bases.

The small boy who does not see eye to eye with his mother on the subject of spinach and potatoes would do well to get rid of page 20 of yesterday's TIMES, in case the lady has not already laid hands on same.

THIS was going to be a feed-box special to end all feed-box specials. We had been properly introduced and this wanderer hurriedly glanced around before whispering, "Come clean. Are you going to win the Kentucky Derby?" There was no answer. Stir Up pawed away at the straw in his stall and very impolitely turned his back.
WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, on the Garigliano River Front, April 25 -- "If we put a bridge here, Jerry wouldn't leave it here very long," Sergt. George Huber of St. Louis said. "So we use this."

CHICAGO, April 25 -- The Office of Price Administration and the War Production Board will relax production, material and price controls as the war draws to a close, and ultimately abandon them, Chester Bowles declared in an address here tonight. But, he said, it would call for a government that would "underwrite a high and expanding level of business and a high and rising level of national income."

LONDON, April 25 -- Marshal Rommel, who will command the German field armies intended for a counter-offensive against the Allies' invasion, has completed an inspection of the secondary defenses of the Atlantic Wall, according to the German radio.

Expressing skepticism as to whether a free world press could be established by a clause in the peace treaty, Hugh Baillie, president of The United Press Associations, said yesterday that the goal to be pursued at the peace conference was "competitive equality in access to the news and to transmission facilities."

CHUNGKING, China, April 24 (Delayed) -- Although the daily war bulletins from the Yellow River front are ominous, the objectives of the Japanese offensive are still obscure. After crossing the river in three columns east of Chengchow April 18 the Japanese have been infiltrating that area with small artillery, some light armored cars and some air support. Loyang to the west has been bombed.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
The Manufacturers Trust Company, as trustee, has sold the Van Dorn Apartments, fifteen - story building at 148-50 West Fifty-eighth Street, to the Merit Holding Company, headed by Samuel Moses.

How social agencies can help parents and children with problems of school and family life was explained yesterday by speakers from three family service agencies in the Bronx at a meeting of about forty parents, representing the parent-teacher associations of fifteen schools in the borough.

Several New York newspapers have recently published an interview of an emissary of General Mihailovich accusing the Yugoslav Partisans of terrorism and collusion with the enemy. The emissary, Captain B. Todorovich, asserted that Mihailovich could mobilize 400,000 effectives, while Tito's forces numbered only 20,000 to 25,000 men.

Carle C. Conway, chairman of the board and president of the Continental Can Company, Inc., announced yesterday in a report to stockholders that for the twelve months ended on March 31 net earnings were $5,519,873 after deducting $9,014,865 for depreciation and estimated income and excess profits taxes.
LONDON, April 25 (UP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

WITH UNITED STATES ARMY FORCES at Tadji, New Guinea, April 24 (Delayed) (AP) -- Combat and troop carrier planes began landing on this important airstrip today, less than forty-eight hours after its capture.

Easing his way out of the rough spots by the expedient of serving up three double-play balls, Hank Borowy twirled the Yankees to a 6-2 victory over the Athletics at the Stadium yesterday. It was Fordham Hank's second triumph and, counting his seven straight at the end of last season, plus his world series decision over the Cardinals, the young right-hander possesses a ten-game winning streak.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 26 (AP) -- Jean Pierre Roy, Rochester right-hander, limited Jersey City to two hits today to give the Red Wings a 1-to-0 victory. Rochester made only two safeties from the combined offerings of Bob Henry and Frank Rosso, but won in the eighth when Henry, who walked nine and hit a batsman, issued two bases on balls, after which Jack Sturdy singled home Otis Davis from second.

Leslie Grey, hard-running daughter of Isolator out of Themesong, carried the Longchamps Farms' silks to victory yesterday in the thirty-fifth Rosedale Stakes, five-furlong dash for 2-year-old fillies, at Jamaica.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 26 -- German Army, Air Force, airborne infantry and paratroop reinforcements are pouring into Denmark on a scale that indicates Germany's action in sealing off the country has strategic importance and is not aimed merely at crushing suddenly intensified sabotage, advices said tonight.

General Eisenhower's message to the American Newspaper Publishers Association is a striking statement to come from the commander of the Allied armies in Britain at the time when he is completing preparations for the greatest test of military force in American history.

While the enforcement division of the Office of Price Administration cannot offer "complete immunity" from sanctions given the agency by Congress to enforce the price act, John D. Hill and Norman Lazarus, attorneys of the apparel and industrial materials enforcement section of the OPA, stated yesterday that "consideration" would be given to black-market operators who voluntarily disclose their illegal actions and promised future compliance.

Grants of $1,000 to each of fifteen artists who are doing creative work in the fields of music, literature and art have been awarded by the American Academy and the National Institute of Arts and Letters, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Expressing concern over a growing tendency upon the part of the American people to concentrate their thinking on post-war problems at a time when the "toughest part of the war is still before us," Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, said today that WPB is now concentrating upon war-production problems and intends to continue to do so until victory is assured.

The Japanese campaigns in China are not easy to understand at this distance. They are not easy to understand in China itself. One reason is that there is a Chinese as well as a Japanese censorship. Another is that the Japanese activities do not always make military sense.

LONDON, Thursday, April 27 (AP) -- Blasting at an Axis fleet presumably attempting to evacuate large numbers of the besieged forces at Sevastopol, the Russians sank five German and Rumanian transports and damaged two others in twenty-four hours, Moscow announced today.

Mayor La Guardia asked the directors of the newly incorporated New York War Fund yesterday to discuss with him at an early conference plans for the "gigantic" task of rehabilitating those of the city's 740,000 men and women in the armed services who will require care when the war ends.

In a move dictated largely by the faith of his father -- a doctor -- in the worth of physical medicine and his own deep desire to help rehabilitate the sick and wounded war veterans, Bernard M. Baruch, financier, philanthropist and key figure on the American home front in two World Wars, made yesterday a gift of $1,100,000 to advance teaching and research in that field.

Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., yesterday offered medical testimony to support its contention offered in company advertising that Philip Morris cigarettes are less irritating to the throat than other brands in answer to a Federal Trade Commission charge that such advertising is false and misleading.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Thursday, April 27 (AP) -- A communique:

LONDON, April 26 -- The budget speech of the Chancellor of the Exchequer met with a good reception in today's stock markets here. The decision to allow research expenditure as a deduction from profits had a good effect in the industrial section, with textiles, steel and engineering shares and radio issues benefitting.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Asserting that the United Steel Workers Union, CIO, was seeking a "private 'storm cellar' for its present membership" at the expense of others, the steel industry today told a panel of the National War Labor Board that a general wage increase for steel workers wound have serious repercussions upon the national economy.

SUPPOSEDLY, statistics are cold and deadly. They don't make inspired reading at best. Yet there were a few sets of figures produced over the past week-end which are startling to say the least. The wagering of more than $3,000,000 at Jamaica was something of a stunner, but probably more amazing than that was the record attendance of 133,000 at the England-Scotland football game in Glasgow.

Following a protest by Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, Mark A. Daly of Buffalo, executive vice president of the Associated Industries of New York, Inc., revised yesterday his former testimony concerning her given before the Moreland Act inquiry into the administration of the State Workmen's compensation law.

The United Aircraft Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiary, the United Aircraft Service Corporation, reported yesterday in its statement of operations for the first quarter of 1944 that shipments rose 35 per cent to $215,280,014 from the $159,169,553 volume last year.

PITTSBURGH, April 26 (AP) -- The steel city showed today that it had a soft heart as far as heroes are concerned as thousands of its citizens, war workers, dignitaries, children and housewives, turned out to yell themselves hoarse at the first public appearances of Commando Kelly.
Operators were active yesterday in the purchase and sale of properties in Manhattan.

Ford Frick, president of the National League, urged the continuance of organized baseball and other competitive sports as "an integral part of American tradition" at the forum luncheon of the Advertising Club of New York yesterday. He told of the contributions baseball is making to the war effort and declared that the sport is "asking no favors."

Continuing his triumphant march in the United States chess championship, wherein he has not lost a game nor permitted a draw, Arnold S. Denker of Forest Hills, champion of the Manhattan Chess Club, last night tallied his ninth victory over Sven Almgren of the Hawthorne Chess Club, Brooklyn, in their adjourned game from the ninth round, at the Manhattan Chess Club.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
LONDON, April 26 -- The American Broadcasting Station in Europe, its official name, will go on the air for the first time at 5:30 P.M. Sunday, British time [11:30 A.M. New York time].
Beginning today, 30,000 food retailers in this city will receive weekly from the Office of Price Administration a list of wholesale ceiling prices on fresh vegetables and fruits.

PITTSBURGH, April 26 (AP) -- Elwin (Preacher) Roe pitched the Pirates to a 6-1 victory over the Cubs today, allowing seven well-scattered hits. Meanwhile, Pittsburgh was collecting twelve safeties, including Vince DiMaggio's homer in the sixth with two on.

Working schedules of city firemen on duty in Staten Island will be changed from the three to the two-platoon system starting Monday, Fire Commissioner Patrick J. Walsh announced yesterday. Only Richmond is affected by the change because men are most needed there as a result of the number who have gone into military service.

As one who interrupted a busy operatic career during the last war to raise money for musical instruments for service men, I should like to bring to your attention the fine work which the Metropolitan Opera Guild is doing today along similar lines.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Decision to continue the Office of Price Administration's "highest price line" limitation order at the manufacturing level, but to modify its requirements at wholesale and retail levels, was announced today by Chester Bowles, administrator.
THINGS I never knew before reading W.E. Woodward's "The Way Our People Lived: An Intimate American History"*:

CINCINNATI, April 26 -- Frank McCormick's thirteenth-inning homer broke up a previously scoreless two-hour twenty-six minute baseball game today as the Reds won their second straight from the Cardinals, 1 -- 0. It was the tall first baseman's first circuit clout of the year and the first run Cincinnati made for Bucky Walters in twenty-two innings.

CHUNGKING, China, April 26 -- China will continue to fight Japan with all her own resources if her Allies do not greatly increase their help, according to P.H. Chang, Government spokesman, at a press conference today.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Complete harmony between his views and those of President Roosevelt regarding the strategic position in the Pacific and post-war measures against future aggression and economic insecurity was reported tonight by Prime Minister John Curtain of Australia in a radio broadcast on an NBC hook-up.

The Italian Relief Workshop Committee held an informal luncheon meeting yesterday in the Cafe DuBois, 10 East Fifty-second Street, to seek cooperation among relief agencies on aid for the population of liberated Italy.

Changes in the rules covering special offerings have been approved by the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange. They provide that a "regular-way" offer shall not interrupt a special offering unless the net price to the customer is lower and a broker is authorized to buy cheaper regular-way stock during a special offering without notifying the customer.

Great Britain is determined to fight until both Germany and Japan are defeated, the Archbishop of York declared last night at a dinner given in his honor by the Church Club of New York. Discussing the spirit of Britain after nearly five years of war, the Archbishop, the Most Rev. Cyril Forster Garbett, told the 800 attending at the affair at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria:

CINCINNATI, April 26 (AP) -- A court martial trying the biggest case growing out of the nation's four-year war production effort found three AAF officers guilty today of neglect of their duty to stamp out what the Government described as malpractices in inspection of airplane engines and parts at the $155,000,000 Lockland, Ohio, plant of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation.

A little yellow door and a big real estate company have become involved in a controversy. The door of Mary Lewis' new dress shop at 746 Fifth Avenue is not dignified enough for one of the nicest blocks (between 57th and 58th Streets) on the Avenue, according to Brown Wheelock, Harris, Stevens.

Fortune Gallo's San Carlo Opera Company opened its twelve-day spring season at the Center Theatre last night with a smooth and spirited performance of Bizet's "Carmen." All of the participants entered enthusiastically into their respective contributions to the presentation as a whole, resulting in an interpretation that was brim full of life and evoked hearty demonstrations of approval from the large audience.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Civilians doing expert work at War Department posts, arsenals and other stations may be retained for the same duties even after induction into the Army under an order issued recently by the War Department, it was learned today.
BERNE, Switzerland, April 26 -- For the first time since the exodus of June, 1940, Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain went to Paris today returning to Vichy later in the evening.

CERVARO, Italy, April 26 -- In other days when Anita Canale flung open the broad windows on the second floor of her trim and sturdy home here, she could see the majestic summit of Mount Cassino, topped by the abbey, less than four miles away.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 26 (AP) -- The War Department will not use any of the 10,000 Japanese-Americans in uniform as combat soldiers against the Japanese Imperial Army because of possible enemy retaliation and "considerable confusion and increasing hazards of enemy infiltration," the Army notified the War Relocation Authority today.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- With butter supplies at the highest levels since September, the Office of Price Administration said today that beginning Sunday it would slash ration point values for the commodity to twelve points from the present level of sixteen.

You have reported food gluts locally in potatoes, eggs and fish. Now Mayor La Guardia urges a boycott of the latter to bring down prices; also "the Mayor insisted that bacon at 42 cents a pound for sliced and 33 cents for slab is 'just too high' in view of the 'abundance of pork products.'"

LOS ANGELES, April 26 -- The heads of fifteen of the country's leading aircraft companies, sitting as the board of governors of a rejuvenated Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America, today joined in asking for the early drafting of an American air-power policy and in setting forth a group of suggested principles to guide it.

LONDON, April 26 (U.P.) -- One of four German destroyers on anti-invasion patrol in the English Channel was sunk today by British and Canadian warships and the three others, possibly damaged, fled under a smoke screen.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The United Federal Workers of America, an affiliate of the CIO, today filed a complaint in the District Court of the United States for the District of Columbia requesting that the Civil Service Commission be enjoined from enforcing Section 9 (a) of the Hatch act, which prohibits political activity by Federal employes.
LONDON, April 26 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

The story of the battle of the Warsaw Ghetto, as told by Harold Denny in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Wednesday, April 19, 1944, requires some correction. According to Mr. Denny, the special messenger from the Polish underground, who just reached London, said: "The revolt came not by deliberate plan but spontaneously, out of desperation."

The American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation recently opened its third plant for the production of magnesium castings for airplane engines and is doing considerable work for Navy ships and landing barges, Henry M. Reed, chairman and president, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders here.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- President Roosevelt declared May 22 to be National Maritime Day in a proclamation today which called for public recognition of "the patriotism, courage, sacrifice and labor" of the men and women "ashore and afloat" who have worked in building and manning our merchant marine.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- An improved, partly managed gold standard administered by central banks free of Government domination, was advocated before the House Foreign Affairs Committee today by Prof. Edwin Walter Kemmerer of Princeton University.

Edward Salner, formerly with the Bartlett Hayward division, Baltimore, of the Koppers Company has been appointed manager of industrial relations of the company's tar and chemical division with headquarters in Pittsburgh.

A resurgence of British interest in Latin America as a post-war market is indicated in two separate actions proceeding in the market, exporters reported yesterday. Great Britain, it was said, has prepared a contract with Chile for the annual purchase of 750,000 tons of Chilean nitrate for several years, with the possible option of buying 3,000,000 tons at the end of this year.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Eighty per cent of the women's wash dress business is gone, Robert A. Seidel, of W.T. Grant Co., a low-cost department store chain, today told the House Banking and Currency Committee in testimony directed against OPA's highest price line rulings.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, after hearing Leo T. Crowley, Foreign Economic Administrator, trace military successes attributable to lend-lease aid and declare that there could be no slackening of the program "until the United Nations' armies finally march down the streets of Berlin and Tokyo," approved unanimously today the House-adopted bill extending for another year the existing reciprocal agreements with more than forty countries.

LONDON, April 26 -- Prime Minister Churchill told the House of Commons today there was not the "slightest question of any cession of British territories" in the leasing in September, 1940, of bases to the United States in exchange for fifty American destroyers.

The nation's gasoline stocks at the close of last week were 88,729,000 barrels, a decline of 49,000 from the 88,778,000 a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A year ago, they were 90,751,000 barrels.

Establishment of "termination teams," empowered to verify and approve payment of grouped contract cancellation claims, was called for yesterday in a plan worked out by representatives of industrial companies in cooperation with contracting officers of several government procurement agencies.

Mrs. Ruth Williams Ricci of this city, a private in the Wacs, received the American Newspaper Publishers Association gold medal and a cash prize of $500 yesterday as winner of the first prize in the third annual ANPA monograph contest, conducted this year on the topic "Newspaper Achievements and Responsibilities in Post-War Readjustment."

Mayor La Guardia has filed with the Army, Navy and other agencies in Washington a vigorous protest against the relocation of Japanese-Americans in New York City or in any of the States on the Eastern seaboard, it was revealed last night.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- President Roosevelt directed Secretary Jesse Jones this afternoon to take over the Chicago plants of Montgomery Ward Co., following its ignoring of his Sunday telegram setting noon yesterday as a deadline for taking steps to settle its labor dispute.

PEARL HARBOR, April 26 (AP) -- The far-reaching American aerial arm struck at Japan's far northern Kurile Islands Monday night, for the second consecutive night, and also delivered a thirty-six-ton bombing attack on the enemy's Caroline Islands fortress of Truk, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz disclosed today.

The occupational group system advocated by the Catholic Church and some form of collectivism, sponsored principally by left-wing liberal groups, are the two leading theories for reconstruction of the social order, Mgr. John A. Ryan, director of the social action department of the National Catholic Welfare Conference in Washington, said yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 26 -- The Greek political crisis accompanying the recent serious mutiny that was crushed early this week was temporarily solved by the appointment of a new government, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Unification of command of the armed services not only is desirable but should begin before the end of this war so that advantage may be taken of the bitter but effective experience it offers, rather than dawdling over possible procedures when peace has come again.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 26 -- While the Swedish people were uneasily wondering whether Ger many's latest moves in Scandinavia presage a military invasion of their country, the news reaching here tonight from Denmark suggests at least that a blockade will be applied to travelers and communications between Denmark and Sweden.

ST. LOUIS, April 26 -- The equal rights amendment, a subject which has divided the ranks of women's organizations for many years, gained new supporters tonight when announcement was made that a recent poll of the 16,500 members groups of the general Federation of Women's Clubs showed an overwhelming majority in favor of the measure.

SEATTLE, April 26 (AP) -- The Boeing Airplane Company and subsidiaries reported today net profits of $4,482,870 for 1943, or $4.14 a share, compared with $5,237,624, or $4.84 a share, for the preceding year.

CHICAGO, April 26 (AP) -- Purcell L. Smith, president of the Middle West Corporation, asserted today in his annual report to stockholders that some rural electric cooperatives receiving power from Middle West companies were using this energy to compete with utility concerns.

Reports from Mexico City yesterday stated that the Mexican Government had decided finally to place an embargo on the export or import of gold, except by the Bank of Mexico. Apparently this action was taken on the recommendation of the Mexican Bankers Association made at the association's annual meeting last week.

Unlike some cheats in Atlanta, Ga., and Covington, Ky., who have been jamming coin-box mechanisms on street railways and buses by dropping ration tokens into them, New Yorkers have not fouled a single fare device on the municipal transportation system with the little red and blue disks.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 26 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration moved today to prevent payment to Mohawk-Hudson area producers of a State-ordered increase of 60 cents a hundred pounds over the ceiling price of fluid milk.

Dr. Morris Fishbein, editor of The Journal of the American Medical Association, asserted last night that socialization of medicine in this nation would "inevitably inhibit the advancement of medical science and lower the quality of medical service."

A new synthetic rubber process employing lactic acid, a fermentation product of milk, molasses, starch and other abundant and cheap carbohydrates, was described yesterday at a meeting of the rubber division of the American Chemical Society in the Hotel Commodore.
LONDON, April 26 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

The season of the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House, which was to have closed on May 7, has been extended for an additional two weeks by S. Hurok. The added performances will contain as novelty a revival by Catherine Littlefield of her ballet, "Barn Dance," originally composed for the now defunct Philadelphia Ballet.

Charges that being a Nazi-hater, taking a drink of sherry, smoking excessively or making a bet on a horse race were indications of an unsound mind were held to be "flimsy and ludicrous" by Surrogate James A. Foley, who after two days of a trial directed a jury yesterday to bring in a verdict admitting to probate the will of August Kiel.

Amos E. Taylor, director of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce of the Department of Commerce, declared yesterday at the graduation of 123 cadets from the New York State Maritime Academy at Fort Schuyler, the Bronx, that the United States had overcome its war losses and now possessed the largest merchant fleet in the world.

ALGIERS, April 26 -- When the Provisional Consultative Assembly meets next week to discuss the war policy, aid to France and foreign affairs, there will probably be further murmurs of opposition and perhaps outspoken speeches, but nothing like the parliamentary revolt that had seemed possible lately.

Tonight's events: "La Traviata," San Carlo Opera, Center Theatre, 8:30 o'clock; benefit concert by Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra for Red Mogen Dovid, Palestine first-aid agency, Leonard Bernstein conducting, Selma Kramer, pianist, assisting artist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; program of portraitures in song, Bartalini, Times Hall, 8:30; concert, Glee Club of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick, George Mead conducting, Town Hall, 8:30.
LONDON, April 26 (UP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

A memorial concert for Joseph Achron, distinguished composer, who died a year ago, was held at Town Hall last night. The featured work on the program was the first public performance of one of Achron's last works, a concerto for piano alone, Op. 74. It was performed by Edward Steuermann.

KANSAS CITY, April 26 (AP) -- The world's 8,000,000 Methodists "must rise up * * * and demand an international organization which will make another war impossible," Bishop Arthur Moore of Atlanta told 762 delegates at the church's quadrennial general conference here tonight.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 26 -- The Prensa, great Buenos Aires democratic daily, which ranks among the first half-dozen organs of public opinion in the world was suspended for five days today. It was perhaps the most fearless of all Argentine newspapers in opposition to the policies of the Argentine military governments that succeeded one another since the revolution of June 4, 1943.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (UP) -- A Pacific Fleet announcement:

The seven-story building at 84-94 Hudson Street, southeast corner of Leonard Street, has been leased by the American Book-Stratford Press, Inc., for a long term from the Duke of Roxburghe. It contains about 70,000 square feet of space, including interior loading facilities for seven truck, and will be used as a warehouse for the lessee's expanding business.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Fluctuating stock-market prices, which started reflecting the uncertainties of war after France fell in 1939, have been going through a period of stability since last July, fluctuating within a range of only seven points in the index, the Department of Commerce said today.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Mrs. John Curtin, a Prime Minister's wife who does all her own housework and shopping because "there's no help to be had under Australia's national service system," today gave many honest opinions of matters American and Australian at the first press conference she has ever held.

LONDON, Thursday, April 27 -- A daring attack yesterday morning by British Fleet Air Arm planes against a large German convoy off northern Norway, in which at least five enemy ships were hit, was revealed early this morning in a brief communique issued by the Admiralty.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., April 26 -- A War Department telegram received last night by the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Harold R. Husted of this city notifying them their son, First Lieut. William D. Husted, navigator of a Flying Fortress, was reported missing in action April 11 came as belated news to the parents, who already had received a letter by him to be delivered in the event he was listed as missing.

"This Is the Life," a comedy produced by Universal from the Sinclair Lewis-Fay Wray play, "Angela Is 22," will have its premiere this morning at Loew's State. Heading the cast are Donald O'Connor, Susanna Foster, Patric Knowles, Louise Allbritton, Eddie Quillan, Peggy Ryan and Dorothy Peterson.

Consolidated net sales of the City Stores Company, which controls a chain of department stores largely in the South, and its subsidiaries, for the year ended on Jan. 31 rose $7,275,114, or 12 per cent, to a new high mark of $67,898,670 from the previous year's volume of $60,623,556, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

The annual report of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, issued yesterday, showed a combined net income for the year ended on Dec. 25 of $12,920,455, equal after preferred dividend requirements to $6.52 a common share.

The first rose show held in New York since November, 1942, opened yesterday at John Wanamaker's with a lavish demonstration of the versatility of roses as floral decorations for all kinds of table settings. The display, which will remain on view today, is sponsored by the growers' association, Roses Inc., which donated the flowers, in cooperation with the Women's Florists Association, which arranged the show.

Elmer Rice is diligently at work these days putting the finishing touches on a brand new play, as yet untitled. When the script is completed it will go to Jed Harris, who will produce the work next season in conjunction with the Playwrights' Company marking their first managerial association.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Following are the texts of President Roosevelt's order for the seizure of the Montgomery Ward Co. plant in Chicago, Attorney General Biddle's opinion and a letter sent to Sewell L. Avery, chairman of the company, by Secretary Jones.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, April 26 (AP) -- Waves of Japanese jungle troops are throwing themselves desperately against Allied road blocks in central Burma and are "perishing in droves" as they try to break the stranglehold clamped on their communications by thousands of airborne Chindits, an Allied spokesman announced today.

We are living in a fool's paradise of food abundance, Dr. F.A. Harper of the Department of Agricultural Economics, Cornell University, declared yesterday at the first in a series of Wednesday morning lectures sponsored by the New York State Emergency Food Commission's Wartime School for Housewives.

Retail Stores in the Midwest are recognizing the selling value of labels on garments which were allowed to remain because of the scarcity of sales help, according to Miss Rajean Codish of the Consumer Service Division of the United States Testing Company, Inc., Hoboken, who recently returned from a trip through that section.

Montgomery Ward Co., Inc., one of the country's largest retail and mail order chain stores, had a net income in the twelve months ended on Jan. 31 of $20,677,098, or $3.69 a share on the common stock. This, however, represented a decline compared with 1942, when the net income was in excess of $26,000,000, or $4.79 a share.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 26 (AP) -- A surprise victory by M.B. Goff's Skytracer in the $10,000 added Blue Grass Stakes at Churchill Downs today confirmed the consensus that this year's Kentucky Derby would be a wide-open affair.

LONDON, Thursday, April 27 -- Brunswick, important railway junction and a center of Messerschmitt production 110 miles west of Berlin, was hammered by a fleet of about 500 Flying Fortresses and Liberators yesterday.

More than ten million books were distributed to the armed forces during 1942 and 1943 by the sponsors of the Victory Book campaign. These books, representing the suitable and undamaged 60 per cent of the total contributed by the American people, ranged from classics to light fiction and technical fields.

Scoring eleven runs in the first two innings, C.C.N.Y.'s hard-hitting baseball team had an easy time defeating Brooklyn College, 18 to 8, yesterday in a Metropolitan Collegiate Conference game on the Brooklyn diamond. Every man except one in the starting City line-up hit safely, George Tunick's five hits in as many times at bat pacing the attack.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The impending Senate fight over repeal of the poll tax in eight Southern States appeared tonight to be heading toward a repetition of the last contest on this issue in 1942, when the legislation was withdrawn after failure of its proponents to invoke closure to halt a filibuster.

The Army has been able to cut the convalescent period of wounded men in two and return them to the front lines in better physical condition than before, Lieut. Col. Howard A. Rusk, chief of the Convalescent Rehabilitation Program, Medical Services Division, Headquarters Army Air Forces, reported last night.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- The War Department today pointedly disowned Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton's remark that the Americans, British and Russians were destined "to rule the world."

PHILADELPHIA, April 26, -- A demand by the Indian workers' delegate that the International Labor Organization meeting here draw up at once a set of principles to guide Governments, in dealing with their colonial possessions touched off a debate today between, British and Australian Government delegates during which London was accused of "timidity" in meeting the issue.

DOVER, N.J., April 25 -- Men under 26 years of age who work in the Government's Picatinny Arsenal here may be drafted and then be assigned to carry on with their old jobs, in Army uniform and at Army pay, it was disclosed here today.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Ceiling prices effective May 1 on pulpwood imported from the Canadian provinces of Quebec, New Brunswick and Nova Scotia were announced by the Office of Price Administration today in a move which it said would increase the supply.

CHICAGO, April 26 -- Buying of July wheat today by houses with Southwestern connections, which brokers regarded as for mills, gave the market for that grain on the Board of Trade a rather firm undertone, and although the deferred deliveries were under some pressure, the market rallied late and closing trades were unchanged to 1/2 cent a bushel higher on the day, the latter on July.

More than $210,000 has been raised to date by the Red Cross Greater New York 1944 War Fund Sports Committee and a much larger total is in prospect. Announcement of the progress of the committee was made yesterday by Albert J. Pitman, Red Cross headquarters representative.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26 -- The decisive "write-in" vote polled by Gov. Thomas E. Dewey in the Republican preference balloting in Tuesday's Pennsylvania primary appeared today to have assured the New York State Executive of the support of this State's seventy delegates to the party's national convention.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Thursday, April 27 -- In an amazing over-water operation on the fresh-water Lake Sentani American doughboys bypassed Japanese positions and on Tuesday captured two of Hollandia's key airdromes, Sentani and Cyclops, after killing 100 Japanese, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced in a communique today.

ALBANY, April 26 -- Budget Director E.W. Burton made public tonight the interpretation of the Corporation Tax Bureau of the State Tax Commission in respect to Chapter 510 of this year's laws as to Federal renegotiation of war contracts, and its effect on the computation of the State's franchise taxes under Article 9-A of the tax law.

Supreme Court Justice Thomas J. Cuff, sitting in Brooklyn, ruled yesterday that Mrs. Caroline Burdy of 31-13 Thirty-fourth Street, Astoria, Queens, was not guilty of contempt of court when she refused to testify before Queens County Judge Joseph M. Conroy at the trial of her husband, John, who was accused of possessing a pistol without a permit.

While forty-one tons of valuable waste paper less than the amount picked up last week was collected yesterday by Department of Sanitation trucks throughout the five boroughs, officials said the "harvest" was more useful becaust patriotic housewives were taking more care in bundling clean paper that can all be converted into war material wrappings and containers.

A broad investigation of an increasing number of violations of the fabric conservation order, L-224, covering the men's and boys' clothing industries, is under way by the compliance division, New York region, of the War Production Board, it was learned yesterday.

NAPLES, April 26 (U.P.) -- American troops, giving a bold advance notice of their attack by a "voice of doom" warning for the Germans to surrender, have moved within twenty-four miles of Rome in a series of thrusts at the center of the Anzio beachhead line, dispatches revealed today.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 26 --County Executive J. Russel Sprague announced today that service men in uniform would be permitted to play golf free for the duration of the war at the county-owned Salisbury golf courses in Westbury.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- The War Food Administration announced today that dairy production subsidy payment rates would be reduced 15 cents a hundred pounds on whole milk and 2 cents a pound on butterfat during May, June, July and August.

The first far-reaching plan for rehabilitation of the casualties of war and industry comes from Bernard Baruch. Impressed by the possibilities of physical medicine (the treatment of disease and injuries by light, water, massage and mechanical and electrical means), he will distribute $1,100,000 among various institutions which are to train physiotherapists and to engage in research.

The striped bass have begun their run along the Long Island shore and this week-end, given better weather than has been on tap during the past few weeks, should see devotees of the art of surf casting out in full strength.

BAYONNE, N.J., April 26 -- Bayonne's seventy-fifth anniversary of its incorporation was observed in City Hall today where the proceedings of the first meeting of the City Council were reenacted before a throng that filled the Council Chamber to capacity.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Attorney General Francis Diddle denied today the statement made yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers that the Justice Department refused to let members of an oil industry advisory committee participate with departmental officials in Anglo-American oil talks now going on or make suggestions or criticisms.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 26 -- Jack Carson has been assigned by Warner Brothers to the lead, with Rosalind Russell, in "Roughly Speaking." The picture will be put into production tomorrow under the direction of Michael Curtiz. Carson, who is now in the cast of "The Doughgirls," will portray the second husband of Louise Randall Pierson, author of the factual family story.

CHUNGKING, China, April 26 (UP) -- Mitchell bombers of the Fourteenth United States Air Force bombed and sank a 150-foot Japanese steamer and left another listing badly off the southeastern coast of Hainan Island Monday, a communique from Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters said today.

John Mendicino of The Chicago Sun was declared the winner of the national grand prize of a $500 War Bond in the National News Picture Contest of the United States Victory Waste Paper Campaign yesterday.
