The results of the contest were announced by Linwood I. Noyes, president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, at the convention of that organization at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (U.P.) --Army air forces opened its ranks to some 11,000 Civilian flying instructors and trainees tonight in a move apparently designed to meet criticism that such talent was being overlooked while the A@rmy continued to train@less experienced women fliers as Wasps.

Ralph Branca hung up his second consecutive shut-out yesterday as the New York University baseball team overwhelmed Stevens Tech, 9 to 0, at Ohio Field. The triumph was the third in a row for the Violets, who haven't been beaten since Navy turned the trick in the opener.

ST. LOUIS, April 26 (AP) -- With a four-run uprising in the sixth inning, the Browns beat the Indians 5 to 2, today to remain the only undefeated major league team. Their seventh consecutive victory at the opening of the season tied the American League record set by the Yankees in 1933. The National League record is nine.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- Early Wynn limited the Red Sox to six scattered singles today as the Senators scored a 2 -- 1 victory to even the series. It was Wynn's second victory.

The total volume of construction work in this country during the first decade after war should at least double the average annual volume for the decade which began in 1930, in the opinion of Thomas S. Holden, president of the F.W. Dodge Corporation.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Support of the plan to combine the War and Navy Departments after the war into a Department of the Armed Forces is very strong. No more appealing proposal to apply certain lessons of the war is before Congress. Thousands of officers and men in the Army and the Navy -- though a lesser percentage in the air forces -- favor it, the result of battle experience.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- Early Wynn limited the Red Sox to six scattered singles today as the Senators scored a 2 -- 1 victory to even the series. It was Wynn's second victory.

The total volume of construction work in this country during the first decade after war should at least double the average annual volume for the decade which began in 1930, in the opinion of Thomas S. Holden, president of the F.W. Dodge Corporation.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Support of the plan to combine the War and Navy Departments after the war into a Department of the Armed Forces is very strong. No more appealing proposal to apply certain lessons of the war is before Congress. Thousands of officers and men in the Army and the Navy -- though a lesser percentage in the air forces -- favor it, the result of battle experience.

Store modernization programs, new products, personnel research and better selling will put drug retailing in a strongly entrenched position to meet post-war problems, speakers said yesterday at the luncheon closing the three-day meeting of the Affiliated Drug Stores in the Hotel Biltmore.

A syndicate headed by Stranahan, Harris Co., Inc., and John Nuveen Co. won yesterday the award of $5,350,000 of Lakeland, Fla., 3 per cent refunding bonds due serially from July 1, 1945, to 1971. The price paid was 100.02.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 26 (AP) -- The controversial novel, "Strange Fruit," by Lillian Smith, was adjudged "obscene" by District Court Judge Arthur P. Stone today, although he said it was "a story that might be told," and Abraham Isenstadt, Cambridge bookseller was fined $200 for possessing and selling it.

LONDON, April 26 -- The Polish underground army, in its most daring and effective blows to date, has blown up railway bridges on two lines leading to Lwow, the key to the German defenses in southern Poland.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruquay, April 26 -- The Federal Commissioner of the Argentine Province of Tucuman has expropriated an electric power company called Compania Hidro-Electrica de Tucuman, a subsidiary of the American and Foreign Power Company.

The mixing unit in the Municipal Asphalt Plant, over whose aesthetic lure there is a difference of opinion between Park Commissioner Robert Moses and the Museum of Modern Art, looks very much like the "shell" from which symphony orchestras project their music in open-air performances.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- William H. Davis, chairman of the National War Labor Board, sent telegrams today to James C. Petrillo, president, and to officials of two locals of the American Federation of Musicians directing them to appear before the board Monday to show cause why penalties should not be visited upon them for refusing to call off strikes of musicians in Chicago and Minneapolis.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer yesterday announced details of the Annual Novel Award which the company will make for the first time on Aug. 15. The winning author of a work of fiction containing not less than 40,000 words will receive a cash award of $125,000, plus royalties not to exceed $50,000. To the publisher of the winning novel will be paid an additional $25,000.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, April 26 -- Seaborne generals and land-based admirals featured the United States landings on Netherland New Guinea, it was disclosed today, when the names of the commanders were made public.

PLYMOUTH, England, April 26 -- In improvised quarters only a stone's throw from the completely devastated center of Plymouth a committee of the City Council met today with delegates from satellite towns on the periphery to consider a daring and far-sighted plan to rebuild the ancient city in a modern manner.
Price fluctuations on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday were narrow, but the finish was steady at net gains of 3 to 5 points on active months. The volume of business was moderate.

Selected issues imparted yesterday a better tone to the stock market, but the turnover was one of the lightest so far this year. The improvement embraced approximately one-half of the active issues, but gains in the main were limited to fractions.

NEWARK, N.J., April 26 -- The contents of a score of letters purporting to prove that the German-American Vocational League carried on an almost uninterrupted daily correspondence with the Berlin office of the German Labor Front were read today to the jury in Federal Court here at the propaganda conspiracy trial involving nineteen men and two corporations.
Howard E. Kershner, chairman of the Temporary Council on Food for Europe's Children, appealed yesterday to President Roosevelt to "start the mercy ships before it is too late."

What ho! Bring us a flagon of your best ale. Quaff it, Piscator, tellin' of the cruise of Mary Ellen and the illuminated flounder caught off the Jersey shore. Five Mary Elleners brought the spoil into Fulton Fish Market, calling it a fluke, which the same in American is a flounder.

In recognition of their sale of $7,250,000 in war bonds during the Fourth War Loan drive, Treasury Department citations were presented last night to seventeen B'nai B'rith Lodges and women's auxiliaries in the metropolitan area at a dinner-meeting of the B'nai B'rith War Service Council of Greater New York at the Fifth Avenue Hotel.
CHICAGO, April 26 -- Troops took possession tonight of the Chicago headquarters of Montgomery Ward Co., $300,000,000 mail order and chain store corporation.

CHICAGO, April 26 -- After debate by delegates of strongly divided opinions, especially on the subject of eliminating their State groups, the National League of Women Voters voted today to recommit, without decision, most of the proposed new by-laws.

Declaring that remarkable reductions had been achieved in the accident rate of newspaper trucks as a result of the annual safe-driving contests, Linwood I Noyes, president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, announced yesterday at the convention of that organization at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria the results of the third yearly contest jointly sponsored by the ANPA and the International Circulation Managers Association.

Last week's 334-to-21 vote in the House and yesterday's recommendation of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee have made certain the extension of the Lend-Lease system for another year. No other action would be conceivable. Lend-Lease is an integral part of the war.
The twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the Newark Real Estate Board will be marked by a dinner on Saturday evening at the Newark Athletic Club. James J. Fitzsimmons is chairman of the event.

LONDON, April 26 -- Sweden is to be asked to reconsider her refusal to reduce her exports of ball-bearings to Germany, it was learned today. This became known as it was disclosed that a British military mission has arrived in Turkey, which has halted exports of chrome to Germany, to take up discussions where they were left off last February when the Turks became bashful over their alliance with Britain.

The newspapers of this country should keep uppermost in mind their responsibility as the guardians of our constitutional liberties, Linwood I. Noyes, president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, declared yesterday at the first general session of its fifty-eighth annual convention, meeting at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
DUBLIN, Eire, April 26 -- A filly paid off at 467 to 1 today at the Punchestown steeplechase meeting near here -- but that was only one of the odd occurrences in connection with the meeting.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- A tentative jury for the sedition trial remained seated today after five members were excused but replaced in a gavel-resounding session interrupted continuously by "out-of-order" defense attorneys objecting to procedure. Each side, the Government and the thirty defendants, used up six of their ten peremptory challenges.
LONDON, April 26 -- Britain is suffering from an embarrassment of riches in the matter of allies.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Friday, April 28 (AP) -- The bypassed and isolated Japanese base of Wewak, New Guinea, was raided by more than 120 Bostons that dropped sixty tons of bombs.

The Board of Estimate unanimously adopted yesterday a budget of $737,400,923 for 1944-45, increasing by $67,775 the total fixed in the executive budget of $737,333,148 submitted by Mayor La Guardia on April 1.

The German Transkontinent agency, in a wireless dispatch directed to the Turkish press, reported that "a Wilhelmstrasse military spokesman" had made a statement Thursday calling Turkey's suspension of chrome supplies to Germany a "breach of agreement."

With a message from President Roosevelt hailing its work and activity, the Committee for the Care of the Jewish Tuberculous, social welfare agency of the New York Federation of Jewish Charities, celebrated last night its thirtieth anniversary with a dinner at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

ST. LOUIS, April 27 -- After a spirited debate, the General Federation of Women's Clubs voted today in favor of Federal support of the school luncheon program and approved a resolution to petition Congress for restoration of the $50,000,000 annual contribution recently withdrawn.

HOLLYWVOOD, Calif., April 27 -- Anne Baxter, now appearing in the lead in "Guest in the House" for Hunt Stromberg, will return to Twentieth Century-Fox on completion of the picture for the principal feminine role in "Sunday Dinner for a Soldier."

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Congressional reaction to the seizure of the Montgomery Ward plant was marked today by the introduction of a resolution in the House by Charles S. Dewey, Republican, of Illinois, calling for appointment of a committee of seven to investigate the action against the Chicago company.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 27 -- Hard on the heels of yesterday's suspension for five days of the great Buenos Aires democratic newspaper, Prensa, comes another most extraordinary measure that emphasizes what the army officers, who at present are ruling Argentina, think of the press and of its functions.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, April 27--Only a handful of American soldiers are getting home under the program that has been functioning for several months in the southwest Pacific area under which men who have served a long time overseas, particularly in the forward areas, are to be replaced.

ALBANY, April 27 -- Of the 249 applicants for admission to the bar who took the examinations on March 2 and 3 only 112 were successful, it was announced today by John Kirkland Clark of New York City, Philip J. Wickser of Buffalo and John T. DeGraff of Albany, comprising the Board of Law Examiners.

Argentina's preposterous Government, still trying to introduce into this hemisphere Fascist ideas which have been the ruination of Europe, has just honored the Prensa, one of the great dailies of Buenos Aires, by suppressing it for five days. The editors of the Prensa had charged that the Government had introduced such stringent economies into the Buenos Aires hospitals that patients were suffering.

Fluctuations in prices for cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday were narrow again, but the undertone continued steady with final prices 3 to 5 points higher on the day on active months. Trade support continued in near months, while liquidation supplied most of the contracts.

CHICAGO, April 27--In a specified and virtually unprecedented night hearing, Judge William H. Holly of the Federal District Court at 10:50 o'clock tonight granted a temporary injunction to the Government restraining officials of Montgomery Ward Co. from interfering with the Government's operation of the plant, which was seized with the help of soldiers yesterday.
CINCINNATI, April 27 (AP) -- Twenty-one innings of scoreless ball ended for St. Louis today as the Cards beat the Reds, 3 -- 2, for their only victory in the series of three games.

MUNSINGEN, Switzerland, April 28 (AP) -- Twelve young American fliers killed in action or crashes were buried with full military honors today in a peaceful little cemetery over which fly the Stars and Stripes and where all American airmen who have lost their lives in Switzerland will lie.

A druggist who sold harmful "sleeping capsules" without a doctor's prescription to Mo Fu, a Chinese sleuth, was sentenced yesterday in the Municipal Term Court to a thirty-day workhouse term. The druggist, Walter Hochberg, 27 years old, of 95 Lenox Avenue, was also fined $500, which, if not paid, will add 100 days to the jail term.
ST. LOUIS, April 27 (AP) -- Like "Ol' Man River," the unbelievable Browns just keep rollin' along.

LONDON, April 27 (AP) -- The statement of condition of the Bank of England for the week ended yesterday, issued today, reported a new high record for note circulation with an increase of u3,716,000 to u1,124,473,000.

MOSCOW, April 27 (U.P.) -- Red Star, the Russian Army newspaper, charged today that German troops in northern Finland had established a frontier behind which they were plundering Finnish resources, including nickel reserves and forest wealth, and making wide use of slave labor conscripted from the Finnish inhabitants.

CINCINNATI, April 27 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Musicians Union, an AFL affiliate, announced today that Eugene Goossens, conductor, and five other members of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra had been fined in amounts ranging from $100 to $2,500 on what it termed "charges of conduct detrimental to the association during negotiations for a contract" for the 1944-45 symphony season.

The children stole the show yesterday at the Hotel Plaza but everyone was delighted, including the grown-up models, who were the mothers of the children, and Bonwit Teller who dressed them all. Fashions for the younger generation, starting at 16 months, and for their mothers were shown in two settings.

The joint board of the New York State Racing Commission and The Jockey Club yesterday rendered its decision in the case of Jockey Bobby Merritt who, set down in 1942 and denied a riding license in 1943, had won a review on his appeal to the State courts.

The advisory board of Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism opened its annual two-day meeting at the school yesterday to consider recommendations for the Pulitzer prizes in letters, journalism and music. The awards will be made on Monday.

Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday that tons of obsolete records, accumulated in the last twenty years in the store rooms, files and vaults of 1,100 member firms and branch offices, are being turned over to the city's waste paper drive. In a letter to all member firms, he wrote:

The Foreign Funds Control Department of the Treasury has just issued new rules which relax to some extent the limitations on acquisitions of securities for foreign accounts blocked in this country. Up to now such a blocked account could not hold securities of a given company if the amount held exceeded 1 per cent of the total of such securities outstanding.

The office of distribution of the War Food Administration has leased nine floors -- the eleventh to nineteenth, inclusive -- in the Westinghouse Building at 150 Broadway, together with part of the twenty-second floor, and has renewed its lease on the entire sixth floor in the building, through Carl A. Leasenfeld, broker.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- A rider designed to force the Interior Department to discharge many of its younger draft-deferred employes was written into the department's appropriation bill today even as Secretary Ickes was protesting that congressional reports of his agency's deferments were unfair.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- An American Catholic priest has gone to Russia at the invitation of the Soviet Government, it was learned today.

Devonshire Plymouth, so thoroughly blasted by the Germans in 1941, is to rise again, a better place to live in. If the city authorities and those of some of the neighboring towns can agree upon and finance a plan, they hope to make it a city of wider streets, of surrounding parkways, of small, neat houses, with country fields in sight.

Three thousand American-bred chinchilla pelts will be sold auction here next Tuesday by Lampson, Fraser Huth, marking the first sale of these rare furs since the wild types practically disappeared from the fur market some twenty years ago, Dr. M.R. Howard of Denver, fur breeder and chairman of the National Chinchilla Breeders Association, said in an interview here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- Secretary Ickes accused Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia of New York City and two Republican Governors, John W. Bricker of Ohio and Walter E. Edge of New Jersey, today of "racial discrimination" on the question of resettlement of Japanese-Americans.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- In an exchange of personal letters between Prime Minister Churchill and Dr. Antonio de Oliveira Salazar, Portuguese Prime Minister, Mr. Churchill, who initiated the exchange, urged the Lisbon Government to do away once for all with the wolfram exports to Germany.

A resolution recommending that equipment and facilities for physical fitness and recreation in the armed forces be made available for school and community use after the war was adopted yesterday by the American Association for Health, Physical Education and Recreation, at the closing session of a four-day convention in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

SEAT OF THE ITALIAN GOVERNMENT, April 27 -- Liberated Italy's new Government of National Union met this morning for the first time in the Council Chamber of the town hall in this small seaport town. All the Ministers were present, including those without portfolio.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 27 -- The Garden Pier Theatre, New Jersey Avenue and the Board-walk, was leased for three years today to Lee Shubert, New York theatrical producer.

HUTCHINSON, Kan., April 27 (AP) -- Artemus L. Gates, assistant Secretary of the Navy for Air, disclosed today that American air forces have expanded in the Pacific to the point where "we have been conducting 1,000-plane raids."

WASHINGTON, April 27 (U.P.) -- Henry F. Butler, Washington attorney for Montgomery Ward Co., today petitioned the Federal District Court here for a prompt trial of three suits requesting injunctions restraining the War Labor Board from enforcing a maintenance-of-membership order against the company.

Excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City, and for the nation as a whole, again declined in the week ended Wednesday, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Mrs. Mary Chirco of 606 Liberty Avenue, Brooklyn, received a suspended sentence yesterday from Judge Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. in General Sessions on the conspiracy charge to which she had pleaded guilty in July, 1942, in violating the State Banking Law when she was manager of the West Fifty-seventh Street office of the now defunct Madison Personal Loan Corporation.
PALO ALTO, Calif., April 27 -- Stanford University authorities have abolished all sororities "in the interests of campus unity" and ordered the sorority houses converted into residence halls.
In these trying days our faith in human nature is restored by some little incident or gesture such as happened to me this past Christmas.
The king cried bitterly. He wanted his shirt.
Two district prisons were closed yesterday by Peter F. Amoroso, Commissioner of Correction, in accordance with a consolidation program established by Mayor La Guardia.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Mayor La Guardia of New York, testifying before a Senate Military Affairs subcommittee on termination of war contracts today, presented a six-point program which he recommended as an aid in the converting of the economy frown a wartime to a peacetime basis.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- With weaker markets for certain agricultural commodities, principally rye, cotton, hogs, sheep, apples and onions, commodity prices in primary markets dropped 0.2 per cent during the week ended on April 22. The decline brought the Bureau of Labor Statistics all-commodity index of nearly 900 price series to 103.6 per cent of the 1926 average.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 27 -- That Soviet Russia is planning to widen the area of its diplomatic representation in the Middle East by establishing relations between the Armenian Soviet Republic and the governments of Syria and Lebanon is indicated by press reports reaching Cairo from Beirut, Lebanon.

Reports submitted yesterday at the second annual meeting of the New York Metropolitan Council of Fair Employment Practices at 40 East Fortieth Street disclosed that, despite manpower shortages, many employers still reject job applicants because of race, creed or color.

The finding and recommendations of a faculty-student committee investigating recent illegal election procedures at Columbia College were made public yesterday by Associate Dean Nicholas McD. McKnight together with an announcement that students guilty of misconduct were being asked to withdraw from all extra-curricular activities and were subject to academic discipline.

Inasmuch as this is a between-season period so far as lamb is concerned, there is very little to be had and the point value reductions, to become effective on Sunday, will be of small benefit to shoppers for the time being at least. Stocks of fed lamb are about running out, according to the War Food Administration.

CHICAGO, April 27 (AP) -- Bob Swift's twelfth-inning double with two mates aboard today settled a tight pitching duel between Hal Newhouser and Thornton Lee to give the Tigers a 2-to-0 victory over the White Sox. It was Chicago's fourth consecutive defeat.

PASSAIC, N.J., April 27 -- Chief Torpedoman Marvin H. De Vries, United States Navy, is home from the war after nearly two years of existence in the jungles of Japanese-held Mindanao in the Philippine Islands, but the story of his adventures there and his ultimate escape from that enemy stronghold apparently will have to remain a secret until the war is over.

LONDON, Friday, April 28 (U.P.) -- About 45,000,000 persons in the British Isles were isolated from the outside world at midnight last night when all normal travel to points abroad ceased under one of the most drastic anti-spy decrees ever promulgated.

BOSTON, April 27 -- Jim Tobin pitched himself into baseball immortality today against the Dodgers when he hurled the first no-hitter turned in by a Braves pitcher since Tom Hughes turned the trick against the Pirates here on June 16, 1916, and the Braves won by the same score, 2 -- 0, this afternoon as in the Houghes classic.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27 -- Committees on social security and post-war employment of the International Labor Organization conference got started today, ending what has been for most of the fourteen official women delegates a week of watchful waiting.

With the Bronx Zoo's Farm-in-the-Zoo scheduled to open to the public tomorrow, zoo officials were in a dither yesterday. Joe Kane, 46-year-old farmer who has been supervising the farm for the last year, has bought his own farm and there is no one to milk the cows.
The large exhibition of modern drawings and the exhibition of Cuban paintings at the Museum of Modern Art will close, respectively, on May 10 and May 7.

Daniel P. Woolley, head of the Regional Office of Price Administration, speaking last night at the opening of the new Harlem war price and rationing board at 144 West 125th Street, hinted that there might be "a tightening up" on shoe rationing.

LONDON, April 27 (AP) -- A blinded American hero of the North African campaign and his bride, a British Red Cross nurse, were flying to America tonight to make a fresh start in life, after the Army cut through red tape and pre-invasion restrictions to speed them on their journey.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Friday, April 28 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur and Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, America's two theatre commanders in the Pacific, have conferred at General MacArthur's Australian headquarters and worked out "completely integrated" plans for the campaign against Japan, according to a joint announcement made simultaneously here and at Pearl Harbor.

The question of cartels will come up again for consideration by stockholders of the Standard Oil Company (N.J.), according to the proxy statement for the meeting, which will be held on June 6 in Flemington, N.J. A minority group headed by William Floyd 2d of New York has notified the management that it intends to present for action a resolution that would forbid the company from participating in any cartel arrangement.

Not even the ungentle art of tuna fishing is going to escape the mechanical wonders created by the war if A. Paul King, who is active in New Jersey fishing circles, is right. The mechanical age will descend upon sport fishing via radar, which will be used to locate fish just as it now locates our enemies.
KANDY, Ceylon, April 27 (AP) -- A communique:

Prospects of Chile remaining a strong post-war market for American exporters are dimmed substantially by that country's concern that United States' purchases of copper and nitrate will be heavily curtailed before the rest of the world is in a position to use these commodities, Richard P. Butrick, economic counselor of the American Embassy in Chile, stated yesterday.

While in custody in Bellevue Hospital pending a hearing on a charge of stealing $225 from a patient, Miss Helen Prushinski, 24-year-old private nurse, of 437 East Eighty-sixth Street, had a temperature of 105, but what puzzled doctors, at first, was the fact that there was apparently nothing organically wrong with the nurse.

Development by du Pont chemists of a chemical plasticizer that makes synthetic rubber more workable so that it behaves more like natural rubber in the fabrication of tires was reported yesterday at the annual spring meeting of the rubber division of the American Chemical Society.

CHICAGO, April 27 (UP) -- "I've been fired before, but this is the first time they ever carried me out feet first," Sewell Avery, chairman of the board of Montgomery Ward Co., told The Chicago Daily News tonight in an exclusive copyrighted interview.

TOPEKA, Kans., April 27 (AP) -- Joint purchase of the Oklahoma Railway Company by the Santa Fe and Rock Island Railroads was authorized today at the forty-ninth annual meeting of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway Company's stockholders.

Numerous issues of fact and principle are involved in the seizure of the Chicago headquarters of the mail-order house of Montgomery Ward Co., and it is important that they be disentangled from one another.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- "The Races of Mankind," a publication of which 55,000 copies were bought by the Army for distribution among students of its orientation course, was assailed by a House Military Affairs subcommittee today as containing statements ranging "all the way from half-truths through innuendos to downright inaccuracies."

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY ON THE GARIGLIANO FRONT, April 27--The jeep spun across a sag in the road where the Germans had blown it up and engineers had put it together again. A little farther on a sign read: "American Cemetery," and the military police lieutenant said it was the farthest forward American cemetery in this sector.

JIM DURFEE was one of the quaintest football officials ever to work a game. He hated having to assess penalties and often he'd even them up by calling off-sides on both teams just so that one would not gain what he considered an unfair advantage over the other.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The illness of James True held up today the trial of himself and twenty-nine others in Federal District Court on charges of sedition.

The March 19 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES carried under the headline "A Bureaucratic Rule" a letter from Harley L. Lutz, Professor of Public Finance, Princeton University, in which Professor Lutz criticized the Treasury's regulations regarding the elimination or change of a beneficiary designated on War Savings Bonds of Series E.

James T. Neilson, 37 years old, a Harvard graduate, who gave up the ministry to become a lawyer, got off with a suspended sentence in General Sessions yesterday on his previous guilty plea to the theft of $35,000 from the Texas Oil Company when he was connected with its legal department.

DETROIT, April 27 (AP) -- Big Rudy York, major league homerun champion, was rejected today for military service because of a trick left knee, the result of an old basketball injury, and the Tigers immediately looked up timetables for an early departure from the American League's second division.

More than 800 delegates to the annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria spent most of the afternoon yesterday listening to engineering and organizational leaders in the frequency modulation radio field extoll FM's advantages and opportunities for all newspaper publishers, both large and small.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- To adjust wages to changes in living cost would accelerate inflationary trends, according to Donald R.G. Cowan, economist for the Republic Steel Corporation, who testified today before a panel of the National War Labor Board.

ALGIERS, April 27 -- French authorities concerned here said today that they had every expectation of harmonious cooperation with the Allies in France despite the divergencies between their legislative act of March 14 and the terms of Secretary of State Cordell Hull's speech of April 9.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 27 -- The House of Delegates of the Medical Society of New Jersey voted at its concluding session here today to make a 50 per cent reduction in medical fees for families of men in the military service when their incomes are not sufficient to maintain the American standard of living.

LONDON, Friday, April 28 (AP) -- Moscow said last night that the lull on the Eastern Front continued throught its sixth day yesterday, but the Germans declared the Russians still were attacking in northern Rumania and in the Carpathian foothills.

Governor Dewey's address last night before the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association will give new and strong encouragement to all those who hope that on the great issues of the war and the peace there will be an essential unity of American opinion.

Explosion, fire and flood were visited upon the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday morning, without loss of life and without injury to any of the 3,000 guests and employes. The fire was confined pretty much to the eighteenth, or top floor, where it started and where there are no guest rooms.

LONDON, April 27 -- Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King of Canada and Prime Minister Peter Fraser of New Zealand arrived here today by plane to meet and discuss with Prime Minister Churchill and two other Prime Ministers of the British Commonwealth, the problems that their respective countries will collectively and separately have to face when the main issue of defeating Germany and Japan is decided.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Acting on the unanimous recommendation of a special investigating board, which held that operation of the Breakers Hotel as an Army general hospital was an impracticable and financially unsound arrangement, the War Department announced definitely tonight that the Palm Beach resort would be returned to its owners Dec. 11.
VENTNOR, N.J., April 27 (AP) -Governor Edge said tonight that he would not decide whether to comment until after he had con sidered Secretary Ickes' entire statement.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- A decision of the Supreme Court in the Government's anti-trust suit against The Associated Press can hardly be expected before November or December at the earliest, it was surmised at the Department of Justice today.

Emmett Leo Kelly, the Big Show's sad-faced clown and star pantomimist, was anything but lachrymose at 6 P.M. yesterday when he married Miss Mildred Elizabeth Ritchie, aerialist in the Ringling Brothers, Barnum and Bailey Circus.

Mystery and detective story addicts will have an opportunity soon to hear four outstanding writers of this type of fiction describe the pitfalls into which they often fail in their endeavors to hide the identity of the criminal until the final chapter.

WASHINGTON, April 27--An appeal from Representative Frances P. Bolton of Ohio to the House Military Affairs Committee not to be "yes men for the War Department" but to grant Army nurses permanent rather than duration rank, brought today a free-for-all airing of committee opinion, in which it was charged that the War Department held up legislative action by delaying reports.

LONDON, April 27--While reported Nazi troop movements in Denmark and the severance of communications of that country with Sweden have naturally caused some uneasiness in Stockholm, the British are convinced that Nazi activities on the Jutland Peninsula are defensive rather than offensive in character. Adolf Hitler just has not got troops to spare for an adventure in Sweden, nor is there any political reason for doing so.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- Swift, concerted action has been urged on price and production authorities to head off a serious shortage of cotton textiles for civilians this year. Stabilization Director Fred M. Vinson, Chairman Donald M. Nelson of the War Production Board, and Price Administrator Chester Bowles are scheduled to confer tomorrow on means of coping with the shortage without clothes rationing.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The impending Senate fight over repeal of the poll tax in eight Southern States will begin on May 9, Senator Albert W. Barkley, Senate majority leader, announced today.

" Advertisers must develop a technique by which they can be informed before they inform others," C.C. Carr, advertising manager of Aluminum Corporation of America, said yesterday in outlining the theme of the program to be presented to members of the Association of National Advertisers at its annual meeting at the Westchester Country Club, Rye, N.Y., May 1-3.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27 (U.P.) -- Individual performers will enjoy only a small share of the spotlight in the fiftieth University of Pennsylvania relay carnival starting at Franklin Field tomorrow, with 2,000 athletes from 300 schools, colleges and service camps competing in the sixty-nine event two-day program.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- A special Senate subcommittee studying the plight of "white-collar" workers whose wages and salaries have remained static or risen less than the most conservative estimates of living cost increases, reported tonight that among 20,000,000 of them there has been imposed such inequality of sacrifice as to be "unjust, unnecessary and detrimental to the health, morale and efficiency of a nation at war."

Since the Blackfriars Guild prefers never to rest, it went on last evening to give its third drama of the current season. This time the play is something in the mood of China, "Earth Journey" by name, Sheldon Davis by authorship. It is a story of an emperor and his daughter, a temple priest and the temple idol who comes to life and behaves in quite normal fashion at the sight of the daughter.

Declaring that college football coaches were concerned over not only the rules being frozen but the possibility of their game being "frozen out" by professional football, Lou Little announced yesterday that, in self-defense, some college coaches were likely to enter into gentlemen's agreements to alleviate the situation during the 1944 season.

Asserting that through the War Labor Board the Government is now "managing one tremendously important phase of every newspaper employer's business," the special standing committee of the American Newspaper Publishers Association charged yesterday that findings of the WLB's boards "are indiscriminate and frequently unjust."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Friday, April 28 -- American infantrymen from Tanahmera and Humboldt Bays overwhelmed disorganized Japanese resistance and met Thursday on the big Hollandia airdrome to end the Hollandia campaign six days after their landing, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's communique today reported.

Stanley H. Fuld, one of the aides of Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor, in his drive against labor union and political racketeering, resigned yesterday as an assistant District Attorney, and head of the Appeals Bureau, to return to private practice.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- The War Shipping Administration said today the Navy had advised that the Liberty ship John Straub, previously reported to have broken its back at sea with a loss of sixty-five, had actually been destroyed "as a result of a violent explosion of undetermined origin."

PHILADELPHIA, April 27 -- The Canadian Government delegation attending the conference of the International Labor Organization introduced a resolution today designed to take from the current meeting the authority to define the role of the ILO in the post-war international order.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson, in commenting with satisfaction today that he considered the Allied bombings of Rumania a form of "meeting" with the advancing Soviet forces, dropped a hint that the end of the European war may be in sight.

BALTIMORE, April 27 (AP) -- A group of stockholders of the Certain-teed Products Corporation, manufacturer of building materials, who are seeking to oust the present management, won today dissolution of an injunction which had prevented election proceedings at an annual meeting April 12.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Friday, April 28 (AP) -- A communique:

Price Administrator Bowles' announcement with respect to the "highest price line limitation" involving further delay in settling an issue of major importance in low-cost distribution, and the claims he advanced in defense of the limitation, leave retailers "dumbfounded," Robert A. Seidel, controller of the W.T. Grant Company, said here yesterday.

The stock market progressed yesterday a little, although the rally was half-hearted and, except for individual situations, gains generally were fractional. Testing-out operations were apparent in several issues, but for the most part the demand exceeded the pressure that appeared in some recent favorites.

The General Foods Corporation, in its report of operations for the first three months of this year, announced yesterday record net sales of $78,312,122 and an increase of $17,248,551 over the $61,066,571 volume for the corresponding quarter a year ago.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 27 -- Planes with British markings today flew over Copenhagen and dropped faked leaflets, telling Danes that the hour of liberation was approaching but asking them to accept occupation by Russian or specially trained American Negro troops until the initial disorder resulting from military operations was over.

The Columbia Broadcasting System, in its first major statement on post-war policy, called yesterday for a completely new approach to the problems of television lest the public be caught with receivers that suddenly will become obsolete and the video art possibly suffer "eventual failure."
In the interest of reputable motor coach manufacturers, we feel the comments of Harry Roberts printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES in regard to safe travel in motor coaches must be answered.

CHICAGO, April 27 -- Clear weather prevailed over a large part of the grain belt today, resulting in creating bearish trading sentiment. There was some local pressure on wheat futures, and although a fair rally came at one time in sympathy with rye, it was not maintained in full and the active deliveries on the board of trade closed at losses of 1/8 to 1/2 cent a bushel.

Janet Reed last night stepped into the central role of Agnes de Mille's "Tally-Ho" for the first time in the Ballet Theatre's season at the Metropolitan Opera House. She had danced the role on the West Coast during the early performances of the piece, but thus far during the local engagement Miss de Mille herself has done it.

CHICAGO, April 27 -- A cleavage of opinion among delegates to the National League of Women Voters developed today when attempts were made to reconsider yesterday's action of recommiting the revised by-laws, which failed, and to re-open the nominations, which succeeded.

Under the auspices of George Abbott, "A Highland Fling," another play written by an actress as a vehicle for herself, makes its Broadway debut this evening at the Plymouth Theatre. Margaret Curtis is author of the comedy, in which she portrays one of the more important roles.

CHUNGKING, China, Friday April 28 (AP) -- Chinese military authorities announced today that Japanese troops had occupied the strategic railway junction of Chengchow in their new offensive in northern Honan Province to clear the north-south Peiping-Hankow line.

As the second offering of its spring season the San Carlo Opera Company presented Verdi's "La Traviata" last night at the Center Theatre. Stella Andreva, who appeared as guest artist, was the Violetta, and Pvt. Eugene Conley of the Army Air Force show, "Winged Victory," sang Alfredo with the special permission of that organization.

Military manpower demands have cut Britain's textile production to one-half of pre-war output, and the nation's industry has had no new machines made "at home" since the war began, Sir Frank Platt, British cotton controller, declared last night.
Following is the text of Governor Dewey's address last evening at the diviner of the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Associations, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Breaking his long silence on foreign policy, Governor Dewey called last night for the establishment of solid post-war relations among the United States, Great Britain, Russia and China. He proposed three fundamental principles for our foreign policy, which, he declared, would command the overwhelming support of the American people. They are:

Two new films will open in midtown theatres today. At the Rialto the attraction will be "The Whistler," a Columbia melodrama based on the radio character and starring Richard Dix. Featured in the cast are Gloria Stuart, J. Carrol Naish, Joan Woodbury and Alan Dinehart. . . .
LONDON, April 27 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
A communique, as broadcast from Chungking yesterday in Cantonese to North America and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

Arnold S. Denker of Forest Hills, Manhattan Chess Club titleholder, last night drew his game with George Shainswit of the Bronx in the tenth round of the United States championship at the Hotel Park Central. The match, developed along the lines of the queen's gambit, was over in 18 moves.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Not more than eleven of the original twenty-six officer candidate schools in the continental United States will remain in operation next fall, the War Department disclosed today, emphasizing the great decrease in the need for junior officers since the Army reached its full strength of 7,700,000.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, April 27 -The fifty-nine "upforwardest" Wacs in the world received a Fifth Army plaque this morning from their Commander in Chief who assured them that besides releasing men for more arduous jobs they had made everyone up there spruce up in his appearance and watch his language.

There has been too much misinformed talk regarding lowered quality and higher prices of men's and boys' clothing coming from consumer groups, Government officials and others in public life, according to the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U.S.A.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 27 -- The unexplored Doce River valley will become the greatest asset of Brazil, bringing untold wealth to the country, Warren Lee Pierson, president of the United States Export-Import Bank, told American newsmen today.

The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, has decided to sell thirty-eight items from its collection "to provide funds for the purchase of paintings and sculpture, particularly by living artists."

Responding to the Wall Street adage that the time to buy is when the bad news comes out, the stock of Montgomery Ward Co. rose yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The advance, brokers asserted, could not be ascribed to Wall Street's confidence in Government management.
LONDON, April 27 (UP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Calls for life insurance cash surrender values are running 23 per cent under 1943 and 84 per cent under the high record reached in 1933, according to the Institute of Life Insurance. In the first two months of 1944 they were at the annual rate of $223,000,000.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The War Production Board cleared the way today for unrestricted importation of Caribbean rums which have been aged for three years or more.

Newspaper editors and publishers, when they speak of the power of the press for the public good, must be thinking not only of their writers but of their cartoonists, too; even when they forget to mention them. If not, the journalist executives are seriously in error.

MIDDLE AMERICA is a clumsy phrase that has nothing to do with the area between Ohio and Nebraska. It is a blanket term for that part of Latin America which is north of South America and south of the United States. It includes the six Central American States -- Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua, Costa Rica and Panama, plus Mexico, Cuba, Haiti and the Dominican Republic.

At the annual meeting of stockholders of Aluminium, Ltd., held yesterday in Montreal, the points discussed were new products, improvement in bauxite reserves, the part of the Shipshaw hydroelectric development in bringing Canada from fourth to second place as a world aluminum producer, a three-fold increase in the number of shareholders and 1943 sales of $291,000,000 on which the company's net income was 4.5 per cent.

The Allied amphibious operations along the New Guinea coast, which, at Hollandia, have extended our footholds 415 miles west of our previous most advanced positions near Madang, have so far been completely successful.

The French Committee of National Liberation looks for "harmonious cooperation" among the Allies in France, according to a dispatch from Harold Callender published in today's TIMES. The news reflects the imminence of invasion and confidence in success. Four years ago it would have been academic, two years ago it would have seemed a fling at a vague future, a year ago it was important but not urgent.

Special emphasis was laid last year in the program of the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness upon protection of eyesight in industry and prevention of blindness from glaucoma, according to the society's annual report, made public yesterday.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 27 -- Newsday, a local daily, in a copyrighted article today quotes Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman of the State Racing Commission, as backing the proposal made by that newspaper that the State of New York legalize off-course, parimutuel betting on horse races.

Lieut. Col. Edward Gordon Jr. pleaded guilty in Federal Court yesterday and was sentenced to three years' imprisonment immediately after the unsealing of an indictment accusing him and five other men of defrauding the Government.

Holders of fifteen-year 5 1/2 per cent debentures due on April 1, 1952, of the National Container Corporation are being notified that the company will redeem all of the debentures outstanding on Oct. 1, next at 103 1/2 and accrued interest at the Manufacturers Trust Company.

In his extraordinary interesting letter in THE TIMES of Sunday, April 23, Thomas W. Lamont suggests "not to be too impatient as to the construction of the edifice for collaboration in its entirety. We tried that at Paris in 1919 and got a structure that was so elaborate and complete that in critical emergencies it was not adaptable or workable."

LONDON, April 27 -- Business was more active on today's stock markets here, the good impression made by the budget speech attracting fresh buyers of shares which are thought likely to benefit from the Chancellor's proposals for helping industry after the war.

ON THE DIMAPUR-KOHIMA ROAD in Northern Manipur, April 24 (Delayed) -- Efforts to drive back the Japanese from northern Manipur and the Naga Hills fringing the tea garden districts of northeastern Assam are now focused in a crucial battle for full control of the little mountain center of Kohima.

WASHINGTON, April 27--With the collapse of Germany, 35 per cent of America's productive capacity now devoted to war goods output will become available for peace-time purposes, Charles E. Wilson, executive vice chairman of the War Production Board, told a meeting of the Automobile Labor Advisory Committee today in a discussion of post-war planning.

A dinner in tribute to the guerrilla fighters of the various "conquered" nations will be given at the Hotel Biltmore, May 10, at 6:45 P.M., under the auspices of the Joint Anti-Fascist Refugee Committee, at which a number of prominent writers will speak.

ABOARD A UNITED STATES DESTROYER OFF HOLLANDIA, Netherland New Guinea, April 23 (delayed) (AP) -- The Japanese bombardier who dropped a bomb squarely on a captured enemy ammunition dump on the Hollandia beach today caused the biggest fireworks of the entire invasion. With Lieut.

LONDON, April 27 (U.P.) -- Amphibious forces of the Yugoslav Partisan Army, supported by Yugoslav and Allied warships, have stormed ashore on the major Dalmatian coastal island of Curzola and have captured two of its three principal cities, Marshal Tito announced today.

Orders on the books of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation decreased $466,000,000 during the first quarter of this year to $1,663,000,000, the lowest figure in two years, reflecting changes in the shipbuilding program, Eugene G. Grace, president, said yesterday after the quarterly meeting of directors.

LONDON, Friday, April 28 -- Pre-invasion bombing reached a new peak yesterday. It was estimated that no fewer than 2,200 heavy, medium and fighter bombers, escorted and covered by clouds of fighters, ripped and tore at enemy defensive positions, air fields and railways throughout northern France in attacks that began at dawn and ended at dusk.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 27 -- Lashed down in the forward compartment of the "Dakota," belonging to the Mediterranean group of the Transport Command, a jeep has been flown by a Royal Air Force crew into Yugoslavia and delivered to the Partisans for the personal use of Marshal Tito, according to a statement made here today by an RAF public relations official.

LONDON, April 27 -- Under a crescent moon and starry skies American service men and women are dancing on the heights above Plymouth Harbor, where, after the fury of the early 1941 blitz had been spent, Viscountess Astor Lady Mayoress of the town, first inaugurated the frolics as a morale builder for the stricken townfolk and as a gesture of defiance.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

JERUSALEM, April 27 -- An effective international attempt to combat the locust menace on a rational basis lies behind the present hard battle being fought across 50,000 square miles of the Saudi Arabian wilderness, in country that the proposed American pipeline will eventually cross.

NAPLES, April 27 -- American-built P-51 Mustangs, long-range fighters powered by Merlin Rolls-Royce engines, are used now in this theatre, it was revealed today and already they have established what is described as a remarkable record of achievement. Flying their first mission on April 16, Mustang pilots scored thirty-six victories in more than 300 sorties, suffering only twelve losses themselves.

NAPLES, April. 27 (U.P.) -- Newly formed German paratroop units have been thrown into action on the Anzio beachhead to halt the swelling power of the Allies' thrusts, it was disclosed today in an Allied announcement.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Federal Government action to supply Puerto Rico with essential food imports due to the threat created by German submarine activity had been carried far beyond any present necessity, a House Insular Affairs subcommittee reported today.
Dr. Charles G. Ferrari, formerly with General Mills, Inc., will join the division of research and development of Standard Brands on May 15.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The War Production Board's tools division has undertaken a survey of the percentage of machine-tool building capacity devoted to other war work, it was announced here today. Purpose of the survey is to obtain up-to-date statistics on the demand for machine tools and available capacity remaining for machine-tool production.

The Witkind Greenberg Realties, Inc., purchased the five-story apartment building on a plot 78 by 106 feet at 370 Columbus Avenue, between Seventy-seventh and Seventy-eighth Streets, from the 370 Columbus Avenue Corporation. The house, which faces the Museum of Natural History, was rebuilt in 1940 at a cost of more than $100,000 and contains fifty-four apartments.

The fourteen-story apartment house at 471 Park Avenue, southeast corner of Fifty-eighth Street, has been resold by Frederick Brown to a syndicate of builders represented by Benjamin Mintz, attorney. The property, which is assessed at $1,030,000, is 120 by 92 feet and adjoins the Ritz Towers.

Three judges of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals handed down yesterday a decision that sustained a Brooklyn Federal court ruling that the red-striped label of domestic Chateau Martin champagne looked deceptively an illegally like that of the imported Mumm brand.

CAIRO, April 27--Prime Minister George Papandreou, newly appointed head of the Greek Government, today announced an eight-point national program that he says his "National Union" Cabinet intends to carry out.

An artists' advisory committee of sixty outstanding conductors, composers and instrumentalist has been named to collaborate with the Rachmaninoff Memorial Fund in perpetuating the memory of the Russian composer, according to an announcement of Vladimir Horowitz, president of the fund.

Although yesterday was no day for a handicap bearing the name of Sunnyside, that event, a six-furlong sprint for Class D 4-year-olds and upward, was run not once, but twice at Jamaica, each division with five starters.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Department store sales in the week ended on April 22 were 11 per cent below sales in the corresponding period of last year. Sales for the year up to April 22, however, were 4 per cent above the corresponding period of 1943.

The flood-ravaged banks of the Mississippi and Missouri Rivers yesterday bore the brunt of damage from torrential waters nearing their crests and threatening costly inundation of additional crop lands and property.

Upholding the attitude of Great Britain toward India and Palestine, the Archbishop of York told a meeting of clergy of various Protestant denominations yesterday that the offer of independence made to India by Sir Stafford Cripps still "holds good."

KUNMING, China, April 24 (Delayed) (AP) -- The Japanese have drawn eighteen divisions, largely from Manchuria, to the Chengchow front and are embarked upon a grandiose plan to link their conquests in north and south China by rail with 60,000 troops already in action, the Chinese said today.

A plan for post-war navigation assistance for civilian pilots based on a system of L-shaped ground markers giving latitude and longitude was offered yesterday by Maj. William P. Lear, director of communication for the Civil Air Patrol, for study by a two-day conference of wing commanders of the patrol representing each of the States.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Tentative discussion of settlement by agreement of the problem of post-war shipping has been started through Anglo-American diplomatic channels.

The recovery of prices continued yesterday in the stock markets, and with additional gains in selected issues and some pivotal spots the list on the New York Stock Exchange returned to and slightly exceeded last Saturday's level. While the general recovery remained in a fractional range, with major gains in individual instances, the market completed the restoration of values shaken by the severe drop of Monday.

Deliveries of war materials by the General Motors Corporation reached a new peak of $1,048,456,895 in the first quarter of 1944, or an annual rate of better than $4,000,000,000, according to the quarterly report issued yesterday by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the company.

Today's events: "Faust," 2:30 P.M., and "Rigoletto," 8:30, San Carlo Opera Company, Center Theatre; "Abduction From the Seraglio," Juilliard Concert Hall, 8:15; Eddie Condon Jazz Concert, Town Hall, 5:30; Frances Hall, piano, and Charles Petremont, violin, in Victory concert, New York Public Library, 5:30; New York Mandolin Symphony Orchestra, Town Hall, 8:30.

Of Frank Knox it can be said that first and last he was a great and sincere patriot. He proved this, not for the first time, when he accepted the appointment from President Roosevelt as Secretary of the Navy in the summer of 1940. He knew then that he was laying himself open to misunderstanding and to partisan anger of the most violent order.

ALBANY, April 28 -- George P. Monaghan, special prosecutor in the investigation of alleged crime in Albany County, called on Acting Mayor Frank S. Harris today to remove Frank J. Cassidy, Commissioner of the Department of Water, for refusal to sign a waiver of immunity concerning his official acts when called before the grand jury.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Hourly and weekly earnings of steel workers are within the top field of all industrial workers, according to Dr. Jules Backman, economist of New York University, who testified today before a panel of the National War Labor Board. His testimony was offered to refute contentions of the United Steel Workers of America, CIO.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 28 -- How little impression has been made by the breach with the Axis and its satellite states upon Argentina's present rulers is indicated by the fact that Jacques Deniker, charge d'affaires in Buenos Aires of Vichy France, with which Argentina severed relations Feb. 4, was received with full honors when he visited the city of Tucuman recently.

NEWARK, N.J., April 28 (AP) -- Behind brilliant hurling by Henry Oana, Buffalo mixed eight hits with six walks and three errors for a 6-to-0 victory over Newark today. It was the fourth straight triumph for the Bucky Harris forces. Oana allowed four singles, struck out eight and granted three walks.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 28 -- The Bolivian Government announced tonight that a vast conspiracy had been broken up with the detention of numerous revolutionaries and that a state of siege had been declared throughout the country.

LONDON, April 28 (U.P.) -- The German Transocean news agency commentator, Capt. Ludwig Sertorious, said the Russians had deployed "major forces against the German-Rumanian position stretching 100 miles from the middle Dniester north of Kishinev and north of Jassy toward the Siret River.

A pro-Axis Swedish newspaper's recent reference to the United States as "the Allied nation which has done the least in the war" drew a sharp rebuke yesterday from another Swedish newspaper, said a Stockholm dispatch to the American-Swedish News Exchange.

New municipal financing in the amount of $6,533,566 is scheduled to be done next week, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. This compares with this week's revised total of $7,342,000 and with the weekly average for 1943 thus far of $15,992,823.

CHICAGO, April 28 (AP) -- Prices of hogs continued even today with the week's decline, with sows off 10 cents a hundredweight more. New and held-over supplies exceeded the slaughter capacity of meat-packing plants by about 7,000 head, and big packers had an additional 5,000 head billed direct from outside loading points. Price declines were halted at yesterday's levels, but the bearish undertone persisted because of the over supply.

The Giants' merry dash from the National League barrier, momentarily checked in Philadelphia earlier in the week, regained momentum yesterday at the Polo Grounds as Mel Ott's astonishing cast vanquished the Dodgers in the opener of a four-game series, 6 to 4, before a Ladies' Day crowd of 10,009.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, April 28 -- Lieut. John L. Cross Jr. of New York, whose wife is a Powers model, was a hero when a Japanese bomber scored a lucky hit last Sunday night on large stores of captured Japanese and some American stores concentrated on the Hollandia beach.

Telegrams urging that the principle of the "highest price line limitation" be specifically prohibited by Congress when the Price Control Act is extended were sent yesterday by the executive committee of the American Retail Federation to Senator Wagner and Representative Spence, chairmen, respectively, of the Senate and House Committees on Banking and Currency.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a series of transactions among the United Gas Corporation's subsidiaries designed to eliminate the Houston Gulf Gas Company from the system.

Governor Dewey, after assisting yesterday afternoon in the swearing in of three women who will occupy important positions in the State Department of Labor, said that the triple ceremony pointed up the current trend toward "getting a greater number of women into the State service."

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- A "miracle of production" by which the output of 100-octane gasoline has been stepped up from a prewar total of 40,000 barrels a day to more than 400,000 barrels, or "enough to send 10,000 planes over Berlin every day in the year," was revealed at a press conference today by Secretary Ickes, Petroleum Administrator for War.

Sales of Bloomingdale Brothers, Inc., and its wholly owned subsidiaries established new high records for the six and twelve months ended with January, according to the annual report of operations announced yesterday. Sales for the fiscal year to Jan. 31, 1944, rose 13.30 per cent to $33,685,458 from the $29,731,085 volume for the previous fiscal year.

Virtually the entire television industry of the country went on record here yesterday as decisively opposed to the television policy announced on Thursday by the Columbia Broadcasting System. The board of directors of Television Broadcasters Association, Inc., characterized the CBS statement "as not based on experience or sound technical principles."

BERNE, Switzerland, April 28 -- In France the war of nerves is in full swing in preparation for invasion. On the Allied side a new form of American appeal has come into action. Planes of the United States Air Force are dropping what are described as large cardboard drums containing a charge of powder which on explosion scatters thousands of leaflets over a wide area.

The barrack-room Government of Argentina continues to play with Fascism, as though that doctrine were a shiny new toy. Its latest action, taken by the Federal Commissioner in the State of Entre Rios, just north of Buenos Aires on the border of Uruguay, is to forbid newspapers even to discuss such subjects as freedom, the Constitution or religion.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Senator Burton K. Wheeler of Montana, whose legislative efforts to prevent the drafting of pre-Pearl Harbor fathers into military service failed in the Senate last year, introduced today a measure designed to halt the induction of parents 30 years of age and over, provided their children are minors.

Since this is the season in which actresses, growing completely emancipated, have been writing their own plays, Margaret Curtis has come along with and in "A Highland Fling." It is easy to see why a number of people were interested in the script before George Abbott finally took it over, for the comedy has a good idea and some nice characters.

Ivar Haug, 25-year-old Norwegian Nazi seaman, was convicted of draft evasion yesterday in Federal court by a jury which deliberated fifty minutes before returning its verdict to Judge Alfred C. Coxe. Although he had funds in the bank Haug was defended by Jacob Rosenblum, who served by appointment of the court, and without fee.

THE American Racing Manual never will become a best seller. In size it is as bulky as "Gone With the Wind" and nowhere near as readable or as engrossing. But it is jammed to the gunwales with choice tidbits of turf statistics, some unknown, some known, and most of the latter probably forgotten. So suppose we take a whirl through its pages and see what we shall see. Hold your hats. Here we go.
LONDON, April 28 -- Parliament sustained today the decree imposing heavy penalties on strike instigators which Minister of Labor Ernest Bevin announced recently. The vote was 314 to 23.
